<BOS>Signs and symptoms of osteosarcoma and MFH include swelling over a bone or a bony part of the body and joint pain.<EOS>
<BOS>These and other signs and symptoms may be caused by osteosarcoma or MFH or by other conditions.<EOS>
<BOS>Check with a doctor if your child has any of the following: Swelling over a bone or bony part of the body.<EOS>
<BOS>Pain in a bone or joint.<EOS>
<BOS>A bone that breaks for no known reason.<EOS>
<BOS>Tests that examine the blood and bone marrow are used to detect (find) and diagnose chronic myeloproliferative neoplasms.<EOS>
<BOS>The following tests and procedures may be used: Physical exam and history : An exam of the body to check general signs of health, including checking for signs of disease, such as lumps or anything else that seems unusual.<EOS>
<BOS>A history of the patients health habits and past illnesses and treatments will also be taken.<EOS>
<BOS>Complete blood count (CBC) with differential : A procedure in which a sample of blood is drawn and checked for the following: The number of red blood cells and platelets.<EOS>
<BOS>The number and type of white blood cells.<EOS>
<BOS>The amount of hemoglobin (the protein that carries oxygen) in the red blood cells.<EOS>
<BOS>The portion of the blood sample made up of red blood cells.<EOS>
<BOS>Peripheral blood smear : A procedure in which a sample of blood is checked for the following: Whether there are red blood cells shaped like teardrops.<EOS>
<BOS>The number and kinds of white blood cells.<EOS>
<BOS>The number of platelets.<EOS>
<BOS>Whether there are blast cells.<EOS>
<BOS>Blood chemistry studies : A procedure in which a blood sample is checked to measure the amounts of certain substances released into the blood by organs and tissues in the body.<EOS>
<BOS>An unusual (higher or lower than normal) amount of a substance can be a sign of disease.<EOS>
<BOS>Bone marrow aspiration and biopsy : The removal of bone marrow, blood, and a small piece of bone by inserting a hollow needle into the hipbone or breastbone.<EOS>
<BOS>A pathologist views the bone marrow, blood, and bone under a microscope to look for abnormal cells.<EOS>
<BOS>Cytogenetic analysis : A test in which cells in a sample of blood or bone marrow are viewed under a microscope to look for certain changes in the chromosomes.<EOS>
<BOS>Certain diseases or disorders may be diagnosed or ruled out based on the chromosomal changes.<EOS>
<BOS>Gene mutation test: A laboratory test done on a bone marrow or blood sample to check for mutations in JAK2 , MPL , or CALR genes.<EOS>
<BOS>A JAK2 gene mutation is often found in patients with polycythemia vera, essential thrombocythemia, or primary myelofibrosis.<EOS>
<BOS>MPL or CALR gene mutations are found in patients with essential thrombocythemia or primary myelofibrosis.<EOS>
<BOS>Signs of vulvar cancer include bleeding or itching.<EOS>
<BOS>Vulvar cancer often does not cause early signs or symptoms.<EOS>
<BOS>Signs and symptoms may be caused by vulvar cancer or by other conditions.<EOS>
<BOS>Check with your doctor if you have any of the following: A lump or growth on the vulva.<EOS>
<BOS>Changes in the vulvar skin, such as color changes or growths that look like a wart or ulcer.<EOS>
<BOS>Itching in the vulvar area, that does not go away.<EOS>
<BOS>Bleeding not related to menstruation (periods).<EOS>
<BOS>Tenderness in the vulvar area.<EOS>
<BOS>Tobacco and alcohol use can affect the risk of lip and oral cavity cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Anything that increases your risk of getting a disease is called a risk factor.<EOS>
<BOS>Having a risk factor does not mean that you will get cancer; not having risk factors doesn't mean that you will not get cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Talk with your doctor if you think you may be at risk.<EOS>
<BOS>Risk factors for lip and oral cavity cancer include the following: Using tobacco products.<EOS>
<BOS>Heavy alcohol use.<EOS>
<BOS>Being exposed to natural sunlight or artificial sunlight (such as from tanning beds) over long periods of time.<EOS>
<BOS>Being male.<EOS>
<BOS>Key Points Liver cancer is a disease in which malignant (cancer) cells form in the tissues of the liver.<EOS>
<BOS>Liver cancer is not common in the United States.<EOS>
<BOS>Being infected with certain types of the hepatitis virus can cause hepatitis and increase the risk of liver cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Hepatitis A Hepatitis B Hepatitis C Hepatitis D Hepatitis E Hepatitis G Liver cancer is a disease in which malignant (cancer) cells form in the tissues of the liver.<EOS>
<BOS>The liver is one of the largest organs in the body.<EOS>
<BOS>It has four lobes and fills the upper right side of the abdomen inside the rib cage.<EOS>
<BOS>Three of the many important functions of the liver are: To filter harmful substances from the blood so they can be passed from the body in stools and urine.<EOS>
<BOS>To make bile to help digest fats from food.<EOS>
<BOS>To store glycogen (sugar), which the body uses for energy.<EOS>
<BOS>See the following PDQ summaries for more information about liver (hepatocellular) cancer: Liver (Hepatocellular) Cancer Screening Adult Primary Liver Cancer Treatment Childhood Liver Cancer Treatment Liver cancer is not common in the United States.<EOS>
<BOS>Liver cancer is the fourth most common cancer and the third leading cause of cancer death in the world.<EOS>
<BOS>In the United States, men, especially Asian/Pacific Islander men, have an increased risk of liver cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>The number of new cases of liver cancer and the number of deaths from liver cancer continue to increase, especially among middleaged black, Hispanic, and white men.<EOS>
<BOS>People are usually older than 40 years when they develop this cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Finding and treating liver cancer early may prevent death from liver cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Having certain genetic conditions increases the risk of developing a pituitary tumor.<EOS>
<BOS>Anything that increases your risk of getting a disease is called a risk factor.<EOS>
<BOS>Having a risk factor does not mean that you will get cancer; not having risk factors doesnt mean that you will not get cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Talk with your doctor if you think you may be at risk.<EOS>
<BOS>Risk factors for pituitary tumors include having the following hereditary diseases: Multiple endocrine neoplasia type 1 (MEN1) syndrome.<EOS>
<BOS>Carney complex.<EOS>
<BOS>Isolated familial acromegaly.<EOS>
<BOS>Different factors increase or decrease the risk of developing prostate cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Anything that increases a person's chance of developing a disease is called a risk factor.<EOS>
<BOS>Anything that decreases your chance of getting a disease is called a protective factor.<EOS>
<BOS>For information about risk factors and protective factors for prostate cancer, see the PDQ summary on Prostate Cancer Prevention.<EOS>
<BOS>Certain factors affect prognosis (chance of recovery) and treatment options.<EOS>
<BOS>The prognosis (chance of recovery) and treatment options depend on the following: The type of germ cell tumor.<EOS>
<BOS>Where the tumor first began to grow.<EOS>
<BOS>The stage of the cancer (whether it has spread to nearby areas or to other places in the body).<EOS>
<BOS>How well the tumor responds to treatment (lower AFP and hCG levels).<EOS>
<BOS>Whether the tumor can be completely removed by surgery.<EOS>
<BOS>The patient's age and general health.<EOS>
<BOS>Whether the cancer has just been diagnosed or has recurred (come back).<EOS>
<BOS>The prognosis for childhood extracranial germ cell tumors, especially ovarian germ cell tumors, is good.<EOS>
<BOS>Imaging studies and tests that examine the blood and urine are used to detect (find) and diagnose gastrointestinal carcinoid tumors.<EOS>
<BOS>The following tests and procedures may be used: Physical exam and history : An exam of the body to check general signs of health, including checking for signs of disease, such as lumps or anything else that seems unusual.<EOS>
<BOS>A history of the patients health habits and past illnesses and treatments will also be taken.<EOS>
<BOS>Blood chemistry studies : A procedure in which a blood sample is checked to measure the amounts of certain substances, such as hormones, released into the blood by organs and tissues in the body.<EOS>
<BOS>An unusual (higher or lower than normal) amount of a substance can be a sign of disease.<EOS>
<BOS>The blood sample is checked to see if it contains a hormone produced by carcinoid tumors.<EOS>
<BOS>This test is used to help diagnose carcinoid syndrome.<EOS>
<BOS>Tumor marker test : A procedure in which a sample of blood, urine, or tissue is checked to measure the amounts of certain substances, such as chromogranin A, made by organs, tissues, or tumor cells in the body.<EOS>
<BOS>Chromogranin A is a tumor marker.<EOS>
<BOS>It has been linked to neuroendocrine tumors when found in increased levels in the body.<EOS>
<BOS>Twentyfourhour urine test: A test in which urine is collected for 24 hours to measure the amounts of certain substances, such as 5HIAA or serotonin (hormone).<EOS>
<BOS>An unusual (higher or lower than normal) amount of a substance can be a sign of disease in the organ or tissue that makes it.<EOS>
<BOS>This test is used to help diagnose carcinoid syndrome.<EOS>
<BOS>MIBG scan : A procedure used to find neuroendocrine tumors, such as carcinoid tumors.<EOS>
<BOS>A very small amount of radioactive material called MIBG (metaiodobenzylguanidine) is injected into a vein and travels through the bloodstream.<EOS>
<BOS>Carcinoid tumors take up the radioactive material and are detected by a device that measures radiation.<EOS>
<BOS>CT scan (CAT scan): A procedure that makes a series of detailed pictures of areas inside the body, taken from different angles.<EOS>
<BOS>The pictures are made by a computer linked to an xray machine.<EOS>
<BOS>A dye may be injected into a vein or swallowed to help the organs or tissues show up more clearly.<EOS>
<BOS>This procedure is also called computed tomography, computerized tomography, or computerized axial tomography.<EOS>
<BOS>MRI (magnetic resonance imaging): A procedure that uses a magnet, radio waves, and a computer to make a series of detailed pictures of areas inside the body.<EOS>
<BOS>This procedure is also called nuclear magnetic resonance imaging PET scan (positron emission tomography scan): A procedure to find malignant tumor cells in the body.<EOS>
<BOS>A small amount of radioactive glucose (sugar) is injected into a vein.<EOS>
<BOS>The PET scanner rotates around the body and makes a picture of where glucose is being used in the body.<EOS>
<BOS>Malignant tumor cells show up brighter in the picture because they are more active and take up more glucose than normal cells.<EOS>
<BOS>Endoscopic ultrasound (EUS): A procedure in which an endoscope is inserted into the body, usually through the mouth or rectum.<EOS>
<BOS>An endoscope is a thin, tubelike instrument with a light and a lens for viewing.<EOS>
<BOS>A probe at the end of the endoscope is used to bounce highenergy sound waves (ultrasound) off internal tissues or organs, such as the stomach, small intestine, colon, or rectum, and make echoes.<EOS>
<BOS>The echoes form a picture of body tissues called a sonogram.<EOS>
<BOS>This procedure is also called endosonography.<EOS>
<BOS>Upper endoscopy : A procedure to look at organs and tissues inside the body to check for abnormal areas.<EOS>
<BOS>An endoscope is inserted through the mouth and passed through the esophagus into the stomach.<EOS>
<BOS>Sometimes the endoscope also is passed from the stomach into the small intestine.<EOS>
<BOS>An endoscope is a thin, tubelike instrument with a light and a lens for viewing.<EOS>
<BOS>It may also have a tool to remove tissue or lymph node samples, which are checked under a microscope for signs of disease.<EOS>
<BOS>Colonoscopy : A procedure to look inside the rectum and colon for polyps, abnormal areas, or cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>A colonoscope is inserted through the rectum into the colon.<EOS>
<BOS>A colonoscope is a thin, tubelike instrument with a light and a lens for viewing.<EOS>
<BOS>It may also have a tool to remove polyps or tissue samples, which are checked under a microscope for signs of cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Capsule endoscopy : A procedure used to see all of the small intestine.<EOS>
<BOS>The patient swallows a capsule that contains a tiny camera.<EOS>
<BOS>As the capsule moves through the gastrointestinal tract, the camera takes pictures and sends them to a receiver worn on the outside of the body.<EOS>
<BOS>Biopsy : The removal of cells or tissues so they can be viewed under a microscope to check for signs of cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Tissue samples may be taken during endoscopy and colonoscopy.<EOS>
<BOS>Tests that examine the lymph system and other parts of the body are used to help detect (find) and diagnose AIDSrelated lymphoma.<EOS>
<BOS>The following tests and procedures may be used: Physical exam and history : An exam of the body to check general signs of health, including checking for signs of disease, such as lumps or anything else that seems unusual.<EOS>
<BOS>A history of the patients health habits and past illnesses and treatments will also be taken.<EOS>
<BOS>Complete blood count (CBC): A procedure in which a sample of blood is drawn and checked for the following: The number of red blood cells, white blood cells, and platelets.<EOS>
<BOS>The amount of hemoglobin (the protein that carries oxygen) in the red blood cells.<EOS>
<BOS>The portion of the sample made up of red blood cells.<EOS>
<BOS>HIV test : A test to measure the level of HIV antibodies in a sample of blood.<EOS>
<BOS>Antibodies are made by the body when it is invaded by a foreign substance.<EOS>
<BOS>A high level of HIV antibodies may mean the body has been infected with HIV.<EOS>
<BOS>Lymph node biopsy : The removal of all or part of a lymph node.<EOS>
<BOS>A pathologist views the tissue under a microscope to look for cancer cells.<EOS>
<BOS>One of the following types of biopsies may be done: Excisional biopsy : The removal of an entire lymph node.<EOS>
<BOS>Incisional biopsy : The removal of part of a lymph node.<EOS>
<BOS>Core biopsy : The removal of tissue from a lymph node using a wide needle.<EOS>
<BOS>Fineneedle aspiration (FNA) biopsy : The removal of tissue from a lymph node using a thin needle.<EOS>
<BOS>Bone marrow aspiration and biopsy : The removal of bone marrow and a small piece of bone by inserting a hollow needle into the hipbone or breastbone.<EOS>
<BOS>A pathologist views the bone marrow and bone under a microscope to look for signs of cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Chest xray : An xray of the organs and bones inside the chest.<EOS>
<BOS>An xray is a type of energy beam that can go through the body and onto film, making a picture of areas inside the body.<EOS>
<BOS>Cancer prevention clinical trials are used to study ways to prevent cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Cancer prevention clinical trials are used to study ways to lower the risk of developing certain types of cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Some cancer prevention trials are conducted with healthy people who have not had cancer but who have an increased risk for cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Other prevention trials are conducted with people who have had cancer and are trying to prevent another cancer of the same type or to lower their chance of developing a new type of cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Other trials are done with healthy volunteers who are not known to have any risk factors for cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>The purpose of some cancer prevention clinical trials is to find out whether actions people take can prevent cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>These may include eating fruits and vegetables, exercising, quitting smoking, or taking certain medicines, vitamins, minerals, or food supplements.<EOS>
<BOS>New ways to prevent ovarian, fallopian tube, and primary peritoneal cancer are being studied in clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>Clinical trials are taking place in many parts of the country.<EOS>
<BOS>Information about clinical trials can be found in the Clinical Trials section of the NCI website.<EOS>
<BOS>Check NCI's list of cancer clinical trials for ovarian cancer prevention trials that are now accepting patients.<EOS>
<BOS>Signs and symptoms of oropharyngeal cancer include a lump in the neck and a sore throat.<EOS>
<BOS>These and other signs and symptoms may be caused by oropharyngeal cancer or by other conditions.<EOS>
<BOS>Check with your doctor if you have any of the following: A sore throat that does not go away.<EOS>
<BOS>Trouble swallowing.<EOS>
<BOS>Trouble opening the mouth fully.<EOS>
<BOS>Trouble moving the tongue.<EOS>
<BOS>Weight loss for no known reason.<EOS>
<BOS>Ear pain.<EOS>
<BOS>A lump in the back of the mouth, throat, or neck.<EOS>
<BOS>A white patch on the tongue or lining of the mouth that does not go away.<EOS>
<BOS>Coughing up blood.<EOS>
<BOS>Sometimes oropharyngeal cancer does not cause early signs or symptoms.<EOS>
<BOS>Key Points There are different types of treatment for children with ependymoma.<EOS>
<BOS>Children with ependymoma should have their treatment planned by a team of health care providers who are experts in treating childhood brain tumors.<EOS>
<BOS>Childhood brain and spinal cord tumors may cause signs or symptoms that begin before the cancer is diagnosed and continue for months or years.<EOS>
<BOS>Some cancer treatments cause side effects months or years after treatment has ended.<EOS>
<BOS>Four types of standard treatment are used: Surgery Radiation therapy Chemotherapy Observation New types of treatment are being tested in clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients may want to think about taking part in a clinical trial.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients can enter clinical trials before, during, or after starting their cancer treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Followup tests may be needed.<EOS>
<BOS>There are different types of treatment for children with ependymoma.<EOS>
<BOS>Different types of treatment are available for children with ependymoma.<EOS>
<BOS>Some treatments are standard (the currently used treatment), and some are being tested in clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>A treatment clinical trial is a research study meant to help improve current treatments or obtain information on new treatments for patients with cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>When clinical trials show that a new treatment is better than the standard treatment, the new treatment may become the standard treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Because cancer in children is rare, taking part in a clinical trial should be considered.<EOS>
<BOS>Some clinical trials are open only to patients who have not started treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Children with ependymoma should have their treatment planned by a team of health care providers who are experts in treating childhood brain tumors.<EOS>
<BOS>Treatment will be overseen by a pediatric oncologist, a doctor who specializes in treating children with cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>The pediatric oncologist works with other pediatric health care providers who are experts in treating children with brain tumors and who specialize in certain areas of medicine.<EOS>
<BOS>These may include the following specialists: Pediatric neurosurgeon.<EOS>
<BOS>Neurologist.<EOS>
<BOS>Neuropathologist.<EOS>
<BOS>Neuroradiologist.<EOS>
<BOS>Pediatrician.<EOS>
<BOS>Rehabilitation specialist.<EOS>
<BOS>Radiation oncologist.<EOS>
<BOS>Medical oncologist.<EOS>
<BOS>Endocrinologist.<EOS>
<BOS>Psychologist.<EOS>
<BOS>Childhood brain and spinal cord tumors may cause signs or symptoms that begin before the cancer is diagnosed and continue for months or years.<EOS>
<BOS>Childhood brain and spinal cord tumors may cause signs or symptoms that continue for months or years.<EOS>
<BOS>Signs or symptoms caused by the tumor may begin before diagnosis.<EOS>
<BOS>Signs or symptoms caused by treatment may begin during or right after treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Some cancer treatments cause side effects months or years after treatment has ended.<EOS>
<BOS>These are called late effects.<EOS>
<BOS>Late effects of cancer treatment may include the following: Physical problems.<EOS>
<BOS>Changes in mood, feelings, thinking, learning, or memory.<EOS>
<BOS>Second cancers (new types of cancer).<EOS>
<BOS>Some late effects may be treated or controlled.<EOS>
<BOS>It is important to talk with your child's doctors about the effects cancer treatment can have on your child.<EOS>
<BOS>(See the PDQ summary on Late Effects of Treatment for Childhood Cancer for more information).<EOS>
<BOS>Four types of standard treatment are used: Surgery If the results of diagnostic tests show there may be a brain tumor, a biopsy is done by removing part of the skull and using a needle to remove a sample of the brain tissue.<EOS>
<BOS>A pathologist views the tissue under a microscope to check for cancer cells.<EOS>
<BOS>If cancer cells are found, the doctor will remove as much tumor as safely possible during the same surgery.<EOS>
<BOS>An MRI is often done after the tumor is removed to find out whether any tumor remains.<EOS>
<BOS>If tumor remains, a second surgery to remove as much of the remaining tumor as possible may be done.<EOS>
<BOS>Even if the doctor removes all the cancer that can be seen at the time of the surgery, some patients may be given chemotherapy or radiation therapy after surgery to kill any cancer cells that are left.<EOS>
<BOS>Treatment to lower the risk that the cancer will come back after surgery is called adjuvant therapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Radiation therapy Radiation therapy is a cancer treatment that uses highenergy xrays or other types of radiation to kill cancer cells or keep them from growing.<EOS>
<BOS>There are two types of radiation therapy: External radiation therapy uses a machine outside the body to send radiation toward the cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Certain ways of giving radiation therapy can help keep radiation from damaging nearby healthy tissue.<EOS>
<BOS>These types of radiation therapy include the following: Conformal radiation therapy: Conformal radiation therapy is a type of external radiation therapy that uses a computer to make a 3dimensional (3D) picture of the tumor and shapes the radiation beams to fit the tumor.<EOS>
<BOS>Intensitymodulated radiation therapy (IMRT): IMRT is a type of 3dimensional (3D) radiation therapy that uses a computer to make pictures of the size and shape of the tumor.<EOS>
<BOS>Thin beams of radiation of different intensities (strengths) are aimed at the tumor from many angles.<EOS>
<BOS>Protonbeam radiation therapy: Protonbeam therapy is a type of highenergy, external radiation therapy.<EOS>
<BOS>A radiation therapy machine aims streams of protons (tiny, invisible, positivelycharged particles) at the cancer cells to kill them.<EOS>
<BOS>Stereotactic radiosurgery: Stereotactic radiosurgery is a type of external radiation therapy.<EOS>
<BOS>A rigid head frame is attached to the skull to keep the head still during the radiation treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>A machine aims a single large dose of radiation directly at the tumor.<EOS>
<BOS>This procedure does not involve surgery.<EOS>
<BOS>It is also called stereotaxic radiosurgery, radiosurgery, and radiation surgery.<EOS>
<BOS>Internal radiation therapy uses a radioactive substance sealed in needles, seeds, wires, or catheters that are placed directly into or near the cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>The way the radiation therapy is given depends on the type of cancer being treated.<EOS>
<BOS>External radiation therapy is used to treat childhood ependymoma.<EOS>
<BOS>Children younger than 3 years who receive radiation therapy to the brain have a higher risk of problems with growth and development than older children.<EOS>
<BOS>3D conformal radiation therapy and protonbeam therapy are being studied in children younger than 3 years to see if the effects of radiation on growth and development are lessened.<EOS>
<BOS>Chemotherapy Chemotherapy is a cancer treatment that uses drugs to stop the growth of cancer cells, either by killing the cells or by stopping them from dividing.<EOS>
<BOS>When chemotherapy is taken by mouth or injected into a vein or muscle, the drugs enter the bloodstream and can reach cancer cells throughout the body (systemic chemotherapy).<EOS>
<BOS>When chemotherapy is placed directly into the cerebrospinal fluid, an organ, or a body cavity such as the abdomen, the drugs mainly affect cancer cells in those areas (regional chemotherapy).<EOS>
<BOS>The way the chemotherapy is given depends on the type of cancer being treated.<EOS>
<BOS>Observation Observation is closely monitoring a patients condition without giving any treatment until signs or symptoms appear or change.<EOS>
<BOS>Observation may be used to treat a child with a subependymoma who has no symptoms and whose tumor is found while treating another condition.<EOS>
<BOS>New types of treatment are being tested in clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>Information about clinical trials is available from the NCI website.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients may want to think about taking part in a clinical trial.<EOS>
<BOS>For some patients, taking part in a clinical trial may be the best treatment choice.<EOS>
<BOS>Clinical trials are part of the cancer research process.<EOS>
<BOS>Clinical trials are done to find out if new cancer treatments are safe and effective or better than the standard treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Many of today's standard treatments for cancer are based on earlier clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients who take part in a clinical trial may receive the standard treatment or be among the first to receive a new treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients who take part in clinical trials also help improve the way cancer will be treated in the future.<EOS>
<BOS>Even when clinical trials do not lead to effective new treatments, they often answer important questions and help move research forward.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients can enter clinical trials before, during, or after starting their cancer treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Some clinical trials only include patients who have not yet received treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Other trials test treatments for patients whose cancer has not gotten better.<EOS>
<BOS>There are also clinical trials that test new ways to stop cancer from recurring (coming back) or reduce the side effects of cancer treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Clinical trials are taking place in many parts of the country.<EOS>
<BOS>See the Treatment Options section that follows for links to current treatment clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>These have been retrieved from NCI's listing of clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>Followup tests may be needed.<EOS>
<BOS>Some of the tests that were done to diagnose the cancer or to find out the stage of the cancer may be repeated.<EOS>
<BOS>Some tests will be repeated in order to see how well the treatment is working.<EOS>
<BOS>Decisions about whether to continue, change, or stop treatment may be based on the results of these tests.<EOS>
<BOS>Some of the tests will continue to be done from time to time after treatment has ended.<EOS>
<BOS>The results of these tests can show if your child's condition has changed or if the cancer has recurred (come back).<EOS>
<BOS>These tests are sometimes called followup tests or checkups.<EOS>
<BOS>Followup tests for childhood ependymoma include an MRI (magnetic resonance imaging) of the brain and spinal cord every 3 months for the first 1 or 2 years after treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>After 2 years, MRIs may be done every 6 months for the next 3 years.<EOS>
<BOS>Treatment Options for Childhood Ependymoma Newly Diagnosed Childhood Ependymoma A child with a newly diagnosed ependymoma has not had treatment for the tumor.<EOS>
<BOS>The child may have had treatment to relieve signs or symptoms caused by the tumor.<EOS>
<BOS>Subependymoma Treatment of newly diagnosed subependymoma (WHO Grade I) is: Surgery.<EOS>
<BOS>Observation (rarely).<EOS>
<BOS>Myxopapillary ependymoma Treatment of newly diagnosed myxopapillary ependymoma (WHO Grade I) is: Surgery with or without radiation therapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Childhood ependymoma, anaplastic ependymoma, or RELA fusionpositive ependymoma Treatment of newly diagnosed childhood ependymoma (WHO Grade II), anaplastic ependymoma (WHO Grade III), or RELA fusionpositive ependymoma (WHO Grade II or Grade III) is: Surgery.<EOS>
<BOS>After surgery, the plan for further treatment depends on the following: Whether any cancer cells remain after surgery.<EOS>
<BOS>Whether the cancer has spread to other parts of the brain or spinal cord.<EOS>
<BOS>The age of the child.<EOS>
<BOS>When the tumor is completely removed and cancer cells have not spread, treatment may include the following: Radiation therapy.<EOS>
<BOS>A clinical trial of radiation therapy followed by chemotherapy.<EOS>
<BOS>A clinical trial of observation for patients whose tumor is completely removed or who have no sign of cancer after chemotherapy.<EOS>
<BOS>When part of the tumor remains after surgery, but cancer cells have not spread, treatment may include the following: A second surgery to remove as much of the remaining tumor as possible.<EOS>
<BOS>Radiation therapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Chemotherapy followed by radiation therapy.<EOS>
<BOS>A clinical trial of chemotherapy given before and after radiation therapy.<EOS>
<BOS>When cancer cells have spread within the brain and spinal cord, treatment may include the following: Radiation therapy to the brain and spinal cord.<EOS>
<BOS>Treatment for children younger than 3 years of age may include the following: Chemotherapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Radiation therapy.<EOS>
<BOS>A clinical trial of 3dimensional (3D) conformal radiation therapy or protonbeam radiation therapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Check the list of NCIsupported cancer clinical trials that are now accepting patients with newly diagnosed childhood ependymoma.<EOS>
<BOS>For more specific results, refine the search by using other search features, such as the location of the trial, the type of treatment, or the name of the drug.<EOS>
<BOS>Talk with your child's doctor about clinical trials that may be right for your child.<EOS>
<BOS>General information about clinical trials is available from the NCI website.<EOS>
<BOS>Recurrent Childhood Ependymoma Treatment of recurrent childhood ependymoma may include the following: Surgery.<EOS>
<BOS>Radiation therapy, which may include stereotactic radiosurgery, intensitymodulated radiation therapy, or protonbeam radiation therapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Chemotherapy.<EOS>
<BOS>A clinical trial of a new treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Check the list of NCIsupported cancer clinical trials that are now accepting patients with recurrent childhood ependymoma.<EOS>
<BOS>For more specific results, refine the search by using other search features, such as the location of the trial, the type of treatment, or the name of the drug.<EOS>
<BOS>Talk with your child's doctor about clinical trials that may be right for your child.<EOS>
<BOS>General information about clinical trials is available from the NCI website.<EOS>
<BOS>Key Points After prostate cancer has been diagnosed, tests are done to find out if cancer cells have spread within the prostate or to other parts of the body.<EOS>
<BOS>There are three ways that cancer spreads in the body.<EOS>
<BOS>Cancer may spread from where it began to other parts of the body.<EOS>
<BOS>The following stages are used for prostate cancer: Stage I Stage II Stage III Stage IV After prostate cancer has been diagnosed, tests are done to find out if cancer cells have spread within the prostate or to other parts of the body.<EOS>
<BOS>The process used to find out if cancer has spread within the prostate or to other parts of the body is called staging.<EOS>
<BOS>The information gathered from the staging process determines the stage of the disease.<EOS>
<BOS>It is important to know the stage in order to plan treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>The results of the tests used to diagnose prostate cancer are often also used to stage the disease.<EOS>
<BOS>(See the General Information section.<EOS>
<BOS>) In prostate cancer, staging tests may not be done unless the patient has symptoms or signs that the cancer has spread, such as bone pain, a high PSA level, or a high Gleason score.<EOS>
<BOS>The following tests and procedures also may be used in the staging process: Bone scan : A procedure to check if there are rapidly dividing cells, such as cancer cells, in the bone.<EOS>
<BOS>A very small amount of radioactive material is injected into a vein and travels through the bloodstream.<EOS>
<BOS>The radioactive material collects in the bones and is detected by a scanner.<EOS>
<BOS>MRI (magnetic resonance imaging): A procedure that uses a magnet, radio waves, and a computer to make a series of detailed pictures of areas inside the body.<EOS>
<BOS>This procedure is also called nuclear magnetic resonance imaging (NMRI).<EOS>
<BOS>CT scan (CAT scan): A procedure that makes a series of detailed pictures of areas inside the body, taken from different angles.<EOS>
<BOS>The pictures are made by a computer linked to an xray machine.<EOS>
<BOS>A dye may be injected into a vein or swallowed to help the organs or tissues show up more clearly.<EOS>
<BOS>This procedure is also called computed tomography, computerized tomography, or computerized axial tomography.<EOS>
<BOS>Pelvic lymphadenectomy : A surgical procedure to remove the lymph nodes in the pelvis.<EOS>
<BOS>A pathologist views the tissue under a microscope to look for cancer cells.<EOS>
<BOS>Seminal vesicle biopsy : The removal of fluid from the seminal vesicles (glands that make semen) using a needle.<EOS>
<BOS>A pathologist views the fluid under a microscope to look for cancer cells.<EOS>
<BOS>ProstaScint scan : A procedure to check for cancer that has spread from the prostate to other parts of the body, such as the lymph nodes.<EOS>
<BOS>A very small amount of radioactive material is injected into a vein and travels through the bloodstream.<EOS>
<BOS>The radioactive material attaches to prostate cancer cells and is detected by a scanner.<EOS>
<BOS>The radioactive material shows up as a bright spot on the picture in areas where there are a lot of prostate cancer cells.<EOS>
<BOS>The stage of the cancer is based on the results of the staging and diagnostic tests, including the prostatespecific antigen (PSA) test and the Gleason score.<EOS>
<BOS>The tissue samples removed during the biopsy are used to find out the Gleason score.<EOS>
<BOS>The Gleason score ranges from 210 and describes how different the cancer cells look from normal cells and how likely it is that the tumor will spread.<EOS>
<BOS>The lower the number, the less likely the tumor is to spread.<EOS>
<BOS>There are three ways that cancer spreads in the body.<EOS>
<BOS>Cancer can spread through tissue, the lymph system, and the blood: Tissue.<EOS>
<BOS>The cancer spreads from where it began by growing into nearby areas.<EOS>
<BOS>Lymph system.<EOS>
<BOS>The cancer spreads from where it began by getting into the lymph system.<EOS>
<BOS>The cancer travels through the lymph vessels to other parts of the body.<EOS>
<BOS>Blood.<EOS>
<BOS>The cancer spreads from where it began by getting into the blood.<EOS>
<BOS>The cancer travels through the blood vessels to other parts of the body.<EOS>
<BOS>Cancer may spread from where it began to other parts of the body.<EOS>
<BOS>When cancer spreads to another part of the body, it is called metastasis.<EOS>
<BOS>Cancer cells break away from where they began (the primary tumor) and travel through the lymph system or blood.<EOS>
<BOS>Lymph system.<EOS>
<BOS>The cancer gets into the lymph system, travels through the lymph vessels, and forms a tumor (metastatic tumor) in another part of the body.<EOS>
<BOS>Blood.<EOS>
<BOS>The cancer gets into the blood, travels through the blood vessels, and forms a tumor (metastatic tumor) in another part of the body.<EOS>
<BOS>The metastatic tumor is the same type of cancer as the primary tumor.<EOS>
<BOS>For example, if prostate cancer spreads to the bone, the cancer cells in the bone are actually prostate cancer cells.<EOS>
<BOS>The disease is metastatic prostate cancer, not bone cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Denosumab, a monoclonal antibody, may be used to prevent bone metastases.<EOS>
<BOS>The following stages are used for prostate cancer: Stage I In stage I, cancer is found in the prostate only.<EOS>
<BOS>The cancer: is found by needle biopsy (done for a high PSA level) or in a small amount of tissue during surgery for other reasons (such as benign prostatic hyperplasia).<EOS>
<BOS>The PSA level is lower than 10 and the Gleason score is 6 or lower; or is found in onehalf or less of one lobe of the prostate.<EOS>
<BOS>The PSA level is lower than 10 and the Gleason score is 6 or lower; or cannot be felt during a digital rectal exam and cannot be seen in imaging tests.<EOS>
<BOS>Cancer is found in onehalf or less of one lobe of the prostate.<EOS>
<BOS>The PSA level and the Gleason score are not known.<EOS>
<BOS>Stage II In stage II, cancer is more advanced than in stage I, but has not spread outside the prostate.<EOS>
<BOS>Stage II is divided into stages IIA and IIB.<EOS>
<BOS>In stage IIA, cancer: is found by needle biopsy (done for a high PSA level) or in a small amount of tissue during surgery for other reasons (such as benign prostatic hyperplasia).<EOS>
<BOS>The PSA level is lower than 20 and the Gleason score is 7; or is found by needle biopsy (done for a high PSA level) or in a small amount of tissue during surgery for other reasons (such as benign prostatic hyperplasia).<EOS>
<BOS>The PSA level is at least 10 but lower than 20 and the Gleason score is 6 or lower; or is found in onehalf or less of one lobe of the prostate.<EOS>
<BOS>The PSA level is at least 10 but lower than 20 and the Gleason score is 6 or lower; or is found in onehalf or less of one lobe of the prostate.<EOS>
<BOS>The PSA level is lower than 20 and the Gleason score is 7; or is found in more than onehalf of one lobe of the prostate.<EOS>
<BOS>In stage IIB, cancer: is found in opposite sides of the prostate.<EOS>
<BOS>The PSA can be any level and the Gleason score can range from 2 to 10; or cannot be felt during a digital rectal exam and cannot be seen in imaging tests.<EOS>
<BOS>The PSA level is 20 or higher and the Gleason score can range from 2 to 10; or cannot be felt during a digital rectal exam and cannot be seen in imaging tests.<EOS>
<BOS>The PSA can be any level and the Gleason score is 8 or higher.<EOS>
<BOS>Stage III In stage III, cancer has spread beyond the outer layer of the prostate and may have spread to the seminal vesicles.<EOS>
<BOS>The PSA can be any level and the Gleason score can range from 2 to 10.<EOS>
<BOS>Stage IV In stage IV, the PSA can be any level and the Gleason score can range from 2 to 10.<EOS>
<BOS>Also, cancer: has spread beyond the seminal vesicles to nearby tissue or organs, such as the rectum, bladder, or pelvic wall; or may have spread to the seminal vesicles or to nearby tissue or organs, such as the rectum, bladder, or pelvic wall.<EOS>
<BOS>Cancer has spread to nearby lymph nodes; or has spread to distant parts of the body, which may include lymph nodes or bones.<EOS>
<BOS>Prostate cancer often spreads to the bones.<EOS>
<BOS>Tests that examine the skin and blood are used to detect (find) and diagnose mycosis fungoides and the Szary syndrome.<EOS>
<BOS>The following tests and procedures may be used: Physical exam and history : An exam of the body to check general signs of health, including checking for signs of disease, such as lumps, the number and type of skin lesions, or anything else that seems unusual.<EOS>
<BOS>Pictures of the skin and a history of the patients health habits and past illnesses and treatments will also be taken.<EOS>
<BOS>Complete blood count with differential : A procedure in which a sample of blood is drawn and checked for the following: The number of red blood cells and platelets.<EOS>
<BOS>The number and type of white blood cells.<EOS>
<BOS>The amount of hemoglobin (the protein that carries oxygen) in the red blood cells.<EOS>
<BOS>The portion of the blood sample made up of red blood cells.<EOS>
<BOS>Peripheral blood smear : A procedure in which a sample of blood is viewed under a microscope to count different circulating blood cells (red blood cells, white blood cells, platelets, etc.<EOS>
<BOS>) and see whether the cells look normal.<EOS>
<BOS>Skin biopsy : The removal of cells or tissues so they can be viewed under a microscope to check for signs of cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>The doctor may remove a growth from the skin, which will be examined by a pathologist.<EOS>
<BOS>More than one skin biopsy may be needed to diagnose mycosis fungoides.<EOS>
<BOS>Immunophenotyping : A process used to identify cells, based on the types of antigens or markers on the surface of the cell.<EOS>
<BOS>This process may include special staining of the blood cells.<EOS>
<BOS>It is used to diagnose specific types of leukemia and lymphoma by comparing the cancer cells to normal cells of the immune system.<EOS>
<BOS>Tcell receptor (TCR) gene rearrangement test: A laboratory test in which cells in a sample of tissue are checked to see if there is a certain change in the genes.<EOS>
<BOS>This gene change can lead to too many of one kind of Tcells (white blood cells that fight infection) to be made.<EOS>
<BOS>Flow cytometry : A laboratory test that measures the number of cells in a sample of blood, the percentage of live cells in a sample, and certain characteristics of cells, such as size, shape, and the presence of tumor markers on the cell surface.<EOS>
<BOS>The cells are stained with a lightsensitive dye, placed in a fluid, and passed in a stream before a laser or other type of light.<EOS>
<BOS>The measurements are based on how the lightsensitive dye reacts to the light.<EOS>
<BOS>Key Points Melanoma is a disease in which malignant (cancer) cells form in melanocytes (cells that color the skin).<EOS>
<BOS>There are different types of cancer that start in the skin.<EOS>
<BOS>Melanoma can occur anywhere on the skin.<EOS>
<BOS>Unusual moles, exposure to sunlight, and health history can affect the risk of melanoma.<EOS>
<BOS>Signs of melanoma include a change in the way a mole or pigmented area looks.<EOS>
<BOS>Tests that examine the skin are used to detect (find) and diagnose melanoma.<EOS>
<BOS>Certain factors affect prognosis (chance of recovery) and treatment options.<EOS>
<BOS>Melanoma is a disease in which malignant (cancer) cells form in melanocytes (cells that color the skin).<EOS>
<BOS>The skin is the bodys largest organ.<EOS>
<BOS>It protects against heat, sunlight, injury, and infection.<EOS>
<BOS>Skin also helps control body temperature and stores water, fat, and vitamin D.<EOS>
<BOS>The skin has several layers, but the two main layers are the epidermis (upper or outer layer) and the dermis (lower or inner layer).<EOS>
<BOS>Skin cancer begins in the epidermis, which is made up of three kinds of cells: Squamous cells: Thin, flat cells that form the top layer of the epidermis.<EOS>
<BOS>Basal cells: Round cells under the squamous cells.<EOS>
<BOS>Melanocytes: Cells that make melanin and are found in the lower part of the epidermis.<EOS>
<BOS>Melanin is the pigment that gives skin its natural color.<EOS>
<BOS>When skin is exposed to the sun or artificial light, melanocytes make more pigment and cause the skin to darken.<EOS>
<BOS>The number of new cases of melanoma has been increasing over the last 40 years.<EOS>
<BOS>Melanoma is most common in adults, but it is sometimes found in children and adolescents.<EOS>
<BOS>(See the PDQ summary on Unusual Cancers of Childhood Treatment for more information on melanoma in children and adolescents.<EOS>
<BOS>) There are different types of cancer that start in the skin.<EOS>
<BOS>There are two forms of skin cancer: melanoma and nonmelanoma.<EOS>
<BOS>Melanoma is a rare form of skin cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>It is more likely to invade nearby tissues and spread to other parts of the body than other types of skin cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>When melanoma starts in the skin, it is called cutaneous melanoma.<EOS>
<BOS>Melanoma may also occur in mucous membranes (thin, moist layers of tissue that cover surfaces such as the lips).<EOS>
<BOS>This PDQ summary is about cutaneous (skin) melanoma and melanoma that affects the mucous membranes.<EOS>
<BOS>The most common types of skin cancer are basal cell carcinoma and squamous cell carcinoma.<EOS>
<BOS>They are nonmelanoma skin cancers.<EOS>
<BOS>Nonmelanoma skin cancers rarely spread to other parts of the body.<EOS>
<BOS>(See the PDQ summary on Skin Cancer Treatment for more information on basal cell and squamous cell skin cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>) Melanoma can occur anywhere on the skin.<EOS>
<BOS>In men, melanoma is often found on the trunk (the area from the shoulders to the hips) or the head and neck.<EOS>
<BOS>In women, melanoma forms most often on the arms and legs.<EOS>
<BOS>When melanoma occurs in the eye, it is called intraocular or ocular melanoma.<EOS>
<BOS>(See the PDQ summary on Intraocular (Uveal) Melanoma Treatment for more information.<EOS>
<BOS>).<EOS>
<BOS>Key Points There are different types of treatment for patients with thymoma and thymic carcinoma.<EOS>
<BOS>Four types of standard treatment are used: Surgery Radiation therapy Chemotherapy Hormone therapy New types of treatment are being tested in clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients may want to think about taking part in a clinical trial.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients can enter clinical trials before, during, or after starting their cancer treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Followup tests may be needed.<EOS>
<BOS>There are different types of treatment for patients with thymoma and thymic carcinoma.<EOS>
<BOS>Different types of treatments are available for patients with thymoma and thymic carcinoma.<EOS>
<BOS>Some treatments are standard (the currently used treatment), and some are being tested in clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>A treatment clinical trial is a research study meant to help improve current treatments or obtain information on new treatments for patients with cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>When clinical trials show that a new treatment is better than the standard treatment, the new treatment may become the standard treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients may want to think about taking part in a clinical trial.<EOS>
<BOS>Some clinical trials are open only to patients who have not started treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Four types of standard treatment are used: Surgery Surgery to remove the tumor is the most common treatment of thymoma.<EOS>
<BOS>Even if the doctor removes all the cancer that can be seen at the time of the surgery, some patients may be given radiation therapy after surgery to kill any cancer cells that are left.<EOS>
<BOS>Treatment given after the surgery, to lower the risk that the cancer will come back, is called adjuvant therapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Radiation therapy Radiation therapy is a cancer treatment that uses highenergy xrays or other types of radiation to kill cancer cells or keep them from growing.<EOS>
<BOS>There are two types of radiation therapy: External radiation therapy uses a machine outside the body to send radiation toward the cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Internal radiation therapy uses a radioactive substance sealed in needles, seeds, wires, or catheters that are placed directly into or near the cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>The way the radiation therapy is given depends on the type and stage of the cancer being treated.<EOS>
<BOS>External radiation therapy is used to treat thymoma and thymic carcinoma.<EOS>
<BOS>Chemotherapy Chemotherapy is a cancer treatment that uses drugs to stop the growth of cancer cells, either by killing the cells or by stopping them from dividing.<EOS>
<BOS>When chemotherapy is taken by mouth or injected into a vein or muscle, the drugs enter the bloodstream and can reach cancer cells throughout the body (systemic chemotherapy).<EOS>
<BOS>When chemotherapy is placed directly into the cerebrospinal fluid, an organ, or a body cavity such as the abdomen, the drugs mainly affect cancer cells in those areas (regional chemotherapy).<EOS>
<BOS>The way the chemotherapy is given depends on the type and stage of the cancer being treated.<EOS>
<BOS>Chemotherapy may be used to shrink the tumor before surgery or radiation therapy.<EOS>
<BOS>This is called neoadjuvant chemotherapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Hormone therapy Hormone therapy is a cancer treatment that removes hormones or blocks their action and stops cancer cells from growing.<EOS>
<BOS>Hormones are substances produced by glands in the body and circulated in the bloodstream.<EOS>
<BOS>Some hormones can cause certain cancers to grow.<EOS>
<BOS>If tests show that the cancer cells have places where hormones can attach (receptors), drugs, surgery, or radiation therapy is used to reduce the production of hormones or block them from working.<EOS>
<BOS>Hormone therapy with drugs called corticosteroids may be used to treat thymoma or thymic carcinoma.<EOS>
<BOS>New types of treatment are being tested in clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>This summary section describes treatments that are being studied in clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>It may not mention every new treatment being studied.<EOS>
<BOS>Information about clinical trials is available from the NCI website.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients may want to think about taking part in a clinical trial.<EOS>
<BOS>For some patients, taking part in a clinical trial may be the best treatment choice.<EOS>
<BOS>Clinical trials are part of the cancer research process.<EOS>
<BOS>Clinical trials are done to find out if new cancer treatments are safe and effective or better than the standard treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Many of today's standard treatments for cancer are based on earlier clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients who take part in a clinical trial may receive the standard treatment or be among the first to receive a new treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients who take part in clinical trials also help improve the way cancer will be treated in the future.<EOS>
<BOS>Even when clinical trials do not lead to effective new treatments, they often answer important questions and help move research forward.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients can enter clinical trials before, during, or after starting their cancer treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Some clinical trials only include patients who have not yet received treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Other trials test treatments for patients whose cancer has not gotten better.<EOS>
<BOS>There are also clinical trials that test new ways to stop cancer from recurring (coming back) or reduce the side effects of cancer treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Clinical trials are taking place in many parts of the country.<EOS>
<BOS>See the Treatment Options section that follows for links to current treatment clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>These have been retrieved from NCI's listing of clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>Followup tests may be needed.<EOS>
<BOS>Some of the tests that were done to diagnose the cancer or to find out the stage of the cancer may be repeated.<EOS>
<BOS>Some tests will be repeated in order to see how well the treatment is working.<EOS>
<BOS>Decisions about whether to continue, change, or stop treatment may be based on the results of these tests.<EOS>
<BOS>Some of the tests will continue to be done from time to time after treatment has ended.<EOS>
<BOS>The results of these tests can show if your condition has changed or if the cancer has recurred (come back).<EOS>
<BOS>These tests are sometimes called followup tests or checkups.<EOS>
<BOS>Treatment Options for Thymoma and Thymic Carcinoma Stage I and Stage II Thymoma Treatment of stage I thymoma is surgery.<EOS>
<BOS>Treatment of stage II thymoma is surgery followed by radiation therapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Check the list of NCIsupported cancer clinical trials that are now accepting patients with stage I thymoma and stage II thymoma.<EOS>
<BOS>For more specific results, refine the search by using other search features, such as the location of the trial, the type of treatment, or the name of the drug.<EOS>
<BOS>Talk with your doctor about clinical trials that may be right for you.<EOS>
<BOS>General information about clinical trials is available from the NCI website.<EOS>
<BOS>Stage III and Stage IV Thymoma Treatment of stage III and stage IV thymoma that may be completely removed by surgery includes the following: Surgery with or without radiation therapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Neoadjuvant chemotherapy followed by surgery with or without radiation therapy.<EOS>
<BOS>A clinical trial of anticancer drugs in new combinations or doses.<EOS>
<BOS>A clinical trial of new ways of giving radiation therapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Treatment of stage III and stage IV thymoma that cannot be completely removed by surgery includes the following: Neoadjuvant chemotherapy followed by surgery and/or radiation therapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Radiation therapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Chemotherapy.<EOS>
<BOS>A clinical trial of anticancer drugs in new combinations or doses.<EOS>
<BOS>A clinical trial of new ways of giving radiation therapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Check the list of NCIsupported cancer clinical trials that are now accepting patients with stage III thymoma and stage IV thymoma.<EOS>
<BOS>For more specific results, refine the search by using other search features, such as the location of the trial, the type of treatment, or the name of the drug.<EOS>
<BOS>Talk with your doctor about clinical trials that may be right for you.<EOS>
<BOS>General information about clinical trials is available from the NCI website.<EOS>
<BOS>Thymic Carcinoma Treatment of thymic carcinoma that may be completely removed by surgery includes the following: Surgery with or without radiation therapy.<EOS>
<BOS>A clinical trial of anticancer drugs in new combinations or doses.<EOS>
<BOS>A clinical trial of new ways of giving radiation therapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Treatment of thymic carcinoma that cannot be completely removed by surgery includes the following: Radiation therapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Chemotherapy with or without surgery to remove part of the tumor and/or radiation therapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Chemotherapy with radiation therapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Chemotherapy.<EOS>
<BOS>A clinical trial of anticancer drugs in new combinations or doses.<EOS>
<BOS>A clinical trial of new ways of giving radiation therapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Check the list of NCIsupported cancer clinical trials that are now accepting patients with thymic carcinoma.<EOS>
<BOS>For more specific results, refine the search by using other search features, such as the location of the trial, the type of treatment, or the name of the drug.<EOS>
<BOS>Talk with your doctor about clinical trials that may be right for you.<EOS>
<BOS>General information about clinical trials is available from the NCI website.<EOS>
<BOS>Recurrent Thymoma and Thymic Carcinoma Treatment of recurrent thymoma and thymic carcinoma may include the following: Surgery with or without radiation therapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Radiation therapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Hormone therapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Chemotherapy.<EOS>
<BOS>A clinical trial of anticancer drugs in new combinations or doses.<EOS>
<BOS>A clinical trial of new ways of giving radiation therapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Check the list of NCIsupported cancer clinical trials that are now accepting patients with recurrent thymoma and thymic carcinoma.<EOS>
<BOS>For more specific results, refine the search by using other search features, such as the location of the trial, the type of treatment, or the name of the drug.<EOS>
<BOS>Talk with your doctor about clinical trials that may be right for you.<EOS>
<BOS>General information about clinical trials is available from the NCI website.<EOS>
<BOS>Certain factors affect prognosis (chance of recovery) and treatment options.<EOS>
<BOS>The prognosis (chance of recovery) and treatment options depend on the following: The stage of the cancer (the size of the tumor and whether it has spread to the lymph nodes or other parts of the body).<EOS>
<BOS>Where the cancer is in the body.<EOS>
<BOS>Whether the cancer has just been diagnosed or has recurred (come back).<EOS>
<BOS>The patient's age and general health.<EOS>
<BOS>Prognosis also depends on how deeply the tumor has grown into the skin.<EOS>
<BOS>Symptoms of primary myelofibrosis include pain below the ribs on the left side and feeling very tired.<EOS>
<BOS>Primary myelofibrosis often does not cause early signs or symptoms.<EOS>
<BOS>It may be found during a routine blood test.<EOS>
<BOS>Signs and symptoms may be caused by primary myelofibrosis or by other conditions.<EOS>
<BOS>Check with your doctor if you have any of the following: Feeling pain or fullness below the ribs on the left side.<EOS>
<BOS>Feeling full sooner than normal when eating.<EOS>
<BOS>Feeling very tired.<EOS>
<BOS>Shortness of breath.<EOS>
<BOS>Easy bruising or bleeding.<EOS>
<BOS>Petechiae (flat, red, pinpoint spots under the skin that are caused by bleeding).<EOS>
<BOS>Fever.<EOS>
<BOS>Night sweats.<EOS>
<BOS>Weight loss.<EOS>
<BOS>New types of treatment are being tested in clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>Information about clinical trials is available from the NCI website.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients may want to think about taking part in a clinical trial.<EOS>
<BOS>For some patients, taking part in a clinical trial may be the best treatment choice.<EOS>
<BOS>Clinical trials are part of the cancer research process.<EOS>
<BOS>Clinical trials are done to find out if new cancer treatments are safe and effective or better than the standard treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Many of today's standard treatments for cancer are based on earlier clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients who take part in a clinical trial may receive the standard treatment or be among the first to receive a new treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients who take part in clinical trials also help improve the way cancer will be treated in the future.<EOS>
<BOS>Even when clinical trials do not lead to effective new treatments, they often answer important questions and help move research forward.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients can enter clinical trials before, during, or after starting their cancer treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Some clinical trials only include patients who have not yet received treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Other trials test treatments for patients whose cancer has not gotten better.<EOS>
<BOS>There are also clinical trials that test new ways to stop cancer from recurring (coming back) or reduce the side effects of cancer treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Clinical trials are taking place in many parts of the country.<EOS>
<BOS>See the Treatment Options section that follows for links to current treatment clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>These have been retrieved from NCI's listing of clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>Key Points Endometrial cancer is a disease in which malignant (cancer) cells form in the tissues of the endometrium.<EOS>
<BOS>Obesity and having metabolic syndrome may increase the risk of endometrial cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Taking tamoxifen for breast cancer or taking estrogen alone (without progesterone) can increase the risk of endometrial cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Signs and symptoms of endometrial cancer include unusual vaginal bleeding or pain in the pelvis.<EOS>
<BOS>Tests that examine the endometrium are used to detect (find) and diagnose endometrial cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Certain factors affect prognosis (chance of recovery) and treatment options.<EOS>
<BOS>Endometrial cancer is a disease in which malignant (cancer) cells form in the tissues of the endometrium.<EOS>
<BOS>The endometrium is the lining of the uterus, a hollow, muscular organ in a womans pelvis.<EOS>
<BOS>The uterus is where a fetus grows.<EOS>
<BOS>In most nonpregnant women, the uterus is about 3 inches long.<EOS>
<BOS>The lower, narrow end of the uterus is the cervix, which leads to the vagina.<EOS>
<BOS>Cancer of the endometrium is different from cancer of the muscle of the uterus, which is called sarcoma of the uterus.<EOS>
<BOS>See the PDQ summary on Uterine Sarcoma Treatment for more information about uterine sarcoma.<EOS>
<BOS>Obesity and having metabolic syndrome may increase the risk of endometrial cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Anything that increases your risk of getting a disease is called a risk factor.<EOS>
<BOS>Having a risk factor does not mean that you will get cancer; not having risk factors doesn't mean that you will not get cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Talk with your doctor if you think you may be at risk.<EOS>
<BOS>Risk factors for endometrial cancer include the following: Having endometrial hyperplasia.<EOS>
<BOS>Being obese.<EOS>
<BOS>Having metabolic syndrome, a set of conditions that occur together, including extra fat around the abdomen, high blood sugar, high blood pressure, high levels of triglycerides and low levels of highdensity lipoproteins in the blood.<EOS>
<BOS>Never giving birth.<EOS>
<BOS>Beginning menstruation at an early age.<EOS>
<BOS>Reaching menopause at an older age.<EOS>
<BOS>Having polycystic ovarian syndrome (PCOS).<EOS>
<BOS>Having a mother, sister, or daughter with uterine cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Having a certain gene change that is linked to Lynch syndrome (hereditary nonpolyposis colon cancer).<EOS>
<BOS>Having hyperinsulinemia (high levels of insulin in the blood).<EOS>
<BOS>Taking tamoxifen for breast cancer or taking estrogen alone (without progesterone) can increase the risk of endometrial cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Endometrial cancer may develop in breast cancer patients who have been treated with tamoxifen.<EOS>
<BOS>A patient who takes this drug and has abnormal vaginal bleeding should have a followup exam and a biopsy of the endometrial lining if needed.<EOS>
<BOS>Women taking estrogen (a hormone that can affect the growth of some cancers) alone also have an increased risk of endometrial cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Taking estrogen combined with progesterone (another hormone) does not increase a womans risk of endometrial cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>New types of treatment are being tested in clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>This summary section describes treatments that are being studied in clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>It may not mention every new treatment being studied.<EOS>
<BOS>Information about clinical trials is available from the NCI website.<EOS>
<BOS>Radiation therapy Radiation therapy is a cancer treatment that uses highenergy xrays or other types of radiation to kill cancer cells or keep them from growing.<EOS>
<BOS>Some women receive a treatment called intraperitoneal radiation therapy, in which radioactive liquid is put directly in the abdomen through a catheter.<EOS>
<BOS>Intraperitoneal radiation therapy is being studied to treat advanced ovarian cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Immunotherapy Immunotherapy is a treatment that uses the patients immune system to fight cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Substances made by the body or made in a laboratory are used to boost, direct, or restore the bodys natural defenses against cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>This type of cancer treatment is also called biotherapy or immunotherapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Vaccine therapy uses a substance to stimulate the immune system to destroy a tumor.<EOS>
<BOS>Vaccine therapy is being studied to treat advanced ovarian cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients may want to think about taking part in a clinical trial.<EOS>
<BOS>For some patients, taking part in a clinical trial may be the best treatment choice.<EOS>
<BOS>Clinical trials are part of the cancer research process.<EOS>
<BOS>Clinical trials are done to find out if new cancer treatments are safe and effective or better than the standard treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Many of today's standard treatments for cancer are based on earlier clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients who take part in a clinical trial may receive the standard treatment or be among the first to receive a new treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients who take part in clinical trials also help improve the way cancer will be treated in the future.<EOS>
<BOS>Even when clinical trials do not lead to effective new treatments, they often answer important questions and help move research forward.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients can enter clinical trials before, during, or after starting their cancer treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Some clinical trials only include patients who have not yet received treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Other trials test treatments for patients whose cancer has not gotten better.<EOS>
<BOS>There are also clinical trials that test new ways to stop cancer from recurring (coming back) or reduce the side effects of cancer treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Clinical trials are taking place in many parts of the country.<EOS>
<BOS>See the Treatment Options section that follows for links to current treatment clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>These have been retrieved from NCI's listing of clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>Gender and age may affect the risk of hairy cell leukemia.<EOS>
<BOS>Anything that increases your chance of getting a disease is called a risk factor.<EOS>
<BOS>Having a risk factor does not mean that you will get cancer; not having risk factors doesnt mean that you will not get cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Talk with your doctor if you think you may be at risk.<EOS>
<BOS>The cause of hairy cell leukemia is unknown.<EOS>
<BOS>It occurs more often in older men.<EOS>
<BOS>Key Points There are different types of treatment for patients with adult soft tissue sarcoma.<EOS>
<BOS>Three types of standard treatment are used: Surgery Radiation therapy Chemotherapy New types of treatment are being tested in clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>Regional chemotherapy Treatment for adult soft tissue sarcoma may cause side effects.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients may want to think about taking part in a clinical trial.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients can enter clinical trials before, during, or after starting their cancer treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Followup tests may be needed.<EOS>
<BOS>There are different types of treatment for patients with adult soft tissue sarcoma.<EOS>
<BOS>Different types of treatments are available for patients with adult soft tissue sarcoma.<EOS>
<BOS>Some treatments are standard (the currently used treatment), and some are being tested in clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>A treatment clinical trial is a research study meant to help improve current treatments or obtain information on new treatments for patients with cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>When clinical trials show that a new treatment is better than the standard treatment, the new treatment may become the standard treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients may want to think about taking part in a clinical trial.<EOS>
<BOS>Some clinical trials are open only to patients who have not started treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Three types of standard treatment are used: Surgery Surgery is the most common treatment for adult soft tissue sarcoma.<EOS>
<BOS>For some softtissue sarcomas, removal of the tumor in surgery may be the only treatment needed.<EOS>
<BOS>The following surgical procedures may be used: Mohs microsurgery: A procedure in which the tumor is cut from the skin in thin layers.<EOS>
<BOS>During surgery, the edges of the tumor and each layer of tumor removed are viewed through a microscope to check for cancer cells.<EOS>
<BOS>Layers continue to be removed until no more cancer cells are seen.<EOS>
<BOS>This type of surgery removes as little normal tissue as possible and is often used where appearance is important, such as on the skin.<EOS>
<BOS>Wide local excision: Removal of the tumor along with some normal tissue around it.<EOS>
<BOS>For tumors of the head, neck, abdomen, and trunk, as little normal tissue as possible is removed.<EOS>
<BOS>Limbsparing surgery: Removal of the tumor in an arm or leg without amputation, so the use and appearance of the limb is saved.<EOS>
<BOS>Radiation therapy or chemotherapy may be given first to shrink the tumor.<EOS>
<BOS>The tumor is then removed in a wide local excision.<EOS>
<BOS>Tissue and bone that are removed may be replaced with a graft using tissue and bone taken from another part of the patient's body, or with an implant such as artificial bone.<EOS>
<BOS>Amputation: Surgery to remove part or all of a limb or appendage, such as an arm or leg.<EOS>
<BOS>Amputation is rarely used to treat soft tissue sarcoma of the arm or leg.<EOS>
<BOS>Lymphadenectomy: A surgical procedure in which lymph nodes are removed and a sample of tissue is checked under a microscope for signs of cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>This procedure is also called a lymph node dissection.<EOS>
<BOS>Radiation therapy or chemotherapy may be given before or after surgery to remove the tumor.<EOS>
<BOS>When given before surgery, radiation therapy or chemotherapy will make the tumor smaller and reduce the amount of tissue that needs to be removed during surgery.<EOS>
<BOS>Treatment given before surgery is called neoadjuvant therapy.<EOS>
<BOS>When given after surgery, radiation therapy or chemotherapy will kill any remaining cancer cells.<EOS>
<BOS>Treatment given after the surgery, to lower the risk that the cancer will come back, is called adjuvant therapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Radiation therapy Radiation therapy is a cancer treatment that uses highenergy xrays or other types of radiation to kill cancer cells or keep them from growing.<EOS>
<BOS>There are two types of radiation therapy: External radiation therapy uses a machine outside the body to send radiation toward the cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Internal radiation therapy uses a radioactive substance sealed in needles, seeds, wires, or catheters that are placed directly into or near the cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Intensitymodulated radiation therapy (IMRT) is a type of 3dimensional (3D) radiation therapy that uses a computer to make pictures of the size and shape of the tumor.<EOS>
<BOS>Thin beams of radiation of different intensities (strengths) are aimed at the tumor from many angles.<EOS>
<BOS>This type of external radiation therapy causes less damage to nearby healthy tissue and is less likely to cause dry mouth, trouble swallowing, and damage to the skin.<EOS>
<BOS>The way the radiation therapy is given depends on the type and stage of the cancer being treated.<EOS>
<BOS>External radiation therapy and internal radiation therapy may be used to treat adult soft tissue sarcoma.<EOS>
<BOS>Chemotherapy Chemotherapy is a cancer treatment that uses drugs to stop the growth of cancer cells, either by killing the cells or by stopping them from dividing.<EOS>
<BOS>When chemotherapy is taken by mouth or injected into a vein or muscle, the drugs enter the bloodstream and can reach cancer cells throughout the body (systemic chemotherapy).<EOS>
<BOS>The way the chemotherapy is given depends on the type and stage of the cancer being treated.<EOS>
<BOS>See Drugs Approved for Soft Tissue Sarcoma for more information.<EOS>
<BOS>New types of treatment are being tested in clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>This summary section describes treatments that are being studied in clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>It may not mention every new treatment being studied.<EOS>
<BOS>Information about clinical trials is available from the NCI website.<EOS>
<BOS>Regional chemotherapy Clinical trials are studying ways to improve the effect of chemotherapy on tumor cells, including the following: Regional hyperthermia therapy: A treatment in which tissue around the tumor is exposed to high temperatures to damage and kill cancer cells or to make cancer cells more sensitive to chemotherapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Isolated limb perfusion: A procedure that sends chemotherapy directly to an arm or leg in which the cancer has formed.<EOS>
<BOS>The flow of blood to and from the limb is temporarily stopped with a tourniquet, and anticancer drugs are put directly into the blood of the limb.<EOS>
<BOS>This sends a high dose of drugs to the tumor.<EOS>
<BOS>Treatment for adult soft tissue sarcoma may cause side effects.<EOS>
<BOS>For information about side effects caused by treatment for cancer, see our Side Effects page.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients may want to think about taking part in a clinical trial.<EOS>
<BOS>For some patients, taking part in a clinical trial may be the best treatment choice.<EOS>
<BOS>Clinical trials are part of the cancer research process.<EOS>
<BOS>Clinical trials are done to find out if new cancer treatments are safe and effective or better than the standard treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Many of today's standard treatments for cancer are based on earlier clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients who take part in a clinical trial may receive the standard treatment or be among the first to receive a new treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients who take part in clinical trials also help improve the way cancer will be treated in the future.<EOS>
<BOS>Even when clinical trials do not lead to effective new treatments, they often answer important questions and help move research forward.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients can enter clinical trials before, during, or after starting their cancer treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Some clinical trials only include patients who have not yet received treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Other trials test treatments for patients whose cancer has not gotten better.<EOS>
<BOS>There are also clinical trials that test new ways to stop cancer from recurring (coming back) or reduce the side effects of cancer treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Clinical trials are taking place in many parts of the country.<EOS>
<BOS>See the Treatment Options section that follows for links to current treatment clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>These have been retrieved from NCI's listing of clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>Followup tests may be needed.<EOS>
<BOS>Some of the tests that were done to diagnose the cancer or to find out the stage of the cancer may be repeated.<EOS>
<BOS>Some tests will be repeated in order to see how well the treatment is working.<EOS>
<BOS>Decisions about whether to continue, change, or stop treatment may be based on the results of these tests.<EOS>
<BOS>Some of the tests will continue to be done from time to time after treatment has ended.<EOS>
<BOS>The results of these tests can show if your condition has changed or if the cancer has recurred (come back).<EOS>
<BOS>These tests are sometimes called followup tests or checkups.<EOS>
<BOS>Treatment Options for Adult Soft Tissue Sarcoma Stage I Adult Soft Tissue Sarcoma Treatment of stage I soft tissue sarcoma may include the following: Surgery to remove the tumor, such as Mohs microsurgery for small sarcomas of the skin, wide local excision, or limbsparing surgery.<EOS>
<BOS>Radiation therapy before and/or after surgery.<EOS>
<BOS>Check the list of NCIsupported cancer clinical trials that are now accepting patients with stage I adult soft tissue sarcoma.<EOS>
<BOS>For more specific results, refine the search by using other search features, such as the location of the trial, the type of treatment, or the name of the drug.<EOS>
<BOS>Talk with your doctor about clinical trials that may be right for you.<EOS>
<BOS>General information about clinical trials is available from the NCI website.<EOS>
<BOS>Stage II Adult Soft Tissue Sarcoma and Stage III Adult Soft Tissue Sarcoma That Has Not Spread to Lymph Nodes Treatment of stage II adult soft tissue sarcoma and stage III adult soft tissue sarcoma that has not spread to lymph nodes may include the following: Surgery to remove the tumor, such as wide local excision or limbsparing surgery.<EOS>
<BOS>Radiation therapy before or after surgery.<EOS>
<BOS>Radiation therapy or chemotherapy before limbsparing surgery.<EOS>
<BOS>Radiation therapy may also be given after surgery.<EOS>
<BOS>Highdose radiation therapy for tumors that cannot be removed by surgery.<EOS>
<BOS>Check the list of NCIsupported cancer clinical trials that are now accepting patients with stage II adult soft tissue sarcoma and stage III adult soft tissue sarcoma.<EOS>
<BOS>For more specific results, refine the search by using other search features, such as the location of the trial, the type of treatment, or the name of the drug.<EOS>
<BOS>Talk with your doctor about clinical trials that may be right for you.<EOS>
<BOS>General information about clinical trials is available from the NCI website.<EOS>
<BOS>Stage III Adult Soft Tissue Sarcoma That Has Spread to Lymph Nodes (Advanced) Treatment of stage III adult soft tissue sarcoma that has spread to lymph nodes (advanced) may include the following: Surgery (wide local excision) with lymphadenectomy.<EOS>
<BOS>Radiation therapy may also be given after surgery.<EOS>
<BOS>A clinical trial of surgery followed by chemotherapy.<EOS>
<BOS>A clinical trial of regional hyperthermia therapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Check the list of NCIsupported cancer clinical trials that are now accepting patients with stage III adult soft tissue sarcoma.<EOS>
<BOS>For more specific results, refine the search by using other search features, such as the location of the trial, the type of treatment, or the name of the drug.<EOS>
<BOS>Talk with your doctor about clinical trials that may be right for you.<EOS>
<BOS>General information about clinical trials is available from the NCI website.<EOS>
<BOS>Stage IV Adult Soft Tissue Sarcoma Treatment of stage IV adult soft tissue sarcoma may include the following: Chemotherapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Surgery to remove cancer that has spread to the lungs.<EOS>
<BOS>Check the list of NCIsupported cancer clinical trials that are now accepting patients with stage IV adult soft tissue sarcoma.<EOS>
<BOS>For more specific results, refine the search by using other search features, such as the location of the trial, the type of treatment, or the name of the drug.<EOS>
<BOS>Talk with your doctor about clinical trials that may be right for you.<EOS>
<BOS>General information about clinical trials is available from the NCI website.<EOS>
<BOS>Certain factors affect prognosis (chance of recovery) and treatment options.<EOS>
<BOS>The prognosis (chance of recovery) and treatment options depend on the following: The stage of the cancer (the size of the tumor and whether it is in the breast only or has spread to lymph nodes or other places in the body).<EOS>
<BOS>The type of breast cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Estrogen receptor and progesterone receptor levels in the tumor tissue.<EOS>
<BOS>Human epidermal growth factor type 2 receptor (HER2/neu) levels in the tumor tissue.<EOS>
<BOS>Whether the tumor tissue is triple negative (cells that do not have estrogen receptors, progesterone receptors, or high levels of HER2/neu).<EOS>
<BOS>How fast the tumor is growing.<EOS>
<BOS>How likely the tumor is to recur (come back).<EOS>
<BOS>A womans age, general health, and menopausal status (whether a woman is still having menstrual periods).<EOS>
<BOS>Whether the cancer has just been diagnosed or has recurred (come back).<EOS>
<BOS>Key Points Childhood craniopharyngiomas are benign brain tumors found near the pituitary gland.<EOS>
<BOS>There are no known risk factors for childhood craniopharyngioma.<EOS>
<BOS>Signs of childhood craniopharyngioma include vision changes and slow growth.<EOS>
<BOS>Tests that examine the brain, vision, and hormone levels are used to detect (find) childhood craniopharyngiomas.<EOS>
<BOS>Childhood craniopharyngiomas are diagnosed and may be removed in the same surgery.<EOS>
<BOS>Certain factors affect prognosis (chance of recovery) and treatment options.<EOS>
<BOS>Childhood craniopharyngiomas are benign brain tumors found near the pituitary gland.<EOS>
<BOS>Childhood craniopharyngiomas are rare tumors usually found near the pituitary gland (a peasized organ at the bottom of the brain that controls other glands) and the hypothalamus (a small coneshaped organ connected to the pituitary gland by nerves).<EOS>
<BOS>Craniopharyngiomas are usually part solid mass and part fluid filled cyst.<EOS>
<BOS>They are benign (not cancer) and do not spread to other parts of the brain or to other parts of the body.<EOS>
<BOS>However, they may grow and press on nearby parts of the brain or other areas, including the pituitary gland, the optic chiasm, optic nerves, and fluidfilled spaces in the brain.<EOS>
<BOS>Craniopharyngiomas may affect many functions of the brain.<EOS>
<BOS>They may affect hormone making, growth, and vision.<EOS>
<BOS>Benign brain tumors need treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>This summary is about the treatment of primary brain tumors (tumors that begin in the brain).<EOS>
