<BOS>Treatment for metastatic brain tumors, which are tumors formed by cancer cells that begin in other parts of the body and spread to the brain, is not covered in this summary.<EOS>
<BOS>See the PDQ treatment summary on Childhood Brain and Spinal Cord Tumors Treatment Overview for information about the different types of childhood brain and spinal cord tumors.<EOS>
<BOS>Brain tumors can occur in both children and adults; however, treatment for children may be different than treatment for adults.<EOS>
<BOS>(See the PDQ summary on Adult Central Nervous System Tumors Treatment for more information.<EOS>
<BOS>).<EOS>
<BOS>New types of treatment are being tested in clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>This summary section describes treatments that are being studied in clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>It may not mention every new treatment being studied.<EOS>
<BOS>Information about clinical trials is available from the NCI website.<EOS>
<BOS>Targeted therapy Targeted therapy is a type of treatment that uses drugs or other substances to attack specific cancer cells.<EOS>
<BOS>Targeted therapies usually cause less harm to normal cells than chemotherapy or radiation therapy do.<EOS>
<BOS>Targeted therapy is being studied for the treatment of undifferentiated embryonal sarcoma of the liver and liver cancer that has come back.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients may want to think about taking part in a clinical trial.<EOS>
<BOS>For some patients, taking part in a clinical trial may be the best treatment choice.<EOS>
<BOS>Clinical trials are part of the cancer research process.<EOS>
<BOS>Clinical trials are done to find out if new cancer treatments are safe and effective or better than the standard treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Many of today's standard treatments for cancer are based on earlier clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients who take part in a clinical trial may receive the standard treatment or be among the first to receive a new treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients who take part in clinical trials also help improve the way cancer will be treated in the future.<EOS>
<BOS>Even when clinical trials do not lead to effective new treatments, they often answer important questions and help move research forward.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients can enter clinical trials before, during, or after starting their cancer treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Some clinical trials only include patients who have not yet received treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Other trials test treatments for patients whose cancer has not gotten better.<EOS>
<BOS>There are also clinical trials that test new ways to stop cancer from recurring (coming back) or reduce the side effects of cancer treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Clinical trials are taking place in many parts of the country.<EOS>
<BOS>See the Treatment Options section that follows for links to current treatment clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>These have been retrieved from NCI's listing of clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>Treatment Options in Clinical Trials Check the list of NCIsupported cancer clinical trials that are now accepting patients with childhood liver cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>For more specific results, refine the search by using other search features, such as the location of the trial, the type of treatment, or the name of the drug.<EOS>
<BOS>Talk with your child's doctor about clinical trials that may be right for your child.<EOS>
<BOS>General information about clinical trials is available from the NCI website.<EOS>
<BOS>Key Points Endometrial cancer is a disease in which malignant (cancer) cells form in the tissues of the endometrium.<EOS>
<BOS>Endometrial cancer is the most common invasive cancer of the female reproductive system.<EOS>
<BOS>Endometrial cancer is a disease in which malignant (cancer) cells form in the tissues of the endometrium.<EOS>
<BOS>The endometrium is the lining of the uterus.<EOS>
<BOS>The uterus is part of the female reproductive system.<EOS>
<BOS>It is a hollow, pearshaped, muscular organ in the pelvis, where a fetus grows.<EOS>
<BOS>Cancer of the endometrium is different from cancer of the muscle of the uterus, which is called sarcoma of the uterus.<EOS>
<BOS>See the PDQ summary on Uterine Sarcoma Treatment for more information.<EOS>
<BOS>See the following PDQ summaries for more information about endometrial cancer: Endometrial Cancer Screening Endometrial Cancer Treatment Endometrial cancer is the most common invasive cancer of the female reproductive system.<EOS>
<BOS>Endometrial cancer is diagnosed most often in postmenopausal women at an average age of 60 years.<EOS>
<BOS>From 2004 to 2013, the number of new cases of endometrial cancer increased slightly in white and African American women.<EOS>
<BOS>From 2005 to 2014, the number of deaths from endometrial cancer also increased slightly in white and African American women.<EOS>
<BOS>Compared with white women, rates of endometrial cancer are lower in Japanese Americans and in Latinas.<EOS>
<BOS>The rates of endometrial cancer in white women are about the same as in African Americans or in native Hawaiians.<EOS>
<BOS>The number of deaths from endometrial cancer is higher in African American women compared with women of other races.<EOS>
<BOS>Certain factors affect prognosis (chance of recovery) and treatment options.<EOS>
<BOS>Prognosis (chance of recovery) depends on the following: The stage of the disease.<EOS>
<BOS>The location and size of the tumor.<EOS>
<BOS>The grade of the tumor.<EOS>
<BOS>The patient's age, gender, and general health, including whether the patient is anemic.<EOS>
<BOS>Treatment options depend on the following: The stage of the disease.<EOS>
<BOS>The location and size of the tumor.<EOS>
<BOS>Keeping the patient's ability to talk, eat, and breathe as normal as possible.<EOS>
<BOS>Whether the cancer has come back (recurred).<EOS>
<BOS>Smoking tobacco and drinking alcohol decrease the effectiveness of treatment for laryngeal cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients with laryngeal cancer who continue to smoke and drink are less likely to be cured and more likely to develop a second tumor.<EOS>
<BOS>After treatment for laryngeal cancer, frequent and careful followup is important.<EOS>
<BOS>Key Points There are different types of treatment for patients with ovarian low malignant potential tumor.<EOS>
<BOS>Two types of standard treatment are used: Surgery Chemotherapy New types of treatment are being tested in clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients may want to think about taking part in a clinical trial.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients can enter clinical trials before, during, or after starting their treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Followup tests may be needed.<EOS>
<BOS>There are different types of treatment for patients with ovarian low malignant potential tumor.<EOS>
<BOS>Different types of treatment are available for patients with ovarian low malignant potential tumor.<EOS>
<BOS>Some treatments are standard (the currently used treatment), and some are being tested in clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>A treatment clinical trial is a research study meant to help improve current treatments or obtain information on new treatments for patients with cancer, tumors, and related conditions.<EOS>
<BOS>When clinical trials show that a new treatment is better than the standard treatment, the new treatment may become the standard treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients may want to think about taking part in a clinical trial.<EOS>
<BOS>Some clinical trials are open only to patients who have not started treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Two types of standard treatment are used: Surgery The type of surgery (removing the tumor in an operation) depends on the size and spread of the tumor and the womans plans for having children.<EOS>
<BOS>Surgery may include the following: Unilateral salpingooophorectomy: Surgery to remove one ovary and one fallopian tube.<EOS>
<BOS>Bilateral salpingooophorectomy: Surgery to remove both ovaries and both fallopian tubes.<EOS>
<BOS>Total hysterectomy and bilateral salpingooophorectomy: Surgery to remove the uterus, cervix, and both ovaries and fallopian tubes.<EOS>
<BOS>If the uterus and cervix are taken out through the vagina, the operation is called a vaginal hysterectomy.<EOS>
<BOS>If the uterus and cervix are taken out through a large incision (cut) in the abdomen, the operation is called a total abdominal hysterectomy.<EOS>
<BOS>If the uterus and cervix are taken out through a small incision (cut) in the abdomen using a laparoscope, the operation is called a total laparoscopic hysterectomy.<EOS>
<BOS>Partial oophorectomy: Surgery to remove part of one ovary or part of both ovaries.<EOS>
<BOS>Omentectomy: Surgery to remove the omentum (a piece of the tissue lining the abdominal wall).<EOS>
<BOS>Even if the doctor removes all disease that can be seen at the time of the operation, the patient may be given chemotherapy after surgery to kill any tumor cells that are left.<EOS>
<BOS>Treatment given after the surgery, to lower the risk that the tumor will come back, is called adjuvant therapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Chemotherapy Chemotherapy is a cancer treatment that uses drugs to stop the growth of cancer cells, either by killing the cells or by stopping them from dividing.<EOS>
<BOS>When chemotherapy is taken by mouth or injected into a vein or muscle, the drugs enter the bloodstream and can reach cancer cells throughout the body (systemic chemotherapy).<EOS>
<BOS>When chemotherapy is placed directly into the cerebrospinal fluid, an organ, or a body cavity such as the abdomen, the drugs mainly affect cancer cells in those areas (regional chemotherapy).<EOS>
<BOS>The way the chemotherapy is given depends on the type and stage of the cancer being treated.<EOS>
<BOS>New types of treatment are being tested in clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>Information about clinical trials is available from the NCI Web site.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients may want to think about taking part in a clinical trial.<EOS>
<BOS>For some patients, taking part in a clinical trial may be the best treatment choice.<EOS>
<BOS>Clinical trials are part of the medical research process.<EOS>
<BOS>Clinical trials are done to find out if new treatments are safe and effective or better than the standard treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Many of today's standard treatments for disease are based on earlier clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients who take part in a clinical trial may receive the standard treatment or be among the first to receive a new treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients who take part in clinical trials also help improve the way diseases will be treated in the future.<EOS>
<BOS>Even when clinical trials do not lead to effective new treatments, they often answer important questions and help move research forward.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients can enter clinical trials before, during, or after starting their treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Some clinical trials only include patients who have not yet received treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Other trials test treatments for patients whose disease has not gotten better.<EOS>
<BOS>There are also clinical trials that test new ways to stop a disease from recurring (coming back) or reduce the side effects of treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Clinical trials are taking place in many parts of the country.<EOS>
<BOS>See the Treatment Options section that follows for links to current treatment clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>These have been retrieved from NCI's clinical trials database.<EOS>
<BOS>Followup tests may be needed.<EOS>
<BOS>Some of the tests that were done to diagnose the disease may be repeated.<EOS>
<BOS>Some tests will be repeated in order to see how well the treatment is working.<EOS>
<BOS>Decisions about whether to continue, change, or stop treatment may be based on the results of these tests.<EOS>
<BOS>This is sometimes called restaging.<EOS>
<BOS>Some of the tests will continue to be done from time to time after treatment has ended.<EOS>
<BOS>The results of these tests can show if your condition has changed or if the disease has recurred (come back).<EOS>
<BOS>These tests are sometimes called followup tests or checkups.<EOS>
<BOS>Treatment Options for Ovarian Low Malignant Potential Tumors Early Stage Ovarian Low Malignant Potential Tumors (Stage I and II) Surgery is the standard treatment for early stage ovarian low malignant potential tumor.<EOS>
<BOS>The type of surgery usually depends on whether a woman plans to have children.<EOS>
<BOS>For women who plan to have children, surgery is either: unilateral salpingooophorectomy; or partial oophorectomy.<EOS>
<BOS>To prevent recurrence of disease, most doctors recommend surgery to remove the remaining ovarian tissue when a woman no longer plans to have children.<EOS>
<BOS>For women who do not plan to have children, treatment may be hysterectomy and bilateral salpingooophorectomy.<EOS>
<BOS>Check the list of NCIsupported cancer clinical trials that are now accepting patients with stage I borderline ovarian surface epithelialstromal tumor and stage II borderline ovarian surface epithelialstromal tumor.<EOS>
<BOS>For more specific results, refine the search by using other search features, such as the location of the trial, the type of treatment, or the name of the drug.<EOS>
<BOS>Talk with your doctor about clinical trials that may be right for you.<EOS>
<BOS>General information about clinical trials is available from the NCI website.<EOS>
<BOS>Late Stage Ovarian Low Malignant Potential Tumors (Stage III and IV) Treatment for late stage ovarian low malignant potential tumor may be hysterectomy, bilateral salpingooophorectomy, and omentectomy.<EOS>
<BOS>A lymph node dissection may also be done.<EOS>
<BOS>Check the list of NCIsupported cancer clinical trials that are now accepting patients with stage III borderline ovarian surface epithelialstromal tumor and stage IV borderline ovarian surface epithelialstromal tumor.<EOS>
<BOS>For more specific results, refine the search by using other search features, such as the location of the trial, the type of treatment, or the name of the drug.<EOS>
<BOS>Talk with your doctor about clinical trials that may be right for you.<EOS>
<BOS>General information about clinical trials is available from the NCI website.<EOS>
<BOS>Recurrent Ovarian Low Malignant Potential Tumors Treatment for recurrent ovarian low malignant potential tumor may include the following: Surgery.<EOS>
<BOS>Surgery followed by chemotherapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Check the list of NCIsupported cancer clinical trials that are now accepting patients with recurrent borderline ovarian surface epithelialstromal tumor.<EOS>
<BOS>For more specific results, refine the search by using other search features, such as the location of the trial, the type of treatment, or the name of the drug.<EOS>
<BOS>Talk with your doctor about clinical trials that may be right for you.<EOS>
<BOS>General information about clinical trials is available from the NCI website.<EOS>
<BOS>Key Points There are different types of treatment for patients with transitional cell cancer of the renal pelvis and ureter.<EOS>
<BOS>One type of standard treatment is used: Surgery New types of treatment are being tested in clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>Fulguration Segmental resection of the renal pelvis Laser surgery Regional chemotherapy and regional biologic therapy Patients may want to think about taking part in a clinical trial.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients can enter clinical trials before, during, or after starting their cancer treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Followup tests may be needed.<EOS>
<BOS>There are different types of treatment for patients with transitional cell cancer of the renal pelvis and ureter.<EOS>
<BOS>Different types of treatments are available for patients with transitional cell cancer of the renal pelvis and ureter.<EOS>
<BOS>Some treatments are standard (the currently used treatment), and some are being tested in clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>A treatment clinical trial is a research study meant to help improve current treatments or obtain information on new treatments for patients with cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>When clinical trials show that a new treatment is better than the standard treatment, the new treatment may become the standard treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients may want to think about taking part in a clinical trial.<EOS>
<BOS>Some clinical trials are open only to patients who have not started treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>One type of standard treatment is used: Surgery One of the following surgical procedures may be used to treat transitional cell cancer of the renal pelvis and ureter: Nephroureterectomy: Surgery to remove the entire kidney, the ureter, and the bladder cuff (tissue that connects the ureter to the bladder).<EOS>
<BOS>Segmental resection of the ureter: A surgical procedure to remove the part of the ureter that contains cancer and some of the healthy tissue around it.<EOS>
<BOS>The ends of the ureter are then reattached.<EOS>
<BOS>This treatment is used when the cancer is superficial and in the lower third of the ureter only, near the bladder.<EOS>
<BOS>New types of treatment are being tested in clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>This summary section describes treatments that are being studied in clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>It may not mention every new treatment being studied.<EOS>
<BOS>Information about clinical trials is available from the NCI Web site.<EOS>
<BOS>Fulguration Fulguration is a surgical procedure that destroys tissue using an electric current.<EOS>
<BOS>A tool with a small wire loop on the end is used to remove the cancer or to burn away the tumor with electricity.<EOS>
<BOS>Segmental resection of the renal pelvis This is a surgical procedure to remove localized cancer from the renal pelvis without removing the entire kidney.<EOS>
<BOS>Segmental resection may be done to save kidney function when the other kidney is damaged or has already been removed.<EOS>
<BOS>Laser surgery A laser beam (narrow beam of intense light) is used as a knife to remove the cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>A laser beam can also be used to kill the cancer cells.<EOS>
<BOS>This procedure may also be called or laser fulguration.<EOS>
<BOS>Regional chemotherapy and regional biologic therapy Chemotherapy is a cancer treatment that uses drugs to stop the growth of cancer cells, either by killing the cells or by stopping the cells from dividing.<EOS>
<BOS>Biologic therapy is a treatment that uses the patient's immune system to fight cancer; substances made by the body or made in a laboratory are used to boost, direct, or restore the body's natural defenses against cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Regional treatment means the anticancer drugs or biologic substances are placed directly into an organ or a body cavity such as the abdomen, so the drugs will affect cancer cells in that area.<EOS>
<BOS>Clinical trials are studying chemotherapy or biologic therapy using drugs placed directly into the renal pelvis or the ureter.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients may want to think about taking part in a clinical trial.<EOS>
<BOS>For some patients, taking part in a clinical trial may be the best treatment choice.<EOS>
<BOS>Clinical trials are part of the cancer research process.<EOS>
<BOS>Clinical trials are done to find out if new cancer treatments are safe and effective or better than the standard treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Many of today's standard treatments for cancer are based on earlier clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients who take part in a clinical trial may receive the standard treatment or be among the first to receive a new treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients who take part in clinical trials also help improve the way cancer will be treated in the future.<EOS>
<BOS>Even when clinical trials do not lead to effective new treatments, they often answer important questions and help move research forward.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients can enter clinical trials before, during, or after starting their cancer treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Some clinical trials only include patients who have not yet received treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Other trials test treatments for patients whose cancer has not gotten better.<EOS>
<BOS>There are also clinical trials that test new ways to stop cancer from recurring (coming back) or reduce the side effects of cancer treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Clinical trials are taking place in many parts of the country.<EOS>
<BOS>See the Treatment Options section that follows for links to current treatment clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>These have been retrieved from NCI's listing of clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>Followup tests may be needed.<EOS>
<BOS>Some of the tests that were done to diagnose the cancer or to find out the stage of the cancer may be repeated.<EOS>
<BOS>Some tests will be repeated in order to see how well the treatment is working.<EOS>
<BOS>Decisions about whether to continue, change, or stop treatment may be based on the results of these tests.<EOS>
<BOS>Some of the tests will continue to be done from time to time after treatment has ended.<EOS>
<BOS>The results of these tests can show if your condition has changed or if the cancer has recurred (come back).<EOS>
<BOS>These tests are sometimes called followup tests or checkups.<EOS>
<BOS>Treatment Options for Transitional Cell Cancer of the Renal Pelvis and Ureter Localized Transitional Cell Cancer of the Renal Pelvis and Ureter Treatment of localized transitional cell cancer of the renal pelvis and ureter may include the following: Surgery (nephroureterectomy or segmental resection of ureter).<EOS>
<BOS>A clinical trial of fulguration.<EOS>
<BOS>A clinical trial of laser surgery.<EOS>
<BOS>A clinical trial of segmental resection of the renal pelvis.<EOS>
<BOS>A clinical trial of regional chemotherapy.<EOS>
<BOS>A clinical trial of regional biologic therapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Check the list of NCIsupported cancer clinical trials that are now accepting patients with localized transitional cell cancer of the renal pelvis and ureter.<EOS>
<BOS>For more specific results, refine the search by using other search features, such as the location of the trial, the type of treatment, or the name of the drug.<EOS>
<BOS>Talk with your doctor about clinical trials that may be right for you.<EOS>
<BOS>General information about clinical trials is available from the NCI website.<EOS>
<BOS>Regional Transitional Cell Cancer of the Renal Pelvis and Ureter Treatment of regional transitional cell cancer of the renal pelvis and ureter is usually done in a clinical trial.<EOS>
<BOS>Check the list of NCIsupported cancer clinical trials that are now accepting patients with regional transitional cell cancer of the renal pelvis and ureter.<EOS>
<BOS>For more specific results, refine the search by using other search features, such as the location of the trial, the type of treatment, or the name of the drug.<EOS>
<BOS>Talk with your doctor about clinical trials that may be right for you.<EOS>
<BOS>General information about clinical trials is available from the NCI website.<EOS>
<BOS>Metastatic Transitional Cell Cancer of the Renal Pelvis and Ureter Treatment of metastatic transitional cell cancer of the renal pelvis and ureter is usually done in a clinical trial, which may include chemotherapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Check the list of NCIsupported cancer clinical trials that are now accepting patients with metastatic transitional cell cancer of the renal pelvis and ureter.<EOS>
<BOS>For more specific results, refine the search by using other search features, such as the location of the trial, the type of treatment, or the name of the drug.<EOS>
<BOS>Talk with your doctor about clinical trials that may be right for you.<EOS>
<BOS>General information about clinical trials is available from the NCI website.<EOS>
<BOS>Recurrent Transitional Cell Cancer of the Renal Pelvis and Ureter Treatment of recurrent transitional cell cancer of the renal pelvis and ureter is usually done in a clinical trial, which may include chemotherapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Check the list of NCIsupported cancer clinical trials that are now accepting patients with recurrent transitional cell cancer of the renal pelvis and ureter.<EOS>
<BOS>For more specific results, refine the search by using other search features, such as the location of the trial, the type of treatment, or the name of the drug.<EOS>
<BOS>Talk with your doctor about clinical trials that may be right for you.<EOS>
<BOS>General information about clinical trials is available from the NCI website.<EOS>
<BOS>Key Points There are different types of treatment for patients with salivary gland cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients with salivary gland cancer should have their treatment planned by a team of doctors who are experts in treating head and neck cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Three types of standard treatment are used: Surgery Radiation therapy Chemotherapy New types of treatment are being tested in clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>Radiosensitizers Patients may want to think about taking part in a clinical trial.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients can enter clinical trials before, during, or after starting their cancer treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Followup tests may be needed.<EOS>
<BOS>There are different types of treatment for patients with salivary gland cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Different types of treatment are available for patients with salivary gland cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Some treatments are standard (the currently used treatment), and some are being tested in clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>A treatment clinical trial is a research study meant to help improve current treatments or obtain information on new treatments for patients with cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>When clinical trials show that a new treatment is better than the standard treatment, the new treatment may become the standard treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients may want to think about taking part in a clinical trial.<EOS>
<BOS>Some clinical trials are open only to patients who have not started treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients with salivary gland cancer should have their treatment planned by a team of doctors who are experts in treating head and neck cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Your treatment will be overseen by a medical oncologist, a doctor who specializes in treating people with cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Because the salivary glands help in eating and digesting food, patients may need special help adjusting to the side effects of the cancer and its treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>The medical oncologist may refer you to other doctors who have experience and expertise in treating patients with head and neck cancer and who specialize in certain areas of medicine.<EOS>
<BOS>These include the following: Head and neck surgeon.<EOS>
<BOS>Radiation oncologist.<EOS>
<BOS>Dentist.<EOS>
<BOS>Speech therapist.<EOS>
<BOS>Dietitian.<EOS>
<BOS>Psychologist.<EOS>
<BOS>Rehabilitation specialist.<EOS>
<BOS>Plastic surgeon.<EOS>
<BOS>Three types of standard treatment are used: Surgery Surgery (removing the cancer in an operation) is a common treatment for salivary gland cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>A doctor may remove the cancer and some of the healthy tissue around the cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>In some cases, a lymphadenectomy (surgery in which lymph nodes are removed) will also be done.<EOS>
<BOS>Even if the doctor removes all the cancer that can be seen at the time of the surgery, some patients may be given radiation therapy after surgery to kill any cancer cells that are left.<EOS>
<BOS>Treatment given after surgery, to lower the risk that the cancer will come back, is called adjuvant therapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Radiation therapy Radiation therapy is a cancer treatment that uses highenergy xrays or other types of radiation to kill cancer cells or keep them from growing.<EOS>
<BOS>There are two types of radiation therapy: External radiation therapy uses a machine outside the body to send radiation toward the cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Special types of external radiation may be used to treat some salivary gland tumors.<EOS>
<BOS>These include: Fast neutron radiation therapy: Fast neutron radiation therapy is a type of highenergy external radiation therapy.<EOS>
<BOS>A radiation therapy machine aims neutrons (tiny, invisible particles) at the cancer cells to kill them.<EOS>
<BOS>Fast neutron radiation therapy uses a higherenergy radiation than the xray type of radiation therapy.<EOS>
<BOS>This allows the radiation therapy to be given in fewer treatments.<EOS>
<BOS>Photonbeam radiation therapy: Photonbeam radiation therapy is a type of external radiation therapy that reaches deep tumors with highenergy xrays made by a machine called a linear accelerator.<EOS>
<BOS>This can be delivered as hyperfractionated radiation therapy, in which the total dose of radiation is divided into small doses and the treatments are given more than once a day.<EOS>
<BOS>Internal radiation therapy uses a radioactive substance sealed in needles, seeds, wires, or catheters that are placed directly into or near the cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>The way the radiation therapy is given depends on the type and stage of the cancer being treated.<EOS>
<BOS>External radiation therapy is used to treat salivary gland cancer, and may also be used as palliative therapy to relieve symptoms and improve quality of life.<EOS>
<BOS>Chemotherapy Chemotherapy is a cancer treatment that uses drugs to stop the growth of cancer cells, either by killing the cells or by stopping them from dividing.<EOS>
<BOS>When chemotherapy is taken by mouth or injected into a vein or muscle, the drugs enter the bloodstream and can reach cancer cells throughout the body (systemic chemotherapy).<EOS>
<BOS>When chemotherapy is placed directly into the cerebrospinal fluid, an organ, or a body cavity such as the abdomen, the drugs mainly affect cancer cells in those areas (regional chemotherapy).<EOS>
<BOS>The way the chemotherapy is given depends on the type and stage of the cancer being treated.<EOS>
<BOS>See Drugs Approved for Head and Neck Cancer for more information.<EOS>
<BOS>(Salivary gland cancer is a type of head and neck cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>) New types of treatment are being tested in clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>This summary section describes treatments that are being studied in clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>It may not mention every new treatment being studied.<EOS>
<BOS>Information about clinical trials is available from the NCI website.<EOS>
<BOS>Radiosensitizers Radiosensitizers are drugs that make tumor cells more sensitive to radiation therapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Combining radiation therapy with radiosensitizers may kill more tumor cells.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients may want to think about taking part in a clinical trial.<EOS>
<BOS>For some patients, taking part in a clinical trial may be the best treatment choice.<EOS>
<BOS>Clinical trials are part of the cancer research process.<EOS>
<BOS>Clinical trials are done to find out if new cancer treatments are safe and effective or better than the standard treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Many of today's standard treatments for cancer are based on earlier clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients who take part in a clinical trial may receive the standard treatment or be among the first to receive a new treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients who take part in clinical trials also help improve the way cancer will be treated in the future.<EOS>
<BOS>Even when clinical trials do not lead to effective new treatments, they often answer important questions and help move research forward.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients can enter clinical trials before, during, or after starting their cancer treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Some clinical trials only include patients who have not yet received treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Other trials test treatments for patients whose cancer has not gotten better.<EOS>
<BOS>There are also clinical trials that test new ways to stop cancer from recurring (coming back) or reduce the side effects of cancer treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Clinical trials are taking place in many parts of the country.<EOS>
<BOS>See the Treatment Options section that follows for links to current treatment clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>These have been retrieved from NCI's listing of clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>Followup tests may be needed.<EOS>
<BOS>Some of the tests that were done to diagnose the cancer or to find out the stage of the cancer may be repeated.<EOS>
<BOS>Some tests will be repeated in order to see how well the treatment is working.<EOS>
<BOS>Decisions about whether to continue, change, or stop treatment may be based on the results of these tests.<EOS>
<BOS>Some of the tests will continue to be done from time to time after treatment has ended.<EOS>
<BOS>The results of these tests can show if your condition has changed or if the cancer has recurred (come back).<EOS>
<BOS>These tests are sometimes called followup tests or checkups.<EOS>
<BOS>Treatment Options by Stage Stage I Salivary Gland Cancer Treatment for stage I salivary gland cancer depends on whether the cancer is lowgrade (slow growing) or highgrade (fast growing).<EOS>
<BOS>If the cancer is lowgrade, treatment may include the following: Surgery with or without radiation therapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Fast neutron radiation therapy.<EOS>
<BOS>If the cancer is highgrade, treatment may include the following: Surgery with or without radiation therapy.<EOS>
<BOS>A clinical trial of chemotherapy.<EOS>
<BOS>A clinical trial of a new local therapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Check the list of NCIsupported cancer clinical trials that are now accepting patients with stage I salivary gland cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>For more specific results, refine the search by using other search features, such as the location of the trial, the type of treatment, or the name of the drug.<EOS>
<BOS>Talk with your doctor about clinical trials that may be right for you.<EOS>
<BOS>General information about clinical trials is available from the NCI website.<EOS>
<BOS>Stage II Salivary Gland Cancer Treatment for stage II salivary gland cancer depends on whether the cancer is lowgrade (slow growing) or highgrade (fast growing).<EOS>
<BOS>If the cancer is lowgrade, treatment may include the following: Surgery with or without radiation therapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Radiation therapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Chemotherapy.<EOS>
<BOS>If the cancer is highgrade, treatment may include the following: Surgery with or without radiation therapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Fast neutron or photonbeam radiation therapy.<EOS>
<BOS>A clinical trial of radiation therapy and/or radiosensitizers.<EOS>
<BOS>A clinical trial of chemotherapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Check the list of NCIsupported cancer clinical trials that are now accepting patients with stage II salivary gland cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>For more specific results, refine the search by using other search features, such as the location of the trial, the type of treatment, or the name of the drug.<EOS>
<BOS>Talk with your doctor about clinical trials that may be right for you.<EOS>
<BOS>General information about clinical trials is available from the NCI website.<EOS>
<BOS>Stage III Salivary Gland Cancer Treatment for stage III salivary gland cancer depends on whether the cancer is lowgrade (slow growing) or highgrade (fast growing).<EOS>
<BOS>If the cancer is lowgrade, treatment may include the following: Surgery with or without lymphadenectomy.<EOS>
<BOS>Radiation therapy may also be given after surgery.<EOS>
<BOS>Radiation therapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Fast neutron radiation therapy to lymph nodes with cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Chemotherapy.<EOS>
<BOS>A clinical trial of fast neutron radiation therapy to the tumor.<EOS>
<BOS>A clinical trial of chemotherapy.<EOS>
<BOS>If the cancer is highgrade, treatment may include the following: Surgery with or without lymphadenectomy.<EOS>
<BOS>Radiation therapy may also be given after surgery.<EOS>
<BOS>Fast neutron radiation therapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Radiation therapy as palliative therapy to relieve symptoms and improve quality of life.<EOS>
<BOS>A clinical trial of radiation therapy and/or radiosensitizers.<EOS>
<BOS>A clinical trial of chemotherapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Check the list of NCIsupported cancer clinical trials that are now accepting patients with stage III salivary gland cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>For more specific results, refine the search by using other search features, such as the location of the trial, the type of treatment, or the name of the drug.<EOS>
<BOS>Talk with your doctor about clinical trials that may be right for you.<EOS>
<BOS>General information about clinical trials is available from the NCI website.<EOS>
<BOS>Stage IV Salivary Gland Cancer Treatment of stage IV salivary gland cancer may include the following: Fast neutron or photonbeam radiation therapy.<EOS>
<BOS>A clinical trial of chemotherapy with or without radiation therapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Check the list of NCIsupported cancer clinical trials that are now accepting patients with stage IV salivary gland cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>For more specific results, refine the search by using other search features, such as the location of the trial, the type of treatment, or the name of the drug.<EOS>
<BOS>Talk with your doctor about clinical trials that may be right for you.<EOS>
<BOS>General information about clinical trials is available from the NCI website.<EOS>
<BOS>Key Points Adult soft tissue sarcoma is a disease in which malignant (cancer) cells form in the soft tissues of the body.<EOS>
<BOS>Having certain inherited disorders can increase the risk of adult soft tissue sarcoma.<EOS>
<BOS>A sign of adult soft tissue sarcoma is a lump or swelling in soft tissue of the body.<EOS>
<BOS>Adult soft tissue sarcoma is diagnosed with a biopsy.<EOS>
<BOS>Certain factors affect treatment options and prognosis (chance of recovery).<EOS>
<BOS>Adult soft tissue sarcoma is a disease in which malignant (cancer) cells form in the soft tissues of the body.<EOS>
<BOS>The soft tissues of the body include the muscles, tendons (bands of fiber that connect muscles to bones), fat, blood vessels, lymph vessels, nerves, and tissues around joints.<EOS>
<BOS>Adult soft tissue sarcomas can form almost anywhere in the body, but are most common in the head, neck, arms, legs, trunk, and abdomen.<EOS>
<BOS>There are many types of soft tissue sarcoma.<EOS>
<BOS>The cells of each type of sarcoma look different under a microscope, based on the type of soft tissue in which the cancer began.<EOS>
<BOS>See the following PDQ summaries for more information on soft tissue sarcomas: Childhood Soft Tissue Sarcoma Treatment Ewing Sarcoma Family of Tumors Treatment Gastrointestinal Stromal Tumors Treatment Kaposi Sarcoma Treatment Uterine Sarcoma Treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Key Points There are different types of treatment for patients with osteosarcoma or malignant fibrous histiocytoma (MFH) of bone.<EOS>
<BOS>Children with osteosarcoma or MFH should have their treatment planned by a team of health care providers who are experts in treating cancer in children.<EOS>
<BOS>Treatment for osteosarcoma or malignant fibrous histiocytoma may cause side effects.<EOS>
<BOS>Four types of standard treatment are used: Surgery Chemotherapy Radiation therapy Samarium New types of treatment are being tested in clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>Targeted therapy Patients may want to think about taking part in a clinical trial.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients can enter clinical trials before, during, or after starting their cancer treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Followup tests may be needed.<EOS>
<BOS>There are different types of treatment for patients with osteosarcoma or malignant fibrous histiocytoma (MFH) of bone.<EOS>
<BOS>Different types of treatment are available for children with osteosarcoma or malignant fibrous histiocytoma (MFH) of bone.<EOS>
<BOS>Some treatments are standard (the currently used treatment), and some are being tested in clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>A treatment clinical trial is a research study meant to help improve current treatments or obtain information on new treatments for patients with cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>When clinical trials show that a new treatment is better than the standard treatment, the new treatment may become the standard treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Because cancer in children is rare, taking part in a clinical trial should be considered.<EOS>
<BOS>Some clinical trials are open only to patients who have not started treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Children with osteosarcoma or MFH should have their treatment planned by a team of health care providers who are experts in treating cancer in children.<EOS>
<BOS>Treatment will be overseen by a pediatric oncologist, a doctor who specializes in treating children with cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>The pediatric oncologist works with other pediatric health care providers who are experts in treating osteosarcoma and MFH and who specialize in certain areas of medicine.<EOS>
<BOS>These may include the following specialists: Pediatrician.<EOS>
<BOS>Orthopedic surgeon.<EOS>
<BOS>Radiation oncologist.<EOS>
<BOS>Rehabilitation specialist.<EOS>
<BOS>Pediatric nurse specialist.<EOS>
<BOS>Social worker.<EOS>
<BOS>Psychologist.<EOS>
<BOS>Treatment for osteosarcoma or malignant fibrous histiocytoma may cause side effects.<EOS>
<BOS>For information about side effects that begin during treatment for cancer, see our Side Effects page.<EOS>
<BOS>Side effects from cancer treatment that begin after treatment and continue for months or years are called late effects.<EOS>
<BOS>Late effects of cancer treatment may include the following: Physical problems.<EOS>
<BOS>Changes in mood, feelings, thinking, learning, or memory.<EOS>
<BOS>Second cancers (new types of cancer).<EOS>
<BOS>Some late effects may be treated or controlled.<EOS>
<BOS>It is important to talk with your child's doctors about the effects cancer treatment can have on your child.<EOS>
<BOS>(See the PDQ summary on Late Effects of Treatment for Childhood Cancer for more information).<EOS>
<BOS>Four types of standard treatment are used: Surgery Surgery to remove the entire tumor will be done when possible.<EOS>
<BOS>Chemotherapy may be given before surgery to make the tumor smaller.<EOS>
<BOS>This is called neoadjuvant chemotherapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Chemotherapy is given so less bone tissue needs to be removed and there are fewer problems after surgery.<EOS>
<BOS>The following types of surgery may be done: Wide local excision: Surgery to remove the cancer and some healthy tissue around it.<EOS>
<BOS>Limbsparing surgery: Removal of the tumor in a limb (arm or leg) without amputation, so the use and appearance of the limb is saved.<EOS>
<BOS>Most patients with osteosarcoma in a limb can be treated with limbsparing surgery.<EOS>
<BOS>The tumor is removed by wide local excision.<EOS>
<BOS>Tissue and bone that are removed may be replaced with a graft using tissue and bone taken from another part of the patient's body, or with an implant such as artificial bone.<EOS>
<BOS>If a fracture is found at diagnosis or during chemotherapy before surgery, limbsparing surgery may still be possible in some cases.<EOS>
<BOS>If the surgeon is not able to remove all of the tumor and enough healthy tissue around it, an amputation may be done.<EOS>
<BOS>Amputation: Surgery to remove part or all of an arm or leg.<EOS>
<BOS>This may be done when it is not possible to remove all of the tumor in limbsparing surgery.<EOS>
<BOS>The patient may be fitted with a prosthesis (artificial limb) after amputation.<EOS>
<BOS>Rotationplasty: Surgery to remove the tumor and the knee joint.<EOS>
<BOS>The part of the leg that remains below the knee is then attached to the part of the leg that remains above the knee, with the foot facing backward and the ankle acting as a knee.<EOS>
<BOS>A prosthesis may then be attached to the foot.<EOS>
<BOS>Studies have shown that survival is the same whether the first surgery done is a limbsparing surgery or an amputation.<EOS>
<BOS>Even if the doctor removes all the cancer that can be seen at the time of the surgery, patients are also given chemotherapy after surgery to kill any cancer cells that are left in the area where the tumor was removed or that have spread to other parts of the body.<EOS>
<BOS>Treatment given after the surgery, to lower the risk that the cancer will come back, is called adjuvant therapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Chemotherapy Chemotherapy is a cancer treatment that uses drugs to stop the growth of cancer cells, either by killing the cells or by stopping them from dividing.<EOS>
<BOS>When chemotherapy is taken by mouth or injected into a vein or muscle, the drugs enter the bloodstream and can reach cancer cells throughout the body (systemic chemotherapy).<EOS>
<BOS>When chemotherapy is placed directly into the cerebrospinal fluid, an organ, or a body cavity such as the abdomen, the drugs mainly affect cancer cells in those areas (regional chemotherapy).<EOS>
<BOS>Combination chemotherapy is the use of more than one anticancer drug.<EOS>
<BOS>The way the chemotherapy is given depends on the type and stage of the cancer being treated.<EOS>
<BOS>In the treatment of osteosarcoma and malignant fibrous histiocytosis of bone, chemotherapy is usually given before and after surgery to remove the primary tumor.<EOS>
<BOS>See Drugs Approved for Bone Cancer for more information.<EOS>
<BOS>Radiation therapy Radiation therapy is a cancer treatment that uses highenergy xrays or other types of radiation to kill cancer cells or keep them from growing.<EOS>
<BOS>There are two types of radiation therapy: External radiation therapy uses a machine outside the body to send radiation toward the cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Internal radiation therapy uses a radioactive substance sealed in needles, seeds, wires, or catheters that are placed directly into or near the cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>The way the radiation therapy is given depends on the type and stage of the cancer being treated.<EOS>
<BOS>Osteosarcoma and MFH cells are not killed easily by external radiation therapy.<EOS>
<BOS>It may be used when a small amount of cancer is left after surgery or used together with other treatments.<EOS>
<BOS>Samarium Samarium is a radioactive drug that targets areas where bone cells are growing, such as tumor cells in bone.<EOS>
<BOS>It helps relieve pain caused by cancer in the bone and it also kills blood cells in the bone marrow.<EOS>
<BOS>It also is used to treat osteosarcoma that has come back after treatment in a different bone.<EOS>
<BOS>Treatment with samarium may be followed by stem cell transplant.<EOS>
<BOS>Before treatment with samarium, stem cells (immature blood cells) are removed from the blood or bone marrow of the patient and are frozen and stored.<EOS>
<BOS>After treatment with samarium is complete, the stored stem cells are thawed and given back to the patient through an infusion.<EOS>
<BOS>These reinfused stem cells grow into (and restore) the body's blood cells.<EOS>
<BOS>New types of treatment are being tested in clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>This summary section describes treatments that are being studied in clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>It may not mention every new treatment being studied.<EOS>
<BOS>Information about ongoing clinical trials is available from the NCI website.<EOS>
<BOS>Targeted therapy Targeted therapy is a treatment that uses drugs or other substances to find and attack specific cancer cells without harming normal cells.<EOS>
<BOS>Kinase inhibitor therapy and monoclonal antibody therapy are types of targeted therapy being studied in clinical trials for osteosarcoma.<EOS>
<BOS>Kinase inhibitor therapy blocks a protein needed for cancer cells to divide.<EOS>
<BOS>Sorafenib is a type of kinase inhibitor therapy being studied for the treatment of recurrent osteosarcoma.<EOS>
<BOS>Monoclonal antibody therapy is a cancer treatment that uses antibodies made in the laboratory, from a single type of immune system cell.<EOS>
<BOS>These antibodies can identify substances on cancer cells or normal substances that may help cancer cells grow.<EOS>
<BOS>The antibodies attach to the substances and kill the cancer cells, block their growth, or keep them from spreading.<EOS>
<BOS>Monoclonal antibodies are given by infusion.<EOS>
<BOS>They may be used alone or to carry drugs, toxins, or radioactive material directly to cancer cells.<EOS>
<BOS>Denosumab, dinutuximab, and glembatumumab are monoclonal antibodies being studied for the treatment of recurrent osteosarcoma.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients may want to think about taking part in a clinical trial.<EOS>
<BOS>For some patients, taking part in a clinical trial may be the best treatment choice.<EOS>
<BOS>Clinical trials are part of the cancer research process.<EOS>
<BOS>Clinical trials are done to find out if new cancer treatments are safe and effective or better than the standard treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Many of today's standard treatments for cancer are based on earlier clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients who take part in a clinical trial may receive the standard treatment or be among the first to receive a new treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients who take part in clinical trials also help improve the way cancer will be treated in the future.<EOS>
<BOS>Even when clinical trials do not lead to effective new treatments, they often answer important questions and help move research forward.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients can enter clinical trials before, during, or after starting their cancer treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Some clinical trials only include patients who have not yet received treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Other trials test treatments for patients whose cancer has not gotten better.<EOS>
<BOS>There are also clinical trials that test new ways to stop cancer from recurring (coming back) or reduce the side effects of cancer treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Clinical trials are taking place in many parts of the country.<EOS>
<BOS>See the Treatment Options section that follows for links to current treatment clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>These have been retrieved from NCI's listing of clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>Followup tests may be needed.<EOS>
<BOS>Some of the tests that were done to diagnose the cancer or to find out the stage of the cancer may be repeated.<EOS>
<BOS>Some tests will be repeated in order to see how well the treatment is working.<EOS>
<BOS>Decisions about whether to continue, change, or stop treatment may be based on the results of these tests.<EOS>
<BOS>Some of the tests will continue to be done from time to time after treatment has ended.<EOS>
<BOS>The results of these tests can show if your child's condition has changed or if the cancer has recurred (come back).<EOS>
<BOS>These tests are sometimes called followup tests or checkups.<EOS>
<BOS>Treatment Options for Osteosarcoma and Malignant Fibrous Histiocytoma of Bone Localized Osteosarcoma and Malignant Fibrous Histiocytoma of Bone Treatment may include the following: Surgery.<EOS>
<BOS>Combination chemotherapy is usually given before and after surgery.<EOS>
<BOS>Surgery followed by radiation therapy when the tumor cannot be completely removed by surgery.<EOS>
<BOS>Check the list of NCIsupported cancer clinical trials that are now accepting patients with localized osteosarcoma and localized childhood malignant fibrous histiocytoma of bone.<EOS>
<BOS>For more specific results, refine the search by using other search features, such as the location of the trial, the type of treatment, or the name of the drug.<EOS>
<BOS>Talk with your child's doctor about clinical trials that may be right for your child.<EOS>
<BOS>General information about clinical trials is available from the NCI website.<EOS>
<BOS>Metastatic Osteosarcoma and Malignant Fibrous Histiocytoma of Bone Lung Metastasis When osteosarcoma or malignant fibrous histiocytoma (MFH) spreads, it usually spreads to the lung.<EOS>
<BOS>Treatment of osteosarcoma and MFH with lung metastasis may include the following: Combination chemotherapy followed by surgery to remove the primary cancer and the cancer that has spread to the lung.<EOS>
<BOS>Bone Metastasis or Bone with Lung Metastasis Osteosarcoma and malignant fibrous histiocytoma may spread to a distant bone and/or the lung.<EOS>
<BOS>Treatment may include the following: Combination chemotherapy followed by surgery to remove the primary tumor and the cancer that has spread to other parts of the body.<EOS>
<BOS>More chemotherapy is given after surgery.<EOS>
<BOS>Surgery to remove the primary tumor followed by chemotherapy and surgery to remove cancer that has spread to other parts of the body.<EOS>
<BOS>Check the list of NCIsupported cancer clinical trials that are now accepting patients with metastatic osteosarcoma and metastatic childhood malignant fibrous histiocytoma of bone.<EOS>
<BOS>For more specific results, refine the search by using other search features, such as the location of the trial, the type of treatment, or the name of the drug.<EOS>
<BOS>Talk with your child's doctor about clinical trials that may be right for your child.<EOS>
<BOS>General information about clinical trials is available from the NCI website.<EOS>
<BOS>Recurrent Osteosarcoma and Malignant Fibrous Histiocytoma of Bone Treatment of recurrent osteosarcoma and malignant fibrous histiocytoma of bone may include the following: Surgery to remove the tumor with or without chemotherapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Samarium with or without stem cell transplant using the patient's own stem cells, as palliative treatment to relieve pain and improve the quality of life.<EOS>
<BOS>A clinical trial of new types of treatment for patients whose cancer cannot be removed by surgery.<EOS>
<BOS>These may include targeted therapy such as kinase inhibitor therapy or monoclonal antibody therapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Check the list of NCIsupported cancer clinical trials that are now accepting patients with recurrent osteosarcoma and recurrent childhood malignant fibrous histiocytoma of bone.<EOS>
<BOS>For more specific results, refine the search by using other search features, such as the location of the trial, the type of treatment, or the name of the drug.<EOS>
<BOS>Talk with your child's doctor about clinical trials that may be right for your child.<EOS>
<BOS>General information about clinical trials is available from the NCI website.<EOS>
<BOS>Signs of paranasal sinus and nasal cavity cancer include sinus problems and nosebleeds.<EOS>
<BOS>These and other signs and symptoms may be caused by paranasal sinus and nasal cavity cancer or by other conditions.<EOS>
<BOS>There may be no signs or symptoms in the early stages.<EOS>
<BOS>Signs and symptoms may appear as the tumor grows.<EOS>
<BOS>Check with your doctor if you have any of the following: Blocked sinuses that do not clear, or sinus pressure.<EOS>
<BOS>Headaches or pain in the sinus areas.<EOS>
<BOS>A runny nose.<EOS>
<BOS>Nosebleeds.<EOS>
<BOS>A lump or sore inside the nose that does not heal.<EOS>
<BOS>A lump on the face or roof of the mouth.<EOS>
<BOS>Numbness or tingling in the face.<EOS>
<BOS>Swelling or other trouble with the eyes, such as double vision or the eyes pointing in different directions.<EOS>
<BOS>Pain in the upper teeth, loose teeth, or dentures that no longer fit well.<EOS>
<BOS>Pain or pressure in the ear.<EOS>
<BOS>Signs of bile duct cancer include jaundice and pain in the abdomen.<EOS>
<BOS>These and other signs and symptoms may be caused by bile duct cancer or by other conditions.<EOS>
<BOS>Check with your doctor if you have any of the following: Jaundice (yellowing of the skin or whites of the eyes).<EOS>
<BOS>Dark urine.<EOS>
<BOS>Clay colored stool.<EOS>
<BOS>Pain in the abdomen.<EOS>
<BOS>Fever.<EOS>
<BOS>Itchy skin.<EOS>
<BOS>Nausea and vomiting.<EOS>
<BOS>Weight loss for an unknown reason.<EOS>
<BOS>Certain factors affect treatment options and prognosis (chance of recovery).<EOS>
<BOS>The treatment options may depend on the following: The number of hairy (leukemia) cells and healthy blood cells in the blood and bone marrow.<EOS>
<BOS>Whether the spleen is swollen.<EOS>
<BOS>Whether there are signs or symptoms of leukemia, such as infection.<EOS>
<BOS>Whether the leukemia has recurred (come back) after previous treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>The prognosis (chance of recovery) depends on the following: Whether the hairy cell leukemia does not grow or grows so slowly it does not need treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Whether the hairy cell leukemia responds to treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Treatment often results in a longlasting remission (a period during which some or all of the signs and symptoms of the leukemia are gone).<EOS>
<BOS>If the leukemia returns after it has been in remission, retreatment often causes another remission.<EOS>
<BOS>New types of treatment are being tested in clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>Information about clinical trials is available from the NCI website.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients may want to think about taking part in a clinical trial.<EOS>
<BOS>For some patients, taking part in a clinical trial may be the best treatment choice.<EOS>
<BOS>Clinical trials are part of the cancer research process.<EOS>
<BOS>Clinical trials are done to find out if new cancer treatments are safe and effective or better than the standard treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Many of today's standard treatments for cancer are based on earlier clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients who take part in a clinical trial may receive the standard treatment or be among the first to receive a new treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients who take part in clinical trials also help improve the way cancer will be treated in the future.<EOS>
<BOS>Even when clinical trials do not lead to effective new treatments, they often answer important questions and help move research forward.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients can enter clinical trials before, during, or after starting their cancer treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Some clinical trials only include patients who have not yet received treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Other trials test treatments for patients whose cancer has not gotten better.<EOS>
<BOS>There are also clinical trials that test new ways to stop cancer from recurring (coming back) or reduce the side effects of cancer treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Clinical trials are taking place in many parts of the country.<EOS>
<BOS>See the Treatment Options section that follows for links to current treatment clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>These have been retrieved from NCI's listing of clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>The risk factors for neuroblastoma are not known.<EOS>
<BOS>un exposure and having a weak immune system can affect the risk of Merkel cell carcinoma.<EOS>
<BOS>Anything that increases your risk of getting a disease is called a risk factor.<EOS>
<BOS>Having a risk factor does not mean that you will get cancer; not having risk factors doesn't mean that you will not get cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Talk with your doctor if you think you may be at risk.<EOS>
<BOS>Risk factors for Merkel cell carcinoma include the following: Being exposed to a lot of natural sunlight.<EOS>
<BOS>Being exposed to artificial sunlight, such as from tanning beds or psoralen and ultraviolet A (PUVA) therapy for psoriasis.<EOS>
<BOS>Having an immune system weakened by disease, such as chronic lymphocytic leukemia or HIV infection.<EOS>
<BOS>Taking drugs that make the immune system less active, such as after an organ transplant.<EOS>
<BOS>Having a history of other types of cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Being older than 50 years, male, or white.<EOS>
<BOS>Key Points There are different types of treatment for patients with gallbladder cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Three types of standard treatment are used: Surgery Radiation therapy Chemotherapy New types of treatment are being tested in clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>Radiation sensitizers Patients may want to think about taking part in a clinical trial.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients can enter clinical trials before, during, or after starting their cancer treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Followup tests may be needed.<EOS>
<BOS>There are different types of treatment for patients with gallbladder cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Different types of treatments are available for patients with gallbladder cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Some treatments are standard (the currently used treatment), and some are being tested in clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>A treatment clinical trial is a research study meant to help improve current treatments or obtain information on new treatments for patients with cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>When clinical trials show that a new treatment is better than the standard treatment, the new treatment may become the standard treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients may want to think about taking part in a clinical trial.<EOS>
<BOS>Some clinical trials are open only to patients who have not started treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Three types of standard treatment are used: Surgery Gallbladder cancer may be treated with a cholecystectomy, surgery to remove the gallbladder and some of the tissues around it.<EOS>
<BOS>Nearby lymph nodes may be removed.<EOS>
<BOS>A laparoscope is sometimes used to guide gallbladder surgery.<EOS>
<BOS>The laparoscope is attached to a video camera and inserted through an incision (port) in the abdomen.<EOS>
<BOS>Surgical instruments are inserted through other ports to perform the surgery.<EOS>
<BOS>Because there is a risk that gallbladder cancer cells may spread to these ports, tissue surrounding the port sites may also be removed.<EOS>
<BOS>If the cancer has spread and cannot be removed, the following types of palliative surgery may relieve symptoms: Surgical biliary bypass: If the tumor is blocking the small intestine and bile is building up in the gallbladder, a biliary bypass may be done.<EOS>
<BOS>During this operation, the gallbladder or bile duct will be cut and sewn to the small intestine to create a new pathway around the blocked area.<EOS>
<BOS>Endoscopic stent placement: If the tumor is blocking the bile duct, surgery may be done to put in a stent (a thin, flexible tube) to drain bile that has built up in the area.<EOS>
<BOS>The stent may be placed through a catheter that drains to the outside of the body or the stent may go around the blocked area and drain the bile into the small intestine.<EOS>
<BOS>Percutaneous transhepatic biliary drainage: A procedure done to drain bile when there is a blockage and endoscopic stent placement is not possible.<EOS>
<BOS>An xray of the liver and bile ducts is done to locate the blockage.<EOS>
<BOS>Images made by ultrasound are used to guide placement of a stent, which is left in the liver to drain bile into the small intestine or a collection bag outside the body.<EOS>
<BOS>This procedure may be done to relieve jaundice before surgery.<EOS>
<BOS>Radiation therapy Radiation therapy is a cancer treatment that uses highenergy xrays or other types of radiation to kill cancer cells or keep them from growing.<EOS>
<BOS>There are two types of radiation therapy: External radiation therapy uses a machine outside the body to send radiation toward the cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Internal radiation therapy uses a radioactive substance sealed in needles, seeds, wires, or catheters that are placed directly into or near the cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>The way the radiation therapy is given depends on the type and stage of the cancer being treated.<EOS>
<BOS>External radiation therapy is used to treat gallbladder cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Chemotherapy Chemotherapy is a cancer treatment that uses drugs to stop the growth of cancer cells, either by killing the cells or by stopping the cells from dividing.<EOS>
<BOS>When chemotherapy is taken by mouth or injected into a vein or muscle, the drugs enter the bloodstream and can reach cancer cells throughout the body (systemic chemotherapy).<EOS>
<BOS>When chemotherapy is placed directly into the cerebrospinal fluid, an organ, or a body cavity such as the abdomen, the drugs mainly affect cancer cells in those areas (regional chemotherapy).<EOS>
<BOS>The way the chemotherapy is given depends on the type and stage of the cancer being treated.<EOS>
<BOS>New types of treatment are being tested in clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>This summary section describes treatments that are being studied in clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>It may not mention every new treatment being studied.<EOS>
<BOS>Information about clinical trials is available from the NCI website.<EOS>
<BOS>Radiation sensitizers Clinical trials are studying ways to improve the effect of radiation therapy on tumor cells, including the following: Hyperthermia therapy: A treatment in which body tissue is exposed to high temperatures to damage and kill cancer cells or to make cancer cells more sensitive to the effects of radiation therapy and certain anticancer drugs.<EOS>
<BOS>Radiosensitizers: Drugs that make tumor cells more sensitive to radiation therapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Giving radiation therapy together with radiosensitizers may kill more tumor cells.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients may want to think about taking part in a clinical trial.<EOS>
<BOS>For some patients, taking part in a clinical trial may be the best treatment choice.<EOS>
<BOS>Clinical trials are part of the cancer research process.<EOS>
<BOS>Clinical trials are done to find out if new cancer treatments are safe and effective or better than the standard treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Many of today's standard treatments for cancer are based on earlier clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients who take part in a clinical trial may receive the standard treatment or be among the first to receive a new treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients who take part in clinical trials also help improve the way cancer will be treated in the future.<EOS>
<BOS>Even when clinical trials do not lead to effective new treatments, they often answer important questions and help move research forward.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients can enter clinical trials before, during, or after starting their cancer treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Some clinical trials only include patients who have not yet received treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Other trials test treatments for patients whose cancer has not gotten better.<EOS>
<BOS>There are also clinical trials that test new ways to stop cancer from recurring (coming back) or reduce the side effects of cancer treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Clinical trials are taking place in many parts of the country.<EOS>
<BOS>See the Treatment Options section that follows for links to current treatment clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>These have been retrieved from NCI's listing of clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>Followup tests may be needed.<EOS>
<BOS>Some of the tests that were done to diagnose the cancer or to find out the stage of the cancer may be repeated.<EOS>
<BOS>Some tests will be repeated in order to see how well the treatment is working.<EOS>
<BOS>Decisions about whether to continue, change, or stop treatment may be based on the results of these tests.<EOS>
<BOS>Some of the tests will continue to be done from time to time after treatment has ended.<EOS>
<BOS>The results of these tests can show if your condition has changed or if the cancer has recurred (come back).<EOS>
<BOS>These tests are sometimes called followup tests or checkups.<EOS>
<BOS>Treatment Options for Gallbladder Cancer Localized Gallbladder Cancer Treatment of localized gallbladder cancer may include the following: Surgery to remove the gallbladder and some of the tissue around it.<EOS>
<BOS>Part of the liver and nearby lymph nodes may also be removed.<EOS>
<BOS>Radiation therapy with or without chemotherapy may follow surgery.<EOS>
<BOS>Radiation therapy with or without chemotherapy.<EOS>
<BOS>A clinical trial of radiation therapy with radiosensitizers.<EOS>
<BOS>Check the list of NCIsupported cancer clinical trials that are now accepting patients with localized gallbladder cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>For more specific results, refine the search by using other search features, such as the location of the trial, the type of treatment, or the name of the drug.<EOS>
<BOS>Talk with your doctor about clinical trials that may be right for you.<EOS>
<BOS>General information about clinical trials is available from the NCI website.<EOS>
<BOS>Unresectable, Recurrent, or Metastatic Gallbladder Cancer Treatment of unresectable, recurrent, or metastatic gallbladder cancer is usually within a clinical trial.<EOS>
<BOS>Treatment may include the following: Percutaneous transhepatic biliary drainage or the placement of stents to relieve symptoms caused by blocked bile ducts.<EOS>
<BOS>This may be followed by radiation therapy as palliative treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Surgery as palliative treatment to relieve symptoms caused by blocked bile ducts.<EOS>
<BOS>Chemotherapy.<EOS>
<BOS>A clinical trial of new ways to give palliative radiation therapy, such as giving it together with hyperthermia therapy, radiosensitizers, or chemotherapy.<EOS>
<BOS>A clinical trial of new drugs and drug combinations.<EOS>
<BOS>Check the list of NCIsupported cancer clinical trials that are now accepting patients with unresectable gallbladder cancer, recurrent gallbladder cancer and metastatic gallbladder cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>For more specific results, refine the search by using other search features, such as the location of the trial, the type of treatment, or the name of the drug.<EOS>
<BOS>Talk with your doctor about clinical trials that may be right for you.<EOS>
<BOS>General information about clinical trials is available from the NCI website.<EOS>
<BOS>Tests that examine the endometrium are used to detect (find) and diagnose endometrial cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Because endometrial cancer begins inside the uterus, it does not usually show up in the results of a Pap test.<EOS>
<BOS>For this reason, a sample of endometrial tissue must be removed and checked under a microscope to look for cancer cells.<EOS>
<BOS>One of the following procedures may be used: Endometrial biopsy : The removal of tissue from the endometrium (inner lining of the uterus) by inserting a thin, flexible tube through the cervix and into the uterus.<EOS>
<BOS>The tube is used to gently scrape a small amount of tissue from the endometrium and then remove the tissue samples.<EOS>
<BOS>A pathologist views the tissue under a microscope to look for cancer cells.<EOS>
<BOS>Dilatation and curettage : A procedure to remove samples of tissue from the inner lining of the uterus.<EOS>
<BOS>The cervix is dilated and a curette (spoonshaped instrument) is inserted into the uterus to remove tissue.<EOS>
<BOS>The tissue samples are checked under a microscope for signs of disease.<EOS>
<BOS>This procedure is also called a D&C.<EOS>
<BOS>Hysteroscopy: A procedure to look inside the uterus for abnormal areas.<EOS>
<BOS>A hysteroscope is inserted through the vagina and cervix into the uterus.<EOS>
<BOS>A hysteroscope is a thin, tubelike instrument with a light and a lens for viewing.<EOS>
<BOS>It may also have a tool to remove tissue samples, which are checked under a microscope for signs of cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Other tests and procedures used to diagnose endometrial cancer include the following: Physical exam and history : An exam of the body to check general signs of health, including checking for signs of disease, such as lumps or anything else that seems unusual.<EOS>
<BOS>A history of the patients health habits and past illnesses and treatments will also be taken.<EOS>
<BOS>Transvaginal ultrasound exam: A procedure used to examine the vagina, uterus, fallopian tubes, and bladder.<EOS>
<BOS>An ultrasound transducer (probe) is inserted into the vagina and used to bounce highenergy sound waves (ultrasound) off internal tissues or organs and make echoes.<EOS>
<BOS>The echoes form a picture of body tissues called a sonogram.<EOS>
<BOS>The doctor can identify tumors by looking at the sonogram.<EOS>
<BOS>Age can affect the risk of plasma cell neoplasms.<EOS>
<BOS>Anything that increases your risk of getting a disease is called a risk factor.<EOS>
<BOS>Having a risk factor does not mean that you will get cancer; not having risk factors doesn't mean that you will not get cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Talk with your doctor if you think you may be at risk.<EOS>
<BOS>Plasma cell neoplasms are most common in people who are middle aged or older.<EOS>
<BOS>For multiple myeloma and plasmacytoma, other risk factors include the following: Being black.<EOS>
<BOS>Being male.<EOS>
<BOS>Having a personal history of MGUS or plasmacytoma.<EOS>
<BOS>Being exposed to radiation or certain chemicals.<EOS>
<BOS>Use of tobacco products and heavy drinking can affect the risk of developing hypopharyngeal cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Anything that increases your risk of getting a disease is called a risk factor.<EOS>
<BOS>Having a risk factor does not mean that you will get cancer; not having risk factors doesn't mean that you will not get cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Talk with your doctor if you think you may be at risk.<EOS>
<BOS>Risk factors include the following: Smoking tobacco.<EOS>
<BOS>Chewing tobacco.<EOS>
<BOS>Heavy alcohol use.<EOS>
<BOS>Eating a diet without enough nutrients.<EOS>
<BOS>Having PlummerVinson syndrome.<EOS>
<BOS>Key Points Myelodysplastic/myeloproliferative neoplasms are a group of diseases in which the bone marrow makes too many white blood cells.<EOS>
<BOS>Myelodysplastic/myeloproliferative neoplasms have features of both myelodysplastic syndromes and myeloproliferative neoplasms.<EOS>
<BOS>There are different types of myelodysplastic/myeloproliferative neoplasms.<EOS>
<BOS>Tests that examine the blood and bone marrow are used to detect (find) and diagnose myelodysplastic/myeloproliferative neoplasms.<EOS>
<BOS>Myelodysplastic/myeloproliferative neoplasms are a group of diseases in which the bone marrow makes too many white blood cells.<EOS>
<BOS>Myelodysplastic /myeloproliferative neoplasms are diseases of the blood and bone marrow.<EOS>
<BOS>Normally, the bone marrow makes blood stem cells (immature cells) that become mature blood cells over time.<EOS>
<BOS>A blood stem cell may become a myeloid stem cell or a lymphoid stem cell.<EOS>
<BOS>A lymphoid stem cell becomes a white blood cell.<EOS>
<BOS>A myeloid stem cell becomes one of three types of mature blood cells: Red blood cells that carry oxygen and other substances to all tissues of the body.<EOS>
<BOS>White blood cells that fight infection and disease.<EOS>
<BOS>Platelets that form blood clots to stop bleeding.<EOS>
<BOS>Myelodysplastic/myeloproliferative neoplasms have features of both myelodysplastic syndromes and myeloproliferative neoplasms.<EOS>
<BOS>In myelodysplastic diseases, the blood stem cells do not mature into healthy red blood cells, white blood cells, or platelets.<EOS>
<BOS>The immature blood cells, called blasts, do not work the way they should and die in the bone marrow or soon after they enter the blood.<EOS>
<BOS>As a result, there are fewer healthy red blood cells, white blood cells, and platelets.<EOS>
<BOS>In myeloproliferative diseases, a greater than normal number of blood stem cells become one or more types of blood cells and the total number of blood cells slowly increases.<EOS>
<BOS>This summary is about neoplasms that have features of both myelodysplastic and myeloproliferative diseases.<EOS>
<BOS>See the following PDQ summaries for more information about related diseases: Myelodysplastic Syndromes Treatment Chronic Myeloproliferative Neoplasms Treatment Chronic Myelogenous Leukemia Treatment There are different types of myelodysplastic/myeloproliferative neoplasms.<EOS>
<BOS>The 3 main types of myelodysplastic/myeloproliferative neoplasms include the following: Chronic myelomonocytic leukemia (CMML).<EOS>
<BOS>Juvenile myelomonocytic leukemia (JMML).<EOS>
<BOS>Atypical chronic myelogenous leukemia (CML).<EOS>
<BOS>When a myelodysplastic/myeloproliferative neoplasm does not match any of these types, it is called myelodysplastic/myeloproliferative neoplasm, unclassifiable (MDS/MPNUC).<EOS>
<BOS>Myelodysplastic/myeloproliferative neoplasms may progress to acute leukemia.<EOS>
<BOS>Testicular cancer is the most common cancer in men aged 15 to 34 years.<EOS>
<BOS>Testicular cancer is very rare, but it is the most common cancer found in men between the ages of 15 and 34.<EOS>
<BOS>White men are four times more likely than black men to have testicular cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Key Points After nasopharyngeal cancer has been diagnosed, tests are done to find out if cancer cells have spread within the nasopharynx or to other parts of the body.<EOS>
<BOS>There are three ways that cancer spreads in the body.<EOS>
<BOS>Cancer may spread from where it began to other parts of the body.<EOS>
<BOS>The following stages are used for nasopharyngeal cancer: Stage 0 (Carcinoma in Situ) Stage I Stage II Stage III Stage IV After nasopharyngeal cancer has been diagnosed, tests are done to find out if cancer cells have spread within the nasopharynx or to other parts of the body.<EOS>
<BOS>The process used to find out whether cancer has spread within the nasopharynx or to other parts of the body is called staging.<EOS>
<BOS>The information gathered from the staging process determines the stage of the disease.<EOS>
<BOS>It is important to know the stage in order to plan treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>The results of the tests used to diagnose nasopharyngeal cancer are often also used to stage the disease.<EOS>
<BOS>(See the General Information section.<EOS>
<BOS>) There are three ways that cancer spreads in the body.<EOS>
<BOS>Cancer can spread through tissue, the lymph system, and the blood: Tissue.<EOS>
<BOS>The cancer spreads from where it began by growing into nearby areas.<EOS>
<BOS>Lymph system.<EOS>
<BOS>The cancer spreads from where it began by getting into the lymph system.<EOS>
<BOS>The cancer travels through the lymph vessels to other parts of the body.<EOS>
<BOS>Blood.<EOS>
<BOS>The cancer spreads from where it began by getting into the blood.<EOS>
<BOS>The cancer travels through the blood vessels to other parts of the body.<EOS>
<BOS>Cancer may spread from where it began to other parts of the body.<EOS>
<BOS>When cancer spreads to another part of the body, it is called metastasis.<EOS>
<BOS>Cancer cells break away from where they began (the primary tumor) and travel through the lymph system or blood.<EOS>
<BOS>Lymph system.<EOS>
<BOS>The cancer gets into the lymph system, travels through the lymph vessels, and forms a tumor (metastatic tumor) in another part of the body.<EOS>
<BOS>Blood.<EOS>
<BOS>The cancer gets into the blood, travels through the blood vessels, and forms a tumor (metastatic tumor) in another part of the body.<EOS>
<BOS>The metastatic tumor is the same type of cancer as the primary tumor.<EOS>
<BOS>For example, if nasopharyngeal cancer spreads to the lung, the cancer cells in the lung are actually nasopharyngeal cancer cells.<EOS>
<BOS>The disease is metastatic nasopharyngeal cancer, not lung cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>The following stages are used for nasopharyngeal cancer: Stage 0 (Carcinoma in Situ) In stage 0, abnormal cells are found in the lining of the nasopharynx.<EOS>
<BOS>These abnormal cells may become cancer and spread into nearby normal tissue.<EOS>
<BOS>Stage 0 is also called carcinoma in situ.<EOS>
<BOS>Stage I In stage I, cancer has formed and the cancer: is found in the nasopharynx only; or has spread from the nasopharynx to the oropharynx and/or to the nasal cavity.<EOS>
<BOS>The oropharynx is the middle part of the throat and includes the soft palate, the base of the tongue, and the tonsils.<EOS>
<BOS>Stage II In stage II nasopharyngeal cancer, the cancer: is found in the nasopharynx only or has spread from the nasopharynx to the oropharynx and/or to the nasal cavity.<EOS>
<BOS>Cancer has spread to one or more lymph nodes on one side of the neck and/or to lymph nodes behind the pharynx.<EOS>
<BOS>The affected lymph nodes are 6 centimeters or smaller; or is found in the parapharyngeal space.<EOS>
<BOS>Cancer may have spread to one or more lymph nodes on one side of the neck and/or to lymph nodes behind the pharynx.<EOS>
<BOS>The affected lymph nodes are 6 centimeters or smaller.<EOS>
<BOS>The oropharynx is the middle part of the throat and includes the soft palate, the base of the tongue, and the tonsils.<EOS>
<BOS>The parapharyngeal space is a fatfilled, triangular area near the pharynx, between the base of the skull and the lower jaw.<EOS>
<BOS>Stage III In stage III nasopharyngeal cancer, the cancer: is found in the nasopharynx only or has spread from the nasopharynx to the oropharynx and/or to the nasal cavity.<EOS>
<BOS>Cancer has spread to one or more lymph nodes on both sides of the neck.<EOS>
<BOS>The affected lymph nodes are 6 centimeters or smaller; or is found in the parapharyngeal space.<EOS>
<BOS>Cancer has spread to one or more lymph nodes on both sides of the neck.<EOS>
