<BOS>The affected lymph nodes are 6 centimeters or smaller; or has spread to nearby bones or sinuses.<EOS>
<BOS>Cancer may have spread to one or more lymph nodes on one or both sides of the neck and/or to lymph nodes behind the pharynx.<EOS>
<BOS>The affected lymph nodes are 6 centimeters or smaller.<EOS>
<BOS>The oropharynx is the middle part of the throat and includes the soft palate, the base of the tongue, and the tonsils.<EOS>
<BOS>The parapharyngeal space is a fatfilled, triangular area near the pharynx, between the base of the skull and the lower jaw.<EOS>
<BOS>Stage IV Stage IV nasopharyngeal cancer is divided into stages IVA, IVB, and IVC.<EOS>
<BOS>Stage IVA: Cancer has spread beyond the nasopharynx and may have spread to the cranial nerves, the hypopharynx (bottom part of the throat), areas in and around the side of the skull or jawbone, and/or the bone around the eye.<EOS>
<BOS>Cancer may also have spread to one or more lymph nodes on one or both sides of the neck and/or to lymph nodes behind the pharynx.<EOS>
<BOS>The affected lymph nodes are 6 centimeters or smaller.<EOS>
<BOS>Stage IVB: Cancer has spread to lymph nodes between the collarbone and the top of the shoulder and/or the affected lymph nodes are larger than 6 centimeters.<EOS>
<BOS>Stage IVC: Cancer has spread beyond nearby lymph nodes to other parts of the body.<EOS>
<BOS>Cancer prevention clinical trials are used to study ways to prevent cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Cancer prevention clinical trials are used to study ways to lower the risk of certain types of cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Some cancer prevention trials are done with healthy people who have not had cancer but who have an increased risk for cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Other prevention trials are done with people who have had cancer and are trying to prevent another cancer of the same type or to lower their chance of developing a new type of cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Other trials are done with healthy volunteers who are not known to have any risk factors for cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>The purpose of some cancer prevention clinical trials is to find out whether actions people take can prevent cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>These may include eating fruits and vegetables, exercising, quitting smoking, or taking certain medicines, vitamins, minerals, or food supplements.<EOS>
<BOS>New ways to prevent oral cavity cancer and oropharyngeal cancer are being studied in clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>Clinical trials are taking place in many parts of the country.<EOS>
<BOS>Information about clinical trials can be found in the Clinical Trials section of the NCI website.<EOS>
<BOS>Check NCI's list of cancer clinical trials for oral cavity cancer prevention trials and oropharyngeal cancer prevention trials that are now accepting patients.<EOS>
<BOS>Key Points Avoiding risk factors and increasing protective factors may help prevent cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>The following are risk factors for ovarian, fallopian tube, and primary peritoneal cancer: Family history of ovarian, fallopian tube, and primary peritoneal cancer Inherited risk Hormone replacement therapy Weight and height The following are protective factors for ovarian, fallopian tube, and primary peritoneal cancer: Oral contraceptives Tubal ligation Breastfeeding Riskreducing salpingooophorectomy It is not clear whether the following affect the risk of ovarian, fallopian tube, and primary peritoneal cancer: Diet Alcohol Aspirin and nonsteroidal antiinflammatory drugs Smoking Talc Infertility treatment Cancer prevention clinical trials are used to study ways to prevent cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>New ways to prevent ovarian, fallopian tube, and primary peritoneal cancer are being studied in clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>Avoiding risk factors and increasing protective factors may help prevent cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Avoiding cancer risk factors may help prevent certain cancers.<EOS>
<BOS>Risk factors include smoking, being overweight, and not getting enough exercise.<EOS>
<BOS>Increasing protective factors such as quitting smoking and exercising may also help prevent some cancers.<EOS>
<BOS>Talk to your doctor or other health care professional about how you might lower your risk of cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>The following are risk factors for ovarian, fallopian tube, and primary peritoneal cancer: Family history of ovarian, fallopian tube, and primary peritoneal cancer A woman whose mother or sister had ovarian cancer has an increased risk of ovarian cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>A woman with two or more relatives with ovarian cancer also has an increased risk of ovarian cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Inherited risk The risk of ovarian cancer is increased in women who have inherited certain changes in the BRCA1, BRCA2, or other genes.<EOS>
<BOS>The risk of ovarian cancer is also increased in women who have certain inherited syndromes that include: Familial sitespecific ovarian cancer syndrome.<EOS>
<BOS>Familial breast/ovarian cancer syndrome.<EOS>
<BOS>Hereditary nonpolyposis colorectal cancer (HNPCC; Lynch syndrome).<EOS>
<BOS>Hormone replacement therapy The use of estrogen only hormone replacement therapy (HRT) after menopause is linked to a slightly increased risk of ovarian cancer in women who are taking HRT or have taken HRT within the past 3 years.<EOS>
<BOS>The risk of ovarian cancer increases the longer a woman uses estrogenonly HRT.<EOS>
<BOS>When hormone therapy is stopped, the risk of ovarian cancer decreases over time.<EOS>
<BOS>It is not clear whether there is an increased risk of ovarian cancer with the use of HRT that has both estrogen and progestin.<EOS>
<BOS>Weight and height Being overweight or obese during the teenage years is linked to an increased risk of ovarian cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Being obese is linked to an increased risk of death from ovarian cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Being tall (5'8" or taller) may also be linked to a slight increase in the risk of ovarian cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>It is not clear whether the following affect the risk of ovarian, fallopian tube, and primary peritoneal cancer: Diet Studies of dietary factors including various foods, teas, and nutrients have not found a strong link to ovarian cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Alcohol Studies have not shown a link between drinking alcohol and the risk of ovarian cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Aspirin and nonsteroidal antiinflammatory drugs Some studies of aspirin and nonsteroidal antiinflammatory drugs (NSAIDs) have found a decreased risk of ovarian cancer and others have not.<EOS>
<BOS>Smoking Some studies found a very small increased risk of one rare type of ovarian cancer in women who were current smokers compared with women who never smoked.<EOS>
<BOS>Talc Studies of women who used talcum powder (talc) dusted on the perineum (the area between the vagina and the anus) have not found clear evidence of an increased risk of ovarian cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Infertility treatment Overall, studies in women using fertility drugs have not found clear evidence of an increased risk of ovarian cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Risk of ovarian borderline malignant tumors may be higher in women who take fertility drugs.<EOS>
<BOS>The risk of invasive ovarian cancer may be higher in women who do not get pregnant after taking fertility drugs.<EOS>
<BOS>Key Points There are different types of treatment for patients with penile cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Four types of standard treatment are used: Surgery Radiation therapy Chemotherapy Biologic therapy New types of treatment are being tested in clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>Radiosensitizers Sentinel lymph node biopsy followed by surgery Patients may want to think about taking part in a clinical trial.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients can enter clinical trials before, during, or after starting their cancer treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Followup tests may be needed.<EOS>
<BOS>There are different types of treatment for patients with penile cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Different types of treatments are available for patients with penile cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Some treatments are standard (the currently used treatment), and some are being tested in clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>A treatment clinical trial is a research study meant to help improve current treatments or obtain information on new treatments for patients with cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>When clinical trials show that a new treatment is better than the standard treatment, the new treatment may become the standard treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients may want to think about taking part in a clinical trial.<EOS>
<BOS>Some clinical trials are open only to patients who have not started treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Four types of standard treatment are used: Surgery Surgery is the most common treatment for all stages of penile cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>A doctor may remove the cancer using one of the following operations: Mohs microsurgery: A procedure in which the tumor is cut from the skin in thin layers.<EOS>
<BOS>During the surgery, the edges of the tumor and each layer of tumor removed are viewed through a microscope to check for cancer cells.<EOS>
<BOS>Layers continue to be removed until no more cancer cells are seen.<EOS>
<BOS>This type of surgery removes as little normal tissue as possible and is often used to remove cancer on the skin.<EOS>
<BOS>It is also called Mohs surgery.<EOS>
<BOS>Laser surgery: A surgical procedure that uses a laser beam (a narrow beam of intense light) as a knife to make bloodless cuts in tissue or to remove a surface lesion such as a tumor.<EOS>
<BOS>Cryosurgery: A treatment that uses an instrument to freeze and destroy abnormal tissue.<EOS>
<BOS>This type of treatment is also called cryotherapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Circumcision: Surgery to remove part or all of the foreskin of the penis.<EOS>
<BOS>Wide local excision: Surgery to remove only the cancer and some normal tissue around it.<EOS>
<BOS>Amputation of the penis: Surgery to remove part or all of the penis.<EOS>
<BOS>If part of the penis is removed, it is a partial penectomy.<EOS>
<BOS>If all of the penis is removed, it is a total penectomy.<EOS>
<BOS>Lymph nodes in the groin may be taken out during surgery.<EOS>
<BOS>Even if the doctor removes all the cancer that can be seen at the time of the surgery, some patients may be given chemotherapy or radiation therapy after surgery to kill any cancer cells that are left.<EOS>
<BOS>Treatment given after the surgery, to lower the risk that the cancer will come back, is called adjuvant therapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Radiation therapy Radiation therapy is a cancer treatment that uses highenergy xrays or other types of radiation to kill cancer cells or keep them from growing.<EOS>
<BOS>There are two types of radiation therapy: External radiation therapy uses a machine outside the body to send radiation toward the cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Internal radiation therapy uses a radioactive substance sealed in needles, seeds, wires, or catheters that are placed directly into or near the cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>The way the radiation therapy is given depends on the type and stage of the cancer being treated.<EOS>
<BOS>External and internal radiation therapy are used to treat penile cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Chemotherapy Chemotherapy is a cancer treatment that uses drugs to stop the growth of cancer cells, either by killing the cells or by stopping them from dividing.<EOS>
<BOS>When chemotherapy is taken by mouth or injected into a vein or muscle, the drugs enter the bloodstream and can reach cancer cells throughout the body (systemic chemotherapy).<EOS>
<BOS>When chemotherapy is placed directly onto the skin (topical chemotherapy) or into the cerebrospinal fluid, an organ, or a body cavity such as the abdomen, the drugs mainly affect cancer cells in those areas (regional chemotherapy).<EOS>
<BOS>The way the chemotherapy is given depends on the type and stage of the cancer being treated.<EOS>
<BOS>Topical chemotherapy may be used to treat stage 0 penile cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>See Drugs Approved for Penile Cancer for more information.<EOS>
<BOS>Biologic therapy Biologic therapy is a treatment that uses the patient's immune system to fight cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Substances made by the body or made in a laboratory are used to boost, direct, or restore the body's natural defenses against cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>This type of cancer treatment is also called biotherapy or immunotherapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Topical biologic therapy with imiquimod may be used to treat stage 0 penile cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>New types of treatment are being tested in clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>This summary section describes treatments that are being studied in clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>It may not mention every new treatment being studied.<EOS>
<BOS>Information about clinical trials is available from the NCI website.<EOS>
<BOS>Radiosensitizers Radiosensitizers are drugs that make tumor cells more sensitive to radiation therapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Combining radiation therapy with radiosensitizers helps kill more tumor cells.<EOS>
<BOS>Sentinel lymph node biopsy followed by surgery Sentinel lymph node biopsy is the removal of the sentinel lymph node during surgery.<EOS>
<BOS>The sentinel lymph node is the first lymph node to receive lymphatic drainage from a tumor.<EOS>
<BOS>It is the first lymph node the cancer is likely to spread to from the tumor.<EOS>
<BOS>A radioactive substance and/or blue dye is injected near the tumor.<EOS>
<BOS>The substance or dye flows through the lymph ducts to the lymph nodes.<EOS>
<BOS>The first lymph node to receive the substance or dye is removed.<EOS>
<BOS>A pathologist views the tissue under a microscope to look for cancer cells.<EOS>
<BOS>If cancer cells are not found, it may not be necessary to remove more lymph nodes.<EOS>
<BOS>After the sentinel lymph node biopsy, the surgeon removes the cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients may want to think about taking part in a clinical trial.<EOS>
<BOS>For some patients, taking part in a clinical trial may be the best treatment choice.<EOS>
<BOS>Clinical trials are part of the cancer research process.<EOS>
<BOS>Clinical trials are done to find out if new cancer treatments are safe and effective or better than the standard treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Many of today's standard treatments for cancer are based on earlier clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients who take part in a clinical trial may receive the standard treatment or be among the first to receive a new treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients who take part in clinical trials also help improve the way cancer will be treated in the future.<EOS>
<BOS>Even when clinical trials do not lead to effective new treatments, they often answer important questions and help move research forward.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients can enter clinical trials before, during, or after starting their cancer treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Some clinical trials only include patients who have not yet received treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Other trials test treatments for patients whose cancer has not gotten better.<EOS>
<BOS>There are also clinical trials that test new ways to stop cancer from recurring (coming back) or reduce the side effects of cancer treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Clinical trials are taking place in many parts of the country.<EOS>
<BOS>See the Treatment Options section that follows for links to current treatment clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>These have been retrieved from NCI's listing of clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>Followup tests may be needed.<EOS>
<BOS>Some of the tests that were done to diagnose the cancer or to find out the stage of the cancer may be repeated.<EOS>
<BOS>Some tests will be repeated in order to see how well the treatment is working.<EOS>
<BOS>Decisions about whether to continue, change, or stop treatment may be based on the results of these tests.<EOS>
<BOS>Some of the tests will continue to be done from time to time after treatment has ended.<EOS>
<BOS>The results of these tests can show if your condition has changed or if the cancer has recurred (come back).<EOS>
<BOS>These tests are sometimes called followup tests or checkups.<EOS>
<BOS>Treatment Options by Stage Stage 0 (Carcinoma in Situ) Treatment of stage 0 may be one of the following: Mohs microsurgery.<EOS>
<BOS>Topical chemotherapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Topical biologic therapy with imiquimod.<EOS>
<BOS>Laser surgery.<EOS>
<BOS>Cryosurgery.<EOS>
<BOS>Check the list of NCIsupported cancer clinical trials that are now accepting patients with stage 0 penile cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>For more specific results, refine the search by using other search features, such as the location of the trial, the type of treatment, or the name of the drug.<EOS>
<BOS>Talk with your doctor about clinical trials that may be right for you.<EOS>
<BOS>General information about clinical trials is available from the NCI website.<EOS>
<BOS>Stage I Penile Cancer If the cancer is only in the foreskin, wide local excision and circumcision may be the only treatment needed.<EOS>
<BOS>Treatment of stage I penile cancer may include the following: Surgery (partial or total penectomy with or without removal of lymph nodes in the groin.<EOS>
<BOS>External or internal radiation therapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Mohs microsurgery.<EOS>
<BOS>A clinical trial of laser therapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Check the list of NCIsupported cancer clinical trials that are now accepting patients with stage I penile cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>For more specific results, refine the search by using other search features, such as the location of the trial, the type of treatment, or the name of the drug.<EOS>
<BOS>Talk with your doctor about clinical trials that may be right for you.<EOS>
<BOS>General information about clinical trials is available from the NCI website.<EOS>
<BOS>Stage II Penile Cancer Treatment of stage II penile cancer may include the following: Surgery (partial or total penectomy, with or without removal of lymph nodes in the groin).<EOS>
<BOS>External or internal radiation therapy followed by surgery.<EOS>
<BOS>A clinical trial of sentinel lymph node biopsy followed by surgery.<EOS>
<BOS>A clinical trial of laser surgery.<EOS>
<BOS>Check the list of NCIsupported cancer clinical trials that are now accepting patients with stage II penile cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>For more specific results, refine the search by using other search features, such as the location of the trial, the type of treatment, or the name of the drug.<EOS>
<BOS>Talk with your doctor about clinical trials that may be right for you.<EOS>
<BOS>General information about clinical trials is available from the NCI website.<EOS>
<BOS>Stage III Penile Cancer Treatment of stage III penile cancer may include the following: Surgery (penectomy and removal of lymph nodes in the groin) with or without radiation therapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Radiation therapy.<EOS>
<BOS>A clinical trial of sentinel lymph node biopsy followed by surgery.<EOS>
<BOS>A clinical trial of radiosensitizers.<EOS>
<BOS>A clinical trial of chemotherapy before or after surgery.<EOS>
<BOS>A clinical trial of new drugs, biologic therapy, or new kinds of surgery.<EOS>
<BOS>Check the list of NCIsupported cancer clinical trials that are now accepting patients with stage III penile cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>For more specific results, refine the search by using other search features, such as the location of the trial, the type of treatment, or the name of the drug.<EOS>
<BOS>Talk with your doctor about clinical trials that may be right for you.<EOS>
<BOS>General information about clinical trials is available from the NCI website.<EOS>
<BOS>Stage IV Penile Cancer Treatment of stage IV penile cancer is usually palliative (to relieve symptoms and improve the quality of life).<EOS>
<BOS>Treatment may include the following: Surgery (wide local excision and removal of lymph nodes in the groin).<EOS>
<BOS>Radiation therapy.<EOS>
<BOS>A clinical trial of chemotherapy before or after surgery.<EOS>
<BOS>A clinical trial of new drugs, biologic therapy, or new kinds of surgery.<EOS>
<BOS>Check the list of NCIsupported cancer clinical trials that are now accepting patients with stage IV penile cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>For more specific results, refine the search by using other search features, such as the location of the trial, the type of treatment, or the name of the drug.<EOS>
<BOS>Talk with your doctor about clinical trials that may be right for you.<EOS>
<BOS>General information about clinical trials is available from the NCI website.<EOS>
<BOS>Key Points After small cell lung cancer has been diagnosed, tests are done to find out if cancer cells have spread within the chest or to other parts of the body.<EOS>
<BOS>There are three ways that cancer spreads in the body.<EOS>
<BOS>Cancer may spread from where it began to other parts of the body.<EOS>
<BOS>The following stages are used for small cell lung cancer: LimitedStage Small Cell Lung Cancer ExtensiveStage Small Cell Lung Cancer After small cell lung cancer has been diagnosed, tests are done to find out if cancer cells have spread within the chest or to other parts of the body.<EOS>
<BOS>The process used to find out if cancer has spread within the chest or to other parts of the body is called staging.<EOS>
<BOS>The information gathered from the staging process determines the stage of the disease.<EOS>
<BOS>It is important to know the stage in order to plan treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Some of the tests used to diagnose small cell lung cancer are also used to stage the disease.<EOS>
<BOS>(See the General Information section.<EOS>
<BOS>) Other tests and procedures that may be used in the staging process include the following: MRI (magnetic resonance imaging) of the brain: A procedure that uses a magnet, radio waves, and a computer to make a series of detailed pictures of areas inside the body.<EOS>
<BOS>This procedure is also called nuclear magnetic resonance imaging (NMRI).<EOS>
<BOS>CT scan (CAT scan): A procedure that makes a series of detailed pictures of areas inside the body, such as the brain, chest or upper abdomen, taken from different angles.<EOS>
<BOS>The pictures are made by a computer linked to an xray machine.<EOS>
<BOS>A dye may be injected into a vein or swallowed to help the organs or tissues show up more clearly.<EOS>
<BOS>This procedure is also called computed tomography, computerized tomography, or computerized axial tomography.<EOS>
<BOS>PET scan (positron emission tomography scan): A procedure to find malignant tumor cells in the body.<EOS>
<BOS>A small amount of radioactive glucose (sugar) is injected into a vein.<EOS>
<BOS>The PET scanner rotates around the body and makes a picture of where glucose is being used in the body.<EOS>
<BOS>Malignant tumor cells show up brighter in the picture because they are more active and take up more glucose than normal cells do.<EOS>
<BOS>A PET scan and CT scan may be done at the same time.<EOS>
<BOS>This is called a PETCT.<EOS>
<BOS>Bone scan : A procedure to check if there are rapidly dividing cells, such as cancer cells, in the bone.<EOS>
<BOS>A very small amount of radioactive material is injected into a vein and travels through the bloodstream.<EOS>
<BOS>The radioactive material collects in the bones and is detected by a scanner.<EOS>
<BOS>There are three ways that cancer spreads in the body.<EOS>
<BOS>Cancer can spread through tissue, the lymph system, and the blood: Tissue.<EOS>
<BOS>The cancer spreads from where it began by growing into nearby areas.<EOS>
<BOS>Lymph system.<EOS>
<BOS>The cancer spreads from where it began by getting into the lymph system.<EOS>
<BOS>The cancer travels through the lymph vessels to other parts of the body.<EOS>
<BOS>Blood.<EOS>
<BOS>The cancer spreads from where it began by getting into the blood.<EOS>
<BOS>The cancer travels through the blood vessels to other parts of the body.<EOS>
<BOS>Cancer may spread from where it began to other parts of the body.<EOS>
<BOS>When cancer spreads to another part of the body, it is called metastasis.<EOS>
<BOS>Cancer cells break away from where they began (the primary tumor) and travel through the lymph system or blood.<EOS>
<BOS>Lymph system.<EOS>
<BOS>The cancer gets into the lymph system, travels through the lymph vessels, and forms a tumor (metastatic tumor) in another part of the body.<EOS>
<BOS>Blood.<EOS>
<BOS>The cancer gets into the blood, travels through the blood vessels, and forms a tumor (metastatic tumor) in another part of the body.<EOS>
<BOS>The metastatic tumor is the same type of cancer as the primary tumor.<EOS>
<BOS>For example, if small cell lung cancer spreads to the brain, the cancer cells in the brain are actually lung cancer cells.<EOS>
<BOS>The disease is metastatic small cell lung cancer, not brain cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>The following stages are used for small cell lung cancer: LimitedStage Small Cell Lung Cancer In limitedstage, cancer is in the lung where it started and may have spread to the area between the lungs or to the lymph nodes above the collarbone.<EOS>
<BOS>ExtensiveStage Small Cell Lung Cancer In extensivestage, cancer has spread beyond the lung or the area between the lungs or the lymph nodes above the collarbone to other places in the body.<EOS>
<BOS>Key Points Nasopharyngeal cancer is a disease in which malignant (cancer) cells form in the tissues of the nasopharynx.<EOS>
<BOS>Ethnic background and being exposed to the EpsteinBarr virus can affect the risk of nasopharyngeal cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Signs of nasopharyngeal cancer include trouble breathing, speaking, or hearing.<EOS>
<BOS>Tests that examine the nose and throat are used to detect (find) and diagnose nasopharyngeal cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Certain factors affect prognosis (chance of recovery) and treatment options.<EOS>
<BOS>Nasopharyngeal cancer is a disease in which malignant (cancer) cells form in the tissues of the nasopharynx.<EOS>
<BOS>The nasopharynx is the upper part of the pharynx (throat) behind the nose.<EOS>
<BOS>The pharynx is a hollow tube about 5 inches long that starts behind the nose and ends at the top of the trachea (windpipe) and esophagus (the tube that goes from the throat to the stomach).<EOS>
<BOS>Air and food pass through the pharynx on the way to the trachea or the esophagus.<EOS>
<BOS>The nostrils lead into the nasopharynx.<EOS>
<BOS>An opening on each side of the nasopharynx leads into an ear.<EOS>
<BOS>Nasopharyngeal cancer most commonly starts in the squamous cells that line the nasopharynx.<EOS>
<BOS>Nasopharyngeal cancer is a type of head and neck cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Male breast cancer is sometimes caused by inherited gene mutations (changes).<EOS>
<BOS>The genes in cells carry the hereditary information that is received from a persons parents.<EOS>
<BOS>Hereditary breast cancer makes up about 5% to 10% of all breast cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Some mutated genes related to breast cancer are more common in certain ethnic groups.<EOS>
<BOS>Men who have a mutated gene related to breast cancer have an increased risk of this disease.<EOS>
<BOS>There are tests that can detect (find) mutated genes.<EOS>
<BOS>These genetic tests are sometimes done for members of families with a high risk of cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>See the following PDQ summaries for more information: Genetics of Breast and Gynecologic Cancers Breast Cancer Prevention Breast Cancer Screening.<EOS>
<BOS>Health history and certain medicines can affect the risk of developing endometrial cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Anything that increases your chance of getting a disease is called a risk factor.<EOS>
<BOS>Having a risk factor does not mean that you will get cancer; not having risk factors doesnt mean that you will not get cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>People who think they may be at risk should discuss this with their doctor.<EOS>
<BOS>Risk factors for endometrial cancer include the following: Taking tamoxifen for treatment or prevention of breast cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Taking estrogen alone.<EOS>
<BOS>(Taking estrogen in combination with progestin does not appear to increase the risk of endometrial cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>) Being overweight.<EOS>
<BOS>Eating a highfat diet.<EOS>
<BOS>Never giving birth.<EOS>
<BOS>Beginning menstruation at an early age.<EOS>
<BOS>Reaching menopause at an older age.<EOS>
<BOS>Having the gene for hereditary nonpolyposis colon cancer (HNPCC).<EOS>
<BOS>Being white.<EOS>
<BOS>Signs of melanoma include a change in the way a mole or pigmented area looks.<EOS>
<BOS>These and other signs and symptoms may be caused by melanoma or by other conditions.<EOS>
<BOS>Check with your doctor if you have any of the following: A mole that: changes in size, shape, or color.<EOS>
<BOS>has irregular edges or borders.<EOS>
<BOS>is more than one color.<EOS>
<BOS>is asymmetrical (if the mole is divided in half, the 2 halves are different in size or shape).<EOS>
<BOS>itches.<EOS>
<BOS>oozes, bleeds, or is ulcerated (a hole forms in the skin when the top layer of cells breaks down and the tissue below shows through).<EOS>
<BOS>A change in pigmented (colored) skin.<EOS>
<BOS>Satellite moles (new moles that grow near an existing mole).<EOS>
<BOS>For pictures and descriptions of common moles and melanoma, see Common Moles, Dysplastic Nevi, and Risk of Melanoma.<EOS>
<BOS>Certain factors affect prognosis (chance of recovery) and treatment options.<EOS>
<BOS>The prognosis (chance of recovery) and treatment options depend on the following: The stage of the cancer (whether the cancer is in the inner lining of the colon only or has spread through the colon wall, or has spread to lymph nodes or other places in the body).<EOS>
<BOS>Whether the cancer has blocked or made a hole in the colon.<EOS>
<BOS>Whether there are any cancer cells left after surgery.<EOS>
<BOS>Whether the cancer has recurred.<EOS>
<BOS>The patients general health.<EOS>
<BOS>The prognosis also depends on the blood levels of carcinoembryonic antigen (CEA) before treatment begins.<EOS>
<BOS>CEA is a substance in the blood that may be increased when cancer is present.<EOS>
<BOS>Survival for men with breast cancer is similar to survival for women with breast cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Survival for men with breast cancer is similar to that for women with breast cancer when their stage at diagnosis is the same.<EOS>
<BOS>Breast cancer in men, however, is often diagnosed at a later stage.<EOS>
<BOS>Cancer found at a later stage may be less likely to be cured.<EOS>
<BOS>Certain factors affect prognosis (chance of recovery) and treatment options.<EOS>
<BOS>The prognosis (chance of recovery) and treatment options depend on the following: The stage of the cancer (whether it is in the breast only or has spread to other places in the body).<EOS>
<BOS>The type of breast cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Estrogenreceptor and progesteronereceptor levels in the tumor tissue.<EOS>
<BOS>Whether the cancer is also found in the other breast.<EOS>
<BOS>The patients age and general health.<EOS>
<BOS>Certain factors affect prognosis (chance of recovery) and treatment options.<EOS>
<BOS>The prognosis (chance of recovery) and treatment options depend on the following: The stage of the cancer (whether it is in the endometrium only, involves the uterus wall, or has spread to other places in the body).<EOS>
<BOS>How the cancer cells look under a microscope.<EOS>
<BOS>Whether the cancer cells are affected by progesterone.<EOS>
<BOS>Endometrial cancer can usually be cured because it is usually diagnosed early.<EOS>
<BOS>Signs and symptoms of childhood AML, childhood CML, JMML, or MDS include fever, feeling tired, and easy bleeding or bruising.<EOS>
<BOS>These and other signs and symptoms may be caused by childhood AML, childhood CML, JMML, or MDS or by other conditions.<EOS>
<BOS>Check with a doctor if your child has any of the following: Fever with or without an infection.<EOS>
<BOS>Night sweats.<EOS>
<BOS>Shortness of breath.<EOS>
<BOS>Weakness or feeling tired.<EOS>
<BOS>Easy bruising or bleeding.<EOS>
<BOS>Petechiae (flat, pinpoint spots under the skin caused by bleeding).<EOS>
<BOS>Pain in the bones or joints.<EOS>
<BOS>Pain or feeling of fullness below the ribs.<EOS>
<BOS>Painless lumps in the neck, underarm, stomach, groin, or other parts of the body.<EOS>
<BOS>In childhood AML, these lumps, called leukemia cutis, may be blue or purple.<EOS>
<BOS>Painless lumps that are sometimes around the eyes.<EOS>
<BOS>These lumps, called chloromas, are sometimes seen in childhood AML and may be bluegreen.<EOS>
<BOS>An eczema like skin rash.<EOS>
<BOS>The signs and symptoms of TMD may include the following: Swelling all over the body.<EOS>
<BOS>Shortness of breath.<EOS>
<BOS>Trouble breathing.<EOS>
<BOS>Weakness or feeling tired.<EOS>
<BOS>Pain below the ribs.<EOS>
<BOS>Prostate cancer is most common in older men.<EOS>
<BOS>In the U.<EOS>
<BOS>S.<EOS>
<BOS>, about one out of five men will be diagnosed with prostate cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Most men diagnosed with prostate cancer do not die of it.<EOS>
<BOS>See the following PDQ summaries for more information about prostate cancer: Prostate Cancer Screening Prostate Cancer Treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>The use of certain medicines and other factors decrease the risk of breast cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Anything that decreases your chance of getting a disease is called a protective factor.<EOS>
<BOS>Protective factors for breast cancer include the following: Taking any of the following: Estrogenonly hormone therapy after a hysterectomy.<EOS>
<BOS>Selective estrogen receptor modulators (SERMs).<EOS>
<BOS>Aromatase inhibitors.<EOS>
<BOS>Less exposure of breast tissue to estrogen made by the body.<EOS>
<BOS>This can be a result of: Early pregnancy.<EOS>
<BOS>Breastfeeding.<EOS>
<BOS>Getting enough exercise.<EOS>
<BOS>Having any of the following procedures: Mastectomy to reduce the risk of cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Oophorectomy to reduce the risk of cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Ovarian ablation.<EOS>
<BOS>Certain factors affect prognosis (chance of recovery) and treatment options.<EOS>
<BOS>The prognosis (chance of recovery) and treatment options depend on the following: The thickness of the tumor and where it is in the body.<EOS>
<BOS>How quickly the cancer cells are dividing.<EOS>
<BOS>Whether there was bleeding or ulceration of the tumor.<EOS>
<BOS>How much cancer is in the lymph nodes.<EOS>
<BOS>The number of places cancer has spread to in the body.<EOS>
<BOS>The level of lactate dehydrogenase (LDH) in the blood.<EOS>
<BOS>Whether the cancer has certain mutations (changes) in a gene called BRAF.<EOS>
<BOS>The patients age and general health.<EOS>
<BOS>Key Points Chronic myelogenous leukemia is a disease in which the bone marrow makes too many white blood cells.<EOS>
<BOS>Leukemia may affect red blood cells, white blood cells, and platelets.<EOS>
<BOS>Signs and symptoms of chronic myelogenous leukemia include fever, night sweats, and tiredness.<EOS>
<BOS>Most people with CML have a gene mutation (change) called the Philadelphia chromosome.<EOS>
<BOS>Tests that examine the blood and bone marrow are used to detect (find) and diagnose chronic myelogenous leukemia.<EOS>
<BOS>Certain factors affect prognosis (chance of recovery) and treatment options.<EOS>
<BOS>Chronic myelogenous leukemia is a disease in which the bone marrow makes too many white blood cells.<EOS>
<BOS>Chronic myelogenous leukemia (also called CML or chronic granulocytic leukemia) is a slowly progressing blood and bone marrow disease that usually occurs during or after middle age, and rarely occurs in children.<EOS>
<BOS>Leukemia may affect red blood cells, white blood cells, and platelets.<EOS>
<BOS>Normally, the bone marrow makes blood stem cells (immature cells) that become mature blood cells over time.<EOS>
<BOS>A blood stem cell may become a myeloid stem cell or a lymphoid stem cell.<EOS>
<BOS>A lymphoid stem cell becomes a white blood cell.<EOS>
<BOS>A myeloid stem cell becomes one of three types of mature blood cells: Red blood cells that carry oxygen and other substances to all tissues of the body.<EOS>
<BOS>Platelets that form blood clots to stop bleeding.<EOS>
<BOS>Granulocytes (white blood cells) that fight infection and disease.<EOS>
<BOS>In CML, too many blood stem cells become a type of white blood cell called granulocytes.<EOS>
<BOS>These granulocytes are abnormal and do not become healthy white blood cells.<EOS>
<BOS>They are also called leukemia cells.<EOS>
<BOS>The leukemia cells can build up in the blood and bone marrow so there is less room for healthy white blood cells, red blood cells, and platelets.<EOS>
<BOS>When this happens, infection, anemia, or easy bleeding may occur.<EOS>
<BOS>This summary is about chronic myelogenous leukemia.<EOS>
<BOS>See the following PDQ summaries for more information about leukemia: Adult Acute Lymphoblastic Leukemia Treatment Childhood Acute Lymphoblastic Leukemia Treatment Adult Acute Myeloid Leukemia Treatment Childhood Acute Myeloid Leukemia/Other Myeloid Malignancies Treatment Chronic Lymphocytic Leukemia Treatment Hairy Cell Leukemia Treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Key Points After nonmelanoma skin cancer has been diagnosed, tests are done to find out if cancer cells have spread within the skin or to other parts of the body.<EOS>
<BOS>There are three ways that cancer spreads in the body.<EOS>
<BOS>Cancer may spread from where it began to other parts of the body.<EOS>
<BOS>Staging of nonmelanoma skin cancer depends on whether the tumor has certain "highrisk" features and if the tumor is on the eyelid.<EOS>
<BOS>The following stages are used for nonmelanoma skin cancer that is not on the eyelid: Stage 0 (Carcinoma in Situ) Stage I Stage I nonmelanoma skin cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>The tumor is no more than 2 centimeters.<EOS>
<BOS>Stage II Stage II nonmelanoma skin cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>The tumor is more than 2 centimeters wide.<EOS>
<BOS>Stage III Stage IV The following stages are used for nonmelanoma skin cancer on the eyelid: Stage 0 (Carcinoma in Situ) Stage I Stage II Stage III Stage IV Treatment is based on the type of nonmelanoma skin cancer or other skin condition diagnosed: Basal cell carcinoma Squamous cell carcinoma Actinic keratosis After nonmelanoma skin cancer has been diagnosed, tests are done to find out if cancer cells have spread within the skin or to other parts of the body.<EOS>
<BOS>The process used to find out if cancer has spread within the skin or to other parts of the body is called staging.<EOS>
<BOS>The information gathered from the staging process determines the stage of the disease.<EOS>
<BOS>It is important to know the stage in order to plan treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>The following tests and procedures may be used in the staging process: CT scan (CAT scan): A procedure that makes a series of detailed pictures of areas inside the body, taken from different angles.<EOS>
<BOS>The pictures are made by a computer linked to an xray machine.<EOS>
<BOS>A dye may be injected into a vein or swallowed to help the organs or tissues show up more clearly.<EOS>
<BOS>This procedure is also called computed tomography, computerized tomography, or computerized axial tomography.<EOS>
<BOS>MRI (magnetic resonance imaging): A procedure that uses a magnet, radio waves, and a computer to make a series of detailed pictures of areas inside the body.<EOS>
<BOS>This procedure is also called nuclear magnetic resonance imaging (NMRI).<EOS>
<BOS>Lymph node biopsy : For squamous cell carcinoma, the lymph nodes may be removed and checked to see if cancer has spread to them.<EOS>
<BOS>There are three ways that cancer spreads in the body.<EOS>
<BOS>Cancer can spread through tissue, the lymph system, and the blood: Tissue.<EOS>
<BOS>The cancer spreads from where it began by growing into nearby areas.<EOS>
<BOS>Lymph system.<EOS>
<BOS>The cancer spreads from where it began by getting into the lymph system.<EOS>
<BOS>The cancer travels through the lymph vessels to other parts of the body.<EOS>
<BOS>Blood.<EOS>
<BOS>The cancer spreads from where it began by getting into the blood.<EOS>
<BOS>The cancer travels through the blood vessels to other parts of the body.<EOS>
<BOS>Cancer may spread from where it began to other parts of the body.<EOS>
<BOS>When cancer spreads to another part of the body, it is called metastasis.<EOS>
<BOS>Cancer cells break away from where they began (the primary tumor) and travel through the lymph system or blood.<EOS>
<BOS>Lymph system.<EOS>
<BOS>The cancer gets into the lymph system, travels through the lymph vessels, and forms a tumor (metastatic tumor) in another part of the body.<EOS>
<BOS>Blood.<EOS>
<BOS>The cancer gets into the blood, travels through the blood vessels, and forms a tumor (metastatic tumor) in another part of the body.<EOS>
<BOS>The metastatic tumor is the same type of cancer as the primary tumor.<EOS>
<BOS>For example, if skin cancer spreads to the lung, the cancer cells in the lung are actually skin cancer cells.<EOS>
<BOS>The disease is metastatic skin cancer, not lung cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Staging of nonmelanoma skin cancer depends on whether the tumor has certain "highrisk" features and if the tumor is on the eyelid.<EOS>
<BOS>Staging for nonmelanoma skin cancer that is on the eyelid is different from staging for nonmelanoma skin cancer that affects other parts of the body.<EOS>
<BOS>The following are highrisk features for nonmelanoma skin cancer that is not on the eyelid: The tumor is thicker than 2 millimeters.<EOS>
<BOS>The tumor is described as Clark level IV (has spread into the lower layer of the dermis) or Clark level V (has spread into the layer of fat below the skin).<EOS>
<BOS>The tumor has grown and spread along nerve pathways.<EOS>
<BOS>The tumor began on an ear or on a lip that has hair on it.<EOS>
<BOS>The tumor has cells that look very different from normal cells under a microscope.<EOS>
<BOS>The following stages are used for nonmelanoma skin cancer that is not on the eyelid: Stage 0 (Carcinoma in Situ) In stage 0, abnormal cells are found in the squamous cell or basal cell layer of the epidermis (topmost layer of the skin).<EOS>
<BOS>These abnormal cells may become cancer and spread into nearby normal tissue.<EOS>
<BOS>Stage 0 is also called carcinoma in situ.<EOS>
<BOS>Stage I In stage I, cancer has formed.<EOS>
<BOS>The tumor is not larger than 2 centimeters at its widest point and may have one highrisk feature.<EOS>
<BOS>Stage II In stage II, the tumor is either: larger than 2 centimeters at its widest point; or any size and has two or more highrisk features.<EOS>
<BOS>Stage III In stage III: The tumor has spread to the jaw, eye socket, or side of the skull.<EOS>
<BOS>Cancer may have spread to one lymph node on the same side of the body as the tumor.<EOS>
<BOS>The lymph node is not larger than 3 centimeters.<EOS>
<BOS>or Cancer has spread to one lymph node on the same side of the body as the tumor.<EOS>
<BOS>The lymph node is not larger than 3 centimeters and one of the following is true: the tumor is not larger than 2 centimeters at its widest point and may have one highrisk feature; or the tumor is larger than 2 centimeters at its widest point; or the tumor is any size and has two or more highrisk features.<EOS>
<BOS>Stage IV In stage IV, one of the following is true: The tumor is any size and may have spread to the jaw, eye socket, or side of the skull.<EOS>
<BOS>Cancer has spread to one lymph node on the same side of the body as the tumor and the affected node is larger than 3 centimeters but not larger than 6 centimeters, or cancer has spread to more than one lymph node on one or both sides of the body and the affected nodes are not larger than 6 centimeters; or The tumor is any size and may have spread to the jaw, eye socket, skull, spine, or ribs.<EOS>
<BOS>Cancer has spread to one lymph node that is larger than 6 centimeters; or The tumor is any size and has spread to the base of the skull, spine, or ribs.<EOS>
<BOS>Cancer may have spread to the lymph nodes; or Cancer has spread to other parts of the body, such as the lung.<EOS>
<BOS>The following stages are used for nonmelanoma skin cancer on the eyelid: Stage 0 (Carcinoma in Situ) In stage 0, abnormal cells are found in the epidermis (topmost layer of the skin).<EOS>
<BOS>These abnormal cells may become cancer and spread into nearby normal tissue.<EOS>
<BOS>Stage 0 is also called carcinoma in situ.<EOS>
<BOS>Stage I Stage I is divided into stages IA, IB, and IC.<EOS>
<BOS>Stage IA: The tumor is 5 millimeters or smaller and has not spread to the connective tissue of the eyelid or to the edge of the eyelid where the lashes are.<EOS>
<BOS>Stage IB: The tumor is larger than 5 millimeters but not larger than 10 millimeters or has spread to the connective tissue of the eyelid, or to the edge of the eyelid where the lashes are.<EOS>
<BOS>Stage IC: The tumor is larger than 10 millimeters but not larger than 20 millimeters or has spread through the full thickness of the eyelid.<EOS>
<BOS>Stage II In stage II, one of the following is true: The tumor is larger than 20 millimeters.<EOS>
<BOS>The tumor has spread to nearby parts of the eye or eye socket.<EOS>
<BOS>The tumor has spread to spaces around the nerves in the eyelid.<EOS>
<BOS>Stage III Stage III is divided into stages IIIA, IIIB, and IIIC.<EOS>
<BOS>Stage IIIA: To remove all of the tumor, the whole eye and part of the optic nerve must be removed.<EOS>
<BOS>The bone, muscles, fat, and connective tissue around the eye may also be removed.<EOS>
<BOS>Stage IIIB: The tumor may be anywhere in or near the eye and has spread to nearby lymph nodes.<EOS>
<BOS>Stage IIIC: The tumor has spread to structures around the eye or in the face, or to the brain, and cannot be removed in surgery.<EOS>
<BOS>Stage IV The tumor has spread to distant parts of the body.<EOS>
<BOS>Treatment is based on the type of nonmelanoma skin cancer or other skin condition diagnosed: Basal cell carcinoma Basal cell carcinoma is the most common type of skin cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>It usually occurs on areas of the skin that have been in the sun, most often the nose.<EOS>
<BOS>Often this cancer appears as a raised bump that looks smooth and pearly.<EOS>
<BOS>Another type looks like a scar and is flat and firm and may be white, yellow, or waxy.<EOS>
<BOS>Basal cell carcinoma may spread to tissues around the cancer, but it usually does not spread to other parts of the body.<EOS>
<BOS>Squamous cell carcinoma Squamous cell carcinoma occurs on areas of the skin that have been in the sun, such as the ears, lower lip, and the back of the hands.<EOS>
<BOS>Squamous cell carcinoma may also appear on areas of the skin that have been burned or exposed to chemicals or radiation.<EOS>
<BOS>Often this cancer appears as a firm red bump.<EOS>
<BOS>The tumor may feel scaly, bleed, or form a crust.<EOS>
<BOS>Squamous cell tumors may spread to nearby lymph nodes.<EOS>
<BOS>Squamous cell carcinoma that has not spread can usually be cured.<EOS>
<BOS>Actinic keratosis Actinic keratosis is a skin condition that is not cancer, but sometimes changes into squamous cell carcinoma.<EOS>
<BOS>It usually occurs in areas that have been exposed to the sun, such as the face, the back of the hands, and the lower lip.<EOS>
<BOS>It looks like rough, red, pink, or brown scaly patches on the skin that may be flat or raised, or the lower lip cracks and peels and is not helped by lip balm or petroleum jelly.<EOS>
<BOS>Key Points Tests and procedures to stage gallbladder cancer are usually done at the same time as diagnosis.<EOS>
<BOS>There are three ways that cancer spreads in the body.<EOS>
<BOS>Cancer may spread from where it began to other parts of the body.<EOS>
<BOS>The following stages are used for gallbladder cancer: Stage 0 (Carcinoma in Situ) Stage I Stage II Stage IIIA Stage IIIB Stage IVA Stage IVB For gallbladder cancer, stages are also grouped according to how the cancer may be treated.<EOS>
<BOS>There are two treatment groups: Localized (Stage I) Unresectable, recurrent, or metastatic (Stage II, Stage III, and Stage IV) Tests and procedures to stage gallbladder cancer are usually done at the same time as diagnosis.<EOS>
<BOS>See the General Information section for a description of tests and procedures used to detect, diagnose, and stage gallbladder cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>There are three ways that cancer spreads in the body.<EOS>
<BOS>Cancer can spread through tissue, the lymph system, and the blood: Tissue.<EOS>
<BOS>The cancer spreads from where it began by growing into nearby areas.<EOS>
<BOS>Lymph system.<EOS>
<BOS>The cancer spreads from where it began by getting into the lymph system.<EOS>
<BOS>The cancer travels through the lymph vessels to other parts of the body.<EOS>
<BOS>Blood.<EOS>
<BOS>The cancer spreads from where it began by getting into the blood.<EOS>
<BOS>The cancer travels through the blood vessels to other parts of the body.<EOS>
<BOS>Cancer may spread from where it began to other parts of the body.<EOS>
<BOS>When cancer spreads to another part of the body, it is called metastasis.<EOS>
<BOS>Cancer cells break away from where they began (the primary tumor) and travel through the lymph system or blood.<EOS>
<BOS>Lymph system.<EOS>
<BOS>The cancer gets into the lymph system, travels through the lymph vessels, and forms a tumor (metastatic tumor) in another part of the body.<EOS>
<BOS>Blood.<EOS>
<BOS>The cancer gets into the blood, travels through the blood vessels, and forms a tumor (metastatic tumor) in another part of the body.<EOS>
<BOS>The metastatic tumor is the same type of cancer as the primary tumor.<EOS>
<BOS>For example, if gallbladder cancer spreads to the liver, the cancer cells in the liver are actually gallbladder cancer cells.<EOS>
<BOS>The disease is metastatic gallbladder cancer, not liver cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>The following stages are used for gallbladder cancer: Stage 0 (Carcinoma in Situ) In stage 0, abnormal cells are found in the inner (mucosal) layer of the gallbladder.<EOS>
<BOS>These abnormal cells may become cancer and spread into nearby normal tissue.<EOS>
<BOS>Stage 0 is also called carcinoma in situ.<EOS>
<BOS>Stage I In stage I, cancer has formed and has spread beyond the inner (mucosal) layer to a layer of tissue with blood vessels or to the muscle layer.<EOS>
<BOS>Stage II In stage II, cancer has spread beyond the muscle layer to the connective tissue around the muscle.<EOS>
<BOS>Stage IIIA In stage IIIA, cancer has spread through the thin layers of tissue that cover the gallbladder and/or to the liver and/or to one nearby organ (such as the stomach, small intestine, colon, pancreas, or bile ducts outside the liver).<EOS>
<BOS>Stage IIIB In stage IIIB, cancer has spread to nearby lymph nodes and: beyond the inner layer of the gallbladder to a layer of tissue with blood vessels or to the muscle layer; or beyond the muscle layer to the connective tissue around the muscle; or through the thin layers of tissue that cover the gallbladder and/or to the liver and/or to one nearby organ (such as the stomach, small intestine, colon, pancreas, or bile ducts outside the liver).<EOS>
<BOS>Stage IVA In stage IVA, cancer has spread to a main blood vessel of the liver or to 2 or more nearby organs or areas other than the liver.<EOS>
<BOS>Cancer may have spread to nearby lymph nodes.<EOS>
<BOS>Stage IVB In stage IVB, cancer has spread to either: lymph nodes along large arteries in the abdomen and/or near the lower part of the backbone; or to organs or areas far away from the gallbladder.<EOS>
<BOS>For gallbladder cancer, stages are also grouped according to how the cancer may be treated.<EOS>
<BOS>There are two treatment groups: Localized (Stage I) Cancer is found in the wall of the gallbladder and can be completely removed by surgery.<EOS>
<BOS>Unresectable, recurrent, or metastatic (Stage II, Stage III, and Stage IV) Unresectable cancer cannot be removed completely by surgery.<EOS>
<BOS>Most patients with gallbladder cancer have unresectable cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Recurrent cancer is cancer that has recurred (come back) after it has been treated.<EOS>
<BOS>Gallbladder cancer may come back in the gallbladder or in other parts of the body.<EOS>
<BOS>Metastasis is the spread of cancer from the primary site (place where it started) to other places in the body.<EOS>
<BOS>Metastatic gallbladder cancer may spread to surrounding tissues, organs, throughout the abdominal cavity, or to distant parts of the body.<EOS>
<BOS>Tests that examine the urethra and bladder are used to detect (find) and diagnose urethral cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>The following tests and procedures may be used: Physical exam and history : An exam of the body to check general signs of health, including checking for signs of disease, such as lumps or anything else that seems unusual.<EOS>
<BOS>A history of the patient's health habits and past illnesses and treatments will also be taken.<EOS>
<BOS>Pelvic exam : An exam of the vagina, cervix, uterus, fallopian tubes, ovaries, and rectum.<EOS>
<BOS>A speculum is inserted into the vagina and the doctor or nurse looks at the vagina and cervix for signs of disease.<EOS>
<BOS>The doctor or nurse also inserts one or two lubricated, gloved fingers of one hand into the vagina and places the other hand over the lower abdomen to feel the size, shape, and position of the uterus and ovaries.<EOS>
<BOS>The doctor or nurse also inserts a lubricated, gloved finger into the rectum to feel for lumps or abnormal areas.<EOS>
<BOS>Digital rectal exam : An exam of the rectum.<EOS>
<BOS>The doctor or nurse inserts a lubricated, gloved finger into the lower part of the rectum to feel for lumps or anything else that seems unusual.<EOS>
<BOS>Urine cytology : A laboratory test in which a sample of urine is checked under a microscope for abnormal cells.<EOS>
<BOS>Urinalysis : A test to check the color of urine and its contents, such as sugar, protein, blood, and white blood cells.<EOS>
<BOS>If white blood cells (a sign of infection) are found, a urine culture is usually done to find out what type of infection it is.<EOS>
<BOS>Blood chemistry studies : A procedure in which a blood sample is checked to measure the amounts of certain substances released into the blood by organs and tissues in the body.<EOS>
<BOS>An unusual (higher or lower than normal) amount of a substance can be a sign of disease.<EOS>
<BOS>Complete blood count (CBC): A procedure in which a sample of blood is drawn and checked for the following: The number of red blood cells, white blood cells, and platelets.<EOS>
<BOS>The amount of hemoglobin (the protein that carries oxygen) in the red blood cells.<EOS>
<BOS>The portion of the blood sample made up of red blood cells.<EOS>
<BOS>CT scan (CAT scan): A procedure that makes a series of detailed pictures of areas inside the body, such as the pelvis and abdomen, taken from different angles.<EOS>
<BOS>The pictures are made by a computer linked to an xray machine.<EOS>
<BOS>A dye may be injected into a vein or swallowed to help the organs or tissues show up more clearly.<EOS>
<BOS>This procedure is also called computed tomography, computerized tomography, or computerized axial tomography.<EOS>
<BOS>Ureteroscopy : A procedure to look inside the ureter and renal pelvis to check for abnormal areas.<EOS>
<BOS>A ureteroscope is a thin, tubelike instrument with a light and a lens for viewing.<EOS>
<BOS>The ureteroscope is inserted through the urethra into the bladder, ureter, and renal pelvis.<EOS>
<BOS>A tool may be inserted through the ureteroscope to take tissue samples to be checked under a microscope for signs of disease.<EOS>
<BOS>Biopsy: The removal of cell or tissue samples from the urethra, bladder, and, sometimes, the prostate gland.<EOS>
<BOS>The samples are viewed under a microscope by a pathologist to check for signs of cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Key Points There are different types of treatment for patients with lip and oral cavity cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients with lip and oral cavity cancer should have their treatment planned by a team of doctors who are expert in treating head and neck cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Two types of standard treatment are used: Surgery Radiation therapy New types of treatment are being tested in clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>Chemotherapy Hyperfractionated radiation therapy Hyperthermia therapy Patients may want to think about taking part in a clinical trial.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients can enter clinical trials before, during, or after starting their cancer treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Followup tests may be needed.<EOS>
<BOS>There are different types of treatment for patients with lip and oral cavity cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Different types of treatment are available for patients with lip and oral cavity cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Some treatments are standard (the currently used treatment), and some are being tested in clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>A treatment clinical trial is a research study meant to help improve current treatments or obtain information on new treatments for patients with cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>When clinical trials show that a new treatment is better than the standard treatment, the new treatment may become the standard treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients may want to think about taking part in a clinical trial.<EOS>
<BOS>Some clinical trials are open only to patients who have not started treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients with lip and oral cavity cancer should have their treatment planned by a team of doctors who are expert in treating head and neck cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Treatment will be overseen by a medical oncologist, a doctor who specializes in treating people with cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Because the lips and oral cavity are important for breathing, eating, and talking, patients may need special help adjusting to the side effects of the cancer and its treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>The medical oncologist may refer the patient to other health professionals with special training in the treatment of patients with head and neck cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>These include the following: Head and neck surgeon.<EOS>
<BOS>Radiation oncologist.<EOS>
<BOS>Dentist.<EOS>
<BOS>Speech therapist.<EOS>
<BOS>Dietitian.<EOS>
<BOS>Psychologist.<EOS>
<BOS>Rehabilitation specialist.<EOS>
<BOS>Plastic surgeon.<EOS>
<BOS>Two types of standard treatment are used: Surgery Surgery (removing the cancer in an operation) is a common treatment for all stages of lip and oral cavity cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Surgery may include the following: Wide local excision: Removal of the cancer and some of the healthy tissue around it.<EOS>
<BOS>If cancer has spread into bone, surgery may include removal of the involved bone tissue.<EOS>
<BOS>Neck dissection: Removal of lymph nodes and other tissues in the neck.<EOS>
<BOS>This is done when cancer may have spread from the lip and oral cavity.<EOS>
<BOS>Plastic surgery: An operation that restores or improves the appearance of parts of the body.<EOS>
<BOS>Dental implants, a skin graft, or other plastic surgery may be needed to repair parts of the mouth, throat, or neck after removal of large tumors.<EOS>
<BOS>Even if the doctor removes all the cancer that can be seen at the time of the surgery, some patients may be given chemotherapy or radiation therapy after surgery to kill any cancer cells that are left.<EOS>
<BOS>Treatment given after the surgery, to lower the risk that the cancer will come back, is called adjuvant therapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Radiation therapy Radiation therapy is a cancer treatment that uses highenergy xrays or other types of radiation to kill cancer cells or keep them from growing.<EOS>
<BOS>There are two types of radiation therapy: External radiation therapy uses a machine outside the body to send radiation toward the cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Internal radiation therapy uses a radioactive substance sealed in needles, seeds, wires, or catheters that are placed directly into or near the cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>The way the radiation therapy is given depends on the type and stage of the cancer being treated.<EOS>
<BOS>External and internal radiation therapy are used to treat lip and oral cavity cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Radiation therapy may work better in patients who have stopped smoking before beginning treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>It is also important for patients to have a dental exam before radiation therapy begins, so that existing problems can be treated.<EOS>
<BOS>New types of treatment are being tested in clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>This summary section describes treatments that are being studied in clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>It may not mention every new treatment being studied.<EOS>
<BOS>Information about clinical trials is available from the NCI website.<EOS>
<BOS>Chemotherapy Chemotherapy is a cancer treatment that uses drugs to stop the growth of cancer cells, either by killing the cells or by stopping the cells from dividing.<EOS>
<BOS>When chemotherapy is taken by mouth or injected into a vein or muscle, the drugs enter the bloodstream and can reach cancer cells throughout the body (systemic chemotherapy).<EOS>
<BOS>When chemotherapy is placed directly into the cerebrospinal fluid, an organ, or a body cavity such as the abdomen, the drugs mainly affect cancer cells in those areas (regional chemotherapy).<EOS>
<BOS>The way the chemotherapy is given depends on the type and stage of the cancer being treated.<EOS>
<BOS>Hyperfractionated radiation therapy Hyperfractionated radiation therapy is radiation treatment in which the total dose of radiation is divided into small doses and the treatments are given more than once a day.<EOS>
<BOS>Hyperthermia therapy Hyperthermia therapy is a treatment in which body tissue is heated above normal temperature to damage and kill cancer cells or to make cancer cells more sensitive to the effects of radiation and certain anticancer drugs.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients may want to think about taking part in a clinical trial.<EOS>
<BOS>For some patients, taking part in a clinical trial may be the best treatment choice.<EOS>
<BOS>Clinical trials are part of the cancer research process.<EOS>
<BOS>Clinical trials are done to find out if new cancer treatments are safe and effective or better than the standard treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Many of today's standard treatments for cancer are based on earlier clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients who take part in a clinical trial may receive the standard treatment or be among the first to receive a new treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients who take part in clinical trials also help improve the way cancer will be treated in the future.<EOS>
<BOS>Even when clinical trials do not lead to effective new treatments, they often answer important questions and help move research forward.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients can enter clinical trials before, during, or after starting their cancer treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Some clinical trials only include patients who have not yet received treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Other trials test treatments for patients whose cancer has not gotten better.<EOS>
<BOS>There are also clinical trials that test new ways to stop cancer from recurring (coming back) or reduce the side effects of cancer treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Clinical trials are taking place in many parts of the country.<EOS>
<BOS>See the Treatment Options section that follows for links to current treatment clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>These have been retrieved from NCI's listing of clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>Followup tests may be needed.<EOS>
<BOS>Some of the tests that were done to diagnose the cancer or to find out the stage of the cancer may be repeated.<EOS>
<BOS>Some tests will be repeated in order to see how well the treatment is working.<EOS>
<BOS>Decisions about whether to continue, change, or stop treatment may be based on the results of these tests.<EOS>
<BOS>Some of the tests will continue to be done from time to time after treatment has ended.<EOS>
<BOS>The results of these tests can show if your condition has changed or if the cancer has recurred (come back).<EOS>
<BOS>These tests are sometimes called followup tests or checkups.<EOS>
<BOS>Treatment Options by Stage Stage I Lip and Oral Cavity Cancer Treatment of stage I lip and oral cavity cancer depends on where cancer is found in the lip and oral cavity.<EOS>
<BOS>Lip If cancer is in the lip, treatment may include the following: Surgery (wide local excision).<EOS>
<BOS>Internal radiation therapy with or without external radiation therapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Front of the tongue If cancer is in the front of the tongue, treatment may include the following: Surgery (wide local excision).<EOS>
<BOS>Internal radiation therapy with or without external radiation therapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Radiation therapy to lymph nodes in the neck.<EOS>
<BOS>Buccal mucosa If cancer is in the buccal mucosa (the lining of the inside of the cheeks), treatment may include the following: Surgery (wide local excision) for tumors smaller than 1 centimeter, with or without internal and/or external radiation therapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Surgery (wide local excision with skin graft) or radiation therapy for larger tumors.<EOS>
<BOS>Floor of the mouth If cancer is in the floor (bottom) of the mouth, treatment may include the following: Surgery (wide local excision) for tumors smaller than centimeter.<EOS>
<BOS>Surgery (wide local excision) or radiation therapy for larger tumors.<EOS>
<BOS>Lower gingiva If cancer is in the lower gingiva (gums), treatment may include the following: Surgery (wide local excision, which may include removing part of the jawbone, and skin graft).<EOS>
<BOS>Radiation therapy with or without surgery.<EOS>
<BOS>Retromolar trigone If cancer is in the retromolar trigone (the small area behind the wisdom teeth), treatment may include the following: Surgery (wide local excision, which may include removing part of the jawbone.<EOS>
<BOS>) Radiation therapy with or without surgery.<EOS>
<BOS>Upper gingiva or hard palate If cancer is in the upper gingiva (gums) or the hard palate (the roof of the mouth), treatment is usually surgery (wide local excision) with or without radiation therapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Check the list of NCIsupported cancer clinical trials that are now accepting patients with stage I lip and oral cavity cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>For more specific results, refine the search by using other search features, such as the location of the trial, the type of treatment, or the name of the drug.<EOS>
<BOS>Talk with your doctor about clinical trials that may be right for you.<EOS>
<BOS>General information about clinical trials is available from the NCI website.<EOS>
<BOS>Stage II Lip and Oral Cavity Cancer Treatment of stage II lip and oral cavity cancer depends on where cancer is found in the lip and oral cavity.<EOS>
<BOS>Lip If cancer is in the lip, treatment may include the following: Surgery (wide local excision).<EOS>
<BOS>External radiation therapy and/or internal radiation therapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Front of the tongue If cancer is in the front of the tongue, treatment may include the following: Radiation therapy and/or surgery (wide local excision).<EOS>
<BOS>Internal radiation therapy with surgery (neck dissection).<EOS>
<BOS>Buccal mucosa If cancer is in the buccal mucosa (the lining of the inside of the cheeks), treatment may include the following: Radiation therapy for tumors that are 3 centimeters or smaller.<EOS>
<BOS>Surgery (wide local excision) and/or radiation therapy for larger tumors.<EOS>
<BOS>Floor of the mouth If cancer is in the floor (bottom) of the mouth, treatment may include the following: Surgery (wide local excision).<EOS>
<BOS>Radiation therapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Surgery (wide local excision) followed by external radiation therapy, with or without internal radiation therapy, for large tumors.<EOS>
<BOS>Lower gingiva If cancer is in the lower gingiva (gums), treatment may include the following: Surgery (wide local excision, which may include removing part of the jawbone, and a skin graft).<EOS>
<BOS>Radiation therapy alone or after surgery.<EOS>
<BOS>Retromolar trigone If cancer is in the retromolar trigone (the small area behind the wisdom teeth), treatment may include the following: Surgery (wide local excision, which includes removing part of the jawbone).<EOS>
<BOS>Radiation therapy with or without surgery.<EOS>
<BOS>Upper gingiva or hard palate If cancer is in the upper gingiva (gums) or the hard palate (the roof of the mouth), treatment may include the following: Surgery (wide local excision) with or without radiation therapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Radiation therapy alone.<EOS>
<BOS>Check the list of NCIsupported cancer clinical trials that are now accepting patients with stage II lip and oral cavity cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>For more specific results, refine the search by using other search features, such as the location of the trial, the type of treatment, or the name of the drug.<EOS>
<BOS>Talk with your doctor about clinical trials that may be right for you.<EOS>
<BOS>General information about clinical trials is available from the NCI website.<EOS>
<BOS>Stage III Lip and Oral Cavity Cancer Treatment of stage III lip and oral cavity cancer depends on where cancer is found in the lip and oral cavity.<EOS>
<BOS>Lip If cancer is in the lip, treatment may include the following: Surgery and external radiation therapy with or without internal radiation therapy.<EOS>
<BOS>A clinical trial of chemotherapy before or after surgery.<EOS>
<BOS>A clinical trial of chemotherapy and radiation therapy.<EOS>
<BOS>A clinical trial of hyperfractionated radiation therapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Front of the tongue If cancer is in the front of the tongue, treatment may include the following: External radiation therapy with or without internal radiation therapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Surgery (wide local excision) followed by radiation therapy.<EOS>
<BOS>A clinical trial of chemotherapy and radiation therapy.<EOS>
<BOS>A clinical trial of hyperfractionated radiation therapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Buccal mucosa If cancer is in the buccal mucosa (the lining of the inside of the cheeks), treatment may include the following: Surgery (wide local excision) with or without radiation therapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Radiation therapy.<EOS>
<BOS>A clinical trial of chemotherapy before or after surgery.<EOS>
<BOS>A clinical trial of chemotherapy and radiation therapy.<EOS>
<BOS>A clinical trial of hyperfractionated radiation therapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Floor of the mouth If cancer is in the floor (bottom) of the mouth, treatment may include the following: Surgery (wide local excision, which may include removing part of the jawbone, with or without neck dissection).<EOS>
<BOS>External radiation therapy with or without internal radiation therapy.<EOS>
<BOS>A clinical trial of chemotherapy before or after surgery.<EOS>
<BOS>A clinical trial of chemotherapy and radiation therapy.<EOS>
<BOS>A clinical trial of hyperfractionated radiation therapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Lower gingiva If cancer is in the lower gingiva (gums), treatment may include the following: Surgery (wide local excision) with or without radiation therapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Radiation may be given before or after surgery.<EOS>
<BOS>A clinical trial of chemotherapy and radiation therapy.<EOS>
<BOS>A clinical trial of hyperfractionated radiation therapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Retromolar trigone If cancer is in the retromolar trigone (the small area behind the wisdom teeth), treatment may include the following: Surgery to remove the tumor, lymph nodes, and part of the jawbone, with or without radiation therapy.<EOS>
<BOS>A clinical trial of chemotherapy before or after surgery.<EOS>
<BOS>A clinical trial of chemotherapy and radiation therapy.<EOS>
<BOS>A clinical trial of hyperfractionated radiation therapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Upper gingiva If cancer is in the upper gingiva (gums), treatment may include the following: Radiation therapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Surgery (wide local excision) and radiation therapy.<EOS>
<BOS>A clinical trial of chemotherapy and radiation therapy.<EOS>
<BOS>A clinical trial of hyperfractionated radiation therapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Hard palate If cancer is in the hard palate (the roof of the mouth), treatment may include the following: Radiation therapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Surgery (wide local excision) with or without radiation therapy.<EOS>
<BOS>A clinical trial of chemotherapy and radiation therapy.<EOS>
<BOS>A clinical trial of hyperfractionated radiation therapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Lymph nodes For cancer that may have spread to lymph nodes, treatment may include the following: Radiation therapy and/or surgery (neck dissection).<EOS>
<BOS>A clinical trial of chemotherapy and radiation therapy.<EOS>
<BOS>A clinical trial of hyperfractionated radiation therapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Check the list of NCIsupported cancer clinical trials that are now accepting patients with stage III lip and oral cavity cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>For more specific results, refine the search by using other search features, such as the location of the trial, the type of treatment, or the name of the drug.<EOS>
<BOS>Talk with your doctor about clinical trials that may be right for you.<EOS>
<BOS>General information about clinical trials is available from the NCI website.<EOS>
<BOS>Stage IV Lip and Oral Cavity Cancer Treatment of stage IV lip and oral cavity cancer depends on where cancer is found in the lip and oral cavity.<EOS>
<BOS>Lip If cancer is in the lip, treatment may include the following: Surgery and external radiation therapy with or without internal radiation therapy.<EOS>
<BOS>A clinical trial of chemotherapy and radiation therapy.<EOS>
<BOS>A clinical trial of chemotherapy before or after surgery.<EOS>
<BOS>A clinical trial of hyperfractionated radiation therapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Front of the tongue If cancer is in the front of the tongue, treatment may include the following: Surgery to remove the tongue and sometimes the larynx (voice box) with or without radiation therapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Radiation therapy as palliative therapy to relieve symptoms and improve quality of life.<EOS>
<BOS>A clinical trial of chemotherapy and radiation therapy.<EOS>
<BOS>A clinical trial of chemotherapy before or after surgery.<EOS>
<BOS>A clinical trial of hyperfractionated radiation therapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Buccal mucosa If cancer is in the buccal mucosa (the lining of the inside of the cheeks), treatment may include the following: Surgery (wide local excision) and/or radiation therapy.<EOS>
<BOS>A clinical trial of chemotherapy and radiation therapy.<EOS>
<BOS>A clinical trial of chemotherapy before or after surgery.<EOS>
<BOS>A clinical trial of hyperfractionated radiation therapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Floor of the mouth If cancer is in the floor (bottom) of the mouth, treatment may include the following: Surgery before or after radiation therapy.<EOS>
<BOS>A clinical trial of chemotherapy and radiation therapy.<EOS>
<BOS>A clinical trial of chemotherapy before or after surgery.<EOS>
<BOS>A clinical trial of hyperfractionated radiation therapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Lower gingiva If cancer is in the lower gingiva (gums), treatment may include the following: Surgery and/or radiation therapy.<EOS>
<BOS>A clinical trial of chemotherapy and radiation therapy.<EOS>
<BOS>A clinical trial of chemotherapy before or after surgery.<EOS>
<BOS>A clinical trial of hyperfractionated radiation therapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Retromolar trigone If cancer is in the retromolar trigone (the small area behind the wisdom teeth), treatment may include the following: Surgery to remove the tumor, lymph nodes, and part of the jawbone, followed by radiation therapy.<EOS>
<BOS>A clinical trial of chemotherapy and radiation therapy.<EOS>
<BOS>A clinical trial of chemotherapy before or after surgery.<EOS>
<BOS>A clinical trial of hyperfractionated radiation therapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Upper gingiva or hard palate If cancer is in the upper gingiva (gums) or hard palate (the roof of the mouth), treatment may include the following: Surgery with radiation therapy.<EOS>
<BOS>A clinical trial of chemotherapy and radiation therapy.<EOS>
<BOS>A clinical trial of chemotherapy before or after surgery.<EOS>
<BOS>A clinical trial of hyperfractionated radiation therapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Lymph nodes For cancer that may have spread to lymph nodes, treatment may include the following: Radiation therapy and/or surgery (neck dissection).<EOS>
<BOS>A clinical trial of chemotherapy and radiation therapy.<EOS>
<BOS>A clinical trial of chemotherapy before or after surgery.<EOS>
<BOS>A clinical trial of hyperfractionated radiation therapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Check the list of NCIsupported cancer clinical trials that are now accepting patients with stage IV lip and oral cavity cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>For more specific results, refine the search by using other search features, such as the location of the trial, the type of treatment, or the name of the drug.<EOS>
<BOS>Talk with your doctor about clinical trials that may be right for you.<EOS>
<BOS>General information about clinical trials is available from the NCI website.<EOS>
<BOS>The following tests and procedures may be used: Physical exam and history : An exam of the body to check general signs of health, including checking for signs of disease, such as lumps or anything else that seems unusual.<EOS>
<BOS>A history of the patients health habits and past illnesses and treatments will also be taken.<EOS>
<BOS>The doctor will ask if there is a family history of retinoblastoma.<EOS>
<BOS>Eye exam with dilated pupil: An exam of the eye in which the pupil is dilated (opened wider) with medicated eye drops to allow the doctor to look through the lens and pupil to the retina.<EOS>
<BOS>The inside of the eye, including the retina and the optic nerve, is examined with a light.<EOS>
<BOS>Depending on the age of the child, this exam may be done under anesthesia.<EOS>
<BOS>There are several types of eye exams that are done with the pupil dilated: Ophthalmoscopy : An exam of the inside of the back of the eye to check the retina and optic nerve using a small magnifying lens and a light.<EOS>
<BOS>Slitlamp biomicroscopy : An exam of the inside of the eye to check the retina, optic nerve, and other parts of the eye using a strong beam of light and a microscope.<EOS>
<BOS>Fluorescein angiography : A procedure to look at blood vessels and the flow of blood inside the eye.<EOS>
<BOS>An orange fluorescent dye called fluorescein is injected into a blood vessel in the arm and goes into the bloodstream.<EOS>
<BOS>As the dye travels through blood vessels of the eye, a special camera takes pictures of the retina and choroid to find any blood vessels that are blocked or leaking.<EOS>
<BOS>RB1 gene test: A laboratory test in which a sample of blood or tissue is tested for a change in the RB1 gene.<EOS>
<BOS>Ultrasound exam of the eye: A procedure in which highenergy sound waves (ultrasound) are bounced off the internal tissues of the eye to make echoes.<EOS>
<BOS>Eye drops are used to numb the eye and a small probe that sends and receives sound waves is placed gently on the surface of the eye.<EOS>
<BOS>The echoes make a picture of the inside of the eye and the distance from the cornea to the retina is measured.<EOS>
<BOS>The picture, called a sonogram, shows on the screen of the ultrasound monitor.<EOS>
<BOS>The picture can be printed to be looked at later.<EOS>
<BOS>MRI (magnetic resonance imaging): A procedure that uses a magnet, radio waves, and a computer to make a series of detailed pictures of areas inside the body, such as the eye.<EOS>
<BOS>This procedure is also called nuclear magnetic resonance imaging (NMRI).<EOS>
<BOS>CT scan (CAT scan): A procedure that makes a series of detailed pictures of areas inside the body, such as the eye, taken from different angles.<EOS>
<BOS>The pictures are made by a computer linked to an xray machine.<EOS>
<BOS>A dye may be injected into a vein or swallowed to help the organs or tissues show up more clearly.<EOS>
<BOS>This procedure is also called computed tomography, computerized tomography, or computerized axial tomography.<EOS>
<BOS>Retinoblastoma can usually be diagnosed without a biopsy.<EOS>
<BOS>When retinoblastoma is in one eye, it sometimes forms in the other eye.<EOS>
<BOS>Exams of the unaffected eye are done until it is known if the retinoblastoma is the heritable form.<EOS>
<BOS>Key Points There are different types of treatment for childhood vascular tumors.<EOS>
<BOS>Children with childhood vascular tumors should have their treatment planned by a team of health care providers who are experts in treating cancer in children.<EOS>
<BOS>Some treatments cause side effects months or years after treatment has ended.<EOS>
