<BOS>Eleven types of standard treatment are used: Betablocker therapy Surgery Photocoagulation Embolization Chemotherapy Sclerotherapy Radiation therapy Targeted therapy Immunotherapy Other drug therapy Observation New types of treatment are being tested in clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients may want to think about taking part in a clinical trial.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients can enter clinical trials before, during, or after starting their cancer treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Followup tests may be needed.<EOS>
<BOS>There are different types of treatment for childhood vascular tumors.<EOS>
<BOS>Different types of treatment are available for children with vascular tumors.<EOS>
<BOS>Some treatments are standard (the currently used treatment), and some are being tested in clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>A treatment clinical trial is a research study meant to help improve current treatments or obtain information on new treatments.<EOS>
<BOS>When clinical trials show that a new treatment is better than the standard treatment, the new treatment may become the standard treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Because vascular tumors in children are rare, taking part in a clinical trial should be considered.<EOS>
<BOS>Some clinical trials are open only to patients who have not started treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Children with childhood vascular tumors should have their treatment planned by a team of health care providers who are experts in treating cancer in children.<EOS>
<BOS>Treatment will be overseen by a pediatric oncologist, a doctor who specializes in treating children with cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>The pediatric oncologist works with other pediatric health care providers who are experts in treating children with cancer and who specialize in certain areas of medicine.<EOS>
<BOS>These may include the following specialists: Pediatric vascular anomaly specialist (expert in treating children with vascular tumors).<EOS>
<BOS>Pediatric surgeon.<EOS>
<BOS>Orthopedic surgeon.<EOS>
<BOS>Radiation oncologist.<EOS>
<BOS>Pediatric nurse specialist.<EOS>
<BOS>Rehabilitation specialist.<EOS>
<BOS>Psychologist.<EOS>
<BOS>Social worker.<EOS>
<BOS>Some treatments cause side effects months or years after treatment has ended.<EOS>
<BOS>Some treatments, such as chemotherapy and radiation therapy, cause side effects that continue or appear months or years after treatment has ended.<EOS>
<BOS>These are called late effects.<EOS>
<BOS>Late effects of treatment may include: Physical problems.<EOS>
<BOS>Changes in mood, feelings, thinking, learning, or memory.<EOS>
<BOS>Second cancers (new types of cancer).<EOS>
<BOS>Some late effects may be treated or controlled.<EOS>
<BOS>It is important to talk with your child's doctors about the possible late effects caused by some treatments.<EOS>
<BOS>(See the PDQ summary on Late Effects of Treatment for Childhood Cancer for more information).<EOS>
<BOS>Eleven types of standard treatment are used: Betablocker therapy Betablockers are drugs that decrease blood pressure and heart rate.<EOS>
<BOS>When used in patients with vascular tumors, betablockers may help shrink the tumors.<EOS>
<BOS>Betablocker therapy may be given by vein (IV), by mouth, or placed on the skin (topical).<EOS>
<BOS>The way the betablocker therapy is given depends on the type of vascular tumor and where the tumor first formed.<EOS>
<BOS>The betablocker propranolol is usually the first treatment for hemangiomas.<EOS>
<BOS>Infants treated with IV propranolol may need to have their treatment started in a hospital.<EOS>
<BOS>Propranolol is also used to treat benign vascular tumor of liver and kaposiform hemangioendothelioma.<EOS>
<BOS>Other betablockers used to treat vascular tumors include atenolol, nadolol, and timolol.<EOS>
<BOS>Infantile hemangioma may also be treated with propranolol and steroid therapy or propranolol and topical betablocker therapy.<EOS>
<BOS>See the drug information summary on Propranolol Hydrochloride for more information.<EOS>
<BOS>Surgery The following types of surgery may be used to remove many types of vascular tumors: Excision: Surgery to remove the entire tumor and some of the healthy tissue around it.<EOS>
<BOS>Laser surgery: A surgical procedure that uses a laser beam (a narrow beam of intense light) as a knife to make bloodless cuts in tissue or to remove a skin lesion such as a tumor.<EOS>
<BOS>Surgery with a pulsed dye laser may be used for some hemangiomas.<EOS>
<BOS>This type of laser uses a beam of light that targets blood vessels in the skin.<EOS>
<BOS>The light is changed into heat and the blood vessels are destroyed without damaging nearby skin.<EOS>
<BOS>Total hepatectomy and liver transplant: A surgical procedure to remove the entire liver followed by a transplant of a healthy liver from a donor.<EOS>
<BOS>Curettage: A procedure in which abnormal tissue is removed using a small, spoonshaped instrument called a curette.<EOS>
<BOS>The type of surgery used depends on the type of vascular tumor and where the tumor formed in the body.<EOS>
<BOS>For malignant tumors, even if the doctor removes all the cancer that can be seen at the time of the surgery, some patients may be given chemotherapy or radiation therapy after surgery to kill any cancer cells that are left.<EOS>
<BOS>Treatment given after the surgery, to lower the risk that the tumor will come back, is called adjuvant therapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Photocoagulation Photocoagulation is the use of an intense beam of light, such as a laser, to seal off blood vessels or destroy tissue.<EOS>
<BOS>It is used to treat pyogenic granuloma.<EOS>
<BOS>Embolization Embolization is a procedure that uses particles, such as tiny gelatin sponges or beads, to block blood vessels in the liver.<EOS>
<BOS>It may be used to treat some benign vascular tumors of the liver and kaposiform hemangioendothelioma.<EOS>
<BOS>Chemotherapy Chemotherapy is a treatment that uses drugs to stop the growth of tumor cells, either by killing the cells or by stopping them from dividing.<EOS>
<BOS>When chemotherapy is taken by mouth or injected into a vein or muscle, the drugs enter the bloodstream and can reach tumor cells throughout the body (systemic chemotherapy).<EOS>
<BOS>When chemotherapy is placed directly into the cerebrospinal fluid, an organ, or a body cavity such as the abdomen, the drugs mainly affect tumor cells in those areas (regional chemotherapy).<EOS>
<BOS>Chemotherapy for hemangiomas may also be given topically (applied to the skin in a cream or lotion).<EOS>
<BOS>The way the chemotherapy is given depends on the type of the vascular tumor being treated.<EOS>
<BOS>Sclerotherapy Sclerotherapy is a treatment used to destroy the blood vessel with the tumor.<EOS>
<BOS>A liquid is injected into the blood vessel, causing it to scar and break down.<EOS>
<BOS>Over time, the destroyed blood vessel is absorbed into normal tissue.<EOS>
<BOS>The blood flows through nearby healthy veins instead.<EOS>
<BOS>Sclerotherapy is used in the treatment of epithelioid hemangioma.<EOS>
<BOS>Radiation therapy Radiation therapy is a treatment that uses highenergy xrays or other types of radiation to kill tumor cells or keep them from growing.<EOS>
<BOS>There are two types of radiation therapy: External radiation therapy uses a machine outside the body to send radiation toward the tumor.<EOS>
<BOS>Internal radiation therapy uses a radioactive substance sealed in needles, seeds, wires, or catheters that are placed directly into or near the tumor.<EOS>
<BOS>The way the radiation therapy is given depends on the type of the vascular tumor being treated.<EOS>
<BOS>External radiation is used to treat some vascular tumors.<EOS>
<BOS>Targeted therapy Targeted therapy is a type of treatment that uses drugs or other substances to attack specific tumor cells.<EOS>
<BOS>Targeted therapies usually cause less harm to normal cells than chemotherapy or radiation therapy do.<EOS>
<BOS>Angiogenesis inhibitors are a type of targeted therapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Angiogenesis inhibitors are drugs that stop cells from dividing and prevent the growth of new blood vessels that tumors need to grow.<EOS>
<BOS>The targeted therapy drugs thalidomide, sorafenib, pazopanib, sirolimus, and bevacizumab are angiogenesis inhibitors used to treat childhood vascular tumors.<EOS>
<BOS>Immunotherapy Immunotherapy is a treatment that uses the patients immune system to fight disease.<EOS>
<BOS>Substances made by the body or made in a laboratory are used to boost, direct, or restore the bodys natural defenses against disease.<EOS>
<BOS>Interferon is a type of immunotherapy used to treat childhood vascular tumors.<EOS>
<BOS>It interferes with the division of tumor cells and can slow tumor growth.<EOS>
<BOS>It is used in the treatment of juvenile nasopharyngeal angiofibroma, kaposiform hemangioendothelioma, and epithelioid hemangioendothelioma.<EOS>
<BOS>Other drug therapy Other drugs used to treat childhood vascular tumors or manage their effects include the following: Steroid therapy: Steroids are hormones made naturally in the body.<EOS>
<BOS>They can also be made in a laboratory and used as drugs.<EOS>
<BOS>Steroid drugs help shrink some vascular tumors.<EOS>
<BOS>Nonsteroidal antiinflammatory drugs (NSAIDs): NSAIDs are commonly used to decrease fever, swelling, pain, and redness.<EOS>
<BOS>Examples of NSAIDs are aspirin, ibuprofen, and naproxen.<EOS>
<BOS>In the treatment of vascular tumors, NSAIDs can increase the flow of blood through the tumors and decrease the chance that an unwanted blood clot will form.<EOS>
<BOS>Antifibrinolytic therapy: These drugs help the blood clot in patients who have KasabachMerritt syndrome.<EOS>
<BOS>Fibrin is the main protein in a blood clot that helps stop bleeding and heal wounds.<EOS>
<BOS>Some vascular tumors cause fibrin to break down and the patient's blood does not clot normally, causing uncontrolled bleeding.<EOS>
<BOS>Antifibrinolytics help prevent the breakdown of fibrin.<EOS>
<BOS>Observation Observation is closely monitoring a patients condition without giving any treatment until signs or symptoms appear or change.<EOS>
<BOS>New types of treatment are being tested in clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>Information about clinical trials is available from the NCI website.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients may want to think about taking part in a clinical trial.<EOS>
<BOS>For some patients, taking part in a clinical trial may be the best treatment choice.<EOS>
<BOS>Clinical trials are part of the research process.<EOS>
<BOS>Clinical trials are done to find out if new treatments are safe and effective or better than the standard treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Many of today's standard treatments are based on earlier clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients who take part in a clinical trial may receive the standard treatment or be among the first to receive a new treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients who take part in clinical trials also help improve the way disease will be treated in the future.<EOS>
<BOS>Even when clinical trials do not lead to effective new treatments, they often answer important questions and help move research forward.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients can enter clinical trials before, during, or after starting their cancer treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Some clinical trials only include patients who have not yet received treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Other trials test treatments for patients whose tumors have not gotten better.<EOS>
<BOS>There are also clinical trials that test new ways to stop tumors from recurring (coming back) or reduce the side effects of treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Clinical trials are taking place in many parts of the country.<EOS>
<BOS>See the Treatment Options section that follows for links to current treatment clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>These have been retrieved from NCI's listing of clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>Followup tests may be needed.<EOS>
<BOS>Some of the tests that were done to diagnose the vascular tumor may be repeated.<EOS>
<BOS>Some tests will be repeated in order to see how well the treatment is working.<EOS>
<BOS>Decisions about whether to continue, change, or stop treatment may be based on the results of these tests.<EOS>
<BOS>Some of the tests will continue to be done from time to time after treatment has ended.<EOS>
<BOS>The results of these tests can show if your child's condition has changed or if the tumor has recurred (come back).<EOS>
<BOS>These tests are sometimes called followup tests or checkups.<EOS>
<BOS>Certain factors affect the prognosis (chance of recovery) and treatment options.<EOS>
<BOS>The prognosis (chance of recovery) depends on the following: The size of the tumor.<EOS>
<BOS>Where the tumor is in the anus.<EOS>
<BOS>Whether the cancer has spread to the lymph nodes.<EOS>
<BOS>The treatment options depend on the following: The stage of the cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Where the tumor is in the anus.<EOS>
<BOS>Whether the patient has human immunodeficiency virus (HIV).<EOS>
<BOS>Whether cancer remains after initial treatment or has recurred.<EOS>
<BOS>Tests that examine the brain and spinal cord are used to detect (find) childhood brain and spinal cord tumors.<EOS>
<BOS>The following tests and procedures may be used: Physical exam and history : An exam of the body to check general signs of health, including checking for signs of disease, such as lumps or anything else that seems unusual.<EOS>
<BOS>A history of the patients health habits and past illnesses and treatments will also be taken.<EOS>
<BOS>Neurological exam : A series of questions and tests to check the brain, spinal cord, and nerve function.<EOS>
<BOS>The exam checks a persons mental status, coordination, and ability to walk normally, and how well the muscles, senses, and reflexes work.<EOS>
<BOS>This may also be called a neuro exam or a neurologic exam.<EOS>
<BOS>MRI (magnetic resonance imaging) with gadolinium : A procedure that uses a magnet, radio waves, and a computer to make a series of detailed pictures of the brain and spinal cord.<EOS>
<BOS>A substance called gadolinium is injected into a vein.<EOS>
<BOS>The gadolinium collects around the cancer cells so they show up brighter in the picture.<EOS>
<BOS>This procedure is also called nuclear magnetic resonance imaging (NMRI).<EOS>
<BOS>Serum tumor marker test : A procedure in which a sample of blood is examined to measure the amounts of certain substances released into the blood by organs, tissues, or tumor cells in the body.<EOS>
<BOS>Certain substances are linked to specific types of cancer when found in increased levels in the blood.<EOS>
<BOS>These are called tumor markers.<EOS>
<BOS>Most childhood brain tumors are diagnosed and removed in surgery.<EOS>
<BOS>If doctors think there might be a brain tumor, a biopsy may be done to remove a sample of tissue.<EOS>
<BOS>For tumors in the brain, the biopsy is done by removing part of the skull and using a needle to remove a sample of tissue.<EOS>
<BOS>A pathologist views the tissue under a microscope to look for cancer cells.<EOS>
<BOS>If cancer cells are found, the doctor may remove as much tumor as safely possible during the same surgery.<EOS>
<BOS>The pathologist checks the cancer cells to find out the type and grade of brain tumor.<EOS>
<BOS>The grade of the tumor is based on how abnormal the cancer cells look under a microscope and how quickly the tumor is likely to grow and spread.<EOS>
<BOS>The following test may be done on the sample of tissue that is removed: Immunohistochemistry : A test that uses antibodies to check for certain antigens in a sample of tissue.<EOS>
<BOS>The antibody is usually linked to a radioactive substance or a dye that causes the tissue to light up under a microscope.<EOS>
<BOS>This type of test may be used to tell the difference between different types of cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Some childhood brain and spinal cord tumors are diagnosed by imaging tests.<EOS>
<BOS>Sometimes a biopsy or surgery cannot be done safely because of where the tumor formed in the brain or spinal cord.<EOS>
<BOS>These tumors are diagnosed based on the results of imaging tests and other procedures.<EOS>
<BOS>Key Points After ovarian germ cell tumor has been diagnosed, tests are done to find out if cancer cells have spread within the ovary or to other parts of the body.<EOS>
<BOS>There are three ways that cancer spreads in the body.<EOS>
<BOS>Cancer may spread from where it began to other parts of the body.<EOS>
<BOS>The following stages are used for ovarian germ cell tumors: Stage I Stage II Stage III Stage IV After ovarian germ cell tumor has been diagnosed, tests are done to find out if cancer cells have spread within the ovary or to other parts of the body.<EOS>
<BOS>The process used to find out whether cancer has spread within the ovary or to other parts of the body is called staging.<EOS>
<BOS>The information gathered from the staging process determines the stage of the disease.<EOS>
<BOS>Unless a doctor is sure the cancer has spread from the ovaries to other parts of the body, an operation called a laparotomy is done to see if the cancer has spread.<EOS>
<BOS>The doctor must cut into the abdomen and carefully look at all the organs to see if they have cancer in them.<EOS>
<BOS>The doctor will cut out small pieces of tissue so they can be checked under a microscope for signs of cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>The doctor may also wash the abdominal cavity with fluid, which is also checked under a microscope to see if it has cancer cells in it.<EOS>
<BOS>Usually the doctor will remove the cancer and other organs that have cancer in them during the laparotomy.<EOS>
<BOS>It is important to know the stage in order to plan treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Many of the tests used to diagnose ovarian germ cell tumor are also used for staging.<EOS>
<BOS>The following tests and procedures may also be used for staging: PET scan (positron emission tomography scan): A procedure to find malignant tumor cells in the body.<EOS>
<BOS>A small amount of radioactive glucose (sugar) is injected into a vein.<EOS>
<BOS>The PET scanner rotates around the body and makes a picture of where glucose is being used in the body.<EOS>
<BOS>Malignant tumor cells show up brighter in the picture because they are more active and take up more glucose than normal cells do.<EOS>
<BOS>MRI (magnetic resonance imaging): A procedure that uses a magnet, radio waves, and a computer to make a series of detailed pictures of areas inside the body.<EOS>
<BOS>This procedure is also called nuclear magnetic resonance imaging (NMRI).<EOS>
<BOS>Transvaginal ultrasound exam: A procedure used to examine the vagina, uterus, fallopian tubes, and bladder.<EOS>
<BOS>An ultrasound transducer (probe) is inserted into the vagina and used to bounce highenergy sound waves (ultrasound) off internal tissues or organs and make echoes.<EOS>
<BOS>The echoes form a picture of body tissues called a sonogram.<EOS>
<BOS>The doctor can identify tumors by looking at the sonogram.<EOS>
<BOS>There are three ways that cancer spreads in the body.<EOS>
<BOS>Cancer can spread through tissue, the lymph system, and the blood: Tissue.<EOS>
<BOS>The cancer spreads from where it began by growing into nearby areas.<EOS>
<BOS>Lymph system.<EOS>
<BOS>The cancer spreads from where it began by getting into the lymph system.<EOS>
<BOS>The cancer travels through the lymph vessels to other parts of the body.<EOS>
<BOS>Blood.<EOS>
<BOS>The cancer spreads from where it began by getting into the blood.<EOS>
<BOS>The cancer travels through the blood vessels to other parts of the body.<EOS>
<BOS>Cancer may spread from where it began to other parts of the body.<EOS>
<BOS>When cancer spreads to another part of the body, it is called metastasis.<EOS>
<BOS>Cancer cells break away from where they began (the primary tumor) and travel through the lymph system or blood.<EOS>
<BOS>Lymph system.<EOS>
<BOS>The cancer gets into the lymph system, travels through the lymph vessels, and forms a tumor (metastatic tumor) in another part of the body.<EOS>
<BOS>Blood.<EOS>
<BOS>The cancer gets into the blood, travels through the blood vessels, and forms a tumor (metastatic tumor) in another part of the body.<EOS>
<BOS>The metastatic tumor is the same type of tumor as the primary tumor.<EOS>
<BOS>For example, if an ovarian germ cell tumor spreads to the liver, the tumor cells in the liver are actually cancerous ovarian germ cells.<EOS>
<BOS>The disease is metastatic ovarian germ cell tumor, not liver cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>The following stages are used for ovarian germ cell tumors: Stage I In stage I, cancer is found in one or both ovaries.<EOS>
<BOS>Stage I is divided into stage IA, stage IB, and stage IC.<EOS>
<BOS>Stage IA: Cancer is found inside a single ovary.<EOS>
<BOS>Stage IB: Cancer is found inside both ovaries.<EOS>
<BOS>Stage IC: Cancer is found inside one or both ovaries and one of the following is true: cancer is also found on the outside surface of one or both ovaries; or the capsule (outer covering) of the ovary has ruptured (broken open); or cancer cells are found in the fluid of the peritoneal cavity (the body cavity that contains most of the organs in the abdomen) or in washings of the peritoneum (tissue lining the peritoneal cavity).<EOS>
<BOS>Stage II In stage II, cancer is found in one or both ovaries and has spread into other areas of the pelvis.<EOS>
<BOS>Stage II is divided into stage IIA, stage IIB, and stage IIC.<EOS>
<BOS>Stage IIA: Cancer has spread to the uterus and/or fallopian tubes (the long slender tubes through which eggs pass from the ovaries to the uterus).<EOS>
<BOS>Stage IIB: Cancer has spread to other tissue within the pelvis.<EOS>
<BOS>Stage IIC: Cancer is found inside one or both ovaries and has spread to the uterus and/or fallopian tubes, or to other tissue within the pelvis.<EOS>
<BOS>Also, one of the following is true: cancer is found on the outside surface of one or both ovaries; or the capsule (outer covering) of the ovary has ruptured (broken open); or cancer cells are found in the fluid of the peritoneal cavity (the body cavity that contains most of the organs in the abdomen) or in washings of the peritoneum (tissue lining the peritoneal cavity).<EOS>
<BOS>Stage III In stage III, cancer is found in one or both ovaries and has spread outside the pelvis to other parts of the abdomen and/or nearby lymph nodes.<EOS>
<BOS>Stage III is divided into stage IIIA, stage IIIB, and stage IIIC.<EOS>
<BOS>Stage IIIA: The tumor is found in the pelvis only, but cancer cells that can be seen only with a microscope have spread to the surface of the peritoneum (tissue that lines the abdominal wall and covers most of the organs in the abdomen), the small intestines, or the tissue that connects the small intestines to the wall of the abdomen.<EOS>
<BOS>Stage IIIB: Cancer has spread to the peritoneum and the cancer in the peritoneum is 2 centimeters or smaller.<EOS>
<BOS>Stage IIIC: Cancer has spread to the peritoneum and the cancer in the peritoneum is larger than 2 centimeters and/or cancer has spread to lymph nodes in the abdomen.<EOS>
<BOS>Cancer that has spread to the surface of the liver is also considered stage III ovarian cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Stage IV In stage IV, cancer has spread beyond the abdomen to other parts of the body, such as the lungs or tissue inside the liver.<EOS>
<BOS>Cancer cells in the fluid around the lungs is also considered stage IV ovarian cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients may want to think about taking part in a clinical trial.<EOS>
<BOS>For some patients, taking part in a clinical trial may be the best treatment choice.<EOS>
<BOS>Clinical trials are part of the cancer research process.<EOS>
<BOS>Clinical trials are done to find out if new cancer treatments are safe and effective or better than the standard treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Many of today's standard treatments for cancer are based on earlier clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients who take part in a clinical trial may receive the standard treatment or be among the first to receive a new treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients who take part in clinical trials also help improve the way cancer will be treated in the future.<EOS>
<BOS>Even when clinical trials do not lead to effective new treatments, they often answer important questions and help move research forward.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients can enter clinical trials before, during, or after starting their cancer treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Some clinical trials only include patients who have not yet received treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Other trials test treatments for patients whose cancer has not gotten better.<EOS>
<BOS>There are also clinical trials that test new ways to stop cancer from recurring (coming back) or reduce the side effects of cancer treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Clinical trials are taking place in many parts of the country.<EOS>
<BOS>See the Treatment Options section that follows for links to current treatment clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>These have been retrieved from NCI's listing of clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients may want to think about taking part in a clinical trial.<EOS>
<BOS>For some patients, taking part in a clinical trial may be the best treatment choice.<EOS>
<BOS>Clinical trials are part of the cancer research process.<EOS>
<BOS>Clinical trials are done to find out if new cancer treatments are safe and effective or better than the standard treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Many of today's standard treatments for cancer are based on earlier clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients who take part in a clinical trial may receive the standard treatment or be among the first to receive a new treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients who take part in clinical trials also help improve the way cancer will be treated in the future.<EOS>
<BOS>Even when clinical trials do not lead to effective new treatments, they often answer important questions and help move research forward.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients can enter clinical trials before, during, or after starting their cancer treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Some clinical trials only include patients who have not yet received treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Other trials test treatments for patients whose cancer has not gotten better.<EOS>
<BOS>There are also clinical trials that test new ways to stop cancer from recurring (coming back) or reduce the side effects of cancer treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Clinical trials are taking place in many parts of the country.<EOS>
<BOS>See the Treatment Options section that follows for links to current treatment clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>These have been retrieved from NCI's listing of clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>Key Points There is no standard staging system for central nervous system atypical teratoid/rhabdoid tumor.<EOS>
<BOS>There is no standard staging system for central nervous system atypical teratoid/rhabdoid tumor.<EOS>
<BOS>The extent or spread of cancer is usually described as stages.<EOS>
<BOS>There is no standard staging system for central nervous system atypical teratoid/rhabdoid tumor.<EOS>
<BOS>For treatment, this tumor is grouped as newly diagnosed or recurrent.<EOS>
<BOS>Treatment depends on the following: The age of the child.<EOS>
<BOS>How much cancer remains after surgery to remove the tumor.<EOS>
<BOS>Results from the following procedure are also used to plan treatment: Ultrasound exam: A procedure in which highenergy sound waves (ultrasound) are bounced off internal tissues or organs, such as the kidney, and make echoes.<EOS>
<BOS>The echoes form a picture of body tissues called a sonogram.<EOS>
<BOS>The picture can be printed to be looked at later.<EOS>
<BOS>This procedure is done to check for tumors that may also have formed in the kidney.<EOS>
<BOS>Key Points Once adult ALL has been diagnosed, tests are done to find out if the cancer has spread to the central nervous system (brain and spinal cord) or to other parts of the body.<EOS>
<BOS>There is no standard staging system for adult ALL.<EOS>
<BOS>Once adult ALL has been diagnosed, tests are done to find out if the cancer has spread to the central nervous system (brain and spinal cord) or to other parts of the body.<EOS>
<BOS>The extent or spread of cancer is usually described as stages.<EOS>
<BOS>It is important to know whether the leukemia has spread outside the blood and bone marrow in order to plan treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>The following tests and procedures may be used to determine if the leukemia has spread: Chest xray : An xray of the organs and bones inside the chest.<EOS>
<BOS>An xray is a type of energy beam that can go through the body and onto film, making a picture of areas inside the body.<EOS>
<BOS>Lumbar puncture : A procedure used to collect a sample of cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) from the spinal column.<EOS>
<BOS>This is done by placing a needle between two bones in the spine and into the CSF around the spinal cord and removing a sample of the fluid.<EOS>
<BOS>The sample of CSF is checked under a microscope for signs that leukemia cells have spread to the brain and spinal cord.<EOS>
<BOS>This procedure is also called an LP or spinal tap.<EOS>
<BOS>CT scan (CAT scan): A procedure that makes a series of detailed pictures of the abdomen, taken from different angles.<EOS>
<BOS>The pictures are made by a computer linked to an xray machine.<EOS>
<BOS>A dye may be injected into a vein or swallowed to help the organs or tissues show up more clearly.<EOS>
<BOS>This procedure is also called computed tomography, computerized tomography, or computerized axial tomography.<EOS>
<BOS>MRI (magnetic resonance imaging): A procedure that uses a magnet, radio waves, and a computer to make a series of detailed pictures of areas inside the body.<EOS>
<BOS>This procedure is also called nuclear magnetic resonance imaging (NMRI).<EOS>
<BOS>There is no standard staging system for adult ALL.<EOS>
<BOS>The disease is described as untreated, in remission, or recurrent.<EOS>
<BOS>Untreated adult ALL The ALL is newly diagnosed and has not been treated except to relieve signs and symptoms such as fever, bleeding, or pain.<EOS>
<BOS>The complete blood count is abnormal.<EOS>
<BOS>More than 5% of the cells in the bone marrow are blasts (leukemia cells).<EOS>
<BOS>There are signs and symptoms of leukemia.<EOS>
<BOS>Adult ALL in remission The ALL has been treated.<EOS>
<BOS>The complete blood count is normal.<EOS>
<BOS>5% or fewer of the cells in the bone marrow are blasts (leukemia cells).<EOS>
<BOS>There are no signs or symptoms of leukemia other than in the bone marrow.<EOS>
<BOS>Tests that examine the brain and spinal cord are used to detect (find) CNS atypical teratoid/rhabdoid tumor.<EOS>
<BOS>The following tests and procedures may be used: Physical exam and history : An exam of the body to check general signs of health, including checking for signs of disease, such as lumps or anything else that seems unusual.<EOS>
<BOS>A history of the patient's health habits and past illnesses and treatments will also be taken.<EOS>
<BOS>Neurological exam : A series of questions and tests to check the brain, spinal cord, and nerve function.<EOS>
<BOS>The exam checks a persons mental status, coordination, and ability to walk normally, and how well the muscles, senses, and reflexes work.<EOS>
<BOS>This may also be called a neuro exam or a neurologic exam.<EOS>
<BOS>MRI (magnetic resonance imaging): A procedure that uses a magnet, radio waves, and a computer to make a series of detailed pictures of areas inside the brain and spinal cord.<EOS>
<BOS>This procedure is also called nuclear magnetic resonance imaging (NMRI).<EOS>
<BOS>Lumbar puncture : A procedure used to collect cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) from the spinal column.<EOS>
<BOS>This is done by placing a needle between two bones in the spine and into the CSF around the spinal cord and removing a sample of fluid.<EOS>
<BOS>The sample of CSF is checked under a microscope for signs of tumor cells.<EOS>
<BOS>The sample may also be checked for the amounts of protein and glucose.<EOS>
<BOS>A higher than normal amount of protein or lower than normal amount of glucose may be a sign of a tumor.<EOS>
<BOS>This procedure is also called an LP or spinal tap.<EOS>
<BOS>SMARCB1 and SMARCA4 gene testing: A laboratory test in which a sample of blood or tissue is tested for the SMARCB1 and SMARCA4 genes.<EOS>
<BOS>Childhood atypical teratoid/rhabdoid tumor is diagnosed and may be removed in surgery.<EOS>
<BOS>If doctors think there might be a brain tumor, a biopsy may be done to remove a sample of tissue.<EOS>
<BOS>For tumors in the brain, the biopsy is done by removing part of the skull and using a needle to remove a sample of tissue.<EOS>
<BOS>A pathologist views the tissue under a microscope to look for cancer cells.<EOS>
<BOS>If cancer cells are found, the doctor may remove as much tumor as safely possible during the same surgery.<EOS>
<BOS>The pathologist checks the cancer cells to find out the type of brain tumor.<EOS>
<BOS>It is often difficult to completely remove AT/RT because of where the tumor is in the brain and because it may already have spread at the time of diagnosis.<EOS>
<BOS>The following test may be done on the sample of tissue that is removed: Immunohistochemistry : A test that uses antibodies to check for certain antigens in a sample of tissue.<EOS>
<BOS>The antibody is usually linked to a radioactive substance or a dye that causes the tissue to light up under a microscope.<EOS>
<BOS>This test is used to tell the difference between AT/RT and other brain tumors.<EOS>
<BOS>New types of treatment are being tested in clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>This summary section describes treatments that are being studied in clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>It may not mention every new treatment being studied.<EOS>
<BOS>Information about clinical trials is available from the NCI website.<EOS>
<BOS>Chemotherapy with stem cell transplant Chemotherapy with stem cell transplant is a method of giving chemotherapy and replacing blood forming cells destroyed by the cancer treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Stem cells (immature blood cells) are removed from the blood or bone marrow of the patient or a donor and are frozen and stored.<EOS>
<BOS>After the chemotherapy is completed, the stored stem cells are thawed and given back to the patient through an infusion.<EOS>
<BOS>These reinfused stem cells grow into (and restore) the bodys blood cells.<EOS>
<BOS>Biologic therapy Biologic therapy is a treatment that uses the patient's immune system to fight cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Substances made by the body or made in a laboratory are used to boost, direct, or restore the body's natural defenses against cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>This type of cancer treatment is also called biotherapy or immunotherapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Chimeric antigen receptor (CAR) Tcell therapy CAR Tcell therapy is a type of immunotherapy that changes the patient's T cells (a type of immune system cell) so they will attack certain proteins on the surface of cancer cells.<EOS>
<BOS>T cells are taken from the patient and special receptors are added to their surface in the laboratory.<EOS>
<BOS>The changed cells are called chimeric antigen receptor (CAR) T cells.<EOS>
<BOS>The CAR T cells are grown in the laboratory and given to the patient by infusion.<EOS>
<BOS>The CAR T cells multiply in the patient's blood and attack cancer cells.<EOS>
<BOS>CAR Tcell therapy is being studied in the treatment of chronic lymphocytic leukemia.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients may want to think about taking part in a clinical trial.<EOS>
<BOS>For some patients, taking part in a clinical trial may be the best treatment choice.<EOS>
<BOS>Clinical trials are part of the cancer research process.<EOS>
<BOS>Clinical trials are done to find out if new cancer treatments are safe and effective or better than the standard treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Many of today's standard treatments for cancer are based on earlier clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients who take part in a clinical trial may receive the standard treatment or be among the first to receive a new treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients who take part in clinical trials also help improve the way cancer will be treated in the future.<EOS>
<BOS>Even when clinical trials do not lead to effective new treatments, they often answer important questions and help move research forward.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients can enter clinical trials before, during, or after starting their cancer treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Some clinical trials only include patients who have not yet received treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Other trials test treatments for patients whose cancer has not gotten better.<EOS>
<BOS>There are also clinical trials that test new ways to stop cancer from recurring (coming back) or reduce the side effects of cancer treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Clinical trials are taking place in many parts of the country.<EOS>
<BOS>See the Treatment Options section that follows for links to current treatment clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>These have been retrieved from NCI's listing of clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>Key Points There are different types of treatment for patients with myelodysplastic/myeloproliferative neoplasms.<EOS>
<BOS>Five types of standard treatment are used: Chemotherapy Other drug therapy Stem cell transplant Supportive care Targeted therapy New types of treatment are being tested in clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients may want to think about taking part in a clinical trial.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients can enter clinical trials before, during, or after starting their cancer treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Followup tests may be needed.<EOS>
<BOS>There are different types of treatment for patients with myelodysplastic/myeloproliferative neoplasms.<EOS>
<BOS>Different types of treatments are available for patients with myelodysplastic /myeloproliferative neoplasms.<EOS>
<BOS>Some treatments are standard (the currently used treatment), and some are being tested in clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>A treatment clinical trial is a research study meant to help improve current treatments or obtain information on new treatments for patients with cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>When clinical trials show that a new treatment is better than the standard treatment, the new treatment may become the standard treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients may want to think about taking part in a clinical trial.<EOS>
<BOS>Some clinical trials are open only to patients who have not started treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Five types of standard treatment are used: Chemotherapy Chemotherapy is a cancer treatment that uses drugs to stop the growth of cancer cells, either by killing the cells or by stopping them from dividing.<EOS>
<BOS>When chemotherapy is taken by mouth or injected into a vein or muscle, the drugs enter the bloodstream and can reach cancer cells throughout the body (systemic chemotherapy).<EOS>
<BOS>When chemotherapy is placed directly into the cerebrospinal fluid, an organ, or a body cavity such as the abdomen, the drugs mainly affect cancer cells in those areas (regional chemotherapy).<EOS>
<BOS>The way the chemotherapy is given depends on the type and stage of the cancer being treated.<EOS>
<BOS>Combination chemotherapy is treatment using more than one anticancer drug.<EOS>
<BOS>See Drugs Approved for Myeloproliferative Neoplasms for more information.<EOS>
<BOS>Other drug therapy 13cis retinoic acid is a vitamin like drug that slows the cancer's ability to make more cancer cells and changes the way these cells look and act.<EOS>
<BOS>Stem cell transplant Stem cell transplant is a method of replacing blood forming cells that are destroyed by chemotherapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Stem cells (immature blood cells) are removed from the blood or bone marrow of the patient or a donor and are frozen and stored.<EOS>
<BOS>After the chemotherapy is completed, the stored stem cells are thawed and given back to the patient through an infusion.<EOS>
<BOS>These reinfused stem cells grow into (and restore) the body's blood cells.<EOS>
<BOS>Supportive care Supportive care is given to lessen the problems caused by the disease or its treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Supportive care may include transfusion therapy or drug therapy, such as antibiotics to fight infection.<EOS>
<BOS>Targeted therapy Targeted therapy is a cancer treatment that uses drugs or other substances to attack cancer cells without harming normal cells.<EOS>
<BOS>Targeted therapy drugs called tyrosine kinase inhibitors (TKIs) are used to treat myelodysplastic/myeloproliferative neoplasm, unclassifiable.<EOS>
<BOS>TKIs block the enzyme, tyrosine kinase, that causes stem cells to become more blood cells (blasts) than the body needs.<EOS>
<BOS>Imatinib mesylate (Gleevec) is a TKI that may be used.<EOS>
<BOS>Other targeted therapy drugs are being studied in the treatment of JMML.<EOS>
<BOS>See Drugs Approved for Myeloproliferative Neoplasms for more information.<EOS>
<BOS>New types of treatment are being tested in clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>Information about clinical trials is available from the NCI website.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients may want to think about taking part in a clinical trial.<EOS>
<BOS>For some patients, taking part in a clinical trial may be the best treatment choice.<EOS>
<BOS>Clinical trials are part of the cancer research process.<EOS>
<BOS>Clinical trials are done to find out if new cancer treatments are safe and effective or better than the standard treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Many of today's standard treatments for cancer are based on earlier clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients who take part in a clinical trial may receive the standard treatment or be among the first to receive a new treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients who take part in clinical trials also help improve the way cancer will be treated in the future.<EOS>
<BOS>Even when clinical trials do not lead to effective new treatments, they often answer important questions and help move research forward.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients can enter clinical trials before, during, or after starting their cancer treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Some clinical trials only include patients who have not yet received treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Other trials test treatments for patients whose cancer has not gotten better.<EOS>
<BOS>There are also clinical trials that test new ways to stop cancer from recurring (coming back) or reduce the side effects of cancer treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Clinical trials are taking place in many parts of the country.<EOS>
<BOS>See the Treatment Options section that follows for links to current treatment clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>These have been retrieved from NCI's listing of clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>Followup tests may be needed.<EOS>
<BOS>Some of the tests that were done to diagnose the cancer or to find out the stage of the cancer may be repeated.<EOS>
<BOS>Some tests will be repeated in order to see how well the treatment is working.<EOS>
<BOS>Decisions about whether to continue, change, or stop treatment may be based on the results of these tests.<EOS>
<BOS>Some of the tests will continue to be done from time to time after treatment has ended.<EOS>
<BOS>The results of these tests can show if your condition has changed or if the cancer has recurred (come back).<EOS>
<BOS>These tests are sometimes called followup tests or checkups.<EOS>
<BOS>Treatment Options for Myelodysplastic/ Myeloproliferative Neoplasms Chronic Myelomonocytic Leukemia Treatment of chronic myelomonocytic leukemia (CMML) may include the following: Chemotherapy with one or more agents.<EOS>
<BOS>Stem cell transplant.<EOS>
<BOS>A clinical trial of a new treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Check the list of NCIsupported cancer clinical trials that are now accepting patients with chronic myelomonocytic leukemia.<EOS>
<BOS>For more specific results, refine the search by using other search features, such as the location of the trial, the type of treatment, or the name of the drug.<EOS>
<BOS>Talk with your doctor about clinical trials that may be right for you.<EOS>
<BOS>General information about clinical trials is available from the NCI website.<EOS>
<BOS>Juvenile Myelomonocytic Leukemia Treatment of juvenile myelomonocytic leukemia (JMML) may include the following: Combination chemotherapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Stem cell transplant.<EOS>
<BOS>13cisretinoic acid therapy.<EOS>
<BOS>A clinical trial of a new treatment, such as targeted therapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Check the list of NCIsupported cancer clinical trials that are now accepting patients with juvenile myelomonocytic leukemia.<EOS>
<BOS>For more specific results, refine the search by using other search features, such as the location of the trial, the type of treatment, or the name of the drug.<EOS>
<BOS>Talk with your doctor about clinical trials that may be right for you.<EOS>
<BOS>General information about clinical trials is available from the NCI website.<EOS>
<BOS>Atypical Chronic Myelogenous Leukemia Treatment of atypical chronic myelogenous leukemia (CML) may include chemotherapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Check the list of NCIsupported cancer clinical trials that are now accepting patients with atypical chronic myeloid leukemia, BCRABL1 negative.<EOS>
<BOS>For more specific results, refine the search by using other search features, such as the location of the trial, the type of treatment, or the name of the drug.<EOS>
<BOS>Talk with your doctor about clinical trials that may be right for you.<EOS>
<BOS>General information about clinical trials is available from the NCI website.<EOS>
<BOS>Myelodysplastic/ Myeloproliferative Neoplasm, Unclassifiable Because myelodysplastic /myeloproliferative neoplasm, unclassifiable (MDS/MPNUC) is a rare disease, little is known about its treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Treatment may include the following: Supportive care treatments to manage problems caused by the disease such as infection, bleeding, and anemia.<EOS>
<BOS>Targeted therapy (imatinib mesylate).<EOS>
<BOS>Check the list of NCIsupported cancer clinical trials that are now accepting patients with myelodysplastic/myeloproliferative neoplasm, unclassifiable.<EOS>
<BOS>For more specific results, refine the search by using other search features, such as the location of the trial, the type of treatment, or the name of the drug.<EOS>
<BOS>Talk with your doctor about clinical trials that may be right for you.<EOS>
<BOS>General information about clinical trials is available from the NCI website.<EOS>
<BOS>New types of treatment are being tested in clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>This summary section describes treatments that are being studied in clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>It may not mention every new treatment being studied.<EOS>
<BOS>Information about clinical trials is available from the NCI website.<EOS>
<BOS>Vaccine therapy Vaccine therapy is a type of biologic therapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Biologic therapy is a treatment that uses the patients immune system to fight cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Substances made by the body or made in a laboratory are used to boost, direct, or restore the bodys natural defenses against cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>This type of cancer treatment is also called biotherapy or immunotherapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Vaccine therapy can also be a type of targeted therapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients may want to think about taking part in a clinical trial.<EOS>
<BOS>For some patients, taking part in a clinical trial may be the best treatment choice.<EOS>
<BOS>Clinical trials are part of the cancer research process.<EOS>
<BOS>Clinical trials are done to find out if new cancer treatments are safe and effective or better than the standard treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Many of today's standard treatments for cancer are based on earlier clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients who take part in a clinical trial may receive the standard treatment or be among the first to receive a new treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients who take part in clinical trials also help improve the way cancer will be treated in the future.<EOS>
<BOS>Even when clinical trials do not lead to effective new treatments, they often answer important questions and help move research forward.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients can enter clinical trials before, during, or after starting their cancer treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Some clinical trials only include patients who have not yet received treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Other trials test treatments for patients whose cancer has not gotten better.<EOS>
<BOS>There are also clinical trials that test new ways to stop cancer from recurring (coming back) or reduce the side effects of cancer treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Clinical trials are taking place in many parts of the country.<EOS>
<BOS>See the Treatment Options section that follows for links to current treatment clinical trials.<EOS>

<BOS>Key Points There are different types of treatment for patients with extragonadal germ cell tumors.<EOS>
<BOS>Three types of standard treatment are used: Radiation therapy Chemotherapy Surgery New types of treatment are being tested in clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>Highdose chemotherapy with stem cell transplant Patients may want to think about taking part in a clinical trial.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients can enter clinical trials before, during, or after starting their cancer treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Followup tests may be needed.<EOS>
<BOS>There are different types of treatment for patients with extragonadal germ cell tumors.<EOS>
<BOS>Different types of treatments are available for patients with extragonadal germ cell tumors.<EOS>
<BOS>Some treatments are standard (the currently used treatment), and some are being tested in clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>A treatment clinical trial is a research study meant to help improve current treatments or obtain information on new treatments for patients with cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>When clinical trials show that a new treatment is better than the standard treatment, the new treatment may become the standard treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients may want to think about taking part in a clinical trial.<EOS>
<BOS>Some clinical trials are open only to patients who have not started treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Three types of standard treatment are used: Radiation therapy Radiation therapy is a cancer treatment that uses highenergy xrays or other types of radiation to kill cancer cells or keep them from growing.<EOS>
<BOS>There are two types of radiation therapy: External radiation therapy uses a machine outside the body to send radiation toward the cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Internal radiation therapy uses a radioactive substance sealed in needles, seeds, wires, or catheters that are placed directly into or near the cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>The way the radiation therapy is given depends on the type and stage of the cancer being treated.<EOS>
<BOS>External radiation therapy is used to treat seminoma.<EOS>
<BOS>Chemotherapy Chemotherapy is a cancer treatment that uses drugs to stop the growth of cancer cells, either by killing the cells or by stopping them from dividing.<EOS>
<BOS>When chemotherapy is taken by mouth or injected into a vein or muscle, the drugs enter the bloodstream and can reach cancer cells throughout the body (systemic chemotherapy).<EOS>
<BOS>When chemotherapy is placed directly in the cerebrospinal fluid, an organ, or a body cavity such as the abdomen, the drugs mainly affect cancer cells in those areas (regional chemotherapy).<EOS>
<BOS>The way the chemotherapy is given depends on the type and stage of the cancer being treated.<EOS>
<BOS>Surgery Patients who have benign tumors or tumor remaining after chemotherapy or radiation therapy may need to have surgery.<EOS>
<BOS>New types of treatment are being tested in clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>This summary section describes treatments that are being studied in clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>It may not mention every new treatment being studied.<EOS>
<BOS>Information about clinical trials is available from the NCI website.<EOS>
<BOS>Highdose chemotherapy with stem cell transplant Highdose chemotherapy with stem cell transplant is a method of giving high doses of chemotherapy and replacing blood forming cells destroyed by the cancer treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Stem cells (immature blood cells) are removed from the blood or bone marrow of the patient or a donor and are frozen and stored.<EOS>
<BOS>After the chemotherapy is completed, the stored stem cells are thawed and given back to the patient through an infusion.<EOS>
<BOS>These reinfused stem cells grow into (and restore) the body's blood cells.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients may want to think about taking part in a clinical trial.<EOS>
<BOS>For some patients, taking part in a clinical trial may be the best treatment choice.<EOS>
<BOS>Clinical trials are part of the cancer research process.<EOS>
<BOS>Clinical trials are done to find out if new cancer treatments are safe and effective or better than the standard treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Many of today's standard treatments for cancer are based on earlier clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients who take part in a clinical trial may receive the standard treatment or be among the first to receive a new treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients who take part in clinical trials also help improve the way cancer will be treated in the future.<EOS>
<BOS>Even when clinical trials do not lead to effective new treatments, they often answer important questions and help move research forward.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients can enter clinical trials before, during, or after starting their cancer treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Some clinical trials only include patients who have not yet received treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Other trials test treatments for patients whose cancer has not gotten better.<EOS>
<BOS>There are also clinical trials that test new ways to stop cancer from recurring (coming back) or reduce the side effects of cancer treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Clinical trials are taking place in many parts of the country.<EOS>
<BOS>See the Treatment Options section that follows for links to current treatment clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>These have been retrieved from NCI's listing of clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>Followup tests may be needed.<EOS>
<BOS>Some of the tests that were done to diagnose the cancer or to find out the stage of the cancer may be repeated.<EOS>
<BOS>Some tests will be repeated in order to see how well the treatment is working.<EOS>
<BOS>Decisions about whether to continue, change, or stop treatment may be based on the results of these tests.<EOS>
<BOS>Some of the tests will continue to be done from time to time after treatment has ended.<EOS>
<BOS>The results of these tests can show if your condition has changed or if the cancer has recurred (come back).<EOS>
<BOS>These tests are sometimes called followup tests or checkups.<EOS>
<BOS>After initial treatment for extragonadal germ cell tumors, blood levels of AFP and other tumor markers continue to be checked to find out how well the treatment is working.<EOS>
<BOS>Treatment Options for Extragonadal Germ Cell Tumors Benign Teratoma Treatment of benign teratomas is surgery.<EOS>
<BOS>Check the list of NCIsupported cancer clinical trials that are now accepting patients with benign teratoma.<EOS>
<BOS>For more specific results, refine the search by using other search features, such as the location of the trial, the type of treatment, or the name of the drug.<EOS>
<BOS>Talk with your doctor about clinical trials that may be right for you.<EOS>
<BOS>General information about clinical trials is available from the NCI website.<EOS>
<BOS>Seminoma Treatment of seminoma extragonadal germ cell tumors may include the following: Radiation therapy for small tumors in one area, followed by watchful waiting if there is tumor remaining after treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Chemotherapy for larger tumors or tumors that have spread.<EOS>
<BOS>If a tumor smaller than 3 centimeters remains after chemotherapy, watchful waiting follows.<EOS>
<BOS>If a larger tumor remains after treatment, surgery or watchful waiting follow.<EOS>
<BOS>Check the list of NCIsupported cancer clinical trials that are now accepting patients with extragonadal seminoma.<EOS>
<BOS>For more specific results, refine the search by using other search features, such as the location of the trial, the type of treatment, or the name of the drug.<EOS>
<BOS>Talk with your doctor about clinical trials that may be right for you.<EOS>
<BOS>General information about clinical trials is available from the NCI website.<EOS>
<BOS>Nonseminoma Treatment of nonseminoma extragonadal germ cell tumors may include the following: Combination chemotherapy followed by surgery to remove any remaining tumor.<EOS>
<BOS>A clinical trial of a new treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Check the list of NCIsupported cancer clinical trials that are now accepting patients with malignant extragonadal nonseminomatous germ cell tumor.<EOS>
<BOS>For more specific results, refine the search by using other search features, such as the location of the trial, the type of treatment, or the name of the drug.<EOS>
<BOS>Talk with your doctor about clinical trials that may be right for you.<EOS>
<BOS>General information about clinical trials is available from the NCI website.<EOS>
<BOS>Recurrent or Refractory Extragonadal Germ Cell Tumors Treatment of extragonadal germ cell tumors that are recurrent (come back after being treated) or refractory (do not get better during treatment) may include the following: Chemotherapy.<EOS>
<BOS>A clinical trial of highdose chemotherapy with stem cell transplant.<EOS>
<BOS>A clinical trial of a new treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Check the list of NCIsupported cancer clinical trials that are now accepting patients with recurrent extragonadal germ cell tumor.<EOS>
<BOS>For more specific results, refine the search by using other search features, such as the location of the trial, the type of treatment, or the name of the drug.<EOS>
<BOS>Talk with your doctor about clinical trials that may be right for you.<EOS>
<BOS>General information about clinical trials is available from the NCI website.<EOS>
<BOS>The cause of most childhood brain tumors is not known.<EOS>
<BOS>Key Points Treatment options for pregnant women depend on the stage of the disease and the age of the unborn baby.<EOS>
<BOS>Three types of standard treatment are used: Surgery Radiation therapy Chemotherapy Ending the pregnancy does not seem to improve the mothers chance of survival.<EOS>
<BOS>Treatment for breast cancer may cause side effects.<EOS>
<BOS>Treatment options for pregnant women depend on the stage of the disease and the age of the unborn baby.<EOS>
<BOS>Three types of standard treatment are used: Surgery Most pregnant women with breast cancer have surgery to remove the breast.<EOS>
<BOS>Some of the lymph nodes under the arm may be removed and checked under a microscope for signs of cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Types of surgery to remove the cancer include: Modified radical mastectomy: Surgery to remove the whole breast that has cancer, many of the lymph nodes under the arm, the lining over the chest muscles, and sometimes, part of the chest wall muscles.<EOS>
<BOS>This type of surgery is most common in pregnant women.<EOS>
<BOS>Breastconserving surgery: Surgery to remove the cancer and some normal tissue around it, but not the breast itself.<EOS>
<BOS>Part of the chest wall lining may also be removed if the cancer is near it.<EOS>
<BOS>This type of surgery may also be called lumpectomy, partial mastectomy, segmental mastectomy, quadrantectomy, or breastsparing surgery.<EOS>
<BOS>Even if the doctor removes all of the cancer that can be seen at the time of surgery, the patient may be given radiation therapy or chemotherapy after surgery to try to kill any cancer cells that may be left.<EOS>
<BOS>For pregnant women with earlystage breast cancer, radiation therapy and hormone therapy are given after the baby is born.<EOS>
<BOS>Treatment given after surgery, to lower the risk that the cancer will come back, is called adjuvant therapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Radiation therapy Radiation therapy is a cancer treatment that uses highenergy xrays or other types of radiation to kill cancer cells or keep them from growing.<EOS>
<BOS>There are two types of radiation therapy: External radiation therapy uses a machine outside the body to send radiation toward the cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Internal radiation therapy uses a radioactive substance sealed in needles, seeds, wires, or catheters that are placed directly into or near the cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>The way the radiation therapy is given depends on the type and stage of the cancer being treated.<EOS>
<BOS>External radiation therapy is not given to pregnant women with early stage (stage I or II) breast cancer because it can harm the unborn baby.<EOS>
<BOS>For women with late stage (stage III or IV) breast cancer, radiation therapy is not given during the first 3 months of pregnancy and is delayed until after the baby is born, if possible.<EOS>
<BOS>Chemotherapy Chemotherapy is a cancer treatment that uses drugs to stop the growth of cancer cells, either by killing the cells or by stopping the cells from dividing.<EOS>
<BOS>When chemotherapy is taken by mouth or injected into a vein or muscle, the drugs enter the bloodstream and can reach cancer cells throughout the body (systemic chemotherapy).<EOS>
<BOS>When chemotherapy is placed directly into the cerebrospinal fluid, an organ, or a body cavity such as the abdomen, the drugs mainly affect cancer cells in those areas (regional chemotherapy).<EOS>
<BOS>The way the chemotherapy is given depends on the type and stage of the cancer being treated.<EOS>
<BOS>Chemotherapy is usually not given during the first 3 months of pregnancy.<EOS>
<BOS>Chemotherapy given after this time does not usually harm the unborn baby but may cause early labor and low birth weight.<EOS>
<BOS>See Drugs Approved for Breast Cancer for more information.<EOS>
<BOS>Ending the pregnancy does not seem to improve the mothers chance of survival.<EOS>
<BOS>Because ending the pregnancy is not likely to improve the mothers chance of survival, it is not usually a treatment option.<EOS>
<BOS>Treatment for breast cancer may cause side effects.<EOS>
<BOS>For information about side effects caused by treatment for cancer, see our Side Effects page.<EOS>
<BOS>Treatment Options by Stage Early Stage Breast Cancer (Stage I and Stage II) Treatment of earlystage breast cancer (stage I and stage II) may include the following: Modified radical mastectomy.<EOS>
<BOS>Breastconserving surgery followed by radiation therapy.<EOS>
<BOS>In pregnant women, radiation therapy is delayed until after the baby is born.<EOS>
<BOS>Modified radical mastectomy or breastconserving surgery during pregnancy followed by chemotherapy after the first 3 months of pregnancy.<EOS>
<BOS>Late Stage Breast Cancer (Stage III and Stage IV) Treatment of latestage breast cancer (stage III and stage IV) may include the following: Radiation therapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Chemotherapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Radiation therapy and chemotherapy should not be given during the first 3 months of pregnancy.<EOS>
<BOS>Certain factors affect prognosis (chance of recovery) and treatment options.<EOS>
<BOS>The prognosis (chance of recovery) depends on the following: Whether the patient has HPV infection of the oropharynx.<EOS>
<BOS>Whether the patient has a history of smoking cigarettes for ten or more pack years.<EOS>
<BOS>The stage of the cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>The number and size of lymph nodes with cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Oropharyngeal tumors related to HPV infection have a better prognosis and are less likely to recur than tumors not linked to HPV infection.<EOS>
<BOS>Treatment options depend on the following: The stage of the cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Keeping the patient's ability to speak and swallow as normal as possible.<EOS>
<BOS>The patient's general health.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients with oropharyngeal cancer have an increased risk of another cancer in the head or neck.<EOS>
<BOS>This risk is increased in patients who continue to smoke or drink alcohol after treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>See the PDQ summary Cigarette Smoking: Health Risks and How to Quit for more information.<EOS>
<BOS>Signs and symptoms of adult ALL include fever, feeling tired, and easy bruising or bleeding.<EOS>
<BOS>The early signs and symptoms of ALL may be like the flu or other common diseases.<EOS>
<BOS>Check with your doctor if you have any of the following: Weakness or feeling tired.<EOS>
<BOS>Fever or night sweats.<EOS>
<BOS>Easy bruising or bleeding.<EOS>
<BOS>Petechiae (flat, pinpoint spots under the skin, caused by bleeding).<EOS>
<BOS>Shortness of breath.<EOS>
<BOS>Weight loss or loss of appetite.<EOS>
<BOS>Pain in the bones or stomach.<EOS>
<BOS>Pain or feeling of fullness below the ribs.<EOS>
<BOS>Painless lumps in the neck, underarm, stomach, or groin.<EOS>
<BOS>Having many infections.<EOS>
<BOS>These and other signs and symptoms may be caused by adult acute lymphoblastic leukemia or by other conditions.<EOS>
<BOS>Signs of breast cancer include a lump or change in the breast.<EOS>
<BOS>These and other signs may be caused by breast cancer or by other conditions.<EOS>
<BOS>Check with your doctor if you have any of the following: A lump or thickening in or near the breast or in the underarm area.<EOS>
<BOS>A change in the size or shape of the breast.<EOS>
<BOS>A dimple or puckering in the skin of the breast.<EOS>
<BOS>A nipple turned inward into the breast.<EOS>
<BOS>Fluid, other than breast milk, from the nipple, especially if it's bloody.<EOS>
<BOS>Scaly, red, or swollen skin on the breast, nipple, or areola (the dark area of skin around the nipple).<EOS>
<BOS>Dimples in the breast that look like the skin of an orange, called peau dorange.<EOS>
<BOS>It may be difficult to detect (find) breast cancer early in pregnant or nursing women.<EOS>
<BOS>The breasts usually get larger, tender, or lumpy in women who are pregnant, nursing, or have just given birth.<EOS>
<BOS>This occurs because of normal hormone changes that take place during pregnancy.<EOS>
<BOS>These changes can make small lumps difficult to detect.<EOS>
<BOS>The breasts may also become denser.<EOS>
<BOS>It is more difficult to detect breast cancer in women with dense breasts using mammography.<EOS>
<BOS>Because these breast changes can delay diagnosis, breast cancer is often found at a later stage in these women.<EOS>
<BOS>Signs of childhood ALL include fever and bruising.<EOS>
<BOS>These and other signs and symptoms may be caused by childhood ALL or by other conditions.<EOS>
<BOS>Check with your child's doctor if your child has any of the following: Fever.<EOS>
<BOS>Easy bruising or bleeding.<EOS>
<BOS>Petechiae (flat, pinpoint, darkred spots under the skin caused by bleeding).<EOS>
<BOS>Bone or joint pain.<EOS>
<BOS>Painless lumps in the neck, underarm, stomach, or groin.<EOS>
<BOS>Pain or feeling of fullness below the ribs.<EOS>
<BOS>Weakness, feeling tired, or looking pale.<EOS>
<BOS>Loss of appetite.<EOS>
<BOS>Key Points Thymoma and thymic carcinoma are diseases in which malignant (cancer) cells form on the outside surface of the thymus.<EOS>
<BOS>Thymoma is linked with myasthenia gravis and other autoimmune diseases.<EOS>
<BOS>Signs and symptoms of thymoma and thymic carcinoma include a cough and chest pain.<EOS>
<BOS>Tests that examine the thymus are used to detect (find) thymoma or thymic carcinoma.<EOS>
<BOS>Thymoma and thymic carcinoma are usually diagnosed, staged, and treated during surgery.<EOS>
<BOS>Certain factors affect prognosis (chance of recovery) and treatment options.<EOS>
<BOS>Thymoma and thymic carcinoma are diseases in which malignant (cancer) cells form on the outside surface of the thymus.<EOS>
<BOS>The thymus, a small organ that lies in the upper chest under the breastbone, is part of the lymph system.<EOS>
<BOS>It makes white blood cells, called lymphocytes, that protect the body against infections.<EOS>
<BOS>There are different types of tumors of the thymus.<EOS>
<BOS>Thymomas and thymic carcinomas are rare tumors of the cells that are on the outside surface of the thymus.<EOS>
<BOS>The tumor cells in a thymoma look similar to the normal cells of the thymus, grow slowly, and rarely spread beyond the thymus.<EOS>
<BOS>On the other hand, the tumor cells in a thymic carcinoma look very different from the normal cells of the thymus, grow more quickly, and have usually spread to other parts of the body when the cancer is found.<EOS>
<BOS>Thymic carcinoma is more difficult to treat than thymoma.<EOS>
<BOS>For information on thymoma and thymic carcinoma in children, see the PDQ summary on Unusual Cancers of Childhood Treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Thymoma is linked with myasthenia gravis and other autoimmune diseases.<EOS>
<BOS>People with thymoma often have autoimmune diseases as well.<EOS>
<BOS>These diseases cause the immune system to attack healthy tissue and organs.<EOS>
<BOS>They include: Myasthenia gravis.<EOS>
<BOS>Acquired pure red cell aplasia.<EOS>
<BOS>Hypogammaglobulinemia.<EOS>
<BOS>Polymyositis.<EOS>
<BOS>Lupus erythematosus.<EOS>
<BOS>Rheumatoid arthritis.<EOS>
<BOS>Thyroiditis.<EOS>
<BOS>Sjgren syndrome.<EOS>
<BOS>Signs of Wilms tumor and other childhood kidney tumors include a lump in the abdomen and blood in the urine.<EOS>
<BOS>Sometimes childhood kidney tumors do not cause signs and symptoms and the parent finds a mass in the abdomen by chance or the mass is found during a wellchild health check up.<EOS>
<BOS>These and other signs and symptoms may be caused by kidney tumors or by other conditions.<EOS>
<BOS>Check with your child's doctor if your child has any of the following: A lump, swelling, or pain in the abdomen.<EOS>
<BOS>Blood in the urine.<EOS>
<BOS>High blood pressure (headache, feeling very tired, chest pain, or trouble seeing or breathing).<EOS>
<BOS>Hypercalcemia (loss of appetite, nausea and vomiting, weakness, or feeling very tired).<EOS>
<BOS>Fever for no known reason.<EOS>
<BOS>Loss of appetite.<EOS>
<BOS>Weight loss for no known reason.<EOS>
<BOS>Wilms tumor that has spread to the lungs or liver may cause the following signs and symptoms: Cough.<EOS>
<BOS>Blood in the sputum.<EOS>
<BOS>Trouble breathing.<EOS>
<BOS>Pain in the abdomen.<EOS>
<BOS>New types of treatment are being tested in clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>Information about clinical trials is available from the NCI website.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients may want to think about taking part in a clinical trial.<EOS>
<BOS>For some patients, taking part in a clinical trial may be the best treatment choice.<EOS>
<BOS>Clinical trials are part of the cancer research process.<EOS>
<BOS>Clinical trials are done to find out if new cancer treatments are safe and effective or better than the standard treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Many of today's standard treatments for cancer are based on earlier clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients who take part in a clinical trial may receive the standard treatment or be among the first to receive a new treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients who take part in clinical trials also help improve the way cancer will be treated in the future.<EOS>
<BOS>Even when clinical trials do not lead to effective new treatments, they often answer important questions and help move research forward.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients can enter clinical trials before, during, or after starting their cancer treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Some clinical trials only include patients who have not yet received treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Other trials test treatments for patients whose cancer has not gotten better.<EOS>
<BOS>There are also clinical trials that test new ways to stop cancer from recurring (coming back) or reduce the side effects of cancer treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Clinical trials are taking place in many parts of the country.<EOS>
<BOS>See the Treatment Options section that follows for links to current treatment clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>These have been retrieved from NCI's listing of clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>Retinoblastoma occurs in heritable and nonheritable forms.<EOS>
<BOS>A child is thought to have the heritable form of retinoblastoma when one of the following is true: There is a family history of retinoblastoma.<EOS>
<BOS>There is a certain mutation (change) in the RB1 gene.<EOS>
<BOS>The mutation in the RB1 gene may be passed from the parent to the child or it may occur in the egg or sperm before conception or soon after conception.<EOS>
<BOS>There is more than one tumor in the eye or there is a tumor in both eyes.<EOS>
<BOS>There is a tumor in one eye and the child is younger than 1 year.<EOS>
<BOS>After heritable retinoblastoma has been diagnosed and treated, new tumors may continue to form for a few years.<EOS>
<BOS>Regular eye exams to check for new tumors are usually done every 2 to 4 months for at least 28 months.<EOS>
<BOS>Nonheritable retinoblastoma is retinoblastoma that is not the heritable form.<EOS>
<BOS>Most cases of retinoblastoma are the nonheritable form.<EOS>
<BOS>Treatment for both forms of retinoblastoma should include genetic counseling.<EOS>
<BOS>Parents should receive genetic counseling (a discussion with a trained professional about the risk of genetic diseases) to discuss genetic testing to check for a mutation (change) in the RB1 gene.<EOS>
<BOS>Genetic counseling also includes a discussion of the risk of retinoblastoma for the child and the child's brothers or sisters.<EOS>
<BOS>Children with a family history of retinoblastoma should have eye exams to check for retinoblastoma.<EOS>
<BOS>A child with a family history of retinoblastoma should have regular eye exams beginning early in life to check for retinoblastoma, unless it is known that the child does not have the RB1 gene change.<EOS>
<BOS>Early diagnosis of retinoblastoma may mean the child will need less intense treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Brothers or sisters of a child with retinoblastoma should have regular eye exams by an ophthalmologist until age 3 to 5 years, unless it is known that the brother or sister does not have the RB1 gene change.<EOS>
<BOS>A child who has heritable retinoblastoma has an increased risk of trilateral retinoblastoma and other cancers.<EOS>
<BOS>A child with heritable retinoblastoma has an increased risk of a pineal tumor in the brain.<EOS>
<BOS>When retinoblastoma and a brain tumor occur at the same time, it is called trilateral retinoblastoma.<EOS>
<BOS>The brain tumor is usually diagnosed between 20 and 36 months of age.<EOS>
<BOS>Regular screening using MRI (magnetic resonance imaging) may be done for a child thought to have heritable retinoblastoma or for a child with retinoblastoma in one eye and a family history of the disease.<EOS>
<BOS>CT (computerized tomography) scans are usually not used for routine screening in order to avoid exposing the child to ionizing radiation.<EOS>
<BOS>Heritable retinoblastoma also increases the child's risk of other types of cancer such as lung cancer, bladder cancer, or melanoma in later years.<EOS>
<BOS>Regular followup exams are important.<EOS>
<BOS>The risk factors for childhood AML, childhood CML, JMML, and MDS are similar.<EOS>
<BOS>Anything that increases your risk of getting a disease is called a risk factor.<EOS>
<BOS>Having a risk factor does not mean that you will get cancer; not having risk factors doesnt mean that you will not get cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Talk with your childs doctor if you think your child may be at risk.<EOS>
<BOS>These and other factors may increase the risk of childhood AML, childhood CML, JMML, and MDS: Having a brother or sister, especially a twin, with leukemia.<EOS>
<BOS>Being Hispanic.<EOS>
<BOS>Being exposed to cigarette smoke or alcohol before birth.<EOS>
<BOS>Having a personal history of aplastic anemia.<EOS>
<BOS>Having a personal or family history of MDS.<EOS>
<BOS>Having a family history of AML.<EOS>
<BOS>Past treatment with chemotherapy or radiation therapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Being exposed to ionizing radiation or chemicals such as benzene.<EOS>
<BOS>Having certain genetic disorders, such as: Down syndrome.<EOS>
<BOS>Fanconi anemia.<EOS>
<BOS>Neurofibromatosis type 1.<EOS>
<BOS>Noonan syndrome.<EOS>
<BOS>ShwachmanDiamond syndrome.<EOS>
<BOS>Key Points Liver cancer is a disease in which malignant (cancer) cells form in the tissues of the liver.<EOS>
<BOS>Liver cancer is less common in the United States than in other parts of the world.<EOS>
<BOS>Having hepatitis or cirrhosis can increase the risk of developing liver cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Liver cancer is a disease in which malignant (cancer) cells form in the tissues of the liver.<EOS>
<BOS>The liver is one of the largest organs in the body.<EOS>
<BOS>It has four lobes and fills the upper right side of the abdomen inside the rib cage.<EOS>
<BOS>Three of the many important functions of the liver are: To filter harmful substances from the blood so they can be passed from the body in stools and urine.<EOS>
<BOS>To make bile to help digest fats from food.<EOS>
<BOS>To store glycogen (sugar), which the body uses for energy.<EOS>
<BOS>See the following PDQ summaries for more information about liver (hepatocellular) cancer: Liver (Hepatocellular) Cancer Prevention Adult Primary Liver Cancer Treatment Childhood Liver Cancer Treatment Liver cancer is less common in the United States than in other parts of the world.<EOS>
<BOS>Liver cancer is uncommon in the United States, but is the fourth most common cancer in the world.<EOS>
<BOS>In the United States, men, especially Chinese American men, have a greater risk of developing liver cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Key Points Childhood vascular tumors form from cells that make blood vessels or lymph vessels.<EOS>
<BOS>Tests are used to detect (find) and diagnose childhood vascular tumors.<EOS>
<BOS>Childhood vascular tumors may be classified into four groups.<EOS>
<BOS>Benign tumors Intermediate (locally aggressive) tumors Intermediate (rarely metastasizing) tumors Malignant tumors Childhood vascular tumors form from cells that make blood vessels or lymph vessels.<EOS>
<BOS>Vascular tumors can form from abnormal blood vessel or lymph vessel cells anywhere in the body.<EOS>
<BOS>They may be benign (not cancer) or malignant (cancer).<EOS>
<BOS>There are many types of vascular tumors.<EOS>
<BOS>The most common type of childhood vascular tumor is hemangioma, which is a benign tumor that usually goes away on its own.<EOS>
<BOS>Because malignant vascular tumors are rare in children, there is not a lot of information about what treatment works best.<EOS>
<BOS>Childhood vascular tumors may be classified into four groups.<EOS>
<BOS>Benign tumors Benign tumors are not cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>This summary has information about the following benign vascular tumors: Infantile hemangioma.<EOS>
<BOS>Congenital hemangioma.<EOS>
<BOS>Benign vascular tumors of the liver.<EOS>
<BOS>Spindle cell hemangioma.<EOS>
<BOS>Epithelioid hemangioma.<EOS>
<BOS>Pyogenic granuloma (lobular capillary hemangioma).<EOS>
<BOS>Angiofibroma.<EOS>
<BOS>Juvenile nasopharyngeal angiofibroma.<EOS>
<BOS>Intermediate (locally aggressive) tumors Intermediate tumors that are locally aggressive often spread to the area around the tumor.<EOS>
<BOS>This summary has information about the following locally aggressive vascular tumors: Kaposiform hemangioendothelioma and tufted angioma.<EOS>
<BOS>Intermediate (rarely metastasizing) tumors Intermediate (rarely metastasizing) tumors sometimes spread to other parts of the body.<EOS>
<BOS>This summary has information about the following vascular tumors that rarely metastasize: Retiform hemangioendothelioma.<EOS>
<BOS>Papillary intralymphatic angioendothelioma.<EOS>
<BOS>Composite hemangioendothelioma.<EOS>
<BOS>Kaposi sarcoma.<EOS>
<BOS>Malignant tumors Malignant tumors are cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>This summary has information about the following malignant vascular tumors: Epithelioid hemangioendothelioma.<EOS>
<BOS>Angiosarcoma of soft tissue.<EOS>
<BOS>Benign Tumors Infantile Hemangioma Infantile hemangiomas are the most common type of benign vascular tumor in children.<EOS>
<BOS>An infantile hemangioma may also be called a "strawberry mark.<EOS>
<BOS>" Immature cells that are meant to form blood vessels form a tumor instead.<EOS>
<BOS>These tumors are not usually seen at birth but appear when the infant is 3 to 6 weeks old.<EOS>
<BOS>Most hemangiomas get bigger for about 5 months, then stop growing and slowly fade away completely during the next several years.<EOS>
<BOS>It is rare for them to come back.<EOS>
<BOS>Hemangiomas may be on the skin, in the tissue below the skin, and/or in an organ.<EOS>
<BOS>They are usually on the head and neck but can be anywhere on or in the body.<EOS>
