<BOS>Hemangiomas may appear as a single lesion, one or more lesions spread over a larger area of the body, or multiple lesions in more than one part of the body.<EOS>
<BOS>Lesions that are spread over a larger area of the body or multiple lesions are more likely to cause problems.<EOS>
<BOS>Risk Factors Anything that increases your risk of getting a disease is called a risk factor.<EOS>
<BOS>Having a risk factor does not mean that you will get the disease; not having risk factors doesnt mean that you will not get the disease.<EOS>
<BOS>Talk with your child's doctor if you think your child may be at risk.<EOS>
<BOS>Infantile hemangiomas are more common in the following: Girls.<EOS>
<BOS>Whites.<EOS>
<BOS>Premature babies.<EOS>
<BOS>Twins, triplets, or other multiple births.<EOS>
<BOS>Babies of mothers who are older at time of the pregnancy or who have problems with the placenta during pregnancy.<EOS>
<BOS>Other risk factors for infantile hemangiomas include the following: Having certain syndromes.<EOS>
<BOS>PHACE syndrome: A syndrome in which the hemangioma spreads across a large area of the body (usually the head or face).<EOS>
<BOS>Other health problems involving the large blood vessels, heart, eyes, and/or brain may also occur.<EOS>
<BOS>LUMBAR/PELVIS/SACRAL syndrome: A syndrome in which the hemangioma spreads across a large area of the lower back.<EOS>
<BOS>Other health problems that affect the urinary system, genitals, rectum, anus, brain, spinal cord, and nerve function may also occur.<EOS>
<BOS>Having more than one hemangioma or an airway hemangioma increases the risk of having other health problems.<EOS>
<BOS>Multiple hemangiomas: Having more than five hemangiomas on the skin is a sign that there may be hemangiomas in an organ, most commonly the liver.<EOS>
<BOS>Heart, muscle, and thyroid gland problems can also occur.<EOS>
<BOS>Airway hemangiomas: Hemangiomas in the airway usually occur along with a large, beardshaped area of hemangioma on the face (from the ears, around the mouth, lower chin, and front of neck).<EOS>
<BOS>It is important for airway hemangiomas to be treated before the child has trouble breathing.<EOS>
<BOS>Signs and Symptoms Infantile hemangiomas may cause any of the following signs and symptoms.<EOS>
<BOS>Check with your childs doctor if your child has any of the following: Skin lesions: An area of spidery veins or lightened or discolored skin may appear before the hemangioma does.<EOS>
<BOS>Hemangiomas occur as firm, warm, bright redblue lesions on the skin.<EOS>
<BOS>Lesions that form ulcers are also painful.<EOS>
<BOS>Later, as the hemangiomas go away, they begin fading in the center before flattening and losing color.<EOS>
<BOS>Lesions below the skin: Lesions that grow under the skin in the fat may appear blue or purple.<EOS>
<BOS>If the lesions are deep enough under the skin surface, they may not be seen.<EOS>
<BOS>Lesions in an organ: There may be no signs that hemangiomas have formed on an organ.<EOS>
<BOS>Although most infantile hemangiomas are nothing to worry about, if your child develops any lumps or red or blue marks on the skin check with your child's doctor.<EOS>
<BOS>He or she can recommend a specialist if needed.<EOS>
<BOS>Diagnostic Tests A physical exam and history are usually all that are needed to diagnose infantile hemangiomas.<EOS>
<BOS>If there is something about the tumor that looks unusual, a biopsy may be done.<EOS>
<BOS>If the hemangioma is deeper inside the body with no change to the skin, or the lesions are spread across a large area of the body, an ultrasound or MRI may be done.<EOS>
<BOS>See the General Information section for a description of these tests and procedures.<EOS>
<BOS>If the hemangiomas are part of a syndrome, more tests may be done such as an echocardiogram, magnetic resonance angiogram, and eye exam.<EOS>
<BOS>Treatment Most hemangiomas fade and shrink without treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>If the hemangioma is large or causing other health problems, treatment may include the following: Propranolol or other betablocker therapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Steroid therapy, before betablocker therapy is begun or when betablockers cannot be used.<EOS>
<BOS>Pulsed dye laser surgery, for hemangiomas that have ulcers or have not gone away.<EOS>
<BOS>Surgery (excision) for hemangiomas that have ulcers, cause vision problems, or have not gone away.<EOS>
<BOS>Topical betablocker therapy for hemangiomas that are in one area of the skin.<EOS>
<BOS>Combined therapy, such as propranolol and steroid therapy or propranolol and topical betablocker therapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Congenital Hemangioma Congenital hemangioma is a benign vascular tumor that begins forming before birth and is fully formed when the baby is born.<EOS>
<BOS>They're usually on the skin but can be in another organ.<EOS>
<BOS>There are three types of congenital hemangiomas: Rapidly Involuting Congenital Hemangioma: These tumors go away on their own 12 to 15 months after birth.<EOS>
<BOS>They can form ulcers, bleed, and cause temporary heart and blood clotting problems.<EOS>
<BOS>The skin may look a little different even after the hemangiomas go away.<EOS>
<BOS>Partial Involuting Congenital Hemangioma: These tumors do not go away completely.<EOS>
<BOS>NonInvoluting Congenital Hemangioma: These tumors never go away on their own.<EOS>
<BOS>Diagnostic Tests See the General Information section for a description of tests and procedures used to diagnose congenital hemangioma.<EOS>
<BOS>Treatment Treatment of rapidly involuting congenital hemangioma and partial involuting congenital hemangioma may include the following: Observation only.<EOS>
<BOS>Treatment of noninvoluting congenital hemangioma may include the following: Surgery to remove the tumor depending on where it is and whether it is causing symptoms.<EOS>
<BOS>Benign Vascular Tumors of the Liver Benign vascular tumors of the liver may be focal (a single lesion in one area of the liver), multifocal (multiple lesions in one area of the liver), or diffuse (multiple lesions in more than one area of the liver).<EOS>
<BOS>The liver has many functions, including filtering blood and making proteins needed for blood clotting.<EOS>
<BOS>Sometimes, blood that normally flows through the liver is blocked or slowed by the tumor.<EOS>
<BOS>This sends blood directly to the heart without going through the liver and is called a liver shunt.<EOS>
<BOS>This can cause heart failure and problems with blood clotting.<EOS>
<BOS>Focal Tumors Focal tumors are usually rapidly involuting congenital hemangiomas or noninvoluting congenital hemangiomas.<EOS>
<BOS>Diagnostic Tests See the General Information section for a description of tests and procedures used to diagnose focal benign vascular tumors.<EOS>
<BOS>Treatment Treatment of focal tumors of the liver depends on whether symptoms occur and may include the following: Observation.<EOS>
<BOS>Drugs to manage symptoms, including heart failure and blood clotting problems.<EOS>
<BOS>Embolization of the liver to manage symptoms, including heart failure.<EOS>
<BOS>Multifocal and Diffuse Tumors Multifocal and diffuse tumors of the liver are usually infantile hemangiomas.<EOS>
<BOS>Diffuse tumors of the liver can cause serious effects, including problems with the thyroid gland and heart.<EOS>
<BOS>The liver can enlarge, press on other organs, and cause more symptoms.<EOS>
<BOS>Diagnostic Tests See the General Information section for a description of tests and procedures used to diagnose multifocal or diffuse benign vascular tumors.<EOS>
<BOS>Treatment Treatment of multifocal and diffuse liver tumors may include the following: Observation for multifocal tumors of the liver that do not cause symptoms.<EOS>
<BOS>Betablocker therapy (propranolol).<EOS>
<BOS>Chemotherapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Steroid therapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Total hepatectomy and liver transplant, when the tumors do not respond to drug therapy.<EOS>
<BOS>This is only done when the tumors have spread widely in the liver and more than one organ has failed.<EOS>
<BOS>If a vascular tumor of the liver does not respond to standard treatments, a biopsy may be done to see if the tumor has become malignant.<EOS>
<BOS>Spindle Cell Hemangioma Spindle cell hemangiomas contain cells called spindle cells.<EOS>
<BOS>Under a microscope, spindle cells look long and slender.<EOS>
<BOS>Risk Factors Anything that increases your risk of getting a disease is called a risk factor.<EOS>
<BOS>Having a risk factor does not mean that you will get the disease; not having risk factors doesnt mean that you will not get the disease.<EOS>
<BOS>Talk with your child's doctor if you think your child may be at risk.<EOS>
<BOS>Spindle cell hemangiomas are likely to occur in children with the following syndromes: Maffucci syndrome, which affects cartilage and skin.<EOS>
<BOS>KlippelTrenaunay syndrome, which affects blood vessels, soft tissues, and bones.<EOS>
<BOS>Signs Spindle cell hemangiomas appear on or under the skin.<EOS>
<BOS>They are painful redbrown or bluish lesions that usually appear on the arms or legs.<EOS>
<BOS>They can begin as one lesion and develop into more lesions over years.<EOS>
<BOS>Diagnostic Tests See the General Information section for a description of tests and procedures used to diagnose spindle cell hemangioma.<EOS>
<BOS>Treatment There is no standard treatment for spindle cell hemangiomas.<EOS>
<BOS>Treatment may include the following: Surgery to remove the tumor.<EOS>
<BOS>Spindle cell hemangiomas may come back after surgery.<EOS>
<BOS>Epithelioid Hemangioma Epithelioid hemangiomas usually form on or in the skin, especially the head, but can occur in other areas, such as bone.<EOS>
<BOS>Signs and Symptoms Epithelioid hemangiomas are sometimes caused by injury.<EOS>
<BOS>On the skin, they may appear as firm pink to red bumps and may be itchy.<EOS>
<BOS>Epithelioid hemangioma of the bone may cause swelling, pain, and weakened bone in the affected area.<EOS>
<BOS>Diagnostic Tests See the General Information section for a description of tests and procedures used to diagnose epithelioid hemangioma.<EOS>
<BOS>Treatment There is no standard treatment for epithelioid hemangiomas.<EOS>
<BOS>Treatment may include the following: Surgery (curettage or resection).<EOS>
<BOS>Sclerotherapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Radiation therapy in rare cases.<EOS>
<BOS>Epithelioid hemangiomas often come back after treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Pyogenic Granuloma Pyogenic granuloma is also called lobular capillary hemangioma.<EOS>
<BOS>It is most common in older children and young adults but may occur at any age.<EOS>
<BOS>The lesions are sometimes caused by injury or from the use of certain medicines, including birth control pills and retinoids.<EOS>
<BOS>They may also form for no known reason inside capillaries (the smallest blood vessels) or other places on the body.<EOS>
<BOS>Usually there is only one lesion, but sometimes multiple lesions occur in the same area or the lesions may spread to other areas of the body.<EOS>
<BOS>Signs Pyogenic granulomas are raised, bright red lesions that may be small or large and smooth or bumpy.<EOS>
<BOS>They grow quickly over weeks to months and may bleed a lot.<EOS>
<BOS>Diagnostic Tests See the General Information section for a description of tests and procedures used to diagnose pyogenic granuloma.<EOS>
<BOS>Treatment Some pyogenic granulomas go away without treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Other pyogenic granulomas need treatment that may include the following: Surgery (excision or curettage) to remove the lesion.<EOS>
<BOS>Laser photocoagulation.<EOS>
<BOS>Pyogenic granulomas often come back after treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Angiofibroma Angiofibromas are rare.<EOS>
<BOS>They are benign skin lesions that usually occur with a condition called tuberous sclerosis (an inherited disorder that causes skin lesions, seizures, and mental disabilities).<EOS>
<BOS>Signs Angiofibromas appear as red bumps on the face.<EOS>
<BOS>Diagnostic Tests See the General Information section for a description of tests and procedures used to diagnose angiofibroma.<EOS>
<BOS>Treatment Treatment of angiofibromas may include the following: Surgery (excision) to remove the tumor.<EOS>
<BOS>Laser therapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Targeted therapy (sirolimus).<EOS>
<BOS>Juvenile Nasopharyngeal Angiofibroma Juvenile nasopharyngeal angiofibromas are benign tumors but they can invade nearby tissue.<EOS>
<BOS>They begin in the nasal cavity and may spread to the nasopharynx, the paranasal sinuses, the bone around the eyes, and sometimes to the brain.<EOS>
<BOS>Diagnostic Tests See the General Information section for a description of tests and procedures used to diagnose juvenile nasopharyngeal angiofibroma.<EOS>
<BOS>Treatment Treatment of juvenile nasopharyngeal angiofibromas may include the following: Surgery (excision) to remove the tumor.<EOS>
<BOS>Radiation therapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Chemotherapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Immunotherapy (interferon).<EOS>
<BOS>Targeted therapy (sirolimus).<EOS>
<BOS>Intermediate Tumors that Spread Locally Kaposiform Hemangioendothelioma and Tufted Angioma Kaposiform hemangioendotheliomas and tufted angiomas are blood vessel tumors that occur in infants or during early childhood.<EOS>
<BOS>These tumors can cause KasabachMerritt phenomenon, a condition in which the blood is not able to clot and serious bleeding may occur.<EOS>
<BOS>In KasabachMerritt phenomenon the tumor traps and destroys platelets (bloodclotting cells).<EOS>
<BOS>Then there aren't enough platelets in the blood when needed to stop bleeding.<EOS>
<BOS>This type of vascular tumor is not related to Kaposi sarcoma.<EOS>
<BOS>Signs and Symptoms Kaposiform hemangioendotheliomas and tufted angiomas usually occur on the skin of the arms and legs, but may also form in deeper tissues, such as muscle or bone.<EOS>
<BOS>Signs and symptoms may include the following: Firm, painful areas of skin that look bruised.<EOS>
<BOS>Purple or brownishred areas of skin.<EOS>
<BOS>Easy bruising.<EOS>
<BOS>Bleeding more than the usual amount from mucous membranes, wounds, and other tissues.<EOS>
<BOS>Anemia (weakness, feeling tired, or looking pale).<EOS>
<BOS>Diagnostic Tests See the General Information section for a description of tests and procedures used to diagnose kaposiform hemangioendothelioma.<EOS>
<BOS>If a physical exam and MRI clearly show the tumor is a kaposiform hemangioendothelioma or a tufted angioma, a biopsy may not be needed.<EOS>
<BOS>A biopsy is not always done because serious bleeding can occur.<EOS>
<BOS>Treatment Treatment of kaposiform hemangioendotheliomas and tufted angiomas depends on the child's symptoms.<EOS>
<BOS>Infection, delay in treatment, and surgery can cause bleeding that is lifethreatening.<EOS>
<BOS>Kaposiform hemangioendotheliomas and tufted angiomas are best treated by a vascular anomaly specialist.<EOS>
<BOS>Treatment and supportive care to manage bleeding may include the following: Steroid therapy which may be followed by chemotherapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Nonsteroidal antiinflammatory drugs (NSAID), such as aspirin.<EOS>
<BOS>Immunotherapy (interferon).<EOS>
<BOS>Antifibrinolytic therapy to improve blood clotting.<EOS>
<BOS>Chemotherapy with one or more anticancer drugs.<EOS>
<BOS>Betablocker therapy (propranolol).<EOS>
<BOS>Surgery (excision) to remove the tumor, with or without embolization.<EOS>
<BOS>Targeted therapy (sirolimus).<EOS>
<BOS>A clinical trial of targeted therapy (sirolimus) and steroid therapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Even with treatment, these tumors do not fully go away and can come back.<EOS>
<BOS>Longterm effects include chronic pain, heart failure, bone problems, and lymphedema (the build up of lymph fluid in tissues).<EOS>
<BOS>Intermediate Tumors that Rarely Spread Retiform Hemangioendothelioma Retiform hemangioendotheliomas are slow growing, flat tumors that occur in young adults and sometimes children.<EOS>
<BOS>These tumors usually occur on or under the skin of the arms, legs, and trunk.<EOS>
<BOS>These tumors often come back after treatment, but they usually do not spread to other parts of the body.<EOS>
<BOS>Diagnostic Tests See the General Information section for a description of tests and procedures used to diagnose retiform hemangioendothelioma.<EOS>
<BOS>Treatment Treatment of retiform hemangioendotheliomas may include the following: Surgery (excision) to remove the tumor.<EOS>
<BOS>Follow up will include monitoring to see if the tumor comes back.<EOS>
<BOS>Radiation therapy and chemotherapy when surgery cannot be done or when the tumor has come back.<EOS>
<BOS>Papillary Intralymphatic Angioendothelioma Papillary intralymphatic angioendotheliomas are also called Dabska tumors.<EOS>
<BOS>These tumors form in or under the skin anywhere on the body.<EOS>
<BOS>The tumors contain channels that look like lymph vessels.<EOS>
<BOS>Lymph nodes are sometimes affected.<EOS>
<BOS>Signs Papillary intralymphatic angioendotheliomas may appear as firm, raised, purplish bumps, which may be small or large.<EOS>
<BOS>These tumors grow slowly over time.<EOS>
<BOS>Diagnostic Tests See the General Information section for a description of tests and procedures used to diagnose papillary intralymphatic angioendothelioma.<EOS>
<BOS>Treatment Treatment of papillary intralymphatic angioendotheliomas may include the following: Surgery (excision) to remove the tumor.<EOS>
<BOS>Composite Hemangioendothelioma Composite hemangioendotheliomas have features of both benign and malignant vascular tumors.<EOS>
<BOS>These tumors usually occur on or under the skin on the arms or legs.<EOS>
<BOS>They may also occur on the head, neck, or chest.<EOS>
<BOS>Composite hemangioendotheliomas are not likely to metastasize (spread) but they may come back in the same place.<EOS>
<BOS>When the tumors metastasize, they usually spread to nearby lymph nodes.<EOS>
<BOS>Diagnostic Tests See the General Information section for a description of tests and procedures used to diagnose composite hemangioendothelioma and find out whether the tumor has spread.<EOS>
<BOS>Treatment Treatment of composite hemangioendotheliomas may include the following: Surgery to remove the tumor.<EOS>
<BOS>Radiation therapy and chemotherapy for tumors that have spread.<EOS>
<BOS>Kaposi Sarcoma Kaposi sarcoma is a cancer that causes lesions to grow in the skin; the mucous membranes lining the mouth, nose, and throat; lymph nodes; or other organs.<EOS>
<BOS>It is caused by the Kaposi sarcoma herpes virus (KSHV).<EOS>
<BOS>In the United States, it usually occurs in people who have a weak immune system caused by AIDS or by drugs used in organ transplants.<EOS>
<BOS>It is very rare in children and can be caused by HIV infection and rare immune system disorders.<EOS>
<BOS>Signs Signs in children may include the following: Lesions in the skin, mouth, or throat.<EOS>
<BOS>Skin lesions are red, purple, or brown and change from flat, to raised, to scaly areas called plaques, to nodules.<EOS>
<BOS>Swollen lymph nodes.<EOS>
<BOS>Diagnostic Tests See the General Information section for a description of tests and procedures used to diagnose Kaposi sarcoma.<EOS>
<BOS>Treatment Treatment of Kaposi sarcoma may include the following: Chemotherapy.<EOS>
<BOS>See the PDQ summary on Kaposi Sarcoma Treatment for information about Kaposi sarcoma in adults.<EOS>
<BOS>Malignant Tumors Epithelioid Hemangioendothelioma Epithelioid hemangioendotheliomas can occur in children, but are most common in adults between 30 and 50 years of age.<EOS>
<BOS>They usually occur in the liver, lung, or in bone.<EOS>
<BOS>They may be either fast growing or slow growing.<EOS>
<BOS>In about a third of cases, the tumor spreads to other parts of the body very quickly.<EOS>
<BOS>Signs and Symptoms Signs and symptoms depend on where the tumor is: On the skin, the tumors can be raised and rounded or flat, redbrown patches that feel warm.<EOS>
<BOS>In the lung, there may be no early symptoms.<EOS>
<BOS>Signs and symptoms that occur may include: Chest pain.<EOS>
<BOS>Spitting up blood.<EOS>
<BOS>Anemia (weakness, feeling tired, or looking pale).<EOS>
<BOS>Trouble breathing (from scarred lung tissue).<EOS>
<BOS>In bone, the tumors can cause breaks.<EOS>
<BOS>Diagnostic Tests Epithelioid hemangioendotheliomas in the liver are found with CT scans and MRI scans.<EOS>
<BOS>See the General Information section for a description of these tests and procedures used to diagnose epithelioid hemangioendothelioma and find out whether the tumor has spread.<EOS>
<BOS>Xrays may also be done.<EOS>
<BOS>Treatment Treatment of slowgrowing epithelioid hemangioendotheliomas includes the following: Observation.<EOS>
<BOS>Treatment of fastgrowing epithelioid hemangioendotheliomas may include the following: Surgery to remove the tumor when possible.<EOS>
<BOS>Immunotherapy (interferon) and targeted therapy (thalidomide, sorafenib, pazopanib, sirolimus) for tumors that are likely to spread.<EOS>
<BOS>Chemotherapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Total hepatectomy and liver transplant when the tumor is in the liver.<EOS>
<BOS>Angiosarcoma of the Soft Tissue Angiosarcomas are fastgrowing tumors that form in blood vessels or lymph vessels in any part of the body, usually in soft tissue.<EOS>
<BOS>Most angiosarcomas are in or near the skin.<EOS>
<BOS>Those in deeper soft tissue can form in the liver, spleen, and lung.<EOS>
<BOS>These tumors are very rare in children.<EOS>
<BOS>Children sometimes have more than one tumor in the skin and/or liver.<EOS>
<BOS>Risk Factors Anything that increases your risk of getting a disease is called a risk factor.<EOS>
<BOS>Having a risk factor does not mean that you will get the disease; not having risk factors doesnt mean that you will not get the disease.<EOS>
<BOS>Talk with your child's doctor if you think your child may be at risk.<EOS>
<BOS>Risk factors for angiosarcomas include the following: Being exposed to radiation.<EOS>
<BOS>Chronic (longterm) lymphedema, a condition in which extra lymph fluid builds up in tissues and causes swelling.<EOS>
<BOS>Having a benign vascular tumor.<EOS>
<BOS>A benign tumor, such as a hemangioma, may become an angiosarcoma but this rare.<EOS>
<BOS>Signs Signs of angiosarcoma depend on where the tumor is and may include the following: Red patches on the skin that bleed easily.<EOS>
<BOS>Purple tumors.<EOS>
<BOS>Diagnostic Tests See the General Information section for a description of tests and procedures used to diagnose angiosarcoma and find out whether the tumor has spread.<EOS>
<BOS>Treatment Treatment of angiosarcoma may include the following: Surgery to completely remove the tumor.<EOS>
<BOS>A combination of surgery, chemotherapy, and radiation therapy for angiosarcomas that have spread.<EOS>
<BOS>Targeted therapy (bevacizumab) and chemotherapy for angiosarcomas that began as infantile hemangiomas.<EOS>
<BOS>A clinical trial of targeted therapy, radiation therapy, and surgery with or without chemotherapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Tests or procedures that examine the skin are used to detect (find) and diagnose nonmelanoma skin cancer and actinic keratosis.<EOS>
<BOS>The following procedures may be used: Skin exam: A doctor or nurse checks the skin for bumps or spots that look abnormal in color, size, shape, or texture.<EOS>
<BOS>Skin biopsy : All or part of the abnormallooking growth is cut from the skin and viewed under a microscope by a pathologist to check for signs of cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>There are four main types of skin biopsies: Shave biopsy : A sterile razor blade is used to shaveoff the abnormallooking growth.<EOS>
<BOS>Punch biopsy : A special instrument called a punch or a trephine is used to remove a circle of tissue from the abnormallooking growth.<EOS>
<BOS>Incisional biopsy : A scalpel is used to remove part of a growth.<EOS>
<BOS>Excisional biopsy : A scalpel is used to remove the entire growth.<EOS>
<BOS>Some gastrointestinal carcinoid tumors have no signs or symptoms in the early stages.<EOS>
<BOS>Signs and symptoms may be caused by the growth of the tumor and/or the hormones the tumor makes.<EOS>
<BOS>Some tumors, especially tumors of the stomach or appendix, may not cause signs or symptoms.<EOS>
<BOS>Carcinoid tumors are often found during tests or treatments for other conditions.<EOS>
<BOS>Carcinoid tumors in the small intestine (duodenum, jejunum, and ileum), colon, and rectum sometimes cause signs or symptoms as they grow or because of the hormones they make.<EOS>
<BOS>Other conditions may cause the same signs or symptoms.<EOS>
<BOS>Check with your doctor if you have any of the following: Duodenum Signs and symptoms of GI carcinoid tumors in the duodenum (first part of the small intestine, that connects to the stomach) may include the following: Abdominal pain.<EOS>
<BOS>Constipation.<EOS>
<BOS>Diarrhea.<EOS>
<BOS>Change in stool color.<EOS>
<BOS>Nausea.<EOS>
<BOS>Vomiting.<EOS>
<BOS>Jaundice (yellowing of the skin and whites of the eyes).<EOS>
<BOS>Heartburn.<EOS>
<BOS>Jejunum and ileum Signs and symptoms of GI carcinoid tumors in the jejunum (middle part of the small intestine) and ileum (last part of the small intestine, that connects to the colon) may include the following: Abdominal pain.<EOS>
<BOS>Weight loss for no known reason.<EOS>
<BOS>Feeling very tired.<EOS>
<BOS>Feeling bloated Diarrhea.<EOS>
<BOS>Nausea.<EOS>
<BOS>Vomiting.<EOS>
<BOS>Colon Signs and symptoms of GI carcinoid tumors in the colon may include the following: Abdominal pain.<EOS>
<BOS>Weight loss for no known reason.<EOS>
<BOS>Rectum Signs and symptoms of GI carcinoid tumors in the rectum may include the following: Blood in the stool.<EOS>
<BOS>Pain in the rectum.<EOS>
<BOS>Constipation.<EOS>
<BOS>Signs of AIDSrelated lymphoma include weight loss, fever, and night sweats.<EOS>
<BOS>These and other signs and symptoms may be caused by AIDSrelated lymphoma or by other conditions.<EOS>
<BOS>Check with your doctor if you have any of the following: Weight loss or fever for no known reason.<EOS>
<BOS>Night sweats.<EOS>
<BOS>Painless, swollen lymph nodes in the neck, chest, underarm, or groin.<EOS>
<BOS>A feeling of fullness below the ribs.<EOS>
<BOS>Being infected with the human papillomavirus (HPV) increases the risk of developing anal cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Risk factors include the following: Being infected with human papillomavirus (HPV).<EOS>
<BOS>Having many sexual partners.<EOS>
<BOS>Having receptive anal intercourse (anal sex).<EOS>
<BOS>Being older than 50 years.<EOS>
<BOS>Frequent anal redness, swelling, and soreness.<EOS>
<BOS>Having anal fistulas (abnormal openings).<EOS>
<BOS>Smoking cigarettes.<EOS>
<BOS>New types of treatment are being tested in clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>Information about clinical trials is available from the NCI website.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients may want to think about taking part in a clinical trial.<EOS>
<BOS>For some patients, taking part in a clinical trial may be the best treatment choice.<EOS>
<BOS>Clinical trials are part of the cancer research process.<EOS>
<BOS>Clinical trials are done to find out if new cancer treatments are safe and effective or better than the standard treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Many of today's standard treatments for cancer are based on earlier clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients who take part in a clinical trial may receive the standard treatment or be among the first to receive a new treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients who take part in clinical trials also help improve the way cancer will be treated in the future.<EOS>
<BOS>Even when clinical trials do not lead to effective new treatments, they often answer important questions and help move research forward.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients can enter clinical trials before, during, or after starting their cancer treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Some clinical trials only include patients who have not yet received treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Other trials test treatments for patients whose cancer has not gotten better.<EOS>
<BOS>There are also clinical trials that test new ways to stop cancer from recurring (coming back) or reduce the side effects of cancer treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Clinical trials are taking place in many parts of the country.<EOS>
<BOS>See the Treatment Options section that follows for links to current treatment clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>These have been retrieved from NCI's listing of clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>The signs and symptoms of atypical teratoid/rhabdoid tumor are not the same in every patient.<EOS>
<BOS>Signs and symptoms depend on the following: The child's age.<EOS>
<BOS>Where the tumor has formed.<EOS>
<BOS>Because atypical teratoid/rhabdoid tumor is fast growing, signs and symptoms may develop quickly and get worse over a period of days or weeks.<EOS>
<BOS>Signs and symptoms may be caused by AT/RT or by other conditions.<EOS>
<BOS>Check with your child's doctor if your child has any of the following: Morning headache or headache that goes away after vomiting.<EOS>
<BOS>Nausea and vomiting.<EOS>
<BOS>Unusual sleepiness or change in activity level.<EOS>
<BOS>Loss of balance, lack of coordination, or trouble walking.<EOS>
<BOS>Increase in head size (in infants).<EOS>
<BOS>Signs and symptoms of endometrial cancer include unusual vaginal bleeding or pain in the pelvis.<EOS>
<BOS>These and other signs and symptoms may be caused by endometrial cancer or by other conditions.<EOS>
<BOS>Check with your doctor if you have any of the following: Vaginal bleeding or discharge not related to menstruation (periods).<EOS>
<BOS>Vaginal bleeding after menopause.<EOS>
<BOS>Difficult or painful urination.<EOS>
<BOS>Pain during sexual intercourse.<EOS>
<BOS>Pain in the pelvic area.<EOS>
<BOS>Key Points After urethral cancer has been diagnosed, tests are done to find out if cancer cells have spread within the urethra or to other parts of the body.<EOS>
<BOS>There are three ways that cancer spreads in the body.<EOS>
<BOS>Cancer may spread from where it began to other parts of the body.<EOS>
<BOS>Urethral cancer is staged and treated based on the part of the urethra that is affected.<EOS>
<BOS>Distal urethral cancer Proximal urethral cancer Bladder and/or prostate cancer may occur at the same time as urethral cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>After urethral cancer has been diagnosed, tests are done to find out if cancer cells have spread within the urethra or to other parts of the body.<EOS>
<BOS>The process used to find out if cancer has spread within the urethra or to other parts of the body is called staging.<EOS>
<BOS>The information gathered from the staging process determines the stage of the disease.<EOS>
<BOS>It is important to know the stage in order to plan treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>The following procedures may be used in the staging process: Chest xray : An xray of the organs and bones inside the chest.<EOS>
<BOS>An xray is a type of energy beam that can go through the body and onto film, making a picture of areas inside the body.<EOS>
<BOS>CT scan (CAT scan) of the pelvis and abdomen : A procedure that makes a series of detailed pictures of the pelvis and abdomen, taken from different angles.<EOS>
<BOS>The pictures are made by a computer linked to an xray machine.<EOS>
<BOS>A dye may be injected into a vein or swallowed to help the organs or tissues show up more clearly.<EOS>
<BOS>This procedure is also called computed tomography, computerized tomography, or computerized axial tomography.<EOS>
<BOS>MRI (magnetic resonance imaging): A procedure that uses a magnet, radio waves, and a computer to make a series of detailed pictures of the urethra, nearby lymph nodes, and other soft tissue and bones in the pelvis.<EOS>
<BOS>A substance called gadolinium is injected into the patient through a vein.<EOS>
<BOS>The gadolinium collects around the cancer cells so they show up brighter in the picture.<EOS>
<BOS>This procedure is also called nuclear magnetic resonance imaging (NMRI).<EOS>
<BOS>Urethrography: A series of xrays of the urethra.<EOS>
<BOS>An xray is a type of energy beam that can go through the body and onto film, making a picture of areas inside the body.<EOS>
<BOS>A dye is injected through the urethra into the bladder.<EOS>
<BOS>The dye coats the bladder and urethra and xrays are taken to see if the urethra is blocked and if cancer has spread to nearby tissue.<EOS>
<BOS>There are three ways that cancer spreads in the body.<EOS>
<BOS>Cancer can spread through tissue, the lymph system, and the blood: Tissue.<EOS>
<BOS>The cancer spreads from where it began by growing into nearby areas.<EOS>
<BOS>Lymph system.<EOS>
<BOS>The cancer spreads from where it began by getting into the lymph system.<EOS>
<BOS>The cancer travels through the lymph vessels to other parts of the body.<EOS>
<BOS>Blood.<EOS>
<BOS>The cancer spreads from where it began by getting into the blood.<EOS>
<BOS>The cancer travels through the blood vessels to other parts of the body.<EOS>
<BOS>Cancer may spread from where it began to other parts of the body.<EOS>
<BOS>When cancer spreads to another part of the body, it is called metastasis.<EOS>
<BOS>Cancer cells break away from where they began (the primary tumor) and travel through the lymph system or blood.<EOS>
<BOS>Lymph system.<EOS>
<BOS>The cancer gets into the lymph system, travels through the lymph vessels, and forms a tumor (metastatic tumor) in another part of the body.<EOS>
<BOS>Blood.<EOS>
<BOS>The cancer gets into the blood, travels through the blood vessels, and forms a tumor (metastatic tumor) in another part of the body.<EOS>
<BOS>The metastatic tumor is the same type of cancer as the primary tumor.<EOS>
<BOS>For example, if urethral cancer spreads to the lung, the cancer cells in the lung are actually urethral cancer cells.<EOS>
<BOS>The disease is metastatic urethral cancer, not lung cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Urethral cancer is staged and treated based on the part of the urethra that is affected.<EOS>
<BOS>Urethral cancer is staged and treated based on the part of the urethra that is affected and how deeply the tumor has spread into tissue around the urethra.<EOS>
<BOS>Urethral cancer can be described as distal or proximal.<EOS>
<BOS>Distal urethral cancer In distal urethral cancer, the cancer usually has not spread deeply into the tissue.<EOS>
<BOS>In women, the part of the urethra that is closest to the outside of the body (about inch) is affected.<EOS>
<BOS>In men, the part of the urethra that is in the penis is affected.<EOS>
<BOS>Proximal urethral cancer Proximal urethral cancer affects the part of the urethra that is not the distal urethra.<EOS>
<BOS>In women and men, proximal urethral cancer usually has spread deeply into tissue.<EOS>
<BOS>Bladder and/or prostate cancer may occur at the same time as urethral cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>In men, cancer that forms in the proximal urethra (the part of the urethra that passes through the prostate to the bladder) may occur at the same time as cancer of the bladder and/or prostate.<EOS>
<BOS>Sometimes this occurs at diagnosis and sometimes it occurs later.<EOS>
<BOS>Being infected with certain types of the hepatitis virus can cause hepatitis and increase the risk of liver cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Hepatitis is most commonly caused by the hepatitis virus.<EOS>
<BOS>Hepatitis is a disease that causes inflammation (swelling) of the liver.<EOS>
<BOS>Damage to the liver from hepatitis that lasts a long time can increase the risk of liver cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>There are six types of the hepatitis virus.<EOS>
<BOS>Hepatitis A (HAV), hepatitis B (HBV), and hepatitis C (HCV) are the three most common types.<EOS>
<BOS>These three viruses cause similar symptoms, but the ways they spread and affect the liver are different.<EOS>
<BOS>The Hepatitis A vaccine and the hepatitis B vaccine prevent infection with hepatitis A and hepatitis B.<EOS>
<BOS>There is no vaccine to prevent infection with hepatitis C.<EOS>
<BOS>If a person has had one type of hepatitis in the past, it is still possible to get the other types.<EOS>
<BOS>Hepatitis viruses include: Hepatitis A Hepatitis A is caused by eating food or drinking water infected with hepatitis A virus.<EOS>
<BOS>It does not lead to chronic disease.<EOS>
<BOS>People with hepatitis A usually get better without treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Hepatitis B Hepatitis B is caused by contact with the blood, semen, or other body fluid of a person infected with hepatitis B virus.<EOS>
<BOS>It is a serious infection that may become chronic and cause scarring of the liver (cirrhosis).<EOS>
<BOS>This may lead to liver cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Blood banks test all donated blood for hepatitis B, which greatly lowers the risk of getting the virus from blood transfusions.<EOS>
<BOS>Hepatitis C Hepatitis C is caused by contact with the blood of a person infected with hepatitis C virus.<EOS>
<BOS>Hepatitis C may range from a mild illness that lasts a few weeks to a serious, lifelong illness.<EOS>
<BOS>Most people who have hepatitis C develop a chronic infection that may cause scarring of the liver (cirrhosis).<EOS>
<BOS>This may lead to liver cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Blood banks test all donated blood for hepatitis C, which greatly lowers the risk of getting the virus from blood transfusions.<EOS>
<BOS>Hepatitis D Hepatitis D develops in people already infected with hepatitis B.<EOS>
<BOS>It is caused by hepatitis D virus (HDV) and is spread through contact with infected blood or dirty needles, or by having unprotected sex with a person infected with HDV.<EOS>
<BOS>Hepatitis D causes acute hepatitis.<EOS>
<BOS>Hepatitis E Hepatitis E is caused by hepatitis E virus (HEV).<EOS>
<BOS>Hepatitis E can be spread through oral anal contact or by drinking infected water.<EOS>
<BOS>Hepatitis E is rare in the United States.<EOS>
<BOS>Hepatitis G Being infected with hepatitis G virus (HGV) has not been shown to cause liver cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Key Points Avoiding risk factors and increasing protective factors may help prevent cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>The following risk factors may increase the risk of liver cancer: Hepatitis B and C Cirrhosis Aflatoxin The following protective factor may decrease the risk of liver cancer: Hepatitis B vaccine Cancer prevention clinical trials are used to study ways to prevent cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>New ways to prevent liver cancer are being studied in clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>Avoiding risk factors and increasing protective factors may help prevent cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Avoiding cancer risk factors may help prevent certain cancers.<EOS>
<BOS>Risk factors include smoking, being overweight, and not getting enough exercise.<EOS>
<BOS>Increasing protective factors such as quitting smoking and exercising may also help prevent some cancers.<EOS>
<BOS>Talk to your doctor or other health care professional about how you might lower your risk of cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>The following risk factors may increase the risk of liver cancer: Hepatitis B and C Having chronic hepatitis B or chronic hepatitis C increases the risk of developing liver cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>The risk is even greater for people with both hepatitis B and C.<EOS>
<BOS>Also, the longer the hepatitis infection lasts (especially hepatitis C), the greater the risk.<EOS>
<BOS>In a study of patients with chronic hepatitis C, those who were treated to lower their iron levels by having blood drawn and eating a lowiron diet were less likely to develop liver cancer than those who did not have this treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Cirrhosis The risk of developing liver cancer is increased for people who have cirrhosis, a disease in which healthy liver tissue is replaced by scar tissue.<EOS>
<BOS>The scar tissue blocks the flow of blood through the liver and keeps it from working as it should.<EOS>
<BOS>Chronic alcoholism and chronic hepatitis C are the most common causes of cirrhosis.<EOS>
<BOS>Aflatoxin The risk of developing liver cancer may be increased by eating foods that contain aflatoxin (poison from a fungus that can grow on foods, such as grains and nuts, that have not been stored properly).<EOS>
<BOS>Certain factors affect prognosis (chance of recovery) and treatment options.<EOS>
<BOS>The prognosis (chance of recovery) and treatment options depend on the following: The patient's age.<EOS>
<BOS>Where in the body the tumor started.<EOS>
<BOS>The size of the tumor at the time of diagnosis.<EOS>
<BOS>Whether the tumor has been completely removed by surgery.<EOS>
<BOS>The type of rhabdomyosarcoma (embryonal, alveolar, or anaplastic).<EOS>
<BOS>Whether there are certain changes in the genes.<EOS>
<BOS>Whether the tumor had spread to other parts of the body at the time of diagnosis.<EOS>
<BOS>Whether the tumor was in the lymph nodes at the time of diagnosis.<EOS>
<BOS>Whether the tumor responds to chemotherapy and/or radiation therapy.<EOS>
<BOS>For patients with recurrent cancer, prognosis and treatment also depend on the following: Where in the body the tumor recurred (came back).<EOS>
<BOS>How much time passed between the end of cancer treatment and when the cancer recurred.<EOS>
<BOS>Whether the tumor was treated with radiation therapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Key Points The results of diagnostic and staging tests are used to find out if cancer cells have spread.<EOS>
<BOS>Ewing sarcoma is described based on whether the cancer has spread from the bone or soft tissue in which the cancer began.<EOS>
<BOS>Localized Ewing sarcoma Metastatic Ewing sarcoma There are three ways that cancer spreads in the body.<EOS>
<BOS>Cancer may spread from where it began to other parts of the body.<EOS>
<BOS>The results of diagnostic and staging tests are used to find out if cancer cells have spread.<EOS>
<BOS>The process used to find out if cancer has spread from where it began to other parts of the body is called staging.<EOS>
<BOS>There is no standard staging system for Ewing sarcoma.<EOS>
<BOS>The results of the tests and procedures done to diagnose and stage Ewing sarcoma are used to group the tumors into localized or metastatic.<EOS>
<BOS>Ewing sarcoma is described based on whether the cancer has spread from the bone or soft tissue in which the cancer began.<EOS>
<BOS>Ewing sarcoma is described as either localized or metastatic.<EOS>
<BOS>Localized Ewing sarcoma The cancer is found in the bone or soft tissue in which it began and may have spread to nearby tissue, including nearby lymph nodes.<EOS>
<BOS>Metastatic Ewing sarcoma The cancer has spread from the bone or soft tissue in which it began to other parts of the body.<EOS>
<BOS>In Ewing tumor of bone, the cancer most often spreads to the lung, other bones, and bone marrow.<EOS>
<BOS>There are three ways that cancer spreads in the body.<EOS>
<BOS>Cancer can spread through tissue, the lymph system, and the blood: Tissue.<EOS>
<BOS>The cancer spreads from where it began by growing into nearby areas.<EOS>
<BOS>Lymph system.<EOS>
<BOS>The cancer spreads from where it began by getting into the lymph system.<EOS>
<BOS>The cancer travels through the lymph vessels to other parts of the body.<EOS>
<BOS>Blood.<EOS>
<BOS>The cancer spreads from where it began by getting into the blood.<EOS>
<BOS>The cancer travels through the blood vessels to other parts of the body.<EOS>
<BOS>Cancer may spread from where it began to other parts of the body.<EOS>
<BOS>When cancer spreads to another part of the body, it is called metastasis.<EOS>
<BOS>Cancer cells break away from where they began (the primary tumor) and travel through the lymph system or blood.<EOS>
<BOS>Lymph system.<EOS>
<BOS>The cancer gets into the lymph system, travels through the lymph vessels, and forms a tumor (metastatic tumor) in another part of the body.<EOS>
<BOS>Blood.<EOS>
<BOS>The cancer gets into the blood, travels through the blood vessels, and forms a tumor (metastatic tumor) in another part of the body.<EOS>
<BOS>The metastatic tumor is the same type of cancer as the primary tumor.<EOS>
<BOS>For example, if Ewing sarcoma spreads to the lung, the cancer cells in the lung are actually Ewing sarcoma cells.<EOS>
<BOS>The disease is metastatic Ewing sarcoma, not lung cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>The cause of most childhood extracranial germ cell tumors is unknown.<EOS>
<BOS>Special blood tests are used to diagnose polycythemia vera.<EOS>
<BOS>In addition to a complete blood count, bone marrow aspiration and biopsy, and cytogenetic analysis, a serum erythropoietin test is used to diagnose polycythemia vera.<EOS>
<BOS>In this test, a sample of blood is checked for the level of erythropoietin (a hormone that stimulates new red blood cells to be made).<EOS>
<BOS>In polycythemia vera, the erythropoietin level would be lower than normal because the body does not need to make more red blood cells.<EOS>
<BOS>Key Points Neuroblastoma is a disease in which malignant (cancer) cells form in neuroblasts (immature nerve tissue) in the adrenal gland, neck, chest, or spinal cord.<EOS>
<BOS>Neuroblastoma is sometimes caused by a gene mutation (change) passed from the parent to the child.<EOS>
<BOS>Signs and symptoms of neuroblastoma include bone pain and a lump in the abdomen, neck, or chest.<EOS>
<BOS>Tests that examine many different body tissues and fluids are used to detect (find) and diagnose neuroblastoma.<EOS>
<BOS>A biopsy is done to diagnose neuroblastoma.<EOS>
<BOS>Certain factors affect prognosis (chance of recovery) and treatment options.<EOS>
<BOS>Neuroblastoma is a disease in which malignant (cancer) cells form in neuroblasts (immature nerve tissue) in the adrenal gland, neck, chest, or spinal cord.<EOS>
<BOS>Neuroblastoma often begins in the nerve tissue of the adrenal glands.<EOS>
<BOS>There are two adrenal glands, one on top of each kidney in the back of the upper abdomen.<EOS>
<BOS>The adrenal glands make important hormones that help control heart rate, blood pressure, blood sugar, and the way the body reacts to stress.<EOS>
<BOS>Neuroblastoma may also begin in nerve tissue in the neck, chest, abdomen or pelvis.<EOS>
<BOS>Neuroblastoma most often begins in infancy and may be diagnosed in the first month of life.<EOS>
<BOS>It is found when the tumor begins to grow and cause signs or symptoms.<EOS>
<BOS>Sometimes it forms before birth and is found during a fetal ultrasound.<EOS>
<BOS>By the time neuroblastoma is diagnosed, the cancer has usually metastasized (spread).<EOS>
<BOS>Neuroblastoma spreads most often to the lymph nodes, bones, bone marrow, and liver.<EOS>
<BOS>In infants, it also spreads to the skin.<EOS>
<BOS>New types of treatment are being tested in clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>Information about clinical trials is available from the NCI website.<EOS>
<BOS>Treatment for skin cancer may cause side effects.<EOS>
<BOS>For information about side effects caused by treatment for cancer, see our Side Effects page.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients may want to think about taking part in a clinical trial.<EOS>
<BOS>For some patients, taking part in a clinical trial may be the best treatment choice.<EOS>
<BOS>Clinical trials are part of the cancer research process.<EOS>
<BOS>Clinical trials are done to find out if new cancer treatments are safe and effective or better than the standard treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Many of today's standard treatments for cancer are based on earlier clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients who take part in a clinical trial may receive the standard treatment or be among the first to receive a new treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients who take part in clinical trials also help improve the way cancer will be treated in the future.<EOS>
<BOS>Even when clinical trials do not lead to effective new treatments, they often answer important questions and help move research forward.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients can enter clinical trials before, during, or after starting their cancer treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Some clinical trials only include patients who have not yet received treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Other trials test treatments for patients whose cancer has not gotten better.<EOS>
<BOS>There are also clinical trials that test new ways to stop cancer from recurring (coming back) or reduce the side effects of cancer treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Clinical trials are taking place in many parts of the country.<EOS>
<BOS>See the Treatment Options section that follows for links to current treatment clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>These have been retrieved from NCI's listing of clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>Signs of a pituitary tumor include problems with vision and certain physical changes.<EOS>
<BOS>Signs and symptoms can be caused by the growth of the tumor and/or by hormones the tumor makes or by other conditions.<EOS>
<BOS>Some tumors may not cause signs or symptoms.<EOS>
<BOS>Check with your doctor if you have any of these problems.<EOS>
<BOS>Signs and symptoms of a nonfunctioning pituitary tumor Sometimes, a pituitary tumor may press on or damage parts of the pituitary gland, causing it to stop making one or more hormones.<EOS>
<BOS>Too little of a certain hormone will affect the work of the gland or organ that the hormone controls.<EOS>
<BOS>The following signs and symptoms may occur: Headache.<EOS>
<BOS>Some loss of vision.<EOS>
<BOS>Loss of body hair.<EOS>
<BOS>In women, less frequent or no menstrual periods or no milk from the breasts.<EOS>
<BOS>In men, loss of facial hair, growth of breast tissue, and impotence.<EOS>
<BOS>In women and men, lower sex drive.<EOS>
<BOS>In children, slowed growth and sexual development.<EOS>
<BOS>Most of the tumors that make LH and FSH do not make enough extra hormone to cause signs and symptoms.<EOS>
<BOS>These tumors are considered to be nonfunctioning tumors.<EOS>
<BOS>Signs and symptoms of a functioning pituitary tumor When a functioning pituitary tumor makes extra hormones, the signs and symptoms will depend on the type of hormone being made.<EOS>
<BOS>Too much prolactin may cause: Headache.<EOS>
<BOS>Some loss of vision.<EOS>
<BOS>Less frequent or no menstrual periods or menstrual periods with a very light flow.<EOS>
<BOS>Trouble becoming pregnant or an inability to become pregnant.<EOS>
<BOS>Impotence in men.<EOS>
<BOS>Lower sex drive.<EOS>
<BOS>Flow of breast milk in a woman who is not pregnant or breastfeeding.<EOS>
<BOS>Too much ACTH may cause: Headache.<EOS>
<BOS>Some loss of vision.<EOS>
<BOS>Weight gain in the face, neck, and trunk of the body, and thin arms and legs.<EOS>
<BOS>A lump of fat on the back of the neck.<EOS>
<BOS>Thin skin that may have purple or pink stretch marks on the chest or abdomen.<EOS>
<BOS>Easy bruising.<EOS>
<BOS>Growth of fine hair on the face, upper back, or arms.<EOS>
<BOS>Bones that break easily.<EOS>
<BOS>Anxiety, irritability, and depression.<EOS>
<BOS>Too much growth hormone may cause: Headache.<EOS>
<BOS>Some loss of vision.<EOS>
<BOS>In adults, acromegaly (growth of the bones in the face, hands, and feet).<EOS>
<BOS>In children, the whole body may grow much taller and larger than normal.<EOS>
<BOS>Tingling or numbness in the hands and fingers.<EOS>
<BOS>Snoring or pauses in breathing during sleep.<EOS>
<BOS>Joint pain.<EOS>
<BOS>Sweating more than usual.<EOS>
<BOS>Dysmorphophobia (extreme dislike of or concern about one or more parts of the body).<EOS>
<BOS>Too much thyroidstimulating hormone may cause: Irregular heartbeat.<EOS>
<BOS>Shakiness.<EOS>
<BOS>Weight loss.<EOS>
<BOS>Trouble sleeping.<EOS>
<BOS>Frequent bowel movements.<EOS>
<BOS>Sweating.<EOS>
<BOS>Other general signs and symptoms of pituitary tumors: Nausea and vomiting.<EOS>
<BOS>Confusion.<EOS>
<BOS>Dizziness.<EOS>
<BOS>Seizures.<EOS>
<BOS>Runny or "drippy" nose (cerebrospinal fluid that surrounds the brain and spinal cord leaks into the nose).<EOS>
<BOS>Key Points There are different types of treatment for patients with hypopharyngeal cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Three types of standard treatment are used: Surgery Radiation therapy Chemotherapy New types of treatment are being tested in clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients may want to think about taking part in a clinical trial.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients can enter clinical trials before, during, or after starting their cancer treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Followup tests may be needed.<EOS>
<BOS>There are different types of treatment for patients with hypopharyngeal cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Different types of treatment are available for patients with hypopharyngeal cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Some treatments are standard (the currently used treatment), and some are being tested in clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>A treatment clinical trial is a research study meant to help improve current treatments or obtain information on new treatments for patients with cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>When clinical trials show that a new treatment is better than the standard treatment, the new treatment may become the standard treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients may want to think about taking part in a clinical trial.<EOS>
<BOS>Some clinical trials are open only to patients who have not started treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Three types of standard treatment are used: Surgery Surgery (removing the cancer in an operation) is a common treatment for all stages of hypopharyngeal cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>The following surgical procedures may be used: Laryngopharyngectomy: Surgery to remove the larynx (voice box) and part of the pharynx (throat).<EOS>
<BOS>Partial laryngopharyngectomy: Surgery to remove part of the larynx and part of the pharynx.<EOS>
<BOS>A partial laryngopharyngectomy prevents loss of the voice.<EOS>
<BOS>Neck dissection: Surgery to remove lymph nodes and other tissues in the neck.<EOS>
<BOS>Even if the doctor removes all the cancer that can be seen at the time of the surgery, some patients may be given chemotherapy or radiation therapy after surgery to kill any cancer cells that are left.<EOS>
<BOS>Treatment given after the surgery, to lower the risk that the cancer will come back, is called adjuvant therapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Radiation therapy Radiation therapy is a cancer treatment that uses highenergy xrays or other types of radiation to kill cancer cells or keep them from growing.<EOS>
<BOS>There are two types of radiation therapy: External radiation therapy uses a machine outside the body to send radiation toward the cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Internal radiation therapy uses a radioactive substance sealed in needles, seeds, wires, or catheters that are placed directly into or near the cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>The way the radiation therapy is given depends on the type and stage of the cancer being treated.<EOS>
<BOS>External radiation therapy is used to treat hypopharyngeal cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Radiation therapy may work better in patients who have stopped smoking before beginning treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>External radiation therapy to the thyroid or the pituitary gland may change the way the thyroid gland works.<EOS>
<BOS>A blood test to check the thyroid hormone level in the body may be done before and after therapy to make sure the thyroid gland is working properly.<EOS>
<BOS>Chemotherapy Chemotherapy is a cancer treatment that uses drugs to stop the growth of cancer cells, either by killing the cells or by stopping the cells from dividing.<EOS>
<BOS>When chemotherapy is taken by mouth or injected into a vein or muscle, the drugs enter the bloodstream and can reach cancer cells throughout the body (systemic chemotherapy).<EOS>
<BOS>When chemotherapy is placed directly into the cerebrospinal fluid, an organ, or a body cavity such as the abdomen, the drugs mainly affect cancer cells in those areas (regional chemotherapy).<EOS>
<BOS>The way the chemotherapy is given depends on the type and stage of the cancer being treated.<EOS>
<BOS>Chemotherapy may be used to shrink the tumor before surgery or radiation therapy.<EOS>
<BOS>This is called neoadjuvant chemotherapy.<EOS>
<BOS>See Drugs Approved for Head and Neck Cancer for more information.<EOS>
<BOS>(Hypopharyngeal cancer is a type of head and neck cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>) New types of treatment are being tested in clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>Information about clinical trials is available from the NCI website.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients may want to think about taking part in a clinical trial.<EOS>
<BOS>For some patients, taking part in a clinical trial may be the best treatment choice.<EOS>
<BOS>Clinical trials are part of the cancer research process.<EOS>
<BOS>Clinical trials are done to find out if new cancer treatments are safe and effective or better than the standard treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Many of today's standard treatments for cancer are based on earlier clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients who take part in a clinical trial may receive the standard treatment or be among the first to receive a new treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients who take part in clinical trials also help improve the way cancer will be treated in the future.<EOS>
<BOS>Even when clinical trials do not lead to effective new treatments, they often answer important questions and help move research forward.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients can enter clinical trials before, during, or after starting their cancer treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Some clinical trials only include patients who have not yet received treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Other trials test treatments for patients whose cancer has not gotten better.<EOS>
<BOS>There are also clinical trials that test new ways to stop cancer from recurring (coming back) or reduce the side effects of cancer treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Clinical trials are taking place in many parts of the country.<EOS>
<BOS>See the Treatment Options section that follows for links to current treatment clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>These have been retrieved from NCI's listing of clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>Followup tests may be needed.<EOS>
<BOS>Some of the tests that were done to diagnose the cancer or to find out the stage of the cancer may be repeated.<EOS>
<BOS>Some tests will be repeated in order to see how well the treatment is working.<EOS>
<BOS>Decisions about whether to continue, change, or stop treatment may be based on the results of these tests.<EOS>
<BOS>Some of the tests will continue to be done from time to time after treatment has ended.<EOS>
<BOS>The results of these tests can show if your condition has changed or if the cancer has recurred (come back).<EOS>
<BOS>These tests are sometimes called followup tests or checkups.<EOS>
<BOS>For hypopharyngeal cancer, followup to check for recurrence should include careful head and neck exams once a month in the first year after treatment ends, every 2 months in the second year, every 3 months in the third year, and every 6 months thereafter.<EOS>
<BOS>Treatment Options by Stage Stage I Hypopharyngeal Cancer Treatment of stage I hypopharyngeal cancer may include the following: Laryngopharyngectomy and neck dissection with or without highdose radiation therapy to the lymph nodes of the neck.<EOS>
<BOS>Partial laryngopharyngectomy with or without highdose radiation therapy to the lymph nodes on both sides of the neck.<EOS>
<BOS>Check the list of NCIsupported cancer clinical trials that are now accepting patients with stage I hypopharyngeal cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>For more specific results, refine the search by using other search features, such as the location of the trial, the type of treatment, or the name of the drug.<EOS>
<BOS>Talk with your doctor about clinical trials that may be right for you.<EOS>
<BOS>General information about clinical trials is available from the NCI website.<EOS>
<BOS>Stage II Hypopharyngeal Cancer Treatment of stage II hypopharyngeal cancer may include the following: Laryngopharyngectomy and neck dissection.<EOS>
<BOS>Highdose radiation therapy to the lymph nodes of the neck may be given before or after surgery.<EOS>
<BOS>Partial laryngopharyngectomy.<EOS>
<BOS>Highdose radiation therapy to the lymph nodes of the neck may be given before or after surgery.<EOS>
<BOS>Chemotherapy given during or after radiation therapy or after surgery.<EOS>
<BOS>A clinical trial of chemotherapy followed by radiation therapy or surgery.<EOS>
<BOS>Check the list of NCIsupported cancer clinical trials that are now accepting patients with stage II hypopharyngeal cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>For more specific results, refine the search by using other search features, such as the location of the trial, the type of treatment, or the name of the drug.<EOS>
<BOS>Talk with your doctor about clinical trials that may be right for you.<EOS>
<BOS>General information about clinical trials is available from the NCI website.<EOS>
<BOS>Stage III Hypopharyngeal Cancer Treatment of stage III hypopharyngeal cancer may include the following: Radiation therapy before or after surgery.<EOS>
<BOS>Chemotherapy given during or after radiation therapy or after surgery.<EOS>
<BOS>A clinical trial of chemotherapy followed by surgery and/or radiation therapy.<EOS>
<BOS>A clinical trial of chemotherapy given at the same time as radiation therapy.<EOS>
<BOS>A clinical trial of surgery followed by chemotherapy given at the same time as radiation therapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Treatment and followup of stage III hypopharyngeal cancer is complex and is ideally overseen by a team of specialists with experience and expertise in treating this type of cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>If all or part of the hypopharynx is removed, the patient may need plastic surgery and other special help with breathing, eating, and talking.<EOS>
<BOS>Check the list of NCIsupported cancer clinical trials that are now accepting patients with stage III hypopharyngeal cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>For more specific results, refine the search by using other search features, such as the location of the trial, the type of treatment, or the name of the drug.<EOS>
<BOS>Talk with your doctor about clinical trials that may be right for you.<EOS>
<BOS>General information about clinical trials is available from the NCI website.<EOS>
<BOS>Stage IV Hypopharyngeal Cancer Treatment of stage IV hypopharyngeal cancer that can be treated with surgery may include the following: Radiation therapy before or after surgery.<EOS>
<BOS>A clinical trial of chemotherapy followed by surgery and/or radiation therapy.<EOS>
<BOS>A clinical trial of surgery followed by chemotherapy given at the same time as radiation therapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Surgical treatment and followup of stage IV hypopharyngeal cancer is complex and is ideally overseen by a team of specialists with experience and expertise in treating this type of cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>If all or part of the hypopharynx is removed, the patient may need plastic surgery and other special help with breathing, eating, and talking.<EOS>
<BOS>Treatment of stage IV hypopharyngeal cancer that cannot be treated with surgery may include the following: Radiation therapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Chemotherapy given at the same time as radiation therapy.<EOS>
<BOS>A clinical trial of radiation therapy with chemotherapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Check the list of NCIsupported cancer clinical trials that are now accepting patients with stage IV hypopharyngeal cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>For more specific results, refine the search by using other search features, such as the location of the trial, the type of treatment, or the name of the drug.<EOS>
<BOS>Talk with your doctor about clinical trials that may be right for you.<EOS>
<BOS>General information about clinical trials is available from the NCI website.<EOS>
<BOS>Tests that examine the blood and bone marrow are used to detect (find) and diagnose hairy cell leukemia.<EOS>
<BOS>The following tests and procedures may be used: Physical exam and history : An exam of the body to check general signs of health, including checking for signs of disease, such as a swollen spleen, lumps, or anything else that seems unusual.<EOS>
<BOS>A history of the patients health habits and past illnesses and treatments will also be taken.<EOS>
<BOS>Complete blood count (CBC): A procedure in which a sample of blood is drawn and checked for the following: The number of red blood cells, white blood cells, and platelets.<EOS>
<BOS>The amount of hemoglobin (the protein that carries oxygen) in the red blood cells.<EOS>
<BOS>The portion of the sample made up of red blood cells.<EOS>
<BOS>Peripheral blood smear : A procedure in which a sample of blood is checked for cells that look "hairy," the number and kinds of white blood cells, the number of platelets, and changes in the shape of blood cells.<EOS>
<BOS>Blood chemistry studies : A procedure in which a blood sample is checked to measure the amounts of certain substances released into the blood by organs and tissues in the body.<EOS>
<BOS>An unusual (higher or lower than normal) amount of a substance can be a sign of disease.<EOS>
<BOS>Bone marrow aspiration and biopsy : The removal of bone marrow, blood, and a small piece of bone by inserting a hollow needle into the hipbone or breastbone.<EOS>
<BOS>A pathologist views the bone marrow, blood, and bone under a microscope to look for signs of cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Immunophenotyping : A laboratory test in which the antigens or markers on the surface of a blood or bone marrow cell are checked to see what type of cell it is.<EOS>
<BOS>This test is done to diagnose the specific type of leukemia by comparing the cancer cells to normal cells of the immune system.<EOS>
<BOS>Flow cytometry : A laboratory test that measures the number of cells in a sample, the percentage of live cells in a sample, and certain characteristics of cells, such as size, shape, and the presence of tumor markers on the cell surface.<EOS>
<BOS>The cells are stained with a lightsensitive dye, placed in a fluid, and passed in a stream before a laser or other type of light.<EOS>
<BOS>The measurements are based on how the lightsensitive dye reacts to the light.<EOS>
<BOS>Cytogenetic analysis : A laboratory test in which cells in a sample of tissue are viewed under a microscope to look for certain changes in the chromosomes.<EOS>
<BOS>Gene mutation test: A laboratory test done on a bone marrow or blood sample to check for mutations in the BRAF gene.<EOS>
<BOS>A BRAF gene mutation is often found in patients with hairy cell leukemia.<EOS>
<BOS>CT scan (CAT scan): A procedure that makes a series of detailed pictures of areas inside the body, taken from different angles.<EOS>
<BOS>The pictures are made by a computer linked to an xray machine.<EOS>
<BOS>A dye may be injected into a vein or swallowed to help the organs or tissues show up more clearly.<EOS>
<BOS>This procedure is also called computed tomography, computerized tomography, or computerized axial tomography.<EOS>
<BOS>A CT scan of the abdomen may be done to check for swollen lymph nodes or a swollen spleen.<EOS>
<BOS>There are no known risk factors for childhood craniopharyngioma.<EOS>
<BOS>Craniopharyngiomas are rare in children younger than 2 years of age and are most often diagnosed in children aged 5 to 14 years.<EOS>
<BOS>It is not known what causes these tumors.<EOS>
<BOS>Check the list of NCIsupported cancer clinical trials that are now accepting patients with childhood central nervous system germ cell tumor.<EOS>
<BOS>For more specific results, refine the search by using other search features, such as the location of the trial, the type of treatment, or the name of the drug.<EOS>
<BOS>Talk with your child's doctor about clinical trials that may be right for your child.<EOS>
<BOS>General information about clinical trials is available from the NCI website.<EOS>
<BOS>New types of treatment are being tested in clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>Information about clinical trials is available from the NCI website.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients may want to think about taking part in a clinical trial.<EOS>
<BOS>For some patients, taking part in a clinical trial may be the best treatment choice.<EOS>
<BOS>Clinical trials are part of the cancer research process.<EOS>
<BOS>Clinical trials are done to find out if new cancer treatments are safe and effective or better than the standard treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Many of today's standard treatments for cancer are based on earlier clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients who take part in a clinical trial may receive the standard treatment or be among the first to receive a new treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients who take part in clinical trials also help improve the way cancer will be treated in the future.<EOS>
<BOS>Even when clinical trials do not lead to effective new treatments, they often answer important questions and help move research forward.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients can enter clinical trials before, during, or after starting their cancer treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Some clinical trials only include patients who have not yet received treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Other trials test treatments for patients whose cancer has not gotten better.<EOS>
<BOS>There are also clinical trials that test new ways to stop cancer from recurring (coming back) or reduce the side effects of cancer treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Clinical trials are taking place in many parts of the country.<EOS>
<BOS>See the Current Clinical Trials section that follows for links to current treatment clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>These have been retrieved from the NCI's listing of clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>Key Points Ovarian, fallopian tube, and primary peritoneal cancers are diseases in which malignant (cancer) cells form in the ovaries, fallopian tubes, or peritoneum.<EOS>
<BOS>Ovarian cancer is the leading cause of death from cancer of the female reproductive system.<EOS>
<BOS>Ovarian, fallopian tube, and primary peritoneal cancers are diseases in which malignant (cancer) cells form in the ovaries, fallopian tubes, or peritoneum.<EOS>
<BOS>The ovaries are a pair of organs in the female reproductive system.<EOS>
<BOS>They are in the pelvis, one on each side of the uterus (the hollow, pearshaped organ where a fetus grows).<EOS>
<BOS>Each ovary is about the size and shape of an almond.<EOS>
<BOS>The ovaries make eggs and female hormones (chemicals that control the way certain cells or organs work in the body).<EOS>
<BOS>The fallopian tubes are a pair of long, slender tubes, one on each side of the uterus.<EOS>
<BOS>Eggs pass from the ovaries, through the fallopian tubes, to the uterus.<EOS>
<BOS>Cancer sometimes begins at the end of the fallopian tube near the ovary and spreads to the ovary.<EOS>
<BOS>The peritoneum is the tissue that lines the abdominal wall and covers organs in the abdomen.<EOS>
<BOS>Primary peritoneal cancer is cancer that forms in the peritoneum and has not spread there from another part of the body.<EOS>
<BOS>Cancer sometimes begins in the peritoneum and spreads to the ovary.<EOS>
<BOS>Ovarian cancer is the leading cause of death from cancer of the female reproductive system.<EOS>
<BOS>In recent years, there has been a small decrease in the number of new cases of ovarian cancer and the number of deaths from ovarian cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>New cases of ovarian cancer and deaths from ovarian cancer are higher among white women than black women, but have decreased in both groups.<EOS>
<BOS>Women who have a family history of ovarian cancer and/or certain inherited gene changes, such as BRCA1 or BRCA2 gene changes, have a higher risk than women who do not have a family history or who have not inherited these gene changes.<EOS>
<BOS>For women with inherited risk, genetic counseling and genetic testing can be used to find out more about how likely they are to develop ovarian cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>It is hard to find ovarian cancer early.<EOS>
<BOS>Early ovarian cancer may not cause any symptoms.<EOS>
<BOS>When symptoms do appear, ovarian cancer is often advanced.<EOS>
<BOS>See the following PDQ summaries for more information about ovarian, fallopian tube, and primary peritoneal cancers: Genetics of Breast and Gynecologic Cancers (written for health professionals) Ovarian, Fallopian Tube, and Primary Peritoneal Cancer Screening Ovarian Epithelial, Fallopian Tube, and Primary Peritoneal Cancer Treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>New types of treatment are being tested in clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>This summary section describes treatments that are being studied in clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>It may not mention every new treatment being studied.<EOS>
<BOS>Information about clinical trials is available from the NCI website.<EOS>
<BOS>Liver transplant In a liver transplant, the entire liver is removed and replaced with a healthy donated liver.<EOS>
<BOS>A liver transplant may be done in patients with perihilar bile duct cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>If the patient has to wait for a donated liver, other treatment is given as needed.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients may want to think about taking part in a clinical trial.<EOS>
<BOS>For some patients, taking part in a clinical trial may be the best treatment choice.<EOS>
<BOS>Clinical trials are part of the cancer research process.<EOS>
<BOS>Clinical trials are done to find out if new cancer treatments are safe and effective or better than the standard treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Many of today's standard treatments for cancer are based on earlier clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients who take part in a clinical trial may receive the standard treatment or be among the first to receive a new treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients who take part in clinical trials also help improve the way cancer will be treated in the future.<EOS>
<BOS>Even when clinical trials do not lead to effective new treatments, they often answer important questions and help move research forward.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients can enter clinical trials before, during, or after starting their cancer treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Some clinical trials only include patients who have not yet received treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Other trials test treatments for patients whose cancer has not gotten better.<EOS>
<BOS>There are also clinical trials that test new ways to stop cancer from recurring (coming back) or reduce the side effects of cancer treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Clinical trials are taking place in many parts of the country.<EOS>
<BOS>See the Treatment Options section that follows for links to current treatment clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>These have been retrieved from NCI's listing of clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>Key Points Hypopharyngeal cancer is a disease in which malignant (cancer) cells form in the tissues of the hypopharynx.<EOS>
<BOS>Use of tobacco products and heavy drinking can affect the risk of developing hypopharyngeal cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Signs and symptoms of hypopharyngeal cancer include a sore throat and ear pain.<EOS>
<BOS>Tests that examine the throat and neck are used to help detect (find) and diagnose hypopharyngeal cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Certain factors affect prognosis (chance of recovery) and treatment options.<EOS>
<BOS>Hypopharyngeal cancer is a disease in which malignant (cancer) cells form in the tissues of the hypopharynx.<EOS>
<BOS>The hypopharynx is the bottom part of the pharynx (throat).<EOS>
<BOS>The pharynx is a hollow tube about 5 inches long that starts behind the nose, goes down the neck, and ends at the top of the trachea (windpipe) and esophagus (the tube that goes from the throat to the stomach).<EOS>
<BOS>Air and food pass through the pharynx on the way to the trachea or the esophagus.<EOS>
<BOS>Most hypopharyngeal cancers form in squamous cells, the thin, flat cells lining the inside of the hypopharynx.<EOS>
<BOS>The hypopharynx has 3 different areas.<EOS>
<BOS>Cancer may be found in 1 or more of these areas.<EOS>
<BOS>Hypopharyngeal cancer is a type of head and neck cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Certain factors affect prognosis (chance of recovery) and treatment options for essential thrombocythemia.<EOS>
<BOS>Prognosis (chance of recovery) and treatment options depend on the following: The age of the patient.<EOS>
<BOS>Whether the patient has signs or symptoms or other problems related to essential thrombocythemia.<EOS>
<BOS>Certain factors affect prognosis (chance of recovery) and treatment options.<EOS>
<BOS>The prognosis (chance of recovery) and treatment options depend on the following: Whether the cancer is in the upper or lower part of the bile duct system.<EOS>
<BOS>The stage of the cancer (whether it affects only the bile ducts or has spread to the liver, lymph nodes, or other places in the body).<EOS>
<BOS>Whether the cancer has spread to nearby nerves or veins.<EOS>
<BOS>Whether the cancer can be completely removed by surgery.<EOS>
<BOS>Whether the patient has other conditions, such as primary sclerosing cholangitis.<EOS>
<BOS>Whether the level of CA 199 is higher than normal.<EOS>
<BOS>Whether the cancer has just been diagnosed or has recurred (come back).<EOS>
<BOS>Treatment options may also depend on the symptoms caused by the cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Bile duct cancer is usually found after it has spread and can rarely be completely removed by surgery.<EOS>
<BOS>Palliative therapy may relieve symptoms and improve the patient's quality of life.<EOS>
<BOS>Key Points There are different types of treatment for patients with melanoma.<EOS>
<BOS>Five types of standard treatment are used: Surgery Chemotherapy Radiation therapy Immunotherapy Targeted therapy New types of treatment are being tested in clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>Treatment for melanoma may cause side effects.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients may want to think about taking part in a clinical trial.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients can enter clinical trials before, during, or after starting their cancer treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Followup tests may be needed.<EOS>
<BOS>There are different types of treatment for patients with melanoma.<EOS>
<BOS>Different types of treatment are available for patients with melanoma.<EOS>
<BOS>Some treatments are standard (the currently used treatment), and some are being tested in clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>A treatment clinical trial is a research study meant to help improve current treatments or obtain information on new treatments for patients with cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>When clinical trials show that a new treatment is better than the standard treatment, the new treatment may become the standard treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients may want to think about taking part in a clinical trial.<EOS>
<BOS>Some clinical trials are open only to patients who have not started treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Five types of standard treatment are used: Surgery Surgery to remove the tumor is the primary treatment of all stages of melanoma.<EOS>
<BOS>A wide local excision is used to remove the melanoma and some of the normal tissue around it.<EOS>
<BOS>Skin grafting (taking skin from another part of the body to replace the skin that is removed) may be done to cover the wound caused by surgery.<EOS>
<BOS>It is important to know whether cancer has spread to the lymph nodes.<EOS>
<BOS>Lymph node mapping and sentinel lymph node biopsy are done to check for cancer in the sentinel lymph node (the first lymph node the cancer is likely to spread to from the tumor) during surgery.<EOS>
<BOS>A radioactive substance and/or blue dye is injected near the tumor.<EOS>
<BOS>The substance or dye flows through the lymph ducts to the lymph nodes.<EOS>
<BOS>The first lymph node to receive the substance or dye is removed.<EOS>
<BOS>A pathologist views the tissue under a microscope to look for cancer cells.<EOS>
<BOS>If cancer cells are found, more lymph nodes will be removed and tissue samples will be checked for signs of cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>This is called a lymphadenectomy.<EOS>
<BOS>Even if the doctor removes all the melanoma that can be seen at the time of surgery, some patients may be given chemotherapy after surgery to kill any cancer cells that are left.<EOS>
<BOS>Chemotherapy given after surgery, to lower the risk that the cancer will come back, is called adjuvant therapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Surgery to remove cancer that has spread to the lymph nodes, lung, gastrointestinal (GI) tract, bone, or brain may be done to improve the patients quality of life by controlling symptoms.<EOS>
<BOS>Chemotherapy Chemotherapy is a cancer treatment that uses drugs to stop the growth of cancer cells, either by killing the cells or by stopping them from dividing.<EOS>
<BOS>When chemotherapy is taken by mouth or injected into a vein or muscle, the drugs enter the bloodstream and can reach cancer cells throughout the body (systemic chemotherapy).<EOS>
<BOS>When chemotherapy is placed directly into the cerebrospinal fluid, an organ, or a body cavity such as the abdomen, the drugs mainly affect cancer cells in those areas (regional chemotherapy).<EOS>
<BOS>One type of regional chemotherapy is hyperthermic isolated limb perfusion.<EOS>
<BOS>With this method, anticancer drugs go directly to the arm or leg the cancer is in.<EOS>
