<BOS>The flow of blood to and from the limb is temporarily stopped with a tourniquet.<EOS>
<BOS>A warm solution with the anticancer drug is put directly into the blood of the limb.<EOS>
<BOS>This gives a high dose of drugs to the area where the cancer is.<EOS>
<BOS>The way the chemotherapy is given depends on the type and stage of the cancer being treated.<EOS>
<BOS>See Drugs Approved for Melanoma for more information.<EOS>
<BOS>Radiation therapy Radiation therapy is a cancer treatment that uses highenergy xrays or other types of radiation to kill cancer cells or keep them from growing.<EOS>
<BOS>There are two types of radiation therapy: External radiation therapy uses a machine outside the body to send radiation toward the cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Internal radiation therapy uses a radioactive substance sealed in needles, seeds, wires, or catheters that are placed directly into or near the cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>The way the radiation therapy is given depends on the type and stage of the cancer being treated.<EOS>
<BOS>External radiation therapy is used to treat melanoma, and may also be used as palliative therapy to relieve symptoms and improve quality of life.<EOS>
<BOS>Immunotherapy Immunotherapy is a treatment that uses the patients immune system to fight cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Substances made by the body or made in a laboratory are used to boost, direct, or restore the bodys natural defenses against cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>This type of cancer treatment is also called biotherapy or biologic therapy.<EOS>
<BOS>The following types of immunotherapy are being used in the treatment of melanoma: Immune checkpoint inhibitor therapy: Some types of immune cells, such as T cells, and some cancer cells have certain proteins, called checkpoint proteins, on their surface that keep immune responses in check.<EOS>
<BOS>When cancer cells have large amounts of these proteins, they will not be attacked and killed by T cells.<EOS>
<BOS>Immune checkpoint inhibitors block these proteins and the ability of T cells to kill cancer cells is increased.<EOS>
<BOS>They are used to treat some patients with advanced melanoma or tumors that cannot be removed by surgery.<EOS>
<BOS>There are two types of immune checkpoint inhibitor therapy: CTLA4 inhibitor: CTL4A is a protein on the surface of T cells that helps keep the bodys immune responses in check.<EOS>
<BOS>When CTLA4 attaches to another protein called B7 on a cancer cell, it stops the T cell from killing the cancer cell.<EOS>
<BOS>CTLA4 inhibitors attach to CTLA4 and allow the T cells to kill cancer cells.<EOS>
<BOS>Ipilimumab is a type of CTLA4 inhibitor.<EOS>
<BOS>PD1 inhibitor: PD1 is a protein on the surface of T cells that helps keep the bodys immune responses in check.<EOS>
<BOS>When PD1 attaches to another protein called PDL1 on a cancer cell, it stops the T cell from killing the cancer cell.<EOS>
<BOS>PD1 inhibitors attach to PDL1 and allow the T cells to kill cancer cells.<EOS>
<BOS>Pembrolizumab and nivolumab are types of PD1 inhibitors.<EOS>
<BOS>Interferon: Interferon affects the division of cancer cells and can slow tumor growth.<EOS>
<BOS>Interleukin2 (IL2): IL2 boosts the growth and activity of many immune cells, especially lymphocytes (a type of white blood cell).<EOS>
<BOS>Lymphocytes can attack and kill cancer cells.<EOS>
<BOS>Tumor necrosis factor (TNF) therapy: TNF is a protein made by white blood cells in response to an antigen or infection.<EOS>
<BOS>TNF is made in the laboratory and used as a treatment to kill cancer cells.<EOS>
<BOS>It is being studied in the treatment of melanoma.<EOS>
<BOS>See Drugs Approved for Melanoma for more information.<EOS>
<BOS>Targeted therapy Targeted therapy is a type of treatment that uses drugs or other substances to attack cancer cells.<EOS>
<BOS>Targeted therapies usually cause less harm to normal cells than chemotherapy or radiation therapy do.<EOS>
<BOS>The following types of targeted therapy are used or being studied in the treatment of melanoma: Signal transduction inhibitor therapy: Signal transduction inhibitors block signals that are passed from one molecule to another inside a cell.<EOS>
<BOS>Blocking these signals may kill cancer cells.<EOS>
<BOS>Vemurafenib, dabrafenib, trametinib, and cobimetinib are signal transduction inhibitors used to treat some patients with advanced melanoma or tumors that cannot be removed by surgery.<EOS>
<BOS>Vemurafenib and dabrafenib block the activity of proteins made by mutant BRAF genes.<EOS>
<BOS>Trametinib and cobimetinib affect the growth and survival of cancer cells.<EOS>
<BOS>Oncolytic virus therapy: A type of targeted therapy that is used in the treatment of melanoma.<EOS>
<BOS>Oncolytic virus therapy uses a virus that infects and breaks down cancer cells but not normal cells.<EOS>
<BOS>Radiation therapy or chemotherapy may be given after oncolytic virus therapy to kill more cancer cells.<EOS>
<BOS>Angiogenesis inhibitors: A type of targeted therapy that is being studied in the treatment of melanoma.<EOS>
<BOS>Angiogenesis inhibitors block the growth of new blood vessels.<EOS>
<BOS>In cancer treatment, they may be given to prevent the growth of new blood vessels that tumors need to grow.<EOS>
<BOS>New targeted therapies and combinations of therapies are being studied in the treatment of melanoma.<EOS>
<BOS>See Drugs Approved for Melanoma for more information.<EOS>
<BOS>New types of treatment are being tested in clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>Information about clinical trials is available from the NCI website Treatment for melanoma may cause side effects.<EOS>
<BOS>For information about side effects caused by treatment for cancer, see our Side Effects page.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients may want to think about taking part in a clinical trial.<EOS>
<BOS>For some patients, taking part in a clinical trial may be the best treatment choice.<EOS>
<BOS>Clinical trials are part of the cancer research process.<EOS>
<BOS>Clinical trials are done to find out if new cancer treatments are safe and effective or better than the standard treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Many of today's standard treatments for cancer are based on earlier clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients who take part in a clinical trial may receive the standard treatment or be among the first to receive a new treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients who take part in clinical trials also help improve the way cancer will be treated in the future.<EOS>
<BOS>Even when clinical trials do not lead to effective new treatments, they often answer important questions and help move research forward.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients can enter clinical trials before, during, or after starting their cancer treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Some clinical trials only include patients who have not yet received treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Other trials test treatments for patients whose cancer has not gotten better.<EOS>
<BOS>There are also clinical trials that test new ways to stop cancer from recurring (coming back) or reduce the side effects of cancer treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Clinical trials are taking place in many parts of the country.<EOS>
<BOS>See the Treatment Options section that follows for links to current treatment clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>These have been retrieved from NCI's listing of clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>Followup tests may be needed.<EOS>
<BOS>Some of the tests that were done to diagnose the cancer or to find out the stage of the cancer may be repeated.<EOS>
<BOS>Some tests will be repeated in order to see how well the treatment is working.<EOS>
<BOS>Decisions about whether to continue, change, or stop treatment may be based on the results of these tests.<EOS>
<BOS>Some of the tests will continue to be done from time to time after treatment has ended.<EOS>
<BOS>The results of these tests can show if your condition has changed or if the cancer has recurred (come back).<EOS>
<BOS>These tests are sometimes called followup tests or checkups.<EOS>
<BOS>Treatment Options by Stage Stage 0 (Melanoma in Situ) Treatment of stage 0 is usually surgery to remove the area of abnormal cells and a small amount of normal tissue around it.<EOS>
<BOS>Check the list of NCIsupported cancer clinical trials that are now accepting patients with stage 0 melanoma.<EOS>
<BOS>For more specific results, refine the search by using other search features, such as the location of the trial, the type of treatment, or the name of the drug.<EOS>
<BOS>Talk with your doctor about clinical trials that may be right for you.<EOS>
<BOS>General information about clinical trials is available from the NCI website.<EOS>
<BOS>Stage I Melanoma Treatment of stage I melanoma may include the following: Surgery to remove the tumor and some of the normal tissue around it.<EOS>
<BOS>Sometimes lymph node mapping and removal of lymph nodes is also done.<EOS>
<BOS>A clinical trial of new ways to find cancer cells in the lymph nodes.<EOS>
<BOS>Check the list of NCIsupported cancer clinical trials that are now accepting patients with stage I melanoma.<EOS>
<BOS>For more specific results, refine the search by using other search features, such as the location of the trial, the type of treatment, or the name of the drug.<EOS>
<BOS>Talk with your doctor about clinical trials that may be right for you.<EOS>
<BOS>General information about clinical trials is available from the NCI website.<EOS>
<BOS>Stage II Melanoma Treatment of stage II melanoma may include the following: Surgery to remove the tumor and some of the normal tissue around it.<EOS>
<BOS>Sometimes lymph node mapping and sentinel lymph node biopsy are done to check for cancer in the lymph nodes at the same time as the surgery to remove the tumor.<EOS>
<BOS>If cancer is found in the sentinel lymph node, more lymph nodes may be removed.<EOS>
<BOS>Surgery followed by immunotherapy with interferon if there is a high risk that the cancer will come back.<EOS>
<BOS>A clinical trial of new types of treatment to be used after surgery.<EOS>
<BOS>Check the list of NCIsupported cancer clinical trials that are now accepting patients with stage II melanoma.<EOS>
<BOS>For more specific results, refine the search by using other search features, such as the location of the trial, the type of treatment, or the name of the drug.<EOS>
<BOS>Talk with your doctor about clinical trials that may be right for you.<EOS>
<BOS>General information about clinical trials is available from the NCI website.<EOS>
<BOS>Stage III Melanoma That Can Be Removed By Surgery Treatment of stage III melanoma that can be removed by surgery may include the following: Surgery to remove the tumor and some of the normal tissue around it.<EOS>
<BOS>Skin grafting may be done to cover the wound caused by surgery.<EOS>
<BOS>Sometimes lymph node mapping and sentinel lymph node biopsy are done to check for cancer in the lymph nodes at the same time as the surgery to remove the tumor.<EOS>
<BOS>If cancer is found in the sentinel lymph node, more lymph nodes may be removed.<EOS>
<BOS>Surgery followed by immunotherapy with ipilimumab or interferon if there is a high risk that the cancer will come back.<EOS>
<BOS>A clinical trial of immunotherapy or targeted therapy to be used after surgery.<EOS>
<BOS>Check the list of NCIsupported cancer clinical trials that are now accepting patients with stage III melanoma.<EOS>
<BOS>For more specific results, refine the search by using other search features, such as the location of the trial, the type of treatment, or the name of the drug.<EOS>
<BOS>Talk with your doctor about clinical trials that may be right for you.<EOS>
<BOS>General information about clinical trials is available from the NCI website.<EOS>
<BOS>Stage III Melanoma That Cannot Be Removed By Surgery, Stage IV Melanoma, and Recurrent Melanoma Treatment of stage III melanoma that cannot be removed by surgery, stage IV melanoma, and recurrent melanoma may include the following: Immunotherapy with ipilimumab, pembrolizumab, nivolumab, or interleukin2 (IL2).<EOS>
<BOS>Sometimes ipilimumab and nivolumab are given together.<EOS>
<BOS>Targeted therapy with vemurafenib, dabrafenib, trametinib, or cobimetinib.<EOS>
<BOS>Sometimes vemurafenib and cobimetinib or dabrafenib and trametinib are given together.<EOS>
<BOS>Injections into the tumor, such as oncolytic virus therapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Chemotherapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Palliative therapy to relieve symptoms and improve the quality of life.<EOS>
<BOS>This may include: Surgery to remove lymph nodes or tumors in the lung, gastrointestinal (GI) tract, bone, or brain.<EOS>
<BOS>Radiation therapy to the brain, spinal cord, or bone.<EOS>
<BOS>Treatments that are being studied in clinical trials for stage III melanoma that cannot be removed by surgery, stage IV melanoma, and recurrent melanoma include the following: Immunotherapy alone or in combination with other therapies such as targeted therapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Targeted therapy, such as signal transduction inhibitors, angiogenesis inhibitors, oncolytic virus therapy, or drugs that target certain gene mutations.<EOS>
<BOS>These may be given alone or in combination.<EOS>
<BOS>Surgery to remove all known cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Regional chemotherapy (hyperthermic isolated limb perfusion).<EOS>
<BOS>Some patients may also have immunotherapy with tumor necrosis factor.<EOS>
<BOS>Systemic chemotherapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Check the list of NCIsupported cancer clinical trials that are now accepting patients with stage IV melanoma and recurrent melanoma.<EOS>
<BOS>For more specific results, refine the search by using other search features, such as the location of the trial, the type of treatment, or the name of the drug.<EOS>
<BOS>Talk with your doctor about clinical trials that may be right for you.<EOS>
<BOS>General information about clinical trials is available from the NCI website.<EOS>
<BOS>Key Points Prostate cancer is a disease in which malignant (cancer) cells form in the tissues of the prostate.<EOS>
<BOS>Prostate cancer is the second most common cancer among men in the United States.<EOS>
<BOS>Prostate cancer is a disease in which malignant (cancer) cells form in the tissues of the prostate.<EOS>
<BOS>The prostate is a gland in the male reproductive system.<EOS>
<BOS>The prostate is just below the bladder (the organ that collects and empties urine) and in front of the rectum (the lower part of the intestine).<EOS>
<BOS>It is about the size of a walnut and surrounds part of the urethra (the tube that empties urine from the bladder).<EOS>
<BOS>The prostate gland produces fluid that makes up part of the semen.<EOS>
<BOS>As men age, the prostate may get bigger.<EOS>
<BOS>A bigger prostate may block the flow of urine from the bladder and cause problems with sexual function.<EOS>
<BOS>This condition is called benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH).<EOS>
<BOS>BPH is not cancer, but surgery may be needed to correct it.<EOS>
<BOS>The symptoms of BPH or of other problems in the prostate may be like symptoms of prostate cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Certain factors affect prognosis (chance of recovery) and treatment options.<EOS>
<BOS>The prognosis (chance of recovery) and treatment options depend on the following: The number and size of lymph nodes that have cancer in them.<EOS>
<BOS>Whether the cancer has responded to treatment or has recurred (come back).<EOS>
<BOS>How different from normal the cancer cells look under a microscope.<EOS>
<BOS>The patient's age and general health.<EOS>
<BOS>Treatment options also depend on the following: Which part of the neck the cancer is in.<EOS>
<BOS>Whether certain tumor markers are found.<EOS>
<BOS>Tests that examine the rectum and colon are used to detect (find) and diagnose rectal cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Tests used to diagnose rectal cancer include the following: Physical exam and history : An exam of the body to check general signs of health, including checking for signs of disease, such as lumps or anything else that seems unusual.<EOS>
<BOS>A history of the patients health habits and past illnesses and treatments will also be taken.<EOS>
<BOS>Digital rectal exam (DRE): An exam of the rectum.<EOS>
<BOS>The doctor or nurse inserts a lubricated, gloved finger into the lower part of the rectum to feel for lumps or anything else that seems unusual.<EOS>
<BOS>In women, the vagina may also be examined.<EOS>
<BOS>Colonoscopy : A procedure to look inside the rectum and colon for polyps (small pieces of bulging tissue), abnormal areas, or cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>A colonoscope is a thin, tubelike instrument with a light and a lens for viewing.<EOS>
<BOS>It may also have a tool to remove polyps or tissue samples, which are checked under a microscope for signs of cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Biopsy : The removal of cells or tissues so they can be viewed under a microscope to check for signs of cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Tumor tissue that is removed during the biopsy may be checked to see if the patient is likely to have the gene mutation that causes HNPCC.<EOS>
<BOS>This may help to plan treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>The following tests may be used: Reverse transcriptionpolymerase chain reaction (RTPCR) test: A laboratory test in which cells in a sample of tissue are studied using chemicals to look for certain changes in the structure or function of genes.<EOS>
<BOS>Immunohistochemistry : A test that uses antibodies to check for certain antigens in a sample of tissue.<EOS>
<BOS>The antibody is usually linked to a radioactive substance or a dye that causes the tissue to light up under a microscope.<EOS>
<BOS>This type of test may be used to tell the difference between different types of cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Carcinoembryonic antigen (CEA) assay : A test that measures the level of CEA in the blood.<EOS>
<BOS>CEA is released into the bloodstream from both cancer cells and normal cells.<EOS>
<BOS>When found in higher than normal amounts, it can be a sign of rectal cancer or other conditions.<EOS>
<BOS>Signs of urethral cancer include bleeding or trouble with urination.<EOS>
<BOS>These and other signs and symptoms may be caused by urethral cancer or by other conditions.<EOS>
<BOS>There may be no signs or symptoms in the early stages.<EOS>
<BOS>Check with your doctor if you have any of the following: Trouble starting the flow of urine.<EOS>
<BOS>Weak or interrupted ("stopandgo") flow of urine.<EOS>
<BOS>Frequent urination, especially at night.<EOS>
<BOS>Incontinence.<EOS>
<BOS>Discharge from the urethra.<EOS>
<BOS>Bleeding from the urethra or blood in the urine.<EOS>
<BOS>A lump or thickness in the perineum or penis.<EOS>
<BOS>A painless lump or swelling in the groin.<EOS>
<BOS>Key Points Male breast cancer is a disease in which malignant (cancer) cells form in the tissues of the breast.<EOS>
<BOS>Radiation exposure, high levels of estrogen, and a family history of breast cancer can increase a mans risk of breast cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Male breast cancer is sometimes caused by inherited gene mutations (changes).<EOS>
<BOS>Men with breast cancer usually have lumps that can be felt.<EOS>
<BOS>Tests that examine the breasts are used to detect (find) and diagnose breast cancer in men.<EOS>
<BOS>If cancer is found, tests are done to study the cancer cells.<EOS>
<BOS>Survival for men with breast cancer is similar to survival for women with breast cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Certain factors affect prognosis (chance of recovery) and treatment options.<EOS>
<BOS>Male breast cancer is a disease in which malignant (cancer) cells form in the tissues of the breast.<EOS>
<BOS>Breast cancer may occur in men.<EOS>
<BOS>Men at any age may develop breast cancer, but it is usually detected (found) in men between 60 and 70 years of age.<EOS>
<BOS>Male breast cancer makes up less than 1% of all cases of breast cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>The following types of breast cancer are found in men: Infiltrating ductal carcinoma: Cancer that has spread beyond the cells lining ducts in the breast.<EOS>
<BOS>Most men with breast cancer have this type of cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Ductal carcinoma in situ: Abnormal cells that are found in the lining of a duct; also called intraductal carcinoma.<EOS>
<BOS>Inflammatory breast cancer: A type of cancer in which the breast looks red and swollen and feels warm.<EOS>
<BOS>Paget disease of the nipple: A tumor that has grown from ducts beneath the nipple onto the surface of the nipple.<EOS>
<BOS>Lobular carcinoma in situ (abnormal cells found in one of the lobes or sections of the breast), which sometimes occurs in women, has not been seen in men.<EOS>
<BOS>Men with breast cancer usually have lumps that can be felt.<EOS>
<BOS>Lumps and other signs may be caused by male breast cancer or by other conditions.<EOS>
<BOS>Check with your doctor if you notice a change in your breasts.<EOS>
<BOS>Key Points Intraocular melanoma is a disease in which malignant (cancer) cells form in the tissues of the eye.<EOS>
<BOS>Being older and having fair skin may increase the risk of intraocular melanoma.<EOS>
<BOS>Signs of intraocular melanoma include blurred vision or a dark spot on the iris.<EOS>
<BOS>Tests that examine the eye are used to help detect (find) and diagnose intraocular melanoma.<EOS>
<BOS>A biopsy of the tumor is rarely needed to diagnose intraocular melanoma.<EOS>
<BOS>Certain factors affect prognosis (chance of recovery) and treatment options.<EOS>
<BOS>Intraocular melanoma is a disease in which malignant (cancer) cells form in the tissues of the eye.<EOS>
<BOS>Intraocular melanoma begins in the middle of three layers of the wall of the eye.<EOS>
<BOS>The outer layer includes the white sclera (the "white of the eye") and the clear cornea at the front of the eye.<EOS>
<BOS>The inner layer has a lining of nerve tissue, called the retina, which senses light and sends images along the optic nerve to the brain.<EOS>
<BOS>The middle layer, where intraocular melanoma forms, is called the uvea or uveal tract, and has three main parts: Iris The iris is the colored area at the front of the eye (the "eye color").<EOS>
<BOS>It can be seen through the clear cornea.<EOS>
<BOS>The pupil is in the center of the iris and it changes size to let more or less light into the eye.<EOS>
<BOS>Intraocular melanoma of the iris is usually a small tumor that grows slowly and rarely spreads to other parts of the body.<EOS>
<BOS>Ciliary body The ciliary body is a ring of tissue with muscle fibers that change the size of the pupil and the shape of the lens.<EOS>
<BOS>It is found behind the iris.<EOS>
<BOS>Changes in the shape of the lens help the eye focus.<EOS>
<BOS>The ciliary body also makes the clear fluid that fills the space between the cornea and the iris.<EOS>
<BOS>Intraocular melanoma of the ciliary body is often larger and more likely to spread to other parts of the body than intraocular melanoma of the iris.<EOS>
<BOS>Choroid The choroid is a layer of blood vessels that bring oxygen and nutrients to the eye.<EOS>
<BOS>Most intraocular melanomas begin in the choroid.<EOS>
<BOS>Intraocular melanoma of the choroid is often larger and more likely to spread to other parts of the body than intraocular melanoma of the iris.<EOS>
<BOS>Intraocular melanoma is a rare cancer that forms from cells that make melanin in the iris, ciliary body, and choroid.<EOS>
<BOS>It is the most common eye cancer in adults.<EOS>
<BOS>Key Points Adult primary liver cancer is a disease in which malignant (cancer) cells form in the tissues of the liver.<EOS>
<BOS>There are two types of adult primary liver cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Having hepatitis or cirrhosis can affect the risk of adult primary liver cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Signs and symptoms of adult primary liver cancer include a lump or pain on the right side.<EOS>
<BOS>Tests that examine the liver and the blood are used to detect (find) and diagnose adult primary liver cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Certain factors affect prognosis (chance of recovery) and treatment options.<EOS>
<BOS>Adult primary liver cancer is a disease in which malignant (cancer) cells form in the tissues of the liver.<EOS>
<BOS>The liver is one of the largest organs in the body.<EOS>
<BOS>It has four lobes and fills the upper right side of the abdomen inside the rib cage.<EOS>
<BOS>Three of the many important functions of the liver are: To filter harmful substances from the blood so they can be passed from the body in stools and urine.<EOS>
<BOS>To make bile to help digest fat that comes from food.<EOS>
<BOS>To store glycogen (sugar), which the body uses for energy.<EOS>
<BOS>There are two types of adult primary liver cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>The two types of adult primary liver cancer are: Hepatocellular carcinoma.<EOS>
<BOS>Cholangiocarcinoma (bile duct cancer).<EOS>
<BOS>(See the PDQ summary on Bile Duct Cancer Treatment for more information.<EOS>
<BOS>) The most common type of adult primary liver cancer is hepatocellular carcinoma.<EOS>
<BOS>This type of liver cancer is the third leading cause of cancerrelated deaths worldwide.<EOS>
<BOS>This summary is about the treatment of primary liver cancer (cancer that begins in the liver).<EOS>
<BOS>Treatment of cancer that begins in other parts of the body and spreads to the liver is not covered in this summary.<EOS>
<BOS>Primary liver cancer can occur in both adults and children.<EOS>
<BOS>However, treatment for children is different than treatment for adults.<EOS>
<BOS>(See the PDQ summary on Childhood Liver Cancer Treatment for more information.<EOS>
<BOS>).<EOS>
<BOS>Key Points There are different types of treatment for patients with neuroblastoma.<EOS>
<BOS>Children with neuroblastoma should have their treatment planned by a team of doctors who are experts in treating childhood cancer, especially neuroblastoma.<EOS>
<BOS>Children who are treated for neuroblastoma may have late effects, including an increased risk of second cancers.<EOS>
<BOS>Seven types of standard treatment are used: Observation Surgery Radiation therapy Iodine 131mIBG therapy Chemotherapy Highdose chemotherapy and radiation therapy with stem cell rescue Targeted therapy New types of treatment are being tested in clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>Immunotherapy Other drug therapy Patients may want to think about taking part in a clinical trial.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients can enter clinical trials before, during, or after starting their cancer treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Followup tests may be needed.<EOS>
<BOS>There are different types of treatment for patients with neuroblastoma.<EOS>
<BOS>Different types of treatment are available for patients with neuroblastoma.<EOS>
<BOS>Some treatments are standard (the currently used treatment), and some are being tested in clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>A treatment clinical trial is a research study meant to help improve current treatments or obtain information on new treatments for patients with cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>When clinical trials show that a new treatment is better than the standard treatment, the new treatment may become the standard treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Because cancer in children is rare, taking part in a clinical trial should be considered.<EOS>
<BOS>Some clinical trials are open only to patients who have not started treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Children with neuroblastoma should have their treatment planned by a team of doctors who are experts in treating childhood cancer, especially neuroblastoma.<EOS>
<BOS>Treatment will be overseen by a pediatric oncologist, a doctor who specializes in treating children with cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>The pediatric oncologist works with other pediatric health care providers who are experts in treating children with neuroblastoma and who specialize in certain areas of medicine.<EOS>
<BOS>These may include the following specialists: Pediatric surgeon.<EOS>
<BOS>Pediatric radiation oncologist.<EOS>
<BOS>Endocrinologist.<EOS>
<BOS>Neurologist.<EOS>
<BOS>Pediatric neuropathologist.<EOS>
<BOS>Neuroradiologist.<EOS>
<BOS>Pediatrician.<EOS>
<BOS>Pediatric nurse specialist.<EOS>
<BOS>Social worker.<EOS>
<BOS>Child life professional.<EOS>
<BOS>Psychologist.<EOS>
<BOS>Children who are treated for neuroblastoma may have late effects, including an increased risk of second cancers.<EOS>
<BOS>Some cancer treatments cause side effects that continue or appear years after cancer treatment has ended.<EOS>
<BOS>These are called late effects.<EOS>
<BOS>Late effects of cancer treatment may include: Physical problems.<EOS>
<BOS>Changes in mood, feelings, thinking, learning, or memory.<EOS>
<BOS>Second cancers (new types of cancer).<EOS>
<BOS>Some late effects may be treated or controlled.<EOS>
<BOS>It is important that parents of children who are treated for neuroblastoma talk with their doctors about the possible late effects caused by some treatments.<EOS>
<BOS>See the PDQ summary on Late Effects of Treatment for Childhood Cancer for more information.<EOS>
<BOS>Seven types of standard treatment are used: Observation Observation is closely monitoring a patient's condition without giving any treatment until signs or symptoms appear or change.<EOS>
<BOS>Surgery Surgery is used to treat neuroblastoma unless it has spread to other parts of the body.<EOS>
<BOS>Depending on where the tumor is, as much of the tumor as is safely possible will be removed.<EOS>
<BOS>If the tumor cannot be removed, a biopsy may be done instead.<EOS>
<BOS>Radiation therapy Radiation therapy is a cancer treatment that uses highenergy xrays or other types of radiation to kill cancer cells or keep them from growing.<EOS>
<BOS>There are two types of radiation therapy: External radiation therapy uses a machine outside the body to send radiation toward the cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Internal radiation therapy uses a radioactive substance sealed in needles, seeds, wires, or catheters that are placed directly into or near the cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>The way the radiation therapy is given depends on the type of cancer being treated and the child's risk group.<EOS>
<BOS>External radiation therapy is used to treat neuroblastoma.<EOS>
<BOS>Iodine 131mIBG therapy Iodine 131mIBG therapy is a treatment with radioactive iodine.<EOS>
<BOS>The radioactive iodine is given through an intravenous (IV) line and enters the bloodstream which carries radiation directly to tumor cells.<EOS>
<BOS>Radioactive iodine collects in neuroblastoma cells and kills them with the radiation that is given off.<EOS>
<BOS>Iodine 131mIBG therapy is sometimes used to treat highrisk neuroblastoma that comes back after initial treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Chemotherapy Chemotherapy is a cancer treatment that uses drugs to stop the growth of cancer cells, either by killing the cells or by stopping them from dividing.<EOS>
<BOS>When chemotherapy is taken by mouth or injected into a vein or muscle, the drugs enter the bloodstream and can reach cancer cells throughout the body (systemic chemotherapy).<EOS>
<BOS>When chemotherapy is placed directly into the cerebrospinal fluid, an organ, or a body cavity such as the abdomen, the drugs mainly affect cancer cells in those areas (regional chemotherapy).<EOS>
<BOS>The way the chemotherapy is given depends on the type of cancer being treated and the child's risk group.<EOS>
<BOS>The use of two or more anticancer drugs is called combination chemotherapy.<EOS>
<BOS>See Drugs Approved for Neuroblastoma for more information.<EOS>
<BOS>Highdose chemotherapy and radiation therapy with stem cell rescue Highdose chemotherapy and radiation therapy with stem cell rescue is a way of giving high doses of chemotherapy and radiation therapy and replacing blood forming cells destroyed by cancer treatment for highrisk neuroblastoma.<EOS>
<BOS>Stem cells (immature blood cells) are removed from the blood or bone marrow of the patient and are frozen and stored.<EOS>
<BOS>After chemotherapy and radiation therapy are completed, the stored stem cells are thawed and given back to the patient through an infusion.<EOS>
<BOS>These reinfused stem cells grow into (and restore) the body's blood cells.<EOS>
<BOS>Maintenance therapy is given after highdose chemotherapy and radiation therapy with stem cell rescue to kill any cancer cells that may regrow and cause the disease to come back.<EOS>
<BOS>Maintenance therapy is given for 6 months and includes the following treatments: Isotretinoin: A vitamin like drug that slows the cancer's ability to make more cancer cells and changes how these cells look and act.<EOS>
<BOS>This drug is taken by mouth.<EOS>
<BOS>Dinutuximab: A type of monoclonal antibody therapy that uses an antibody made in the laboratory from a single type of immune system cell.<EOS>
<BOS>Dinutuximab identifies and attaches to a substance, called GD2, on the surface of neuroblastoma cells.<EOS>
<BOS>Once dinutuximab attaches to the GD2, a signal is sent to the immune system that a foreign substance has been found and needs to be killed.<EOS>
<BOS>Then the body's immune system kills the neuroblastoma cell.<EOS>
<BOS>Dinutuximab is given by infusion.<EOS>
<BOS>It is a type of targeted therapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Granulocytemacrophage colonystimulating factor (GMCSF): A cytokine that helps make more immune system cells, especially granulocytes and macrophages (white blood cells), which can attack and kill cancer cells.<EOS>
<BOS>Interleukin2 (IL2): A type of immunotherapy that boosts the growth and activity of many immune cells, especially lymphocytes (a type of white blood cell).<EOS>
<BOS>Lymphocytes can attack and kill cancer cells.<EOS>
<BOS>See Drugs Approved for Neuroblastoma for more information.<EOS>
<BOS>Targeted therapy Targeted therapy is a type of treatment that uses drugs or other substances to identify and attack cancer cells with less harm to normal cells.<EOS>
<BOS>There are different types of targeted therapy: Tyrosine kinase inhibitors are smallmolecule drugs that go through the cell membrane and work inside cancer cells to block signals that cancer cells need to grow and divide.<EOS>
<BOS>Crizotinib is used to treat neuroblastoma that has come back after treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Antibodydrug conjugates are made up of a monoclonal antibody attached to a drug.<EOS>
<BOS>The monoclonal antibody binds to specific proteins or receptors found on certain cells, including cancer cells.<EOS>
<BOS>The drug enters these cells and kills them without harming other cells.<EOS>
<BOS>Lorvotuzumab mertansine is an antibodydrug conjugate being studied to treat neuroblastoma that has come back after treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>New types of treatment are being tested in clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>This summary section describes treatments that are being studied in clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>It may not mention every new treatment being studied.<EOS>
<BOS>Information about clinical trials is available from the NCI website.<EOS>
<BOS>Immunotherapy Immunotherapy is a treatment that uses the patients immune system to fight cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Substances made by the body or made in a laboratory are used to boost, direct, or restore the bodys natural defenses against cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>This type of cancer treatment is also called biotherapy or biological therapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Vaccine therapy uses a substance to stimulate the immune system to destroy a tumor.<EOS>
<BOS>Vaccine therapy is being studied to treat neuroblastoma that has come back after treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Other drug therapy Lenalidomide is a type of angiogenesis inhibitor.<EOS>
<BOS>It prevents the growth of new blood vessels that are needed by a tumor to grow.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients may want to think about taking part in a clinical trial.<EOS>
<BOS>For some patients, taking part in a clinical trial may be the best treatment choice.<EOS>
<BOS>Clinical trials are part of the cancer research process.<EOS>
<BOS>Clinical trials are done to find out if new cancer treatments are safe and effective or better than the standard treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Many of today's standard treatments for cancer are based on earlier clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients who take part in a clinical trial may receive the standard treatment or be among the first to receive a new treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients who take part in clinical trials also help improve the way cancer will be treated in the future.<EOS>
<BOS>Even when clinical trials do not lead to effective new treatments, they often answer important questions and help move research forward.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients can enter clinical trials before, during, or after starting their cancer treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Some clinical trials only include patients who have not yet received treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Other trials test treatments for patients whose cancer has not gotten better.<EOS>
<BOS>There are also clinical trials that test new ways to stop cancer from recurring (coming back) or reduce the side effects of cancer treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Clinical trials are taking place in many parts of the country.<EOS>
<BOS>See the Treatment Options section that follows for links to current treatment clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>These have been retrieved from NCI's listing of clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>Followup tests may be needed.<EOS>
<BOS>Some of the tests that were done to diagnose the cancer or to find out the stage of the cancer may be repeated.<EOS>
<BOS>Some tests will be repeated in order to see how well the treatment is working.<EOS>
<BOS>Decisions about whether to continue, change, or stop treatment may be based on the results of these tests.<EOS>
<BOS>Some of the tests will continue to be done from time to time after treatment has ended.<EOS>
<BOS>The results of these tests can show if your child's condition has changed or if the cancer has recurred (come back).<EOS>
<BOS>These tests are sometimes called followup tests or checkups.<EOS>
<BOS>Treatment Options for Neuroblastoma LowRisk Neuroblastoma Treatment of lowrisk neuroblastoma may include the following: Surgery followed by observation.<EOS>
<BOS>Chemotherapy with or without surgery, for children with symptoms, children whose tumor has continued to grow and cannot be removed by surgery, or children with unfavorable tumor biology.<EOS>
<BOS>Observation alone for infants younger than 6 months who have small adrenal tumors.<EOS>
<BOS>Observation alone for infants who do not have signs or symptoms of neuroblastoma.<EOS>
<BOS>Radiation therapy to treat tumors that are causing serious problems and do not respond quickly to chemotherapy or surgery.<EOS>
<BOS>A clinical trial of treatment based on the tumor's response to treatment and tumor biology.<EOS>
<BOS>IntermediateRisk Neuroblastoma Treatment of intermediaterisk neuroblastoma may include the following: Chemotherapy for children with symptoms or to shrink a tumor that cannot be removed by surgery.<EOS>
<BOS>Surgery may be done after chemotherapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Surgery alone for infants.<EOS>
<BOS>Observation alone for certain infants.<EOS>
<BOS>Radiation therapy to treat tumors that are causing serious problems and do not respond quickly to chemotherapy or surgery.<EOS>
<BOS>Radiation therapy for tumors that do not respond to other treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>A clinical trial of treatment based on the tumor's response to treatment and tumor biology.<EOS>
<BOS>HighRisk Neuroblastoma Treatment of highrisk neuroblastoma may include the following: A regimen of combination chemotherapy, surgery, stem cell rescue, radiation therapy, and monoclonal antibody therapy (dinutuximab) with interleukin2 (IL2), granulocytemacrophage colonystimulating factor (GMCSF), and isotretinoin.<EOS>
<BOS>Stage 4S Neuroblastoma There is no standard treatment for stage 4S neuroblastoma but treatment options include the following: Observation with supportive care for certain children who have favorable tumor biology and do not have signs or symptoms.<EOS>
<BOS>Chemotherapy, for children who have signs or symptoms of neuroblastoma or unfavorable tumor biology, or for very young infants.<EOS>
<BOS>A clinical trial of treatment based on the tumor's response to treatment and tumor biology.<EOS>
<BOS>Recurrent Neuroblastoma Patients First Treated for LowRisk Neuroblastoma Treatment for recurrent neuroblastoma that is found only in the area where the cancer first formed may include the following: Surgery followed by observation or chemotherapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Chemotherapy that may be followed by surgery.<EOS>
<BOS>Treatment for recurrent neuroblastoma that has spread to other parts of the body may include the following: Observation.<EOS>
<BOS>Chemotherapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Surgery followed by chemotherapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Treatment as for newly diagnosed highrisk neuroblastoma for children older than 1 year.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients First Treated for IntermediateRisk Neuroblastoma Treatment for recurrent neuroblastoma that is found only in the area where the cancer first formed may include the following: Surgery that may be followed by chemotherapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Treatment as for newly diagnosed highrisk neuroblastoma for neuroblastoma that has spread to other parts of the body.<EOS>
<BOS>Recurrent neuroblastoma that has spread to other parts of the body is treated the same way as newly diagnosed highrisk neuroblastoma.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients First Treated for HighRisk Neuroblastoma Treatment for recurrent neuroblastoma may include the following: Combination chemotherapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Iodine 131mIBG therapy to relieve symptoms and improve quality of life.<EOS>
<BOS>It may be given alone or in combination with other therapy, or before stem cell rescue.<EOS>
<BOS>A second course of highdose chemotherapy and stem cell rescue.<EOS>
<BOS>Tyrosine kinase inhibitor therapy (crizotinib) for patients with changes in the ALK gene.<EOS>
<BOS>Because there is no standard treatment for recurrent neuroblastoma in patients first treated for highrisk neuroblastoma, patients may want to consider a clinical trial.<EOS>
<BOS>For information about clinical trials, please see the NCI website.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients with Recurrent CNS Neuroblastoma Treatment for neuroblastoma that recurs (comes back) in the central nervous system (CNS; brain and spinal cord) may include the following: Surgery to remove the tumor in the CNS followed by radiation therapy.<EOS>
<BOS>A clinical trial of a new therapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Treatments Being Studied for Progressive/Recurrent Neuroblastoma Some of the treatments being studied in clinical trials for neuroblastoma that recurs (comes back) or progresses (grows, spreads, or does not respond to treatment) include the following: Combination chemotherapy and monoclonal antibody therapy (dinutuximab).<EOS>
<BOS>Lenalidomide and monoclonal antibody therapy (dinutuximab) with or without isotretinoin.<EOS>
<BOS>Iodine 131mIBG given alone or with other anticancer drugs.<EOS>
<BOS>Immunotherapy (vaccine therapy).<EOS>
<BOS>Tyrosine kinase inhibitor (crizotinib) and combination chemotherapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Targeted therapy with an antibodydrug conjugate (lorvotuzumab mertansine).<EOS>
<BOS>Signs of childhood Hodgkin lymphoma include swollen lymph nodes, fever, night sweats, and weight loss.<EOS>
<BOS>These and other signs and symptoms may be caused by childhood Hodgkin lymphoma or by other conditions.<EOS>
<BOS>Check with your child's doctor if your child has any of the following: Painless, swollen lymph nodes near the collarbone or in the neck, chest, underarm, or groin.<EOS>
<BOS>Fever for no known reason.<EOS>
<BOS>Weight loss for no known reason.<EOS>
<BOS>Night sweats.<EOS>
<BOS>Fatigue.<EOS>
<BOS>Anorexia.<EOS>
<BOS>Itchy skin.<EOS>
<BOS>Pain in the lymph nodes after drinking alcohol.<EOS>
<BOS>Fever, weight loss, and night sweats are called B symptoms.<EOS>
<BOS>Certain factors affect prognosis (chance of recovery).<EOS>
<BOS>The prognosis (chance of recovery) depends on the following: The type of germ cell tumor.<EOS>
<BOS>The type and level of any tumor markers.<EOS>
<BOS>Where the tumor is in the brain or in the spinal cord.<EOS>
<BOS>Whether the cancer has spread within the brain and spinal cord or to other parts of the body.<EOS>
<BOS>Whether the tumor is newly diagnosed or has recurred (come back) after treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>The following tests and procedures may be used to detect (find) and diagnose LCH or conditions caused by LCH: Physical exam and history : An exam of the body to check general signs of health, including checking for signs of disease, such as lumps or anything else that seems unusual.<EOS>
<BOS>A history of the patient's health habits and past illnesses and treatments will also be taken.<EOS>
<BOS>Neurological exam : A series of questions and tests to check the brain, spinal cord, and nerve function.<EOS>
<BOS>The exam checks a person's mental status, coordination, and ability to walk normally, and how well the muscles, senses, and reflexes work.<EOS>
<BOS>This may also be called a neuro exam or a neurologic exam.<EOS>
<BOS>Complete blood count (CBC) with differential : A procedure in which a sample of blood is drawn and checked for the following: The amount of hemoglobin (the protein that carries oxygen) in the red blood cells.<EOS>
<BOS>The portion of the blood sample made up of red blood cells.<EOS>
<BOS>The number and type of white blood cells.<EOS>
<BOS>The number of red blood cells and platelets.<EOS>
<BOS>Blood chemistry studies : A procedure in which a blood sample is checked to measure the amounts of certain substances released into the body by organs and tissues in the body.<EOS>
<BOS>An unusual (higher or lower than normal) amount of a substance can be a sign of disease.<EOS>
<BOS>Liver function test : A blood test to measure the blood levels of certain substances released by the liver.<EOS>
<BOS>A high or low level of these substances can be a sign of disease in the liver.<EOS>
<BOS>BRAF gene testing : A laboratory test in which a sample of blood or tissue is tested for mutations of the BRAF gene.<EOS>
<BOS>Urinalysis : A test to check the color of urine and its contents, such as sugar, protein, red blood cells, and white blood cells.<EOS>
<BOS>Water deprivation test : A test to check how much urine is made and whether it becomes concentrated when little or no water is given.<EOS>
<BOS>This test is used to diagnose diabetes insipidus, which may be caused by LCH.<EOS>
<BOS>Bone marrow aspiration and biopsy : The removal of bone marrow and a small piece of bone by inserting a hollow needle into the hipbone.<EOS>
<BOS>A pathologist views the bone marrow and bone under a microscope to look for signs of LCH.<EOS>
<BOS>The following tests may be done on the tissue that was removed: Immunohistochemistry : A test that uses antibodies to check for certain antigens in a sample of tissue.<EOS>
<BOS>The antibody is usually linked to a radioactive substance or a dye that causes the tissue to light up under a microscope.<EOS>
<BOS>This type of test may be used to tell the difference between different types of cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Flow cytometry : A laboratory test that measures the number of cells in a sample, how many cells are live, and the size of the cells.<EOS>
<BOS>It also shows the shapes of the cells and whether there are tumor markers on the surface of the cells.<EOS>
<BOS>The cells are stained with a lightsensitive dye, placed in a fluid, and passed in a stream before a laser or other type of light.<EOS>
<BOS>The measurements are based on how the lightsensitive dye reacts to the light.<EOS>
<BOS>Bone scan : A procedure to check if there are rapidly dividing cells in the bone.<EOS>
<BOS>A very small amount of radioactive material is injected into a vein and travels through the bloodstream.<EOS>
<BOS>The radioactive material collects in the bones with cancer and is detected by a scanner.<EOS>
<BOS>Xray : An xray of the organs and bones inside the body.<EOS>
<BOS>An xray is a type of energy beam that can go through the body and onto film, making a picture of areas inside the body.<EOS>
<BOS>Sometimes a skeletal survey is done.<EOS>
<BOS>This is a procedure to xray all of the bones in the body.<EOS>
<BOS>CT scan (CAT scan): A procedure that makes a series of detailed pictures of areas inside the body, taken from different angles.<EOS>
<BOS>The pictures are made by a computer linked to an xray machine.<EOS>
<BOS>A dye may be injected into a vein or swallowed to help the organs or tissues show up more clearly.<EOS>
<BOS>This procedure is also called computed tomography, computerized tomography, or computerized axial tomography.<EOS>
<BOS>MRI (magnetic resonance imaging): A procedure that uses a magnet, radio waves, and a computer to make a series of detailed pictures of areas inside the body.<EOS>
<BOS>A substance called gadolinium may be injected into a vein.<EOS>
<BOS>The gadolinium collects around the LCH cells so that they show up brighter in the picture.<EOS>
<BOS>This procedure is also called nuclear magnetic resonance imaging (NMRI).<EOS>
<BOS>PET scan (positron emission tomography scan): A procedure to find tumor cells in the body.<EOS>
<BOS>A small amount of radioactive glucose (sugar) is injected into a vein.<EOS>
<BOS>The PET scanner rotates around the body and makes a picture of where glucose is being used in the body.<EOS>
<BOS>Tumor cells show up brighter in the picture because they are more active and take up more glucose than normal cells do.<EOS>
<BOS>Ultrasound exam: A procedure in which highenergy sound waves (ultrasound) are bounced off internal tissues or organs and make echoes.<EOS>
<BOS>The echoes form a picture of body tissues called a sonogram.<EOS>
<BOS>The picture can be printed to be looked at later.<EOS>
<BOS>Bronchoscopy : A procedure to look inside the trachea and large airways in the lung for abnormal areas.<EOS>
<BOS>A bronchoscope is inserted through the nose or mouth into the trachea and lungs.<EOS>
<BOS>A bronchoscope is a thin, tubelike instrument with a light and a lens for viewing.<EOS>
<BOS>It may also have a tool to remove tissue samples, which are checked under a microscope for signs of cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Endoscopy : A procedure to look at organs and tissues inside the body to check for abnormal areas in the gastrointestinal tract or lungs.<EOS>
<BOS>An endoscope is inserted through an incision (cut) in the skin or opening in the body, such as the mouth.<EOS>
<BOS>An endoscope is a thin, tubelike instrument with a light and a lens for viewing.<EOS>
<BOS>It may also have a tool to remove tissue or lymph node samples, which are checked under a microscope for signs of disease.<EOS>
<BOS>Biopsy : The removal of cells or tissues so they can be viewed under a microscope by a pathologist to check for LCH cells.<EOS>
<BOS>To diagnose LCH, a biopsy of bone lesions, skin, lymph nodes, or the liver may be done.<EOS>
<BOS>Key Points Childhood acute myeloid leukemia (AML) is a type of cancer in which the bone marrow makes a large number of abnormal blood cells.<EOS>
<BOS>Leukemia and other diseases of the blood and bone marrow may affect red blood cells, white blood cells, and platelets.<EOS>
<BOS>Other myeloid diseases can affect the blood and bone marrow.<EOS>
<BOS>Chronic myelogenous leukemia Juvenile myelomonocytic leukemia Myelodysplastic syndromes AML or MDS may occur after treatment with certain anticancer drugs and/or radiation therapy.<EOS>
<BOS>The risk factors for childhood AML, childhood CML, JMML, and MDS are similar.<EOS>
<BOS>Signs and symptoms of childhood AML, childhood CML, JMML, or MDS include fever, feeling tired, and easy bleeding or bruising.<EOS>
<BOS>Tests that examine the blood and bone marrow are used to detect (find) and diagnose childhood AML, childhood CML, JMML, and MDS.<EOS>
<BOS>Certain factors affect prognosis (chance of recovery) and treatment options.<EOS>
<BOS>Childhood acute myeloid leukemia (AML) is a type of cancer in which the bone marrow makes a large number of abnormal blood cells.<EOS>
<BOS>Childhood acute myeloid leukemia (AML) is a cancer of the blood and bone marrow.<EOS>
<BOS>AML is also called acute myelogenous leukemia, acute myeloblastic leukemia, acute granulocytic leukemia, and acute nonlymphocytic leukemia.<EOS>
<BOS>Cancers that are acute usually get worse quickly if they are not treated.<EOS>
<BOS>Cancers that are chronic usually get worse slowly.<EOS>
<BOS>Leukemia and other diseases of the blood and bone marrow may affect red blood cells, white blood cells, and platelets.<EOS>
<BOS>Normally, the bone marrow makes blood stem cells (immature cells) that become mature blood cells over time.<EOS>
<BOS>A blood stem cell may become a myeloid stem cell or a lymphoid stem cell.<EOS>
<BOS>A lymphoid stem cell becomes a white blood cell.<EOS>
<BOS>A myeloid stem cell becomes one of three types of mature blood cells: Red blood cells that carry oxygen and other substances to all tissues of the body.<EOS>
<BOS>White blood cells that fight infection and disease.<EOS>
<BOS>Platelets that form blood clots to stop bleeding.<EOS>
<BOS>In AML, the myeloid stem cells usually become a type of immature white blood cell called myeloblasts (or myeloid blasts).<EOS>
<BOS>The myeloblasts, or leukemia cells, in AML are abnormal and do not become healthy white blood cells.<EOS>
<BOS>The leukemia cells can build up in the blood and bone marrow so there is less room for healthy white blood cells, red blood cells, and platelets.<EOS>
<BOS>When this happens, infection, anemia, or easy bleeding may occur.<EOS>
<BOS>The leukemia cells can spread outside the blood to other parts of the body, including the central nervous system (brain and spinal cord), skin, and gums.<EOS>
<BOS>Sometimes leukemia cells form a solid tumor called a granulocytic sarcoma or chloroma.<EOS>
<BOS>There are subtypes of AML based on the type of blood cell that is affected.<EOS>
<BOS>The treatment of AML is different when it is a subtype called acute promyelocytic leukemia (APL) or when the child has Down syndrome.<EOS>
<BOS>Other myeloid diseases can affect the blood and bone marrow.<EOS>
<BOS>Chronic myelogenous leukemia In chronic myelogenous leukemia (CML), too many bone marrow stem cells become a type of white blood cell called granulocytes.<EOS>
<BOS>Some of these bone marrow stem cells never become mature white blood cells.<EOS>
<BOS>These are called blasts.<EOS>
<BOS>Over time, the granulocytes and blasts crowd out the red blood cells and platelets in the bone marrow.<EOS>
<BOS>CML is rare in children.<EOS>
<BOS>Juvenile myelomonocytic leukemia Juvenile myelomonocytic leukemia (JMML) is a rare childhood cancer that occurs more often in children around the age of 2 years and is more common in boys.<EOS>
<BOS>In JMML, too many bone marrow stem cells become 2 types of white blood cells called myelocytes and monocytes.<EOS>
<BOS>Some of these bone marrow stem cells never become mature white blood cells.<EOS>
<BOS>These immature cells, called blasts, are unable to do their usual work.<EOS>
<BOS>Over time, the myelocytes, monocytes, and blasts crowd out the red blood cells and platelets in the bone marrow.<EOS>
<BOS>When this happens, infection, anemia, or easy bleeding may occur.<EOS>
<BOS>Myelodysplastic syndromes Myelodysplastic syndromes (MDS) occur less often in children than in adults.<EOS>
<BOS>In MDS, the bone marrow makes too few red blood cells, white blood cells, and platelets.<EOS>
<BOS>These blood cells may not mature and enter the blood.<EOS>
<BOS>The treatment for MDS depends on how low the numbers of red blood cells, white blood cells, or platelets are.<EOS>
<BOS>Over time, MDS may become AML.<EOS>
<BOS>Transient myeloproliferative disorder (TMD) is a type of MDS.<EOS>
<BOS>This disorder of the bone marrow can develop in newborns who have Down syndrome.<EOS>
<BOS>It usually goes away on its own within the first 3 weeks of life.<EOS>
<BOS>Infants who have Down syndrome and TMD have an increased chance of developing AML before the age of 3 years.<EOS>
<BOS>This summary is about childhood AML, childhood CML, JMML, and MDS.<EOS>
<BOS>See the following PDQ summaries for more information about other types of leukemia and diseases of the blood and bone marrow in children and adults: Childhood Acute Lymphoblastic Leukemia Treatment Adult Acute Myeloid Leukemia Treatment Adult Acute Lymphoblastic Leukemia Treatment Chronic Myelogenous Leukemia Treatment Chronic Lymphocytic Leukemia Treatment Hairy Cell Leukemia Treatment Myelodysplastic Syndromes Treatment Myelodysplastic/Myeloproliferative Neoplasms Treatment AML or MDS may occur after treatment with certain anticancer drugs and/or radiation therapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Cancer treatment with certain anticancer drugs and/or radiation therapy may cause therapy related AML (tAML) or therapyrelated MDS (tMDS).<EOS>
<BOS>The risk of these therapyrelated myeloid diseases depends on the total dose of the anticancer drugs used and the radiation dose and treatment field.<EOS>
<BOS>Some patients also have an inherited risk for tAML and tMDS.<EOS>
<BOS>These therapyrelated diseases usually occur within 7 years after treatment, but are rare in children.<EOS>
<BOS>Certain factors affect treatment options and prognosis (chance of recovery).<EOS>
<BOS>The treatment options and prognosis (chance of recovery) depend on the following: The stage of the cancer (especially the size of the tumor).<EOS>
<BOS>The type of salivary gland the cancer is in.<EOS>
<BOS>The type of cancer cells (how they look under a microscope).<EOS>
<BOS>The patient's age and general health.<EOS>
<BOS>Tests that examine the penis are used to detect (find) and diagnose penile cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>The following tests and procedures may be used: Physical exam and history : An exam of the body to check general signs of health, including checking the penis for signs of disease, such as lumps or anything else that seems unusual.<EOS>
<BOS>A history of the patients health habits and past illnesses and treatments will also be taken.<EOS>
<BOS>Biopsy : The removal of cells or tissues so they can be viewed under a microscope by a pathologist to check for signs of cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>The tissue sample is removed during one of the following procedures: Fineneedle aspiration (FNA) biopsy : The removal of tissue or fluid using a thin needle.<EOS>
<BOS>Incisional biopsy : The removal of part of a lump or a sample of tissue that doesn't look normal.<EOS>
<BOS>Excisional biopsy : The removal of an entire lump or area of tissue that doesnt look normal.<EOS>
<BOS>Some ovarian, fallopian tube, and primary peritoneal cancers are caused by inherited gene mutations (changes).<EOS>
<BOS>The genes in cells carry the hereditary information that is received from a persons parents.<EOS>
<BOS>Hereditary ovarian cancer makes up about 20% of all cases of ovarian cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>There are three hereditary patterns: ovarian cancer alone, ovarian and breast cancers, and ovarian and colon cancers.<EOS>
<BOS>Fallopian tube cancer and peritoneal cancer may also be caused by certain inherited gene mutations.<EOS>
<BOS>There are tests that can detect gene mutations.<EOS>
<BOS>These genetic tests are sometimes done for members of families with a high risk of cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>See the following PDQ summaries for more information: Ovarian, Fallopian Tube, and Primary Peritoneal Cancer Prevention Genetics of Breast and Gynecologic Cancers (for health professionals).<EOS>
<BOS>Imaging and blood tests are used to detect (find) and diagnose extragonadal germ cell tumors.<EOS>
<BOS>The following tests and procedures may be used: Physical exam and history : An exam of the body to check general signs of health, including checking for signs of disease, such as lumps or anything else that seems unusual.<EOS>
<BOS>The testicles may be checked for lumps, swelling, or pain.<EOS>
<BOS>A history of the patient's health habits and past illnesses and treatments will also be taken.<EOS>
<BOS>Chest xray : An xray of the organs and bones inside the chest.<EOS>
<BOS>An xray is a type of energy beam that can go through the body and onto film, making a picture of areas inside the body.<EOS>
<BOS>Serum tumor marker test : A procedure in which a sample of blood is examined to measure the amounts of certain substances released into the blood by organs, tissues, or tumor cells in the body.<EOS>
<BOS>Certain substances are linked to specific types of cancer when found in increased levels in the blood.<EOS>
<BOS>These are called tumor markers.<EOS>
<BOS>The following three tumor markers are used to detect extragonadal germ cell tumor: Alphafetoprotein (AFP).<EOS>
<BOS>Betahuman chorionic gonadotropin (hCG).<EOS>
<BOS>Lactate dehydrogenase (LDH).<EOS>
<BOS>Blood levels of the tumor markers help determine if the tumor is a seminoma or nonseminoma.<EOS>
<BOS>CT scan (CAT scan): A procedure that makes a series of detailed pictures of areas inside the body, taken from different angles.<EOS>
<BOS>The pictures are made by a computer linked to an xray machine.<EOS>
<BOS>A dye may be injected into a vein or swallowed to help the organs or tissues show up more clearly.<EOS>
<BOS>This procedure is also called computed tomography, computerized tomography, or computerized axial tomography.<EOS>
<BOS>Sometimes a CT scan and a PET scan are done at the same time.<EOS>
<BOS>A PET scan is a procedure to find malignant tumor cells in the body.<EOS>
<BOS>A small amount of radioactive glucose (sugar) is injected into a vein.<EOS>
<BOS>The PET scanner rotates around the body and makes a picture of where glucose is being used in the body.<EOS>
<BOS>Malignant tumor cells show up brighter in the picture because they are more active and take up more glucose than normal cells do.<EOS>
<BOS>When a PET scan and CT scan are done at the same time, it is called a PETCT.<EOS>
<BOS>Biopsy : The removal of cells or tissues so they can be viewed under a microscope by a pathologist to check for signs of cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>The type of biopsy used depends on where the extragonadal germ cell tumor is found.<EOS>
<BOS>Excisional biopsy : The removal of an entire lump of tissue.<EOS>
<BOS>Incisional biopsy : The removal of part of a lump or sample of tissue.<EOS>
<BOS>Core biopsy : The removal of tissue using a wide needle.<EOS>
<BOS>Fineneedle aspiration (FNA) biopsy : The removal of tissue or fluid using a thin needle.<EOS>
<BOS>Key Points There are different types of treatment for patients with pituitary tumors.<EOS>
<BOS>Four types of standard treatment are used: Surgery Radiation therapy Drug therapy Chemotherapy New types of treatment are being tested in clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients may want to think about taking part in a clinical trial.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients can enter clinical trials before, during, or after starting their cancer treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Followup tests may be needed.<EOS>
<BOS>There are different types of treatment for patients with pituitary tumors.<EOS>
<BOS>Different types of treatments are available for patients with pituitary tumors.<EOS>
<BOS>Some treatments are standard (the currently used treatment), and some are being tested in clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>A treatment clinical trial is a research study meant to help improve current treatments or obtain information on new treatments for patients with cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>When clinical trials show that a new treatment is better than the standard treatment, the new treatment may become the standard treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients may want to think about taking part in a clinical trial.<EOS>
<BOS>Some clinical trials are open only to patients who have not started treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Four types of standard treatment are used: Surgery Many pituitary tumors can be removed by surgery using one of the following operations: Transsphenoidal surgery: A type of surgery in which the instruments are inserted into part of the brain by going through an incision (cut) made under the upper lip or at the bottom of the nose between the nostrils and then through the sphenoid bone (a butterflyshaped bone at the base of the skull) to reach the pituitary gland.<EOS>
<BOS>The pituitary gland lies just above the sphenoid bone.<EOS>
<BOS>Endoscopic transsphenoidal surgery: A type of surgery in which an endoscope is inserted through an incision (cut) made at the back of the inside of the nose and then through the sphenoid bone to reach the pituitary gland.<EOS>
<BOS>An endoscope is a thin, tubelike instrument with a light, a lens for viewing, and a tool for removing tumor tissue.<EOS>
<BOS>Craniotomy: Surgery to remove the tumor through an opening made in the skull.<EOS>
<BOS>Even if the doctor removes all the cancer that can be seen at the time of the surgery, some patients may be given chemotherapy or radiation therapy after surgery to kill any cancer cells that are left.<EOS>
<BOS>Treatment given after the surgery, to lower the risk that the cancer will come back, is called adjuvant therapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Radiation therapy Radiation therapy is a cancer treatment that uses highenergy xrays or other types of radiation to kill cancer cells or keep them from growing.<EOS>
<BOS>There are two types of radiation therapy: External radiation therapy uses a machine outside the body to send radiation toward the cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Certain ways of giving radiation therapy can help keep radiation from damaging nearby healthy tissue.<EOS>
<BOS>This type of radiation therapy may include the following: Stereotactic radiosurgery: A rigid head frame is attached to the skull to keep the head still during the radiation treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>A machine aims a single large dose of radiation directly at the tumor.<EOS>
<BOS>This procedure does not involve surgery.<EOS>
<BOS>It is also called stereotaxic radiosurgery, radiosurgery, and radiation surgery.<EOS>
<BOS>Internal radiation therapy uses a radioactive substance sealed in needles, seeds, wires, or catheters that are placed directly into or near the cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>The way the radiation therapy is given depends on the type of the cancer being treated.<EOS>
<BOS>External radiation therapy is used to treat pituitary tumors.<EOS>
<BOS>Drug therapy Drugs may be given to stop a functioning pituitary tumor from making too many hormones.<EOS>
<BOS>Chemotherapy Chemotherapy may be used as palliative treatment for pituitary carcinomas, to relieve symptoms and improve the patient's quality of life.<EOS>
<BOS>Chemotherapy uses drugs to stop the growth of cancer cells, either by killing the cells or by stopping them from dividing.<EOS>
<BOS>When chemotherapy is taken by mouth or injected into a vein or muscle, the drugs enter the bloodstream and can reach cancer cells throughout the body (systemic chemotherapy).<EOS>
<BOS>When chemotherapy is placed directly into the cerebrospinal fluid, an organ, or a body cavity such as the abdomen, the drugs mainly affect cancer cells in those areas (regional chemotherapy).<EOS>
<BOS>The way the chemotherapy is given depends on the type of the cancer being treated.<EOS>
<BOS>New types of treatment are being tested in clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>Information about clinical trials is available from the NCI website.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients may want to think about taking part in a clinical trial.<EOS>
<BOS>For some patients, taking part in a clinical trial may be the best treatment choice.<EOS>
<BOS>Clinical trials are part of the cancer research process.<EOS>
<BOS>Clinical trials are done to find out if new cancer treatments are safe and effective or better than the standard treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Many of today's standard treatments for cancer are based on earlier clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients who take part in a clinical trial may receive the standard treatment or be among the first to receive a new treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients who take part in clinical trials also help improve the way cancer will be treated in the future.<EOS>
<BOS>Even when clinical trials do not lead to effective new treatments, they often answer important questions and help move research forward.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients can enter clinical trials before, during, or after starting their cancer treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Some clinical trials only include patients who have not yet received treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Other trials test treatments for patients whose cancer has not gotten better.<EOS>
<BOS>There are also clinical trials that test new ways to stop cancer from recurring (coming back) or reduce the side effects of cancer treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Clinical trials are taking place in many parts of the country.<EOS>
<BOS>See the Treatment Options section that follows for links to current treatment clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>These have been retrieved from NCI's listing of clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>Followup tests may be needed.<EOS>
<BOS>Some of the tests that were done to diagnose the cancer or to find out the stage of the cancer may be repeated.<EOS>
<BOS>Some tests will be repeated in order to see how well the treatment is working.<EOS>
<BOS>Decisions about whether to continue, change, or stop treatment may be based on the results of these tests.<EOS>
<BOS>Some of the tests will continue to be done from time to time after treatment has ended.<EOS>
<BOS>The results of these tests can show if your condition has changed or if the cancer has recurred (come back).<EOS>
<BOS>These tests are sometimes called followup tests or checkups.<EOS>
<BOS>Treatment Options for Pituitary Tumors Nonfunctioning Pituitary Tumors Treatment may include the following: Surgery (transsphenoidal surgery, if possible) to remove the tumor, followed by watchful waiting (closely monitoring a patients condition without giving any treatment until signs or symptoms appear or change).<EOS>
<BOS>Radiation therapy is given if the tumor comes back.<EOS>
<BOS>Radiation therapy alone.<EOS>
<BOS>Treatment for luteinizing hormone producing and folliclestimulating hormone producing tumors is usually transsphenoidal surgery to remove the tumor.<EOS>
<BOS>ProlactinProducing Pituitary Tumors Treatment may include the following: Drug therapy to stop the tumor from making prolactin and to stop the tumor from growing.<EOS>
<BOS>Surgery to remove the tumor (transsphenoidal surgery or craniotomy) when the tumor does not respond to drug therapy or when the patient cannot take the drug.<EOS>
<BOS>Radiation therapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Surgery followed by radiation therapy.<EOS>
<BOS>ACTHProducing Pituitary Tumors Treatment may include the following: Surgery (usually transsphenoidal surgery) to remove the tumor, with or without radiation therapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Radiation therapy alone.<EOS>
<BOS>Drug therapy to stop the tumor from making ACTH.<EOS>
<BOS>A clinical trial of stereotactic radiation surgery.<EOS>
<BOS>Growth HormoneProducing Pituitary Tumors Treatment may include the following: Surgery (usually transsphenoidal or endoscopic transsphenoidal surgery) to remove the tumor, with or without radiation therapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Drug therapy to stop the tumor from making growth hormone.<EOS>
<BOS>ThyroidStimulating HormoneProducing Tumors Treatment may include the following: Surgery (usually transsphenoidal surgery) to remove the tumor, with or without radiation therapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Drug therapy to stop the tumor from making hormones.<EOS>
<BOS>Pituitary Carcinomas Treatment of pituitary carcinomas is palliative, to relieve symptoms and improve the quality of life.<EOS>
<BOS>Treatment may include the following: Surgery (transsphenoidal surgery or craniotomy) to remove the cancer, with or without radiation therapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Drug therapy to stop the tumor from making hormones.<EOS>
<BOS>Chemotherapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Recurrent Pituitary Tumors Treatment may include the following: Radiation therapy.<EOS>
<BOS>A clinical trial of stereotactic radiation surgery.<EOS>
<BOS>Imaging studies and tests are used to detect (find) and diagnose childhood CNS germ cell tumors.<EOS>
<BOS>The following tests and procedures may be used: Physical exam and history : An exam of the body to check general signs of health, including checking for signs of disease, such as lumps or anything else that seems unusual.<EOS>
<BOS>A history of the patient's health habits and past illnesses and treatments will also be taken.<EOS>
<BOS>Neurological exam : A series of questions and tests to check the brain, spinal cord, and nerve function.<EOS>
<BOS>The exam checks a persons mental status, coordination, and ability to walk normally, and how well the muscles, senses, and reflexes work.<EOS>
<BOS>This may also be called a neuro exam or a neurologic exam.<EOS>
<BOS>Visual field exam: An exam to check a persons field of vision (the total area in which objects can be seen).<EOS>
<BOS>This test measures both central vision (how much a person can see when looking straight ahead) and peripheral vision (how much a person can see in all other directions while staring straight ahead).<EOS>
<BOS>The eyes are tested one at a time.<EOS>
<BOS>The eye not being tested is covered.<EOS>
<BOS>MRI (magnetic resonance imaging) with gadolinium : A procedure that uses a magnet, radio waves, and a computer to make a series of detailed pictures of areas inside the brain and spinal cord.<EOS>
<BOS>A substance called gadolinium is injected into a vein.<EOS>
<BOS>The gadolinium collects around the cancer cells so they show up brighter in the picture.<EOS>
<BOS>This procedure is also called nuclear magnetic resonance imaging (NMRI).<EOS>
<BOS>Lumbar puncture : A procedure used to collect cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) from the spinal column.<EOS>
<BOS>This is done by placing a needle between two bones in the spine and into the CSF around the spinal cord and removing a sample of the fluid.<EOS>
<BOS>The sample of CSF is checked under a microscope for signs of tumor cells.<EOS>
<BOS>The sample may also be checked for the amounts of protein and glucose.<EOS>
<BOS>A higher than normal amount of protein or lower than normal amount of glucose may be a sign of a tumor.<EOS>
<BOS>This procedure is also called an LP or spinal tap.<EOS>
<BOS>Tumor marker tests : A procedure in which a sample of blood or cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) is checked to measure the amounts of certain substances released into the blood and CSF by organs, tissues, or tumor cells in the body.<EOS>
<BOS>Certain substances are linked to specific types of cancer when found in increased levels in the blood.<EOS>
<BOS>These are called tumor markers.<EOS>
<BOS>The following tumor markers are used to diagnose some CNS germ cell tumors: Alphafetoprotein (AFP).<EOS>
<BOS>Betahuman chorionic gonadotropin (hCG).<EOS>
<BOS>Blood chemistry studies : A procedure in which a blood sample is checked to measure the amounts of certain substances released into the blood by organs and tissues in the body.<EOS>
<BOS>An unusual (higher or lowerthannormal) amount of a substance can be a sign of disease.<EOS>
<BOS>Blood hormone studies: A procedure in which a blood sample is checked to measure the amounts of certain hormones released into the blood by organs and tissues in the body.<EOS>
<BOS>An unusual (higher or lowerthannormal) amount of a substance can be a sign of disease in the organ or tissue that makes it.<EOS>
<BOS>The blood will be checked for the levels of hormones made by the pituitary gland and other glands.<EOS>
<BOS>A biopsy may be done to be sure of the diagnosis of CNS germ cell tumor.<EOS>
<BOS>If doctors think your child may have a CNS germ cell tumor, a biopsy may be done.<EOS>
<BOS>For brain tumors, the biopsy is done by removing part of the skull and using a needle to remove a sample of tissue.<EOS>
<BOS>Sometimes, a needle guided by a computer is used to remove the tissue sample.<EOS>
<BOS>A pathologist views the tissue under a microscope to look for cancer cells.<EOS>
<BOS>If cancer cells are found, the doctor may remove as much tumor as safely possible during the same surgery.<EOS>
<BOS>The piece of skull is usually put back in place after the procedure.<EOS>
<BOS>Sometimes the diagnosis can be made based on the results of imaging and tumor marker tests and a biopsy is not needed.<EOS>
<BOS>The following test may be done on the sample of tissue that is removed: Immunohistochemistry : A test that uses antibodies to check for certain antigens in a sample of tissue.<EOS>
<BOS>The antibody is usually linked to a radioactive substance or a dye that causes the tissue to light up under a microscope.<EOS>
<BOS>This type of test may be used to tell the difference between different types of brain tumors.<EOS>
<BOS>New types of treatment are being tested in clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>This summary section describes treatments that are being studied in clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>It may not mention every new treatment being studied.<EOS>
<BOS>Information about clinical trials is available from the NCI website.<EOS>
<BOS>Targeted therapy Targeted therapy is a type of treatment that uses drugs or other substances to attack specific cancer cells.<EOS>
<BOS>Targeted therapies usually cause less harm to normal cells than chemotherapy or radiation therapy do.<EOS>
<BOS>Targeted therapy is being studied in the treatment of recurrent childhood central nervous system atypical teratoid/rhabdoid tumor.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients may want to think about taking part in a clinical trial.<EOS>
<BOS>For some patients, taking part in a clinical trial may be the best treatment choice.<EOS>
<BOS>Clinical trials are part of the cancer research process.<EOS>
<BOS>Clinical trials are done to find out if new cancer treatments are safe and effective or better than the standard treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Many of today's standard treatments for cancer are based on earlier clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients who take part in a clinical trial may receive the standard treatment or be among the first to receive a new treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients who take part in clinical trials also help improve the way cancer will be treated in the future.<EOS>
<BOS>Even when clinical trials do not lead to effective new treatments, they often answer important questions and help move research forward.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients can enter clinical trials before, during, or after starting their cancer treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Some clinical trials only include patients who have not yet received treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Other trials test treatments for patients whose cancer has not gotten better.<EOS>
<BOS>There are also clinical trials that test new ways to stop cancer from recurring (coming back) or reduce the side effects of cancer treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Clinical trials are taking place in many parts of the country.<EOS>
<BOS>See the Treatment Options section that follows for links to current treatment clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>These have been retrieved from NCI's listing of clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>Imaging studies and blood tests are used to detect (find) and diagnose childhood extracranial germ cell tumors.<EOS>
<BOS>The following tests and procedures may be used: Physical exam and history : An exam of the body to check general signs of health, including checking for signs of disease, such as lumps or anything else that seems unusual.<EOS>
<BOS>The testicles may be checked for lumps, swelling, or pain.<EOS>
<BOS>A history of the patient's health habits and past illnesses and treatments will also be taken.<EOS>
<BOS>Serum tumor marker test : A procedure in which a sample of blood is checked to measure the amounts of certain substances released into the blood by organs, tissues, or tumor cells in the body.<EOS>
<BOS>Certain substances are linked to specific types of cancer when found in increased levels in the blood.<EOS>
<BOS>These are called tumor markers.<EOS>
<BOS>Most malignant germ cell tumors release tumor markers.<EOS>
<BOS>The following tumor markers are used to detect extracranial germ cell tumors: Alphafetoprotein (AFP).<EOS>
<BOS>Betahuman chorionic gonadotropin (hCG).<EOS>
<BOS>For testicular germ cell tumors, blood levels of the tumor markers help show if the tumor is a seminoma or nonseminoma.<EOS>
<BOS>Blood chemistry studies : A procedure in which a blood sample is checked to measure the amounts of certain substances released into the blood by organs and tissues in the body.<EOS>
<BOS>An unusual (higher or lower than normal) amount of a substance can be a sign of disease.<EOS>
<BOS>Chest xray : An xray of the organs and bones inside the chest.<EOS>
<BOS>An xray is a type of energy beam that can go through the body and onto film, making a picture of areas inside the body.<EOS>
