<BOS>CT scan (CAT scan): A procedure that makes a series of detailed pictures of areas inside the body, taken from different angles.<EOS>
<BOS>The pictures are made by a computer linked to an xray machine.<EOS>
<BOS>A dye may be injected into a vein or swallowed to help the organs or tissues show up more clearly.<EOS>
<BOS>This procedure is also called computed tomography, computerized tomography, or computerized axial tomography.<EOS>
<BOS>MRI (magnetic resonance imaging): A procedure that uses a magnet, radio waves, and a computer to make a series of detailed pictures of areas inside the body.<EOS>
<BOS>This procedure is also called nuclear magnetic resonance imaging (NMRI).<EOS>
<BOS>Ultrasound exam: A procedure in which highenergy sound waves (ultrasound) are bounced off internal tissues or organs and make echoes.<EOS>
<BOS>The echoes form a picture of body tissues called a sonogram.<EOS>
<BOS>The picture can be printed to be looked at later.<EOS>
<BOS>Biopsy : The removal of cells or tissues so they can be viewed under a microscope by a pathologist to check for signs of cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>In some cases, the tumor is removed during surgery and then a biopsy is done.<EOS>
<BOS>The following tests may be done on the sample of tissue that is removed: Cytogenetic analysis : A laboratory test in which cells in a sample of tissue are viewed under a microscope to look for certain changes in the chromosomes.<EOS>
<BOS>Immunohistochemistry : A test that uses antibodies to check for certain antigens in a sample of tissue.<EOS>
<BOS>The antibody is usually linked to a radioactive substance or a dye that causes the tissue to light up under a microscope.<EOS>
<BOS>This type of test may be used to tell the difference between different types of cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Certain factors affect prognosis (chance of recovery) and treatment options.<EOS>
<BOS>The prognosis (chance of recovery) and treatment options depend on the following: The stage of the cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>The location and size of the tumor.<EOS>
<BOS>Whether the cancer has just been diagnosed or has recurred (come back).<EOS>
<BOS>Women with an increased risk of ovarian cancer may consider surgery to lessen the risk.<EOS>
<BOS>Some women who have an increased risk of ovarian cancer may choose to have a riskreducing oophorectomy (the removal of healthy ovaries so that cancer cannot grow in them).<EOS>
<BOS>In highrisk women, this procedure has been shown to greatly decrease the risk of ovarian cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>(See the PDQ summary on Ovarian, Fallopian Tube, and Primary Peritoneal Cancer Prevention for more information.<EOS>
<BOS>).<EOS>
<BOS>Key Points After paranasal sinus and nasal cavity cancer has been diagnosed, tests are done to find out if cancer cells have spread within the paranasal sinuses and nasal cavity or to other parts of the body.<EOS>
<BOS>There are three ways that cancer spreads in the body.<EOS>
<BOS>Cancer may spread from where it began to other parts of the body.<EOS>
<BOS>There is no standard staging system for cancer of the sphenoid and frontal sinuses.<EOS>
<BOS>The following stages are used for maxillary sinus cancer: Stage 0 (Carcinoma in Situ) Stage I Stage II Stage III Stage IV The following stages are used for nasal cavity and ethmoid sinus cancer: Stage 0 (Carcinoma in Situ) Stage I Stage II Stage III Stage IV After paranasal sinus and nasal cavity cancer has been diagnosed, tests are done to find out if cancer cells have spread within the paranasal sinuses and nasal cavity or to other parts of the body.<EOS>
<BOS>The process used to find out if cancer has spread within the paranasal sinuses and nasal cavity or to other parts of the body is called staging.<EOS>
<BOS>The information gathered from the staging process determines the stage of the disease.<EOS>
<BOS>It is important to know the stage in order to plan treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>The following tests and procedures may be used in the staging process: Endoscopy : A procedure to look at organs and tissues inside the body to check for abnormal areas.<EOS>
<BOS>An endoscope is inserted through an opening in the body, such as the nose or mouth.<EOS>
<BOS>An endoscope is a thin, tubelike instrument with a light and a lens for viewing.<EOS>
<BOS>It may also have a tool to remove tissue or lymph node samples, which are checked under a microscope for signs of disease.<EOS>
<BOS>CT scan (CAT scan): A procedure that makes a series of detailed pictures of areas inside the body, taken from different angles.<EOS>
<BOS>The pictures are made by a computer linked to an xray machine.<EOS>
<BOS>A dye may be injected into a vein or swallowed to help the organs or tissues show up more clearly.<EOS>
<BOS>This procedure is also called computed tomography, computerized tomography, or computerized axial tomography.<EOS>
<BOS>Chest xray : An xray of the organs and bones inside the chest.<EOS>
<BOS>An xray is a type of energy beam that can go through the body and onto film, making a picture of areas inside the body.<EOS>
<BOS>MRI (magnetic resonance imaging) with gadolinium : A procedure that uses a magnet, radio waves, and a computer to make a series of detailed pictures of areas inside the body.<EOS>
<BOS>Sometimes a substance called gadolinium is injected into a vein.<EOS>
<BOS>The gadolinium collects around the cancer cells so they show up brighter in the picture.<EOS>
<BOS>This procedure is also called nuclear magnetic resonance imaging (NMRI).<EOS>
<BOS>PET scan (positron emission tomography scan): A procedure to find malignant tumor cells in the body.<EOS>
<BOS>A small amount of radioactive glucose (sugar) is injected into a vein.<EOS>
<BOS>The PET scanner rotates around the body and makes a picture of where glucose is being used in the body.<EOS>
<BOS>Malignant tumor cells show up brighter in the picture because they are more active and take up more glucose than normal cells do.<EOS>
<BOS>Bone scan : A procedure to check if there are rapidly dividing cells, such as cancer cells, in the bone.<EOS>
<BOS>A very small amount of radioactive material is injected into a vein and travels through the bloodstream.<EOS>
<BOS>The radioactive material collects in the bones and is detected by a scanner.<EOS>
<BOS>There are three ways that cancer spreads in the body.<EOS>
<BOS>Cancer can spread through tissue, the lymph system, and the blood: Tissue.<EOS>
<BOS>The cancer spreads from where it began by growing into nearby areas.<EOS>
<BOS>Lymph system.<EOS>
<BOS>The cancer spreads from where it began by getting into the lymph system.<EOS>
<BOS>The cancer travels through the lymph vessels to other parts of the body.<EOS>
<BOS>Blood.<EOS>
<BOS>The cancer spreads from where it began by getting into the blood.<EOS>
<BOS>The cancer travels through the blood vessels to other parts of the body.<EOS>
<BOS>Cancer may spread from where it began to other parts of the body.<EOS>
<BOS>When cancer spreads to another part of the body, it is called metastasis.<EOS>
<BOS>Cancer cells break away from where they began (the primary tumor) and travel through the lymph system or blood.<EOS>
<BOS>Lymph system.<EOS>
<BOS>The cancer gets into the lymph system, travels through the lymph vessels, and forms a tumor (metastatic tumor) in another part of the body.<EOS>
<BOS>Blood.<EOS>
<BOS>The cancer gets into the blood, travels through the blood vessels, and forms a tumor (metastatic tumor) in another part of the body.<EOS>
<BOS>The metastatic tumor is the same type of cancer as the primary tumor.<EOS>
<BOS>For example, if nasal cavity cancer spreads to the lung, the cancer cells in the lung are actually nasal cavity cancer cells.<EOS>
<BOS>The disease is metastatic nasal cavity cancer, not lung cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>There is no standard staging system for cancer of the sphenoid and frontal sinuses.<EOS>
<BOS>The following stages are used for maxillary sinus cancer: Stage 0 (Carcinoma in Situ) In stage 0, abnormal cells are found in the innermost lining of the maxillary sinus.<EOS>
<BOS>These abnormal cells may become cancer and spread into nearby normal tissue.<EOS>
<BOS>Stage 0 is also called carcinoma in situ.<EOS>
<BOS>Stage I In stage I, cancer has formed in the mucous membranes of the maxillary sinus.<EOS>
<BOS>Stage II In stage II, cancer has spread to bone around the maxillary sinus, including the roof of the mouth and the nose, but not to bone at the back of the maxillary sinus or the base of the skull.<EOS>
<BOS>Stage III In stage III, cancer has spread to any of the following: Bone at the back of the maxillary sinus.<EOS>
<BOS>Tissues under the skin.<EOS>
<BOS>The eye socket.<EOS>
<BOS>The base of the skull.<EOS>
<BOS>The ethmoid sinuses.<EOS>
<BOS>or Cancer has spread to one lymph node on the same side of the neck as the cancer and the lymph node is 3 centimeters or smaller.<EOS>
<BOS>Cancer has also spread to any of the following: The lining of the maxillary sinus.<EOS>
<BOS>Bones around the maxillary sinus, including the roof of the mouth and the nose.<EOS>
<BOS>Tissues under the skin.<EOS>
<BOS>The eye socket.<EOS>
<BOS>The base of the skull.<EOS>
<BOS>The ethmoid sinuses.<EOS>
<BOS>Stage IV Stage IV is divided into stage IVA, IVB, and IVC.<EOS>
<BOS>Stage IVA In stage IVA, cancer has spread: to one lymph node on the same side of the neck as the cancer and the lymph node is larger than 3 centimeters but not larger than 6 centimeters; or to more than one lymph node on the same side of the neck as the original tumor and the lymph nodes are not larger than 6 centimeters; or to lymph nodes on the opposite side of the neck as the original tumor or on both sides of the neck, and the lymph nodes are not larger than 6 centimeters.<EOS>
<BOS>and cancer has spread to any of the following: The lining of the maxillary sinus.<EOS>
<BOS>Bones around the maxillary sinus, including the roof of the mouth and the nose.<EOS>
<BOS>Tissues under the skin.<EOS>
<BOS>The eye socket.<EOS>
<BOS>The base of the skull.<EOS>
<BOS>The ethmoid sinuses.<EOS>
<BOS>or Cancer has spread to any of the following: The front of the eye.<EOS>
<BOS>The skin of the cheek.<EOS>
<BOS>The base of the skull.<EOS>
<BOS>Behind the jaw.<EOS>
<BOS>The bone between the eyes.<EOS>
<BOS>The sphenoid or frontal sinuses.<EOS>
<BOS>and cancer may also have spread to one or more lymph nodes 6 centimeters or smaller, anywhere in the neck.<EOS>
<BOS>Stage IVB In stage IVB, cancer has spread to any of the following: The back of the eye.<EOS>
<BOS>The brain.<EOS>
<BOS>The middle parts of the skull.<EOS>
<BOS>The nerves in the head that go to the brain.<EOS>
<BOS>The upper part of the throat behind the nose.<EOS>
<BOS>The base of the skull.<EOS>
<BOS>and cancer may be found in one or more lymph nodes of any size, anywhere in the neck.<EOS>
<BOS>or Cancer is found in a lymph node larger than 6 centimeters.<EOS>
<BOS>Cancer may also be found anywhere in or near the maxillary sinus.<EOS>
<BOS>Stage IVC In stage IVC, cancer may be anywhere in or near the maxillary sinus, may have spread to lymph nodes, and has spread to organs far away from the maxillary sinus, such as the lungs.<EOS>
<BOS>The following stages are used for nasal cavity and ethmoid sinus cancer: Stage 0 (Carcinoma in Situ) In stage 0, abnormal cells are found in the innermost lining of the nasal cavity or ethmoid sinus.<EOS>
<BOS>These abnormal cells may become cancer and spread into nearby normal tissue.<EOS>
<BOS>Stage 0 is also called carcinoma in situ.<EOS>
<BOS>Stage I In stage I, cancer has formed and is found in only one area (of either the nasal cavity or the ethmoid sinus) and may have spread into bone.<EOS>
<BOS>Stage II In stage II, cancer is found in two areas (of either the nasal cavity or the ethmoid sinus) that are near each other or has spread to an area next to the sinuses.<EOS>
<BOS>Cancer may also have spread into bone.<EOS>
<BOS>Stage III In stage III, cancer has spread to any of the following: The eye socket.<EOS>
<BOS>The maxillary sinus.<EOS>
<BOS>The roof of the mouth.<EOS>
<BOS>The bone between the eyes.<EOS>
<BOS>or Cancer has spread to one lymph node on the same side of the neck as the cancer and the lymph node is 3 centimeters or smaller.<EOS>
<BOS>Cancer has also spread to any of the following: The nasal cavity.<EOS>
<BOS>The ethmoid sinus.<EOS>
<BOS>The eye socket.<EOS>
<BOS>The maxillary sinus.<EOS>
<BOS>The roof of the mouth.<EOS>
<BOS>The bone between the eyes.<EOS>
<BOS>Stage IV Stage IV is divided into stage IVA, IVB, and IVC.<EOS>
<BOS>Stage IVA In stage IVA, cancer has spread: to one lymph node on the same side of the neck as the cancer and the lymph node is larger than 3 centimeters but not larger than 6 centimeters; or to more than one lymph node on the same side of the neck as the original tumor and the lymph nodes are not larger than 6 centimeters; or to lymph nodes on the opposite side of the neck as the original tumor or on both sides of the neck, and the lymph nodes are not larger than 6 centimeters.<EOS>
<BOS>and cancer has spread to any of the following: The nasal cavity.<EOS>
<BOS>The ethmoid sinus.<EOS>
<BOS>The eye socket.<EOS>
<BOS>The maxillary sinus.<EOS>
<BOS>The roof of the mouth.<EOS>
<BOS>The bone between the eyes.<EOS>
<BOS>or Cancer has spread to any of the following: The front of the eye.<EOS>
<BOS>The skin of the nose or cheek.<EOS>
<BOS>Front parts of the skull.<EOS>
<BOS>The base of the skull.<EOS>
<BOS>The sphenoid or frontal sinuses.<EOS>
<BOS>and cancer may have spread to one or more lymph nodes 6 centimeters or smaller, anywhere in the neck.<EOS>
<BOS>Stage IVB In stage IVB, cancer has spread to any of the following: The back of the eye.<EOS>
<BOS>The brain.<EOS>
<BOS>The middle parts of the skull.<EOS>
<BOS>The nerves in the head that go to the brain.<EOS>
<BOS>The upper part of the throat behind the nose.<EOS>
<BOS>The base of the skull.<EOS>
<BOS>and cancer may be found in one or more lymph nodes of any size, anywhere in the neck.<EOS>
<BOS>or Cancer is found in a lymph node larger than 6 centimeters.<EOS>
<BOS>Cancer may also be found anywhere in or near the nasal cavity and ethmoid sinus.<EOS>
<BOS>Stage IVC In stage IVC, cancer may be anywhere in or near the nasal cavity and ethmoid sinus, may have spread to lymph nodes, and has spread to organs far away from the nasal cavity and ethmoid sinus, such as the lungs.<EOS>
<BOS>New types of treatment are being tested in clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>Information about clinical trials is available from the NCI website.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients may want to think about taking part in a clinical trial.<EOS>
<BOS>For some patients, taking part in a clinical trial may be the best treatment choice.<EOS>
<BOS>Clinical trials are part of the cancer research process.<EOS>
<BOS>Clinical trials are done to find out if new cancer treatments are safe and effective or better than the standard treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Many of today's standard treatments for cancer are based on earlier clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients who take part in a clinical trial may receive the standard treatment or be among the first to receive a new treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients who take part in clinical trials also help improve the way cancer will be treated in the future.<EOS>
<BOS>Even when clinical trials do not lead to effective new treatments, they often answer important questions and help move research forward.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients can enter clinical trials before, during, or after starting their treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Some clinical trials only include patients who have not yet received treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Other trials test treatments for patients whose cancer has not gotten better.<EOS>
<BOS>There are also clinical trials that test new ways to stop cancer from recurring (coming back) or reduce the side effects of cancer treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Clinical trials are taking place in many parts of the country.<EOS>
<BOS>See the Treatment Options for Childhood LCH and the Treatment Options for Adult LCH sections for links to current treatment clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>These have been retrieved from NCI's clinical trials database.<EOS>
<BOS>Key Points There are different types of treatment for patients with gastrointestinal stromal tumors.<EOS>
<BOS>Four types of standard treatment are used: Surgery Targeted therapy Watchful waiting Supportive care New types of treatment are being tested in clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients may want to think about taking part in a clinical trial.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients can enter clinical trials before, during, or after starting their cancer treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Followup tests may be needed.<EOS>
<BOS>There are different types of treatment for patients with gastrointestinal stromal tumors.<EOS>
<BOS>Different types of treatments are available for patients with gastrointestinal stromal tumors (GISTs).<EOS>
<BOS>Some treatments are standard (the currently used treatment), and some are being tested in clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>A treatment clinical trial is a research study meant to help improve current treatments or obtain information on new treatments for patients with cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>When clinical trials show that a new treatment is better than the standard treatment, the new treatment may become the standard treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients may want to think about taking part in a clinical trial.<EOS>
<BOS>Some clinical trials are open only to patients who have not started treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Four types of standard treatment are used: Surgery If the GIST has not spread and is in a place where surgery can be safely done, the tumor and some of the tissue around it may be removed.<EOS>
<BOS>Sometimes surgery is done using a laparoscope (a thin, lighted tube) to see inside the body.<EOS>
<BOS>Small incisions (cuts) are made in the wall of the abdomen and a laparoscope is inserted into one of the incisions.<EOS>
<BOS>Instruments may be inserted through the same incision or through other incisions to remove organs or tissues.<EOS>
<BOS>Targeted therapy Targeted therapy is a type of treatment that uses drugs or other substances to identify and attack specific cancer cells without harming normal cells.<EOS>
<BOS>Tyrosine kinase inhibitors (TKIs) are targeted therapy drugs that block signals needed for tumors to grow.<EOS>
<BOS>TKIs may be used to treat GISTs that cannot be removed by surgery or to shrink GISTs so they become small enough to be removed by surgery.<EOS>
<BOS>Imatinib mesylate and sunitinib are two TKIs used to treat GISTs.<EOS>
<BOS>TKIs are sometimes given for as long as the tumor does not grow and serious side effects do not occur.<EOS>
<BOS>See Drugs Approved for Gastrointestinal Stromal Tumors for more information.<EOS>
<BOS>Watchful waiting Watchful waiting is closely monitoring a patients condition without giving any treatment until signs or symptoms appear or change.<EOS>
<BOS>Supportive care If a GIST gets worse during treatment or there are side effects, supportive care is usually given.<EOS>
<BOS>The goal of supportive care is to prevent or treat the symptoms of a disease, side effects caused by treatment, and psychological, social, and spiritual problems related to a disease or its treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Supportive care helps improve the quality of life of patients who have a serious or lifethreatening disease.<EOS>
<BOS>Radiation therapy is sometimes given as supportive care to relieve pain in patients with large tumors that have spread.<EOS>
<BOS>New types of treatment are being tested in clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>Information about clinical trials is available from the NCI website.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients may want to think about taking part in a clinical trial.<EOS>
<BOS>For some patients, taking part in a clinical trial may be the best treatment choice.<EOS>
<BOS>Clinical trials are part of the cancer research process.<EOS>
<BOS>Clinical trials are done to find out if new cancer treatments are safe and effective or better than the standard treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Many of today's standard treatments for cancer are based on earlier clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients who take part in a clinical trial may receive the standard treatment or be among the first to receive a new treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients who take part in clinical trials also help improve the way cancer will be treated in the future.<EOS>
<BOS>Even when clinical trials do not lead to effective new treatments, they often answer important questions and help move research forward.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients can enter clinical trials before, during, or after starting their cancer treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Some clinical trials only include patients who have not yet received treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Other trials test treatments for patients whose cancer has not gotten better.<EOS>
<BOS>There are also clinical trials that test new ways to stop cancer from recurring (coming back) or reduce the side effects of cancer treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Clinical trials are taking place in many parts of the country.<EOS>
<BOS>See the Treatment Options section that follows for links to current treatment clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>These have been retrieved from NCI's listing of clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>Followup tests may be needed.<EOS>
<BOS>Some of the tests that were done to diagnose the cancer or to find out the stage of the cancer may be repeated.<EOS>
<BOS>Some tests will be repeated in order to see how well the treatment is working.<EOS>
<BOS>Decisions about whether to continue, change, or stop treatment may be based on the results of these tests.<EOS>
<BOS>Some of the tests will continue to be done from time to time after treatment has ended.<EOS>
<BOS>The results of these tests can show if your condition has changed or if the cancer has recurred (come back).<EOS>
<BOS>These tests are sometimes called followup tests or checkups.<EOS>
<BOS>Followup for GISTs that were removed by surgery may include CT scan of the liver and pelvis or watchful waiting.<EOS>
<BOS>For GISTs that are treated with tyrosine kinase inhibitors, followup tests, such as CT, MRI, or PET scans, may be done to check how well the targeted therapy is working.<EOS>
<BOS>Treatment Options for Gastrointestinal Stromal Tumors Resectable Gastrointestinal Stromal Tumors Resectable gastrointestinal stromal tumors (GISTs) can be completely or almost completely removed by surgery.<EOS>
<BOS>Treatment may include the following: Surgery to remove tumors that are 2 centimeters or larger.<EOS>
<BOS>Laparoscopic surgery may be done if the tumor is 5 cm or smaller.<EOS>
<BOS>If there are cancer cells remaining at the edges of the area where the tumor was removed, watchful waiting or targeted therapy with imatinib mesylate may follow.<EOS>
<BOS>A clinical trial of targeted therapy with imatinib mesylate following surgery, to decrease the chance the tumor will recur (come back).<EOS>
<BOS>Unresectable Gastrointestinal Stromal Tumors Unresectable GISTs cannot be completely removed by surgery because they are too large or in a place where there would be too much damage to nearby organs if the tumor is removed.<EOS>
<BOS>Treatment is usually a clinical trial of targeted therapy with imatinib mesylate to shrink the tumor, followed by surgery to remove as much of the tumor as possible.<EOS>
<BOS>Metastatic and Recurrent Gastrointestinal Stromal Tumors Treatment of GISTs that are metastatic (spread to other parts of the body) or recurrent (came back after treatment) may include the following: Targeted therapy with imatinib mesylate.<EOS>
<BOS>Targeted therapy with sunitinib, if the tumor begins to grow during imatinib mesylate therapy or if the side effects are too bad.<EOS>
<BOS>Surgery to remove tumors that have been treated with targeted therapy and are shrinking, stable (not changing), or that have slightly increased in size.<EOS>
<BOS>Targeted therapy may continue after surgery.<EOS>
<BOS>Surgery to remove tumors when there are serious complications, such as bleeding, a hole in the gastrointestinal (GI) tract, a blocked GI tract, or infection.<EOS>
<BOS>A clinical trial of a new treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Refractory Gastrointestinal Stromal Tumors Many GISTs treated with a tyrosine kinase inhibitor (TKI) become refractory (stop responding) to the drug after a while.<EOS>
<BOS>Treatment is usually a clinical trial with a different TKI or a clinical trial of a new drug.<EOS>
<BOS>Treatment Options in Clinical Trials Check the list of NCIsupported cancer clinical trials that are now accepting patients with gastrointestinal stromal tumor.<EOS>
<BOS>For more specific results, refine the search by using other search features, such as the location of the trial, the type of treatment, or the name of the drug.<EOS>
<BOS>Talk with your doctor about clinical trials that may be right for you.<EOS>
<BOS>General information about clinical trials is available from the NCI website.<EOS>
<BOS>Certain factors affect prognosis (chance of recovery) and treatment options.<EOS>
<BOS>The prognosis (chance of recovery) and treatment options depend on the following: Where the cancer formed in the urethra.<EOS>
<BOS>Whether the cancer has spread through the mucosa lining the urethra to nearby tissue, to lymph nodes, or to other parts of the body.<EOS>
<BOS>Whether the patient is a male or female.<EOS>
<BOS>The patient's general health.<EOS>
<BOS>Whether the cancer has just been diagnosed or has recurred (come back).<EOS>
<BOS>Key Points Breast cancer is a disease in which malignant (cancer) cells form in the tissues of the breast.<EOS>
<BOS>A family history of breast cancer and other factors increase the risk of breast cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Breast cancer is sometimes caused by inherited gene mutations (changes).<EOS>
<BOS>The use of certain medicines and other factors decrease the risk of breast cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Signs of breast cancer include a lump or change in the breast.<EOS>
<BOS>Tests that examine the breasts are used to detect (find) and diagnose breast cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>If cancer is found, tests are done to study the cancer cells.<EOS>
<BOS>Certain factors affect prognosis (chance of recovery) and treatment options.<EOS>
<BOS>Breast cancer is a disease in which malignant (cancer) cells form in the tissues of the breast.<EOS>
<BOS>The breast is made up of lobes and ducts.<EOS>
<BOS>Each breast has 15 to 20 sections called lobes.<EOS>
<BOS>Each lobe has many smaller sections called lobules.<EOS>
<BOS>Lobules end in dozens of tiny bulbs that can make milk.<EOS>
<BOS>The lobes, lobules, and bulbs are linked by thin tubes called ducts.<EOS>
<BOS>Each breast also has blood vessels and lymph vessels.<EOS>
<BOS>The lymph vessels carry an almost colorless fluid called lymph.<EOS>
<BOS>Lymph vessels carry lymph between lymph nodes.<EOS>
<BOS>Lymph nodes are small beanshaped structures that are found throughout the body.<EOS>
<BOS>They filter substances in lymph and help fight infection and disease.<EOS>
<BOS>Clusters of lymph nodes are found near the breast in the axilla (under the arm), above the collarbone, and in the chest.<EOS>
<BOS>The most common type of breast cancer is ductal carcinoma, which begins in the cells of the ducts.<EOS>
<BOS>Cancer that begins in the lobes or lobules is called lobular carcinoma and is more often found in both breasts than are other types of breast cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Inflammatory breast cancer is an uncommon type of breast cancer in which the breast is warm, red, and swollen.<EOS>
<BOS>See the following PDQ summaries for more information about breast cancer: Breast Cancer Prevention Breast Cancer Screening Breast Cancer Treatment and Pregnancy Male Breast Cancer Treatment Unusual Cancers of Childhood Treatment (for information about breast cancer in childhood).<EOS>
<BOS>Prostate cancer is the most common nonskin cancer among men in the United States.<EOS>
<BOS>Prostate cancer is found mainly in older men.<EOS>
<BOS>Although the number of men with prostate cancer is large, most men diagnosed with this disease do not die from it.<EOS>
<BOS>Prostate cancer causes more deaths in men than any other cancer except lung cancer and colorectal cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Prostate cancer occurs more often in AfricanAmerican men than in white men.<EOS>
<BOS>AfricanAmerican men with prostate cancer are more likely to die from the disease than white men with prostate cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Key Points Avoiding risk factors and increasing protective factors may help prevent cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Being exposed to ultraviolet radiation is a risk factor for skin cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>It is not known if the following lower the risk of nonmelanoma skin cancer: Sunscreen use and avoiding sun exposure Chemopreventive agents It is not known if the following lower the risk of melanoma: Sunscreen Counseling and protecting the skin from the sun Cancer prevention clinical trials are used to study ways to prevent cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>New ways to prevent skin cancer are being studied in clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>Avoiding risk factors and increasing protective factors may help prevent cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Avoiding cancer risk factors may help prevent certain cancers.<EOS>
<BOS>Risk factors include smoking, being overweight, and not getting enough exercise.<EOS>
<BOS>Increasing protective factors such as quitting smoking and exercising may also help prevent some cancers.<EOS>
<BOS>Talk to your doctor or other health care professional about how you might lower your risk of cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Being exposed to ultraviolet radiation is a risk factor for skin cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Some studies suggest that being exposed to ultraviolet (UV) radiation and the sensitivity of a persons skin to UV radiation are risk factors for skin cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>UV radiation is the name for the invisible rays that are part of the energy that comes from the sun.<EOS>
<BOS>Sunlamps and tanning beds also give off UV radiation.<EOS>
<BOS>Risk factors for nonmelanoma and melanoma cancers are not the same.<EOS>
<BOS>Risk factors for nonmelanoma skin cancer: Being exposed to natural sunlight or artificial sunlight (such as from tanning beds) over long periods of time.<EOS>
<BOS>Having a fair complexion, which includes the following: Fair skin that freckles and burns easily, does not tan, or tans poorly.<EOS>
<BOS>Blue or green or other lightcolored eyes.<EOS>
<BOS>Red or blond hair.<EOS>
<BOS>Having actinic keratosis.<EOS>
<BOS>Past treatment with radiation.<EOS>
<BOS>Having a weakened immune system.<EOS>
<BOS>Being exposed to arsenic.<EOS>
<BOS>Risk factors for melanoma skin cancer: Having a fair complexion, which includes the following: Fair skin that freckles and burns easily, does not tan, or tans poorly.<EOS>
<BOS>Blue or green or other lightcolored eyes.<EOS>
<BOS>Red or blond hair.<EOS>
<BOS>Being exposed to natural sunlight or artificial sunlight (such as from tanning beds) over long periods of time.<EOS>
<BOS>Having a history of many blistering sunburns, especially as a child or teenager.<EOS>
<BOS>Having several large or many small moles.<EOS>
<BOS>Having a family history of unusual moles (atypical nevus syndrome).<EOS>
<BOS>Having a family or personal history of melanoma.<EOS>
<BOS>Being white.<EOS>
<BOS>It is not known if the following lower the risk of nonmelanoma skin cancer: Sunscreen use and avoiding sun exposure It is not known if nonmelanoma skin cancer risk is decreased by staying out of the sun, using sunscreens, or wearing protective clothing when outdoors.<EOS>
<BOS>This is because not enough studies have been done to prove this.<EOS>
<BOS>Sunscreen may help decrease the amount of UV radiation to the skin.<EOS>
<BOS>One study found that wearing sunscreen can help prevent actinic keratoses, scaly patches of skin that sometimes become squamous cell carcinoma.<EOS>
<BOS>The harms of using sunscreen are likely to be small and include allergic reactions to skin creams and lower levels of vitamin D made in the skin because of less sun exposure.<EOS>
<BOS>It is also possible that when a person uses sunscreen to avoid sunburn they may spend too much time in the sun and be exposed to harmful UV radiation.<EOS>
<BOS>Although protecting the skin and eyes from the sun has not been proven to lower the chance of getting skin cancer, skin experts suggest the following: Use sunscreen that protects against UV radiation.<EOS>
<BOS>Do not stay out in the sun for long periods of time, especially when the sun is at its strongest.<EOS>
<BOS>Wear long sleeve shirts, long pants, sun hats, and sunglasses, when outdoors.<EOS>
<BOS>Chemopreventive agents Chemoprevention is the use of drugs, vitamins, or other agents to try to reduce the risk of cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>The following chemopreventive agents have been studied to find whether they lower the risk of nonmelanoma skin cancer: Beta carotene Studies of beta carotene (taken as a supplement in pills) have not shown that it prevents nonmelanoma skin cancer from forming or coming back.<EOS>
<BOS>Isotretinoin High doses of isotretinoin have been shown to prevent new skin cancers in patients with xeroderma pigmentosum.<EOS>
<BOS>However, isotretinoin has not been shown to prevent nonmelanoma skin cancers from coming back in patients previously treated for nonmelanoma skin cancers.<EOS>
<BOS>Treatment with isotretinoin can cause serious side effects.<EOS>
<BOS>Selenium Studies have shown that selenium (taken in brewer's yeast tablets) does not lower the risk of basal cell carcinoma, and may increase the risk of squamous cell carcinoma.<EOS>
<BOS>Celecoxib A study of celecoxib in patients with actinic keratosis and a history of nonmelanoma skin cancer found those who took celecoxib had slightly lower rates of recurrent nonmelanoma skin cancers.<EOS>
<BOS>Celecoxib may have serious side effects on the heart and blood vessels.<EOS>
<BOS>Alphadifluoromethylornithine (DFMO) A study of alphadifluoromethylornithine (DFMO) in patients with a history of nonmelanoma skin cancer showed that those who took DFMO had lower rates of nonmelanoma skin cancers coming back than those who took a placebo.<EOS>
<BOS>DFMO may cause hearing loss which is usually temporary.<EOS>
<BOS>Nicotinamide (vitamin B3) Studies have shown that nicotinamide (vitamin B3) helps prevent new actinic keratoses lesions from forming in people who had four or fewer actinic lesions before taking nicotinamide.<EOS>
<BOS>More studies are needed to find out if nicotinamide prevents nonmelanoma skin cancer from forming or coming back.<EOS>
<BOS>It is not known if the following lower the risk of melanoma: Sunscreen It has not been proven that using sunscreen to prevent sunburn can protect against melanoma caused by UV radiation.<EOS>
<BOS>Other risk factors such as having skin that burns easily, having a large number of benign moles, or having atypical nevi may also play a role in whether melanoma forms.<EOS>
<BOS>Counseling and protecting the skin from the sun It is not known if people who receive counseling or information about avoiding sun exposure make changes in their behavior to protect their skin from the sun.<EOS>
<BOS>The cause of most childhood brain tumors is unknown.<EOS>
<BOS>Key Points There are different types of treatment for patients with renal cell cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Five types of standard treatment are used: Surgery Radiation therapy Chemotherapy Biologic therapy Targeted therapy New types of treatment are being tested in clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients may want to think about taking part in a clinical trial.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients can enter clinical trials before, during, or after starting their cancer treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Followup tests may be needed.<EOS>
<BOS>There are different types of treatment for patients with renal cell cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Different types of treatments are available for patients with renal cell cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Some treatments are standard (the currently used treatment), and some are being tested in clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>A treatment clinical trial is a research study meant to help improve current treatments or obtain information on new treatments for patients with cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>When clinical trials show that a new treatment is better than the standard treatment, the new treatment may become the standard treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients may want to think about taking part in a clinical trial.<EOS>
<BOS>Some clinical trials are open only to patients who have not started treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Five types of standard treatment are used: Surgery Surgery to remove part or all of the kidney is often used to treat renal cell cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>The following types of surgery may be used: Partial nephrectomy: A surgical procedure to remove the cancer within the kidney and some of the tissue around it.<EOS>
<BOS>A partial nephrectomy may be done to prevent loss of kidney function when the other kidney is damaged or has already been removed.<EOS>
<BOS>Simple nephrectomy: A surgical procedure to remove the kidney only.<EOS>
<BOS>Radical nephrectomy: A surgical procedure to remove the kidney, the adrenal gland, surrounding tissue, and, usually, nearby lymph nodes.<EOS>
<BOS>A person can live with part of 1 working kidney, but if both kidneys are removed or not working, the person will need dialysis (a procedure to clean the blood using a machine outside of the body) or a kidney transplant (replacement with a healthy donated kidney).<EOS>
<BOS>A kidney transplant may be done when the disease is in the kidney only and a donated kidney can be found.<EOS>
<BOS>If the patient has to wait for a donated kidney, other treatment is given as needed.<EOS>
<BOS>When surgery to remove the cancer is not possible, a treatment called arterial embolization may be used to shrink the tumor.<EOS>
<BOS>A small incision is made and a catheter (thin tube) is inserted into the main blood vessel that flows to the kidney.<EOS>
<BOS>Small pieces of a special gelatin sponge are injected through the catheter into the blood vessel.<EOS>
<BOS>The sponges block the blood flow to the kidney and prevent the cancer cells from getting oxygen and other substances they need to grow.<EOS>
<BOS>Even if the doctor removes all the cancer that can be seen at the time of the surgery, some patients may be given chemotherapy or radiation therapy after surgery to kill any cancer cells that are left.<EOS>
<BOS>Treatment given after the surgery, to lower the risk that the cancer will come back, is called adjuvant therapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Radiation therapy Radiation therapy is a cancer treatment that uses highenergy xrays or other types of radiation to kill cancer cells or keep them from growing.<EOS>
<BOS>There are two types of radiation therapy: External radiation therapy uses a machine outside the body to send radiation toward the cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Internal radiation therapy uses a radioactive substance sealed in needles, seeds, wires, or catheters that are placed directly into or near the cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>The way the radiation therapy is given depends on the type and stage of the cancer being treated.<EOS>
<BOS>External radiation therapy is used to treat renal cell cancer, and may also be used as palliative therapy to relieve symptoms and improve quality of life.<EOS>
<BOS>Chemotherapy Chemotherapy is a cancer treatment that uses drugs to stop the growth of cancer cells, either by killing the cells or by stopping them from dividing.<EOS>
<BOS>When chemotherapy is taken by mouth or injected into a vein or muscle, the drugs enter the bloodstream and can reach cancer cells throughout the body (systemic chemotherapy).<EOS>
<BOS>When chemotherapy is placed directly into the cerebrospinal fluid, an organ, or a body cavity such as the abdomen, the drugs mainly affect cancer cells in those areas (regional chemotherapy).<EOS>
<BOS>The way the chemotherapy is given depends on the type and stage of the cancer being treated.<EOS>
<BOS>See Drugs Approved for Kidney (Renal Cell) Cancer for more information.<EOS>
<BOS>Biologic therapy Biologic therapy is a treatment that uses the patient's immune system to fight cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Substances made by the body or made in a laboratory are used to boost, direct, or restore the body's natural defenses against cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>This type of cancer treatment is also called biotherapy or immunotherapy.<EOS>
<BOS>The following types of biologic therapy are being used or studied in the treatment of renal cell cancer: Nivolumab: Nivolumab is a monoclonal antibody that boosts the bodys immune response against renal cell cancer cells.<EOS>
<BOS>Interferon: Interferon affects the division of cancer cells and can slow tumor growth.<EOS>
<BOS>Interleukin2 (IL2): IL2 boosts the growth and activity of many immune cells, especially lymphocytes (a type of white blood cell).<EOS>
<BOS>Lymphocytes can attack and kill cancer cells.<EOS>
<BOS>See Drugs Approved for Kidney (Renal Cell) Cancer for more information.<EOS>
<BOS>Targeted therapy Targeted therapy uses drugs or other substances to identify and attack specific cancer cells without harming normal cells.<EOS>
<BOS>Targeted therapy with antiangiogenic agents are used to treat advanced renal cell cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Antiangiogenic agents keep blood vessels from forming in a tumor, causing the tumor to starve and stop growing or to shrink.<EOS>
<BOS>Monoclonal antibodies and kinase inhibitors are two types of antiangiogenic agents used to treat renal cell cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Monoclonal antibody therapy uses antibodies made in the laboratory, from a single type of immune system cell.<EOS>
<BOS>These antibodies can identify substances on cancer cells or normal substances that may help cancer cells grow.<EOS>
<BOS>The antibodies attach to the substances and kill the cancer cells, block their growth, or keep them from spreading.<EOS>
<BOS>Monoclonal antibodies are given by infusion.<EOS>
<BOS>They may be used alone or to carry drugs, toxins, or radioactive material directly to cancer cells.<EOS>
<BOS>Monoclonal antibodies used to treat renal cell cancer attach to and block substances that cause new blood vessels to form in tumors.<EOS>
<BOS>Kinase inhibitors stop cells from dividing and may prevent the growth of new blood vessels that tumors need to grow.<EOS>
<BOS>An mTOR inhibitor is a type of kinase inhibitor.<EOS>
<BOS>Everolimus and temsirolimus are mTOR inhibitors used to treat advanced renal cell cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>See Drugs Approved for Kidney (Renal Cell) Cancer for more information.<EOS>
<BOS>New types of treatment are being tested in clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>Information about clinical trials is available from the NCI website.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients may want to think about taking part in a clinical trial.<EOS>
<BOS>For some patients, taking part in a clinical trial may be the best treatment choice.<EOS>
<BOS>Clinical trials are part of the cancer research process.<EOS>
<BOS>Clinical trials are done to find out if new cancer treatments are safe and effective or better than the standard treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Many of today's standard treatments for cancer are based on earlier clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients who take part in a clinical trial may receive the standard treatment or be among the first to receive a new treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients who take part in clinical trials also help improve the way cancer will be treated in the future.<EOS>
<BOS>Even when clinical trials do not lead to effective new treatments, they often answer important questions and help move research forward.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients can enter clinical trials before, during, or after starting their cancer treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Some clinical trials only include patients who have not yet received treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Other trials test treatments for patients whose cancer has not gotten better.<EOS>
<BOS>There are also clinical trials that test new ways to stop cancer from recurring (coming back) or reduce the side effects of cancer treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Clinical trials are taking place in many parts of the country.<EOS>
<BOS>See the Treatment Options section that follows for links to current treatment clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>These have been retrieved from NCI's listing of clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>Followup tests may be needed.<EOS>
<BOS>Some of the tests that were done to diagnose the cancer or to find out the stage of the cancer may be repeated.<EOS>
<BOS>Some tests will be repeated in order to see how well the treatment is working.<EOS>
<BOS>Decisions about whether to continue, change, or stop treatment may be based on the results of these tests.<EOS>
<BOS>Some of the tests will continue to be done from time to time after treatment has ended.<EOS>
<BOS>The results of these tests can show if your condition has changed or if the cancer has recurred (come back).<EOS>
<BOS>These tests are sometimes called followup tests or checkups.<EOS>
<BOS>Treatment Options for Renal Cell Cancer Stage I Renal Cell Cancer Treatment of stage I renal cell cancer may include the following: Surgery (radical nephrectomy, simple nephrectomy, or partial nephrectomy).<EOS>
<BOS>Radiation therapy as palliative therapy to relieve symptoms in patients who cannot have surgery.<EOS>
<BOS>Arterial embolization as palliative therapy.<EOS>
<BOS>A clinical trial of a new treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Check the list of NCIsupported cancer clinical trials that are now accepting patients with stage I renal cell cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>For more specific results, refine the search by using other search features, such as the location of the trial, the type of treatment, or the name of the drug.<EOS>
<BOS>Talk with your doctor about clinical trials that may be right for you.<EOS>
<BOS>General information about clinical trials is available from the NCI website.<EOS>
<BOS>Stage II Renal Cell Cancer Treatment of stage II renal cell cancer may include the following: Surgery (radical nephrectomy or partial nephrectomy).<EOS>
<BOS>Surgery (nephrectomy), before or after radiation therapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Radiation therapy as palliative therapy to relieve symptoms in patients who cannot have surgery.<EOS>
<BOS>Arterial embolization as palliative therapy.<EOS>
<BOS>A clinical trial of a new treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Check the list of NCIsupported cancer clinical trials that are now accepting patients with stage II renal cell cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>For more specific results, refine the search by using other search features, such as the location of the trial, the type of treatment, or the name of the drug.<EOS>
<BOS>Talk with your doctor about clinical trials that may be right for you.<EOS>
<BOS>General information about clinical trials is available from the NCI website.<EOS>
<BOS>Stage III Renal Cell Cancer Treatment of stage III renal cell cancer may include the following: Surgery (radical nephrectomy).<EOS>
<BOS>Blood vessels of the kidney and some lymph nodes may also be removed.<EOS>
<BOS>Arterial embolization followed by surgery (radical nephrectomy).<EOS>
<BOS>Radiation therapy as palliative therapy to relieve symptoms and improve the quality of life.<EOS>
<BOS>Arterial embolization as palliative therapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Surgery (nephrectomy) as palliative therapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Radiation therapy before or after surgery (radical nephrectomy).<EOS>
<BOS>A clinical trial of biologic therapy following surgery.<EOS>
<BOS>Check the list of NCIsupported cancer clinical trials that are now accepting patients with stage III renal cell cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>For more specific results, refine the search by using other search features, such as the location of the trial, the type of treatment, or the name of the drug.<EOS>
<BOS>Talk with your doctor about clinical trials that may be right for you.<EOS>
<BOS>General information about clinical trials is available from the NCI website.<EOS>
<BOS>Stage IV and Recurrent Renal Cell Cancer Treatment of stage IV and recurrent renal cell cancer may include the following: Surgery (radical nephrectomy).<EOS>
<BOS>Surgery (nephrectomy) to reduce the size of the tumor.<EOS>
<BOS>Targeted therapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Biologic therapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Radiation therapy as palliative therapy to relieve symptoms and improve the quality of life.<EOS>
<BOS>A clinical trial of a new treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Check the list of NCIsupported cancer clinical trials that are now accepting patients with stage IV renal cell cancer and recurrent renal cell cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>For more specific results, refine the search by using other search features, such as the location of the trial, the type of treatment, or the name of the drug.<EOS>
<BOS>Talk with your doctor about clinical trials that may be right for you.<EOS>
<BOS>General information about clinical trials is available from the NCI website.<EOS>
<BOS>Key Points There are different types of treatment for patients with nonsmall cell lung cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Nine types of standard treatment are used: Surgery Radiation therapy Chemotherapy Targeted therapy Laser therapy Photodynamic therapy (PDT) Cryosurgery Electrocautery Watchful waiting New types of treatment are being tested in clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>Chemoprevention Radiosensitizers New combinations Patients may want to think about taking part in a clinical trial.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients can enter clinical trials before, during, or after starting their cancer treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Followup tests may be needed.<EOS>
<BOS>There are different types of treatment for patients with nonsmall cell lung cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Different types of treatments are available for patients with nonsmall cell lung cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Some treatments are standard (the currently used treatment), and some are being tested in clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>A treatment clinical trial is a research study meant to help improve current treatments or obtain information on new treatments for patients with cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>When clinical trials show that a new treatment is better than the standard treatment, the new treatment may become the standard treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients may want to think about taking part in a clinical trial.<EOS>
<BOS>Some clinical trials are open only to patients who have not started treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Nine types of standard treatment are used: Surgery Four types of surgery are used to treat lung cancer: Wedge resection: Surgery to remove a tumor and some of the normal tissue around it.<EOS>
<BOS>When a slightly larger amount of tissue is taken, it is called a segmental resection.<EOS>
<BOS>Lobectomy: Surgery to remove a whole lobe (section) of the lung.<EOS>
<BOS>Pneumonectomy: Surgery to remove one whole lung.<EOS>
<BOS>Sleeve resection: Surgery to remove part of the bronchus.<EOS>
<BOS>Even if the doctor removes all the cancer that can be seen at the time of the surgery, some patients may be given chemotherapy or radiation therapy after surgery to kill any cancer cells that are left.<EOS>
<BOS>Treatment given after the surgery, to lower the risk that the cancer will come back, is called adjuvant therapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Radiation therapy Radiation therapy is a cancer treatment that uses highenergy xrays or other types of radiation to kill cancer cells or keep them from growing.<EOS>
<BOS>There are two types of radiation therapy: External radiation therapy uses a machine outside the body to send radiation toward the cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Internal radiation therapy uses a radioactive substance sealed in needles, seeds, wires, or catheters that are placed directly into or near the cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Stereotactic body radiation therapy is a type of external radiation therapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Special equipment is used to place the patient in the same position for each radiation treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Once a day for several days, a radiation machine aims a larger than usual dose of radiation directly at the tumor.<EOS>
<BOS>By having the patient in the same position for each treatment, there is less damage to nearby healthy tissue.<EOS>
<BOS>This procedure is also called stereotactic externalbeam radiation therapy and stereotaxic radiation therapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Stereotactic radiosurgery is a type of external radiation therapy used to treat lung cancer that has spread to the brain.<EOS>
<BOS>A rigid head frame is attached to the skull to keep the head still during the radiation treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>A machine aims a single large dose of radiation directly at the tumor in the brain.<EOS>
<BOS>This procedure does not involve surgery.<EOS>
<BOS>It is also called stereotaxic radiosurgery, radiosurgery, and radiation surgery.<EOS>
<BOS>For tumors in the airways, radiation is given directly to the tumor through an endoscope.<EOS>
<BOS>The way the radiation therapy is given depends on the type and stage of the cancer being treated.<EOS>
<BOS>It also depends on where the cancer is found.<EOS>
<BOS>External and internal radiation therapy are used to treat nonsmall cell lung cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Chemotherapy Chemotherapy is a cancer treatment that uses drugs to stop the growth of cancer cells, either by killing the cells or by stopping them from dividing.<EOS>
<BOS>When chemotherapy is taken by mouth or injected into a vein or muscle, the drugs enter the bloodstream and can reach cancer cells throughout the body (systemic chemotherapy).<EOS>
<BOS>When chemotherapy is placed directly into the cerebrospinal fluid, an organ, or a body cavity such as the abdomen, the drugs mainly affect cancer cells in those areas (regional chemotherapy).<EOS>
<BOS>The way the chemotherapy is given depends on the type and stage of the cancer being treated.<EOS>
<BOS>See Drugs Approved for NonSmall Cell Lung Cancer for more information.<EOS>
<BOS>Targeted therapy Targeted therapy is a type of treatment that uses drugs or other substances to attack specific cancer cells.<EOS>
<BOS>Targeted therapies usually cause less harm to normal cells than chemotherapy or radiation therapy do.<EOS>
<BOS>Monoclonal antibodies and tyrosine kinase inhibitors are the two main types of targeted therapy being used to treat advanced, metastatic, or recurrent nonsmall cell lung cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Monoclonal antibodies Monoclonal antibody therapy is a cancer treatment that uses antibodies made in the laboratory from a single type of immune system cell.<EOS>
<BOS>These antibodies can identify substances on cancer cells or normal substances in the blood or tissues that may help cancer cells grow.<EOS>
<BOS>The antibodies attach to the substances and kill the cancer cells, block their growth, or keep them from spreading.<EOS>
<BOS>Monoclonal antibodies are given by infusion.<EOS>
<BOS>They may be used alone or to carry drugs, toxins, or radioactive material directly to cancer cells.<EOS>
<BOS>There are different types of monoclonal antibody therapy: Vascular endothelial growth factor (VEGF) inhibitor therapy: Cancer cells make a substance called VEGF, which causes new blood vessels to form (angiogenesis) and helps the cancer grow.<EOS>
<BOS>VEGF inhibitors block VEGF and stop new blood vessels from forming.<EOS>
<BOS>This may kill cancer cells because they need new blood vessels to grow.<EOS>
<BOS>Bevacizumab and ramucirumab are VEGF inhibitors and angiogenesis inhibitors.<EOS>
<BOS>Epidermal growth factor receptor (EGFR) inhibitor therapy: EGFRs are proteins found on the surface of certain cells, including cancer cells.<EOS>
<BOS>Epidermal growth factor attaches to the EGFR on the surface of the cell and causes the cells to grow and divide.<EOS>
<BOS>EGFR inhibitors block the receptor and stop the epidermal growth factor from attaching to the cancer cell.<EOS>
<BOS>This stops the cancer cell from growing and dividing.<EOS>
<BOS>Cetuximab and necitumumab are EGFR inhibitors.<EOS>
<BOS>Immune checkpoint inhibitor therapy: PD1 is a protein on the surface of T cells that helps keep the bodys immune responses in check.<EOS>
<BOS>When PD1 attaches to another protein called PDL1 on a cancer cell, it stops the T cell from killing the cancer cell.<EOS>
<BOS>PD1 inhibitors attach to PDL1 and allow the T cells to kill cancer cells.<EOS>
<BOS>Nivolumab, pembrolizumab, and atezolizumab are types of immune checkpoint inhibitors.<EOS>
<BOS>Tyrosine kinase inhibitors Tyrosine kinase inhibitors are smallmolecule drugs that go through the cell membrane and work inside cancer cells to block signals that cancer cells need to grow and divide.<EOS>
<BOS>Some tyrosine kinase inhibitors also have angiogenesis inhibitor effects.<EOS>
<BOS>There are different types of tyrosine kinase inhibitors: Epidermal growth factor receptor (EGFR) tyrosine kinase inhibitors: EGFRs are proteins found on the surface and inside certain cells, including cancer cells.<EOS>
<BOS>Epidermal growth factor attaches to the EGFR inside the cell and sends signals to the tyrosine kinase area of the cell, which tells the cell to grow and divide.<EOS>
<BOS>EGFR tyrosine kinase inhibitors stop these signals and stop the cancer cell from growing and dividing.<EOS>
<BOS>Erlotinib, gefitinib, and afatinib are types of EGFR tyrosine kinase inhibitors.<EOS>
<BOS>Some of these drugs work better when there is also a mutation (change) in the EGFR gene.<EOS>
<BOS>Kinase inhibitors that affect cells with certain gene changes: Certain changes in the ALK and ROS1 genes cause too much protein to be made.<EOS>
<BOS>Blocking these proteins may stop the cancer from growing and spreading.<EOS>
<BOS>Crizotinib is used to stop proteins from being made by the ALK and ROS1 gene.<EOS>
<BOS>Ceritinib is used to stop proteins from being made by the ALK gene.<EOS>
<BOS>See Drugs Approved for NonSmall Cell Lung Cancer for more information.<EOS>
<BOS>Laser therapy Laser therapy is a cancer treatment that uses a laser beam (a narrow beam of intense light) to kill cancer cells.<EOS>
<BOS>Photodynamic therapy (PDT) Photodynamic therapy (PDT) is a cancer treatment that uses a drug and a certain type of laser light to kill cancer cells.<EOS>
<BOS>A drug that is not active until it is exposed to light is injected into a vein.<EOS>
<BOS>The drug collects more in cancer cells than in normal cells.<EOS>
<BOS>Fiberoptic tubes are then used to carry the laser light to the cancer cells, where the drug becomes active and kills the cells.<EOS>
<BOS>Photodynamic therapy causes little damage to healthy tissue.<EOS>
<BOS>It is used mainly to treat tumors on or just under the skin or in the lining of internal organs.<EOS>
<BOS>When the tumor is in the airways, PDT is given directly to the tumor through an endoscope.<EOS>
<BOS>Cryosurgery Cryosurgery is a treatment that uses an instrument to freeze and destroy abnormal tissue, such as carcinoma in situ.<EOS>
<BOS>This type of treatment is also called cryotherapy.<EOS>
<BOS>For tumors in the airways, cryosurgery is done through an endoscope.<EOS>
<BOS>Electrocautery Electrocautery is a treatment that uses a probe or needle heated by an electric current to destroy abnormal tissue.<EOS>
<BOS>For tumors in the airways, electrocautery is done through an endoscope.<EOS>
<BOS>Watchful waiting Watchful waiting is closely monitoring a patients condition without giving any treatment until signs or symptoms appear or change.<EOS>
<BOS>This may be done in certain rare cases of nonsmall cell lung cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>New types of treatment are being tested in clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>This summary section describes treatments that are being studied in clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>It may not mention every new treatment being studied.<EOS>
<BOS>Information about clinical trials is available from the NCI website.<EOS>
<BOS>Chemoprevention Chemoprevention is the use of drugs, vitamins, or other substances to reduce the risk of cancer or to reduce the risk cancer will recur (come back).<EOS>
<BOS>For lung cancer, chemoprevention is used to lessen the chance that a new tumor will form in the lung.<EOS>
<BOS>Radiosensitizers Radiosensitizers are substances that make tumor cells easier to kill with radiation therapy.<EOS>
<BOS>The combination of chemotherapy and radiation therapy given with a radiosensitizer is being studied in the treatment of nonsmall cell lung cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>New combinations New combinations of treatments are being studied in clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients may want to think about taking part in a clinical trial.<EOS>
<BOS>For some patients, taking part in a clinical trial may be the best treatment choice.<EOS>
<BOS>Clinical trials are part of the cancer research process.<EOS>
<BOS>Clinical trials are done to find out if new cancer treatments are safe and effective or better than the standard treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Many of today's standard treatments for cancer are based on earlier clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients who take part in a clinical trial may receive the standard treatment or be among the first to receive a new treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients who take part in clinical trials also help improve the way cancer will be treated in the future.<EOS>
<BOS>Even when clinical trials do not lead to effective new treatments, they often answer important questions and help move research forward.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients can enter clinical trials before, during, or after starting their cancer treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Some clinical trials only include patients who have not yet received treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Other trials test treatments for patients whose cancer has not gotten better.<EOS>
<BOS>There are also clinical trials that test new ways to stop cancer from recurring (coming back) or reduce the side effects of cancer treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Clinical trials are taking place in many parts of the country.<EOS>
<BOS>See the Treatment Options section that follows for links to current treatment clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>These have been retrieved from NCI's listing of clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>Followup tests may be needed.<EOS>
<BOS>Some of the tests that were done to diagnose the cancer or to find out the stage of the cancer may be repeated.<EOS>
<BOS>Some tests will be repeated in order to see how well the treatment is working.<EOS>
<BOS>Decisions about whether to continue, change, or stop treatment may be based on the results of these tests.<EOS>
<BOS>Some of the tests will continue to be done from time to time after treatment has ended.<EOS>
<BOS>The results of these tests can show if your condition has changed or if the cancer has recurred (come back).<EOS>
<BOS>These tests are sometimes called followup tests or checkups.<EOS>
<BOS>Treatment Options by Stage Occult NonSmall Cell Lung Cancer Treatment of occult nonsmall cell lung cancer depends on the stage of the disease.<EOS>
<BOS>Occult tumors are often found at an early stage (the tumor is in the lung only) and sometimes can be cured by surgery.<EOS>
<BOS>Check the list of NCIsupported cancer clinical trials that are now accepting patients with occult nonsmall cell lung cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>For more specific results, refine the search by using other search features, such as the location of the trial, the type of treatment, or the name of the drug.<EOS>
<BOS>Talk with your doctor about clinical trials that may be right for you.<EOS>
<BOS>General information about clinical trials is available from the NCI website.<EOS>
<BOS>Stage 0 (Carcinoma in Situ) Treatment of stage 0 may include the following: Surgery (wedge resection or segmental resection).<EOS>
<BOS>Photodynamic therapy for tumors in or near the bronchus.<EOS>
<BOS>Electrocautery, cryosurgery, or laser surgery for tumors in or near the bronchus.<EOS>
<BOS>Check the list of NCIsupported cancer clinical trials that are now accepting patients with stage 0 nonsmall cell lung cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>For more specific results, refine the search by using other search features, such as the location of the trial, the type of treatment, or the name of the drug.<EOS>
<BOS>Talk with your doctor about clinical trials that may be right for you.<EOS>
<BOS>General information about clinical trials is available from the NCI website.<EOS>
<BOS>Stage I NonSmall Cell Lung Cancer Treatment of stage I nonsmall cell lung cancer may include the following: Surgery (wedge resection, segmental resection, sleeve resection, or lobectomy).<EOS>
<BOS>External radiation therapy, including stereotactic body radiation therapy for patients who cannot have surgery or choose not to have surgery.<EOS>
<BOS>A clinical trial of chemotherapy or radiation therapy following surgery.<EOS>
<BOS>A clinical trial of treatment given through an endoscope, such as photodynamic therapy (PDT).<EOS>
<BOS>A clinical trial of surgery followed by chemoprevention.<EOS>
<BOS>Check the list of NCIsupported cancer clinical trials that are now accepting patients with stage I nonsmall cell lung cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>For more specific results, refine the search by using other search features, such as the location of the trial, the type of treatment, or the name of the drug.<EOS>
<BOS>Talk with your doctor about clinical trials that may be right for you.<EOS>
<BOS>General information about clinical trials is available from the NCI website.<EOS>
<BOS>Stage II NonSmall Cell Lung Cancer Treatment of stage II nonsmall cell lung cancer may include the following: Surgery (wedge resection, segmental resection, sleeve resection, lobectomy, or pneumonectomy).<EOS>
<BOS>Chemotherapy followed by surgery.<EOS>
<BOS>Surgery followed by chemotherapy.<EOS>
<BOS>External radiation therapy for patients who cannot have surgery.<EOS>
<BOS>A clinical trial of radiation therapy following surgery.<EOS>
<BOS>Check the list of NCIsupported cancer clinical trials that are now accepting patients with stage II nonsmall cell lung cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>For more specific results, refine the search by using other search features, such as the location of the trial, the type of treatment, or the name of the drug.<EOS>
<BOS>Talk with your doctor about clinical trials that may be right for you.<EOS>
<BOS>General information about clinical trials is available from the NCI website.<EOS>
<BOS>Stage IIIA NonSmall Cell Lung Cancer Treatment of stage IIIA nonsmall cell lung cancer that can be removed with surgery may include the following: Surgery followed by chemotherapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Surgery followed by radiation therapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Chemotherapy followed by surgery.<EOS>
<BOS>Surgery followed by chemotherapy combined with radiation therapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Chemotherapy and radiation therapy followed by surgery.<EOS>
<BOS>A clinical trial of new combinations of treatments.<EOS>
<BOS>Treatment of stage IIIA nonsmall cell lung cancer that cannot be removed with surgery may include the following: Chemotherapy and radiation therapy given over the same period of time or one followed by the other.<EOS>
<BOS>External radiation therapy alone for patients who cannot be treated with combined therapy, or as palliative treatment to relieve symptoms and improve the quality of life.<EOS>
<BOS>Internal radiation therapy or laser surgery, as palliative treatment to relieve symptoms and improve the quality of life.<EOS>
<BOS>A clinical trial of new combinations of treatments.<EOS>
<BOS>For more information about supportive care for signs and symptoms including cough, shortness of breath, and chest pain, see the PDQ summary on Cardiopulmonary Syndromes.<EOS>
<BOS>Nonsmall cell lung cancer of the superior sulcus, often called Pancoast tumor, begins in the upper part of the lung and spreads to nearby tissues such as the chest wall, large blood vessels, and spine.<EOS>
<BOS>Treatment of Pancoast tumors may include the following: Radiation therapy alone.<EOS>
<BOS>Radiation therapy followed by surgery.<EOS>
<BOS>Chemotherapy and radiation therapy given as separate treatments over the same period of time.<EOS>
<BOS>Surgery may also be done after chemotherapy and radiation therapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Surgery alone.<EOS>
<BOS>A clinical trial of new combinations of treatments.<EOS>
<BOS>Some stage IIIA nonsmall cell lung tumors that have grown into the chest wall may be completely removed.<EOS>
<BOS>Treatment of chest wall tumors may include the following: Surgery.<EOS>
<BOS>Surgery and radiation therapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Radiation therapy alone.<EOS>
<BOS>Chemotherapy combined with radiation therapy and/or surgery.<EOS>
<BOS>A clinical trial of new combinations of treatments.<EOS>
<BOS>Check the list of NCIsupported cancer clinical trials that are now accepting patients with stage III nonsmall cell lung cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>For more specific results, refine the search by using other search features, such as the location of the trial, the type of treatment, or the name of the drug.<EOS>
<BOS>Talk with your doctor about clinical trials that may be right for you.<EOS>
<BOS>General information about clinical trials is available from the NCI website.<EOS>
<BOS>Stage IIIB NonSmall Cell Lung Cancer Treatment of stage IIIB nonsmall cell lung cancer may include the following: Chemotherapy followed by external radiation therapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Chemotherapy and radiation therapy given as separate treatments over the same period of time.<EOS>
<BOS>Chemotherapy followed by surgery.<EOS>
<BOS>External radiation therapy alone for patients who cannot be treated with chemotherapy.<EOS>
<BOS>External radiation therapy as palliative therapy, to relieve symptoms and improve the quality of life.<EOS>
<BOS>Laser therapy and/or internal radiation therapy to relieve symptoms and improve the quality of life.<EOS>
<BOS>Clinical trials of new external radiation therapy schedules and new types of treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>A clinical trial of chemotherapy and radiation therapy combined with a radiosensitizer.<EOS>
<BOS>Clinical trials of targeted therapy combined with chemotherapy and radiation therapy.<EOS>
<BOS>For more information about supportive care for signs and symptoms such as cough, shortness of breath, and chest pain, see the following PDQ summaries: Cardiopulmonary Syndromes Cancer Pain Check the list of NCIsupported cancer clinical trials that are now accepting patients with stage III nonsmall cell lung cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>For more specific results, refine the search by using other search features, such as the location of the trial, the type of treatment, or the name of the drug.<EOS>
<BOS>Talk with your doctor about clinical trials that may be right for you.<EOS>
<BOS>General information about clinical trials is available from the NCI website.<EOS>
<BOS>Stage IV NonSmall Cell Lung Cancer Treatment of stage IV nonsmall cell lung cancer may include the following: Chemotherapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Chemotherapy followed by more chemotherapy as maintenance therapy to help keep cancer from progressing.<EOS>
<BOS>Combination chemotherapy and targeted therapy with a monoclonal antibody, such as bevacizumab, cetuximab, or necitumumab.<EOS>
<BOS>Targeted therapy with a monoclonal antibody, such as nivolumab, pembrolizumab, or atezolizumab.<EOS>
<BOS>Targeted therapy with a tyrosine kinase inhibitor, such as erlotinib, gefitinib, afatinib, crizotinib, or ceritinib.<EOS>
<BOS>External radiation therapy as palliative therapy, to relieve symptoms and improve the quality of life.<EOS>
<BOS>Laser therapy and/or internal radiation therapy for tumors that are blocking the airways.<EOS>
<BOS>A clinical trial of new drugs and combinations of treatments.<EOS>
<BOS>For more information about supportive care for signs and symptoms including cough, shortness of breath, and chest pain, see the following PDQ summaries: Cardiopulmonary Syndromes Cancer Pain Last Days of Life Check the list of NCIsupported cancer clinical trials that are now accepting patients with stage IV nonsmall cell lung cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>For more specific results, refine the search by using other search features, such as the location of the trial, the type of treatment, or the name of the drug.<EOS>
<BOS>Talk with your doctor about clinical trials that may be right for you.<EOS>
<BOS>General information about clinical trials is available from the NCI website.<EOS>
<BOS>Signs and symptoms of laryngeal cancer include a sore throat and ear pain.<EOS>
<BOS>These and other signs and symptoms may be caused by laryngeal cancer or by other conditions.<EOS>
<BOS>Check with your doctor if you have any of the following: A sore throat or cough that does not go away.<EOS>
<BOS>Trouble or pain when swallowing.<EOS>
<BOS>Ear pain.<EOS>
<BOS>A lump in the neck or throat.<EOS>
<BOS>A change or hoarseness in the voice.<EOS>
<BOS>Key Points Plasma cell neoplasms are diseases in which the body makes too many plasma cells.<EOS>
<BOS>Plasma cell neoplasms can be benign (not cancer) or malignant (cancer).<EOS>
<BOS>There are several types of plasma cell neoplasms.<EOS>
<BOS>Monoclonal gammopathy of undetermined significance (MGUS) Plasmacytoma Multiple myeloma Multiple myeloma and other plasma cell neoplasms may cause a condition called amyloidosis.<EOS>
<BOS>Age can affect the risk of plasma cell neoplasms.<EOS>
<BOS>Tests that examine the blood, bone marrow, and urine are used to detect (find) and diagnose multiple myeloma and other plasma cell neoplasms.<EOS>
<BOS>Certain factors affect prognosis (chance of recovery) and treatment options.<EOS>
<BOS>Plasma cell neoplasms are diseases in which the body makes too many plasma cells.<EOS>
<BOS>Plasma cells develop from B lymphocytes (B cells), a type of white blood cell that is made in the bone marrow.<EOS>
<BOS>Normally, when bacteria or viruses enter the body, some of the B cells will change into plasma cells.<EOS>
<BOS>The plasma cells make antibodies to fight bacteria and viruses, to stop infection and disease.<EOS>
<BOS>Plasma cell neoplasms are diseases in which abnormal plasma cells or myeloma cells form tumors in the bones or soft tissues of the body.<EOS>
<BOS>The plasma cells also make an antibody protein, called M protein, that is not needed by the body and does not help fight infection.<EOS>
<BOS>These antibody proteins build up in the bone marrow and can cause the blood to thicken or can damage the kidneys.<EOS>
<BOS>Plasma cell neoplasms can be benign (not cancer) or malignant (cancer).<EOS>
<BOS>Monoclonal gammopathy of undetermined significance (MGUS) is not cancer but can become cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>The following types of plasma cell neoplasms are cancer: Lymphoplasmacytic lymphoma.<EOS>
<BOS>(See Adult NonHodgkin Lymphoma Treatment for more information.<EOS>
<BOS>) Plasmacytoma.<EOS>
<BOS>Multiple myeloma.<EOS>
<BOS>There are several types of plasma cell neoplasms.<EOS>
<BOS>Plasma cell neoplasms include the following: Monoclonal gammopathy of undetermined significance (MGUS) In this type of plasma cell neoplasm, less than 10% of the bone marrow is made up of abnormal plasma cells and there is no cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>The abnormal plasma cells make M protein, which is sometimes found during a routine blood or urine test.<EOS>
<BOS>In most patients, the amount of M protein stays the same and there are no signs, symptoms, or health problems.<EOS>
<BOS>In some patients, MGUS may later become a more serious condition, such as amyloidosis, or cause problems with the kidneys, heart, or nerves.<EOS>
<BOS>MGUS can also become cancer, such as multiple myeloma, lymphoplasmacytic lymphoma, or chronic lymphocytic leukemia.<EOS>
<BOS>Plasmacytoma In this type of plasma cell neoplasm, the abnormal plasma cells (myeloma cells) are in one place and form one tumor, called a plasmacytoma.<EOS>
<BOS>Sometimes plasmacytoma can be cured.<EOS>
<BOS>There are two types of plasmacytoma.<EOS>
<BOS>In isolated plasmacytoma of bone, one plasma cell tumor is found in the bone, less than 10% of the bone marrow is made up of plasma cells, and there are no other signs of cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Plasmacytoma of the bone often becomes multiple myeloma.<EOS>
<BOS>In extramedullary plasmacytoma, one plasma cell tumor is found in soft tissue but not in the bone or the bone marrow.<EOS>
<BOS>Extramedullary plasmacytomas commonly form in tissues of the throat, tonsil, and paranasal sinuses.<EOS>
<BOS>Signs and symptoms depend on where the tumor is.<EOS>
<BOS>In bone, the plasmacytoma may cause pain or broken bones.<EOS>
<BOS>In soft tissue, the tumor may press on nearby areas and cause pain or other problems.<EOS>
<BOS>For example, a plasmacytoma in the throat can make it hard to swallow.<EOS>
<BOS>Multiple myeloma In multiple myeloma, abnormal plasma cells (myeloma cells) build up in the bone marrow and form tumors in many bones of the body.<EOS>
<BOS>These tumors may keep the bone marrow from making enough healthy blood cells.<EOS>
<BOS>Normally, the bone marrow makes stem cells (immature cells) that become three types of mature blood cells: Red blood cells that carry oxygen and other substances to all tissues of the body.<EOS>
<BOS>White blood cells that fight infection and disease.<EOS>
<BOS>Platelets that form blood clots to help prevent bleeding.<EOS>
<BOS>As the number of myeloma cells increases, fewer red blood cells, white blood cells, and platelets are made.<EOS>
<BOS>The myeloma cells also damage and weaken the bone.<EOS>
<BOS>Sometimes multiple myeloma does not cause any signs or symptoms.<EOS>
<BOS>This is called smoldering multiple myeloma.<EOS>
<BOS>It may be found when a blood or urine test is done for another condition.<EOS>
<BOS>Signs and symptoms may be caused by multiple myeloma or other conditions.<EOS>
<BOS>Check with your doctor if you have any of the following: Bone pain, especially in the back or ribs.<EOS>
<BOS>Bones that break easily.<EOS>
<BOS>Fever for no known reason or frequent infections.<EOS>
<BOS>Easy bruising or bleeding.<EOS>
<BOS>Trouble breathing.<EOS>
<BOS>Weakness of the arms or legs.<EOS>
<BOS>Feeling very tired.<EOS>
<BOS>A tumor can damage the bone and cause hypercalcemia (too much calcium in the blood).<EOS>
<BOS>This can affect many organs in the body, including the kidneys, nerves, heart, muscles, and digestive tract, and cause serious health problems.<EOS>
<BOS>Hypercalcemia may cause the following signs and symptoms: Loss of appetite.<EOS>
<BOS>Nausea or vomiting.<EOS>
<BOS>Feeling thirsty.<EOS>
<BOS>Frequent urination.<EOS>
<BOS>Constipation.<EOS>
<BOS>Feeling very tired.<EOS>
<BOS>Muscle weakness.<EOS>
<BOS>Restlessness.<EOS>
<BOS>Confusion or trouble thinking.<EOS>
<BOS>Multiple myeloma and other plasma cell neoplasms may cause a condition called amyloidosis.<EOS>
<BOS>In rare cases, multiple myeloma can cause peripheral nerves (nerves that are not in the brain or spinal cord) and organs to fail.<EOS>
<BOS>This may be caused by a condition called amyloidosis.<EOS>
<BOS>Antibody proteins build up and stick together in peripheral nerves and organs, such as the kidney and heart.<EOS>
<BOS>This can cause the nerves and organs to become stiff and unable to work the way they should.<EOS>
<BOS>Amyloidosis may cause the following signs and symptoms: Feeling very tired.<EOS>
<BOS>Purple spots on the skin.<EOS>
<BOS>Enlarged tongue.<EOS>
<BOS>Diarrhea.<EOS>
<BOS>Swelling caused by fluid in your body's tissues.<EOS>
<BOS>Tingling or numbness in your legs and feet.<EOS>
<BOS>Smoking, previous chemotherapy treatment, and exposure to radiation may affect the risk of adult AML.<EOS>
<BOS>Anything that increases your risk of getting a disease is called a risk factor.<EOS>
<BOS>Having a risk factor does not mean that you will get cancer; not having risk factors doesnt mean that you will not get cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Talk with your doctor if you think you may be at risk.<EOS>
<BOS>Possible risk factors for AML include the following: Being male.<EOS>
<BOS>Smoking, especially after age 60.<EOS>
<BOS>Having had treatment with chemotherapy or radiation therapy in the past.<EOS>
<BOS>Having had treatment for childhood acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL) in the past.<EOS>
<BOS>Being exposed to radiation from an atomic bomb or to the chemical benzene.<EOS>
<BOS>Having a history of a blood disorder such as myelodysplastic syndrome.<EOS>
<BOS>Certain factors affect prognosis (chance of recovery) and treatment options.<EOS>
<BOS>The prognosis (chance of recovery) and treatment options depend on the following: The stage of the cancer (the size of the tumor, whether it affects part or all of the liver, or has spread to other places in the body).<EOS>
<BOS>How well the liver is working.<EOS>
