<BOS>The patients general health, including whether there is cirrhosis of the liver.<EOS>
<BOS>New types of treatment are being tested in clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>This summary section describes treatments that are being studied in clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>It may not mention every new treatment being studied.<EOS>
<BOS>Information about clinical trials is available from the NCI website.<EOS>
<BOS>Biologic therapy Biologic therapy is a treatment that uses the patients immune system to fight cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Substances made by the body or made in a laboratory are used to boost, direct, or restore the bodys natural defenses against cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>This type of cancer treatment is also called biotherapy or immunotherapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients may want to think about taking part in a clinical trial.<EOS>
<BOS>For some patients, taking part in a clinical trial may be the best treatment choice.<EOS>
<BOS>Clinical trials are part of the cancer research process.<EOS>
<BOS>Clinical trials are done to find out if new cancer treatments are safe and effective or better than the standard treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Many of today's standard treatments for cancer are based on earlier clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients who take part in a clinical trial may receive the standard treatment or be among the first to receive a new treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients who take part in clinical trials also help improve the way cancer will be treated in the future.<EOS>
<BOS>Even when clinical trials do not lead to effective new treatments, they often answer important questions and help move research forward.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients can enter clinical trials before, during, or after starting their cancer treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Some clinical trials only include patients who have not yet received treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Other trials test treatments for patients whose cancer has not gotten better.<EOS>
<BOS>There are also clinical trials that test new ways to stop cancer from recurring (coming back) or reduce the side effects of cancer treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Clinical trials are taking place in many parts of the country.<EOS>
<BOS>See the Treatment Options section that follows for links to current treatment clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>These have been retrieved from NCI's listing of clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>Signs of uterine sarcoma include abnormal bleeding.<EOS>
<BOS>Abnormal bleeding from the vagina and other signs and symptoms may be caused by uterine sarcoma or by other conditions.<EOS>
<BOS>Check with your doctor if you have any of the following: Bleeding that is not part of menstrual periods.<EOS>
<BOS>Bleeding after menopause.<EOS>
<BOS>A mass in the vagina.<EOS>
<BOS>Pain or a feeling of fullness in the abdomen.<EOS>
<BOS>Frequent urination.<EOS>
<BOS>Key Points Avoiding risk factors and increasing protective factors may help prevent cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>The following risk factors increase the risk of colorectal cancer: Age Family history of colorectal cancer Personal history Inherited risk Alcohol Cigarette smoking Obesity The following protective factors decrease the risk of colorectal cancer: Physical activity Aspirin Combination hormone replacement therapy Polyp removal It is not clear if the following affect the risk of colorectal cancer: Nonsteroidal antiinflammatory drugs (NSAIDs) other than aspirin Calcium Diet The following factors do not affect the risk of colorectal cancer: Hormone replacement therapy with estrogen only Statins Cancer prevention clinical trials are used to study ways to prevent cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>New ways to prevent colorectal cancer are being studied in clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>Avoiding risk factors and increasing protective factors may help prevent cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Avoiding cancer risk factors may help prevent certain cancers.<EOS>
<BOS>Risk factors include smoking, being overweight, and not getting enough exercise.<EOS>
<BOS>Increasing protective factors such as quitting smoking and exercising may also help prevent some cancers.<EOS>
<BOS>Talk to your doctor or other health care professional about how you might lower your risk of cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>The following risk factors increase the risk of colorectal cancer: Age The risk of colorectal cancer increases after age 50.<EOS>
<BOS>Most cases of colorectal cancer are diagnosed after age 50.<EOS>
<BOS>Family history of colorectal cancer Having a parent, brother, sister, or child with colorectal cancer doubles a person's risk of colorectal cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Personal history Having a personal history of the following conditions increases the risk of colorectal cancer: Previous colorectal cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Highrisk adenomas (colorectal polyps that are 1 centimeter or larger in size or that have cells that look abnormal under a microscope).<EOS>
<BOS>Ovarian cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Inflammatory bowel disease (such as ulcerative colitis or Crohn disease).<EOS>
<BOS>Inherited risk The risk of colorectal cancer is increased when certain gene changes linked to familial adenomatous polyposis (FAP) or hereditary nonpolyposis colon cancer (HNPCC or Lynch Syndrome) are inherited.<EOS>
<BOS>Alcohol Drinking 3 or more alcoholic beverages per day increases the risk of colorectal cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Drinking alcohol is also linked to the risk of forming large colorectal adenomas (benign tumors).<EOS>
<BOS>Cigarette smoking Cigarette smoking is linked to an increased risk of colorectal cancer and death from colorectal cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Smoking cigarettes is also linked to an increased risk of forming colorectal adenomas.<EOS>
<BOS>Cigarette smokers who have had surgery to remove colorectal adenomas are at an increased risk for the adenomas to recur (come back).<EOS>
<BOS>Obesity Obesity is linked to an increased risk of colorectal cancer and death from colorectal cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>It is not clear if the following affect the risk of colorectal cancer: Nonsteroidal antiinflammatory drugs (NSAIDs) other than aspirin It is not known if the use of nonsteroidal antiinflammatory drugs or NSAIDs (such as sulindac, celecoxib, naproxen, and ibuprofen) lowers the risk of colorectal cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Studies have shown that taking the nonsteroidal antiinflammatory drug celecoxib reduces the risk of colorectal adenomas (benign tumors) coming back after they have been removed.<EOS>
<BOS>It is not clear if this results in a lower risk of colorectal cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Taking sulindac or celecoxib has been shown to reduce the number and size of polyps that form in the colon and rectum of people with familial adenomatous polyposis (FAP).<EOS>
<BOS>It is not clear if this results in a lower risk of colorectal cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>The possible harms of NSAIDs include: Kidney problems.<EOS>
<BOS>Bleeding in the stomach, intestines, or brain.<EOS>
<BOS>Heart problems such as heart attack and congestive heart failure.<EOS>
<BOS>Calcium It is not known if taking calcium supplements lowers the risk of colorectal cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Diet It is not known if a diet low in fat and meat and high in fiber, fruits, and vegetables lowers the risk of colorectal cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Some studies have shown that a diet high in fat, proteins, calories, and meat increases the risk of colorectal cancer, but other studies have not.<EOS>
<BOS>The following factors do not affect the risk of colorectal cancer: Hormone replacement therapy with estrogen only Hormone replacement therapy with estrogen only does not lower the risk of having invasive colorectal cancer or the risk of dying from colorectal cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Statins Studies have shown that taking statins (drugs that lower cholesterol) does not increase or decrease the risk of colorectal cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Having certain genetic syndromes may increase the risk of a central nervous system tumor.<EOS>
<BOS>Anything that increases your chance of getting a disease is called a risk factor.<EOS>
<BOS>Having a risk factor does not mean that you will get cancer; not having risk factors doesnt mean that you will not get cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Talk with your doctor if you think you may be at risk.<EOS>
<BOS>There are few known risk factors for brain tumors.<EOS>
<BOS>The following conditions may increase the risk of certain types of brain tumors: Being exposed to vinyl chloride may increase the risk of glioma.<EOS>
<BOS>Infection with the EpsteinBarr virus, having AIDS (acquired immunodeficiency syndrome), or receiving an organ transplant may increase the risk of primary CNS lymphoma.<EOS>
<BOS>(See the PDQ summary on Primary CNS Lymphoma for more information.<EOS>
<BOS>) Having certain genetic syndromes may increase the risk brain tumors: Neurofibromatosis type 1 (NF1) or 2 (NF2).<EOS>
<BOS>von HippelLindau disease.<EOS>
<BOS>Tuberous sclerosis.<EOS>
<BOS>LiFraumeni syndrome.<EOS>
<BOS>Turcot syndrome type 1 or 2.<EOS>
<BOS>Nevoid basal cell carcinoma syndrome.<EOS>
<BOS>Tests that examine the bone and soft tissue are used to diagnose and stage Ewing sarcoma.<EOS>
<BOS>Procedures that make pictures of the bones and soft tissues and nearby areas help diagnose Ewing sarcoma and show how far the cancer has spread.<EOS>
<BOS>The process used to find out if cancer cells have spread within and around the bones and soft tissues is called staging.<EOS>
<BOS>In order to plan treatment, it is important to know if the cancer is in the area where it first formed or if it has spread to other parts of the body.<EOS>
<BOS>Tests and procedures to detect, diagnose, and stage Ewing sarcoma are usually done at the same time.<EOS>
<BOS>The following tests and procedures may be used to diagnose or stage Ewing sarcoma: Physical exam and history : An exam of the body to check general signs of health, including checking for signs of disease, such as lumps or anything else that seems unusual.<EOS>
<BOS>A history of the patients health habits and past illnesses and treatments will also be taken.<EOS>
<BOS>MRI (magnetic resonance imaging): A procedure that uses a magnet, radio waves, and a computer to make a series of detailed pictures of areas inside the body, such as the area where the tumor formed.<EOS>
<BOS>This procedure is also called nuclear magnetic resonance imaging (NMRI).<EOS>
<BOS>CT scan (CAT scan): A procedure that makes a series of detailed pictures of areas inside the body, such as the area where the tumor formed or the chest, taken from different angles.<EOS>
<BOS>The pictures are made by a computer linked to an xray machine.<EOS>
<BOS>A dye may be injected into a vein or swallowed to help the organs or tissues show up more clearly.<EOS>
<BOS>This procedure is also called computed tomography, computerized tomography, or computerized axial tomography.<EOS>
<BOS>PET scan (positron emission tomography scan): A procedure to find malignant tumor cells in the body.<EOS>
<BOS>A small amount of radioactive glucose (sugar) is injected into a vein.<EOS>
<BOS>The PET scanner rotates around the body and makes a picture of where glucose is being used in the body.<EOS>
<BOS>Malignant tumor cells show up brighter in the picture because they are more active and take up more glucose than normal cells do.<EOS>
<BOS>A PET scan and a CT scan are often done at the same time.<EOS>
<BOS>If there is any cancer, this increases the chance that it will be found.<EOS>
<BOS>Bone scan : A procedure to check if there are rapidly dividing cells, such as cancer cells, in the bone.<EOS>
<BOS>A very small amount of radioactive material is injected into a vein and travels through the bloodstream.<EOS>
<BOS>The radioactive material collects in the bones with cancer and is detected by a scanner.<EOS>
<BOS>Bone marrow aspiration and biopsy : The removal of bone marrow and a small piece of bone by inserting a hollow needle into the hipbone.<EOS>
<BOS>Samples are removed from both hipbones.<EOS>
<BOS>A pathologist views the bone marrow and bone under a microscope to see if the cancer has spread.<EOS>
<BOS>Xray: An xray is a type of energy beam that can go through the body and onto film, making a picture of areas inside the body, such as the chest or the area where the tumor formed.<EOS>
<BOS>Complete blood count (CBC): A procedure in which a sample of blood is drawn and checked for the following: The number of red blood cells, white blood cells, and platelets.<EOS>
<BOS>The amount of hemoglobin (the protein that carries oxygen) in the red blood cells.<EOS>
<BOS>The portion of the blood sample made up of red blood cells.<EOS>
<BOS>Blood chemistry studies : A procedure in which a blood sample is checked to measure the amounts of certain substances, such as lactate dehydrogenase (LDH), released into the blood by organs and tissues in the body.<EOS>
<BOS>An unusual (higher or lower than normal) amount of a substance can be a sign of disease.<EOS>
<BOS>A biopsy is done to diagnose Ewing sarcoma.<EOS>
<BOS>Tissue samples are removed during a biopsy so they can be viewed under a microscope by a pathologist to check for signs of cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>It is helpful if the biopsy is done at the same center where treatment will be given.<EOS>
<BOS>Needle biopsy : For a needle biopsy, tissue is removed using a needle.<EOS>
<BOS>This type of needle biopsy may be done if its possible to remove tissue samples large enough to be used for testing.<EOS>
<BOS>Incisional biopsy : For an incisional biopsy, a sample of tissue is removed through an incision in the skin.<EOS>
<BOS>Excisional biopsy : The removal of an entire lump or area of tissue that doesnt look normal.<EOS>
<BOS>The specialists (pathologist, radiation oncologist, and surgeon) who will treat the patient usually work together to decide where the needle should be placed or the biopsy incision should be made.<EOS>
<BOS>This is done so that the biopsy doesn't affect later treatment such as surgery to remove the tumor or radiation therapy.<EOS>
<BOS>If there is a chance that the cancer has spread to nearby lymph nodes, one or more lymph nodes may be removed and checked for signs of cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>The following tests may be done on the tissue that is removed: Cytogenetic analysis : A laboratory test in which cells in a sample of tissue are viewed under a microscope to look for certain changes in the chromosomes.<EOS>
<BOS>Immunohistochemistry : A test that uses antibodies to check for certain antigens in a sample of tissue.<EOS>
<BOS>The antibody is usually linked to a radioactive substance or a dye that causes the tissue to light up under a microscope.<EOS>
<BOS>This type of test may be used to tell the difference between different types of cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Flow cytometry : A laboratory test that measures the number of cells in a sample, the percentage of live cells in a sample, and certain characteristics of cells, such as size, shape, and the presence of tumor markers on the cell surface.<EOS>
<BOS>The cells are stained with a lightsensitive dye, placed in a fluid, and passed in a stream before a laser or other type of light.<EOS>
<BOS>The measurements are based on how the lightsensitive dye reacts to the light.<EOS>
<BOS>Key Points After transitional cell cancer of the renal pelvis and ureter has been diagnosed, tests are done to find out if cancer cells have spread within the renal pelvis and ureter or to other parts of the body.<EOS>
<BOS>There are three ways that cancer spreads in the body.<EOS>
<BOS>Cancer may spread from where it began to other parts of the body.<EOS>
<BOS>The following stages are used for transitional cell cancer of the renal pelvis and/or ureter: Stage 0 (Papillary Carcinoma and Carcinoma in Situ) Stage I Stage II Stage III Stage IV Transitional cell cancer of the renal pelvis and ureter is also described as localized, regional, or metastatic: Localized Regional Metastatic After transitional cell cancer of the renal pelvis and ureter has been diagnosed, tests are done to find out if cancer cells have spread within the renal pelvis and ureter or to other parts of the body.<EOS>
<BOS>The process used to find out if cancer has spread within the renal pelvis and ureter or to other parts of the body is called staging.<EOS>
<BOS>The information gathered from the staging process determines the stage of the disease.<EOS>
<BOS>It is important to know the stage in order to plan treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>The following tests and procedures may be used in the staging process: CT scan (CAT scan): A procedure that makes a series of detailed pictures of areas inside the body, taken from different angles.<EOS>
<BOS>The pictures are made by a computer linked to an xray machine.<EOS>
<BOS>A dye may be injected into a vein or swallowed to help the organs or tissues show up more clearly.<EOS>
<BOS>This procedure is also called computed tomography, computerized tomography, or computerized axial tomography.<EOS>
<BOS>Ureteroscopy : A procedure to look inside the ureter and renal pelvis to check for abnormal areas.<EOS>
<BOS>A ureteroscope is a thin, tubelike instrument with a light and a lens for viewing.<EOS>
<BOS>The ureteroscope is inserted through the urethra into the bladder, ureter, and renal pelvis.<EOS>
<BOS>A tool may be inserted through the ureteroscope to take tissue samples to be checked under a microscope for signs of disease.<EOS>
<BOS>There are three ways that cancer spreads in the body.<EOS>
<BOS>Cancer can spread through tissue, the lymph system, and the blood: Tissue.<EOS>
<BOS>The cancer spreads from where it began by growing into nearby areas.<EOS>
<BOS>Lymph system.<EOS>
<BOS>The cancer spreads from where it began by getting into the lymph system.<EOS>
<BOS>The cancer travels through the lymph vessels to other parts of the body.<EOS>
<BOS>Blood.<EOS>
<BOS>The cancer spreads from where it began by getting into the blood.<EOS>
<BOS>The cancer travels through the blood vessels to other parts of the body.<EOS>
<BOS>Cancer may spread from where it began to other parts of the body.<EOS>
<BOS>When cancer spreads to another part of the body, it is called metastasis.<EOS>
<BOS>Cancer cells break away from where they began (the primary tumor) and travel through the lymph system or blood.<EOS>
<BOS>Lymph system.<EOS>
<BOS>The cancer gets into the lymph system, travels through the lymph vessels, and forms a tumor (metastatic tumor) in another part of the body.<EOS>
<BOS>Blood.<EOS>
<BOS>The cancer gets into the blood, travels through the blood vessels, and forms a tumor (metastatic tumor) in another part of the body.<EOS>
<BOS>The metastatic tumor is the same type of cancer as the primary tumor.<EOS>
<BOS>For example, if transitional cell cancer of the ureter spreads to the lung, the cancer cells in the lung are actually ureter cancer cells.<EOS>
<BOS>The disease is metastatic cancer of the ureter, not lung cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>The following stages are used for transitional cell cancer of the renal pelvis and/or ureter: Stage 0 (Papillary Carcinoma and Carcinoma in Situ) In stage 0, abnormal cells are found in tissue lining the inside of the renal pelvis or ureter.<EOS>
<BOS>These abnormal cells may become cancer and spread into nearby normal tissue.<EOS>
<BOS>Stage 0 is divided into stage 0a and stage 0is, depending on the type of tumor: Stage 0a may look like tiny mushrooms growing from the tissue lining the inside of the renal pelvis or ureter.<EOS>
<BOS>Stage 0a is also called noninvasive papillary carcinoma.<EOS>
<BOS>Stage 0is is a flat tumor on the tissue lining the inside of the renal pelvis or ureter.<EOS>
<BOS>Stage 0is is also called carcinoma in situ.<EOS>
<BOS>Stage I In stage I, cancer has formed and spread through the lining of the renal pelvis and/or ureter, into the layer of connective tissue.<EOS>
<BOS>Stage II In stage II, cancer has spread through the layer of connective tissue to the muscle layer of the renal pelvis and/or ureter.<EOS>
<BOS>Stage III In stage III, cancer has spread: From the renal pelvis to tissue or fat in the kidney; or From the ureter to fat that surrounds the ureter.<EOS>
<BOS>Stage IV In stage IV, cancer has spread to at least one of the following: A nearby organ.<EOS>
<BOS>The layer of fat surrounding the kidney.<EOS>
<BOS>One or more lymph nodes.<EOS>
<BOS>Distant parts of the body, such as the lung, liver, or bone.<EOS>
<BOS>Transitional cell cancer of the renal pelvis and ureter is also described as localized, regional, or metastatic: Localized The cancer is found only in the kidney.<EOS>
<BOS>Regional The cancer has spread to tissues around the kidney and to nearby lymph nodes and blood vessels in the pelvis.<EOS>
<BOS>Metastatic The cancer has spread to other parts of the body.<EOS>
<BOS>New types of treatment are being tested in clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>This summary section describes treatments that are being studied in clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>It may not mention every new treatment being studied.<EOS>
<BOS>Information about clinical trials is available from the NCI website.<EOS>
<BOS>Highdose chemotherapy with stem cell transplant Highdose chemotherapy with stem cell transplant is a method of giving high doses of chemotherapy and replacing blood forming cells destroyed by the cancer treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Stem cells (immature blood cells) are removed from the blood or bone marrow of the patient or a donor and are frozen and stored.<EOS>
<BOS>After the chemotherapy is completed, the stored stem cells are thawed and given back to the patient through an infusion.<EOS>
<BOS>These reinfused stem cells grow into (and restore) the body's blood cells.<EOS>
<BOS>Targeted therapy Targeted therapy is a type of treatment that uses drugs or other substances to attack cancer cells.<EOS>
<BOS>Targeted therapies usually cause less harm to normal cells than chemotherapy or radiation therapy do.<EOS>
<BOS>Monoclonal antibody therapy is one type of targeted therapy being studied in the treatment of primary CNS lymphoma.<EOS>
<BOS>Monoclonal antibody therapy is a cancer treatment that uses antibodies made in the laboratory from a single type of immune system cell.<EOS>
<BOS>These antibodies can identify substances on cancer cells or normal substances that may help cancer cells grow.<EOS>
<BOS>The antibodies attach to the substances and kill the cancer cells, block their growth, or keep them from spreading.<EOS>
<BOS>Monoclonal antibodies are given by infusion.<EOS>
<BOS>They may be used alone or to carry drugs, toxins, or radioactive material directly to cancer cells.<EOS>
<BOS>Rituximab is a type of monoclonal antibody used to treat newly diagnosed primary CNS lymphoma in patients who do not have AIDS.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients may want to think about taking part in a clinical trial.<EOS>
<BOS>For some patients, taking part in a clinical trial may be the best treatment choice.<EOS>
<BOS>Clinical trials are part of the cancer research process.<EOS>
<BOS>Clinical trials are done to find out if new cancer treatments are safe and effective or better than the standard treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Many of today's standard treatments for cancer are based on earlier clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients who take part in a clinical trial may receive the standard treatment or be among the first to receive a new treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients who take part in clinical trials also help improve the way cancer will be treated in the future.<EOS>
<BOS>Even when clinical trials do not lead to effective new treatments, they often answer important questions and help move research forward.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients can enter clinical trials before, during, or after starting their cancer treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Some clinical trials only include patients who have not yet received treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Other trials test treatments for patients whose cancer has not gotten better.<EOS>
<BOS>There are also clinical trials that test new ways to stop cancer from recurring (coming back) or reduce the side effects of cancer treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Clinical trials are taking place in many parts of the country.<EOS>
<BOS>See the Treatment Options section that follows for links to current treatment clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>These have been retrieved from NCI's listing of clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>Other screening tests are being studied in clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>Thermography Thermography is a procedure in which a special camera that senses heat is used to record the temperature of the skin that covers the breasts.<EOS>
<BOS>A computer makes a map of the breast showing the changes in temperature.<EOS>
<BOS>Tumors can cause temperature changes that may show up on the thermogram.<EOS>
<BOS>There have been no clinical trials of thermography to find out how well it detects breast cancer or if having the procedure decreases the risk of dying from breast cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Tissue sampling Breast tissue sampling is taking cells from breast tissue to check under a microscope.<EOS>
<BOS>Abnormal cells in breast fluid have been linked to an increased risk of breast cancer in some studies.<EOS>
<BOS>Scientists are studying whether breast tissue sampling can be used to find breast cancer at an early stage or predict the risk of developing breast cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Three ways of taking tissue samples are being studied: Fineneedle aspiration: A thin needle is inserted into the breast tissue around the areola (darkened area around the nipple) to take out a sample of cells and fluid.<EOS>
<BOS>Nipple aspiration: The use of gentle suction to collect fluid through the nipple.<EOS>
<BOS>This is done with a device similar to the breast pumps used by women who are breastfeeding.<EOS>
<BOS>Ductal lavage: A hairsize catheter (tube) is inserted into the nipple and a small amount of salt water is released into the duct.<EOS>
<BOS>The water picks up breast cells and is removed.<EOS>
<BOS>Screening clinical trials are taking place in many parts of the country.<EOS>
<BOS>Information about ongoing clinical trials is available from the NCI website.<EOS>
<BOS>Key Points Ovarian low malignant potential tumor is a disease in which abnormal cells form in the tissue covering the ovary.<EOS>
<BOS>Signs and symptoms of ovarian low malignant potential tumor include pain or swelling in the abdomen.<EOS>
<BOS>Tests that examine the ovaries are used to detect (find), diagnose, and stage ovarian low malignant potential tumor.<EOS>
<BOS>Certain factors affect prognosis (chance of recovery) and treatment options.<EOS>
<BOS>Ovarian low malignant potential tumor is a disease in which abnormal cells form in the tissue covering the ovary.<EOS>
<BOS>Ovarian low malignant potential tumors have abnormal cells that may become cancer, but usually do not.<EOS>
<BOS>This disease usually remains in the ovary.<EOS>
<BOS>When disease is found in one ovary, the other ovary should also be checked carefully for signs of disease.<EOS>
<BOS>The ovaries are a pair of organs in the female reproductive system.<EOS>
<BOS>They are in the pelvis, one on each side of the uterus (the hollow, pearshaped organ where a fetus grows).<EOS>
<BOS>Each ovary is about the size and shape of an almond.<EOS>
<BOS>The ovaries make eggs and female hormones.<EOS>
<BOS>Key Points Avoiding risk factors and increasing protective factors may help prevent cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>The following are risk factors for breast cancer: Older age A personal history of breast cancer or benign (noncancer) breast disease Inherited risk of breast cancer Dense breasts Exposure of breast tissue to estrogen made in the body Taking hormone therapy for symptoms of menopause Radiation therapy to the breast or chest Obesity Drinking alcohol The following are protective factors for breast cancer: Less exposure of breast tissue to estrogen made by the body Taking estrogenonly hormone therapy after hysterectomy, selective estrogen receptor modulators, or aromatase inhibitors and inactivators Estrogenonly hormone therapy after hysterectomy Selective estrogen receptor modulators Aromatase inhibitors and inactivators Riskreducing mastectomy Ovarian ablation Getting enough exercise It is not clear whether the following affect the risk of breast cancer: Oral contraceptives Environment Studies have shown that some factors do not affect the risk of breast cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Cancer prevention clinical trials are used to study ways to prevent cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>New ways to prevent breast cancer are being studied in clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>Avoiding risk factors and increasing protective factors may help prevent cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Avoiding cancer risk factors may help prevent certain cancers.<EOS>
<BOS>Risk factors include smoking, being overweight, and not getting enough exercise.<EOS>
<BOS>Increasing protective factors such as quitting smoking and exercising may also help prevent some cancers.<EOS>
<BOS>Talk to your doctor or other health care professional about how you might lower your risk of cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>NCI's Breast Cancer Risk Assessment Tool uses a woman's risk factors to estimate her risk for breast cancer during the next five years and up to age 90.<EOS>
<BOS>This online tool is meant to be used by a health care provider.<EOS>
<BOS>For more information on breast cancer risk, call 18004CANCER.<EOS>
<BOS>The following are risk factors for breast cancer: Older age Older age is the main risk factor for most cancers.<EOS>
<BOS>The chance of getting cancer increases as you get older.<EOS>
<BOS>A personal history of breast cancer or benign (noncancer) breast disease Women with any of the following have an increased risk of breast cancer: A personal history of invasive breast cancer, ductal carcinoma in situ (DCIS), or lobular carcinoma in situ (LCIS).<EOS>
<BOS>A personal history of benign (noncancer) breast disease.<EOS>
<BOS>Inherited risk of breast cancer Women with a family history of breast cancer in a firstdegree relative (mother, sister, or daughter) have an increased risk of breast cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Women who have inherited changes in the BRCA1 and BRCA2 genes or in certain other genes have a higher risk of breast cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>The risk of breast cancer caused by inherited gene changes depends on the type of gene mutation, family history of cancer, and other factors.<EOS>
<BOS>Dense breasts Having breast tissue that is dense on a mammogram is a factor in breast cancer risk.<EOS>
<BOS>The level of risk depends on how dense the breast tissue is.<EOS>
<BOS>Women with very dense breasts have a higher risk of breast cancer than women with low breast density.<EOS>
<BOS>Increased breast density is often an inherited trait, but it may also occur in women who have not had children, have a first pregnancy late in life, take postmenopausal hormones, or drink alcohol.<EOS>
<BOS>Exposure of breast tissue to estrogen made in the body Estrogen is a hormone made by the body.<EOS>
<BOS>It helps the body develop and maintain female sex characteristics.<EOS>
<BOS>Being exposed to estrogen over a long time may increase the risk of breast cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Estrogen levels are highest during the years a woman is menstruating.<EOS>
<BOS>A woman's exposure to estrogen is increased in the following ways: Early menstruation: Beginning to have menstrual periods at age 11 or younger increases the number of years the breast tissue is exposed to estrogen.<EOS>
<BOS>Starting menopause at a later age: The more years a woman menstruates, the longer her breast tissue is exposed to estrogen.<EOS>
<BOS>Older age at first birth or never having given birth: Because estrogen levels are lower during pregnancy, breast tissue is exposed to more estrogen in women who become pregnant for the first time after age 35 or who never become pregnant.<EOS>
<BOS>Taking hormone therapy for symptoms of menopause Hormones, such as estrogen and progesterone, can be made into a pill form in a laboratory.<EOS>
<BOS>Estrogen, progestin, or both may be given to replace the estrogen no longer made by the ovaries in postmenopausal women or women who have had their ovaries removed.<EOS>
<BOS>This is called hormone replacement therapy (HRT) or hormone therapy (HT).<EOS>
<BOS>Combination HRT/HT is estrogen combined with progestin.<EOS>
<BOS>This type of HRT/HT increases the risk of breast cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Studies show that when women stop taking estrogen combined with progestin, the risk of breast cancer decreases.<EOS>
<BOS>Radiation therapy to the breast or chest Radiation therapy to the chest for the treatment of cancer increases the risk of breast cancer, starting 10 years after treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>The risk of breast cancer depends on the dose of radiation and the age at which it is given.<EOS>
<BOS>The risk is highest if radiation treatment was used during puberty, when breasts are forming.<EOS>
<BOS>Radiation therapy to treat cancer in one breast does not appear to increase the risk of cancer in the other breast.<EOS>
<BOS>For women who have inherited changes in the BRCA1 and BRCA2 genes, exposure to radiation, such as that from chest xrays, may further increase the risk of breast cancer, especially in women who were xrayed before 20 years of age.<EOS>
<BOS>Obesity Obesity increases the risk of breast cancer, especially in postmenopausal women who have not used hormone replacement therapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Drinking alcohol Drinking alcohol increases the risk of breast cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>The level of risk rises as the amount of alcohol consumed rises.<EOS>
<BOS>The following are protective factors for breast cancer: Less exposure of breast tissue to estrogen made by the body Decreasing the length of time a woman's breast tissue is exposed to estrogen may help prevent breast cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Exposure to estrogen is reduced in the following ways: Early pregnancy: Estrogen levels are lower during pregnancy.<EOS>
<BOS>Women who have a fullterm pregnancy before age 20 have a lower risk of breast cancer than women who have not had children or who give birth to their first child after age 35.<EOS>
<BOS>Breastfeeding: Estrogen levels may remain lower while a woman is breastfeeding.<EOS>
<BOS>Women who breastfed have a lower risk of breast cancer than women who have had children but did not breastfeed.<EOS>
<BOS>Taking estrogenonly hormone therapy after hysterectomy, selective estrogen receptor modulators, or aromatase inhibitors and inactivators Estrogenonly hormone therapy after hysterectomy Hormone therapy with estrogen only may be given to women who have had a hysterectomy.<EOS>
<BOS>In these women, estrogenonly therapy after menopause may decrease the risk of breast cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>There is an increased risk of stroke and heart and blood vessel disease in postmenopausal women who take estrogen after a hysterectomy.<EOS>
<BOS>Selective estrogen receptor modulators Tamoxifen and raloxifene belong to the family of drugs called selective estrogen receptor modulators (SERMs).<EOS>
<BOS>SERMs act like estrogen on some tissues in the body, but block the effect of estrogen on other tissues.<EOS>
<BOS>Treatment with tamoxifen lowers the risk of estrogen receptorpositive (ERpositive) breast cancer and ductal carcinoma in situ in premenopausal and postmenopausal women at high risk.<EOS>
<BOS>Treatment with raloxifene also lowers the risk of breast cancer in postmenopausal women.<EOS>
<BOS>With either drug, the reduced risk lasts for several years or longer after treatment is stopped.<EOS>
<BOS>Lower rates of broken bones have been noted in patients taking raloxifene.<EOS>
<BOS>Taking tamoxifen increases the risk of hot flashes, endometrial cancer, stroke, cataracts, and blood clots (especially in the lungs and legs).<EOS>
<BOS>The risk of having these problems increases markedly in women older than 50 years compared with younger women.<EOS>
<BOS>Women younger than 50 years who have a high risk of breast cancer may benefit the most from taking tamoxifen.<EOS>
<BOS>The risk of having these problems decreases after tamoxifen is stopped.<EOS>
<BOS>Talk with your doctor about the risks and benefits of taking this drug.<EOS>
<BOS>Taking raloxifene increases the risk of blood clots in the lungs and legs, but does not appear to increase the risk of endometrial cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>In postmenopausal women with osteoporosis (decreased bone density), raloxifene lowers the risk of breast cancer for women who have a high or low risk of breast cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>It is not known if raloxifene would have the same effect in women who do not have osteoporosis.<EOS>
<BOS>Talk with your doctor about the risks and benefits of taking this drug.<EOS>
<BOS>Other SERMs are being studied in clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>Aromatase inhibitors and inactivators Aromatase inhibitors (anastrozole, letrozole) and inactivators (exemestane) lower the risk of recurrence and of new breast cancers in women who have a history of breast cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Aromatase inhibitors also decrease the risk of breast cancer in women with the following conditions: Postmenopausal women with a personal history of breast cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Women with no personal history of breast cancer who are 60 years and older, have a history of ductal carcinoma in situ with mastectomy, or have a high risk of breast cancer based on the Gail model tool (a tool used to estimate the risk of breast cancer).<EOS>
<BOS>In women with an increased risk of breast cancer, taking aromatase inhibitors decreases the amount of estrogen made by the body.<EOS>
<BOS>Before menopause, estrogen is made by the ovaries and other tissues in a woman's body, including the brain, fat tissue, and skin.<EOS>
<BOS>After menopause, the ovaries stop making estrogen, but the other tissues do not.<EOS>
<BOS>Aromatase inhibitors block the action of an enzyme called aromatase, which is used to make all of the body's estrogen.<EOS>
<BOS>Aromatase inactivators stop the enzyme from working.<EOS>
<BOS>Possible harms from taking aromatase inhibitors include muscle and joint pain, osteoporosis, hot flashes, and feeling very tired.<EOS>
<BOS>Riskreducing mastectomy Some women who have a high risk of breast cancer may choose to have a riskreducing mastectomy (the removal of both breasts when there are no signs of cancer).<EOS>
<BOS>The risk of breast cancer is much lower in these women and most feel less anxious about their risk of breast cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>However, it is very important to have a cancer risk assessment and counseling about the different ways to prevent breast cancer before making this decision.<EOS>
<BOS>Ovarian ablation The ovaries make most of the estrogen that is made by the body.<EOS>
<BOS>Treatments that stop or lower the amount of estrogen made by the ovaries include surgery to remove the ovaries, radiation therapy, or taking certain drugs.<EOS>
<BOS>This is called ovarian ablation.<EOS>
<BOS>Premenopausal women who have a high risk of breast cancer due to certain changes in the BRCA1 and BRCA2 genes may choose to have a riskreducing oophorectomy (the removal of both ovaries when there are no signs of cancer).<EOS>
<BOS>This decreases the amount of estrogen made by the body and lowers the risk of breast cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Riskreducing oophorectomy also lowers the risk of breast cancer in normal premenopausal women and in women with an increased risk of breast cancer due to radiation to the chest.<EOS>
<BOS>However, it is very important to have a cancer risk assessment and counseling before making this decision.<EOS>
<BOS>The sudden drop in estrogen levels may cause the symptoms of menopause to begin.<EOS>
<BOS>These include hot flashes, trouble sleeping, anxiety, and depression.<EOS>
<BOS>Longterm effects include decreased sex drive, vaginal dryness, and decreased bone density.<EOS>
<BOS>Getting enough exercise Women who exercise four or more hours a week have a lower risk of breast cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>The effect of exercise on breast cancer risk may be greatest in premenopausal women who have normal or low body weight.<EOS>
<BOS>It is not clear whether the following affect the risk of breast cancer: Oral contraceptives Certain oral contraceptives contain estrogen.<EOS>
<BOS>Some studies have shown that taking oral contraceptives ("the pill") may slightly increase the risk of breast cancer in current users.<EOS>
<BOS>This risk decreases over time.<EOS>
<BOS>Other studies have not shown an increased risk of breast cancer in women who take oral contraceptives.<EOS>
<BOS>Progestin only contraceptives that are injected or implanted do not appear to increase the risk of breast cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>More studies are needed to know whether progestinonly oral contraceptives increase the risk of breast cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Environment Studies have not proven that being exposed to certain substances in the environment, such as chemicals, increases the risk of breast cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Studies have shown that some factors do not affect the risk of breast cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>The following do not affect the risk of breast cancer: Having an abortion.<EOS>
<BOS>Making diet changes such as eating less fat or more fruits and vegetables.<EOS>
<BOS>Taking vitamins, including fenretinide (a type of vitamin A).<EOS>
<BOS>Cigarette smoking, both active and passive (inhaling secondhand smoke).<EOS>
<BOS>Using underarm deodorant or antiperspirant.<EOS>
<BOS>Taking statins (cholesterol lowering drugs).<EOS>
<BOS>Taking bisphosphonates (drugs used to treat osteoporosis and hypercalcemia) by mouth or by intravenous infusion.<EOS>
<BOS>Key Points Once childhood acute myeloid leukemia (AML) has been diagnosed, tests are done to find out if the cancer has spread to other parts of the body.<EOS>
<BOS>There is no standard staging system for childhood AML, childhood chronic myelogenous leukemia (CML), juvenile myelomonocytic leukemia (JMML), or myelodysplastic syndromes (MDS).<EOS>
<BOS>Once childhood acute myeloid leukemia (AML) has been diagnosed, tests are done to find out if the cancer has spread to other parts of the body.<EOS>
<BOS>The following tests and procedures may be used to determine if the leukemia has spread: Lumbar puncture : A procedure used to collect a sample of cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) from the spinal column.<EOS>
<BOS>This is done by placing a needle between two bones in the spine and into the CSF around the spinal cord and removing a sample of the fluid.<EOS>
<BOS>The sample of CSF is checked under a microscope for signs that leukemia cells have spread to the brain and spinal cord.<EOS>
<BOS>This procedure is also called an LP or spinal tap.<EOS>
<BOS>Biopsy of the testicles, ovaries, or skin: The removal of cells or tissues from the testicles, ovaries, or skin so they can be viewed under a microscope to check for signs of cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>This is done only if something unusual about the testicles, ovaries, or skin is found during the physical exam.<EOS>
<BOS>There is no standard staging system for childhood AML, childhood chronic myelogenous leukemia (CML), juvenile myelomonocytic leukemia (JMML), or myelodysplastic syndromes (MDS).<EOS>
<BOS>The extent or spread of cancer is usually described as stages.<EOS>
<BOS>Instead of stages, treatment of childhood AML, childhood CML, JMML, and MDS is based on one or more of the following: The type of disease or the subtype of AML.<EOS>
<BOS>Whether leukemia has spread outside the blood and bone marrow.<EOS>
<BOS>Whether the disease is newly diagnosed, in remission, or recurrent.<EOS>
<BOS>Newly diagnosed childhood AML Newly diagnosed childhood AML has not been treated except to relieve signs and symptoms such as fever, bleeding, or pain, and one of the following is true: More than 20% of the cells in the bone marrow are blasts (leukemia cells).<EOS>
<BOS>or Less than 20% of the cells in the bone marrow are blasts and there is a specific change in the chromosome.<EOS>
<BOS>Childhood AML in remission In childhood AML in remission, the disease has been treated and the following are true: The complete blood count is almost normal.<EOS>
<BOS>Less than 5% of the cells in the bone marrow are blasts (leukemia cells).<EOS>
<BOS>There are no signs or symptoms of leukemia in the brain, spinal cord, or other parts of the body.<EOS>
<BOS>Key Points There are different types of treatment for patients with gastrointestinal carcinoid tumors.<EOS>
<BOS>Four types of standard treatment are used: Surgery Radiation therapy Chemotherapy Hormone therapy Treatment for carcinoid syndrome may also be needed.<EOS>
<BOS>New types of treatment are being tested in clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>Targeted therapy Patients may want to think about taking part in a clinical trial.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients can enter clinical trials before, during, or after starting their cancer treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Followup tests may be needed.<EOS>
<BOS>There are different types of treatment for patients with gastrointestinal carcinoid tumors.<EOS>
<BOS>Different types of treatment are available for patients with gastrointestinal carcinoid tumor.<EOS>
<BOS>Some treatments are standard (the currently used treatment), and some are being tested in clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>A treatment clinical trial is a research study meant to help improve current treatments or obtain information on new treatments for patients with cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>When clinical trials show that a new treatment is better than the standard treatment, the new treatment may become the standard treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients may want to think about taking part in a clinical trial.<EOS>
<BOS>Some clinical trials are open only to patients who have not started treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Four types of standard treatment are used: Surgery Treatment of GI carcinoid tumors usually includes surgery.<EOS>
<BOS>One of the following surgical procedures may be used: Endoscopic resection: Surgery to remove a small tumor that is on the inside lining of the GI tract.<EOS>
<BOS>An endoscope is inserted through the mouth and passed through the esophagus to the stomach and sometimes, the duodenum.<EOS>
<BOS>An endoscope is a thin, tubelike instrument with a light, a lens for viewing, and a tool for removing tumor tissue.<EOS>
<BOS>Local excision: Surgery to remove the tumor and a small amount of normal tissue around it.<EOS>
<BOS>Resection: Surgery to remove part or all of the organ that contains cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Nearby lymph nodes may also be removed.<EOS>
<BOS>Cryosurgery: A treatment that uses an instrument to freeze and destroy carcinoid tumor tissue.<EOS>
<BOS>This type of treatment is also called cryotherapy.<EOS>
<BOS>The doctor may use ultrasound to guide the instrument.<EOS>
<BOS>Radiofrequency ablation: The use of a special probe with tiny electrodes that release highenergy radio waves (similar to microwaves) that kill cancer cells.<EOS>
<BOS>The probe may be inserted through the skin or through an incision (cut) in the abdomen.<EOS>
<BOS>Liver transplant: Surgery to remove the whole liver and replace it with a healthy donated liver.<EOS>
<BOS>Hepatic artery embolization: A procedure to embolize (block) the hepatic artery, which is the main blood vessel that brings blood into the liver.<EOS>
<BOS>Blocking the flow of blood to the liver helps kill cancer cells growing there.<EOS>
<BOS>Radiation therapy Radiation therapy is a cancer treatment that uses highenergy xrays or other types of radiation to kill cancer cells or keep them from growing.<EOS>
<BOS>There are two types of radiation therapy: External radiation therapy uses a machine outside the body to send radiation toward the cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Internal radiation therapy uses a radioactive substance sealed in needles, seeds, wires, or catheters that are placed directly into or near the cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Radiopharmaceutical therapy is a type of internal radiation therapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Radiation is given to the tumor using a drug that has a radioactive substance, such as iodine I 131, attached to it.<EOS>
<BOS>The radioactive substance kills the tumor cells.<EOS>
<BOS>External and internal radiation therapy are used to treat gastrointestinal carcinoid tumors that have spread to other parts of the body.<EOS>
<BOS>Chemotherapy Chemotherapy is a cancer treatment that uses drugs to stop the growth of cancer cells, either by killing the cells or by stopping the cells from dividing.<EOS>
<BOS>When chemotherapy is taken by mouth or injected into a vein or muscle, the drugs enter the bloodstream and can reach cancer cells throughout the body (systemic chemotherapy).<EOS>
<BOS>When chemotherapy is placed directly into the cerebrospinal fluid, an organ, or a body cavity such as the abdomen, the drugs mainly affect cancer cells in those areas (regional chemotherapy).<EOS>
<BOS>Chemoembolization of the hepatic artery is a type of regional chemotherapy that may be used to treat a gastrointestinal carcinoid tumor that has spread to the liver.<EOS>
<BOS>The anticancer drug is injected into the hepatic artery through a catheter (thin tube).<EOS>
<BOS>The drug is mixed with a substance that embolizes (blocks) the artery, and cuts off blood flow to the tumor.<EOS>
<BOS>Most of the anticancer drug is trapped near the tumor and only a small amount of the drug reaches other parts of the body.<EOS>
<BOS>The blockage may be temporary or permanent, depending on the substance used to block the artery.<EOS>
<BOS>The tumor is prevented from getting the oxygen and nutrients it needs to grow.<EOS>
<BOS>The liver continues to receive blood from the hepatic portal vein, which carries blood from the stomach and intestine.<EOS>
<BOS>The way the chemotherapy is given depends on the type and stage of the cancer being treated.<EOS>
<BOS>Hormone therapy Hormone therapy with a somatostatin analogue is a treatment that stops extra hormones from being made.<EOS>
<BOS>GI carcinoid tumors are treated with octreotide or lanreotide which are injected under the skin or into the muscle.<EOS>
<BOS>Octreotide and lanreotide may also have a small effect on stopping tumor growth.<EOS>
<BOS>Treatment for carcinoid syndrome may also be needed.<EOS>
<BOS>Treatment of carcinoid syndrome may include the following: Hormone therapy with a somatostatin analogue stops extra hormones from being made.<EOS>
<BOS>Carcinoid syndrome is treated with octreotide or lanreotide to lessen flushing and diarrhea.<EOS>
<BOS>Octreotide and lanreotide may also help slow tumor growth.<EOS>
<BOS>Interferon therapy stimulates the bodys immune system to work better and lessens flushing and diarrhea.<EOS>
<BOS>Interferon may also help slow tumor growth.<EOS>
<BOS>Taking medicine for diarrhea.<EOS>
<BOS>Taking medicine for skin rashes.<EOS>
<BOS>Taking medicine to breathe easier.<EOS>
<BOS>Taking medicine before having anesthesia for a medical procedure.<EOS>
<BOS>Other ways to help treat carcinoid syndrome include avoiding things that cause flushing or difficulty breathing such as alcohol, nuts, certain cheeses and foods with capsaicin, such as chili peppers.<EOS>
<BOS>Avoiding stressful situations and certain types of physical activity can also help treat carcinoid syndrome.<EOS>
<BOS>For some patients with carcinoid heart syndrome, a heart valve replacement may be done.<EOS>
<BOS>New types of treatment are being tested in clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>This summary section describes treatments that are being studied in clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>It may not mention every new treatment being studied.<EOS>
<BOS>Information about clinical trials is available from the NCI website.<EOS>
<BOS>Targeted therapy Targeted therapy is a type of treatment that uses drugs or other substances to identify and attack specific cancer cells without harming normal cells.<EOS>
<BOS>Several types of targeted therapy are being studied in the treatment of GI carcinoid tumors.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients may want to think about taking part in a clinical trial.<EOS>
<BOS>For some patients, taking part in a clinical trial may be the best treatment choice.<EOS>
<BOS>Clinical trials are part of the cancer research process.<EOS>
<BOS>Clinical trials are done to find out if new cancer treatments are safe and effective or better than the standard treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Many of today's standard treatments for cancer are based on earlier clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients who take part in a clinical trial may receive the standard treatment or be among the first to receive a new treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients who take part in clinical trials also help improve the way cancer will be treated in the future.<EOS>
<BOS>Even when clinical trials do not lead to effective new treatments, they often answer important questions and help move research forward.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients can enter clinical trials before, during, or after starting their cancer treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Some clinical trials only include patients who have not yet received treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Other trials test treatments for patients whose cancer has not gotten better.<EOS>
<BOS>There are also clinical trials that test new ways to stop cancer from recurring (coming back) or reduce the side effects of cancer treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Clinical trials are taking place in many parts of the country.<EOS>
<BOS>See the Treatment Options section that follows for links to current treatment clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>These have been retrieved from NCI's listing of clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>Followup tests may be needed.<EOS>
<BOS>Some of the tests that were done to diagnose the cancer or to find out the stage of the cancer may be repeated.<EOS>
<BOS>Some tests will be repeated in order to see how well the treatment is working.<EOS>
<BOS>Decisions about whether to continue, change, or stop treatment may be based on the results of these tests.<EOS>
<BOS>Some of the tests will continue to be done from time to time after treatment has ended.<EOS>
<BOS>The results of these tests can show if your condition has changed or if the cancer has recurred (come back).<EOS>
<BOS>These tests are sometimes called followup tests or checkups.<EOS>
<BOS>Treatment Options for Gastrointestinal Carcinoid Tumors Carcinoid Tumors in the Stomach Treatment of gastrointestinal (GI) carcinoid tumors in the stomach may include the following: Endoscopic surgery (resection) for small tumors.<EOS>
<BOS>Surgery (resection) to remove part or all of the stomach.<EOS>
<BOS>Nearby lymph nodes for larger tumors, tumors that grow deep into the stomach wall, or tumors that are growing and spreading quickly may also be removed.<EOS>
<BOS>For patients with GI carcinoid tumors in the stomach and MEN1 syndrome, treatment may also include: Surgery (resection) to remove tumors in the duodenum (first part of the small intestine, that connects to the stomach).<EOS>
<BOS>Hormone therapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Check the list of NCIsupported cancer clinical trials that are now accepting patients with localized gastrointestinal carcinoid tumor and regional gastrointestinal carcinoid tumor.<EOS>
<BOS>For more specific results, refine the search by using other search features, such as the location of the trial, the type of treatment, or the name of the drug.<EOS>
<BOS>Talk with your doctor about clinical trials that may be right for you.<EOS>
<BOS>General information about clinical trials is available from the NCI website.<EOS>
<BOS>Carcinoid Tumors in the Small Intestine It is not clear what the best treatment is for GI carcinoid tumors in the duodenum (first part of the small intestine, that connects to the stomach).<EOS>
<BOS>Treatment may include the following: Endoscopic surgery (resection) for small tumors.<EOS>
<BOS>Surgery (local excision) to remove slightly larger tumors.<EOS>
<BOS>Surgery (resection) to remove the tumor and nearby lymph nodes.<EOS>
<BOS>Treatment of GI carcinoid tumors in the jejunum (middle part of the small intestine) and ileum (last part of the small intestine, that connects to the colon) may include the following: Surgery (resection) to remove the tumor and the membrane that connects the intestines to the back of the abdominal wall.<EOS>
<BOS>Nearby lymph nodes are also removed.<EOS>
<BOS>A second surgery to remove the membrane that connects the intestines to the back of the abdominal wall, if any tumor remains or the tumor continues to grow.<EOS>
<BOS>Hormone therapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Check the list of NCIsupported cancer clinical trials that are now accepting patients with localized gastrointestinal carcinoid tumor and regional gastrointestinal carcinoid tumor.<EOS>
<BOS>For more specific results, refine the search by using other search features, such as the location of the trial, the type of treatment, or the name of the drug.<EOS>
<BOS>Talk with your doctor about clinical trials that may be right for you.<EOS>
<BOS>General information about clinical trials is available from the NCI website.<EOS>
<BOS>Carcinoid Tumors in the Appendix Treatment of GI carcinoid tumors in the appendix may include the following: Surgery (resection) to remove the appendix.<EOS>
<BOS>Surgery (resection) to remove the right side of the colon including the appendix.<EOS>
<BOS>Nearby lymph nodes are also removed.<EOS>
<BOS>Check the list of NCIsupported cancer clinical trials that are now accepting patients with localized gastrointestinal carcinoid tumor and regional gastrointestinal carcinoid tumor.<EOS>
<BOS>For more specific results, refine the search by using other search features, such as the location of the trial, the type of treatment, or the name of the drug.<EOS>
<BOS>Talk with your doctor about clinical trials that may be right for you.<EOS>
<BOS>General information about clinical trials is available from the NCI website.<EOS>
<BOS>Carcinoid Tumors in the Colon Treatment of GI carcinoid tumors in the colon may include the following: Surgery (resection) to remove part of the colon and nearby lymph nodes, in order to remove as much of the cancer as possible.<EOS>
<BOS>Check the list of NCIsupported cancer clinical trials that are now accepting patients with localized gastrointestinal carcinoid tumor and regional gastrointestinal carcinoid tumor.<EOS>
<BOS>For more specific results, refine the search by using other search features, such as the location of the trial, the type of treatment, or the name of the drug.<EOS>
<BOS>Talk with your doctor about clinical trials that may be right for you.<EOS>
<BOS>General information about clinical trials is available from the NCI website.<EOS>
<BOS>Carcinoid Tumors in the Rectum Treatment of GI carcinoid tumors in the rectum may include the following: Endoscopic surgery (resection) for tumors that are smaller than 1 centimeter.<EOS>
<BOS>Surgery (resection) for tumors that are larger than 2 centimeters or that have spread to the muscle layer of the rectal wall.<EOS>
<BOS>This may be either: surgery to remove part of the rectum; or surgery to remove the anus, the rectum, and part of the colon through an incision made in the abdomen.<EOS>
<BOS>It is not clear what the best treatment is for tumors that are 1 to 2 centimeters.<EOS>
<BOS>Treatment may include the following: Endoscopic surgery (resection).<EOS>
<BOS>Surgery (resection) to remove part of the rectum.<EOS>
<BOS>Surgery (resection) to remove the anus, the rectum, and part of the colon through an incision made in the abdomen.<EOS>
<BOS>Check the list of NCIsupported cancer clinical trials that are now accepting patients with localized gastrointestinal carcinoid tumor and regional gastrointestinal carcinoid tumor.<EOS>
<BOS>For more specific results, refine the search by using other search features, such as the location of the trial, the type of treatment, or the name of the drug.<EOS>
<BOS>Talk with your doctor about clinical trials that may be right for you.<EOS>
<BOS>General information about clinical trials is available from the NCI website.<EOS>
<BOS>Metastatic Gastrointestinal Carcinoid Tumors Distant metastases Treatment of distant metastases of GI carcinoid tumors is usually palliative therapy to relieve symptoms and improve quality of life.<EOS>
<BOS>Treatment may include the following: Surgery (resection) to remove as much of the tumor as possible.<EOS>
<BOS>Hormone therapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Radiopharmaceutical therapy.<EOS>
<BOS>External radiation therapy for cancer that has spread to the bone, brain, or spinal cord.<EOS>
<BOS>A clinical trial of a new treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Liver metastases Treatment of cancer that has spread to the liver may include the following: Surgery (local excision) to remove the tumor from the liver.<EOS>
<BOS>Hepatic artery embolization.<EOS>
<BOS>Cryosurgery.<EOS>
<BOS>Radiofrequency ablation.<EOS>
<BOS>Liver transplant.<EOS>
<BOS>Check the list of NCIsupported cancer clinical trials that are now accepting patients with metastatic gastrointestinal carcinoid tumor.<EOS>
<BOS>For more specific results, refine the search by using other search features, such as the location of the trial, the type of treatment, or the name of the drug.<EOS>
<BOS>Talk with your doctor about clinical trials that may be right for you.<EOS>
<BOS>General information about clinical trials is available from the NCI website.<EOS>
<BOS>Recurrent Gastrointestinal Carcinoid Tumors Treatment of recurrent GI carcinoid tumors may include the following: Surgery (local excision) to remove part or all of the tumor.<EOS>
<BOS>A clinical trial of a new treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Check the list of NCIsupported cancer clinical trials that are now accepting patients with recurrent gastrointestinal carcinoid tumor.<EOS>
<BOS>For more specific results, refine the search by using other search features, such as the location of the trial, the type of treatment, or the name of the drug.<EOS>
<BOS>Talk with your doctor about clinical trials that may be right for you.<EOS>
<BOS>General information about clinical trials is available from the NCI website.<EOS>
<BOS>New types of treatment are being tested in clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>Information about clinical trials is available from the NCI website.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients may want to think about taking part in a clinical trial.<EOS>
<BOS>For some patients, taking part in a clinical trial may be the best treatment choice.<EOS>
<BOS>Clinical trials are part of the cancer research process.<EOS>
<BOS>Clinical trials are done to find out if new cancer treatments are safe and effective or better than the standard treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Many of today's standard treatments for cancer are based on earlier clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients who take part in a clinical trial may receive the standard treatment or be among the first to receive a new treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients who take part in clinical trials also help improve the way cancer will be treated in the future.<EOS>
<BOS>Even when clinical trials do not lead to effective new treatments, they often answer important questions and help move research forward.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients can enter clinical trials before, during, or after starting their cancer treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Some clinical trials only include patients who have not yet received treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Other trials test treatments for patients whose cancer has not gotten better.<EOS>
<BOS>There are also clinical trials that test new ways to stop cancer from recurring (coming back) or reduce the side effects of cancer treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Clinical trials are taking place in many parts of the country.<EOS>
<BOS>See the Treatment Options section that follows for links to current treatment clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>These have been retrieved from NCI's listing of clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>Tests that examine the skin are used to detect (find) and diagnose melanoma.<EOS>
<BOS>If a mole or pigmented area of the skin changes or looks abnormal, the following tests and procedures can help find and diagnose melanoma: Skin exam: A doctor or nurse checks the skin for moles, birthmarks, or other pigmented areas that look abnormal in color, size, shape, or texture.<EOS>
<BOS>Biopsy : A procedure to remove the abnormal tissue and a small amount of normal tissue around it.<EOS>
<BOS>A pathologist looks at the tissue under a microscope to check for cancer cells.<EOS>
<BOS>It can be hard to tell the difference between a colored mole and an early melanoma lesion.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients may want to have the sample of tissue checked by a second pathologist.<EOS>
<BOS>If the abnormal mole or lesion is cancer, the sample of tissue may also be tested for certain gene changes.<EOS>
<BOS>It is important that abnormal areas of the skin not be shaved off or cauterized (destroyed with a hot instrument, an electric current, or a caustic substance) because cancer cells that remain may grow and spread.<EOS>
<BOS>See the PDQ summary on Skin Cancer Screening for more information.<EOS>
<BOS>Key Points Osteosarcoma and malignant fibrous histiocytoma (MFH) of the bone are diseases in which malignant (cancer) cells form in bone.<EOS>
<BOS>Having past treatment with radiation can increase the risk of osteosarcoma.<EOS>
<BOS>Signs and symptoms of osteosarcoma and MFH include swelling over a bone or a bony part of the body and joint pain.<EOS>
<BOS>Imaging tests are used to detect (find) osteosarcoma and MFH.<EOS>
<BOS>A biopsy is done to diagnose osteosarcoma.<EOS>
<BOS>Certain factors affect prognosis (chance of recovery) and treatment options.<EOS>
<BOS>Osteosarcoma and malignant fibrous histiocytoma (MFH) of the bone are diseases in which malignant (cancer) cells form in bone.<EOS>
<BOS>Osteosarcoma usually starts in osteoblasts, which are a type of bone cell that becomes new bone tissue.<EOS>
<BOS>Osteosarcoma is most common in adolescents.<EOS>
<BOS>It commonly forms in the ends of the long bones of the body, which include bones of the arms and legs.<EOS>
<BOS>In children and adolescents, it often forms in the bones near the knee.<EOS>
<BOS>Rarely, osteosarcoma may be found in soft tissue or organs in the chest or abdomen.<EOS>
<BOS>Osteosarcoma is the most common type of bone cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Malignant fibrous histiocytoma (MFH) of bone is a rare tumor of the bone.<EOS>
<BOS>It is treated like osteosarcoma.<EOS>
<BOS>Ewing sarcoma is another kind of bone cancer, but it is not covered in this summary.<EOS>
<BOS>See the PDQ summary about Ewing Sarcoma Treatment for more information.<EOS>
<BOS>Treatment of primary myelofibrosis in patients without signs or symptoms is usually watchful waiting.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients with primary myelofibrosis may have signs or symptoms of anemia.<EOS>
<BOS>Anemia is usually treated with transfusion of red blood cells to relieve symptoms and improve quality of life.<EOS>
<BOS>In addition, anemia may be treated with: Erythropoietic growth factors.<EOS>
<BOS>Prednisone.<EOS>
<BOS>Danazol.<EOS>
<BOS>Thalidomide, lenalidomide, or pomalidomide, with or without prednisone.<EOS>
<BOS>Treatment of primary myelofibrosis in patients with other signs or symptoms may include the following: Targeted therapy with ruxolitinib.<EOS>
<BOS>Chemotherapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Donor stem cell transplant.<EOS>
<BOS>Thalidomide, lenalidomide, or pomalidomide.<EOS>
<BOS>Splenectomy.<EOS>
<BOS>Radiation therapy to the spleen, lymph nodes, or other areas outside the bone marrow where blood cells are forming.<EOS>
<BOS>Biologic therapy using interferon alfa or erythropoietic growth factors.<EOS>
<BOS>A clinical trial of other targeted therapy drugs.<EOS>
<BOS>Check the list of NCIsupported cancer clinical trials that are now accepting patients with primary myelofibrosis.<EOS>
<BOS>For more specific results, refine the search by using other search features, such as the location of the trial, the type of treatment, or the name of the drug.<EOS>
<BOS>Talk with your doctor about clinical trials that may be right for you.<EOS>
<BOS>General information about clinical trials is available from the NCI website.<EOS>
<BOS>The cause of most childhood brain tumors is unknown.<EOS>
<BOS>Signs of prostate cancer include a weak flow of urine or frequent urination.<EOS>
<BOS>These and other signs and symptoms may be caused by prostate cancer or by other conditions.<EOS>
<BOS>Check with your doctor if you have any of the following: Weak or interrupted ("stopandgo") flow of urine.<EOS>
<BOS>Sudden urge to urinate.<EOS>
<BOS>Frequent urination (especially at night).<EOS>
<BOS>Trouble starting the flow of urine.<EOS>
<BOS>Trouble emptying the bladder completely.<EOS>
<BOS>Pain or burning while urinating.<EOS>
<BOS>Blood in the urine or semen.<EOS>
<BOS>A pain in the back, hips, or pelvis that doesn't go away.<EOS>
<BOS>Shortness of breath, feeling very tired, fast heartbeat, dizziness, or pale skin caused by anemia.<EOS>
<BOS>Other conditions may cause the same symptoms.<EOS>
<BOS>As men age, the prostate may get bigger and block the urethra or bladder.<EOS>
<BOS>This may cause trouble urinating or sexual problems.<EOS>
<BOS>The condition is called benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH), and although it is not cancer, surgery may be needed.<EOS>
<BOS>The symptoms of benign prostatic hyperplasia or of other problems in the prostate may be like symptoms of prostate cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Certain factors affect prognosis (chance of recovery) and treatment options.<EOS>
<BOS>The prognosis (chance of recovery) and treatment options depend on the following: The stage of the cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>The size of the tumor.<EOS>
<BOS>Whether there are B symptoms at diagnosis.<EOS>
<BOS>The type of Hodgkin lymphoma.<EOS>
<BOS>Certain features of the cancer cells.<EOS>
<BOS>Whether there are too many white blood cells or too few red blood cells at the time of diagnosis.<EOS>
<BOS>How well the tumor responds to initial treatment with chemotherapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Whether the cancer is newly diagnosed or has recurred (come back).<EOS>
<BOS>The treatment options also depend on: The child's age and gender.<EOS>
<BOS>The risk of longterm side effects.<EOS>
<BOS>Most children and adolescents with newly diagnosed Hodgkin lymphoma can be cured.<EOS>
<BOS>Key Points Lung cancer is a disease in which malignant (cancer) cells form in the tissues of the lung.<EOS>
<BOS>Lung cancer is the leading cause of cancer death in the United States.<EOS>
<BOS>Different factors increase or decrease the risk of lung cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Lung cancer is a disease in which malignant (cancer) cells form in the tissues of the lung.<EOS>
<BOS>The lungs are a pair of coneshaped breathing organs inside the chest.<EOS>
<BOS>The lungs bring oxygen into the body when breathing in and send carbon dioxide out of the body when breathing out.<EOS>
<BOS>Each lung has sections called lobes.<EOS>
<BOS>The left lung has two lobes.<EOS>
<BOS>The right lung, which is slightly larger, has three.<EOS>
<BOS>A thin membrane called the pleura surrounds the lungs.<EOS>
<BOS>Two tubes called bronchi lead from the trachea (windpipe) to the right and left lungs.<EOS>
<BOS>The bronchi are sometimes involved in lung cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Small tubes called bronchioles and tiny air sacs called alveoli make up the inside of the lungs.<EOS>
<BOS>There are two types of lung cancer: small cell lung cancer and nonsmall cell lung cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>See the following PDQ summaries for more information about lung cancer: Lung Cancer Prevention NonSmall Cell Lung Cancer Treatment Small Cell Lung Cancer Treatment Lung cancer is the leading cause of cancer death in the United States.<EOS>
<BOS>Lung cancer is the third most common type of nonskin cancer in the United States.<EOS>
<BOS>Lung cancer is the leading cause of cancer death in men and in women.<EOS>
<BOS>Key Points Small cell lung cancer is a disease in which malignant (cancer) cells form in the tissues of the lung.<EOS>
<BOS>There are two main types of small cell lung cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Smoking is the major risk factor for small cell lung cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Signs and symptoms of small cell lung cancer include coughing, shortness of breath, and chest pain.<EOS>
<BOS>Tests and procedures that examine the lungs are used to detect (find), diagnose, and stage small cell lung cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Certain factors affect prognosis (chance of recovery) and treatment options.<EOS>
<BOS>For most patients with small cell lung cancer, current treatments do not cure the cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Small cell lung cancer is a disease in which malignant (cancer) cells form in the tissues of the lung.<EOS>
<BOS>The lungs are a pair of coneshaped breathing organs that are found in the chest.<EOS>
<BOS>The lungs bring oxygen into the body when you breathe in and take out carbon dioxide when you breathe out.<EOS>
<BOS>Each lung has sections called lobes.<EOS>
<BOS>The left lung has two lobes.<EOS>
<BOS>The right lung, which is slightly larger, has three.<EOS>
<BOS>A thin membrane called the pleura surrounds the lungs.<EOS>
<BOS>Two tubes called bronchi lead from the trachea (windpipe) to the right and left lungs.<EOS>
<BOS>The bronchi are sometimes also affected by lung cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Small tubes called bronchioles and tiny air sacs called alveoli make up the inside of the lungs.<EOS>
<BOS>There are two types of lung cancer: small cell lung cancer and nonsmall cell lung cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>This summary is about small cell lung cancer and its treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>See the following PDQ summaries for more information about lung cancer: NonSmall Cell Lung Cancer Treatment Unusual Cancers of Childhood Treatment Lung Cancer Prevention Lung Cancer Screening There are two main types of small cell lung cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>These two types include many different types of cells.<EOS>
<BOS>The cancer cells of each type grow and spread in different ways.<EOS>
<BOS>The types of small cell lung cancer are named for the kinds of cells found in the cancer and how the cells look when viewed under a microscope: Small cell carcinoma (oat cell cancer).<EOS>
<BOS>Combined small cell carcinoma.<EOS>
<BOS>For most patients with small cell lung cancer, current treatments do not cure the cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>If lung cancer is found, patients should think about taking part in one of the many clinical trials being done to improve treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Clinical trials are taking place in most parts of the country for patients with all stages of small cell lung cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Information about ongoing clinical trials is available from the NCI website.<EOS>
<BOS>Key Points Childhood Hodgkin lymphoma is a disease in which malignant (cancer) cells form in the lymph system.<EOS>
<BOS>There are two types of childhood Hodgkin lymphoma.<EOS>
<BOS>EpsteinBarr virus infection increases the risk of childhood Hodgkin lymphoma.<EOS>
<BOS>Signs of childhood Hodgkin lymphoma include swollen lymph nodes, fever, night sweats, and weight loss.<EOS>
<BOS>Tests that examine the lymph system are used to detect (find) and diagnose childhood Hodgkin lymphoma.<EOS>
<BOS>Certain factors affect prognosis (chance of recovery) and treatment options.<EOS>
<BOS>Childhood Hodgkin lymphoma is a disease in which malignant (cancer) cells form in the lymph system.<EOS>
<BOS>Childhood Hodgkin lymphoma is a type of cancer that develops in the lymph system, which is part of the body's immune system.<EOS>
<BOS>The immune system protects the body from foreign substances, infection, and diseases.<EOS>
<BOS>The lymph system is made up of the following: Lymph: Colorless, watery fluid that carries white blood cells called lymphocytes through the lymph system.<EOS>
<BOS>Lymphocytes protect the body against infections and the growth of tumors.<EOS>
<BOS>Lymph vessels: A network of thin tubes that collect lymph from different parts of the body and return it to the bloodstream.<EOS>
<BOS>Lymph nodes: Small, beanshaped structures that filter lymph and store white blood cells that help fight infection and disease.<EOS>
<BOS>Lymph nodes are located along the network of lymph vessels found throughout the body.<EOS>
<BOS>Clusters of lymph nodes are found in the neck, underarm, abdomen, pelvis, and groin.<EOS>
<BOS>Spleen: An organ that makes lymphocytes, filters the blood, stores blood cells, and destroys old blood cells.<EOS>
<BOS>The spleen is on the left side of the abdomen near the stomach.<EOS>
<BOS>Thymus: An organ in which lymphocytes grow and multiply.<EOS>
<BOS>The thymus is in the chest behind the breastbone.<EOS>
<BOS>Tonsils: Two small masses of lymph tissue at the back of the throat.<EOS>
<BOS>The tonsils make lymphocytes.<EOS>
<BOS>Bone marrow: The soft, spongy tissue in the center of large bones.<EOS>
<BOS>Bone marrow makes white blood cells, red blood cells, and platelets.<EOS>
<BOS>Lymph tissue is also found in other parts of the body such as the stomach, thyroid gland, brain, and skin.<EOS>
<BOS>There are two general types of lymphoma: Hodgkin lymphoma and nonHodgkin lymphoma.<EOS>
<BOS>(See the PDQ summary on Childhood NonHodgkin Lymphoma Treatment for more information.<EOS>
<BOS>) Hodgkin lymphoma often occurs in adolescents 15 to 19 years of age.<EOS>
<BOS>The treatment for children and adolescents is different than treatment for adults.<EOS>
<BOS>(See the PDQ summary on Adult Hodgkin Lymphoma Treatment for more information.<EOS>
<BOS>) There are two types of childhood Hodgkin lymphoma.<EOS>
<BOS>The two types of childhood Hodgkin lymphoma are: Classical Hodgkin lymphoma.<EOS>
<BOS>Nodular lymphocytepredominant Hodgkin lymphoma.<EOS>
<BOS>Classical Hodgkin lymphoma is divided into four subtypes, based on how the cancer cells look under a microscope: Lymphocyterich classical Hodgkin lymphoma.<EOS>
<BOS>Nodular sclerosis Hodgkin lymphoma.<EOS>
<BOS>Mixed cellularity Hodgkin lymphoma.<EOS>
<BOS>Lymphocytedepleted Hodgkin lymphoma.<EOS>
<BOS>Signs and symptoms of small cell lung cancer include coughing, shortness of breath, and chest pain.<EOS>
<BOS>These and other signs and symptoms may be caused by small cell lung cancer or by other conditions.<EOS>
<BOS>Check with your doctor if you have any of the following: Chest discomfort or pain.<EOS>
<BOS>A cough that doesnt go away or gets worse over time.<EOS>
<BOS>Trouble breathing.<EOS>
<BOS>Wheezing.<EOS>
<BOS>Blood in sputum (mucus coughed up from the lungs).<EOS>
<BOS>Hoarseness.<EOS>
<BOS>Trouble swallowing.<EOS>
<BOS>Loss of appetite.<EOS>
<BOS>Weight loss for no known reason.<EOS>
<BOS>Feeling very tired.<EOS>
<BOS>Swelling in the face and/or veins in the neck.<EOS>
<BOS>Key Points There are different types of treatment for patients with nonHodgkin lymphoma.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients with nonHodgkin lymphoma should have their treatment planned by a team of health care providers who are experts in treating lymphomas.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients may develop late effects that appear months or years after their treatment for nonHodgkin lymphoma.<EOS>
<BOS>Nine types of standard treatment are used: Radiation therapy Chemotherapy Immunotherapy Targeted therapy Plasmapheresis Watchful waiting Antibiotic therapy Surgery Stem cell transplant New types of treatment are being tested in clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>Vaccine therapy Patients may want to think about taking part in a clinical trial.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients can enter clinical trials before, during, or after starting their cancer treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Followup tests may be needed.<EOS>
<BOS>There are different types of treatment for patients with nonHodgkin lymphoma.<EOS>
<BOS>Different types of treatment are available for patients with nonHodgkin lymphoma.<EOS>
<BOS>Some treatments are standard (the currently used treatment), and some are being tested in clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>A treatment clinical trial is a research study meant to help improve current treatments or obtain information on new treatments for patients with cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>When clinical trials show that a new treatment is better than the standard treatment, the new treatment may become the standard treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients may want to think about taking part in a clinical trial.<EOS>
<BOS>Some clinical trials are open only to patients who have not started treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>For pregnant women with nonHodgkin lymphoma, treatment is carefully chosen to protect the baby.<EOS>
<BOS>Treatment decisions are based on the mothers wishes, the stage of the nonHodgkin lymphoma, and the age of the baby.<EOS>
<BOS>The treatment plan may change as the signs and symptoms, cancer, and pregnancy change.<EOS>
<BOS>Choosing the most appropriate cancer treatment is a decision that ideally involves the patient, family, and health care team.<EOS>
