<BOS>Patients with nonHodgkin lymphoma should have their treatment planned by a team of health care providers who are experts in treating lymphomas.<EOS>
<BOS>Treatment will be overseen by a medical oncologist, a doctor who specializes in treating cancer, or a hematologist, a doctor who specializes in treating blood cancers.<EOS>
<BOS>The medical oncologist may refer you to other health care providers who have experience and are experts in treating adult nonHodgkin lymphoma and who specialize in certain areas of medicine.<EOS>
<BOS>These may include the following specialists: Neurosurgeon.<EOS>
<BOS>Neurologist.<EOS>
<BOS>Radiation oncologist.<EOS>
<BOS>Endocrinologist.<EOS>
<BOS>Rehabilitation specialist.<EOS>
<BOS>Other oncology specialists.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients may develop late effects that appear months or years after their treatment for nonHodgkin lymphoma.<EOS>
<BOS>Side effects from cancer treatment that begin during or after treatment and continue for months or years are called late effects.<EOS>
<BOS>Treatment with chemotherapy, radiation therapy, or stem cell transplant for nonHodgkin lymphoma may increase the risk of late effects.<EOS>
<BOS>Late effects of cancer treatment may include the following: Heart problems.<EOS>
<BOS>Infertility (inability to have children).<EOS>
<BOS>Loss of bone density.<EOS>
<BOS>Neuropathy (nerve damage that causes numbness or trouble walking).<EOS>
<BOS>A second cancer, such as: Lung cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Brain cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Kidney cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Bladder cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Melanoma.<EOS>
<BOS>Hodgkin lymphoma.<EOS>
<BOS>Myelodysplastic syndrome.<EOS>
<BOS>Acute myeloid leukemia.<EOS>
<BOS>Some late effects may be treated or controlled.<EOS>
<BOS>It is important to talk with your doctor about the effects cancer treatment can have on you.<EOS>
<BOS>Regular followup to check for late effects is important.<EOS>
<BOS>Nine types of standard treatment are used: Radiation therapy Radiation therapy is a cancer treatment that uses highenergy xrays or other types of radiation to kill cancer cells or keep them from growing.<EOS>
<BOS>There are two types of radiation therapy: External radiation therapy uses a machine outside the body to send radiation toward the cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Internal radiation therapy uses a radioactive substance sealed in needles, seeds, wires, or catheters that are placed directly into or near the cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Totalbody irradiation is a type of external radiation therapy that is given to the entire body.<EOS>
<BOS>It may be given before a stem cell transplant.<EOS>
<BOS>The way the radiation therapy is given depends on the type and stage of the cancer being treated.<EOS>
<BOS>External radiation therapy is used to treat adult nonHodgkin lymphoma, and may also be used as palliative therapy to relieve symptoms and improve quality of life.<EOS>
<BOS>For pregnant women with nonHodgkin lymphoma, radiation therapy should be given after delivery, if possible, to avoid any risk to the baby.<EOS>
<BOS>If treatment is needed right away, pregnant women may decide to continue the pregnancy and receive radiation therapy.<EOS>
<BOS>However, lead used to shield the baby may not protect it from scattered radiation that could possibly cause cancer in the future.<EOS>
<BOS>Chemotherapy Chemotherapy is a cancer treatment that uses drugs to stop the growth of cancer cells, either by killing the cells or by stopping them from dividing.<EOS>
<BOS>When chemotherapy is taken by mouth or injected into a vein or muscle, the drugs enter the bloodstream and can reach cancer cells throughout the body (systemic chemotherapy).<EOS>
<BOS>When chemotherapy is placed directly into the cerebrospinal fluid (intrathecal chemotherapy), an organ, or a body cavity such as the abdomen, the drugs mainly affect cancer cells in those areas (regional chemotherapy).<EOS>
<BOS>Combination chemotherapy is treatment using two or more anticancer drugs.<EOS>
<BOS>Steroid drugs may be added, to lessen inflammation and lower the body's immune response.<EOS>
<BOS>The way the chemotherapy is given depends on the type and stage of the cancer being treated.<EOS>
<BOS>Intrathecal chemotherapy may also be used in the treatment of lymphoma that first forms in the testicles or sinuses (hollow areas) around the nose, diffuse large Bcell lymphoma, Burkitt lymphoma, lymphoblastic lymphoma, and some aggressive Tcell lymphomas.<EOS>
<BOS>It is given to lessen the chance that lymphoma cells will spread to the brain and spinal cord.<EOS>
<BOS>This is called CNS prophylaxis.<EOS>
<BOS>In pregnant women, the baby is exposed to chemotherapy when the mother is treated, and some anticancer drugs cause birth defects.<EOS>
<BOS>Because anticancer drugs are passed to the baby through the mother, both must be watched closely when chemotherapy is given.<EOS>
<BOS>See Drugs Approved for NonHodgkin Lymphoma for more information.<EOS>
<BOS>Immunotherapy Immunotherapy is a treatment that uses the patients immune system to fight cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Substances made by the body or made in a laboratory are used to boost, direct, or restore the bodys natural defenses against cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Immunomodulators are a type of immunotherapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Lenalidomide is an immunomodulator used to treat adult nonHodgkin lymphoma.<EOS>
<BOS>See Drugs Approved for NonHodgkin Lymphoma for more information.<EOS>
<BOS>Targeted therapy Targeted therapy is a type of treatment that uses drugs or other substances to identify and attack specific cancer cells without harming normal cells.<EOS>
<BOS>Monoclonal antibody therapy, proteasome inhibitor therapy, and kinase inhibitor therapy are types of targeted therapy used to treat adult nonHodgkin lymphoma.<EOS>
<BOS>Monoclonal antibody therapy is a cancer treatment that uses antibodies made in the laboratory from a single type of immune system cell.<EOS>
<BOS>These antibodies can identify substances on cancer cells or normal substances that may help cancer cells grow.<EOS>
<BOS>The antibodies attach to the substances and kill the cancer cells, block their growth, or keep them from spreading.<EOS>
<BOS>They may be used alone or to carry drugs, toxins, or radioactive material directly to cancer cells.<EOS>
<BOS>Rituximab is a monoclonal antibody used to treat many types of nonHodgkin lymphoma.<EOS>
<BOS>Monoclonal antibodies that have been joined to radioactive material are called radiolabeled monoclonal antibodies.<EOS>
<BOS>Yttrium Y 90ibritumomab tiuxetan is an example of a radiolabeled monoclonal antibody.<EOS>
<BOS>Monoclonal antibodies are given by infusion.<EOS>
<BOS>Proteasome inhibitor therapy blocks the action of proteasomes in cancer cells and may prevent the growth of tumors.<EOS>
<BOS>Kinase inhibitor therapy, such as idelalisib, blocks certain proteins, which may help keep lymphoma cells from growing and may kill them.<EOS>
<BOS>It is used to treat indolent lymphoma.<EOS>
<BOS>Ibrutinib, a type of Bruton's tyrosine kinase inhibitor therapy, is used to treat lymphoplasmacytic lymphoma and mantle cell lymphoma.<EOS>
<BOS>See Drugs Approved for NonHodgkin Lymphoma for more information.<EOS>
<BOS>Plasmapheresis If the blood becomes thick with extra antibody proteins and affects circulation, plasmapheresis is done to remove extra plasma and antibody proteins from the blood.<EOS>
<BOS>In this procedure, blood is removed from the patient and sent through a machine that separates the plasma (the liquid part of the blood) from the blood cells.<EOS>
<BOS>The patient's plasma contains the unneeded antibodies and is not returned to the patient.<EOS>
<BOS>The normal blood cells are returned to the bloodstream along with donated plasma or a plasma replacement.<EOS>
<BOS>Plasmapheresis does not keep new antibodies from forming.<EOS>
<BOS>Watchful waiting Watchful waiting is closely monitoring a patients condition without giving any treatment until signs or symptoms appear or change.<EOS>
<BOS>Antibiotic therapy Antibiotic therapy is a treatment that uses drugs to treat infections and cancer caused by bacteria and other microorganisms.<EOS>
<BOS>See Drugs Approved for NonHodgkin Lymphoma for more information.<EOS>
<BOS>Surgery Surgery may be used to remove the lymphoma in certain patients with indolent or aggressive nonHodgkin lymphoma.<EOS>
<BOS>The type of surgery used depends on where the lymphoma formed in the body: Local excision for certain patients with mucosaassociated lymphoid tissue (MALT) lymphoma, PTLD, and small bowel Tcell lymphoma.<EOS>
<BOS>Splenectomy for patients with marginal zone lymphoma of the spleen.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients who have a heart, lung, liver, kidney, or pancreas transplant usually need to take drugs to suppress their immune system for the rest of their lives.<EOS>
<BOS>Longterm immunosuppression after an organ transplant can cause a certain type of nonHodgkin lymphoma called posttransplant lymphoproliferative disorder (PLTD).<EOS>
<BOS>Small bowel surgery is often needed to diagnose celiac disease in adults who develop a type of Tcell lymphoma.<EOS>
<BOS>Stem cell transplant Stem cell transplant is a method of giving high doses of chemotherapy and/or totalbody irradiation and then replacing bloodforming cells destroyed by the cancer treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Stem cells (immature blood cells) are removed from the blood or bone marrow of the patient (autologous transplant) or a donor (allogeneic transplant) and are frozen and stored.<EOS>
<BOS>After the chemotherapy and/or radiation therapy is completed, the stored stem cells are thawed and given back to the patient through an infusion.<EOS>
<BOS>These reinfused stem cells grow into (and restore) the bodys blood cells.<EOS>
<BOS>New types of treatment are being tested in clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>This summary section describes treatments that are being studied in clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>It may not mention every new treatment being studied.<EOS>
<BOS>Information about clinical trials is available from the NCI website.<EOS>
<BOS>Vaccine therapy Vaccine therapy is a type of biologic therapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Biologic therapy is a treatment that uses the patients immune system to fight cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Substances made by the body or made in a laboratory are used to boost, direct, or restore the bodys natural defenses against cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>This type of cancer treatment is also called biotherapy or immunotherapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Vaccine therapy can also be a type of targeted therapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients may want to think about taking part in a clinical trial.<EOS>
<BOS>For some patients, taking part in a clinical trial may be the best treatment choice.<EOS>
<BOS>Clinical trials are part of the cancer research process.<EOS>
<BOS>Clinical trials are done to find out if new cancer treatments are safe and effective or better than the standard treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Many of today's standard treatments for cancer are based on earlier clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients who take part in a clinical trial may receive the standard treatment or be among the first to receive a new treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients who take part in clinical trials also help improve the way cancer will be treated in the future.<EOS>
<BOS>Even when clinical trials do not lead to effective new treatments, they often answer important questions and help move research forward.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients can enter clinical trials before, during, or after starting their cancer treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Some clinical trials only include patients who have not yet received treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Other trials test treatments for patients whose cancer has not gotten better.<EOS>
<BOS>There are also clinical trials that test new ways to stop cancer from recurring (coming back) or reduce the side effects of cancer treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Clinical trials are taking place in many parts of the country.<EOS>
<BOS>See the Treatment Options section that follows for links to current treatment clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>These have been retrieved from NCI's listing of clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>Followup tests may be needed.<EOS>
<BOS>Some of the tests that were done to diagnose the cancer or to find out the stage of the cancer may be repeated.<EOS>
<BOS>Some tests will be repeated in order to see how well the treatment is working.<EOS>
<BOS>Decisions about whether to continue, change, or stop treatment may be based on the results of these tests.<EOS>
<BOS>Some of the tests will continue to be done from time to time after treatment has ended.<EOS>
<BOS>The results of these tests can show if your condition has changed or if the cancer has recurred (come back).<EOS>
<BOS>These tests are sometimes called followup tests or checkups.<EOS>
<BOS>Treatment Options for NonHodgkin Lymphoma During Pregnancy Indolent NonHodgkin Lymphoma During Pregnancy Women who have indolent (slowgrowing) nonHodgkin lymphoma during pregnancy may be treated with watchful waiting until after they give birth.<EOS>
<BOS>(See the Treatment Options for Indolent NonHodgkin Lymphoma section for more information.<EOS>
<BOS>) Aggressive NonHodgkin Lymphoma During Pregnancy Treatment of aggressive nonHodgkin lymphoma during pregnancy may include the following: Treatment given right away based on the type of nonHodgkin lymphoma to increase the mother's chance of survival.<EOS>
<BOS>Treatment may include combination chemotherapy and rituximab.<EOS>
<BOS>Early delivery of the baby followed by treatment based on the type of nonHodgkin lymphoma.<EOS>
<BOS>If in the first trimester of pregnancy, medical oncologists may advise ending the pregnancy so that treatment may begin.<EOS>
<BOS>Treatment depends on the type of nonHodgkin lymphoma.<EOS>
<BOS>Certain factors affect prognosis (chance of recovery) and treatment options.<EOS>
<BOS>The prognosis (chance of recovery) and treatment options depend on the following: Where the tumor is in the gastrointestinal tract.<EOS>
<BOS>The size of the tumor.<EOS>
<BOS>Whether the cancer has spread from the stomach and intestines to other parts of the body, such as the liver or lymph nodes.<EOS>
<BOS>Whether the patient has carcinoid syndrome or has carcinoid heart syndrome.<EOS>
<BOS>Whether the cancer can be completely removed by surgery.<EOS>
<BOS>Whether the cancer is newly diagnosed or has recurred.<EOS>
<BOS>Key Points There are different types of treatment for patients with laryngeal cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Three types of standard treatment are used: Radiation therapy Surgery Chemotherapy New types of treatment are being tested in clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>Chemoprevention Radiosensitizers Patients may want to think about taking part in a clinical trial.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients can enter clinical trials before, during, or after starting their cancer treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Followup tests may be needed.<EOS>
<BOS>There are different types of treatment for patients with laryngeal cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Different types of treatment are available for patients with laryngeal cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Some treatments are standard (the currently used treatment), and some are being tested in clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>A treatment clinical trial is a research study meant to help improve current treatments or obtain information on new treatments for patients with cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>When clinical trials show that a new treatment is better than the standard treatment, the new treatment may become the standard treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients may want to think about taking part in a clinical trial.<EOS>
<BOS>Some clinical trials are open only to patients who have not started treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Three types of standard treatment are used: Radiation therapy Radiation therapy is a cancer treatment that uses highenergy xrays or other types of radiation to kill cancer cells.<EOS>
<BOS>There are two types of radiation therapy.<EOS>
<BOS>External radiation therapy uses a machine outside the body to send radiation toward the cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Internal radiation therapy uses a radioactive substance sealed in needles, seeds, wires, or catheters that are placed directly into or near the cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>The way the radiation therapy is given depends on the type and stage of the cancer being treated.<EOS>
<BOS>Radiation therapy may work better in patients who have stopped smoking before beginning treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>External radiation therapy to the thyroid or the pituitary gland may change the way the thyroid gland works.<EOS>
<BOS>The doctor may test the thyroid gland before and after therapy to make sure it is working properly.<EOS>
<BOS>Hyperfractionated radiation therapy and new types of radiation therapy are being studied in the treatment of laryngeal cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Surgery Surgery (removing the cancer in an operation) is a common treatment for all stages of laryngeal cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>The following surgical procedures may be used: Cordectomy: Surgery to remove the vocal cords only.<EOS>
<BOS>Supraglottic laryngectomy: Surgery to remove the supraglottis only.<EOS>
<BOS>Hemilaryngectomy: Surgery to remove half of the larynx (voice box).<EOS>
<BOS>A hemilaryngectomy saves the voice.<EOS>
<BOS>Partial laryngectomy: Surgery to remove part of the larynx (voice box).<EOS>
<BOS>A partial laryngectomy helps keep the patient's ability to talk.<EOS>
<BOS>Total laryngectomy: Surgery to remove the whole larynx.<EOS>
<BOS>During this operation, a hole is made in the front of the neck to allow the patient to breathe.<EOS>
<BOS>This is called a tracheostomy.<EOS>
<BOS>Thyroidectomy: The removal of all or part of the thyroid gland.<EOS>
<BOS>Laser surgery: A surgical procedure that uses a laser beam (a narrow beam of intense light) as a knife to make bloodless cuts in tissue or to remove a surface lesion such as a tumor Even if the doctor removes all the cancer that can be seen at the time of the surgery, some patients may be given chemotherapy or radiation therapy after surgery to kill any cancer cells that are left.<EOS>
<BOS>Treatment given after the surgery, to lower the risk that the cancer will come back, is called adjuvant therapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Chemotherapy Chemotherapy is a cancer treatment that uses drugs to stop the growth of cancer cells, either by killing the cells or by stopping the cells from dividing.<EOS>
<BOS>When chemotherapy is taken by mouth or injected into a vein or muscle, the drugs enter the bloodstream and can reach cancer cells throughout the body (systemic chemotherapy).<EOS>
<BOS>When chemotherapy is placed directly into the cerebrospinal fluid, an organ, or a body cavity such as the abdomen, the drugs mainly affect cancer cells in those areas (regional chemotherapy).<EOS>
<BOS>The way the chemotherapy is given depends on the type and stage of the cancer being treated.<EOS>
<BOS>See Drugs Approved for Head and Neck Cancer for more information.<EOS>
<BOS>(Laryngeal cancer is a type of head and neck cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>) New types of treatment are being tested in clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>This summary section describes treatments that are being studied in clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>It may not mention every new treatment being studied.<EOS>
<BOS>Information about clinical trials is available from the NCI Web site.<EOS>
<BOS>Chemoprevention Chemoprevention is the use of drugs, vitamins, or other substances to reduce the risk of developing cancer or to reduce the risk cancer will recur (come back).<EOS>
<BOS>The drug isotretinoin is being studied to prevent the development of a second cancer in patients who have had cancer of the head or neck.<EOS>
<BOS>Radiosensitizers Radiosensitizers are drugs that make tumor cells more sensitive to radiation therapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Combining radiation therapy with radiosensitizers may kill more tumor cells.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients may want to think about taking part in a clinical trial.<EOS>
<BOS>For some patients, taking part in a clinical trial may be the best treatment choice.<EOS>
<BOS>Clinical trials are part of the cancer research process.<EOS>
<BOS>Clinical trials are done to find out if new cancer treatments are safe and effective or better than the standard treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Many of today's standard treatments for cancer are based on earlier clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients who take part in a clinical trial may receive the standard treatment or be among the first to receive a new treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients who take part in clinical trials also help improve the way cancer will be treated in the future.<EOS>
<BOS>Even when clinical trials do not lead to effective new treatments, they often answer important questions and help move research forward.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients can enter clinical trials before, during, or after starting their cancer treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Some clinical trials only include patients who have not yet received treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Other trials test treatments for patients whose cancer has not gotten better.<EOS>
<BOS>There are also clinical trials that test new ways to stop cancer from recurring (coming back) or reduce the side effects of cancer treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Clinical trials are taking place in many parts of the country.<EOS>
<BOS>See the Treatment Options section that follows for links to current treatment clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>These have been retrieved from NCI's listing of clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>Followup tests may be needed.<EOS>
<BOS>Some of the tests that were done to diagnose the cancer or to find out the stage of the cancer may be repeated.<EOS>
<BOS>Some tests will be repeated in order to see how well the treatment is working.<EOS>
<BOS>Decisions about whether to continue, change, or stop treatment may be based on the results of these tests.<EOS>
<BOS>Some of the tests will continue to be done from time to time after treatment has ended.<EOS>
<BOS>The results of these tests can show if your condition has changed or if the cancer has recurred (come back).<EOS>
<BOS>These tests are sometimes called followup tests or checkups.<EOS>
<BOS>Treatment Options by Stage Stage I Laryngeal Cancer Treatment of stage I laryngeal cancer depends on where cancer is found in the larynx.<EOS>
<BOS>If cancer is in the supraglottis, treatment may include the following: Radiation therapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Supraglottic laryngectomy.<EOS>
<BOS>If cancer is in the glottis, treatment may include the following: Radiation therapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Cordectomy.<EOS>
<BOS>Partial laryngectomy, hemilaryngectomy, or total laryngectomy.<EOS>
<BOS>Laser surgery.<EOS>
<BOS>If cancer is in the subglottis, treatment may include the following: Radiation therapy with or without surgery.<EOS>
<BOS>Surgery alone.<EOS>
<BOS>Check the list of NCIsupported cancer clinical trials that are now accepting patients with stage I laryngeal cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>For more specific results, refine the search by using other search features, such as the location of the trial, the type of treatment, or the name of the drug.<EOS>
<BOS>Talk with your doctor about clinical trials that may be right for you.<EOS>
<BOS>General information about clinical trials is available from the NCI website.<EOS>
<BOS>Stage II Laryngeal Cancer Treatment of stage II laryngeal cancer depends on where cancer is found in the larynx.<EOS>
<BOS>If cancer is in the supraglottis, treatment may include the following: Radiation therapy Supraglottic laryngectomy or total laryngectomy with or without radiation therapy.<EOS>
<BOS>A clinical trial of radiation therapy.<EOS>
<BOS>A clinical trial of chemoprevention.<EOS>
<BOS>If cancer is in the glottis, treatment may include the following: Radiation therapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Partial laryngectomy, hemilaryngectomy, or total laryngectomy.<EOS>
<BOS>Laser surgery.<EOS>
<BOS>A clinical trial of radiation therapy.<EOS>
<BOS>A clinical trial of chemoprevention.<EOS>
<BOS>If cancer is in the subglottis, treatment may include the following: Radiation therapy with or without surgery.<EOS>
<BOS>Surgery alone.<EOS>
<BOS>A clinical trial of radiation therapy.<EOS>
<BOS>A clinical trial of chemoprevention.<EOS>
<BOS>Check the list of NCIsupported cancer clinical trials that are now accepting patients with stage II laryngeal cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>For more specific results, refine the search by using other search features, such as the location of the trial, the type of treatment, or the name of the drug.<EOS>
<BOS>Talk with your doctor about clinical trials that may be right for you.<EOS>
<BOS>General information about clinical trials is available from the NCI website.<EOS>
<BOS>Stage III Laryngeal Cancer Treatment of stage III laryngeal cancer depends on where cancer is found in the larynx.<EOS>
<BOS>If cancer is in the supraglottis or glottis, treatment may include the following: Chemotherapy and radiation therapy given together.<EOS>
<BOS>Chemotherapy followed by chemotherapy and radiation therapy given together.<EOS>
<BOS>Laryngectomy may be done if cancer remains.<EOS>
<BOS>Radiation therapy for patients who cannot be treated with chemotherapy and surgery.<EOS>
<BOS>For tumors that do not respond to radiation, total laryngectomy may be done.<EOS>
<BOS>Surgery, which may be followed by radiation therapy.<EOS>
<BOS>A clinical trial of radiation therapy.<EOS>
<BOS>A clinical trial of chemotherapy, radiosensitizers, or radiation therapy.<EOS>
<BOS>A clinical trial of chemoprevention.<EOS>
<BOS>If cancer is in the subglottis, treatment may include the following: Laryngectomy plus total thyroidectomy and removal of lymph nodes in the throat, usually followed by radiation therapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Radiation therapy with or without surgery.<EOS>
<BOS>A clinical trial of chemotherapy, radiosensitizers, or radiation therapy.<EOS>
<BOS>A clinical trial of chemoprevention.<EOS>
<BOS>Check the list of NCIsupported cancer clinical trials that are now accepting patients with stage III laryngeal cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>For more specific results, refine the search by using other search features, such as the location of the trial, the type of treatment, or the name of the drug.<EOS>
<BOS>Talk with your doctor about clinical trials that may be right for you.<EOS>
<BOS>General information about clinical trials is available from the NCI website.<EOS>
<BOS>Stage IV Laryngeal Cancer Treatment of stage IV laryngeal cancer depends on where cancer is found in the larynx.<EOS>
<BOS>If cancer is in the supraglottis or glottis, treatment may include the following: Chemotherapy and radiation therapy given together.<EOS>
<BOS>Chemotherapy followed by chemotherapy and radiation therapy given together.<EOS>
<BOS>Laryngectomy may be done if cancer remains.<EOS>
<BOS>Radiation therapy for patients who cannot be treated with chemotherapy and surgery.<EOS>
<BOS>For tumors that do not respond to radiation, total laryngectomy may be done.<EOS>
<BOS>Surgery followed by radiation therapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Chemotherapy may be given with the radiation therapy.<EOS>
<BOS>A clinical trial of radiation therapy.<EOS>
<BOS>A clinical trial of chemotherapy, radiosensitizers, or radiation therapy.<EOS>
<BOS>A clinical trial of chemoprevention.<EOS>
<BOS>If cancer is in the subglottis, treatment may include the following: Laryngectomy plus total thyroidectomy and removal of lymph nodes in the throat, usually with radiation therapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Radiation therapy.<EOS>
<BOS>A clinical trial of radiation therapy.<EOS>
<BOS>A clinical trial of chemotherapy, radiosensitizers, or radiation therapy.<EOS>
<BOS>A clinical trial of chemoprevention.<EOS>
<BOS>Check the list of NCIsupported cancer clinical trials that are now accepting patients with stage IV laryngeal cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>For more specific results, refine the search by using other search features, such as the location of the trial, the type of treatment, or the name of the drug.<EOS>
<BOS>Talk with your doctor about clinical trials that may be right for you.<EOS>
<BOS>General information about clinical trials is available from the NCI website.<EOS>
<BOS>Certain factors affect prognosis (chance of recovery) and treatment options.<EOS>
<BOS>The prognosis (chance of recovery) and treatment options depend on the following: The stage of the cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>The type of nonHodgkin lymphoma.<EOS>
<BOS>The amount of lactate dehydrogenase (LDH) in the blood.<EOS>
<BOS>Whether there are certain changes in the genes.<EOS>
<BOS>The patients age and general health.<EOS>
<BOS>Whether the lymphoma has just been diagnosed or has recurred (come back).<EOS>
<BOS>For nonHodgkin lymphoma during pregnancy, the treatment options also depend on: The wishes of the patient.<EOS>
<BOS>Which trimester of pregnancy the patient is in.<EOS>
<BOS>Whether the baby can be delivered early.<EOS>
<BOS>Some types of nonHodgkin lymphoma spread more quickly than others do.<EOS>
<BOS>Most nonHodgkin lymphomas that occur during pregnancy are aggressive.<EOS>
<BOS>Delaying treatment of aggressive lymphoma until after the baby is born may lessen the mother's chance of survival.<EOS>
<BOS>Immediate treatment is often recommended, even during pregnancy.<EOS>
<BOS>Key Points After childhood rhabdomyosarcoma has been diagnosed, treatment is based in part on the stage of the cancer and sometimes it is based on whether all the cancer was removed by surgery.<EOS>
<BOS>There are three ways that cancer spreads in the body.<EOS>
<BOS>Cancer may spread from where it began to other parts of the body.<EOS>
<BOS>Staging of childhood rhabdomyosarcoma is done in three parts.<EOS>
<BOS>The staging system is based on the size of the tumor, where it is in the body, and whether it has spread to other parts of the body: Stage 1 Stage 2 Stage 3 Stage 4 The grouping system is based on whether the cancer has spread and whether all the cancer was removed by surgery: Group I Group II Group III Group IV The risk group is based on the staging system and the grouping system.<EOS>
<BOS>Lowrisk childhood rhabdomyosarcoma Intermediaterisk childhood rhabdomyosarcoma Highrisk childhood rhabdomyosarcoma After childhood rhabdomyosarcoma has been diagnosed, treatment is based in part on the stage of the cancer and sometimes it is based on whether all the cancer was removed by surgery.<EOS>
<BOS>The process used to find out if cancer has spread within the tissue or to other parts of the body is called staging.<EOS>
<BOS>It is important to know the stage in order to plan treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>The doctor will use results of the diagnostic tests to help find out the stage of the disease.<EOS>
<BOS>Treatment for childhood rhabdomyosarcoma is based in part on the stage and sometimes on the amount of cancer that remains after surgery to remove the tumor.<EOS>
<BOS>The pathologist will use a microscope to check the tissues removed during surgery, including tissue samples from the edges of the areas where the cancer was removed and the lymph nodes.<EOS>
<BOS>This is done to see if all the cancer cells were taken out during the surgery.<EOS>
<BOS>There are three ways that cancer spreads in the body.<EOS>
<BOS>Cancer can spread through tissue, the lymph system, and the blood: Tissue.<EOS>
<BOS>The cancer spreads from where it began by growing into nearby areas.<EOS>
<BOS>Lymph system.<EOS>
<BOS>The cancer spreads from where it began by getting into the lymph system.<EOS>
<BOS>The cancer travels through the lymph vessels to other parts of the body.<EOS>
<BOS>Blood.<EOS>
<BOS>The cancer spreads from where it began by getting into the blood.<EOS>
<BOS>The cancer travels through the blood vessels to other parts of the body.<EOS>
<BOS>Cancer may spread from where it began to other parts of the body.<EOS>
<BOS>When cancer spreads to another part of the body, it is called metastasis.<EOS>
<BOS>Cancer cells break away from where they began (the primary tumor) and travel through the lymph system or blood.<EOS>
<BOS>Lymph system.<EOS>
<BOS>The cancer gets into the lymph system, travels through the lymph vessels, and forms a tumor (metastatic tumor) in another part of the body.<EOS>
<BOS>Blood.<EOS>
<BOS>The cancer gets into the blood, travels through the blood vessels, and forms a tumor (metastatic tumor) in another part of the body.<EOS>
<BOS>The metastatic tumor is the same type of cancer as the primary tumor.<EOS>
<BOS>For example, if rhabdomyosarcoma spreads to the lung, the cancer cells in the lung are actually rhabdomyosarcoma cells.<EOS>
<BOS>The disease is metastatic rhabdomyosarcoma, not lung cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Staging of childhood rhabdomyosarcoma is done in three parts.<EOS>
<BOS>Childhood rhabdomyosarcoma is staged by using three different ways to describe the cancer: A staging system.<EOS>
<BOS>A grouping system.<EOS>
<BOS>A risk group.<EOS>
<BOS>The staging system is based on the size of the tumor, where it is in the body, and whether it has spread to other parts of the body: Stage 1 In stage 1, the tumor is any size, may have spread to lymph nodes, and is found in only one of the following "favorable" sites: Eye or area around the eye.<EOS>
<BOS>Head and neck (but not in the tissue next to the brain and spinal cord).<EOS>
<BOS>Gallbladder and bile ducts.<EOS>
<BOS>Ureters or urethra.<EOS>
<BOS>Testes, ovary, vagina, or uterus.<EOS>
<BOS>Rhabdomyosarcoma that forms in a "favorable" site has a better prognosis.<EOS>
<BOS>If the site where cancer occurs is not one of the favorable sites listed above, it is said to be an "unfavorable" site.<EOS>
<BOS>Stage 2 In stage 2, cancer is found in an "unfavorable" site (any one area not described as "favorable" in stage 1).<EOS>
<BOS>The tumor is no larger than 5 centimeters and has not spread to lymph nodes.<EOS>
<BOS>Stage 3 In stage 3, cancer is found in an "unfavorable" site (any one area not described as "favorable" in stage 1) and one of the following is true: The tumor is no larger than 5 centimeters and cancer has spread to nearby lymph nodes.<EOS>
<BOS>The tumor is larger than 5 centimeters and cancer may have spread to nearby lymph nodes.<EOS>
<BOS>Stage 4 In stage 4, the tumor may be any size and cancer may have spread to nearby lymph nodes.<EOS>
<BOS>Cancer has spread to distant parts of the body, such as the lung, bone marrow, or bone.<EOS>
<BOS>The grouping system is based on whether the cancer has spread and whether all the cancer was removed by surgery: Group I Cancer was found only in the place where it started and it was completely removed by surgery.<EOS>
<BOS>Tissue was taken from the edges of where the tumor was removed.<EOS>
<BOS>The tissue was checked under a microscope by a pathologist and no cancer cells were found.<EOS>
<BOS>Group II Group II is divided into groups IIA, IIB, and IIC.<EOS>
<BOS>IIA: Cancer was removed by surgery but cancer cells were seen when the tissue, taken from the edges of where the tumor was removed, was viewed under a microscope by a pathologist.<EOS>
<BOS>IIB: Cancer had spread to nearby lymph nodes and the cancer and lymph nodes were removed by surgery.<EOS>
<BOS>IIC: Cancer had spread to nearby lymph nodes, the cancer and lymph nodes were removed by surgery, and at least one of the following is true: Tissue taken from the edges of where the tumor was removed was checked under a microscope by a pathologist and cancer cells were seen.<EOS>
<BOS>The furthest lymph node from the tumor that was removed was checked under a microscope by a pathologist and cancer cells were seen.<EOS>
<BOS>Group III Cancer was partly removed by biopsy or surgery but there is tumor remaining that can be seen with the eye.<EOS>
<BOS>Group IV Cancer had spread to distant parts of the body when the cancer was diagnosed.<EOS>
<BOS>Cancer cells are found by an imaging test; or There are cancer cells in the fluid around the brain, spinal cord, or lungs, or in fluid in the abdomen; or tumors are found in those areas.<EOS>
<BOS>The risk group is based on the staging system and the grouping system.<EOS>
<BOS>The risk group describes the chance that rhabdomyosarcoma will recur (come back).<EOS>
<BOS>Every child treated for rhabdomyosarcoma should receive chemotherapy to decrease the chance cancer will recur.<EOS>
<BOS>The type of anticancer drug, dose, and the number of treatments given depends on whether the child has lowrisk, intermediaterisk, or highrisk rhabdomyosarcoma.<EOS>
<BOS>The following risk groups are used: Lowrisk childhood rhabdomyosarcoma Lowrisk childhood rhabdomyosarcoma is one of the following: An embryonal tumor of any size that is found in a "favorable" site.<EOS>
<BOS>There may be tumor remaining after surgery that can be seen with or without a microscope.<EOS>
<BOS>The cancer may have spread to nearby lymph nodes.<EOS>
<BOS>The following areas are "favorable" sites: Eye or area around the eye.<EOS>
<BOS>Head or neck (but not in the tissue near the ear, nose, sinuses, or base of the skull).<EOS>
<BOS>Gallbladder and bile ducts.<EOS>
<BOS>Ureter or urethra.<EOS>
<BOS>Testes, ovary, vagina, or uterus.<EOS>
<BOS>An embryonal tumor of any size that is not found in a "favorable" site.<EOS>
<BOS>There may be tumor remaining after surgery that can be seen only with a microscope.<EOS>
<BOS>The cancer may have spread to nearby lymph nodes.<EOS>
<BOS>Intermediaterisk childhood rhabdomyosarcoma Intermediaterisk childhood rhabdomyosarcoma is one of the following: An embryonal tumor of any size that is not found in one of the "favorable" sites listed above.<EOS>
<BOS>There is tumor remaining after surgery, that can be seen with or without a microscope.<EOS>
<BOS>The cancer may have spread to nearby lymph nodes.<EOS>
<BOS>An alveolar tumor of any size in a "favorable" or "unfavorable" site.<EOS>
<BOS>There may be tumor remaining after surgery that can be seen with or without a microscope.<EOS>
<BOS>The cancer may have spread to nearby lymph nodes.<EOS>
<BOS>Highrisk childhood rhabdomyosarcoma Highrisk childhood rhabdomyosarcoma may be the embryonal type or the alveolar type.<EOS>
<BOS>It may have spread to nearby lymph nodes and has spread to one or more of the following: Other parts of the body that are not near where the tumor first formed.<EOS>
<BOS>Fluid around the brain or spinal cord.<EOS>
<BOS>Fluid in the lung or abdomen.<EOS>
<BOS>Cancer prevention clinical trials are used to study ways to prevent cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Cancer prevention clinical trials are used to study ways to lower the risk of developing certain types of cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Some cancer prevention trials are conducted with healthy people who have not had cancer but who have an increased risk for cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Other prevention trials are conducted with people who have had cancer and are trying to prevent another cancer of the same type or to lower their chance of developing a new type of cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Other trials are done with healthy volunteers who are not known to have any risk factors for cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>The purpose of some cancer prevention clinical trials is to find out whether actions people take can prevent cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>These may include exercising more or quitting smoking or taking certain medicines, vitamins, minerals, or food supplements.<EOS>
<BOS>New ways to prevent colorectal cancer are being studied in clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>Clinical trials are taking place in many parts of the country.<EOS>
<BOS>Information about clinical trials can be found in the Clinical Trials section of the NCI website.<EOS>
<BOS>Check NCI's list of cancer clinical trials for colon cancer prevention trials or rectal cancer prevention trials that are now accepting patients.<EOS>
<BOS>Key Points There are different types of treatment for patients with central nervous system atypical teratoid/rhabdoid tumor.<EOS>
<BOS>Children with atypical teratoid/rhabdoid tumor should have their treatment planned by a team of health care providers who are experts in treating cancer in children.<EOS>
<BOS>Childhood brain tumors may cause signs or symptoms that begin before the cancer is diagnosed and continue for months or years.<EOS>
<BOS>Some cancer treatments cause side effects months or years after treatment has ended.<EOS>
<BOS>Four types of treatment are used: Surgery Chemotherapy Radiation therapy Highdose chemotherapy with stem cell transplant New types of treatment are being tested in clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>Targeted therapy Patients may want to think about taking part in a clinical trial.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients can enter clinical trials before, during, or after starting their cancer treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Followup tests may be needed.<EOS>
<BOS>There are different types of treatment for patients with central nervous system atypical teratoid/rhabdoid tumor.<EOS>
<BOS>Different types of treatment are available for patients with central nervous system atypical teratoid/rhabdoid tumor (AT/RT).<EOS>
<BOS>Treatment for AT/RT is usually within a clinical trial.<EOS>
<BOS>A treatment clinical trial is a research study meant to help improve current treatments or obtain information on new treatments for patients with cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Clinical trials are taking place in many parts of the country.<EOS>
<BOS>Information about ongoing clinical trials is available from the NCI website.<EOS>
<BOS>Choosing the most appropriate cancer treatment is a decision that ideally involves the patient, family, and health care team.<EOS>
<BOS>Children with atypical teratoid/rhabdoid tumor should have their treatment planned by a team of health care providers who are experts in treating cancer in children.<EOS>
<BOS>Treatment will be overseen by a pediatric oncologist, a doctor who specializes in treating children with cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>The pediatric oncologist works with other pediatric health care providers who are experts in treating children with central nervous system cancer and who specialize in certain areas of medicine.<EOS>
<BOS>These may include the following specialists: Pediatrician.<EOS>
<BOS>Pediatric neurosurgeon.<EOS>
<BOS>Radiation oncologist.<EOS>
<BOS>Neurologist.<EOS>
<BOS>Pediatric nurse specialist.<EOS>
<BOS>Rehabilitation specialist.<EOS>
<BOS>Psychologist.<EOS>
<BOS>Social worker.<EOS>
<BOS>Geneticist or genetic counselor.<EOS>
<BOS>Childhood brain tumors may cause signs or symptoms that begin before the cancer is diagnosed and continue for months or years.<EOS>
<BOS>Signs or symptoms caused by the tumor may begin before diagnosis.<EOS>
<BOS>These signs or symptoms may continue for months or years.<EOS>
<BOS>It is important to talk with your child's doctors about signs or symptoms caused by the tumor that may continue after treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Some cancer treatments cause side effects months or years after treatment has ended.<EOS>
<BOS>Side effects from cancer treatment that begin during or after treatment and continue for months or years are called late effects.<EOS>
<BOS>Late effects of cancer treatment may include the following: Physical problems.<EOS>
<BOS>Changes in mood, feelings, thinking, learning, or memory.<EOS>
<BOS>Second cancers (new types of cancer).<EOS>
<BOS>Some late effects may be treated or controlled.<EOS>
<BOS>It is important to talk with your child's doctors about the effects cancer treatment can have on your child.<EOS>
<BOS>(See the PDQ summary on Late Effects of Treatment for Childhood Cancer for more information).<EOS>
<BOS>Four types of treatment are used: Surgery Surgery is used to diagnose and treat CNS atypical teratoid/rhabdoid tumor.<EOS>
<BOS>See the General Information section of this summary.<EOS>
<BOS>Even if the doctor removes all the cancer that can be seen at the time of the surgery, most patients will be given chemotherapy and possibly radiation therapy after surgery to kill any cancer cells that are left.<EOS>
<BOS>Treatment given after the surgery, to lower the risk that the cancer will come back, is called adjuvant therapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Chemotherapy Chemotherapy is a cancer treatment that uses drugs to stop the growth of cancer cells, either by killing the cells or by stopping them from dividing.<EOS>
<BOS>When chemotherapy is placed directly into the cerebrospinal fluid, an organ, or a body cavity such as the abdomen, the drugs mainly affect tumor cells in those areas (regional chemotherapy).<EOS>
<BOS>Regular doses of anticancer drugs given by mouth or vein to treat brain and spinal cord tumors cannot cross the bloodbrain barrier and reach the tumor.<EOS>
<BOS>Anticancer drugs injected into the cerebrospinal fluid are able to reach the tumor.<EOS>
<BOS>This is called intrathecal chemotherapy.<EOS>
<BOS>When chemotherapy is taken by mouth or injected into a vein or muscle, the drugs enter the bloodstream and can reach tumor cells throughout the body (systemic chemotherapy).<EOS>
<BOS>High doses of some anticancer drugs given into a vein can cross the bloodbrain barrier and reach the tumor.<EOS>
<BOS>Radiation therapy Radiation therapy is a cancer treatment that uses highenergy xrays or other types of radiation to kill cancer cells or keep them from growing.<EOS>
<BOS>There are two types of radiation therapy: External radiation therapy uses a machine outside the body to send radiation toward the cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Internal radiation therapy uses a radioactive substance sealed in needles, seeds, wires, or catheters that are placed directly into or near the cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>The way the radiation therapy is given depends on the type of tumor being treated and whether it has spread.<EOS>
<BOS>External radiation therapy may be given to the brain and spinal cord.<EOS>
<BOS>Because radiation therapy can affect growth and brain development in young children, especially children who are three years old or younger, the dose of radiation therapy may be lower than in older children.<EOS>
<BOS>Highdose chemotherapy with stem cell transplant Highdose chemotherapy with stem cell transplant is a method of giving high doses of chemotherapy and replacing blood forming cells destroyed by the cancer treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Stem cells (immature blood cells) are removed from the blood or bone marrow of the patient or a donor and are frozen and stored.<EOS>
<BOS>After the chemotherapy is completed, the stored stem cells are thawed and given back to the patient through an infusion.<EOS>
<BOS>These reinfused stem cells grow into (and restore) the bodys blood cells.<EOS>
<BOS>New types of treatment are being tested in clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>This summary section describes treatments that are being studied in clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>It may not mention every new treatment being studied.<EOS>
<BOS>Information about clinical trials is available from the NCI website.<EOS>
<BOS>Targeted therapy Targeted therapy is a type of treatment that uses drugs or other substances to attack specific cancer cells.<EOS>
<BOS>Targeted therapies usually cause less harm to normal cells than chemotherapy or radiation therapy do.<EOS>
<BOS>Targeted therapy is being studied in the treatment of recurrent childhood central nervous system atypical teratoid/rhabdoid tumor.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients may want to think about taking part in a clinical trial.<EOS>
<BOS>For some patients, taking part in a clinical trial may be the best treatment choice.<EOS>
<BOS>Clinical trials are part of the cancer research process.<EOS>
<BOS>Clinical trials are done to find out if new cancer treatments are safe and effective or better than the standard treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Many of today's standard treatments for cancer are based on earlier clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients who take part in a clinical trial may receive the standard treatment or be among the first to receive a new treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients who take part in clinical trials also help improve the way cancer will be treated in the future.<EOS>
<BOS>Even when clinical trials do not lead to effective new treatments, they often answer important questions and help move research forward.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients can enter clinical trials before, during, or after starting their cancer treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Some clinical trials only include patients who have not yet received treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Other trials test treatments for patients whose cancer has not gotten better.<EOS>
<BOS>There are also clinical trials that test new ways to stop cancer from recurring (coming back) or reduce the side effects of cancer treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Clinical trials are taking place in many parts of the country.<EOS>
<BOS>See the Treatment Options section that follows for links to current treatment clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>These have been retrieved from NCI's listing of clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>Followup tests may be needed.<EOS>
<BOS>Some of the tests that were done to diagnose the cancer may be repeated.<EOS>
<BOS>Some tests will be repeated in order to see how well the treatment is working.<EOS>
<BOS>Decisions about whether to continue, change, or stop treatment may be based on the results of these tests.<EOS>
<BOS>Some of the tests will continue to be done from time to time after treatment has ended.<EOS>
<BOS>The results of these tests can show if your child's condition has changed or if the cancer has recurred (come back).<EOS>
<BOS>These tests are sometimes called followup tests or checkups.<EOS>
<BOS>Treatment Options for Newly Diagnosed Childhood CNS Atypical Teratoid/Rhabdoid Tumor Key Points There is no standard treatment for patients with central nervous system atypical teratoid/rhabdoid tumor.<EOS>
<BOS>Combinations of treatments are used for patients with atypical teratoid/rhabdoid tumor.<EOS>
<BOS>There is no standard treatment for patients with central nervous system atypical teratoid/rhabdoid tumor.<EOS>
<BOS>Combinations of treatments are used for patients with atypical teratoid/rhabdoid tumor.<EOS>
<BOS>Because atypical teratoid/rhabdoid tumor (AT/RT) is fastgrowing, a combination of treatments is usually given.<EOS>
<BOS>After surgery to remove the tumor, treatments for AT/RT may include combinations of the following: Chemotherapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Radiation therapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Highdose chemotherapy with stem cell transplant.<EOS>
<BOS>Clinical trials of new treatments should be considered for patients with newly diagnosed atypical teratoid/rhabdoid tumor.<EOS>
<BOS>Key Points There are different types of treatment for patients with myelodysplastic syndromes.<EOS>
<BOS>Treatment for myelodysplastic syndromes includes supportive care, drug therapy, and stem cell transplantation.<EOS>
<BOS>Three types of standard treatment are used: Supportive care Drug therapy Chemotherapy with stem cell transplant New types of treatment are being tested in clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients may want to think about taking part in a clinical trial.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients can enter clinical trials before, during, or after starting their treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Followup tests may be needed.<EOS>
<BOS>There are different types of treatment for patients with myelodysplastic syndromes.<EOS>
<BOS>Different types of treatment are available for patients with myelodysplastic syndromes.<EOS>
<BOS>Some treatments are standard (the currently used treatment), and some are being tested in clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>A treatment clinical trial is a research study meant to help improve current treatments or obtain information on new treatments for patients with cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>When clinical trials show that a new treatment is better than the standard treatment, the new treatment may become the standard treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients may want to think about taking part in a clinical trial.<EOS>
<BOS>Some clinical trials are open only to patients who have not started treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Treatment for myelodysplastic syndromes includes supportive care, drug therapy, and stem cell transplantation.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients with a myelodysplastic syndrome who have symptoms caused by low blood counts are given supportive care to relieve symptoms and improve quality of life.<EOS>
<BOS>Drug therapy may be used to slow progression of the disease.<EOS>
<BOS>Certain patients can be cured with aggressive treatment with chemotherapy followed by stem cell transplant using stem cells from a donor.<EOS>
<BOS>Three types of standard treatment are used: Supportive care Supportive care is given to lessen the problems caused by the disease or its treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Supportive care may include the following: Transfusion therapy Transfusion therapy (blood transfusion) is a method of giving red blood cells, white blood cells, or platelets to replace blood cells destroyed by disease or treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>A red blood cell transfusion is given when the red blood cell count is low and signs or symptoms of anemia, such as shortness of breath or feeling very tired, occur.<EOS>
<BOS>A platelet transfusion is usually given when the patient is bleeding, is having a procedure that may cause bleeding, or when the platelet count is very low.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients who receive many blood cell transfusions may have tissue and organ damage caused by the buildup of extra iron.<EOS>
<BOS>These patients may be treated with iron chelation therapy to remove the extra iron from the blood.<EOS>
<BOS>Erythropoiesisstimulating agents Erythropoiesisstimulating agents (ESAs) may be given to increase the number of mature red blood cells made by the body and to lessen the effects of anemia.<EOS>
<BOS>Sometimes granulocyte colonystimulating factor (GCSF) is given with ESAs to help the treatment work better.<EOS>
<BOS>Antibiotic therapy Antibiotics may be given to fight infection.<EOS>
<BOS>Drug therapy Lenalidomide Patients with myelodysplastic syndrome associated with an isolated del(5q) chromosome abnormality who need frequent red blood cell transfusions may be treated with lenalidomide.<EOS>
<BOS>Lenalidomide is used to lessen the need for red blood cell transfusions.<EOS>
<BOS>Immunosuppressive therapy Antithymocyte globulin (ATG) works to suppress or weaken the immune system.<EOS>
<BOS>It is used to lessen the need for red blood cell transfusions.<EOS>
<BOS>Azacitidine and decitabine Azacitidine and decitabine are used to treat myelodysplastic syndromes by killing cells that are dividing rapidly.<EOS>
<BOS>They also help genes that are involved in cell growth to work the way they should.<EOS>
<BOS>Treatment with azacitidine and decitabine may slow the progression of myelodysplastic syndromes to acute myeloid leukemia.<EOS>
<BOS>Chemotherapy used in acute myeloid leukemia (AML) Patients with a myelodysplastic syndrome and a high number of blasts in their bone marrow have a high risk of acute leukemia.<EOS>
<BOS>They may be treated with the same chemotherapy regimen used in patients with acute myeloid leukemia.<EOS>
<BOS>Chemotherapy with stem cell transplant Stem cell transplant is a method of giving chemotherapy and replacing bloodforming cells destroyed by the treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Stem cells (immature blood cells) are removed from the blood or bone marrow of a donor and are frozen for storage.<EOS>
<BOS>After the chemotherapy is completed, the stored stem cells are thawed and given back to the patient through an infusion.<EOS>
<BOS>These reinfused stem cells grow into (and restore) the body's blood cells.<EOS>
<BOS>This treatment may not work as well in patients whose myelodysplastic syndrome was caused by past treatment for cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>New types of treatment are being tested in clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>Information about clinical trials is available from the NCI website.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients may want to think about taking part in a clinical trial.<EOS>
<BOS>For some patients, taking part in a clinical trial may be the best treatment choice.<EOS>
<BOS>Clinical trials are part of the cancer research process.<EOS>
<BOS>Clinical trials are done to find out if new cancer treatments are safe and effective or better than the standard treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Many of today's standard treatments for cancer are based on earlier clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients who take part in a clinical trial may receive the standard treatment or be among the first to receive a new treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients who take part in clinical trials also help improve the way cancer will be treated in the future.<EOS>
<BOS>Even when clinical trials do not lead to effective new treatments, they often answer important questions and help move research forward.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients can enter clinical trials before, during, or after starting their treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Some clinical trials only include patients who have not yet received treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Other trials test treatments for patients whose cancer has not gotten better.<EOS>
<BOS>There are also clinical trials that test new ways to stop cancer from recurring (coming back) or reduce the side effects of cancer treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Clinical trials are taking place in many parts of the country.<EOS>
<BOS>See the Treatment Options section that follows for links to current treatment clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>These have been retrieved from NCI's listing of clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>Followup tests may be needed.<EOS>
<BOS>Some of the tests that were done to diagnose the cancer or to find out the stage of the cancer may be repeated.<EOS>
<BOS>Some tests will be repeated in order to see how well the treatment is working.<EOS>
<BOS>Decisions about whether to continue, change, or stop treatment may be based on the results of these tests.<EOS>
<BOS>Some of the tests will continue to be done from time to time after treatment has ended.<EOS>
<BOS>The results of these tests can show if your condition has changed or if the cancer has recurred (come back).<EOS>
<BOS>These tests are sometimes called followup tests or checkups.<EOS>
<BOS>Age and gender can affect the risk of extragonadal germ cell tumors.<EOS>
<BOS>Anything that increases your chance of getting a disease is called a risk factor.<EOS>
<BOS>Having a risk factor does not mean that you will get cancer; not having risk factors doesnt mean that you will not get cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Talk with your doctor if you think you may be at risk.<EOS>
<BOS>Risk factors for malignant extragonadal germ cell tumors include the following: Being male.<EOS>
<BOS>Being age 20 or older.<EOS>
<BOS>Having Klinefelter syndrome.<EOS>
<BOS>Certain factors affect prognosis (chance of recovery) and treatment options.<EOS>
<BOS>The prognosis (chance of recovery) and treatment options depend on the following: The type of small intestine cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Whether the cancer is in the inner lining of the small intestine only or has spread into or beyond the wall of the small intestine.<EOS>
<BOS>Whether the cancer has spread to other places in the body, such as the lymph nodes, liver, or peritoneum (tissue that lines the wall of the abdomen and covers most of the organs in the abdomen).<EOS>
<BOS>Whether the cancer can be completely removed by surgery.<EOS>
<BOS>Whether the cancer is newly diagnosed or has recurred.<EOS>
<BOS>Certain factors affect prognosis (chance of recovery) and treatment options.<EOS>
<BOS>The prognosis (chance of recovery) and treatment options depend on the following: The stage of the cancer (whether it affects part of the nasopharynx, involves the whole nasopharynx, or has spread to other places in the body).<EOS>
<BOS>The type of nasopharyngeal cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>The size of the tumor.<EOS>
<BOS>The patients age and general health.<EOS>
<BOS>Certain diseases and disorders can increase the risk of childhood liver cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Anything that increases your chance of getting a disease is called a risk factor.<EOS>
<BOS>Having a risk factor does not mean that you will get cancer; not having risk factors doesnt mean that you will not get cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Talk with your childs doctor if you think your child may be at risk.<EOS>
<BOS>Risk factors for hepatoblastoma include the following syndromes or conditions: Aicardi syndrome.<EOS>
<BOS>BeckwithWiedemann syndrome.<EOS>
<BOS>Familial adenomatous polyposis (FAP).<EOS>
<BOS>Glycogen storage disease.<EOS>
<BOS>A very low weight at birth.<EOS>
<BOS>SimpsonGolabiBehmel syndrome.<EOS>
<BOS>Certain genetic changes, such as Trisomy 18.<EOS>
<BOS>Risk factors for hepatocellular carcinoma include the following syndromes or conditions: Alagille syndrome.<EOS>
<BOS>Glycogen storage disease.<EOS>
<BOS>Hepatitis B virus infection that was passed from mother to child at birth.<EOS>
<BOS>Progressive familial intrahepatic disease.<EOS>
<BOS>Tyrosinemia.<EOS>
<BOS>Some patients with tyrosinemia or progressive familial intrahepatic disease will have a liver transplant before there are signs or symptoms of cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>A condition called cryptorchidism (an undescended testicle) is a risk factor for testicular cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Anything that increases the chance of getting a disease is called a risk factor.<EOS>
<BOS>Having a risk factor does not mean that you will get cancer; not having risk factors doesn't mean that you will not get cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Talk to your doctor if you think you may be at risk.<EOS>
<BOS>Risk factors for testicular cancer include the following: Having cryptorchidism (an undescended testicle).<EOS>
<BOS>Having a testicle that is not normal, such as a small testicle that does not work the way it should.<EOS>
<BOS>Having testicular carcinoma in situ.<EOS>
<BOS>Being white.<EOS>
<BOS>Having a personal or family history of testicular cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Having Klinefelter syndrome.<EOS>
<BOS>Men who have cryptorchidism, a testicle that is not normal, or testicular carcinoma in situ have an increased risk of testicular cancer in one or both testicles, and need to be followed closely.<EOS>
<BOS>Key Points Salivary gland cancer is a rare disease in which malignant (cancer) cells form in the tissues of the salivary glands.<EOS>
<BOS>Being exposed to certain types of radiation may increase the risk of salivary cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Signs of salivary gland cancer include a lump or trouble swallowing.<EOS>
<BOS>Tests that examine the head, neck, and the inside of the mouth are used to detect (find) and diagnose salivary gland cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Certain factors affect treatment options and prognosis (chance of recovery).<EOS>
<BOS>Salivary gland cancer is a rare disease in which malignant (cancer) cells form in the tissues of the salivary glands.<EOS>
<BOS>The salivary glands make saliva and release it into the mouth.<EOS>
<BOS>Saliva has enzymes that help digest food and antibodies that help protect against infections of the mouth and throat.<EOS>
<BOS>There are 3 pairs of major salivary glands: Parotid glands: These are the largest salivary glands and are found in front of and just below each ear.<EOS>
<BOS>Most major salivary gland tumors begin in this gland.<EOS>
<BOS>Sublingual glands: These glands are found under the tongue in the floor of the mouth.<EOS>
<BOS>Submandibular glands: These glands are found below the jawbone.<EOS>
<BOS>There are also hundreds of small (minor) salivary glands lining parts of the mouth, nose, and larynx that can be seen only with a microscope.<EOS>
<BOS>Most small salivary gland tumors begin in the palate (roof of the mouth).<EOS>
<BOS>More than half of all salivary gland tumors are benign (not cancerous) and do not spread to other tissues.<EOS>
<BOS>Salivary gland cancer is a type of head and neck cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Tests that examine the blood and bone marrow are used to detect (find) and diagnose chronic myelogenous leukemia.<EOS>
<BOS>The following tests and procedures may be used: Physical exam and history : An exam of the body to check general signs of health, including checking for signs of disease such as an enlarged spleen.<EOS>
<BOS>A history of the patients health habits and past illnesses and treatments will also be taken.<EOS>
<BOS>Complete blood count (CBC) with differential : A procedure in which a sample of blood is drawn and checked for the following: The number of red blood cells and platelets.<EOS>
<BOS>The number and type of white blood cells.<EOS>
<BOS>The amount of hemoglobin (the protein that carries oxygen) in the red blood cells.<EOS>
<BOS>The portion of the blood sample made up of red blood cells.<EOS>
<BOS>Blood chemistry studies : A procedure in which a blood sample is checked to measure the amounts of certain substances released into the blood by organs and tissues in the body.<EOS>
<BOS>An unusual (higher or lower than normal) amount of a substance can be a sign of disease.<EOS>
<BOS>Bone marrow aspiration and biopsy : The removal of bone marrow, blood, and a small piece of bone by inserting a needle into the hipbone or breastbone.<EOS>
<BOS>A pathologist views the bone marrow, blood, and bone under a microscope to look for abnormal cells.<EOS>
<BOS>One of the following tests may be done on the samples of blood or bone marrow tissue that are removed: Cytogenetic analysis: A test in which cells in a sample of blood or bone marrow are viewed under a microscope to look for certain changes in the chromosomes, such as the Philadelphia chromosome.<EOS>
<BOS>FISH (fluorescence in situ hybridization): A laboratory technique used to look at genes or chromosomes in cells and tissues.<EOS>
<BOS>Pieces of DNA that contain a fluorescent dye are made in the laboratory and added to cells or tissues on a glass slide.<EOS>
<BOS>When these pieces of DNA bind to specific genes or areas of chromosomes on the slide, they light up when viewed under a microscope with a special light.<EOS>
<BOS>Reverse transcriptionpolymerase chain reaction (RTPCR): A laboratory test in which cells in a sample of tissue are studied using chemicals to look for certain changes in the structure or function of genes.<EOS>
<BOS>Key Points Avoiding risk factors and increasing protective factors may help prevent cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>The following risk factors increase the risk of colorectal cancer: Age Family history of colorectal cancer Personal history Inherited risk Alcohol Cigarette smoking Obesity The following protective factors decrease the risk of colorectal cancer: Physical activity Aspirin Combination hormone replacement therapy Polyp removal It is not clear if the following affect the risk of colorectal cancer: Nonsteroidal antiinflammatory drugs (NSAIDs) other than aspirin Calcium Diet The following factors do not affect the risk of colorectal cancer: Hormone replacement therapy with estrogen only Statins Cancer prevention clinical trials are used to study ways to prevent cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>New ways to prevent colorectal cancer are being studied in clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>Avoiding risk factors and increasing protective factors may help prevent cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Avoiding cancer risk factors may help prevent certain cancers.<EOS>
<BOS>Risk factors include smoking, being overweight, and not getting enough exercise.<EOS>
<BOS>Increasing protective factors such as quitting smoking and exercising may also help prevent some cancers.<EOS>
<BOS>Talk to your doctor or other health care professional about how you might lower your risk of cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>The following risk factors increase the risk of colorectal cancer: Age The risk of colorectal cancer increases after age 50.<EOS>
<BOS>Most cases of colorectal cancer are diagnosed after age 50.<EOS>
<BOS>Family history of colorectal cancer Having a parent, brother, sister, or child with colorectal cancer doubles a person's risk of colorectal cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Personal history Having a personal history of the following conditions increases the risk of colorectal cancer: Previous colorectal cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Highrisk adenomas (colorectal polyps that are 1 centimeter or larger in size or that have cells that look abnormal under a microscope).<EOS>
<BOS>Ovarian cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Inflammatory bowel disease (such as ulcerative colitis or Crohn disease).<EOS>
<BOS>Inherited risk The risk of colorectal cancer is increased when certain gene changes linked to familial adenomatous polyposis (FAP) or hereditary nonpolyposis colon cancer (HNPCC or Lynch Syndrome) are inherited.<EOS>
<BOS>Alcohol Drinking 3 or more alcoholic beverages per day increases the risk of colorectal cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Drinking alcohol is also linked to the risk of forming large colorectal adenomas (benign tumors).<EOS>
<BOS>Cigarette smoking Cigarette smoking is linked to an increased risk of colorectal cancer and death from colorectal cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Smoking cigarettes is also linked to an increased risk of forming colorectal adenomas.<EOS>
<BOS>Cigarette smokers who have had surgery to remove colorectal adenomas are at an increased risk for the adenomas to recur (come back).<EOS>
<BOS>Obesity Obesity is linked to an increased risk of colorectal cancer and death from colorectal cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>The following protective factors decrease the risk of colorectal cancer: Physical activity A lifestyle that includes regular physical activity is linked to a decreased risk of colorectal cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Aspirin Studies have shown that taking aspirin lowers the risk of colorectal cancer and the risk of death from colorectal cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>The decrease in risk begins 10 to 20 years after patients start taking aspirin.<EOS>
<BOS>The possible harms of aspirin use (100 mg or less) daily or every other day include an increased risk of stroke and bleeding in the stomach and intestines.<EOS>
<BOS>These risks may be greater among the elderly, men, and those with conditions linked to a higher than normal risk of bleeding.<EOS>
<BOS>Combination hormone replacement therapy Studies have shown that combination hormone replacement therapy (HRT) that includes both estrogen and progestin lowers the risk of invasive colorectal cancer in postmenopausal women.<EOS>
<BOS>However, in women who take combination HRT and do develop colorectal cancer, the cancer is more likely to be advanced when it is diagnosed and the risk of dying from colorectal cancer is not decreased.<EOS>
<BOS>The possible harms of combination HRT include an increased risk of having: Breast cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Heart disease.<EOS>
<BOS>Blood clots.<EOS>
<BOS>Polyp removal Most colorectal polyps are adenomas, which may develop into cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Removing colorectal polyps that are larger than 1 centimeter (peasized) may lower the risk of colorectal cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>It is not known if removing smaller polyps lowers the risk of colorectal cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>The possible harms of polyp removal during colonoscopy or sigmoidoscopy include a tear in the wall of the colon and bleeding.<EOS>
<BOS>It is not clear if the following affect the risk of colorectal cancer: Nonsteroidal antiinflammatory drugs (NSAIDs) other than aspirin It is not known if the use of nonsteroidal antiinflammatory drugs or NSAIDs (such as sulindac, celecoxib, naproxen, and ibuprofen) lowers the risk of colorectal cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Studies have shown that taking the nonsteroidal antiinflammatory drug celecoxib reduces the risk of colorectal adenomas (benign tumors) coming back after they have been removed.<EOS>
<BOS>It is not clear if this results in a lower risk of colorectal cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Taking sulindac or celecoxib has been shown to reduce the number and size of polyps that form in the colon and rectum of people with familial adenomatous polyposis (FAP).<EOS>
<BOS>It is not clear if this results in a lower risk of colorectal cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>The possible harms of NSAIDs include: Kidney problems.<EOS>
<BOS>Bleeding in the stomach, intestines, or brain.<EOS>
<BOS>Heart problems such as heart attack and congestive heart failure.<EOS>
<BOS>Calcium It is not known if taking calcium supplements lowers the risk of colorectal cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Diet It is not known if a diet low in fat and meat and high in fiber, fruits, and vegetables lowers the risk of colorectal cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Some studies have shown that a diet high in fat, proteins, calories, and meat increases the risk of colorectal cancer, but other studies have not.<EOS>
<BOS>The following factors do not affect the risk of colorectal cancer: Hormone replacement therapy with estrogen only Hormone replacement therapy with estrogen only does not lower the risk of having invasive colorectal cancer or the risk of dying from colorectal cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Statins Studies have shown that taking statins (drugs that lower cholesterol) does not increase or decrease the risk of colorectal cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Cancer prevention clinical trials are used to study ways to prevent cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Cancer prevention clinical trials are used to study ways to lower the risk of developing certain types of cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Some cancer prevention trials are conducted with healthy people who have not had cancer but who have an increased risk for cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Other prevention trials are conducted with people who have had cancer and are trying to prevent another cancer of the same type or to lower their chance of developing a new type of cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Other trials are done with healthy volunteers who are not known to have any risk factors for cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>The purpose of some cancer prevention clinical trials is to find out whether actions people take can prevent cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>These may include exercising more or quitting smoking or taking certain medicines, vitamins, minerals, or food supplements.<EOS>
<BOS>New ways to prevent colorectal cancer are being studied in clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>Clinical trials are taking place in many parts of the country.<EOS>
<BOS>Information about clinical trials can be found in the Clinical Trials section of the NCI website.<EOS>
<BOS>Check NCI's list of cancer clinical trials for colon cancer prevention trials or rectal cancer prevention trials that are now accepting patients.<EOS>
<BOS>Key Points There are different types of treatment for children with Ewing sarcoma.<EOS>
<BOS>Children with Ewing sarcoma should have their treatment planned by a team of health care providers who are experts in treating cancer in children.<EOS>
<BOS>Treatment for Ewing sarcoma may cause side effects.<EOS>
<BOS>Five types of standard treatment are used: Chemotherapy Radiation therapy Surgery Targeted therapy Highdose chemotherapy with stem cell rescue New types of treatment are being tested in clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>Chimeric antigen receptor (CAR) Tcell therapy Patients may want to think about taking part in a clinical trial.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients can enter clinical trials before, during, or after starting their cancer treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Followup tests may be needed.<EOS>
<BOS>There are different types of treatment for children with Ewing sarcoma.<EOS>
<BOS>Different types of treatments are available for children with Ewing sarcoma.<EOS>
<BOS>Some treatments are standard (the currently used treatment), and some are being tested in clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>A treatment clinical trial is a research study meant to help improve current treatments or obtain information on new treatments for patients with cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>When clinical trials show that a new treatment is better than the standard treatment, the new treatment may become the standard treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Because cancer in children is rare, taking part in a clinical trial should be considered.<EOS>
<BOS>Some clinical trials are open only to patients who have not started treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Children with Ewing sarcoma should have their treatment planned by a team of health care providers who are experts in treating cancer in children.<EOS>
<BOS>Treatment will be overseen by a pediatric oncologist, a doctor who specializes in treating children with cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>The pediatric oncologist works with other health care providers who are experts in treating children with Ewing sarcoma and who specialize in certain areas of medicine.<EOS>
<BOS>These may include the following specialists: Pediatrician.<EOS>
<BOS>Surgical oncologist or orthopedic oncologist.<EOS>
<BOS>Radiation oncologist.<EOS>
<BOS>Pediatric nurse specialist.<EOS>
<BOS>Social worker.<EOS>
<BOS>Rehabilitation specialist.<EOS>
<BOS>Psychologist.<EOS>
<BOS>Treatment for Ewing sarcoma may cause side effects.<EOS>
<BOS>For information about side effects that begin during treatment for cancer, see our Side Effects page.<EOS>
<BOS>Side effects from cancer treatment that begin after treatment and continue for months or years are called late effects.<EOS>
<BOS>Late effects of cancer treatment may include the following: Physical problems.<EOS>
<BOS>Changes in mood, feelings, thinking, learning, or memory.<EOS>
<BOS>Second cancers (new types of cancer).<EOS>
<BOS>Patients treated for Ewing sarcoma have an increased risk of acute myeloid leukemia and myelodysplastic syndrome.<EOS>
<BOS>There is also an increased risk of sarcoma in the area treated with radiation therapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Some late effects may be treated or controlled.<EOS>
<BOS>It is important to talk with your child's doctors about the effects cancer treatment can have on your child.<EOS>
<BOS>(See the PDQ summary on Late Effects of Treatment for Childhood Cancer for more information.<EOS>
<BOS>) Five types of standard treatment are used: Chemotherapy Chemotherapy is a cancer treatment that uses drugs to stop the growth of cancer cells, either by killing the cells or by stopping them from dividing.<EOS>
<BOS>When chemotherapy is taken by mouth or injected into a vein or muscle, the drugs enter the bloodstream and can reach cancer cells throughout the body (systemic chemotherapy).<EOS>
<BOS>When chemotherapy is placed directly into the cerebrospinal fluid, an organ, or a body cavity such as the abdomen, the drugs mainly affect cancer cells in those areas (regional chemotherapy).<EOS>
<BOS>Combination chemotherapy is treatment using more than one anticancer drug.<EOS>
<BOS>Systemic chemotherapy is part of the treatment for all patients with Ewing tumors.<EOS>
<BOS>It is often the first treatment given and lasts for about 6 to 12 months.<EOS>
<BOS>Chemotherapy is often given to shrink the tumor before surgery or radiation therapy and to kill any tumor cells that may have spread to other parts of the body.<EOS>
<BOS>See Drugs Approved for Soft Tissue Sarcoma for more information.<EOS>
<BOS>Radiation therapy Radiation therapy is a cancer treatment that uses highenergy xrays or other types of radiation to kill cancer cells or keep them from growing.<EOS>
<BOS>There are two types of radiation therapy: External radiation therapy uses a machine outside the body to send radiation toward the cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Internal radiation therapy uses a radioactive substance sealed in needles, seeds, wires, or catheters that are placed directly into or near the cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>External radiation therapy is used to treat Ewing sarcoma.<EOS>
<BOS>Radiation therapy is used when the tumor cannot be removed by surgery or when surgery to remove the tumor will affect important body functions or the way the child will look.<EOS>
<BOS>It may be used to make the tumor smaller and decrease the amount of tissue that needs to be removed during surgery.<EOS>
<BOS>It may also be used to treat any tumor that remains after surgery and tumors that have spread to other parts of the body.<EOS>
<BOS>Surgery Surgery is usually done to remove cancer that is left after chemotherapy or radiation therapy.<EOS>
<BOS>When possible, the whole tumor is removed by surgery.<EOS>
<BOS>Tissue and bone that are removed may be replaced with a graft, which uses tissue and bone taken from another part of the patient's body or a donor.<EOS>
<BOS>Sometimes an implant, such as artificial bone, is used.<EOS>
<BOS>Even if the doctor removes all of the cancer that can be seen at the time of the operation, chemotherapy or radiation therapy may be given after surgery to kill any cancer cells that are left.<EOS>
<BOS>Chemotherapy or radiation therapy given after surgery to lower the risk that the cancer will come back is called adjuvant therapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Targeted therapy Targeted therapy is a type of treatment that uses drugs or other substances to identify and attack specific cancer cells without harming normal cells.<EOS>
<BOS>Monoclonal antibody therapy is a type of targeted therapy used in the treatment of recurrent Ewing sarcoma.<EOS>
<BOS>It is being studied for the treatment of metastatic Ewing sarcoma.<EOS>
<BOS>Monoclonal antibodies are made in the laboratory from a single type of immune system cell.<EOS>
