<BOS>These antibodies can identify substances on cancer cells or normal substances that may help cancer cells grow.<EOS>
<BOS>The antibodies attach to the substances and kill the cancer cells, block their growth, or keep them from spreading.<EOS>
<BOS>Monoclonal antibodies are given by infusion.<EOS>
<BOS>They may be used alone or to carry drugs, toxins, or radioactive material directly to cancer cells.<EOS>
<BOS>New types of targeted therapy are being studied.<EOS>
<BOS>Kinase inhibitor therapy is another type of targeted therapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Kinase inhibitors are drugs that block a protein needed for cancer cells to divide.<EOS>
<BOS>They are being studied in the treatment of recurrent Ewing sarcoma.<EOS>
<BOS>PARP inhibitor therapy is another type of targeted therapy.<EOS>
<BOS>PARP inhibitors are drugs that block DNA repair and may cause cancer cells to die.<EOS>
<BOS>They are being studied in the treatment of recurrent Ewing sarcoma.<EOS>
<BOS>Highdose chemotherapy with stem cell rescue Highdose chemotherapy with stem cell rescue is a way of giving high doses of chemotherapy to treat Ewing sarcoma and then replacing blood forming cells destroyed by cancer treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Stem cells (immature blood cells) are removed from the blood or bone marrow of the patient and are frozen and stored.<EOS>
<BOS>After chemotherapy is completed, the stored stem cells are thawed and given back to the patient through an infusion.<EOS>
<BOS>These reinfused stem cells grow into (and restore) the body's blood cells.<EOS>
<BOS>Chemotherapy with stem cell rescue is used to treat recurrent Ewing sarcoma.<EOS>
<BOS>New types of treatment are being tested in clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>This summary section describes treatments that are being studied in clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>It may not mention every new treatment being studied.<EOS>
<BOS>Information about clinical trials is available from the NCI website.<EOS>
<BOS>Chimeric antigen receptor (CAR) Tcell therapy CAR Tcell therapy is a type of immunotherapy that changes the patient's T cells (a type of immune system cell) so they will attack certain proteins on the surface of cancer cells.<EOS>
<BOS>T cells are taken from the patient and special receptors are added to their surface in the laboratory.<EOS>
<BOS>The changed cells are called chimeric antigen receptor (CAR) T cells.<EOS>
<BOS>The CAR T cells are grown in the laboratory and given to the patient by infusion.<EOS>
<BOS>The CAR T cells multiply in the patient's blood and attack cancer cells.<EOS>
<BOS>CAR Tcell therapy is being studied in the treatment of Ewing sarcoma that has recurred.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients may want to think about taking part in a clinical trial.<EOS>
<BOS>For some patients, taking part in a clinical trial may be the best treatment choice.<EOS>
<BOS>Clinical trials are part of the cancer research process.<EOS>
<BOS>Clinical trials are done to find out if new cancer treatments are safe and effective or better than the standard treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Many of today's standard treatments for cancer are based on earlier clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients who take part in a clinical trial may receive the standard treatment or be among the first to receive a new treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients who take part in clinical trials also help improve the way cancer will be treated in the future.<EOS>
<BOS>Even when clinical trials do not lead to effective new treatments, they often answer important questions and help move research forward.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients can enter clinical trials before, during, or after starting their cancer treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Some clinical trials only include patients who have not yet received treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Other trials test treatments for patients whose cancer has not gotten better.<EOS>
<BOS>There are also clinical trials that test new ways to stop cancer from recurring (coming back) or reduce the side effects of cancer treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Clinical trials are taking place in many parts of the country.<EOS>
<BOS>See the Treatment Options section that follows for links to current treatment clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>These have been retrieved from NCI's listing of clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>Followup tests may be needed.<EOS>
<BOS>Some of the tests that were done to diagnose the cancer or to find out the stage of the cancer may be repeated.<EOS>
<BOS>Some tests will be repeated in order to see how well the treatment is working.<EOS>
<BOS>Decisions about whether to continue, change, or stop treatment may be based on the results of these tests.<EOS>
<BOS>Some of the tests will continue to be done from time to time after treatment has ended.<EOS>
<BOS>The results of these tests can show if your child's condition has changed or if the cancer has recurred (come back).<EOS>
<BOS>These tests are sometimes called followup tests or checkups.<EOS>
<BOS>Treatment Options for Ewing Sarcoma Localized Ewing Sarcoma Standard treatments for localized Ewing sarcoma include: Chemotherapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Surgery and/or radiation therapy.<EOS>
<BOS>These treatments and the order they are given depend on the following: Where in the body the tumor started.<EOS>
<BOS>How large the tumor is when the cancer is diagnosed.<EOS>
<BOS>Whether the tumor was completely removed by surgery.<EOS>
<BOS>The child's age and general health.<EOS>
<BOS>Whether the treatment will affect important body functions or the way the child will look.<EOS>
<BOS>Treatments being studied for localized Ewing sarcoma include: Highdose chemotherapy with stem cell rescue.<EOS>
<BOS>Check the list of NCIsupported cancer clinical trials that are now accepting patients with localized Ewing sarcoma/peripheral primitive neuroectodermal tumor.<EOS>
<BOS>For more specific results, refine the search by using other search features, such as the location of the trial, the type of treatment, or the name of the drug.<EOS>
<BOS>Talk with your child's doctor about clinical trials that may be right for your child.<EOS>
<BOS>General information about clinical trials is available from the NCI website.<EOS>
<BOS>Metastatic Ewing Sarcoma Standard treatments for metastatic Ewing sarcoma include: Chemotherapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Surgery.<EOS>
<BOS>Radiation therapy.<EOS>
<BOS>These treatments and the order they are given depend on the following: Where in the body the tumor started.<EOS>
<BOS>Where the tumor has spread.<EOS>
<BOS>How large the tumor is.<EOS>
<BOS>Whether the treatment will affect important body functions or the way the child will look.<EOS>
<BOS>The child's age and general health.<EOS>
<BOS>Treatments being studied for metastatic Ewing sarcoma include the following: Combination chemotherapy with or without targeted therapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Radiation therapy is given to areas of bone where cancer has spread.<EOS>
<BOS>Highdose chemotherapy with stem cell rescue.<EOS>
<BOS>Check the list of NCIsupported cancer clinical trials that are now accepting patients with metastatic Ewing sarcoma/peripheral primitive neuroectodermal tumor.<EOS>
<BOS>For more specific results, refine the search by using other search features, such as the location of the trial, the type of treatment, or the name of the drug.<EOS>
<BOS>Talk with your child's doctor about clinical trials that may be right for your child.<EOS>
<BOS>General information about clinical trials is available from the NCI website.<EOS>
<BOS>Recurrent Ewing Sarcoma There is no standard treatment for recurrent Ewing sarcoma but treatment options may include the following: Combination chemotherapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Radiation therapy to bone tumors, as palliative therapy to relieve symptoms and improve the quality of life.<EOS>
<BOS>Radiation therapy that may be followed by surgery to remove tumors that have spread to the lungs.<EOS>
<BOS>Highdose chemotherapy with stem cell rescue.<EOS>
<BOS>Targeted therapy with a monoclonal antibody.<EOS>
<BOS>These treatments and the order they are given depend on the following: Where in the body the tumor came back.<EOS>
<BOS>The initial treatment given.<EOS>
<BOS>Treatment options being studied for recurrent Ewing sarcoma include the following: Targeted therapy with a monoclonal antibody.<EOS>
<BOS>Chimeric antigen receptor (CAR) Tcell therapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Targeted therapy with a PARP inhibitor and chemotherapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Check the list of NCIsupported cancer clinical trials that are now accepting patients with recurrent Ewing sarcoma/peripheral primitive neuroectodermal tumor.<EOS>
<BOS>For more specific results, refine the search by using other search features, such as the location of the trial, the type of treatment, or the name of the drug.<EOS>
<BOS>Talk with your child's doctor about clinical trials that may be right for your child.<EOS>
<BOS>General information about clinical trials is available from the NCI website.<EOS>
<BOS>Key Points After penile cancer has been diagnosed, tests are done to find out if cancer cells have spread within the penis or to other parts of the body.<EOS>
<BOS>There are three ways that cancer spreads in the body.<EOS>
<BOS>Cancer may spread from where it began to other parts of the body.<EOS>
<BOS>The following stages are used for penile cancer: Stage 0 (Carcinoma in Situ) Stage I Stage II Stage III Stage IV After penile cancer has been diagnosed, tests are done to find out if cancer cells have spread within the penis or to other parts of the body.<EOS>
<BOS>The process used to find out if cancer has spread within the penis or to other parts of the body is called staging.<EOS>
<BOS>The information gathered from the staging process determines the stage of the disease.<EOS>
<BOS>It is important to know the stage in order to plan treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>The following tests and procedures may be used in the staging process: CT scan (CAT scan): A procedure that makes a series of detailed pictures of areas inside the body, taken from different angles.<EOS>
<BOS>The pictures are made by a computer linked to an xray machine.<EOS>
<BOS>A dye may be injected into a vein or swallowed to help the organs or tissues show up more clearly.<EOS>
<BOS>This procedure is also called computed tomography, computerized tomography, or computerized axial tomography.<EOS>
<BOS>MRI (magnetic resonance imaging): A procedure that uses a magnet, radio waves, and a computer to make a series of detailed pictures of areas inside the body.<EOS>
<BOS>A substance called gadolinium is injected into a vein.<EOS>
<BOS>The gadolinium collects around the cancer cells so they show up brighter in the picture.<EOS>
<BOS>This procedure is also called nuclear magnetic resonance imaging (NMRI).<EOS>
<BOS>Ultrasound exam: A procedure in which highenergy sound waves (ultrasound) are bounced off internal tissues or organs and make echoes.<EOS>
<BOS>The echoes form a picture of body tissues called a sonogram.<EOS>
<BOS>Chest xray : An xray of the organs and bones inside the chest.<EOS>
<BOS>An xray is a type of energy beam that can go through the body and onto film, making a picture of areas inside the body.<EOS>
<BOS>Biopsy : The removal of cells or tissues so they can be viewed under a microscope by a pathologist to check for signs of cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>The tissue sample is removed during one of the following procedures: Sentinel lymph node biopsy : The removal of the sentinel lymph node during surgery.<EOS>
<BOS>The sentinel lymph node is the first lymph node to receive lymphatic drainage from a tumor.<EOS>
<BOS>It is the first lymph node the cancer is likely to spread to from the tumor.<EOS>
<BOS>A radioactive substance and/or blue dye is injected near the tumor.<EOS>
<BOS>The substance or dye flows through the lymph ducts to the lymph nodes.<EOS>
<BOS>The first lymph node to receive the substance or dye is removed.<EOS>
<BOS>A pathologist views the tissue under a microscope to look for cancer cells.<EOS>
<BOS>If cancer cells are not found, it may not be necessary to remove more lymph nodes.<EOS>
<BOS>Lymph node dissection : A procedure to remove one or more lymph nodes during surgery.<EOS>
<BOS>A sample of tissue is checked under a microscope for signs of cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>This procedure is also called a lymphadenectomy.<EOS>
<BOS>There are three ways that cancer spreads in the body.<EOS>
<BOS>Cancer can spread through tissue, the lymph system, and the blood: Tissue.<EOS>
<BOS>The cancer spreads from where it began by growing into nearby areas.<EOS>
<BOS>Lymph system.<EOS>
<BOS>The cancer spreads from where it began by getting into the lymph system.<EOS>
<BOS>The cancer travels through the lymph vessels to other parts of the body.<EOS>
<BOS>Blood.<EOS>
<BOS>The cancer spreads from where it began by getting into the blood.<EOS>
<BOS>The cancer travels through the blood vessels to other parts of the body.<EOS>
<BOS>Cancer may spread from where it began to other parts of the body.<EOS>
<BOS>When cancer spreads to another part of the body, it is called metastasis.<EOS>
<BOS>Cancer cells break away from where they began (the primary tumor) and travel through the lymph system or blood.<EOS>
<BOS>Lymph system.<EOS>
<BOS>The cancer gets into the lymph system, travels through the lymph vessels, and forms a tumor (metastatic tumor) in another part of the body.<EOS>
<BOS>Blood.<EOS>
<BOS>The cancer gets into the blood, travels through the blood vessels, and forms a tumor (metastatic tumor) in another part of the body.<EOS>
<BOS>The metastatic tumor is the same type of cancer as the primary tumor.<EOS>
<BOS>For example, if penile cancer spreads to the lung, the cancer cells in the lung are actually penile cancer cells.<EOS>
<BOS>The disease is metastatic penile cancer, not lung cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>The following stages are used for penile cancer: Stage 0 (Carcinoma in Situ) In stage 0, abnormal cells or growths that look like warts are found on the surface of the skin of the penis.<EOS>
<BOS>These abnormal cells or growths may become cancer and spread into nearby normal tissue.<EOS>
<BOS>Stage 0 is also called carcinoma in situ.<EOS>
<BOS>Stage I In stage I, cancer has formed and spread to connective tissue just under the skin of the penis.<EOS>
<BOS>Cancer has not spread to lymph vessels or blood vessels.<EOS>
<BOS>The tumor cells look a lot like normal cells under a microscope.<EOS>
<BOS>Stage II In stage II, cancer has spread: to connective tissue just under the skin of the penis.<EOS>
<BOS>Also, cancer has spread to lymph vessels or blood vessels or the tumor cells may look very different from normal cells under a microscope; or through connective tissue to erectile tissue (spongy tissue that fills with blood to make an erection); or beyond erectile tissue to the urethra.<EOS>
<BOS>Stage III Stage III is divided into stage IIIa and stage IIIb.<EOS>
<BOS>In stage IIIa, cancer has spread to one lymph node in the groin.<EOS>
<BOS>Cancer has also spread: to connective tissue just under the skin of the penis.<EOS>
<BOS>Also, cancer may have spread to lymph vessels or blood vessels or the tumor cells may look very different from normal cells under a microscope; or through connective tissue to erectile tissue (spongy tissue that fills with blood to make an erection); or beyond erectile tissue to the urethra.<EOS>
<BOS>In stage IIIb, cancer has spread to more than one lymph node on one side of the groin or to lymph nodes on both sides of the groin.<EOS>
<BOS>Cancer has also spread: to connective tissue just under the skin of the penis.<EOS>
<BOS>Also, cancer may have spread to lymph vessels or blood vessels or the tumor cells may look very different from normal cells under a microscope; or through connective tissue to erectile tissue (spongy tissue that fills with blood to make an erection); or beyond erectile tissue to the urethra.<EOS>
<BOS>Stage IV In stage IV, cancer has spread: to tissues near the penis such as the prostate, and may have spread to lymph nodes in the groin or pelvis; or to one or more lymph nodes in the pelvis, or cancer has spread from the lymph nodes to the tissues around the lymph nodes; or to distant parts of the body.<EOS>
<BOS>Key Points Uterine sarcoma is a disease in which malignant (cancer) cells form in the muscles of the uterus or other tissues that support the uterus.<EOS>
<BOS>Being exposed to xrays can increase the risk of uterine sarcoma.<EOS>
<BOS>Signs of uterine sarcoma include abnormal bleeding.<EOS>
<BOS>Tests that examine the uterus are used to detect (find) and diagnose uterine sarcoma.<EOS>
<BOS>Certain factors affect prognosis (chance of recovery) and treatment options.<EOS>
<BOS>Uterine sarcoma is a disease in which malignant (cancer) cells form in the muscles of the uterus or other tissues that support the uterus.<EOS>
<BOS>The uterus is part of the female reproductive system.<EOS>
<BOS>The uterus is the hollow, pearshaped organ in the pelvis, where a fetus grows.<EOS>
<BOS>The cervix is at the lower, narrow end of the uterus, and leads to the vagina.<EOS>
<BOS>Uterine sarcoma is a very rare kind of cancer that forms in the uterine muscles or in tissues that support the uterus.<EOS>
<BOS>(Information about other types of sarcomas can be found in the PDQ summary on Adult Soft Tissue Sarcoma Treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>) Uterine sarcoma is different from cancer of the endometrium, a disease in which cancer cells start growing inside the lining of the uterus.<EOS>
<BOS>(See the PDQ summary on Endometrial Cancer Treatment for information).<EOS>
<BOS>Key Points Primary myelofibrosis is a disease in which abnormal blood cells and fibers build up inside the bone marrow.<EOS>
<BOS>Symptoms of primary myelofibrosis include pain below the ribs on the left side and feeling very tired.<EOS>
<BOS>Certain factors affect prognosis (chance of recovery) and treatment options for primary myelofibrosis.<EOS>
<BOS>Primary myelofibrosis is a disease in which abnormal blood cells and fibers build up inside the bone marrow.<EOS>
<BOS>The bone marrow is made of tissues that make blood cells (red blood cells, white blood cells, and platelets) and a web of fibers that support the bloodforming tissues.<EOS>
<BOS>In primary myelofibrosis (also called chronic idiopathic myelofibrosis), large numbers of blood stem cells become blood cells that do not mature properly (blasts).<EOS>
<BOS>The web of fibers inside the bone marrow also becomes very thick (like scar tissue) and slows the bloodforming tissues ability to make blood cells.<EOS>
<BOS>This causes the bloodforming tissues to make fewer and fewer blood cells.<EOS>
<BOS>In order to make up for the low number of blood cells made in the bone marrow, the liver and spleen begin to make the blood cells.<EOS>
<BOS>Key Points Hairy cell leukemia is a type of cancer in which the bone marrow makes too many lymphocytes (a type of white blood cell).<EOS>
<BOS>Leukemia may affect red blood cells, white blood cells, and platelets.<EOS>
<BOS>Gender and age may affect the risk of hairy cell leukemia.<EOS>
<BOS>Signs and symptoms of hairy cell leukemia include infections, tiredness, and pain below the ribs.<EOS>
<BOS>Tests that examine the blood and bone marrow are used to detect (find) and diagnose hairy cell leukemia.<EOS>
<BOS>Certain factors affect treatment options and prognosis (chance of recovery).<EOS>
<BOS>Hairy cell leukemia is a type of cancer in which the bone marrow makes too many lymphocytes (a type of white blood cell).<EOS>
<BOS>Hairy cell leukemia is a cancer of the blood and bone marrow.<EOS>
<BOS>This rare type of leukemia gets worse slowly or does not get worse at all.<EOS>
<BOS>The disease is called hairy cell leukemia because the leukemia cells look "hairy" when viewed under a microscope.<EOS>
<BOS>Leukemia may affect red blood cells, white blood cells, and platelets.<EOS>
<BOS>Normally, the bone marrow makes blood stem cells (immature cells) that become mature blood cells over time.<EOS>
<BOS>A blood stem cell may become a myeloid stem cell or a lymphoid stem cell.<EOS>
<BOS>A myeloid stem cell becomes one of three types of mature blood cells: Red blood cells that carry oxygen and other substances to all tissues of the body.<EOS>
<BOS>White blood cells that fight infection and disease.<EOS>
<BOS>Platelets that form blood clots to stop bleeding.<EOS>
<BOS>A lymphoid stem cell becomes a lymphoblast cell and then into one of three types of lymphocytes (white blood cells): B lymphocytes that make antibodies to help fight infection.<EOS>
<BOS>T lymphocytes that help B lymphocytes make antibodies to help fight infection.<EOS>
<BOS>Natural killer cells that attack cancer cells and viruses.<EOS>
<BOS>In hairy cell leukemia, too many blood stem cells become lymphocytes.<EOS>
<BOS>These lymphocytes are abnormal and do not become healthy white blood cells.<EOS>
<BOS>They are also called leukemia cells.<EOS>
<BOS>The leukemia cells can build up in the blood and bone marrow so there is less room for healthy white blood cells, red blood cells, and platelets.<EOS>
<BOS>This may cause infection, anemia, and easy bleeding.<EOS>
<BOS>Some of the leukemia cells may collect in the spleen and cause it to swell.<EOS>
<BOS>This summary is about hairy cell leukemia.<EOS>
<BOS>See the following PDQ summaries for information about other types of leukemia: Adult Acute Lymphoblastic Leukemia Treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Childhood Acute Lymphoblastic Leukemia Treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Chronic Lymphocytic Leukemia Treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Adult Acute Myeloid Leukemia Treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Childhood Acute Myeloid Leukemia/Other Myeloid Malignancies Treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Chronic Myelogenous Leukemia Treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Key Points After ovarian low malignant potential tumor has been diagnosed, tests are done to find out if abnormal cells have spread within the ovary or to other parts of the body.<EOS>
<BOS>The following stages are used for ovarian low malignant potential tumor: Stage I Stage II Stage III Stage IV After ovarian low malignant potential tumor has been diagnosed, tests are done to find out if abnormal cells have spread within the ovary or to other parts of the body.<EOS>
<BOS>The process used to find out whether abnormal cells have spread within the ovary or to other parts of the body is called staging.<EOS>
<BOS>The information gathered from the staging process determines the stage of the disease.<EOS>
<BOS>It is important to know the stage in order to plan treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Certain tests or procedures are used for staging.<EOS>
<BOS>Staging laparotomy (a surgical incision made in the wall of the abdomen to remove ovarian tissue) may be used.<EOS>
<BOS>Most patients are diagnosed with stage I disease.<EOS>
<BOS>The following stages are used for ovarian low malignant potential tumor: Stage I In stage I, the tumor is found in one or both ovaries.<EOS>
<BOS>Stage I is divided into stage IA, stage IB, and stage IC.<EOS>
<BOS>Stage IA: The tumor is found inside a single ovary.<EOS>
<BOS>Stage IB: The tumor is found inside both ovaries.<EOS>
<BOS>Stage IC: The tumor is found inside one or both ovaries and one of the following is true: tumor cells are found on the outside surface of one or both ovaries; or the capsule (outer covering) of the ovary has ruptured (broken open); or tumor cells are found in the fluid of the peritoneal cavity (the body cavity that contains most of the organs in the abdomen) or in washings of the peritoneum (tissue lining the peritoneal cavity).<EOS>
<BOS>Stage II In stage II, the tumor is found in one or both ovaries and has spread into other areas of the pelvis.<EOS>
<BOS>Stage II is divided into stage IIA, stage IIB, and stage IIC.<EOS>
<BOS>Stage IIA: The tumor has spread to the uterus and/or fallopian tubes (the long slender tubes through which eggs pass from the ovaries to the uterus).<EOS>
<BOS>Stage IIB: The tumor has spread to other tissue within the pelvis.<EOS>
<BOS>Stage IIC: The tumor is found inside one or both ovaries and has spread to the uterus and/or fallopian tubes, or to other tissue within the pelvis.<EOS>
<BOS>Also, one of the following is true: tumor cells are found on the outside surface of one or both ovaries; or the capsule (outer covering) of the ovary has ruptured (broken open); or tumor cells are found in the fluid of the peritoneal cavity (the body cavity that contains most of the organs in the abdomen) or in washings of the peritoneum (tissue lining the peritoneal cavity).<EOS>
<BOS>Stage III In stage III, the tumor is found in one or both ovaries and has spread outside the pelvis to other parts of the abdomen and/or nearby lymph nodes.<EOS>
<BOS>Stage III is divided into stage IIIA, stage IIIB, and stage IIIC.<EOS>
<BOS>Stage IIIA: The tumor is found in the pelvis only, but tumor cells that can be seen only with a microscope have spread to the surface of the peritoneum (tissue that lines the abdominal wall and covers most of the organs in the abdomen), the small intestines, or the tissue that connects the small intestines to the wall of the abdomen.<EOS>
<BOS>Stage IIIB: The tumor has spread to the peritoneum and the tumor in the peritoneum is 2 centimeters or smaller.<EOS>
<BOS>Stage IIIC: The tumor has spread to the peritoneum and the tumor in the peritoneum is larger than 2 centimeters and/or has spread to lymph nodes in the abdomen.<EOS>
<BOS>The spread of tumor cells to the surface of the liver is also considered stage III disease.<EOS>
<BOS>Stage IV In stage IV, tumor cells have spread beyond the abdomen to other parts of the body, such as the lungs or tissue inside the liver.<EOS>
<BOS>Tumor cells in the fluid around the lungs is also considered stage IV disease.<EOS>
<BOS>Ovarian low malignant potential tumors almost never reach stage IV.<EOS>
<BOS>Key Points Chronic eosinophilic leukemia is a disease in which too many white blood cells (eosinophils) are made in the bone marrow.<EOS>
<BOS>Signs and symptoms of chronic eosinophilic leukemia include fever and feeling very tired.<EOS>
<BOS>Chronic eosinophilic leukemia is a disease in which too many white blood cells (eosinophils) are made in the bone marrow.<EOS>
<BOS>Eosinophils are white blood cells that react to allergens (substances that cause an allergic response) and help fight infections caused by certain parasites.<EOS>
<BOS>In chronic eosinophilic leukemia, there are too many eosinophils in the blood, bone marrow, and other tissues.<EOS>
<BOS>Chronic eosinophilic leukemia may stay the same for many years or it may progress quickly to acute leukemia.<EOS>
<BOS>Tests that examine the brain and spinal cord are used to detect (find) childhood ependymoma.<EOS>
<BOS>The following tests and procedures may be used: Physical exam and history : An exam of the body to check general signs of health, including checking for signs of disease, such as lumps or anything else that seems unusual.<EOS>
<BOS>A history of the patients health habits and past illnesses and treatments will also be taken.<EOS>
<BOS>Neurological exam : A series of questions and tests to check the brain, spinal cord, and nerve function.<EOS>
<BOS>The exam checks a persons mental status, coordination, and ability to walk normally, and how well the muscles, senses, and reflexes work.<EOS>
<BOS>This may also be called a neuro exam or a neurologic exam.<EOS>
<BOS>MRI (magnetic resonance imaging) with gadolinium : A procedure that uses a magnet, radio waves, and a computer to make a series of detailed pictures of areas inside the brain and spinal cord.<EOS>
<BOS>A substance called gadolinium is injected into a vein and travels through the bloodstream.<EOS>
<BOS>The gadolinium collects around the cancer cells so they show up brighter in the picture.<EOS>
<BOS>This procedure is also called nuclear magnetic resonance imaging (NMRI).<EOS>
<BOS>Lumbar puncture : A procedure used to collect cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) from the spinal column.<EOS>
<BOS>This is done by placing a needle between two bones in the spine and into the CSF around the spinal cord and removing a sample of fluid.<EOS>
<BOS>The sample of CSF is checked under a microscope for signs of tumor cells.<EOS>
<BOS>The sample may also be checked for the amounts of protein and glucose.<EOS>
<BOS>A higher than normal amount of protein or lower than normal amount of glucose may be a sign of a tumor.<EOS>
<BOS>This procedure is also called an LP or spinal tap.<EOS>
<BOS>Childhood ependymoma is diagnosed and removed in surgery.<EOS>
<BOS>If the diagnostic tests show there may be a brain tumor, a biopsy is done by removing part of the skull and using a needle to remove a sample of the brain tissue.<EOS>
<BOS>A pathologist views the tissue under a microscope to look for cancer cells.<EOS>
<BOS>If cancer cells are found, the doctor will remove as much tumor as safely possible during the same surgery.<EOS>
<BOS>The following test may be done on the tissue that was removed: Immunohistochemistry : A test that uses antibodies to check for certain antigens in a sample of tissue.<EOS>
<BOS>The antibody is usually linked to a radioactive substance or a dye that causes the tissue to light up under a microscope.<EOS>
<BOS>This type of test may be used to tell the difference between brain stem glioma and other brain tumors.<EOS>
<BOS>An MRI is often done after the tumor is removed to find out whether any tumor remains.<EOS>
<BOS>See the PDQ summary about Chronic Myelogenous Leukemia Treatment for information.<EOS>
<BOS>Use of tobacco products and drinking too much alcohol can affect the risk of laryngeal cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Anything that increases your risk of getting a disease is called a risk factor.<EOS>
<BOS>Having a risk factor does not mean that you will get cancer; not having risk factors doesn't mean that you will not get cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Talk with your doctor if you think you may be at risk.<EOS>
<BOS>Key Points Breast cancer is a disease in which malignant (cancer) cells form in the tissues of the breast.<EOS>
<BOS>Sometimes breast cancer occurs in women who are pregnant or have just given birth.<EOS>
<BOS>Signs of breast cancer include a lump or change in the breast.<EOS>
<BOS>It may be difficult to detect (find) breast cancer early in pregnant or nursing women.<EOS>
<BOS>Breast exams should be part of prenatal and postnatal care.<EOS>
<BOS>Tests that examine the breasts are used to detect (find) and diagnose breast cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>If cancer is found, tests are done to study the cancer cells.<EOS>
<BOS>Certain factors affect prognosis (chance of recovery) and treatment options.<EOS>
<BOS>Breast cancer is a disease in which malignant (cancer) cells form in the tissues of the breast.<EOS>
<BOS>The breast is made up of lobes and ducts.<EOS>
<BOS>Each breast has 15 to 20 sections called lobes.<EOS>
<BOS>Each lobe has many smaller sections called lobules.<EOS>
<BOS>Lobules end in dozens of tiny bulbs that can make milk.<EOS>
<BOS>The lobes, lobules, and bulbs are linked by thin tubes called ducts.<EOS>
<BOS>Each breast also has blood vessels and lymph vessels.<EOS>
<BOS>The lymph vessels carry an almost colorless fluid called lymph.<EOS>
<BOS>Lymph vessels carry lymph between lymph nodes.<EOS>
<BOS>Lymph nodes are small beanshaped structures that are found throughout the body.<EOS>
<BOS>They filter substances in lymph and help fight infection and disease.<EOS>
<BOS>Clusters of lymph nodes are found near the breast in the axilla (under the arm), above the collarbone, and in the chest.<EOS>
<BOS>It may be difficult to detect (find) breast cancer early in pregnant or nursing women.<EOS>
<BOS>The breasts usually get larger, tender, or lumpy in women who are pregnant, nursing, or have just given birth.<EOS>
<BOS>This occurs because of normal hormone changes that take place during pregnancy.<EOS>
<BOS>These changes can make small lumps difficult to detect.<EOS>
<BOS>The breasts may also become denser.<EOS>
<BOS>It is more difficult to detect breast cancer in women with dense breasts using mammography.<EOS>
<BOS>Because these breast changes can delay diagnosis, breast cancer is often found at a later stage in these women.<EOS>
<BOS>Other Information About Pregnancy and Breast Cancer Key Points Lactation (breast milk production) and breastfeeding should be stopped if surgery or chemotherapy is planned.<EOS>
<BOS>Breast cancer does not appear to harm the unborn baby.<EOS>
<BOS>Pregnancy does not seem to affect the survival of women who have had breast cancer in the past.<EOS>
<BOS>Lactation (breast milk production) and breastfeeding should be stopped if surgery or chemotherapy is planned.<EOS>
<BOS>If surgery is planned, breastfeeding should be stopped to reduce blood flow in the breasts and make them smaller.<EOS>
<BOS>Breastfeeding should also be stopped if chemotherapy is planned.<EOS>
<BOS>Many anticancer drugs, especially cyclophosphamide and methotrexate, may occur in high levels in breast milk and may harm the nursing baby.<EOS>
<BOS>Women receiving chemotherapy should not breastfeed.<EOS>
<BOS>Stopping lactation does not improve the mother's prognosis.<EOS>
<BOS>Breast cancer does not appear to harm the unborn baby.<EOS>
<BOS>Breast cancer cells do not seem to pass from the mother to the unborn baby.<EOS>
<BOS>Pregnancy does not seem to affect the survival of women who have had breast cancer in the past.<EOS>
<BOS>For women who have had breast cancer, pregnancy does not seem to affect their survival.<EOS>
<BOS>However, some doctors recommend that a woman wait 2 years after treatment for breast cancer before trying to have a baby, so that any early return of the cancer would be detected.<EOS>
<BOS>This may affect a womans decision to become pregnant.<EOS>
<BOS>The unborn baby does not seem to be affected if the mother has had breast cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>A sign of mycosis fungoides is a red rash on the skin.<EOS>
<BOS>Mycosis fungoides may go through the following phases: Premycotic phase: A scaly, red rash in areas of the body that usually are not exposed to the sun.<EOS>
<BOS>This rash does not cause symptoms and may last for months or years.<EOS>
<BOS>It is hard to diagnose the rash as mycosis fungoides during this phase.<EOS>
<BOS>Patch phase: Thin, reddened, eczema like rash.<EOS>
<BOS>Plaque phase: Small raised bumps (papules) or hardened lesions on the skin, which may be reddened.<EOS>
<BOS>Tumor phase: Tumors form on the skin.<EOS>
<BOS>These tumors may develop ulcers and the skin may get infected.<EOS>
<BOS>Check with your doctor if you have any of these signs.<EOS>
<BOS>Key Points Nonsmall cell lung cancer is a disease in which malignant (cancer) cells form in the tissues of the lung.<EOS>
<BOS>There are several types of nonsmall cell lung cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Smoking is the major risk factor for nonsmall cell lung cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Signs of nonsmall cell lung cancer include a cough that doesn't go away and shortness of breath.<EOS>
<BOS>Tests that examine the lungs are used to detect (find), diagnose, and stage nonsmall cell lung cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Certain factors affect prognosis (chance of recovery) and treatment options.<EOS>
<BOS>For most patients with nonsmall cell lung cancer, current treatments do not cure the cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Nonsmall cell lung cancer is a disease in which malignant (cancer) cells form in the tissues of the lung.<EOS>
<BOS>The lungs are a pair of coneshaped breathing organs in the chest.<EOS>
<BOS>The lungs bring oxygen into the body as you breathe in.<EOS>
<BOS>They release carbon dioxide, a waste product of the bodys cells, as you breathe out.<EOS>
<BOS>Each lung has sections called lobes.<EOS>
<BOS>The left lung has two lobes.<EOS>
<BOS>The right lung is slightly larger and has three lobes.<EOS>
<BOS>Two tubes called bronchi lead from the trachea (windpipe) to the right and left lungs.<EOS>
<BOS>The bronchi are sometimes also involved in lung cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Tiny air sacs called alveoli and small tubes called bronchioles make up the inside of the lungs.<EOS>
<BOS>A thin membrane called the pleura covers the outside of each lung and lines the inside wall of the chest cavity.<EOS>
<BOS>This creates a sac called the pleural cavity.<EOS>
<BOS>The pleural cavity normally contains a small amount of fluid that helps the lungs move smoothly in the chest when you breathe.<EOS>
<BOS>There are two main types of lung cancer: nonsmall cell lung cancer and small cell lung cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>See the following PDQ summaries for more information about lung cancer: Small Cell Lung Cancer Treatment Unusual Cancers of Childhood Treatment Lung Cancer Prevention Lung Cancer Screening There are several types of nonsmall cell lung cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Each type of nonsmall cell lung cancer has different kinds of cancer cells.<EOS>
<BOS>The cancer cells of each type grow and spread in different ways.<EOS>
<BOS>The types of nonsmall cell lung cancer are named for the kinds of cells found in the cancer and how the cells look under a microscope: Squamous cell carcinoma: Cancer that begins in squamous cells, which are thin, flat cells that look like fish scales.<EOS>
<BOS>This is also called epidermoid carcinoma.<EOS>
<BOS>Large cell carcinoma: Cancer that may begin in several types of large cells.<EOS>
<BOS>Adenocarcinoma: Cancer that begins in the cells that line the alveoli and make substances such as mucus.<EOS>
<BOS>Other less common types of nonsmall cell lung cancer are: pleomorphic, carcinoid tumor, salivary gland carcinoma, and unclassified carcinoma.<EOS>
<BOS>For most patients with nonsmall cell lung cancer, current treatments do not cure the cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>If lung cancer is found, taking part in one of the many clinical trials being done to improve treatment should be considered.<EOS>
<BOS>Clinical trials are taking place in most parts of the country for patients with all stages of nonsmall cell lung cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Information about ongoing clinical trials is available from the NCI website.<EOS>
<BOS>New types of treatment are being tested in clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>Information about clinical trials is available from the NCI website.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients may want to think about taking part in a clinical trial.<EOS>
<BOS>For some patients, taking part in a clinical trial may be the best treatment choice.<EOS>
<BOS>Clinical trials are part of the cancer research process.<EOS>
<BOS>Clinical trials are done to find out if new cancer treatments are safe and effective or better than the standard treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Many of today's standard treatments for cancer are based on earlier clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients who take part in a clinical trial may receive the standard treatment or be among the first to receive a new treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients who take part in clinical trials also help improve the way cancer will be treated in the future.<EOS>
<BOS>Even when clinical trials do not lead to effective new treatments, they often answer important questions and help move research forward.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients can enter clinical trials before, during, or after starting their cancer treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Some clinical trials only include patients who have not yet received treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Other trials test treatments for patients whose cancer has not gotten better.<EOS>
<BOS>There are also clinical trials that test new ways to stop cancer from recurring (coming back) or reduce the side effects of cancer treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Clinical trials are taking place in many parts of the country.<EOS>
<BOS>See the Treatment Options section that follows for links to current treatment clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>These have been retrieved from NCI's listing of clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>Key Points There are different types of treatment for patients with ovarian epithelial cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Three kinds of standard treatment are used.<EOS>
<BOS>Surgery Chemotherapy Targeted therapy New types of treatment are being tested in clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>Radiation therapy Immunotherapy Patients may want to think about taking part in a clinical trial.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients can enter clinical trials before, during, or after starting their cancer treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Followup tests may be needed.<EOS>
<BOS>There are different types of treatment for patients with ovarian epithelial cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Different types of treatment are available for patients with ovarian epithelial cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Some treatments are standard, and some are being tested in clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>A treatment clinical trial is a research study meant to help improve current treatments or obtain information on new treatments for patients with cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>When clinical trials show that a new treatment is better than the treatment currently used as standard treatment, the new treatment may become the standard treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients with any stage of ovarian cancer may want to think about taking part in a clinical trial.<EOS>
<BOS>Some clinical trials are open only to patients who have not started treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Three kinds of standard treatment are used.<EOS>
<BOS>Surgery Most patients have surgery to remove as much of the tumor as possible.<EOS>
<BOS>Different types of surgery may include: Hysterectomy: Surgery to remove the uterus and, sometimes, the cervix.<EOS>
<BOS>When only the uterus is removed, it is called a partial hysterectomy.<EOS>
<BOS>When both the uterus and the cervix are removed, it is called a total hysterectomy.<EOS>
<BOS>If the uterus and cervix are taken out through the vagina, the operation is called a vaginal hysterectomy.<EOS>
<BOS>If the uterus and cervix are taken out through a large incision (cut) in the abdomen, the operation is called a total abdominal hysterectomy.<EOS>
<BOS>If the uterus and cervix are taken out through a small incision (cut) in the abdomen using a laparoscope, the operation is called a total laparoscopic hysterectomy.<EOS>
<BOS>Unilateral salpingooophorectomy: A surgical procedure to remove one ovary and one fallopian tube.<EOS>
<BOS>Bilateral salpingooophorectomy: A surgical procedure to remove both ovaries and both fallopian tubes.<EOS>
<BOS>Omentectomy: A surgical procedure to remove the omentum (tissue in the peritoneum that contains blood vessels, nerves, lymph vessels, and lymph nodes).<EOS>
<BOS>Lymph node biopsy: The removal of all or part of a lymph node.<EOS>
<BOS>A pathologist views the tissue under a microscope to look for cancer cells.<EOS>
<BOS>Chemotherapy Chemotherapy is a cancer treatment that uses drugs to stop the growth of cancer cells, either by killing the cells or by stopping them from dividing.<EOS>
<BOS>When chemotherapy is taken by mouth or injected into a vein or muscle, the drugs enter the bloodstream and can reach cancer cells throughout the body (systemic chemotherapy).<EOS>
<BOS>When chemotherapy is placed directly into the cerebrospinal fluid, an organ, or a body cavity such as the abdomen, the drugs mainly affect cancer cells in those areas (regional chemotherapy).<EOS>
<BOS>A type of regional chemotherapy used to treat ovarian cancer is intraperitoneal (IP) chemotherapy.<EOS>
<BOS>In IP chemotherapy, the anticancer drugs are carried directly into the peritoneal cavity (the space that contains the abdominal organs) through a thin tube.<EOS>
<BOS>Treatment with more than one anticancer drug is called combination chemotherapy.<EOS>
<BOS>The way the chemotherapy is given depends on the type and stage of the cancer being treated.<EOS>
<BOS>See Drugs Approved for Ovarian, Fallopian Tube, or Primary Peritoneal Cancer for more information.<EOS>
<BOS>Targeted therapy Targeted therapy is a type of treatment that uses drugs or other substances to identify and attack specific cancer cells without harming normal cells.<EOS>
<BOS>Monoclonal antibody therapy is a type of targeted therapy that uses antibodies made in the laboratory, from a single type of immune system cell.<EOS>
<BOS>These antibodies can identify substances on cancer cells or normal substances that may help cancer cells grow.<EOS>
<BOS>The antibodies attach to the substances and kill the cancer cells, block their growth, or keep them from spreading.<EOS>
<BOS>Monoclonal antibodies are given by infusion.<EOS>
<BOS>They may be used alone or to carry drugs, toxins, or radioactive material directly to cancer cells.<EOS>
<BOS>Bevacizumab is a monoclonal antibody that may be used with chemotherapy to treat ovarian epithelial cancer, fallopian tube cancer, or primary peritoneal cancer that has recurred (come back).<EOS>
<BOS>Poly (ADPribose) polymerase inhibitors (PARP inhibitors) are targeted therapy drugs that block DNA repair and may cause cancer cells to die.<EOS>
<BOS>Olaparib and niraparib are PARP inhibitors that may be used to treat advanced ovarian cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>See Drugs Approved for Ovarian, Fallopian Tube, or Primary Peritoneal Cancer for more information.<EOS>
<BOS>New types of treatment are being tested in clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>This summary section describes treatments that are being studied in clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>It may not mention every new treatment being studied.<EOS>
<BOS>Information about clinical trials is available from the NCI website.<EOS>
<BOS>Radiation therapy Radiation therapy is a cancer treatment that uses highenergy xrays or other types of radiation to kill cancer cells or keep them from growing.<EOS>
<BOS>Some women receive a treatment called intraperitoneal radiation therapy, in which radioactive liquid is put directly in the abdomen through a catheter.<EOS>
<BOS>Intraperitoneal radiation therapy is being studied to treat advanced ovarian cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Immunotherapy Immunotherapy is a treatment that uses the patients immune system to fight cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Substances made by the body or made in a laboratory are used to boost, direct, or restore the bodys natural defenses against cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>This type of cancer treatment is also called biotherapy or immunotherapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Vaccine therapy uses a substance to stimulate the immune system to destroy a tumor.<EOS>
<BOS>Vaccine therapy is being studied to treat advanced ovarian cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients may want to think about taking part in a clinical trial.<EOS>
<BOS>For some patients, taking part in a clinical trial may be the best treatment choice.<EOS>
<BOS>Clinical trials are part of the cancer research process.<EOS>
<BOS>Clinical trials are done to find out if new cancer treatments are safe and effective or better than the standard treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Many of today's standard treatments for cancer are based on earlier clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients who take part in a clinical trial may receive the standard treatment or be among the first to receive a new treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients who take part in clinical trials also help improve the way cancer will be treated in the future.<EOS>
<BOS>Even when clinical trials do not lead to effective new treatments, they often answer important questions and help move research forward.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients can enter clinical trials before, during, or after starting their cancer treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Some clinical trials only include patients who have not yet received treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Other trials test treatments for patients whose cancer has not gotten better.<EOS>
<BOS>There are also clinical trials that test new ways to stop cancer from recurring (coming back) or reduce the side effects of cancer treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Clinical trials are taking place in many parts of the country.<EOS>
<BOS>See the Treatment Options section that follows for links to current treatment clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>These have been retrieved from NCI's listing of clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>Followup tests may be needed.<EOS>
<BOS>Some of the tests that were done to diagnose the cancer or to find out the stage of the cancer may be repeated.<EOS>
<BOS>Some tests will be repeated in order to see how well the treatment is working.<EOS>
<BOS>Decisions about whether to continue, change, or stop treatment may be based on the results of these tests.<EOS>
<BOS>Some of the tests will continue to be done from time to time after treatment has ended.<EOS>
<BOS>The results of these tests can show if your condition has changed or if the cancer has recurred (come back).<EOS>
<BOS>These tests are sometimes called followup tests or checkups.<EOS>
<BOS>Treatment Options by Stage Early Ovarian Epithelial and Fallopian Tube Cancer Treatment of early ovarian epithelial cancer or fallopian tube cancer may include the following: Hysterectomy, bilateral salpingooophorectomy, and omentectomy.<EOS>
<BOS>Lymph nodes and other tissues in the pelvis and abdomen are removed and checked under a microscope for cancer cells.<EOS>
<BOS>Chemotherapy may be given after surgery.<EOS>
<BOS>Unilateral salpingooophorectomy may be done in certain women who wish to have children.<EOS>
<BOS>Chemotherapy may be given after surgery.<EOS>
<BOS>Check the list of NCIsupported cancer clinical trials that are now accepting patients with stage I ovarian epithelial cancer and fallopian tube cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>For more specific results, refine the search by using other search features, such as the location of the trial, the type of treatment, or the name of the drug.<EOS>
<BOS>Talk with your doctor about clinical trials that may be right for you.<EOS>
<BOS>General information about clinical trials is available from the NCI website.<EOS>
<BOS>Advanced Ovarian Epithelial, Fallopian Tube, and Primary Peritoneal Cancer Treatment of advanced ovarian epithelial cancer, fallopian tube cancer, or primary peritoneal cancer may include the following: Hysterectomy, bilateral salpingooophorectomy, and omentectomy.<EOS>
<BOS>Lymph nodes and other tissues in the pelvis and abdomen are removed and checked under a microscope to look for cancer cells.<EOS>
<BOS>Surgery is followed by one of the following: Intravenous chemotherapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Intraperitoneal chemotherapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Chemotherapy and targeted therapy (bevacizumab, olaparib, or niraparib).<EOS>
<BOS>Chemotherapy followed by hysterectomy, bilateral salpingooophorectomy, and omentectomy.<EOS>
<BOS>Chemotherapy alone for patients who cannot have surgery.<EOS>
<BOS>A clinical trial of intraperitoneal radiation therapy, immunotherapy (vaccine therapy), or targeted therapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Check the list of NCIsupported cancer clinical trials that are now accepting patients with stage II ovarian epithelial cancer, stage III ovarian epithelial cancer, stage IV ovarian epithelial cancer, fallopian tube cancer and primary peritoneal cavity cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>For more specific results, refine the search by using other search features, such as the location of the trial, the type of treatment, or the name of the drug.<EOS>
<BOS>Talk with your doctor about clinical trials that may be right for you.<EOS>
<BOS>General information about clinical trials is available from the NCI website.<EOS>
<BOS>Anything that increases your risk of getting a disease is called a risk factor.<EOS>
<BOS>Having a risk factor does not mean that you will get cancer; not having risk factors doesn't mean that you will not get cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Talk with your doctor if you think you may be at risk.<EOS>
<BOS>Risk factors for LCH include the following: Having a parent who was exposed to certain chemicals such as benzene.<EOS>
<BOS>Having a parent who was exposed to metal, granite, or wood dust in the workplace.<EOS>
<BOS>A family history of cancer, including LCH.<EOS>
<BOS>Having infections as a newborn.<EOS>
<BOS>Having a personal history or family history of thyroid disease.<EOS>
<BOS>Smoking, especially in young adults.<EOS>
<BOS>Being Hispanic.<EOS>
<BOS>Smoking or being infected with human papillomavirus can increase the risk of oropharyngeal cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Anything that increases your risk of getting a disease is called a risk factor.<EOS>
<BOS>Having a risk factor does not mean that you will get cancer; not having risk factors doesn't mean that you will not get cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Talk with your doctor if you think you may be at risk.<EOS>
<BOS>The most common risk factors for oropharyngeal cancer include the following: A history of smoking cigarettes for more than 10 pack years and other tobacco use.<EOS>
<BOS>Personal history of head and neck cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Heavy alcohol use.<EOS>
<BOS>Being infected with human papillomavirus (HPV), especially HPV type 16.<EOS>
<BOS>The number of cases of oropharyngeal cancers linked to HPV infection is increasing.<EOS>
<BOS>Chewing betel quid, a stimulant commonly used in parts of Asia.<EOS>
<BOS>Key Points After breast cancer has been diagnosed, tests are done to find out if cancer cells have spread within the breast or to other parts of the body.<EOS>
<BOS>There are three ways that cancer spreads in the body.<EOS>
<BOS>Cancer may spread from where it began to other parts of the body.<EOS>
<BOS>The following stages are used for breast cancer: Stage 0 (carcinoma in situ) Stage I Stage II Stage IIIA Stage IIIB Stage IIIC Stage IV The treatment of breast cancer depends partly on the stage of the disease.<EOS>
<BOS>After breast cancer has been diagnosed, tests are done to find out if cancer cells have spread within the breast or to other parts of the body.<EOS>
<BOS>The process used to find out whether the cancer has spread within the breast or to other parts of the body is called staging.<EOS>
<BOS>The information gathered from the staging process determines the stage of the disease.<EOS>
<BOS>It is important to know the stage in order to plan treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>The results of some of the tests used to diagnose breast cancer are also used to stage the disease.<EOS>
<BOS>(See the General Information section.<EOS>
<BOS>) The following tests and procedures also may be used in the staging process: Sentinel lymph node biopsy : The removal of the sentinel lymph node during surgery.<EOS>
<BOS>The sentinel lymph node is the first lymph node to receive lymphatic drainage from a tumor.<EOS>
<BOS>It is the first lymph node the cancer is likely to spread to from the tumor.<EOS>
<BOS>A radioactive substance and/or blue dye is injected near the tumor.<EOS>
<BOS>The substance or dye flows through the lymph ducts to the lymph nodes.<EOS>
<BOS>The first lymph node to receive the substance or dye is removed.<EOS>
<BOS>A pathologist views the tissue under a microscope to look for cancer cells.<EOS>
<BOS>If cancer cells are not found, it may not be necessary to remove more lymph nodes.<EOS>
<BOS>Chest xray : An xray of the organs and bones inside the chest.<EOS>
<BOS>An xray is a type of energy beam that can go through the body and onto film, making a picture of areas inside the body.<EOS>
<BOS>CT scan (CAT scan): A procedure that makes a series of detailed pictures of areas inside the body, taken from different angles.<EOS>
<BOS>The pictures are made by a computer linked to an xray machine.<EOS>
<BOS>A dye may be injected into a vein or swallowed to help the organs or tissues show up more clearly.<EOS>
<BOS>This procedure is also called computed tomography, computerized tomography, or computerized axial tomography.<EOS>
<BOS>Bone scan : A procedure to check if there are rapidly dividing cells, such as cancer cells, in the bone.<EOS>
<BOS>A very small amount of radioactive material is injected into a vein and travels through the bloodstream.<EOS>
<BOS>The radioactive material collects in the bones and is detected by a scanner.<EOS>
<BOS>PET scan (positron emission tomography scan): A procedure to find malignant tumor cells in the body.<EOS>
<BOS>A small amount of radioactive glucose (sugar) is injected into a vein.<EOS>
<BOS>The PET scanner rotates around the body and makes a picture of where glucose is being used in the body.<EOS>
<BOS>Malignant tumor cells show up brighter in the picture because they are more active and take up more glucose than normal cells do.<EOS>
<BOS>There are three ways that cancer spreads in the body.<EOS>
<BOS>Cancer can spread through tissue, the lymph system, and the blood: Tissue.<EOS>
<BOS>The cancer spreads from where it began by growing into nearby areas.<EOS>
<BOS>Lymph system.<EOS>
<BOS>The cancer spreads from where it began by getting into the lymph system.<EOS>
<BOS>The cancer travels through the lymph vessels to other parts of the body.<EOS>
<BOS>Blood.<EOS>
<BOS>The cancer spreads from where it began by getting into the blood.<EOS>
<BOS>The cancer travels through the blood vessels to other parts of the body.<EOS>
<BOS>Cancer may spread from where it began to other parts of the body.<EOS>
<BOS>When cancer spreads to another part of the body, it is called metastasis.<EOS>
<BOS>Cancer cells break away from where they began (the primary tumor) and travel through the lymph system or blood.<EOS>
<BOS>Lymph system.<EOS>
<BOS>The cancer gets into the lymph system, travels through the lymph vessels, and forms a tumor (metastatic tumor) in another part of the body.<EOS>
<BOS>Blood.<EOS>
<BOS>The cancer gets into the blood, travels through the blood vessels, and forms a tumor (metastatic tumor) in another part of the body.<EOS>
<BOS>The metastatic tumor is the same type of cancer as the primary tumor.<EOS>
<BOS>For example, if breast cancer spreads to the bone, the cancer cells in the bone are actually breast cancer cells.<EOS>
<BOS>The disease is metastatic breast cancer, not bone cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>The following stages are used for breast cancer: This section describes the stages of breast cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>The breast cancer stage is based on the results of tests that are done on the tumor and lymph nodes removed during surgery and on other tests.<EOS>
<BOS>Stage 0 (carcinoma in situ) There are 3 types of breast carcinoma in situ: Ductal carcinoma in situ (DCIS) is a noninvasive condition in which abnormal cells are found in the lining of a breast duct.<EOS>
<BOS>The abnormal cells have not spread outside the duct to other tissues in the breast.<EOS>
<BOS>In some cases, DCIS may become invasive cancer and spread to other tissues.<EOS>
<BOS>At this time, there is no way to know which lesions could become invasive.<EOS>
<BOS>Lobular carcinoma in situ (LCIS) is a condition in which abnormal cells are found in the lobules of the breast.<EOS>
<BOS>This condition seldom becomes invasive cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Information about LCIS is not included in this summary.<EOS>
<BOS>Paget disease of the nipple is a condition in which abnormal cells are found in the nipple only.<EOS>
<BOS>Stage I In stage I, cancer has formed.<EOS>
<BOS>Stage I is divided into stages IA and IB.<EOS>
<BOS>In stage IA, the tumor is 2 centimeters or smaller.<EOS>
<BOS>Cancer has not spread outside the breast.<EOS>
<BOS>In stage IB, small clusters of breast cancer cells (larger than 0.<EOS>
<BOS>2 millimeter but not larger than 2 millimeters) are found in the lymph nodes and either: no tumor is found in the breast; or the tumor is 2 centimeters or smaller.<EOS>
<BOS>Stage II Stage II is divided into stages IIA and IIB.<EOS>
<BOS>In stage IIA: no tumor is found in the breast or the tumor is 2 centimeters or smaller.<EOS>
<BOS>Cancer (larger than 2 millimeters) is found in 1 to 3 axillary lymph nodes or in the lymph nodes near the breastbone (found during a sentinel lymph node biopsy); or the tumor is larger than 2 centimeters but not larger than 5 centimeters.<EOS>
<BOS>Cancer has not spread to the lymph nodes.<EOS>
<BOS>In stage IIB, the tumor is: larger than 2 centimeters but not larger than 5 centimeters.<EOS>
<BOS>Small clusters of breast cancer cells (larger than 0.<EOS>
<BOS>2 millimeter but not larger than 2 millimeters) are found in the lymph nodes; or larger than 2 centimeters but not larger than 5 centimeters.<EOS>
<BOS>Cancer has spread to 1 to 3 axillary lymph nodes or to the lymph nodes near the breastbone (found during a sentinel lymph node biopsy); or larger than 5 centimeters.<EOS>
<BOS>Cancer has not spread to the lymph nodes.<EOS>
<BOS>Stage IIIA In stage IIIA: no tumor is found in the breast or the tumor may be any size.<EOS>
<BOS>Cancer is found in 4 to 9 axillary lymph nodes or in the lymph nodes near the breastbone (found during imaging tests or a physical exam); or the tumor is larger than 5 centimeters.<EOS>
<BOS>Small clusters of breast cancer cells (larger than 0.<EOS>
<BOS>2 millimeter but not larger than 2 millimeters) are found in the lymph nodes; or the tumor is larger than 5 centimeters.<EOS>
<BOS>Cancer has spread to 1 to 3 axillary lymph nodes or to the lymph nodes near the breastbone (found during a sentinel lymph node biopsy).<EOS>
<BOS>Stage IIIB In stage IIIB, the tumor may be any size and cancer has spread to the chest wall and/or to the skin of the breast and caused swelling or an ulcer.<EOS>
<BOS>Also, cancer may have spread to: up to 9 axillary lymph nodes; or the lymph nodes near the breastbone.<EOS>
<BOS>Cancer that has spread to the skin of the breast may also be inflammatory breast cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>See the section on Inflammatory Breast Cancer for more information.<EOS>
<BOS>Stage IIIC In stage IIIC, no tumor is found in the breast or the tumor may be any size.<EOS>
<BOS>Cancer may have spread to the skin of the breast and caused swelling or an ulcer and/or has spread to the chest wall.<EOS>
<BOS>Also, cancer has spread to: 10 or more axillary lymph nodes; or lymph nodes above or below the collarbone; or axillary lymph nodes and lymph nodes near the breastbone.<EOS>
<BOS>Cancer that has spread to the skin of the breast may also be inflammatory breast cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>See the section on Inflammatory Breast Cancer for more information.<EOS>
<BOS>Stage IV In stage IV, cancer has spread to other organs of the body, most often the bones, lungs, liver, or brain.<EOS>
<BOS>The treatment of breast cancer depends partly on the stage of the disease.<EOS>
<BOS>For ductal carcinoma in situ (DCIS) treatment options, see Ductal Carcinoma in Situ.<EOS>
<BOS>For treatment options for stage I, stage II, stage IIIA, and operable stage IIIC breast cancer, see Early, Localized, or Operable Breast Cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>For treatment options for stage IIIB, inoperable stage IIIC, and inflammatory breast cancer, see Locally Advanced or Inflammatory Breast Cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>For treatment options for cancer that has recurred near the area where it first formed, see Locoregional Recurrent Breast Cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>For treatment options for stage IV breast cancer or breast cancer that has recurred in other parts of the body, see Metastatic Breast Cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>New types of treatment are being tested in clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>This summary section describes treatments that are being studied in clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>It may not mention every new treatment being studied.<EOS>
<BOS>Information about clinical trials is available from the NCI Web site.<EOS>
<BOS>Chemoprevention Chemoprevention is the use of drugs, vitamins, or other substances to reduce the risk of developing cancer or to reduce the risk cancer will recur (come back).<EOS>
<BOS>The drug isotretinoin is being studied to prevent the development of a second cancer in patients who have had cancer of the head or neck.<EOS>
<BOS>Radiosensitizers Radiosensitizers are drugs that make tumor cells more sensitive to radiation therapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Combining radiation therapy with radiosensitizers may kill more tumor cells.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients may want to think about taking part in a clinical trial.<EOS>
<BOS>For some patients, taking part in a clinical trial may be the best treatment choice.<EOS>
<BOS>Clinical trials are part of the cancer research process.<EOS>
<BOS>Clinical trials are done to find out if new cancer treatments are safe and effective or better than the standard treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Many of today's standard treatments for cancer are based on earlier clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients who take part in a clinical trial may receive the standard treatment or be among the first to receive a new treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients who take part in clinical trials also help improve the way cancer will be treated in the future.<EOS>
<BOS>Even when clinical trials do not lead to effective new treatments, they often answer important questions and help move research forward.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients can enter clinical trials before, during, or after starting their cancer treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Some clinical trials only include patients who have not yet received treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Other trials test treatments for patients whose cancer has not gotten better.<EOS>
<BOS>There are also clinical trials that test new ways to stop cancer from recurring (coming back) or reduce the side effects of cancer treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Clinical trials are taking place in many parts of the country.<EOS>
<BOS>See the Treatment Options section that follows for links to current treatment clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>These have been retrieved from NCI's listing of clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>Radiation exposure, high levels of estrogen, and a family history of breast cancer can increase a mans risk of breast cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Anything that increases your risk of getting a disease is called a risk factor.<EOS>
<BOS>Having a risk factor does not mean that you will get cancer; not having risk factors doesnt mean that you will not get cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Talk with your doctor if you think you may be at risk.<EOS>
<BOS>Risk factors for breast cancer in men may include the following: Being exposed to radiation.<EOS>
<BOS>Having a disease linked to high levels of estrogen in the body, such as cirrhosis (liver disease) or Klinefelter syndrome (a genetic disorder.<EOS>
<BOS>) Having several female relatives who have had breast cancer, especially relatives who have an alteration of the BRCA2 gene.<EOS>
<BOS>Certain genetic conditions increase the risk of childhood rhabdomyosarcoma.<EOS>
<BOS>Anything that increases the risk of getting a disease is called a risk factor.<EOS>
<BOS>Having a risk factor does not mean that you will get cancer; not having risk factors doesnt mean that you will not get cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Talk with your childs doctor if you think your child may be at risk.<EOS>
<BOS>Risk factors for rhabdomyosarcoma include having the following inherited diseases: LiFraumeni syndrome.<EOS>
<BOS>Pleuropulmonary blastoma.<EOS>
<BOS>Neurofibromatosis type 1 (NF1).<EOS>
<BOS>Costello syndrome.<EOS>
<BOS>BeckwithWiedemann syndrome.<EOS>
<BOS>Noonan syndrome.<EOS>
<BOS>Children who had a high birth weight or were larger than expected at birth may have an increased risk of embryonal rhabdomyosarcoma.<EOS>
<BOS>In most cases, the cause of rhabdomyosarcoma is not known.<EOS>
<BOS>Key Points There are no standard staging systems for monoclonal gammopathy of undetermined significance (MGUS), macroglobulinemia, and plasmacytoma.<EOS>
<BOS>After multiple myeloma has been diagnosed, tests are done to find out the amount of cancer in the body.<EOS>
<BOS>The stage of multiple myeloma is based on the levels of beta2microglobulin and albumin in the blood.<EOS>
<BOS>The following stages are used for multiple myeloma: Stage I multiple myeloma Stage II multiple myeloma Stage III multiple myeloma There are no standard staging systems for monoclonal gammopathy of undetermined significance (MGUS), macroglobulinemia, and plasmacytoma.<EOS>
<BOS>After multiple myeloma has been diagnosed, tests are done to find out the amount of cancer in the body.<EOS>
<BOS>The process used to find out the amount of cancer in the body is called staging.<EOS>
<BOS>It is important to know the stage in order to plan treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>The following tests and procedures may be used in the staging process: Skeletal bone survey: In a skeletal bone survey, xrays of all the bones in the body are taken.<EOS>
<BOS>The xrays are used to find areas where the bone is damaged.<EOS>
<BOS>An xray is a type of energy beam that can go through the body and onto film, making a picture of areas inside the body.<EOS>
<BOS>MRI (magnetic resonance imaging): A procedure that uses a magnet, radio waves, and a computer to make a series of detailed pictures of areas inside the body, such as the bone marrow.<EOS>
<BOS>This procedure is also called nuclear magnetic resonance imaging (NMRI).<EOS>
<BOS>Bone densitometry: A procedure that uses a special type of xray to measure bone density.<EOS>
<BOS>The stage of multiple myeloma is based on the levels of beta2microglobulin and albumin in the blood.<EOS>
<BOS>Beta2microglobulin and albumin are found in the blood.<EOS>
<BOS>Beta2microglobulin is a protein found on plasma cells.<EOS>
<BOS>Albumin makes up the biggest part of the blood plasma.<EOS>
<BOS>It keeps fluid from leaking out of blood vessels.<EOS>
<BOS>It also brings nutrients to tissues, and carries hormones, vitamins, drugs, and other substances, such as calcium, all through the body.<EOS>
<BOS>In the blood of patients with multiple myeloma, the amount of beta2microglobulin is increased and the amount of albumin is decreased.<EOS>
<BOS>The following stages are used for multiple myeloma: Stage I multiple myeloma In stage I multiple myeloma, the blood levels are as follows: beta2microglobulin level is lower than 3.<EOS>
<BOS>5 mg/L; and albumin level is 3.<EOS>
<BOS>5 g/dL or higher.<EOS>
<BOS>Stage II multiple myeloma In stage II multiple myeloma, the blood levels are in between the levels for stage I and stage III.<EOS>
<BOS>Stage III multiple myeloma In stage III multiple myeloma, the blood level of beta2microglobulin is 5.<EOS>
<BOS>5 mg/L or higher and the patient also has one of the following: high levels of lactate dehydrogenase (LDH); or certain changes in the chromosomes.<EOS>
<BOS>Key Points There are different types of treatment for patients with primary CNS lymphoma.<EOS>
<BOS>Three standard treatments are used: Radiation therapy Chemotherapy Steroid therapy New types of treatment are being tested in clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>Highdose chemotherapy with stem cell transplant Targeted therapy Patients may want to think about taking part in a clinical trial.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients can enter clinical trials before, during, or after starting their cancer treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Followup tests may be needed.<EOS>
<BOS>There are different types of treatment for patients with primary CNS lymphoma.<EOS>
<BOS>Different types of treatment are available for patients with primary central nervous system (CNS) lymphoma.<EOS>
<BOS>Some treatments are standard (the currently used treatment), and some are being tested in clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>A treatment clinical trial is a research study meant to help improve current treatments or obtain information on new treatments for patients with cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>When clinical trials show that a new treatment is better than the standard treatment, the new treatment may become the standard treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients may want to think about taking part in a clinical trial.<EOS>
<BOS>Some clinical trials are open only to patients who have not started treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Surgery is not used to treat primary CNS lymphoma.<EOS>
<BOS>Three standard treatments are used: Radiation therapy Radiation therapy is a cancer treatment that uses highenergy xrays or other types of radiation to kill cancer cells or keep them from growing.<EOS>
<BOS>There are two types of radiation therapy: External radiation therapy uses a machine outside the body to send radiation toward the cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Because primary CNS lymphoma spreads throughout the brain, external radiation therapy is given to the whole brain.<EOS>
<BOS>This is called whole brain radiation therapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Internal radiation therapy uses a radioactive substance sealed in needles, seeds, wires, or catheters that are placed directly into or near the cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>The way the radiation therapy is given depends on whether the patient has primary CNS lymphoma and AIDS.<EOS>
<BOS>External radiation therapy is used to treat primary CNS lymphoma.<EOS>
<BOS>Highdose radiation therapy to the brain can damage healthy tissue and cause disorders that can affect thinking, learning, problem solving, speech, reading, writing, and memory.<EOS>
<BOS>Clinical trials have tested the use of chemotherapy alone or before radiation therapy to reduce the damage to healthy brain tissue that occurs with the use of radiation therapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Chemotherapy Chemotherapy is a cancer treatment that uses drugs to stop the growth of cancer cells, either by killing the cells or by stopping them from dividing.<EOS>
<BOS>When chemotherapy is taken by mouth or injected into a vein or muscle, the drugs enter the bloodstream and can reach cancer cells throughout the body (systemic chemotherapy).<EOS>
<BOS>When chemotherapy is placed directly into the cerebrospinal fluid (intrathecal chemotherapy), an organ, or a body cavity such as the abdomen, the drugs mainly affect cancer cells in those areas (regional chemotherapy).<EOS>
<BOS>The way the chemotherapy is given depends on where the tumor is in the CNS or eye.<EOS>
<BOS>Primary CNS lymphoma may be treated with systemic chemotherapy, intrathecal chemotherapy and/or intraventricular chemotherapy, in which anticancer drugs are placed into the ventricles (fluid filled cavities) of the brain.<EOS>
<BOS>If primary CNS lymphoma is found in the eye, anticancer drugs are injected directly into the vitreous humor (jellylike substance) inside the eye.<EOS>
<BOS>A network of blood vessels and tissue, called the bloodbrain barrier, protects the brain from harmful substances.<EOS>
<BOS>This barrier can also keep anticancer drugs from reaching the brain.<EOS>
<BOS>In order to treat CNS lymphoma, certain drugs may be used to make openings between cells in the bloodbrain barrier.<EOS>
<BOS>This is called bloodbrain barrier disruption.<EOS>
<BOS>Anticancer drugs infused into the bloodstream may then reach the brain.<EOS>
<BOS>Steroid therapy Steroids are hormones made naturally in the body.<EOS>
<BOS>They can also be made in a laboratory and used as drugs.<EOS>
<BOS>Glucocorticoids are steroid drugs that have an anticancer effect in lymphomas.<EOS>
<BOS>New types of treatment are being tested in clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>This summary section describes treatments that are being studied in clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>It may not mention every new treatment being studied.<EOS>
<BOS>Information about clinical trials is available from the NCI website.<EOS>
<BOS>Highdose chemotherapy with stem cell transplant Highdose chemotherapy with stem cell transplant is a method of giving high doses of chemotherapy and replacing blood forming cells destroyed by the cancer treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Stem cells (immature blood cells) are removed from the blood or bone marrow of the patient or a donor and are frozen and stored.<EOS>
<BOS>After the chemotherapy is completed, the stored stem cells are thawed and given back to the patient through an infusion.<EOS>
<BOS>These reinfused stem cells grow into (and restore) the body's blood cells.<EOS>
<BOS>Targeted therapy Targeted therapy is a type of treatment that uses drugs or other substances to attack cancer cells.<EOS>
<BOS>Targeted therapies usually cause less harm to normal cells than chemotherapy or radiation therapy do.<EOS>
<BOS>Monoclonal antibody therapy is one type of targeted therapy being studied in the treatment of primary CNS lymphoma.<EOS>
<BOS>Monoclonal antibody therapy is a cancer treatment that uses antibodies made in the laboratory from a single type of immune system cell.<EOS>
<BOS>These antibodies can identify substances on cancer cells or normal substances that may help cancer cells grow.<EOS>
<BOS>The antibodies attach to the substances and kill the cancer cells, block their growth, or keep them from spreading.<EOS>
<BOS>Monoclonal antibodies are given by infusion.<EOS>
<BOS>They may be used alone or to carry drugs, toxins, or radioactive material directly to cancer cells.<EOS>
<BOS>Rituximab is a type of monoclonal antibody used to treat newly diagnosed primary CNS lymphoma in patients who do not have AIDS.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients may want to think about taking part in a clinical trial.<EOS>
<BOS>For some patients, taking part in a clinical trial may be the best treatment choice.<EOS>
<BOS>Clinical trials are part of the cancer research process.<EOS>
<BOS>Clinical trials are done to find out if new cancer treatments are safe and effective or better than the standard treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Many of today's standard treatments for cancer are based on earlier clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients who take part in a clinical trial may receive the standard treatment or be among the first to receive a new treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients who take part in clinical trials also help improve the way cancer will be treated in the future.<EOS>
<BOS>Even when clinical trials do not lead to effective new treatments, they often answer important questions and help move research forward.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients can enter clinical trials before, during, or after starting their cancer treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Some clinical trials only include patients who have not yet received treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Other trials test treatments for patients whose cancer has not gotten better.<EOS>
<BOS>There are also clinical trials that test new ways to stop cancer from recurring (coming back) or reduce the side effects of cancer treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Clinical trials are taking place in many parts of the country.<EOS>
<BOS>See the Treatment Options section that follows for links to current treatment clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>These have been retrieved from NCI's listing of clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>Followup tests may be needed.<EOS>
<BOS>Some of the tests that were done to diagnose the cancer or to find out the stage of the cancer may be repeated.<EOS>
<BOS>Some tests will be repeated in order to see how well the treatment is working.<EOS>
<BOS>Decisions about whether to continue, change, or stop treatment may be based on the results of these tests.<EOS>
<BOS>Some of the tests will continue to be done from time to time after treatment has ended.<EOS>
<BOS>The results of these tests can show if your condition has changed or if the cancer has recurred (come back).<EOS>
<BOS>These tests are sometimes called followup tests or checkups.<EOS>
<BOS>Treatment Options for Primary CNS Lymphoma Primary CNS Lymphoma Not Related to AIDS Treatment of primary central nervous system (CNS) lymphoma in patients who do not have AIDS may include the following: Whole brain radiation therapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Chemotherapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Chemotherapy followed by radiation therapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Chemotherapy and targeted therapy (rituximab) followed by highdose chemotherapy and stem cell transplant.<EOS>
<BOS>A clinical trial of highdose chemotherapy with stem cell transplant.<EOS>
<BOS>A clinical trial of highdose chemotherapy and targeted therapy (rituximab), with or without stem cell transplant or whole brain radiation therapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Primary CNS Lymphoma Related to AIDS Treatment of primary central nervous system (CNS) lymphoma in patients who do have AIDS may include the following: Whole brain radiation therapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Chemotherapy followed by radiation therapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Treatment of primary CNS lymphoma is different in patients with AIDS because the treatment side effects may be more severe.<EOS>
<BOS>(See the PDQ summary on AIDSRelated Lymphoma Treatment for more information).<EOS>
<BOS>Primary Intraocular Lymphoma Treatment of primary intraocular lymphoma may include the following: Chemotherapy (intraocular or systemic).<EOS>
<BOS>Whole brain radiation therapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Recurrent Primary CNS Lymphoma Treatment of recurrent primary central nervous system (CNS) lymphoma may include the following: Chemotherapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Radiation therapy (if not received in earlier treatment).<EOS>
<BOS>A clinical trial of a new drug or treatment schedule.<EOS>
<BOS>Key Points There are different types of treatment for patients with metastatic squamous neck cancer with occult primary.<EOS>
<BOS>Two types of standard treatment are used: Surgery Radiation therapy New types of treatment are being tested in clinical trials.<EOS>
