<BOS>Chemotherapy Hyperfractionated radiation therapy Patients may want to think about taking part in a clinical trial.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients can enter clinical trials before, during, or after starting their cancer treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Followup tests may be needed.<EOS>
<BOS>There are different types of treatment for patients with metastatic squamous neck cancer with occult primary.<EOS>
<BOS>Different types of treatment are available for patients with metastatic squamous neck cancer with occult primary.<EOS>
<BOS>Some treatments are standard (the currently used treatment), and some are being tested in clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>A treatment clinical trial is a research study meant to help improve current treatments or obtain information on new treatments for patients with cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>When clinical trials show that a new treatment is better than the standard treatment, the new treatment may become the standard treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients may want to think about taking part in a clinical trial.<EOS>
<BOS>Some clinical trials are open only to patients who have not started treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Two types of standard treatment are used: Surgery Surgery may include neck dissection.<EOS>
<BOS>There are different types of neck dissection, based on the amount of tissue that is removed.<EOS>
<BOS>Radical neck dissection: Surgery to remove tissues in one or both sides of the neck between the jawbone and the collarbone, including the following: All lymph nodes.<EOS>
<BOS>The jugular vein.<EOS>
<BOS>Muscles and nerves that are used for face, neck, and shoulder movement, speech, and swallowing.<EOS>
<BOS>The patient may need physical therapy of the throat, neck, shoulder, and/or arm after radical neck dissection.<EOS>
<BOS>Radical neck dissection may be used when cancer has spread widely in the neck.<EOS>
<BOS>Modified radical neck dissection: Surgery to remove all the lymph nodes in one or both sides of the neck without removing the neck muscles.<EOS>
<BOS>The nerves and/or the jugular vein may be removed.<EOS>
<BOS>Partial neck dissection: Surgery to remove some of the lymph nodes in the neck.<EOS>
<BOS>This is also called selective neck dissection.<EOS>
<BOS>Even if the doctor removes all the cancer that can be seen at the time of surgery, some patients may be given radiation therapy after surgery to kill any cancer cells that are left.<EOS>
<BOS>Treatment given after surgery, to lower the risk that the cancer will come back, is called adjuvant therapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Radiation therapy Radiation therapy is a cancer treatment that uses highenergy xrays or other types of radiation to kill cancer cells or keep them from growing.<EOS>
<BOS>There are two types of radiation therapy: External radiation therapy uses a machine outside the body to send radiation toward the cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Certain ways of giving radiation therapy can help keep radiation from damaging nearby healthy tissue.<EOS>
<BOS>This type of radiation therapy may include the following: Intensitymodulated radiation therapy (IMRT): IMRT is a type of 3dimensional (3D) radiation therapy that uses a computer to make pictures of the size and shape of the tumor.<EOS>
<BOS>Thin beams of radiation of different intensities (strengths) are aimed at the tumor from many angles.<EOS>
<BOS>This type of radiation therapy is less likely to cause dry mouth, trouble swallowing, and damage to the skin.<EOS>
<BOS>Internal radiation therapy uses a radioactive substance sealed in needles, seeds, wires, or catheters that are placed directly into or near the cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>The way the radiation therapy is given depends on the type of cancer being treated.<EOS>
<BOS>External radiation therapy is used to treat metastatic squamous neck cancer with occult primary.<EOS>
<BOS>Radiation therapy to the neck may change the way the thyroid gland works.<EOS>
<BOS>Blood tests may be done to check the thyroid hormone level in the body before treatment and at regular checkups after treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>New types of treatment are being tested in clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>This summary section describes treatments that are being studied in clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>It may not mention every new treatment being studied.<EOS>
<BOS>Information about clinical trials is available from the NCI website.<EOS>
<BOS>Chemotherapy Chemotherapy is a cancer treatment that uses drugs to stop the growth of cancer cells, either by killing the cells or by stopping them from dividing.<EOS>
<BOS>When chemotherapy is taken by mouth or injected into a vein or muscle, the drugs enter the bloodstream and can reach cancer cells throughout the body (systemic chemotherapy).<EOS>
<BOS>When chemotherapy is placed directly into the cerebrospinal fluid, an organ, or a body cavity such as the abdomen, the drugs mainly affect cancer cells in those areas (regional chemotherapy).<EOS>
<BOS>Hyperfractionated radiation therapy Hyperfractionated radiation therapy is a type of external radiation treatment in which a smaller than usual total daily dose of radiation is divided into two doses and the treatments are given twice a day.<EOS>
<BOS>Hyperfractionated radiation therapy is given over the same period of time (days or weeks) as standard radiation therapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients may want to think about taking part in a clinical trial.<EOS>
<BOS>For some patients, taking part in a clinical trial may be the best treatment choice.<EOS>
<BOS>Clinical trials are part of the cancer research process.<EOS>
<BOS>Clinical trials are done to find out if new cancer treatments are safe and effective or better than the standard treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Many of today's standard treatments for cancer are based on earlier clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients who take part in a clinical trial may receive the standard treatment or be among the first to receive a new treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients who take part in clinical trials also help improve the way cancer will be treated in the future.<EOS>
<BOS>Even when clinical trials do not lead to effective new treatments, they often answer important questions and help move research forward.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients can enter clinical trials before, during, or after starting their cancer treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Some clinical trials only include patients who have not yet received treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Other trials test treatments for patients whose cancer has not gotten better.<EOS>
<BOS>There are also clinical trials that test new ways to stop cancer from recurring (coming back) or reduce the side effects of cancer treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Clinical trials are taking place in many parts of the country.<EOS>
<BOS>See the Treatment Options section that follows for links to current treatment clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>These have been retrieved from NCI's listing of clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>Followup tests may be needed.<EOS>
<BOS>Some of the tests that were done to diagnose the cancer or to find out the stage of the cancer may be repeated.<EOS>
<BOS>Some tests will be repeated in order to see how well the treatment is working.<EOS>
<BOS>Decisions about whether to continue, change, or stop treatment may be based on the results of these tests.<EOS>
<BOS>Some of the tests will continue to be done from time to time after treatment has ended.<EOS>
<BOS>The results of these tests can show if your condition has changed or if the cancer has recurred (come back).<EOS>
<BOS>These tests are sometimes called followup tests or checkups.<EOS>
<BOS>Treatment Options for Metastatic Squamous Neck Cancer with Occult Primary Untreated Metastatic Squamous Neck Cancer with Occult Primary Treatment of untreated metastatic squamous neck cancer with occult primary may include the following: Radiation therapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Surgery.<EOS>
<BOS>Radiation therapy followed by surgery.<EOS>
<BOS>A clinical trial of chemotherapy followed by radiation therapy.<EOS>
<BOS>A clinical trial of chemotherapy given at the same time as hyperfractionated radiation therapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Clinical trials of new treatments.<EOS>
<BOS>Check the list of NCIsupported cancer clinical trials that are now accepting patients with untreated metastatic squamous neck cancer with occult primary.<EOS>
<BOS>For more specific results, refine the search by using other search features, such as the location of the trial, the type of treatment, or the name of the drug.<EOS>
<BOS>Talk with your doctor about clinical trials that may be right for you.<EOS>
<BOS>General information about clinical trials is available from the NCI website.<EOS>
<BOS>Recurrent Metastatic Squamous Neck Cancer with Occult Primary Treatment of recurrent metastatic squamous neck cancer with occult primary is usually within a clinical trial.<EOS>
<BOS>Check the list of NCIsupported cancer clinical trials that are now accepting patients with recurrent metastatic squamous neck cancer with occult primary.<EOS>
<BOS>For more specific results, refine the search by using other search features, such as the location of the trial, the type of treatment, or the name of the drug.<EOS>
<BOS>Talk with your doctor about clinical trials that may be right for you.<EOS>
<BOS>General information about clinical trials is available from the NCI website.<EOS>
<BOS>Other types of treatment are being tested in clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>Information about clinical trials is available from the NCI website.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients may want to think about taking part in a clinical trial.<EOS>
<BOS>For some patients, taking part in a clinical trial may be the best treatment choice.<EOS>
<BOS>Clinical trials are part of the cancer research process.<EOS>
<BOS>Clinical trials are done to find out if new cancer treatments are safe and effective or better than the standard treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Many of today's standard treatments for cancer are based on earlier clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients who take part in a clinical trial may receive the standard treatment or be among the first to receive a new treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients who take part in clinical trials also help improve the way cancer will be treated in the future.<EOS>
<BOS>Even when clinical trials do not lead to effective new treatments, they often answer important questions and help move research forward.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients can enter clinical trials before, during, or after starting their cancer treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Some clinical trials only include patients who have not yet received treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Other trials test treatments for patients whose cancer has not gotten better.<EOS>
<BOS>There are also clinical trials that test new ways to stop cancer from recurring (coming back) or reduce the side effects of cancer treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Clinical trials are taking place in many parts of the country.<EOS>
<BOS>See the Treatment Options section that follows for links to current treatment clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>These have been retrieved from NCI's listing of clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>Adult soft tissue sarcoma is diagnosed with a biopsy.<EOS>
<BOS>If your doctor thinks you may have a soft tissue sarcoma, a biopsy will be done.<EOS>
<BOS>The type of biopsy will be based on the size of the tumor and where it is in the body.<EOS>
<BOS>There are three types of biopsy that may be used: Incisional biopsy : The removal of part of a lump or a sample of tissue.<EOS>
<BOS>Core biopsy : The removal of tissue using a wide needle.<EOS>
<BOS>Excisional biopsy : The removal of an entire lump or area of tissue that doesnt look normal.<EOS>
<BOS>Samples will be taken from the primary tumor, lymph nodes, and other suspicious areas.<EOS>
<BOS>A pathologist views the tissue under a microscope to look for cancer cells and to find out the grade of the tumor.<EOS>
<BOS>The grade of a tumor depends on how abnormal the cancer cells look under a microscope and how quickly the cells are dividing.<EOS>
<BOS>Highgrade tumors usually grow and spread more quickly than lowgrade tumors.<EOS>
<BOS>Because soft tissue sarcoma can be hard to diagnose, patients should ask to have tissue samples checked by a pathologist who has experience in diagnosing soft tissue sarcoma.<EOS>
<BOS>The following tests may be done on the tissue that was removed: Immunohistochemistry : A test that uses antibodies to check for certain antigens in a sample of tissue.<EOS>
<BOS>The antibody is usually linked to a radioactive substance or a dye that causes the tissue to light up under a microscope.<EOS>
<BOS>This type of test may be used to tell the difference between different types of cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Light and electron microscopy : A laboratory test in which cells in a sample of tissue are viewed under regular and highpowered microscopes to look for certain changes in the cells.<EOS>
<BOS>Cytogenetic analysis : A laboratory test in which cells in a sample of tissue are viewed under a microscope to look for certain changes in the chromosomes.<EOS>
<BOS>FISH (fluorescence in situ hybridization): A laboratory test used to look at genes or chromosomes in cells and tissues.<EOS>
<BOS>Pieces of DNA that contain a fluorescent dye are made in the laboratory and added to cells or tissues on a glass slide.<EOS>
<BOS>When these pieces of DNA attach to certain genes or areas of chromosomes on the slide, they light up when viewed under a microscope with a special light.<EOS>
<BOS>Flow cytometry : A laboratory test that measures the number of cells in a sample, the percentage of live cells in a sample, and certain characteristics of cells, such as size, shape, and the presence of tumor markers on the cell surface.<EOS>
<BOS>The cells are stained with a lightsensitive dye, placed in a fluid, and passed in a stream before a laser or other type of light.<EOS>
<BOS>The measurements are based on how the lightsensitive dye reacts to the light.<EOS>
<BOS>Key Points There are different types of treatment for patients with adult acute myeloid leukemia.<EOS>
<BOS>The treatment of adult AML usually has 2 phases.<EOS>
<BOS>Four types of standard treatment are used: Chemotherapy Radiation therapy Stem cell transplant Other drug therapy New types of treatment are being tested in clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>Targeted therapy Patients may want to think about taking part in a clinical trial.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients can enter clinical trials before, during, or after starting their cancer treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Followup tests may be needed.<EOS>
<BOS>There are different types of treatment for patients with adult acute myeloid leukemia.<EOS>
<BOS>Different types of treatment are available for patients with adult acute myeloid leukemia (AML).<EOS>
<BOS>Some treatments are standard (the currently used treatment), and some are being tested in clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>A treatment clinical trial is a research study meant to help improve current treatments or obtain information on new treatments for patients with cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>When clinical trials show that a new treatment is better than the standard treatment, the new treatment may become the standard treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients may want to think about taking part in a clinical trial.<EOS>
<BOS>Some clinical trials are open only to patients who have not started treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>The treatment of adult AML usually has 2 phases.<EOS>
<BOS>The 2 treatment phases of adult AML are: Remission induction therapy: This is the first phase of treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>The goal is to kill the leukemia cells in the blood and bone marrow.<EOS>
<BOS>This puts the leukemia into remission.<EOS>
<BOS>Postremission therapy: This is the second phase of treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>It begins after the leukemia is in remission.<EOS>
<BOS>The goal of postremission therapy is to kill any remaining leukemia cells that may not be active but could begin to regrow and cause a relapse.<EOS>
<BOS>This phase is also called remission continuation therapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Four types of standard treatment are used: Chemotherapy Chemotherapy is a cancer treatment that uses drugs to stop the growth of cancer cells, either by killing the cells or by stopping them from dividing.<EOS>
<BOS>When chemotherapy is taken by mouth or injected into a vein or muscle, the drugs enter the bloodstream and can reach cancer cells throughout the body (systemic chemotherapy).<EOS>
<BOS>When chemotherapy is placed directly into the cerebrospinal fluid (intrathecal chemotherapy), an organ, or a body cavity such as the abdomen, the drugs mainly affect cancer cells in those areas (regional chemotherapy).<EOS>
<BOS>Intrathecal chemotherapy may be used to treat adult AML that has spread to the brain and spinal cord.<EOS>
<BOS>Combination chemotherapy is treatment using more than one anticancer drug.<EOS>
<BOS>The way the chemotherapy is given depends on the subtype of AML being treated and whether leukemia cells have spread to the brain and spinal cord.<EOS>
<BOS>See Drugs Approved for Acute Myeloid Leukemia for more information.<EOS>
<BOS>Radiation therapy Radiation therapy is a cancer treatment that uses highenergy xrays or other types of radiation to kill cancer cells or keep them from growing.<EOS>
<BOS>There are two types of radiation therapy: External radiation therapy uses a machine outside the body to send radiation toward the cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Internal radiation therapy uses a radioactive substance sealed in needles, seeds, wires, or catheters that are placed directly into or near the cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>The way the radiation therapy is given depends on the type of cancer being treated and whether leukemia cells have spread to the brain and spinal cord.<EOS>
<BOS>External radiation therapy is used to treat adult AML.<EOS>
<BOS>Stem cell transplant Stem cell transplant is a method of giving chemotherapy and replacing blood forming cells that are abnormal or destroyed by the cancer treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Stem cells (immature blood cells) are removed from the blood or bone marrow of the patient or a donor and are frozen and stored.<EOS>
<BOS>After the chemotherapy is completed, the stored stem cells are thawed and given back to the patient through an infusion.<EOS>
<BOS>These reinfused stem cells grow into (and restore) the body's blood cells.<EOS>
<BOS>Other drug therapy Arsenic trioxide and alltrans retinoic acid (ATRA) are anticancer drugs that kill leukemia cells, stop the leukemia cells from dividing, or help the leukemia cells mature into white blood cells.<EOS>
<BOS>These drugs are used in the treatment of a subtype of AML called acute promyelocytic leukemia.<EOS>
<BOS>See Drugs Approved for Acute Myeloid Leukemia for more information.<EOS>
<BOS>New types of treatment are being tested in clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>This summary section describes treatments that are being studied in clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>It may not mention every new treatment being studied.<EOS>
<BOS>Information about clinical trials is available from the NCI website.<EOS>
<BOS>Targeted therapy Targeted therapy is a type of treatment that uses drugs or other substances to identify and attack specific cancer cells without harming normal cells.<EOS>
<BOS>Monoclonal antibody therapy is one type of targeted therapy being studied in the treatment of adult AML.<EOS>
<BOS>Monoclonal antibody therapy is a cancer treatment that uses antibodies made in the laboratory from a single type of immune system cell.<EOS>
<BOS>These antibodies can identify substances on cancer cells or normal substances that may help cancer cells grow.<EOS>
<BOS>The antibodies attach to the substances and kill the cancer cells, block their growth, or keep them from spreading.<EOS>
<BOS>Monoclonal antibodies are given by infusion.<EOS>
<BOS>They may be used alone or to carry drugs, toxins, or radioactive material directly to cancer cells.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients may want to think about taking part in a clinical trial.<EOS>
<BOS>For some patients, taking part in a clinical trial may be the best treatment choice.<EOS>
<BOS>Clinical trials are part of the cancer research process.<EOS>
<BOS>Clinical trials are done to find out if new cancer treatments are safe and effective or better than the standard treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Many of today's standard treatments for cancer are based on earlier clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients who take part in a clinical trial may receive the standard treatment or be among the first to receive a new treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients who take part in clinical trials also help improve the way cancer will be treated in the future.<EOS>
<BOS>Even when clinical trials do not lead to effective new treatments, they often answer important questions and help move research forward.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients can enter clinical trials before, during, or after starting their cancer treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Some clinical trials only include patients who have not yet received treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Other trials test treatments for patients whose cancer has not gotten better.<EOS>
<BOS>There are also clinical trials that test new ways to stop cancer from recurring (coming back) or reduce the side effects of cancer treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Clinical trials are taking place in many parts of the country.<EOS>
<BOS>See the Treatment Options section that follows for links to current treatment clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>These have been retrieved from NCI's listing of clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>Followup tests may be needed.<EOS>
<BOS>Some of the tests that were done to diagnose the cancer or to find out the stage of the cancer may be repeated.<EOS>
<BOS>Some tests will be repeated in order to see how well the treatment is working.<EOS>
<BOS>Decisions about whether to continue, change, or stop treatment may be based on the results of these tests.<EOS>
<BOS>Some of the tests will continue to be done from time to time after treatment has ended.<EOS>
<BOS>The results of these tests can show if your condition has changed or if the cancer has recurred (come back).<EOS>
<BOS>These tests are sometimes called followup tests or checkups.<EOS>
<BOS>Treatment Options for Adult Acute Myeloid Leukemia Untreated Adult Acute Myeloid Leukemia Standard treatment of untreated adult acute myeloid leukemia (AML) during the remission induction phase depends on the subtype of AML and may include the following: Combination chemotherapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Highdose combination chemotherapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Lowdose chemotherapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Intrathecal chemotherapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Alltrans retinoic acid (ATRA) plus arsenic trioxide for the treatment of acute promyelocytic leukemia (APL).<EOS>
<BOS>ATRA plus combination chemotherapy followed by arsenic trioxide for the treatment of APL.<EOS>
<BOS>Check the list of NCIsupported cancer clinical trials that are now accepting patients with untreated adult acute myeloid leukemia.<EOS>
<BOS>For more specific results, refine the search by using other search features, such as the location of the trial, the type of treatment, or the name of the drug.<EOS>
<BOS>Talk with your doctor about clinical trials that may be right for you.<EOS>
<BOS>General information about clinical trials is available from the NCI website.<EOS>
<BOS>Adult Acute Myeloid Leukemia in Remission Treatment of adult AML during the remission phase depends on the subtype of AML and may include the following: Combination chemotherapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Highdose chemotherapy, with or without radiation therapy, and stem cell transplant using the patient's stem cells.<EOS>
<BOS>Highdose chemotherapy and stem cell transplant using donor stem cells.<EOS>
<BOS>A clinical trial of arsenic trioxide.<EOS>
<BOS>Check the list of NCIsupported cancer clinical trials that are now accepting patients with adult acute myeloid leukemia in remission.<EOS>
<BOS>For more specific results, refine the search by using other search features, such as the location of the trial, the type of treatment, or the name of the drug.<EOS>
<BOS>Talk with your doctor about clinical trials that may be right for you.<EOS>
<BOS>General information about clinical trials is available from the NCI website.<EOS>
<BOS>Recurrent Adult Acute Myeloid Leukemia There is no standard treatment for recurrent adult AML.<EOS>
<BOS>Treatment depends on the subtype of AML and may include the following: Combination chemotherapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Targeted therapy with monoclonal antibodies.<EOS>
<BOS>Stem cell transplant.<EOS>
<BOS>Arsenic trioxide therapy.<EOS>
<BOS>A clinical trial of arsenic trioxide therapy followed by stem cell transplant.<EOS>
<BOS>Check the list of NCIsupported cancer clinical trials that are now accepting patients with recurrent adult acute myeloid leukemia.<EOS>
<BOS>For more specific results, refine the search by using other search features, such as the location of the trial, the type of treatment, or the name of the drug.<EOS>
<BOS>Talk with your doctor about clinical trials that may be right for you.<EOS>
<BOS>General information about clinical trials is available from the NCI website.<EOS>
<BOS>Having a weakened immune system may increase the risk of developing primary CNS lymphoma.<EOS>
<BOS>Anything that increases your chance of getting a disease is called a risk factor.<EOS>
<BOS>Having a risk factor does not mean that you will get cancer; not having risk factors doesnt mean that you will not get cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Talk with your doctor if you think you may be at risk.<EOS>
<BOS>Primary CNS lymphoma may occur in patients who have acquired immunodeficiency syndrome (AIDS) or other disorders of the immune system or who have had a kidney transplant.<EOS>
<BOS>For more information about lymphoma in patients with AIDS, see the PDQ summary on AIDSRelated Lymphoma Treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Key Points Ewing sarcoma is a type of tumor that forms in bone or soft tissue.<EOS>
<BOS>Signs and symptoms of Ewing sarcoma include swelling and pain near the tumor.<EOS>
<BOS>Tests that examine the bone and soft tissue are used to diagnose and stage Ewing sarcoma.<EOS>
<BOS>A biopsy is done to diagnose Ewing sarcoma.<EOS>
<BOS>Certain factors affect prognosis (chance of recovery).<EOS>
<BOS>Ewing sarcoma is a type of tumor that forms in bone or soft tissue.<EOS>
<BOS>Ewing sarcoma is a type of tumor that forms from a certain kind of cell in bone or soft tissue.<EOS>
<BOS>Ewing sarcoma may be found in the bones of the legs, arms, feet, hands, chest, pelvis, spine, or skull.<EOS>
<BOS>Ewing sarcoma also may be found in the soft tissue of the trunk, arms, legs, head and neck, abdominal cavity, or other areas.<EOS>
<BOS>Ewing sarcoma is most common in adolescents and young adults.<EOS>
<BOS>Ewing sarcoma has also been called peripheral primitive neuroectodermal tumor, Askin tumor (Ewing sarcoma of the chest wall), extraosseous Ewing sarcoma (Ewing sarcoma in tissue other than bone), and Ewing sarcoma family of tumors.<EOS>
<BOS>Key Points Lung cancer is a disease in which malignant (cancer) cells form in the tissues of the lung.<EOS>
<BOS>Lung cancer is the leading cause of cancer death in both men and women.<EOS>
<BOS>Lung cancer is a disease in which malignant (cancer) cells form in the tissues of the lung.<EOS>
<BOS>The lungs are a pair of coneshaped breathing organs in the chest.<EOS>
<BOS>The lungs bring oxygen into the body as you breathe in.<EOS>
<BOS>They release carbon dioxide, a waste product of the body's cells, as you breathe out.<EOS>
<BOS>Each lung has sections called lobes.<EOS>
<BOS>The left lung has two lobes.<EOS>
<BOS>The right lung is slightly larger, and has three lobes.<EOS>
<BOS>A thin membrane called the pleura surrounds the lungs.<EOS>
<BOS>Two tubes called bronchi lead from the trachea (windpipe) to the right and left lungs.<EOS>
<BOS>The bronchi are sometimes also involved in lung cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Tiny air sacs called alveoli and small tubes called bronchioles make up the inside of the lungs.<EOS>
<BOS>There are two types of lung cancer: small cell lung cancer and nonsmall cell lung cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>See the following PDQ summaries for more information about lung cancer: Lung Cancer Screening NonSmall Cell Lung Cancer Treatment Small Cell Lung Cancer Treatment Lung cancer is the leading cause of cancer death in both men and women.<EOS>
<BOS>More people die from lung cancer than from any other type of cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Lung cancer is the second most common cancer in the United States, after skin cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>The number of new cases and deaths from lung cancer is highest in black men.<EOS>
<BOS>Smoking is the major risk factor for nonsmall cell lung cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Anything that increases your chance of getting a disease is called a risk factor.<EOS>
<BOS>Having a risk factor does not mean that you will get cancer; not having risk factors doesn't mean that you will not get cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Talk to your doctor if you think you may be at risk for lung cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Risk factors for lung cancer include the following: Smoking cigarettes, pipes, or cigars, now or in the past.<EOS>
<BOS>This is the most important risk factor for lung cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>The earlier in life a person starts smoking, the more often a person smokes, and the more years a person smokes, the greater the risk of lung cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Being exposed to secondhand smoke.<EOS>
<BOS>Being exposed to radiation from any of the following: Radiation therapy to the breast or chest.<EOS>
<BOS>Radon in the home or workplace.<EOS>
<BOS>Imaging tests such as CT scans.<EOS>
<BOS>Atomic bomb radiation.<EOS>
<BOS>Being exposed to asbestos, chromium, nickel, beryllium, arsenic, soot, or tar in the workplace.<EOS>
<BOS>Living where there is air pollution.<EOS>
<BOS>Having a family history of lung cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Being infected with the human immunodeficiency virus (HIV).<EOS>
<BOS>Taking beta carotene supplements and being a heavy smoker.<EOS>
<BOS>Older age is the main risk factor for most cancers.<EOS>
<BOS>The chance of getting cancer increases as you get older.<EOS>
<BOS>When smoking is combined with other risk factors, the risk of lung cancer is increased.<EOS>
<BOS>Having certain inherited disorders can increase the risk of an extracranial germ cell tumor.<EOS>
<BOS>Anything that increases your risk of getting a disease is called a risk factor.<EOS>
<BOS>Having a risk factor does not mean that you will get cancer; not having risk factors doesnt mean that you will not get cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Talk with your childs doctor if you think your child may be at risk.<EOS>
<BOS>Possible risk factors for extracranial germ cell tumors include the following: Having certain genetic syndromes: Klinefelter syndrome may increase the risk of germ cell tumors in the mediastinum.<EOS>
<BOS>Swyer syndrome may increase the risk of germ cell tumors in the testicles or ovaries.<EOS>
<BOS>Turner syndrome may increase the risk of germ cell tumors in the ovaries.<EOS>
<BOS>Having an undescended testicle may increase the risk of developing a testicular germ cell tumor.<EOS>
<BOS>Key Points There are different types of treatment for patients with uterine sarcoma.<EOS>
<BOS>Four types of standard treatment are used: Surgery Radiation therapy Chemotherapy Hormone therapy New types of treatment are being tested in clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients may want to think about taking part in a clinical trial.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients can enter clinical trials before, during, or after starting their cancer treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Followup tests may be needed.<EOS>
<BOS>There are different types of treatment for patients with uterine sarcoma.<EOS>
<BOS>Different types of treatments are available for patients with uterine sarcoma.<EOS>
<BOS>Some treatments are standard (the currently used treatment), and some are being tested in clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>A treatment clinical trial is a research study meant to help improve current treatments or obtain information on new treatments for patients with cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>When clinical trials show that a new treatment is better than the standard treatment, the new treatment may become the standard treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients may want to think about taking part in a clinical trial.<EOS>
<BOS>Some clinical trials are open only to patients who have not started treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Four types of standard treatment are used: Surgery Surgery is the most common treatment for uterine sarcoma, as described in the Stages of Uterine Sarcoma section of this summary.<EOS>
<BOS>Even if the doctor removes all the cancer that can be seen at the time of the surgery, some patients may be given chemotherapy or radiation therapy after surgery to kill any cancer cells that are left.<EOS>
<BOS>Treatment given after the surgery, to lower the risk that the cancer will come back, is called adjuvant therapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Radiation therapy Radiation therapy is a cancer treatment that uses high energy xrays or other types of radiation to kill cancer cells or keep them from growing.<EOS>
<BOS>There are two types of radiation therapy: External radiation therapy uses a machine outside the body to send radiation toward the cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Internal radiation therapy uses a radioactive substance sealed in needles, seeds, wires, or catheters that are placed directly into or near the cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>The way the radiation therapy is given depends on the type and stage of the cancer being treated.<EOS>
<BOS>External and internal radiation therapy are used to treat uterine sarcoma, and may also be used as palliative therapy to relieve symptoms and improve quality of life.<EOS>
<BOS>Chemotherapy Chemotherapy is a cancer treatment that uses drugs to stop the growth of cancer cells, either by killing the cells or by stopping them from dividing.<EOS>
<BOS>When chemotherapy is taken by mouth or injected into a vein or muscle, the drugs enter the bloodstream and can reach cancer cells throughout the body (systemic chemotherapy).<EOS>
<BOS>When chemotherapy is placed directly into the cerebrospinal fluid, an organ, or a body cavity such as the abdomen, the drugs mainly affect cancer cells in those areas (regional chemotherapy).<EOS>
<BOS>The way the chemotherapy is given depends on the type and stage of the cancer being treated.<EOS>
<BOS>Hormone therapy Hormone therapy is a cancer treatment that removes hormones or blocks their action and stops cancer cells from growing.<EOS>
<BOS>Hormones are substances produced by glands in the body and circulated in the bloodstream.<EOS>
<BOS>Some hormones can cause certain cancers to grow.<EOS>
<BOS>If tests show the cancer cells have places where hormones can attach (receptors), drugs, surgery, or radiation therapy is used to reduce the production of hormones or block them from working.<EOS>
<BOS>New types of treatment are being tested in clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>Information about clinical trials is available from the NCI website.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients may want to think about taking part in a clinical trial.<EOS>
<BOS>For some patients, taking part in a clinical trial may be the best treatment choice.<EOS>
<BOS>Clinical trials are part of the cancer research process.<EOS>
<BOS>Clinical trials are done to find out if new cancer treatments are safe and effective or better than the standard treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Many of today's standard treatments for cancer are based on earlier clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients who take part in a clinical trial may receive the standard treatment or be among the first to receive a new treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients who take part in clinical trials also help improve the way cancer will be treated in the future.<EOS>
<BOS>Even when clinical trials do not lead to effective new treatments, they often answer important questions and help move research forward.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients can enter clinical trials before, during, or after starting their cancer treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Some clinical trials only include patients who have not yet received treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Other trials test treatments for patients whose cancer has not gotten better.<EOS>
<BOS>There are also clinical trials that test new ways to stop cancer from recurring (coming back) or reduce the side effects of cancer treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Clinical trials are taking place in many parts of the country.<EOS>
<BOS>See the Treatment Options section that follows for links to current treatment clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>These have been retrieved from NCI's listing of clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>Followup tests may be needed.<EOS>
<BOS>Some of the tests that were done to diagnose the cancer or to find out the stage of the cancer may be repeated.<EOS>
<BOS>Some tests will be repeated in order to see how well the treatment is working.<EOS>
<BOS>Decisions about whether to continue, change, or stop treatment may be based on the results of these tests.<EOS>
<BOS>Some of the tests will continue to be done from time to time after treatment has ended.<EOS>
<BOS>The results of these tests can show if your condition has changed or if the cancer has recurred (come back).<EOS>
<BOS>These tests are sometimes called followup tests or checkups.<EOS>
<BOS>Treatment Options by Stage Stage I Uterine Sarcoma Treatment of stage I uterine sarcoma may include the following: Surgery (total abdominal hysterectomy, bilateral salpingooophorectomy, and lymphadenectomy).<EOS>
<BOS>Surgery followed by radiation therapy to the pelvis.<EOS>
<BOS>Surgery followed by chemotherapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Check the list of NCIsupported cancer clinical trials that are now accepting patients with stage I uterine sarcoma.<EOS>
<BOS>For more specific results, refine the search by using other search features, such as the location of the trial, the type of treatment, or the name of the drug.<EOS>
<BOS>Talk with your doctor about clinical trials that may be right for you.<EOS>
<BOS>General information about clinical trials is available from the NCI website.<EOS>
<BOS>Stage II Uterine Sarcoma Treatment of stage II uterine sarcoma may include the following: Surgery (total abdominal hysterectomy, bilateral salpingooophorectomy, and lymphadenectomy).<EOS>
<BOS>Surgery followed by radiation therapy to the pelvis.<EOS>
<BOS>Surgery followed by chemotherapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Check the list of NCIsupported cancer clinical trials that are now accepting patients with stage II uterine sarcoma.<EOS>
<BOS>For more specific results, refine the search by using other search features, such as the location of the trial, the type of treatment, or the name of the drug.<EOS>
<BOS>Talk with your doctor about clinical trials that may be right for you.<EOS>
<BOS>General information about clinical trials is available from the NCI website.<EOS>
<BOS>Stage III Uterine Sarcoma Treatment of stage III uterine sarcoma may include the following: Surgery (total abdominal hysterectomy, bilateral salpingooophorectomy, and lymphadenectomy).<EOS>
<BOS>A clinical trial of surgery followed by radiation therapy to the pelvis.<EOS>
<BOS>A clinical trial of surgery followed by chemotherapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Check the list of NCIsupported cancer clinical trials that are now accepting patients with stage III uterine sarcoma.<EOS>
<BOS>For more specific results, refine the search by using other search features, such as the location of the trial, the type of treatment, or the name of the drug.<EOS>
<BOS>Talk with your doctor about clinical trials that may be right for you.<EOS>
<BOS>General information about clinical trials is available from the NCI website.<EOS>
<BOS>Stage IV Uterine Sarcoma There is no standard treatment for patients with stage IV uterine sarcoma.<EOS>
<BOS>Treatment may include a clinical trial using chemotherapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Check the list of NCIsupported cancer clinical trials that are now accepting patients with stage IV uterine sarcoma.<EOS>
<BOS>For more specific results, refine the search by using other search features, such as the location of the trial, the type of treatment, or the name of the drug.<EOS>
<BOS>Talk with your doctor about clinical trials that may be right for you.<EOS>
<BOS>General information about clinical trials is available from the NCI website.<EOS>
<BOS>Key Points Gestational trophoblastic disease (GTD) is a group of rare diseases in which abnormal trophoblast cells grow inside the uterus after conception.<EOS>
<BOS>Hydatidiform mole (HM) is the most common type of GTD.<EOS>
<BOS>Gestational trophoblastic neoplasia (GTN) is a type of gestational trophoblastic disease (GTD) that is almost always malignant.<EOS>
<BOS>Invasive moles Choriocarcinomas Placentalsite trophoblastic tumors Epithelioid trophoblastic tumors Age and a previous molar pregnancy affect the risk of GTD.<EOS>
<BOS>Signs of GTD include abnormal vaginal bleeding and a uterus that is larger than normal.<EOS>
<BOS>Tests that examine the uterus are used to detect (find) and diagnose gestational trophoblastic disease.<EOS>
<BOS>Certain factors affect prognosis (chance of recovery) and treatment options.<EOS>
<BOS>Gestational trophoblastic disease (GTD) is a group of rare diseases in which abnormal trophoblast cells grow inside the uterus after conception.<EOS>
<BOS>In gestational trophoblastic disease (GTD), a tumor develops inside the uterus from tissue that forms after conception (the joining of sperm and egg).<EOS>
<BOS>This tissue is made of trophoblast cells and normally surrounds the fertilized egg in the uterus.<EOS>
<BOS>Trophoblast cells help connect the fertilized egg to the wall of the uterus and form part of the placenta (the organ that passes nutrients from the mother to the fetus).<EOS>
<BOS>Sometimes there is a problem with the fertilized egg and trophoblast cells.<EOS>
<BOS>Instead of a healthy fetus developing, a tumor forms.<EOS>
<BOS>Until there are signs or symptoms of the tumor, the pregnancy will seem like a normal pregnancy.<EOS>
<BOS>Most GTD is benign (not cancer) and does not spread, but some types become malignant (cancer) and spread to nearby tissues or distant parts of the body.<EOS>
<BOS>Gestational trophoblastic disease (GTD) is a general term that includes different types of disease: Hydatidiform Moles (HM) Complete HM.<EOS>
<BOS>Partial HM.<EOS>
<BOS>Gestational Trophoblastic Neoplasia (GTN) Invasive moles.<EOS>
<BOS>Choriocarcinomas.<EOS>
<BOS>Placentalsite trophoblastic tumors (PSTT; very rare).<EOS>
<BOS>Epithelioid trophoblastic tumors (ETT; even more rare).<EOS>
<BOS>Hydatidiform mole (HM) is the most common type of GTD.<EOS>
<BOS>HMs are slowgrowing tumors that look like sacs of fluid.<EOS>
<BOS>An HM is also called a molar pregnancy.<EOS>
<BOS>The cause of hydatidiform moles is not known.<EOS>
<BOS>HMs may be complete or partial: A complete HM forms when sperm fertilizes an egg that does not contain the mothers DNA.<EOS>
<BOS>The egg has DNA from the father and the cells that were meant to become the placenta are abnormal.<EOS>
<BOS>A partial HM forms when sperm fertilizes a normal egg and there are two sets of DNA from the father in the fertilized egg.<EOS>
<BOS>Only part of the fetus forms and the cells that were meant to become the placenta are abnormal.<EOS>
<BOS>Most hydatidiform moles are benign, but they sometimes become cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Having one or more of the following risk factors increases the risk that a hydatidiform mole will become cancer: A pregnancy before 20 or after 35 years of age.<EOS>
<BOS>A very high level of beta human chorionic gonadotropin (hCG), a hormone made by the body during pregnancy.<EOS>
<BOS>A large tumor in the uterus.<EOS>
<BOS>An ovarian cyst larger than 6 centimeters.<EOS>
<BOS>High blood pressure during pregnancy.<EOS>
<BOS>An overactive thyroid gland (extra thyroid hormone is made).<EOS>
<BOS>Severe nausea and vomiting during pregnancy.<EOS>
<BOS>Trophoblastic cells in the blood, which may block small blood vessels.<EOS>
<BOS>Serious blood clotting problems caused by the HM.<EOS>
<BOS>Gestational trophoblastic neoplasia (GTN) is a type of gestational trophoblastic disease (GTD) that is almost always malignant.<EOS>
<BOS>Gestational trophoblastic neoplasia (GTN) includes the following: Invasive moles Invasive moles are made up of trophoblast cells that grow into the muscle layer of the uterus.<EOS>
<BOS>Invasive moles are more likely to grow and spread than a hydatidiform mole.<EOS>
<BOS>Rarely, a complete or partial HM may become an invasive mole.<EOS>
<BOS>Sometimes an invasive mole will disappear without treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Choriocarcinomas A choriocarcinoma is a malignant tumor that forms from trophoblast cells and spreads to the muscle layer of the uterus and nearby blood vessels.<EOS>
<BOS>It may also spread to other parts of the body, such as the brain, lungs, liver, kidney, spleen, intestines, pelvis, or vagina.<EOS>
<BOS>A choriocarcinoma is more likely to form in women who have had any of the following: Molar pregnancy, especially with a complete hydatidiform mole.<EOS>
<BOS>Normal pregnancy.<EOS>
<BOS>Tubal pregnancy (the fertilized egg implants in the fallopian tube rather than the uterus).<EOS>
<BOS>Miscarriage.<EOS>
<BOS>Placentalsite trophoblastic tumors A placentalsite trophoblastic tumor (PSTT) is a rare type of gestational trophoblastic neoplasia that forms where the placenta attaches to the uterus.<EOS>
<BOS>The tumor forms from trophoblast cells and spreads into the muscle of the uterus and into blood vessels.<EOS>
<BOS>It may also spread to the lungs, pelvis, or lymph nodes.<EOS>
<BOS>A PSTT grows very slowly and signs or symptoms may appear months or years after a normal pregnancy.<EOS>
<BOS>Epithelioid trophoblastic tumors An epithelioid trophoblastic tumor (ETT) is a very rare type of gestational trophoblastic neoplasia that may be benign or malignant.<EOS>
<BOS>When the tumor is malignant, it may spread to the lungs.<EOS>
<BOS>Signs and symptoms of hairy cell leukemia include infections, tiredness, and pain below the ribs.<EOS>
<BOS>These and other signs and symptoms may be caused by hairy cell leukemia or by other conditions.<EOS>
<BOS>Check with your doctor if you have any of the following: Weakness or feeling tired.<EOS>
<BOS>Fever or frequent infections.<EOS>
<BOS>Easy bruising or bleeding.<EOS>
<BOS>Shortness of breath.<EOS>
<BOS>Weight loss for no known reason.<EOS>
<BOS>Pain or a feeling of fullness below the ribs.<EOS>
<BOS>Painless lumps in the neck, underarm, stomach, or groin.<EOS>
<BOS>Key Points There is no staging system for Langerhans cell histiocytosis (LCH).<EOS>
<BOS>Treatment of LCH is based on where LCH cells are found in the body and how many body systems are affected.<EOS>
<BOS>There is no staging system for Langerhans cell histiocytosis (LCH).<EOS>
<BOS>The extent or spread of cancer is usually described as stages.<EOS>
<BOS>There is no staging system for LCH.<EOS>
<BOS>Treatment of LCH is based on where LCH cells are found in the body and how many body systems are affected.<EOS>
<BOS>LCH is described as singlesystem disease or multisystem disease, depending on how many body systems are affected: Singlesystem LCH: LCH is found in one part of an organ or body system (unifocal) or in more than one part of that organ or body system (multifocal).<EOS>
<BOS>Bone is the most common single place for LCH to be found.<EOS>
<BOS>Multisystem LCH: LCH occurs in two or more organs or body systems or may be spread throughout the body.<EOS>
<BOS>Multisystem LCH is less common than singlesystem LCH.<EOS>
<BOS>LCH may affect lowrisk organs or highrisk organs: Lowrisk organs include the skin, bone, lungs, lymph nodes, gastrointestinal tract, pituitary gland, and central nervous system (CNS).<EOS>
<BOS>Highrisk organs include the liver, spleen, and bone marrow.<EOS>
<BOS>Key Points There are different types of treatment for patients with retinoblastoma.<EOS>
<BOS>Children with retinoblastoma should have their treatment planned by a team of health care providers who are experts in treating cancer in children.<EOS>
<BOS>Treatment for retinoblastoma may cause side effects.<EOS>
<BOS>Six types of standard treatment are used: Cryotherapy Thermotherapy Chemotherapy Radiation therapy Highdose chemotherapy with stem cell rescue Surgery (enucleation) New types of treatment are being tested in clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients may want to think about taking part in a clinical trial.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients can enter clinical trials before, during, or after starting their cancer treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Followup tests may be needed.<EOS>
<BOS>There are different types of treatment for patients with retinoblastoma.<EOS>
<BOS>Different types of treatment are available for patients with retinoblastoma.<EOS>
<BOS>Some treatments are standard (the currently used treatment), and some are being tested in clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>A treatment clinical trial is a research study meant to help improve current treatments or obtain information on new treatments for patients with cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>When clinical trials show that a new treatment is better than the standard treatment, the new treatment may become the standard treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Because cancer in children is rare, taking part in a clinical trial should be considered.<EOS>
<BOS>Some clinical trials are open only to patients who have not started treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Children with retinoblastoma should have their treatment planned by a team of health care providers who are experts in treating cancer in children.<EOS>
<BOS>The goals of treatment are to save the child's life, to save vision and the eye, and to prevent serious side effects.<EOS>
<BOS>Treatment will be overseen by a pediatric oncologist, a doctor who specializes in treating children with cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>The pediatric oncologist works with other health care providers who are experts in treating children with eye cancer and who specialize in certain areas of medicine.<EOS>
<BOS>These may include a pediatric ophthalmologist (children's eye doctor) who has a lot of experience in treating retinoblastoma and the following specialists: Pediatric surgeon.<EOS>
<BOS>Radiation oncologist.<EOS>
<BOS>Pediatrician.<EOS>
<BOS>Pediatric nurse specialist.<EOS>
<BOS>Rehabilitation specialist.<EOS>
<BOS>Social worker.<EOS>
<BOS>Geneticist or genetic counselor.<EOS>
<BOS>Treatment for retinoblastoma may cause side effects.<EOS>
<BOS>For information about side effects that begin during treatment for cancer, see our Side Effects page.<EOS>
<BOS>Side effects from cancer treatment that begin after treatment and continue for months or years are called late effects.<EOS>
<BOS>Late effects of treatment for retinoblastoma may include the following: Physical problems such as seeing or hearing problems or, if the eye is removed, a change in the shape and size of the bone around the eye.<EOS>
<BOS>Changes in mood, feelings, thinking, learning, or memory.<EOS>
<BOS>Second cancers (new types of cancer), such as lung and bladder cancers, osteosarcoma, soft tissue sarcoma, or melanoma.<EOS>
<BOS>The following risk factors may increase the risk of having another cancer: Having the heritable form of retinoblastoma.<EOS>
<BOS>Past treatment with radiation therapy, especially before age 1 year.<EOS>
<BOS>Having already had a previous second cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>It is important to talk with your child's doctors about the effects cancer treatment can have on your child.<EOS>
<BOS>Regular followup by health professionals who are experts in diagnosing and treating late effects is important.<EOS>
<BOS>See the PDQ summary on Late Effects of Treatment for Childhood Cancer for more information.<EOS>
<BOS>Six types of standard treatment are used: Cryotherapy Cryotherapy is a treatment that uses an instrument to freeze and destroy abnormal tissue.<EOS>
<BOS>This type of treatment is also called cryosurgery.<EOS>
<BOS>Thermotherapy Thermotherapy is the use of heat to destroy cancer cells.<EOS>
<BOS>Thermotherapy may be given using a laser beam aimed through the dilated pupil or onto the outside of the eyeball.<EOS>
<BOS>Thermotherapy may be used alone for small tumors or combined with chemotherapy for larger tumors.<EOS>
<BOS>This treatment is a type of laser therapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Chemotherapy Chemotherapy is a cancer treatment that uses drugs to stop the growth of cancer cells, either by killing the cells or by stopping them from dividing.<EOS>
<BOS>The way the chemotherapy is given depends on the stage of the cancer and where the cancer is in the body.<EOS>
<BOS>There are different types of chemotherapy: Systemic chemotherapy: When chemotherapy is taken by mouth or injected into a vein or muscle, the drugs enter the bloodstream and can reach cancer cells throughout the body.<EOS>
<BOS>Systemic chemotherapy is given to shrink the tumor (chemoreduction) and avoid surgery to remove the eye.<EOS>
<BOS>After chemoreduction, other treatments may include radiation therapy, cryotherapy, laser therapy, or regional chemotherapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Systemic chemotherapy may also be given to kill any cancer cells that are left after the initial treatment or to patients with retinoblastoma that occurs outside the eye.<EOS>
<BOS>Treatment given after the initial treatment, to lower the risk that the cancer will come back, is called adjuvant therapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Regional chemotherapy: When chemotherapy is placed directly into the cerebrospinal fluid (intrathecal chemotherapy), an organ (such as the eye), or a body cavity, the drugs mainly affect cancer cells in those areas.<EOS>
<BOS>Several types of regional chemotherapy are used to treat retinoblastoma.<EOS>
<BOS>Ophthalmic artery infusion chemotherapy: Ophthalmic artery infusion chemotherapy carries anticancer drugs directly to the eye.<EOS>
<BOS>A catheter is put into an artery that leads to the eye and the anticancer drug is given through the catheter.<EOS>
<BOS>After the drug is given, a small balloon may be inserted into the artery to block it and keep most of the anticancer drug trapped near the tumor.<EOS>
<BOS>This type of chemotherapy may be given as the initial treatment when the tumor is in the eye only or when the tumor has not responded to other types of treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Ophthalmic artery infusion chemotherapy is given at special retinoblastoma treatment centers.<EOS>
<BOS>Intravitreal chemotherapy: Intravitreal chemotherapy is the injection of anticancer drugs directly into the vitreous humor (jellylike substance) inside in the eye.<EOS>
<BOS>It is used to treat cancer that has spread to the vitreous humor and has not responded to treatment or has come back after treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>See Drugs Approved for Retinoblastoma for more information.<EOS>
<BOS>Radiation therapy Radiation therapy is a cancer treatment that uses highenergy xrays or other types of radiation to kill cancer cells or keep them from growing.<EOS>
<BOS>There are two types of radiation therapy: Externalbeam radiation therapy uses a machine outside the body to send radiation toward the cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Certain ways of giving radiation therapy can help keep radiation from damaging nearby healthy tissue.<EOS>
<BOS>These types of radiation therapy include the following: Intensitymodulated radiation therapy (IMRT): IMRT is a type of 3dimensional (3D) external radiation therapy that uses a computer to make pictures of the size and shape of the tumor.<EOS>
<BOS>Thin beams of radiation of different intensities (strengths) are aimed at the tumor from many angles.<EOS>
<BOS>Protonbeam radiation therapy: Protonbeam therapy is a type of highenergy, external radiation therapy.<EOS>
<BOS>A radiation therapy machine aims streams of protons (tiny, invisible, positivelycharged particles) at the cancer cells to kill them.<EOS>
<BOS>Internal radiation therapy uses a radioactive substance sealed in needles, seeds, wires, or catheters that are placed directly into or near the cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Certain ways of giving radiation therapy can help keep radiation from damaging nearby healthy tissue.<EOS>
<BOS>This type of internal radiation therapy may include the following: Plaque radiotherapy: Radioactive seeds are attached to one side of a disk, called a plaque, and placed directly on the outside wall of the eye near the tumor.<EOS>
<BOS>The side of the plaque with the seeds on it faces the eyeball, aiming radiation at the tumor.<EOS>
<BOS>The plaque helps protect other nearby tissue from the radiation.<EOS>
<BOS>The way the radiation therapy is given depends on the type and stage of the cancer being treated and how the cancer responded to other treatments.<EOS>
<BOS>External and internal radiation therapy are used to treat retinoblastoma.<EOS>
<BOS>Highdose chemotherapy with stem cell rescue Highdose chemotherapy with stem cell rescue is a way of giving high doses of chemotherapy and replacing blood forming cells destroyed by the cancer treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Stem cells (immature blood cells) are removed from the blood or bone marrow of the patient and are frozen and stored.<EOS>
<BOS>After the chemotherapy is completed, the stored stem cells are thawed and given back to the patient through an infusion.<EOS>
<BOS>These reinfused stem cells grow into (and restore) the body's blood cells.<EOS>
<BOS>See Drugs Approved for Retinoblastoma for more information.<EOS>
<BOS>Surgery (enucleation) Enucleation is surgery to remove the eye and part of the optic nerve.<EOS>
<BOS>A sample of the eye tissue that is removed will be checked under a microscope to see if there are any signs that the cancer is likely to spread to other parts of the body.<EOS>
<BOS>This should be done by an experienced pathologist, who is familiar with retinoblastoma and other diseases of the eye.<EOS>
<BOS>Enucleation is done if there is little or no chance that vision can be saved and when the tumor is large, did not respond to treatment, or comes back after treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>The patient will be fitted for an artificial eye.<EOS>
<BOS>Close followup is needed for 2 years or more to check for signs of recurrence in the area around the affected eye and to check the other eye.<EOS>
<BOS>New types of treatment are being tested in clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>Information about clinical trials is available from the NCI website.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients may want to think about taking part in a clinical trial.<EOS>
<BOS>For some patients, taking part in a clinical trial may be the best treatment choice.<EOS>
<BOS>Clinical trials are part of the cancer research process.<EOS>
<BOS>Clinical trials are done to find out if new cancer treatments are safe and effective or better than the standard treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Many of today's standard treatments for cancer are based on earlier clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients who take part in a clinical trial may receive the standard treatment or be among the first to receive a new treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients who take part in clinical trials also help improve the way cancer will be treated in the future.<EOS>
<BOS>Even when clinical trials do not lead to effective new treatments, they often answer important questions and help move research forward.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients can enter clinical trials before, during, or after starting their cancer treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Some clinical trials only include patients who have not yet received treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Other trials test treatments for patients whose cancer has not gotten better.<EOS>
<BOS>There are also clinical trials that test new ways to stop cancer from recurring (coming back) or reduce the side effects of cancer treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Clinical trials are taking place in many parts of the country.<EOS>
<BOS>See the Treatment Options section that follows for links to current treatment clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>These have been retrieved from NCI's listing of clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>Followup tests may be needed.<EOS>
<BOS>Some of the tests that were done to diagnose the cancer or to find out the stage of the cancer may be repeated.<EOS>
<BOS>Some tests will be repeated in order to see how well the treatment is working.<EOS>
<BOS>Decisions about whether to continue, change, or stop treatment may be based on the results of these tests.<EOS>
<BOS>Some of the tests will continue to be done from time to time after treatment has ended.<EOS>
<BOS>The results of these tests can show if your child's condition has changed or if the cancer has recurred (come back).<EOS>
<BOS>These tests are sometimes called followup tests or checkups.<EOS>
<BOS>Treatment Options for Retinoblastoma Treatment of Unilateral, Bilateral, and Cavitary Retinoblastoma If it is likely that the eye can be saved, treatment may include the following: Systemic chemotherapy or ophthalmic artery infusion chemotherapy, with or without intravitreal chemotherapy, to shrink the tumor.<EOS>
<BOS>This may be followed by one or more of the following: Cryotherapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Thermotherapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Plaque radiotherapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Externalbeam radiation therapy for bilateral intraocular retinoblastoma that does not respond to other treatments.<EOS>
<BOS>A clinical trial of ophthalmic artery infusion for unilateral retinoblastoma that has spread to the vitreous humor.<EOS>
<BOS>If the tumor is large and it is not likely that the eye can be saved, treatment may include the following: Surgery (enucleation).<EOS>
<BOS>After surgery, systemic chemotherapy may be given to lower the risk that the cancer will spread to other parts of the body.<EOS>
<BOS>When retinoblastoma is in both eyes, the treatment for each eye may be different, depending on the size of the tumor and whether it is likely that the eye can be saved.<EOS>
<BOS>The dose of systemic chemotherapy is usually based on the eye that has more cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Treatment for cavitary retinoblastoma, a type of intraocular retinoblastoma, may include the following: Systemic chemotherapy or ophthalmic artery infusion chemotherapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Check the list of NCIsupported cancer clinical trials that are now accepting patients with intraocular retinoblastoma.<EOS>
<BOS>For more specific results, refine the search by using other search features, such as the location of the trial, the type of treatment, or the name of the drug.<EOS>
<BOS>Talk with your child's doctor about clinical trials that may be right for your child.<EOS>
<BOS>General information about clinical trials is available from the NCI website.<EOS>
<BOS>Treatment of Extraocular Retinoblastoma Treatment for extraocular retinoblastoma that has spread to the area around the eye may include the following: Systemic chemotherapy and externalbeam radiation therapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Systemic chemotherapy followed by surgery (enucleation).<EOS>
<BOS>Externalbeam radiation therapy and more chemotherapy may be given after surgery.<EOS>
<BOS>Treatment for extraocular retinoblastoma that has spread to the brain may include the following: Systemic or intrathecal chemotherapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Externalbeam radiation therapy to the brain and spinal cord.<EOS>
<BOS>Chemotherapy followed by highdose chemotherapy with stem cell rescue.<EOS>
<BOS>It is not clear whether treatment with chemotherapy, radiation therapy, or highdose chemotherapy with stem cell rescue helps patients with extraocular retinoblastoma live longer.<EOS>
<BOS>For trilateral retinoblastoma, treatment may include the following: Systemic chemotherapy followed by highdose chemotherapy with stem cell rescue.<EOS>
<BOS>Systemic chemotherapy followed by surgery and externalbeam radiation therapy.<EOS>
<BOS>For retinoblastoma that has spread to other parts of the body, but not the brain, treatment may include the following: Chemotherapy followed by highdose chemotherapy with stem cell rescue and externalbeam radiation therapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Check the list of NCIsupported cancer clinical trials that are now accepting patients with extraocular retinoblastoma.<EOS>
<BOS>For more specific results, refine the search by using other search features, such as the location of the trial, the type of treatment, or the name of the drug.<EOS>
<BOS>Talk with your child's doctor about clinical trials that may be right for your child.<EOS>
<BOS>General information about clinical trials is available from the NCI website.<EOS>
<BOS>Treatment of Progressive or Recurrent Retinoblastoma Treatment of progressive or recurrent intraocular retinoblastoma may include the following: Externalbeam radiation therapy or plaque radiotherapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Cryotherapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Thermotherapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Systemic chemotherapy or ophthalmic artery infusion chemotherapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Intravitreal chemotherapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Surgery (enucleation).<EOS>
<BOS>Treatment of progressive or recurrent extraocular retinoblastoma may include the following: Systemic chemotherapy and externalbeam radiation therapy for retinoblastoma that comes back after surgery to remove the eye.<EOS>
<BOS>Systemic chemotherapy followed by highdose chemotherapy with stem cell rescue and externalbeam radiation therapy.<EOS>
<BOS>A clinical trial of a new treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Check the list of NCIsupported cancer clinical trials that are now accepting patients with recurrent retinoblastoma.<EOS>
<BOS>For more specific results, refine the search by using other search features, such as the location of the trial, the type of treatment, or the name of the drug.<EOS>
<BOS>Talk with your child's doctor about clinical trials that may be right for your child.<EOS>
<BOS>General information about clinical trials is available from the NCI website.<EOS>
<BOS>Cancer prevention clinical trials are used to study ways to prevent cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Cancer prevention clinical trials are used to study ways to lower the risk of developing certain types of cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Some cancer prevention trials are conducted with healthy people who have not had cancer but who have an increased risk for cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Other prevention trials are conducted with people who have had cancer and are trying to prevent another cancer of the same type or to lower their chance of developing a new type of cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Other trials are done with healthy volunteers who are not known to have any risk factors for cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>The purpose of some cancer prevention clinical trials is to find out whether actions people take can prevent cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>These may include exercising more or quitting smoking or taking certain medicines, vitamins, minerals, or food supplements.<EOS>
<BOS>New ways to prevent breast cancer are being studied in clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>New types of treatment are being tested in clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>Information about clinical trials is available from the NCI website.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients may want to think about taking part in a clinical trial.<EOS>
<BOS>For some patients, taking part in a clinical trial may be the best treatment choice.<EOS>
<BOS>Clinical trials are part of the cancer research process.<EOS>
<BOS>Clinical trials are done to find out if new cancer treatments are safe and effective or better than the standard treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Many of today's standard treatments for cancer are based on earlier clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients who take part in a clinical trial may receive the standard treatment or be among the first to receive a new treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients who take part in clinical trials also help improve the way cancer will be treated in the future.<EOS>
<BOS>Even when clinical trials do not lead to effective new treatments, they often answer important questions and help move research forward.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients can enter clinical trials before, during, or after starting their cancer treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Some clinical trials only include patients who have not yet received treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Other trials test treatments for patients whose cancer has not gotten better.<EOS>
<BOS>There are also clinical trials that test new ways to stop cancer from recurring (coming back) or reduce the side effects of cancer treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Clinical trials are taking place in many parts of the country.<EOS>
<BOS>See the Treatment Options section that follows for links to current treatment clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>These have been retrieved from NCI's listing of clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>New types of treatment are being tested in clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>This summary section describes treatments that are being studied in clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>It may not mention every new treatment being studied.<EOS>
<BOS>Information about clinical trials is available from the NCI website.<EOS>
<BOS>Highdose chemotherapy with stem cell transplant Highdose chemotherapy with stem cell transplant is a way of giving high doses of chemotherapy and replacing blood forming cells destroyed by the cancer treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Stem cells (immature blood cells) are removed from the blood or bone marrow of the patient or a donor and are frozen and stored.<EOS>
<BOS>After the chemotherapy is completed, the stored stem cells are thawed and given back to the patient through an infusion.<EOS>
<BOS>These reinfused stem cells grow into (and restore) the bodys blood cells.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients may want to think about taking part in a clinical trial.<EOS>
<BOS>For some patients, taking part in a clinical trial may be the best treatment choice.<EOS>
<BOS>Clinical trials are part of the cancer research process.<EOS>
<BOS>Clinical trials are done to find out if new cancer treatments are safe and effective or better than the standard treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Many of today's standard treatments for cancer are based on earlier clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients who take part in a clinical trial may receive the standard treatment or be among the first to receive a new treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients who take part in clinical trials also help improve the way cancer will be treated in the future.<EOS>
<BOS>Even when clinical trials do not lead to effective new treatments, they often answer important questions and help move research forward.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients can enter clinical trials before, during, or after starting their cancer treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Some clinical trials only include patients who have not yet received treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Other trials test treatments for patients whose cancer has not gotten better.<EOS>
<BOS>There are also clinical trials that test new ways to stop cancer from recurring (coming back) or reduce the side effects of cancer treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Clinical trials are taking place in many parts of the country.<EOS>
<BOS>Information about clinical trials is available from the NCI website.<EOS>
<BOS>Key Points After an extragonadal germ cell tumor has been diagnosed, tests are done to find out if cancer cells have spread to other parts of the body.<EOS>
<BOS>There are three ways that cancer spreads in the body.<EOS>
<BOS>Cancer may spread from where it began to other parts of the body.<EOS>
<BOS>The following prognostic groups are used for extragonadal germ cell tumors: Good prognosis Intermediate prognosis Poor prognosis After an extragonadal germ cell tumor has been diagnosed, tests are done to find out if cancer cells have spread to other parts of the body.<EOS>
<BOS>The extent or spread of cancer is usually described as stages.<EOS>
<BOS>For extragonadal germ cell tumors, prognostic groups are used instead of stages.<EOS>
<BOS>The tumors are grouped according to how well the cancer is expected to respond to treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>It is important to know the prognostic group in order to plan treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>There are three ways that cancer spreads in the body.<EOS>
<BOS>Cancer can spread through tissue, the lymph system, and the blood: Tissue.<EOS>
<BOS>The cancer spreads from where it began by growing into nearby areas.<EOS>
<BOS>Lymph system.<EOS>
<BOS>The cancer spreads from where it began by getting into the lymph system.<EOS>
<BOS>The cancer travels through the lymph vessels to other parts of the body.<EOS>
<BOS>Blood.<EOS>
<BOS>The cancer spreads from where it began by getting into the blood.<EOS>
<BOS>The cancer travels through the blood vessels to other parts of the body.<EOS>
<BOS>Cancer may spread from where it began to other parts of the body.<EOS>
<BOS>When cancer spreads to another part of the body, it is called metastasis.<EOS>
<BOS>Cancer cells break away from where they began (the primary tumor) and travel through the lymph system or blood.<EOS>
<BOS>Lymph system.<EOS>
<BOS>The cancer gets into the lymph system, travels through the lymph vessels, and forms a tumor (metastatic tumor) in another part of the body.<EOS>
<BOS>Blood.<EOS>
<BOS>The cancer gets into the blood, travels through the blood vessels, and forms a tumor (metastatic tumor) in another part of the body.<EOS>
<BOS>The metastatic tumor is the same type of tumor as the primary tumor.<EOS>
<BOS>For example, if an extragonadal germ cell tumor spreads to the lung, the tumor cells in the lung are actually cancerous germ cells.<EOS>
<BOS>The disease is metastatic extragonadal germ cell tumor, not lung cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>The following prognostic groups are used for extragonadal germ cell tumors: Good prognosis A nonseminoma extragonadal germ cell tumor is in the good prognosis group if: the tumor is in the back of the abdomen; and the tumor has not spread to organs other than the lungs; and the levels of tumor markers AFP and hCG are normal and LDH is slightly above normal.<EOS>
<BOS>A seminoma extragonadal germ cell tumor is in the good prognosis group if: the tumor has not spread to organs other than the lungs; and the level of AFP is normal; hCG and LDH may be at any level.<EOS>
<BOS>Intermediate prognosis A nonseminoma extragonadal germ cell tumor is in the intermediate prognosis group if: the tumor is in the back of the abdomen; and the tumor has not spread to organs other than the lungs; and the level of any one of the tumor markers (AFP, hCG, or LDH) is more than slightly above normal.<EOS>
<BOS>A seminoma extragonadal germ cell tumor is in the intermediate prognosis group if: the tumor has spread to organs other than the lungs; and the level of AFP is normal; hCG and LDH may be at any level.<EOS>
<BOS>Poor prognosis A nonseminoma extragonadal germ cell tumor is in the poor prognosis group if: the tumor is in the chest; or the tumor has spread to organs other than the lungs; or the level of any one of the tumor markers (AFP, hCG, or LDH) is high.<EOS>
<BOS>Seminoma extragonadal germ cell tumor does not have a poor prognosis group.<EOS>
<BOS>Signs and symptoms of juvenile myelomonocytic leukemia include fever, weight loss, and feeling very tired.<EOS>
<BOS>These and other signs and symptoms may be caused by JMML or by other conditions.<EOS>
<BOS>Check with your doctor if you have any of the following: Fever for no known reason.<EOS>
<BOS>Having infections, such as bronchitis or tonsillitis.<EOS>
<BOS>Feeling very tired.<EOS>
<BOS>Easy bruising or bleeding.<EOS>
<BOS>Skin rash.<EOS>
<BOS>Painless swelling of the lymph nodes in the neck, underarm, stomach, or groin.<EOS>
<BOS>Pain or a feeling of fullness below the ribs.<EOS>
<BOS>Key Points Merkel cell carcinoma is a very rare disease in which malignant (cancer) cells form in the skin.<EOS>
<BOS>Sun exposure and having a weak immune system can affect the risk of Merkel cell carcinoma.<EOS>
<BOS>Merkel cell carcinoma usually appears as a single painless lump on sunexposed skin.<EOS>
<BOS>Tests and procedures that examine the skin are used to detect (find) and diagnose Merkel cell carcinoma.<EOS>
<BOS>Certain factors affect prognosis (chance of recovery) and treatment options.<EOS>
<BOS>Merkel cell carcinoma is a very rare disease in which malignant (cancer) cells form in the skin.<EOS>
<BOS>Merkel cells are found in the top layer of the skin.<EOS>
<BOS>These cells are very close to the nerve endings that receive the sensation of touch.<EOS>
<BOS>Merkel cell carcinoma, also called neuroendocrine carcinoma of the skin or trabecular cancer, is a very rare type of skin cancer that forms when Merkel cells grow out of control.<EOS>
<BOS>Merkel cell carcinoma starts most often in areas of skin exposed to the sun, especially the head and neck, as well as the arms, legs, and trunk.<EOS>
<BOS>Merkel cell carcinoma tends to grow quickly and to metastasize (spread) at an early stage.<EOS>
<BOS>It usually spreads first to nearby lymph nodes and then may spread to lymph nodes or skin in distant parts of the body, lungs, brain, bones, or other organs.<EOS>
<BOS>Tests that examine the breasts are used to detect (find) and diagnose breast cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Check with your doctor if you notice any changes in your breasts.<EOS>
<BOS>The following tests and procedures may be used: Physical exam and history : An exam of the body to check general signs of health, including checking for signs of disease, such as lumps or anything else that seems unusual.<EOS>
<BOS>A history of the patients health habits and past illnesses and treatments will also be taken.<EOS>
<BOS>Clinical breast exam (CBE): An exam of the breast by a doctor or other health professional.<EOS>
<BOS>The doctor will carefully feel the breasts and under the arms for lumps or anything else that seems unusual.<EOS>
<BOS>Mammogram: An xray of the breast.<EOS>
<BOS>Ultrasound exam: A procedure in which highenergy sound waves (ultrasound) are bounced off internal tissues or organs and make echoes.<EOS>
<BOS>The echoes form a picture of body tissues called a sonogram.<EOS>
<BOS>The picture can be printed to be looked at later.<EOS>
<BOS>MRI (magnetic resonance imaging): A procedure that uses a magnet, radio waves, and a computer to make a series of detailed pictures of both breasts.<EOS>
<BOS>This procedure is also called nuclear magnetic resonance imaging (NMRI).<EOS>
<BOS>Blood chemistry studies : A procedure in which a blood sample is checked to measure the amounts of certain substances released into the blood by organs and tissues in the body.<EOS>
<BOS>An unusual (higher or lower than normal) amount of a substance can be a sign of disease.<EOS>
<BOS>Biopsy : The removal of cells or tissues so they can be viewed under a microscope by a pathologist to check for signs of cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>If a lump in the breast is found, a biopsy may be done.<EOS>
<BOS>There are four types of biopsy used to check for breast cancer: Excisional biopsy : The removal of an entire lump of tissue.<EOS>
<BOS>Incisional biopsy : The removal of part of a lump or a sample of tissue.<EOS>
<BOS>Core biopsy : The removal of tissue using a wide needle.<EOS>
<BOS>Fineneedle aspiration (FNA) biopsy : The removal of tissue or fluid, using a thin needle.<EOS>
<BOS>If cancer is found, tests are done to study the cancer cells.<EOS>
<BOS>Decisions about the best treatment are based on the results of these tests.<EOS>
<BOS>The tests give information about: how quickly the cancer may grow.<EOS>
<BOS>how likely it is that the cancer will spread through the body.<EOS>
<BOS>how well certain treatments might work.<EOS>
<BOS>how likely the cancer is to recur (come back).<EOS>
<BOS>Tests include the following: Estrogen and progesterone receptor test : A test to measure the amount of estrogen and progesterone (hormones) receptors in cancer tissue.<EOS>
<BOS>If there are more estrogen and progesterone receptors than normal, the cancer is called estrogen and/or progesterone receptor positive.<EOS>
<BOS>This type of breast cancer may grow more quickly.<EOS>
<BOS>The test results show whether treatment to block estrogen and progesterone may stop the cancer from growing.<EOS>
<BOS>Human epidermal growth factor type 2 receptor (HER2/neu) test : A laboratory test to measure how many HER2/neu genes there are and how much HER2/neu protein is made in a sample of tissue.<EOS>
<BOS>If there are more HER2/neu genes or higher levels of HER2/neu protein than normal, the cancer is called HER2/neu positive.<EOS>
<BOS>This type of breast cancer may grow more quickly and is more likely to spread to other parts of the body.<EOS>
<BOS>The cancer may be treated with drugs that target the HER2/neu protein, such as trastuzumab and pertuzumab.<EOS>
<BOS>Multigene tests: Tests in which samples of tissue are studied to look at the activity of many genes at the same time.<EOS>
<BOS>These tests may help predict whether cancer will spread to other parts of the body or recur (come back).<EOS>
<BOS>There are many types of multigene tests.<EOS>
