<BOS>The following multigene tests have been studied in clinical trials: Oncotype DX : This test helps predict whether stage I or stage II breast cancer that is estrogen receptor positive and node negative will spread to other parts of the body.<EOS>
<BOS>If the risk that the cancer will spread is high, chemotherapy may be given to lower the risk.<EOS>
<BOS>MammaPrint : This test helps predict whether stage I or stage II breast cancer that is node negative will spread to other parts of the body.<EOS>
<BOS>If the risk that the cancer will spread is high, chemotherapy may be given to lower the risk.<EOS>
<BOS>Based on these tests, breast cancer is described as one of the following types: Hormone receptor positive (estrogen and/or progesterone receptor positive) or hormone receptor negative (estrogen and/or progesterone receptor negative).<EOS>
<BOS>HER2/neu positive or HER2/neu negative.<EOS>
<BOS>Triple negative (estrogen receptor, progesterone receptor, and HER2/neu negative).<EOS>
<BOS>This information helps the doctor decide which treatments will work best for your cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Human papillomavirus infection may increase the risk of developing penile cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Anything that increases your chance of getting a disease is called a risk factor.<EOS>
<BOS>Having a risk factor does not mean that you will get cancer; not having risk factors doesn't mean that you will not get cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Talk with your doctor if you think you may be at risk.<EOS>
<BOS>Risk factors for penile cancer include the following: Circumcision may help prevent infection with the human papillomavirus (HPV).<EOS>
<BOS>A circumcision is an operation in which the doctor removes part or all of the foreskin from the penis.<EOS>
<BOS>Many boys are circumcised shortly after birth.<EOS>
<BOS>Men who were not circumcised at birth may have a higher risk of developing penile cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Other risk factors for penile cancer include the following: Being age 60 or older.<EOS>
<BOS>Having phimosis (a condition in which the foreskin of the penis cannot be pulled back over the glans).<EOS>
<BOS>Having poor personal hygiene.<EOS>
<BOS>Having many sexual partners.<EOS>
<BOS>Using tobacco products.<EOS>
<BOS>Certain factors affect prognosis (chance of recovery) and treatment options.<EOS>
<BOS>The prognosis (chance of recovery) depends on the stage and grade of the tumor.<EOS>
<BOS>The treatment options depend on the following: The stage and grade of the tumor.<EOS>
<BOS>Where the tumor is.<EOS>
<BOS>Whether the patient's other kidney is healthy.<EOS>
<BOS>Whether the cancer has recurred.<EOS>
<BOS>Most transitional cell cancer of the renal pelvis and ureter can be cured if found early.<EOS>
<BOS>Tests are used to screen for Wilms tumor.<EOS>
<BOS>Screening tests are done in children with an increased risk of Wilms tumor.<EOS>
<BOS>These tests may help find cancer early and decrease the chance of dying from cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>In general, children with an increased risk of Wilms tumor should be screened for Wilms tumor every three months until they are at least 8 years old.<EOS>
<BOS>An ultrasound test of the abdomen is usually used for screening.<EOS>
<BOS>Small Wilms tumors may be found and removed before symptoms occur.<EOS>
<BOS>Children with BeckwithWiedemann syndrome or hemihyperplasia are also screened for liver and adrenal tumors that are linked to these genetic syndromes.<EOS>
<BOS>A test to check the alphafetoprotein (AFP) level in the blood and an ultrasound of the abdomen are done until the child is 4 years old.<EOS>
<BOS>An ultrasound of the kidneys is done after the child is 4 years old.<EOS>
<BOS>In children with certain gene changes, a different schedule for ultrasound of the abdomen may be used.<EOS>
<BOS>Children with aniridia and a certain gene change are screened for Wilms tumor every three months until they are 8 years old.<EOS>
<BOS>An ultrasound test of the abdomen is used for screening.<EOS>
<BOS>Some children develop Wilms tumor in both kidneys.<EOS>
<BOS>These often appear when Wilms tumor is first diagnosed, but Wilms tumor may also occur in the second kidney after the child is successfully treated for Wilms tumor in one kidney.<EOS>
<BOS>Children with an increased risk of a second Wilms tumor in the other kidney should be screened for Wilms tumor every three months for up to eight years.<EOS>
<BOS>An ultrasound test of the abdomen may be used for screening.<EOS>
<BOS>Tests that examine the kidney and the blood are used to detect (find) and diagnose Wilms tumor and other childhood kidney tumors.<EOS>
<BOS>The following tests and procedures may be used: Physical exam and history : An exam of the body to check general signs of health, including checking for signs of disease, such as lumps or anything else that seems unusual.<EOS>
<BOS>A history of the patients health habits and past illnesses and treatments will also be taken.<EOS>
<BOS>Complete blood count (CBC): A procedure in which a sample of blood is drawn and checked for the following: The number of red blood cells, white blood cells, and platelets.<EOS>
<BOS>The amount of hemoglobin (the protein that carries oxygen) in the red blood cells.<EOS>
<BOS>The portion of the blood sample made up of red blood cells.<EOS>
<BOS>Blood chemistry studies : A procedure in which a blood sample is checked to measure the amounts of certain substances released into the blood by organs and tissues in the body.<EOS>
<BOS>An unusual (higher or lower than normal) amount of a substance can be a sign of disease.<EOS>
<BOS>This test is done to check how well the liver and kidneys are working.<EOS>
<BOS>Renal function test : A procedure in which blood or urine samples are checked to measure the amounts of certain substances released into the blood or urine by the kidneys.<EOS>
<BOS>A higher or lower than normal amount of a substance can be a sign that the kidneys are not working as they should.<EOS>
<BOS>Urinalysis : A test to check the color of urine and its contents, such as sugar, protein, blood, and bacteria.<EOS>
<BOS>Ultrasound exam: A procedure in which highenergy sound waves (ultrasound) are bounced off internal tissues or organs and make echoes.<EOS>
<BOS>The echoes form a picture of body tissues called a sonogram.<EOS>
<BOS>An ultrasound of the abdomen is done to diagnose a kidney tumor.<EOS>
<BOS>CT scan (CAT scan): A procedure that makes a series of detailed pictures of areas inside the body, such as the chest, abdomen, and pelvis, taken from different angles.<EOS>
<BOS>The pictures are made by a computer linked to an xray machine.<EOS>
<BOS>A dye is injected into a vein or swallowed to help the organs or tissues show up more clearly.<EOS>
<BOS>This procedure is also called computed tomography, computerized tomography, or computerized axial tomography.<EOS>
<BOS>MRI (magnetic resonance imaging) with gadolinium: A procedure that uses a magnet, radio waves, and a computer to make a series of detailed pictures of areas inside the body, such as the abdomen.<EOS>
<BOS>A substance called gadolinium is injected into a vein.<EOS>
<BOS>The gadolinium collects around the cancer cells so they show up brighter in the picture.<EOS>
<BOS>This procedure is also called nuclear magnetic resonance imaging (NMRI).<EOS>
<BOS>Xray: An xray is a type of energy beam that can go through the body and onto film, making a picture of areas inside the body, such as the chest and abdomen.<EOS>
<BOS>PETCT scan : A procedure that combines the pictures from a positron emission tomography (PET) scan and a computed tomography (CT) scan.<EOS>
<BOS>The PET and CT scans are done at the same time on the same machine.<EOS>
<BOS>The pictures from both scans are combined to make a more detailed picture than either test would make by itself.<EOS>
<BOS>A PET scan is a procedure to find malignant tumor cells in the body.<EOS>
<BOS>A small amount of radioactive glucose (sugar) is injected into a vein.<EOS>
<BOS>The PET scanner rotates around the body and makes a picture of where glucose is being used in the body.<EOS>
<BOS>Malignant tumor cells show up brighter in the picture because they are more active and take up more glucose than normal cells do.<EOS>
<BOS>Biopsy : The removal of cells or tissues so they can be viewed under a microscope by a pathologist to check for signs of cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>The decision of whether to do a biopsy is based on the following: The size of the tumor.<EOS>
<BOS>The stage of the cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Whether cancer is in one or both kidneys.<EOS>
<BOS>Whether imaging tests clearly show the cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Whether the tumor can be removed by surgery.<EOS>
<BOS>Whether the patient is in a clinical trial.<EOS>
<BOS>A biopsy may be done before any treatment is given, after chemotherapy to shrink the tumor, or after surgery to remove the tumor.<EOS>
<BOS>EpsteinBarr virus infection increases the risk of childhood Hodgkin lymphoma.<EOS>
<BOS>Anything that increases your risk of getting a disease is called a risk factor.<EOS>
<BOS>Having a risk factor does not mean that you will get cancer; not having risk factors doesnt mean that you will not get cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Talk with your childs doctor if you think your child may be at risk.<EOS>
<BOS>Risk factors for childhood Hodgkin lymphoma include the following: Being infected with the EpsteinBarr virus.<EOS>
<BOS>Being infected with the human immunodeficiency virus (HIV).<EOS>
<BOS>Having certain diseases of the immune system.<EOS>
<BOS>Having a personal history of mononucleosis ("mono").<EOS>
<BOS>Having a parent or sibling with a personal history of Hodgkin lymphoma.<EOS>
<BOS>Being exposed to common infections in early childhood may decrease the risk of Hodgkin lymphoma in children because of the effect it has on the immune system.<EOS>
<BOS>Signs of adult Hodgkin lymphoma include swollen lymph nodes, fever, night sweats, and weight loss.<EOS>
<BOS>These and other signs and symptoms may be caused by adult Hodgkin lymphoma or by other conditions.<EOS>
<BOS>Check with your doctor if any of the following do not go away: Painless, swollen lymph nodes in the neck, underarm, or groin.<EOS>
<BOS>Fever for no known reason.<EOS>
<BOS>Drenching night sweats.<EOS>
<BOS>Weight loss for no known reason.<EOS>
<BOS>Itchy skin.<EOS>
<BOS>Feeling very tired.<EOS>
<BOS>Skin color and being exposed to sunlight can increase the risk of nonmelanoma skin cancer and actinic keratosis.<EOS>
<BOS>Anything that increases your chance of getting a disease is called a risk factor.<EOS>
<BOS>Having a risk factor does not mean that you will get cancer; not having risk factors doesnt mean that you will not get cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Talk with your doctor if you think you may be at risk.<EOS>
<BOS>Risk factors for basal cell carcinoma and squamous cell carcinoma include the following: Being exposed to natural sunlight or artificial sunlight (such as from tanning beds) over long periods of time.<EOS>
<BOS>Having a fair complexion, which includes the following: Fair skin that freckles and burns easily, does not tan, or tans poorly.<EOS>
<BOS>Blue or green or other lightcolored eyes.<EOS>
<BOS>Red or blond hair.<EOS>
<BOS>Having actinic keratosis.<EOS>
<BOS>Past treatment with radiation.<EOS>
<BOS>Having a weakened immune system.<EOS>
<BOS>Having certain changes in the genes that are linked to skin cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Being exposed to arsenic.<EOS>
<BOS>Key Points After a gastrointestinal stromal tumor has been diagnosed, tests are done to find out if cancer cells have spread within the gastrointestinal tract or to other parts of the body.<EOS>
<BOS>There are three ways that cancer spreads in the body.<EOS>
<BOS>Cancer may spread from where it began to other parts of the body.<EOS>
<BOS>The results of diagnostic and staging tests are used to plan treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>After a gastrointestinal stromal tumor has been diagnosed, tests are done to find out if cancer cells have spread within the gastrointestinal tract or to other parts of the body.<EOS>
<BOS>The process used to find out if cancer has spread within the gastrointestinal (GI) tract or to other parts of the body is called staging.<EOS>
<BOS>The information gathered from the staging process determines the stage of the disease.<EOS>
<BOS>The following tests and procedures may be used in the staging process: PET scan (positron emission tomography scan): A procedure to find malignant tumor cells in the body.<EOS>
<BOS>A small amount of radioactive glucose (sugar) is injected into a vein.<EOS>
<BOS>The PET scanner rotates around the body and makes a picture of where glucose is being used in the body.<EOS>
<BOS>Malignant tumor cells show up brighter in the picture because they are more active and take up more glucose than normal cells do.<EOS>
<BOS>CT scan (CAT scan): A procedure that makes a series of detailed pictures of areas inside the body, taken from different angles.<EOS>
<BOS>The pictures are made by a computer linked to an xray machine.<EOS>
<BOS>A dye may be injected into a vein or swallowed to help the organs or tissues show up more clearly.<EOS>
<BOS>This procedure is also called computed tomography, computerized tomography, or computerized axial tomography.<EOS>
<BOS>MRI (magnetic resonance imaging): A procedure that uses a magnet, radio waves, and a computer to make a series of detailed pictures of areas inside the body.<EOS>
<BOS>This procedure is also called nuclear magnetic resonance imaging (NMRI).<EOS>
<BOS>Chest xray : An xray of the organs and bones inside the chest.<EOS>
<BOS>An xray is a type of energy beam that can go through the body and onto film, making a picture of areas inside the body.<EOS>
<BOS>Bone scan : A procedure to check if there are rapidly dividing cells, such as cancer cells, in the bone.<EOS>
<BOS>A very small amount of radioactive material is injected into a vein and travels through the bloodstream.<EOS>
<BOS>The radioactive material collects in the bones and is detected by a scanner.<EOS>
<BOS>There are three ways that cancer spreads in the body.<EOS>
<BOS>Cancer can spread through tissue, the lymph system, and the blood: Tissue.<EOS>
<BOS>The cancer spreads from where it began by growing into nearby areas.<EOS>
<BOS>Lymph system.<EOS>
<BOS>The cancer spreads from where it began by getting into the lymph system.<EOS>
<BOS>The cancer travels through the lymph vessels to other parts of the body.<EOS>
<BOS>Blood.<EOS>
<BOS>The cancer spreads from where it began by getting into the blood.<EOS>
<BOS>The cancer travels through the blood vessels to other parts of the body.<EOS>
<BOS>Cancer may spread from where it began to other parts of the body.<EOS>
<BOS>When cancer spreads to another part of the body, it is called metastasis.<EOS>
<BOS>Cancer cells break away from where they began (the primary tumor) and travel through the lymph system or blood.<EOS>
<BOS>Lymph system.<EOS>
<BOS>The cancer gets into the lymph system, travels through the lymph vessels, and forms a tumor (metastatic tumor) in another part of the body.<EOS>
<BOS>Blood.<EOS>
<BOS>The cancer gets into the blood, travels through the blood vessels, and forms a tumor (metastatic tumor) in another part of the body.<EOS>
<BOS>The metastatic tumor is the same type of tumor as the primary tumor.<EOS>
<BOS>For example, if a gastrointestinal stromal tumor (GIST) spreads to the liver, the tumor cells in the liver are actually GIST cells.<EOS>
<BOS>The disease is metastatic GIST, not liver cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>The results of diagnostic and staging tests are used to plan treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>For many cancers it is important to know the stage of the cancer in order to plan treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>However, the treatment of GIST is not based on the stage of the cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Treatment is based on whether the tumor can be removed by surgery and if the tumor has spread to other parts of the abdomen or to distant parts of the body.<EOS>
<BOS>Treatment is based on whether the tumor is: Resectable: These tumors can be removed by surgery.<EOS>
<BOS>Unresectable: These tumors cannot be completely removed by surgery.<EOS>
<BOS>Metastatic and recurrent: Metastatic tumors have spread to other parts of the body.<EOS>
<BOS>Recurrent tumors have recurred (come back) after treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Recurrent GISTs may come back in the gastrointestinal tract or in other parts of the body.<EOS>
<BOS>They are usually found in the abdomen, peritoneum, and/or liver.<EOS>
<BOS>Refractory: These tumors have not gotten better with treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Different factors increase or decrease the risk of lung cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Anything that increases your chance of getting a disease is called a risk factor.<EOS>
<BOS>Anything that decreases your chance of getting a disease is called a protective factor.<EOS>
<BOS>For information about risk factors and protective factors for lung cancer, see the PDQ summary on Lung Cancer Prevention.<EOS>
<BOS>Key Points Screening tests have risks.<EOS>
<BOS>The risks of lung cancer screening tests include the following: Finding lung cancer may not improve health or help you live longer.<EOS>
<BOS>Falsenegative test results can occur.<EOS>
<BOS>Falsepositive test results can occur.<EOS>
<BOS>Chest xrays and lowdose spiral CT scans expose the chest to radiation.<EOS>
<BOS>Talk to your doctor about your risk for lung cancer and your need for screening tests.<EOS>
<BOS>Screening tests have risks.<EOS>
<BOS>Decisions about screening tests can be difficult.<EOS>
<BOS>Not all screening tests are helpful and most have risks.<EOS>
<BOS>Before having any screening test, you may want to discuss the test with your doctor.<EOS>
<BOS>It is important to know the risks of the test and whether it has been proven to reduce the risk of dying from cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>The risks of lung cancer screening tests include the following: Finding lung cancer may not improve health or help you live longer.<EOS>
<BOS>Screening may not improve your health or help you live longer if you have lung cancer that has already spread to other places in your body.<EOS>
<BOS>When a screening test result leads to the diagnosis and treatment of a disease that may never have caused symptoms or become lifethreatening, it is called overdiagnosis.<EOS>
<BOS>It is not known if treatment of these cancers would help you live longer than if no treatment were given, and treatments for cancer may have serious side effects.<EOS>
<BOS>Harms of treatment may happen more often in people who have medical problems caused by heavy or longterm smoking.<EOS>
<BOS>Falsenegative test results can occur.<EOS>
<BOS>Screening test results may appear to be normal even though lung cancer is present.<EOS>
<BOS>A person who receives a falsenegative test result (one that shows there is no cancer when there really is) may delay seeking medical care even if there are symptoms.<EOS>
<BOS>Falsepositive test results can occur.<EOS>
<BOS>Screening test results may appear to be abnormal even though no cancer is present.<EOS>
<BOS>A falsepositive test result (one that shows there is cancer when there really isn't) can cause anxiety and is usually followed by more tests (such as biopsy), which also have risks.<EOS>
<BOS>A biopsy to diagnose lung cancer can cause part of the lung to collapse.<EOS>
<BOS>Sometimes surgery is needed to reinflate the lung.<EOS>
<BOS>Harms of diagnostic tests may happen more often in patients who have medical problems caused by heavy or longterm smoking.<EOS>
<BOS>Chest xrays and lowdose spiral CT scans expose the chest to radiation.<EOS>
<BOS>Radiation exposure from chest xrays and lowdose spiral CT scans may increase the risk of cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Younger people and people at low risk for lung cancer are more likely to develop lung cancer caused by radiation exposure.<EOS>
<BOS>Talk to your doctor about your risk for lung cancer and your need for screening tests.<EOS>
<BOS>Talk to your doctor or other health care provider about your risk for lung cancer, whether a screening test is right for you, and about the benefits and harms of the screening test.<EOS>
<BOS>You should take part in the decision about whether a screening test is right for you.<EOS>
<BOS>(See the PDQ summary on Cancer Screening Overview for more information.<EOS>
<BOS>).<EOS>
<BOS>Signs of GTD include abnormal vaginal bleeding and a uterus that is larger than normal.<EOS>
<BOS>These and other signs and symptoms may be caused by gestational trophoblastic disease or by other conditions.<EOS>
<BOS>Check with your doctor if you have any of the following: Vaginal bleeding not related to menstruation.<EOS>
<BOS>A uterus that is larger than expected during pregnancy.<EOS>
<BOS>Pain or pressure in the pelvis.<EOS>
<BOS>Severe nausea and vomiting during pregnancy.<EOS>
<BOS>High blood pressure with headache and swelling of feet and hands early in the pregnancy.<EOS>
<BOS>Vaginal bleeding that continues for longer than normal after delivery.<EOS>
<BOS>Fatigue, shortness of breath, dizziness, and a fast or irregular heartbeat caused by anemia.<EOS>
<BOS>GTD sometimes causes an overactive thyroid.<EOS>
<BOS>Signs and symptoms of an overactive thyroid include the following: Fast or irregular heartbeat.<EOS>
<BOS>Shakiness.<EOS>
<BOS>Sweating.<EOS>
<BOS>Frequent bowel movements.<EOS>
<BOS>Trouble sleeping.<EOS>
<BOS>Feeling anxious or irritable.<EOS>
<BOS>Weight loss.<EOS>
<BOS>Key Points Screening tests have risks.<EOS>
<BOS>The risks of neuroblastoma screening include the following: Neuroblastoma may be overdiagnosed.<EOS>
<BOS>Falsenegative test results can occur.<EOS>
<BOS>Falsepositive test results can occur.<EOS>
<BOS>Screening tests have risks.<EOS>
<BOS>Decisions about screening tests can be difficult.<EOS>
<BOS>Not all screening tests are helpful and most have risks.<EOS>
<BOS>Before having any screening test, you may want to discuss the test with your doctor.<EOS>
<BOS>It is important to know the risks of the test and whether it has been proven to reduce the risk of dying from cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>The risks of neuroblastoma screening include the following: Neuroblastoma may be overdiagnosed.<EOS>
<BOS>When a screening test result leads to the diagnosis and treatment of a disease that may never have caused symptoms or become lifethreatening, it is called overdiagnosis.<EOS>
<BOS>For example, when a urine test result shows a higher than normal amount of homovanillic acid (HMA) or vanillyl mandelic acid (VMA), tests and treatments for neuroblastoma are likely to be done, but may not be needed.<EOS>
<BOS>At this time, it is not possible to know which neuroblastomas found by a screening test will cause symptoms and which neuroblastomas will not.<EOS>
<BOS>Diagnostic tests (such as biopsies) and cancer treatments (such as surgery, radiation therapy, and chemotherapy) can have serious risks, including physical and emotional problems.<EOS>
<BOS>Falsenegative test results can occur.<EOS>
<BOS>Screening test results may appear to be normal even though neuroblastoma is present.<EOS>
<BOS>A person who receives a falsenegative test result (one that shows there is no cancer when there really is) may delay seeking medical care even if there are symptoms.<EOS>
<BOS>Falsepositive test results can occur.<EOS>
<BOS>Screening test results may appear to be abnormal even though no cancer is present.<EOS>
<BOS>A falsepositive test result (one that shows there is cancer when there really isn't) can cause anxiety and is usually followed by more tests and procedures, which also have risks.<EOS>
<BOS>Key Points Renal cell cancer is a disease in which malignant (cancer) cells form in tubules of the kidney.<EOS>
<BOS>Smoking and misuse of certain pain medicines can affect the risk of renal cell cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Signs of renal cell cancer include blood in the urine and a lump in the abdomen.<EOS>
<BOS>Tests that examine the abdomen and kidneys are used to detect (find) and diagnose renal cell cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Certain factors affect prognosis (chance of recovery) and treatment options.<EOS>
<BOS>Renal cell cancer is a disease in which malignant (cancer) cells form in tubules of the kidney.<EOS>
<BOS>Renal cell cancer (also called kidney cancer or renal adenocarcinoma) is a disease in which malignant (cancer) cells are found in the lining of tubules (very small tubes) in the kidney.<EOS>
<BOS>There are 2 kidneys, one on each side of the backbone, above the waist.<EOS>
<BOS>Tiny tubules in the kidneys filter and clean the blood.<EOS>
<BOS>They take out waste products and make urine.<EOS>
<BOS>The urine passes from each kidney through a long tube called a ureter into the bladder.<EOS>
<BOS>The bladder holds the urine until it passes through the urethra and leaves the body.<EOS>
<BOS>Cancer that starts in the ureters or the renal pelvis (the part of the kidney that collects urine and drains it to the ureters) is different from renal cell cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>(See the PDQ summary about Transitional Cell Cancer of the Renal Pelvis and Ureter Treatment for more information).<EOS>
<BOS>Certain factors affect prognosis (chance of recovery) and treatment options.<EOS>
<BOS>The prognosis (chance of recovery) and treatment options for primary brain and spinal cord tumors depend on the following: The type and grade of the tumor.<EOS>
<BOS>Where the tumor is in the brain or spinal cord.<EOS>
<BOS>Whether the tumor can be removed by surgery.<EOS>
<BOS>Whether cancer cells remain after surgery.<EOS>
<BOS>Whether there are certain changes in the chromosomes.<EOS>
<BOS>Whether the cancer has just been diagnosed or has recurred (come back).<EOS>
<BOS>The patient's general health.<EOS>
<BOS>The prognosis and treatment options for metastatic brain and spinal cord tumors depend on the following: Whether there are more than two tumors in the brain or spinal cord.<EOS>
<BOS>Where the tumor is in the brain or spinal cord.<EOS>
<BOS>How well the tumor responds to treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Whether the primary tumor continues to grow or spread.<EOS>
<BOS>Certain factors affect the prognosis (chance of recovery) and treatment options.<EOS>
<BOS>The prognosis (chance of recovery) and treatment options depend on the following: The stage of the cancer (whether the cancer has spread from the gallbladder to other places in the body).<EOS>
<BOS>Whether the cancer can be completely removed by surgery.<EOS>
<BOS>The type of gallbladder cancer (how the cancer cell looks under a microscope).<EOS>
<BOS>Whether the cancer has just been diagnosed or has recurred (come back).<EOS>
<BOS>Treatment may also depend on the age and general health of the patient and whether the cancer is causing signs or symptoms.<EOS>
<BOS>Gallbladder cancer can be cured only if it is found before it has spread, when it can be removed by surgery.<EOS>
<BOS>If the cancer has spread, palliative treatment can improve the patient's quality of life by controlling the symptoms and complications of this disease.<EOS>
<BOS>Taking part in one of the clinical trials being done to improve treatment should be considered.<EOS>
<BOS>Information about ongoing clinical trials is available from the NCI website.<EOS>
<BOS>Having colitis or certain liver diseases can increase the risk of bile duct cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Anything that increases your risk of getting a disease is called a risk factor.<EOS>
<BOS>Having a risk factor does not mean that you will get cancer; not having risk factors doesn't mean that you will not get cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>People who think they may be at risk should discuss this with their doctor.<EOS>
<BOS>Risk factors for bile duct cancer include the following conditions: Primary sclerosing cholangitis (a progressive disease in which the bile ducts become blocked by inflammation and scarring).<EOS>
<BOS>Chronic ulcerative colitis.<EOS>
<BOS>Cysts in the bile ducts (cysts block the flow of bile and can cause swollen bile ducts, inflammation, and infection).<EOS>
<BOS>Infection with a Chinese liver fluke parasite.<EOS>
<BOS>New types of treatment are being tested in clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>This summary section describes treatments that are being studied in clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>It may not mention every new treatment being studied.<EOS>
<BOS>Information about clinical trials is available from the NCI website.<EOS>
<BOS>Highdose chemotherapy with stem cell transplant Highdose chemotherapy with stem cell transplant is a way of giving high doses of chemotherapy and replacing blood forming cells destroyed by the cancer treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Stem cells (immature blood cells) are removed from the blood or bone marrow of the patient or a donor and are frozen and stored.<EOS>
<BOS>After the chemotherapy is completed, the stored stem cells are thawed and given back to the patient through an infusion.<EOS>
<BOS>These reinfused stem cells grow into (and restore) the body's blood cells.<EOS>
<BOS>Radiation therapy Radiation therapy is a cancer treatment that uses highenergy xrays or other types of radiation to kill cancer cells or keep them from growing.<EOS>
<BOS>There are two types of radiation therapy: External radiation therapy uses a machine outside the body to send radiation toward the cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Internal radiation therapy uses a radioactive substance sealed in needles, seeds, wires, or catheters that are placed directly into or near the cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>The way the radiation therapy is given depends on the type of cancer and whether it has come back.<EOS>
<BOS>External radiation therapy is being studied for the treatment of childhood extracranial germ cell tumors that have come back.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients may want to think about taking part in a clinical trial.<EOS>
<BOS>For some patients, taking part in a clinical trial may be the best treatment choice.<EOS>
<BOS>Clinical trials are part of the cancer research process.<EOS>
<BOS>Clinical trials are done to find out if new cancer treatments are safe and effective or better than the standard treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Many of today's standard treatments for cancer are based on earlier clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients who take part in a clinical trial may receive the standard treatment or be among the first to receive a new treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients who take part in clinical trials also help improve the way cancer will be treated in the future.<EOS>
<BOS>Even when clinical trials do not lead to effective new treatments, they often answer important questions and help move research forward.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients can enter clinical trials before, during, or after starting their cancer treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Some clinical trials only include patients who have not yet received treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Other trials test treatments for patients whose cancer has not gotten better.<EOS>
<BOS>There are also clinical trials that test new ways to stop cancer from recurring (coming back) or reduce the side effects of cancer treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Clinical trials are taking place in many parts of the country.<EOS>
<BOS>See the Treatment Options section that follows for links to current treatment clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>These have been retrieved from NCI's listing of clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients may want to think about taking part in a clinical trial.<EOS>
<BOS>For some patients, taking part in a clinical trial may be the best treatment choice.<EOS>
<BOS>Clinical trials are part of the medical research process.<EOS>
<BOS>Clinical trials are done to find out if new treatments are safe and effective or better than the standard treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Many of today's standard treatments are based on earlier clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients who take part in a clinical trial may receive the standard treatment or be among the first to receive a new treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients who take part in clinical trials also help improve the way diseases will be treated in the future.<EOS>
<BOS>Even when clinical trials do not lead to effective new treatments, they often answer important questions and help move research forward.<EOS>
<BOS>Check the list of NCIsupported cancer clinical trials that are now accepting patients with childhood craniopharyngioma.<EOS>
<BOS>For more specific results, refine the search by using other search features, such as the location of the trial, the type of treatment, or the name of the drug.<EOS>
<BOS>Talk with your child's doctor about clinical trials that may be right for your child.<EOS>
<BOS>General information about clinical trials is available from the NCI website.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients can enter clinical trials before, during, or after starting their treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Some clinical trials only include patients who have not yet received treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Other trials test treatments for patients who have not improved.<EOS>
<BOS>There are also clinical trials that test new ways to stop a disease from recurring (coming back) or reduce the side effects of treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Clinical trials are taking place in many parts of the country.<EOS>
<BOS>See the Treatment Options section that follows for links to current treatment clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>These have been retrieved from NCI's clinical trials database.<EOS>
<BOS>Tests that examine the pancreas are used to detect (find), diagnose, and stage pancreatic cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Pancreatic cancer is usually diagnosed with tests and procedures that make pictures of the pancreas and the area around it.<EOS>
<BOS>The process used to find out if cancer cells have spread within and around the pancreas is called staging.<EOS>
<BOS>Tests and procedures to detect, diagnose, and stage pancreatic cancer are usually done at the same time.<EOS>
<BOS>In order to plan treatment, it is important to know the stage of the disease and whether or not the pancreatic cancer can be removed by surgery.<EOS>
<BOS>The following tests and procedures may be used: Physical exam and history : An exam of the body to check general signs of health, including checking for signs of disease, such as lumps or anything else that seems unusual.<EOS>
<BOS>A history of the patients health habits and past illnesses and treatments will also be taken.<EOS>
<BOS>Blood chemistry studies : A procedure in which a blood sample is checked to measure the amounts of certain substances, such as bilirubin, released into the blood by organs and tissues in the body.<EOS>
<BOS>An unusual (higher or lower than normal) amount of a substance can be a sign of disease.<EOS>
<BOS>Tumor marker test : A procedure in which a sample of blood, urine, or tissue is checked to measure the amounts of certain substances, such as CA 199, and carcinoembryonic antigen (CEA), made by organs, tissues, or tumor cells in the body.<EOS>
<BOS>Certain substances are linked to specific types of cancer when found in increased levels in the body.<EOS>
<BOS>These are called tumor markers.<EOS>
<BOS>MRI (magnetic resonance imaging): A procedure that uses a magnet, radio waves, and a computer to make a series of detailed pictures of areas inside the body.<EOS>
<BOS>This procedure is also called nuclear magnetic resonance imaging (NMRI).<EOS>
<BOS>CT scan (CAT scan): A procedure that makes a series of detailed pictures of areas inside the body, taken from different angles.<EOS>
<BOS>The pictures are made by a computer linked to an xray machine.<EOS>
<BOS>A dye may be injected into a vein or swallowed to help the organs or tissues show up more clearly.<EOS>
<BOS>This procedure is also called computed tomography, computerized tomography, or computerized axial tomography.<EOS>
<BOS>A spiral or helical CT scan makes a series of very detailed pictures of areas inside the body using an xray machine that scans the body in a spiral path.<EOS>
<BOS>PET scan (positron emission tomography scan): A procedure to find malignant tumor cells in the body.<EOS>
<BOS>A small amount of radioactive glucose (sugar) is injected into a vein.<EOS>
<BOS>The PET scanner rotates around the body and makes a picture of where glucose is being used in the body.<EOS>
<BOS>Malignant tumor cells show up brighter in the picture because they are more active and take up more glucose than normal cells do.<EOS>
<BOS>A PET scan and CT scan may be done at the same time.<EOS>
<BOS>This is called a PETCT.<EOS>
<BOS>Abdominal ultrasound : An ultrasound exam used to make pictures of the inside of the abdomen.<EOS>
<BOS>The ultrasound transducer is pressed against the skin of the abdomen and directs highenergy sound waves (ultrasound) into the abdomen.<EOS>
<BOS>The sound waves bounce off the internal tissues and organs and make echoes.<EOS>
<BOS>The transducer receives the echoes and sends them to a computer, which uses the echoes to make pictures called sonograms.<EOS>
<BOS>The picture can be printed to be looked at later.<EOS>
<BOS>Endoscopic ultrasound (EUS): A procedure in which an endoscope is inserted into the body, usually through the mouth or rectum.<EOS>
<BOS>An endoscope is a thin, tubelike instrument with a light and a lens for viewing.<EOS>
<BOS>A probe at the end of the endoscope is used to bounce highenergy sound waves (ultrasound) off internal tissues or organs and make echoes.<EOS>
<BOS>The echoes form a picture of body tissues called a sonogram.<EOS>
<BOS>This procedure is also called endosonography.<EOS>
<BOS>Endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography (ERCP): A procedure used to xray the ducts (tubes) that carry bile from the liver to the gallbladder and from the gallbladder to the small intestine.<EOS>
<BOS>Sometimes pancreatic cancer causes these ducts to narrow and block or slow the flow of bile, causing jaundice.<EOS>
<BOS>An endoscope (a thin, lighted tube) is passed through the mouth, esophagus, and stomach into the first part of the small intestine.<EOS>
<BOS>A catheter (a smaller tube) is then inserted through the endoscope into the pancreatic ducts.<EOS>
<BOS>A dye is injected through the catheter into the ducts and an xray is taken.<EOS>
<BOS>If the ducts are blocked by a tumor, a fine tube may be inserted into the duct to unblock it.<EOS>
<BOS>This tube (or stent) may be left in place to keep the duct open.<EOS>
<BOS>Tissue samples may also be taken.<EOS>
<BOS>Percutaneous transhepatic cholangiography (PTC): A procedure used to xray the liver and bile ducts.<EOS>
<BOS>A thin needle is inserted through the skin below the ribs and into the liver.<EOS>
<BOS>Dye is injected into the liver or bile ducts and an xray is taken.<EOS>
<BOS>If a blockage is found, a thin, flexible tube called a stent is sometimes left in the liver to drain bile into the small intestine or a collection bag outside the body.<EOS>
<BOS>This test is done only if ERCP cannot be done.<EOS>
<BOS>Laparoscopy : A surgical procedure to look at the organs inside the abdomen to check for signs of disease.<EOS>
<BOS>Small incisions (cuts) are made in the wall of the abdomen and a laparoscope (a thin, lighted tube) is inserted into one of the incisions.<EOS>
<BOS>The laparoscope may have an ultrasound probe at the end in order to bounce highenergy sound waves off internal organs, such as the pancreas.<EOS>
<BOS>This is called laparoscopic ultrasound.<EOS>
<BOS>Other instruments may be inserted through the same or other incisions to perform procedures such as taking tissue samples from the pancreas or a sample of fluid from the abdomen to check for cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Biopsy: The removal of cells or tissues so they can be viewed under a microscope by a pathologist to check for signs of cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>There are several ways to do a biopsy for pancreatic cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>A fine needle or a core needle may be inserted into the pancreas during an xray or ultrasound to remove cells.<EOS>
<BOS>Tissue may also be removed during a laparoscopy.<EOS>
<BOS>Breast cancer is sometimes caused by inherited gene mutations (changes).<EOS>
<BOS>The genes in cells carry the hereditary information that is received from a persons parents.<EOS>
<BOS>Hereditary breast cancer makes up about 5% to 10% of all breast cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Some mutated genes related to breast cancer are more common in certain ethnic groups.<EOS>
<BOS>Women who have certain gene mutations, such as a BRCA1 or BRCA2 mutation, have an increased risk of breast cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>These women also have an increased risk of ovarian cancer, and may have an increased risk of other cancers.<EOS>
<BOS>Men who have a mutated gene related to breast cancer also have an increased risk of breast cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>For more information, see the PDQ summary on Male Breast Cancer Treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>There are tests that can detect (find) mutated genes.<EOS>
<BOS>These genetic tests are sometimes done for members of families with a high risk of cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>See the PDQ summary on Genetics of Breast and Gynecologic Cancers for more information.<EOS>
<BOS>Tests that examine the blood and bone marrow are used to detect (find) and diagnose childhood ALL.<EOS>
<BOS>The following tests and procedures may be used to diagnose childhood ALL and find out if leukemia cells have spread to other parts of the body such as the brain or testicles: Physical exam and history : An exam of the body to check general signs of health, including checking for signs of disease, such as lumps or anything else that seems unusual.<EOS>
<BOS>A history of the patient's health habits and past illnesses and treatments will also be taken.<EOS>
<BOS>Complete blood count (CBC) with differential : A procedure in which a sample of blood is drawn and checked for the following: The number of red blood cells and platelets.<EOS>
<BOS>The number and type of white blood cells.<EOS>
<BOS>The amount of hemoglobin (the protein that carries oxygen) in the red blood cells.<EOS>
<BOS>The portion of the sample made up of red blood cells.<EOS>
<BOS>Blood chemistry studies : A procedure in which a blood sample is checked to measure the amounts of certain substances released into the blood by organs and tissues in the body.<EOS>
<BOS>An unusual (higher or lower than normal) amount of a substance can be a sign of disease.<EOS>
<BOS>Bone marrow aspiration and biopsy : The removal of bone marrow and a small piece of bone by inserting a hollow needle into the hipbone or breastbone.<EOS>
<BOS>A pathologist views the bone marrow and bone under a microscope to look for signs of cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>The following tests are done on blood or the bone marrow tissue that is removed: Cytogenetic analysis : A laboratory test in which the cells in a sample of blood or bone marrow are viewed under a microscope to look for certain changes in the chromosomes of lymphocytes.<EOS>
<BOS>For example, in Philadelphia chromosome positive ALL, part of one chromosome switches places with part of another chromosome.<EOS>
<BOS>This is called the Philadelphia chromosome.<EOS>
<BOS>Immunophenotyping : A laboratory test in which the antigens or markers on the surface of a blood or bone marrow cell are checked to see if they are lymphocytes or myeloid cells.<EOS>
<BOS>If the cells are malignant lymphocytes (cancer) they are checked to see if they are B lymphocytes or T lymphocytes.<EOS>
<BOS>Lumbar puncture : A procedure used to collect a sample of cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) from the spinal column.<EOS>
<BOS>This is done by placing a needle between two bones in the spine and into the CSF around the spinal cord and removing a sample of the fluid.<EOS>
<BOS>The sample of CSF is checked under a microscope for signs that leukemia cells have spread to the brain and spinal cord.<EOS>
<BOS>This procedure is also called an LP or spinal tap.<EOS>
<BOS>This procedure is done after leukemia is diagnosed to find out if leukemia cells have spread to the brain and spinal cord.<EOS>
<BOS>Intrathecal chemotherapy is given after the sample of fluid is removed to treat any leukemia cells that may have spread to the brain and spinal cord.<EOS>
<BOS>Chest xray : An xray of the organs and bones inside the chest.<EOS>
<BOS>An xray is a type of energy beam that can go through the body and onto film, making a picture of areas inside the body.<EOS>
<BOS>The chest xray is done to see if leukemia cells have formed a mass in the middle of the chest.<EOS>
<BOS>Key Points A gastrointestinal carcinoid tumor is cancer that forms in the lining of the gastrointestinal tract.<EOS>
<BOS>Health history can affect the risk of gastrointestinal carcinoid tumors.<EOS>
<BOS>Some gastrointestinal carcinoid tumors have no signs or symptoms in the early stages.<EOS>
<BOS>Carcinoid syndrome may occur if the tumor spreads to the liver or other parts of the body.<EOS>
<BOS>Imaging studies and tests that examine the blood and urine are used to detect (find) and diagnose gastrointestinal carcinoid tumors.<EOS>
<BOS>Certain factors affect prognosis (chance of recovery) and treatment options.<EOS>
<BOS>A gastrointestinal carcinoid tumor is cancer that forms in the lining of the gastrointestinal tract.<EOS>
<BOS>The gastrointestinal (GI) tract is part of the body's digestive system.<EOS>
<BOS>It helps to digest food, takes nutrients (vitamins, minerals, carbohydrates, fats, proteins, and water) from food to be used by the body and helps pass waste material out of the body.<EOS>
<BOS>The GI tract is made up of these and other organs: Stomach.<EOS>
<BOS>Small intestine (duodenum, jejunum, and ileum).<EOS>
<BOS>Colon.<EOS>
<BOS>Rectum.<EOS>
<BOS>Gastrointestinal carcinoid tumors form from a certain type of neuroendocrine cell (a type of cell that is like a nerve cell and a hormone making cell).<EOS>
<BOS>These cells are scattered throughout the chest and abdomen but most are found in the GI tract.<EOS>
<BOS>Neuroendocrine cells make hormones that help control digestive juices and the muscles used in moving food through the stomach and intestines.<EOS>
<BOS>A GI carcinoid tumor may also make hormones and release them into the body.<EOS>
<BOS>GI carcinoid tumors are rare and most grow very slowly.<EOS>
<BOS>Most of them occur in the small intestine, rectum, and appendix.<EOS>
<BOS>Sometimes more than one tumor will form.<EOS>
<BOS>See the following PDQ summaries for more information related to GI and other types of carcinoid tumors: NonSmall Cell Lung Cancer Treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Pancreatic Neuroendocrine Tumors (Islet Cell Tumors) Treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Rectal Cancer Treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Small Intestine Cancer Treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Unusual Cancers of Childhood Treatment Carcinoid syndrome may occur if the tumor spreads to the liver or other parts of the body.<EOS>
<BOS>The hormones made by gastrointestinal carcinoid tumors are usually destroyed by liver enzymes in the blood.<EOS>
<BOS>If the tumor has spread to the liver and the liver enzymes cannot destroy the extra hormones made by the tumor, high amounts of these hormones may remain in the body and cause carcinoid syndrome.<EOS>
<BOS>This can also happen if tumor cells enter the blood.<EOS>
<BOS>Signs and symptoms of carcinoid syndrome include the following: Redness or a feeling of warmth in the face and neck.<EOS>
<BOS>Abdominal pain.<EOS>
<BOS>Feeling bloated.<EOS>
<BOS>Diarrhea.<EOS>
<BOS>Wheezing or other trouble breathing.<EOS>
<BOS>Fast heartbeat.<EOS>
<BOS>These signs and symptoms may be caused by gastrointestinal carcinoid tumors or by other conditions.<EOS>
<BOS>Talk to your doctor if you have any of these signs or symptoms.<EOS>
<BOS>Tests that examine the liver and the blood are used to detect (find) and diagnose adult primary liver cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>The following tests and procedures may be used: Physical exam and history : An exam of the body to check general signs of health, including checking for signs of disease, such as lumps or anything else that seems unusual.<EOS>
<BOS>A history of the patients health habits and past illnesses and treatments will also be taken.<EOS>
<BOS>Serum tumor marker test : A procedure in which a sample of blood is examined to measure the amounts of certain substances released into the blood by organs, tissues, or tumor cells in the body.<EOS>
<BOS>Certain substances are linked to specific types of cancer when found in increased levels in the blood.<EOS>
<BOS>These are called tumor markers.<EOS>
<BOS>An increased level of alphafetoprotein (AFP) in the blood may be a sign of liver cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Other cancers and certain noncancerous conditions, including cirrhosis and hepatitis, may also increase AFP levels.<EOS>
<BOS>Sometimes the AFP level is normal even when there is liver cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Liver function tests : A procedure in which a blood sample is checked to measure the amounts of certain substances released into the blood by the liver.<EOS>
<BOS>A higher than normal amount of a substance can be a sign of liver cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>CT scan (CAT scan): A procedure that makes a series of detailed pictures of areas inside the body, such as the abdomen, taken from different angles.<EOS>
<BOS>The pictures are made by a computer linked to an xray machine.<EOS>
<BOS>A dye may be injected into a vein or swallowed to help the organs or tissues show up more clearly.<EOS>
<BOS>This procedure is also called computed tomography, computerized tomography, or computerized axial tomography.<EOS>
<BOS>Images may be taken at three different times after the dye is injected, to get the best picture of abnormal areas in the liver.<EOS>
<BOS>This is called triplephase CT.<EOS>
<BOS>A spiral or helical CT scan makes a series of very detailed pictures of areas inside the body using an xray machine that scans the body in a spiral path.<EOS>
<BOS>MRI (magnetic resonance imaging): A procedure that uses a magnet, radio waves, and a computer to make a series of detailed pictures of areas inside the body, such as the liver.<EOS>
<BOS>This procedure is also called nuclear magnetic resonance imaging (NMRI).<EOS>
<BOS>To create detailed pictures of blood vessels in and near the liver, dye is injected into a vein.<EOS>
<BOS>This procedure is called MRA (magnetic resonance angiography).<EOS>
<BOS>Images may be taken at three different times after the dye is injected, to get the best picture of abnormal areas in the liver.<EOS>
<BOS>This is called triplephase MRI.<EOS>
<BOS>Ultrasound exam: A procedure in which highenergy sound waves (ultrasound) are bounced off internal tissues or organs and make echoes.<EOS>
<BOS>The echoes form a picture of body tissues called a sonogram.<EOS>
<BOS>The picture can be printed to be looked at later.<EOS>
<BOS>Biopsy : The removal of cells or tissues so they can be viewed under a microscope by a pathologist to check for signs of cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Procedures used to collect the sample of cells or tissues include the following: Fineneedle aspiration biopsy : The removal of cells, tissue or fluid using a thin needle.<EOS>
<BOS>Core needle biopsy : The removal of cells or tissue using a slightly wider needle.<EOS>
<BOS>Laparoscopy : A surgical procedure to look at the organs inside the abdomen to check for signs of disease.<EOS>
<BOS>Small incisions (cuts) are made in the wall of the abdomen and a laparoscope (a thin, lighted tube) is inserted into one of the incisions.<EOS>
<BOS>Another instrument is inserted through the same or another incision to remove the tissue samples.<EOS>
<BOS>A biopsy is not always needed to diagnose adult primary liver cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Certain factors affect prognosis (chance of recovery) and treatment options.<EOS>
<BOS>Pancreatic NETs can often be cured.<EOS>
<BOS>The prognosis (chance of recovery) and treatment options depend on the following: The type of cancer cell.<EOS>
<BOS>Where the tumor is found in the pancreas.<EOS>
<BOS>Whether the tumor has spread to more than one place in the pancreas or to other parts of the body.<EOS>
<BOS>Whether the patient has MEN1 syndrome.<EOS>
<BOS>The patient's age and general health.<EOS>
<BOS>Whether the cancer has just been diagnosed or has recurred (come back).<EOS>
<BOS>New types of treatment are being tested in clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>Information about clinical trials is available from the NCI website.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients may want to think about taking part in a clinical trial.<EOS>
<BOS>For some patients, taking part in a clinical trial may be the best treatment choice.<EOS>
<BOS>Clinical trials are part of the cancer research process.<EOS>
<BOS>Clinical trials are done to find out if new cancer treatments are safe and effective or better than the standard treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Many of today's standard treatments for cancer are based on earlier clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients who take part in a clinical trial may receive the standard treatment or be among the first to receive a new treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients who take part in clinical trials also help improve the way cancer will be treated in the future.<EOS>
<BOS>Even when clinical trials do not lead to effective new treatments, they often answer important questions and help move research forward.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients can enter clinical trials before, during, or after starting their cancer treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Some clinical trials only include patients who have not yet received treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Other trials test treatments for patients whose cancer has not gotten better.<EOS>
<BOS>There are also clinical trials that test new ways to stop cancer from recurring (coming back) or reduce the side effects of cancer treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Clinical trials are taking place in many parts of the country.<EOS>
<BOS>See the Treatment Options section that follows for links to current treatment clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>These have been retrieved from NCI's listing of clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>Key Points There are different types of treatment for patients with nonmelanoma skin cancer and actinic keratosis.<EOS>
<BOS>Six types of standard treatment are used: Surgery Radiation therapy Chemotherapy Photodynamic therapy Biologic therapy Targeted therapy New types of treatment are being tested in clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>Treatment for skin cancer may cause side effects.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients may want to think about taking part in a clinical trial.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients can enter clinical trials before, during, or after starting their cancer treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Followup tests may be needed.<EOS>
<BOS>There are different types of treatment for patients with nonmelanoma skin cancer and actinic keratosis.<EOS>
<BOS>Different types of treatment are available for patients with nonmelanoma skin cancer and actinic keratosis.<EOS>
<BOS>Some treatments are standard (the currently used treatment), and some are being tested in clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>A treatment clinical trial is a research study meant to help improve current treatments or obtain information on new treatments for patients with cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>When clinical trials show that a new treatment is better than the standard treatment, the new treatment may become the standard treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients may want to think about taking part in a clinical trial.<EOS>
<BOS>Some clinical trials are open only to patients who have not started treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Six types of standard treatment are used: Surgery One or more of the following surgical procedures may be used to treat nonmelanoma skin cancer or actinic keratosis: Mohs micrographic surgery: The tumor is cut from the skin in thin layers.<EOS>
<BOS>During surgery, the edges of the tumor and each layer of tumor removed are viewed through a microscope to check for cancer cells.<EOS>
<BOS>Layers continue to be removed until no more cancer cells are seen.<EOS>
<BOS>This type of surgery removes as little normal tissue as possible and is often used to remove skin cancer on the face.<EOS>
<BOS>Simple excision: The tumor is cut from the skin along with some of the normal skin around it.<EOS>
<BOS>Shave excision: The abnormal area is shaved off the surface of the skin with a small blade.<EOS>
<BOS>Electrodesiccation and curettage: The tumor is cut from the skin with a curette (a sharp, spoonshaped tool).<EOS>
<BOS>A needleshaped electrode is then used to treat the area with an electric current that stops the bleeding and destroys cancer cells that remain around the edge of the wound.<EOS>
<BOS>The process may be repeated one to three times during the surgery to remove all of the cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Cryosurgery: A treatment that uses an instrument to freeze and destroy abnormal tissue, such as carcinoma in situ.<EOS>
<BOS>This type of treatment is also called cryotherapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Laser surgery: A surgical procedure that uses a laser beam (a narrow beam of intense light) as a knife to make bloodless cuts in tissue or to remove a surface lesion such as a tumor.<EOS>
<BOS>Dermabrasion: Removal of the top layer of skin using a rotating wheel or small particles to rub away skin cells.<EOS>
<BOS>Radiation therapy Radiation therapy is a cancer treatment that uses highenergy xrays or other types of radiation to kill cancer cells or keep them from growing.<EOS>
<BOS>There are two types of radiation therapy: External radiation therapy uses a machine outside the body to send radiation toward the cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Internal radiation therapy uses a radioactive substance sealed in needles, seeds, wires, or catheters that are placed directly into or near the cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>The way the radiation therapy is given depends on the type of cancer being treated.<EOS>
<BOS>External radiation therapy is used to treat skin cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Chemotherapy Chemotherapy is a cancer treatment that uses drugs to stop the growth of cancer cells, either by killing the cells or by stopping them from dividing.<EOS>
<BOS>When chemotherapy is taken by mouth or injected into a vein or muscle, the drugs enter the bloodstream and can reach cancer cells throughout the body (systemic chemotherapy).<EOS>
<BOS>When chemotherapy is placed directly into the cerebrospinal fluid, an organ, or a body cavity such as the abdomen, the drugs mainly affect cancer cells in those areas (regional chemotherapy).<EOS>
<BOS>Chemotherapy for nonmelanoma skin cancer and actinic keratosis is usually topical (applied to the skin in a cream or lotion).<EOS>
<BOS>The way the chemotherapy is given depends on the condition being treated.<EOS>
<BOS>Retinoids (drugs related to vitamin A) are sometimes used to treat squamous cell carcinoma of the skin.<EOS>
<BOS>See Drugs Approved for Basal Cell Carcinoma for more information.<EOS>
<BOS>Photodynamic therapy Photodynamic therapy (PDT) is a cancer treatment that uses a drug and a certain type of laser light to kill cancer cells.<EOS>
<BOS>A drug that is not active until it is exposed to light is injected into a vein.<EOS>
<BOS>The drug collects more in cancer cells than in normal cells.<EOS>
<BOS>For skin cancer, laser light is shined onto the skin and the drug becomes active and kills the cancer cells.<EOS>
<BOS>Photodynamic therapy causes little damage to healthy tissue.<EOS>
<BOS>Biologic therapy Biologic therapy is a treatment that uses the patients immune system to fight cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Substances made by the body or made in a laboratory are used to boost, direct, or restore the bodys natural defenses against cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>This type of cancer treatment is also called biotherapy or immunotherapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Interferon and imiquimod are biologic agents used to treat skin cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Interferon (by injection) may be used to treat squamous cell carcinoma of the skin.<EOS>
<BOS>Topical imiquimod therapy (a cream applied to the skin) may be used to treat some small basal cell carcinomas.<EOS>
<BOS>See Drugs Approved for Basal Cell Carcinoma for more information.<EOS>
<BOS>Targeted therapy Targeted therapy is a type of treatment that uses drugs or other substances to attack cancer cells.<EOS>
<BOS>Targeted therapies usually cause less harm to normal cells than chemotherapy or radiation therapy do.<EOS>
<BOS>Targeted therapy with a signal transduction inhibitor is used to treat basal cell carcinoma.<EOS>
<BOS>Signal transduction inhibitors block signals that are passed from one molecule to another inside a cell.<EOS>
<BOS>Blocking these signals may kill cancer cells.<EOS>
<BOS>Vismodegib and sonidegib are signal transduction inhibitors used to treat basal cell carcinoma.<EOS>
<BOS>See Drugs Approved for Basal Cell Carcinoma for more information.<EOS>
<BOS>New types of treatment are being tested in clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>Information about clinical trials is available from the NCI website.<EOS>
<BOS>Treatment for skin cancer may cause side effects.<EOS>
<BOS>For information about side effects caused by treatment for cancer, see our Side Effects page.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients may want to think about taking part in a clinical trial.<EOS>
<BOS>For some patients, taking part in a clinical trial may be the best treatment choice.<EOS>
<BOS>Clinical trials are part of the cancer research process.<EOS>
<BOS>Clinical trials are done to find out if new cancer treatments are safe and effective or better than the standard treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Many of today's standard treatments for cancer are based on earlier clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients who take part in a clinical trial may receive the standard treatment or be among the first to receive a new treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients who take part in clinical trials also help improve the way cancer will be treated in the future.<EOS>
<BOS>Even when clinical trials do not lead to effective new treatments, they often answer important questions and help move research forward.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients can enter clinical trials before, during, or after starting their cancer treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Some clinical trials only include patients who have not yet received treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Other trials test treatments for patients whose cancer has not gotten better.<EOS>
<BOS>There are also clinical trials that test new ways to stop cancer from recurring (coming back) or reduce the side effects of cancer treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Clinical trials are taking place in many parts of the country.<EOS>
<BOS>See the Treatment Options section that follows for links to current treatment clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>These have been retrieved from NCI's listing of clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>Followup tests may be needed.<EOS>
<BOS>Some of the tests that were done to diagnose the cancer or to find out the stage of the cancer may be repeated.<EOS>
<BOS>Some tests will be repeated in order to see how well the treatment is working.<EOS>
<BOS>Decisions about whether to continue, change, or stop treatment may be based on the results of these tests.<EOS>
<BOS>Some of the tests will continue to be done from time to time after treatment has ended.<EOS>
<BOS>The results of these tests can show if your condition has changed or if the cancer has recurred (come back).<EOS>
<BOS>These tests are sometimes called followup tests or checkups.<EOS>
<BOS>Basal cell carcinoma and squamous cell carcinoma are likely to recur (come back), usually within 5 years, or new tumors may form.<EOS>
<BOS>Talk to your doctor about how often you should have your skin checked for signs of cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Treatment Options for Nonmelanoma Skin Cancer Basal Cell Carcinoma Treatment of basal cell carcinoma may include the following: Simple excision.<EOS>
<BOS>Mohs micrographic surgery.<EOS>
<BOS>Radiation therapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Electrodesiccation and curettage.<EOS>
<BOS>Cryosurgery.<EOS>
<BOS>Photodynamic therapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Topical chemotherapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Topical biologic therapy with imiquimod.<EOS>
<BOS>Laser surgery.<EOS>
<BOS>Treatment of recurrent basal cell carcinoma is usually Mohs micrographic surgery.<EOS>
<BOS>Treatment of basal cell carcinoma that is metastatic or cannot be treated with local therapy may include the following: Targeted therapy with a signal transduction inhibitor.<EOS>
<BOS>Chemotherapy.<EOS>
<BOS>A clinical trial of a new treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Check the list of NCIsupported cancer clinical trials that are now accepting patients with basal cell carcinoma of the skin.<EOS>
<BOS>For more specific results, refine the search by using other search features, such as the location of the trial, the type of treatment, or the name of the drug.<EOS>
<BOS>Talk with your doctor about clinical trials that may be right for you.<EOS>
<BOS>General information about clinical trials is available from the NCI website.<EOS>
<BOS>Squamous Cell Carcinoma Treatment of squamous cell carcinoma may include the following: Simple excision.<EOS>
<BOS>Mohs micrographic surgery.<EOS>
<BOS>Radiation therapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Electrodesiccation and curettage.<EOS>
<BOS>Cryosurgery.<EOS>
<BOS>Treatment of recurrent squamous cell carcinoma may include the following: Simple excision.<EOS>
<BOS>Mohs micrographic surgery.<EOS>
<BOS>Radiation therapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Treatment of squamous cell carcinoma that is metastatic or cannot be treated with local therapy may include the following: Chemotherapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Retinoid therapy and biologic therapy with interferon.<EOS>
<BOS>A clinical trial of a new treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Check the list of NCIsupported cancer clinical trials that are now accepting patients with squamous cell carcinoma of the skin.<EOS>
<BOS>For more specific results, refine the search by using other search features, such as the location of the trial, the type of treatment, or the name of the drug.<EOS>
<BOS>Talk with your doctor about clinical trials that may be right for you.<EOS>
<BOS>General information about clinical trials is available from the NCI website.<EOS>
<BOS>Tests that examine the brain are used to detect (find) childhood brain stem glioma.<EOS>
<BOS>The following tests and procedures may be used: Physical exam and history : An exam of the body to check general signs of health, including checking for signs of disease, such as lumps or anything else that seems unusual.<EOS>
<BOS>A history of the patients health habits and past illnesses and treatments will also be taken.<EOS>
<BOS>Neurological exam : A series of questions and tests to check the brain, spinal cord, and nerve function.<EOS>
<BOS>The exam checks a persons mental status, coordination, and ability to walk normally, and how well the muscles, senses, and reflexes work.<EOS>
<BOS>This may also be called a neuro exam or a neurologic exam.<EOS>
<BOS>MRI (magnetic resonance imaging) with gadolinium : A procedure that uses a magnet, radio waves, and a computer to make a series of detailed pictures of areas inside the brain.<EOS>
<BOS>A substance called gadolinium is injected into a vein.<EOS>
<BOS>The gadolinium collects around the cancer cells so they show up brighter in the picture.<EOS>
<BOS>This procedure is also called nuclear magnetic resonance imaging (NMRI).<EOS>
<BOS>A biopsy may be done to diagnose certain types of brain stem glioma.<EOS>
<BOS>If the MRI scan looks like the tumor is a DIPG, a biopsy is usually not done and the tumor is not removed.<EOS>
<BOS>If the MRI scan looks like a focal brain stem glioma, a biopsy may be done.<EOS>
<BOS>A part of the skull is removed and a needle is used to remove a sample of the brain tissue.<EOS>
<BOS>Sometimes, the needle is guided by a computer.<EOS>
<BOS>A pathologist views the tissue under a microscope to look for cancer cells.<EOS>
<BOS>If cancer cells are found, the doctor will remove as much tumor as safely possible during the same surgery.<EOS>
<BOS>The following test may be done on the tissue that was removed: Immunohistochemistry : A test that uses antibodies to check for certain antigens in a sample of tissue.<EOS>
<BOS>The antibody is usually linked to a radioactive substance or a dye that causes the tissue to light up under a microscope.<EOS>
<BOS>This type of test may be used to tell the difference between brain stem glioma and other brain tumors.<EOS>
<BOS>Key Points Childhood central nervous system (CNS) germ cell tumors form from germ cells.<EOS>
<BOS>There are different types of childhood CNS germ cell tumors.<EOS>
<BOS>Germinomas Nongerminomas The cause of most childhood CNS germ cell tumors is not known.<EOS>
<BOS>Signs and symptoms of childhood CNS germ cell tumors include unusual thirst, frequent urination, early puberty, or vision changes.<EOS>
<BOS>Imaging studies and tests are used to detect (find) and diagnose childhood CNS germ cell tumors.<EOS>
<BOS>A biopsy may be done to be sure of the diagnosis of CNS germ cell tumor.<EOS>
<BOS>Certain factors affect prognosis (chance of recovery).<EOS>
<BOS>Childhood central nervous system (CNS) germ cell tumors form from germ cells.<EOS>
<BOS>Germ cells are a type of cell that form as a fetus (unborn baby) develops.<EOS>
<BOS>These cells later become sperm in the testicles or eggs in the ovaries.<EOS>
<BOS>Sometimes while the fetus is forming, germ cells travel to other parts of the body and grow into germ cell tumors.<EOS>
<BOS>Germ cells tumors that form in the brain or spinal cord are called CNS germ cell tumors.<EOS>
<BOS>The most common places for one or more central nervous system (CNS) germ cell tumors to form is near the pineal gland and in an area of the brain that includes the pituitary gland and the tissue just above it.<EOS>
<BOS>Sometimes germ cell tumors may form in other areas of the brain.<EOS>
<BOS>This summary is about germ cell tumors that start in the central nervous system (brain and spinal cord).<EOS>
<BOS>Germ cell tumors may also form in other parts of the body.<EOS>
<BOS>See the PDQ summary on Childhood Extracranial Germ Cell Tumors Treatment for information on germ cell tumors that are extracranial (outside the brain).<EOS>
<BOS>CNS germ cell tumors usually occur in children, but may occur in adults.<EOS>
<BOS>Treatment for children may be different than treatment for adults.<EOS>
<BOS>See the following PDQ summaries for information about treatment for adults: Adult Central Nervous System Tumors Treatment Extragonadal Germ Cell Tumors Treatment For information about other types of childhood brain and spinal cord tumors, see the PDQ summary on Childhood Brain and Spinal Cord Tumors Treatment Overview.<EOS>
<BOS>There are different types of childhood CNS germ cell tumors.<EOS>
<BOS>There are different types of CNS germ cell tumors.<EOS>
<BOS>The type of CNS germ cell tumor depends on what the cells look like under a microscope.<EOS>
<BOS>This summary is about the treatment of the following types of CNS germ cell tumors: Germinomas Germinomas are the most common type of CNS germ cell tumor and have a good prognosis.<EOS>
<BOS>Nongerminomas Some nongerminomas make hormones.<EOS>
<BOS>CNS teratomas are a type of nongerminoma that does not make hormones.<EOS>
<BOS>They may have different kinds of tissue in them, such as hair, muscle, and bone.<EOS>
<BOS>Teratomas are described as mature or immature, based on how normal the cells look under a microscope.<EOS>
<BOS>Sometimes teratomas are a mix of mature and immature cells.<EOS>
<BOS>Other types of nongerminomas include the following: Choriocarcinomas make the hormone betahuman chorionic gonadotropin (hCG).<EOS>
<BOS>Embryonal carcinomas do not make hormones.<EOS>
<BOS>Yolk sac tumors make the hormone alphafetoprotein (AFP).<EOS>
<BOS>Mixed germ cell tumors are made of more than one kind of germ cell.<EOS>
<BOS>New types of treatment are being tested in clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>This summary section describes treatments that are being studied in clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>It may not mention every new treatment being studied.<EOS>
<BOS>Information about clinical trials is available from the NCI website.<EOS>
<BOS>Radiosensitizers Radiosensitizers are drugs that make tumor cells more sensitive to radiation therapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Combining radiation therapy with radiosensitizers helps kill more tumor cells.<EOS>
<BOS>Sentinel lymph node biopsy followed by surgery Sentinel lymph node biopsy is the removal of the sentinel lymph node during surgery.<EOS>
<BOS>The sentinel lymph node is the first lymph node to receive lymphatic drainage from a tumor.<EOS>
<BOS>It is the first lymph node the cancer is likely to spread to from the tumor.<EOS>
<BOS>A radioactive substance and/or blue dye is injected near the tumor.<EOS>
<BOS>The substance or dye flows through the lymph ducts to the lymph nodes.<EOS>
<BOS>The first lymph node to receive the substance or dye is removed.<EOS>
<BOS>A pathologist views the tissue under a microscope to look for cancer cells.<EOS>
<BOS>If cancer cells are not found, it may not be necessary to remove more lymph nodes.<EOS>
<BOS>After the sentinel lymph node biopsy, the surgeon removes the cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients may want to think about taking part in a clinical trial.<EOS>
<BOS>For some patients, taking part in a clinical trial may be the best treatment choice.<EOS>
<BOS>Clinical trials are part of the cancer research process.<EOS>
<BOS>Clinical trials are done to find out if new cancer treatments are safe and effective or better than the standard treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Many of today's standard treatments for cancer are based on earlier clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients who take part in a clinical trial may receive the standard treatment or be among the first to receive a new treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients who take part in clinical trials also help improve the way cancer will be treated in the future.<EOS>
<BOS>Even when clinical trials do not lead to effective new treatments, they often answer important questions and help move research forward.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients can enter clinical trials before, during, or after starting their cancer treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Some clinical trials only include patients who have not yet received treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Other trials test treatments for patients whose cancer has not gotten better.<EOS>
<BOS>There are also clinical trials that test new ways to stop cancer from recurring (coming back) or reduce the side effects of cancer treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Clinical trials are taking place in many parts of the country.<EOS>
<BOS>See the Treatment Options section that follows for links to current treatment clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>These have been retrieved from NCI's listing of clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>Signs and symptoms of Ewing sarcoma include swelling and pain near the tumor.<EOS>
<BOS>These and other signs and symptoms may be caused by Ewing sarcoma or by other conditions.<EOS>
<BOS>Check with your childs doctor if your child has any of the following: Pain and/or swelling, usually in the arms, legs, chest, back, or pelvis.<EOS>
<BOS>A lump (which may feel soft and warm) in the arms, legs, chest, or pelvis.<EOS>
<BOS>Fever for no known reason.<EOS>
<BOS>A bone that breaks for no known reason.<EOS>
<BOS>Signs and symptoms of parathyroid cancer include weakness, feeling tired, and a lump in the neck.<EOS>
<BOS>Most parathyroid cancer signs and symptoms are caused by the hypercalcemia that develops.<EOS>
<BOS>Signs and symptoms of hypercalcemia include the following: Weakness.<EOS>
<BOS>Feeling very tired.<EOS>
<BOS>Nausea and vomiting.<EOS>
<BOS>Loss of appetite.<EOS>
<BOS>Weight loss for no known reason.<EOS>
<BOS>Being much more thirsty than usual.<EOS>
<BOS>Urinating much more than usual.<EOS>
<BOS>Constipation.<EOS>
<BOS>Trouble thinking clearly.<EOS>
<BOS>Other signs and symptoms of parathyroid cancer include the following: Pain in the abdomen, side, or back that doesn't go away.<EOS>
<BOS>Pain in the bones.<EOS>
<BOS>A broken bone.<EOS>
<BOS>A lump in the neck.<EOS>
<BOS>Change in voice such as hoarseness.<EOS>
<BOS>Trouble swallowing.<EOS>
<BOS>Other conditions may cause the same signs and symptoms as parathyroid cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Check with your doctor if you have any of these problems.<EOS>
<BOS>Key Points After adult soft tissue sarcoma has been diagnosed, tests are done to find out if cancer cells have spread within the soft tissue or to other parts of the body.<EOS>
<BOS>There are three ways that cancer spreads in the body.<EOS>
<BOS>Cancer may spread from where it began to other parts of the body.<EOS>
<BOS>The following stages are used for adult soft tissue sarcoma: Stage I Stage II Stage III Stage IV After adult soft tissue sarcoma has been diagnosed, tests are done to find out if cancer cells have spread within the soft tissue or to other parts of the body.<EOS>
<BOS>The process used to find out if cancer has spread within the soft tissue or to other parts of the body is called staging.<EOS>
<BOS>Staging of soft tissue sarcoma is also based on the grade and size of the tumor, whether it is superficial (close to the skin's surface) or deep, and whether it has spread to the lymph nodes or other parts of the body.<EOS>
<BOS>The information gathered from the staging process determines the stage of the disease.<EOS>
<BOS>It is important to know the stage in order to plan treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>The following tests and procedures may be used in the staging process: Physical exam and history : An exam of the body to check general signs of health, including checking for signs of disease, such as lumps or anything else that seems unusual.<EOS>
<BOS>A history of the patients health habits and past illnesses and treatments will also be taken.<EOS>
<BOS>Chest xray : An xray of the organs and bones inside the chest.<EOS>
<BOS>An xray is a type of energy beam that can go through the body and onto film, making a picture of areas inside the body.<EOS>
<BOS>Blood chemistry studies : A procedure in which a blood sample is checked to measure the amounts of certain substances released into the blood by organs and tissues in the body.<EOS>
<BOS>An unusual (higher or lower than normal) amount of a substance can be a sign of disease.<EOS>
<BOS>Complete blood count (CBC): A procedure in which a sample of blood is drawn and checked for the following: The number of red blood cells, white blood cells, and platelets.<EOS>
<BOS>The amount of hemoglobin (the protein that carries oxygen) in the red blood cells.<EOS>
<BOS>The portion of the blood sample made up of red blood cells.<EOS>
<BOS>CT scan (CAT scan): A procedure that makes a series of detailed pictures of areas inside of the body, such as the lung and abdomen, taken from different angles.<EOS>
<BOS>The pictures are made by a computer linked to an xray machine.<EOS>
<BOS>A dye may be injected into a vein or swallowed to help the organs or tissues show up more clearly.<EOS>
<BOS>This procedure is also called computed tomography, computerized tomography, or computerized axial tomography.<EOS>
<BOS>MRI (magnetic resonance imaging): A procedure that uses a magnet, radio waves, and a computer to make a series of detailed pictures of areas inside the body.<EOS>
<BOS>This procedure is also called nuclear magnetic resonance imaging (NMRI).<EOS>
<BOS>PET scan (positron emission tomography scan): A procedure to find malignant tumor cells in the body.<EOS>
<BOS>A small amount of radioactive glucose (sugar) is injected into a vein.<EOS>
<BOS>The PET scanner rotates around the body and makes a picture of where glucose is being used in the body.<EOS>
<BOS>Malignant tumor cells show up brighter in the picture because they are more active and take up more glucose than normal cells do.<EOS>
<BOS>The results of these tests are viewed together with the results of the tumor biopsy to find out the stage of the soft tissue sarcoma before treatment is given.<EOS>
<BOS>Sometimes chemotherapy or radiation therapy is given as the initial treatment and afterwards the soft tissue sarcoma is staged again.<EOS>
<BOS>There are three ways that cancer spreads in the body.<EOS>
<BOS>Cancer can spread through tissue, the lymph system, and the blood: Tissue.<EOS>
<BOS>The cancer spreads from where it began by growing into nearby areas.<EOS>
<BOS>Lymph system.<EOS>
<BOS>The cancer spreads from where it began by getting into the lymph system.<EOS>
<BOS>The cancer travels through the lymph vessels to other parts of the body.<EOS>
<BOS>Blood.<EOS>
<BOS>The cancer spreads from where it began by getting into the blood.<EOS>
<BOS>The cancer travels through the blood vessels to other parts of the body.<EOS>
<BOS>Cancer may spread from where it began to other parts of the body.<EOS>
<BOS>When cancer spreads to another part of the body, it is called metastasis.<EOS>
