<BOS>Cancer cells break away from where they began (the primary tumor) and travel through the lymph system or blood.<EOS>
<BOS>Lymph system.<EOS>
<BOS>The cancer gets into the lymph system, travels through the lymph vessels, and forms a tumor (metastatic tumor) in another part of the body.<EOS>
<BOS>Blood.<EOS>
<BOS>The cancer gets into the blood, travels through the blood vessels, and forms a tumor (metastatic tumor) in another part of the body.<EOS>
<BOS>The metastatic tumor is the same type of cancer as the primary tumor.<EOS>
<BOS>For example, if soft tissue sarcoma spreads to the lung, the cancer cells in the lung are actually soft tissue sarcoma cells.<EOS>
<BOS>The disease is metastatic soft tissue sarcoma, not lung cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>The following stages are used for adult soft tissue sarcoma: Stage I Stage I is divided into stages IA and IB: In stage IA, the tumor is lowgrade (likely to grow and spread slowly) and 5 centimeters or smaller.<EOS>
<BOS>It may be either superficial (in subcutaneous tissue with no spread into connective tissue or muscle below) or deep (in the muscle and may be in connective or subcutaneous tissue).<EOS>
<BOS>In stage IB, the tumor is lowgrade (likely to grow and spread slowly) and larger than 5 centimeters.<EOS>
<BOS>It may be either superficial (in subcutaneous tissue with no spread into connective tissue or muscle below) or deep (in the muscle and may be in connective or subcutaneous tissue).<EOS>
<BOS>Stage II Stage II is divided into stages IIA and IIB: In stage IIA, the tumor is midgrade (somewhat likely to grow and spread quickly) or highgrade (likely to grow and spread quickly) and 5 centimeters or smaller.<EOS>
<BOS>It may be either superficial (in subcutaneous tissue with no spread into connective tissue or muscle below) or deep (in the muscle and may be in connective or subcutaneous tissue).<EOS>
<BOS>In stage IIB, the tumor is midgrade (somewhat likely to grow and spread quickly) and larger than 5 centimeters.<EOS>
<BOS>It may be either superficial (in subcutaneous tissue with no spread into connective tissue or muscle below) or deep (in the muscle and may be in connective or subcutaneous tissue).<EOS>
<BOS>Stage III In stage III, the tumor is either: highgrade (likely to grow and spread quickly), larger than 5 centimeters, and either superficial (in subcutaneous tissue with no spread into connective tissue or muscle below) or deep (in the muscle and may be in connective or subcutaneous tissue); or any grade, any size, and has spread to nearby lymph nodes.<EOS>
<BOS>Stage III cancer that has spread to the lymph nodes is advanced stage III.<EOS>
<BOS>Stage IV In stage IV, the tumor is any grade, any size, and may have spread to nearby lymph nodes.<EOS>
<BOS>Cancer has spread to distant parts of the body, such as the lungs.<EOS>
<BOS>Tests that examine the abdomen and kidneys are used to detect (find) and diagnose transitional cell cancer of the renal pelvis and ureter.<EOS>
<BOS>The following tests and procedures may be used: Physical exam and history : An exam of the body to check general signs of health, including checking for signs of disease, such as lumps or anything else that seems unusual.<EOS>
<BOS>A history of the patients health habits and past illnesses and treatments will also be taken.<EOS>
<BOS>Urinalysis : A test to check the color of urine and its contents, such as sugar, protein, blood, and bacteria.<EOS>
<BOS>Ureteroscopy : A procedure to look inside the ureter and renal pelvis to check for abnormal areas.<EOS>
<BOS>A ureteroscope is a thin, tubelike instrument with a light and a lens for viewing.<EOS>
<BOS>The ureteroscope is inserted through the urethra into the bladder, ureter, and renal pelvis.<EOS>
<BOS>A tool may be inserted through the ureteroscope to take tissue samples to be checked under a microscope for signs of disease.<EOS>
<BOS>Urine cytology : A laboratory test in which a sample of urine is checked under a microscope for abnormal cells.<EOS>
<BOS>Cancer in the kidney, bladder, or ureter may shed cancer cells into the urine.<EOS>
<BOS>Intravenous pyelogram (IVP): A series of xrays of the kidneys, ureters, and bladder to check for cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>A contrast dye is injected into a vein.<EOS>
<BOS>As the contrast dye moves through the kidneys, ureters, and bladder, xrays are taken to see if there are any blockages.<EOS>
<BOS>CT scan (CAT scan): A procedure that makes a series of detailed pictures of areas inside the body, taken from different angles.<EOS>
<BOS>The pictures are made by a computer linked to an xray machine.<EOS>
<BOS>A dye may be injected into a vein or swallowed to help the organs or tissues show up more clearly.<EOS>
<BOS>This procedure is also called computed tomography, computerized tomography, or computerized axial tomography.<EOS>
<BOS>Ultrasound : A procedure in which highenergy sound waves (ultrasound) are bounced off internal tissues or organs and make echoes.<EOS>
<BOS>The echoes form a picture of body tissues called a sonogram.<EOS>
<BOS>An ultrasound of the abdomen may be done to help diagnose cancer of the renal pelvis and ureter.<EOS>
<BOS>MRI (magnetic resonance imaging): A procedure that uses a magnet, radio waves, and a computer to make a series of detailed pictures of areas inside the body, such as the pelvis.<EOS>
<BOS>This procedure is also called nuclear magnetic resonance imaging (NMRI).<EOS>
<BOS>Biopsy : The removal of cells or tissues so they can be viewed under a microscope by a pathologist to check for signs of cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>This may be done during a ureteroscopy or surgery.<EOS>
<BOS>Cancer prevention clinical trials are used to study ways to prevent cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Cancer prevention clinical trials are used to study ways to lower the risk of developing certain types of cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Some cancer prevention trials are conducted with healthy people who have not had cancer but who have an increased risk for cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Other prevention trials are conducted with people who have had cancer and are trying to prevent another cancer of the same type or to lower their chance of developing a new type of cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Other trials are done with healthy volunteers who are not known to have any risk factors for cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>The purpose of some cancer prevention clinical trials is to find out whether actions people take can prevent cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>These may include eating fruits and vegetables, exercising, quitting smoking, or taking certain medicines, vitamins, minerals, or food supplements.<EOS>
<BOS>New ways to prevent liver cancer are being studied in clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>Clinical trials are taking place in many parts of the country.<EOS>
<BOS>Information about clinical trials can be found in the Clinical Trials section of the NCI website.<EOS>
<BOS>Check NCI's list of cancer clinical trials for liver cancer prevention trials that are now accepting patients.<EOS>
<BOS>Being exposed to certain chemicals or dust in the workplace can increase the risk of paranasal sinus and nasal cavity cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Anything that increases your chance of getting a disease is called a risk factor.<EOS>
<BOS>Having a risk factor does not mean that you will get cancer; not having risk factors doesnt mean that you will not get cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Talk with your doctor if you think you may be at risk.<EOS>
<BOS>Risk factors for paranasal sinus and nasal cavity cancer include the following: Being exposed to certain workplace chemicals or dust, such as those found in the following jobs: Furnituremaking.<EOS>
<BOS>Sawmill work.<EOS>
<BOS>Woodworking (carpentry).<EOS>
<BOS>Shoemaking.<EOS>
<BOS>Metalplating.<EOS>
<BOS>Flour mill or bakery work.<EOS>
<BOS>Being infected with human papillomavirus (HPV).<EOS>
<BOS>Being male and older than 40 years.<EOS>
<BOS>Smoking.<EOS>
<BOS>Having past treatment with radiation can increase the risk of osteosarcoma.<EOS>
<BOS>Anything that increases your risk of getting a disease is called a risk factor.<EOS>
<BOS>Having a risk factor does not mean that you will get cancer; not having risk factors doesnt mean that you will not get cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Talk with your child's doctor if you think your child may be at risk.<EOS>
<BOS>Risk factors for osteosarcoma include the following: Past treatment with radiation therapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Past treatment with anticancer drugs called alkylating agents.<EOS>
<BOS>Having a certain change in the retinoblastoma gene.<EOS>
<BOS>Having certain conditions, such as the following: Bloom syndrome.<EOS>
<BOS>DiamondBlackfan anemia.<EOS>
<BOS>LiFraumeni syndrome.<EOS>
<BOS>Paget disease.<EOS>
<BOS>Hereditary retinoblastoma.<EOS>
<BOS>RothmundThomson syndrome.<EOS>
<BOS>Werner syndrome.<EOS>
<BOS>Key Points Avoiding risk factors and increasing protective factors may help prevent cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>The following are risk factors for ovarian, fallopian tube, and primary peritoneal cancer: Family history of ovarian, fallopian tube, and primary peritoneal cancer Inherited risk Hormone replacement therapy Weight and height The following are protective factors for ovarian, fallopian tube, and primary peritoneal cancer: Oral contraceptives Tubal ligation Breastfeeding Riskreducing salpingooophorectomy It is not clear whether the following affect the risk of ovarian, fallopian tube, and primary peritoneal cancer: Diet Alcohol Aspirin and nonsteroidal antiinflammatory drugs Smoking Talc Infertility treatment Cancer prevention clinical trials are used to study ways to prevent cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>New ways to prevent ovarian, fallopian tube, and primary peritoneal cancer are being studied in clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>Avoiding risk factors and increasing protective factors may help prevent cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Avoiding cancer risk factors may help prevent certain cancers.<EOS>
<BOS>Risk factors include smoking, being overweight, and not getting enough exercise.<EOS>
<BOS>Increasing protective factors such as quitting smoking and exercising may also help prevent some cancers.<EOS>
<BOS>Talk to your doctor or other health care professional about how you might lower your risk of cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>The following are risk factors for ovarian, fallopian tube, and primary peritoneal cancer: Family history of ovarian, fallopian tube, and primary peritoneal cancer A woman whose mother or sister had ovarian cancer has an increased risk of ovarian cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>A woman with two or more relatives with ovarian cancer also has an increased risk of ovarian cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Inherited risk The risk of ovarian cancer is increased in women who have inherited certain changes in the BRCA1, BRCA2, or other genes.<EOS>
<BOS>The risk of ovarian cancer is also increased in women who have certain inherited syndromes that include: Familial sitespecific ovarian cancer syndrome.<EOS>
<BOS>Familial breast/ovarian cancer syndrome.<EOS>
<BOS>Hereditary nonpolyposis colorectal cancer (HNPCC; Lynch syndrome).<EOS>
<BOS>Hormone replacement therapy The use of estrogen only hormone replacement therapy (HRT) after menopause is linked to a slightly increased risk of ovarian cancer in women who are taking HRT or have taken HRT within the past 3 years.<EOS>
<BOS>The risk of ovarian cancer increases the longer a woman uses estrogenonly HRT.<EOS>
<BOS>When hormone therapy is stopped, the risk of ovarian cancer decreases over time.<EOS>
<BOS>It is not clear whether there is an increased risk of ovarian cancer with the use of HRT that has both estrogen and progestin.<EOS>
<BOS>Weight and height Being overweight or obese during the teenage years is linked to an increased risk of ovarian cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Being obese is linked to an increased risk of death from ovarian cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Being tall (5'8" or taller) may also be linked to a slight increase in the risk of ovarian cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>The following are protective factors for ovarian, fallopian tube, and primary peritoneal cancer: Oral contraceptives Taking oral contraceptives (the pill) lowers the risk of ovarian cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>The longer oral contraceptives are used, the lower the risk may be.<EOS>
<BOS>The decrease in risk may last up to 30 years after a woman has stopped taking oral contraceptives.<EOS>
<BOS>Taking oral contraceptives increases the risk of blood clots.<EOS>
<BOS>This risk is higher in women who also smoke.<EOS>
<BOS>Tubal ligation The risk of ovarian cancer is decreased in women who have a tubal ligation (surgery to close both fallopian tubes).<EOS>
<BOS>Breastfeeding Breastfeeding is linked to a decreased risk of ovarian cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>The longer a woman breastfeeds, the lower her risk of ovarian cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Riskreducing salpingooophorectomy Some women who have a high risk of ovarian cancer may choose to have a riskreducing salpingooophorectomy (surgery to remove the fallopian tubes and ovaries when there are no signs of cancer).<EOS>
<BOS>This includes women who have inherited certain changes in the BRCA1 and BRCA2 genes or have an inherited syndrome.<EOS>
<BOS>(See the Riskreducing salpingooophorectomy section in the PDQ health professional summary on Genetics of Breast and Gynecologic Cancers for more information.<EOS>
<BOS>) It is very important to have a cancer risk assessment and counseling before making this decision.<EOS>
<BOS>These and other factors may be discussed: Infertility.<EOS>
<BOS>Early menopause: The drop in estrogen levels caused by removing the ovaries can cause early menopause.<EOS>
<BOS>Symptoms of menopause include the following: Hot flashes.<EOS>
<BOS>Night sweats.<EOS>
<BOS>Trouble sleeping.<EOS>
<BOS>Mood changes.<EOS>
<BOS>Decreased sex drive.<EOS>
<BOS>Heart disease.<EOS>
<BOS>Vaginal dryness.<EOS>
<BOS>Frequent urination.<EOS>
<BOS>Osteoporosis (decreased bone density).<EOS>
<BOS>These symptoms may not be the same in all women.<EOS>
<BOS>Hormone replacement therapy (HRT) may be used to lessen these symptoms.<EOS>
<BOS>Risk of ovarian cancer in the peritoneum: Women who have had a riskreducing salpingooophorectomy continue to have a small risk of ovarian cancer in the peritoneum (thin layer of tissue that lines the inside of the abdomen).<EOS>
<BOS>This may occur if ovarian cancer cells had already spread to the peritoneum before the surgery or if some ovarian tissue remains after surgery.<EOS>
<BOS>It is not clear whether the following affect the risk of ovarian, fallopian tube, and primary peritoneal cancer: Diet Studies of dietary factors including various foods, teas, and nutrients have not found a strong link to ovarian cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Alcohol Studies have not shown a link between drinking alcohol and the risk of ovarian cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Aspirin and nonsteroidal antiinflammatory drugs Some studies of aspirin and nonsteroidal antiinflammatory drugs (NSAIDs) have found a decreased risk of ovarian cancer and others have not.<EOS>
<BOS>Smoking Some studies found a very small increased risk of one rare type of ovarian cancer in women who were current smokers compared with women who never smoked.<EOS>
<BOS>Talc Studies of women who used talcum powder (talc) dusted on the perineum (the area between the vagina and the anus) have not found clear evidence of an increased risk of ovarian cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Infertility treatment Overall, studies in women using fertility drugs have not found clear evidence of an increased risk of ovarian cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Risk of ovarian borderline malignant tumors may be higher in women who take fertility drugs.<EOS>
<BOS>The risk of invasive ovarian cancer may be higher in women who do not get pregnant after taking fertility drugs.<EOS>
<BOS>Cancer prevention clinical trials are used to study ways to prevent cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Cancer prevention clinical trials are used to study ways to lower the risk of developing certain types of cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Some cancer prevention trials are conducted with healthy people who have not had cancer but who have an increased risk for cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Other prevention trials are conducted with people who have had cancer and are trying to prevent another cancer of the same type or to lower their chance of developing a new type of cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Other trials are done with healthy volunteers who are not known to have any risk factors for cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>The purpose of some cancer prevention clinical trials is to find out whether actions people take can prevent cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>These may include eating fruits and vegetables, exercising, quitting smoking, or taking certain medicines, vitamins, minerals, or food supplements.<EOS>
<BOS>New ways to prevent ovarian, fallopian tube, and primary peritoneal cancer are being studied in clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>Clinical trials are taking place in many parts of the country.<EOS>
<BOS>Information about clinical trials can be found in the Clinical Trials section of the NCI website.<EOS>
<BOS>Check NCI's list of cancer clinical trials for ovarian cancer prevention trials that are now accepting patients.<EOS>
<BOS>Imaging studies and tests that examine the blood and urine are used to detect (find) and diagnose a pituitary tumor.<EOS>
<BOS>The following tests and procedures may be used: Physical exam and history : An exam of the body to check general signs of health, including checking for signs of disease, such as lumps or anything else that seems unusual.<EOS>
<BOS>A history of the patients health habits and past illnesses and treatments will also be taken.<EOS>
<BOS>Eye exam: An exam to check vision and the general health of the eyes.<EOS>
<BOS>Visual field exam: An exam to check a persons field of vision (the total area in which objects can be seen).<EOS>
<BOS>This test measures both central vision (how much a person can see when looking straight ahead) and peripheral vision (how much a person can see in all other directions while staring straight ahead).<EOS>
<BOS>The eyes are tested one at a time.<EOS>
<BOS>The eye not being tested is covered.<EOS>
<BOS>Neurological exam : A series of questions and tests to check the brain, spinal cord, and nerve function.<EOS>
<BOS>The exam checks a persons mental status, coordination, and ability to walk normally, and how well the muscles, senses, and reflexes work.<EOS>
<BOS>This may also be called a neuro exam or a neurologic exam.<EOS>
<BOS>MRI (magnetic resonance imaging) with gadolinium : A procedure that uses a magnet, radio waves, and a computer to make a series of detailed pictures of areas inside the brain and spinal cord.<EOS>
<BOS>A substance called gadolinium is injected into a vein.<EOS>
<BOS>The gadolinium collects around the cancer cells so they show up brighter in the picture.<EOS>
<BOS>This procedure is also called nuclear magnetic resonance imaging (NMRI).<EOS>
<BOS>Blood chemistry study : A procedure in which a blood sample is checked to measure the amounts of certain substances, such as glucose (sugar), released into the blood by organs and tissues in the body.<EOS>
<BOS>An unusual (higher or lower than normal) amount of a substance can be a sign of disease.<EOS>
<BOS>Blood tests: Tests to measure the levels of testosterone or estrogen in the blood.<EOS>
<BOS>A higher or lower than normal amount of these hormones may be a sign of pituitary tumor.<EOS>
<BOS>Twentyfourhour urine test: A test in which urine is collected for 24 hours to measure the amounts of certain substances.<EOS>
<BOS>An unusual (higher or lower than normal) amount of a substance can be a sign of disease in the organ or tissue that makes it.<EOS>
<BOS>A higher than normal amount of the hormone cortisol may be a sign of a pituitary tumor and Cushing syndrome.<EOS>
<BOS>Highdose dexamethasone suppression test: A test in which one or more high doses of dexamethasone are given.<EOS>
<BOS>The level of cortisol is checked from a sample of blood or from urine that is collected for three days.<EOS>
<BOS>This test is done to check if the adrenal gland is making too much cortisol or if the pituitary gland is telling the adrenal glands to make too much cortisol.<EOS>
<BOS>Lowdose dexamethasone suppression test: A test in which one or more small doses of dexamethasone are given.<EOS>
<BOS>The level of cortisol is checked from a sample of blood or from urine that is collected for three days.<EOS>
<BOS>This test is done to check if the adrenal gland is making too much cortisol.<EOS>
<BOS>Venous sampling for pituitary tumors: A procedure in which a sample of blood is taken from veins coming from the pituitary gland.<EOS>
<BOS>The sample is checked to measure the amount of ACTH released into the blood by the gland.<EOS>
<BOS>Venous sampling may be done if blood tests show there is a tumor making ACTH, but the pituitary gland looks normal in the imaging tests.<EOS>
<BOS>Biopsy : The removal of cells or tissues so they can be viewed under a microscope by a pathologist to check for signs of cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>The following tests may be done on the sample of tissue that is removed: Immunohistochemistry : A test that uses antibodies to check for certain antigens in a sample of tissue.<EOS>
<BOS>The antibody is usually linked to a radioactive substance or a dye that causes the tissue to light up under a microscope.<EOS>
<BOS>This type of test may be used to tell the difference between different types of cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Immunocytochemistry : A test that uses antibodies to check for certain antigens in a sample of cells.<EOS>
<BOS>The antibody is usually linked to a radioactive substance or a dye that causes the cells to light up under a microscope.<EOS>
<BOS>This type of test may be used to tell the difference between different types of cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Light and electron microscopy : A laboratory test in which cells in a sample of tissue are viewed under regular and highpowered microscopes to look for certain changes in the cells.<EOS>
<BOS>Key Points Metastatic squamous neck cancer with occult primary is a disease in which squamous cell cancer spreads to lymph nodes in the neck and it is not known where the cancer first formed in the body.<EOS>
<BOS>Signs and symptoms of metastatic squamous neck cancer with occult primary include a lump or pain in the neck or throat.<EOS>
<BOS>Tests that examine the tissues of the neck, respiratory tract, and upper part of the digestive tract are used to detect (find) and diagnose metastatic squamous neck cancer and the primary tumor.<EOS>
<BOS>Certain factors affect prognosis (chance of recovery) and treatment options.<EOS>
<BOS>Metastatic squamous neck cancer with occult primary is a disease in which squamous cell cancer spreads to lymph nodes in the neck and it is not known where the cancer first formed in the body.<EOS>
<BOS>Squamous cells are thin, flat cells found in tissues that form the surface of the skin and the lining of body cavities such as the mouth, hollow organs such as the uterus and blood vessels, and the lining of the respiratory (breathing) and digestive tracts.<EOS>
<BOS>Some organs with squamous cells are the esophagus, lungs, kidneys, and uterus.<EOS>
<BOS>Cancer can begin in squamous cells anywhere in the body and metastasize (spread) through the blood or lymph system to other parts of the body.<EOS>
<BOS>When squamous cell cancer spreads to lymph nodes in the neck or around the collarbone, it is called metastatic squamous neck cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>The doctor will try to find the primary tumor (the cancer that first formed in the body), because treatment for metastatic cancer is the same as treatment for the primary tumor.<EOS>
<BOS>For example, when lung cancer spreads to the neck, the cancer cells in the neck are lung cancer cells and they are treated the same as the cancer in the lung.<EOS>
<BOS>Sometimes doctors cannot find where in the body the cancer first began to grow.<EOS>
<BOS>When tests cannot find a primary tumor, it is called an occult (hidden) primary tumor.<EOS>
<BOS>In many cases, the primary tumor is never found.<EOS>
<BOS>Tests that examine the blood and bone marrow are used to detect (find) and diagnose childhood AML, childhood CML, JMML, and MDS.<EOS>
<BOS>The following tests and procedures may be used: Physical exam and history : An exam of the body to check general signs of health, including checking for signs of disease, such as lumps or anything else that seems unusual.<EOS>
<BOS>A history of the patients health habits and past illnesses and treatments will also be taken.<EOS>
<BOS>Complete blood count (CBC) with differential: A procedure in which a sample of blood is drawn and checked for the following: The number of red blood cells and platelets.<EOS>
<BOS>The number and type of white blood cells.<EOS>
<BOS>The amount of hemoglobin (the protein that carries oxygen) in the red blood cells.<EOS>
<BOS>The portion of the blood sample made up of red blood cells.<EOS>
<BOS>Peripheral blood smear : A procedure in which a sample of blood is checked for blast cells, the number and kinds of white blood cells, number of platelets, and changes in the shape of the blood cells.<EOS>
<BOS>Blood chemistry studies : A procedure in which a blood sample is checked to measure the amounts of certain substances released into the blood by organs and tissues in the body.<EOS>
<BOS>An unusual (higher or lower than normal) amount of a substance can be a sign of disease.<EOS>
<BOS>Chest xray : An xray of the organs and bones inside the chest.<EOS>
<BOS>An xray is a type of energy beam that can go through the body and onto film, making a picture of areas inside the body.<EOS>
<BOS>Biopsy : The removal of cells or tissues so they can be viewed under a microscope by a pathologist to check for signs of cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Biopsies that may be done include the following: Bone marrow aspiration and biopsy : The removal of bone marrow, blood, and a small piece of bone by inserting a hollow needle into the hipbone or breastbone.<EOS>
<BOS>Tumor biopsy: A biopsy of a chloroma may be done.<EOS>
<BOS>Lymph node biopsy: The removal of all or part of a lymph node.<EOS>
<BOS>Cytogenetic analysis : A laboratory test in which cells in a sample of blood or bone marrow are viewed under a microscope to look for certain changes in the chromosomes.<EOS>
<BOS>Changes in the chromosomes may include when part of one chromosome is switched with part of another chromosome, part of one chromosome is missing or repeated, or part of one chromosome is turned upside down.<EOS>
<BOS>The following test is a type of cytogenetic analysis: FISH (fluorescence in situ hybridization): A laboratory technique used to look at genes or chromosomes in cells and tissues.<EOS>
<BOS>Pieces of DNA that contain a fluorescent dye are made in the laboratory and added to cells or tissues on a glass slide.<EOS>
<BOS>When these pieces of DNA bind to specific genes or areas of chromosomes on the slide, they light up when viewed under a microscope with a special light.<EOS>
<BOS>Reverse transcriptionpolymerase chain reaction (RTPCR) test: A laboratory test in which cells in a sample of tissue are studied using chemicals to look for certain changes in the structure or function of genes.<EOS>
<BOS>Immunophenotyping : A process used to identify cells, based on the types of antigens or markers on the surface of the cell, that may include special staining of the blood and bone marrow cells.<EOS>
<BOS>This process is used to diagnose the subtype of AML by comparing the cancer cells to normal cells of the immune system.<EOS>
<BOS>Molecular testing : A laboratory test to check for certain genes, proteins, or other molecules in a sample of blood or bone marrow.<EOS>
<BOS>Molecular tests also check for certain changes in a gene or chromosome that may cause or affect the chance of developing AML.<EOS>
<BOS>A molecular test may be used to help plan treatment, find out how well treatment is working, or make a prognosis.<EOS>
<BOS>Lumbar puncture : A procedure used to collect a sample of cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) from the spinal column.<EOS>
<BOS>This is done by placing a needle between two bones in the spine and into the CSF around the spinal cord and removing a sample of the fluid.<EOS>
<BOS>The sample of CSF is checked under a microscope for signs that leukemia cells have spread to the brain and spinal cord.<EOS>
<BOS>This procedure is also called an LP or spinal tap.<EOS>
<BOS>Tests that examine the blood, bone marrow, and urine are used to detect (find) and diagnose multiple myeloma and other plasma cell neoplasms.<EOS>
<BOS>The following tests and procedures may be used: Physical exam and history : An exam of the body to check general signs of health, including checking for signs of disease, such as lumps or anything else that seems unusual.<EOS>
<BOS>A history of the patients health habits and past illnesses and treatments will also be taken.<EOS>
<BOS>Blood and urine immunoglobulin studies: A procedure in which a blood or urine sample is checked to measure the amounts of certain antibodies (immunoglobulins).<EOS>
<BOS>For multiple myeloma, beta2microglobulin, M protein, free light chains, and other proteins made by the myeloma cells are measured.<EOS>
<BOS>A higherthannormal amount of these substances can be a sign of disease.<EOS>
<BOS>Bone marrow aspiration and biopsy : The removal of bone marrow, blood, and a small piece of bone by inserting a hollow needle into the hipbone or breastbone.<EOS>
<BOS>A pathologist views the bone marrow, blood, and bone under a microscope to look for abnormal cells.<EOS>
<BOS>The following test may be done on the sample of tissue removed during the bone marrow aspiration and biopsy: Cytogenetic analysis : A test in which cells in a sample of bone marrow are viewed under a microscope to look for certain changes in the chromosomes.<EOS>
<BOS>Other tests, such as fluorescence in situ hybridization (FISH) and flow cytometry, may also be done to look for certain changes in the chromosomes.<EOS>
<BOS>Skeletal bone survey: In a skeletal bone survey, xrays of all the bones in the body are taken.<EOS>
<BOS>The xrays are used to find areas where the bone is damaged.<EOS>
<BOS>An xray is a type of energy beam that can go through the body and onto film, making a picture of areas inside the body.<EOS>
<BOS>Complete blood count (CBC) with differential : A procedure in which a sample of blood is drawn and checked for the following: The number of red blood cells and platelets.<EOS>
<BOS>The number and type of white blood cells.<EOS>
<BOS>The amount of hemoglobin (the protein that carries oxygen) in the red blood cells.<EOS>
<BOS>The portion of the blood sample made up of red blood cells.<EOS>
<BOS>Blood chemistry studies : A procedure in which a blood sample is checked to measure the amounts of certain substances, such as calcium or albumin, released into the blood by organs and tissues in the body.<EOS>
<BOS>An unusual (higher or lower than normal) amount of a substance can be a sign of disease.<EOS>
<BOS>Twentyfourhour urine test: A test in which urine is collected for 24 hours to measure the amounts of certain substances.<EOS>
<BOS>An unusual (higher or lower than normal) amount of a substance can be a sign of disease in the organ or tissue that makes it.<EOS>
<BOS>A higher than normal amount of protein may be a sign of multiple myeloma.<EOS>
<BOS>MRI (magnetic resonance imaging): A procedure that uses a magnet, radio waves, and a computer to make a series of detailed pictures of areas inside the body.<EOS>
<BOS>This procedure is also called nuclear magnetic resonance imaging (NMRI).<EOS>
<BOS>An MRI of the spine and pelvis may be used to find areas where the bone is damaged.<EOS>
<BOS>CT scan (CAT scan): A procedure that makes a series of detailed pictures of areas inside the body, such as the spine, taken from different angles.<EOS>
<BOS>The pictures are made by a computer linked to an xray machine.<EOS>
<BOS>A dye may be injected into a vein or swallowed to help the organs or tissues show up more clearly.<EOS>
<BOS>This procedure is also called computed tomography, computerized tomography, or computerized axial tomography.<EOS>
<BOS>PETCT scan : A procedure that combines the pictures from a positron emission tomography (PET) scan and a computed tomography (CT) scan.<EOS>
<BOS>The PET and CT scans are done at the same time with the same machine.<EOS>
<BOS>The combined scans give more detailed pictures of areas inside the body, such as the spine, than either scan gives by itself.<EOS>
<BOS>Certain factors affect prognosis (chance of recovery) and treatment options.<EOS>
<BOS>The prognosis (chance of recovery) and treatment options depend on the following: The part of the body where the tumor first formed.<EOS>
<BOS>The size and grade of the tumor.<EOS>
<BOS>The type of soft tissue sarcoma.<EOS>
<BOS>How deep the tumor is under the skin.<EOS>
<BOS>Whether the tumor has spread to other places in the body.<EOS>
<BOS>The amount of tumor remaining after surgery to remove it.<EOS>
<BOS>Whether radiation therapy was used to treat the tumor.<EOS>
<BOS>The age and gender of the patient.<EOS>
<BOS>Whether the cancer has just been diagnosed or has recurred (come back).<EOS>
<BOS>Key Points Avoiding risk factors and increasing protective factors may help prevent cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>The following risk factors increase the risk of endometrial cancer: Endometrial hyperplasia Estrogen Tamoxifen Obesity, weight gain, metabolic syndrome, and diabetes Genetic factors The following protective factors decrease the risk of endometrial cancer: Pregnancy and breastfeeding Combination oral contraceptives Physical activity Cigarette smoking It is not known if the following factors affect the risk of endometrial cancer: Weight loss Fruits, vegetables, and vitamins Cancer prevention clinical trials are used to study ways to prevent cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>New ways to prevent endometrial cancer are being studied in clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>Avoiding risk factors and increasing protective factors may help prevent cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Avoiding cancer risk factors may help prevent certain cancers.<EOS>
<BOS>Risk factors include smoking, being overweight, and not getting enough exercise.<EOS>
<BOS>Increasing protective factors such as quitting smoking and exercising may also help prevent some cancers.<EOS>
<BOS>Talk to your doctor or other health care professional about how you might lower your risk of cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>The following risk factors increase the risk of endometrial cancer: Endometrial hyperplasia Endometrial hyperplasia is an abnormal thickening of the endometrium (lining of the uterus).<EOS>
<BOS>It is not cancer, but in some cases, it may lead to endometrial cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Estrogen Estrogen is a hormone made by the body.<EOS>
<BOS>It helps the body develop and maintain female sex characteristics.<EOS>
<BOS>Estrogen can affect the growth of some cancers, including endometrial cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>A woman's risk of developing endometrial cancer is increased by being exposed to estrogen in the following ways: Estrogenonly hormone replacement therapy: Estrogen may be given to replace the estrogen no longer produced by the ovaries in postmenopausal women or women whose ovaries have been removed.<EOS>
<BOS>This is called hormone replacement therapy (HRT), or hormone therapy (HT).<EOS>
<BOS>The use of HRT that contains only estrogen increases the risk of endometrial cancer and endometrial hyperplasia.<EOS>
<BOS>For this reason, estrogen therapy alone is usually prescribed only for women who do not have a uterus.<EOS>
<BOS>HRT that contains only estrogen also increases the risk of stroke and blood clots.<EOS>
<BOS>When estrogen is combined with progestin (another hormone), it is called combination estrogenprogestin replacement therapy.<EOS>
<BOS>For postmenopausal women, taking estrogen in combination with progestin does not increase the risk of endometrial cancer, but it does increase the risk of breast cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>(See the Breast Cancer Prevention summary for more information.<EOS>
<BOS>) Early menstruation: Beginning to have menstrual periods at an early age increases the number of years the body is exposed to estrogen and increases a woman's risk of endometrial cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Late menopause: Women who reach menopause at an older age are exposed to estrogen for a longer time and have an increased risk of endometrial cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Never being pregnant: Because estrogen levels are lower during pregnancy, women who have never been pregnant are exposed to estrogen for a longer time than women who have been pregnant.<EOS>
<BOS>This increases the risk of endometrial cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Tamoxifen Tamoxifen is one of a group of drugs called selective estrogen receptor modulators, or SERMs.<EOS>
<BOS>Tamoxifen acts like estrogen on some tissues in the body, such as the uterus, but blocks the effects of estrogen on other tissues, such as the breast.<EOS>
<BOS>Tamoxifen is used to prevent breast cancer in women who are at high risk for the disease.<EOS>
<BOS>However, using tamoxifen for more than 2 years increases the risk of endometrial cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>This risk is greater in postmenopausal women.<EOS>
<BOS>Raloxifene is a SERM that is used to prevent bone weakness in postmenopausal women.<EOS>
<BOS>However, it does not have estrogenlike effects on the uterus and has not been shown to increase the risk of endometrial cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Obesity, weight gain, metabolic syndrome, and diabetes Obesity, gaining weight as an adult, or having metabolic syndrome increases the risk of endometrial cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Obesity is related to other risk factors such as high estrogen levels, having extra fat around the waist, polycystic ovary syndrome, and lack of physical activity.<EOS>
<BOS>Having metabolic syndrome increases the risk of endometrial cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Metabolic syndrome is a condition that includes extra fat around the waist, high blood sugar, high blood pressure, and high levels of triglycerides (a type of fat) in the blood.<EOS>
<BOS>Genetic factors Hereditary nonpolyposis colon cancer (HNPCC) syndrome (also known as Lynch Syndrome) is an inherited disorder caused by changes in certain genes.<EOS>
<BOS>Women who have HNPCC syndrome have a much higher risk of developing endometrial cancer than women who do not have HNPCC syndrome.<EOS>
<BOS>Polycystic ovary syndrome (a disorder of the hormones made by the ovaries), and Cowden syndrome are inherited conditions that are linked to an increased risk of endometrial cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Women with a family history of endometrial cancer in a firstdegree relative (mother, sister, or daughter) are also at increased risk of endometrial cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>It is not known if the following factors affect the risk of endometrial cancer: Weight loss It is not known if losing weight decreases the risk of endometrial cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Fruits, vegetables, and vitamins A diet that includes, fruits, vegetables, phytoestrogen, soy, and vitamin D has not been found to affect the risk of endometrial cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Taking multivitamins has little or no effect on the risk of common cancers, including endometrial cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Key Points There are different types of treatment for children with craniopharyngioma.<EOS>
<BOS>Children with craniopharyngioma should have their treatment planned by a team of health care providers who are experts in treating brain tumors in children.<EOS>
<BOS>Childhood brain tumors may cause signs or symptoms that begin before the cancer is diagnosed and continue for months or years.<EOS>
<BOS>Some treatments for tumors cause side effects months or years after treatment has ended.<EOS>
<BOS>Five types of treatment are used: Surgery (resection) Surgery and radiation therapy Surgery with cyst drainage Chemotherapy Biologic therapy Patients may want to think about taking part in a clinical trial.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients can enter clinical trials before, during, or after starting their treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Followup tests may be needed.<EOS>
<BOS>There are different types of treatment for children with craniopharyngioma.<EOS>
<BOS>Different types of treatments are available for children with craniopharyngioma.<EOS>
<BOS>Some treatments are standard (the currently used treatment), and some are being tested in clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>A treatment clinical trial is a research study meant to help improve current treatments or obtain information on new treatments for patients with tumors.<EOS>
<BOS>When clinical trials show that a new treatment is better than the standard treatment, the new treatment may become the standard treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Because tumors in children are rare, taking part in a clinical trial should be considered.<EOS>
<BOS>Clinical trials are taking place in many parts of the country.<EOS>
<BOS>Information about ongoing clinical trials is available from the NCI website.<EOS>
<BOS>Choosing the most appropriate treatment is a decision that ideally involves the patient, family, and health care team.<EOS>
<BOS>Children with craniopharyngioma should have their treatment planned by a team of health care providers who are experts in treating brain tumors in children.<EOS>
<BOS>Treatment will be overseen by a pediatric oncologist, a doctor who specializes in treating children with tumors.<EOS>
<BOS>The pediatric oncologist works with other pediatric healthcare providers who are experts in treating children with brain tumors and who specialize in certain areas of medicine.<EOS>
<BOS>These may include the following specialists: Pediatrician.<EOS>
<BOS>Neurosurgeon.<EOS>
<BOS>Radiation oncologist.<EOS>
<BOS>Neurologist.<EOS>
<BOS>Endocrinologist.<EOS>
<BOS>Ophthalmologist.<EOS>
<BOS>Rehabilitation specialist.<EOS>
<BOS>Psychologist.<EOS>
<BOS>Social worker.<EOS>
<BOS>Nurse specialist.<EOS>
<BOS>Childhood brain tumors may cause signs or symptoms that begin before the cancer is diagnosed and continue for months or years.<EOS>
<BOS>Signs or symptoms caused by the tumor may begin before diagnosis and continue for months or years.<EOS>
<BOS>It is important to talk with your child's doctors about signs or symptoms caused by the tumor that may continue after treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Some treatments for tumors cause side effects months or years after treatment has ended.<EOS>
<BOS>Side effects from tumor treatment that begin during or after treatment and continue for months or years are called late effects.<EOS>
<BOS>Late effects of tumor treatment may include the following: Physical problems such as seizures.<EOS>
<BOS>Behavior problems.<EOS>
<BOS>Changes in mood, feelings, thinking, learning, or memory.<EOS>
<BOS>Second cancers (new types of cancer).<EOS>
<BOS>The following serious physical problems may occur if the pituitary gland, hypothalamus, optic nerves, or carotid artery are affected during surgery or radiation therapy: Obesity.<EOS>
<BOS>Metabolic syndrome, including fatty liver disease not caused by drinking alcohol.<EOS>
<BOS>Vision problems, including blindness.<EOS>
<BOS>Blood vessel problems or stroke.<EOS>
<BOS>Loss of the ability to make certain hormones.<EOS>
<BOS>Some late effects may be treated or controlled.<EOS>
<BOS>Lifelong hormone replacement therapy with several medicines may be needed.<EOS>
<BOS>It is important to talk with your child's doctors about the effects tumor treatment can have on your child.<EOS>
<BOS>(See the PDQ summary on Late Effects of Treatment for Childhood Cancer for more information).<EOS>
<BOS>Five types of treatment are used: Surgery (resection) The way the surgery is done depends on the size of the tumor and where it is in the brain.<EOS>
<BOS>It also depends on whether the tumor has grown into nearby tissue in a fingerlike way and expected late effects after surgery.<EOS>
<BOS>The types of surgery that may be used to remove all of the tumor that can be seen with the eye include the following: Transsphenoidal surgery: A type of surgery in which the instruments are inserted into part of the brain by going through an incision (cut) made under the upper lip or at the bottom of the nose between the nostrils and then through the sphenoid bone (a butterflyshaped bone at the base of the skull).<EOS>
<BOS>Craniotomy: Surgery to remove the tumor through an opening made in the skull.<EOS>
<BOS>Sometimes all of the tumor that can be seen is removed in surgery and no further treatment is needed.<EOS>
<BOS>At other times, it is hard to remove the tumor because it is growing into or pressing on nearby organs.<EOS>
<BOS>If there is tumor remaining after the surgery, radiation therapy is usually given to kill any tumor cells that are left.<EOS>
<BOS>Treatment given after the surgery, to lower the risk that the cancer will come back, is called adjuvant therapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Surgery and radiation therapy Partial resection is used to treat some craniopharyngiomas.<EOS>
<BOS>It is used to diagnose the tumor, remove fluid from a cyst, and relieve pressure on the optic nerves.<EOS>
<BOS>If the tumor is near the pituitary gland or hypothalamus, it is not removed.<EOS>
<BOS>This reduces the number of serious side effects after surgery.<EOS>
<BOS>Partial resection is followed by radiation therapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Radiation therapy is a tumor treatment that uses highenergy xrays or other types of radiation to kill tumor cells or keep them from growing.<EOS>
<BOS>There are two types of radiation therapy: External radiation therapy uses a machine outside the body to send radiation toward the tumor.<EOS>
<BOS>Internal radiation therapy uses a radioactive substance sealed in needles, seeds, wires, or catheters that are placed directly into or near the tumor.<EOS>
<BOS>The way the radiation therapy is given depends on the type of tumor, whether the tumor is newly diagnosed or has come back, and where the tumor formed in the brain.<EOS>
<BOS>External and internal radiation therapy are used to treat childhood craniopharyngioma.<EOS>
<BOS>Because radiation therapy to the brain can affect growth and development in young children, ways of giving radiation therapy that have fewer side effects are being used.<EOS>
<BOS>These include: Stereotactic radiosurgery: For very small craniopharyngiomas at the base of the brain, stereotactic radiosurgery may be used.<EOS>
<BOS>Stereotactic radiosurgery is a type of external radiation therapy.<EOS>
<BOS>A rigid head frame is attached to the skull to keep the head still during the radiation treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>A machine aims a single large dose of radiation directly at the tumor.<EOS>
<BOS>This procedure does not involve surgery.<EOS>
<BOS>It is also called stereotaxic radiosurgery, radiosurgery, and radiation surgery.<EOS>
<BOS>Intracavitary radiation therapy: Intracavitary radiation therapy is a type of internal radiation therapy that may be used in tumors that are part solid mass and part fluidfilled cyst.<EOS>
<BOS>Radioactive material is placed inside the tumor.<EOS>
<BOS>This type of radiation therapy causes less damage to the nearby hypothalamus and optic nerves.<EOS>
<BOS>Intensitymodulated proton therapy: A type of radiation therapy that uses streams of protons (tiny particles with a positive charge) to kill tumor cells.<EOS>
<BOS>A computer is used to target the exact shape and location of the tumor with proton therapy.<EOS>
<BOS>This type of 3dimensional radiation therapy may cause less damage to healthy tissue in the brain and other parts of the body.<EOS>
<BOS>Proton radiation is different from xray radiation.<EOS>
<BOS>Surgery with cyst drainage Surgery may be done to drain tumors that are mostly fluidfilled cysts.<EOS>
<BOS>This lowers pressure in the brain and relieves symptoms.<EOS>
<BOS>A catheter (thin tube) is inserted into the cyst and a small container is placed under the skin.<EOS>
<BOS>The fluid drains into the container and is later removed.<EOS>
<BOS>Sometimes, after the cyst is drained, a drug is put through the catheter into the cyst.<EOS>
<BOS>This causes the inside wall of the cyst to scar and stops the cyst from making fluid or increases the amount of the time it takes for the fluid to build up again.<EOS>
<BOS>Surgery to remove the tumor may be done after the cyst is drained.<EOS>
<BOS>Chemotherapy Chemotherapy is a treatment that uses anticancer drugs to stop the growth of tumor cells, either by killing the cells or by stopping them from dividing.<EOS>
<BOS>When chemotherapy is taken by mouth or injected into a vein or muscle, the drugs enter the bloodstream and can reach tumor cells throughout the body (systemic chemotherapy).<EOS>
<BOS>When chemotherapy is placed directly into the cerebrospinal fluid or an organ, the drugs mainly affect tumor cells in those areas (regional chemotherapy).<EOS>
<BOS>Intracavitary chemotherapy is a type of regional chemotherapy that places drugs directly into a cavity, such as a cyst.<EOS>
<BOS>It is used for craniopharyngioma that has come back after treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Biologic therapy Biologic therapy is a treatment that uses the patients immune system to fight cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Substances made by the body or made in a laboratory are used to boost, direct, or restore the bodys natural defenses against cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>This type of cancer treatment is also called biotherapy or immunotherapy.<EOS>
<BOS>For craniopharyngioma that has come back after treatment, the biologic therapy drug is placed inside the tumor using a catheter (intracavitary) or in a vein (intravenous).<EOS>
<BOS>Patients may want to think about taking part in a clinical trial.<EOS>
<BOS>For some patients, taking part in a clinical trial may be the best treatment choice.<EOS>
<BOS>Clinical trials are part of the medical research process.<EOS>
<BOS>Clinical trials are done to find out if new treatments are safe and effective or better than the standard treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Many of today's standard treatments are based on earlier clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients who take part in a clinical trial may receive the standard treatment or be among the first to receive a new treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients who take part in clinical trials also help improve the way diseases will be treated in the future.<EOS>
<BOS>Even when clinical trials do not lead to effective new treatments, they often answer important questions and help move research forward.<EOS>
<BOS>Check the list of NCIsupported cancer clinical trials that are now accepting patients with childhood craniopharyngioma.<EOS>
<BOS>For more specific results, refine the search by using other search features, such as the location of the trial, the type of treatment, or the name of the drug.<EOS>
<BOS>Talk with your child's doctor about clinical trials that may be right for your child.<EOS>
<BOS>General information about clinical trials is available from the NCI website.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients can enter clinical trials before, during, or after starting their treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Some clinical trials only include patients who have not yet received treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Other trials test treatments for patients who have not improved.<EOS>
<BOS>There are also clinical trials that test new ways to stop a disease from recurring (coming back) or reduce the side effects of treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Clinical trials are taking place in many parts of the country.<EOS>
<BOS>See the Treatment Options section that follows for links to current treatment clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>These have been retrieved from NCI's clinical trials database.<EOS>
<BOS>Followup tests may be needed.<EOS>
<BOS>Some of the tests that were done to diagnose the disease or decide how to treat it may be repeated.<EOS>
<BOS>Some tests will be repeated in order to see how well the treatment is working.<EOS>
<BOS>Decisions about whether to continue, change, or stop treatment may be based on the results of these tests.<EOS>
<BOS>Some of the tests will continue to be done from time to time after treatment has ended.<EOS>
<BOS>The results of these tests can show if your condition has changed.<EOS>
<BOS>These tests are sometimes called followup tests or checkups.<EOS>
<BOS>After treatment, followup testing with MRI will be done for several years to check if the tumor has come back.<EOS>
<BOS>Treatment Options for Childhood Craniopharyngioma Newly Diagnosed Childhood Craniopharyngioma Treatment of newly diagnosed childhood craniopharyngioma may include the following: Surgery (resection) with or without radiation therapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Partial resection followed by radiation therapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Cyst drainage with or without radiation therapy or surgery.<EOS>
<BOS>Check the list of NCIsupported cancer clinical trials that are now accepting patients with childhood craniopharyngioma.<EOS>
<BOS>For more specific results, refine the search by using other search features, such as the location of the trial, the type of treatment, or the name of the drug.<EOS>
<BOS>Talk with your child's doctor about clinical trials that may be right for your child.<EOS>
<BOS>General information about clinical trials is available from the NCI website.<EOS>
<BOS>Recurrent Childhood Craniopharyngioma Craniopharyngioma may recur (come back) no matter how it was treated the first time.<EOS>
<BOS>Treatment options for recurrent childhood craniopharyngioma depend on the type of treatment that was given when the tumor was first diagnosed and the needs of the child.<EOS>
<BOS>Treatment may include the following: Surgery (resection).<EOS>
<BOS>Externalbeam radiation therapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Stereotactic radiosurgery.<EOS>
<BOS>Intracavitary radiation therapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Intracavitary chemotherapy or intracavitary biologic therapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Intravenous biologic therapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Cyst drainage.<EOS>
<BOS>A clinical trial of biologic therapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Check the list of NCIsupported cancer clinical trials that are now accepting patients with childhood craniopharyngioma.<EOS>
<BOS>For more specific results, refine the search by using other search features, such as the location of the trial, the type of treatment, or the name of the drug.<EOS>
<BOS>Talk with your child's doctor about clinical trials that may be right for your child.<EOS>
<BOS>General information about clinical trials is available from the NCI website.<EOS>
<BOS>Key Points Childhood acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL) is a type of cancer in which the bone marrow makes too many immature lymphocytes (a type of white blood cell).<EOS>
<BOS>Leukemia may affect red blood cells, white blood cells, and platelets.<EOS>
<BOS>Past treatment for cancer and certain genetic conditions affect the risk of having childhood ALL.<EOS>
<BOS>Signs of childhood ALL include fever and bruising.<EOS>
<BOS>Tests that examine the blood and bone marrow are used to detect (find) and diagnose childhood ALL.<EOS>
<BOS>Certain factors affect prognosis (chance of recovery) and treatment options.<EOS>
<BOS>Childhood acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL) is a type of cancer in which the bone marrow makes too many immature lymphocytes (a type of white blood cell).<EOS>
<BOS>Childhood acute lymphoblastic leukemia (also called ALL or acute lymphocytic leukemia) is a cancer of the blood and bone marrow.<EOS>
<BOS>This type of cancer usually gets worse quickly if it is not treated.<EOS>
<BOS>ALL is the most common type of cancer in children.<EOS>
<BOS>Leukemia may affect red blood cells, white blood cells, and platelets.<EOS>
<BOS>In a healthy child, the bone marrow makes blood stem cells (immature cells) that become mature blood cells over time.<EOS>
<BOS>A blood stem cell may become a myeloid stem cell or a lymphoid stem cell.<EOS>
<BOS>A myeloid stem cell becomes one of three types of mature blood cells: Red blood cells that carry oxygen and other substances to all tissues of the body.<EOS>
<BOS>Platelets that form blood clots to stop bleeding.<EOS>
<BOS>White blood cells that fight infection and disease.<EOS>
<BOS>A lymphoid stem cell becomes a lymphoblast cell and then one of three types of lymphocytes (white blood cells): B lymphocytes that make antibodies to help fight infection.<EOS>
<BOS>T lymphocytes that help B lymphocytes make the antibodies that help fight infection.<EOS>
<BOS>Natural killer cells that attack cancer cells and viruses.<EOS>
<BOS>In a child with ALL, too many stem cells become lymphoblasts, B lymphocytes, or T lymphocytes.<EOS>
<BOS>The cells do not work like normal lymphocytes and are not able to fight infection very well.<EOS>
<BOS>These cells are cancer (leukemia) cells.<EOS>
<BOS>Also, as the number of leukemia cells increases in the blood and bone marrow, there is less room for healthy white blood cells, red blood cells, and platelets.<EOS>
<BOS>This may lead to infection, anemia, and easy bleeding.<EOS>
<BOS>This summary is about acute lymphoblastic leukemia in children, adolescents, and young adults.<EOS>
<BOS>See the following PDQ summaries for information about other types of leukemia: Childhood Acute Myeloid Leukemia/Other Myeloid Malignancies Treatment Adult Acute Lymphoblastic Leukemia Treatment Chronic Lymphocytic Leukemia Treatment Adult Acute Myeloid Leukemia Treatment Chronic Myelogenous Leukemia Treatment Hairy Cell Leukemia Treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Key Points After rectal cancer has been diagnosed, tests are done to find out if cancer cells have spread within the rectum or to other parts of the body.<EOS>
<BOS>There are three ways that cancer spreads in the body.<EOS>
<BOS>Cancer may spread from where it began to other parts of the body.<EOS>
<BOS>The following stages are used for rectal cancer: Stage 0 (Carcinoma in Situ) Stage I Stage II Stage III Stage IV After rectal cancer has been diagnosed, tests are done to find out if cancer cells have spread within the rectum or to other parts of the body.<EOS>
<BOS>The process used to find out whether cancer has spread within the rectum or to other parts of the body is called staging.<EOS>
<BOS>The information gathered from the staging process determines the stage of the disease.<EOS>
<BOS>It is important to know the stage in order to plan treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>The following tests and procedures may be used in the staging process: Chest xray : An xray of the organs and bones inside the chest.<EOS>
<BOS>An xray is a type of energy beam that can go through the body and onto film, making a picture of areas inside the body.<EOS>
<BOS>Colonoscopy : A procedure to look inside the rectum and colon for polyps (small pieces of bulging tissue).<EOS>
<BOS>abnormal areas, or cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>A colonoscope is a thin, tubelike instrument with a light and a lens for viewing.<EOS>
<BOS>It may also have a tool to remove polyps or tissue samples, which are checked under a microscope for signs of cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>CT scan (CAT scan): A procedure that makes a series of detailed pictures of areas inside the body, such as the abdomen, pelvis, or chest, taken from different angles.<EOS>
<BOS>The pictures are made by a computer linked to an xray machine.<EOS>
<BOS>A dye may be injected into a vein or swallowed to help the organs or tissues show up more clearly.<EOS>
<BOS>This procedure is also called computed tomography, computerized tomography, or computerized axial tomography.<EOS>
<BOS>MRI (magnetic resonance imaging): A procedure that uses a magnet, radio waves, and a computer to make a series of detailed pictures of areas inside the body.<EOS>
<BOS>This procedure is also called nuclear magnetic resonance imaging (NMRI).<EOS>
<BOS>PET scan (positron emission tomography scan): A procedure to find malignant tumor cells in the body.<EOS>
<BOS>A small amount of radioactive glucose (sugar) is injected into a vein.<EOS>
<BOS>The PET scanner rotates around the body and makes a picture of where glucose is being used in the body.<EOS>
<BOS>Malignant tumor cells show up brighter in the picture because they are more active and take up more glucose than normal cells do.<EOS>
<BOS>Endorectal ultrasound : A procedure used to examine the rectum and nearby organs.<EOS>
<BOS>An ultrasound transducer (probe) is inserted into the rectum and used to bounce highenergy sound waves (ultrasound) off internal tissues or organs and make echoes.<EOS>
<BOS>The echoes form a picture of body tissues called a sonogram.<EOS>
<BOS>The doctor can identify tumors by looking at the sonogram.<EOS>
<BOS>This procedure is also called transrectal ultrasound.<EOS>
<BOS>There are three ways that cancer spreads in the body.<EOS>
<BOS>Cancer can spread through tissue, the lymph system, and the blood: Tissue.<EOS>
<BOS>The cancer spreads from where it began by growing into nearby areas.<EOS>
<BOS>Lymph system.<EOS>
<BOS>The cancer spreads from where it began by getting into the lymph system.<EOS>
<BOS>The cancer travels through the lymph vessels to other parts of the body.<EOS>
<BOS>Blood.<EOS>
<BOS>The cancer spreads from where it began by getting into the blood.<EOS>
<BOS>The cancer travels through the blood vessels to other parts of the body.<EOS>
<BOS>Cancer may spread from where it began to other parts of the body.<EOS>
<BOS>When cancer spreads to another part of the body, it is called metastasis.<EOS>
<BOS>Cancer cells break away from where they began (the primary tumor) and travel through the lymph system or blood.<EOS>
<BOS>Lymph system.<EOS>
<BOS>The cancer gets into the lymph system, travels through the lymph vessels, and forms a tumor (metastatic tumor) in another part of the body.<EOS>
<BOS>Blood.<EOS>
<BOS>The cancer gets into the blood, travels through the blood vessels, and forms a tumor (metastatic tumor) in another part of the body.<EOS>
<BOS>The metastatic tumor is the same type of cancer as the primary tumor.<EOS>
<BOS>For example, if rectal cancer spreads to the lung, the cancer cells in the lung are actually rectal cancer cells.<EOS>
<BOS>The disease is metastatic rectal cancer, not lung cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>The following stages are used for rectal cancer: Stage 0 (Carcinoma in Situ) In stage 0, abnormal cells are found in the mucosa (innermost layer) of the rectum wall.<EOS>
<BOS>These abnormal cells may become cancer and spread.<EOS>
<BOS>Stage 0 is also called carcinoma in situ.<EOS>
<BOS>Stage I In stage I, cancer has formed in the mucosa (innermost layer) of the rectum wall and has spread to the submucosa (layer of tissue under the mucosa).<EOS>
<BOS>Cancer may have spread to the muscle layer of the rectum wall.<EOS>
<BOS>Stage II Stage II rectal cancer is divided into stage IIA, stage IIB, and stage IIC.<EOS>
<BOS>Stage IIA: Cancer has spread through the muscle layer of the rectum wall to the serosa (outermost layer) of the rectum wall.<EOS>
<BOS>Stage IIB: Cancer has spread through the serosa (outermost layer) of the rectum wall but has not spread to nearby organs.<EOS>
<BOS>Stage IIC: Cancer has spread through the serosa (outermost layer) of the rectum wall to nearby organs.<EOS>
<BOS>Stage III Stage III rectal cancer is divided into stage IIIA, stage IIIB, and stage IIIC.<EOS>
<BOS>In stage IIIA: Cancer has spread through the mucosa (innermost layer) of the rectum wall to the submucosa (layer of tissue under the mucosa) and may have spread to the muscle layer of the rectum wall.<EOS>
<BOS>Cancer has spread to at least one but not more than 3 nearby lymph nodes or cancer cells have formed in tissues near the lymph nodes; or Cancer has spread through the mucosa (innermost layer) of the rectum wall to the submucosa (layer of tissue under the mucosa).<EOS>
<BOS>Cancer has spread to at least 4 but not more than 6 nearby lymph nodes.<EOS>
<BOS>In stage IIIB: Cancer has spread through the muscle layer of the rectum wall to the serosa (outermost layer) of the rectum wall or has spread through the serosa but not to nearby organs.<EOS>
<BOS>Cancer has spread to at least one but not more than 3 nearby lymph nodes or cancer cells have formed in tissues near the lymph nodes; or Cancer has spread to the muscle layer of the rectum wall or to the serosa (outermost layer) of the rectum wall.<EOS>
<BOS>Cancer has spread to at least 4 but not more than 6 nearby lymph nodes; or Cancer has spread through the mucosa (innermost layer) of the rectum wall to the submucosa (layer of tissue under the mucosa) and may have spread to the muscle layer of the rectum wall.<EOS>
<BOS>Cancer has spread to 7 or more nearby lymph nodes.<EOS>
<BOS>In stage IIIC: Cancer has spread through the serosa (outermost layer) of the rectum wall but has not spread to nearby organs.<EOS>
<BOS>Cancer has spread to at least 4 but not more than 6 nearby lymph nodes; or Cancer has spread through the muscle layer of the rectum wall to the serosa (outermost layer) of the rectum wall or has spread through the serosa but has not spread to nearby organs.<EOS>
<BOS>Cancer has spread to 7 or more nearby lymph nodes; or Cancer has spread through the serosa (outermost layer) of the rectum wall and has spread to nearby organs.<EOS>
<BOS>Cancer has spread to one or more nearby lymph nodes or cancer cells have formed in tissues near the lymph nodes.<EOS>
<BOS>Stage IV Stage IV rectal cancer is divided into stage IVA and stage IVB.<EOS>
<BOS>Stage IVA: Cancer may have spread through the rectum wall and may have spread to nearby organs or lymph nodes.<EOS>
<BOS>Cancer has spread to one organ that is not near the rectum, such as the liver, lung, or ovary, or to a distant lymph node.<EOS>
<BOS>Stage IVB: Cancer may have spread through the rectum wall and may have spread to nearby organs or lymph nodes.<EOS>
<BOS>Cancer has spread to more than one organ that is not near the rectum or into the lining of the abdominal wall.<EOS>
<BOS>Key Points Primary central nervous system (CNS) lymphoma is a disease in which malignant (cancer) cells form in the lymph tissue of the brain and/or spinal cord.<EOS>
<BOS>Having a weakened immune system may increase the risk of developing primary CNS lymphoma.<EOS>
<BOS>Tests that examine the eyes, brain, and spinal cord are used to detect (find) and diagnose primary CNS lymphoma.<EOS>
<BOS>Certain factors affect prognosis (chance of recovery) and treatment options.<EOS>
<BOS>Primary central nervous system (CNS) lymphoma is a disease in which malignant (cancer) cells form in the lymph tissue of the brain and/or spinal cord.<EOS>
<BOS>Lymphoma is a disease in which malignant (cancer) cells form in the lymph system.<EOS>
<BOS>The lymph system is part of the immune system and is made up of the lymph, lymph vessels, lymph nodes, spleen, thymus, tonsils, and bone marrow.<EOS>
<BOS>Lymphocytes (carried in the lymph) travel in and out of the central nervous system (CNS).<EOS>
<BOS>It is thought that some of these lymphocytes become malignant and cause lymphoma to form in the CNS.<EOS>
<BOS>Primary CNS lymphoma can start in the brain, spinal cord, or meninges (the layers that form the outer covering of the brain).<EOS>
<BOS>Because the eye is so close to the brain, primary CNS lymphoma can also start in the eye (called ocular lymphoma).<EOS>
<BOS>Tests that examine the vulva are used to detect (find) and diagnose vulvar cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>The following tests and procedures may be used: Physical exam and history : An exam of the body to check general signs of health, including checking the vulva for signs of disease, such as lumps or anything else that seems unusual.<EOS>
<BOS>A history of the patients health habits and past illnesses and treatments will also be taken.<EOS>
<BOS>Biopsy : The removal of samples of cells or tissues from the vulva so they can be viewed under a microscope by a pathologist to check for signs of cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Cancer prevention clinical trials are used to study ways to prevent cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Cancer prevention clinical trials are used to study ways to lower the risk of developing certain types of cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Some cancer prevention trials are conducted with healthy people who have not had cancer but who have an increased risk for cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Other prevention trials are conducted with people who have had cancer and are trying to prevent another cancer of the same type or to lower their chance of developing a new type of cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Other trials are done with healthy volunteers who are not known to have any risk factors for cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>The purpose of some cancer prevention clinical trials is to find out whether actions people take can prevent cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>These may include eating fruits and vegetables, exercising, quitting smoking, or taking certain medicines, vitamins, minerals, or food supplements.<EOS>
<BOS>New ways to prevent skin cancer are being studied in clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>Clinical trials are taking place in many parts of the country.<EOS>
<BOS>Information about clinical trials can be found in the Clinical Trials section of the NCI Web site.<EOS>
<BOS>Check NCI's list of cancer clinical trials for nonmelanoma skin cancer prevention trials and melanoma prevention trials that are now accepting patients.<EOS>
<BOS>Key Points Ovarian epithelial cancer, fallopian tube cancer, and primary peritoneal cancer are diseases in which malignant (cancer) cells form in the tissue covering the ovary or lining the fallopian tube or peritoneum.<EOS>
<BOS>Ovarian epithelial cancer, fallopian tube cancer, and primary peritoneal cancer form in the same type of tissue and are treated the same way.<EOS>
<BOS>Women who have a family history of ovarian cancer are at an increased risk of ovarian cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Some ovarian, fallopian tube, and primary peritoneal cancers are caused by inherited gene mutations (changes).<EOS>
<BOS>Women with an increased risk of ovarian cancer may consider surgery to lessen the risk.<EOS>
<BOS>Signs and symptoms of ovarian, fallopian tube, or peritoneal cancer include pain or swelling in the abdomen.<EOS>
<BOS>Tests that examine the ovaries and pelvic area are used to detect (find) and diagnose ovarian, fallopian tube, and peritoneal cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Certain factors affect treatment options and prognosis (chance of recovery).<EOS>
<BOS>Ovarian epithelial cancer, fallopian tube cancer, and primary peritoneal cancer are diseases in which malignant (cancer) cells form in the tissue covering the ovary or lining the fallopian tube or peritoneum.<EOS>
<BOS>The ovaries are a pair of organs in the female reproductive system.<EOS>
<BOS>They are in the pelvis, one on each side of the uterus (the hollow, pearshaped organ where a fetus grows).<EOS>
<BOS>Each ovary is about the size and shape of an almond.<EOS>
<BOS>The ovaries make eggs and female hormones (chemicals that control the way certain cells or organs work).<EOS>
<BOS>The fallopian tubes are a pair of long, slender tubes, one on each side of the uterus.<EOS>
<BOS>Eggs pass from the ovaries, through the fallopian tubes, to the uterus.<EOS>
<BOS>Cancer sometimes begins at the end of the fallopian tube near the ovary and spreads to the ovary.<EOS>
<BOS>The peritoneum is the tissue that lines the abdominal wall and covers organs in the abdomen.<EOS>
<BOS>Primary peritoneal cancer is cancer that forms in the peritoneum and has not spread there from another part of the body.<EOS>
<BOS>Cancer sometimes begins in the peritoneum and spreads to the ovary.<EOS>
<BOS>Ovarian epithelial cancer is one type of cancer that affects the ovary.<EOS>
<BOS>See the following PDQ treatment summaries for information about other types of ovarian tumors: Ovarian Germ Cell Tumors Ovarian Low Malignant Potential Tumors Unusual Cancers of Childhood Treatment (ovarian cancer in children) Ovarian epithelial cancer, fallopian tube cancer, and primary peritoneal cancer form in the same type of tissue and are treated the same way.<EOS>
<BOS>New types of treatment are being tested in clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients may want to think about taking part in a clinical trial.<EOS>
<BOS>For some patients, taking part in a clinical trial may be the best treatment choice.<EOS>
<BOS>Clinical trials are part of the cancer research process.<EOS>
<BOS>Clinical trials are done to find out if new cancer treatments are safe and effective or better than the standard treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Many of today's standard treatments for cancer are based on earlier clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients who take part in a clinical trial may receive the standard treatment or be among the first to receive a new treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients who take part in clinical trials also help improve the way cancer will be treated in the future.<EOS>
<BOS>Even when clinical trials do not lead to effective new treatments, they often answer important questions and help move research forward.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients can enter clinical trials before, during, or after starting their cancer treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Some clinical trials only include patients who have not yet received treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Other trials test treatments for patients whose cancer has not gotten better.<EOS>
<BOS>There are also clinical trials that test new ways to stop cancer from recurring (coming back) or reduce the side effects of cancer treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Clinical trials are taking place in many parts of the country.<EOS>
<BOS>See the Treatment Options section that follows for links to current treatment clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>These have been retrieved from NCI's listing of clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>Breast exams should be part of prenatal and postnatal care.<EOS>
<BOS>To detect breast cancer, pregnant and nursing women should examine their breasts themselves.<EOS>
<BOS>Women should also receive clinical breast exams during their regular prenatal and postnatal checkups.<EOS>
<BOS>Talk to your doctor if you notice any changes in your breasts that you do not expect or that worry you.<EOS>
<BOS>Tests that examine the breasts are used to detect (find) and diagnose breast cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>The following tests and procedures may be used: Physical exam and history : An exam of the body to check general signs of health, including checking for signs of disease, such as lumps or anything else that seems unusual.<EOS>
<BOS>A history of the patients health habits and past illnesses and treatments will also be taken.<EOS>
<BOS>Clinical breast exam (CBE): An exam of the breast by a doctor or other health professional.<EOS>
<BOS>The doctor will carefully feel the breasts and under the arms for lumps or anything else that seems unusual.<EOS>
<BOS>MRI (magnetic resonance imaging): A procedure that uses a magnet, radio waves, and a computer to make a series of detailed pictures of both breasts.<EOS>
<BOS>This procedure is also called nuclear magnetic resonance imaging (NMRI).<EOS>
<BOS>Ultrasound exam: A procedure in which highenergy sound waves (ultrasound) are bounced off internal tissues or organs and make echoes.<EOS>
<BOS>The echoes form a picture of body tissues called a sonogram.<EOS>
<BOS>The picture can be printed to look at later.<EOS>
<BOS>Mammogram : An xray of the breast.<EOS>
<BOS>A mammogram can be done with little risk to the unborn baby.<EOS>
<BOS>Mammograms in pregnant women may appear negative even though cancer is present.<EOS>
<BOS>Blood chemistry studies : A procedure in which a blood sample is checked to measure the amounts of certain substances released into the blood by organs and tissues in the body.<EOS>
<BOS>An unusual (higher or lower than normal) amount of a substance can be a sign of disease.<EOS>
<BOS>Biopsy : The removal of cells or tissues so they can be viewed under a microscope by a pathologist to check for signs of cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>If a lump in the breast is found, a biopsy may be done.<EOS>
<BOS>There are four types of breast biopsies: Excisional biopsy : The removal of an entire lump of tissue.<EOS>
<BOS>Incisional biopsy : The removal of part of a lump or a sample of tissue.<EOS>
<BOS>Core biopsy : The removal of tissue using a wide needle.<EOS>
<BOS>Fineneedle aspiration (FNA) biopsy : The removal of tissue or fluid, using a thin needle.<EOS>
<BOS>If cancer is found, tests are done to study the cancer cells.<EOS>
<BOS>Decisions about the best treatment are based on the results of these tests and the age of the unborn baby.<EOS>
<BOS>The tests give information about: How quickly the cancer may grow.<EOS>
<BOS>How likely it is that the cancer will spread to other parts of the body.<EOS>
<BOS>How well certain treatments might work.<EOS>
<BOS>How likely the cancer is to recur (come back).<EOS>
<BOS>Tests may include the following: Estrogen and progesterone receptor test : A test to measure the amount of estrogen and progesterone (hormones) receptors in cancer tissue.<EOS>
<BOS>If there are more estrogen and progesterone receptors than normal, the cancer is called estrogen and/or progesterone receptor positive.<EOS>
<BOS>This type of breast cancer may grow more quickly.<EOS>
<BOS>The test results show whether treatment to block estrogen and progesterone given after the baby is born may stop the cancer from growing.<EOS>
<BOS>Human epidermal growth factor type 2 receptor (HER2/neu) test : A laboratory test to measure how many HER2/neu genes there are and how much HER2/neu protein is made in a sample of tissue.<EOS>
<BOS>If there are more HER2/neu genes or higher levels of HER2/neu protein than normal, the cancer is called HER2/neu positive.<EOS>
<BOS>This type of breast cancer may grow more quickly and is more likely to spread to other parts of the body.<EOS>
<BOS>The cancer may be treated with drugs that target the HER2/neu protein, such as trastuzumab and pertuzumab, after the baby is born.<EOS>
<BOS>Multigene tests: Tests in which samples of tissue are studied to look at the activity of many genes at the same time.<EOS>
<BOS>These tests may help predict whether cancer will spread to other parts of the body or recur (come back).<EOS>
<BOS>Oncotype DX : This test helps predict whether stage I or stage II breast cancer that is estrogen receptor positive and nodenegative will spread to other parts of the body.<EOS>
<BOS>If the risk of the cancer spreading is high, chemotherapy may be given to lower the risk.<EOS>
<BOS>MammaPrint : This test helps predict whether stage I or stage II breast cancer that is nodenegative will spread to other parts of the body.<EOS>
<BOS>If the risk of the cancer spreading is high, chemotherapy may be given to lower the risk.<EOS>
<BOS>Tests that examine the blood and bone marrow are used to detect (find) and diagnose myelodysplastic/myeloproliferative neoplasms.<EOS>
<BOS>The following tests and procedures may be used: Physical exam and history : An exam of the body to check general signs of health, including checking for signs of disease such as an enlarged spleen and liver.<EOS>
<BOS>A history of the patients health habits and past illnesses and treatments will also be taken.<EOS>
<BOS>Complete blood count (CBC) with differential : A procedure in which a sample of blood is drawn and checked for the following: The number of red blood cells and platelets.<EOS>
<BOS>The number and type of white blood cells.<EOS>
<BOS>The amount of hemoglobin (the protein that carries oxygen) in the red blood cells.<EOS>
<BOS>The portion of the sample made up of red blood cells.<EOS>
<BOS>Peripheral blood smear : A procedure in which a sample of blood is checked for blast cells, the number and kinds of white blood cells, the number of platelets, and changes in the shape of blood cells.<EOS>
<BOS>Blood chemistry studies : A procedure in which a blood sample is checked to measure the amounts of certain substances released into the blood by organs and tissues in the body.<EOS>
<BOS>An unusual (higher or lower than normal) amount of a substance can be a sign of disease.<EOS>
<BOS>Bone marrow aspiration and biopsy : The removal of a small piece of bone and bone marrow by inserting a needle into the hipbone or breastbone.<EOS>
<BOS>A pathologist views both the bone and bone marrow samples under a microscope to look for abnormal cells.<EOS>
<BOS>The following tests may be done on the sample of tissue that is removed: Cytogenetic analysis : A test in which cells in a sample of blood or bone marrow are viewed under a microscope to look for certain changes in the chromosomes.<EOS>
