<BOS>The cancer cells in myelodysplastic/myeloproliferative neoplasms do not contain the Philadelphia chromosome that is present in chronic myelogenous leukemia.<EOS>
<BOS>Immunocytochemistry : A test that uses antibodies to check for certain antigens in a sample of bone marrow.<EOS>
<BOS>The antibody is usually linked to a radioactive substance or a dye that causes the cells in the sample to light up under a microscope.<EOS>
<BOS>This type of test is used to tell the difference between myelodysplastic/myeloproliferative neoplasms, leukemia, and other conditions.<EOS>
<BOS>Key Points There are different types of treatment for patients with gestational trophoblastic disease.<EOS>
<BOS>Three types of standard treatment are used: Surgery Chemotherapy Radiation therapy New types of treatment are being tested in clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients may want to think about taking part in a clinical trial.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients can enter clinical trials before, during, or after starting their cancer treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Followup tests may be needed.<EOS>
<BOS>There are different types of treatment for patients with gestational trophoblastic disease.<EOS>
<BOS>Different types of treatment are available for patients with gestational trophoblastic disease.<EOS>
<BOS>Some treatments are standard (the currently used treatment), and some are being tested in clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>Before starting treatment, patients may want to think about taking part in a clinical trial.<EOS>
<BOS>A treatment clinical trial is a research study meant to help improve current treatments or obtain information on new treatments for patients with cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>When clinical trials show that a new treatment is better than the standard treatment, the new treatment may become the standard treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Clinical trials are taking place in many parts of the country.<EOS>
<BOS>Information about ongoing clinical trials is available from the NCI website.<EOS>
<BOS>Choosing the most appropriate cancer treatment is a decision that ideally involves the patient, family, and health care team.<EOS>
<BOS>Three types of standard treatment are used: Surgery The doctor may remove the cancer using one of the following operations: Dilatation and curettage (D&C) with suction evacuation: A surgical procedure to remove abnormal tissue and parts of the inner lining of the uterus.<EOS>
<BOS>The cervix is dilated and the material inside the uterus is removed with a small vacuumlike device.<EOS>
<BOS>The walls of the uterus are then gently scraped with a curette (spoonshaped instrument) to remove any material that may remain in the uterus.<EOS>
<BOS>This procedure may be used for molar pregnancies.<EOS>
<BOS>Hysterectomy: Surgery to remove the uterus, and sometimes the cervix.<EOS>
<BOS>If the uterus and cervix are taken out through the vagina, the operation is called a vaginal hysterectomy.<EOS>
<BOS>If the uterus and cervix are taken out through a large incision (cut) in the abdomen, the operation is called a total abdominal hysterectomy.<EOS>
<BOS>If the uterus and cervix are taken out through a small incision (cut) in the abdomen using a laparoscope, the operation is called a total laparoscopic hysterectomy.<EOS>
<BOS>Chemotherapy Chemotherapy is a cancer treatment that uses drugs to stop the growth of cancer cells, either by killing the cells or by stopping them from dividing.<EOS>
<BOS>When chemotherapy is taken by mouth or injected into a vein or muscle, the drugs enter the bloodstream and can reach cancer cells throughout the body (systemic chemotherapy).<EOS>
<BOS>When chemotherapy is placed directly into the cerebrospinal fluid, an organ, or a body cavity such as the abdomen, the drugs mainly affect cancer cells in those areas (regional chemotherapy).<EOS>
<BOS>The way the chemotherapy is given depends on the type and stage of the cancer being treated, or whether the tumor is lowrisk or highrisk.<EOS>
<BOS>Combination chemotherapy is treatment using more than one anticancer drug.<EOS>
<BOS>Even if the doctor removes all the cancer that can be seen at the time of the surgery, some patients may be given chemotherapy after surgery to kill any tumor cells that are left.<EOS>
<BOS>Treatment given after the surgery, to lower the risk that the cancer will come back, is called adjuvant therapy.<EOS>
<BOS>See Drugs Approved for Gestational Trophoblastic Disease for more information.<EOS>
<BOS>Radiation therapy Radiation therapy is a cancer treatment that uses highenergy xrays or other types of radiation to kill cancer cells or keep them from growing.<EOS>
<BOS>There are two types of radiation therapy: External radiation therapy uses a machine outside the body to send radiation toward the cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Internal radiation therapy uses a radioactive substance sealed in needles, seeds, wires, or catheters that are placed directly into or near the cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>The way the radiation therapy is given depends on the type of gestational trophoblastic disease being treated.<EOS>
<BOS>External radiation therapy is used to treat gestational trophoblastic disease.<EOS>
<BOS>New types of treatment are being tested in clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>Information about ongoing clinical trials is available from the NCI website.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients may want to think about taking part in a clinical trial.<EOS>
<BOS>For some patients, taking part in a clinical trial may be the best treatment choice.<EOS>
<BOS>Clinical trials are part of the cancer research process.<EOS>
<BOS>Clinical trials are done to find out if new cancer treatments are safe and effective or better than the standard treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Many of today's standard treatments for cancer are based on earlier clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients who take part in a clinical trial may receive the standard treatment or be among the first to receive a new treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients who take part in clinical trials also help improve the way cancer will be treated in the future.<EOS>
<BOS>Even when clinical trials do not lead to effective new treatments, they often answer important questions and help move research forward.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients can enter clinical trials before, during, or after starting their cancer treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Some clinical trials only include patients who have not yet received treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Other trials test treatments for patients whose cancer has not gotten better.<EOS>
<BOS>There are also clinical trials that test new ways to stop cancer from recurring (coming back) or reduce the side effects of cancer treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Clinical trials are taking place in many parts of the country.<EOS>
<BOS>See the Treatment Options section that follows for links to current treatment clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>These have been retrieved from NCI's listing of clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>Followup tests may be needed.<EOS>
<BOS>Some of the tests that were done to diagnose the cancer or to find out the stage of the cancer may be repeated.<EOS>
<BOS>Some tests will be repeated in order to see how well the treatment is working.<EOS>
<BOS>Decisions about whether to continue, change, or stop treatment may be based on the results of these tests.<EOS>
<BOS>Some of the tests will continue to be done from time to time after treatment has ended.<EOS>
<BOS>The results of these tests can show if your condition has changed or if the cancer has recurred (come back).<EOS>
<BOS>These tests are sometimes called followup tests or checkups.<EOS>
<BOS>Blood levels of beta human chorionic gonadotropin (hCG) will be checked for up to 6 months after treatment has ended.<EOS>
<BOS>This is because a hCG level that is higher than normal may mean that the tumor has not responded to treatment or it has become cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Treatment Options for Gestational Trophoblastic Disease Hydatidiform Moles Treatment of a hydatidiform mole may include the following: Surgery (Dilatation and curettage with suction evacuation) to remove the tumor.<EOS>
<BOS>After surgery, beta human chorionic gonadotropin (hCG) blood tests are done every week until the hCG level returns to normal.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients also have followup doctor visits monthly for up to 6 months.<EOS>
<BOS>If the level of hCG does not return to normal or increases, it may mean the hydatidiform mole was not completely removed and it has become cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Pregnancy causes hCG levels to increase, so your doctor will ask you not to become pregnant until followup is finished.<EOS>
<BOS>For disease that remains after surgery, treatment is usually chemotherapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Check the list of NCIsupported cancer clinical trials that are now accepting patients with hydatidiform mole.<EOS>
<BOS>For more specific results, refine the search by using other search features, such as the location of the trial, the type of treatment, or the name of the drug.<EOS>
<BOS>Talk with your doctor about clinical trials that may be right for you.<EOS>
<BOS>General information about clinical trials is available from the NCI website.<EOS>
<BOS>Gestational Trophoblastic Neoplasia Lowrisk Gestational Trophoblastic Neoplasia Treatment of lowrisk gestational trophoblastic neoplasia (GTN) (invasive mole or choriocarcinoma) may include the following: Chemotherapy with one or more anticancer drugs.<EOS>
<BOS>Treatment is given until the beta human chorionic gonadotropin (hCG) level is normal for at least 3 weeks after treatment ends.<EOS>
<BOS>If the level of hCG in the blood does not return to normal or the tumor spreads to distant parts of the body, chemotherapy regimens used for highrisk metastatic GTN are given.<EOS>
<BOS>Check the list of NCIsupported cancer clinical trials that are now accepting patients with low risk metastatic gestational trophoblastic tumor.<EOS>
<BOS>For more specific results, refine the search by using other search features, such as the location of the trial, the type of treatment, or the name of the drug.<EOS>
<BOS>Talk with your doctor about clinical trials that may be right for you.<EOS>
<BOS>General information about clinical trials is available from the NCI website.<EOS>
<BOS>Highrisk Metastatic Gestational Trophoblastic Neoplasia Treatment of highrisk metastatic gestational trophoblastic neoplasia (invasive mole or choriocarcinoma) may include the following: Combination chemotherapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Intrathecal chemotherapy and radiation therapy to the brain (for cancer that has spread to the lung, to keep it from spreading to the brain).<EOS>
<BOS>Highdose chemotherapy or intrathecal chemotherapy and/or radiation therapy to the brain (for cancer that has spread to the brain).<EOS>
<BOS>Check the list of NCIsupported cancer clinical trials that are now accepting patients with high risk metastatic gestational trophoblastic tumor.<EOS>
<BOS>For more specific results, refine the search by using other search features, such as the location of the trial, the type of treatment, or the name of the drug.<EOS>
<BOS>Talk with your doctor about clinical trials that may be right for you.<EOS>
<BOS>General information about clinical trials is available from the NCI website.<EOS>
<BOS>PlacentalSite Gestational Trophoblastic Tumors and Epithelioid Trophoblastic Tumors Treatment of stage I placentalsite gestational trophoblastic tumors and epithelioid trophoblastic tumors may include the following: Surgery to remove the uterus.<EOS>
<BOS>Treatment of stage II placentalsite gestational trophoblastic tumors and epithelioid trophoblastic tumors may include the following: Surgery to remove the tumor, which may be followed by combination chemotherapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Treatment of stage III and IV placentalsite gestational trophoblastic tumors and epithelioid trophoblastic tumors may include following: Combination chemotherapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Surgery to remove cancer that has spread to other places, such as the lung or abdomen.<EOS>
<BOS>Check the list of NCIsupported cancer clinical trials that are now accepting patients with placentalsite gestational trophoblastic tumor and epithelioid trophoblastic tumor.<EOS>
<BOS>For more specific results, refine the search by using other search features, such as the location of the trial, the type of treatment, or the name of the drug.<EOS>
<BOS>Talk with your doctor about clinical trials that may be right for you.<EOS>
<BOS>General information about clinical trials is available from the NCI website.<EOS>
<BOS>Recurrent or Resistant Gestational Trophoblastic Neoplasia Treatment of recurrent or resistant gestational trophoblastic tumor may include the following: Chemotherapy with one or more anticancer drugs for tumors previously treated with surgery.<EOS>
<BOS>Combination chemotherapy for tumors previously treated with chemotherapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Surgery for tumors that do not respond to chemotherapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Check the list of NCIsupported cancer clinical trials that are now accepting patients with recurrent gestational trophoblastic tumor.<EOS>
<BOS>For more specific results, refine the search by using other search features, such as the location of the trial, the type of treatment, or the name of the drug.<EOS>
<BOS>Talk with your doctor about clinical trials that may be right for you.<EOS>
<BOS>General information about clinical trials is available from the NCI website.<EOS>
<BOS>Key Points There are different types of treatment for patients with nasopharyngeal cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Three types of standard treatment are used: Radiation therapy Chemotherapy Surgery New types of treatment are being tested in clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients may want to think about taking part in a clinical trial.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients can enter clinical trials before, during, or after starting their cancer treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Followup tests may be needed.<EOS>
<BOS>There are different types of treatment for patients with nasopharyngeal cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Different types of treatment are available for patients with nasopharyngeal cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Some treatments are standard (the currently used treatment), and some are being tested in clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>A treatment clinical trial is a research study meant to help improve current treatments or obtain information on new treatments for patients with cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>When clinical trials show that a new treatment is better than the standard treatment, the new treatment may become the standard treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients may want to think about taking part in a clinical trial.<EOS>
<BOS>Some clinical trials are open only to patients who have not started treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Three types of standard treatment are used: Radiation therapy Radiation therapy is a cancer treatment that uses highenergy xrays or other types of radiation to kill cancer cells or keep them from growing.<EOS>
<BOS>There are two types of radiation therapy: External radiation therapy uses a machine outside the body to send radiation toward the cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Certain ways of giving radiation therapy can help keep radiation from damaging nearby healthy tissue.<EOS>
<BOS>These types of radiation therapy include the following: Intensitymodulated radiation therapy (IMRT): IMRT is a type of 3dimensional (3D) radiation therapy that uses a computer to make pictures of the size and shape of the tumor.<EOS>
<BOS>Thin beams of radiation of different intensities (strengths) are aimed at the tumor from many angles.<EOS>
<BOS>Compared to standard radiation therapy, intensitymodulated radiation therapy may be less likely to cause dry mouth.<EOS>
<BOS>Stereotactic radiation therapy: A rigid head frame is attached to the skull to keep the head still during the radiation treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>A machine aims radiation directly at the tumor.<EOS>
<BOS>The total dose of radiation is divided into several smaller doses given over several days.<EOS>
<BOS>This procedure is also called stereotactic externalbeam radiation therapy and stereotaxic radiation therapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Internal radiation therapy uses a radioactive substance sealed in needles, seeds, wires, or catheters that are placed directly into or near the cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>The way the radiation therapy is given depends on the type and stage of the cancer being treated.<EOS>
<BOS>External and internal radiation therapy are used to treat nasopharyngeal cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>External radiation therapy to the thyroid or the pituitary gland may change the way the thyroid gland works.<EOS>
<BOS>A blood test to check the thyroid hormone level in the blood is done before and after therapy to make sure the thyroid gland is working properly.<EOS>
<BOS>It is also important that a dentist check the patients teeth, gums, and mouth, and fix any existing problems before radiation therapy begins.<EOS>
<BOS>Chemotherapy Chemotherapy is a cancer treatment that uses drugs to stop the growth of cancer cells, either by killing the cells or by stopping them from dividing.<EOS>
<BOS>When chemotherapy is taken by mouth or injected into a vein or muscle, the drugs enter the bloodstream and can reach cancer cells throughout the body (systemic chemotherapy).<EOS>
<BOS>When chemotherapy is placed directly into the cerebrospinal fluid, an organ, or a body cavity such as the abdomen, the drugs mainly affect cancer cells in those areas (regional chemotherapy).<EOS>
<BOS>The way the chemotherapy is given depends on the type and stage of the cancer being treated.<EOS>
<BOS>Chemotherapy may be given after radiation therapy to kill any cancer cells that are left.<EOS>
<BOS>Treatment given after radiation therapy, to lower the risk that the cancer will come back, is called adjuvant therapy.<EOS>
<BOS>See Drugs Approved for Head and Neck Cancer for more information.<EOS>
<BOS>(Nasopharyngeal cancer is a type of head and neck cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>) Surgery Surgery is a procedure to find out whether cancer is present, to remove cancer from the body, or to repair a body part.<EOS>
<BOS>Also called an operation.<EOS>
<BOS>Surgery is sometimes used for nasopharyngeal cancer that does not respond to radiation therapy.<EOS>
<BOS>If cancer has spread to the lymph nodes, the doctor may remove lymph nodes and other tissues in the neck.<EOS>
<BOS>New types of treatment are being tested in clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>Information about clinical trials is available from the NCI website.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients may want to think about taking part in a clinical trial.<EOS>
<BOS>For some patients, taking part in a clinical trial may be the best treatment choice.<EOS>
<BOS>Clinical trials are part of the cancer research process.<EOS>
<BOS>Clinical trials are done to find out if new cancer treatments are safe and effective or better than the standard treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Many of today's standard treatments for cancer are based on earlier clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients who take part in a clinical trial may receive the standard treatment or be among the first to receive a new treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients who take part in clinical trials also help improve the way cancer will be treated in the future.<EOS>
<BOS>Even when clinical trials do not lead to effective new treatments, they often answer important questions and help move research forward.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients can enter clinical trials before, during, or after starting their cancer treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Some clinical trials only include patients who have not yet received treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Other trials test treatments for patients whose cancer has not gotten better.<EOS>
<BOS>There are also clinical trials that test new ways to stop cancer from recurring (coming back) or reduce the side effects of cancer treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Clinical trials are taking place in many parts of the country.<EOS>
<BOS>See the Treatment Options section that follows for links to current treatment clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>These have been retrieved from NCI's listing of clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>Followup tests may be needed.<EOS>
<BOS>Some of the tests that were done to diagnose the cancer or to find out the stage of the cancer may be repeated.<EOS>
<BOS>Some tests will be repeated in order to see how well the treatment is working.<EOS>
<BOS>Decisions about whether to continue, change, or stop treatment may be based on the results of these tests.<EOS>
<BOS>Some of the tests will continue to be done from time to time after treatment has ended.<EOS>
<BOS>The results of these tests can show if your condition has changed or if the cancer has recurred (come back).<EOS>
<BOS>These tests are sometimes called followup tests or checkups.<EOS>
<BOS>Treatment Options by Stage Stage I Nasopharyngeal Cancer Treatment of stage I nasopharyngeal cancer is usually radiation therapy to the tumor and lymph nodes in the neck.<EOS>
<BOS>Check the list of NCIsupported cancer clinical trials that are now accepting patients with stage I nasopharyngeal cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>For more specific results, refine the search by using other search features, such as the location of the trial, the type of treatment, or the name of the drug.<EOS>
<BOS>Talk with your doctor about clinical trials that may be right for you.<EOS>
<BOS>General information about clinical trials is available from the NCI website.<EOS>
<BOS>Stage II Nasopharyngeal Cancer Treatment of stage II nasopharyngeal cancer may include the following: Chemotherapy given with radiation therapy, followed by more chemotherapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Radiation therapy to the tumor and lymph nodes in the neck.<EOS>
<BOS>Check the list of NCIsupported cancer clinical trials that are now accepting patients with stage II nasopharyngeal cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>For more specific results, refine the search by using other search features, such as the location of the trial, the type of treatment, or the name of the drug.<EOS>
<BOS>Talk with your doctor about clinical trials that may be right for you.<EOS>
<BOS>General information about clinical trials is available from the NCI website.<EOS>
<BOS>Stage III Nasopharyngeal Cancer Treatment of stage III nasopharyngeal cancer may include the following: Chemotherapy given with radiation therapy, which may be followed by more chemotherapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Radiation therapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Radiation therapy followed by surgery to remove cancer containing lymph nodes in the neck that remain or come back after radiation therapy.<EOS>
<BOS>A clinical trial of chemotherapy given before, with, or after radiation therapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Check the list of NCIsupported cancer clinical trials that are now accepting patients with stage III nasopharyngeal cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>For more specific results, refine the search by using other search features, such as the location of the trial, the type of treatment, or the name of the drug.<EOS>
<BOS>Talk with your doctor about clinical trials that may be right for you.<EOS>
<BOS>General information about clinical trials is available from the NCI website.<EOS>
<BOS>Stage IV Nasopharyngeal Cancer Treatment of stage IV nasopharyngeal cancer may include the following: Chemotherapy given with radiation therapy, followed by more chemotherapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Radiation therapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Radiation therapy followed by surgery to remove cancer containing lymph nodes in the neck that remain or come back after radiation therapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Chemotherapy for cancer that has metastasized (spread) to other parts of the body.<EOS>
<BOS>A clinical trial of chemotherapy given before, with, or after radiation therapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Check the list of NCIsupported cancer clinical trials that are now accepting patients with stage IV nasopharyngeal cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>For more specific results, refine the search by using other search features, such as the location of the trial, the type of treatment, or the name of the drug.<EOS>
<BOS>Talk with your doctor about clinical trials that may be right for you.<EOS>
<BOS>General information about clinical trials is available from the NCI website.<EOS>
<BOS>Treatment of atypical chronic myelogenous leukemia (CML) may include chemotherapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Check the list of NCIsupported cancer clinical trials that are now accepting patients with atypical chronic myeloid leukemia, BCRABL1 negative.<EOS>
<BOS>For more specific results, refine the search by using other search features, such as the location of the trial, the type of treatment, or the name of the drug.<EOS>
<BOS>Talk with your doctor about clinical trials that may be right for you.<EOS>
<BOS>General information about clinical trials is available from the NCI website.<EOS>
<BOS>Key Points Myeloproliferative neoplasms are a group of diseases in which the bone marrow makes too many red blood cells, white blood cells, or platelets.<EOS>
<BOS>There are 6 types of chronic myeloproliferative neoplasms.<EOS>
<BOS>Tests that examine the blood and bone marrow are used to detect (find) and diagnose chronic myeloproliferative neoplasms.<EOS>
<BOS>Myeloproliferative neoplasms are a group of diseases in which the bone marrow makes too many red blood cells, white blood cells, or platelets.<EOS>
<BOS>Normally, the bone marrow makes blood stem cells (immature cells) that become mature blood cells over time.<EOS>
<BOS>A blood stem cell may become a myeloid stem cell or a lymphoid stem cell.<EOS>
<BOS>A lymphoid stem cell becomes a white blood cell.<EOS>
<BOS>A myeloid stem cell becomes one of three types of mature blood cells: Red blood cells that carry oxygen and other substances to all tissues of the body.<EOS>
<BOS>White blood cells that fight infection and disease.<EOS>
<BOS>Platelets that form blood clots to stop bleeding.<EOS>
<BOS>In myeloproliferative neoplasms, too many blood stem cells become one or more types of blood cells.<EOS>
<BOS>The neoplasms usually get worse slowly as the number of extra blood cells increases.<EOS>
<BOS>There are 6 types of chronic myeloproliferative neoplasms.<EOS>
<BOS>The type of myeloproliferative neoplasm is based on whether too many red blood cells, white blood cells, or platelets are being made.<EOS>
<BOS>Sometimes the body will make too many of more than one type of blood cell, but usually one type of blood cell is affected more than the others are.<EOS>
<BOS>Chronic myeloproliferative neoplasms include the following 6 types: Chronic myelogenous leukemia.<EOS>
<BOS>Polycythemia vera.<EOS>
<BOS>Primary myelofibrosis (also called chronic idiopathic myelofibrosis).<EOS>
<BOS>Essential thrombocythemia.<EOS>
<BOS>Chronic neutrophilic leukemia.<EOS>
<BOS>Chronic eosinophilic leukemia.<EOS>
<BOS>These types are described below.<EOS>
<BOS>Chronic myeloproliferative neoplasms sometimes become acute leukemia, in which too many abnormal white blood cells are made.<EOS>
<BOS>Tests that examine the brain and spinal cord are used to detect (find) childhood astrocytomas.<EOS>
<BOS>The following tests and procedures may be used: Physical exam and history : An exam of the body to check general signs of health.<EOS>
<BOS>This includes checking for signs of disease, such as lumps or anything else that seems unusual.<EOS>
<BOS>A history of the patients health habits and past illnesses and treatments will also be taken.<EOS>
<BOS>Neurological exam : A series of questions and tests to check the brain, spinal cord, and nerve function.<EOS>
<BOS>The exam checks a persons mental status, coordination, and ability to walk normally, and how well the muscles, senses, and reflexes work.<EOS>
<BOS>This may also be called a neuro exam or a neurologic exam.<EOS>
<BOS>Visual field exam: An exam to check a persons field of vision (the total area in which objects can be seen).<EOS>
<BOS>This test measures both central vision (how much a person can see when looking straight ahead) and peripheral vision (how much a person can see in all other directions while staring straight ahead).<EOS>
<BOS>The eyes are tested one at a time.<EOS>
<BOS>The eye not being tested is covered.<EOS>
<BOS>MRI (magnetic resonance imaging) with gadolinium : A procedure that uses a magnet, radio waves, and a computer to make a series of detailed pictures of the brain and spinal cord.<EOS>
<BOS>A substance called gadolinium is injected into a vein.<EOS>
<BOS>The gadolinium collects around the cancer cells so they show up brighter in the picture.<EOS>
<BOS>This procedure is also called nuclear magnetic resonance imaging (NMRI).<EOS>
<BOS>Sometimes magnetic resonance spectroscopy (MRS) is done during the same MRI scan to look at the chemical makeup of the brain tissue.<EOS>
<BOS>Childhood astrocytomas are usually diagnosed and removed in surgery.<EOS>
<BOS>If doctors think there may be an astrocytoma, a biopsy may be done to remove a sample of tissue.<EOS>
<BOS>For tumors in the brain, a part of the skull is removed and a needle is used to remove tissue.<EOS>
<BOS>Sometimes, the needle is guided by a computer.<EOS>
<BOS>A pathologist views the tissue under a microscope to look for cancer cells.<EOS>
<BOS>If cancer cells are found, the doctor may remove as much tumor as safely possible during the same surgery.<EOS>
<BOS>Because it can be hard to tell the difference between types of brain tumors, you may want to have your child's tissue sample checked by a pathologist who has experience in diagnosing brain tumors.<EOS>
<BOS>The following test may be done on the tissue that was removed: Immunohistochemistry : A test that uses antibodies to check for certain antigens in a sample of tissue.<EOS>
<BOS>The antibody is usually linked to a radioactive substance or a dye that causes the tissue to light up under a microscope.<EOS>
<BOS>This type of test may be used to tell the difference between different types of cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>An MIB1 test is a type of immunohistochemistry that checks tumor tissue for an antigen called MIB1.<EOS>
<BOS>This may show how fast a tumor is growing.<EOS>
<BOS>Sometimes tumors form in a place that makes them hard to remove.<EOS>
<BOS>If removing the tumor may cause severe physical, emotional, or learning problems, a biopsy is done and more treatment is given after the biopsy.<EOS>
<BOS>Children who have NF1 may form a lowgrade astrocytoma in the area of the brain that controls vision and may not need a biopsy.<EOS>
<BOS>If the tumor does not continue to grow or symptoms do not occur, surgery to remove the tumor may not be needed.<EOS>
<BOS>Key Points After vulvar cancer has been diagnosed, tests are done to find out if cancer cells have spread within the vulva or to other parts of the body.<EOS>
<BOS>There are three ways that cancer spreads in the body.<EOS>
<BOS>Cancer may spread from where it began to other parts of the body.<EOS>
<BOS>In vulvar intraepithelial neoplasia (VIN), abnormal cells are found on the surface of the vulvar skin.<EOS>
<BOS>The following stages are used for vulvar cancer: Stage I Stage II Stage III Stage IV After vulvar cancer has been diagnosed, tests are done to find out if cancer cells have spread within the vulva or to other parts of the body.<EOS>
<BOS>The process used to find out if cancer has spread within the vulva or to other parts of the body is called staging.<EOS>
<BOS>The information gathered from the staging process determines the stage of the disease.<EOS>
<BOS>It is important to know the stage in order to plan treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>The following tests and procedures may be used in the staging process: Pelvic exam : An exam of the vagina, cervix, uterus, fallopian tubes, ovaries, and rectum.<EOS>
<BOS>A speculum is inserted into the vagina and the doctor or nurse looks at the vagina and cervix for signs of disease.<EOS>
<BOS>A Pap test of the cervix is usually done.<EOS>
<BOS>The doctor or nurse also inserts one or two lubricated, gloved fingers of one hand into the vagina and places the other hand over the lower abdomen to feel the size, shape, and position of the uterus and ovaries.<EOS>
<BOS>The doctor or nurse also inserts a lubricated, gloved finger into the rectum to feel for lumps or abnormal areas.<EOS>
<BOS>Colposcopy : A procedure in which a colposcope (a lighted, magnifying instrument) is used to check the vagina and cervix for abnormal areas.<EOS>
<BOS>Tissue samples may be taken using a curette (spoonshaped instrument) or a brush and checked under a microscope for signs of disease.<EOS>
<BOS>Cystoscopy : A procedure to look inside the bladder and urethra to check for abnormal areas.<EOS>
<BOS>A cystoscope is inserted through the urethra into the bladder.<EOS>
<BOS>A cystoscope is a thin, tubelike instrument with a light and a lens for viewing.<EOS>
<BOS>It may also have a tool to remove tissue samples, which are checked under a microscope for signs of cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Proctoscopy : A procedure to look inside the rectum and anus to check for abnormal areas.<EOS>
<BOS>A proctoscope is inserted into the anus and rectum.<EOS>
<BOS>A proctoscope is a thin, tubelike instrument with a light and a lens for viewing.<EOS>
<BOS>It may also have a tool to remove tissue samples, which are checked under a microscope for signs of cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Xrays : An xray is a type of energy beam that can go through the body and onto film, making a picture of areas inside the body.<EOS>
<BOS>To stage vulvar cancer, xrays may be taken of the organs and bones inside the chest, and the pelvic bones.<EOS>
<BOS>Intravenous pyelogram (IVP): A series of xrays of the kidneys, ureters, and bladder to find out if cancer has spread to these organs.<EOS>
<BOS>A contrast dye is injected into a vein.<EOS>
<BOS>As the contrast dye moves through the kidneys, ureters and bladder, xrays are taken to see if there are any blockages.<EOS>
<BOS>This procedure is also called intravenous urography.<EOS>
<BOS>CT scan (CAT scan): A procedure that makes a series of detailed pictures of areas inside the body, taken from different angles.<EOS>
<BOS>The pictures are made by a computer linked to an xray machine.<EOS>
<BOS>A dye may be injected into a vein or swallowed to help the organs or tissues show up more clearly.<EOS>
<BOS>This procedure is also called computed tomography, computerized tomography, or computerized axial tomography.<EOS>
<BOS>MRI (magnetic resonance imaging): A procedure that uses a magnet, radio waves, and a computer to make a series of detailed pictures of areas inside the body.<EOS>
<BOS>This procedure is also called nuclear magnetic resonance imaging (NMRI).<EOS>
<BOS>PET scan (positron emission tomography scan): A procedure to find malignant tumor cells in the body.<EOS>
<BOS>A small amount of radioactive glucose (sugar) is injected into a vein.<EOS>
<BOS>The PET scanner rotates around the body and makes a picture of where glucose is being used in the body.<EOS>
<BOS>Malignant tumor cells show up brighter in the picture because they are more active and take up more glucose than normal cells do.<EOS>
<BOS>Sentinel lymph node biopsy : The removal of the sentinel lymph node during surgery.<EOS>
<BOS>The sentinel lymph node is the first lymph node to receive lymphatic drainage from a tumor.<EOS>
<BOS>It is the first lymph node the cancer is likely to spread to from the tumor.<EOS>
<BOS>A radioactive substance and/or blue dye is injected near the tumor.<EOS>
<BOS>The substance or dye flows through the lymph ducts to the lymph nodes.<EOS>
<BOS>The first lymph node to receive the substance or dye is removed.<EOS>
<BOS>A pathologist views the tissue under a microscope to look for cancer cells.<EOS>
<BOS>If cancer cells are not found, it may not be necessary to remove more lymph nodes.<EOS>
<BOS>Sentinel lymph node biopsy may be done during surgery to remove the tumor for earlystage vulvar cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>There are three ways that cancer spreads in the body.<EOS>
<BOS>Cancer can spread through tissue, the lymph system, and the blood: Tissue.<EOS>
<BOS>The cancer spreads from where it began by growing into nearby areas.<EOS>
<BOS>Lymph system.<EOS>
<BOS>The cancer spreads from where it began by getting into the lymph system.<EOS>
<BOS>The cancer travels through the lymph vessels to other parts of the body.<EOS>
<BOS>Blood.<EOS>
<BOS>The cancer spreads from where it began by getting into the blood.<EOS>
<BOS>The cancer travels through the blood vessels to other parts of the body.<EOS>
<BOS>Cancer may spread from where it began to other parts of the body.<EOS>
<BOS>When cancer spreads to another part of the body, it is called metastasis.<EOS>
<BOS>Cancer cells break away from where they began (the primary tumor) and travel through the lymph system or blood.<EOS>
<BOS>Lymph system.<EOS>
<BOS>The cancer gets into the lymph system, travels through the lymph vessels, and forms a tumor (metastatic tumor) in another part of the body.<EOS>
<BOS>Blood.<EOS>
<BOS>The cancer gets into the blood, travels through the blood vessels, and forms a tumor (metastatic tumor) in another part of the body.<EOS>
<BOS>The metastatic tumor is the same type of cancer as the primary tumor.<EOS>
<BOS>For example, if vulvar cancer spreads to the lung, the cancer cells in the lung are actually vulvar cancer cells.<EOS>
<BOS>The disease is metastatic vulvar cancer, not lung cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>In vulvar intraepithelial neoplasia (VIN), abnormal cells are found on the surface of the vulvar skin.<EOS>
<BOS>These abnormal cells are not cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Vulvar intraepithelial neoplasia (VIN) may become cancer and spread into nearby tissue.<EOS>
<BOS>VIN is sometimes called stage 0 or carcinoma in situ.<EOS>
<BOS>The following stages are used for vulvar cancer: Stage I In stage I, cancer has formed.<EOS>
<BOS>The tumor is found only in the vulva or perineum (area between the rectum and the vagina).<EOS>
<BOS>Stage I is divided into stages IA and IB.<EOS>
<BOS>In stage IA, the tumor is 2 centimeters or smaller and has spread 1 millimeter or less into the tissue of the vulva.<EOS>
<BOS>Cancer has not spread to the lymph nodes.<EOS>
<BOS>In stage IB, the tumor is larger than 2 centimeters or has spread more than 1 millimeter into the tissue of the vulva.<EOS>
<BOS>Cancer has not spread to the lymph nodes.<EOS>
<BOS>Stage II In stage II, the tumor is any size and has spread into the lower part of the urethra, the lower part of the vagina, or the anus.<EOS>
<BOS>Cancer has not spread to the lymph nodes.<EOS>
<BOS>Stage III In stage III, the tumor is any size and may have spread into the lower part of the urethra, the lower part of the vagina, or the anus.<EOS>
<BOS>Cancer has spread to one or more nearby lymph nodes.<EOS>
<BOS>Stage III is divided into stages IIIA, IIIB, and IIIC.<EOS>
<BOS>In stage IIIA, cancer is found in 1 or 2 lymph nodes that are smaller than 5 millimeters or in one lymph node that is 5 millimeters or larger.<EOS>
<BOS>In stage IIIB, cancer is found in 2 or more lymph nodes that are 5 millimeters or larger, or in 3 or more lymph nodes that are smaller than 5 millimeters.<EOS>
<BOS>In stage IIIC, cancer is found in lymph nodes and has spread to the outside surface of the lymph nodes.<EOS>
<BOS>Stage IV In stage IV, the tumor has spread into the upper part of the urethra, the upper part of the vagina, or to other parts of the body.<EOS>
<BOS>Stage IV is divided into stages IVA and IVB.<EOS>
<BOS>In stage IVA: cancer has spread into the lining of the upper urethra, the upper vagina, the bladder, or the rectum, or has attached to the pelvic bone; or cancer has spread to nearby lymph nodes and the lymph nodes are not moveable or have formed an ulcer.<EOS>
<BOS>In stage IVB, cancer has spread to lymph nodes in the pelvis or to other parts of the body.<EOS>
<BOS>Certain factors affect prognosis (chance of recovery) and treatment options for primary myelofibrosis.<EOS>
<BOS>Prognosis (chance of recovery) depends on the following: The age of the patient.<EOS>
<BOS>The number of abnormal red blood cells and white blood cells.<EOS>
<BOS>The number of blasts in the blood.<EOS>
<BOS>Whether there are certain changes in the chromosomes.<EOS>
<BOS>Whether the patient has signs such as fever, night sweats, or weight loss.<EOS>
<BOS>Treatment of chronic neutrophilic leukemia may include the following: Donor bone marrow transplant.<EOS>
<BOS>Chemotherapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Biologic therapy using interferon alfa.<EOS>
<BOS>A clinical trial of a new treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Check the list of NCIsupported cancer clinical trials that are now accepting patients with chronic neutrophilic leukemia.<EOS>
<BOS>For more specific results, refine the search by using other search features, such as the location of the trial, the type of treatment, or the name of the drug.<EOS>
<BOS>Talk with your doctor about clinical trials that may be right for you.<EOS>
<BOS>General information about clinical trials is available from the NCI website.<EOS>
<BOS>Tests that examine the liver and the blood are used to detect (find) and diagnose childhood liver cancer and find out whether the cancer has spread.<EOS>
<BOS>The following tests and procedures may be used: Physical exam and history : An exam of the body to check general signs of health, including checking for signs of disease, such as lumps or anything else that seems unusual.<EOS>
<BOS>A history of the patient's health habits and past illnesses and treatments will also be taken.<EOS>
<BOS>Serum tumor marker test : A procedure in which a blood sample is checked to measure the amounts of certain substances released into the blood by organs, tissues, or tumor cells in the body.<EOS>
<BOS>Certain substances are linked to specific types of cancer when found in increased levels in the blood.<EOS>
<BOS>These are called tumor markers.<EOS>
<BOS>The blood of children who have liver cancer may have increased amounts of a hormone called betahuman chorionic gonadotropin (hCG) or a protein called alphafetoprotein (AFP).<EOS>
<BOS>Other cancers and certain noncancer conditions, including cirrhosis and hepatitis, can also increase AFP levels.<EOS>
<BOS>Complete blood count (CBC): A procedure in which a sample of blood is drawn and checked for the following: The number of red blood cells, white blood cells, and platelets.<EOS>
<BOS>The amount of hemoglobin (the protein that carries oxygen) in the red blood cells.<EOS>
<BOS>The portion of the blood sample made up of red blood cells.<EOS>
<BOS>Liver function tests : A procedure in which a blood sample is checked to measure the amounts of certain substances released into the blood by the liver.<EOS>
<BOS>A higher than normal amount of a substance can be a sign of liver damage or cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Blood chemistry studies : A procedure in which a blood sample is checked to measure the amounts of certain substances, such as bilirubin or lactate dehydrogenase (LDH), released into the blood by organs and tissues in the body.<EOS>
<BOS>An unusual (higher or lower than normal) amount of a substance can be a sign of disease.<EOS>
<BOS>EpsteinBarr virus (EBV) test: A blood test to check for antibodies to the EBV and DNA markers of the EBV.<EOS>
<BOS>These are found in the blood of patients who have been infected with EBV.<EOS>
<BOS>Hepatitis assay : A procedure in which a blood sample is checked for pieces of the hepatitis virus.<EOS>
<BOS>MRI (magnetic resonance imaging) with gadolinium : A procedure that uses a magnet, radio waves, and a computer to make a series of detailed pictures of areas inside the liver.<EOS>
<BOS>A substance called gadolinium is injected into a vein.<EOS>
<BOS>The gadolinium collects around the cancer cells so they show up brighter in the picture.<EOS>
<BOS>This procedure is also called nuclear magnetic resonance imaging (NMRI).<EOS>
<BOS>Ultrasound exam: A procedure in which highenergy sound waves (ultrasound) are bounced off internal tissues or organs and make echoes.<EOS>
<BOS>The echoes form a picture of body tissues called a sonogram.<EOS>
<BOS>The picture can be printed to be looked at later.<EOS>
<BOS>In childhood liver cancer, an ultrasound exam of the abdomen to check the large blood vessels is usually done.<EOS>
<BOS>CT scan (CAT scan): A procedure that makes a series of detailed pictures of areas inside the body, taken from different angles.<EOS>
<BOS>The pictures are made by a computer linked to an xray machine.<EOS>
<BOS>A dye may be injected into a vein or swallowed to help the organs or tissues show up more clearly.<EOS>
<BOS>This procedure is also called computed tomography, computerized tomography, or computerized axial tomography.<EOS>
<BOS>In childhood liver cancer, a CT scan of the chest and abdomen is usually done.<EOS>
<BOS>Abdominal xray : An xray of the organs in the abdomen.<EOS>
<BOS>An xray is a type of energy beam that can go through the body onto film, making a picture of areas inside the body.<EOS>
<BOS>Biopsy : The removal of a sample of cells or tissues so it can be viewed under a microscope to check for signs of cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>The sample may be taken during surgery to remove or view the tumor.<EOS>
<BOS>A pathologist looks at the sample under a microscope to find out the type of liver cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>The following test may be done on the sample of tissue that is removed: Immunohistochemistry : A test that uses antibodies to check for certain antigens in a sample of tissue.<EOS>
<BOS>The antibody is usually linked to a radioactive substance or a dye that causes the tissue to light up under a microscope.<EOS>
<BOS>This type of test is used to check for a certain gene mutation and to tell the difference between different types of cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Key Points Rectal cancer is a disease in which malignant (cancer) cells form in the tissues of the rectum.<EOS>
<BOS>Health history affects the risk of developing rectal cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Signs of rectal cancer include a change in bowel habits or blood in the stool.<EOS>
<BOS>Tests that examine the rectum and colon are used to detect (find) and diagnose rectal cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Certain factors affect prognosis (chance of recovery) and treatment options.<EOS>
<BOS>Rectal cancer is a disease in which malignant (cancer) cells form in the tissues of the rectum.<EOS>
<BOS>The rectum is part of the bodys digestive system.<EOS>
<BOS>The digestive system takes in nutrients (vitamins, minerals, carbohydrates, fats, proteins, and water) from foods and helps pass waste material out of the body.<EOS>
<BOS>The digestive system is made up of the esophagus, stomach, and the small and large intestines.<EOS>
<BOS>The colon (large bowel) is the first part of the large intestine and is about 5 feet long.<EOS>
<BOS>Together, the rectum and anal canal make up the last part of the large intestine and are 68 inches long.<EOS>
<BOS>The anal canal ends at the anus (the opening of the large intestine to the outside of the body).<EOS>
<BOS>See the following PDQ summaries for more information about rectal cancer: Unusual Cancers of Childhood Treatment (see Colorectal Cancer section) Colorectal Cancer Prevention Colorectal Cancer Screening Gastrointestinal Stromal Tumors Treatment Genetics of Colorectal Cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Being older and having fair skin may increase the risk of intraocular melanoma.<EOS>
<BOS>Anything that increases your risk of getting a disease is called a risk factor.<EOS>
<BOS>Having a risk factor does not mean that you will get cancer; not having risk factors doesnt mean that you will not get cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Talk with your doctor if you think you may be at risk.<EOS>
<BOS>Risk factors for intraocular melanoma include the following: Having a fair complexion, which includes the following: Fair skin that freckles and burns easily, does not tan, or tans poorly.<EOS>
<BOS>Blue or green or other lightcolored eyes.<EOS>
<BOS>Older age.<EOS>
<BOS>Being white.<EOS>
<BOS>Key Points After melanoma has been diagnosed, tests are done to find out if cancer cells have spread within the skin or to other parts of the body.<EOS>
<BOS>There are three ways that cancer spreads in the body.<EOS>
<BOS>Cancer may spread from where it began to other parts of the body.<EOS>
<BOS>The method used to stage melanoma is based mainly on the thickness of the tumor and whether cancer has spread to lymph nodes or other parts of the body.<EOS>
<BOS>The following stages are used for melanoma: Stage 0 (Melanoma in Situ) Stage I Stage II Stage III Stage IV After melanoma has been diagnosed, tests are done to find out if cancer cells have spread within the skin or to other parts of the body.<EOS>
<BOS>The process used to find out whether cancer has spread within the skin or to other parts of the body is called staging.<EOS>
<BOS>The information gathered from the staging process determines the stage of the disease.<EOS>
<BOS>It is important to know the stage in order to plan treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>The following tests and procedures may be used in the staging process: Physical exam and history : An exam of the body to check general signs of health, including checking for signs of disease, such as lumps or anything else that seems unusual.<EOS>
<BOS>A history of the patients health habits and past illnesses and treatments will also be taken.<EOS>
<BOS>Lymph node mapping and sentinel lymph node biopsy : Procedures in which a radioactive substance and/or blue dye is injected near the tumor.<EOS>
<BOS>The substance or dye flows through lymph ducts to the sentinel node or nodes (the first lymph node or nodes where cancer cells are likely to spread).<EOS>
<BOS>The surgeon removes only the nodes with the radioactive substance or dye.<EOS>
<BOS>A pathologist views a sample of tissue under a microscope to check for cancer cells.<EOS>
<BOS>If no cancer cells are found, it may not be necessary to remove more nodes.<EOS>
<BOS>CT scan (CAT scan): A procedure that makes a series of detailed pictures of areas inside the body taken from different angles.<EOS>
<BOS>The pictures are made by a computer linked to an xray machine.<EOS>
<BOS>A dye may be injected into a vein or swallowed to help the organs or tissues show up more clearly.<EOS>
<BOS>This procedure is also called computed tomography, computerized tomography, or computerized axial tomography.<EOS>
<BOS>For melanoma, pictures may be taken of the chest, abdomen, and pelvis.<EOS>
<BOS>PET scan (positron emission tomography scan): A procedure to find malignant tumor cells in the body.<EOS>
<BOS>A small amount of radioactive glucose (sugar) is injected into a vein.<EOS>
<BOS>The PET scanner rotates around the body and makes a picture of where glucose is being used in the body.<EOS>
<BOS>Malignant tumor cells show up brighter in the picture because they are more active and take up more glucose than normal cells do.<EOS>
<BOS>MRI (magnetic resonance imaging) with gadolinium : A procedure that uses a magnet, radio waves, and a computer to make a series of detailed pictures of areas inside the body, such as the brain.<EOS>
<BOS>A substance called gadolinium is injected into a vein.<EOS>
<BOS>The gadolinium collects around the cancer cells so they show up brighter in the picture.<EOS>
<BOS>This procedure is also called nuclear magnetic resonance imaging (NMRI).<EOS>
<BOS>Blood chemistry studies : A procedure in which a blood sample is checked to measure the amounts of certain substances released into the blood by organs and tissues in the body.<EOS>
<BOS>For melanoma, the blood is checked for an enzyme called lactate dehydrogenase (LDH).<EOS>
<BOS>LDH levels that are higher than normal may be a sign of melanoma.<EOS>
<BOS>The results of these tests are viewed together with the results of the tumor biopsy to find out the stage of the melanoma.<EOS>
<BOS>There are three ways that cancer spreads in the body.<EOS>
<BOS>Cancer can spread through tissue, the lymph system, and the blood: Tissue.<EOS>
<BOS>The cancer spreads from where it began by growing into nearby areas.<EOS>
<BOS>Lymph system.<EOS>
<BOS>The cancer spreads from where it began by getting into the lymph system.<EOS>
<BOS>The cancer travels through the lymph vessels to other parts of the body.<EOS>
<BOS>Blood.<EOS>
<BOS>The cancer spreads from where it began by getting into the blood.<EOS>
<BOS>The cancer travels through the blood vessels to other parts of the body.<EOS>
<BOS>Cancer may spread from where it began to other parts of the body.<EOS>
<BOS>When cancer spreads to another part of the body, it is called metastasis.<EOS>
<BOS>Cancer cells break away from where they began (the primary tumor) and travel through the lymph system or blood.<EOS>
<BOS>Lymph system.<EOS>
<BOS>The cancer gets into the lymph system, travels through the lymph vessels, and forms a tumor (metastatic tumor) in another part of the body.<EOS>
<BOS>Blood.<EOS>
<BOS>The cancer gets into the blood, travels through the blood vessels, and forms a tumor (metastatic tumor) in another part of the body.<EOS>
<BOS>The metastatic tumor is the same type of cancer as the primary tumor.<EOS>
<BOS>For example, if melanoma spreads to the lung, the cancer cells in the lung are actually melanoma cells.<EOS>
<BOS>The disease is metastatic melanoma, not lung cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>The method used to stage melanoma is based mainly on the thickness of the tumor and whether cancer has spread to lymph nodes or other parts of the body.<EOS>
<BOS>The staging of melanoma depends on the following: The thickness of the tumor.<EOS>
<BOS>The thickness is described using the Breslow scale.<EOS>
<BOS>Whether the tumor is ulcerated (has broken through the skin).<EOS>
<BOS>Whether the tumor has spread to the lymph nodes and if the lymph nodes are joined together (matted).<EOS>
<BOS>Whether the tumor has spread to other parts of the body.<EOS>
<BOS>The following stages are used for melanoma: Stage 0 (Melanoma in Situ) In stage 0, abnormal melanocytes are found in the epidermis.<EOS>
<BOS>These abnormal melanocytes may become cancer and spread into nearby normal tissue.<EOS>
<BOS>Stage 0 is also called melanoma in situ.<EOS>
<BOS>Stage I In stage I, cancer has formed.<EOS>
<BOS>Stage I is divided into stages IA and IB.<EOS>
<BOS>Stage IA: In stage IA, the tumor is not more than 1 millimeter thick, with no ulceration.<EOS>
<BOS>Stage IB: In stage IB, the tumor is either: not more than 1 millimeter thick and it has ulceration; or more than 1 but not more than 2 millimeters thick, with no ulceration.<EOS>
<BOS>Stage II Stage II is divided into stages IIA, IIB, and IIC.<EOS>
<BOS>Stage IIA: In stage IIA, the tumor is either: more than 1 but not more than 2 millimeters thick, with ulceration; or more than 2 but not more than 4 millimeters thick, with no ulceration.<EOS>
<BOS>Stage IIB: In stage IIB, the tumor is either: more than 2 but not more than 4 millimeters thick, with ulceration; or more than 4 millimeters thick, with no ulceration.<EOS>
<BOS>Stage IIC: In stage IIC, the tumor is more than 4 millimeters thick, with ulceration.<EOS>
<BOS>Stage III In stage III, the tumor may be any thickness, with or without ulceration.<EOS>
<BOS>One or more of the following is true: Cancer has spread to one or more lymph nodes.<EOS>
<BOS>Lymph nodes are joined together (matted).<EOS>
<BOS>Cancer is in a lymph vessel between the primary tumor and nearby lymph nodes.<EOS>
<BOS>The cancer is more than 2 centimeters away from the primary tumor.<EOS>
<BOS>Very small tumors are found on or under the skin, not more than 2 centimeters away from the primary tumor.<EOS>
<BOS>Stage IV In stage IV, the cancer has spread to other places in the body, such as the lung, liver, brain, bone, soft tissue, or gastrointestinal (GI) tract.<EOS>
<BOS>Cancer may have spread to places in the skin far away from where it first started.<EOS>
<BOS>Tests that examine the tissues of the neck, respiratory tract, and upper part of the digestive tract are used to detect (find) and diagnose metastatic squamous neck cancer and the primary tumor.<EOS>
<BOS>Tests will include checking for a primary tumor in the organs and tissues of the respiratory tract (part of the trachea), the upper part of the digestive tract (including the lips, mouth, tongue, nose, throat, vocal cords, and part of the esophagus), and the genitourinary system.<EOS>
<BOS>The following procedures may be used: Physical exam and history : An exam of the body, especially the head and neck, to check general signs of health.<EOS>
<BOS>This includes checking for signs of disease, such as lumps or anything else that seems unusual.<EOS>
<BOS>A history of the patients health habits and past illnesses and treatments will also be taken.<EOS>
<BOS>Biopsy : The removal of cells or tissues so they can be viewed under a microscope by a pathologist or tested in the laboratory to check for signs of cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Three types of biopsy may be done: Fineneedle aspiration (FNA) biopsy : The removal of tissue or fluid using a thin needle.<EOS>
<BOS>Core needle biopsy : The removal of tissue using a wide needle.<EOS>
<BOS>Excisional biopsy : The removal of an entire lump of tissue.<EOS>
<BOS>The following procedures are used to remove samples of cells or tissue: Tonsillectomy: Surgery to remove both tonsils.<EOS>
<BOS>Endoscopy : A procedure to look at organs and tissues inside the body to check for abnormal areas.<EOS>
<BOS>An endoscope is inserted through an incision (cut) in the skin or opening in the body, such as the mouth or nose.<EOS>
<BOS>An endoscope is a thin, tubelike instrument with a light and a lens for viewing.<EOS>
<BOS>It may also have a tool to remove abnormal tissue or lymph node samples, which are checked under a microscope for signs of disease.<EOS>
<BOS>The nose, throat, back of the tongue, esophagus, stomach, voice box, windpipe, and large airways will be checked.<EOS>
<BOS>One or more of the following laboratory tests may be done to study the tissue samples: Immunohistochemistry : A test that uses antibodies to check for certain antigens in a sample of blood or bone marrow.<EOS>
<BOS>The antibody is usually linked to a radioactive substance or a dye that causes the tissue to light up under a microscope.<EOS>
<BOS>This type of test may be used to tell the difference between different types of cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Light and electron microscopy : A test in which cells in a sample of tissue are viewed under regular and highpowered microscopes to look for certain changes in the cells.<EOS>
<BOS>EpsteinBarr virus (EBV) and human papillomavirus (HPV) test: A test that checks the cells in a sample of tissue for EBV and HPV DNA.<EOS>
<BOS>MRI (magnetic resonance imaging): A procedure that uses a magnet, radio waves, and a computer to make a series of detailed pictures of areas inside the body.<EOS>
<BOS>This procedure is also called nuclear magnetic resonance imaging (NMRI).<EOS>
<BOS>CT scan (CAT scan): A procedure that makes a series of detailed pictures of areas inside the body, taken from different angles.<EOS>
<BOS>The pictures are made by a computer linked to an xray machine.<EOS>
<BOS>A dye may be injected into a vein or swallowed to help the organs or tissues show up more clearly.<EOS>
<BOS>This procedure is also called computed tomography, computerized tomography, or computerized axial tomography.<EOS>
<BOS>PET scan (positron emission tomography scan): A procedure to find malignant tumor cells in the body.<EOS>
<BOS>A small amount of radioactive glucose (sugar) is injected into a vein.<EOS>
<BOS>The PET scanner rotates around the body and makes a picture of where glucose is being used in the body.<EOS>
<BOS>Malignant tumor cells show up brighter in the picture because they are more active and take up more glucose than normal cells do.<EOS>
<BOS>A whole body PET scan and a CT scan are done at the same time to look for where the cancer first formed.<EOS>
<BOS>If there is any cancer, this increases the chance that it will be found.<EOS>
<BOS>A diagnosis of occult primary tumor is made if the primary tumor is not found during testing or treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Older age can affect the risk of developing chronic lymphocytic leukemia.<EOS>
<BOS>Anything that increases your risk of getting a disease is called a risk factor.<EOS>
<BOS>Having a risk factor does not mean that you will get cancer; not having risk factors doesnt mean that you will not get cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Talk with your doctor if you think you may be at risk.<EOS>
<BOS>Risk factors for CLL include the following: Being middleaged or older, male, or white.<EOS>
<BOS>A family history of CLL or cancer of the lymph system.<EOS>
<BOS>Having relatives who are Russian Jews or Eastern European Jews.<EOS>
<BOS>Key Points Atypical chronic myelogenous leukemia is a disease in which too many granulocytes (immature white blood cells) are made in the bone marrow.<EOS>
<BOS>Signs and symptoms of atypical chronic myelogenous leukemia include easy bruising or bleeding and feeling tired and weak.<EOS>
<BOS>Certain factors affect prognosis (chance of recovery).<EOS>
<BOS>Atypical chronic myelogenous leukemia is a disease in which too many granulocytes (immature white blood cells) are made in the bone marrow.<EOS>
<BOS>In atypical chronic myelogenous leukemia (CML), the body tells too many blood stem cells to become a type of white blood cell called granulocytes.<EOS>
<BOS>Some of these blood stem cells never become mature white blood cells.<EOS>
<BOS>These immature white blood cells are called blasts.<EOS>
<BOS>Over time, the granulocytes and blasts crowd out the red blood cells and platelets in the bone marrow.<EOS>
<BOS>The leukemia cells in atypical CML and CML look alike under a microscope.<EOS>
<BOS>However, in atypical CML a certain chromosome change, called the "Philadelphia chromosome" is not there.<EOS>
<BOS>Certain factors affect prognosis (chance of recovery) and treatment options.<EOS>
<BOS>The prognosis (chance of recovery) and treatment options depend on the following: The stage of the cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>The type of lesion (patches, plaques, or tumors).<EOS>
<BOS>Mycosis fungoides and the Szary syndrome are hard to cure.<EOS>
<BOS>Treatment is usually palliative, to relieve symptoms and improve the quality of life.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients with early stage disease may live many years.<EOS>
<BOS>Key Points There are different types of treatment for patients with Langerhans cell histiocytosis (LCH).<EOS>
<BOS>Children with LCH should have their treatment planned by a team of health care providers who are experts in treating childhood cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Some cancer treatments cause side effects months or years after treatment for childhood cancer has ended.<EOS>
<BOS>Nine types of standard treatment are used: Chemotherapy Surgery Radiation therapy Photodynamic therapy Biologic therapy Targeted therapy Other drug therapy Stem cell transplant Observation New types of treatment are being tested in clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients may want to think about taking part in a clinical trial.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients can enter clinical trials before, during, or after starting their treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>When treatment of LCH stops, new lesions may appear or old lesions may come back.<EOS>
<BOS>Followup tests may be needed.<EOS>
<BOS>There are different types of treatment for patients with Langerhans cell histiocytosis (LCH).<EOS>
<BOS>Different types of treatments are available for patients with LCH.<EOS>
<BOS>Some treatments are standard (the currently used treatment), and some are being tested in clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>A treatment clinical trial is a research study meant to help improve current treatments or obtain information on new treatments for patients with cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>When clinical trials show that a new treatment is better than the standard treatment, the new treatment may become the standard treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Whenever possible, patients should take part in a clinical trial in order to receive new types of treatment for LCH.<EOS>
<BOS>Some clinical trials are open only to patients who have not started treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Clinical trials are taking place in many parts of the country.<EOS>
<BOS>Information about ongoing clinical trials is available from the NCI website.<EOS>
<BOS>Choosing the most appropriate treatment is a decision that ideally involves the patient, family, and health care team.<EOS>
<BOS>Children with LCH should have their treatment planned by a team of health care providers who are experts in treating childhood cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Treatment will be overseen by a pediatric oncologist, a doctor who specializes in treating children with cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>The pediatric oncologist works with other pediatric healthcare providers who are experts in treating children with LCH and who specialize in certain areas of medicine.<EOS>
<BOS>These may include the following specialists: Pediatrician.<EOS>
<BOS>Primary care physician.<EOS>
<BOS>Pediatric surgeon.<EOS>
<BOS>Pediatric hematologist.<EOS>
<BOS>Radiation oncologist.<EOS>
<BOS>Neurologist.<EOS>
<BOS>Endocrinologist.<EOS>
<BOS>Pediatric nurse specialist.<EOS>
<BOS>Rehabilitation specialist.<EOS>
<BOS>Psychologist.<EOS>
<BOS>Social worker.<EOS>
<BOS>Some cancer treatments cause side effects months or years after treatment for childhood cancer has ended.<EOS>
<BOS>Side effects from cancer treatment that begin during or after treatment and continue for months or years are called late effects.<EOS>
<BOS>Late effects of cancer treatment may include the following: Slow growth and development.<EOS>
<BOS>Hearing loss.<EOS>
<BOS>Bone, tooth, liver, and lung problems.<EOS>
<BOS>Changes in mood, feeling, learning, thinking, or memory.<EOS>
<BOS>Second cancers, such as leukemia, retinoblastoma, Ewing sarcoma, brain or liver cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Some late effects may be treated or controlled.<EOS>
<BOS>It is important to talk with your child's doctors about the effects cancer treatment can have on your child.<EOS>
<BOS>(See the PDQ summary on Late Effects of Treatment for Childhood Cancer for more information.<EOS>
<BOS>) Many patients with multisystem LCH have late effects caused by treatment or by the disease itself.<EOS>
<BOS>These patients often have longterm health problems that affect their quality of life.<EOS>
<BOS>Nine types of standard treatment are used: Chemotherapy Chemotherapy is a cancer treatment that uses drugs to stop the growth of cancer cells, either by killing the cells or by stopping them from dividing.<EOS>
<BOS>When chemotherapy is taken by mouth or injected into a vein or muscle, the drugs enter the bloodstream and can reach cancer cells throughout the body (systemic chemotherapy).<EOS>
<BOS>When chemotherapy is placed directly onto the skin or into the cerebrospinal fluid, an organ, or a body cavity such as the abdomen, the drugs mainly affect cancer cells in those areas (regional chemotherapy).<EOS>
<BOS>Chemotherapy agents given by injection or by mouth are used to treat LCH.<EOS>
<BOS>Chemotherapy agents include vinblastine, cytarabine, cladribine, and methotrexate.<EOS>
<BOS>Nitrogen mustard is a drug that is put directly on the skin to treat small LCH lesions.<EOS>
<BOS>Surgery Surgery may be used to remove LCH lesions and a small amount of nearby healthy tissue.<EOS>
<BOS>Curettage is a type of surgery that uses a curette (a sharp, spoonshaped tool) to scrape LCH cells from bone.<EOS>
<BOS>When there is severe liver or lung damage, the entire organ may be removed and replaced with a healthy liver or lung from a donor.<EOS>
<BOS>Radiation therapy Radiation therapy is a cancer treatment that uses highenergy xrays or other types of radiation to kill cancer cells or keep them from growing.<EOS>
<BOS>External radiation therapy uses a machine outside the body to send radiation toward the cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>In LCH, a special lamp may be used to send ultraviolet B (UVB) radiation toward LCH skin lesions.<EOS>
<BOS>Photodynamic therapy Photodynamic therapy is a cancer treatment that uses a drug and a certain type of laser light to kill cancer cells.<EOS>
<BOS>A drug that is not active until it is exposed to light is injected into a vein.<EOS>
<BOS>The drug collects more in cancer cells than in normal cells.<EOS>
<BOS>For LCH, laser light is aimed at the skin and the drug becomes active and kills the cancer cells.<EOS>
<BOS>Photodynamic therapy causes little damage to healthy tissue.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients who have photodynamic therapy should not spend too much time in the sun.<EOS>
<BOS>In one type of photodynamic therapy, called psoralen and ultraviolet A (PUVA) therapy, the patient receives a drug called psoralen and then ultraviolet A radiation is directed to the skin.<EOS>
<BOS>Biologic therapy Biologic therapy is a treatment that uses the patients immune system to fight cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Substances made by the body or made in a laboratory are used to boost, direct, or restore the bodys natural defenses against cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>This type of cancer treatment is also called biotherapy or immunotherapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Interferon is a type of biologic therapy used to treat LCH of the skin.<EOS>
<BOS>Immunomodulators are also a type of biologic therapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Thalidomide is an immunomodulator used to treat LCH.<EOS>
<BOS>Targeted therapy Targeted therapy is a type of treatment that uses drugs or other substances to find and attack LCH cells without harming normal cells.<EOS>
<BOS>Imatinib mesylate is a type of targeted therapy called a tyrosine kinase inhibitor.<EOS>
<BOS>It stops blood stem cells from turning into dendritic cells that may become cancer cells.<EOS>
<BOS>Other types of kinase inhibitors that affect cells with mutations (changes) in the BRAF gene, such as dabrafenib and vemurafenib, are being studied in clinical trials for LCH.<EOS>
<BOS>A family of genes, called ras genes, may cause cancer when they are mutated.<EOS>
<BOS>Ras genes make proteins that are involved in cell signaling pathways, cell growth, and cell death.<EOS>
<BOS>Ras pathway inhibitors are a type of targeted therapy being studied in clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>They block the actions of a mutated ras gene or its protein and may stop the growth of cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Other drug therapy Other drugs used to treat LCH include the following: Steroid therapy, such as prednisone, is used to treat LCH lesions.<EOS>
<BOS>Bisphosphonate therapy (such as pamidronate, zoledronate, or alendronate) is used to treat LCH lesions of the bone and to lessen bone pain.<EOS>
<BOS>Nonsteroidal antiinflammatory drugs (NSAIDs) are drugs (such as aspirin and ibuprofen) that are commonly used to decrease fever, swelling, pain, and redness.<EOS>
<BOS>Sometimes an NSAID called indomethacin is used to treat LCH.<EOS>
<BOS>Retinoids, such as isotretinoin, are drugs related to vitamin A that can slow the growth of LCH cells in the skin.<EOS>
<BOS>The retinoids are taken by mouth.<EOS>
<BOS>Stem cell transplant Stem cell transplant is a method of giving chemotherapy and replacing bloodforming cells destroyed by the LCH treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Stem cells (immature blood cells) are removed from the blood or bone marrow of the patient or a donor and are frozen and stored.<EOS>
<BOS>After the chemotherapy is completed, the stored stem cells are thawed and given back to the patient through an infusion.<EOS>
<BOS>These reinfused stem cells grow into (and restore) the body's blood cells.<EOS>
<BOS>Observation Observation is closely monitoring a patient's condition without giving any treatment until signs or symptoms appear or change.<EOS>
<BOS>New types of treatment are being tested in clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>Information about clinical trials is available from the NCI website.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients may want to think about taking part in a clinical trial.<EOS>
<BOS>For some patients, taking part in a clinical trial may be the best treatment choice.<EOS>
<BOS>Clinical trials are part of the cancer research process.<EOS>
<BOS>Clinical trials are done to find out if new cancer treatments are safe and effective or better than the standard treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Many of today's standard treatments for cancer are based on earlier clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients who take part in a clinical trial may receive the standard treatment or be among the first to receive a new treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients who take part in clinical trials also help improve the way cancer will be treated in the future.<EOS>
<BOS>Even when clinical trials do not lead to effective new treatments, they often answer important questions and help move research forward.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients can enter clinical trials before, during, or after starting their treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Some clinical trials only include patients who have not yet received treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Other trials test treatments for patients whose cancer has not gotten better.<EOS>
<BOS>There are also clinical trials that test new ways to stop cancer from recurring (coming back) or reduce the side effects of cancer treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Clinical trials are taking place in many parts of the country.<EOS>
<BOS>See the Treatment Options for Childhood LCH and the Treatment Options for Adult LCH sections for links to current treatment clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>These have been retrieved from NCI's clinical trials database.<EOS>
<BOS>When treatment of LCH stops, new lesions may appear or old lesions may come back.<EOS>
<BOS>Many patients with LCH get better with treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>However, when treatment stops, new lesions may appear or old lesions may come back.<EOS>
<BOS>This is called reactivation (recurrence) and may occur within one year after stopping treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients with multisystem disease are more likely to have a reactivation.<EOS>
<BOS>More common sites of reactivation are bone, ears, or skin.<EOS>
<BOS>Diabetes insipidus also may develop.<EOS>
<BOS>Less common sites of reactivation include lymph nodes, bone marrow, spleen, liver, or lung.<EOS>
<BOS>Some patients may have more than one reactivation over a number of years.<EOS>
<BOS>Followup tests may be needed.<EOS>
<BOS>Some of the tests that were done to diagnose LCH may be repeated.<EOS>
<BOS>This is to see how well the treatment is working and if there are any new lesions.<EOS>
<BOS>These tests may include: Physical exam.<EOS>
<BOS>Neurological exam.<EOS>
<BOS>Ultrasound exam.<EOS>
<BOS>MRI.<EOS>
<BOS>CT scan.<EOS>
<BOS>PET scan.<EOS>
<BOS>Other tests that may be needed include: Brain stem auditory evoked response (BAER) test: A test that measures the brain's response to clicking sounds or certain tones.<EOS>
<BOS>Pulmonary function test (PFT): A test to see how well the lungs are working.<EOS>
<BOS>It measures how much air the lungs can hold and how quickly air moves into and out of the lungs.<EOS>
<BOS>It also measures how much oxygen is used and how much carbon dioxide is given off during breathing.<EOS>
<BOS>This is also called a lung function test.<EOS>
<BOS>Chest xray: An xray of the organs and bones inside the chest.<EOS>
<BOS>An xray is a type of energy beam that can go through the body and onto film, making a picture of areas inside the body.<EOS>
<BOS>Decisions about whether to continue, change, or stop treatment may be based on the results of these tests.<EOS>
<BOS>Some of the tests will continue to be done from time to time after treatment has ended.<EOS>
<BOS>The results of these tests can show if your condition has changed or if the cancer has recurred (come back).<EOS>
<BOS>These tests are sometimes called followup tests or checkups.<EOS>
<BOS>Treatment Options for LCH in Children Treatment of LowRisk Disease in Children Skin Lesions Treatment of childhood Langerhans cell histiocytosis (LCH) skin lesions may include the following: Observation.<EOS>
<BOS>When severe rashes, pain, ulceration, or bleeding occur, treatment may include the following: Steroid therapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Chemotherapy, given by mouth.<EOS>
<BOS>Nitrogen mustard applied to the skin.<EOS>
<BOS>Photodynamic therapy with psoralen and ultraviolet A (PUVA) therapy.<EOS>
<BOS>UVB radiation therapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Lesions in Bones or Other LowRisk Organs Treatment of childhood LCH bone lesions in the front, sides, or back of the skull, or in any other single bone may include the following: Surgery (curettage) with or without steroid therapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Lowdose radiation therapy for lesions that affect nearby organs.<EOS>
<BOS>Treatment of childhood LCH lesions in bones around the ears or eyes is done to lower the risk of diabetes insipidus and other longterm problems.<EOS>
<BOS>Treatment may include: Chemotherapy and steroid therapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Surgery (curettage).<EOS>
<BOS>Treatment of childhood LCH lesions of the spine or thigh bone lesions may include: Observation.<EOS>
<BOS>Lowdose radiation therapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Chemotherapy, for lesions that spread from the spine into nearby tissue.<EOS>
<BOS>Surgery to strengthen the weakened bone by bracing or fusing the bones together.<EOS>
<BOS>Treatment of two or more bone lesions may include: Chemotherapy and steroid therapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Treatment of two or more bone lesions combined with childhood LCH skin lesions, lymph node lesions, or diabetes insipidus may include: Chemotherapy with or without steroid therapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Bisphosphonate therapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Treatment of HighRisk Disease in Children Treatment of childhood LCH multisystem disease lesions in the spleen, liver, or bone marrow (with or without skin, bone, lymph node, lung, or pituitary gland lesions) may include: Chemotherapy and steroid therapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Higher doses of combination chemotherapy and steroid therapy may be given to patients whose tumors do not respond to initial chemotherapy.<EOS>
<BOS>A liver transplant for patients with severe liver damage.<EOS>
<BOS>Treatment of childhood LCH central nervous system (CNS) lesions may include: Chemotherapy with or without steroid therapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Steroid therapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Treatment of LCH CNS neurodegenerative syndrome may include: Retinoid therapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Chemotherapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Treatment Options for Recurrent, Refractory, and Progressive Childhood LCH in Children Recurrent LCH is cancer that cannot be detected for some time after treatment and then comes back.<EOS>
<BOS>Treatment of recurrent childhood LCH in the skin, bone, lymph nodes, gastrointestinal tract, pituitary gland, or central nervous system (lowrisk organs) may include: Chemotherapy with or without steroid therapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Bisphosphonate therapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Nonsteroidal antiinflammatory drug (NSAID) therapy with indomethacin.<EOS>
<BOS>A clinical trial of a targeted therapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Refractory LCH is cancer that does not get better with treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Treatment of refractory childhood LCH in highrisk organs and in multisystem lowrisk organs may include highdose chemotherapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Treatment of childhood LCH in multisystem highrisk organs that did not respond to chemotherapy may include stem cell transplant.<EOS>
<BOS>Progressive LCH is cancer that continues to grow during treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Treatment of progressive childhood LCH in patients with multisystem disease may include anticancer drugs that have not been given to the patient before.<EOS>
<BOS>Treatment Options for LCH in Adults Treatment Options for LCH of the Lung in Adults Treatment for LCH of the lung in adults may include: Quitting smoking for all patients who smoke.<EOS>
<BOS>Lung damage will get worse over time in patients who do not quit smoking.<EOS>
<BOS>In patients who quit smoking, lung damage may get better or it may get worse over time.<EOS>
<BOS>Chemotherapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Lung transplant for patients with severe lung damage.<EOS>
<BOS>Sometimes LCH of the lung will go away or not get worse even if it's not treated.<EOS>
<BOS>Treatment Options for LCH of the Bone in Adults Treatment for LCH that affects only the bone in adults may include: Surgery with or without steroid therapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Chemotherapy with or without lowdose radiation therapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Radiation therapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Bisphosphonate therapy, for severe bone pain.<EOS>
<BOS>Treatment Options for LCH of the Skin in Adults Treatment for LCH that affects only the skin in adults may include: Surgery.<EOS>
<BOS>Steroid or other drug therapy applied or injected into the skin.<EOS>
<BOS>Photodynamic therapy with psoralen and ultraviolet A (PUVA) radiation.<EOS>
<BOS>UVB radiation therapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Chemotherapy or biologic therapy given by mouth, such as methotrexate, thalidomide, or interferon.<EOS>
