<BOS>Retinoid therapy may be used if the skin lesions do not get better with other treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Treatment for LCH that affects the skin and other body systems in adults may include: Chemotherapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Treatment Options for SingleSystem and Multisystem LCH in Adults Treatment of singlesystem and multisystem disease in adults may include: Chemotherapy with or without a drug given to weaken the immune system.<EOS>
<BOS>Bisphosphonate therapy, for severe bone pain.<EOS>
<BOS>A clinical trial of a targeted therapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Older age and being male increase the risk of chronic myelomonocytic leukemia.<EOS>
<BOS>Anything that increases your chance of getting a disease is called a risk factor.<EOS>
<BOS>Possible risk factors for CMML include the following: Older age.<EOS>
<BOS>Being male.<EOS>
<BOS>Being exposed to certain substances at work or in the environment.<EOS>
<BOS>Being exposed to radiation.<EOS>
<BOS>Past treatment with certain anticancer drugs.<EOS>
<BOS>New types of treatment are being tested in clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>Information about clinical trials is available from the NCI website.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients may want to think about taking part in a clinical trial.<EOS>
<BOS>For some patients, taking part in a clinical trial may be the best treatment choice.<EOS>
<BOS>Clinical trials are part of the cancer research process.<EOS>
<BOS>Clinical trials are done to find out if new cancer treatments are safe and effective or better than the standard treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Many of today's standard treatments for cancer are based on earlier clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients who take part in a clinical trial may receive the standard treatment or be among the first to receive a new treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients who take part in clinical trials also help improve the way cancer will be treated in the future.<EOS>
<BOS>Even when clinical trials do not lead to effective new treatments, they often answer important questions and help move research forward.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients can enter clinical trials before, during, or after starting their cancer treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Some clinical trials only include patients who have not yet received treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Other trials test treatments for patients whose cancer has not gotten better.<EOS>
<BOS>There are also clinical trials that test new ways to stop cancer from recurring (coming back) or reduce the side effects of cancer treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Clinical trials are taking place in many parts of the country.<EOS>
<BOS>See the Treatment Options section that follows for links to current treatment clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>These have been retrieved from NCI's listing of clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>Being female can increase the risk of developing gallbladder cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Anything that increases your chance of getting a disease is called a risk factor.<EOS>
<BOS>Having a risk factor does not mean that you will get cancer; not having risk factors doesn't mean that you will not get cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Talk with your doctor if you think you may be at risk.<EOS>
<BOS>Risk factors for gallbladder cancer include the following: Being female.<EOS>
<BOS>Being Native American.<EOS>
<BOS>Key Points Skin cancer is a disease in which malignant (cancer) cells form in the tissues of the skin.<EOS>
<BOS>Nonmelanoma skin cancer is the most common cancer in the United States.<EOS>
<BOS>Being exposed to ultraviolet radiation may increase the risk of skin cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Skin cancer is a disease in which malignant (cancer) cells form in the tissues of the skin.<EOS>
<BOS>The skin is the body's largest organ.<EOS>
<BOS>It protects against heat, sunlight, injury, and infection.<EOS>
<BOS>Skin also helps control body temperature and stores water, fat, and vitamin D.<EOS>
<BOS>The skin has several layers, but the two main layers are the epidermis (top or outer layer) and the dermis (lower or inner layer).<EOS>
<BOS>Skin cancer begins in the epidermis, which is made up of three kinds of cells: Squamous cells: Thin, flat cells that form the top layer of the epidermis.<EOS>
<BOS>Cancer that forms in squamous cells is called squamous cell carcinoma.<EOS>
<BOS>Basal cells: Round cells under the squamous cells.<EOS>
<BOS>Cancer that forms in basal cells is called basal cell carcinoma.<EOS>
<BOS>Melanocytes: Found in the lower part of the epidermis, these cells make melanin, the pigment that gives skin its natural color.<EOS>
<BOS>When skin is exposed to the sun, melanocytes make more pigment and cause the skin to tan, or darken.<EOS>
<BOS>Cancer that forms in melanocytes is called melanoma.<EOS>
<BOS>Nonmelanoma skin cancer is the most common cancer in the United States.<EOS>
<BOS>Basal cell carcinoma and squamous cell carcinoma are also called nonmelanoma skin cancer and are the most common forms of skin cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Most basal cell and squamous cell skin cancers can be cured.<EOS>
<BOS>Melanoma is more likely to spread to nearby tissues and other parts of the body and can be harder to cure.<EOS>
<BOS>Melanoma is easier to cure if the tumor is found before it spreads to the dermis (inner layer of skin).<EOS>
<BOS>Melanoma is less likely to cause death when it is found and treated early.<EOS>
<BOS>In the United States, the number of cases of nonmelanoma skin cancer seems to have increased in recent years.<EOS>
<BOS>The number of cases of melanoma has increased over the last 30 years.<EOS>
<BOS>Part of the reason for these increases may be that people are more aware of skin cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>They are more likely to have skin exams and biopsies and to be diagnosed with skin cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Over the past 20 years, the number of deaths from melanoma has decreased slightly among white men and women younger than 50 years.<EOS>
<BOS>During that time, the number of deaths from melanoma has increased slightly among white men older than 50 years and stayed about the same among white women older than 50 years.<EOS>
<BOS>The number of cases of childhood melanoma diagnosed in the United States is low, but increasing over time.<EOS>
<BOS>The number of childhood deaths from melanoma has stayed about the same.<EOS>
<BOS>See the following PDQ summaries for more information about skin cancer: Skin Cancer Prevention Skin Cancer Treatment Melanoma Treatment Genetics of Skin Cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Certain factors affect prognosis (chance of recovery) and treatment options.<EOS>
<BOS>The prognosis (chance of recovery) and treatment options for childhood AML depend on the following: The age of the child when the cancer is diagnosed.<EOS>
<BOS>The race or ethnic group of the child.<EOS>
<BOS>Whether the child is greatly overweight.<EOS>
<BOS>Number of white blood cells in the blood at diagnosis.<EOS>
<BOS>Whether the AML occurred after previous cancer treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>The subtype of AML.<EOS>
<BOS>Whether there are certain chromosome or gene changes in the leukemia cells.<EOS>
<BOS>Whether the child has Down syndrome.<EOS>
<BOS>Most children with AML and Down syndrome can be cured of their leukemia.<EOS>
<BOS>Whether the leukemia is in the central nervous system (brain and spinal cord).<EOS>
<BOS>How quickly the leukemia responds to treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Whether the AML is newly diagnosed (untreated) or has recurred (come back) after being treated.<EOS>
<BOS>The length of time since treatment ended, for AML that has recurred.<EOS>
<BOS>The prognosis and treatment options for childhood CML depend on how long it has been since the patient was diagnosed and how many blast cells are in the blood.<EOS>
<BOS>The prognosis (chance of recovery) and treatment options for JMML depend on the following: The age of the child when the cancer is diagnosed.<EOS>
<BOS>The type of gene affected and the number of genes that have changes.<EOS>
<BOS>How many red blood cells, white blood cells, or platelets are in the blood.<EOS>
<BOS>Whether the JMML is newly diagnosed (untreated) or has recurred after treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>The prognosis (chance of recovery) and treatment options for MDS depend on the following: Whether the MDS was caused by previous cancer treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>How low the numbers of red blood cells, white blood cells, or platelets are.<EOS>
<BOS>Whether the MDS is newly diagnosed (untreated) or has recurred after treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Chronic neutrophilic leukemia is a disease in which too many blood stem cells become a type of white blood cell called neutrophils.<EOS>
<BOS>Neutrophils are infection fighting blood cells that surround and destroy dead cells and foreign substances (such as bacteria).<EOS>
<BOS>The spleen and liver may swell because of the extra neutrophils.<EOS>
<BOS>Chronic neutrophilic leukemia may stay the same or it may progress quickly to acute leukemia.<EOS>
<BOS>Key Points After anal cancer has been diagnosed, tests are done to find out if cancer cells have spread within the anus or to other parts of the body.<EOS>
<BOS>There are three ways that cancer spreads in the body.<EOS>
<BOS>Cancer may spread from where it began to other parts of the body.<EOS>
<BOS>The following stages are used for anal cancer: Stage 0 (Carcinoma in Situ) Stage I Stage II Stage IIIA Stage IIIB Stage IV After anal cancer has been diagnosed, tests are done to find out if cancer cells have spread within the anus or to other parts of the body.<EOS>
<BOS>The process used to find out if cancer has spread within the anus or to other parts of the body is called staging.<EOS>
<BOS>The information gathered from the staging process determines the stage of the disease.<EOS>
<BOS>It is important to know the stage in order to plan treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>The following tests may be used in the staging process: CT scan (CAT scan): A procedure that makes a series of detailed pictures of areas inside the body, such as the abdomen or chest, taken from different angles.<EOS>
<BOS>The pictures are made by a computer linked to an xray machine.<EOS>
<BOS>A dye may be injected into a vein or swallowed to help the organs or tissues show up more clearly.<EOS>
<BOS>This procedure is also called computed tomography, computerized tomography, or computerized axial tomography.<EOS>
<BOS>For anal cancer, a CT scan of the pelvis and abdomen may be done.<EOS>
<BOS>Chest xray : An xray of the organs and bones inside the chest.<EOS>
<BOS>An xray is a type of energy beam that can go through the body and onto film, making a picture of areas inside the body.<EOS>
<BOS>MRI (magnetic resonance imaging): A procedure that uses a magnet, radio waves, and a computer to make a series of detailed pictures of areas inside the body.<EOS>
<BOS>This procedure is also called nuclear magnetic resonance imaging (NMRI).<EOS>
<BOS>PET scan (positron emission tomography scan): A procedure to find malignant tumor cells in the body.<EOS>
<BOS>A small amount of radioactive glucose (sugar) is injected into a vein.<EOS>
<BOS>The PET scanner rotates around the body and makes a picture of where glucose is being used in the body.<EOS>
<BOS>Malignant tumor cells show up brighter in the picture because they are more active and take up more glucose than normal cells do.<EOS>
<BOS>There are three ways that cancer spreads in the body.<EOS>
<BOS>Cancer can spread through tissue, the lymph system, and the blood: Tissue.<EOS>
<BOS>The cancer spreads from where it began by growing into nearby areas.<EOS>
<BOS>Lymph system.<EOS>
<BOS>The cancer spreads from where it began by getting into the lymph system.<EOS>
<BOS>The cancer travels through the lymph vessels to other parts of the body.<EOS>
<BOS>Blood.<EOS>
<BOS>The cancer spreads from where it began by getting into the blood.<EOS>
<BOS>The cancer travels through the blood vessels to other parts of the body.<EOS>
<BOS>Cancer may spread from where it began to other parts of the body.<EOS>
<BOS>When cancer spreads to another part of the body, it is called metastasis.<EOS>
<BOS>Cancer cells break away from where they began (the primary tumor) and travel through the lymph system or blood.<EOS>
<BOS>Lymph system.<EOS>
<BOS>The cancer gets into the lymph system, travels through the lymph vessels, and forms a tumor (metastatic tumor) in another part of the body.<EOS>
<BOS>Blood.<EOS>
<BOS>The cancer gets into the blood, travels through the blood vessels, and forms a tumor (metastatic tumor) in another part of the body.<EOS>
<BOS>The metastatic tumor is the same type of cancer as the primary tumor.<EOS>
<BOS>For example, if anal cancer spreads to the lung, the cancer cells in the lung are actually anal cancer cells.<EOS>
<BOS>The disease is metastatic anal cancer, not lung cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>The following stages are used for anal cancer: Stage 0 (Carcinoma in Situ) In stage 0, abnormal cells are found in the innermost lining of the anus.<EOS>
<BOS>These abnormal cells may become cancer and spread into nearby normal tissue.<EOS>
<BOS>Stage 0 is also called carcinoma in situ.<EOS>
<BOS>Stage I In stage I, cancer has formed and the tumor is 2 centimeters or smaller.<EOS>
<BOS>Stage II In stage II, the tumor is larger than 2 centimeters.<EOS>
<BOS>Stage IIIA In stage IIIA, the tumor may be any size and has spread to either: lymph nodes near the rectum; or nearby organs, such as the vagina, urethra, and bladder.<EOS>
<BOS>Stage IIIB In stage IIIB, the tumor may be any size and has spread: to nearby organs and to lymph nodes near the rectum; or to lymph nodes on one side of the pelvis and/or groin, and may have spread to nearby organs; or to lymph nodes near the rectum and in the groin, and/or to lymph nodes on both sides of the pelvis and/or groin, and may have spread to nearby organs.<EOS>
<BOS>Stage IV In stage IV, the tumor may be any size and cancer may have spread to lymph nodes or nearby organs and has spread to distant parts of the body.<EOS>
<BOS>Health history affects the risk of developing rectal cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Anything that increases your chance of getting a disease is called a risk factor.<EOS>
<BOS>Having a risk factor does not mean that you will get cancer; not having risk factors doesnt mean that you will not get cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Talk to your doctor if you think you may be at risk for colorectal cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Risk factors for colorectal cancer include the following: Having a family history of colon or rectal cancer in a firstdegree relative (parent, sibling, or child).<EOS>
<BOS>Having a personal history of cancer of the colon, rectum, or ovary.<EOS>
<BOS>Having a personal history of highrisk adenomas (colorectal polyps that are 1 centimeter or larger in size or that have cells that look abnormal under a microscope).<EOS>
<BOS>Having inherited changes in certain genes that increase the risk of familial adenomatous polyposis (FAP) or Lynch syndrome (hereditary nonpolyposis colorectal cancer).<EOS>
<BOS>Having a personal history of chronic ulcerative colitis or Crohn disease for 8 years or more.<EOS>
<BOS>Having three or more alcoholic drinks per day.<EOS>
<BOS>Smoking cigarettes.<EOS>
<BOS>Being black.<EOS>
<BOS>Being obese.<EOS>
<BOS>Older age is a main risk factor for most cancers.<EOS>
<BOS>The chance of getting cancer increases as you get older.<EOS>
<BOS>These and other signs and symptoms may be caused by LCH or by other conditions.<EOS>
<BOS>Check with your doctor if you or your child have any of the following: Skin and nails LCH in infants may affect the skin only.<EOS>
<BOS>In some cases, skinonly LCH may get worse over weeks or months and become a form called highrisk multisystem LCH.<EOS>
<BOS>In infants, signs or symptoms of LCH that affects the skin may include: Flaking of the scalp that may look like cradle cap.<EOS>
<BOS>Raised, brown or purple skin rash anywhere on the body.<EOS>
<BOS>In children and adults, signs or symptoms of LCH that affects the skin and nails may include: Flaking of the scalp that may look like dandruff.<EOS>
<BOS>Raised, red or brown, crusted rash in the groin area, abdomen, back, or chest, that may be itchy.<EOS>
<BOS>Bumps or ulcers on the scalp.<EOS>
<BOS>Ulcers behind the ears, under the breasts, or in the groin area.<EOS>
<BOS>Fingernails that fall off or have discolored grooves that run the length of the nail.<EOS>
<BOS>Mouth Signs or symptoms of LCH that affects the mouth may include: Swollen gums.<EOS>
<BOS>Sores on the roof of the mouth, inside the cheeks, or on the tongue or lips.<EOS>
<BOS>Teeth that become uneven.<EOS>
<BOS>Tooth loss.<EOS>
<BOS>Bone Signs or symptoms of LCH that affects the bone may include: Swelling or a lump over a bone, such as the skull, ribs, spine, thigh bone, upper arm bone, elbow, eye socket, or bones around the ear.<EOS>
<BOS>Pain where there is swelling or a lump over a bone.<EOS>
<BOS>Children with LCH lesions in bones around the ears or eyes have a high risk for diabetes insipidus and other central nervous system disease.<EOS>
<BOS>Lymph nodes and thymus Signs or symptoms of LCH that affects the lymph nodes or thymus may include: Swollen lymph nodes.<EOS>
<BOS>Trouble breathing.<EOS>
<BOS>Superior vena cava syndrome.<EOS>
<BOS>This can cause coughing, trouble breathing, and swelling of the face, neck, and upper arms.<EOS>
<BOS>Endocrine system Signs or symptoms of LCH that affects the pituitary gland may include: Diabetes insipidus.<EOS>
<BOS>This can cause a strong thirst and frequent urination.<EOS>
<BOS>Slow growth.<EOS>
<BOS>Early or late puberty.<EOS>
<BOS>Being very overweight.<EOS>
<BOS>Signs or symptoms of LCH that affects the thyroid may include: Swollen thyroid gland.<EOS>
<BOS>Hypothyroidism.<EOS>
<BOS>This can cause tiredness, lack of energy, being sensitive to cold, constipation, dry skin, thinning hair, memory problems, trouble concentrating, and depression.<EOS>
<BOS>In infants, this can also cause a loss of appetite and choking on food.<EOS>
<BOS>In children and adolescents, this can also cause behavior problems, weight gain, slow growth, and late puberty.<EOS>
<BOS>Trouble breathing.<EOS>
<BOS>Central nervous system (CNS) Signs or symptoms of LCH that affects the CNS (brain and spinal cord) may include: Loss of balance, uncoordinated body movements, and trouble walking.<EOS>
<BOS>Trouble speaking.<EOS>
<BOS>Trouble seeing.<EOS>
<BOS>Headaches.<EOS>
<BOS>Changes in behavior or personality.<EOS>
<BOS>Memory problems.<EOS>
<BOS>These signs and symptoms may be caused by lesions in the CNS or by CNS neurodegenerative syndrome.<EOS>
<BOS>Liver and spleen Signs or symptoms of LCH that affects the liver or spleen may include: Swelling in the abdomen caused by a buildup of extra fluid.<EOS>
<BOS>Trouble breathing.<EOS>
<BOS>Yellowing of the skin and whites of the eyes.<EOS>
<BOS>Itching.<EOS>
<BOS>Easy bruising or bleeding.<EOS>
<BOS>Feeling very tired.<EOS>
<BOS>Lung Signs or symptoms of LCH that affects the lung may include: Collapsed lung.<EOS>
<BOS>This condition can cause chest pain or tightness, trouble breathing, feeling tired, and a bluish color to the skin.<EOS>
<BOS>Trouble breathing, especially in adults who smoke.<EOS>
<BOS>Dry cough.<EOS>
<BOS>Chest pain.<EOS>
<BOS>Bone marrow Signs or symptoms of LCH that affects the bone marrow may include: Easy bruising or bleeding.<EOS>
<BOS>Fever.<EOS>
<BOS>Frequent infections.<EOS>
<BOS>New types of treatment are being tested in clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>This summary section describes treatments that are being studied in clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>It may not mention every new treatment being studied.<EOS>
<BOS>Information about clinical trials is available from the NCI website.<EOS>
<BOS>Cryosurgery Cryosurgery is a treatment that uses an instrument to freeze and destroy prostate cancer cells.<EOS>
<BOS>Ultrasound is used to find the area that will be treated.<EOS>
<BOS>This type of treatment is also called cryotherapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Cryosurgery can cause impotence and leakage of urine from the bladder or stool from the rectum.<EOS>
<BOS>Highintensityfocused ultrasound therapy Highintensityfocused ultrasound therapy is a treatment that uses ultrasound (highenergy sound waves) to destroy cancer cells.<EOS>
<BOS>To treat prostate cancer, an endorectal probe is used to make the sound waves.<EOS>
<BOS>Proton beam radiation therapy Proton beam radiation therapy is a type of highenergy, external radiation therapy that targets tumors with streams of protons (small, positively charged particles).<EOS>
<BOS>This type of radiation therapy is being studied in the treatment of prostate cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients may want to think about taking part in a clinical trial.<EOS>
<BOS>For some patients, taking part in a clinical trial may be the best treatment choice.<EOS>
<BOS>Clinical trials are part of the cancer research process.<EOS>
<BOS>Clinical trials are done to find out if new cancer treatments are safe and effective or better than the standard treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Many of today's standard treatments for cancer are based on earlier clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients who take part in a clinical trial may receive the standard treatment or be among the first to receive a new treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients who take part in clinical trials also help improve the way cancer will be treated in the future.<EOS>
<BOS>Even when clinical trials do not lead to effective new treatments, they often answer important questions and help move research forward.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients can enter clinical trials before, during, or after starting their cancer treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Some clinical trials only include patients who have not yet received treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Other trials test treatments for patients whose cancer has not gotten better.<EOS>
<BOS>There are also clinical trials that test new ways to stop cancer from recurring (coming back) or reduce the side effects of cancer treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Clinical trials are taking place in many parts of the country.<EOS>
<BOS>See the Treatment Options section that follows for links to current treatment clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>These have been retrieved from NCI's listing of clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>Key Points After adult Hodgkin lymphoma has been diagnosed, tests are done to find out if cancer cells have spread within the lymph system or to other parts of the body.<EOS>
<BOS>There are three ways that cancer spreads in the body.<EOS>
<BOS>Stages of adult Hodgkin lymphoma may include A, B, E, and S.<EOS>
<BOS>The following stages are used for adult Hodgkin lymphoma: Stage I Stage II Stage III Stage IV Adult Hodgkin lymphoma may be grouped for treatment as follows: Early Favorable Early Unfavorable Advanced After adult Hodgkin lymphoma has been diagnosed, tests are done to find out if cancer cells have spread within the lymph system or to other parts of the body.<EOS>
<BOS>The process used to find out if cancer has spread within the lymph system or to other parts of the body is called staging.<EOS>
<BOS>The information gathered from the staging process determines the stage of the disease.<EOS>
<BOS>It is important to know the stage in order to plan treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>The following tests and procedures may be used in the staging process: CT scan (CAT scan): A procedure that makes a series of detailed pictures of areas inside the body, taken from different angles.<EOS>
<BOS>The pictures are made by a computer linked to an xray machine.<EOS>
<BOS>A dye may be injected into a vein or swallowed to help the organs or tissues show up more clearly.<EOS>
<BOS>This procedure is also called computed tomography, computerized tomography, or computerized axial tomography.<EOS>
<BOS>For adult Hodgkin lymphoma, CT scans of the neck, chest, abdomen, and pelvis are taken.<EOS>
<BOS>PETCT scan : A procedure that combines the pictures from a positron emission tomography (PET) scan and a computed tomography (CT) scan.<EOS>
<BOS>The PET and CT scans are done at the same time on the same machine.<EOS>
<BOS>The pictures from both scans are combined to make a more detailed picture than either test would make by itself.<EOS>
<BOS>A PET scan is a procedure to find malignant tumor cells in the body.<EOS>
<BOS>A small amount of radioactive glucose (sugar) is injected into a vein.<EOS>
<BOS>The PET scanner rotates around the body and makes a picture of where glucose is being used in the body.<EOS>
<BOS>Malignant tumor cells show up brighter in the picture because they are more active and take up more glucose than normal cells do.<EOS>
<BOS>Bone marrow aspiration and biopsy : The removal of bone marrow, blood, and a small piece of bone by inserting a hollow needle into the hipbone or breastbone.<EOS>
<BOS>A pathologist views the bone marrow, blood, and bone under a microscope to look for signs of cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>For pregnant women with Hodgkin lymphoma, staging tests that protect the fetus from the harms of radiation are used.<EOS>
<BOS>These include: MRI (magnetic resonance imaging): A procedure that uses a magnet, radio waves, and a computer to make a series of detailed pictures of areas inside the body.<EOS>
<BOS>This procedure is also called nuclear magnetic resonance imaging (NMRI).<EOS>
<BOS>Ultrasound exam: A procedure in which highenergy sound waves (ultrasound) are bounced off internal tissues or organs and make echoes.<EOS>
<BOS>The echoes form a picture of body tissues called a sonogram.<EOS>
<BOS>There are three ways that cancer spreads in the body.<EOS>
<BOS>Cancer can spread through tissue, the lymph system, and the blood: Tissue.<EOS>
<BOS>The cancer spreads from where it began by growing into nearby areas.<EOS>
<BOS>Lymph system.<EOS>
<BOS>The cancer spreads from where it began by getting into the lymph system.<EOS>
<BOS>The cancer travels through the lymph vessels to other parts of the body.<EOS>
<BOS>Blood.<EOS>
<BOS>The cancer spreads from where it began by getting into the blood.<EOS>
<BOS>The cancer travels through the blood vessels to other parts of the body.<EOS>
<BOS>Stages of adult Hodgkin lymphoma may include A, B, E, and S.<EOS>
<BOS>Adult Hodgkin lymphoma may be described as follows: A: The patient does not have B symptoms (fever, weight loss, or night sweats).<EOS>
<BOS>B: The patient has B symptoms.<EOS>
<BOS>E: Cancer is found in an organ or tissue that is not part of the lymph system but which may be next to an involved area of the lymph system.<EOS>
<BOS>S: Cancer is found in the spleen.<EOS>
<BOS>The following stages are used for adult Hodgkin lymphoma: Stage I Stage I is divided into stage I and stage IE.<EOS>
<BOS>Stage I: Cancer is found in one of the following places in the lymph system: One or more lymph nodes in one lymph node group.<EOS>
<BOS>Waldeyer's ring.<EOS>
<BOS>Thymus.<EOS>
<BOS>Spleen.<EOS>
<BOS>Stage IE: Cancer is found outside the lymph system in one organ or area.<EOS>
<BOS>Stage II Stage II is divided into stage II and stage IIE.<EOS>
<BOS>Stage II: Cancer is found in two or more lymph node groups either above or below the diaphragm (the thin muscle below the lungs that helps breathing and separates the chest from the abdomen).<EOS>
<BOS>Stage IIE: Cancer is found in one or more lymph node groups either above or below the diaphragm and outside the lymph nodes in a nearby organ or area.<EOS>
<BOS>Stage III Stage III is divided into stage III, stage IIIE, stage IIIS, and stage IIIE,S.<EOS>
<BOS>Stage III: Cancer is found in lymph node groups above and below the diaphragm (the thin muscle below the lungs that helps breathing and separates the chest from the abdomen).<EOS>
<BOS>Stage IIIE: Cancer is found in lymph node groups above and below the diaphragm and outside the lymph nodes in a nearby organ or area.<EOS>
<BOS>Stage IIIS: Cancer is found in lymph node groups above and below the diaphragm, and in the spleen.<EOS>
<BOS>Stage IIIE,S: Cancer is found in lymph node groups above and below the diaphragm, outside the lymph nodes in a nearby organ or area, and in the spleen.<EOS>
<BOS>Stage IV In stage IV, the cancer: is found outside the lymph nodes throughout one or more organs, and may be in lymph nodes near those organs; or is found outside the lymph nodes in one organ and has spread to areas far away from that organ; or is found in the lung, liver, bone marrow, or cerebrospinal fluid (CSF).<EOS>
<BOS>The cancer has not spread to the lung, liver, bone marrow, or CSF from nearby areas.<EOS>
<BOS>Adult Hodgkin lymphoma may be grouped for treatment as follows: Early Favorable Early favorable adult Hodgkin lymphoma is stage I or stage II, without risk factors.<EOS>
<BOS>Early Unfavorable Early unfavorable adult Hodgkin lymphoma is stage I or stage II with one or more of the following risk factors: A tumor in the chest that is larger than 1/3 of the width of the chest or at least 10 centimeters.<EOS>
<BOS>Cancer in an organ other than the lymph nodes.<EOS>
<BOS>A high sedimentation rate (in a sample of blood, the red blood cells settle to the bottom of the test tube more quickly than normal).<EOS>
<BOS>Three or more lymph nodes with cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Symptoms such as fever, weight loss, or night sweats.<EOS>
<BOS>Advanced Advanced Hodgkin lymphoma includes some or all of the following risk factors: Being male.<EOS>
<BOS>Being aged 45 years or older.<EOS>
<BOS>Having stage IV disease.<EOS>
<BOS>Having a low blood albumin (protein) level (below 4).<EOS>
<BOS>Having a low hemoglobin level (below 10.<EOS>
<BOS>5).<EOS>
<BOS>Having a high white blood cell count (15,000 or higher).<EOS>
<BOS>Having a low lymphocyte count (below 600 or less than 8% of the white blood cell count).<EOS>
<BOS>Key Points There are different types of treatment for patients with anal cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Three types of standard treatment are used: Radiation therapy Chemotherapy Surgery Having the human immunodeficiency virus can affect treatment of anal cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>New types of treatment are being tested in clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>Radiosensitizers Patients may want to think about taking part in a clinical trial.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients can enter clinical trials before, during, or after starting their cancer treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Followup tests may be needed.<EOS>
<BOS>There are different types of treatment for patients with anal cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Different types of treatments are available for patients with anal cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Some treatments are standard (the currently used treatment), and some are being tested in clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>A treatment clinical trial is a research study meant to help improve current treatments or obtain information on new treatments for patients with cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>When clinical trials show that a new treatment is better than the standard treatment, the new treatment may become the standard treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients may want to think about taking part in a clinical trial.<EOS>
<BOS>Some clinical trials are open only to patients who have not started treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Three types of standard treatment are used: Radiation therapy Radiation therapy is a cancer treatment that uses highenergy xrays or other types of radiation to kill cancer cells or keep them from growing.<EOS>
<BOS>There are two types of radiation therapy: External radiation therapy uses a machine outside the body to send radiation toward the cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Internal radiation therapy uses a radioactive substance sealed in needles, seeds, wires, or catheters that are placed directly into or near the cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>The way the radiation therapy is given depends on the type and stage of the cancer being treated.<EOS>
<BOS>External and internal radiation therapy are used to treat anal cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Chemotherapy Chemotherapy is a cancer treatment that uses drugs to stop the growth of cancer cells, either by killing the cells or by stopping the cells from dividing.<EOS>
<BOS>When chemotherapy is taken by mouth or injected into a vein or muscle, the drugs enter the bloodstream and can reach cancer cells throughout the body (systemic chemotherapy).<EOS>
<BOS>When chemotherapy is placed directly into the cerebrospinal fluid, an organ, or a body cavity such as the abdomen, the drugs mainly affect cancer cells in those areas (regional chemotherapy).<EOS>
<BOS>The way the chemotherapy is given depends on the type and stage of the cancer being treated.<EOS>
<BOS>Surgery Local resection: A surgical procedure in which the tumor is cut from the anus along with some of the healthy tissue around it.<EOS>
<BOS>Local resection may be used if the cancer is small and has not spread.<EOS>
<BOS>This procedure may save the sphincter muscles so the patient can still control bowel movements.<EOS>
<BOS>Tumors that form in the lower part of the anus can often be removed with local resection.<EOS>
<BOS>Abdominoperineal resection: A surgical procedure in which the anus, the rectum, and part of the sigmoid colon are removed through an incision made in the abdomen.<EOS>
<BOS>The doctor sews the end of the intestine to an opening, called a stoma, made in the surface of the abdomen so body waste can be collected in a disposable bag outside of the body.<EOS>
<BOS>This is called a colostomy.<EOS>
<BOS>Lymph nodes that contain cancer may also be removed during this operation.<EOS>
<BOS>Having the human immunodeficiency virus can affect treatment of anal cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Cancer therapy can further damage the already weakened immune systems of patients who have the human immunodeficiency virus (HIV).<EOS>
<BOS>For this reason, patients who have anal cancer and HIV are usually treated with lower doses of anticancer drugs and radiation than patients who do not have HIV.<EOS>
<BOS>New types of treatment are being tested in clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>This summary section describes treatments that are being studied in clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>It may not mention every new treatment being studied.<EOS>
<BOS>Information about clinical trials is available from the NCI website.<EOS>
<BOS>Radiosensitizers Radiosensitizers are drugs that make tumor cells more sensitive to radiation therapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Combining radiation therapy with radiosensitizers may kill more tumor cells.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients may want to think about taking part in a clinical trial.<EOS>
<BOS>For some patients, taking part in a clinical trial may be the best treatment choice.<EOS>
<BOS>Clinical trials are part of the cancer research process.<EOS>
<BOS>Clinical trials are done to find out if new cancer treatments are safe and effective or better than the standard treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Many of today's standard treatments for cancer are based on earlier clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients who take part in a clinical trial may receive the standard treatment or be among the first to receive a new treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients who take part in clinical trials also help improve the way cancer will be treated in the future.<EOS>
<BOS>Even when clinical trials do not lead to effective new treatments, they often answer important questions and help move research forward.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients can enter clinical trials before, during, or after starting their cancer treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Some clinical trials only include patients who have not yet received treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Other trials test treatments for patients whose cancer has not gotten better.<EOS>
<BOS>There are also clinical trials that test new ways to stop cancer from recurring (coming back) or reduce the side effects of cancer treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Clinical trials are taking place in many parts of the country.<EOS>
<BOS>See the Treatment Options section that follows for links to current treatment clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>These have been retrieved from NCI's listing of clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>Followup tests may be needed.<EOS>
<BOS>Some of the tests that were done to diagnose the cancer or to find out the stage of the cancer may be repeated.<EOS>
<BOS>Some tests will be repeated in order to see how well the treatment is working.<EOS>
<BOS>Decisions about whether to continue, change, or stop treatment may be based on the results of these tests.<EOS>
<BOS>Some of the tests will continue to be done from time to time after treatment has ended.<EOS>
<BOS>The results of these tests can show if your condition has changed or if the cancer has recurred (come back).<EOS>
<BOS>These tests are sometimes called followup tests or checkups.<EOS>
<BOS>Treatment Options by Stage Stage 0 (Carcinoma in Situ) Treatment of stage 0 is usually local resection.<EOS>
<BOS>Check the list of NCIsupported cancer clinical trials that are now accepting patients with stage 0 anal cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>For more specific results, refine the search by using other search features, such as the location of the trial, the type of treatment, or the name of the drug.<EOS>
<BOS>Talk with your doctor about clinical trials that may be right for you.<EOS>
<BOS>General information about clinical trials is available from the NCI website.<EOS>
<BOS>Stage I Anal Cancer Treatment of stage I anal cancer may include the following: Local resection.<EOS>
<BOS>Externalbeam radiation therapy with or without chemotherapy.<EOS>
<BOS>If cancer remains after treatment, more chemotherapy and radiation therapy may be given to avoid the need for a permanent colostomy.<EOS>
<BOS>Internal radiation therapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Abdominoperineal resection, if cancer remains or comes back after treatment with radiation therapy and chemotherapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Internal radiation therapy for cancer that remains after treatment with externalbeam radiation therapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients who have had treatment that saves the sphincter muscles may receive followup exams every 3 months for the first 2 years, including rectal exams with endoscopy and biopsy, as needed.<EOS>
<BOS>Check the list of NCIsupported cancer clinical trials that are now accepting patients with stage I anal cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>For more specific results, refine the search by using other search features, such as the location of the trial, the type of treatment, or the name of the drug.<EOS>
<BOS>Talk with your doctor about clinical trials that may be right for you.<EOS>
<BOS>General information about clinical trials is available from the NCI website.<EOS>
<BOS>Stage II Anal Cancer Treatment of stage II anal cancer may include the following: Local resection.<EOS>
<BOS>Externalbeam radiation therapy with chemotherapy.<EOS>
<BOS>If cancer remains after treatment, more chemotherapy and radiation therapy may be given to avoid the need for a permanent colostomy.<EOS>
<BOS>Internal radiation therapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Abdominoperineal resection, if cancer remains or comes back after treatment with radiation therapy and chemotherapy.<EOS>
<BOS>A clinical trial of new treatment options.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients who have had treatment that saves the sphincter muscles may receive followup exams every 3 months for the first 2 years, including rectal exams with endoscopy and biopsy, as needed.<EOS>
<BOS>Check the list of NCIsupported cancer clinical trials that are now accepting patients with stage II anal cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>For more specific results, refine the search by using other search features, such as the location of the trial, the type of treatment, or the name of the drug.<EOS>
<BOS>Talk with your doctor about clinical trials that may be right for you.<EOS>
<BOS>General information about clinical trials is available from the NCI website.<EOS>
<BOS>Stage IIIA Anal Cancer Treatment of stage IIIA anal cancer may include the following: Externalbeam radiation therapy with chemotherapy.<EOS>
<BOS>If cancer remains after treatment, more chemotherapy and radiation therapy may be given to avoid the need for a permanent colostomy.<EOS>
<BOS>Internal radiation therapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Abdominoperineal resection, if cancer remains or comes back after treatment with chemotherapy and radiation therapy.<EOS>
<BOS>A clinical trial of new treatment options.<EOS>
<BOS>Check the list of NCIsupported cancer clinical trials that are now accepting patients with stage IIIA anal cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>For more specific results, refine the search by using other search features, such as the location of the trial, the type of treatment, or the name of the drug.<EOS>
<BOS>Talk with your doctor about clinical trials that may be right for you.<EOS>
<BOS>General information about clinical trials is available from the NCI website.<EOS>
<BOS>Stage IIIB Anal Cancer Treatment of stage IIIB anal cancer may include the following: Externalbeam radiation therapy with chemotherapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Local resection or abdominoperineal resection, if cancer remains or comes back after treatment with chemotherapy and radiation therapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Lymph nodes may also be removed.<EOS>
<BOS>A clinical trial of new treatment options.<EOS>
<BOS>Check the list of NCIsupported cancer clinical trials that are now accepting patients with stage IIIB anal cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>For more specific results, refine the search by using other search features, such as the location of the trial, the type of treatment, or the name of the drug.<EOS>
<BOS>Talk with your doctor about clinical trials that may be right for you.<EOS>
<BOS>General information about clinical trials is available from the NCI website.<EOS>
<BOS>Stage IV Anal Cancer Treatment of stage IV anal cancer may include the following: Surgery as palliative therapy to relieve symptoms and improve the quality of life.<EOS>
<BOS>Radiation therapy as palliative therapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Chemotherapy with radiation therapy as palliative therapy.<EOS>
<BOS>A clinical trial of new treatment options.<EOS>
<BOS>Check the list of NCIsupported cancer clinical trials that are now accepting patients with stage IV anal cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>For more specific results, refine the search by using other search features, such as the location of the trial, the type of treatment, or the name of the drug.<EOS>
<BOS>Talk with your doctor about clinical trials that may be right for you.<EOS>
<BOS>General information about clinical trials is available from the NCI website.<EOS>
<BOS>Signs and symptoms of atypical chronic myelogenous leukemia include easy bruising or bleeding and feeling tired and weak.<EOS>
<BOS>These and other signs and symptoms may be caused by atypical CML or by other conditions.<EOS>
<BOS>Check with your doctor if you have any of the following: Shortness of breath.<EOS>
<BOS>Pale skin.<EOS>
<BOS>Feeling very tired and weak.<EOS>
<BOS>Easy bruising or bleeding.<EOS>
<BOS>Petechiae (flat, pinpoint spots under the skin caused by bleeding).<EOS>
<BOS>Pain or a feeling of fullness below the ribs on the left side.<EOS>
<BOS>Key Points Paranasal sinus and nasal cavity cancer is a disease in which malignant (cancer) cells form in the tissues of the paranasal sinuses and nasal cavity.<EOS>
<BOS>Different types of cells in the paranasal sinus and nasal cavity may become malignant.<EOS>
<BOS>Being exposed to certain chemicals or dust in the workplace can increase the risk of paranasal sinus and nasal cavity cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Signs of paranasal sinus and nasal cavity cancer include sinus problems and nosebleeds.<EOS>
<BOS>Tests that examine the sinuses and nasal cavity are used to detect (find) and diagnose paranasal sinus and nasal cavity cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Certain factors affect prognosis (chance of recovery) and treatment options.<EOS>
<BOS>Paranasal sinus and nasal cavity cancer is a disease in which malignant (cancer) cells form in the tissues of the paranasal sinuses and nasal cavity.<EOS>
<BOS>Paranasal sinuses "Paranasal" means near the nose.<EOS>
<BOS>The paranasal sinuses are hollow, airfilled spaces in the bones around the nose.<EOS>
<BOS>The sinuses are lined with cells that make mucus, which keeps the inside of the nose from drying out during breathing.<EOS>
<BOS>There are several paranasal sinuses named after the bones that surround them: The frontal sinuses are in the lower forehead above the nose.<EOS>
<BOS>The maxillary sinuses are in the cheekbones on either side of the nose.<EOS>
<BOS>The ethmoid sinuses are beside the upper nose, between the eyes.<EOS>
<BOS>The sphenoid sinuses are behind the nose, in the center of the skull.<EOS>
<BOS>Nasal cavity The nose opens into the nasal cavity, which is divided into two nasal passages.<EOS>
<BOS>Air moves through these passages during breathing.<EOS>
<BOS>The nasal cavity lies above the bone that forms the roof of the mouth and curves down at the back to join the throat.<EOS>
<BOS>The area just inside the nostrils is called the nasal vestibule.<EOS>
<BOS>A small area of special cells in the roof of each nasal passage sends signals to the brain to give the sense of smell.<EOS>
<BOS>Together the paranasal sinuses and the nasal cavity filter and warm the air, and make it moist before it goes into the lungs.<EOS>
<BOS>The movement of air through the sinuses and other parts of the respiratory system help make sounds for talking.<EOS>
<BOS>Paranasal sinus and nasal cavity cancer is a type of head and neck cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Different types of cells in the paranasal sinus and nasal cavity may become malignant.<EOS>
<BOS>The most common type of paranasal sinus and nasal cavity cancer is squamous cell carcinoma.<EOS>
<BOS>This type of cancer forms in the squamous cells (thin, flat cells) lining the inside of the paranasal sinuses and the nasal cavity.<EOS>
<BOS>Other types of paranasal sinus and nasal cavity cancer include the following: Melanoma: Cancer that starts in cells called melanocytes, the cells that give skin its natural color.<EOS>
<BOS>Sarcoma: Cancer that starts in muscle or connective tissue.<EOS>
<BOS>Inverting papilloma: Benign tumors that form inside the nose.<EOS>
<BOS>A small number of these change into cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Midline granulomas: Cancer of tissues in the middle part of the face.<EOS>
<BOS>Key Points Small intestine cancer is a rare disease in which malignant (cancer) cells form in the tissues of the small intestine.<EOS>
<BOS>There are five types of small intestine cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Diet and health history can affect the risk of developing small intestine cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Signs and symptoms of small intestine cancer include unexplained weight loss and abdominal pain.<EOS>
<BOS>Tests that examine the small intestine are used to detect (find), diagnose, and stage small intestine cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Certain factors affect prognosis (chance of recovery) and treatment options.<EOS>
<BOS>Small intestine cancer is a rare disease in which malignant (cancer) cells form in the tissues of the small intestine.<EOS>
<BOS>The small intestine is part of the bodys digestive system, which also includes the esophagus, stomach, and large intestine.<EOS>
<BOS>The digestive system removes and processes nutrients (vitamins, minerals, carbohydrates, fats, proteins, and water) from foods and helps pass waste material out of the body.<EOS>
<BOS>The small intestine is a long tube that connects the stomach to the large intestine.<EOS>
<BOS>It folds many times to fit inside the abdomen.<EOS>
<BOS>There are five types of small intestine cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>The types of cancer found in the small intestine are adenocarcinoma, sarcoma, carcinoid tumors, gastrointestinal stromal tumor, and lymphoma.<EOS>
<BOS>This summary discusses adenocarcinoma and leiomyosarcoma (a type of sarcoma).<EOS>
<BOS>Adenocarcinoma starts in glandular cells in the lining of the small intestine and is the most common type of small intestine cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Most of these tumors occur in the part of the small intestine near the stomach.<EOS>
<BOS>They may grow and block the intestine.<EOS>
<BOS>Leiomyosarcoma starts in the smooth muscle cells of the small intestine.<EOS>
<BOS>Most of these tumors occur in the part of the small intestine near the large intestine.<EOS>
<BOS>See the following PDQ summaries for more information on small intestine cancer: Adult Soft Tissue Sarcoma Treatment Childhood Soft Tissue Sarcoma Treatment Adult NonHodgkin Lymphoma Treatment Childhood NonHodgkin Lymphoma Treatment Gastrointestinal Carcinoid Tumors Treatment Gastrointestinal Stromal Tumors Treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Tests that examine the eyes, brain, and spinal cord are used to detect (find) and diagnose primary CNS lymphoma.<EOS>
<BOS>The following tests and procedures may be used: Physical exam and history : An exam of the body to check general signs of health, including checking for signs of disease, such as lumps or anything else that seems unusual.<EOS>
<BOS>A history of the patients health habits and past illnesses and treatments will also be taken.<EOS>
<BOS>Neurological exam : A series of questions and tests to check the brain, spinal cord, and nerve function.<EOS>
<BOS>The exam checks a persons mental status, coordination, ability to walk normally, and how well the muscles, senses, and reflexes work.<EOS>
<BOS>This may also be called a neuro exam or a neurologic exam.<EOS>
<BOS>Slitlamp eye exam : An exam that uses a special microscope with a bright, narrow slit of light to check the outside and inside of the eye.<EOS>
<BOS>MRI (magnetic resonance imaging): A procedure that uses a magnet, radio waves, and a computer to make a series of detailed pictures of areas inside the brain and spinal cord.<EOS>
<BOS>A substance called gadolinium is injected into the patient through a vein.<EOS>
<BOS>The gadolinium collects around the cancer cells so they show up brighter in the picture.<EOS>
<BOS>This procedure is also called nuclear magnetic resonance imaging (NMRI).<EOS>
<BOS>PET scan (positron emission tomography scan): A procedure to find malignant tumor cells in the body.<EOS>
<BOS>A small amount of radioactive glucose (sugar) is injected into a vein.<EOS>
<BOS>The PET scanner rotates around the body and makes a picture of where glucose is being used in the body.<EOS>
<BOS>Malignant tumor cells show up brighter in the picture because they are more active and take up more glucose than normal cells do.<EOS>
<BOS>Lumbar puncture : A procedure used to collect cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) from the spinal column.<EOS>
<BOS>This is done by placing a needle between two bones in the spine and into the CSF around the spinal cord and removing a sample of the fluid.<EOS>
<BOS>The sample of CSF is checked under a microscope for signs of tumor cells.<EOS>
<BOS>The sample may also be checked for the amounts of protein and glucose.<EOS>
<BOS>A higher than normal amount of protein or lower than normal amount of glucose may be a sign of a tumor.<EOS>
<BOS>This procedure is also called an LP or spinal tap.<EOS>
<BOS>Stereotactic biopsy : A biopsy procedure that uses a computer and a 3dimensional (3D) scanning device to find a tumor site and guide the removal of tissue so it can be viewed under a microscope to check for signs of cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>The following tests may be done on the samples of tissue that are removed: Flow cytometry : A laboratory test that measures the number of cells in a sample, the percentage of live cells in a sample, and certain characteristics of cells, such as size, shape, and the presence of tumor markers on the cell surface.<EOS>
<BOS>The cells are stained with a lightsensitive dye, placed in a fluid, and passed in a stream before a laser or other type of light.<EOS>
<BOS>The measurements are based on how the lightsensitive dye reacts to the light.<EOS>
<BOS>Immunohistochemistry : A test that uses antibodies to check for certain antigens in a sample of tissue.<EOS>
<BOS>The antibody is usually linked to a radioactive substance or a dye that causes the tissue to light up under a microscope.<EOS>
<BOS>This type of test may be used to tell the difference between different types of cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Cytogenetic analysis: A laboratory test in which cells in a sample of tissue are viewed under a microscope to look for certain changes in the chromosomes.<EOS>
<BOS>Other tests, such as fluorescence in situ hybridization (FISH), may also be done to look for certain changes in the chromosomes.<EOS>
<BOS>Complete blood count (CBC) with differential : A procedure in which a sample of blood is drawn and checked for the following: The number of red blood cells and platelets.<EOS>
<BOS>The number and type of white blood cells.<EOS>
<BOS>The amount of hemoglobin (the protein that carries oxygen) in the red blood cells.<EOS>
<BOS>The portion of the blood sample made up of red blood cells.<EOS>
<BOS>Blood chemistry studies : A procedure in which a blood sample is checked to measure the amounts of certain substances released into the blood by organs and tissues in the body.<EOS>
<BOS>An unusual (higher or lower than normal) amount of a substance can be a sign of disease.<EOS>
<BOS>New types of treatment are being tested in clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>This summary section describes treatments that are being studied in clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>It may not mention every new treatment being studied.<EOS>
<BOS>Information about clinical trials is available from the NCI website.<EOS>
<BOS>New combinations of therapies Clinical trials are studying different combinations of biologic therapy, chemotherapy, steroid therapy, and drugs.<EOS>
<BOS>New treatment regimens using thalidomide or lenalidomide are also being studied.<EOS>
<BOS>Supportive care is given to lessen the problems caused by the disease or its treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>This therapy controls problems or side effects caused by the disease or its treatment, and improves quality of life.<EOS>
<BOS>Supportive care is given to treat problems caused by multiple myeloma and other plasma cell neoplasms.<EOS>
<BOS>Supportive care may include the following: Plasmapheresis: If the blood becomes thick with extra antibody proteins and interferes with circulation, plasmapheresis is done to remove extra plasma and antibody proteins from the blood.<EOS>
<BOS>In this procedure blood is removed from the patient and sent through a machine that separates the plasma (the liquid part of the blood) from the blood cells.<EOS>
<BOS>The patient's plasma contains the unneeded antibodies and is not returned to the patient.<EOS>
<BOS>The normal blood cells are returned to the bloodstream along with donated plasma or a plasma replacement.<EOS>
<BOS>Plasmapheresis does not keep new antibodies from forming.<EOS>
<BOS>Highdose chemotherapy with stem cell transplant: If amyloidosis occurs, treatment may include highdose chemotherapy followed by stem cell transplant using the patient's own stem cells.<EOS>
<BOS>Biologic therapy: Biologic therapy with thalidomide, lenalidomide, or pomalidomide is given to treat amyloidosis.<EOS>
<BOS>Targeted therapy: Targeted therapy with proteasome inhibitors is given to treat amyloidosis.<EOS>
<BOS>Radiation therapy: Radiation therapy is given for bone lesions of the spine.<EOS>
<BOS>Chemotherapy: Chemotherapy is given to reduce back pain from osteoporosis or compression fractures of the spine.<EOS>
<BOS>Bisphosphonate therapy: Bisphosphonate therapy is given to slow bone loss and reduce bone pain.<EOS>
<BOS>See the following PDQ summaries for more information on bisphosphonates and problems related to their use: Cancer Pain Oral Complications of Chemotherapy and Head/Neck Radiation Patients may want to think about taking part in a clinical trial.<EOS>
<BOS>For some patients, taking part in a clinical trial may be the best treatment choice.<EOS>
<BOS>Clinical trials are part of the cancer research process.<EOS>
<BOS>Clinical trials are done to find out if new cancer treatments are safe and effective or better than the standard treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Many of today's standard treatments for cancer are based on earlier clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients who take part in a clinical trial may receive the standard treatment or be among the first to receive a new treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients who take part in clinical trials also help improve the way cancer will be treated in the future.<EOS>
<BOS>Even when clinical trials do not lead to effective new treatments, they often answer important questions and help move research forward.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients can enter clinical trials before, during, or after starting their cancer treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Some clinical trials only include patients who have not yet received treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Other trials test treatments for patients whose cancer has not gotten better.<EOS>
<BOS>There are also clinical trials that test new ways to stop cancer from recurring (coming back) or reduce the side effects of cancer treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Clinical trials are taking place in many parts of the country.<EOS>
<BOS>See the Treatment Options section that follows for links to current treatment clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>These have been retrieved from NCI's listing of clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>Key Points There are different types of treatment for patients with adult brain and spinal cord tumors.<EOS>
<BOS>Five types of standard treatment are used: Active surveillance Surgery Radiation therapy Chemotherapy Targeted therapy Supportive care is given to lessen the problems caused by the disease or its treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>New types of treatment are being tested in clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>Proton beam radiation therapy Biologic therapy Patients may want to think about taking part in a clinical trial.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients can enter clinical trials before, during, or after starting their cancer treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Followup tests may be needed.<EOS>
<BOS>There are different types of treatment for patients with adult brain and spinal cord tumors.<EOS>
<BOS>Different types of treatment are available for patients with adult brain and spinal cord tumors.<EOS>
<BOS>Some treatments are standard (the currently used treatment), and some are being tested in clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>A treatment clinical trial is a research study meant to help improve current treatments or obtain information on new treatments for patients with cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>When clinical trials show that a new treatment is better than the standard treatment, the new treatment may become the standard treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients may want to think about taking part in a clinical trial.<EOS>
<BOS>Some clinical trials are open only to patients who have not started treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Five types of standard treatment are used: Active surveillance Active surveillance is closely watching a patients condition but not giving any treatment unless there are changes in test results that show the condition is getting worse.<EOS>
<BOS>Active surveillance may be used to avoid or delay the need for treatments such as radiation therapy or surgery, which can cause side effects or other problems.<EOS>
<BOS>During active surveillance, certain exams and tests are done on a regular schedule.<EOS>
<BOS>Active surveillance may be used for very slowgrowing tumors that do not cause symptoms.<EOS>
<BOS>Surgery Surgery may be used to diagnose and treat adult brain and spinal cord tumors.<EOS>
<BOS>Removing tumor tissue helps decrease pressure of the tumor on nearby parts of the brain.<EOS>
<BOS>See the General Information section of this summary.<EOS>
<BOS>Even if the doctor removes all the cancer that can be seen at the time of the surgery, some patients may be given chemotherapy or radiation therapy after surgery to kill any cancer cells that are left.<EOS>
<BOS>Treatment given after the surgery, to lower the risk that the cancer will come back, is called adjuvant therapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Radiation therapy Radiation therapy is a cancer treatment that uses highenergy xrays or other types of radiation to kill cancer cells or keep them from growing.<EOS>
<BOS>There are two types of radiation therapy: External radiation therapy uses a machine outside the body to send radiation toward the cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Certain ways of giving radiation therapy can help keep radiation from damaging nearby healthy tissue.<EOS>
<BOS>These types of radiation therapy include the following: Conformal radiation therapy: Conformal radiation therapy is a type of external radiation therapy that uses a computer to make a 3dimensional (3D) picture of the tumor and shapes the radiation beams to fit the tumor.<EOS>
<BOS>Intensitymodulated radiation therapy (IMRT): IMRT is a type of 3dimensional (3D) external radiation therapy that uses a computer to make pictures of the size and shape of the tumor.<EOS>
<BOS>Thin beams of radiation of different intensities (strengths) are aimed at the tumor from many angles.<EOS>
<BOS>Stereotactic radiosurgery: Stereotactic radiosurgery is a type of external radiation therapy.<EOS>
<BOS>A rigid head frame is attached to the skull to keep the head still during the radiation treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>A machine aims a single large dose of radiation directly at the tumor.<EOS>
<BOS>This procedure does not involve surgery.<EOS>
<BOS>It is also called stereotaxic radiosurgery, radiosurgery, and radiation surgery.<EOS>
<BOS>Internal radiation therapy uses a radioactive substance sealed in needles, seeds, wires, or catheters that are placed directly into or near the cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>The way the radiation therapy is given depends on the type and grade of tumor and where it is in the brain or spinal cord.<EOS>
<BOS>External radiation therapy is used to treat adult central nervous system tumors.<EOS>
<BOS>Chemotherapy Chemotherapy is a cancer treatment that uses drugs to stop the growth of cancer cells, either by killing the cells or by stopping them from dividing.<EOS>
<BOS>When chemotherapy is taken by mouth or injected into a vein or muscle, the drugs enter the bloodstream and can reach cancer cells throughout the body (systemic chemotherapy).<EOS>
<BOS>When chemotherapy is placed directly into the cerebrospinal fluid, an organ, or a body cavity such as the abdomen, the drugs mainly affect cancer cells in those areas (regional chemotherapy).<EOS>
<BOS>Combination chemotherapy is treatment using more than one anticancer drug.<EOS>
<BOS>To treat brain tumors, a wafer that dissolves may be used to deliver an anticancer drug directly to the brain tumor site after the tumor has been removed by surgery.<EOS>
<BOS>The way the chemotherapy is given depends on the type and grade of tumor and where it is in the brain.<EOS>
<BOS>Anticancer drugs given by mouth or vein to treat brain and spinal cord tumors cannot cross the bloodbrain barrier and enter the fluid that surrounds the brain and spinal cord.<EOS>
<BOS>Instead, an anticancer drug is injected into the fluidfilled space to kill cancer cells there.<EOS>
<BOS>This is called intrathecal chemotherapy.<EOS>
<BOS>See Drugs Approved for Brain Tumors for more information.<EOS>
<BOS>Targeted therapy Targeted therapy is a type of treatment that uses drugs or other substances to identify and attack specific cancer cells without harming normal cells.<EOS>
<BOS>Monoclonal antibody therapy is a type of targeted therapy that uses antibodies made in the laboratory from a single type of immune system cell.<EOS>
<BOS>These antibodies can identify substances on cancer cells or normal substances that may help cancer cells grow.<EOS>
<BOS>The antibodies attach to the substances and kill the cancer cells, block their growth, or keep them from spreading.<EOS>
<BOS>Monoclonal antibodies are given by infusion.<EOS>
<BOS>They may be used alone or to carry drugs, toxins, or radioactive material directly to cancer cells.<EOS>
<BOS>Bevacizumab is a monoclonal antibody that binds to a protein called vascular endothelial growth factor (VEGF) and may prevent the growth of new blood vessels that tumors need to grow.<EOS>
<BOS>Bevacizumab is used in the treatment of recurrent glioblastoma.<EOS>
<BOS>Other types of targeted therapies are being studied for adult brain tumors, including tyrosine kinase inhibitors and new VEGF inhibitors.<EOS>
<BOS>See Drugs Approved for Brain Tumors for more information.<EOS>
<BOS>Supportive care is given to lessen the problems caused by the disease or its treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>This therapy controls problems or side effects caused by the disease or its treatment and improves quality of life.<EOS>
<BOS>For brain tumors, supportive care includes drugs to control seizures and fluid buildup or swelling in the brain.<EOS>
<BOS>New types of treatment are being tested in clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>This summary section refers to new treatments being studied in clinical trials, but it may not mention every new treatment being studied.<EOS>
<BOS>Information about clinical trials is available from the NCI website.<EOS>
<BOS>Proton beam radiation therapy Proton beam radiation therapy is a type of highenergy, external radiation therapy that uses streams of protons (small, positivelycharged pieces of matter) to make radiation.<EOS>
<BOS>This type of radiation kills tumor cells with little damage to nearby tissues.<EOS>
<BOS>It is used to treat cancers of the head, neck, and spine and organs such as the brain, eye, lung, and prostate.<EOS>
<BOS>Proton beam radiation is different from xray radiation.<EOS>
<BOS>Biologic therapy Biologic therapy is a treatment that uses the patients immune system to fight cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Substances made by the body or made in a laboratory are used to boost, direct, or restore the bodys natural defenses against cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>This type of cancer treatment is also called biotherapy or immunotherapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Biologic therapy is being studied for the treatment of some types of brain tumors.<EOS>
<BOS>Treatments may include the following: Dendritic cell vaccine therapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Gene therapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients may want to think about taking part in a clinical trial.<EOS>
<BOS>For some patients, taking part in a clinical trial may be the best treatment choice.<EOS>
<BOS>Clinical trials are part of the cancer research process.<EOS>
<BOS>Clinical trials are done to find out if new cancer treatments are safe and effective or better than the standard treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Many of today's standard treatments for cancer are based on earlier clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients who take part in a clinical trial may receive the standard treatment or be among the first to receive a new treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients who take part in clinical trials also help improve the way cancer will be treated in the future.<EOS>
<BOS>Even when clinical trials do not lead to effective new treatments, they often answer important questions and help move research forward.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients can enter clinical trials before, during, or after starting their cancer treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Some clinical trials only include patients who have not yet received treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Other trials test treatments for patients whose cancer has not gotten better.<EOS>
<BOS>There are also clinical trials that test new ways to stop cancer from recurring (coming back) or reduce the side effects of cancer treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Clinical trials are taking place in many parts of the country.<EOS>
<BOS>See the Treatment Options section that follows for links to current treatment clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>These have been retrieved from NCI's listing of clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>Followup tests may be needed.<EOS>
<BOS>Some of the tests that were done to diagnose the cancer or to find out the stage of the cancer may be repeated.<EOS>
<BOS>Some tests will be repeated in order to see how well the treatment is working.<EOS>
<BOS>Decisions about whether to continue, change, or stop treatment may be based on the results of these tests.<EOS>
<BOS>Some of the tests will continue to be done from time to time after treatment has ended.<EOS>
<BOS>The results of these tests can show if your condition has changed or if the cancer has recurred (come back).<EOS>
<BOS>These tests are sometimes called followup tests or checkups.<EOS>
<BOS>The following tests and procedures may be used to check whether a brain tumor has come back after treatment: SPECT scan (single photon emission computed tomography scan): A procedure that uses a special camera linked to a computer to make a 3dimensional (3D) picture of the brain.<EOS>
<BOS>A very small amount of a radioactive substance is injected into a vein or inhaled through the nose.<EOS>
<BOS>As the substance travels through the blood, the camera rotates around the head and takes pictures of the brain.<EOS>
<BOS>Blood flow and metabolism are higher than normal in areas where cancer cells are growing.<EOS>
<BOS>These areas will show up brighter in the picture.<EOS>
<BOS>This procedure may be done just before or after a CT scan.<EOS>
<BOS>PET scan (positron emission tomography scan): A procedure to find malignant tumor cells in the body.<EOS>
<BOS>A small amount of radioactive glucose (sugar) is injected into a vein.<EOS>
<BOS>The PET scanner rotates around the body and makes a picture of where glucose is being used in the brain.<EOS>
<BOS>Malignant tumor cells show up brighter in the picture because they are more active and take up more glucose than normal cells do.<EOS>
<BOS>Treatment Options by Type of Primary Adult Brain Tumor Astrocytic Tumors Brain Stem Gliomas Treatment of brain stem gliomas may include the following: Radiation therapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Check the list of NCIsupported cancer clinical trials that are now accepting patients with adult brain stem glioma.<EOS>
<BOS>For more specific results, refine the search by using other search features, such as the location of the trial, the type of treatment, or the name of the drug.<EOS>
<BOS>Talk with your doctor about clinical trials that may be right for you.<EOS>
<BOS>General information about clinical trials is available from the NCI website.<EOS>

<BOS>Germ Cell Tumors There is no standard treatment for germ cell tumors (germinoma, embryonal carcinoma, choriocarcinoma, and teratoma).<EOS>

<BOS>Key Points Wilms tumors are staged during surgery and with imaging tests.<EOS>
<BOS>There are three ways that cancer spreads in the body.<EOS>
<BOS>Cancer may spread from where it began to other parts of the body.<EOS>
<BOS>In addition to the stages, Wilms tumors are described by their histology.<EOS>
<BOS>The following stages are used for both favorable histology and anaplastic Wilms tumors: Stage I Stage II Stage III Stage IV Stage V The treatment of other childhood kidney tumors depends on the tumor type.<EOS>
<BOS>Wilms tumors are staged during surgery and with imaging tests.<EOS>
<BOS>The process used to find out if cancer has spread outside of the kidney to other parts of the body is called staging.<EOS>
<BOS>The information gathered from the staging process determines the stage of the disease.<EOS>
<BOS>It is important to know the stage in order to plan treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>The doctor will use results of the diagnostic and staging tests to help find out the stage of the disease.<EOS>
<BOS>The following tests may be done to see if cancer has spread to other places in the body: Lymph node biopsy : A surgical procedure in which lymph nodes in the abdomen are removed and a sample of tissue is checked under a microscope for signs of cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>This procedure is also called lymphadenectomy or lymph node dissection.<EOS>
<BOS>Liver function test : A procedure in which a blood sample is checked to measure the amounts of certain substances released into the blood by the liver.<EOS>
<BOS>A higher than normal amount of a substance can be a sign that the liver is not working as it should.<EOS>
<BOS>Xray of the chest and bones: An xray is a type of energy beam that can go through the body and onto film, making a picture of areas inside the body, such as the chest.<EOS>
<BOS>CT scan (CAT scan): A procedure that makes a series of detailed pictures of areas inside the body, such as the abdomen, pelvis, chest, and brain, taken from different angles.<EOS>
<BOS>The pictures are made by a computer linked to an xray machine.<EOS>
<BOS>A dye is injected into a vein or swallowed to help the organs or tissues show up more clearly.<EOS>
<BOS>This procedure is also called computed tomography, computerized tomography, or computerized axial tomography.<EOS>
<BOS>PETCT scan : A procedure that combines the pictures from a positron emission tomography (PET) scan and a computed tomography (CT) scan.<EOS>
<BOS>The PET and CT scans are done at the same time on the same machine.<EOS>
<BOS>The pictures from both scans are combined to make a more detailed picture than either test would make by itself.<EOS>
<BOS>A PET scan is a procedure to find malignant tumor cells in the body.<EOS>
<BOS>A small amount of radioactive glucose (sugar) is injected into a vein.<EOS>
<BOS>The PET scanner rotates around the body and makes a picture of where glucose is being used in the body.<EOS>
<BOS>Malignant tumor cells show up brighter in the picture because they are more active and take up more glucose than normal cells do.<EOS>
<BOS>MRI (magnetic resonance imaging): A procedure that uses a magnet, radio waves, and a computer to make a series of detailed pictures of areas inside the body, such as the abdomen, pelvis, and brain.<EOS>
<BOS>This procedure is also called nuclear magnetic resonance imaging (NMRI).<EOS>
<BOS>Bone scan : A procedure to check if there are rapidly dividing cells, such as cancer cells, in the bone.<EOS>
<BOS>A very small amount of radioactive material is injected into a vein and travels through the bloodstream.<EOS>
<BOS>The radioactive material collects in the bones with cancer and is detected by a scanner.<EOS>
<BOS>Ultrasound exam: A procedure in which highenergy sound waves (ultrasound) are bounced off internal tissues or organs and make echoes.<EOS>
<BOS>The echoes form a picture of body tissues called a sonogram.<EOS>
<BOS>An ultrasound of the major heart vessels is done to stage Wilms tumor.<EOS>
<BOS>Cystoscopy : A procedure to look inside the bladder and urethra to check for abnormal areas.<EOS>
<BOS>A cystoscope is inserted through the urethra into the bladder.<EOS>
<BOS>A cystoscope is a thin, tubelike instrument with a light and a lens for viewing.<EOS>
<BOS>It may also have a tool to remove tissue samples, which are checked under a microscope for signs of cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>There are three ways that cancer spreads in the body.<EOS>
<BOS>Cancer can spread through tissue, the lymph system, and the blood: Tissue.<EOS>
<BOS>The cancer spreads from where it began by growing into nearby areas.<EOS>
<BOS>Lymph system.<EOS>
<BOS>The cancer spreads from where it began by getting into the lymph system.<EOS>
<BOS>The cancer travels through the lymph vessels to other parts of the body.<EOS>
<BOS>Blood.<EOS>
<BOS>The cancer spreads from where it began by getting into the blood.<EOS>
<BOS>The cancer travels through the blood vessels to other parts of the body.<EOS>
<BOS>Cancer may spread from where it began to other parts of the body.<EOS>
<BOS>When cancer spreads to another part of the body, it is called metastasis.<EOS>
<BOS>Cancer cells break away from where they began (the primary tumor) and travel through the lymph system or blood.<EOS>
<BOS>Lymph system.<EOS>
<BOS>The cancer gets into the lymph system, travels through the lymph vessels, and forms a tumor (metastatic tumor) in another part of the body.<EOS>
<BOS>Blood.<EOS>
<BOS>The cancer gets into the blood, travels through the blood vessels, and forms a tumor (metastatic tumor) in another part of the body.<EOS>
<BOS>The metastatic tumor is the same type of cancer as the primary tumor.<EOS>
<BOS>For example, if Wilms tumor spreads to the lung, the cancer cells in the lung are actually Wilms tumor cells.<EOS>
<BOS>The disease is metastatic Wilms tumor, not lung cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>In addition to the stages, Wilms tumors are described by their histology.<EOS>
<BOS>The histology (how the cells look under a microscope) of the tumor affects the prognosis and the treatment of Wilms tumor.<EOS>
<BOS>The histology may be favorable or anaplastic (unfavorable).<EOS>
<BOS>Tumors with a favorable histology have a better prognosis and respond better to chemotherapy than anaplastic tumors.<EOS>
<BOS>Tumor cells that are anaplastic divide quickly and under a microscope do not look like the type of cells they came from.<EOS>
<BOS>Anaplastic tumors are harder to treat with chemotherapy than other Wilms tumors at the same stage.<EOS>
<BOS>The following stages are used for both favorable histology and anaplastic Wilms tumors: Stage I In stage I, the tumor was completely removed by surgery and all of the following are true: Cancer was found only in the kidney and had not spread to blood vessels in the renal sinus (the part of the kidney where it joins the ureter) or to the lymph nodes.<EOS>
<BOS>The outer layer of the kidney did not break open.<EOS>
<BOS>The tumor did not break open.<EOS>
<BOS>A biopsy was not done before the tumor was removed.<EOS>
<BOS>No cancer cells were found at the edges of the area where the tumor was removed.<EOS>
<BOS>Stage II In stage II, the tumor was completely removed by surgery and no cancer cells were found at the edges of the area where the cancer was removed.<EOS>
<BOS>Cancer has not spread to lymph nodes.<EOS>
<BOS>Before the tumor was removed, one of the following was true: Cancer had spread to the renal sinus (the part of the kidney where it joins the ureter).<EOS>
<BOS>Cancer had spread to blood vessels outside the area of the kidney where urine is made, such as the renal sinus.<EOS>
<BOS>Stage III In stage III, cancer remains in the abdomen after surgery and one of the following may be true: Cancer has spread to lymph nodes in the abdomen or pelvis (the part of the body between the hips).<EOS>
<BOS>Cancer has spread to or through the surface of the peritoneum (the layer of tissue that lines the abdominal cavity and covers most organs in the abdomen).<EOS>
<BOS>A biopsy of the tumor was done before it was removed.<EOS>
<BOS>The tumor broke open before or during surgery to remove it.<EOS>
<BOS>The tumor was removed in more than one piece.<EOS>
<BOS>Cancer cells are found at the edges of the area where the tumor was removed.<EOS>
<BOS>The entire tumor could not be removed because important organs or tissues in the body would be damaged.<EOS>
<BOS>Stage IV In stage IV, cancer has spread through the blood to organs such as the lungs, liver, bone, or brain, or to lymph nodes outside of the abdomen and pelvis.<EOS>
<BOS>Stage V In stage V, cancer cells are found in both kidneys when the cancer is first diagnosed.<EOS>
<BOS>The treatment of other childhood kidney tumors depends on the tumor type.<EOS>
<BOS>New types of treatment are being tested in clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>Information about clinical trials is available from the NCI website.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients may want to think about taking part in a clinical trial.<EOS>
<BOS>For some patients, taking part in a clinical trial may be the best treatment choice.<EOS>
<BOS>Clinical trials are part of the cancer research process.<EOS>
<BOS>Clinical trials are done to find out if new cancer treatments are safe and effective or better than the standard treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Many of today's standard treatments for cancer are based on earlier clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients who take part in a clinical trial may receive the standard treatment or be among the first to receive a new treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients who take part in clinical trials also help improve the way cancer will be treated in the future.<EOS>
<BOS>Even when clinical trials do not lead to effective new treatments, they often answer important questions and help move research forward.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients can enter clinical trials before, during, or after starting their cancer treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Some clinical trials only include patients who have not yet received treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Other trials test treatments for patients whose cancer has not gotten better.<EOS>
<BOS>There are also clinical trials that test new ways to stop cancer from recurring (coming back) or reduce the side effects of cancer treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Clinical trials are taking place in many parts of the country.<EOS>
<BOS>See the Treatment Options section that follows for links to current treatment clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>These have been retrieved from NCI's listing of clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>Signs and symptoms of myelodysplastic/myeloproliferative neoplasm, unclassifiable, include fever, weight loss, and feeling very tired.<EOS>
