<BOS>These and other signs and symptoms may be caused by MDS/MPNUC or by other conditions.<EOS>
<BOS>Check with your doctor if you have any of the following: Fever or frequent infections.<EOS>
<BOS>Shortness of breath.<EOS>
<BOS>Feeling very tired and weak.<EOS>
<BOS>Pale skin.<EOS>
<BOS>Easy bruising or bleeding.<EOS>
<BOS>Petechiae (flat, pinpoint spots under the skin caused by bleeding).<EOS>
<BOS>Pain or a feeling of fullness below the ribs.<EOS>
<BOS>Certain factors affect prognosis (chance of recovery) and treatment options.<EOS>
<BOS>The prognosis (chance of recovery) and treatment options depend on: The type of tumor and where it is in the brain.<EOS>
<BOS>Whether the cancer has spread within the brain and spinal cord when the tumor is found.<EOS>
<BOS>The age of the child when the tumor is found.<EOS>
<BOS>How much of the tumor remains after surgery.<EOS>
<BOS>Whether there are certain changes in the chromosomes, genes, or brain cells.<EOS>
<BOS>Whether the tumor has just been diagnosed or has recurred (come back).<EOS>
<BOS>Key Points Once adult acute myeloid leukemia (AML) has been diagnosed, tests are done to find out if the cancer has spread to other parts of the body.<EOS>
<BOS>There is no standard staging system for adult AML.<EOS>
<BOS>Once adult acute myeloid leukemia (AML) has been diagnosed, tests are done to find out if the cancer has spread to other parts of the body.<EOS>
<BOS>The extent or spread of cancer is usually described as stages.<EOS>
<BOS>In adult acute myeloid leukemia (AML), the subtype of AML and whether the leukemia has spread outside the blood and bone marrow are used instead of the stage to plan treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>The following tests and procedures may be used to determine if the leukemia has spread: Lumbar puncture : A procedure used to collect a sample of cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) from the spinal column.<EOS>
<BOS>This is done by placing a needle between two bones in the spine and into the CSF around the spinal cord and removing a sample of the fluid.<EOS>
<BOS>The sample of CSF is checked under a microscope for signs that leukemia cells have spread to the brain and spinal cord.<EOS>
<BOS>This procedure is also called an LP or spinal tap.<EOS>
<BOS>CT scan (CAT scan): A procedure that makes a series of detailed pictures of the abdomen, taken from different angles.<EOS>
<BOS>The pictures are made by a computer linked to an xray machine.<EOS>
<BOS>A dye may be injected into a vein or swallowed to help the organs or tissues show up more clearly.<EOS>
<BOS>This procedure is also called computed tomography, computerized tomography, or computerized axial tomography.<EOS>
<BOS>There is no standard staging system for adult AML.<EOS>
<BOS>The disease is described as untreated, in remission, or recurrent.<EOS>
<BOS>Untreated adult AML In untreated adult AML, the disease is newly diagnosed.<EOS>
<BOS>It has not been treated except to relieve signs and symptoms such as fever, bleeding, or pain, and the following are true: The complete blood count is abnormal.<EOS>
<BOS>At least 20% of the cells in the bone marrow are blasts (leukemia cells).<EOS>
<BOS>There are signs or symptoms of leukemia.<EOS>
<BOS>Adult AML in remission In adult AML in remission, the disease has been treated and the following are true: The complete blood count is normal.<EOS>
<BOS>Less than 5% of the cells in the bone marrow are blasts (leukemia cells).<EOS>
<BOS>There are no signs or symptoms of leukemia in the brain and spinal cord or elsewhere in the body.<EOS>
<BOS>Recurrent Adult AML Recurrent AML is cancer that has recurred (come back) after it has been treated.<EOS>
<BOS>The AML may come back in the blood or bone marrow.<EOS>
<BOS>Signs of intraocular melanoma include blurred vision or a dark spot on the iris.<EOS>
<BOS>Intraocular melanoma may not cause early signs or symptoms.<EOS>
<BOS>It is sometimes found during a regular eye exam when the doctor dilates the pupil and looks into the eye.<EOS>
<BOS>Signs and symptoms may be caused by intraocular melanoma or by other conditions.<EOS>
<BOS>Check with your doctor if you have any of the following: Blurred vision or other change in vision.<EOS>
<BOS>Floaters (spots that drift in your field of vision) or flashes of light.<EOS>
<BOS>A dark spot on the iris.<EOS>
<BOS>A change in the size or shape of the pupil.<EOS>
<BOS>A change in the position of the eyeball in the eye socket.<EOS>
<BOS>Key Points Urethral cancer is a disease in which malignant (cancer) cells form in the tissues of the urethra.<EOS>
<BOS>There are different types of urethral cancer that begin in cells that line the urethra.<EOS>
<BOS>A history of bladder cancer can affect the risk of urethral cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Signs of urethral cancer include bleeding or trouble with urination.<EOS>
<BOS>Tests that examine the urethra and bladder are used to detect (find) and diagnose urethral cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Certain factors affect prognosis (chance of recovery) and treatment options.<EOS>
<BOS>Urethral cancer is a disease in which malignant (cancer) cells form in the tissues of the urethra.<EOS>
<BOS>The urethra is the tube that carries urine from the bladder to outside the body.<EOS>
<BOS>In women, the urethra is about 1 inches long and is just above the vagina.<EOS>
<BOS>In men, the urethra is about 8 inches long, and goes through the prostate gland and the penis to the outside of the body.<EOS>
<BOS>In men, the urethra also carries semen.<EOS>
<BOS>Urethral cancer is a rare cancer that occurs more often in men than in women.<EOS>
<BOS>There are different types of urethral cancer that begin in cells that line the urethra.<EOS>
<BOS>These cancers are named for the types of cells that become malignant (cancer): Squamous cell carcinoma is the most common type of urethral cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>It forms in cells in the part of the urethra near the bladder in women, and in the lining of the urethra in the penis in men.<EOS>
<BOS>Transitional cell carcinoma forms in the area near the urethral opening in women, and in the part of the urethra that goes through the prostate gland in men.<EOS>
<BOS>Adenocarcinoma forms in the glands that are around the urethra in both men and women.<EOS>
<BOS>Urethral cancer can metastasize (spread) quickly to tissues around the urethra and is often found in nearby lymph nodes by the time it is diagnosed.<EOS>
<BOS>A history of bladder cancer can affect the risk of urethral cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Anything that increases your chance of getting a disease is called a risk factor.<EOS>
<BOS>Having a risk factor does not mean that you will get cancer; not having risk factors doesnt mean that you will not get cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Talk with your doctor if you think you may be at risk.<EOS>
<BOS>Risk factors for urethral cancer include the following: Having a history of bladder cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Having conditions that cause chronic inflammation in the urethra, including: Sexually transmitted diseases (STDs), including human papillomavirus (HPV), especially HPV type 16.<EOS>
<BOS>Frequent urinary tract infections (UTIs).<EOS>
<BOS>Tests that examine the brain and spinal cord are used to diagnose adult brain and spinal cord tumors.<EOS>
<BOS>The following tests and procedures may be used: Physical exam and history : An exam of the body to check general signs of health, including checking for signs of disease, such as lumps or anything else that seems unusual.<EOS>
<BOS>A history of the patients health habits and past illnesses and treatments will also be taken.<EOS>
<BOS>Neurological exam : A series of questions and tests to check the brain, spinal cord, and nerve function.<EOS>
<BOS>The exam checks a persons mental status, coordination, and ability to walk normally, and how well the muscles, senses, and reflexes work.<EOS>
<BOS>This may also be called a neuro exam or a neurologic exam.<EOS>
<BOS>Visual field exam: An exam to check a persons field of vision (the total area in which objects can be seen).<EOS>
<BOS>This test measures both central vision (how much a person can see when looking straight ahead) and peripheral vision (how much a person can see in all other directions while staring straight ahead).<EOS>
<BOS>Any loss of vision may be a sign of a tumor that has damaged or pressed on the parts of the brain that affect eyesight.<EOS>
<BOS>Tumor marker test : A procedure in which a sample of blood, urine, or tissue is checked to measure the amounts of certain substances made by organs, tissues, or tumor cells in the body.<EOS>
<BOS>Certain substances are linked to specific types of cancer when found in increased levels in the body.<EOS>
<BOS>These are called tumor markers.<EOS>
<BOS>This test may be done to diagnose a germ cell tumor.<EOS>
<BOS>Gene testing : A laboratory test in which a sample of blood or tissue is tested for changes in a chromosome that has been linked with a certain type of brain tumor.<EOS>
<BOS>This test may be done to diagnose an inherited syndrome.<EOS>
<BOS>CT scan (CAT scan): A procedure that makes a series of detailed pictures of areas inside the body, taken from different angles.<EOS>
<BOS>The pictures are made by a computer linked to an xray machine.<EOS>
<BOS>A dye may be injected into a vein or swallowed to help the organs or tissues show up more clearly.<EOS>
<BOS>This procedure is also called computed tomography, computerized tomography, or computerized axial tomography.<EOS>
<BOS>MRI (magnetic resonance imaging) with gadolinium : A procedure that uses a magnet, radio waves, and a computer to make a series of detailed pictures of the brain and spinal cord.<EOS>
<BOS>A substance called gadolinium is injected into a vein.<EOS>
<BOS>The gadolinium collects around the cancer cells so they show up brighter in the picture.<EOS>
<BOS>This procedure is also called nuclear magnetic resonance imaging (NMRI).<EOS>
<BOS>MRI is often used to diagnose tumors in the spinal cord.<EOS>
<BOS>Sometimes a procedure called magnetic resonance spectroscopy (MRS) is done during the MRI scan.<EOS>
<BOS>An MRS is used to diagnose tumors, based on their chemical makeup.<EOS>
<BOS>SPECT scan (single photon emission computed tomography scan): A procedure that uses a special camera linked to a computer to make a 3dimensional (3D) picture of the brain.<EOS>
<BOS>A very small amount of a radioactive substance is injected into a vein or inhaled through the nose.<EOS>
<BOS>As the substance travels through the blood, the camera rotates around the head and takes pictures of the brain.<EOS>
<BOS>Blood flow and metabolism are higher than normal in areas where cancer cells are growing.<EOS>
<BOS>These areas will show up brighter in the picture.<EOS>
<BOS>This procedure may be done just before or after a CT scan.<EOS>
<BOS>SPECT is used to tell the difference between a primary tumor and a tumor that has spread to the brain from somewhere else in the body.<EOS>
<BOS>PET scan (positron emission tomography scan): A procedure to find malignant tumor cells in the body.<EOS>
<BOS>A small amount of radioactive glucose (sugar) is injected into a vein.<EOS>
<BOS>The PET scanner rotates around the body and makes a picture of where glucose is being used in the brain.<EOS>
<BOS>Malignant tumor cells show up brighter in the picture because they are more active and take up more glucose than normal cells do.<EOS>
<BOS>PET is used to tell the difference between a primary tumor and a tumor that has spread to the brain from somewhere else in the body.<EOS>
<BOS>A biopsy is also used to diagnose a brain tumor.<EOS>
<BOS>If imaging tests show there may be a brain tumor, a biopsy is usually done.<EOS>
<BOS>One of the following types of biopsies may be used: Stereotactic biopsy : When imaging tests show there may be a tumor deep in the brain in a hard to reach place, a stereotactic brain biopsy may be done.<EOS>
<BOS>This kind of biopsy uses a computer and a 3dimensional (3D) scanning device to find the tumor and guide the needle used to remove the tissue.<EOS>
<BOS>A small incision is made in the scalp and a small hole is drilled through the skull.<EOS>
<BOS>A biopsy needle is inserted through the hole to remove cells or tissues so they can be viewed under a microscope by a pathologist to check for signs of cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Open biopsy : When imaging tests show that there may be a tumor that can be removed by surgery, an open biopsy may be done.<EOS>
<BOS>A part of the skull is removed in an operation called a craniotomy.<EOS>
<BOS>A sample of brain tissue is removed and viewed under a microscope by a pathologist.<EOS>
<BOS>If cancer cells are found, some or all of the tumor may be removed during the same surgery.<EOS>
<BOS>Tests are done before surgery to find the areas around the tumor that are important for normal brain function.<EOS>
<BOS>There are also ways to test brain function during surgery.<EOS>
<BOS>The doctor will use the results of these tests to remove as much of the tumor as possible with the least damage to normal tissue in the brain.<EOS>
<BOS>The pathologist checks the biopsy sample to find out the type and grade of brain tumor.<EOS>
<BOS>The grade of the tumor is based on how the tumor cells look under a microscope and how quickly the tumor is likely to grow and spread.<EOS>
<BOS>The following tests may be done on the tumor tissue that is removed: Immunohistochemistry : A test that uses antibodies to check for certain antigens in a sample of tissue.<EOS>
<BOS>The antibody is usually linked to a radioactive substance or a dye that causes the tissue to light up under a microscope.<EOS>
<BOS>This type of test may be used to tell the difference between different types of cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Light and electron microscopy : A laboratory test in which cells in a sample of tissue are viewed under regular and highpowered microscopes to look for certain changes in the cells.<EOS>
<BOS>Cytogenetic analysis : A laboratory test in which cells in a sample of tissue are viewed under a microscope to look for certain changes in the chromosomes.<EOS>
<BOS>Sometimes a biopsy or surgery cannot be done.<EOS>
<BOS>For some tumors, a biopsy or surgery cannot be done safely because of where the tumor formed in the brain or spinal cord.<EOS>
<BOS>These tumors are diagnosed and treated based on the results of imaging tests and other procedures.<EOS>
<BOS>Sometimes the results of imaging tests and other procedures show that the tumor is very likely to be benign and a biopsy is not done.<EOS>
<BOS>Key Points Avoiding risk factors and increasing protective factors may help prevent cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>The following are risk factors for oral cavity cancer and oropharyngeal cancer: Tobacco use Alcohol use Tobacco and alcohol use Betel quid or gutka chewing Personal history of head and neck cancer The following is a risk factor for oropharyngeal cancer: HPV infection The following is a protective factor for oral cavity cancer and oropharyngeal cancer: Quitting smoking It is not clear whether avoiding certain risk factors will decrease the risk of oral cavity cancer or oropharyngeal cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Cancer prevention clinical trials are used to study ways to prevent cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>New ways to prevent oral cavity cancer and oropharyngeal cancer are being studied in clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>Avoiding risk factors and increasing protective factors may help prevent cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Avoiding cancer risk factors may help prevent certain cancers.<EOS>
<BOS>Risk factors include smoking, being overweight, and not getting enough exercise.<EOS>
<BOS>Increasing protective factors such as quitting smoking and exercising may also help prevent some cancers.<EOS>
<BOS>Talk to your doctor or other health care professional about how you might lower your risk of cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Oral cavity cancer and oropharyngeal cancer are two different diseases, but they have some risk factors in common.<EOS>
<BOS>The following are risk factors for oral cavity cancer and oropharyngeal cancer: Tobacco use Using tobacco is the most common cause of oral cavity cancer and oropharyngeal cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>The risk of these cancers is about 5 to 10 times higher for current smokers than for people who have never smoked.<EOS>
<BOS>The use of all types of tobacco, including cigarettes, pipes, cigars, and smokeless tobacco (snuff and chewing tobacco) can cause cancer of the oral cavity and oropharynx.<EOS>
<BOS>For cigarette smokers, the risk of oral cavity cancer and oropharyngeal cancer increases with the number of cigarettes smoked per day.<EOS>
<BOS>Alcohol use Using alcohol is also an important risk factor for oral cavity cancer and oropharyngeal cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>The risk of oral cavity cancer and oropharyngeal cancer increases with the number of alcoholic drinks consumed per day.<EOS>
<BOS>The risk of oral cavity cancer and oropharyngeal cancer is about twice as high in people who have 3 to 4 alcoholic drinks per day and 5 times higher in people who have 5 or more alcoholic drinks per day compared with those who don't drink alcohol.<EOS>
<BOS>Tobacco and alcohol use The risk of oral cavity cancer and oropharyngeal cancer is 2 to 3 times higher in people who use both tobacco and alcohol than it is in people who use only tobacco or only alcohol.<EOS>
<BOS>The risk of oral cavity cancer and oropharyngeal cancer is about 35 times higher in people who smoke 2 or more packs of cigarettes per day and have more than 4 alcoholic drinks per day than it is in people who have never smoked cigarettes or consumed alcohol.<EOS>
<BOS>Betel quid or gutka chewing Chewing betel quid or gutka (betel quid mixed with tobacco) has been shown to increase the risk of oral cavity cancer and oropharyngeal cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Betel quid contains areca nut, which is a cancercausing substance.<EOS>
<BOS>The risk of oral cavity cancer and oropharyngeal cancer increases with how long and how often betel quid or gutka are chewed.<EOS>
<BOS>The risk for oral cavity cancer and oropharyngeal cancer is higher when chewing gutka than when chewing betel quid alone.<EOS>
<BOS>Betel quid and gutka chewing is common in many countries in South Asia and Southeast Asia, including China and India.<EOS>
<BOS>Personal history of head and neck cancer A personal history of head and neck cancer increases the risk of oral cavity cancer and oropharyngeal cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>The following is a risk factor for oropharyngeal cancer: HPV infection Being infected with certain types of HPV, especially HPV type 16, increases the risk of oropharyngeal cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>HPV infection is spread mainly through sexual contact.<EOS>
<BOS>The risk of oropharyngeal cancer is about 15 times higher in people who have oral HPV 16 infection compared with people who do not have oral HPV 16 infection.<EOS>
<BOS>It is not clear whether avoiding certain risk factors will decrease the risk of oral cavity cancer or oropharyngeal cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>It has not been proven that stopping alcohol use will decrease the risk of oral cavity cancer or oropharyngeal cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Getting an HPV vaccination greatly lessens the risk of oral HPV infection.<EOS>
<BOS>It is not yet known whether getting an HPV vaccination at any age will decrease the risk of oropharyngeal cancer from HPV infection.<EOS>
<BOS>Having hepatitis or cirrhosis can increase the risk of developing liver cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Anything that increases the chance of getting a disease is called a risk factor.<EOS>
<BOS>Having a risk factor does not mean that you will get cancer; not having risk factors doesn't mean that you will not get cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>People who think they may be at risk should discuss this with their doctor.<EOS>
<BOS>Risk factors for liver cancer include: Having hepatitis B or hepatitis C; having both hepatitis B and hepatitis C increases the risk even more.<EOS>
<BOS>Having cirrhosis, which can be caused by: hepatitis (especially hepatitis C); or drinking large amounts of alcohol for many years or being an alcoholic.<EOS>
<BOS>Eating foods tainted with aflatoxin (poison from a fungus that can grow on foods, such as grains and nuts, that have not been stored properly).<EOS>
<BOS>Key Points There are different types of treatment for patients with plasma cell neoplasms.<EOS>
<BOS>Eight types of treatment are used: Chemotherapy Other drug therapy Targeted therapy Highdose chemotherapy with stem cell transplant Biologic therapy Radiation therapy Surgery Watchful waiting New types of treatment are being tested in clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>New combinations of therapies Supportive care is given to lessen the problems caused by the disease or its treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients may want to think about taking part in a clinical trial.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients can enter clinical trials before, during, or after starting their cancer treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Followup tests may be needed.<EOS>
<BOS>There are different types of treatment for patients with plasma cell neoplasms.<EOS>
<BOS>Different types of treatments are available for patients with plasma cell neoplasms.<EOS>
<BOS>Some treatments are standard (the currently used treatment), and some are being tested in clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>A treatment clinical trial is a research study meant to help improve current treatments or obtain information on new treatments for patients with cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>When clinical trials show that a new treatment is better than the standard treatment, the new treatment may become the standard treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients may want to think about taking part in a clinical trial.<EOS>
<BOS>Some clinical trials are open only to patients who have not started treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Eight types of treatment are used: Chemotherapy Chemotherapy is a cancer treatment that uses drugs to stop the growth of cancer cells, either by killing the cells or by stopping them from dividing.<EOS>
<BOS>When chemotherapy is taken by mouth or injected into a vein or muscle, the drugs enter the bloodstream and can reach cancer cells throughout the body (systemic chemotherapy).<EOS>
<BOS>When chemotherapy is placed directly into the cerebrospinal fluid, an organ, or a body cavity such as the abdomen, the drugs mainly affect cancer cells in those areas (regional chemotherapy).<EOS>
<BOS>The way the chemotherapy is given depends on the type and stage of the cancer being treated.<EOS>
<BOS>See Drugs Approved for Multiple Myeloma and Other Plasma Cell Neoplasms for more information.<EOS>
<BOS>Other drug therapy Corticosteroids are steroids that have antitumor effects in multiple myeloma.<EOS>
<BOS>Targeted therapy Targeted therapy is a treatment that uses drugs or other substances to identify and attack specific cancer cells without harming normal cells.<EOS>
<BOS>Several types of targeted therapy may be used to treat multiple myeloma and other plasma cell neoplasms.<EOS>
<BOS>Proteasome inhibitor therapy is a type of targeted therapy that blocks the action of proteasomes in cancer cells and may prevent the growth of tumors.<EOS>
<BOS>Bortezomib, carfilzomib, ixazomib, daratumumab, and elotuzumab are proteasome inhibitors used in the treatment of multiple myeloma and other plasma cell neoplasms.<EOS>
<BOS>Histone deacetylase (HDAC) inhibitor therapy is a type of targeted therapy that blocks enzymes needed for cell division and may stop the growth of cancer cells.<EOS>
<BOS>Panobinostat is an HDAC inhibitor used in the treatment of multiple myeloma and other plasma cell neoplasms.<EOS>
<BOS>See Drugs Approved for Multiple Myeloma and Other Plasma Cell Neoplasms for more information.<EOS>
<BOS>Highdose chemotherapy with stem cell transplant This treatment is a way of giving high doses of chemotherapy and replacing blood forming cells destroyed by the cancer treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Stem cells (immature blood cells) are removed from the blood or bone marrow of the patient (autologous transplant) or a donor (allogeneic transplant) and are frozen and stored.<EOS>
<BOS>After the chemotherapy is completed, the stored stem cells are thawed and given back to the patient through an infusion.<EOS>
<BOS>These reinfused stem cells grow into (and restore) the body's blood cells.<EOS>
<BOS>Biologic therapy Biologic therapy is a treatment that uses the patient's immune system to fight cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Substances made by the body or made in a laboratory are used to boost, direct, or restore the body's natural defenses against cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>This type of cancer treatment is also called biotherapy or immunotherapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Immunomodulators are a type of biologic therapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Thalidomide, lenalidomide, and pomalidomide are immunomodulators used to treat multiple myeloma and other plasma cell neoplasms.<EOS>
<BOS>Interferon is a type of biologic therapy.<EOS>
<BOS>It affects the division of cancer cells and can slow tumor growth.<EOS>
<BOS>See Drugs Approved for Multiple Myeloma and Other Plasma Cell Neoplasms for more information.<EOS>
<BOS>Radiation therapy Radiation therapy is a cancer treatment that uses highenergy xrays or other types of radiation to kill cancer cells or keep them from growing.<EOS>
<BOS>There are two types of radiation therapy: External radiation therapy uses a machine outside the body to send radiation toward the cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Internal radiation therapy uses a radioactive substance sealed in needles, seeds, wires, or catheters that are placed directly into or near the cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>The way the radiation therapy is given depends on the type and stage of the cancer being treated.<EOS>
<BOS>External radiation therapy is used to treat plasma cell neoplasms.<EOS>
<BOS>Surgery Surgery to remove the tumor may be done and is usually followed by radiation therapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Treatment given after the surgery, to lower the risk that the cancer will come back, is called adjuvant therapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Watchful waiting Watchful waiting is closely monitoring a patients condition without giving any treatment until signs or symptoms appear or change.<EOS>
<BOS>New types of treatment are being tested in clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>This summary section describes treatments that are being studied in clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>It may not mention every new treatment being studied.<EOS>
<BOS>Information about clinical trials is available from the NCI website.<EOS>
<BOS>New combinations of therapies Clinical trials are studying different combinations of biologic therapy, chemotherapy, steroid therapy, and drugs.<EOS>
<BOS>New treatment regimens using thalidomide or lenalidomide are also being studied.<EOS>
<BOS>Supportive care is given to lessen the problems caused by the disease or its treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>This therapy controls problems or side effects caused by the disease or its treatment, and improves quality of life.<EOS>
<BOS>Supportive care is given to treat problems caused by multiple myeloma and other plasma cell neoplasms.<EOS>
<BOS>Supportive care may include the following: Plasmapheresis: If the blood becomes thick with extra antibody proteins and interferes with circulation, plasmapheresis is done to remove extra plasma and antibody proteins from the blood.<EOS>
<BOS>In this procedure blood is removed from the patient and sent through a machine that separates the plasma (the liquid part of the blood) from the blood cells.<EOS>
<BOS>The patient's plasma contains the unneeded antibodies and is not returned to the patient.<EOS>
<BOS>The normal blood cells are returned to the bloodstream along with donated plasma or a plasma replacement.<EOS>
<BOS>Plasmapheresis does not keep new antibodies from forming.<EOS>
<BOS>Highdose chemotherapy with stem cell transplant: If amyloidosis occurs, treatment may include highdose chemotherapy followed by stem cell transplant using the patient's own stem cells.<EOS>
<BOS>Biologic therapy: Biologic therapy with thalidomide, lenalidomide, or pomalidomide is given to treat amyloidosis.<EOS>
<BOS>Targeted therapy: Targeted therapy with proteasome inhibitors is given to treat amyloidosis.<EOS>
<BOS>Radiation therapy: Radiation therapy is given for bone lesions of the spine.<EOS>
<BOS>Chemotherapy: Chemotherapy is given to reduce back pain from osteoporosis or compression fractures of the spine.<EOS>
<BOS>Bisphosphonate therapy: Bisphosphonate therapy is given to slow bone loss and reduce bone pain.<EOS>
<BOS>See the following PDQ summaries for more information on bisphosphonates and problems related to their use: Cancer Pain Oral Complications of Chemotherapy and Head/Neck Radiation Patients may want to think about taking part in a clinical trial.<EOS>
<BOS>For some patients, taking part in a clinical trial may be the best treatment choice.<EOS>
<BOS>Clinical trials are part of the cancer research process.<EOS>
<BOS>Clinical trials are done to find out if new cancer treatments are safe and effective or better than the standard treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Many of today's standard treatments for cancer are based on earlier clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients who take part in a clinical trial may receive the standard treatment or be among the first to receive a new treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients who take part in clinical trials also help improve the way cancer will be treated in the future.<EOS>
<BOS>Even when clinical trials do not lead to effective new treatments, they often answer important questions and help move research forward.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients can enter clinical trials before, during, or after starting their cancer treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Some clinical trials only include patients who have not yet received treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Other trials test treatments for patients whose cancer has not gotten better.<EOS>
<BOS>There are also clinical trials that test new ways to stop cancer from recurring (coming back) or reduce the side effects of cancer treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Clinical trials are taking place in many parts of the country.<EOS>
<BOS>See the Treatment Options section that follows for links to current treatment clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>These have been retrieved from NCI's listing of clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>Followup tests may be needed.<EOS>
<BOS>Some of the tests that were done to diagnose the cancer or to find out the stage of the cancer may be repeated.<EOS>
<BOS>Some tests will be repeated in order to see how well the treatment is working.<EOS>
<BOS>Decisions about whether to continue, change, or stop treatment may be based on the results of these tests.<EOS>
<BOS>Some of the tests will continue to be done from time to time after treatment has ended.<EOS>
<BOS>The results of these tests can show if your condition has changed or if the cancer has recurred (come back).<EOS>
<BOS>These tests are sometimes called followup tests or checkups.<EOS>
<BOS>Treatment Options for Plasma Cell Neoplasms Monoclonal Gammopathy of Undetermined Significance Treatment of monoclonal gammopathy of undetermined significance (MGUS) is usually watchful waiting.<EOS>
<BOS>Regular blood tests to check the level of M protein in the blood and physical exams to check for signs or symptoms of cancer will be done.<EOS>
<BOS>Check the list of NCIsupported cancer clinical trials that are now accepting patients with monoclonal gammopathy of undetermined significance.<EOS>
<BOS>For more specific results, refine the search by using other search features, such as the location of the trial, the type of treatment, or the name of the drug.<EOS>
<BOS>Talk with your doctor about clinical trials that may be right for you.<EOS>
<BOS>General information about clinical trials is available from the NCI website.<EOS>
<BOS>Isolated Plasmacytoma of Bone Treatment of isolated plasmacytoma of bone is usually radiation therapy to the bone lesion.<EOS>
<BOS>Check the list of NCIsupported cancer clinical trials that are now accepting patients with isolated plasmacytoma of bone.<EOS>
<BOS>For more specific results, refine the search by using other search features, such as the location of the trial, the type of treatment, or the name of the drug.<EOS>
<BOS>Talk with your doctor about clinical trials that may be right for you.<EOS>
<BOS>General information about clinical trials is available from the NCI website.<EOS>
<BOS>Extramedullary Plasmacytoma Treatment of extramedullary plasmacytoma may include the following: Radiation therapy to the tumor and nearby lymph nodes.<EOS>
<BOS>Surgery, usually followed by radiation therapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Watchful waiting after initial treatment, followed by radiation therapy, surgery, or chemotherapy if the tumor grows or causes signs or symptoms.<EOS>
<BOS>Check the list of NCIsupported cancer clinical trials that are now accepting patients with extramedullary plasmacytoma.<EOS>
<BOS>For more specific results, refine the search by using other search features, such as the location of the trial, the type of treatment, or the name of the drug.<EOS>
<BOS>Talk with your doctor about clinical trials that may be right for you.<EOS>
<BOS>General information about clinical trials is available from the NCI website.<EOS>
<BOS>Multiple Myeloma Patients without signs or symptoms may not need treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>When signs or symptoms appear, the treatment of multiple myeloma may be done in phases: Induction therapy : This is the first phase of treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Its goal is to reduce the amount of disease, and may include one or more of the following: Corticosteroid therapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Biologic therapy with lenalidomide, pomalidomide, or thalidomide therapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Targeted therapy with proteasome inhibitors (bortezomib, carfilzomib, ixazomib, daratumumab, and elotuzumab).<EOS>
<BOS>Chemotherapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Histone deacetylase inhibitor therapy with panobinostat.<EOS>
<BOS>A clinical trial of different combinations of treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Consolidation chemotherapy : This is the second phase of treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Treatment in the consolidation phase is to kill any remaining cancer cells.<EOS>
<BOS>Highdose chemotherapy is followed by either: one autologous stem cell transplant, in which the patient's stem cells from the blood or bone marrow are used; or two autologous stem cell transplants followed by an autologous or allogeneic stem cell transplant, in which the patient receives stem cells from the blood or bone marrow of a donor; or one allogeneic stem cell transplant.<EOS>
<BOS>Maintenance therapy : After the initial treatment, maintenance therapy is often given to help keep the disease in remission for a longer time.<EOS>
<BOS>Several types of treatment are being studied for this use, including the following: Chemotherapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Biologic therapy with interferon.<EOS>
<BOS>Corticosteroid therapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Lenalidomide therapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Targeted therapy with a proteasome inhibitor (bortezomib).<EOS>
<BOS>Check the list of NCIsupported cancer clinical trials that are now accepting patients with multiple myeloma.<EOS>
<BOS>For more specific results, refine the search by using other search features, such as the location of the trial, the type of treatment, or the name of the drug.<EOS>
<BOS>Talk with your doctor about clinical trials that may be right for you.<EOS>
<BOS>General information about clinical trials is available from the NCI website.<EOS>
<BOS>Refractory Multiple Myeloma Treatment of refractory multiple myeloma may include the following: Watchful waiting for patients whose disease is stable.<EOS>
<BOS>A different treatment than treatment already given, for patients whose tumor kept growing during treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>(See Multiple Myeloma treatment options.<EOS>
<BOS>) A clinical trial of a new therapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Check the list of NCIsupported cancer clinical trials that are now accepting patients with refractory multiple myeloma.<EOS>
<BOS>For more specific results, refine the search by using other search features, such as the location of the trial, the type of treatment, or the name of the drug.<EOS>
<BOS>Talk with your doctor about clinical trials that may be right for you.<EOS>
<BOS>General information about clinical trials is available from the NCI website.<EOS>
<BOS>Tests that examine the ovaries, pelvic area, blood, and ovarian tissue are used to detect (find) and diagnose ovarian germ cell tumor.<EOS>
<BOS>The following tests and procedures may be used: Physical exam and history : An exam of the body to check general signs of health, including checking for signs of disease, such as lumps or anything else that seems unusual.<EOS>
<BOS>A history of the patients health habits and past illnesses and treatments will also be taken.<EOS>
<BOS>Pelvic exam : An exam of the vagina, cervix, uterus, fallopian tubes, ovaries, and rectum.<EOS>
<BOS>A speculum is inserted into the vagina and the doctor or nurse looks at the vagina and cervix for signs of disease.<EOS>
<BOS>A Pap test of the cervix is usually done.<EOS>
<BOS>The doctor or nurse also inserts one or two lubricated, gloved fingers of one hand into the vagina and places the other hand over the lower abdomen to feel the size, shape, and position of the uterus and ovaries.<EOS>
<BOS>The doctor or nurse also inserts a lubricated, gloved finger into the rectum to feel for lumps or abnormal areas.<EOS>
<BOS>Laparotomy : A surgical procedure in which an incision (cut) is made in the wall of the abdomen to check the inside of the abdomen for signs of disease.<EOS>
<BOS>The size of the incision depends on the reason the laparotomy is being done.<EOS>
<BOS>Sometimes organs are removed or tissue samples are taken and checked under a microscope for signs of disease.<EOS>
<BOS>CT scan (CAT scan): A procedure that makes a series of detailed pictures of areas inside the body, taken from different angles.<EOS>
<BOS>The pictures are made by a computer linked to an xray machine.<EOS>
<BOS>A dye may be injected into a vein or swallowed to help the organs or tissues show up more clearly.<EOS>
<BOS>This procedure is also called computed tomography, computerized tomography, or computerized axial tomography.<EOS>
<BOS>Serum tumor marker test : A procedure in which a sample of blood is checked to measure the amounts of certain substances released into the blood by organs, tissues, or tumor cells in the body.<EOS>
<BOS>Certain substances are linked to specific types of cancer when found in increased levels in the blood.<EOS>
<BOS>These are called tumor markers.<EOS>
<BOS>An increased level of alpha fetoprotein (AFP) or human chorionic gonadotropin (HCG) in the blood may be a sign of ovarian germ cell tumor.<EOS>
<BOS>Certain factors affect prognosis (chance of recovery) and treatment options.<EOS>
<BOS>The prognosis (chance of recovery) and treatment options depend on: The type of lymphoma.<EOS>
<BOS>Where the tumor is in the body when the tumor is diagnosed.<EOS>
<BOS>The stage of the cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Whether there are certain changes in the chromosomes.<EOS>
<BOS>The type of initial treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Whether the lymphoma responded to initial treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>The patients age and general health.<EOS>
<BOS>Key Points There are different types of treatment for patients with adult primary liver cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients with liver cancer are treated by a team of specialists who are experts in treating liver cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Seven types of standard treatment are used: Surveillance Surgery Liver transplant Ablation therapy Embolization therapy Targeted therapy Radiation therapy New types of treatment are being tested in clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients may want to think about taking part in a clinical trial.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients can enter clinical trials before, during, or after starting their cancer treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Followup tests may be needed.<EOS>
<BOS>There are different types of treatment for patients with adult primary liver cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Different types of treatments are available for patients with adult primary liver cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Some treatments are standard (the currently used treatment), and some are being tested in clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>A treatment clinical trial is a research study meant to help improve current treatments or obtain information on new treatments for patients with cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>When clinical trials show that a new treatment is better than the standard treatment, the new treatment may become the standard treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients may want to think about taking part in a clinical trial.<EOS>
<BOS>Some clinical trials are open only to patients who have not started treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients with liver cancer are treated by a team of specialists who are experts in treating liver cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>The patient's treatment will be overseen by a medical oncologist, a doctor who specializes in treating people with cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>The medical oncologist may refer the patient to other health professionals who have special training in treating patients with liver cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>These may include the following specialists: Hepatologist (specialist in liver disease).<EOS>
<BOS>Surgical oncologist.<EOS>
<BOS>Transplant surgeon.<EOS>
<BOS>Radiation oncologist.<EOS>
<BOS>Interventional radiologist (a specialist who diagnoses and treats diseases using imaging and the smallest incisions possible).<EOS>
<BOS>Pathologist.<EOS>
<BOS>Seven types of standard treatment are used: Surveillance Surveillance for lesions smaller than 1 centimeter found during screening.<EOS>
<BOS>Followup every three months is common.<EOS>
<BOS>Surgery A partial hepatectomy (surgery to remove the part of the liver where cancer is found) may be done.<EOS>
<BOS>A wedge of tissue, an entire lobe, or a larger part of the liver, along with some of the healthy tissue around it is removed.<EOS>
<BOS>The remaining liver tissue takes over the functions of the liver and may regrow.<EOS>
<BOS>Liver transplant In a liver transplant, the entire liver is removed and replaced with a healthy donated liver.<EOS>
<BOS>A liver transplant may be done when the disease is in the liver only and a donated liver can be found.<EOS>
<BOS>If the patient has to wait for a donated liver, other treatment is given as needed.<EOS>
<BOS>Ablation therapy Ablation therapy removes or destroys tissue.<EOS>
<BOS>Different types of ablation therapy are used for liver cancer: Radiofrequency ablation: The use of special needles that are inserted directly through the skin or through an incision in the abdomen to reach the tumor.<EOS>
<BOS>Highenergy radio waves heat the needles and tumor which kills cancer cells.<EOS>
<BOS>Microwave therapy: A type of treatment in which the tumor is exposed to high temperatures created by microwaves.<EOS>
<BOS>This can damage and kill cancer cells or make them more sensitive to the effects of radiation and certain anticancer drugs.<EOS>
<BOS>Percutaneous ethanol injection: A cancer treatment in which a small needle is used to inject ethanol (pure alcohol) directly into a tumor to kill cancer cells.<EOS>
<BOS>Several treatments may be needed.<EOS>
<BOS>Usually local anesthesia is used, but if the patient has many tumors in the liver, general anesthesia may be used.<EOS>
<BOS>Cryoablation: A treatment that uses an instrument to freeze and destroy cancer cells.<EOS>
<BOS>This type of treatment is also called cryotherapy and cryosurgery.<EOS>
<BOS>The doctor may use ultrasound to guide the instrument.<EOS>
<BOS>Electroporation therapy: A treatment that sends electrical pulses through an electrode placed in a tumor to kill cancer cells.<EOS>
<BOS>Electroporation therapy is being studied in clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>Embolization therapy Embolization therapy is the use of substances to block or decrease the flow of blood through the hepatic artery to the tumor.<EOS>
<BOS>When the tumor does not get the oxygen and nutrients it needs, it will not continue to grow.<EOS>
<BOS>Embolization therapy is used for patients who cannot have surgery to remove the tumor or ablation therapy and whose tumor has not spread outside the liver.<EOS>
<BOS>The liver receives blood from the hepatic portal vein and the hepatic artery.<EOS>
<BOS>Blood that comes into the liver from the hepatic portal vein usually goes to the healthy liver tissue.<EOS>
<BOS>Blood that comes from the hepatic artery usually goes to the tumor.<EOS>
<BOS>When the hepatic artery is blocked during embolization therapy, the healthy liver tissue continues to receive blood from the hepatic portal vein.<EOS>
<BOS>There are two main types of embolization therapy: Transarterial embolization (TAE): A small incision (cut) is made in the inner thigh and a catheter (thin, flexible tube) is inserted and threaded up into the hepatic artery.<EOS>
<BOS>Once the catheter is in place, a substance that blocks the hepatic artery and stops blood flow to the tumor is injected.<EOS>
<BOS>Transarterial chemoembolization (TACE): This procedure is like TAE except an anticancer drug is also given.<EOS>
<BOS>The procedure can be done by attaching the anticancer drug to small beads that are injected into the hepatic artery or by injecting the anticancer drug through the catheter into the hepatic artery and then injecting the substance to block the hepatic artery.<EOS>
<BOS>Most of the anticancer drug is trapped near the tumor and only a small amount of the drug reaches other parts of the body.<EOS>
<BOS>This type of treatment is also called chemoembolization.<EOS>
<BOS>Targeted therapy Targeted therapy is a treatment that uses drugs or other substances to identify and attack specific cancer cells without harming normal cells.<EOS>
<BOS>Adult liver cancer may be treated with a targeted therapy drug that stops cells from dividing and prevents the growth of new blood vessels that tumors need to grow.<EOS>
<BOS>See Drugs Approved for Liver Cancer for more information.<EOS>
<BOS>Radiation therapy Radiation therapy is a cancer treatment that uses highenergy xrays or other types of radiation to kill cancer cells or keep them from growing.<EOS>
<BOS>There are two types of radiation therapy: External radiation therapy uses a machine outside the body to send radiation toward the cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Certain ways of giving radiation therapy can help keep radiation from damaging nearby healthy tissue.<EOS>
<BOS>These types of external radiation therapy include the following: Conformal radiation therapy: Conformal radiation therapy is a type of external radiation therapy that uses a computer to make a 3dimensional (3D) picture of the tumor and shapes the radiation beams to fit the tumor.<EOS>
<BOS>This allows a high dose of radiation to reach the tumor and causes less damage to nearby healthy tissue.<EOS>
<BOS>Stereotactic body radiation therapy: Stereotactic body radiation therapy is a type of external radiation therapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Special equipment is used to place the patient in the same position for each radiation treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Once a day for several days, a radiation machine aims a larger than usual dose of radiation directly at the tumor.<EOS>
<BOS>By having the patient in the same position for each treatment, there is less damage to nearby healthy tissue.<EOS>
<BOS>This procedure is also called stereotactic externalbeam radiation therapy and stereotaxic radiation therapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Proton beam radiation therapy: Protonbeam therapy is a type of highenergy, external radiation therapy.<EOS>
<BOS>A radiation therapy machine aims streams of protons (tiny, invisible, positivelycharged particles) at the cancer cells to kill them.<EOS>
<BOS>This type of treatment causes less damage to nearby healthy tissue.<EOS>
<BOS>Internal radiation therapy uses a radioactive substance sealed in needles, seeds, wires, or catheters that are placed directly into or near the cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>The way the radiation therapy is given depends on the type and stage of the cancer being treated.<EOS>
<BOS>External radiation therapy is used to treat adult primary liver cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>New types of treatment are being tested in clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>Information about clinical trials is available from the NCI website.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients may want to think about taking part in a clinical trial.<EOS>
<BOS>For some patients, taking part in a clinical trial may be the best treatment choice.<EOS>
<BOS>Clinical trials are part of the cancer research process.<EOS>
<BOS>Clinical trials are done to find out if new cancer treatments are safe and effective or better than the standard treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Many of today's standard treatments for cancer are based on earlier clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients who take part in a clinical trial may receive the standard treatment or be among the first to receive a new treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients who take part in clinical trials also help improve the way cancer will be treated in the future.<EOS>
<BOS>Even when clinical trials do not lead to effective new treatments, they often answer important questions and help move research forward.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients can enter clinical trials before, during, or after starting their cancer treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Some clinical trials only include patients who have not yet received treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Other trials test treatments for patients whose cancer has not gotten better.<EOS>
<BOS>There are also clinical trials that test new ways to stop cancer from recurring (coming back) or reduce the side effects of cancer treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Clinical trials are taking place in many parts of the country.<EOS>
<BOS>See the Treatment Options section that follows for links to current treatment clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>These have been retrieved from NCI's listing of clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>Followup tests may be needed.<EOS>
<BOS>Some of the tests that were done to diagnose the cancer or to find out the stage of the cancer may be repeated.<EOS>
<BOS>Some tests will be repeated in order to see how well the treatment is working.<EOS>
<BOS>Decisions about whether to continue, change, or stop treatment may be based on the results of these tests.<EOS>
<BOS>Some of the tests will continue to be done from time to time after treatment has ended.<EOS>
<BOS>The results of these tests can show if your condition has changed or if the cancer has recurred (come back).<EOS>
<BOS>These tests are sometimes called followup tests or checkups.<EOS>
<BOS>Treatment Options for Adult Primary Liver Cancer Stages 0, A, and B Adult Primary Liver Cancer Treatment of stages 0, A, and B adult primary liver cancer may include the following: Surveillance for lesions smaller than 1 centimeter.<EOS>
<BOS>Partial hepatectomy.<EOS>
<BOS>Total hepatectomy and liver transplant.<EOS>
<BOS>Ablation of the tumor using one of the following methods: Radiofrequency ablation.<EOS>
<BOS>Microwave therapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Percutaneous ethanol injection.<EOS>
<BOS>Cryoablation.<EOS>
<BOS>A clinical trial of electroporation therapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Check the list of NCIsupported cancer clinical trials that are now accepting patients with stage 0 adult primary liver cancer (BCLC), stage A adult primary liver cancer (BCLC) and stage B adult primary liver cancer (BCLC).<EOS>
<BOS>For more specific results, refine the search by using other search features, such as the location of the trial, the type of treatment, or the name of the drug.<EOS>
<BOS>Talk with your doctor about clinical trials that may be right for you.<EOS>
<BOS>General information about clinical trials is available from the NCI website.<EOS>
<BOS>Stages C and D Adult Primary Liver Cancer Treatment of stages C and D adult primary liver cancer may include the following: Embolization therapy using one of the following methods: Transarterial embolization (TAE).<EOS>
<BOS>Transarterial chemoembolization (TACE).<EOS>
<BOS>Targeted therapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Radiation therapy.<EOS>
<BOS>A clinical trial of targeted therapy after chemoembolization or combined with chemotherapy.<EOS>
<BOS>A clinical trial of new targeted therapy drugs.<EOS>
<BOS>A clinical trial of targeted therapy with or without stereotactic body radiation therapy.<EOS>
<BOS>A clinical trial of stereotactic body radiation therapy or protonbeam radiation therapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Check the list of NCIsupported cancer clinical trials that are now accepting patients with stage C adult primary liver cancer (BCLC) and stage D adult primary liver cancer (BCLC).<EOS>
<BOS>For more specific results, refine the search by using other search features, such as the location of the trial, the type of treatment, or the name of the drug.<EOS>
<BOS>Talk with your doctor about clinical trials that may be right for you.<EOS>
<BOS>General information about clinical trials is available from the NCI website.<EOS>
<BOS>Signs and symptoms of pancreatic cancer include jaundice, pain, and weight loss.<EOS>
<BOS>Pancreatic cancer may not cause early signs or symptoms.<EOS>
<BOS>Signs and symptoms may be caused by pancreatic cancer or by other conditions.<EOS>
<BOS>Check with your doctor if you have any of the following: Jaundice (yellowing of the skin and whites of the eyes).<EOS>
<BOS>Lightcolored stools.<EOS>
<BOS>Dark urine.<EOS>
<BOS>Pain in the upper or middle abdomen and back.<EOS>
<BOS>Weight loss for no known reason.<EOS>
<BOS>Loss of appetite.<EOS>
<BOS>Feeling very tired.<EOS>
<BOS>Pancreatic cancer is difficult to detect (find) and diagnose early.<EOS>
<BOS>Pancreatic cancer is difficult to detect and diagnose for the following reasons: There arent any noticeable signs or symptoms in the early stages of pancreatic cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>The signs and symptoms of pancreatic cancer, when present, are like the signs and symptoms of many other illnesses.<EOS>
<BOS>The pancreas is hidden behind other organs such as the stomach, small intestine, liver, gallbladder, spleen, and bile ducts.<EOS>
<BOS>Key Points After salivary gland cancer has been diagnosed, tests are done to find out if cancer cells have spread within the salivary gland or to other parts of the body.<EOS>
<BOS>There are three ways that cancer spreads in the body.<EOS>
<BOS>Cancer may spread from where it began to other parts of the body.<EOS>
<BOS>The following stages are used for major salivary gland cancers: Stage I Stage II Stage III Stage IV After salivary gland cancer has been diagnosed, tests are done to find out if cancer cells have spread within the salivary gland or to other parts of the body.<EOS>
<BOS>The process used to find out if cancer has spread within the salivary glands or to other parts of the body is called staging.<EOS>
<BOS>The information gathered from the staging process determines the stage of the disease.<EOS>
<BOS>It is important to know the stage in order to plan treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>The following procedures may be used in the staging process: MRI (magnetic resonance imaging): A procedure that uses a magnet, radio waves, and a computer to make a series of detailed pictures of areas inside the body.<EOS>
<BOS>This procedure is also called nuclear magnetic resonance imaging (NMRI).<EOS>
<BOS>CT scan (CAT scan): A procedure that makes a series of detailed pictures of areas inside the body, taken from different angles.<EOS>
<BOS>The pictures are made by a computer linked to an xray machine.<EOS>
<BOS>A dye may be injected into a vein or swallowed to help the organs or tissues show up more clearly.<EOS>
<BOS>This procedure is also called computed tomography, computerized tomography, or computerized axial tomography.<EOS>
<BOS>There are three ways that cancer spreads in the body.<EOS>
<BOS>Cancer can spread through tissue, the lymph system, and the blood: Tissue.<EOS>
<BOS>The cancer spreads from where it began by growing into nearby areas.<EOS>
<BOS>Lymph system.<EOS>
<BOS>The cancer spreads from where it began by getting into the lymph system.<EOS>
<BOS>The cancer travels through the lymph vessels to other parts of the body.<EOS>
<BOS>Blood.<EOS>
<BOS>The cancer spreads from where it began by getting into the blood.<EOS>
<BOS>The cancer travels through the blood vessels to other parts of the body.<EOS>
<BOS>Cancer may spread from where it began to other parts of the body.<EOS>
<BOS>When cancer spreads to another part of the body, it is called metastasis.<EOS>
<BOS>Cancer cells break away from where they began (the primary tumor) and travel through the lymph system or blood.<EOS>
<BOS>Lymph system.<EOS>
<BOS>The cancer gets into the lymph system, travels through the lymph vessels, and forms a tumor (metastatic tumor) in another part of the body.<EOS>
<BOS>Blood.<EOS>
<BOS>The cancer gets into the blood, travels through the blood vessels, and forms a tumor (metastatic tumor) in another part of the body.<EOS>
<BOS>The metastatic tumor is the same type of cancer as the primary tumor.<EOS>
<BOS>For example, if salivary gland cancer spreads to the lung, the cancer cells in the lung are actually salivary gland cancer cells.<EOS>
<BOS>The disease is metastatic salivary gland cancer, not lung cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>The following stages are used for major salivary gland cancers: Stage I In stage I, the tumor is in the salivary gland only and is 2 centimeters or smaller.<EOS>
<BOS>Stage II In stage II, the tumor is in the salivary gland only and is larger than 2 centimeters but not larger than 4 centimeters.<EOS>
<BOS>Stage III In stage III, one of the following is true: The tumor is not larger than 4 centimeters and has spread to a single lymph node on the same side as the tumor and the lymph node is 3 centimeters or smaller.<EOS>
<BOS>The tumor is larger than 4 centimeters and/or has spread to soft tissue around the affected gland.<EOS>
<BOS>Cancer may have spread to a single lymph node on the same side as the tumor and the lymph node is 3 centimeters or smaller.<EOS>
<BOS>Stage IV Stage IV is divided into stages IVA, IVB, and IVC as follows: Stage IVA: The tumor may be any size and may have spread to soft tissue around the affected gland.<EOS>
<BOS>Cancer has spread to a single lymph node on the same side as the tumor and the lymph node is larger than 3 centimeters but not larger than 6 centimeters, or has spread to more than one lymph node on either or both sides of the body and the lymph nodes are not larger than 6 centimeters; or Cancer has spread to the skin, jawbone, ear canal, and/or facial nerve, and may have spread to one or more lymph nodes on either or both sides of the body.<EOS>
<BOS>The lymph nodes are not larger than 6 centimeters.<EOS>
<BOS>Stage IVB: The tumor may be any size and may have spread to soft tissue around the affected gland.<EOS>
<BOS>Cancer has spread to a lymph node larger than 6 centimeters; or Cancer has spread to the base of the skull and/or the carotid artery, and may have spread to one or more lymph nodes of any size on either or both sides of the body.<EOS>
<BOS>Stage IVC: The tumor may be any size and may have spread to soft tissue around the affected gland, to the skin, jawbone, ear canal, facial nerve, base of the skull, or carotid artery, or to one or more lymph nodes on either or both sides of the body.<EOS>
<BOS>Cancer has spread to distant parts of the body.<EOS>
<BOS>Salivary gland cancers are also grouped by grade.<EOS>
<BOS>The grade of a tumor tells how fast the cancer cells are growing, based on how the cells look under a microscope.<EOS>
<BOS>Lowgrade cancers grow more slowly than highgrade cancers.<EOS>
<BOS>Minor salivary gland cancers are staged according to where they were first found in the body.<EOS>
<BOS>Key Points There are different types of treatment for patients with chronic myeloproliferative neoplasms.<EOS>
<BOS>Eleven types of standard treatment are used: Watchful waiting Phlebotomy Platelet apheresis Transfusion therapy Chemotherapy Radiation therapy Other drug therapy Surgery Biologic therapy Targeted therapy Highdose chemotherapy with stem cell transplant New types of treatment are being tested in clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients may want to think about taking part in a clinical trial.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients can enter clinical trials before, during, or after starting their cancer treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Followup tests may be needed.<EOS>
<BOS>There are different types of treatment for patients with chronic myeloproliferative neoplasms.<EOS>
<BOS>Different types of treatments are available for patients with chronic myeloproliferative neoplasms.<EOS>
<BOS>Some treatments are standard (the currently used treatment), and some are being tested in clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>A treatment clinical trial is a research study meant to help improve current treatments or obtain information on new treatments.<EOS>
<BOS>When clinical trials show that a new treatment is better than the standard treatment, the new treatment may become the standard treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients may want to think about taking part in a clinical trial.<EOS>
<BOS>Some clinical trials are open only to patients who have not started treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Eleven types of standard treatment are used: Watchful waiting Watchful waiting is closely monitoring a patients condition without giving any treatment until signs or symptoms appear or change.<EOS>
<BOS>Phlebotomy Phlebotomy is a procedure in which blood is taken from a vein.<EOS>
<BOS>A sample of blood may be taken for tests such as a CBC or blood chemistry.<EOS>
<BOS>Sometimes phlebotomy is used as a treatment and blood is taken from the body to remove extra red blood cells.<EOS>
<BOS>Phlebotomy is used in this way to treat some chronic myeloproliferative neoplasms.<EOS>
<BOS>Platelet apheresis Platelet apheresis is a treatment that uses a special machine to remove platelets from the blood.<EOS>
<BOS>Blood is taken from the patient and put through a blood cell separator where the platelets are removed.<EOS>
<BOS>The rest of the blood is then returned to the patients bloodstream.<EOS>
<BOS>Transfusion therapy Transfusion therapy (blood transfusion) is a method of giving red blood cells, white blood cells, or platelets to replace blood cells destroyed by disease or cancer treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Chemotherapy Chemotherapy is a cancer treatment that uses drugs to stop the growth of cancer cells, either by killing the cells or by stopping them from dividing.<EOS>
<BOS>When chemotherapy is taken by mouth or injected into a vein or muscle, the drugs enter the bloodstream and can reach cancer cells throughout the body (systemic chemotherapy).<EOS>
<BOS>When chemotherapy is placed directly into the cerebrospinal fluid, an organ, or a body cavity such as the abdomen, the drugs mainly affect cancer cells in those areas (regional chemotherapy).<EOS>
<BOS>The way the chemotherapy is given depends on the type and stage of the cancer being treated.<EOS>
<BOS>See Drugs Approved for Myeloproliferative Neoplasms for more information.<EOS>
<BOS>Radiation therapy Radiation therapy is a cancer treatment that uses highenergy xrays or other types of radiation to kill cancer cells or keep them from growing.<EOS>
<BOS>There are two types of radiation therapy: External radiation therapy uses a machine outside the body to send radiation toward the cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Internal radiation therapy uses a radioactive substance sealed in needles, seeds, wires, or catheters that are placed directly into or near the cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>The way the radiation therapy is given depends on the type of cancer being treated.<EOS>
<BOS>External radiation therapy is used to treat chronic myeloproliferative neoplasms, and is usually directed at the spleen.<EOS>
<BOS>Other drug therapy Prednisone and danazol are drugs that may be used to treat anemia in patients with primary myelofibrosis.<EOS>
<BOS>Anagrelide therapy is used to reduce the risk of blood clots in patients who have too many platelets in their blood.<EOS>
<BOS>Lowdose aspirin may also be used to reduce the risk of blood clots.<EOS>
<BOS>Thalidomide, lenalidomide, and pomalidomide are drugs that prevent blood vessels from growing into areas of tumor cells.<EOS>
<BOS>See Drugs Approved for Myeloproliferative Neoplasms for more information.<EOS>
<BOS>Surgery Splenectomy (surgery to remove the spleen) may be done if the spleen is enlarged.<EOS>
<BOS>Biologic therapy Biologic therapy is a treatment that uses the patient's immune system to fight cancer or other diseases.<EOS>
<BOS>Substances made by the body or made in a laboratory are used to boost, direct, or restore the body's natural defenses against disease.<EOS>
<BOS>This type of treatment is also called biotherapy or immunotherapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Interferon alfa and pegylated interferon alpha are biologic agents commonly used to treat some chronic myeloproliferative neoplasms.<EOS>
<BOS>Erythropoietic growth factors are also biologic agents.<EOS>
<BOS>They are used to stimulate the bone marrow to make red blood cells.<EOS>
<BOS>Targeted therapy Targeted therapy is a type of treatment that uses drugs or other substances to identify and attack specific cancer cells without harming normal cells.<EOS>
<BOS>Tyrosine kinase inhibitors are targeted therapy drugs that block signals needed for tumors to grow.<EOS>
<BOS>Ruxolitinib is a tyrosine kinase inhibitor used to treat certain types of myelofibrosis.<EOS>
<BOS>See Drugs Approved for Myeloproliferative Neoplasms for more information.<EOS>
<BOS>Other types of targeted therapies are being studied in clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>Highdose chemotherapy with stem cell transplant Highdose chemotherapy with stem cell transplant is a method of giving high doses of chemotherapy and replacing bloodforming cells destroyed by the cancer treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Stem cells (immature blood cells) are removed from the blood or bone marrow of the patient or a donor and are frozen and stored.<EOS>
<BOS>After the chemotherapy is completed, the stored stem cells are thawed and given back to the patient through an infusion.<EOS>
<BOS>These reinfused stem cells grow into (and restore) the body's blood cells.<EOS>
<BOS>New types of treatment are being tested in clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>Information about clinical trials is available from the NCI website.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients may want to think about taking part in a clinical trial.<EOS>
<BOS>For some patients, taking part in a clinical trial may be the best treatment choice.<EOS>
<BOS>Clinical trials are part of the cancer research process.<EOS>
<BOS>Clinical trials are done to find out if new cancer treatments are safe and effective or better than the standard treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Many of today's standard treatments for cancer are based on earlier clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients who take part in a clinical trial may receive the standard treatment or be among the first to receive a new treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients who take part in clinical trials also help improve the way cancer will be treated in the future.<EOS>
<BOS>Even when clinical trials do not lead to effective new treatments, they often answer important questions and help move research forward.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients can enter clinical trials before, during, or after starting their cancer treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Some clinical trials only include patients who have not yet received treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Other trials test treatments for patients whose cancer has not gotten better.<EOS>
<BOS>There are also clinical trials that test new ways to stop cancer from recurring (coming back) or reduce the side effects of cancer treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Clinical trials are taking place in many parts of the country.<EOS>
<BOS>See the Treatment Options section that follows for links to current treatment clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>These have been retrieved from NCI's listing of clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>Followup tests may be needed.<EOS>
<BOS>Some of the tests that were done to diagnose the cancer or to find out the stage of the cancer may be repeated.<EOS>
<BOS>Some tests will be repeated in order to see how well the treatment is working.<EOS>
<BOS>Decisions about whether to continue, change, or stop treatment may be based on the results of these tests.<EOS>
<BOS>Some of the tests will continue to be done from time to time after treatment has ended.<EOS>
<BOS>The results of these tests can show if your condition has changed or if the cancer has recurred (come back).<EOS>
<BOS>These tests are sometimes called followup tests or checkups.<EOS>
<BOS>Treatment Options for Chronic Myeloproliferative Neoplasms Chronic Myelogenous Leukemia See the PDQ summary about Chronic Myelogenous Leukemia Treatment for information.<EOS>
<BOS>Polycythemia Vera The purpose of treatment for polycythemia vera is to reduce the number of extra blood cells.<EOS>
<BOS>Treatment of polycythemia vera may include the following: Phlebotomy.<EOS>
<BOS>Chemotherapy with or without phlebotomy.<EOS>
<BOS>Biologic therapy using interferon alfa or pegylated interferon alpha.<EOS>
<BOS>Lowdose aspirin.<EOS>
<BOS>Check the list of NCIsupported cancer clinical trials that are now accepting patients with polycythemia vera.<EOS>
<BOS>For more specific results, refine the search by using other search features, such as the location of the trial, the type of treatment, or the name of the drug.<EOS>
<BOS>Talk with your doctor about clinical trials that may be right for you.<EOS>
<BOS>General information about clinical trials is available from the NCI website.<EOS>
<BOS>Primary Myelofibrosis Treatment of primary myelofibrosis in patients without signs or symptoms is usually watchful waiting.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients with primary myelofibrosis may have signs or symptoms of anemia.<EOS>
<BOS>Anemia is usually treated with transfusion of red blood cells to relieve symptoms and improve quality of life.<EOS>
<BOS>In addition, anemia may be treated with: Erythropoietic growth factors.<EOS>
<BOS>Prednisone.<EOS>
<BOS>Danazol.<EOS>
<BOS>Thalidomide, lenalidomide, or pomalidomide, with or without prednisone.<EOS>
<BOS>Treatment of primary myelofibrosis in patients with other signs or symptoms may include the following: Targeted therapy with ruxolitinib.<EOS>
<BOS>Chemotherapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Donor stem cell transplant.<EOS>
<BOS>Thalidomide, lenalidomide, or pomalidomide.<EOS>
<BOS>Splenectomy.<EOS>
<BOS>Radiation therapy to the spleen, lymph nodes, or other areas outside the bone marrow where blood cells are forming.<EOS>
<BOS>Biologic therapy using interferon alfa or erythropoietic growth factors.<EOS>
<BOS>A clinical trial of other targeted therapy drugs.<EOS>
<BOS>Check the list of NCIsupported cancer clinical trials that are now accepting patients with primary myelofibrosis.<EOS>
<BOS>For more specific results, refine the search by using other search features, such as the location of the trial, the type of treatment, or the name of the drug.<EOS>
<BOS>Talk with your doctor about clinical trials that may be right for you.<EOS>
<BOS>General information about clinical trials is available from the NCI website.<EOS>
<BOS>Essential Thrombocythemia Treatment of essential thrombocythemia in patients younger than 60 years who have no signs or symptoms and an acceptable platelet count is usually watchful waiting.<EOS>
<BOS>Treatment of other patients may include the following: Chemotherapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Anagrelide therapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Biologic therapy using interferon alfa or pegylated interferon alpha.<EOS>
<BOS>Platelet apheresis.<EOS>
<BOS>A clinical trial of a new treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Check the list of NCIsupported cancer clinical trials that are now accepting patients with essential thrombocythemia.<EOS>
<BOS>For more specific results, refine the search by using other search features, such as the location of the trial, the type of treatment, or the name of the drug.<EOS>
<BOS>Talk with your doctor about clinical trials that may be right for you.<EOS>
<BOS>General information about clinical trials is available from the NCI website.<EOS>
<BOS>Chronic Neutrophilic Leukemia Treatment of chronic neutrophilic leukemia may include the following: Donor bone marrow transplant.<EOS>
<BOS>Chemotherapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Biologic therapy using interferon alfa.<EOS>
<BOS>A clinical trial of a new treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Check the list of NCIsupported cancer clinical trials that are now accepting patients with chronic neutrophilic leukemia.<EOS>
<BOS>For more specific results, refine the search by using other search features, such as the location of the trial, the type of treatment, or the name of the drug.<EOS>
<BOS>Talk with your doctor about clinical trials that may be right for you.<EOS>
<BOS>General information about clinical trials is available from the NCI website.<EOS>
<BOS>Chronic Eosinophilic Leukemia Treatment of chronic eosinophilic leukemia may include the following: Bone marrow transplant.<EOS>
<BOS>Biologic therapy using interferon alfa.<EOS>
<BOS>A clinical trial of a new treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Check the list of NCIsupported cancer clinical trials that are now accepting patients with chronic eosinophilic leukemia.<EOS>
<BOS>For more specific results, refine the search by using other search features, such as the location of the trial, the type of treatment, or the name of the drug.<EOS>
<BOS>Talk with your doctor about clinical trials that may be right for you.<EOS>
<BOS>General information about clinical trials is available from the NCI website.<EOS>
<BOS>Testicular cancer can usually be cured.<EOS>
<BOS>Although the number of new cases of testicular cancer has doubled in the last 40 years, the number of deaths caused by testicular cancer has decreased greatly because of better treatments.<EOS>
<BOS>Testicular cancer can usually be cured, even in late stages of the disease.<EOS>
<BOS>(See the PDQ summary on Testicular Cancer Treatment for more information.<EOS>
<BOS>).<EOS>
<BOS>A sign of childhood rhabdomyosarcoma is a lump or swelling that keeps getting bigger.<EOS>
<BOS>Signs and symptoms may be caused by childhood rhabdomyosarcoma or by other conditions.<EOS>
<BOS>The signs and symptoms that occur depend on where the cancer forms.<EOS>
<BOS>Check with your child's doctor if your child has any of the following: A lump or swelling that keeps getting bigger or does not go away.<EOS>
<BOS>It may be painful.<EOS>
<BOS>Bulging of the eye.<EOS>
<BOS>Headache.<EOS>
<BOS>Trouble urinating or having bowel movements.<EOS>
<BOS>Blood in the urine.<EOS>
<BOS>Bleeding in the nose, throat, vagina, or rectum.<EOS>
<BOS>Signs and symptoms of childhood liver cancer include a lump or pain in the abdomen.<EOS>
<BOS>Signs and symptoms are more common after the tumor gets big.<EOS>
<BOS>Other conditions can cause the same signs and symptoms.<EOS>
<BOS>Check with your childs doctor if your child has any of the following: A lump in the abdomen that may be painful.<EOS>
<BOS>Swelling in the abdomen.<EOS>
<BOS>Weight loss for no known reason.<EOS>
<BOS>Loss of appetite.<EOS>
<BOS>Nausea and vomiting.<EOS>
<BOS>Ethnic background and being exposed to the EpsteinBarr virus can affect the risk of nasopharyngeal cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Anything that increases your risk of getting a disease is called a risk factor.<EOS>
<BOS>Having a risk factor does not mean that you will get cancer; not having risk factors doesn't mean that you will not get cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Talk with your doctor if you think you may be at risk.<EOS>
<BOS>Risk factors for nasopharyngeal cancer include the following: Having Chinese or Asian ancestry.<EOS>
<BOS>Being exposed to the EpsteinBarr virus: The EpsteinBarr virus has been associated with certain cancers, including nasopharyngeal cancer and some lymphomas.<EOS>
<BOS>Drinking large amounts of alcohol.<EOS>
<BOS>Key Points Avoiding risk factors and increasing protective factors may help prevent lung cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>The following are risk factors for lung cancer: Cigarette, cigar, and pipe smoking Secondhand smoke Family history HIV infection Environmental risk factors Beta carotene supplements in heavy smokers The following are protective factors for lung cancer: Not smoking Quitting smoking Lower exposure to workplace risk factors Lower exposure to radon It is not clear if the following decrease the risk of lung cancer: Diet Physical activity The following do not decrease the risk of lung cancer: Beta carotene supplements in nonsmokers Vitamin E supplements Cancer prevention clinical trials are used to study ways to prevent cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>New ways to prevent lung cancer are being studied in clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>Avoiding risk factors and increasing protective factors may help prevent lung cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Avoiding cancer risk factors may help prevent certain cancers.<EOS>
<BOS>Risk factors include smoking, being overweight, and not getting enough exercise.<EOS>
<BOS>Increasing protective factors such as quitting smoking and exercising may also help prevent some cancers.<EOS>
<BOS>Talk to your doctor or other health care professional about how you might lower your risk of cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>The following are risk factors for lung cancer: Cigarette, cigar, and pipe smoking Tobacco smoking is the most important risk factor for lung cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Cigarette, cigar, and pipe smoking all increase the risk of lung cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Tobacco smoking causes about 9 out of 10 cases of lung cancer in men and about 8 out of 10 cases of lung cancer in women.<EOS>
<BOS>Studies have shown that smoking low tar or low nicotine cigarettes does not lower the risk of lung cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Studies also show that the risk of lung cancer from smoking cigarettes increases with the number of cigarettes smoked per day and the number of years smoked.<EOS>
<BOS>People who smoke have about 20 times the risk of lung cancer compared to those who do not smoke.<EOS>
<BOS>Secondhand smoke Being exposed to secondhand tobacco smoke is also a risk factor for lung cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Secondhand smoke is the smoke that comes from a burning cigarette or other tobacco product, or that is exhaled by smokers.<EOS>
<BOS>People who inhale secondhand smoke are exposed to the same cancer causing agents as smokers, although in smaller amounts.<EOS>
<BOS>Inhaling secondhand smoke is called involuntary or passive smoking.<EOS>
<BOS>Family history Having a family history of lung cancer is a risk factor for lung cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>People with a relative who has had lung cancer may be twice as likely to have lung cancer as people who do not have a relative who has had lung cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Because cigarette smoking tends to run in families and family members are exposed to secondhand smoke, it is hard to know whether the increased risk of lung cancer is from the family history of lung cancer or from being exposed to cigarette smoke.<EOS>
<BOS>HIV infection Being infected with the human immunodeficiency virus (HIV), the cause of acquired immunodeficiency syndrome (AIDS), is linked with a higher risk of lung cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>People infected with HIV may have more than twice the risk of lung cancer than those who are not infected.<EOS>
<BOS>Since smoking rates are higher in those infected with HIV than in those not infected, it is not clear whether the increased risk of lung cancer is from HIV infection or from being exposed to cigarette smoke.<EOS>
<BOS>Environmental risk factors Radiation exposure: Being exposed to radiation is a risk factor for lung cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Atomic bomb radiation, radiation therapy, imaging tests, and radon are sources of radiation exposure: Atomic bomb radiation: Being exposed to radiation after an atomic bomb explosion increases the risk of lung cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Radiation therapy: Radiation therapy to the chest may be used to treat certain cancers, including breast cancer and Hodgkin lymphoma.<EOS>
<BOS>Radiation therapy uses xrays, gamma rays, or other types of radiation that may increase the risk of lung cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>The higher the dose of radiation received, the higher the risk.<EOS>
<BOS>The risk of lung cancer following radiation therapy is higher in patients who smoke than in nonsmokers.<EOS>
<BOS>Imaging tests: Imaging tests, such as CT scans, expose patients to radiation.<EOS>
<BOS>Lowdose spiral CT scans expose patients to less radiation than higher dose CT scans.<EOS>
<BOS>In lung cancer screening, the use of lowdose spiral CT scans can lessen the harmful effects of radiation.<EOS>
<BOS>Radon: Radon is a radioactive gas that comes from the breakdown of uranium in rocks and soil.<EOS>
