<BOS>It seeps up through the ground, and leaks into the air or water supply.<EOS>
<BOS>Radon can enter homes through cracks in floors, walls, or the foundation, and levels of radon can build up over time.<EOS>
<BOS>Studies show that high levels of radon gas inside the home or workplace increase the number of new cases of lung cancer and the number of deaths caused by lung cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>The risk of lung cancer is higher in smokers exposed to radon than in nonsmokers who are exposed to it.<EOS>
<BOS>In people who have never smoked, about 30% of deaths caused by lung cancer have been linked to being exposed to radon.<EOS>
<BOS>Workplace exposure: Studies show that being exposed to the following substances increases the risk of lung cancer: Asbestos.<EOS>
<BOS>Arsenic.<EOS>
<BOS>Chromium.<EOS>
<BOS>Nickel.<EOS>
<BOS>Beryllium.<EOS>
<BOS>Cadmium.<EOS>
<BOS>Tar and soot.<EOS>
<BOS>These substances can cause lung cancer in people who are exposed to them in the workplace and have never smoked.<EOS>
<BOS>As the level of exposure to these substances increases, the risk of lung cancer also increases.<EOS>
<BOS>The risk of lung cancer is even higher in people who are exposed and also smoke.<EOS>
<BOS>Air pollution: Studies show that living in areas with higher levels of air pollution increases the risk of lung cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Beta carotene supplements in heavy smokers Taking beta carotene supplements (pills) increases the risk of lung cancer, especially in smokers who smoke one or more packs a day.<EOS>
<BOS>The risk is higher in smokers who have at least one alcoholic drink every day.<EOS>
<BOS>The following are protective factors for lung cancer: Not smoking The best way to prevent lung cancer is to not smoke.<EOS>
<BOS>Quitting smoking Smokers can decrease their risk of lung cancer by quitting.<EOS>
<BOS>In smokers who have been treated for lung cancer, quitting smoking lowers the risk of new lung cancers.<EOS>
<BOS>Counseling, the use of nicotine replacement products, and antidepressant therapy have helped smokers quit for good.<EOS>
<BOS>In a person who has quit smoking, the chance of preventing lung cancer depends on how many years and how much the person smoked and the length of time since quitting.<EOS>
<BOS>After a person has quit smoking for 10 years, the risk of lung cancer decreases 30% to 50%.<EOS>
<BOS>See the following for more information on quitting smoking: Tobacco (includes help with quitting) Cigarette Smoking: Health Risks and How to Quit Lower exposure to workplace risk factors Laws that protect workers from being exposed to cancercausing substances, such as asbestos, arsenic, nickel, and chromium, may help lower their risk of developing lung cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Laws that prevent smoking in the workplace help lower the risk of lung cancer caused by secondhand smoke.<EOS>
<BOS>Lower exposure to radon Lowering radon levels may lower the risk of lung cancer, especially among cigarette smokers.<EOS>
<BOS>High levels of radon in homes may be reduced by taking steps to prevent radon leakage, such as sealing basements.<EOS>
<BOS>It is not clear if the following decrease the risk of lung cancer: Diet Some studies show that people who eat high amounts of fruits or vegetables have a lower risk of lung cancer than those who eat low amounts.<EOS>
<BOS>However, since smokers tend to have less healthy diets than nonsmokers, it is hard to know whether the decreased risk is from having a healthy diet or from not smoking.<EOS>
<BOS>Physical activity Some studies show that people who are physically active have a lower risk of lung cancer than people who are not.<EOS>
<BOS>However, since smokers tend to have different levels of physical activity than nonsmokers, it is hard to know if physical activity affects the risk of lung cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>The following do not decrease the risk of lung cancer: Beta carotene supplements in nonsmokers Studies of nonsmokers show that taking beta carotene supplements does not lower their risk of lung cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Vitamin E supplements Studies show that taking vitamin E supplements does not affect the risk of lung cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Cancer prevention clinical trials are used to study ways to prevent cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Cancer prevention clinical trials are used to study ways to lower the risk of developing certain types of cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Some cancer prevention trials are conducted with healthy people who have not had cancer but who have an increased risk for cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Other prevention trials are conducted with people who have had cancer and are trying to prevent another cancer of the same type or to lower their chance of developing a new type of cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Other trials are done with healthy volunteers who are not known to have any risk factors for cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>The purpose of some cancer prevention clinical trials is to find out whether actions people take can prevent cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>These may include eating fruits and vegetables, exercising, quitting smoking, or taking certain medicines, vitamins, minerals, or food supplements.<EOS>
<BOS>New ways to prevent lung cancer are being studied in clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>Clinical trials are taking place in many parts of the country.<EOS>
<BOS>Information about clinical trials can be found in the Clinical Trials section of the NCI website.<EOS>
<BOS>Check the list of NCIsupported cancer clinical trials for prevention trials for nonsmall cell lung cancer and small cell lung cancer that are now accepting patients.<EOS>
<BOS>These include trials for quitting smoking.<EOS>
<BOS>Key Points There is no standard staging system for myelodysplastic/myeloproliferative neoplasms.<EOS>
<BOS>There is no standard staging system for myelodysplastic/myeloproliferative neoplasms.<EOS>
<BOS>Staging is the process used to find out how far the cancer has spread.<EOS>
<BOS>There is no standard staging system for myelodysplastic /myeloproliferative neoplasms.<EOS>
<BOS>Treatment is based on the type of myelodysplastic/myeloproliferative neoplasm the patient has.<EOS>
<BOS>It is important to know the type in order to plan treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Tests that examine the nose and throat are used to detect (find) and diagnose nasopharyngeal cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>The following tests and procedures may be used: Physical exam and history : An exam of the body to check general signs of health, including checking for signs of disease, such as swollen lymph nodes in the neck or anything else that seems unusual.<EOS>
<BOS>A history of the patients health habits and past illnesses and treatments will also be taken.<EOS>
<BOS>Neurological exam : A series of questions and tests to check the brain, spinal cord, and nerve function.<EOS>
<BOS>The exam checks a persons mental status, coordination, and ability to walk normally, and how well the muscles, senses, and reflexes work.<EOS>
<BOS>This may also be called a neuro exam or a neurologic exam.<EOS>
<BOS>Biopsy : The removal of cells or tissues so they can be viewed under a microscope by a pathologist to check for signs of cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>The tissue sample is removed during one of the following procedures: Nasoscopy : A procedure to look inside the nose for abnormal areas.<EOS>
<BOS>A nasoscope is inserted through the nose.<EOS>
<BOS>A nasoscope is a thin, tubelike instrument with a light and a lens for viewing.<EOS>
<BOS>It may also have a tool to remove tissue samples, which are checked under a microscope for signs of cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Upper endoscopy : A procedure to look at the inside of the nose, throat, esophagus, stomach, and duodenum (first part of the small intestine, near the stomach).<EOS>
<BOS>An endoscope is inserted through the mouth and into the esophagus, stomach, and duodenum.<EOS>
<BOS>An endoscope is a thin, tubelike instrument with a light and a lens for viewing.<EOS>
<BOS>It may also have a tool to remove tissue samples.<EOS>
<BOS>The tissue samples are checked under a microscope for signs of cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>MRI (magnetic resonance imaging): A procedure that uses a magnet, radio waves, and a computer to make a series of detailed pictures of areas inside the body.<EOS>
<BOS>This procedure is also called nuclear magnetic resonance imaging (NMRI).<EOS>
<BOS>CT scan (CAT scan): A procedure that makes a series of detailed pictures of areas inside the body, taken from different angles.<EOS>
<BOS>The pictures are made by a computer linked to an xray machine.<EOS>
<BOS>A dye may be injected into a vein or swallowed to help the organs or tissues show up more clearly.<EOS>
<BOS>This procedure is also called computed tomography, computerized tomography, or computerized axial tomography.<EOS>
<BOS>PET scan (positron emission tomography scan): A procedure to find malignant tumor cells in the body.<EOS>
<BOS>A small amount of radioactive glucose (sugar) is injected into a vein.<EOS>
<BOS>The PET scanner rotates around the body and makes a picture of where glucose is being used in the body.<EOS>
<BOS>Malignant tumor cells show up brighter in the picture because they are more active and take up more glucose than normal cells do.<EOS>
<BOS>PET scans may be used to find nasopharyngeal cancers that have spread to the bone.<EOS>
<BOS>Sometimes a PET scan and a CT scan are done at the same time.<EOS>
<BOS>If there is any cancer, this increases the chance that it will be found.<EOS>
<BOS>Blood chemistry studies : A procedure in which a blood sample is checked to measure the amounts of certain substances released into the blood by organs and tissues in the body.<EOS>
<BOS>An unusual (higher or lower than normal) amount of a substance can be a sign of disease.<EOS>
<BOS>Complete blood count (CBC): A procedure in which a sample of blood is drawn and checked for the following: The number of red blood cells, white blood cells, and platelets.<EOS>
<BOS>The amount of hemoglobin (the protein that carries oxygen) in the red blood cells.<EOS>
<BOS>The portion of the blood sample made up of red blood cells.<EOS>
<BOS>EpsteinBarr virus (EBV) test: A blood test to check for antibodies to the EpsteinBarr virus and DNA markers of the EpsteinBarr virus.<EOS>
<BOS>These are found in the blood of patients who have been infected with EBV.<EOS>
<BOS>Hearing test: A procedure to check whether soft and loud sounds and low and highpitched sounds can be heard.<EOS>
<BOS>Each ear is checked separately.<EOS>
<BOS>Certain factors affect prognosis (chance of recovery) and treatment options.<EOS>
<BOS>Prognosis (chance of recovery) depends on the following: The stage of the cancer (whether it affects part of the hypopharynx, involves the whole hypopharynx, or has spread to other places in the body).<EOS>
<BOS>Hypopharyngeal cancer is usually detected in later stages because early signs and symptoms rarely occur.<EOS>
<BOS>The patient's age, gender, and general health.<EOS>
<BOS>The location of the cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Whether the patient smokes during radiation therapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Treatment options depend on the following: The stage of the cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Keeping the patient's ability to talk, eat, and breathe as normal as possible.<EOS>
<BOS>The patient's general health.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients who have had hypopharyngeal cancer are at an increased risk of developing a second cancer in the head or neck.<EOS>
<BOS>Frequent and careful followup is important.<EOS>
<BOS>Key Points Myelodysplastic syndromes are a group of cancers in which immature blood cells in the bone marrow do not mature or become healthy blood cells.<EOS>
<BOS>The different types of myelodysplastic syndromes are diagnosed based on certain changes in the blood cells and bone marrow.<EOS>
<BOS>Age and past treatment with chemotherapy or radiation therapy affect the risk of a myelodysplastic syndrome.<EOS>
<BOS>Signs and symptoms of a myelodysplastic syndrome include shortness of breath and feeling tired.<EOS>
<BOS>Tests that examine the blood and bone marrow are used to detect (find) and diagnose myelodysplastic syndromes.<EOS>
<BOS>Certain factors affect prognosis and treatment options.<EOS>
<BOS>Myelodysplastic syndromes are a group of cancers in which immature blood cells in the bone marrow do not mature or become healthy blood cells.<EOS>
<BOS>In a healthy person, the bone marrow makes blood stem cells (immature cells) that become mature blood cells over time.<EOS>
<BOS>A blood stem cell may become a lymphoid stem cell or a myeloid stem cell.<EOS>
<BOS>A lymphoid stem cell becomes a white blood cell.<EOS>
<BOS>A myeloid stem cell becomes one of three types of mature blood cells: Red blood cells that carry oxygen and other substances to all tissues of the body.<EOS>
<BOS>Platelets that form blood clots to stop bleeding.<EOS>
<BOS>White blood cells that fight infection and disease.<EOS>
<BOS>In a patient with a myelodysplastic syndrome, the blood stem cells (immature cells) do not become mature red blood cells, white blood cells, or platelets in the bone marrow.<EOS>
<BOS>These immature blood cells, called blasts, do not work the way they should and either die in the bone marrow or soon after they go into the blood.<EOS>
<BOS>This leaves less room for healthy white blood cells, red blood cells, and platelets to form in the bone marrow.<EOS>
<BOS>When there are fewer healthy blood cells, infection, anemia, or easy bleeding may occur.<EOS>
<BOS>The different types of myelodysplastic syndromes are diagnosed based on certain changes in the blood cells and bone marrow.<EOS>
<BOS>Refractory anemia: There are too few red blood cells in the blood and the patient has anemia.<EOS>
<BOS>The number of white blood cells and platelets is normal.<EOS>
<BOS>Refractory anemia with ring sideroblasts: There are too few red blood cells in the blood and the patient has anemia.<EOS>
<BOS>The red blood cells have too much iron inside the cell.<EOS>
<BOS>The number of white blood cells and platelets is normal.<EOS>
<BOS>Refractory anemia with excess blasts: There are too few red blood cells in the blood and the patient has anemia.<EOS>
<BOS>Five percent to 19% of the cells in the bone marrow are blasts.<EOS>
<BOS>There also may be changes to the white blood cells and platelets.<EOS>
<BOS>Refractory anemia with excess blasts may progress to acute myeloid leukemia (AML).<EOS>
<BOS>See the PDQ Adult Acute Myeloid Leukemia Treatment summary for more information.<EOS>
<BOS>Refractory cytopenia with multilineage dysplasia: There are too few of at least two types of blood cells (red blood cells, platelets, or white blood cells).<EOS>
<BOS>Less than 5% of the cells in the bone marrow are blasts and less than 1% of the cells in the blood are blasts.<EOS>
<BOS>If red blood cells are affected, they may have extra iron.<EOS>
<BOS>Refractory cytopenia may progress to acute myeloid leukemia (AML).<EOS>
<BOS>Refractory cytopenia with unilineage dysplasia: There are too few of one type of blood cell (red blood cells, platelets, or white blood cells).<EOS>
<BOS>There are changes in 10% or more of two other types of blood cells.<EOS>
<BOS>Less than 5% of the cells in the bone marrow are blasts and less than 1% of the cells in the blood are blasts.<EOS>
<BOS>Unclassifiable myelodysplastic syndrome: The numbers of blasts in the bone marrow and blood are normal, and the disease is not one of the other myelodysplastic syndromes.<EOS>
<BOS>Myelodysplastic syndrome associated with an isolated del(5q) chromosome abnormality: There are too few red blood cells in the blood and the patient has anemia.<EOS>
<BOS>Less than 5% of the cells in the bone marrow and blood are blasts.<EOS>
<BOS>There is a specific change in the chromosome.<EOS>
<BOS>Chronic myelomonocytic leukemia (CMML): See the PDQ summary on Myelodysplastic/ Myeloproliferative Neoplasms Treatment for more information.<EOS>
<BOS>Signs and symptoms of thymoma and thymic carcinoma include a cough and chest pain.<EOS>
<BOS>Thymoma and thymic carcinoma may not cause early signs or symptoms.<EOS>
<BOS>The cancer may be found during a routine chest xray.<EOS>
<BOS>Signs and symptoms may be caused by thymoma, thymic carcinoma, or other conditions.<EOS>
<BOS>Check with your doctor if you have any of the following: A cough that doesn't go away.<EOS>
<BOS>Chest pain.<EOS>
<BOS>Trouble breathing.<EOS>
<BOS>Certain factors affect prognosis (chance of recovery) and treatment options.<EOS>
<BOS>The prognosis (chance of recovery) and treatment options depend on the following: Whether the tumor is nonseminoma or seminoma.<EOS>
<BOS>The size of the tumor and where it is in the body.<EOS>
<BOS>The blood levels of AFP, hCG, and LDH.<EOS>
<BOS>Whether the tumor has spread to other parts of the body.<EOS>
<BOS>The way the tumor responds to initial treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Whether the tumor has just been diagnosed or has recurred (come back).<EOS>
<BOS>Tests that examine the uterus are used to detect (find) and diagnose gestational trophoblastic disease.<EOS>
<BOS>The following tests and procedures may be used: Physical exam and history : An exam of the body to check general signs of health, including checking for signs of disease, such as lumps or anything else that seems unusual.<EOS>
<BOS>A history of the patients health habits and past illnesses and treatments will also be taken.<EOS>
<BOS>Pelvic exam : An exam of the vagina, cervix, uterus, fallopian tubes, ovaries, and rectum.<EOS>
<BOS>A speculum is inserted into the vagina and the doctor or nurse looks at the vagina and cervix for signs of disease.<EOS>
<BOS>A Pap test of the cervix is usually done.<EOS>
<BOS>The doctor or nurse also inserts one or two lubricated, gloved fingers of one hand into the vagina and places the other hand over the lower abdomen to feel the size, shape, and position of the uterus and ovaries.<EOS>
<BOS>The doctor or nurse also inserts a lubricated, gloved finger into the rectum to feel for lumps or abnormal areas.<EOS>
<BOS>Ultrasound exam of the pelvis: A procedure in which highenergy sound waves (ultrasound) are bounced off internal tissues or organs in the pelvis and make echoes.<EOS>
<BOS>The echoes form a picture of body tissues called a sonogram.<EOS>
<BOS>Sometimes a transvaginal ultrasound (TVUS) will be done.<EOS>
<BOS>For TVUS, an ultrasound transducer (probe) is inserted into the vagina to make the sonogram.<EOS>
<BOS>Blood chemistry studies : A procedure in which a blood sample is checked to measure the amounts of certain substances released into the blood by organs and tissues in the body.<EOS>
<BOS>An unusual (higher or lower than normal) amount of a substance can be a sign of disease.<EOS>
<BOS>Blood is also tested to check the liver, kidney, and bone marrow.<EOS>
<BOS>Serum tumor marker test : A procedure in which a sample of blood is checked to measure the amounts of certain substances made by organs, tissues, or tumor cells in the body.<EOS>
<BOS>Certain substances are linked to specific types of cancer when found in increased levels in the body.<EOS>
<BOS>These are called tumor markers.<EOS>
<BOS>For GTD, the blood is checked for the level of beta human chorionic gonadotropin (hCG), a hormone that is made by the body during pregnancy.<EOS>
<BOS>hCG in the blood of a woman who is not pregnant may be a sign of GTD.<EOS>
<BOS>Urinalysis : A test to check the color of urine and its contents, such as sugar, protein, blood, bacteria, and the level of hCG.<EOS>
<BOS>Unusual moles, exposure to sunlight, and health history can affect the risk of melanoma.<EOS>
<BOS>Anything that increases your risk of getting a disease is called a risk factor.<EOS>
<BOS>Having a risk factor does not mean that you will get cancer; not having risk factors doesn't mean that you will not get cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Talk with your doctor if you think you may be at risk.<EOS>
<BOS>Risk factors for melanoma include the following: Having a fair complexion, which includes the following: Fair skin that freckles and burns easily, does not tan, or tans poorly.<EOS>
<BOS>Blue or green or other lightcolored eyes.<EOS>
<BOS>Red or blond hair.<EOS>
<BOS>Being exposed to natural sunlight or artificial sunlight (such as from tanning beds) over long periods of time.<EOS>
<BOS>Being exposed to certain factors in the environment (in the air, your home or workplace, and your food and water).<EOS>
<BOS>Some of the environmental risk factors for melanoma are radiation, solvents, vinyl chloride, and PCBs.<EOS>
<BOS>Having a history of many blistering sunburns, especially as a child or teenager.<EOS>
<BOS>Having several large or many small moles.<EOS>
<BOS>Having a family history of unusual moles (atypical nevus syndrome).<EOS>
<BOS>Having a family or personal history of melanoma.<EOS>
<BOS>Being white.<EOS>
<BOS>Having a weakened immune system.<EOS>
<BOS>Having certain changes in the genes that are linked to melanoma.<EOS>
<BOS>Being white or having a fair complexion increases the risk of melanoma, but anyone can have melanoma, including people with dark skin.<EOS>
<BOS>See the following PDQ summaries for more information on risk factors for melanoma: Genetics of Skin Cancer Skin Cancer Prevention.<EOS>
<BOS>Certain factors affect prognosis (chance of recovery) and treatment options.<EOS>
<BOS>The prognosis (chance of recovery) and treatment options depend on the following: The stage of the cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>The age of the patient.<EOS>
<BOS>The number of CD4 lymphocytes (a type of white blood cell) in the blood.<EOS>
<BOS>The number of places in the body lymphoma is found outside the lymph system.<EOS>
<BOS>Whether the patient has a history of intravenous (IV) drug use.<EOS>
<BOS>The patient's ability to carry out regular daily activities.<EOS>
<BOS>Certain factors affect prognosis (chance of recovery) and treatment options.<EOS>
<BOS>The prognosis (chance of recovery) and treatment options depend on: The age of the patient.<EOS>
<BOS>The subtype of AML.<EOS>
<BOS>Whether the patient received chemotherapy in the past to treat a different cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Whether there is a history of a blood disorder such as myelodysplastic syndrome.<EOS>
<BOS>Whether the cancer has spread to the central nervous system.<EOS>
<BOS>Whether the cancer has been treated before or recurred (come back).<EOS>
<BOS>It is important that acute leukemia be treated right away.<EOS>
<BOS>Key Points After retinoblastoma has been diagnosed, tests are done to find out if cancer cells have spread within the eye or to other parts of the body.<EOS>
<BOS>The International Retinoblastoma Staging System (IRSS) may be used for staging retinoblastoma.<EOS>
<BOS>Stage 0 Stage I Stage II Stage III Stage IV There are three ways that cancer spreads in the body.<EOS>
<BOS>Cancer may spread from where it began to other parts of the body.<EOS>
<BOS>Treatment for retinoblastoma depends on whether it is intraocular (within the eye) or extraocular (outside the eye).<EOS>
<BOS>Intraocular retinoblastoma Extraocular retinoblastoma (metastatic) After retinoblastoma has been diagnosed, tests are done to find out if cancer cells have spread within the eye or to other parts of the body.<EOS>
<BOS>The process used to find out if cancer has spread within the eye or to other parts of the body is called staging.<EOS>
<BOS>The information gathered from the staging process determines whether retinoblastoma is only in the eye (intraocular) or has spread outside the eye (extraocular).<EOS>
<BOS>It is important to know the stage in order to plan treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>The results of the tests used to diagnose cancer are often also used to stage the disease.<EOS>
<BOS>(See the General Information section.<EOS>
<BOS>) The following tests and procedures may be used in the staging process: Bone scan : A procedure to check if there are rapidly dividing cells, such as cancer cells, in the bone.<EOS>
<BOS>A very small amount of radioactive material is injected into a vein and travels through the bloodstream.<EOS>
<BOS>The radioactive material collects in the bones and is detected by a scanner that also takes a picture of the body.<EOS>
<BOS>Areas of bone with cancer show up brighter in the picture because they take up more radioactive material than normal bone cells do.<EOS>
<BOS>Bone marrow aspiration and biopsy : The removal of bone marrow and a small piece of bone by inserting a hollow needle into the hipbone or breastbone.<EOS>
<BOS>A pathologist views the bone marrow under a microscope to look for signs of cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>A bone marrow aspiration and biopsy is done if the doctor thinks the cancer has spread outside of the eye.<EOS>
<BOS>Lumbar puncture : A procedure used to collect cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) from the spinal column.<EOS>
<BOS>This is done by placing a needle between two bones in the spine and into the CSF around the spinal cord and removing a sample of the fluid.<EOS>
<BOS>The sample of CSF is checked under a microscope for signs that the cancer has spread to the brain and spinal cord.<EOS>
<BOS>This procedure is also called an LP or spinal tap.<EOS>
<BOS>The International Retinoblastoma Staging System (IRSS) may be used for staging retinoblastoma.<EOS>
<BOS>There are several staging systems for retinoblastoma.<EOS>
<BOS>The IRSS stages are based on how much cancer remains after surgery to remove the tumor and whether the cancer has spread.<EOS>
<BOS>Stage 0 The tumor is in the eye only.<EOS>
<BOS>The eye has not been removed and the tumor was treated without surgery.<EOS>
<BOS>Stage I The tumor is in the eye only.<EOS>
<BOS>The eye has been removed and no cancer cells remain.<EOS>
<BOS>Stage II The tumor is in the eye only.<EOS>
<BOS>The eye has been removed and there are cancer cells left that can be seen only with a microscope.<EOS>
<BOS>Stage III Stage III is divided into stages IIIa and IIIb: In stage IIIa, cancer has spread from the eye to tissues around the eye socket.<EOS>
<BOS>In stage IIIb, cancer has spread from the eye to lymph nodes near the ear or in the neck.<EOS>
<BOS>Stage IV Stage IV is divided into stages IVa and IVb: In stage IVa, cancer has spread to the blood but not to the brain or spinal cord.<EOS>
<BOS>One or more tumors may have spread to other parts of the body such as the bone or liver.<EOS>
<BOS>In stage IVb, cancer has spread to the brain or spinal cord.<EOS>
<BOS>It also may have spread to other parts of the body.<EOS>
<BOS>There are three ways that cancer spreads in the body.<EOS>
<BOS>Cancer can spread through tissue, the lymph system, and the blood: Tissue.<EOS>
<BOS>The cancer spreads from where it began by growing into nearby areas.<EOS>
<BOS>Lymph system.<EOS>
<BOS>The cancer spreads from where it began by getting into the lymph system.<EOS>
<BOS>The cancer travels through the lymph vessels to other parts of the body.<EOS>
<BOS>Blood.<EOS>
<BOS>The cancer spreads from where it began by getting into the blood.<EOS>
<BOS>The cancer travels through the blood vessels to other parts of the body.<EOS>
<BOS>Cancer may spread from where it began to other parts of the body.<EOS>
<BOS>When cancer spreads to another part of the body, it is called metastasis.<EOS>
<BOS>Cancer cells break away from where they began (the primary tumor) and travel through the lymph system or blood.<EOS>
<BOS>Lymph system.<EOS>
<BOS>The cancer gets into the lymph system, travels through the lymph vessels, and forms a tumor (metastatic tumor) in another part of the body.<EOS>
<BOS>Blood.<EOS>
<BOS>The cancer gets into the blood, travels through the blood vessels, and forms a tumor (metastatic tumor) in another part of the body.<EOS>
<BOS>The metastatic tumor is the same type of cancer as the primary tumor.<EOS>
<BOS>For example, if retinoblastoma spreads to the bone, the cancer cells in the bone are actually retinoblastoma cells.<EOS>
<BOS>The disease is metastatic retinoblastoma, not bone cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Treatment for retinoblastoma depends on whether it is intraocular (within the eye) or extraocular (outside the eye).<EOS>
<BOS>Intraocular retinoblastoma In intraocular retinoblastoma, cancer is found in one or both eyes and may be in the retina only or may also be in other parts of the eye such as the choroid, ciliary body, or part of the optic nerve.<EOS>
<BOS>Cancer has not spread to tissues around the outside of the eye or to other parts of the body.<EOS>
<BOS>Extraocular retinoblastoma (metastatic) In extraocular retinoblastoma, cancer has spread beyond the eye.<EOS>
<BOS>It may be found in tissues around the eye (orbital retinoblastoma) or it may have spread to the central nervous system (brain and spinal cord) or to other parts of the body such as the liver, bones, bone marrow, or lymph nodes.<EOS>
<BOS>Health history can affect the risk of gastrointestinal carcinoid tumors.<EOS>
<BOS>Anything that increases a person's chance of developing a disease is called a risk factor.<EOS>
<BOS>Having a risk factor does not mean that you will get cancer; not having risk factors doesnt mean that you will not get cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Talk to your doctor if you think you may be at risk.<EOS>
<BOS>Risk factors for GI carcinoid tumors include the following: Having a family history of multiple endocrine neoplasia type 1 (MEN1) syndrome or neurofibromatosis type 1 (NF1) syndrome.<EOS>
<BOS>Having certain conditions that affect the stomach's ability to make stomach acid, such as atrophic gastritis, pernicious anemia, or ZollingerEllison syndrome.<EOS>
<BOS>Key Points After a childhood extracranial germ cell tumor has been diagnosed, tests are done to find out if cancer cells have spread from where the tumor started to nearby areas or to other parts of the body.<EOS>
<BOS>There are three ways that cancer spreads in the body.<EOS>
<BOS>Cancer may spread from where it began to other parts of the body.<EOS>
<BOS>Stages are used to describe the different types of extracranial germ cell tumors.<EOS>
<BOS>Childhood nonseminoma testicular germ cell tumors Childhood ovarian germ cell tumors Childhood extragonadal extracranial germ cell tumors After a childhood extracranial germ cell tumor has been diagnosed, tests are done to find out if cancer cells have spread from where the tumor started to nearby areas or to other parts of the body.<EOS>
<BOS>The process used to find out if cancer has spread from where the tumor started to other parts of the body is called staging.<EOS>
<BOS>The information gathered from the staging process determines the stage of the disease.<EOS>
<BOS>It is important to know the stage in order to plan treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>In some cases, staging may follow surgery to remove the tumor.<EOS>
<BOS>The following procedures may be used: MRI (magnetic resonance imaging): A procedure that uses a magnet, radio waves, and a computer to make a series of detailed pictures of areas inside the body, such as the lymph nodes.<EOS>
<BOS>This procedure is also called nuclear magnetic resonance imaging.<EOS>
<BOS>CT scan (CAT scan): A procedure that makes a series of detailed pictures of areas inside the body, such as the chest or lymph nodes, taken from different angles.<EOS>
<BOS>The pictures are made by a computer linked to an xray machine.<EOS>
<BOS>A dye may be injected into a vein or swallowed to help the organs or tissues show up more clearly.<EOS>
<BOS>This procedure is also called computed tomography, computerized tomography, or computerized axial tomography.<EOS>
<BOS>Bone scan : A procedure to check if there are rapidly dividing cells, such as cancer cells, in the bone.<EOS>
<BOS>A very small amount of radioactive material is injected into a vein and travels through the bloodstream.<EOS>
<BOS>The radioactive material collects in the bones with cancer and is detected by a scanner.<EOS>
<BOS>Thoracentesis : The removal of fluid from the space between the lining of the chest and the lung, using a needle.<EOS>
<BOS>A pathologist views the fluid under a microscope to look for cancer cells.<EOS>
<BOS>Paracentesis : The removal of fluid from the space between the lining of the abdomen and the organs in the abdomen, using a needle.<EOS>
<BOS>A pathologist views the fluid under a microscope to look for cancer cells.<EOS>
<BOS>The results from tests and procedures used to detect and diagnose childhood extracranial germ cell tumors may also be used in staging.<EOS>
<BOS>There are three ways that cancer spreads in the body.<EOS>
<BOS>Cancer can spread through tissue, the lymph system, and the blood: Tissue.<EOS>
<BOS>The cancer spreads from where it began by growing into nearby areas.<EOS>
<BOS>Lymph system.<EOS>
<BOS>The cancer spreads from where it began by getting into the lymph system.<EOS>
<BOS>The cancer travels through the lymph vessels to other parts of the body.<EOS>
<BOS>Blood.<EOS>
<BOS>The cancer spreads from where it began by getting into the blood.<EOS>
<BOS>The cancer travels through the blood vessels to other parts of the body.<EOS>
<BOS>Cancer may spread from where it began to other parts of the body.<EOS>
<BOS>When cancer spreads to another part of the body, it is called metastasis.<EOS>
<BOS>Cancer cells break away from where they began (the primary tumor) and travel through the lymph system or blood.<EOS>
<BOS>Lymph system.<EOS>
<BOS>The cancer gets into the lymph system, travels through the lymph vessels, and forms a tumor (metastatic tumor) in another part of the body.<EOS>
<BOS>Blood.<EOS>
<BOS>The cancer gets into the blood, travels through the blood vessels, and forms a tumor (metastatic tumor) in another part of the body.<EOS>
<BOS>The metastatic tumor is the same type of cancer as the primary tumor.<EOS>
<BOS>For example, if an extracranial germ cell tumor spreads to the liver, the cancer cells in the liver are actually cancerous germ cells.<EOS>
<BOS>The disease is metastatic extracranial germ cell tumor, not liver cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Stages are used to describe the different types of extracranial germ cell tumors.<EOS>
<BOS>Childhood nonseminoma testicular germ cell tumors Stage I: In stage I, the cancer is found in the testicle only and is completely removed by surgery.<EOS>
<BOS>Stage II: In stage II, the cancer is removed by surgery and some cancer cells remain in the scrotum or cancer that can be seen with a microscope only has spread to the scrotum or spermatic cord.<EOS>
<BOS>Tumor marker levels do not return to normal after surgery or the tumor marker levels increase.<EOS>
<BOS>Stage III: In stage III, the cancer has spread to one or more lymph nodes in the abdomen and is not completely removed by surgery.<EOS>
<BOS>The cancer that remains after surgery can be seen without a microscope.<EOS>
<BOS>Stage IV: In stage IV, the cancer has spread to distant parts of the body such as the liver, brain, bone, or lung.<EOS>
<BOS>Childhood ovarian germ cell tumors There are two types of stages used for childhood ovarian germ cell tumors.<EOS>
<BOS>The following stages are from the Children's Oncology Group: Stage I: In stage I, the cancer is in the ovary and can be completely removed by surgery and the capsule (outer covering) of the ovary has not ruptured (broken open).<EOS>
<BOS>Stage II: In stage II, one of the following is true: The cancer is not completely removed by surgery.<EOS>
<BOS>The remaining cancer can be seen with a microscope only.<EOS>
<BOS>The cancer has spread to the lymph nodes and can be seen with a microscope only.<EOS>
<BOS>The cancer has spread to the capsule (outer covering) of the ovary.<EOS>
<BOS>Stage III: In stage III, one of the following is true: The cancer is not completely removed by surgery.<EOS>
<BOS>The remaining cancer can be seen without a microscope.<EOS>
<BOS>The cancer has spread to lymph nodes and the lymph nodes are 2 centimeters or larger.<EOS>
<BOS>Cancer in the lymph nodes can be seen without a microscope.<EOS>
<BOS>The cancer is found in fluid in the abdomen.<EOS>
<BOS>Stage IV: In stage IV, the cancer has spread to the lung, liver, brain, or bone.<EOS>
<BOS>The following stages are from the International Federation of Gynecology and Obstetrics (FIGO): Stage I: In stage I, cancer is found in one or both of the ovaries and has not spread.<EOS>
<BOS>Stage I is divided into stage IA, stage IB, and stage IC.<EOS>
<BOS>Stage IA: Cancer is found in one ovary.<EOS>
<BOS>Stage IB: Cancer is found in both ovaries.<EOS>
<BOS>Stage IC: Cancer is found in one or both ovaries and one of the following is true: cancer is found on the outside surface of one or both ovaries; or the capsule (outer covering) of the tumor has ruptured (broken open); or cancer cells are found in fluid that has collected in the abdomen; or cancer cells are found in washings of the peritoneal cavity (the body cavity that contains most of the organs in the abdomen).<EOS>
<BOS>Stage II: In stage II, cancer is found in one or both ovaries and has spread into other areas of the pelvis.<EOS>
<BOS>Stage II is divided into stage IIA, stage IIB, and stage IIC.<EOS>
<BOS>Stage IIA: Cancer has spread to the uterus and/or the fallopian tubes (the long slender tubes through which eggs pass from the ovaries to the uterus).<EOS>
<BOS>Stage IIB: Cancer has spread to other tissue within the pelvis such as the bladder, rectum, or vagina.<EOS>
<BOS>Stage IIC: Cancer has spread to the uterus and/or fallopian tubes and/or other tissue within the pelvis and one of the following is true: cancer is found on the outside surface of one or both ovaries; or the capsule (outer covering) of the tumor has ruptured (broken open); or cancer cells are found in fluid that has collected in the abdomen; or cancer cells are found in washings of the peritoneal cavity (the body cavity that contains most of the organs in the abdomen).<EOS>
<BOS>Stage III: In stage III, cancer is found in one or both ovaries and has spread to other parts of the abdomen.<EOS>
<BOS>Cancer that has spread to the surface of the liver is also stage III disease.<EOS>
<BOS>Stage III is divided into stage IIIA, stage IIIB, and stage IIIC: Stage IIIA: The tumor is found in the pelvis only, but cancer cells that can only be seen with a microscope have spread to the surface of the peritoneum (tissue that lines the abdominal wall and covers most of the organs in the abdomen) or to the small bowel.<EOS>
<BOS>Stage IIIB: Cancer has spread to the peritoneum and is 2 centimeters or smaller in diameter.<EOS>
<BOS>Stage IIIC: Cancer has spread to the peritoneum and is larger than 2 centimeters in diameter and/or has spread to lymph nodes in the abdomen.<EOS>
<BOS>Stage IV: In stage IV, cancer is found in one or both ovaries and has metastasized (spread) beyond the abdomen to other parts of the body.<EOS>
<BOS>Cancer that has spread to tissues in the liver is also stage IV disease.<EOS>
<BOS>Childhood extragonadal extracranial germ cell tumors Stage I: In stage I, the cancer is in one place and can be completely removed by surgery.<EOS>
<BOS>For tumors in the sacrum or coccyx (bottom part of the spine), the sacrum and coccyx are completely removed by surgery.<EOS>
<BOS>Tumor marker levels return to normal after surgery.<EOS>
<BOS>Stage II: In stage II, the cancer has spread to the capsule (outer covering) and/or lymph nodes.<EOS>
<BOS>The cancer is not completely removed by surgery and the cancer remaining after surgery can be seen with a microscope only.<EOS>
<BOS>Tumor marker levels do not return to normal after surgery or increase.<EOS>
<BOS>Stage III: In stage III, one of the following is true: The cancer is not completely removed by surgery.<EOS>
<BOS>The cancer remaining after surgery can be seen without a microscope.<EOS>
<BOS>The cancer has spread to lymph nodes and is larger than 2 centimeters in diameter.<EOS>
<BOS>Stage IV: In stage IV, the cancer has spread to distant parts of the body, including the liver, brain, bone, or lung.<EOS>
<BOS>Certain factors affect prognosis (chance of recovery) and treatment options.<EOS>
<BOS>The prognosis (chance of recovery) and treatment options for Wilms tumor depend on the following: How different the tumor cells are from normal kidney cells when looked at under a microscope.<EOS>
<BOS>The stage of the cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>The type of tumor.<EOS>
<BOS>The age of the child.<EOS>
<BOS>Whether the tumor can be completely removed by surgery.<EOS>
<BOS>Whether there are certain changes in chromosomes or genes.<EOS>
<BOS>Whether the cancer has just been diagnosed or has recurred (come back).<EOS>
<BOS>The prognosis for renal cell cancer depends on the following: The stage of the cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Whether the cancer has spread to the lymph nodes.<EOS>
<BOS>The prognosis for rhabdoid tumor of the kidney depends on the following: The age of the child at the time of diagnosis.<EOS>
<BOS>The stage of the cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Whether the cancer has spread to the brain or spinal cord.<EOS>
<BOS>The prognosis for clear cell sarcoma of the kidney depends on the following: The age of the child at the time of diagnosis.<EOS>
<BOS>The stage of the cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Tests that examine the head, neck, and the inside of the mouth are used to detect (find) and diagnose salivary gland cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>The following procedures may be used: Physical exam and history : An exam of the body to check general signs of health.<EOS>
<BOS>The head, neck, mouth, and throat will be checked for signs of disease, such as lumps or anything else that seems unusual.<EOS>
<BOS>A history of the patient's health habits and past illnesses and treatments will also be taken.<EOS>
<BOS>MRI (magnetic resonance imaging): A procedure that uses a magnet, radio waves, and a computer to make a series of detailed pictures of areas inside the body.<EOS>
<BOS>This procedure is also called nuclear magnetic resonance imaging (NMRI).<EOS>
<BOS>CT scan (CAT scan): A procedure that makes a series of detailed pictures of areas inside the body, taken from different angles.<EOS>
<BOS>The pictures are made by a computer linked to an xray machine.<EOS>
<BOS>A dye may be injected into a vein or swallowed to help the organs or tissues show up more clearly.<EOS>
<BOS>This procedure is also called computed tomography, computerized tomography, or computerized axial tomography.<EOS>
<BOS>PET scan (positron emission tomography scan): A procedure to find malignant tumor cells in the body.<EOS>
<BOS>A small amount of radioactive glucose (sugar) is injected into a vein.<EOS>
<BOS>The PET scanner rotates around the body and makes a picture of where glucose is being used in the body.<EOS>
<BOS>Malignant tumor cells show up brighter in the picture because they are more active and take up more glucose than normal cells do.<EOS>
<BOS>Endoscopy : A procedure to look at organs and tissues inside the body to check for abnormal areas.<EOS>
<BOS>For salivary gland cancer, an endoscope is inserted into the mouth to look at the mouth, throat, and larynx.<EOS>
<BOS>An endoscope is a thin, tubelike instrument with a light and a lens for viewing.<EOS>
<BOS>Biopsy : The removal of cells or tissues so they can be viewed under a microscope by a pathologist to check for signs of cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Fine needle aspiration (FNA) biopsy : The removal of tissue or fluid using a thin needle.<EOS>
<BOS>An FNA is the most common type of biopsy used for salivary gland cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Incisional biopsy : The removal of part of a lump or a sample of tissue that doesnt look normal.<EOS>
<BOS>Surgery : If cancer cannot be diagnosed from the sample of tissue removed during an FNA biopsy or an incisional biopsy, the mass may be removed and checked for signs of cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Because salivary gland cancer can be hard to diagnose, patients should ask to have the tissue samples checked by a pathologist who has experience in diagnosing salivary gland cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>New types of treatment are being tested in clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>This summary section describes treatments that are being studied in clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>It may not mention every new treatment being studied.<EOS>
<BOS>Information about ongoing clinical trials is available from the NCI website.<EOS>
<BOS>Targeted therapy Targeted therapy is a treatment that uses drugs or other substances to find and attack specific cancer cells without harming normal cells.<EOS>
<BOS>Kinase inhibitor therapy and monoclonal antibody therapy are types of targeted therapy being studied in clinical trials for osteosarcoma.<EOS>
<BOS>Kinase inhibitor therapy blocks a protein needed for cancer cells to divide.<EOS>
<BOS>Sorafenib is a type of kinase inhibitor therapy being studied for the treatment of recurrent osteosarcoma.<EOS>
<BOS>Monoclonal antibody therapy is a cancer treatment that uses antibodies made in the laboratory, from a single type of immune system cell.<EOS>
<BOS>These antibodies can identify substances on cancer cells or normal substances that may help cancer cells grow.<EOS>
<BOS>The antibodies attach to the substances and kill the cancer cells, block their growth, or keep them from spreading.<EOS>
<BOS>Monoclonal antibodies are given by infusion.<EOS>
<BOS>They may be used alone or to carry drugs, toxins, or radioactive material directly to cancer cells.<EOS>
<BOS>Denosumab, dinutuximab, and glembatumumab are monoclonal antibodies being studied for the treatment of recurrent osteosarcoma.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients may want to think about taking part in a clinical trial.<EOS>
<BOS>For some patients, taking part in a clinical trial may be the best treatment choice.<EOS>
<BOS>Clinical trials are part of the cancer research process.<EOS>
<BOS>Clinical trials are done to find out if new cancer treatments are safe and effective or better than the standard treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Many of today's standard treatments for cancer are based on earlier clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients who take part in a clinical trial may receive the standard treatment or be among the first to receive a new treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients who take part in clinical trials also help improve the way cancer will be treated in the future.<EOS>
<BOS>Even when clinical trials do not lead to effective new treatments, they often answer important questions and help move research forward.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients can enter clinical trials before, during, or after starting their cancer treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Some clinical trials only include patients who have not yet received treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Other trials test treatments for patients whose cancer has not gotten better.<EOS>
<BOS>There are also clinical trials that test new ways to stop cancer from recurring (coming back) or reduce the side effects of cancer treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Clinical trials are taking place in many parts of the country.<EOS>
<BOS>See the Treatment Options section that follows for links to current treatment clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>These have been retrieved from NCI's listing of clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>Followup tests may be needed.<EOS>
<BOS>Some of the tests that were done to diagnose the cancer or to find out the stage of the cancer may be repeated.<EOS>
<BOS>Some tests will be repeated in order to see how well the treatment is working.<EOS>
<BOS>Decisions about whether to continue, change, or stop treatment may be based on the results of these tests.<EOS>
<BOS>Some of the tests will continue to be done from time to time after treatment has ended.<EOS>
<BOS>The results of these tests can show if your child's condition has changed or if the cancer has recurred (come back).<EOS>
<BOS>These tests are sometimes called followup tests or checkups.<EOS>
<BOS>Key Points There are different types of treatment for patients with small intestine cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Three types of standard treatment are used: Surgery Radiation therapy Chemotherapy New types of treatment are being tested in clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>Biologic therapy Radiation therapy with radiosensitizers Patients may want to think about taking part in a clinical trial.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients can enter clinical trials before, during, or after starting their cancer treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Followup tests may be needed.<EOS>
<BOS>There are different types of treatment for patients with small intestine cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Different types of treatments are available for patients with small intestine cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Some treatments are standard (the currently used treatment), and some are being tested in clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>A treatment clinical trial is a research study meant to help improve current treatments or obtain information on new treatments for patients with cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>When clinical trials show that a new treatment is better than the standard treatment, the new treatment may become the standard treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients may want to think about taking part in a clinical trial.<EOS>
<BOS>Some clinical trials are open only to patients who have not started treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Three types of standard treatment are used: Surgery Surgery is the most common treatment of small intestine cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>One of the following types of surgery may be done: Resection: Surgery to remove part or all of an organ that contains cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>The resection may include the small intestine and nearby organs (if the cancer has spread).<EOS>
<BOS>The doctor may remove the section of the small intestine that contains cancer and perform an anastomosis (joining the cut ends of the intestine together).<EOS>
<BOS>The doctor will usually remove lymph nodes near the small intestine and examine them under a microscope to see whether they contain cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Bypass: Surgery to allow food in the small intestine to go around (bypass) a tumor that is blocking the intestine but cannot be removed.<EOS>
<BOS>Even if the doctor removes all the cancer that can be seen at the time of the surgery, some patients may be given radiation therapy after surgery to kill any cancer cells that are left.<EOS>
<BOS>Treatment given after the surgery, to lower the risk that the cancer will come back, is called adjuvant therapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Radiation therapy Radiation therapy is a cancer treatment that uses highenergy xrays or other types of radiation to kill cancer cells or keep them from growing.<EOS>
<BOS>There are two types of radiation therapy: External radiation therapy uses a machine outside the body to send radiation toward the cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Internal radiation therapy uses a radioactive substance sealed in needles, seeds, wires, or catheters that are placed directly into or near the cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>The way the radiation therapy is given depends on the type of the cancer being treated.<EOS>
<BOS>External radiation therapy is used to treat small intestine cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Chemotherapy Chemotherapy is a cancer treatment that uses drugs to stop the growth of cancer cells, either by killing the cells or by stopping them from dividing.<EOS>
<BOS>When chemotherapy is taken by mouth or injected into a vein or muscle, the drugs enter the bloodstream and can reach cancer cells throughout the body (systemic chemotherapy).<EOS>
<BOS>When chemotherapy is placed directly into the cerebrospinal fluid, an organ, or a body cavity such as the abdomen, the drugs mainly affect cancer cells in those areas (regional chemotherapy).<EOS>
<BOS>The way the chemotherapy is given depends on the type and stage of the cancer being treated.<EOS>
<BOS>New types of treatment are being tested in clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>This summary section describes treatments that are being studied in clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>It may not mention every new treatment being studied.<EOS>
<BOS>Information about clinical trials is available from the NCI website.<EOS>
<BOS>Biologic therapy Biologic therapy is a treatment that uses the patient's immune system to fight cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Substances made by the body or made in a laboratory are used to boost, direct, or restore the body's natural defenses against cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>This type of cancer treatment is also called biotherapy or immunotherapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Radiation therapy with radiosensitizers Radiosensitizers are drugs that make tumor cells more sensitive to radiation therapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Combining radiation therapy with radiosensitizers may kill more tumor cells.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients may want to think about taking part in a clinical trial.<EOS>
<BOS>For some patients, taking part in a clinical trial may be the best treatment choice.<EOS>
<BOS>Clinical trials are part of the cancer research process.<EOS>
<BOS>Clinical trials are done to find out if new cancer treatments are safe and effective or better than the standard treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Many of today's standard treatments for cancer are based on earlier clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients who take part in a clinical trial may receive the standard treatment or be among the first to receive a new treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients who take part in clinical trials also help improve the way cancer will be treated in the future.<EOS>
<BOS>Even when clinical trials do not lead to effective new treatments, they often answer important questions and help move research forward.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients can enter clinical trials before, during, or after starting their cancer treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Some clinical trials only include patients who have not yet received treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Other trials test treatments for patients whose cancer has not gotten better.<EOS>
<BOS>There are also clinical trials that test new ways to stop cancer from recurring (coming back) or reduce the side effects of cancer treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Clinical trials are taking place in many parts of the country.<EOS>
<BOS>See the Treatment Options section that follows for links to current treatment clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>These have been retrieved from NCI's listing of clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>Followup tests may be needed.<EOS>
<BOS>Some of the tests that were done to diagnose the cancer or to find out the stage of the cancer may be repeated.<EOS>
<BOS>Some tests will be repeated in order to see how well the treatment is working.<EOS>
<BOS>Decisions about whether to continue, change, or stop treatment may be based on the results of these tests.<EOS>
<BOS>Some of the tests will continue to be done from time to time after treatment has ended.<EOS>
<BOS>The results of these tests can show if your condition has changed or if the cancer has recurred (come back).<EOS>
<BOS>These tests are sometimes called followup tests or checkups.<EOS>
<BOS>Treatment Options for Small Intestine Cancer Small Intestine Adenocarcinoma When possible, treatment of small intestine adenocarcinoma will be surgery to remove the tumor and some of the normal tissue around it.<EOS>
<BOS>Treatment of small intestine adenocarcinoma that cannot be removed by surgery may include the following: Surgery to bypass the tumor.<EOS>
<BOS>Radiation therapy as palliative therapy to relieve symptoms and improve the patient's quality of life.<EOS>
<BOS>A clinical trial of radiation therapy with radiosensitizers, with or without chemotherapy.<EOS>
<BOS>A clinical trial of new anticancer drugs.<EOS>
<BOS>A clinical trial of biologic therapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Check the list of NCIsupported cancer clinical trials that are now accepting patients with small intestine adenocarcinoma.<EOS>
<BOS>For more specific results, refine the search by using other search features, such as the location of the trial, the type of treatment, or the name of the drug.<EOS>
<BOS>Talk with your doctor about clinical trials that may be right for you.<EOS>
<BOS>General information about clinical trials is available from the NCI website.<EOS>
<BOS>Small Intestine Leiomyosarcoma When possible, treatment of small intestine leiomyosarcoma will be surgery to remove the tumor and some of the normal tissue around it.<EOS>
<BOS>Treatment of small intestine leiomyosarcoma that cannot be removed by surgery may include the following: Surgery (to bypass the tumor) and radiation therapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Surgery, radiation therapy, or chemotherapy as palliative therapy to relieve symptoms and improve the patient's quality of life.<EOS>
<BOS>A clinical trial of new anticancer drugs.<EOS>
<BOS>A clinical trial of biologic therapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Check the list of NCIsupported cancer clinical trials that are now accepting patients with small intestine leiomyosarcoma.<EOS>
<BOS>For more specific results, refine the search by using other search features, such as the location of the trial, the type of treatment, or the name of the drug.<EOS>
<BOS>Talk with your doctor about clinical trials that may be right for you.<EOS>
<BOS>General information about clinical trials is available from the NCI website.<EOS>
<BOS>Recurrent Small Intestine Cancer Treatment of recurrent small intestine cancer that has spread to other parts of the body is usually a clinical trial of new anticancer drugs or biologic therapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Treatment of locally recurrent small intestine cancer may include the following: Surgery.<EOS>
<BOS>Radiation therapy or chemotherapy as palliative therapy to relieve symptoms and improve the patient's quality of life.<EOS>
<BOS>A clinical trial of radiation therapy with radiosensitizers, with or without chemotherapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Check the list of NCIsupported cancer clinical trials that are now accepting patients with recurrent small intestine cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>For more specific results, refine the search by using other search features, such as the location of the trial, the type of treatment, or the name of the drug.<EOS>
<BOS>Talk with your doctor about clinical trials that may be right for you.<EOS>
<BOS>General information about clinical trials is available from the NCI website.<EOS>
<BOS>Key Points There are different types of treatment for patients with pancreatic NETs.<EOS>
<BOS>Six types of standard treatment are used: Surgery Chemotherapy Hormone therapy Hepatic arterial occlusion or chemoembolization Targeted therapy Supportive care New types of treatment are being tested in clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients may want to think about taking part in a clinical trial.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients can enter clinical trials before, during, or after starting their cancer treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Followup tests may be needed.<EOS>
<BOS>There are different types of treatment for patients with pancreatic NETs.<EOS>
<BOS>Different types of treatments are available for patients with pancreatic neuroendocrine tumors (NETs).<EOS>
<BOS>Some treatments are standard (the currently used treatment), and some are being tested in clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>A treatment clinical trial is a research study meant to help improve current treatments or obtain information on new treatments for patients with cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>When clinical trials show that a new treatment is better than the standard treatment, the new treatment may become the standard treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients may want to think about taking part in a clinical trial.<EOS>
<BOS>Some clinical trials are open only to patients who have not started treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Six types of standard treatment are used: Surgery An operation may be done to remove the tumor.<EOS>
<BOS>One of the following types of surgery may be used: Enucleation: Surgery to remove the tumor only.<EOS>
<BOS>This may be done when cancer occurs in one place in the pancreas.<EOS>
<BOS>Pancreatoduodenectomy: A surgical procedure in which the head of the pancreas, the gallbladder, nearby lymph nodes and part of the stomach, small intestine, and bile duct are removed.<EOS>
<BOS>Enough of the pancreas is left to make digestive juices and insulin.<EOS>
<BOS>The organs removed during this procedure depend on the patient's condition.<EOS>
<BOS>This is also called the Whipple procedure.<EOS>
<BOS>Distal pancreatectomy: Surgery to remove the body and tail of the pancreas.<EOS>
<BOS>The spleen may also be removed.<EOS>
<BOS>Total gastrectomy: Surgery to remove the whole stomach.<EOS>
<BOS>Parietal cell vagotomy: Surgery to cut the nerve that causes stomach cells to make acid.<EOS>
<BOS>Liver resection: Surgery to remove part or all of the liver.<EOS>
<BOS>Radiofrequency ablation: The use of a special probe with tiny electrodes that kill cancer cells.<EOS>
<BOS>Sometimes the probe is inserted directly through the skin and only local anesthesia is needed.<EOS>
<BOS>In other cases, the probe is inserted through an incision in the abdomen.<EOS>
<BOS>This is done in the hospital with general anesthesia.<EOS>
<BOS>Cryosurgical ablation: A procedure in which tissue is frozen to destroy abnormal cells.<EOS>
<BOS>This is usually done with a special instrument that contains liquid nitrogen or liquid carbon dioxide.<EOS>
<BOS>The instrument may be used during surgery or laparoscopy or inserted through the skin.<EOS>
<BOS>This procedure is also called cryoablation.<EOS>
<BOS>Chemotherapy Chemotherapy is a cancer treatment that uses drugs to stop the growth of cancer cells, either by killing the cells or by stopping them from dividing.<EOS>
<BOS>When chemotherapy is taken by mouth or injected into a vein or muscle, the drugs enter the bloodstream and can reach cancer cells throughout the body (systemic chemotherapy).<EOS>
<BOS>When chemotherapy is placed directly into the cerebrospinal fluid, an organ, or a body cavity such as the abdomen, the drugs mainly affect cancer cells in those areas (regional chemotherapy).<EOS>
<BOS>Combination chemotherapy is the use of more than one anticancer drug.<EOS>
<BOS>The way the chemotherapy is given depends on the type of the cancer being treated.<EOS>
<BOS>Hormone therapy Hormone therapy is a cancer treatment that removes hormones or blocks their action and stops cancer cells from growing.<EOS>
<BOS>Hormones are substances made by glands in the body and circulated in the bloodstream.<EOS>
<BOS>Some hormones can cause certain cancers to grow.<EOS>
<BOS>If tests show that the cancer cells have places where hormones can attach (receptors), drugs, surgery, or radiation therapy is used to reduce the production of hormones or block them from working.<EOS>
<BOS>Hepatic arterial occlusion or chemoembolization Hepatic arterial occlusion uses drugs, small particles, or other agents to block or reduce the flow of blood to the liver through the hepatic artery (the major blood vessel that carries blood to the liver).<EOS>
<BOS>This is done to kill cancer cells growing in the liver.<EOS>
<BOS>The tumor is prevented from getting the oxygen and nutrients it needs to grow.<EOS>
<BOS>The liver continues to receive blood from the hepatic portal vein, which carries blood from the stomach and intestine.<EOS>
<BOS>Chemotherapy delivered during hepatic arterial occlusion is called chemoembolization.<EOS>
<BOS>The anticancer drug is injected into the hepatic artery through a catheter (thin tube).<EOS>
<BOS>The drug is mixed with the substance that blocks the artery and cuts off blood flow to the tumor.<EOS>
<BOS>Most of the anticancer drug is trapped near the tumor and only a small amount of the drug reaches other parts of the body.<EOS>
<BOS>The blockage may be temporary or permanent, depending on the substance used to block the artery.<EOS>
<BOS>Targeted therapy Targeted therapy is a type of treatment that uses drugs or other substances to identify and attack specific cancer cells without harming normal cells.<EOS>
<BOS>Certain types of targeted therapies are being studied in the treatment of pancreatic NETs.<EOS>
<BOS>Supportive care Supportive care is given to lessen the problems caused by the disease or its treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Supportive care for pancreatic NETs may include treatment for the following: Stomach ulcers may be treated with drug therapy such as: Proton pump inhibitor drugs such as omeprazole, lansoprazole, or pantoprazole.<EOS>
<BOS>Histamine blocking drugs such as cimetidine, ranitidine, or famotidine.<EOS>
<BOS>Somatostatintype drugs such as octreotide.<EOS>
<BOS>Diarrhea may be treated with: Intravenous (IV) fluids with electrolytes such as potassium or chloride.<EOS>
<BOS>Somatostatintype drugs such as octreotide.<EOS>
<BOS>Low blood sugar may be treated by having small, frequent meals or with drug therapy to maintain a normal blood sugar level.<EOS>
<BOS>High blood sugar may be treated with drugs taken by mouth or insulin by injection.<EOS>
<BOS>New types of treatment are being tested in clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>Information about clinical trials is available from the NCI website.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients may want to think about taking part in a clinical trial.<EOS>
<BOS>For some patients, taking part in a clinical trial may be the best treatment choice.<EOS>
<BOS>Clinical trials are part of the cancer research process.<EOS>
<BOS>Clinical trials are done to find out if new cancer treatments are safe and effective or better than the standard treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Many of today's standard treatments for cancer are based on earlier clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients who take part in a clinical trial may receive the standard treatment or be among the first to receive a new treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients who take part in clinical trials also help improve the way cancer will be treated in the future.<EOS>
<BOS>Even when clinical trials do not lead to effective new treatments, they often answer important questions and help move research forward.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients can enter clinical trials before, during, or after starting their cancer treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Some clinical trials only include patients who have not yet received treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Other trials test treatments for patients whose cancer has not gotten better.<EOS>
<BOS>There are also clinical trials that test new ways to stop cancer from recurring (coming back) or reduce the side effects of cancer treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Clinical trials are taking place in many parts of the country.<EOS>
<BOS>See the Treatment Options section that follows for links to current treatment clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>These have been retrieved from NCI's listing of clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>Followup tests may be needed.<EOS>
<BOS>Some of the tests that were done to diagnose the cancer or to find out the stage of the cancer may be repeated.<EOS>
<BOS>Some tests will be repeated in order to see how well the treatment is working.<EOS>
<BOS>Decisions about whether to continue, change, or stop treatment may be based on the results of these tests.<EOS>
<BOS>Some of the tests will continue to be done from time to time after treatment has ended.<EOS>
<BOS>The results of these tests can show if your condition has changed or if the cancer has recurred (come back).<EOS>
<BOS>These tests are sometimes called followup tests or checkups.<EOS>
<BOS>Treatment Options for Pancreatic Neuroendocrine Tumors Gastrinoma Treatment of gastrinoma may include supportive care and the following: For symptoms caused by too much stomach acid, treatment may be a drug that decreases the amount of acid made by the stomach.<EOS>
<BOS>For a single tumor in the head of the pancreas: Surgery to remove the tumor.<EOS>
<BOS>Surgery to cut the nerve that causes stomach cells to make acid and treatment with a drug that decreases stomach acid.<EOS>
<BOS>Surgery to remove the whole stomach (rare).<EOS>
<BOS>For a single tumor in the body or tail of the pancreas, treatment is usually surgery to remove the body or tail of the pancreas.<EOS>
<BOS>For several tumors in the pancreas, treatment is usually surgery to remove the body or tail of the pancreas.<EOS>
<BOS>If tumor remains after surgery, treatment may include either: Surgery to cut the nerve that causes stomach cells to make acid and treatment with a drug that decreases stomach acid; or Surgery to remove the whole stomach (rare).<EOS>
<BOS>For one or more tumors in the duodenum (the part of the small intestine that connects to the stomach), treatment is usually pancreatoduodenectomy (surgery to remove the head of the pancreas, the gallbladder, nearby lymph nodes and part of the stomach, small intestine, and bile duct).<EOS>
<BOS>If no tumor is found, treatment may include the following: Surgery to cut the nerve that causes stomach cells to make acid and treatment with a drug that decreases stomach acid.<EOS>
<BOS>Surgery to remove the whole stomach (rare).<EOS>
<BOS>If the cancer has spread to the liver, treatment may include: Surgery to remove part or all of the liver.<EOS>
<BOS>Radiofrequency ablation or cryosurgical ablation.<EOS>
<BOS>Chemoembolization.<EOS>
<BOS>If cancer has spread to other parts of the body or does not get better with surgery or drugs to decrease stomach acid, treatment may include: Chemotherapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Hormone therapy.<EOS>
<BOS>If the cancer mostly affects the liver and the patient has severe symptoms from hormones or from the size of tumor, treatment may include: Hepatic arterial occlusion, with or without systemic chemotherapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Chemoembolization, with or without systemic chemotherapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Check the list of NCIsupported cancer clinical trials that are now accepting patients with gastrinoma.<EOS>
<BOS>For more specific results, refine the search by using other search features, such as the location of the trial, the type of treatment, or the name of the drug.<EOS>
<BOS>Talk with your doctor about clinical trials that may be right for you.<EOS>
<BOS>General information about clinical trials is available from the NCI website.<EOS>
<BOS>Insulinoma Treatment of insulinoma may include the following: For one small tumor in the head or tail of the pancreas, treatment is usually surgery to remove the tumor.<EOS>
<BOS>For one large tumor in the head of the pancreas that cannot be removed by surgery, treatment is usually pancreatoduodenectomy (surgery to remove the head of the pancreas, the gallbladder, nearby lymph nodes and part of the stomach, small intestine, and bile duct).<EOS>
<BOS>For one large tumor in the body or tail of the pancreas, treatment is usually a distal pancreatectomy (surgery to remove the body and tail of the pancreas).<EOS>
<BOS>For more than one tumor in the pancreas, treatment is usually surgery to remove any tumors in the head of the pancreas and the body and tail of the pancreas.<EOS>
<BOS>For tumors that cannot be removed by surgery, treatment may include the following: Combination chemotherapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Palliative drug therapy to decrease the amount of insulin made by the pancreas.<EOS>
<BOS>Hormone therapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Radiofrequency ablation or cryosurgical ablation.<EOS>
<BOS>For cancer that has spread to lymph nodes or other parts of the body, treatment may include the following: Surgery to remove the cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Radiofrequency ablation or cryosurgical ablation, if the cancer cannot be removed by surgery.<EOS>
<BOS>If the cancer mostly affects the liver and the patient has severe symptoms from hormones or from the size of tumor, treatment may include: Hepatic arterial occlusion, with or without systemic chemotherapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Chemoembolization, with or without systemic chemotherapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Check the list of NCIsupported cancer clinical trials that are now accepting patients with insulinoma.<EOS>
<BOS>For more specific results, refine the search by using other search features, such as the location of the trial, the type of treatment, or the name of the drug.<EOS>
<BOS>Talk with your doctor about clinical trials that may be right for you.<EOS>
<BOS>General information about clinical trials is available from the NCI website.<EOS>
<BOS>Glucagonoma Treatment may include the following: For one small tumor in the head or tail of the pancreas, treatment is usually surgery to remove the tumor.<EOS>
<BOS>For one large tumor in the head of the pancreas that cannot be removed by surgery, treatment is usually pancreatoduodenectomy (surgery to remove the head of the pancreas, the gallbladder, nearby lymph nodes and part of the stomach, small intestine, and bile duct).<EOS>
<BOS>For more than one tumor in the pancreas, treatment is usually surgery to remove the tumor or surgery to remove the body and tail of the pancreas.<EOS>
<BOS>For tumors that cannot be removed by surgery, treatment may include the following: Combination chemotherapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Hormone therapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Radiofrequency ablation or cryosurgical ablation.<EOS>
<BOS>For cancer that has spread to lymph nodes or other parts of the body, treatment may include the following: Surgery to remove the cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Radiofrequency ablation or cryosurgical ablation, if the cancer cannot be removed by surgery.<EOS>
<BOS>If the cancer mostly affects the liver and the patient has severe symptoms from hormones or from the size of tumor, treatment may include: Hepatic arterial occlusion, with or without systemic chemotherapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Chemoembolization, with or without systemic chemotherapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Check the list of NCIsupported cancer clinical trials that are now accepting patients with glucagonoma.<EOS>
<BOS>For more specific results, refine the search by using other search features, such as the location of the trial, the type of treatment, or the name of the drug.<EOS>
<BOS>Talk with your doctor about clinical trials that may be right for you.<EOS>
<BOS>General information about clinical trials is available from the NCI website.<EOS>
<BOS>Other Pancreatic Neuroendocrine Tumors (Islet Cell Tumors) For VIPoma, treatment may include the following: Fluids and hormone therapy to replace fluids and electrolytes that have been lost from the body.<EOS>
<BOS>Surgery to remove the tumor and nearby lymph nodes.<EOS>
<BOS>Surgery to remove as much of the tumor as possible when the tumor cannot be completely removed or has spread to distant parts of the body.<EOS>
<BOS>This is palliative therapy to relieve symptoms and improve the quality of life.<EOS>
<BOS>For tumors that have spread to lymph nodes or other parts of the body, treatment may include the following: Surgery to remove the tumor.<EOS>
<BOS>Radiofrequency ablation or cryosurgical ablation, if the tumor cannot be removed by surgery.<EOS>
<BOS>For tumors that continue to grow during treatment or have spread to other parts of the body, treatment may include the following: Chemotherapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Targeted therapy.<EOS>
<BOS>For somatostatinoma, treatment may include the following: Surgery to remove the tumor.<EOS>
<BOS>For cancer that has spread to distant parts of the body, surgery to remove as much of the cancer as possible to relieve symptoms and improve quality of life.<EOS>
<BOS>For tumors that continue to grow during treatment or have spread to other parts of the body, treatment may include the following: Chemotherapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Targeted therapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Treatment of other types of pancreatic neuroendocrine tumors (NETs) may include the following: Surgery to remove the tumor.<EOS>
<BOS>For cancer that has spread to distant parts of the body, surgery to remove as much of the cancer as possible or hormone therapy to relieve symptoms and improve quality of life.<EOS>
<BOS>For tumors that continue to grow during treatment or have spread to other parts of the body, treatment may include the following: Chemotherapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Targeted therapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Check the list of NCIsupported cancer clinical trials that are now accepting patients with islet cell tumor.<EOS>
<BOS>For more specific results, refine the search by using other search features, such as the location of the trial, the type of treatment, or the name of the drug.<EOS>
<BOS>Talk with your doctor about clinical trials that may be right for you.<EOS>
<BOS>General information about clinical trials is available from the NCI website.<EOS>
<BOS>Recurrent or Progressive Pancreatic Neuroendocrine Tumors (Islet Cell Tumors) Treatment of pancreatic neuroendocrine tumors (NETs) that continue to grow during treatment or recur (come back) may include the following: Surgery to remove the tumor.<EOS>
<BOS>Chemotherapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Hormone therapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Targeted therapy.<EOS>
<BOS>For liver metastases: Regional chemotherapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Hepatic arterial occlusion or chemoembolization, with or without systemic chemotherapy.<EOS>
<BOS>A clinical trial of a new therapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Check the list of NCIsupported cancer clinical trials that are now accepting patients with recurrent islet cell carcinoma.<EOS>
<BOS>For more specific results, refine the search by using other search features, such as the location of the trial, the type of treatment, or the name of the drug.<EOS>
<BOS>Talk with your doctor about clinical trials that may be right for you.<EOS>
<BOS>General information about clinical trials is available from the NCI website.<EOS>
<BOS>LCH in organs such as the skin, bones, lymph nodes, or pituitary gland usually gets better with treatment and is called "low risk".<EOS>
<BOS>LCH in the spleen, liver, or bone marrow is harder to treat and is called "highrisk".<EOS>
<BOS>The prognosis (chance of recovery) and treatment options depend on the following: Whether there are mutations of the BRAF gene.<EOS>
<BOS>How old the patient is when diagnosed with LCH.<EOS>
<BOS>How many organs or body systems the cancer affects.<EOS>
<BOS>Whether the cancer is found in the liver, spleen, bone marrow, or certain bones in the skull.<EOS>
<BOS>How quickly the cancer responds to initial treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Whether the cancer has just been diagnosed or has come back (recurred).<EOS>
<BOS>In infants up to one year of age, LCH may go away without treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>New types of treatment are being tested in clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>Information about clinical trials is available from the NCI website.<EOS>
<BOS>Targeted therapy Targeted therapy is a treatment that uses drugs or other substances to identify and attack specific cancer cells without harming normal cells.<EOS>
<BOS>Targeted therapy used to treat childhood kidney tumors may include the following: Monoclonal antibodies: This targeted therapy uses antibodies made in the laboratory, from a single type of immune system cell.<EOS>
<BOS>These antibodies can identify substances on cancer cells or normal substances that may help cancer cells grow.<EOS>
<BOS>The antibodies attach to the substances and kill the cancer cells, block their growth, or keep them from spreading.<EOS>
<BOS>Monoclonal antibodies are given by infusion.<EOS>
<BOS>They may be used alone or to carry drugs, toxins, or radioactive material directly to cancer cells.<EOS>
<BOS>Lorvotuzumab is being studied in the treatment of recurrent Wilms tumor.<EOS>
<BOS>Kinase inhibitors: This targeted therapy blocks signals that cancer cells need to grow and divide.<EOS>
<BOS>LOXO101 and entrectinib are kinase inhibitors being studied to treat congenital mesoblastic nephroma.<EOS>
<BOS>Histone methyltransferase inhibitors: This targeted therapy slows down the cancer cell's ability to grow and divide.<EOS>
<BOS>Tazemetostat is being studied in the treatment of rhabdoid tumor of the kidney.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients may want to think about taking part in a clinical trial.<EOS>
<BOS>For some patients, taking part in a clinical trial may be the best treatment choice.<EOS>
<BOS>Clinical trials are part of the cancer research process.<EOS>
<BOS>Clinical trials are done to find out if new cancer treatments are safe and effective or better than the standard treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Many of today's standard treatments for cancer are based on earlier clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients who take part in a clinical trial may receive the standard treatment or be among the first to receive a new treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients who take part in clinical trials also help improve the way cancer will be treated in the future.<EOS>
<BOS>Even when clinical trials do not lead to effective new treatments, they often answer important questions and help move research forward.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients can enter clinical trials before, during, or after starting their cancer treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Some clinical trials only include patients who have not yet received treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Other trials test treatments for patients whose cancer has not gotten better.<EOS>
<BOS>There are also clinical trials that test new ways to stop cancer from recurring (coming back) or reduce the side effects of cancer treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Clinical trials are taking place in many parts of the country.<EOS>
