<BOS>See the Treatment Options section that follows for links to current treatment clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>These have been retrieved from NCI's listing of clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>Key Points There is no standard staging system for hairy cell leukemia.<EOS>
<BOS>There is no standard staging system for hairy cell leukemia.<EOS>
<BOS>Staging is the process used to find out how far the cancer has spread.<EOS>
<BOS>Groups are used in place of stages for hairy cell leukemia.<EOS>
<BOS>The disease is grouped as untreated, progressive, or refractory.<EOS>
<BOS>Untreated hairy cell leukemia The hairy cell leukemia is newly diagnosed and has not been treated except to relieve signs or symptoms such as weight loss and infections.<EOS>
<BOS>In untreated hairy cell leukemia, some or all of the following conditions occur: Hairy (leukemia) cells are found in the blood and bone marrow.<EOS>
<BOS>The number of red blood cells, white blood cells, or platelets may be lower than normal.<EOS>
<BOS>The spleen may be larger than normal.<EOS>
<BOS>Progressive hairy cell leukemia In progressive hairy cell leukemia, the leukemia has been treated with either chemotherapy or splenectomy (removal of the spleen) and one or both of the following conditions occur: There is an increase in the number of hairy cells in the blood or bone marrow.<EOS>
<BOS>The number of red blood cells, white blood cells, or platelets in the blood is lower than normal.<EOS>
<BOS>Tests that examine the bile ducts and nearby organs are used to detect (find), diagnose, and stage bile duct cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Procedures that make pictures of the bile ducts and the nearby area help diagnose bile duct cancer and show how far the cancer has spread.<EOS>
<BOS>The process used to find out if cancer cells have spread within and around the bile ducts or to distant parts of the body is called staging.<EOS>
<BOS>In order to plan treatment, it is important to know if the bile duct cancer can be removed by surgery.<EOS>
<BOS>Tests and procedures to detect, diagnose, and stage bile duct cancer are usually done at the same time.<EOS>
<BOS>The following tests and procedures may be used: Physical exam and history : An exam of the body to check general signs of health, including checking for signs of disease, such as lumps or anything else that seems unusual.<EOS>
<BOS>A history of the patients health habits and past illnesses and treatments will also be taken.<EOS>
<BOS>Liver function tests : A procedure in which a blood sample is checked to measure the amounts of bilirubin and alkaline phosphatase released into the blood by the liver.<EOS>
<BOS>A higher than normal amount of these substances can be a sign of liver disease that may be caused by bile duct cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Laboratory tests : Medical procedures that test samples of tissue, blood, urine, or other substances in the body.<EOS>
<BOS>These tests help to diagnose disease, plan and check treatment, or monitor the disease over time.<EOS>
<BOS>Carcinoembryonic antigen (CEA) and CA 199 tumor marker test : A procedure in which a sample of blood, urine, or tissue is checked to measure the amounts of certain substances made by organs, tissues, or tumor cells in the body.<EOS>
<BOS>Certain substances are linked to specific types of cancer when found in increased levels in the body.<EOS>
<BOS>These are called tumor markers.<EOS>
<BOS>Higher than normal levels of carcinoembryonic antigen (CEA) and CA 199 may mean there is bile duct cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Ultrasound exam : A procedure in which highenergy sound waves (ultrasound) are bounced off internal tissues or organs, such as the abdomen, and make echoes.<EOS>
<BOS>The echoes form a picture of body tissues called a sonogram.<EOS>
<BOS>The picture can be printed to be looked at later.<EOS>
<BOS>CT scan (CAT scan): A procedure that makes a series of detailed pictures of areas inside the body, such as the abdomen, taken from different angles.<EOS>
<BOS>The pictures are made by a computer linked to an xray machine.<EOS>
<BOS>A dye may be injected into a vein or swallowed to help the organs or tissues show up more clearly.<EOS>
<BOS>This procedure is also called computed tomography, computerized tomography, or computerized axial tomography.<EOS>
<BOS>MRI (magnetic resonance imaging): A procedure that uses a magnet, radio waves, and a computer to make a series of detailed pictures of areas inside the body.<EOS>
<BOS>This procedure is also called nuclear magnetic resonance imaging (NMRI).<EOS>
<BOS>MRCP (magnetic resonance cholangiopancreatography): A procedure that uses a magnet, radio waves, and a computer to make a series of detailed pictures of areas inside the body such as the liver, bile ducts, gallbladder, pancreas, and pancreatic duct.<EOS>
<BOS>Different procedures may be used to obtain a sample of tissue and diagnose bile duct cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Cells and tissues are removed during a biopsy so they can be viewed under a microscope by a pathologist to check for signs of cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Different procedures may be used to obtain the sample of cells and tissue.<EOS>
<BOS>The type of procedure used depends on whether the patient is well enough to have surgery.<EOS>
<BOS>Types of biopsy procedures include the following: Laparoscopy : A surgical procedure to look at the organs inside the abdomen, such as the bile ducts and liver, to check for signs of cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Small incisions (cuts) are made in the wall of the abdomen and a laparoscope (a thin, lighted tube) is inserted into one of the incisions.<EOS>
<BOS>Other instruments may be inserted through the same or other incisions to perform procedures such as taking tissue samples to be checked for signs of cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Percutaneous transhepatic cholangiography (PTC): A procedure used to xray the liver and bile ducts.<EOS>
<BOS>A thin needle is inserted through the skin below the ribs and into the liver.<EOS>
<BOS>Dye is injected into the liver or bile ducts and an xray is taken.<EOS>
<BOS>A sample of tissue is removed and checked for signs of cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>If the bile duct is blocked, a thin, flexible tube called a stent may be left in the liver to drain bile into the small intestine or a collection bag outside the body.<EOS>
<BOS>This procedure may be used when a patient cannot have surgery.<EOS>
<BOS>Endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography (ERCP): A procedure used to xray the ducts (tubes) that carry bile from the liver to the gallbladder and from the gallbladder to the small intestine.<EOS>
<BOS>Sometimes bile duct cancer causes these ducts to narrow and block or slow the flow of bile, causing jaundice.<EOS>
<BOS>An endoscope is passed through the mouth and stomach and into the small intestine.<EOS>
<BOS>Dye is injected through the endoscope (thin, tubelike instrument with a light and a lens for viewing) into the bile ducts and an xray is taken.<EOS>
<BOS>A sample of tissue is removed and checked for signs of cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>If the bile duct is blocked, a thin tube may be inserted into the duct to unblock it.<EOS>
<BOS>This tube (or stent) may be left in place to keep the duct open.<EOS>
<BOS>This procedure may be used when a patient cannot have surgery.<EOS>
<BOS>New types of treatment are being tested in clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>This summary section describes treatments that are being studied in clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>It may not mention every new treatment being studied.<EOS>
<BOS>Information about clinical trials is available from the NCI website.<EOS>
<BOS>Highdose chemotherapy with stem cell transplant Highdose chemotherapy with stem cell transplant is a method of giving high doses of chemotherapy and replacing blood forming cells destroyed by the cancer treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Stem cells (immature blood cells) are removed from the blood or bone marrow of the patient or a donor and are frozen and stored.<EOS>
<BOS>After the chemotherapy is completed, the stored stem cells are thawed and given back to the patient through an infusion.<EOS>
<BOS>These reinfused stem cells grow into (and restore) the body's blood cells.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients may want to think about taking part in a clinical trial.<EOS>
<BOS>For some patients, taking part in a clinical trial may be the best treatment choice.<EOS>
<BOS>Clinical trials are part of the cancer research process.<EOS>
<BOS>Clinical trials are done to find out if new cancer treatments are safe and effective or better than the standard treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Many of today's standard treatments for cancer are based on earlier clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients who take part in a clinical trial may receive the standard treatment or be among the first to receive a new treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients who take part in clinical trials also help improve the way cancer will be treated in the future.<EOS>
<BOS>Even when clinical trials do not lead to effective new treatments, they often answer important questions and help move research forward.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients can enter clinical trials before, during, or after starting their cancer treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Some clinical trials only include patients who have not yet received treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Other trials test treatments for patients whose cancer has not gotten better.<EOS>
<BOS>There are also clinical trials that test new ways to stop cancer from recurring (coming back) or reduce the side effects of cancer treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Clinical trials are taking place in many parts of the country.<EOS>
<BOS>See the Treatment Options section that follows for links to current treatment clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>These have been retrieved from NCI's listing of clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>Key Points Laryngeal cancer is a disease in which malignant (cancer) cells form in the tissues of the larynx.<EOS>
<BOS>Use of tobacco products and drinking too much alcohol can affect the risk of laryngeal cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Signs and symptoms of laryngeal cancer include a sore throat and ear pain.<EOS>
<BOS>Tests that examine the throat and neck are used to help detect (find), diagnose, and stage laryngeal cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Certain factors affect prognosis (chance of recovery) and treatment options.<EOS>
<BOS>Laryngeal cancer is a disease in which malignant (cancer) cells form in the tissues of the larynx.<EOS>
<BOS>The larynx is a part of the throat, between the base of the tongue and the trachea.<EOS>
<BOS>The larynx contains the vocal cords, which vibrate and make sound when air is directed against them.<EOS>
<BOS>The sound echoes through the pharynx, mouth, and nose to make a person's voice.<EOS>
<BOS>There are three main parts of the larynx: Supraglottis: The upper part of the larynx above the vocal cords, including the epiglottis.<EOS>
<BOS>Glottis: The middle part of the larynx where the vocal cords are located.<EOS>
<BOS>Subglottis: The lower part of the larynx between the vocal cords and the trachea (windpipe).<EOS>
<BOS>Most laryngeal cancers form in squamous cells, the thin, flat cells lining the inside of the larynx.<EOS>
<BOS>Laryngeal cancer is a type of head and neck cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Signs of gastrointestinal stromal tumors include blood in the stool or vomit.<EOS>
<BOS>These and other signs and symptoms may be caused by a GIST or by other conditions.<EOS>
<BOS>Check with your doctor if you have any of the following: Blood (either bright red or very dark) in the stool or vomit.<EOS>
<BOS>Pain in the abdomen, which may be severe.<EOS>
<BOS>Feeling very tired.<EOS>
<BOS>Trouble or pain when swallowing.<EOS>
<BOS>Feeling full after only a little food is eaten.<EOS>
<BOS>Certain factors affect treatment options and prognosis (chance of recovery).<EOS>
<BOS>The prognosis (chance of recovery) and treatment options depend on the following: The type of ovarian cancer and how much cancer there is.<EOS>
<BOS>The stage and grade of the cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Whether the patient has extra fluid in the abdomen that causes swelling.<EOS>
<BOS>Whether all of the tumor can be removed by surgery.<EOS>
<BOS>Whether there are changes in the BRCA1 or BRCA2 genes.<EOS>
<BOS>The patients age and general health.<EOS>
<BOS>Whether the cancer has just been diagnosed or has recurred (come back).<EOS>
<BOS>Certain factors affect treatment options and prognosis (chance of recovery).<EOS>
<BOS>The treatment options and prognosis (chance of recovery) depend on the following: The type of soft tissue sarcoma.<EOS>
<BOS>The size, grade, and stage of the tumor.<EOS>
<BOS>How fast the cancer cells are growing and dividing.<EOS>
<BOS>Where the tumor is in the body.<EOS>
<BOS>Whether all of the tumor is removed by surgery.<EOS>
<BOS>The patient's age and general health.<EOS>
<BOS>Whether the cancer has recurred (come back).<EOS>
<BOS>Key Points Parathyroid cancer is a rare disease in which malignant (cancer) cells form in the tissues of a parathyroid gland.<EOS>
<BOS>Having certain inherited disorders can increase the risk of developing parathyroid cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Signs and symptoms of parathyroid cancer include weakness, feeling tired, and a lump in the neck.<EOS>
<BOS>Tests that examine the neck and blood are used to detect (find) and diagnose parathyroid cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Certain factors affect prognosis (chance of recovery) and treatment options.<EOS>
<BOS>Parathyroid cancer is a rare disease in which malignant (cancer) cells form in the tissues of a parathyroid gland.<EOS>
<BOS>The parathyroid glands are four peasized organs found in the neck near the thyroid gland.<EOS>
<BOS>The parathyroid glands make parathyroid hormone (PTH or parathormone).<EOS>
<BOS>PTH helps the body use and store calcium to keep the calcium in the blood at normal levels.<EOS>
<BOS>A parathyroid gland may become overactive and make too much PTH, a condition called hyperparathyroidism.<EOS>
<BOS>Hyperparathyroidism can occur when a benign tumor (noncancer), called an adenoma, forms on one of the parathyroid glands, and causes it to grow and become overactive.<EOS>
<BOS>Sometimes hyperparathyroidism can be caused by parathyroid cancer, but this is very rare.<EOS>
<BOS>The extra PTH causes: The calcium stored in the bones to move into the blood.<EOS>
<BOS>The intestines to absorb more calcium from the food we eat.<EOS>
<BOS>This condition is called hypercalcemia (too much calcium in the blood).<EOS>
<BOS>The hypercalcemia caused by hyperparathyroidism is more serious and lifethreatening than parathyroid cancer itself and treating hypercalcemia is as important as treating the cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Smoking and health history can affect the risk of pancreatic cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Anything that increases your risk of getting a disease is called a risk factor.<EOS>
<BOS>Having a risk factor does not mean that you will get cancer; not having risk factors doesnt mean that you will not get cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Talk with your doctor if you think you may be at risk.<EOS>
<BOS>Risk factors for pancreatic cancer include the following: Smoking.<EOS>
<BOS>Being very overweight.<EOS>
<BOS>Having a personal history of diabetes or chronic pancreatitis.<EOS>
<BOS>Having a family history of pancreatic cancer or pancreatitis.<EOS>
<BOS>Having certain hereditary conditions, such as: Multiple endocrine neoplasia type 1 (MEN1) syndrome.<EOS>
<BOS>Hereditary nonpolyposis colon cancer (HNPCC; Lynch syndrome).<EOS>
<BOS>von HippelLindau syndrome.<EOS>
<BOS>PeutzJeghers syndrome.<EOS>
<BOS>Hereditary breast and ovarian cancer syndrome.<EOS>
<BOS>Familial atypical multiple mole melanoma (FAMMM) syndrome.<EOS>
<BOS>Key Points The grade of the tumor is used to plan cancer treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Lowgrade astrocytomas Highgrade astrocytomas An MRI is done after surgery.<EOS>
<BOS>The grade of the tumor is used to plan cancer treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Staging is the process used to find out how much cancer there is and if cancer has spread.<EOS>
<BOS>It is important to know the stage in order to plan treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>There is no standard staging system for childhood astrocytoma.<EOS>
<BOS>Treatment is based on the following: Whether the tumor is low grade or high grade.<EOS>
<BOS>Whether the tumor is newly diagnosed or recurrent (has come back after treatment).<EOS>
<BOS>The grade of the tumor describes how abnormal the cancer cells look under a microscope and how quickly the tumor is likely to grow and spread.<EOS>
<BOS>The following grades are used: Lowgrade astrocytomas Lowgrade astrocytomas are slowgrowing and rarely spread to other parts of the brain and spinal cord or other parts of the body.<EOS>
<BOS>There are many types of lowgrade astrocytomas.<EOS>
<BOS>Lowgrade astrocytomas can be either: Grade I tumors pilocytic astrocytoma, subependymal giant cell tumor, or angiocentric glioma.<EOS>
<BOS>Grade II tumors diffuse astrocytoma, pleomorphic xanthoastrocytoma, or choroid glioma of the third ventricle.<EOS>
<BOS>Children who have neurofibromatosis type 1 may have more than one lowgrade tumor in the brain.<EOS>
<BOS>Children who have tuberous sclerosis have an increased risk of subependymal giant cell astrocytoma.<EOS>
<BOS>Highgrade astrocytomas Highgrade astrocytomas are fastgrowing and often spread within the brain and spinal cord.<EOS>
<BOS>There are several types of highgrade astrocytomas.<EOS>
<BOS>High grade astrocytomas can be either: Grade III tumors anaplastic astrocytoma or anaplastic pleomorphic xanthoastrocytoma.<EOS>
<BOS>Grade IV tumors glioblastoma or diffuse midline glioma.<EOS>
<BOS>Childhood astrocytomas usually do not spread to other parts of the body.<EOS>
<BOS>An MRI is done after surgery.<EOS>
<BOS>An MRI (magnetic resonance imaging) is done in the first few days after surgery.<EOS>
<BOS>This is to find out how much tumor, if any, remains after surgery and to plan further treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Having certain inherited disorders can increase the risk of adult soft tissue sarcoma.<EOS>
<BOS>Anything that increases your risk of getting a disease is called a risk factor.<EOS>
<BOS>Having a risk factor does not mean that you will get cancer; not having risk factors doesn't mean that you will not get cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Talk with your doctor if you think you may be at risk.<EOS>
<BOS>Risk factors for soft tissue sarcoma include the following inherited disorders: Retinoblastoma.<EOS>
<BOS>Neurofibromatosis type 1 (NF1; von Recklinghausen disease).<EOS>
<BOS>Tuberous sclerosis (Bourneville disease).<EOS>
<BOS>Familial adenomatous polyposis (FAP; Gardner syndrome).<EOS>
<BOS>LiFraumeni syndrome.<EOS>
<BOS>Werner syndrome (adult progeria).<EOS>
<BOS>Nevoid basal cell carcinoma syndrome (Gorlin syndrome).<EOS>
<BOS>Other risk factors for soft tissue sarcoma include the following: Past treatment with radiation therapy for certain cancers.<EOS>
<BOS>Being exposed to certain chemicals, such as Thorotrast (thorium dioxide), vinyl chloride, or arsenic.<EOS>
<BOS>Having swelling (lymphedema) in the arms or legs for a long time.<EOS>
<BOS>Certain factors affect prognosis (chance of recovery) and treatment options.<EOS>
<BOS>The prognosis (chance of recovery) and treatment options depend on the following: The stage of the cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>The type of cancer cell.<EOS>
<BOS>Whether the tumor can be removed completely by surgery.<EOS>
<BOS>The patient's general health.<EOS>
<BOS>Whether the cancer has just been diagnosed or has recurred (come back).<EOS>
<BOS>Certain factors affect prognosis (chance of recovery) and treatment options.<EOS>
<BOS>The prognosis (chance of recovery) depends on: How quickly and how low the leukemia cell count drops after the first month of treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Age at the time of diagnosis, gender, race, and ethnic background.<EOS>
<BOS>The number of white blood cells in the blood at the time of diagnosis.<EOS>
<BOS>Whether the leukemia cells began from B lymphocytes or T lymphocytes.<EOS>
<BOS>Whether there are certain changes in the chromosomes or genes of the lymphocytes with cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Whether the child has Down syndrome.<EOS>
<BOS>Whether leukemia cells are found in the cerebrospinal fluid.<EOS>
<BOS>The child's weight at the time of diagnosis and during treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Treatment options depend on: Whether the leukemia cells began from B lymphocytes or T lymphocytes.<EOS>
<BOS>Whether the child has standardrisk, highrisk, or very highrisk ALL.<EOS>
<BOS>The age of the child at the time of diagnosis.<EOS>
<BOS>Whether there are certain changes in the chromosomes of lymphocytes, such as the Philadelphia chromosome.<EOS>
<BOS>Whether the child was treated with steroids before the start of induction therapy.<EOS>
<BOS>How quickly and how low the leukemia cell count drops during treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>For leukemia that relapses (comes back) after treatment, the prognosis and treatment options depend partly on the following: How long it is between the time of diagnosis and when the leukemia comes back.<EOS>
<BOS>Whether the leukemia comes back in the bone marrow or in other parts of the body.<EOS>
<BOS>Signs and symptoms of chronic myelogenous leukemia include fever, night sweats, and tiredness.<EOS>
<BOS>These and other signs and symptoms may be caused by CML or by other conditions.<EOS>
<BOS>Check with your doctor if you have any of the following: Feeling very tired.<EOS>
<BOS>Weight loss for no known reason.<EOS>
<BOS>Night sweats.<EOS>
<BOS>Fever.<EOS>
<BOS>Pain or a feeling of fullness below the ribs on the left side.<EOS>
<BOS>Sometimes CML does not cause any symptoms at all.<EOS>
<BOS>Key Points There are different types of treatment for patients with hairy cell leukemia.<EOS>
<BOS>Five types of standard treatment are used: Watchful waiting Chemotherapy Biologic therapy Surgery Targeted therapy New types of treatment are being tested in clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients may want to think about taking part in a clinical trial.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients can enter clinical trials before, during, or after starting their cancer treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Followup tests may be needed.<EOS>
<BOS>There are different types of treatment for patients with hairy cell leukemia.<EOS>
<BOS>Different types of treatment are available for patients with hairy cell leukemia.<EOS>
<BOS>Some treatments are standard (the currently used treatment), and some are being tested in clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>A treatment clinical trial is a research study meant to help improve current treatments or obtain information on new treatments for patients with cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>When clinical trials show that a new treatment is better than the standard treatment, the new treatment may become the standard treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients may want to think about taking part in a clinical trial.<EOS>
<BOS>Some clinical trials are open only to patients who have not started treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Five types of standard treatment are used: Watchful waiting Watchful waiting is closely monitoring a patient's condition, without giving any treatment until signs or symptoms appear or change.<EOS>
<BOS>Chemotherapy Chemotherapy is a cancer treatment that uses drugs to stop the growth of cancer cells, either by killing the cells or by stopping them from dividing.<EOS>
<BOS>When chemotherapy is taken by mouth or injected into a vein or muscle, the drugs enter the bloodstream and can reach cancer cells throughout the body (systemic chemotherapy).<EOS>
<BOS>When chemotherapy is placed directly into the cerebrospinal fluid, an organ, or a body cavity such as the abdomen, the drugs mainly affect cancer cells in those areas (regional chemotherapy).<EOS>
<BOS>The way the chemotherapy is given depends on the type and stage of the cancer being treated.<EOS>
<BOS>Cladribine and pentostatin are anticancer drugs commonly used to treat hairy cell leukemia.<EOS>
<BOS>These drugs may increase the risk of other types of cancer, especially Hodgkin lymphoma and nonHodgkin lymphoma.<EOS>
<BOS>Longterm follow up for second cancers is very important.<EOS>
<BOS>Biologic therapy Biologic therapy is a cancer treatment that uses the patients immune system to fight cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Substances made by the body or made in a laboratory are used to boost, direct, or restore the bodys natural defenses against cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>This type of cancer treatment is also called biotherapy or immunotherapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Interferon alfa is a biologic agent commonly used to treat hairy cell leukemia.<EOS>
<BOS>See Drugs Approved for Hairy Cell Leukemia for more information.<EOS>
<BOS>Surgery Splenectomy is a surgical procedure to remove the spleen.<EOS>
<BOS>Targeted therapy Targeted therapy is a treatment that uses drugs or other substances to identify and attack specific cancer cells without harming normal cells.<EOS>
<BOS>Monoclonal antibody therapy is a type of targeted therapy used to treat hairy cell leukemia.<EOS>
<BOS>Monoclonal antibody therapy uses antibodies made in the laboratory from a single type of immune system cell.<EOS>
<BOS>These antibodies can identify substances on cancer cells or normal substances that may help cancer cells grow.<EOS>
<BOS>The antibodies attach to the substances and kill the cancer cells, block their growth, or keep them from spreading.<EOS>
<BOS>Monoclonal antibodies are given by infusion.<EOS>
<BOS>They may be used alone or to carry drugs, toxins, or radioactive material directly to cancer cells.<EOS>
<BOS>A monoclonal antibody called rituximab may be used for certain patients with hairy cell leukemia.<EOS>
<BOS>Other types of targeted therapies are being studied.<EOS>
<BOS>New types of treatment are being tested in clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>Information about clinical trials is available from the NCI website.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients may want to think about taking part in a clinical trial.<EOS>
<BOS>For some patients, taking part in a clinical trial may be the best treatment choice.<EOS>
<BOS>Clinical trials are part of the cancer research process.<EOS>
<BOS>Clinical trials are done to find out if new cancer treatments are safe and effective or better than the standard treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Many of today's standard treatments for cancer are based on earlier clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients who take part in a clinical trial may receive the standard treatment or be among the first to receive a new treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients who take part in clinical trials also help improve the way cancer will be treated in the future.<EOS>
<BOS>Even when clinical trials do not lead to effective new treatments, they often answer important questions and help move research forward.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients can enter clinical trials before, during, or after starting their cancer treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Some clinical trials only include patients who have not yet received treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Other trials test treatments for patients whose cancer has not gotten better.<EOS>
<BOS>There are also clinical trials that test new ways to stop cancer from recurring (coming back) or reduce the side effects of cancer treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Clinical trials are taking place in many parts of the country.<EOS>
<BOS>See the Treatment Options section that follows for links to current treatment clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>These have been retrieved from NCI's listing of clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>Followup tests may be needed.<EOS>
<BOS>Some of the tests that were done to diagnose the cancer or to find out the stage of the cancer may be repeated.<EOS>
<BOS>Some tests will be repeated in order to see how well the treatment is working.<EOS>
<BOS>Decisions about whether to continue, change, or stop treatment may be based on the results of these tests.<EOS>
<BOS>Some of the tests will continue to be done from time to time after treatment has ended.<EOS>
<BOS>The results of these tests can show if your condition has changed or if the cancer has recurred (come back).<EOS>
<BOS>These tests are sometimes called followup tests or checkups.<EOS>
<BOS>Treatment Options for Hairy Cell Leukemia Untreated Hairy Cell Leukemia If the patient's blood cell counts are not too low and there are no signs or symptoms, treatment may not be needed and the patient is carefully watched for changes in his or her condition.<EOS>
<BOS>If blood cell counts become too low or if signs or symptoms appear, initial treatment may include the following: Chemotherapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Splenectomy.<EOS>
<BOS>Check the list of NCIsupported cancer clinical trials that are now accepting patients with untreated hairy cell leukemia.<EOS>
<BOS>For more specific results, refine the search by using other search features, such as the location of the trial, the type of treatment, or the name of the drug.<EOS>
<BOS>Talk with your doctor about clinical trials that may be right for you.<EOS>
<BOS>General information about clinical trials is available from the NCI website.<EOS>
<BOS>Progressive Hairy Cell Leukemia Treatment for progressive hairy cell leukemia may include the following: Chemotherapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Biologic therapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Splenectomy.<EOS>
<BOS>A clinical trial of chemotherapy and targeted therapy with a monoclonal antibody (rituximab).<EOS>
<BOS>Check the list of NCIsupported cancer clinical trials that are now accepting patients with progressive hairy cell leukemia, initial treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>For more specific results, refine the search by using other search features, such as the location of the trial, the type of treatment, or the name of the drug.<EOS>
<BOS>Talk with your doctor about clinical trials that may be right for you.<EOS>
<BOS>General information about clinical trials is available from the NCI website.<EOS>
<BOS>Relapsed or Refractory Hairy Cell Leukemia Treatment of relapsed or refractory hairy cell leukemia may include the following: Chemotherapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Biologic therapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Targeted therapy with a monoclonal antibody (rituximab).<EOS>
<BOS>Highdose chemotherapy.<EOS>
<BOS>A clinical trial of a new biologic therapy.<EOS>
<BOS>A clinical trial of a new targeted therapy.<EOS>
<BOS>A clinical trial of chemotherapy and targeted therapy with a monoclonal antibody (rituximab).<EOS>
<BOS>Check the list of NCIsupported cancer clinical trials that are now accepting patients with refractory hairy cell leukemia.<EOS>
<BOS>For more specific results, refine the search by using other search features, such as the location of the trial, the type of treatment, or the name of the drug.<EOS>
<BOS>Talk with your doctor about clinical trials that may be right for you.<EOS>
<BOS>General information about clinical trials is available from the NCI website.<EOS>
<BOS>Key Points Childhood nonHodgkin lymphoma is a disease in which malignant (cancer) cells form in the lymph system.<EOS>
<BOS>The main types of lymphoma are Hodgkin lymphoma and nonHodgkin lymphoma.<EOS>
<BOS>There are three major types of childhood nonHodgkin lymphoma.<EOS>
<BOS>Mature Bcell nonHodgkin lymphoma Lymphoblastic lymphoma Anaplastic large cell lymphoma Some types of nonHodgkin lymphoma are rare in children.<EOS>
<BOS>Past treatment for cancer and having a weakened immune system affect the risk of having childhood nonHodgkin lymphoma.<EOS>
<BOS>Signs of childhood nonHodgkin lymphoma include breathing problems and swollen lymph nodes.<EOS>
<BOS>Tests that examine the body and lymph system are used to detect (find) and diagnose childhood nonHodgkin lymphoma.<EOS>
<BOS>A biopsy is done to diagnose childhood nonHodgkin lymphoma.<EOS>
<BOS>Certain factors affect prognosis (chance of recovery) and treatment options.<EOS>
<BOS>Childhood nonHodgkin lymphoma is a disease in which malignant (cancer) cells form in the lymph system.<EOS>
<BOS>Childhood nonHodgkin lymphoma is a type of cancer that forms in the lymph system, which is part of the body's immune system.<EOS>
<BOS>The immune system protects the body from foreign substances, infection, and diseases.<EOS>
<BOS>The lymph system is made up of the following: Lymph: Colorless, watery fluid that carries white blood cells called lymphocytes through the lymph system.<EOS>
<BOS>Lymphocytes protect the body against infections and the growth of tumors.<EOS>
<BOS>There are three types of lymphocytes: B lymphocytes that make antibodies to help fight infection.<EOS>
<BOS>T lymphocytes that help B lymphocytes make the antibodies that help fight infection.<EOS>
<BOS>Natural killer cells that attack cancer cells and viruses.<EOS>
<BOS>Lymph vessels: A network of thin tubes that collect lymph from different parts of the body and return it to the bloodstream.<EOS>
<BOS>Lymph nodes: Small, beanshaped structures that filter lymph and store white blood cells that help fight infection and disease.<EOS>
<BOS>Lymph nodes are located along the network of lymph vessels found throughout the body.<EOS>
<BOS>Clusters of lymph nodes are found in the neck, underarm, abdomen, pelvis, and groin.<EOS>
<BOS>Spleen: An organ that makes lymphocytes, filters the blood, stores blood cells, and destroys old blood cells.<EOS>
<BOS>The spleen is on the left side of the abdomen near the stomach.<EOS>
<BOS>Thymus: An organ in which lymphocytes grow and multiply.<EOS>
<BOS>The thymus is in the chest behind the breastbone.<EOS>
<BOS>Tonsils: Two small masses of lymph tissue at the back of the throat.<EOS>
<BOS>The tonsils make lymphocytes.<EOS>
<BOS>Bone marrow: The soft, spongy tissue in the center of large bones.<EOS>
<BOS>Bone marrow makes white blood cells, red blood cells, and platelets.<EOS>
<BOS>NonHodgkin lymphoma can begin in B lymphocytes, T lymphocytes, or natural killer cells.<EOS>
<BOS>Lymphocytes can also be found in the blood and collect in the lymph nodes, spleen, and thymus.<EOS>
<BOS>Lymph tissue is also found in other parts of the body such as the stomach, thyroid gland, brain, and skin.<EOS>
<BOS>NonHodgkin lymphoma can occur in both adults and children.<EOS>
<BOS>Treatment for children is different than treatment for adults.<EOS>
<BOS>See the following PDQ summaries for information about treatment of nonHodgkin lymphoma in adults: Adult NonHodgkin Lymphoma Primary CNS Lymphoma Treatment Mycosis Fungoides and the Sezary Syndrome Treatment The main types of lymphoma are Hodgkin lymphoma and nonHodgkin lymphoma.<EOS>
<BOS>Lymphomas are divided into two general types: Hodgkin lymphoma and nonHodgkin lymphoma.<EOS>
<BOS>This summary is about the treatment of childhood nonHodgkin lymphoma.<EOS>
<BOS>See the PDQ summary on Childhood Hodgkin Lymphoma Treatment for information about childhood Hodgkin lymphoma.<EOS>
<BOS>There are three major types of childhood nonHodgkin lymphoma.<EOS>
<BOS>The type of lymphoma is determined by how the cells look under a microscope.<EOS>
<BOS>The three major types of childhood nonHodgkin lymphoma are: Mature Bcell nonHodgkin lymphoma Mature Bcell nonHodgkin lymphomas include: Burkitt and Burkittlike lymphoma/leukemia: Burkitt lymphoma and Burkitt leukemia are different forms of the same disease.<EOS>
<BOS>Burkitt lymphoma/leukemia is an aggressive (fastgrowing) disorder of B lymphocytes that is most common in children and young adults.<EOS>
<BOS>It may form in the abdomen, Waldeyer's ring, testicles, bone, bone marrow, skin, or central nervous system (CNS).<EOS>
<BOS>Burkitt leukemia may start in the lymph nodes as Burkitt lymphoma and then spread to the blood and bone marrow, or it may start in the blood and bone marrow without forming in the lymph nodes first.<EOS>
<BOS>Both Burkitt leukemia and Burkitt lymphoma have been linked to infection with the EpsteinBarr virus (EBV), although EBV infection is more likely to occur in patients in Africa than in the United States.<EOS>
<BOS>Burkitt and Burkittlike lymphoma/leukemia are diagnosed when a sample of tissue is checked and a certain change to the cmyc gene is found.<EOS>
<BOS>Diffuse large Bcell lymphoma: Diffuse large Bcell lymphoma is the most common type of nonHodgkin lymphoma.<EOS>
<BOS>It is a type of Bcell nonHodgkin lymphoma that grows quickly in the lymph nodes.<EOS>
<BOS>The spleen, liver, bone marrow, or other organs are also often affected.<EOS>
<BOS>Diffuse large Bcell lymphoma occurs more often in adolescents than in children.<EOS>
<BOS>Primary mediastinal Bcell lymphoma: A type of lymphoma that develops from B cells in the mediastinum (the area behind the breastbone).<EOS>
<BOS>It may spread to nearby organs including the lungs and the sac around the heart.<EOS>
<BOS>It may also spread to lymph nodes and distant organs including the kidneys.<EOS>
<BOS>In children and adolescents, primary mediastinal Bcell lymphoma occurs more often in older adolescents.<EOS>
<BOS>Lymphoblastic lymphoma Lymphoblastic lymphoma is a type of lymphoma that mainly affects Tcell lymphocytes.<EOS>
<BOS>It usually forms in the mediastinum (the area behind the breastbone).<EOS>
<BOS>This causes trouble breathing, wheezing, trouble swallowing, or swelling of the head and neck.<EOS>
<BOS>It may spread to lymph nodes, bone, bone marrow, skin, the CNS, abdominal organs, and other areas.<EOS>
<BOS>Lymphoblastic lymphoma is a lot like acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL).<EOS>
<BOS>Anaplastic large cell lymphoma Anaplastic large cell lymphoma is a type of lymphoma that mainly affects Tcell lymphocytes.<EOS>
<BOS>It usually forms in the lymph nodes, skin, or bone, and sometimes forms in the gastrointestinal tract, lung, tissue that covers the lungs, and muscle.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients with anaplastic large cell lymphoma have a receptor, called CD30, on the surface of their T cells.<EOS>
<BOS>In many children, anaplastic large cell lymphoma is marked by changes in the ALK gene that makes a protein called anaplastic lymphoma kinase.<EOS>
<BOS>A pathologist checks for these cell and gene changes to help diagnose anaplastic large cell lymphoma.<EOS>
<BOS>Some types of nonHodgkin lymphoma are rare in children.<EOS>
<BOS>Some types of childhood nonHodgkin lymphoma are less common.<EOS>
<BOS>These include: Pediatrictype follicular lymphoma : In children, follicular lymphoma occurs mainly in males.<EOS>
<BOS>It is more likely to be found in one area and does not spread to other places in the body.<EOS>
<BOS>It usually forms in the tonsils and lymph nodes in the neck, but may also form in the testicles, kidney, gastrointestinal tract, and salivary gland.<EOS>
<BOS>Marginal zone lymphoma : Marginal zone lymphoma is a type of lymphoma that tends to grow and spread slowly and is usually found at an early stage.<EOS>
<BOS>It may be found in the lymph nodes or in areas outside the lymph nodes.<EOS>
<BOS>Marginal zone lymphoma found outside the lymph nodes in children is called mucosaassociated lymphoid tissue (MALT) lymphoma and may be linked to Helicobacter pylori infection of the gastrointestinal tract and Chlamydophila psittaci infection of the conjunctival membrane which lines the eye.<EOS>
<BOS>Primary central nervous system (CNS) lymphoma : Primary CNS lymphoma is extremely rare in children.<EOS>
<BOS>Peripheral Tcell lymphoma : Peripheral Tcell lymphoma is an aggressive (fastgrowing) nonHodgkin lymphoma that begins in mature T lymphocytes.<EOS>
<BOS>The T lymphocytes mature in the thymus gland and travel to other parts of the lymph system, such as the lymph nodes, bone marrow, and spleen.<EOS>
<BOS>Cutaneous Tcell lymphoma : Cutaneous Tcell lymphoma begins in the skin and can cause the skin to thicken or form a tumor.<EOS>
<BOS>It is very rare in children, but is more common in adolescents and young adults.<EOS>
<BOS>There are different types of cutaneous Tcell lymphoma, such as cutaneous anaplastic large cell lymphoma, subcutaneous panniculitislike Tcell lymphoma, gammadelta Tcell lymphoma, and mycosis fungoides.<EOS>
<BOS>Mycosis fungoides rarely occurs in children and adolescents.<EOS>
<BOS>Past treatment for cancer and having a weakened immune system affect the risk of having childhood nonHodgkin lymphoma.<EOS>
<BOS>Anything that increases your risk of getting a disease is called a risk factor.<EOS>
<BOS>Having a risk factor does not mean that you will get cancer; not having risk factors doesnt mean that you will not get cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Talk with your child's doctor if you think your child may be at risk.<EOS>
<BOS>Possible risk factors for childhood nonHodgkin lymphoma include the following: Past treatment for cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Being infected with the EpsteinBarr virus or human immunodeficiency virus (HIV).<EOS>
<BOS>Having a weakened immune system after a transplant or from medicines given after a transplant.<EOS>
<BOS>Having certain inherited diseases of the immune system.<EOS>
<BOS>If lymphoma or lymphoproliferative disease is linked to a weakened immune system from certain inherited diseases, HIV infection, a transplant or medicines given after a transplant, the condition is called lymphoproliferative disease associated with immunodeficiency.<EOS>
<BOS>The different types of lymphoproliferative disease associated with immunodeficiency include: Lymphoproliferative disease associated with primary immunodeficiency.<EOS>
<BOS>HIVassociated nonHodgkin lymphoma.<EOS>
<BOS>Posttransplant lymphoproliferative disease.<EOS>
<BOS>Tests that examine the mouth and throat are used to help detect (find), diagnose, and stage oropharyngeal cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>The following tests and procedures may be used: Physical exam and history : An exam of the body to check general signs of health, including checking for signs of disease, such as swollen lymph nodes in the neck or anything else that seems unusual.<EOS>
<BOS>The medical doctor or dentist does a complete exam of the mouth and neck and looks under the tongue and down the throat with a small, longhandled mirror to check for abnormal areas.<EOS>
<BOS>An exam of the eyes may be done to check for vision problems that are caused by nerves in the head and neck.<EOS>
<BOS>A history of the patients health habits and past illnesses and treatments will also be taken.<EOS>
<BOS>PETCT scan : A procedure that combines the pictures from a positron emission tomography (PET) scan and a computed tomography (CT) scan.<EOS>
<BOS>The PET and CT scans are done at the same time with the same machine.<EOS>
<BOS>The combined scans give more detailed pictures of areas inside the body than either scan gives by itself.<EOS>
<BOS>A PETCT scan may be used to help diagnose disease, such as cancer, plan treatment, or find out how well treatment is working.<EOS>
<BOS>CT scan (CAT scan): A procedure that makes a series of detailed pictures of areas inside the body, such as the head and neck, taken from different angles.<EOS>
<BOS>The pictures are made by a computer linked to an xray machine.<EOS>
<BOS>A dye is injected into a vein or swallowed to help the organs or tissues show up more clearly.<EOS>
<BOS>This procedure is also called computed tomography, computerized tomography, or computerized axial tomography.<EOS>
<BOS>PET scan (positron emission tomography scan): A procedure to find malignant tumor cells in the body.<EOS>
<BOS>A small amount of radioactive glucose (sugar) is injected into a vein.<EOS>
<BOS>The PET scanner rotates around the body and makes a picture of where glucose is being used in the body.<EOS>
<BOS>Malignant tumor cells show up brighter in the picture because they are more active and take up more glucose than normal cells do.<EOS>
<BOS>MRI (magnetic resonance imaging): A procedure that uses a magnet, radio waves, and a computer to make a series of detailed pictures of areas inside the body.<EOS>
<BOS>This procedure is also called nuclear magnetic resonance imaging (NMRI).<EOS>
<BOS>Biopsy : The removal of cells or tissues so they can be viewed under a microscope by a pathologist to check for signs of cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>A fineneedle biopsy is usually done to remove a sample of tissue using a thin needle.<EOS>
<BOS>The following procedures may be used to remove samples of cells or tissue: Endoscopy : A procedure to look at organs and tissues inside the body to check for abnormal areas.<EOS>
<BOS>An endoscope is inserted through an incision (cut) in the skin or opening in the body, such as the mouth or nose.<EOS>
<BOS>An endoscope is a thin, tubelike instrument with a light and a lens for viewing.<EOS>
<BOS>It may also have a tool to remove abnormal tissue or lymph node samples, which are checked under a microscope for signs of disease.<EOS>
<BOS>The nose, throat, back of the tongue, esophagus, stomach, larynx, windpipe, and large airways will be checked.<EOS>
<BOS>The type of endoscopy is named for the part of the body that is being examined.<EOS>
<BOS>For example, pharyngoscopy is an exam to check the pharynx.<EOS>
<BOS>Laryngoscopy : A procedure in which the doctor checks the larynx with a mirror or with a laryngoscope.<EOS>
<BOS>A laryngoscope is a thin, tubelike instrument with a light and a lens for viewing.<EOS>
<BOS>It may also have a tool to remove abnormal tissue or lymph node samples, which are checked under a microscope for signs of disease.<EOS>
<BOS>If cancer is found, the following test may be done to study the cancer cells: HPV test (human papillomavirus test): A laboratory test used to check the sample of tissue for certain types of HPV infection.<EOS>
<BOS>This test is done because oropharyngeal cancer can be caused by HPV.<EOS>
<BOS>Certain factors affect prognosis (chance of recovery) and treatment options.<EOS>
<BOS>The prognosis (chance of recovery) depends mostly on the stage of the cancer and the type of treatment used to remove the cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Treatment options depend on the following: The stage of the cancer (whether it has spread deeper into the skin or to other places in the body).<EOS>
<BOS>The type of cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>The size of the tumor and what part of the body it affects.<EOS>
<BOS>The patients general health.<EOS>
<BOS>Having certain genetic syndromes or other conditions can increase the risk of Wilms tumor.<EOS>
<BOS>Anything that increases the risk of getting a disease is called a risk factor.<EOS>
<BOS>Having a risk factor does not mean that you will get cancer; not having risk factors doesn't mean that you will not get cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Talk to your child's doctor if you think your child may be at risk.<EOS>
<BOS>Wilms tumor may be part of a genetic syndrome that affects growth or development.<EOS>
<BOS>A genetic syndrome is a set of signs and symptoms or conditions that occur together and is caused by certain changes in the genes.<EOS>
<BOS>Certain conditions can also increase a child's risk of developing Wilms tumor.<EOS>
<BOS>These and other genetic syndromes and conditions have been linked to Wilms tumor: WAGR syndrome (Wilms tumor, aniridia, abnormal genitourinary system, and mental retardation).<EOS>
<BOS>DenysDrash syndrome (abnormal genitourinary system).<EOS>
<BOS>Frasier syndrome (abnormal genitourinary system).<EOS>
<BOS>BeckwithWiedemann syndrome (abnormally large growth of one side of the body or a body part, large tongue, umbilical hernia at birth, and abnormal genitourinary system).<EOS>
<BOS>A family history of Wilms tumor.<EOS>
<BOS>Aniridia (the iris, the colored part of the eye, is missing).<EOS>
<BOS>Isolated hemihyperplasia (abnormally large growth of one side of the body or a body part).<EOS>
<BOS>Urinary tract problems such as cryptorchidism or hypospadias.<EOS>
<BOS>Having certain conditions may increase the risk of renal cell cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Renal cell cancer may be related to the following conditions: Von HippelLindau disease (an inherited condition that causes abnormal growth of blood vessels).<EOS>
<BOS>Children with Von HippelLindau disease should be checked yearly for renal cell cancer with an ultrasound of the abdomen or an MRI (magnetic resonance imaging) beginning at age 8 to 11 years.<EOS>
<BOS>Tuberous sclerosis (an inherited disease marked by noncancerous fatty cysts in the kidney).<EOS>
<BOS>Familial renal cell cancer (an inherited condition that occurs when certain changes in the genes that cause kidney cancer are passed down from the parent to the child).<EOS>
<BOS>Renal medullary cancer (a rare kidney cancer that grows and spreads quickly).<EOS>
<BOS>Hereditary leiomyomatosis (an inherited disorder that increases the risk of having cancer of the kidney, skin, and uterus).<EOS>
<BOS>Prior chemotherapy or radiation therapy for a childhood cancer, such as neuroblastoma, soft tissue sarcoma, leukemia, or Wilms tumor may also increase the risk of renal cell cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>See the Second Cancers section in the PDQ summary about Late Effects of Treatment for Childhood Cancer for more information.<EOS>
<BOS>Key Points There are different types of treatment for patients with ovarian germ cell tumors.<EOS>
<BOS>Four types of standard treatment are used: Surgery Observation Chemotherapy Radiation therapy New types of treatment are being tested in clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>Highdose chemotherapy with bone marrow transplant New treatment options Patients may want to think about taking part in a clinical trial.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients can enter clinical trials before, during, or after starting their cancer treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Followup tests may be needed.<EOS>
<BOS>There are different types of treatment for patients with ovarian germ cell tumors.<EOS>
<BOS>Different types of treatment are available for patients with ovarian germ cell tumor.<EOS>
<BOS>Some treatments are standard (the currently used treatment), and some are being tested in clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>A treatment clinical trial is a research study meant to help improve current treatments or obtain information on new treatments for patients with cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>When clinical trials show that a new treatment is better than the standard treatment, the new treatment may become the standard treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients may want to think about taking part in a clinical trial.<EOS>
<BOS>Some clinical trials are open only to patients who have not started treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Four types of standard treatment are used: Surgery Surgery is the most common treatment of ovarian germ cell tumor.<EOS>
<BOS>A doctor may take out the cancer using one of the following types of surgery.<EOS>
<BOS>Unilateral salpingooophorectomy: A surgical procedure to remove one ovary and one fallopian tube.<EOS>
<BOS>Total hysterectomy: A surgical procedure to remove the uterus, including the cervix.<EOS>
<BOS>If the uterus and cervix are taken out through the vagina, the operation is called a vaginal hysterectomy.<EOS>
<BOS>If the uterus and cervix are taken out through a large incision (cut) in the abdomen, the operation is called a total abdominal hysterectomy.<EOS>
<BOS>If the uterus and cervix are taken out through a small incision (cut) in the abdomen using a laparoscope, the operation is called a total laparoscopic hysterectomy.<EOS>
<BOS>Bilateral salpingooophorectomy: A surgical procedure to remove both ovaries and both fallopian tubes.<EOS>
<BOS>Tumor debulking: A surgical procedure in which as much of the tumor as possible is removed.<EOS>
<BOS>Some tumors cannot be completely removed.<EOS>
<BOS>Even if the doctor removes all the cancer that can be seen at the time of the operation, some patients may be offered chemotherapy or radiation therapy after surgery to kill any cancer cells that are left.<EOS>
<BOS>Treatment given after the surgery, to lower the risk that the cancer will come back, is called adjuvant therapy.<EOS>
<BOS>After chemotherapy for an ovarian germ cell tumor, a secondlook laparotomy may be done.<EOS>
<BOS>This is similar to the laparotomy that is done to find out the stage of the cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Secondlook laparotomy is a surgical procedure to find out if tumor cells are left after primary treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>During this procedure, the doctor will take samples of lymph nodes and other tissues in the abdomen to see if any cancer is left.<EOS>
<BOS>This procedure is not done for dysgerminomas.<EOS>
<BOS>Observation Observation is closely watching a patients condition without giving any treatment unless signs or symptoms appear or change.<EOS>
<BOS>Chemotherapy Chemotherapy is a cancer treatment that uses drugs to stop the growth of cancer cells, either by killing the cells or by stopping them from dividing.<EOS>
<BOS>When chemotherapy is taken by mouth or injected into a vein or muscle, the drugs enter the bloodstream and can reach cancer cells throughout the body (systemic chemotherapy).<EOS>
<BOS>When chemotherapy is placed directly into the cerebrospinal fluid, an organ, or a body cavity such as the abdomen, the drugs mainly affect cancer cells in those areas (regional chemotherapy).<EOS>
<BOS>Combination chemotherapy is treatment using more than one anticancer drug.<EOS>
<BOS>The way the chemotherapy is given depends on the type and stage of the cancer being treated.<EOS>
<BOS>See Drugs Approved for Ovarian, Fallopian Tube, or Primary Peritoneal Cancer for more information.<EOS>
<BOS>Radiation therapy Radiation therapy is a cancer treatment that uses highenergy xrays or other types of radiation to kill cancer cells or keep them from growing.<EOS>
<BOS>There are two types of radiation therapy: External radiation therapy uses a machine outside the body to send radiation toward the cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Internal radiation therapy uses a radioactive substance sealed in needles, seeds, wires, or catheters that are placed directly into or near the cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>The way the radiation therapy is given depends on the type and stage of the cancer being treated.<EOS>
<BOS>External radiation therapy is used to treat ovarian germ cell tumors.<EOS>
<BOS>New types of treatment are being tested in clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>This summary section describes treatments that are being studied in clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>It may not mention every new treatment being studied.<EOS>
<BOS>Information about clinical trials is available from the NCI website.<EOS>
<BOS>Highdose chemotherapy with bone marrow transplant Highdose chemotherapy with bone marrow transplant is a method of giving very high doses of chemotherapy and replacing blood forming cells destroyed by the cancer treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Stem cells (immature blood cells) are removed from the bone marrow of the patient or a donor and are frozen and stored.<EOS>
<BOS>After the chemotherapy is completed, the stored stem cells are thawed and given back to the patient through an infusion.<EOS>
<BOS>These reinfused stem cells grow into (and restore) the bodys blood cells.<EOS>
<BOS>New treatment options Combination chemotherapy (the use of more than one anticancer drug) is being tested in clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients may want to think about taking part in a clinical trial.<EOS>
<BOS>For some patients, taking part in a clinical trial may be the best treatment choice.<EOS>
<BOS>Clinical trials are part of the cancer research process.<EOS>
<BOS>Clinical trials are done to find out if new cancer treatments are safe and effective or better than the standard treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Many of today's standard treatments for cancer are based on earlier clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients who take part in a clinical trial may receive the standard treatment or be among the first to receive a new treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients who take part in clinical trials also help improve the way cancer will be treated in the future.<EOS>
<BOS>Even when clinical trials do not lead to effective new treatments, they often answer important questions and help move research forward.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients can enter clinical trials before, during, or after starting their cancer treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Some clinical trials only include patients who have not yet received treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Other trials test treatments for patients whose cancer has not gotten better.<EOS>
<BOS>There are also clinical trials that test new ways to stop cancer from recurring (coming back) or reduce the side effects of cancer treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Clinical trials are taking place in many parts of the country.<EOS>
<BOS>See the Treatment Options section that follows for links to current treatment clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>These have been retrieved from NCI's listing of clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>Followup tests may be needed.<EOS>
<BOS>Some of the tests that were done to diagnose the cancer or to find out the stage of the cancer may be repeated.<EOS>
<BOS>Some tests will be repeated in order to see how well the treatment is working.<EOS>
<BOS>Decisions about whether to continue, change, or stop treatment may be based on the results of these tests.<EOS>
<BOS>Some of the tests will continue to be done from time to time after treatment has ended.<EOS>
<BOS>The results of these tests can show if your condition has changed or if the cancer has recurred (come back).<EOS>
<BOS>These tests are sometimes called followup tests or checkups.<EOS>
<BOS>Treatment Options By Stage Stage I Ovarian Germ Cell Tumors Treatment depends on whether the tumor is a dysgerminoma or another type of ovarian germ cell tumor.<EOS>
<BOS>Treatment of dysgerminoma may include the following: Unilateral salpingooophorectomy with or without lymphangiography or CT scan.<EOS>
<BOS>Unilateral salpingooophorectomy followed by observation.<EOS>
<BOS>Unilateral salpingooophorectomy followed by radiation therapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Unilateral salpingooophorectomy followed by chemotherapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Treatment of other ovarian germ cell tumors may be either: unilateral salpingooophorectomy followed by careful observation; or unilateral salpingooophorectomy, sometimes followed by combination chemotherapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Check the list of NCIsupported cancer clinical trials that are now accepting patients with stage I ovarian germ cell tumor.<EOS>
<BOS>For more specific results, refine the search by using other search features, such as the location of the trial, the type of treatment, or the name of the drug.<EOS>
<BOS>Talk with your doctor about clinical trials that may be right for you.<EOS>
<BOS>General information about clinical trials is available from the NCI website.<EOS>
<BOS>Stage II Ovarian Germ Cell Tumors Treatment depends on whether the tumor is a dysgerminoma or another type of ovarian germ cell tumor.<EOS>
<BOS>Treatment of dysgerminoma may be either: total abdominal hysterectomy and bilateral salpingooophorectomy followed by radiation therapy or combination chemotherapy; or unilateral salpingooophorectomy followed by chemotherapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Treatment of other ovarian germ cell tumors may include the following: Unilateral salpingooophorectomy followed by combination chemotherapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Secondlook laparotomy (surgery done after primary treatment to see if tumor cells remain).<EOS>
<BOS>A clinical trial of a new treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Check the list of NCIsupported cancer clinical trials that are now accepting patients with stage II ovarian germ cell tumor.<EOS>
<BOS>For more specific results, refine the search by using other search features, such as the location of the trial, the type of treatment, or the name of the drug.<EOS>
<BOS>Talk with your doctor about clinical trials that may be right for you.<EOS>
<BOS>General information about clinical trials is available from the NCI website.<EOS>
<BOS>Stage III Ovarian Germ Cell Tumors Treatment depends on whether the tumor is a dysgerminoma or another type of ovarian germ cell tumor.<EOS>
<BOS>Treatment of dysgerminoma may include the following: Total abdominal hysterectomy and bilateral salpingooophorectomy, with removal of as much of the cancer in the pelvis and abdomen as possible.<EOS>
<BOS>Unilateral salpingooophorectomy followed by chemotherapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Treatment of other ovarian germ cell tumors may include the following: Total abdominal hysterectomy and bilateral salpingooophorectomy, with removal of as much of the cancer in the pelvis and abdomen as possible.<EOS>
<BOS>Chemotherapy will be given before and/or after surgery.<EOS>
<BOS>Unilateral salpingooophorectomy followed by chemotherapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Secondlook laparotomy (surgery done after primary treatment to see if tumor cells remain).<EOS>
<BOS>A clinical trial of a new treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Check the list of NCIsupported cancer clinical trials that are now accepting patients with stage III ovarian germ cell tumor.<EOS>
<BOS>For more specific results, refine the search by using other search features, such as the location of the trial, the type of treatment, or the name of the drug.<EOS>
<BOS>Talk with your doctor about clinical trials that may be right for you.<EOS>
<BOS>General information about clinical trials is available from the NCI website.<EOS>
<BOS>Stage IV Ovarian Germ Cell Tumors Treatment depends on whether the tumor is a dysgerminoma or another type of ovarian germ cell tumor.<EOS>
<BOS>Treatment of dysgerminoma may include the following: Total abdominal hysterectomy and bilateral salpingooophorectomy followed by chemotherapy, with removal of as much of the cancer in the pelvis and abdomen as possible.<EOS>
<BOS>Unilateral salpingooophorectomy followed by chemotherapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Treatment of other ovarian germ cell tumors may include the following: Total abdominal hysterectomy and bilateral salpingooophorectomy, with removal of as much of the cancer in the pelvis and abdomen as possible.<EOS>
<BOS>Chemotherapy will be given before and/or after surgery.<EOS>
<BOS>Unilateral salpingooophorectomy followed by chemotherapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Secondlook laparotomy (surgery done after primary treatment to see if tumor cells remain).<EOS>
<BOS>A clinical trial of a new treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Check the list of NCIsupported cancer clinical trials that are now accepting patients with stage IV ovarian germ cell tumor.<EOS>
<BOS>For more specific results, refine the search by using other search features, such as the location of the trial, the type of treatment, or the name of the drug.<EOS>
<BOS>Talk with your doctor about clinical trials that may be right for you.<EOS>
<BOS>General information about clinical trials is available from the NCI website.<EOS>
<BOS>Key Points There are different types of treatment for patients with bile duct cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Three types of standard treatment are used: Surgery Radiation therapy Chemotherapy New types of treatment are being tested in clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>Liver transplant Patients may want to think about taking part in a clinical trial.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients can enter clinical trials before, during, or after starting their cancer treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Followup tests may be needed.<EOS>
<BOS>There are different types of treatment for patients with bile duct cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Different types of treatments are available for patients with bile duct cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Some treatments are standard (the currently used treatment), and some are being tested in clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>A treatment clinical trial is a research study meant to help improve current treatments or obtain information on new treatments for patients with cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>When clinical trials show that a new treatment is better than the standard treatment, the new treatment may become the standard treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients may want to think about taking part in a clinical trial.<EOS>
<BOS>Some clinical trials are open only to patients who have not started treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Three types of standard treatment are used: Surgery The following types of surgery are used to treat bile duct cancer: Removal of the bile duct: A surgical procedure to remove part of the bile duct if the tumor is small and in the bile duct only.<EOS>
<BOS>Lymph nodes are removed and tissue from the lymph nodes is viewed under a microscope to see if there is cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Partial hepatectomy: A surgical procedure in which the part of the liver where cancer is found is removed.<EOS>
<BOS>The part removed may be a wedge of tissue, an entire lobe, or a larger part of the liver, along with some normal tissue around it.<EOS>
<BOS>Whipple procedure: A surgical procedure in which the head of the pancreas, the gallbladder, part of the stomach, part of the small intestine, and the bile duct are removed.<EOS>
<BOS>Enough of the pancreas is left to make digestive juices and insulin.<EOS>
<BOS>Even if the doctor removes all the cancer that can be seen at the time of the operation, some patients may be given chemotherapy or radiation therapy after surgery to kill any cancer cells that are left.<EOS>
<BOS>Treatment given after the surgery, to lower the risk that the cancer will come back, is called adjuvant therapy.<EOS>
<BOS>It is not yet known whether chemotherapy or radiation therapy given after surgery helps keep the cancer from coming back.<EOS>
<BOS>The following types of palliative surgery may be done to relieve symptoms caused by a blocked bile duct and improve quality of life: Biliary bypass: A surgical procedure in which the part of the bile duct before the blockage is connected with part of the bile duct that is past the blockage or to the small intestine.<EOS>
<BOS>This allows bile to flow to the gallbladder or small intestine.<EOS>
<BOS>Stent placement: A surgical procedure in which a stent (a thin, flexible tube or metal tube) is placed in the bile duct to open it and allow bile to flow into the small intestine or through a catheter that goes to a collection bag outside of the body.<EOS>
<BOS>Percutaneous transhepatic biliary drainage: A procedure used to xray the liver and bile ducts.<EOS>
<BOS>A thin needle is inserted through the skin below the ribs and into the liver.<EOS>
<BOS>Dye is injected into the liver or bile ducts and an xray is taken.<EOS>
<BOS>If the bile duct is blocked, a thin, flexible tube called a stent may be left in the liver to drain bile into the small intestine or a collection bag outside the body.<EOS>
<BOS>Radiation therapy Radiation therapy is a cancer treatment that uses highenergy xrays or other types of radiation to kill cancer cells or keep them from growing.<EOS>
<BOS>There are two types of radiation therapy: External radiation therapy uses a machine outside the body to send radiation toward the cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Internal radiation therapy uses a radioactive substance sealed in needles, seeds, wires, or catheters that are placed directly into or near the cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>External and internal radiation therapy are used to treat bile duct cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>It is not yet known whether external radiation therapy helps in the treatment of resectable bile duct cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>In unresectable, metastatic, or recurrent bile duct cancer, new ways to improve the effect of external radiation therapy on cancer cells are being studied: Hyperthermia therapy: A treatment in which body tissue is exposed to high temperatures to make cancer cells more sensitive to the effects of radiation therapy and certain anticancer drugs.<EOS>
<BOS>Radiosensitizers: Drugs that make cancer cells more sensitive to radiation therapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Combining radiation therapy with radiosensitizers may kill more cancer cells.<EOS>
<BOS>Chemotherapy Chemotherapy is a cancer treatment that uses drugs to stop the growth of cancer cells, either by killing the cells or by stopping them from dividing.<EOS>
<BOS>When chemotherapy is taken by mouth or injected into a vein or muscle, the drugs enter the bloodstream and can reach cancer cells throughout the body (systemic chemotherapy).<EOS>
<BOS>When chemotherapy is placed directly into the cerebrospinal fluid, an organ, or a body cavity such as the abdomen, the drugs mainly affect cancer cells in those areas (regional chemotherapy).<EOS>
<BOS>Systemic chemotherapy is used to treat unresectable, metastatic, or recurrent bile duct cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>It is not yet known whether systemic chemotherapy helps in the treatment of resectable bile duct cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>In unresectable, metastatic, or recurrent bile duct cancer, intraarterial embolization is being studied.<EOS>
<BOS>It is a procedure in which the blood supply to a tumor is blocked after anticancer drugs are given in blood vessels near the tumor.<EOS>
<BOS>Sometimes, the anticancer drugs are attached to small beads that are injected into an artery that feeds the tumor.<EOS>
<BOS>The beads block blood flow to the tumor as they release the drug.<EOS>
<BOS>This allows a higher amount of drug to reach the tumor for a longer period of time, which may kill more cancer cells.<EOS>
<BOS>New types of treatment are being tested in clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>This summary section describes treatments that are being studied in clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>It may not mention every new treatment being studied.<EOS>
<BOS>Information about clinical trials is available from the NCI website.<EOS>
<BOS>Liver transplant In a liver transplant, the entire liver is removed and replaced with a healthy donated liver.<EOS>
<BOS>A liver transplant may be done in patients with perihilar bile duct cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>If the patient has to wait for a donated liver, other treatment is given as needed.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients may want to think about taking part in a clinical trial.<EOS>
<BOS>For some patients, taking part in a clinical trial may be the best treatment choice.<EOS>
<BOS>Clinical trials are part of the cancer research process.<EOS>
<BOS>Clinical trials are done to find out if new cancer treatments are safe and effective or better than the standard treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Many of today's standard treatments for cancer are based on earlier clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients who take part in a clinical trial may receive the standard treatment or be among the first to receive a new treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients who take part in clinical trials also help improve the way cancer will be treated in the future.<EOS>
<BOS>Even when clinical trials do not lead to effective new treatments, they often answer important questions and help move research forward.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients can enter clinical trials before, during, or after starting their cancer treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Some clinical trials only include patients who have not yet received treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Other trials test treatments for patients whose cancer has not gotten better.<EOS>
<BOS>There are also clinical trials that test new ways to stop cancer from recurring (coming back) or reduce the side effects of cancer treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Clinical trials are taking place in many parts of the country.<EOS>
<BOS>See the Treatment Options section that follows for links to current treatment clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>These have been retrieved from NCI's listing of clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>Followup tests may be needed.<EOS>
<BOS>Some of the tests that were done to diagnose the cancer or to find out the stage of the cancer may be repeated.<EOS>
<BOS>Some tests will be repeated in order to see how well the treatment is working.<EOS>
<BOS>Decisions about whether to continue, change, or stop treatment may be based on the results of these tests.<EOS>
<BOS>Some of the tests will continue to be done from time to time after treatment has ended.<EOS>
<BOS>The results of these tests can show if your condition has changed or if the cancer has recurred (come back).<EOS>
<BOS>These tests are sometimes called followup tests or checkups.<EOS>
<BOS>Treatment Options for Bile Duct Cancer Intrahepatic Bile Duct Cancer Resectable Intrahepatic Bile Duct Cancer Treatment of resectable intrahepatic bile duct cancer may include: Surgery to remove the cancer, which may include partial hepatectomy.<EOS>
<BOS>Embolization may be done before surgery.<EOS>
<BOS>Surgery followed by chemotherapy and/or radiation therapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Check the list of NCIsupported cancer clinical trials that are now accepting patients with stage I intrahepatic bile duct cancer and stage II intrahepatic bile duct cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>For more specific results, refine the search by using other search features, such as the location of the trial, the type of treatment, or the name of the drug.<EOS>
<BOS>Talk with your doctor about clinical trials that may be right for you.<EOS>
<BOS>General information about clinical trials is available from the NCI website.<EOS>
<BOS>Unresectable, Recurrent, or Metastatic Intrahepatic Bile Duct Cancer Treatment of unresectable, recurrent, or metastatic intrahepatic bile duct cancer may include the following: Stent placement as palliative treatment to relieve symptoms and improve quality of life.<EOS>
<BOS>External or internal radiation therapy as palliative treatment to relieve symptoms and improve the quality of life.<EOS>
<BOS>Chemotherapy.<EOS>
<BOS>A clinical trial of external radiation therapy combined with hyperthermia therapy, radiosensitizer drugs, or chemotherapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Check the list of NCIsupported cancer clinical trials that are now accepting patients with stage III intrahepatic bile duct cancer, stage IV intrahepatic bile duct cancer and recurrent intrahepatic bile duct cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>For more specific results, refine the search by using other search features, such as the location of the trial, the type of treatment, or the name of the drug.<EOS>
<BOS>Talk with your doctor about clinical trials that may be right for you.<EOS>
<BOS>General information about clinical trials is available from the NCI website.<EOS>
<BOS>Perihilar Bile Duct Cancer Resectable Perihilar Bile Duct Cancer Treatment of resectable perihilar bile duct cancer may include the following: Surgery to remove the cancer, which may include partial hepatectomy.<EOS>
<BOS>Stent placement or percutaneous transhepatic biliary drainage as palliative therapy, to relieve jaundice and other symptoms and improve the quality of life.<EOS>
<BOS>Surgery followed by radiation therapy and/or chemotherapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Check the list of NCIsupported cancer clinical trials that are now accepting patients with stage I perihilar bile duct cancer and stage II perihilar bile duct cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>For more specific results, refine the search by using other search features, such as the location of the trial, the type of treatment, or the name of the drug.<EOS>
<BOS>Talk with your doctor about clinical trials that may be right for you.<EOS>
<BOS>General information about clinical trials is available from the NCI website.<EOS>
<BOS>Unresectable, Recurrent, or Metastatic Perihilar Bile Duct Cancer Treatment of unresectable, recurrent, or metastatic perihilar bile duct cancer may include the following: Stent placement or biliary bypass as palliative treatment to relieve symptoms and improve the quality of life.<EOS>
<BOS>External or internal radiation therapy as palliative treatment to relieve symptoms and improve the quality of life.<EOS>
<BOS>Chemotherapy.<EOS>
<BOS>A clinical trial of external radiation therapy combined with hyperthermia therapy, radiosensitizer drugs, or chemotherapy.<EOS>
<BOS>A clinical trial of chemotherapy and radiation therapy followed by a liver transplant.<EOS>
<BOS>Check the list of NCIsupported cancer clinical trials that are now accepting patients with stage III perihilar bile duct cancer, stage IV perihilar bile duct cancer and recurrent perihilar bile duct cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>For more specific results, refine the search by using other search features, such as the location of the trial, the type of treatment, or the name of the drug.<EOS>
<BOS>Talk with your doctor about clinical trials that may be right for you.<EOS>
<BOS>General information about clinical trials is available from the NCI website.<EOS>
<BOS>Distal Extrahepatic Bile Duct Cancer Resectable Distal Extrahepatic Bile Duct Cancer Treatment of resectable distal extrahepatic bile duct cancer may include the following: Surgery to remove the cancer, which may include a Whipple procedure.<EOS>
<BOS>Stent placement or percutaneous transhepatic biliary drainage as palliative therapy, to relieve jaundice and other symptoms and improve the quality of life.<EOS>
<BOS>Surgery followed by radiation therapy and/or chemotherapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Check the list of NCIsupported cancer clinical trials that are now accepting patients with localized extrahepatic bile duct cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>For more specific results, refine the search by using other search features, such as the location of the trial, the type of treatment, or the name of the drug.<EOS>
<BOS>Talk with your doctor about clinical trials that may be right for you.<EOS>
<BOS>General information about clinical trials is available from the NCI website.<EOS>
<BOS>Unresectable, Recurrent, or Metastatic Distal Extrahepatic Bile Duct Cancer Treatment of unresectable, recurrent, or metastatic distal extrahepatic bile duct cancer may include the following: Stent placement or biliary bypass as palliative treatment to relieve symptoms and improve the quality of life.<EOS>
<BOS>External or internal radiation therapy as palliative treatment to relieve symptoms and improve the quality of life.<EOS>
<BOS>Chemotherapy.<EOS>
<BOS>A clinical trial of external radiation therapy combined with hyperthermia therapy, radiosensitizer drugs, or chemotherapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Check the list of NCIsupported cancer clinical trials that are now accepting patients with unresectable extrahepatic bile duct cancer, recurrent extrahepatic bile duct cancer and metastatic extrahepatic bile duct cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>For more specific results, refine the search by using other search features, such as the location of the trial, the type of treatment, or the name of the drug.<EOS>
<BOS>Talk with your doctor about clinical trials that may be right for you.<EOS>
<BOS>General information about clinical trials is available from the NCI website.<EOS>
<BOS>The signs and symptoms of adult brain and spinal cord tumors are not the same in every person.<EOS>
<BOS>Signs and symptoms depend on the following: Where the tumor forms in the brain or spinal cord.<EOS>
<BOS>What the affected part of the brain controls.<EOS>
<BOS>The size of the tumor.<EOS>
<BOS>Signs and symptoms may be caused by CNS tumors or by other conditions, including cancer that has spread to the brain.<EOS>
<BOS>Check with your doctor if you have any of the following: Brain Tumor Symptoms Morning headache or headache that goes away after vomiting.<EOS>
<BOS>Seizures.<EOS>
<BOS>Vision, hearing, and speech problems.<EOS>
<BOS>Loss of appetite.<EOS>
<BOS>Frequent nausea and vomiting.<EOS>
<BOS>Changes in personality, mood, ability to focus, or behavior.<EOS>
<BOS>Loss of balance and trouble walking.<EOS>
<BOS>Weakness.<EOS>
<BOS>Unusual sleepiness or change in activity level.<EOS>
<BOS>Spinal Cord Tumor Symptoms Back pain or pain that spreads from the back towards the arms or legs.<EOS>
<BOS>A change in bowel habits or trouble urinating.<EOS>
<BOS>Weakness or numbness in the arms or legs.<EOS>
<BOS>Trouble walking.<EOS>
<BOS>Key Points Bile duct cancer is a rare disease in which malignant (cancer) cells form in the bile ducts.<EOS>
<BOS>Having colitis or certain liver diseases can increase the risk of bile duct cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Signs of bile duct cancer include jaundice and pain in the abdomen.<EOS>
<BOS>Tests that examine the bile ducts and nearby organs are used to detect (find), diagnose, and stage bile duct cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Different procedures may be used to obtain a sample of tissue and diagnose bile duct cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Certain factors affect prognosis (chance of recovery) and treatment options.<EOS>
<BOS>Bile duct cancer is a rare disease in which malignant (cancer) cells form in the bile ducts.<EOS>
<BOS>A network of tubes, called ducts, connects the liver, gallbladder, and small intestine.<EOS>
<BOS>This network begins in the liver where many small ducts collect bile (a fluid made by the liver to break down fats during digestion).<EOS>
<BOS>The small ducts come together to form the right and left hepatic ducts, which lead out of the liver.<EOS>
<BOS>The two ducts join outside the liver and form the common hepatic duct.<EOS>
<BOS>The cystic duct connects the gallbladder to the common hepatic duct.<EOS>
<BOS>Bile from the liver passes through the hepatic ducts, common hepatic duct, and cystic duct and is stored in the gallbladder.<EOS>
<BOS>When food is being digested, bile stored in the gallbladder is released and passes through the cystic duct to the common bile duct and into the small intestine.<EOS>
<BOS>Bile duct cancer is also called cholangiocarcinoma.<EOS>
