<BOS>There are two types of bile duct cancer: Intrahepatic bile duct cancer : This type of cancer forms in the bile ducts inside the liver.<EOS>
<BOS>Only a small number of bile duct cancers are intrahepatic.<EOS>
<BOS>Intrahepatic bile duct cancers are also called intrahepatic cholangiocarcinomas.<EOS>
<BOS>Extrahepatic bile duct cancer : The extrahepatic bile duct is made up of the hilum region and the distal region.<EOS>
<BOS>Cancer can form in either region: Perihilar bile duct cancer: This type of cancer is found in the hilum region, the area where the right and left bile ducts exit the liver and join to form the common hepatic duct.<EOS>
<BOS>Perihilar bile duct cancer is also called a Klatskin tumor or perihilar cholangiocarcinoma.<EOS>
<BOS>Distal extrahepatic bile duct cancer: This type of cancer is found in the distal region.<EOS>
<BOS>The distal region is made up of the common bile duct which passes through the pancreas and ends in the small intestine.<EOS>
<BOS>Distal extrahepatic bile duct cancer is also called extrahepatic cholangiocarcinoma.<EOS>
<BOS>New types of treatment are being tested in clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>Information about clinical trials is available from the NCI website.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients may want to think about taking part in a clinical trial.<EOS>
<BOS>For some patients, taking part in a clinical trial may be the best treatment choice.<EOS>
<BOS>Clinical trials are part of the cancer research process.<EOS>
<BOS>Clinical trials are done to find out if new cancer treatments are safe and effective or better than the standard treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Many of today's standard treatments for cancer are based on earlier clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients who take part in a clinical trial may receive the standard treatment or be among the first to receive a new treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients who take part in clinical trials also help improve the way cancer will be treated in the future.<EOS>
<BOS>Even when clinical trials do not lead to effective new treatments, they often answer important questions and help move research forward.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients can enter clinical trials before, during, or after starting their cancer treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Some clinical trials only include patients who have not yet received treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Other trials test treatments for patients whose cancer has not gotten better.<EOS>
<BOS>There are also clinical trials that test new ways to stop cancer from recurring (coming back) or reduce the side effects of cancer treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Clinical trials are taking place in many parts of the country.<EOS>
<BOS>See the Treatment Options section that follows for links to current treatment clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>These have been retrieved from NCI's listing of clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>New types of treatment are being tested in clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>This summary section describes treatments that are being studied in clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>It may not mention every new treatment being studied.<EOS>
<BOS>Information about clinical trials is available from the NCI Web site.<EOS>
<BOS>Fulguration Fulguration is a surgical procedure that destroys tissue using an electric current.<EOS>
<BOS>A tool with a small wire loop on the end is used to remove the cancer or to burn away the tumor with electricity.<EOS>
<BOS>Segmental resection of the renal pelvis This is a surgical procedure to remove localized cancer from the renal pelvis without removing the entire kidney.<EOS>
<BOS>Segmental resection may be done to save kidney function when the other kidney is damaged or has already been removed.<EOS>
<BOS>Laser surgery A laser beam (narrow beam of intense light) is used as a knife to remove the cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>A laser beam can also be used to kill the cancer cells.<EOS>
<BOS>This procedure may also be called or laser fulguration.<EOS>
<BOS>Regional chemotherapy and regional biologic therapy Chemotherapy is a cancer treatment that uses drugs to stop the growth of cancer cells, either by killing the cells or by stopping the cells from dividing.<EOS>
<BOS>Biologic therapy is a treatment that uses the patient's immune system to fight cancer; substances made by the body or made in a laboratory are used to boost, direct, or restore the body's natural defenses against cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Regional treatment means the anticancer drugs or biologic substances are placed directly into an organ or a body cavity such as the abdomen, so the drugs will affect cancer cells in that area.<EOS>
<BOS>Clinical trials are studying chemotherapy or biologic therapy using drugs placed directly into the renal pelvis or the ureter.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients may want to think about taking part in a clinical trial.<EOS>
<BOS>For some patients, taking part in a clinical trial may be the best treatment choice.<EOS>
<BOS>Clinical trials are part of the cancer research process.<EOS>
<BOS>Clinical trials are done to find out if new cancer treatments are safe and effective or better than the standard treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Many of today's standard treatments for cancer are based on earlier clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients who take part in a clinical trial may receive the standard treatment or be among the first to receive a new treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients who take part in clinical trials also help improve the way cancer will be treated in the future.<EOS>
<BOS>Even when clinical trials do not lead to effective new treatments, they often answer important questions and help move research forward.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients can enter clinical trials before, during, or after starting their cancer treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Some clinical trials only include patients who have not yet received treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Other trials test treatments for patients whose cancer has not gotten better.<EOS>
<BOS>There are also clinical trials that test new ways to stop cancer from recurring (coming back) or reduce the side effects of cancer treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Clinical trials are taking place in many parts of the country.<EOS>
<BOS>See the Treatment Options section that follows for links to current treatment clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>These have been retrieved from NCI's listing of clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>Tests that examine the lungs are used to detect (find), diagnose, and stage nonsmall cell lung cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Tests and procedures to detect, diagnose, and stage nonsmall cell lung cancer are often done at the same time.<EOS>
<BOS>Some of the following tests and procedures may be used: Physical exam and history : An exam of the body to check general signs of health, including checking for signs of disease, such as lumps or anything else that seems unusual.<EOS>
<BOS>A history of the patients health habits, including smoking, and past jobs, illnesses, and treatments will also be taken.<EOS>
<BOS>Laboratory tests : Medical procedures that test samples of tissue, blood, urine, or other substances in the body.<EOS>
<BOS>These tests help to diagnose disease, plan and check treatment, or monitor the disease over time.<EOS>
<BOS>Chest xray: An xray of the organs and bones inside the chest.<EOS>
<BOS>An xray is a type of energy beam that can go through the body and onto film, making a picture of areas inside the body.<EOS>
<BOS>CT scan (CAT scan): A procedure that makes a series of detailed pictures of areas inside the body, such as the chest, taken from different angles.<EOS>
<BOS>The pictures are made by a computer linked to an xray machine.<EOS>
<BOS>A dye may be injected into a vein or swallowed to help the organs or tissues show up more clearly.<EOS>
<BOS>This procedure is also called computed tomography, computerized tomography, or computerized axial tomography.<EOS>
<BOS>Sputum cytology : A procedure in which a pathologist views a sample of sputum (mucus coughed up from the lungs) under a microscope, to check for cancer cells.<EOS>
<BOS>Fineneedle aspiration (FNA) biopsy of the lung: The removal of tissue or fluid from the lung using a thin needle.<EOS>
<BOS>A CT scan, ultrasound, or other imaging procedure is used to locate the abnormal tissue or fluid in the lung.<EOS>
<BOS>A small incision may be made in the skin where the biopsy needle is inserted into the abnormal tissue or fluid.<EOS>
<BOS>A sample is removed with the needle and sent to the laboratory.<EOS>
<BOS>A pathologist then views the sample under a microscope to look for cancer cells.<EOS>
<BOS>A chest xray is done after the procedure to make sure no air is leaking from the lung into the chest.<EOS>
<BOS>Bronchoscopy : A procedure to look inside the trachea and large airways in the lung for abnormal areas.<EOS>
<BOS>A bronchoscope is inserted through the nose or mouth into the trachea and lungs.<EOS>
<BOS>A bronchoscope is a thin, tubelike instrument with a light and a lens for viewing.<EOS>
<BOS>It may also have a tool to remove tissue samples, which are checked under a microscope for signs of cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Thoracoscopy : A surgical procedure to look at the organs inside the chest to check for abnormal areas.<EOS>
<BOS>An incision (cut) is made between two ribs, and a thoracoscope is inserted into the chest.<EOS>
<BOS>A thoracoscope is a thin, tubelike instrument with a light and a lens for viewing.<EOS>
<BOS>It may also have a tool to remove tissue or lymph node samples, which are checked under a microscope for signs of cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>In some cases, this procedure is used to remove part of the esophagus or lung.<EOS>
<BOS>If certain tissues, organs, or lymph nodes cant be reached, a thoracotomy may be done.<EOS>
<BOS>In this procedure, a larger incision is made between the ribs and the chest is opened.<EOS>
<BOS>Thoracentesis : The removal of fluid from the space between the lining of the chest and the lung, using a needle.<EOS>
<BOS>A pathologist views the fluid under a microscope to look for cancer cells.<EOS>
<BOS>Light and electron microscopy : A laboratory test in which cells in a sample of tissue are viewed under regular and highpowered microscopes to look for certain changes in the cells.<EOS>
<BOS>Immunohistochemistry : A test that uses antibodies to check for certain antigens in a sample of tissue.<EOS>
<BOS>The antibody is usually linked to a radioactive substance or a dye that causes the tissue to light up under a microscope.<EOS>
<BOS>This type of test may be used to tell the difference between different types of cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Key Points Childhood soft tissue sarcoma is a disease in which malignant (cancer) cells form in soft tissues of the body.<EOS>
<BOS>Soft tissue sarcoma occurs in children and adults.<EOS>
<BOS>Having certain diseases and inherited disorders can increase the risk of childhood soft tissue sarcoma.<EOS>
<BOS>The most common sign of childhood soft tissue sarcoma is a painless lump or swelling in soft tissues of the body.<EOS>
<BOS>Diagnostic tests are used to detect (find) and diagnose childhood soft tissue sarcoma.<EOS>
<BOS>If tests show there may be a soft tissue sarcoma, a biopsy is done.<EOS>
<BOS>There are many different types of soft tissue sarcomas.<EOS>
<BOS>Fat tissue tumors Bone and cartilage tumors Fibrous (connective) tissue tumors Skeletal muscle tumors Smooth muscle tumors Socalled fibrohistiocytic tumors Peripheral nervous system tumors Pericytic (Perivascular) Tumors Tumors of unknown origin Blood vessel tumors Certain factors affect prognosis (chance of recovery) and treatment options.<EOS>
<BOS>Childhood soft tissue sarcoma is a disease in which malignant (cancer) cells form in soft tissues of the body.<EOS>
<BOS>Soft tissues of the body connect, support, and surround other body parts and organs.<EOS>
<BOS>The soft tissues include the following: Fat.<EOS>
<BOS>A mix of bone and cartilage.<EOS>
<BOS>Fibrous tissue.<EOS>
<BOS>Muscles.<EOS>
<BOS>Nerves.<EOS>
<BOS>Tendons (bands of tissue that connect muscles to bones).<EOS>
<BOS>Synovial tissues (tissues around joints).<EOS>
<BOS>Blood vessels.<EOS>
<BOS>Lymph vessels.<EOS>
<BOS>Soft tissue sarcoma may be found anywhere in the body.<EOS>
<BOS>In children, the tumors form most often in the arms, legs, or trunk (chest and abdomen).<EOS>
<BOS>Soft tissue sarcoma occurs in children and adults.<EOS>
<BOS>Soft tissue sarcoma in children may respond differently to treatment, and may have a better prognosis than soft tissue sarcoma in adults.<EOS>
<BOS>(See the PDQ summary on Adult Soft Tissue Sarcoma Treatment for information on treatment in adults.<EOS>
<BOS>) There are many different types of soft tissue sarcomas.<EOS>
<BOS>The cells of each type of sarcoma look different under a microscope.<EOS>
<BOS>The soft tissue tumors are grouped based on the type of soft tissue cell where they first formed.<EOS>
<BOS>This summary is about the following types of soft tissue sarcoma: Fat tissue tumors Liposarcoma.<EOS>
<BOS>This is a rare cancer of the fat cells.<EOS>
<BOS>Liposarcoma usually forms in the fat layer just under the skin.<EOS>
<BOS>In children and adolescents, liposarcoma is often low grade (likely to grow and spread slowly).<EOS>
<BOS>There are several different types of liposarcoma.<EOS>
<BOS>Myxoid liposarcoma is usually low grade and responds well to treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>The cells of myxoid liposarcoma have a certain genetic change called a translocation (part of one chromosome switches places with part of another chromosome).<EOS>
<BOS>In order to diagnose myxoid liposarcoma, the tumor cells are checked for this genetic change.<EOS>
<BOS>Pleomorphic liposarcoma is usually high grade (likely to grow and spread quickly) and is less likely to respond well to treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Bone and cartilage tumors Bone and cartilage tumors are a mix of bone cells and cartilage cells.<EOS>
<BOS>Bone and cartilage tumors include the following types: Extraskeletal mesenchymal chondrosarcoma.<EOS>
<BOS>This type of bone and cartilage tumor often affects young adults and occurs in the head and neck.<EOS>
<BOS>Extraskeletal osteosarcoma.<EOS>
<BOS>This type of bone and cartilage tumor is very rare in children and adolescents.<EOS>
<BOS>It is likely to come back after treatment and may spread to the lungs.<EOS>
<BOS>Fibrous (connective) tissue tumors Fibrous (connective) tissue tumors include the following types: Desmoidtype fibromatosis (also called desmoid tumor or aggressive fibromatosis).<EOS>
<BOS>This fibrous tissue tumor is low grade (likely to grow slowly).<EOS>
<BOS>It may come back in nearby tissues but usually does not spread to distant parts of the body.<EOS>
<BOS>Rarely, the tumor may disappear without treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Desmoid tumors sometimes occur in children with changes in the adenomatous polyposis coli (APC) gene.<EOS>
<BOS>Changes in this gene cause familial adenomatous polyposis (FAP).<EOS>
<BOS>FAP is an inherited condition in which many polyps (growths on mucous membranes) form on the inside walls of the colon and rectum.<EOS>
<BOS>Genetic counseling (a discussion with a trained professional about inherited diseases and a possible need for gene testing) may be needed.<EOS>
<BOS>Dermatofibrosarcoma protuberans.<EOS>
<BOS>This is a rare tumor of the deep layers of the skin found in children and adults.<EOS>
<BOS>The cells of this tumor have a certain genetic change called a translocation (part of one chromosome switches places with part of another chromosome).<EOS>
<BOS>In order to diagnose dermatofibrosarcoma protuberans, the tumor cells are checked for this genetic change.<EOS>
<BOS>Fibrosarcoma.<EOS>
<BOS>There are two types of fibrosarcoma in children and adolescents: Infantile fibrosarcoma (also called congenital fibrosarcoma).<EOS>
<BOS>This type of fibrosarcoma is found in children aged 4 years and younger.<EOS>
<BOS>It most often occurs in infants and may be seen in a prenatal ultrasound exam.<EOS>
<BOS>This tumor is often large and fast growing, but rarely spreads to distant parts of the body.<EOS>
<BOS>The cells of this tumor usually have a certain genetic change called a translocation (part of one chromosome switches places with part of another chromosome).<EOS>
<BOS>In order to diagnose infantile fibrosarcoma, the tumor cells are checked for this genetic change.<EOS>
<BOS>Adulttype fibrosarcoma.<EOS>
<BOS>This is the same type of fibrosarcoma found in adults.<EOS>
<BOS>The cells of this tumor do not have the genetic change found in infantile fibrosarcoma.<EOS>
<BOS>See the PDQ summary on Adult Soft Tissue Sarcoma Treatment for more information.<EOS>
<BOS>Inflammatory myofibroblastic tumor.<EOS>
<BOS>This is a fibrous tissue tumor that occurs in children and adolescents.<EOS>
<BOS>It is likely to come back after treatment but rarely spreads to distant parts of the body.<EOS>
<BOS>A certain genetic change has been found in about half of these tumors.<EOS>
<BOS>Lowgrade fibromyxoid sarcoma.<EOS>
<BOS>This is a slowgrowing tumor that affects young and middleaged adults.<EOS>
<BOS>The cells of this tumor usually have a certain genetic change called a translocation (part of one chromosome switches places with part of another chromosome).<EOS>
<BOS>In order to diagnose lowgrade fibromyxoid sarcoma, the tumor cells are checked for this genetic change.<EOS>
<BOS>The tumor may come back many years after treatment and spread to the lungs and the lining of the wall of the chest cavity.<EOS>
<BOS>Lifelong followup is needed.<EOS>
<BOS>Myxofibrosarcoma.<EOS>
<BOS>This is a rare fibrous tissue tumor that is found less often in children than in adults.<EOS>
<BOS>Sclerosing epithelioid fibrosarcoma.<EOS>
<BOS>This is a rare fibrous tissue tumor that can come back and spread to other places years after treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Longterm followup is needed.<EOS>
<BOS>Skeletal muscle tumors Skeletal muscle is attached to bones and helps the body move.<EOS>
<BOS>Rhabdomyosarcoma.<EOS>
<BOS>Rhabdomyosarcoma is the most common childhood soft tissue sarcoma in children 14 years and younger.<EOS>
<BOS>See the PDQ summary on Childhood Rhabdomyosarcoma Treatment for more information.<EOS>
<BOS>Smooth muscle tumors Smooth muscle lines the inside of blood vessels and hollow internal organs such as the stomach, intestines, bladder, and uterus.<EOS>
<BOS>Leiomyosarcoma.<EOS>
<BOS>This smooth muscle tumor has been linked with EpsteinBarr virus in children who also have HIV disease or AIDS.<EOS>
<BOS>Leiomyosarcoma may also form as a second cancer in survivors of inherited retinoblastoma, sometimes many years after the initial treatment for retinoblastoma.<EOS>
<BOS>Socalled fibrohistiocytic tumors Plexiform fibrohistiocytic tumor.<EOS>
<BOS>This is a rare tumor that usually affects children and young adults.<EOS>
<BOS>The tumor usually starts as a painless growth on or just under the skin on the arm, hand, or wrist.<EOS>
<BOS>It may rarely spread to nearby lymph nodes or to the lungs.<EOS>
<BOS>Peripheral nervous system tumors Peripheral nervous system tumors include the following types: Ectomesenchymoma.<EOS>
<BOS>This is a rare, fastgrowing tumor of the nerve sheath (protective covering of nerves that are not part of the brain or spinal cord) that occurs mainly in children.<EOS>
<BOS>Ectomesenchymomas may form in the head and neck, abdomen, perineum, scrotum, arms, or legs.<EOS>
<BOS>Malignant peripheral nerve sheath tumor.<EOS>
<BOS>This is a tumor that forms in the nerve sheath.<EOS>
<BOS>Some children who have a malignant peripheral nerve sheath tumor have a rare genetic condition called neurofibromatosis type 1 (NF1).<EOS>
<BOS>This tumor may be low grade or high grade.<EOS>
<BOS>Malignant triton tumor.<EOS>
<BOS>These are very rare, fastgrowing tumors that occur most often in children with NF1.<EOS>
<BOS>Pericytic (Perivascular) Tumors Pericytic tumors form in cells that wrap around blood vessels.<EOS>
<BOS>Pericytic tumors include the following types: Myopericytoma.<EOS>
<BOS>Infantile hemangiopericytoma is a type of myopericytoma.<EOS>
<BOS>Children younger than 1 year at the time of diagnosis may have a better prognosis.<EOS>
<BOS>In patients older than 1 year, infantile hemangiopericytoma is more likely to spread to other parts of the body, including the lymph nodes and lungs.<EOS>
<BOS>Infantile myofibromatosis.<EOS>
<BOS>Infantile myofibromatosis is another type of myopericytoma.<EOS>
<BOS>It is a fibrous tumor that often forms in the first 2 years of life.<EOS>
<BOS>There may be one nodule under the skin, usually in the head and neck area (myofibroma), or nodules in several skin areas, muscle, and bone (myofibromatosis).<EOS>
<BOS>These tumors may go away without treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Tumors of unknown origin Tumors of unknown origin (the place where the tumor first formed is not known) include the following types: Alveolar soft part sarcoma.<EOS>
<BOS>This is a rare tumor of the soft supporting tissue that connects and surrounds the organs and other tissues.<EOS>
<BOS>It is most commonly found in the limbs but can occur in the tissues of the mouth, jaws, and face.<EOS>
<BOS>It may grow slowly and may have spread to other parts of the body at the time of diagnosis.<EOS>
<BOS>Alveolar soft part sarcoma may have a better prognosis when the tumor is 5 centimeters or smaller or when the tumor is completely removed by surgery.<EOS>
<BOS>The cells of this tumor usually have a certain genetic change called a translocation (part of one chromosome switches places with part of another chromosome).<EOS>
<BOS>In order to diagnose alveolar soft part sarcoma, the tumor cells are checked for this genetic change.<EOS>
<BOS>Clear cell sarcoma of soft tissue.<EOS>
<BOS>This is a slowgrowing soft tissue tumor that begins in a tendon (tough, fibrous, cordlike tissue that connects muscle to bone or to another part of the body).<EOS>
<BOS>Clear cell sarcoma most commonly occurs in deep tissue of the foot, heel, and ankle.<EOS>
<BOS>It may spread to nearby lymph nodes.<EOS>
<BOS>The cells of this tumor usually have a certain genetic change called a translocation (part of one chromosome switches places with part of another chromosome).<EOS>
<BOS>In order to diagnose clear cell sarcoma of soft tissue, the tumor cells are checked for this genetic change.<EOS>
<BOS>Desmoplastic small round cell tumor.<EOS>
<BOS>This tumor most often forms in the abdomen, pelvis or tissues around the testes, but it may form in the kidney.<EOS>
<BOS>Desmoplastic small round cell tumor may also spread to the lungs and other parts of the body.<EOS>
<BOS>The cells of this tumor usually have a certain genetic change called a translocation (part of one chromosome switches places with part of another chromosome).<EOS>
<BOS>In order to diagnose desmoplastic small round cell tumor, the tumor cells are checked for this genetic change.<EOS>
<BOS>Epithelioid sarcoma.<EOS>
<BOS>This is a rare sarcoma that usually starts deep in soft tissue as a slow growing, firm lump and may spread to the lymph nodes.<EOS>
<BOS>Extrarenal (extracranial) rhabdoid tumor.<EOS>
<BOS>This is a rare, fastgrowing tumor of soft tissues such as the liver and peritoneum.<EOS>
<BOS>It usually occurs in young children, including newborns, but it can occur in older children and adults.<EOS>
<BOS>Rhabdoid tumors may be linked to a change in a tumor suppressor gene called SMARCB1.<EOS>
<BOS>This type of gene makes a protein that helps control cell growth.<EOS>
<BOS>Changes in the SMARCB1 gene may be inherited (passed on from parents to offspring).<EOS>
<BOS>Genetic counseling (a discussion with a trained professional about inherited diseases and a possible need for gene testing) may be needed.<EOS>
<BOS>Extraskeletal myxoid chondrosarcoma.<EOS>
<BOS>This is a rare soft tissue sarcoma that may be found in children and adolescents.<EOS>
<BOS>Over time, it tends to spread to other parts of the body, including the lymph nodes and lungs.<EOS>
<BOS>The cells of this tumor usually have a genetic change, often a translocation (part of one chromosome switches places with part of another chromosome).<EOS>
<BOS>In order to diagnose extraskeletal myxoid chondrosarcoma, the tumor cells are checked for this genetic change.<EOS>
<BOS>The tumor may come back many years after treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Perivascular epithelioid cell tumors (PEComas).<EOS>
<BOS>Benign (not cancer) PEComas may be found in children with an inherited condition called tuberous sclerosis.<EOS>
<BOS>They occur in the stomach, intestines, lungs, female reproductive organs, and genitourinary organs.<EOS>
<BOS>Primitive neuroectodermal tumor (PNET)/extraskeletal Ewing tumor.<EOS>
<BOS>See the PDQ summary on Ewing Sarcoma Treatment for information.<EOS>
<BOS>Synovial sarcoma.<EOS>
<BOS>Synovial sarcoma is a common type of soft tissue sarcoma in children and adolescents.<EOS>
<BOS>Synovial sarcoma usually forms in the tissues around the joints in the arms or legs, but may also form in the trunk, head, or neck.<EOS>
<BOS>The cells of this tumor usually have a certain genetic change called a translocation (part of one chromosome switches places with part of another chromosome).<EOS>
<BOS>Larger tumors have a greater risk of spreading to other parts of the body, including the lungs.<EOS>
<BOS>Children younger than 10 years and those whose tumor is 5 centimeters or smaller have a better prognosis.<EOS>
<BOS>Undifferentiated /unclassified sarcoma.<EOS>
<BOS>These tumors usually occur in the muscles that are attached to bones and that help the body move.<EOS>
<BOS>Undifferentiated pleomorphic sarcoma /malignant fibrous histiocytoma (highgrade).<EOS>
<BOS>This type of soft tissue tumor may form in parts of the body where patients have received radiation therapy in the past, or as a second cancer in children with retinoblastoma.<EOS>
<BOS>The tumor is usually found on the arms or legs and may spread to other parts of the body.<EOS>
<BOS>See the PDQ summary on Osteosarcoma and Malignant Fibrous Histiocytoma of Bone Treatment for information about malignant fibrous histiocytoma of bone.<EOS>
<BOS>Blood vessel tumors Blood vessel tumors include the following types: Angiosarcoma of the soft tissue.<EOS>
<BOS>Angiosarcoma of the soft tissue is a fastgrowing tumor that forms in blood vessels or lymph vessels in any part of the body.<EOS>
<BOS>Most angiosarcomas are in or just under the skin.<EOS>
<BOS>Those in deeper soft tissue can form in the liver, spleen, and lung.<EOS>
<BOS>They are very rare in children, who sometimes have more than one tumor in the skin or liver.<EOS>
<BOS>Rarely, infantile hemangioma may become angiosarcoma of the soft tissue.<EOS>
<BOS>(See the PDQ summary on Childhood Vascular Tumors Treatment for more information.<EOS>
<BOS>) Epithelioid hemangioendothelioma.<EOS>
<BOS>Epithelioid hemangioendotheliomas can occur in children, but are most common in adults between 30 and 50 years of age.<EOS>
<BOS>They usually occur in the liver, lung, or bone.<EOS>
<BOS>They may be either fast growing or slow growing.<EOS>
<BOS>In about a third of cases, the tumor spreads to other parts of the body very quickly.<EOS>
<BOS>(See the PDQ summary on Childhood Vascular Tumors Treatment for more information.<EOS>
<BOS>) See the following PDQ summaries for information about types of soft tissue sarcoma not included in this summary: Childhood Rhabdomyosarcoma Treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Ewing Sarcoma Treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Unusual Cancers of Childhood Treatment (gastrointestinal stromal tumors).<EOS>
<BOS>Key Points After childhood Hodgkin lymphoma has been diagnosed, tests are done to find out if cancer cells have spread within the lymph system or to other parts of the body.<EOS>
<BOS>There are three ways that cancer spreads in the body.<EOS>
<BOS>Stages of childhood Hodgkin lymphoma may include A, B, E, and S.<EOS>
<BOS>The following stages are used for childhood Hodgkin lymphoma: Stage I Stage II Stage III Stage IV Untreated Hodgkin lymphoma is divided into risk groups.<EOS>
<BOS>After childhood Hodgkin lymphoma has been diagnosed, tests are done to find out if cancer cells have spread within the lymph system or to other parts of the body.<EOS>
<BOS>The process used to find out if cancer has spread within the lymph system or to other parts of the body is called staging.<EOS>
<BOS>The information gathered from the staging process determines the stage of the disease.<EOS>
<BOS>Treatment is based on the stage and other factors that affect prognosis.<EOS>
<BOS>The following tests and procedures may be used in the staging process: CT scan (CAT scan): A procedure that makes a series of detailed pictures of areas inside the body, such as the neck, chest, abdomen, or pelvis, taken from different angles.<EOS>
<BOS>The pictures are made by a computer linked to an xray machine.<EOS>
<BOS>A dye may be injected into a vein or swallowed to help the organs or tissues show up more clearly.<EOS>
<BOS>This procedure is also called computed tomography, computerized tomography, or computerized axial tomography.<EOS>
<BOS>PET scan (positron emission tomography scan): A procedure to find malignant tumor cells in the body.<EOS>
<BOS>A small amount of radioactive glucose (sugar) is injected into a vein.<EOS>
<BOS>The PET scanner rotates around the body and makes a picture of where glucose is being used in the body.<EOS>
<BOS>Malignant tumor cells show up brighter in the picture because they are more active and take up more glucose than normal cells do.<EOS>
<BOS>Sometimes a PET scan and a CT scan are done at the same time.<EOS>
<BOS>If there is any cancer, this increases the chance that it will be found.<EOS>
<BOS>MRI (magnetic resonance imaging): A procedure that uses a magnet, radio waves, and a computer to make a series of detailed pictures of areas inside the body.<EOS>
<BOS>This procedure is also called nuclear magnetic resonance imaging (NMRI).<EOS>
<BOS>An MRI of the abdomen and pelvis may be done.<EOS>
<BOS>Bone marrow aspiration and biopsy : The removal of bone marrow and a small piece of bone by inserting a hollow needle into the hipbone or breastbone.<EOS>
<BOS>A pathologist views the bone marrow and bone under a microscope to look for abnormal cells.<EOS>
<BOS>There are three ways that cancer spreads in the body.<EOS>
<BOS>Cancer can spread through tissue, the lymph system, and the blood: Tissue.<EOS>
<BOS>The cancer spreads from where it began by growing into nearby areas.<EOS>
<BOS>Lymph system.<EOS>
<BOS>The cancer spreads from where it began by getting into the lymph system.<EOS>
<BOS>The cancer travels through the lymph vessels to other parts of the body.<EOS>
<BOS>Blood.<EOS>
<BOS>The cancer spreads from where it began by getting into the blood.<EOS>
<BOS>The cancer travels through the blood vessels to other parts of the body.<EOS>
<BOS>Stages of childhood Hodgkin lymphoma may include A, B, E, and S.<EOS>
<BOS>Childhood Hodgkin lymphoma may be described as follows: A: The patient does not have B symptoms (fever, weight loss, or night sweats).<EOS>
<BOS>B: The patient has B symptoms.<EOS>
<BOS>E: Cancer is found in an organ or tissue that is not part of the lymph system but which may be next to an area of the lymph system affected by the cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>S: Cancer is found in the spleen.<EOS>
<BOS>The following stages are used for childhood Hodgkin lymphoma: Stage I Stage I is divided into stage I and stage IE.<EOS>
<BOS>Stage I: Cancer is found in one of the following places in the lymph system: One or more lymph nodes in one lymph node group.<EOS>
<BOS>Waldeyer's ring.<EOS>
<BOS>Thymus.<EOS>
<BOS>Spleen.<EOS>
<BOS>Stage IE: Cancer is found outside the lymph system in one organ or area.<EOS>
<BOS>Stage II Stage II is divided into stage II and stage IIE.<EOS>
<BOS>Stage II: Cancer is found in two or more lymph node groups either above or below the diaphragm (the thin muscle below the lungs that helps breathing and separates the chest from the abdomen).<EOS>
<BOS>Stage IIE: Cancer is found in one or more lymph node groups either above or below the diaphragm and outside the lymph nodes in a nearby organ or area.<EOS>
<BOS>Stage III Stage III is divided into stage III, stage IIIE, stage IIIS, and stage IIIE,S.<EOS>
<BOS>Stage III: Cancer is found in lymph node groups above and below the diaphragm (the thin muscle below the lungs that helps breathing and separates the chest from the abdomen).<EOS>
<BOS>Stage IIIE: Cancer is found in lymph node groups above and below the diaphragm and outside the lymph nodes in a nearby organ or area.<EOS>
<BOS>Stage IIIS: Cancer is found in lymph node groups above and below the diaphragm, and in the spleen.<EOS>
<BOS>Stage IIIE,S: Cancer is found in lymph node groups above and below the diaphragm, outside the lymph nodes in a nearby organ or area, and in the spleen.<EOS>
<BOS>Stage IV In stage IV, the cancer: is found outside the lymph nodes throughout one or more organs, and may be in lymph nodes near those organs; or is found outside the lymph nodes in one organ and has spread to areas far away from that organ; or is found in the lung, liver, bone marrow, or cerebrospinal fluid (CSF).<EOS>
<BOS>The cancer has not spread to the lung, liver, bone marrow, or CSF from nearby areas.<EOS>
<BOS>Untreated Hodgkin lymphoma is divided into risk groups.<EOS>
<BOS>Untreated childhood Hodgkin lymphoma is divided into risk groups based on the stage, size of the tumor, and whether the patient has B symptoms (fever, weight loss, or night sweats).<EOS>
<BOS>The risk group is used to plan treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Lowrisk childhood Hodgkin lymphoma.<EOS>
<BOS>Intermediaterisk childhood Hodgkin lymphoma.<EOS>
<BOS>Highrisk childhood Hodgkin lymphoma.<EOS>
<BOS>Key Points Ovarian, fallopian tube, and primary peritoneal cancers are diseases in which malignant (cancer) cells form in the ovaries, fallopian tubes, or peritoneum.<EOS>
<BOS>In the United States, ovarian cancer is the fifth leading cause of cancer death in women.<EOS>
<BOS>Different factors increase or decrease the risk of getting ovarian, fallopian tube, and primary peritoneal cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Ovarian, fallopian tube, and primary peritoneal cancers are diseases in which malignant (cancer) cells form in the ovaries, fallopian tubes, or peritoneum.<EOS>
<BOS>The ovaries are a pair of organs in the female reproductive system.<EOS>
<BOS>They are located in the pelvis, one on each side of the uterus (the hollow, pearshaped organ where a fetus grows).<EOS>
<BOS>Each ovary is about the size and shape of an almond.<EOS>
<BOS>The ovaries produce eggs and female hormones (chemicals that control the way certain cells or organs function).<EOS>
<BOS>The fallopian tubes are a pair of long, slender tubes, one on each side of the uterus.<EOS>
<BOS>Eggs pass from the ovaries, through the fallopian tubes, to the uterus.<EOS>
<BOS>Cancer sometimes begins at the end of the fallopian tube near the ovary and spreads to the ovary.<EOS>
<BOS>The peritoneum is the tissue that lines the abdominal wall and covers organs in the abdomen.<EOS>
<BOS>Primary peritoneal cancer is cancer that forms in the peritoneum and has not spread there from another part of the body.<EOS>
<BOS>Cancer sometimes begins in the peritoneum and spreads to the ovary.<EOS>
<BOS>Ovarian epithelial cancer, fallopian tube cancer, and primary peritoneal cancer form in the same type of tissue.<EOS>
<BOS>Studies of screening tests look at these cancers together.<EOS>
<BOS>See the following PDQ summaries for more information about ovarian, fallopian tube, and primary peritoneal cancers: Ovarian, Fallopian Tube, and Primary Peritoneal Cancer Prevention Genetics of Breast and Gynecologic Cancers Ovarian Epithelial, Fallopian Tube, and Primary Peritoneal Cancer Treatment Ovarian Germ Cell Tumors Treatment Ovarian Low Malignant Potential Tumors Treatment In the United States, ovarian cancer is the fifth leading cause of cancer death in women.<EOS>
<BOS>Ovarian cancer is also the leading cause of death from cancer of the female reproductive system.<EOS>
<BOS>Over the last 20 years, the number of new cases of ovarian cancer has gone down slightly in white women and in black women.<EOS>
<BOS>Since 2005, the number of deaths from ovarian cancer also decreased slightly in white and black women.<EOS>
<BOS>Key Points There are different types of treatment for patients with small cell lung cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Five types of standard treatment are used: Surgery Chemotherapy Radiation therapy Laser therapy Endoscopic stent placement New types of treatment are being tested in clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients may want to think about taking part in a clinical trial.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients can enter clinical trials before, during, or after starting their cancer treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Followup tests may be needed.<EOS>
<BOS>There are different types of treatment for patients with small cell lung cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Different types of treatment are available for patients with small cell lung cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Some treatments are standard (the currently used treatment), and some are being tested in clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>A treatment clinical trial is a research study meant to help improve current treatments or obtain information on new treatments for patients with cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>When clinical trials show that a new treatment is better than the standard treatment, the new treatment may become the standard treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients may want to think about taking part in a clinical trial.<EOS>
<BOS>Some clinical trials are open only to patients who have not started treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Five types of standard treatment are used: Surgery Surgery may be used if the cancer is found in one lung and in nearby lymph nodes only.<EOS>
<BOS>Because this type of lung cancer is usually found in both lungs, surgery alone is not often used.<EOS>
<BOS>During surgery, the doctor will also remove lymph nodes to find out if they have cancer in them.<EOS>
<BOS>Sometimes, surgery may be used to remove a sample of lung tissue to find out the exact type of lung cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Even if the doctor removes all the cancer that can be seen at the time of the operation, some patients may be given chemotherapy or radiation therapy after surgery to kill any cancer cells that are left.<EOS>
<BOS>Treatment given after the surgery, to lower the risk that the cancer will come back, is called adjuvant therapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Chemotherapy Chemotherapy is a cancer treatment that uses drugs to stop the growth of cancer cells, either by killing the cells or by stopping them from dividing.<EOS>
<BOS>When chemotherapy is taken by mouth or injected into a vein or muscle, the drugs enter the bloodstream and can reach cancer cells throughout the body (systemic chemotherapy).<EOS>
<BOS>When chemotherapy is placed directly into the cerebrospinal fluid, an organ, or a body cavity such as the abdomen, the drugs mainly affect cancer cells in those areas (regional chemotherapy).<EOS>
<BOS>The way the chemotherapy is given depends on the type and stage of the cancer being treated.<EOS>
<BOS>See Drugs Approved for Small Cell Lung Cancer for more information.<EOS>
<BOS>Radiation therapy Radiation therapy is a cancer treatment that uses highenergy xrays or other types of radiation to kill cancer cells or keep them from growing.<EOS>
<BOS>There are two types of radiation therapy: External radiation therapy uses a machine outside the body to send radiation toward the cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Internal radiation therapy uses a radioactive substance sealed in needles, seeds, wires, or catheters that are placed directly into or near the cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>The way the radiation therapy is given depends on the type and stage of the cancer being treated.<EOS>
<BOS>External radiation therapy is used to treat small cell lung cancer, and may also be used as palliative therapy to relieve symptoms and improve quality of life.<EOS>
<BOS>Radiation therapy to the brain to lessen the risk that cancer will spread to the brain may also be given.<EOS>
<BOS>Laser therapy Laser therapy is a cancer treatment that uses a laser beam (a narrow beam of intense light) to kill cancer cells.<EOS>
<BOS>Endoscopic stent placement An endoscope is a thin, tubelike instrument used to look at tissues inside the body.<EOS>
<BOS>An endoscope has a light and a lens for viewing and may be used to place a stent in a body structure to keep the structure open.<EOS>
<BOS>An endoscopic stent can be used to open an airway blocked by abnormal tissue.<EOS>
<BOS>New types of treatment are being tested in clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>Information about clinical trials is available from the NCI website.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients may want to think about taking part in a clinical trial.<EOS>
<BOS>For some patients, taking part in a clinical trial may be the best treatment choice.<EOS>
<BOS>Clinical trials are part of the cancer research process.<EOS>
<BOS>Clinical trials are done to find out if new cancer treatments are safe and effective or better than the standard treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Many of today's standard treatments for cancer are based on earlier clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients who take part in a clinical trial may receive the standard treatment or be among the first to receive a new treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients who take part in clinical trials also help improve the way cancer will be treated in the future.<EOS>
<BOS>Even when clinical trials do not lead to effective new treatments, they often answer important questions and help move research forward.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients can enter clinical trials before, during, or after starting their cancer treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Some clinical trials only include patients who have not yet received treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Other trials test treatments for patients whose cancer has not gotten better.<EOS>
<BOS>There are also clinical trials that test new ways to stop cancer from recurring (coming back) or reduce the side effects of cancer treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Clinical trials are taking place in many parts of the country.<EOS>
<BOS>See the Treatment Options section that follows for links to current treatment clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>These have been retrieved from NCI's listing of clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>Followup tests may be needed.<EOS>
<BOS>Some of the tests that were done to diagnose the cancer or to find out the stage of the cancer may be repeated.<EOS>
<BOS>Some tests will be repeated in order to see how well the treatment is working.<EOS>
<BOS>Decisions about whether to continue, change, or stop treatment may be based on the results of these tests.<EOS>
<BOS>Some of the tests will continue to be done from time to time after treatment has ended.<EOS>
<BOS>The results of these tests can show if your condition has changed or if the cancer has recurred (come back).<EOS>
<BOS>These tests are sometimes called followup tests or checkups.<EOS>
<BOS>Treatment Options by Stage LimitedStage Small Cell Lung Cancer Treatment of limitedstage small cell lung cancer may include the following: Combination chemotherapy and radiation therapy to the chest.<EOS>
<BOS>Radiation therapy to the brain may later be given to patients with complete responses.<EOS>
<BOS>Combination chemotherapy alone for patients who cannot be given radiation therapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Surgery followed by chemotherapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Surgery followed by chemotherapy and radiation therapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Radiation therapy to the brain may be given to patients who have had a complete response, to prevent the spread of cancer to the brain.<EOS>
<BOS>Clinical trials of new chemotherapy, surgery, and radiation treatments.<EOS>
<BOS>Check the list of NCIsupported cancer clinical trials that are now accepting patients with limited stage small cell lung cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>For more specific results, refine the search by using other search features, such as the location of the trial, the type of treatment, or the name of the drug.<EOS>
<BOS>Talk with your doctor about clinical trials that may be right for you.<EOS>
<BOS>General information about clinical trials is available from the NCI website.<EOS>
<BOS>ExtensiveStage Small Cell Lung Cancer Treatment of extensivestage small cell lung cancer may include the following: Combination chemotherapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Radiation therapy to the brain, spine, bone, or other parts of the body where the cancer has spread, as palliative therapy to relieve symptoms and improve quality of life.<EOS>
<BOS>Radiation therapy to the chest may be given to patients who respond to chemotherapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Radiation therapy to the brain may be given to patients who have had a complete response, to prevent the spread of cancer to the brain.<EOS>
<BOS>Clinical trials of new chemotherapy treatments.<EOS>
<BOS>Check the list of NCIsupported cancer clinical trials that are now accepting patients with extensive stage small cell lung cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>For more specific results, refine the search by using other search features, such as the location of the trial, the type of treatment, or the name of the drug.<EOS>
<BOS>Talk with your doctor about clinical trials that may be right for you.<EOS>
<BOS>General information about clinical trials is available from the NCI website.<EOS>
<BOS>Key Points Childhood extracranial germ cell tumors form from germ cells in parts of the body other than the brain.<EOS>
<BOS>Childhood extracranial germ cell tumors may be benign or malignant.<EOS>
<BOS>There are three types of extracranial germ cell tumors.<EOS>
<BOS>Mature Teratomas Immature Teratomas Malignant Germ Cell Tumors Childhood extracranial germ cell tumors are grouped as gonadal or extragonadal.<EOS>
<BOS>Gonadal Germ Cell Tumors Extragonadal Extracranial Germ Cell Tumors The cause of most childhood extracranial germ cell tumors is unknown.<EOS>
<BOS>Having certain inherited disorders can increase the risk of an extracranial germ cell tumor.<EOS>
<BOS>Signs of childhood extracranial germ cell tumors depend on the type of tumor and where it is in the body.<EOS>
<BOS>Imaging studies and blood tests are used to detect (find) and diagnose childhood extracranial germ cell tumors.<EOS>
<BOS>Certain factors affect prognosis (chance of recovery) and treatment options.<EOS>
<BOS>Childhood extracranial germ cell tumors form from germ cells in parts of the body other than the brain.<EOS>
<BOS>A germ cell is a type of cell that forms as a fetus (unborn baby) develops.<EOS>
<BOS>These cells later become sperm in the testicles or eggs in the ovaries.<EOS>
<BOS>Sometimes while the fetus is forming, germ cells travel to parts of the body where they should not be and grow into a germ cell tumor.<EOS>
<BOS>The tumor may form before or after birth.<EOS>
<BOS>This summary is about germ cell tumors that form in parts of the body that are extracranial (outside the brain).<EOS>
<BOS>Extracranial germ cell tumors usually form in the following areas of the body: Testicles.<EOS>
<BOS>Ovaries.<EOS>
<BOS>Sacrum or coccyx (bottom part of the spine).<EOS>
<BOS>Retroperitoneum (the back wall of the abdomen).<EOS>
<BOS>Mediastinum (area between the lungs).<EOS>
<BOS>Extracranial germ cell tumors are most common in adolescents 15 to 19 years of age.<EOS>
<BOS>See the PDQ summary on Childhood Central Nervous System Germ Cell Tumors Treatment for information on intracranial (inside the brain) germ cell tumors.<EOS>
<BOS>Childhood extracranial germ cell tumors may be benign or malignant.<EOS>
<BOS>Extracranial germ cell tumors may be benign (noncancer) or malignant (cancer).<EOS>
<BOS>There are three types of extracranial germ cell tumors.<EOS>
<BOS>Extracranial germ cell tumors are grouped into mature teratomas, immature teratomas, and malignant germ cell tumors: Mature Teratomas Mature teratomas are the most common type of extracranial germ cell tumor.<EOS>
<BOS>Mature teratomas are benign tumors and not likely to become cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>They usually occur in the sacrum or coccyx (bottom part of the spine) in newborns or in the ovaries of girls at the start of puberty.<EOS>
<BOS>The cells of mature teratomas look almost like normal cells under a microscope.<EOS>
<BOS>Some mature teratomas release enzymes or hormones that cause signs and symptoms of disease.<EOS>
<BOS>Immature Teratomas Immature teratomas also usually occur in the sacrum or coccyx (bottom part of the spine) in newborns or the ovaries of girls at the start of puberty.<EOS>
<BOS>Immature teratomas have cells that look very different from normal cells under a microscope.<EOS>
<BOS>Immature teratomas may be cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>They often have several different types of tissue in them, such as hair, muscle, and bone.<EOS>
<BOS>Some immature teratomas release enzymes or hormones that cause signs and symptoms of disease.<EOS>
<BOS>Malignant Germ Cell Tumors Malignant germ cell tumors are cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>There are two main types of malignant germ cell tumors: Germinomas: Tumors that make a hormone called betahuman chorionic gonadotropin (hCG).<EOS>
<BOS>There are three types of germinomas.<EOS>
<BOS>Dysgerminomas form in the ovary in girls.<EOS>
<BOS>Seminomas form in the testicle in boys.<EOS>
<BOS>Germinomas form in areas of the body that are not the ovary or testicle.<EOS>
<BOS>Nongerminomas: There are four types of nongerminomas.<EOS>
<BOS>Yolk sac tumors make a hormone called alphafetoprotein (AFP).<EOS>
<BOS>They can form in the ovary, testicle, or other areas of the body.<EOS>
<BOS>Choriocarcinomas make a hormone called betahuman chorionic gonadotropin (hCG).<EOS>
<BOS>They can form in the ovary, testicle, or other areas of the body.<EOS>
<BOS>Embryonal carcinomas may make a hormone called hCG and/or a hormone called AFP.<EOS>
<BOS>They can form in the testicle or other parts of the body, but not in the ovary.<EOS>
<BOS>Mixed germ cell tumors are made up of both malignant germ cell tumor and teratoma.<EOS>
<BOS>They can form in the ovary, testicle, or other areas of the body.<EOS>
<BOS>Childhood extracranial germ cell tumors are grouped as gonadal or extragonadal.<EOS>
<BOS>Malignant extracranial germ cell tumors are gonadal or extragonadal.<EOS>
<BOS>Gonadal Germ Cell Tumors Gonadal germ cell tumors form in the testicles in boys or ovaries in girls.<EOS>
<BOS>Testicular Germ Cell Tumors Testicular germ cell tumors are divided into two main types, seminoma and nonseminoma.<EOS>
<BOS>Seminomas make a hormone called betahuman chorionic gonadotropin (hCG).<EOS>
<BOS>Nonseminomas are usually large and cause signs or symptoms.<EOS>
<BOS>They tend to grow and spread more quickly than seminomas.<EOS>
<BOS>Testicular germ cell tumors usually occur before the age of 4 years or in adolescents and young adults.<EOS>
<BOS>Testicular germ cell tumors in adolescents and young adults are different from those that form in early childhood.<EOS>
<BOS>Boys older than 14 years with testicular germ cell tumors are treated in pediatric cancer centers, but the treatment is much like the treatment used in adults.<EOS>
<BOS>(See the PDQ summary on Testicular Cancer Treatment for more information.<EOS>
<BOS>) Ovarian Germ Cell Tumors Ovarian germ cell tumors are more common in adolescent girls and young women.<EOS>
<BOS>Most ovarian germ cell tumors are benign teratomas.<EOS>
<BOS>Sometimes immature teratomas, dysgerminomas, yolk sac tumors, and mixed germ cell tumors (cancer) occur.<EOS>
<BOS>(See the PDQ summary on Ovarian Germ Cell Tumors Treatment for more information.<EOS>
<BOS>) Extragonadal Extracranial Germ Cell Tumors Extragonadal extracranial germ cell tumors form in areas other than the brain, testicles, or ovaries.<EOS>
<BOS>Most extragonadal extracranial germ cell tumors form along the midline of the body.<EOS>
<BOS>This includes the following: Sacrum (the large, triangleshaped bone in the lower spine that forms part of the pelvis).<EOS>
<BOS>Coccyx (the small bone at the bottom of the spine, also called the tailbone).<EOS>
<BOS>Mediastinum (the area between the lungs).<EOS>
<BOS>Back of the abdomen.<EOS>
<BOS>Neck.<EOS>
<BOS>In younger children, extragonadal extracranial germ cell tumors usually occur at birth or in early childhood.<EOS>
<BOS>Most of these tumors are teratomas in the sacrum or coccyx.<EOS>
<BOS>In older children, adolescents, and young adults, extragonadal extracranial germ cell tumors are often in the mediastinum.<EOS>
<BOS>Being exposed to certain types of radiation may increase the risk of salivary cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Anything that increases the chance of getting a disease is called a risk factor.<EOS>
<BOS>Having a risk factor does not mean that you will get cancer; not having risk factors doesnt mean that you will not get cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Talk with your doctor if you think you may be at risk.<EOS>
<BOS>Although the cause of most salivary gland cancers is not known, risk factors include the following: Older age.<EOS>
<BOS>Treatment with radiation therapy to the head and neck.<EOS>
<BOS>Being exposed to certain substances at work.<EOS>
<BOS>Key Points Juvenile myelomonocytic leukemia is a childhood disease in which too many myelocytes and monocytes (immature white blood cells) are made in the bone marrow.<EOS>
<BOS>Signs and symptoms of juvenile myelomonocytic leukemia include fever, weight loss, and feeling very tired.<EOS>
<BOS>Certain factors affect prognosis (chance of recovery) and treatment options.<EOS>
<BOS>Juvenile myelomonocytic leukemia is a childhood disease in which too many myelocytes and monocytes (immature white blood cells) are made in the bone marrow.<EOS>
<BOS>Juvenile myelomonocytic leukemia (JMML) is a rare childhood cancer that occurs more often in children younger than 2 years.<EOS>
<BOS>Children who have neurofibromatosis type 1 and males have an increased risk of juvenile myelomonocytic leukemia.<EOS>
<BOS>In JMML, the body tells too many blood stem cells to become two types of white blood cells called myelocytes and monocytes.<EOS>
<BOS>Some of these blood stem cells never become mature white blood cells.<EOS>
<BOS>These immature white blood cells are called blasts.<EOS>
<BOS>Over time, the myelocytes, monocytes, and blasts crowd out the red blood cells and platelets in the bone marrow.<EOS>
<BOS>When this happens, infection, anemia, or easy bleeding may occur.<EOS>
<BOS>New types of treatment are being tested in clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>Information about clinical trials is available from the NCI website.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients may want to think about taking part in a clinical trial.<EOS>
<BOS>For some patients, taking part in a clinical trial may be the best treatment choice.<EOS>
<BOS>Clinical trials are part of the cancer research process.<EOS>
<BOS>Clinical trials are done to find out if new cancer treatments are safe and effective or better than the standard treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Many of today's standard treatments for cancer are based on earlier clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients who take part in a clinical trial may receive the standard treatment or be among the first to receive a new treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients who take part in clinical trials also help improve the way cancer will be treated in the future.<EOS>
<BOS>Even when clinical trials do not lead to effective new treatments, they often answer important questions and help move research forward.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients can enter clinical trials before, during, or after starting their cancer treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Some clinical trials only include patients who have not yet received treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Other trials test treatments for patients whose cancer has not gotten better.<EOS>
<BOS>There are also clinical trials that test new ways to stop cancer from recurring (coming back) or reduce the side effects of cancer treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Clinical trials are taking place in many parts of the country.<EOS>
<BOS>See the Treatment Options section that follows for links to current treatment clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>These have been retrieved from NCI's listing of clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>Imaging tests are used to detect (find) osteosarcoma and MFH.<EOS>
<BOS>Imaging tests are done before the biopsy.<EOS>
<BOS>The following tests and procedures may be used: Physical exam and history : An exam of the body to check general signs of health, including checking for signs of disease, such as lumps or anything else that seems unusual.<EOS>
<BOS>A history of the patients health habits and past illnesses and treatments will also be taken.<EOS>
<BOS>Xray : An xray of the organs and bones inside the body.<EOS>
<BOS>An xray is a type of energy beam that can go through the body and onto film, making a picture of areas inside the body.<EOS>
<BOS>CT scan (CAT scan): A procedure that makes a series of detailed pictures of areas inside the body, taken from different angles.<EOS>
<BOS>The pictures are made by a computer linked to an xray machine.<EOS>
<BOS>A dye may be injected into a vein or swallowed to help the organs or tissues show up more clearly.<EOS>
<BOS>This procedure is also called computed tomography, computerized tomography, or computerized axial tomography.<EOS>
<BOS>MRI (magnetic resonance imaging): A procedure that uses a magnet, radio waves, and a computer to make a series of detailed pictures of areas inside the body.<EOS>
<BOS>This procedure is also called nuclear magnetic resonance imaging (NMRI).<EOS>
<BOS>A biopsy is done to diagnose osteosarcoma.<EOS>
<BOS>Cells and tissues are removed during a biopsy so they can be viewed under a microscope by a pathologist to check for signs of cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>It is important that the biopsy be done by a surgeon who is an expert in treating cancer of the bone.<EOS>
<BOS>It is best if that surgeon is also the one who removes the tumor.<EOS>
<BOS>The biopsy and the surgery to remove the tumor are planned together.<EOS>
<BOS>The way the biopsy is done affects which type of surgery can be done later.<EOS>
<BOS>The type of biopsy that is done will be based on the size of the tumor and where it is in the body.<EOS>
<BOS>There are two types of biopsy that may be used: Core biopsy : The removal of tissue using a wide needle.<EOS>
<BOS>Incisional biopsy : The removal of part of a lump or a sample of tissue that doesn't look normal.<EOS>
<BOS>The following test may be done on the tissue that is removed: Light and electron microscopy : A laboratory test in which cells in a sample of tissue are viewed under regular and highpowered microscopes to look for certain changes in the cells.<EOS>
<BOS>Key Points Childhood brain stem glioma is a disease in which benign (noncancer) or malignant (cancer) cells form in the tissues of the brain stem.<EOS>
<BOS>Brain tumors may be benign (not cancer) or malignant (cancer).<EOS>
<BOS>There are two types of brain stem gliomas in children.<EOS>
<BOS>The cause of most childhood brain tumors is unknown.<EOS>
<BOS>The signs and symptoms of brain stem glioma are not the same in every child.<EOS>
<BOS>Tests that examine the brain are used to detect (find) childhood brain stem glioma.<EOS>
<BOS>A biopsy may be done to diagnose certain types of brain stem glioma.<EOS>
<BOS>Certain factors affect prognosis (chance of recovery) and treatment options.<EOS>
<BOS>Childhood brain stem glioma is a disease in which benign (noncancer) or malignant (cancer) cells form in the tissues of the brain stem.<EOS>
<BOS>Gliomas are tumors formed from glial cells.<EOS>
<BOS>Glial cells in the brain hold nerve cells in place, bring food and oxygen to them, and help protect them from disease, such as infection.<EOS>
<BOS>The brain stem is the part of the brain connected to the spinal cord.<EOS>
<BOS>It is in the lowest part of the brain, just above the back of the neck.<EOS>
<BOS>The brain stem is the part of the brain that controls breathing, heart rate, and the nerves and muscles used in seeing, hearing, walking, talking, and eating.<EOS>
<BOS>Most childhood brain stem gliomas are pontine gliomas, which form in a part of the brain stem called the pons.<EOS>
<BOS>Brain tumors are the third most common type of cancer in children.<EOS>
<BOS>This summary refers to the treatment of primary brain tumors (tumors that begin in the brain).<EOS>
<BOS>Treatment for metastatic brain tumors, which are tumors formed by cancer cells that begin in other parts of the body and spread to the brain, is not discussed in this summary.<EOS>
<BOS>Brain tumors can occur in both children and adults; however, treatment for children may be different than treatment for adults.<EOS>
<BOS>See the following PDQ treatment summaries for more information: Childhood Brain and Spinal Cord Tumors Treatment Overview Adult Central Nervous System Tumors Treatment Brain tumors may be benign (not cancer) or malignant (cancer).<EOS>
<BOS>Benign brain tumors grow and press on nearby areas of the brain.<EOS>
<BOS>They rarely spread into other tissues.<EOS>
<BOS>Malignant brain tumors are likely to grow quickly and spread into other brain tissue.<EOS>
<BOS>When a tumor grows into or presses on an area of the brain, it may stop that part of the brain from working the way it should.<EOS>
<BOS>Both benign and malignant brain tumors can cause signs and symptoms and need treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>There are two types of brain stem gliomas in children.<EOS>
<BOS>Childhood brain stem glioma is either a diffuse intrinsic pontine glioma (DIPG) or a focal glioma.<EOS>
<BOS>DIPG is a highgrade tumor that is fastgrowing and spreads all through the brain stem.<EOS>
<BOS>It is hard to treat and has a poor prognosis (chance of recovery).<EOS>
<BOS>Children younger than 3 years diagnosed with DIPG may have a better prognosis than children who are 3 years and older.<EOS>
<BOS>A focal glioma is slowgrowing and is in one area of the brain stem.<EOS>
<BOS>It is easier to treat than DIPG and has a better prognosis.<EOS>
<BOS>Signs and symptoms of adult AML include fever, feeling tired, and easy bruising or bleeding.<EOS>
<BOS>The early signs and symptoms of AML may be like those caused by the flu or other common diseases.<EOS>
<BOS>Check with your doctor if you have any of the following: Fever.<EOS>
<BOS>Shortness of breath.<EOS>
<BOS>Easy bruising or bleeding.<EOS>
<BOS>Petechiae (flat, pinpoint spots under the skin caused by bleeding).<EOS>
<BOS>Weakness or feeling tired.<EOS>
<BOS>Weight loss or loss of appetite.<EOS>
<BOS>Certain factors affect prognosis (chance of recovery) and treatment options.<EOS>
<BOS>The prognosis (chance of recovery) and treatment options for CMML depend on the following: The number of white blood cells or platelets in the blood or bone marrow.<EOS>
<BOS>Whether the patient is anemic.<EOS>
<BOS>The amount of blasts in the blood or bone marrow.<EOS>
<BOS>The amount of hemoglobin in red blood cells.<EOS>
<BOS>Whether there are certain changes in the chromosomes.<EOS>
<BOS>Key Points After osteosarcoma or malignant fibrous histiocytoma (MFH) has been diagnosed, tests are done to find out if cancer cells have spread to other parts of the body.<EOS>
<BOS>There are three ways that cancer spreads in the body.<EOS>
<BOS>Cancer may spread from where it began to other parts of the body.<EOS>
<BOS>Osteosarcoma and MFH are described as either localized or metastatic.<EOS>
<BOS>After osteosarcoma or malignant fibrous histiocytoma (MFH) has been diagnosed, tests are done to find out if cancer cells have spread to other parts of the body.<EOS>
<BOS>The process used to find out if cancer has spread to other parts of the body is called staging.<EOS>
<BOS>For osteosarcoma and malignant fibrous histiocytoma (MFH), most patients are grouped according to whether cancer is found in only one part of the body or has spread.<EOS>
<BOS>The following tests and procedures may be used: Xray : An xray of the organs, such as the chest, and bones inside the body.<EOS>
<BOS>An xray is a type of energy beam that can go through the body and onto film, making a picture of areas inside the body.<EOS>
<BOS>Xrays will be taken of the chest and the area where the tumor formed.<EOS>
<BOS>CT scan (CAT scan): A procedure that makes a series of detailed pictures of areas inside the body, such as the chest, taken from different angles.<EOS>
<BOS>The pictures are made by a computer linked to an xray machine.<EOS>
<BOS>A dye may be injected into a vein or swallowed to help the organs or tissues show up more clearly.<EOS>
<BOS>This procedure is also called computed tomography, computerized tomography, or computerized axial tomography.<EOS>
<BOS>Pictures will be taken of the chest and the area where the tumor formed.<EOS>
<BOS>PETCT scan : A procedure that combines the pictures from a positron emission tomography (PET) scan and a computed tomography (CT) scan.<EOS>
<BOS>The PET and CT scans are done at the same time on the same machine.<EOS>
<BOS>The pictures from both scans are combined to make a more detailed picture than either test would make by itself.<EOS>
<BOS>A PET scan is a procedure to find malignant tumor cells in the body.<EOS>
<BOS>A small amount of radioactive glucose (sugar) is injected into a vein.<EOS>
<BOS>The PET scanner rotates around the body and makes a picture of where glucose is being used in the body.<EOS>
<BOS>Malignant tumor cells show up brighter in the picture because they are more active and take up more glucose than normal cells do.<EOS>
<BOS>MRI (magnetic resonance imaging): A procedure that uses a magnet, radio waves, and a computer to make a series of detailed pictures of areas inside the body.<EOS>
<BOS>This procedure is also called nuclear magnetic resonance imaging (NMRI).<EOS>
<BOS>Bone scan : A procedure to check if there are rapidly dividing cells, such as cancer cells, in the bone.<EOS>
<BOS>A very small amount of radioactive material is injected into a vein and travels through the bloodstream.<EOS>
<BOS>The radioactive material collects in the bones and is detected by a scanner.<EOS>
<BOS>There are three ways that cancer spreads in the body.<EOS>
<BOS>Cancer can spread through tissue, the lymph system, and the blood: Tissue.<EOS>
<BOS>The cancer spreads from where it began by growing into nearby areas.<EOS>
<BOS>Lymph system.<EOS>
<BOS>The cancer spreads from where it began by getting into the lymph system.<EOS>
<BOS>The cancer travels through the lymph vessels to other parts of the body.<EOS>
<BOS>Blood.<EOS>
<BOS>The cancer spreads from where it began by getting into the blood.<EOS>
<BOS>The cancer travels through the blood vessels to other parts of the body.<EOS>
<BOS>Cancer may spread from where it began to other parts of the body.<EOS>
<BOS>When cancer spreads to another part of the body, it is called metastasis.<EOS>
<BOS>Cancer cells break away from where they began (the primary tumor) and travel through the lymph system or blood.<EOS>
<BOS>Lymph system.<EOS>
<BOS>The cancer gets into the lymph system, travels through the lymph vessels, and forms a tumor (metastatic tumor) in another part of the body.<EOS>
<BOS>Blood.<EOS>
<BOS>The cancer gets into the blood, travels through the blood vessels, and forms a tumor (metastatic tumor) in another part of the body.<EOS>
<BOS>The metastatic tumor is the same type of cancer as the primary tumor.<EOS>
<BOS>For example, if osteosarcoma spreads to the lung, the cancer cells in the lung are actually osteosarcoma cells.<EOS>
<BOS>The disease is metastatic osteosarcoma, not lung cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Osteosarcoma and MFH are described as either localized or metastatic.<EOS>
<BOS>Localized osteosarcoma or MFH has not spread out of the bone where the cancer started.<EOS>
<BOS>There may be one or more areas of cancer in the bone that can be removed during surgery.<EOS>
<BOS>Metastatic osteosarcoma or MFH has spread from the bone in which the cancer began to other parts of the body.<EOS>
<BOS>The cancer most often spreads to the lungs.<EOS>
<BOS>It may also spread to other bones.<EOS>
<BOS>New types of treatment are being tested in clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>This summary section describes treatments that are being studied in clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>It may not mention every new treatment being studied.<EOS>
<BOS>Information about clinical trials is available from the NCI website.<EOS>
<BOS>Targeted therapy Targeted therapy is a type of treatment that uses drugs or other substances to identify and attack specific cancer cells without harming normal cells.<EOS>
<BOS>Monoclonal antibody therapy is one type of targeted therapy being studied in the treatment of adult AML.<EOS>
<BOS>Monoclonal antibody therapy is a cancer treatment that uses antibodies made in the laboratory from a single type of immune system cell.<EOS>
<BOS>These antibodies can identify substances on cancer cells or normal substances that may help cancer cells grow.<EOS>
<BOS>The antibodies attach to the substances and kill the cancer cells, block their growth, or keep them from spreading.<EOS>
<BOS>Monoclonal antibodies are given by infusion.<EOS>
<BOS>They may be used alone or to carry drugs, toxins, or radioactive material directly to cancer cells.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients may want to think about taking part in a clinical trial.<EOS>
<BOS>For some patients, taking part in a clinical trial may be the best treatment choice.<EOS>
<BOS>Clinical trials are part of the cancer research process.<EOS>
<BOS>Clinical trials are done to find out if new cancer treatments are safe and effective or better than the standard treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Many of today's standard treatments for cancer are based on earlier clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients who take part in a clinical trial may receive the standard treatment or be among the first to receive a new treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients who take part in clinical trials also help improve the way cancer will be treated in the future.<EOS>
<BOS>Even when clinical trials do not lead to effective new treatments, they often answer important questions and help move research forward.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients can enter clinical trials before, during, or after starting their cancer treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Some clinical trials only include patients who have not yet received treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Other trials test treatments for patients whose cancer has not gotten better.<EOS>
<BOS>There are also clinical trials that test new ways to stop cancer from recurring (coming back) or reduce the side effects of cancer treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Clinical trials are taking place in many parts of the country.<EOS>
<BOS>See the Treatment Options section that follows for links to current treatment clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>These have been retrieved from NCI's listing of clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>New types of treatment are being tested in clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>This summary section describes treatments that are being studied in clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>It may not mention every new treatment being studied.<EOS>
<BOS>Information about clinical trials is available from the NCI website.<EOS>
<BOS>Immunotherapy Immunotherapy is a treatment that uses the patients immune system to fight cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Substances made by the body or made in a laboratory are used to boost, direct, or restore the bodys natural defenses against cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>This type of cancer treatment is also called biotherapy or biological therapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Vaccine therapy uses a substance to stimulate the immune system to destroy a tumor.<EOS>
<BOS>Vaccine therapy is being studied to treat neuroblastoma that has come back after treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Other drug therapy Lenalidomide is a type of angiogenesis inhibitor.<EOS>
<BOS>It prevents the growth of new blood vessels that are needed by a tumor to grow.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients may want to think about taking part in a clinical trial.<EOS>
<BOS>For some patients, taking part in a clinical trial may be the best treatment choice.<EOS>
<BOS>Clinical trials are part of the cancer research process.<EOS>
<BOS>Clinical trials are done to find out if new cancer treatments are safe and effective or better than the standard treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Many of today's standard treatments for cancer are based on earlier clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients who take part in a clinical trial may receive the standard treatment or be among the first to receive a new treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients who take part in clinical trials also help improve the way cancer will be treated in the future.<EOS>
<BOS>Even when clinical trials do not lead to effective new treatments, they often answer important questions and help move research forward.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients can enter clinical trials before, during, or after starting their cancer treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Some clinical trials only include patients who have not yet received treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Other trials test treatments for patients whose cancer has not gotten better.<EOS>
<BOS>There are also clinical trials that test new ways to stop cancer from recurring (coming back) or reduce the side effects of cancer treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Clinical trials are taking place in many parts of the country.<EOS>
<BOS>See the Treatment Options section that follows for links to current treatment clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>These have been retrieved from NCI's listing of clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>Key Points There are different types of treatment for children with brain and spinal cord tumors.<EOS>
<BOS>Children with brain or spinal cord tumors should have their treatment planned by a team of health care providers who are experts in treating childhood brain and spinal cord tumors.<EOS>
<BOS>Childhood brain and spinal cord tumors may cause signs or symptoms that begin before the cancer is diagnosed and continue for months or years.<EOS>
<BOS>Some cancer treatments cause side effects months or years after treatment has ended.<EOS>
<BOS>Three types of standard treatment are used: Surgery Radiation therapy Chemotherapy New types of treatment are being tested in clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>Highdose chemotherapy with stem cell transplant Patients may want to think about taking part in a clinical trial.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients can enter clinical trials before, during, or after starting their cancer treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Followup tests may be needed.<EOS>
<BOS>There are different types of treatment for children with brain and spinal cord tumors.<EOS>
<BOS>Different types of treatment are available for children with brain and spinal cord tumors.<EOS>
<BOS>Some treatments are standard (the currently used treatment), and some are being tested in clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>A treatment clinical trial is a research study meant to help improve current treatments or obtain information on new treatments for patients with cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>When clinical trials show that a new treatment is better than the standard treatment, the new treatment may become the standard treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Because cancer in children is rare, taking part in a clinical trial should be considered.<EOS>
<BOS>Clinical trials are taking place in many parts of the country.<EOS>
<BOS>Some clinical trials are open only to patients who have not started treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Children with brain or spinal cord tumors should have their treatment planned by a team of health care providers who are experts in treating childhood brain and spinal cord tumors.<EOS>
<BOS>Treatment will be overseen by a pediatric oncologist, a doctor who specializes in treating children with cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>The pediatric oncologist works with other health care providers who are experts in treating children with brain tumors and who specialize in certain areas of medicine.<EOS>
<BOS>These may include the following specialists: Pediatrician.<EOS>
<BOS>Neurosurgeon.<EOS>
<BOS>Neurologist.<EOS>
<BOS>Neurooncologist.<EOS>
<BOS>Neuropathologist.<EOS>
<BOS>Neuroradiologist.<EOS>
<BOS>Radiation oncologist.<EOS>
<BOS>Endocrinologist.<EOS>
<BOS>Psychologist.<EOS>
<BOS>Ophthalmologist.<EOS>
<BOS>Rehabilitation specialist.<EOS>
<BOS>Social worker.<EOS>
<BOS>Nurse specialist.<EOS>
<BOS>Childhood brain and spinal cord tumors may cause signs or symptoms that begin before the cancer is diagnosed and continue for months or years.<EOS>
<BOS>Childhood brain and spinal cord tumors may cause signs or symptoms that continue for months or years.<EOS>
<BOS>Signs or symptoms caused by the tumor may begin before diagnosis.<EOS>
<BOS>Signs or symptoms caused by treatment may begin during or right after treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Some cancer treatments cause side effects months or years after treatment has ended.<EOS>
<BOS>These are called late effects.<EOS>
<BOS>Late effects of cancer treatment may include the following: Physical problems.<EOS>
<BOS>Changes in mood, feelings, thinking, learning, or memory.<EOS>
<BOS>Second cancers (new types of cancer).<EOS>
<BOS>Some late effects may be treated or controlled.<EOS>
<BOS>It is important to talk with your child's doctors about the effects cancer treatment can have on your child.<EOS>
<BOS>(See the PDQ summary on Late Effects of Treatment for Childhood Cancer for more information).<EOS>
<BOS>Three types of standard treatment are used: Surgery Surgery may be used to diagnose and treat childhood brain and spinal cord tumors.<EOS>
<BOS>See the General Information section of this summary.<EOS>
<BOS>Radiation therapy Radiation therapy is a cancer treatment that uses highenergy xrays or other types of radiation to kill cancer cells or keep them from growing.<EOS>
<BOS>There are two types of radiation therapy: External radiation therapy uses a machine outside the body to send radiation toward the cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Internal radiation therapy uses a radioactive substance sealed in needles, seeds, wires, or catheters that are placed directly into or near the cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>The way the radiation therapy is given depends on the type of cancer being treated.<EOS>
<BOS>External radiation therapy is used to treat childhood brain and spinal cord tumors.<EOS>
<BOS>Chemotherapy Chemotherapy is a cancer treatment that uses drugs to stop the growth of cancer cells, either by killing the cells or by stopping them from dividing.<EOS>
<BOS>When chemotherapy is taken by mouth or injected into a vein or muscle, the drugs enter the bloodstream and can reach cancer cells throughout the body (systemic chemotherapy).<EOS>
<BOS>When chemotherapy is placed directly in the cerebrospinal fluid, an organ, or a body cavity such as the abdomen, the drugs mainly affect cancer cells in those areas (regional chemotherapy).<EOS>
<BOS>The way the chemotherapy is given depends on the type and stage of the cancer being treated.<EOS>
<BOS>Anticancer drugs given by mouth or vein to treat brain and spinal cord tumors cannot cross the bloodbrain barrier and enter the fluid that surrounds the brain and spinal cord.<EOS>
<BOS>Instead, an anticancer drug is injected into the fluidfilled space to kill cancer cells there.<EOS>
<BOS>This is called intrathecal chemotherapy.<EOS>
<BOS>New types of treatment are being tested in clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>This summary section describes treatments that are being studied in clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>It may not mention every new treatment being studied.<EOS>
<BOS>Information about clinical trials is available from the NCI website.<EOS>
<BOS>Highdose chemotherapy with stem cell transplant Highdose chemotherapy with stem cell transplant is a way of giving high doses of chemotherapy and replacing blood forming cells destroyed by the cancer treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Stem cells (immature blood cells) are removed from the blood or bone marrow of the patient or a donor and are frozen and stored.<EOS>
<BOS>After the chemotherapy is completed, the stored stem cells are thawed and given back to the patient through an infusion.<EOS>
<BOS>These reinfused stem cells grow into (and restore) the bodys blood cells.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients may want to think about taking part in a clinical trial.<EOS>
<BOS>For some patients, taking part in a clinical trial may be the best treatment choice.<EOS>
<BOS>Clinical trials are part of the cancer research process.<EOS>
<BOS>Clinical trials are done to find out if new cancer treatments are safe and effective or better than the standard treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Many of today's standard treatments for cancer are based on earlier clinical trials.<EOS>
