<BOS>Patients who take part in a clinical trial may receive the standard treatment or be among the first to receive a new treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients who take part in clinical trials also help improve the way cancer will be treated in the future.<EOS>
<BOS>Even when clinical trials do not lead to effective new treatments, they often answer important questions and help move research forward.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients can enter clinical trials before, during, or after starting their cancer treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Some clinical trials only include patients who have not yet received treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Other trials test treatments for patients whose cancer has not gotten better.<EOS>
<BOS>There are also clinical trials that test new ways to stop cancer from recurring (coming back) or reduce the side effects of cancer treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Clinical trials are taking place in many parts of the country.<EOS>
<BOS>Information about clinical trials is available from the NCI website.<EOS>
<BOS>Followup tests may be needed.<EOS>
<BOS>Some of the tests that were done to diagnose the cancer or to find out the stage of the cancer may be repeated.<EOS>
<BOS>Some tests will be repeated in order to see how well the treatment is working.<EOS>
<BOS>Decisions about whether to continue, change, or stop treatment may be based on the results of these tests.<EOS>
<BOS>Some of the tests will continue to be done from time to time after treatment has ended.<EOS>
<BOS>The results of these tests can show if your child's condition has changed or if the cancer has recurred (come back).<EOS>
<BOS>These tests are sometimes called followup tests or checkups.<EOS>
<BOS>Cancer prevention clinical trials are used to study ways to prevent cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Cancer prevention clinical trials are used to study ways to lower the risk of developing certain types of cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Some cancer prevention trials are conducted with healthy people who have not had cancer but who have an increased risk for cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Other prevention trials are conducted with people who have had cancer and are trying to prevent another cancer of the same type or to lower their chance of developing a new type of cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Other trials are done with healthy volunteers who are not known to have any risk factors for cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>The purpose of some cancer prevention clinical trials is to find out whether actions people take can prevent cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>These may include eating fruits and vegetables, exercising, quitting smoking, or taking certain medicines, vitamins, minerals, or food supplements.<EOS>
<BOS>New ways to prevent prostate cancer are being studied in clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>Clinical trials are taking place in many parts of the country.<EOS>
<BOS>Information about clinical trials can be found in the Clinical Trials section of the NCI website.<EOS>
<BOS>Check NCI's list of cancer clinical trials for prostate cancer prevention trials that are accepting patients.<EOS>
<BOS>Key Points Mycosis fungoides and the Szary syndrome are diseases in which lymphocytes (a type of white blood cell) become malignant (cancerous) and affect the skin.<EOS>
<BOS>Mycosis fungoides and the Szary syndrome are types of cutaneous Tcell lymphoma.<EOS>
<BOS>A sign of mycosis fungoides is a red rash on the skin.<EOS>
<BOS>In the Szary syndrome, cancerous Tcells are found in the blood.<EOS>
<BOS>Tests that examine the skin and blood are used to detect (find) and diagnose mycosis fungoides and the Szary syndrome.<EOS>
<BOS>Certain factors affect prognosis (chance of recovery) and treatment options.<EOS>
<BOS>Mycosis fungoides and the Szary syndrome are diseases in which lymphocytes (a type of white blood cell) become malignant (cancerous) and affect the skin.<EOS>
<BOS>Normally, the bone marrow makes blood stem cells (immature cells) that become mature blood stem cells over time.<EOS>
<BOS>A blood stem cell may become a myeloid stem cell or a lymphoid stem cell.<EOS>
<BOS>A myeloid stem cell becomes a red blood cell, white blood cell, or platelet.<EOS>
<BOS>A lymphoid stem cell becomes a lymphoblast and then one of three types of lymphocytes (white blood cells): Bcell lymphocytes that make antibodies to help fight infection.<EOS>
<BOS>Tcell lymphocytes that help Blymphocytes make the antibodies that help fight infection.<EOS>
<BOS>Natural killer cells that attack cancer cells and viruses.<EOS>
<BOS>In mycosis fungoides, Tcell lymphocytes become cancerous and affect the skin.<EOS>
<BOS>In the Szary syndrome, cancerous Tcell lymphocytes affect the skin and are in the blood.<EOS>
<BOS>Mycosis fungoides and the Szary syndrome are types of cutaneous Tcell lymphoma.<EOS>
<BOS>Mycosis fungoides and the Szary syndrome are the two most common types of cutaneous Tcell lymphoma (a type of nonHodgkin lymphoma).<EOS>
<BOS>For information about other types of skin cancer or nonHodgkin lymphoma, see the following PDQ summaries: Adult NonHodgkin Lymphoma Treatment Skin Cancer Treatment Melanoma Treatment Kaposi Sarcoma Treatment In the Szary syndrome, cancerous Tcells are found in the blood.<EOS>
<BOS>Also, skin all over the body is reddened, itchy, peeling, and painful.<EOS>
<BOS>There may also be patches, plaques, or tumors on the skin.<EOS>
<BOS>It is not known if the Szary syndrome is an advanced form of mycosis fungoides or a separate disease.<EOS>
<BOS>New types of treatment are being tested in clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>This summary section describes treatments that are being studied in clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>It may not mention every new treatment being studied.<EOS>
<BOS>Information about clinical trials is available from the NCI website.<EOS>
<BOS>Targeted therapy Targeted therapy is a type of treatment that uses drugs or other substances to identify and attack specific cancer cells without harming normal cells.<EOS>
<BOS>Monoclonal antibody therapy and tyrosine kinase inhibitors (TKIs) are types of targeted therapy being studied in the treatment of Kaposi sarcoma.<EOS>
<BOS>Monoclonal antibody therapy is a cancer treatment that uses antibodies made in the laboratory from a single type of immune system cell.<EOS>
<BOS>These antibodies can identify substances on cancer cells or normal substances that may help cancer cells grow.<EOS>
<BOS>The antibodies attach to the substances and kill the cancer cells, block their growth, or keep them from spreading.<EOS>
<BOS>Monoclonal antibodies are given by infusion.<EOS>
<BOS>These may be used alone or to carry drugs, toxins, or radioactive material directly to cancer cells.<EOS>
<BOS>Bevacizumab is a monoclonal antibody that is being studied in the treatment of Kaposi sarcoma.<EOS>
<BOS>TKIs are targeted therapy drugs that block signals needed for tumors to grow.<EOS>
<BOS>Imatinib mesylate is a TKI being studied in the treatment of Kaposi sarcoma.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients may want to think about taking part in a clinical trial.<EOS>
<BOS>For some patients, taking part in a clinical trial may be the best treatment choice.<EOS>
<BOS>Clinical trials are part of the cancer research process.<EOS>
<BOS>Clinical trials are done to find out if new cancer treatments are safe and effective or better than the standard treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Many of today's standard treatments for cancer are based on earlier clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients who take part in a clinical trial may receive the standard treatment or be among the first to receive a new treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients who take part in clinical trials also help improve the way cancer will be treated in the future.<EOS>
<BOS>Even when clinical trials do not lead to effective new treatments, they often answer important questions and help move research forward.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients can enter clinical trials before, during, or after starting their cancer treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Some clinical trials only include patients who have not yet received treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Other trials test treatments for patients whose cancer has not gotten better.<EOS>
<BOS>There are also clinical trials that test new ways to stop cancer from recurring (coming back) or reduce the side effects of cancer treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Clinical trials are taking place in many parts of the country.<EOS>
<BOS>See the Treatment Options section that follows for links to current treatment clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>These have been retrieved from NCI's listing of clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>New types of treatment are being tested in clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>This summary section describes treatments that are being studied in clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>It may not mention every new treatment being studied.<EOS>
<BOS>Information about clinical trials is available from the NCI website.<EOS>
<BOS>Chemoprevention Chemoprevention is the use of drugs, vitamins, or other substances to reduce the risk of cancer or to reduce the risk cancer will recur (come back).<EOS>
<BOS>For lung cancer, chemoprevention is used to lessen the chance that a new tumor will form in the lung.<EOS>
<BOS>Radiosensitizers Radiosensitizers are substances that make tumor cells easier to kill with radiation therapy.<EOS>
<BOS>The combination of chemotherapy and radiation therapy given with a radiosensitizer is being studied in the treatment of nonsmall cell lung cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>New combinations New combinations of treatments are being studied in clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients may want to think about taking part in a clinical trial.<EOS>
<BOS>For some patients, taking part in a clinical trial may be the best treatment choice.<EOS>
<BOS>Clinical trials are part of the cancer research process.<EOS>
<BOS>Clinical trials are done to find out if new cancer treatments are safe and effective or better than the standard treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Many of today's standard treatments for cancer are based on earlier clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients who take part in a clinical trial may receive the standard treatment or be among the first to receive a new treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients who take part in clinical trials also help improve the way cancer will be treated in the future.<EOS>
<BOS>Even when clinical trials do not lead to effective new treatments, they often answer important questions and help move research forward.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients can enter clinical trials before, during, or after starting their cancer treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Some clinical trials only include patients who have not yet received treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Other trials test treatments for patients whose cancer has not gotten better.<EOS>
<BOS>There are also clinical trials that test new ways to stop cancer from recurring (coming back) or reduce the side effects of cancer treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Clinical trials are taking place in many parts of the country.<EOS>
<BOS>See the Treatment Options section that follows for links to current treatment clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>These have been retrieved from NCI's listing of clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>Key Points Avoiding risk factors and increasing protective factors may help prevent lung cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>The following are risk factors for lung cancer: Cigarette, cigar, and pipe smoking Secondhand smoke Family history HIV infection Environmental risk factors Beta carotene supplements in heavy smokers The following are protective factors for lung cancer: Not smoking Quitting smoking Lower exposure to workplace risk factors Lower exposure to radon It is not clear if the following decrease the risk of lung cancer: Diet Physical activity The following do not decrease the risk of lung cancer: Beta carotene supplements in nonsmokers Vitamin E supplements Cancer prevention clinical trials are used to study ways to prevent cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>New ways to prevent lung cancer are being studied in clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>Avoiding risk factors and increasing protective factors may help prevent lung cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Avoiding cancer risk factors may help prevent certain cancers.<EOS>
<BOS>Risk factors include smoking, being overweight, and not getting enough exercise.<EOS>
<BOS>Increasing protective factors such as quitting smoking and exercising may also help prevent some cancers.<EOS>
<BOS>Talk to your doctor or other health care professional about how you might lower your risk of cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>The following are risk factors for lung cancer: Cigarette, cigar, and pipe smoking Tobacco smoking is the most important risk factor for lung cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Cigarette, cigar, and pipe smoking all increase the risk of lung cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Tobacco smoking causes about 9 out of 10 cases of lung cancer in men and about 8 out of 10 cases of lung cancer in women.<EOS>
<BOS>Studies have shown that smoking low tar or low nicotine cigarettes does not lower the risk of lung cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Studies also show that the risk of lung cancer from smoking cigarettes increases with the number of cigarettes smoked per day and the number of years smoked.<EOS>
<BOS>People who smoke have about 20 times the risk of lung cancer compared to those who do not smoke.<EOS>
<BOS>Secondhand smoke Being exposed to secondhand tobacco smoke is also a risk factor for lung cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Secondhand smoke is the smoke that comes from a burning cigarette or other tobacco product, or that is exhaled by smokers.<EOS>
<BOS>People who inhale secondhand smoke are exposed to the same cancer causing agents as smokers, although in smaller amounts.<EOS>
<BOS>Inhaling secondhand smoke is called involuntary or passive smoking.<EOS>
<BOS>Family history Having a family history of lung cancer is a risk factor for lung cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>People with a relative who has had lung cancer may be twice as likely to have lung cancer as people who do not have a relative who has had lung cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Because cigarette smoking tends to run in families and family members are exposed to secondhand smoke, it is hard to know whether the increased risk of lung cancer is from the family history of lung cancer or from being exposed to cigarette smoke.<EOS>
<BOS>HIV infection Being infected with the human immunodeficiency virus (HIV), the cause of acquired immunodeficiency syndrome (AIDS), is linked with a higher risk of lung cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>People infected with HIV may have more than twice the risk of lung cancer than those who are not infected.<EOS>
<BOS>Since smoking rates are higher in those infected with HIV than in those not infected, it is not clear whether the increased risk of lung cancer is from HIV infection or from being exposed to cigarette smoke.<EOS>
<BOS>Environmental risk factors Radiation exposure: Being exposed to radiation is a risk factor for lung cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Atomic bomb radiation, radiation therapy, imaging tests, and radon are sources of radiation exposure: Atomic bomb radiation: Being exposed to radiation after an atomic bomb explosion increases the risk of lung cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Radiation therapy: Radiation therapy to the chest may be used to treat certain cancers, including breast cancer and Hodgkin lymphoma.<EOS>
<BOS>Radiation therapy uses xrays, gamma rays, or other types of radiation that may increase the risk of lung cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>The higher the dose of radiation received, the higher the risk.<EOS>
<BOS>The risk of lung cancer following radiation therapy is higher in patients who smoke than in nonsmokers.<EOS>
<BOS>Imaging tests: Imaging tests, such as CT scans, expose patients to radiation.<EOS>
<BOS>Lowdose spiral CT scans expose patients to less radiation than higher dose CT scans.<EOS>
<BOS>In lung cancer screening, the use of lowdose spiral CT scans can lessen the harmful effects of radiation.<EOS>
<BOS>Radon: Radon is a radioactive gas that comes from the breakdown of uranium in rocks and soil.<EOS>
<BOS>It seeps up through the ground, and leaks into the air or water supply.<EOS>
<BOS>Radon can enter homes through cracks in floors, walls, or the foundation, and levels of radon can build up over time.<EOS>
<BOS>Studies show that high levels of radon gas inside the home or workplace increase the number of new cases of lung cancer and the number of deaths caused by lung cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>The risk of lung cancer is higher in smokers exposed to radon than in nonsmokers who are exposed to it.<EOS>
<BOS>In people who have never smoked, about 30% of deaths caused by lung cancer have been linked to being exposed to radon.<EOS>
<BOS>Workplace exposure: Studies show that being exposed to the following substances increases the risk of lung cancer: Asbestos.<EOS>
<BOS>Arsenic.<EOS>
<BOS>Chromium.<EOS>
<BOS>Nickel.<EOS>
<BOS>Beryllium.<EOS>
<BOS>Cadmium.<EOS>
<BOS>Tar and soot.<EOS>
<BOS>These substances can cause lung cancer in people who are exposed to them in the workplace and have never smoked.<EOS>
<BOS>As the level of exposure to these substances increases, the risk of lung cancer also increases.<EOS>
<BOS>The risk of lung cancer is even higher in people who are exposed and also smoke.<EOS>
<BOS>Air pollution: Studies show that living in areas with higher levels of air pollution increases the risk of lung cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Beta carotene supplements in heavy smokers Taking beta carotene supplements (pills) increases the risk of lung cancer, especially in smokers who smoke one or more packs a day.<EOS>
<BOS>The risk is higher in smokers who have at least one alcoholic drink every day.<EOS>
<BOS>The following are protective factors for lung cancer: Not smoking The best way to prevent lung cancer is to not smoke.<EOS>
<BOS>Quitting smoking Smokers can decrease their risk of lung cancer by quitting.<EOS>
<BOS>In smokers who have been treated for lung cancer, quitting smoking lowers the risk of new lung cancers.<EOS>
<BOS>Counseling, the use of nicotine replacement products, and antidepressant therapy have helped smokers quit for good.<EOS>
<BOS>In a person who has quit smoking, the chance of preventing lung cancer depends on how many years and how much the person smoked and the length of time since quitting.<EOS>
<BOS>After a person has quit smoking for 10 years, the risk of lung cancer decreases 30% to 50%.<EOS>
<BOS>See the following for more information on quitting smoking: Tobacco (includes help with quitting) Cigarette Smoking: Health Risks and How to Quit Lower exposure to workplace risk factors Laws that protect workers from being exposed to cancercausing substances, such as asbestos, arsenic, nickel, and chromium, may help lower their risk of developing lung cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Laws that prevent smoking in the workplace help lower the risk of lung cancer caused by secondhand smoke.<EOS>
<BOS>Lower exposure to radon Lowering radon levels may lower the risk of lung cancer, especially among cigarette smokers.<EOS>
<BOS>High levels of radon in homes may be reduced by taking steps to prevent radon leakage, such as sealing basements.<EOS>
<BOS>It is not clear if the following decrease the risk of lung cancer: Diet Some studies show that people who eat high amounts of fruits or vegetables have a lower risk of lung cancer than those who eat low amounts.<EOS>
<BOS>However, since smokers tend to have less healthy diets than nonsmokers, it is hard to know whether the decreased risk is from having a healthy diet or from not smoking.<EOS>
<BOS>Physical activity Some studies show that people who are physically active have a lower risk of lung cancer than people who are not.<EOS>
<BOS>However, since smokers tend to have different levels of physical activity than nonsmokers, it is hard to know if physical activity affects the risk of lung cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>The following do not decrease the risk of lung cancer: Beta carotene supplements in nonsmokers Studies of nonsmokers show that taking beta carotene supplements does not lower their risk of lung cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Vitamin E supplements Studies show that taking vitamin E supplements does not affect the risk of lung cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Cancer prevention clinical trials are used to study ways to prevent cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Cancer prevention clinical trials are used to study ways to lower the risk of developing certain types of cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Some cancer prevention trials are conducted with healthy people who have not had cancer but who have an increased risk for cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Other prevention trials are conducted with people who have had cancer and are trying to prevent another cancer of the same type or to lower their chance of developing a new type of cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Other trials are done with healthy volunteers who are not known to have any risk factors for cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>The purpose of some cancer prevention clinical trials is to find out whether actions people take can prevent cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>These may include eating fruits and vegetables, exercising, quitting smoking, or taking certain medicines, vitamins, minerals, or food supplements.<EOS>
<BOS>New ways to prevent lung cancer are being studied in clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>Clinical trials are taking place in many parts of the country.<EOS>
<BOS>Information about clinical trials can be found in the Clinical Trials section of the NCI website.<EOS>
<BOS>Check the list of NCIsupported cancer clinical trials for prevention trials for nonsmall cell lung cancer and small cell lung cancer that are now accepting patients.<EOS>
<BOS>These include trials for quitting smoking.<EOS>
<BOS>New types of treatment are being tested in clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>Information about clinical trials is available from the NCI website Treatment for melanoma may cause side effects.<EOS>
<BOS>For information about side effects caused by treatment for cancer, see our Side Effects page.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients may want to think about taking part in a clinical trial.<EOS>
<BOS>For some patients, taking part in a clinical trial may be the best treatment choice.<EOS>
<BOS>Clinical trials are part of the cancer research process.<EOS>
<BOS>Clinical trials are done to find out if new cancer treatments are safe and effective or better than the standard treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Many of today's standard treatments for cancer are based on earlier clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients who take part in a clinical trial may receive the standard treatment or be among the first to receive a new treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients who take part in clinical trials also help improve the way cancer will be treated in the future.<EOS>
<BOS>Even when clinical trials do not lead to effective new treatments, they often answer important questions and help move research forward.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients can enter clinical trials before, during, or after starting their cancer treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Some clinical trials only include patients who have not yet received treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Other trials test treatments for patients whose cancer has not gotten better.<EOS>
<BOS>There are also clinical trials that test new ways to stop cancer from recurring (coming back) or reduce the side effects of cancer treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Clinical trials are taking place in many parts of the country.<EOS>
<BOS>See the Treatment Options section that follows for links to current treatment clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>These have been retrieved from NCI's listing of clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>Followup tests may be needed.<EOS>
<BOS>Some of the tests that were done to diagnose the cancer or to find out the stage of the cancer may be repeated.<EOS>
<BOS>Some tests will be repeated in order to see how well the treatment is working.<EOS>
<BOS>Decisions about whether to continue, change, or stop treatment may be based on the results of these tests.<EOS>
<BOS>Some of the tests will continue to be done from time to time after treatment has ended.<EOS>
<BOS>The results of these tests can show if your condition has changed or if the cancer has recurred (come back).<EOS>
<BOS>These tests are sometimes called followup tests or checkups.<EOS>
<BOS>New types of treatment are being tested in clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>This summary section refers to new treatments being studied in clinical trials, but it may not mention every new treatment being studied.<EOS>
<BOS>Information about clinical trials is available from the NCI website.<EOS>
<BOS>Proton beam radiation therapy Proton beam radiation therapy is a type of highenergy, external radiation therapy that uses streams of protons (small, positivelycharged pieces of matter) to make radiation.<EOS>
<BOS>This type of radiation kills tumor cells with little damage to nearby tissues.<EOS>
<BOS>It is used to treat cancers of the head, neck, and spine and organs such as the brain, eye, lung, and prostate.<EOS>
<BOS>Proton beam radiation is different from xray radiation.<EOS>
<BOS>Biologic therapy Biologic therapy is a treatment that uses the patients immune system to fight cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Substances made by the body or made in a laboratory are used to boost, direct, or restore the bodys natural defenses against cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>This type of cancer treatment is also called biotherapy or immunotherapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Biologic therapy is being studied for the treatment of some types of brain tumors.<EOS>
<BOS>Treatments may include the following: Dendritic cell vaccine therapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Gene therapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients may want to think about taking part in a clinical trial.<EOS>
<BOS>For some patients, taking part in a clinical trial may be the best treatment choice.<EOS>
<BOS>Clinical trials are part of the cancer research process.<EOS>
<BOS>Clinical trials are done to find out if new cancer treatments are safe and effective or better than the standard treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Many of today's standard treatments for cancer are based on earlier clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients who take part in a clinical trial may receive the standard treatment or be among the first to receive a new treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients who take part in clinical trials also help improve the way cancer will be treated in the future.<EOS>
<BOS>Even when clinical trials do not lead to effective new treatments, they often answer important questions and help move research forward.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients can enter clinical trials before, during, or after starting their cancer treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Some clinical trials only include patients who have not yet received treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Other trials test treatments for patients whose cancer has not gotten better.<EOS>
<BOS>There are also clinical trials that test new ways to stop cancer from recurring (coming back) or reduce the side effects of cancer treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Clinical trials are taking place in many parts of the country.<EOS>
<BOS>See the Treatment Options section that follows for links to current treatment clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>These have been retrieved from NCI's listing of clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>Being exposed to xrays can increase the risk of uterine sarcoma.<EOS>
<BOS>Anything that increases your risk of getting a disease is called a risk factor.<EOS>
<BOS>Having a risk factor does not mean that you will get cancer; not having risk factors doesnt mean that you will not get cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Talk with your doctor if you think you may be at risk.<EOS>
<BOS>Risk factors for uterine sarcoma include the following: Past treatment with radiation therapy to the pelvis.<EOS>
<BOS>Treatment with tamoxifen for breast cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>If you are taking this drug, have a pelvic exam every year and report any vaginal bleeding (other than menstrual bleeding) as soon as possible.<EOS>
<BOS>New types of treatment are being tested in clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>Information about clinical trials is available from the NCI website.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients may want to think about taking part in a clinical trial.<EOS>
<BOS>For some patients, taking part in a clinical trial may be the best treatment choice.<EOS>
<BOS>Clinical trials are part of the cancer research process.<EOS>
<BOS>Clinical trials are done to find out if new cancer treatments are safe and effective or better than the standard treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Many of today's standard treatments for cancer are based on earlier clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients who take part in a clinical trial may receive the standard treatment or be among the first to receive a new treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients who take part in clinical trials also help improve the way cancer will be treated in the future.<EOS>
<BOS>Even when clinical trials do not lead to effective new treatments, they often answer important questions and help move research forward.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients can enter clinical trials before, during, or after starting their cancer treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Some clinical trials only include patients who have not yet received treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Other trials test treatments for patients whose cancer has not gotten better.<EOS>
<BOS>There are also clinical trials that test new ways to stop cancer from recurring (coming back) or reduce the side effects of cancer treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Clinical trials are taking place in many parts of the country.<EOS>
<BOS>See the Treatment Options section that follows for links to current treatment clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>These have been retrieved from NCI's listing of clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>Previous chemotherapy and exposure to radiation may increase the risk of developing ALL.<EOS>
<BOS>Anything that increases your risk of getting a disease is called a risk factor.<EOS>
<BOS>Having a risk factor does not mean that you will get cancer; not having risk factors doesnt mean that you will not get cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Talk with your doctor if you think you may be at risk.<EOS>
<BOS>Possible risk factors for ALL include the following: Being male.<EOS>
<BOS>Being white.<EOS>
<BOS>Being older than 70.<EOS>
<BOS>Past treatment with chemotherapy or radiation therapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Being exposed to high levels of radiation in the environment (such as nuclear radiation).<EOS>
<BOS>Having certain genetic disorders, such as Down syndrome.<EOS>
<BOS>Key Points After renal cell cancer has been diagnosed, tests are done to find out if cancer cells have spread within the kidney or to other parts of the body.<EOS>
<BOS>There are three ways that cancer spreads in the body.<EOS>
<BOS>Cancer may spread from where it began to other parts of the body.<EOS>
<BOS>The following stages are used for renal cell cancer: Stage I Stage II Stage III Stage IV After renal cell cancer has been diagnosed, tests are done to find out if cancer cells have spread within the kidney or to other parts of the body.<EOS>
<BOS>The process used to find out if cancer has spread within the kidney or to other parts of the body is called staging.<EOS>
<BOS>The information gathered from the staging process determines the stage of the disease.<EOS>
<BOS>It is important to know the stage in order to plan treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>The following tests and procedures may be used in the staging process: CT scan (CAT scan): A procedure that makes a series of detailed pictures of areas inside the body, taken from different angles.<EOS>
<BOS>The pictures are made by a computer linked to an xray machine.<EOS>
<BOS>A dye may be injected into a vein or swallowed to help the organs or tissues show up more clearly.<EOS>
<BOS>This procedure is also called computed tomography, computerized tomography, or computerized axial tomography.<EOS>
<BOS>MRI (magnetic resonance imaging): A procedure that uses a magnet, radio waves, and a computer to make a series of detailed pictures of areas inside the body.<EOS>
<BOS>This procedure is also called nuclear magnetic resonance imaging (NMRI).<EOS>
<BOS>Chest xray : An xray of the organs and bones inside the chest.<EOS>
<BOS>An xray is a type of energy beam that can go through the body and onto film, making a picture of areas inside the body.<EOS>
<BOS>There are three ways that cancer spreads in the body.<EOS>
<BOS>Cancer can spread through tissue, the lymph system, and the blood: Tissue.<EOS>
<BOS>The cancer spreads from where it began by growing into nearby areas.<EOS>
<BOS>Lymph system.<EOS>
<BOS>The cancer spreads from where it began by getting into the lymph system.<EOS>
<BOS>The cancer travels through the lymph vessels to other parts of the body.<EOS>
<BOS>Blood.<EOS>
<BOS>The cancer spreads from where it began by getting into the blood.<EOS>
<BOS>The cancer travels through the blood vessels to other parts of the body.<EOS>
<BOS>Cancer may spread from where it began to other parts of the body.<EOS>
<BOS>When cancer spreads to another part of the body, it is called metastasis.<EOS>
<BOS>Cancer cells break away from where they began (the primary tumor) and travel through the lymph system or blood.<EOS>
<BOS>Lymph system.<EOS>
<BOS>The cancer gets into the lymph system, travels through the lymph vessels, and forms a tumor (metastatic tumor) in another part of the body.<EOS>
<BOS>Blood.<EOS>
<BOS>The cancer gets into the blood, travels through the blood vessels, and forms a tumor (metastatic tumor) in another part of the body.<EOS>
<BOS>The metastatic tumor is the same type of cancer as the primary tumor.<EOS>
<BOS>For example, if renal cell cancer spreads to the bone, the cancer cells in the bone are actually cancerous renal cells.<EOS>
<BOS>The disease is metastatic renal cell cancer, not bone cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>The following stages are used for renal cell cancer: Stage I In stage I, the tumor is 7 centimeters or smaller and is found only in the kidney.<EOS>
<BOS>Stage II In stage II, the tumor is larger than 7 centimeters and is found only in the kidney.<EOS>
<BOS>Stage III In stage III: the tumor is any size and cancer is found only in the kidney and in 1 or more nearby lymph nodes; or cancer is found in the main blood vessels of the kidney or in the layer of fatty tissue around the kidney.<EOS>
<BOS>Cancer may be found in 1 or more nearby lymph nodes.<EOS>
<BOS>Stage IV In stage IV, cancer has spread: beyond the layer of fatty tissue around the kidney and may be found in the adrenal gland above the kidney with cancer, or in nearby lymph nodes; or to other organs, such as the lungs, liver, bones, or brain, and may have spread to lymph nodes.<EOS>
<BOS>New types of treatment are being tested in clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>Information about clinical trials is available from the NCI website.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients may want to think about taking part in a clinical trial.<EOS>
<BOS>For some patients, taking part in a clinical trial may be the best treatment choice.<EOS>
<BOS>Clinical trials are part of the cancer research process.<EOS>
<BOS>Clinical trials are done to find out if new cancer treatments are safe and effective or better than the standard treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Many of today's standard treatments for cancer are based on earlier clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients who take part in a clinical trial may receive the standard treatment or be among the first to receive a new treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients who take part in clinical trials also help improve the way cancer will be treated in the future.<EOS>
<BOS>Even when clinical trials do not lead to effective new treatments, they often answer important questions and help move research forward.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients can enter clinical trials before, during, or after starting their cancer treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Some clinical trials only include patients who have not yet received treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Other trials test treatments for patients whose cancer has not gotten better.<EOS>
<BOS>There are also clinical trials that test new ways to stop cancer from recurring (coming back) or reduce the side effects of cancer treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Clinical trials are taking place in many parts of the country.<EOS>
<BOS>See the Treatment Options section that follows for links to current treatment clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>These have been retrieved from NCI's listing of clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>Certain factors affect prognosis (chance of recovery) and treatment options.<EOS>
<BOS>The prognosis (chance of recovery) and treatment options depend on the following: The age of the patient.<EOS>
<BOS>Whether the cancer has spread to the brain or spinal cord.<EOS>
<BOS>Whether there are certain changes in the genes, including the Philadelphia chromosome.<EOS>
<BOS>Whether the cancer has been treated before or has recurred (come back).<EOS>
<BOS>Key Points Breast cancer is a disease in which malignant (cancer) cells form in the tissues of the breast.<EOS>
<BOS>Breast cancer is the second most common type of cancer in American women.<EOS>
<BOS>Breast cancer is a disease in which malignant (cancer) cells form in the tissues of the breast.<EOS>
<BOS>The breast is made up of lobes and ducts.<EOS>
<BOS>Each breast has 15 to 20 sections called lobes, which have many smaller sections called lobules.<EOS>
<BOS>Lobules end in dozens of tiny bulbs that can make milk.<EOS>
<BOS>The lobes, lobules, and bulbs are linked by thin tubes called ducts.<EOS>
<BOS>Each breast also has blood vessels and lymph vessels.<EOS>
<BOS>The lymph vessels carry an almost colorless fluid called lymph.<EOS>
<BOS>Lymph vessels lead to organs called lymph nodes.<EOS>
<BOS>Lymph nodes are small beanshaped structures that are found throughout the body.<EOS>
<BOS>They filter lymph and store white blood cells that help fight infection and disease.<EOS>
<BOS>Clusters of lymph nodes are found near the breast in the axilla (under the arm), above the collarbone, and in the chest.<EOS>
<BOS>See the following PDQ summaries for more information about breast cancer: Breast Cancer Screening Breast Cancer Treatment Breast Cancer Treatment and Pregnancy Male Breast Cancer Treatment Genetics of Breast and Ovarian Cancer Breast cancer is the second most common type of cancer in American women.<EOS>
<BOS>Women in the United States get breast cancer more than any other type of cancer except skin cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Breast cancer is second to lung cancer as a cause of cancer death in American women.<EOS>
<BOS>However, deaths from breast cancer have decreased a little bit every year between 2003 and 2012.<EOS>
<BOS>Breast cancer also occurs in men, but the number of new cases is small.<EOS>
<BOS>Certain factors affect prognosis (chance of recovery) and treatment options.<EOS>
<BOS>The prognosis (chance of recovery) and treatment options depend on the following: Where the tumor is in the paranasal sinus or nasal cavity and whether it has spread.<EOS>
<BOS>The size of the tumor.<EOS>
<BOS>The type of cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>The patient's age and general health.<EOS>
<BOS>Whether the cancer has just been diagnosed or has recurred (come back).<EOS>
<BOS>Paranasal sinus and nasal cavity cancers often have spread by the time they are diagnosed and are hard to cure.<EOS>
<BOS>After treatment, a lifetime of frequent and careful followup is important because there is an increased risk of developing a second kind of cancer in the head or neck.<EOS>
<BOS>Key Points Essential thrombocythemia is a disease in which too many platelets are made in the bone marrow.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients with essential thrombocythemia may have no signs or symptoms.<EOS>
<BOS>Certain factors affect prognosis (chance of recovery) and treatment options for essential thrombocythemia.<EOS>
<BOS>Essential thrombocythemia is a disease in which too many platelets are made in the bone marrow.<EOS>
<BOS>Essential thrombocythemia causes an abnormal increase in the number of platelets made in the blood and bone marrow.<EOS>
<BOS>Tests that examine the skin, lungs, and gastrointestinal tract are used to detect (find) and diagnose Kaposi sarcoma.<EOS>
<BOS>The following tests and procedures may be used: Physical exam and history : An exam of the body to check general signs of health, including checking skin and lymph nodes for signs of disease, such as lumps or anything else that seems unusual.<EOS>
<BOS>A history of the patient's health habits and past illnesses and treatments will also be taken.<EOS>
<BOS>Chest xray : An xray of the organs and bones inside the chest.<EOS>
<BOS>An xray is a type of energy beam that can go through the body and onto film, making a picture of areas inside the body.<EOS>
<BOS>This is used to find Kaposi sarcoma in the lungs.<EOS>
<BOS>Biopsy : The removal of cells or tissues so they can be viewed under a microscope by a pathologist to check for signs of cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>One of the following types of biopsies may be done to check for Kaposi sarcoma lesions in the skin: Excisional biopsy : A scalpel is used to remove the entire skin growth.<EOS>
<BOS>Incisional biopsy : A scalpel is used to remove part of a skin growth.<EOS>
<BOS>Core biopsy : A wide needle is used to remove part of a skin growth.<EOS>
<BOS>Fineneedle aspiration (FNA) biopsy : A thin needle is used to remove part of a skin growth.<EOS>
<BOS>An endoscopy or bronchoscopy may be done to check for Kaposi sarcoma lesions in the gastrointestinal tract or lungs.<EOS>
<BOS>Endoscopy for biopsy: A procedure to look at organs and tissues inside the body to check for abnormal areas.<EOS>
<BOS>An endoscope is inserted through an incision (cut) in the skin or opening in the body, such as the mouth.<EOS>
<BOS>An endoscope is a thin, tubelike instrument with a light and a lens for viewing.<EOS>
<BOS>It may also have a tool to remove tissue or lymph node samples, which are checked under a microscope for signs of disease.<EOS>
<BOS>This is used to find Kaposi sarcoma lesions in the gastrointestinal tract.<EOS>
<BOS>Bronchoscopy for biopsy: A procedure to look inside the trachea and large airways in the lung for abnormal areas.<EOS>
<BOS>A bronchoscope is inserted through the nose or mouth into the trachea and lungs.<EOS>
<BOS>A bronchoscope is a thin, tubelike instrument with a light and a lens for viewing.<EOS>
<BOS>It may also have a tool to remove tissue samples, which are checked under a microscope for signs of disease.<EOS>
<BOS>This is used to find Kaposi sarcoma lesions in the lungs.<EOS>
<BOS>After Kaposi sarcoma has been diagnosed, tests are done to find out if cancer cells have spread to other parts of the body.<EOS>
<BOS>The following tests and procedures may be used to find out if cancer has spread to other parts of the body: Blood chemistry studies : A procedure in which a blood sample is checked to measure the amounts of certain substances released into the blood by organs and tissues in the body.<EOS>
<BOS>An unusual (higher or lower than normal) amount of a substance can be a sign of disease.<EOS>
<BOS>CT scan (CAT scan): A procedure that makes a series of detailed pictures of areas inside the body, such as the lung, liver, and spleen, taken from different angles.<EOS>
<BOS>The pictures are made by a computer linked to an xray machine.<EOS>
<BOS>A dye may be injected into a vein or swallowed to help the organs or tissues show up more clearly.<EOS>
<BOS>This procedure is also called computed tomography, computerized tomography, or computerized axial tomography.<EOS>
<BOS>PET scan (positron emission tomography scan): A procedure to find malignant tumor cells in the body.<EOS>
<BOS>A small amount of radioactive glucose (sugar) is injected into a vein.<EOS>
<BOS>The PET scanner rotates around the body and makes a picture of where glucose is being used in the body.<EOS>
<BOS>Malignant tumor cells show up brighter in the picture because they are more active and take up more glucose than normal cells do.<EOS>
<BOS>This imaging test checks for signs of cancer in the lung, liver, and spleen.<EOS>
<BOS>CD34 lymphocyte count: A procedure in which a blood sample is checked to measure the amount of CD34 cells (a type of white blood cell).<EOS>
<BOS>A lower than normal amount of CD34 cells can be a sign the immune system is not working well.<EOS>
<BOS>New types of treatment are being tested in clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>This summary section describes treatments that are being studied in clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>It may not mention every new treatment being studied.<EOS>
<BOS>Information about clinical trials is available from the NCI website.<EOS>
<BOS>Chimeric antigen receptor (CAR) Tcell therapy CAR Tcell therapy is a type of immunotherapy that changes the patient's T cells (a type of immune system cell) so they will attack certain proteins on the surface of cancer cells.<EOS>
<BOS>T cells are taken from the patient and special receptors are added to their surface in the laboratory.<EOS>
<BOS>The changed cells are called chimeric antigen receptor (CAR) T cells.<EOS>
<BOS>The CAR T cells are grown in the laboratory and given to the patient by infusion.<EOS>
<BOS>The CAR T cells multiply in the patient's blood and attack cancer cells.<EOS>
<BOS>CAR Tcell therapy is being studied in the treatment of Ewing sarcoma that has recurred.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients may want to think about taking part in a clinical trial.<EOS>
<BOS>For some patients, taking part in a clinical trial may be the best treatment choice.<EOS>
<BOS>Clinical trials are part of the cancer research process.<EOS>
<BOS>Clinical trials are done to find out if new cancer treatments are safe and effective or better than the standard treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Many of today's standard treatments for cancer are based on earlier clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients who take part in a clinical trial may receive the standard treatment or be among the first to receive a new treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients who take part in clinical trials also help improve the way cancer will be treated in the future.<EOS>
<BOS>Even when clinical trials do not lead to effective new treatments, they often answer important questions and help move research forward.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients can enter clinical trials before, during, or after starting their cancer treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Some clinical trials only include patients who have not yet received treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Other trials test treatments for patients whose cancer has not gotten better.<EOS>
<BOS>There are also clinical trials that test new ways to stop cancer from recurring (coming back) or reduce the side effects of cancer treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Clinical trials are taking place in many parts of the country.<EOS>
<BOS>See the Treatment Options section that follows for links to current treatment clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>These have been retrieved from NCI's listing of clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>Different factors increase or decrease the risk of breast cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Anything that increases your chance of getting a disease is called a risk factor.<EOS>
<BOS>Anything that decreases your chance of getting a disease is called a protective factor.<EOS>
<BOS>For information about risk factors and protective factors for breast cancer, see the PDQ summary on Breast Cancer Prevention.<EOS>
<BOS>Having certain syndromes can increase the risk of pancreatic NETs.<EOS>
<BOS>Anything that increases your risk of getting a disease is called a risk factor.<EOS>
<BOS>Having a risk factor does not mean that you will get cancer; not having risk factors doesn't mean that you will not get cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Talk with your doctor if you think you may be at risk.<EOS>
<BOS>Multiple endocrine neoplasia type 1 (MEN1) syndrome is a risk factor for pancreatic NETs.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients with essential thrombocythemia may have no signs or symptoms.<EOS>
<BOS>Essential thrombocythemia often does not cause early signs or symptoms.<EOS>
<BOS>It may be found during a routine blood test.<EOS>
<BOS>Signs and symptoms may be caused by essential thrombocytopenia or by other conditions.<EOS>
<BOS>Check with your doctor if you have any of the following: Headache.<EOS>
<BOS>Burning or tingling in the hands or feet.<EOS>
<BOS>Redness and warmth of the hands or feet.<EOS>
<BOS>Vision or hearing problems.<EOS>
<BOS>Platelets are sticky.<EOS>
<BOS>When there are too many platelets, they may clump together and make it hard for the blood to flow.<EOS>
<BOS>Clots may form in blood vessels and there may also be increased bleeding.<EOS>
<BOS>These can cause serious health problems such as stroke or heart attack.<EOS>
<BOS>Genetic factors can increase the risk of having a gastrointestinal stromal tumor.<EOS>
<BOS>Anything that increases your risk of getting a disease is called a risk factor.<EOS>
<BOS>Having a risk factor does not mean that you will get cancer; not having risk factors doesn't mean that you will not get cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Talk with your doctor if you think you may be at risk.<EOS>
<BOS>The genes in cells carry the hereditary information received from a persons parents.<EOS>
<BOS>The risk of GIST is increased in people who have inherited a mutation (change) in a certain gene.<EOS>
<BOS>In rare cases, GISTs can be found in several members of the same family.<EOS>
<BOS>GIST may be part of a genetic syndrome, but this is rare.<EOS>
<BOS>A genetic syndrome is a set of symptoms or conditions that occur together and is usually caused by abnormal genes.<EOS>
<BOS>The following genetic syndromes have been linked to GIST: Neurofibromatosis type 1 (NF1).<EOS>
<BOS>Carney triad.<EOS>
<BOS>Key Points Breast cancer is a disease in which malignant (cancer) cells form in the tissues of the breast.<EOS>
<BOS>Breast cancer is the second leading cause of death from cancer in American women.<EOS>
<BOS>Different factors increase or decrease the risk of breast cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Breast cancer is a disease in which malignant (cancer) cells form in the tissues of the breast.<EOS>
<BOS>The breast is made up of lobes and ducts.<EOS>
<BOS>Each breast has 15 to 20 sections called lobes, which have many smaller sections called lobules.<EOS>
<BOS>Lobules end in dozens of tiny bulbs that can produce milk.<EOS>
<BOS>The lobes, lobules, and bulbs are linked by thin tubes called ducts.<EOS>
<BOS>Each breast also contains blood vessels and lymph vessels.<EOS>
<BOS>The lymph vessels carry an almost colorless fluid called lymph.<EOS>
<BOS>Lymph vessels lead to organs called lymph nodes.<EOS>
<BOS>Lymph nodes are small beanshaped structures that are found throughout the body.<EOS>
<BOS>They filter substances in lymph and help fight infection and disease.<EOS>
<BOS>Clusters of lymph nodes are found near the breast in the axilla (under the arm), above the collarbone, and in the chest.<EOS>
<BOS>See the following PDQ summaries for more information about breast cancer: Breast Cancer Prevention Breast Cancer Treatment Genetics of Breast and Gynecologic Cancers Breast cancer is the second leading cause of death from cancer in American women.<EOS>
<BOS>Women in the United States get breast cancer more than any other type of cancer except for skin cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Breast cancer is second only to lung cancer as a cause of cancer death in women.<EOS>
<BOS>Breast cancer occurs more often in white women than in black women.<EOS>
<BOS>However, black women are more likely than white women to die from the disease.<EOS>
<BOS>Breast cancer occurs in men also, but the number of cases is small.<EOS>
<BOS>Certain factors affect prognosis (chance of recovery) and treatment options.<EOS>
<BOS>The prognosis (chance of recovery) depends on the type of tumor and whether the tumor has spread into other areas of the central nervous system (brain and spinal cord) or outside of the central nervous system to other parts of the body.<EOS>
<BOS>Treatment options depend on the following: The type and size of the tumor.<EOS>
<BOS>Whether the tumor is making hormones.<EOS>
<BOS>Whether the tumor is causing problems with vision or other signs or symptoms.<EOS>
<BOS>Whether the tumor has spread into the brain around the pituitary gland or to other parts of the body.<EOS>
<BOS>Whether the tumor has just been diagnosed or has recurred (come back).<EOS>
<BOS>A sign of adult soft tissue sarcoma is a lump or swelling in soft tissue of the body.<EOS>
<BOS>A sarcoma may appear as a painless lump under the skin, often on an arm or a leg.<EOS>
<BOS>Sarcomas that begin in the abdomen may not cause signs or symptoms until they get very big.<EOS>
<BOS>As the sarcoma grows bigger and presses on nearby organs, nerves, muscles, or blood vessels, signs and symptoms may include: Pain.<EOS>
<BOS>Trouble breathing.<EOS>
<BOS>Other conditions may cause the same signs and symptoms.<EOS>
<BOS>Check with your doctor if you have any of these problems.<EOS>
<BOS>Key Points A pituitary tumor is a growth of abnormal cells in the tissues of the pituitary gland.<EOS>
<BOS>The pituitary gland hormones control many other glands in the body.<EOS>
<BOS>Having certain genetic conditions increases the risk of developing a pituitary tumor.<EOS>
<BOS>Signs of a pituitary tumor include problems with vision and certain physical changes.<EOS>
<BOS>Imaging studies and tests that examine the blood and urine are used to detect (find) and diagnose a pituitary tumor.<EOS>
<BOS>Certain factors affect prognosis (chance of recovery) and treatment options.<EOS>
<BOS>A pituitary tumor is a growth of abnormal cells in the tissues of the pituitary gland.<EOS>
<BOS>Pituitary tumors form in the pituitary gland, a peasized organ in the center of the brain, just above the back of the nose.<EOS>
<BOS>The pituitary gland is sometimes called the "master endocrine gland" because it makes hormones that affect the way many parts of the body work.<EOS>
<BOS>It also controls hormones made by many other glands in the body.<EOS>
<BOS>Pituitary tumors are divided into three groups: Benign pituitary adenomas: Tumors that are not cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>These tumors grow very slowly and do not spread from the pituitary gland to other parts of the body.<EOS>
<BOS>Invasive pituitary adenomas: Benign tumors that may spread to bones of the skull or the sinus cavity below the pituitary gland.<EOS>
<BOS>Pituitary carcinomas: Tumors that are malignant (cancer).<EOS>
<BOS>These pituitary tumors spread into other areas of the central nervous system (brain and spinal cord) or outside of the central nervous system.<EOS>
<BOS>Very few pituitary tumors are malignant.<EOS>
<BOS>Pituitary tumors may be either nonfunctioning or functioning.<EOS>
<BOS>Nonfunctioning pituitary tumors do not make extra amounts of hormones.<EOS>
<BOS>Functioning pituitary tumors make more than the normal amount of one or more hormones.<EOS>
<BOS>Most pituitary tumors are functioning tumors.<EOS>
<BOS>The extra hormones made by pituitary tumors may cause certain signs or symptoms of disease.<EOS>
<BOS>The pituitary gland hormones control many other glands in the body.<EOS>
<BOS>Hormones made by the pituitary gland include: Prolactin: A hormone that causes a womans breasts to make milk during and after pregnancy.<EOS>
<BOS>Adrenocorticotropic hormone (ACTH): A hormone that causes the adrenal glands to make a hormone called cortisol.<EOS>
<BOS>Cortisol helps control the use of sugar, protein, and fats in the body and helps the body deal with stress.<EOS>
<BOS>Growth hormone: A hormone that helps control body growth and the use of sugar and fat in the body.<EOS>
<BOS>Growth hormone is also called somatotropin.<EOS>
<BOS>Thyroidstimulating hormone: A hormone that causes the thyroid gland to make other hormones that control growth, body temperature, and heart rate.<EOS>
<BOS>Thyroidstimulating hormone is also called thyrotropin.<EOS>
<BOS>Luteinizing hormone (LH) and folliclestimulating hormone (FSH): Hormones that control the menstrual cycle in women and the making of sperm in men.<EOS>
<BOS>Key Points Colon cancer is a disease in which malignant (cancer) cells form in the tissues of the colon.<EOS>
<BOS>Health history affects the risk of developing colon cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Signs of colon cancer include blood in the stool or a change in bowel habits.<EOS>
<BOS>Tests that examine the colon and rectum are used to detect (find) and diagnose colon cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Certain factors affect prognosis (chance of recovery) and treatment options.<EOS>
<BOS>Colon cancer is a disease in which malignant (cancer) cells form in the tissues of the colon.<EOS>
<BOS>The colon is part of the bodys digestive system.<EOS>
<BOS>The digestive system removes and processes nutrients (vitamins, minerals, carbohydrates, fats, proteins, and water) from foods and helps pass waste material out of the body.<EOS>
<BOS>The digestive system is made up of the esophagus, stomach, and the small and large intestines.<EOS>
<BOS>The colon (large bowel) is the first part of the large intestine and is about 5 feet long.<EOS>
<BOS>Together, the rectum and anal canal make up the last part of the large intestine and are about 68 inches long.<EOS>
<BOS>The anal canal ends at the anus (the opening of the large intestine to the outside of the body).<EOS>
<BOS>Gastrointestinal stromal tumors can occur in the colon.<EOS>
<BOS>See the PDQ summary on Gastrointestinal Stromal Tumors Treatment for more information.<EOS>
<BOS>See the PDQ summary about Unusual Cancers of Childhood Treatment for information about colorectal cancer in children.<EOS>
<BOS>Key Points Chronic myelomonocytic leukemia is a disease in which too many myelocytes and monocytes (immature white blood cells) are made in the bone marrow.<EOS>
<BOS>Older age and being male increase the risk of chronic myelomonocytic leukemia.<EOS>
<BOS>Signs and symptoms of chronic myelomonocytic leukemia include fever, weight loss, and feeling very tired.<EOS>
<BOS>Certain factors affect prognosis (chance of recovery) and treatment options.<EOS>
<BOS>Chronic myelomonocytic leukemia is a disease in which too many myelocytes and monocytes (immature white blood cells) are made in the bone marrow.<EOS>
<BOS>In chronic myelomonocytic leukemia (CMML), the body tells too many blood stem cells to become two types of white blood cells called myelocytes and monocytes.<EOS>
<BOS>Some of these blood stem cells never become mature white blood cells.<EOS>
<BOS>These immature white blood cells are called blasts.<EOS>
<BOS>Over time, the myelocytes, monocytes, and blasts crowd out the red blood cells and platelets in the bone marrow.<EOS>
<BOS>When this happens, infection, anemia, or easy bleeding may occur.<EOS>
<BOS>Certain factors affect prognosis (chance of recovery) and treatment options.<EOS>
<BOS>The prognosis (chance of recovery) and treatment options depend on the following: Whether or not the tumor can be removed by surgery.<EOS>
<BOS>The stage of the cancer (the size of the tumor and whether the cancer has spread outside the pancreas to nearby tissues or lymph nodes or to other places in the body).<EOS>
<BOS>The patients general health.<EOS>
<BOS>Whether the cancer has just been diagnosed or has recurred (come back).<EOS>
<BOS>Pancreatic cancer can be controlled only if it is found before it has spread, when it can be completely removed by surgery.<EOS>
<BOS>If the cancer has spread, palliative treatment can improve the patient's quality of life by controlling the symptoms and complications of this disease.<EOS>
<BOS>New types of treatment are being tested in clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>Information about clinical trials is available from the NCI website.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients may want to think about taking part in a clinical trial.<EOS>
<BOS>For some patients, taking part in a clinical trial may be the best treatment choice.<EOS>
<BOS>Clinical trials are part of the cancer research process.<EOS>
<BOS>Clinical trials are done to find out if new cancer treatments are safe and effective or better than the standard treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Many of today's standard treatments for cancer are based on earlier clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients who take part in a clinical trial may receive the standard treatment or be among the first to receive a new treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients who take part in clinical trials also help improve the way cancer will be treated in the future.<EOS>
<BOS>Even when clinical trials do not lead to effective new treatments, they often answer important questions and help move research forward.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients can enter clinical trials before, during, or after starting their cancer treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Some clinical trials only include patients who have not yet received treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Other trials test treatments for patients whose cancer has not gotten better.<EOS>
<BOS>There are also clinical trials that test new ways to stop cancer from recurring (coming back) or reduce the side effects of cancer treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Clinical trials are taking place in many parts of the country.<EOS>
<BOS>See the Treatment Options section that follows for links to current treatment clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>These have been retrieved from NCI's listing of clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>Key Points There are different types of treatment for patients with colon cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Six types of standard treatment are used: Surgery Radiofrequency ablation Cryosurgery Chemotherapy Radiation therapy Targeted therapy New types of treatment are being tested in clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients may want to think about taking part in a clinical trial.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients can enter clinical trials before, during, or after starting their cancer treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Followup tests may be needed.<EOS>
<BOS>There are different types of treatment for patients with colon cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Different types of treatment are available for patients with colon cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Some treatments are standard (the currently used treatment), and some are being tested in clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>A treatment clinical trial is a research study meant to help improve current treatments or obtain information on new treatments for patients with cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>When clinical trials show that a new treatment is better than the standard treatment, the new treatment may become the standard treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients may want to think about taking part in a clinical trial.<EOS>
<BOS>Some clinical trials are open only to patients who have not started treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Six types of standard treatment are used: Surgery Surgery (removing the cancer in an operation) is the most common treatment for all stages of colon cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>A doctor may remove the cancer using one of the following types of surgery: Local excision: If the cancer is found at a very early stage, the doctor may remove it without cutting through the abdominal wall.<EOS>
<BOS>Instead, the doctor may put a tube with a cutting tool through the rectum into the colon and cut the cancer out.<EOS>
<BOS>This is called a local excision.<EOS>
<BOS>If the cancer is found in a polyp (a small bulging area of tissue), the operation is called a polypectomy.<EOS>
<BOS>Resection of the colon with anastomosis: If the cancer is larger, the doctor will perform a partial colectomy (removing the cancer and a small amount of healthy tissue around it).<EOS>
<BOS>The doctor may then perform an anastomosis (sewing the healthy parts of the colon together).<EOS>
<BOS>The doctor will also usually remove lymph nodes near the colon and examine them under a microscope to see whether they contain cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Resection of the colon with colostomy: If the doctor is not able to sew the 2 ends of the colon back together, a stoma (an opening) is made on the outside of the body for waste to pass through.<EOS>
<BOS>This procedure is called a colostomy.<EOS>
<BOS>A bag is placed around the stoma to collect the waste.<EOS>
<BOS>Sometimes the colostomy is needed only until the lower colon has healed, and then it can be reversed.<EOS>
<BOS>If the doctor needs to remove the entire lower colon, however, the colostomy may be permanent.<EOS>
<BOS>Even if the doctor removes all the cancer that can be seen at the time of the operation, some patients may be given chemotherapy or radiation therapy after surgery to kill any cancer cells that are left.<EOS>
<BOS>Treatment given after the surgery, to lower the risk that the cancer will come back, is called adjuvant therapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Radiofrequency ablation Radiofrequency ablation is the use of a special probe with tiny electrodes that kill cancer cells.<EOS>
<BOS>Sometimes the probe is inserted directly through the skin and only local anesthesia is needed.<EOS>
<BOS>In other cases, the probe is inserted through an incision in the abdomen.<EOS>
<BOS>This is done in the hospital with general anesthesia.<EOS>
<BOS>Cryosurgery Cryosurgery is a treatment that uses an instrument to freeze and destroy abnormal tissue.<EOS>
<BOS>This type of treatment is also called cryotherapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Chemotherapy Chemotherapy is a cancer treatment that uses drugs to stop the growth of cancer cells, either by killing the cells or by stopping them from dividing.<EOS>
<BOS>When chemotherapy is taken by mouth or injected into a vein or muscle, the drugs enter the bloodstream and can reach cancer cells throughout the body (systemic chemotherapy).<EOS>
<BOS>When chemotherapy is placed directly into the cerebrospinal fluid, an organ, or a body cavity such as the abdomen, the drugs mainly affect cancer cells in those areas (regional chemotherapy).<EOS>
<BOS>Chemoembolization of the hepatic artery may be used to treat cancer that has spread to the liver.<EOS>
<BOS>This involves blocking the hepatic artery (the main artery that supplies blood to the liver) and injecting anticancer drugs between the blockage and the liver.<EOS>
<BOS>The livers arteries then deliver the drugs throughout the liver.<EOS>
<BOS>Only a small amount of the drug reaches other parts of the body.<EOS>
<BOS>The blockage may be temporary or permanent, depending on what is used to block the artery.<EOS>
<BOS>The liver continues to receive some blood from the hepatic portal vein, which carries blood from the stomach and intestine.<EOS>
<BOS>The way the chemotherapy is given depends on the type and stage of the cancer being treated.<EOS>
<BOS>See Drugs Approved for Colon and Rectal Cancer for more information.<EOS>
<BOS>Radiation therapy Radiation therapy is a cancer treatment that uses highenergy xrays or other types of radiation to kill cancer cells or keep them from growing.<EOS>
<BOS>There are two types of radiation therapy: External radiation therapy uses a machine outside the body to send radiation toward the cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Internal radiation therapy uses a radioactive substance sealed in needles, seeds, wires, or catheters that are placed directly into or near the cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>The way the radiation therapy is given depends on the type and stage of the cancer being treated.<EOS>
<BOS>External radiation therapy is used as palliative therapy to relieve symptoms and improve quality of life.<EOS>
<BOS>Targeted therapy Targeted therapy is a type of treatment that uses drugs or other substances to identify and attack specific cancer cells without harming normal cells.<EOS>
<BOS>Types of targeted therapies used in the treatment of colon cancer include the following: Monoclonal antibodies: Monoclonal antibodies are made in the laboratory from a single type of immune system cell.<EOS>
<BOS>These antibodies can identify substances on cancer cells or normal substances that may help cancer cells grow.<EOS>
<BOS>The antibodies attach to the substances and kill the cancer cells, block their growth, or keep them from spreading.<EOS>
<BOS>Monoclonal antibodies are given by infusion.<EOS>
<BOS>They may be used alone or to carry drugs, toxins, or radioactive material directly to cancer cells.<EOS>
<BOS>Bevacizumab and ramucirumab are types of monoclonal antibodies that bind to a protein called vascular endothelial growth factor (VEGF).<EOS>
<BOS>This may prevent the growth of new blood vessels that tumors need to grow.<EOS>
<BOS>Cetuximab and panitumumab are types of monoclonal antibodies that bind to a protein called epidermal growth factor receptor (EGFR) on the surface of some types of cancer cells.<EOS>
<BOS>This may stop cancer cells from growing and dividing.<EOS>
<BOS>Angiogenesis inhibitors: Angiogenesis inhibitors stop the growth of new blood vessels that tumors need to grow.<EOS>
<BOS>Zivaflibercept is a vascular endothelial growth factor trap that blocks an enzyme needed for the growth of new blood vessels in tumors.<EOS>
<BOS>Regorafenib is used to treat colorectal cancer that has spread to other parts of the body and has not gotten better with other treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>It blocks the action of certain proteins, including vascular endothelial growth factor.<EOS>
<BOS>This may help keep cancer cells from growing and may kill them.<EOS>
<BOS>It may also prevent the growth of new blood vessels that tumors need to grow.<EOS>
<BOS>See Drugs Approved for Colon and Rectal Cancer for more information.<EOS>
<BOS>New types of treatment are being tested in clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>Information about clinical trials is available from the NCI website.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients may want to think about taking part in a clinical trial.<EOS>
<BOS>For some patients, taking part in a clinical trial may be the best treatment choice.<EOS>
<BOS>Clinical trials are part of the cancer research process.<EOS>
<BOS>Clinical trials are done to find out if new cancer treatments are safe and effective or better than the standard treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Many of today's standard treatments for cancer are based on earlier clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients who take part in a clinical trial may receive the standard treatment or be among the first to receive a new treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients who take part in clinical trials also help improve the way cancer will be treated in the future.<EOS>
<BOS>Even when clinical trials do not lead to effective new treatments, they often answer important questions and help move research forward.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients can enter clinical trials before, during, or after starting their cancer treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Some clinical trials only include patients who have not yet received treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Other trials test treatments for patients whose cancer has not gotten better.<EOS>
<BOS>There are also clinical trials that test new ways to stop cancer from recurring (coming back) or reduce the side effects of cancer treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Clinical trials are taking place in many parts of the country.<EOS>
<BOS>See the Treatment Options section that follows for links to current treatment clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>These have been retrieved from NCI's listing of clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>Followup tests may be needed.<EOS>
<BOS>Some of the tests that were done to diagnose the cancer or to find out the stage of the cancer may be repeated.<EOS>
<BOS>Some tests will be repeated in order to see how well the treatment is working.<EOS>
<BOS>Decisions about whether to continue, change, or stop treatment may be based on the results of these tests.<EOS>
<BOS>Some of the tests will continue to be done from time to time after treatment has ended.<EOS>
<BOS>The results of these tests can show if your condition has changed or if the cancer has recurred (come back).<EOS>
<BOS>These tests are sometimes called followup tests or checkups.<EOS>
<BOS>Treatment Options for Colon Cancer Stage 0 (Carcinoma in Situ) Treatment of stage 0 (carcinoma in situ) may include the following types of surgery: Local excision or simple polypectomy.<EOS>
<BOS>Resection and anastomosis.<EOS>
<BOS>This is done when the tumor is too large to remove by local excision.<EOS>
<BOS>Check the list of NCIsupported cancer clinical trials that are now accepting patients with stage 0 colon cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>For more specific results, refine the search by using other search features, such as the location of the trial, the type of treatment, or the name of the drug.<EOS>
<BOS>Talk with your doctor about clinical trials that may be right for you.<EOS>
<BOS>General information about clinical trials is available from the NCI website.<EOS>
<BOS>Stage I Colon Cancer Treatment of stage I colon cancer usually includes the following: Resection and anastomosis.<EOS>
<BOS>Check the list of NCIsupported cancer clinical trials that are now accepting patients with stage I colon cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>For more specific results, refine the search by using other search features, such as the location of the trial, the type of treatment, or the name of the drug.<EOS>
<BOS>Talk with your doctor about clinical trials that may be right for you.<EOS>
<BOS>General information about clinical trials is available from the NCI website.<EOS>
<BOS>Stage II Colon Cancer Treatment of stage II colon cancer may include the following: Resection and anastomosis.<EOS>
<BOS>Check the list of NCIsupported cancer clinical trials that are now accepting patients with stage II colon cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>For more specific results, refine the search by using other search features, such as the location of the trial, the type of treatment, or the name of the drug.<EOS>
<BOS>Talk with your doctor about clinical trials that may be right for you.<EOS>
<BOS>General information about clinical trials is available from the NCI website.<EOS>
<BOS>Stage III Colon Cancer Treatment of stage III colon cancer may include the following: Resection and anastomosis which may be followed by chemotherapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Clinical trials of new chemotherapy regimens after surgery.<EOS>
<BOS>Check the list of NCIsupported cancer clinical trials that are now accepting patients with stage III colon cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>For more specific results, refine the search by using other search features, such as the location of the trial, the type of treatment, or the name of the drug.<EOS>
<BOS>Talk with your doctor about clinical trials that may be right for you.<EOS>
<BOS>General information about clinical trials is available from the NCI website.<EOS>
<BOS>Stage IV and Recurrent Colon Cancer Treatment of stage IV and recurrent colon cancer may include the following: Local excision for tumors that have recurred.<EOS>
<BOS>Resection with or without anastomosis.<EOS>
<BOS>Surgery to remove parts of other organs, such as the liver, lungs, and ovaries, where the cancer may have recurred or spread.<EOS>
<BOS>Treatment of cancer that has spread to the liver may also include the following: Chemotherapy given before surgery to shrink the tumor, after surgery, or both before and after.<EOS>
<BOS>Radiofrequency ablation or cryosurgery, for patients who cannot have surgery.<EOS>
<BOS>Chemoembolization of the hepatic artery.<EOS>
<BOS>Radiation therapy or chemotherapy may be offered to some patients as palliative therapy to relieve symptoms and improve quality of life.<EOS>
<BOS>Chemotherapy and/or targeted therapy with a monoclonal antibody or an angiogenesis inhibitor.<EOS>
<BOS>Clinical trials of chemotherapy and/or targeted therapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Check the list of NCIsupported cancer clinical trials that are now accepting patients with stage IV colon cancer and recurrent colon cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>For more specific results, refine the search by using other search features, such as the location of the trial, the type of treatment, or the name of the drug.<EOS>
<BOS>Talk with your doctor about clinical trials that may be right for you.<EOS>
<BOS>General information about clinical trials is available from the NCI website.<EOS>
<BOS>Signs of childhood nonHodgkin lymphoma include breathing problems and swollen lymph nodes.<EOS>
<BOS>These and other signs may be caused by childhood nonHodgkin lymphoma or by other conditions.<EOS>
<BOS>Check with a doctor if your child has any of the following: Trouble breathing.<EOS>
<BOS>Wheezing.<EOS>
<BOS>Coughing.<EOS>
<BOS>Highpitched breathing sounds.<EOS>
<BOS>Swelling of the head, neck, upper body, or arms.<EOS>
<BOS>Trouble swallowing.<EOS>
<BOS>Painless swelling of the lymph nodes in the neck, underarm, stomach, or groin.<EOS>
<BOS>Painless lump or swelling in a testicle.<EOS>
<BOS>Fever for no known reason.<EOS>
<BOS>Weight loss for no known reason.<EOS>
<BOS>Night sweats.<EOS>
<BOS>Tests that examine the thymus are used to detect (find) thymoma or thymic carcinoma.<EOS>
<BOS>The following tests and procedures may be used: Physical exam and history : An exam of the body to check general signs of health, including checking for signs of disease, such as lumps or anything else that seems unusual.<EOS>
<BOS>A history of the patients health habits and past illnesses and treatments will also be taken.<EOS>
<BOS>Chest xray: An xray of the organs and bones inside the chest.<EOS>
<BOS>An xray is a type of energy beam that can go through the body and onto film, making a picture of areas inside the body.<EOS>
<BOS>CT scan (CAT scan): A procedure that makes a series of detailed pictures of areas inside the body, such as the chest, taken from different angles.<EOS>
<BOS>The pictures are made by a computer linked to an xray machine.<EOS>
<BOS>A dye may be injected into a vein or swallowed to help the organs or tissues show up more clearly.<EOS>
<BOS>This procedure is also called computed tomography, computerized tomography, or computerized axial tomography.<EOS>
<BOS>MRI (magnetic resonance imaging): A procedure that uses a magnet, radio waves, and a computer to make a series of detailed pictures of areas inside the body, such as the chest.<EOS>
<BOS>This procedure is also called nuclear magnetic resonance imaging (NMRI).<EOS>
<BOS>PET scan (positron emission tomography scan): A procedure to find malignant tumor cells in the body.<EOS>
<BOS>A small amount of radioactive glucose (sugar) is injected into a vein.<EOS>
<BOS>The PET scanner rotates around the body and makes a picture of where glucose is being used in the body.<EOS>
<BOS>Malignant tumor cells show up brighter in the picture because they are more active and take up more glucose than normal cells do.<EOS>
<BOS>Thymoma and thymic carcinoma are usually diagnosed, staged, and treated during surgery.<EOS>
<BOS>A biopsy of the tumor is done to diagnose the disease.<EOS>
<BOS>The biopsy may be done before or during surgery (a mediastinoscopy or mediastinotomy), using a thin needle to remove a sample of cells.<EOS>
<BOS>This is called a fineneedle aspiration (FNA) biopsy.<EOS>
<BOS>Sometimes a wide needle is used to remove a sample of cells and this is called a core biopsy.<EOS>
<BOS>A pathologist will view the sample under a microscope to check for cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>If thymoma or thymic carcinoma is diagnosed, the pathologist will determine the type of cancer cell in the tumor.<EOS>
<BOS>There may be more than one type of cancer cell in a thymoma.<EOS>
<BOS>The surgeon will decide if all or part of the tumor can be removed by surgery.<EOS>
<BOS>In some cases, lymph nodes and other tissues may be removed as well.<EOS>
<BOS>New types of treatment are being tested in clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>This summary section describes treatments that are being studied in clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>It may not mention every new treatment being studied.<EOS>
<BOS>Information about clinical trials is available from the NCI website.<EOS>
<BOS>Radiosensitizers Radiosensitizers are drugs that make tumor cells more sensitive to radiation therapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Combining radiation therapy with radiosensitizers may kill more tumor cells.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients may want to think about taking part in a clinical trial.<EOS>
<BOS>For some patients, taking part in a clinical trial may be the best treatment choice.<EOS>
<BOS>Clinical trials are part of the cancer research process.<EOS>
<BOS>Clinical trials are done to find out if new cancer treatments are safe and effective or better than the standard treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Many of today's standard treatments for cancer are based on earlier clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients who take part in a clinical trial may receive the standard treatment or be among the first to receive a new treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients who take part in clinical trials also help improve the way cancer will be treated in the future.<EOS>
<BOS>Even when clinical trials do not lead to effective new treatments, they often answer important questions and help move research forward.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients can enter clinical trials before, during, or after starting their cancer treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Some clinical trials only include patients who have not yet received treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Other trials test treatments for patients whose cancer has not gotten better.<EOS>
