<BOS>There are also clinical trials that test new ways to stop cancer from recurring (coming back) or reduce the side effects of cancer treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Clinical trials are taking place in many parts of the country.<EOS>
<BOS>See the Treatment Options section that follows for links to current treatment clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>These have been retrieved from NCI's listing of clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>Tests that examine the gallbladder and nearby organs are used to detect (find), diagnose, and stage gallbladder cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Procedures that make pictures of the gallbladder and the area around it help diagnose gallbladder cancer and show how far the cancer has spread.<EOS>
<BOS>The process used to find out if cancer cells have spread within and around the gallbladder is called staging.<EOS>
<BOS>In order to plan treatment, it is important to know if the gallbladder cancer can be removed by surgery.<EOS>
<BOS>Tests and procedures to detect, diagnose, and stage gallbladder cancer are usually done at the same time.<EOS>
<BOS>The following tests and procedures may be used: Physical exam and history : An exam of the body to check general signs of health, including checking for signs of disease, such as lumps or anything else that seems unusual.<EOS>
<BOS>A history of the patients health habits and past illnesses and treatments will also be taken.<EOS>
<BOS>Liver function tests : A procedure in which a blood sample is checked to measure the amounts of certain substances released into the blood by the liver.<EOS>
<BOS>A higher than normal amount of a substance can be a sign of liver disease that may be caused by gallbladder cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Carcinoembryonic antigen (CEA) assay : A test that measures the level of CEA in the blood.<EOS>
<BOS>CEA is released into the bloodstream from both cancer cells and normal cells.<EOS>
<BOS>When found in higher than normal amounts, it can be a sign of gallbladder cancer or other conditions.<EOS>
<BOS>CA 199 assay : A test that measures the level of CA 199 in the blood.<EOS>
<BOS>CA 199 is released into the bloodstream from both cancer cells and normal cells.<EOS>
<BOS>When found in higher than normal amounts, it can be a sign of gallbladder cancer or other conditions.<EOS>
<BOS>Blood chemistry studies : A procedure in which a blood sample is checked to measure the amounts of certain substances released into the blood by organs and tissues in the body.<EOS>
<BOS>An unusual (higher or lower than normal) amount of a substance can be a sign of disease.<EOS>
<BOS>CT scan (CAT scan): A procedure that makes a series of detailed pictures of areas inside the body, such as the chest, abdomen, and pelvis, taken from different angles.<EOS>
<BOS>The pictures are made by a computer linked to an xray machine.<EOS>
<BOS>A dye may be injected into a vein or swallowed to help the organs or tissues show up more clearly.<EOS>
<BOS>This procedure is also called computed tomography, computerized tomography, or computerized axial tomography.<EOS>
<BOS>Ultrasound exam: A procedure in which highenergy sound waves (ultrasound) are bounced off internal tissues or organs and make echoes.<EOS>
<BOS>The echoes form a picture of body tissues called a sonogram.<EOS>
<BOS>An abdominal ultrasound is done to diagnose gallbladder cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>PTC (percutaneous transhepatic cholangiography): A procedure used to xray the liver and bile ducts.<EOS>
<BOS>A thin needle is inserted through the skin below the ribs and into the liver.<EOS>
<BOS>Dye is injected into the liver or bile ducts and an xray is taken.<EOS>
<BOS>If a blockage is found, a thin, flexible tube called a stent is sometimes left in the liver to drain bile into the small intestine or a collection bag outside the body.<EOS>
<BOS>Chest xray : An xray of the organs and bones inside the chest.<EOS>
<BOS>An xray is a type of energy beam that can go through the body and onto film, making a picture of areas inside the body.<EOS>
<BOS>ERCP (endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography): A procedure used to xray the ducts (tubes) that carry bile from the liver to the gallbladder and from the gallbladder to the small intestine.<EOS>
<BOS>Sometimes gallbladder cancer causes these ducts to narrow and block or slow the flow of bile, causing jaundice.<EOS>
<BOS>An endoscope (a thin, lighted tube) is passed through the mouth, esophagus, and stomach into the first part of the small intestine.<EOS>
<BOS>A catheter (a smaller tube) is then inserted through the endoscope into the bile ducts.<EOS>
<BOS>A dye is injected through the catheter into the ducts and an xray is taken.<EOS>
<BOS>If the ducts are blocked by a tumor, a fine tube may be inserted into the duct to unblock it.<EOS>
<BOS>This tube (or stent) may be left in place to keep the duct open.<EOS>
<BOS>Tissue samples may also be taken.<EOS>
<BOS>Laparoscopy : A surgical procedure to look at the organs inside the abdomen to check for signs of disease.<EOS>
<BOS>Small incisions (cuts) are made in the wall of the abdomen and a laparoscope (a thin, lighted tube) is inserted into one of the incisions.<EOS>
<BOS>Other instruments may be inserted through the same or other incisions to perform procedures such as removing organs or taking tissue samples for biopsy.<EOS>
<BOS>The laparoscopy helps to find out if the cancer is within the gallbladder only or has spread to nearby tissues and if it can be removed by surgery.<EOS>
<BOS>Biopsy : The removal of cells or tissues so they can be viewed under a microscope by a pathologist to check for signs of cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>The biopsy may be done after surgery to remove the tumor.<EOS>
<BOS>If the tumor clearly cannot be removed by surgery, the biopsy may be done using a fine needle to remove cells from the tumor.<EOS>
<BOS>Women who have a family history of ovarian cancer are at an increased risk of ovarian cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Anything that increases your risk of getting a disease is called a risk factor.<EOS>
<BOS>Having a risk factor does not mean that you will get cancer; not having risk factors doesn't mean that you will not get cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Talk with your doctor if you think you may be at risk.<EOS>
<BOS>Women who have one firstdegree relative (mother, daughter, or sister) with a history of ovarian cancer have an increased risk of ovarian cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>This risk is higher in women who have one firstdegree relative and one seconddegree relative (grandmother or aunt) with a history of ovarian cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>This risk is even higher in women who have two or more firstdegree relatives with a history of ovarian cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Key Points There are different types of treatment for patients with vulvar cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Four types of standard treatment are used: Surgery Radiation therapy Chemotherapy Biologic therapy New types of treatment are being tested in clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients may want to think about taking part in a clinical trial.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients can enter clinical trials before, during, or after starting their cancer treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Followup tests may be needed.<EOS>
<BOS>There are different types of treatment for patients with vulvar cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Different types of treatments are available for patients with vulvar cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Some treatments are standard (the currently used treatment), and some are being tested in clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>A treatment clinical trial is a research study meant to help improve current treatments or obtain information on new treatments for patients with cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>When clinical trials show that a new treatment is better than the standard treatment, the new treatment may become the standard treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients may want to think about taking part in a clinical trial.<EOS>
<BOS>Some clinical trials are open only to patients who have not started treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Four types of standard treatment are used: Surgery Surgery is the most common treatment for vulvar cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>The goal of surgery is to remove all the cancer without any loss of the woman's sexual function.<EOS>
<BOS>One of the following types of surgery may be done: Laser surgery: A surgical procedure that uses a laser beam (a narrow beam of intense light) as a knife to make bloodless cuts in tissue or to remove a surface lesion such as a tumor.<EOS>
<BOS>Wide local excision: A surgical procedure to remove the cancer and some of the normal tissue around the cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Radical local excision: A surgical procedure to remove the cancer and a large amount of normal tissue around it.<EOS>
<BOS>Nearby lymph nodes in the groin may also be removed.<EOS>
<BOS>Ultrasound surgical aspiration (USA): A surgical procedure to break the tumor up into small pieces using very fine vibrations.<EOS>
<BOS>The small pieces of tumor are washed away and removed by suction.<EOS>
<BOS>This procedure causes less damage to nearby tissue.<EOS>
<BOS>Vulvectomy: A surgical procedure to remove part or all of the vulva: Skinning vulvectomy: The top layer of vulvar skin where the cancer is found is removed.<EOS>
<BOS>Skin grafts from other parts of the body may be needed to cover the area where the skin was removed.<EOS>
<BOS>Modified radical vulvectomy: Surgery to remove part of the vulva.<EOS>
<BOS>Nearby lymph nodes may also be removed.<EOS>
<BOS>Radical vulvectomy: Surgery to remove the entire vulva.<EOS>
<BOS>Nearby lymph nodes are also removed.<EOS>
<BOS>Pelvic exenteration: A surgical procedure to remove the lower colon, rectum, and bladder.<EOS>
<BOS>The cervix, vagina, ovaries, and nearby lymph nodes are also removed.<EOS>
<BOS>Artificial openings (stoma) are made for urine and stool to flow from the body into a collection bag.<EOS>
<BOS>Even if the doctor removes all the cancer that can be seen at the time of the surgery, some patients may have chemotherapy or radiation therapy after surgery to kill any cancer cells that are left.<EOS>
<BOS>Treatment given after the surgery, to lower the risk that the cancer will come back, is called adjuvant therapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Radiation therapy Radiation therapy is a cancer treatment that uses highenergy xrays or other types of radiation to kill cancer cells or keep them from growing.<EOS>
<BOS>There are two types of radiation therapy: External radiation therapy uses a machine outside the body to send radiation toward the cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Internal radiation therapy uses a radioactive substance sealed in needles, seeds, wires, or catheters that are placed directly into or near the cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>The way the radiation therapy is given depends on the type and stage of the cancer being treated.<EOS>
<BOS>External and internal radiation therapy are used to treat vulvar cancer, and external radiation therapy may also be used as palliative therapy to relieve symptoms and improve quality of life.<EOS>
<BOS>Chemotherapy Chemotherapy is a cancer treatment that uses drugs to stop the growth of cancer cells, either by killing the cells or by stopping the cells from dividing.<EOS>
<BOS>When chemotherapy is taken by mouth or injected into a vein or muscle, the drugs enter the bloodstream and can reach cancer cells throughout the body (systemic chemotherapy).<EOS>
<BOS>When chemotherapy is placed directly into the cerebrospinal fluid, an organ, a body cavity such as the abdomen, or onto the skin, the drugs mainly affect cancer cells in those areas (regional chemotherapy).<EOS>
<BOS>The way the chemotherapy is given depends on the type and stage of the cancer being treated.<EOS>
<BOS>Topical chemotherapy for vulvar cancer may be applied to the skin in a cream or lotion.<EOS>
<BOS>See Drugs Approved to Treat Vulvar Cancer for more information.<EOS>
<BOS>Biologic therapy Biologic therapy is a treatment that uses the patients immune system to fight cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Substances made by the body or made in a laboratory are used to boost, direct, or restore the bodys natural defenses against cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>This type of cancer treatment is also called biotherapy or immunotherapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Imiquimod is a biologic therapy that may be used to treat vulvar lesions and is applied to the skin in a cream.<EOS>
<BOS>New types of treatment are being tested in clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>Information about clinical trials is available from the NCI website.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients may want to think about taking part in a clinical trial.<EOS>
<BOS>For some patients, taking part in a clinical trial may be the best treatment choice.<EOS>
<BOS>Clinical trials are part of the cancer research process.<EOS>
<BOS>Clinical trials are done to find out if new cancer treatments are safe and effective or better than the standard treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Many of today's standard treatments for cancer are based on earlier clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients who take part in a clinical trial may receive the standard treatment or be among the first to receive a new treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients who take part in clinical trials also help improve the way cancer will be treated in the future.<EOS>
<BOS>Even when clinical trials do not lead to effective new treatments, they often answer important questions and help move research forward.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients can enter clinical trials before, during, or after starting their cancer treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Some clinical trials only include patients who have not yet received treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Other trials test treatments for patients whose cancer has not gotten better.<EOS>
<BOS>There are also clinical trials that test new ways to stop cancer from recurring (coming back) or reduce the side effects of cancer treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Clinical trials are taking place in many parts of the country.<EOS>
<BOS>See the Treatment Options section that follows for links to current treatment clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>These have been retrieved from NCI's listing of clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>Followup tests may be needed.<EOS>
<BOS>Some of the tests that were done to diagnose the cancer or to find out the stage of the cancer may be repeated.<EOS>
<BOS>Some tests will be repeated in order to see how well the treatment is working.<EOS>
<BOS>Decisions about whether to continue, change, or stop treatment may be based on the results of these tests.<EOS>
<BOS>Some of the tests will continue to be done from time to time after treatment has ended.<EOS>
<BOS>The results of these tests can show if your condition has changed or if the cancer has recurred (come back).<EOS>
<BOS>These tests are sometimes called followup tests or checkups.<EOS>
<BOS>It is important to have regular followup exams to check for recurrent vulvar cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Treatment Options by Stage Vulvar Intraepithelial Neoplasia (VIN): Treatment of vulvar intraepithelial neoplasia (VIN) may include the following: Removal of single lesions or wide local excision.<EOS>
<BOS>Laser surgery.<EOS>
<BOS>Ultrasound surgical aspiration.<EOS>
<BOS>Skinning vulvectomy with or without a skin graft.<EOS>
<BOS>Biologic therapy with topical imiquimod.<EOS>
<BOS>Stage I Vulvar Cancer: Treatment of stage I vulvar cancer may include the following: Wide local excision for lesions that are less than 1 millimeter deep.<EOS>
<BOS>Radical local excision and removal of nearby lymph nodes.<EOS>
<BOS>Radical local excision and sentinel lymph node biopsy.<EOS>
<BOS>If cancer is found in the sentinel lymph node, nearby lymph nodes are also removed.<EOS>
<BOS>Radiation therapy for patients who cannot have surgery.<EOS>
<BOS>Check the list of NCIsupported cancer clinical trials that are now accepting patients with stage I vulvar cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>For more specific results, refine the search by using other search features, such as the location of the trial, the type of treatment, or the name of the drug.<EOS>
<BOS>Talk with your doctor about clinical trials that may be right for you.<EOS>
<BOS>General information about clinical trials is available from the NCI website.<EOS>
<BOS>Stage II Vulvar Cancer: Treatment of stage II vulvar cancer may include the following: Radical local excision and removal of nearby lymph nodes.<EOS>
<BOS>Modified radical vulvectomy or radical vulvectomy for large tumors.<EOS>
<BOS>Nearby lymph nodes may be removed.<EOS>
<BOS>Radiation therapy may be given after surgery.<EOS>
<BOS>Radical local excision and sentinel lymph node biopsy.<EOS>
<BOS>If cancer is found in the sentinel lymph node, nearby lymph nodes are also removed.<EOS>
<BOS>Radiation therapy for patients who cannot have surgery.<EOS>
<BOS>Check the list of NCIsupported cancer clinical trials that are now accepting patients with stage II vulvar cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>For more specific results, refine the search by using other search features, such as the location of the trial, the type of treatment, or the name of the drug.<EOS>
<BOS>Talk with your doctor about clinical trials that may be right for you.<EOS>
<BOS>General information about clinical trials is available from the NCI website.<EOS>
<BOS>Stage III Vulvar Cancer: Treatment of stage III vulvar cancer may include the following: Modified radical vulvectomy or radical vulvectomy.<EOS>
<BOS>Nearby lymph nodes may be removed.<EOS>
<BOS>Radiation therapy may be given after surgery.<EOS>
<BOS>Radiation therapy or chemotherapy and radiation therapy followed by surgery.<EOS>
<BOS>Radiation therapy with or without chemotherapy for patients who cannot have surgery.<EOS>
<BOS>Check the list of NCIsupported cancer clinical trials that are now accepting patients with stage III vulvar cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>For more specific results, refine the search by using other search features, such as the location of the trial, the type of treatment, or the name of the drug.<EOS>
<BOS>Talk with your doctor about clinical trials that may be right for you.<EOS>
<BOS>General information about clinical trials is available from the NCI website.<EOS>
<BOS>Stage IV Vulvar Cancer: Treatment of stage IVA vulvar cancer may include the following: Radical vulvectomy and pelvic exenteration.<EOS>
<BOS>Radical vulvectomy followed by radiation therapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Radiation therapy or chemotherapy and radiation therapy followed by surgery.<EOS>
<BOS>Radiation therapy with or without chemotherapy for patients who cannot have surgery.<EOS>
<BOS>There is no standard treatment for stage IVB vulvar cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Treatment may include a clinical trial of a new treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Check the list of NCIsupported cancer clinical trials that are now accepting patients with stage IVB vulvar cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>For more specific results, refine the search by using other search features, such as the location of the trial, the type of treatment, or the name of the drug.<EOS>
<BOS>Talk with your doctor about clinical trials that may be right for you.<EOS>
<BOS>General information about clinical trials is available from the NCI website.<EOS>
<BOS>Treatment Options for Recurrent Vulvar Cancer Treatment of recurrent vulvar cancer may include the following: Wide local excision with or without radiation therapy to treat cancer that has come back in the same area.<EOS>
<BOS>Radical vulvectomy and pelvic exenteration to treat cancer that has come back in the same area.<EOS>
<BOS>Chemotherapy and radiation therapy with or without surgery.<EOS>
<BOS>Radiation therapy followed by surgery or chemotherapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Radiation therapy as palliative treatment to relieve symptoms and improve quality of life.<EOS>
<BOS>A clinical trial of a new treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Check the list of NCIsupported cancer clinical trials that are now accepting patients with recurrent vulvar cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>For more specific results, refine the search by using other search features, such as the location of the trial, the type of treatment, or the name of the drug.<EOS>
<BOS>Talk with your doctor about clinical trials that may be right for you.<EOS>
<BOS>General information about clinical trials is available from the NCI website.<EOS>
<BOS>Signs of lip and oral cavity cancer include a sore or lump on the lips or in the mouth.<EOS>
<BOS>These and other signs and symptoms may be caused by lip and oral cavity cancer or by other conditions.<EOS>
<BOS>Check with your doctor if you have any of the following: A sore on the lip or in the mouth that does not heal.<EOS>
<BOS>A lump or thickening on the lips or gums or in the mouth.<EOS>
<BOS>A white or red patch on the gums, tongue, or lining of the mouth.<EOS>
<BOS>Bleeding, pain, or numbness in the lip or mouth.<EOS>
<BOS>Change in voice.<EOS>
<BOS>Loose teeth or dentures that no longer fit well.<EOS>
<BOS>Trouble chewing or swallowing or moving the tongue or jaw.<EOS>
<BOS>Swelling of jaw.<EOS>
<BOS>Sore throat or feeling that something is caught in the throat.<EOS>
<BOS>Lip and oral cavity cancer may not have any symptoms and is sometimes found during a regular dental exam.<EOS>
<BOS>Key Points After ovarian, fallopian tube, or peritoneal cancer has been diagnosed, tests are done to find out if cancer cells have spread within the ovaries or to other parts of the body.<EOS>
<BOS>There are three ways that cancer spreads in the body.<EOS>
<BOS>Cancer may spread from where it began to other parts of the body.<EOS>
<BOS>The following stages are used for ovarian epithelial, fallopian tube, and primary peritoneal cancer: Stage I Stage II Stage III Stage IV Ovarian epithelial, fallopian tube, and primary peritoneal cancers are grouped for treatment as early or advanced cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>After ovarian, fallopian tube, or peritoneal cancer has been diagnosed, tests are done to find out if cancer cells have spread within the ovaries or to other parts of the body.<EOS>
<BOS>The process used to find out whether cancer has spread within the organ or to other parts of the body is called staging.<EOS>
<BOS>The information gathered from the staging process determines the stage of the disease.<EOS>
<BOS>It is important to know the stage in order to plan treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>The results of the tests used to diagnose cancer are often also used to stage the disease.<EOS>
<BOS>(See the General Information section.<EOS>
<BOS>) There are three ways that cancer spreads in the body.<EOS>
<BOS>Cancer can spread through tissue, the lymph system, and the blood: Tissue.<EOS>
<BOS>The cancer spreads from where it began by growing into nearby areas.<EOS>
<BOS>Lymph system.<EOS>
<BOS>The cancer spreads from where it began by getting into the lymph system.<EOS>
<BOS>The cancer travels through the lymph vessels to other parts of the body.<EOS>
<BOS>Blood.<EOS>
<BOS>The cancer spreads from where it began by getting into the blood.<EOS>
<BOS>The cancer travels through the blood vessels to other parts of the body.<EOS>
<BOS>Cancer may spread from where it began to other parts of the body.<EOS>
<BOS>When cancer spreads to another part of the body, it is called metastasis.<EOS>
<BOS>Cancer cells break away from where they began (the primary tumor) and travel through the lymph system or blood.<EOS>
<BOS>Lymph system.<EOS>
<BOS>The cancer gets into the lymph system, travels through the lymph vessels, and forms a tumor (metastatic tumor) in another part of the body.<EOS>
<BOS>Blood.<EOS>
<BOS>The cancer gets into the blood, travels through the blood vessels, and forms a tumor (metastatic tumor) in another part of the body.<EOS>
<BOS>The metastatic tumor is the same type of cancer as the primary tumor.<EOS>
<BOS>For example, if ovarian epithelial cancer spreads to the lung, the cancer cells in the lung are actually ovarian epithelial cancer cells.<EOS>
<BOS>The disease is metastatic ovarian epithelial cancer, not lung cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>The following stages are used for ovarian epithelial, fallopian tube, and primary peritoneal cancer: Stage I In stage I, cancer is found in one or both ovaries or fallopian tubes.<EOS>
<BOS>Stage I is divided into stage IA, stage IB, and stage IC.<EOS>
<BOS>Stage IA: Cancer is found inside a single ovary or fallopian tube.<EOS>
<BOS>Stage IB: Cancer is found inside both ovaries or fallopian tubes.<EOS>
<BOS>Stage IC: Cancer is found inside one or both ovaries or fallopian tubes and one of the following is true: cancer is also found on the outside surface of one or both ovaries or fallopian tubes; or the capsule (outer covering) of the ovary ruptured (broke open) before or during surgery; or cancer cells are found in the fluid of the peritoneal cavity (the body cavity that contains most of the organs in the abdomen) or in washings of the peritoneum (tissue lining the peritoneal cavity).<EOS>
<BOS>Stage II In stage II, cancer is found in one or both ovaries or fallopian tubes and has spread into other areas of the pelvis, or primary peritoneal cancer is found within the pelvis.<EOS>
<BOS>Stage II ovarian epithelial and fallopian tube cancers are divided into stage IIA and stage IIB.<EOS>
<BOS>Stage IIA: Cancer has spread from where it first formed to the uterus and/or the fallopian tubes and/or the ovaries.<EOS>
<BOS>Stage IIB: Cancer has spread from the ovary or fallopian tube to organs in the peritoneal cavity (the space that contains the abdominal organs).<EOS>
<BOS>Stage III In stage III, cancer is found in one or both ovaries or fallopian tubes, or is primary peritoneal cancer, and has spread outside the pelvis to other parts of the abdomen and/or to nearby lymph nodes.<EOS>
<BOS>Stage III is divided into stage IIIA, stage IIIB, and stage IIIC.<EOS>
<BOS>In stage IIIA, one of the following is true: Cancer has spread to lymph nodes in the area outside or behind the peritoneum only; or Cancer cells that can be seen only with a microscope have spread to the surface of the peritoneum outside the pelvis.<EOS>
<BOS>Cancer may have spread to nearby lymph nodes.<EOS>
<BOS>Stage IIIB: Cancer has spread to the peritoneum outside the pelvis and the cancer in the peritoneum is 2 centimeters or smaller.<EOS>
<BOS>Cancer may have spread to lymph nodes behind the peritoneum.<EOS>
<BOS>Stage IIIC: Cancer has spread to the peritoneum outside the pelvis and the cancer in the peritoneum is larger than 2 centimeters.<EOS>
<BOS>Cancer may have spread to lymph nodes behind the peritoneum or to the surface of the liver or spleen.<EOS>
<BOS>Stage IV In stage IV, cancer has spread beyond the abdomen to other parts of the body.<EOS>
<BOS>Stage IV is divided into stage IVA and stage IVB.<EOS>
<BOS>Stage IVA: Cancer cells are found in extra fluid that builds up around the lungs.<EOS>
<BOS>Stage IVB: Cancer has spread to organs and tissues outside the abdomen, including lymph nodes in the groin.<EOS>
<BOS>Ovarian epithelial, fallopian tube, and primary peritoneal cancers are grouped for treatment as early or advanced cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Stage I ovarian epithelial and fallopian tube cancers are treated as early cancers.<EOS>
<BOS>Stages II, III, and IV ovarian epithelial, fallopian tube, and primary peritoneal cancers are treated as advanced cancers.<EOS>
<BOS>Certain genetic changes may increase the risk of atypical teratoid/rhabdoid tumor.<EOS>
<BOS>Anything that increases the risk of getting a disease is called a risk factor.<EOS>
<BOS>Having a risk factor does not mean that you will get cancer; not having risk factors doesnt mean that you will not get cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Talk with your child's doctor if you think your child may be at risk.<EOS>
<BOS>Atypical teratoid/rhabdoid tumor may be linked to changes in the tumor suppressor genes SMARCB1 or SMARCA4.<EOS>
<BOS>Genes of this type make a protein that helps control cell growth.<EOS>
<BOS>Changes in the DNA of tumor suppressor genes like SMARCB1 or SMARCA4 may lead to cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Changes in the SMARCB1 or SMARCA4 genes may be inherited (passed on from parents to offspring).<EOS>
<BOS>When this gene change is inherited, tumors may form in two parts of the body at the same time (for example, in the brain and the kidney).<EOS>
<BOS>For patients with AT/RT, genetic counseling (a discussion with a trained professional about inherited diseases and a possible need for gene testing) may be recommended.<EOS>
<BOS>The process used to find out if cancer has spread within the brain or to other parts of the body is called staging.<EOS>
<BOS>There is no standard system for staging childhood craniopharyngioma.<EOS>
<BOS>Craniopharyngioma is described as newly diagnosed disease or recurrent disease.<EOS>
<BOS>The results of the tests and procedures done to diagnose craniopharyngioma are used to help make decisions about treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Key Points After adult primary liver cancer has been diagnosed, tests are done to find out if cancer cells have spread within the liver or to other parts of the body.<EOS>
<BOS>There are three ways that cancer spreads in the body.<EOS>
<BOS>Cancer may spread from where it began to other parts of the body.<EOS>
<BOS>The Barcelona Clinic Liver Cancer Staging System may be used to stage adult primary liver cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>The following groups are used to plan treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>BCLC stages 0, A, and B BCLC stages C and D After adult primary liver cancer has been diagnosed, tests are done to find out if cancer cells have spread within the liver or to other parts of the body.<EOS>
<BOS>The process used to find out if cancer has spread within the liver or to other parts of the body is called staging.<EOS>
<BOS>The information gathered from the staging process determines the stage of the disease.<EOS>
<BOS>It is important to know the stage in order to plan treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>The following tests and procedures may be used in the staging process: CT scan (CAT scan): A procedure that makes a series of detailed pictures of areas inside the body, such as the chest, abdomen, and pelvis, taken from different angles.<EOS>
<BOS>The pictures are made by a computer linked to an xray machine.<EOS>
<BOS>A dye may be injected into a vein or swallowed to help the organs or tissues show up more clearly.<EOS>
<BOS>This procedure is also called computed tomography, computerized tomography, or computerized axial tomography.<EOS>
<BOS>MRI (magnetic resonance imaging): A procedure that uses a magnet, radio waves, and a computer to make a series of detailed pictures of areas inside the body.<EOS>
<BOS>This procedure is also called nuclear magnetic resonance imaging (NMRI).<EOS>
<BOS>PET scan (positron emission tomography scan): A procedure to find malignant tumor cells in the body.<EOS>
<BOS>A small amount of radioactive glucose (sugar) is injected into a vein.<EOS>
<BOS>The PET scanner rotates around the body and makes a picture of where glucose is being used in the body.<EOS>
<BOS>Malignant tumor cells show up brighter in the picture because they are more active and take up more glucose than normal cells do.<EOS>
<BOS>There are three ways that cancer spreads in the body.<EOS>
<BOS>Cancer can spread through tissue, the lymph system, and the blood: Tissue.<EOS>
<BOS>The cancer spreads from where it began by growing into nearby areas.<EOS>
<BOS>Lymph system.<EOS>
<BOS>The cancer spreads from where it began by getting into the lymph system.<EOS>
<BOS>The cancer travels through the lymph vessels to other parts of the body.<EOS>
<BOS>Blood.<EOS>
<BOS>The cancer spreads from where it began by getting into the blood.<EOS>
<BOS>The cancer travels through the blood vessels to other parts of the body.<EOS>
<BOS>Cancer may spread from where it began to other parts of the body.<EOS>
<BOS>When cancer spreads to another part of the body, it is called metastasis.<EOS>
<BOS>Cancer cells break away from where they began (the primary tumor) and travel through the lymph system or blood.<EOS>
<BOS>Lymph system.<EOS>
<BOS>The cancer gets into the lymph system, travels through the lymph vessels, and forms a tumor (metastatic tumor) in another part of the body.<EOS>
<BOS>Blood.<EOS>
<BOS>The cancer gets into the blood, travels through the blood vessels, and forms a tumor (metastatic tumor) in another part of the body.<EOS>
<BOS>The metastatic tumor is the same type of cancer as the primary tumor.<EOS>
<BOS>For example, if primary liver cancer spreads to the lung, the cancer cells in the lung are actually liver cancer cells.<EOS>
<BOS>The disease is metastatic liver cancer, not lung cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>The Barcelona Clinic Liver Cancer Staging System may be used to stage adult primary liver cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>There are several staging systems for liver cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>The Barcelona Clinic Liver Cancer (BCLC) Staging System is widely used and is described below.<EOS>
<BOS>This system is used to predict the patient's chance of recovery and to plan treatment, based on the following: Whether the cancer has spread within the liver or to other parts of the body.<EOS>
<BOS>How well the liver is working.<EOS>
<BOS>The general health and wellness of the patient.<EOS>
<BOS>The symptoms caused by the cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>The BCLC staging system has five stages: Stage 0: Very early Stage A: Early Stage B: Intermediate Stage C: Advanced Stage D: Endstage The following groups are used to plan treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>BCLC stages 0, A, and B Treatment to cure the cancer is given for BCLC stages 0, A, and B.<EOS>
<BOS>BCLC stages C and D Treatment to relieve the symptoms caused by liver cancer and improve the patient's quality of life is given for BCLC stages C and D.<EOS>
<BOS>Treatments are not likely to cure the cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Key Points Colorectal cancer is a disease in which malignant (cancer) cells form in the tissues of the colon or the rectum.<EOS>
<BOS>Colorectal cancer is the second leading cause of death from cancer in the United States.<EOS>
<BOS>Different factors increase or decrease the risk of getting colorectal cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Colorectal cancer is a disease in which malignant (cancer) cells form in the tissues of the colon or the rectum.<EOS>
<BOS>The colon and rectum are parts of the body's digestive system.<EOS>
<BOS>The digestive system removes and processes nutrients (vitamins, minerals, carbohydrates, fats, proteins, and water) from foods and helps pass waste material out of the body.<EOS>
<BOS>The digestive system is made up of the mouth, throat, esophagus, stomach, and the small and large intestines.<EOS>
<BOS>The colon (large bowel) is the first part of the large intestine and is about 5 feet long.<EOS>
<BOS>Together, the rectum and anal canal make up the last part of the large intestine and are 68 inches long.<EOS>
<BOS>The anal canal ends at the anus (the opening of the large intestine to the outside of the body).<EOS>
<BOS>Cancer that begins in the colon is called colon cancer, and cancer that begins in the rectum is called rectal cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Cancer that begins in either of these organs may also be called colorectal cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>See the following PDQ summaries for more information about colorectal cancer: Colorectal Cancer Prevention Colon Cancer Treatment Rectal Cancer Treatment Genetics of Colorectal Cancer Colorectal cancer is the second leading cause of death from cancer in the United States.<EOS>
<BOS>The number of new colorectal cancer cases and the number of deaths from colorectal cancer are decreasing a little bit each year.<EOS>
<BOS>But in adults younger than 50 years, there has been a small increase in the number of new cases each year since 1998.<EOS>
<BOS>Colorectal cancer is found more often in men than in women.<EOS>
<BOS>Signs of anal cancer include bleeding from the anus or rectum or a lump near the anus.<EOS>
<BOS>These and other signs and symptoms may be caused by anal cancer or by other conditions.<EOS>
<BOS>Check with your doctor if you have any of the following: Bleeding from the anus or rectum.<EOS>
<BOS>Pain or pressure in the area around the anus.<EOS>
<BOS>Itching or discharge from the anus.<EOS>
<BOS>A lump near the anus.<EOS>
<BOS>A change in bowel habits.<EOS>
<BOS>Certain factors affect prognosis (chance of recovery) and treatment options.<EOS>
<BOS>The prognosis (chance of recovery) depends on the following: The type of plasma cell neoplasm.<EOS>
<BOS>The stage of the disease.<EOS>
<BOS>Whether a certain immunoglobulin (antibody) is present.<EOS>
<BOS>Whether there are certain genetic changes.<EOS>
<BOS>Whether the kidney is damaged.<EOS>
<BOS>Whether the cancer responds to initial treatment or recurs (comes back).<EOS>
<BOS>Treatment options depend on the following: The type of plasma cell neoplasm.<EOS>
<BOS>The age and general health of the patient.<EOS>
<BOS>Whether there are signs, symptoms, or health problems, such as kidney failure or infection, related to the disease.<EOS>
<BOS>Whether the cancer responds to initial treatment or recurs (comes back).<EOS>
<BOS>Key Points After testicular cancer has been diagnosed, tests are done to find out if cancer cells have spread within the testicles or to other parts of the body.<EOS>
<BOS>There are three ways that cancer spreads in the body.<EOS>
<BOS>Cancer may spread from where it began to other parts of the body.<EOS>
<BOS>The following stages are used for testicular cancer: Stage 0 (Testicular Intraepithelial Neoplasia) Stage I Stage II Stage III After testicular cancer has been diagnosed, tests are done to find out if cancer cells have spread within the testicles or to other parts of the body.<EOS>
<BOS>The process used to find out if cancer has spread within the testicles or to other parts of the body is called staging.<EOS>
<BOS>The information gathered from the staging process determines the stage of the disease.<EOS>
<BOS>It is important to know the stage in order to plan treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>The following tests and procedures may be used in the staging process: Chest xray : An xray of the organs and bones inside the chest.<EOS>
<BOS>An xray is a type of energy beam that can go through the body and onto film, making a picture of areas inside the body.<EOS>
<BOS>CT scan (CAT scan): A procedure that makes a series of detailed pictures of areas inside the body, taken from different angles.<EOS>
<BOS>The pictures are made by a computer linked to an xray machine.<EOS>
<BOS>A dye may be injected into a vein or swallowed to help the organs or tissues show up more clearly.<EOS>
<BOS>This procedure is also called computed tomography, computerized tomography, or computerized axial tomography.<EOS>
<BOS>PET scan (positron emission tomography scan): A procedure to find malignant tumor cells in the body.<EOS>
<BOS>A small amount of radioactive glucose (sugar) is injected into a vein.<EOS>
<BOS>The PET scanner rotates around the body and makes a picture of where glucose is being used in the body.<EOS>
<BOS>Malignant tumor cells show up brighter in the picture because they are more active and take up more glucose than normal cells do.<EOS>
<BOS>MRI (magnetic resonance imaging): A procedure that uses a magnet, radio waves, and a computer to make a series of detailed pictures of areas inside the body.<EOS>
<BOS>This procedure is also called nuclear magnetic resonance imaging (NMRI).<EOS>
<BOS>Abdominal lymph node dissection : A surgical procedure in which lymph nodes in the abdomen are removed and a sample of tissue is checked under a microscope for signs of cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>This procedure is also called lymphadenectomy.<EOS>
<BOS>For patients with nonseminoma, removing the lymph nodes may help stop the spread of disease.<EOS>
<BOS>Cancer cells in the lymph nodes of seminoma patients can be treated with radiation therapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Serum tumor marker test : A procedure in which a sample of blood is examined to measure the amounts of certain substances released into the blood by organs, tissues, or tumor cells in the body.<EOS>
<BOS>Certain substances are linked to specific types of cancer when found in increased levels in the blood.<EOS>
<BOS>These are called tumor markers.<EOS>
<BOS>The following 3 tumor markers are used in staging testicular cancer: Alphafetoprotein (AFP) Betahuman chorionic gonadotropin (hCG).<EOS>
<BOS>Lactate dehydrogenase (LDH).<EOS>
<BOS>Tumor marker levels are measured again, after inguinal orchiectomy and biopsy, in order to determine the stage of the cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>This helps to show if all of the cancer has been removed or if more treatment is needed.<EOS>
<BOS>Tumor marker levels are also measured during followup as a way of checking if the cancer has come back.<EOS>
<BOS>There are three ways that cancer spreads in the body.<EOS>
<BOS>Cancer can spread through tissue, the lymph system, and the blood: Tissue.<EOS>
<BOS>The cancer spreads from where it began by growing into nearby areas.<EOS>
<BOS>Lymph system.<EOS>
<BOS>The cancer spreads from where it began by getting into the lymph system.<EOS>
<BOS>The cancer travels through the lymph vessels to other parts of the body.<EOS>
<BOS>Blood.<EOS>
<BOS>The cancer spreads from where it began by getting into the blood.<EOS>
<BOS>The cancer travels through the blood vessels to other parts of the body.<EOS>
<BOS>Cancer may spread from where it began to other parts of the body.<EOS>
<BOS>When cancer spreads to another part of the body, it is called metastasis.<EOS>
<BOS>Cancer cells break away from where they began (the primary tumor) and travel through the lymph system or blood.<EOS>
<BOS>Lymph system.<EOS>
<BOS>The cancer gets into the lymph system, travels through the lymph vessels, and forms a tumor (metastatic tumor) in another part of the body.<EOS>
<BOS>Blood.<EOS>
<BOS>The cancer gets into the blood, travels through the blood vessels, and forms a tumor (metastatic tumor) in another part of the body.<EOS>
<BOS>The metastatic tumor is the same type of cancer as the primary tumor.<EOS>
<BOS>For example, if testicular cancer spreads to the lung, the cancer cells in the lung are actually testicular cancer cells.<EOS>
<BOS>The disease is metastatic testicular cancer, not lung cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>The following stages are used for testicular cancer: Stage 0 (Testicular Intraepithelial Neoplasia) In stage 0, abnormal cells are found in the tiny tubules where the sperm cells begin to develop.<EOS>
<BOS>These abnormal cells may become cancer and spread into nearby normal tissue.<EOS>
<BOS>All tumor marker levels are normal.<EOS>
<BOS>Stage 0 is also called testicular intraepithelial neoplasia and testicular intratubular germ cell neoplasia.<EOS>
<BOS>Stage I In stage I, cancer has formed.<EOS>
<BOS>Stage I is divided into stage IA, stage IB, and stage IS and is determined after an inguinal orchiectomy is done.<EOS>
<BOS>In stage IA, cancer is in the testicle and epididymis and may have spread to the inner layer of the membrane surrounding the testicle.<EOS>
<BOS>All tumor marker levels are normal.<EOS>
<BOS>In stage IB, cancer: is in the testicle and the epididymis and has spread to the blood vessels or lymph vessels in the testicle; or has spread to the outer layer of the membrane surrounding the testicle; or is in the spermatic cord or the scrotum and may be in the blood vessels or lymph vessels of the testicle.<EOS>
<BOS>All tumor marker levels are normal.<EOS>
<BOS>In stage IS, cancer is found anywhere within the testicle, spermatic cord, or the scrotum and either: all tumor marker levels are slightly above normal; or one or more tumor marker levels are moderately above normal or high.<EOS>
<BOS>Stage II Stage II is divided into stage IIA, stage IIB, and stage IIC and is determined after an inguinal orchiectomy is done.<EOS>
<BOS>In stage IIA, cancer: is anywhere within the testicle, spermatic cord, or scrotum; and has spread to up to 5 lymph nodes in the abdomen, none larger than 2 centimeters.<EOS>
<BOS>All tumor marker levels are normal or slightly above normal.<EOS>
<BOS>In stage IIB, cancer is anywhere within the testicle, spermatic cord, or scrotum; and either: has spread to up to 5 lymph nodes in the abdomen; at least one of the lymph nodes is larger than 2 centimeters, but none are larger than 5 centimeters; or has spread to more than 5 lymph nodes; the lymph nodes are not larger than 5 centimeters.<EOS>
<BOS>All tumor marker levels are normal or slightly above normal.<EOS>
<BOS>In stage IIC, cancer: is anywhere within the testicle, spermatic cord, or scrotum; and has spread to a lymph node in the abdomen that is larger than 5 centimeters.<EOS>
<BOS>All tumor marker levels are normal or slightly above normal.<EOS>
<BOS>Stage III Stage III is divided into stage IIIA, stage IIIB, and stage IIIC and is determined after an inguinal orchiectomy is done.<EOS>
<BOS>In stage IIIA, cancer: is anywhere within the testicle, spermatic cord, or scrotum; and may have spread to one or more lymph nodes in the abdomen; and has spread to distant lymph nodes or to the lungs.<EOS>
<BOS>Tumor marker levels may range from normal to slightly above normal.<EOS>
<BOS>In stage IIIB, cancer: is anywhere within the testicle, spermatic cord, or scrotum; and may have spread to one or more lymph nodes in the abdomen, to distant lymph nodes, or to the lungs.<EOS>
<BOS>The level of one or more tumor markers is moderately above normal.<EOS>
<BOS>In stage IIIC, cancer: is anywhere within the testicle, spermatic cord, or scrotum; and may have spread to one or more lymph nodes in the abdomen, to distant lymph nodes, or to the lungs.<EOS>
<BOS>The level of one or more tumor markers is high.<EOS>
<BOS>or Cancer: is anywhere within the testicle, spermatic cord, or scrotum; and may have spread to one or more lymph nodes in the abdomen; and has not spread to distant lymph nodes or the lung but has spread to other parts of the body.<EOS>
<BOS>Tumor marker levels may range from normal to high.<EOS>
<BOS>The number of new cases of oral cavity and oropharyngeal cancer and the number of deaths from oral cavity and oropharyngeal cancer varies by race and gender.<EOS>
<BOS>Over the past ten years, the number of new cases and deaths from oral cavity and oropharyngeal cancer slightly increased in white men and women.<EOS>
<BOS>The number slightly decreased among black men and women.<EOS>
<BOS>Oral cavity and oropharyngeal cancer is more common in men than in women.<EOS>
<BOS>Although oral cavity and oropharyngeal cancer may occur in adults of any age, it occurs most often in those aged 55 to 64 years.<EOS>
<BOS>France, Brazil, and parts of Asia have much higher rates of oral cavity and oropharyngeal cancer than most other countries.<EOS>
<BOS>The number of new cases of oropharyngeal cancer caused by certain types of human papillomavirus (HPV) infection has increased.<EOS>
<BOS>One kind of HPV, called HPV 16, is often passed from one person to another during sexual activity.<EOS>
<BOS>Key Points After laryngeal cancer has been diagnosed, tests are done to find out if cancer cells have spread within the larynx or to other parts of the body.<EOS>
<BOS>There are three ways that cancer spreads in the body.<EOS>
<BOS>Cancer may spread from where it began to other parts of the body.<EOS>
<BOS>The following stages are used for laryngeal cancer: Stage 0 (Carcinoma in Situ) Stage I Stage II Stage III Stage IV After laryngeal cancer has been diagnosed, tests are done to find out if cancer cells have spread within the larynx or to other parts of the body.<EOS>
<BOS>The process used to find out if cancer has spread within the larynx or to other parts of the body is called staging.<EOS>
<BOS>The information gathered from the staging process determines the stage of the disease.<EOS>
<BOS>It is important to know the stage of the disease in order to plan treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>The results of some of the tests used to diagnose laryngeal cancer are often also used to stage the disease.<EOS>
<BOS>There are three ways that cancer spreads in the body.<EOS>
<BOS>Cancer can spread through tissue, the lymph system, and the blood: Tissue.<EOS>
<BOS>The cancer spreads from where it began by growing into nearby areas.<EOS>
<BOS>Lymph system.<EOS>
<BOS>The cancer spreads from where it began by getting into the lymph system.<EOS>
<BOS>The cancer travels through the lymph vessels to other parts of the body.<EOS>
<BOS>Blood.<EOS>
<BOS>The cancer spreads from where it began by getting into the blood.<EOS>
<BOS>The cancer travels through the blood vessels to other parts of the body.<EOS>
<BOS>Cancer may spread from where it began to other parts of the body.<EOS>
<BOS>When cancer spreads to another part of the body, it is called metastasis.<EOS>
<BOS>Cancer cells break away from where they began (the primary tumor) and travel through the lymph system or blood.<EOS>
<BOS>Lymph system.<EOS>
<BOS>The cancer gets into the lymph system, travels through the lymph vessels, and forms a tumor (metastatic tumor) in another part of the body.<EOS>
<BOS>Blood.<EOS>
<BOS>The cancer gets into the blood, travels through the blood vessels, and forms a tumor (metastatic tumor) in another part of the body.<EOS>
<BOS>The metastatic tumor is the same type of cancer as the primary tumor.<EOS>
<BOS>For example, if laryngeal cancer spreads to the lung, the cancer cells in the lung are actually laryngeal cancer cells.<EOS>
<BOS>The disease is metastatic laryngeal cancer, not lung cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>The following stages are used for laryngeal cancer: Stage 0 (Carcinoma in Situ) In stage 0, abnormal cells are found in the lining of the larynx.<EOS>
<BOS>These abnormal cells may become cancer and spread into nearby normal tissue.<EOS>
<BOS>Stage 0 is also called carcinoma in situ.<EOS>
<BOS>Stage I In stage I, cancer has formed.<EOS>
<BOS>Stage I laryngeal cancer depends on where cancer began in the larynx: Supraglottis: Cancer is in one area of the supraglottis only and the vocal cords can move normally.<EOS>
<BOS>Glottis: Cancer is in one or both vocal cords and the vocal cords can move normally.<EOS>
<BOS>Subglottis: Cancer is in the subglottis only.<EOS>
<BOS>Stage II In stage II, cancer is in the larynx only.<EOS>
<BOS>Stage II laryngeal cancer depends on where cancer began in the larynx: Supraglottis: Cancer is in more than one area of the supraglottis or surrounding tissues.<EOS>
<BOS>Glottis: Cancer has spread to the supraglottis and/or the subglottis and/or the vocal cords cannot move normally.<EOS>
<BOS>Subglottis: Cancer has spread to one or both vocal cords, which may not move normally.<EOS>
<BOS>Stage III Stage III laryngeal cancer depends on whether cancer has spread from the supraglottis, glottis, or subglottis.<EOS>
<BOS>In stage III cancer of the supraglottis: cancer is in the larynx only and the vocal cords cannot move, and/or cancer is in tissues next to the larynx.<EOS>
<BOS>Cancer may have spread to one lymph node on the same side of the neck as the original tumor and the lymph node is 3 centimeters or smaller; or cancer is in one area of the supraglottis and in one lymph node on the same side of the neck as the original tumor; the lymph node is 3 centimeters or smaller and the vocal cords can move normally; or cancer is in more than one area of the supraglottis or surrounding tissues and in one lymph node on the same side of the neck as the original tumor; the lymph node is 3 centimeters or smaller.<EOS>
<BOS>In stage III cancer of the glottis: cancer is in the larynx only and the vocal cords cannot move, and/or cancer is in tissues next to the larynx; cancer may have spread to one lymph node on the same side of the neck as the original tumor and the lymph node is 3 centimeters or smaller; or cancer is in one or both vocal cords and in one lymph node on the same side of the neck as the original tumor; the lymph node is 3 centimeters or smaller and the vocal cords can move normally; or cancer has spread to the supraglottis and/or the subglottis and/or the vocal cords cannot move normally.<EOS>
<BOS>Cancer has also spread to one lymph node on the same side of the neck as the original tumor and the lymph node is 3 centimeters or smaller.<EOS>
<BOS>In stage III cancer of the subglottis: cancer is in the larynx and the vocal cords cannot move; cancer may have spread to one lymph node on the same side of the neck as the original tumor and the lymph node is 3 centimeters or smaller; or cancer is in the subglottis and in one lymph node on the same side of the neck as the original tumor; the lymph node is 3 centimeters or smaller; or cancer has spread to one or both vocal cords, which may not move normally.<EOS>
<BOS>Cancer has also spread to one lymph node on the same side of the neck as the original tumor and the lymph node is 3 centimeters or smaller.<EOS>
<BOS>Stage IV Stage IV is divided into stage IVA, stage IVB, and stage IVC.<EOS>
<BOS>Each substage is the same for cancer in the supraglottis, glottis, or subglottis.<EOS>
<BOS>In stage IVA: cancer has spread through the thyroid cartilage and/or has spread to tissues beyond the larynx such as the neck, trachea, thyroid, or esophagus.<EOS>
<BOS>Cancer may have spread to one lymph node on the same side of the neck as the original tumor and the lymph node is 3 centimeters or smaller; or cancer has spread to one lymph node on the same side of the neck as the original tumor and the lymph node is larger than 3 centimeters but not larger than 6 centimeters, or has spread to more than one lymph node anywhere in the neck with none larger than 6 centimeters.<EOS>
<BOS>Cancer may have spread to tissues beyond the larynx, such as the neck, trachea, thyroid, or esophagus.<EOS>
<BOS>The vocal cords may not move normally.<EOS>
<BOS>In stage IVB: cancer has spread to the space in front of the spinal column, surrounds the carotid artery, or has spread to parts of the chest.<EOS>
<BOS>Cancer may have spread to one or more lymph nodes anywhere in the neck and the lymph nodes may be any size; or cancer has spread to a lymph node that is larger than 6 centimeters and may have spread as far as the space in front of the spinal column, around the carotid artery, or to parts of the chest.<EOS>
<BOS>The vocal cords may not move normally.<EOS>
<BOS>In stage IVC, cancer has spread to other parts of the body, such as the lungs, liver, or bone.<EOS>
<BOS>Signs of nasopharyngeal cancer include trouble breathing, speaking, or hearing.<EOS>
<BOS>These and other signs and symptoms may be caused by nasopharyngeal cancer or by other conditions.<EOS>
<BOS>Check with your doctor if you have any of the following: A lump in the nose or neck.<EOS>
<BOS>A sore throat.<EOS>
<BOS>Trouble breathing or speaking.<EOS>
<BOS>Nosebleeds.<EOS>
<BOS>Trouble hearing.<EOS>
<BOS>Pain or ringing in the ear.<EOS>
<BOS>Headaches.<EOS>
<BOS>Signs and symptoms of ovarian, fallopian tube, or peritoneal cancer include pain or swelling in the abdomen.<EOS>
<BOS>Ovarian, fallopian tube, or peritoneal cancer may not cause early signs or symptoms.<EOS>
<BOS>When signs or symptoms do appear, the cancer is often advanced.<EOS>
<BOS>Signs and symptoms may include the following: Pain, swelling, or a feeling of pressure in the abdomen or pelvis.<EOS>
<BOS>Vaginal bleeding that is heavy or irregular, especially after menopause.<EOS>
<BOS>Vaginal discharge that is clear, white, or colored with blood.<EOS>
<BOS>A lump in the pelvic area.<EOS>
<BOS>Gastrointestinal problems, such as gas, bloating, or constipation.<EOS>
<BOS>These signs and symptoms also may be caused by other conditions and not by ovarian, fallopian tube, or peritoneal cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>If the signs or symptoms get worse or do not go away on their own, check with your doctor so that any problem can be diagnosed and treated as early as possible.<EOS>
<BOS>Key Points An adult central nervous system tumor is a disease in which abnormal cells form in the tissues of the brain and/or spinal cord.<EOS>
<BOS>A tumor that starts in another part of the body and spreads to the brain is called a metastatic brain tumor.<EOS>
<BOS>The brain controls many important body functions.<EOS>
<BOS>The spinal cord connects the brain to nerves in most parts of the body.<EOS>
<BOS>There are different types of brain and spinal cord tumors.<EOS>
<BOS>Astrocytic Tumors Oligodendroglial Tumors Mixed Gliomas Ependymal Tumors Medulloblastomas Pineal Parenchymal Tumors Meningeal Tumors Germ Cell Tumors Craniopharyngioma (Grade I) Having certain genetic syndromes may increase the risk of a central nervous system tumor.<EOS>
<BOS>The cause of most adult brain and spinal cord tumors is not known.<EOS>
<BOS>The signs and symptoms of adult brain and spinal cord tumors are not the same in every person.<EOS>
<BOS>Tests that examine the brain and spinal cord are used to diagnose adult brain and spinal cord tumors.<EOS>
<BOS>A biopsy is also used to diagnose a brain tumor.<EOS>
<BOS>Sometimes a biopsy or surgery cannot be done.<EOS>
<BOS>Certain factors affect prognosis (chance of recovery) and treatment options.<EOS>
<BOS>An adult central nervous system tumor is a disease in which abnormal cells form in the tissues of the brain and/or spinal cord.<EOS>
<BOS>There are many types of brain and spinal cord tumors.<EOS>
<BOS>The tumors are formed by the abnormal growth of cells and may begin in different parts of the brain or spinal cord.<EOS>
<BOS>Together, the brain and spinal cord make up the central nervous system (CNS).<EOS>
<BOS>The tumors may be either benign (not cancer) or malignant (cancer): Benign brain and spinal cord tumors grow and press on nearby areas of the brain.<EOS>
<BOS>They rarely spread into other tissues and may recur (come back).<EOS>
<BOS>Malignant brain and spinal cord tumors are likely to grow quickly and spread into other brain tissue.<EOS>
<BOS>When a tumor grows into or presses on an area of the brain, it may stop that part of the brain from working the way it should.<EOS>
<BOS>Both benign and malignant brain tumors cause signs and symptoms and need treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Brain and spinal cord tumors can occur in both adults and children.<EOS>
<BOS>However, treatment for children may be different than treatment for adults.<EOS>
<BOS>(See the PDQ summary on Childhood Brain and Spinal Cord Tumors Treatment Overview for more information on the treatment of children.<EOS>
<BOS>) For information about lymphoma that begins in the brain, see the PDQ summary on Primary CNS Lymphoma Treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>A tumor that starts in another part of the body and spreads to the brain is called a metastatic brain tumor.<EOS>
<BOS>Tumors that start in the brain are called primary brain tumors.<EOS>
<BOS>Primary brain tumors may spread to other parts of the brain or to the spine.<EOS>
<BOS>They rarely spread to other parts of the body.<EOS>
<BOS>Often, tumors found in the brain have started somewhere else in the body and spread to one or more parts of the brain.<EOS>
<BOS>These are called metastatic brain tumors (or brain metastases).<EOS>
<BOS>Metastatic brain tumors are more common than primary brain tumors.<EOS>
<BOS>Up to half of metastatic brain tumors are from lung cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Other types of cancer that commonly spread to the brain include: Melanoma.<EOS>
<BOS>Breast cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Colon cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Kidney cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Nasopharyngeal cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Cancer of unknown primary site.<EOS>
<BOS>Cancer may spread to the leptomeninges (the two innermost membranes covering the brain and spinal cord).<EOS>
<BOS>This is called leptomeningeal carcinomatosis.<EOS>
<BOS>The most common cancers that spread to the leptomeninges include: Breast cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Lung cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Leukemia.<EOS>
<BOS>Lymphoma.<EOS>
<BOS>See the following for more information from PDQ about cancers that commonly spread to the brain or spinal cord: Adult Hodgkin Lymphoma Treatment Adult NonHodgkin Lymphoma Treatment Breast Cancer Treatment Carcinoma of Unknown Primary Treatment Colon Cancer Treatment Leukemia Home Page Melanoma Treatment Nasopharyngeal Cancer Treatment NonSmall Cell Lung Cancer Treatment Renal Cell Cancer Treatment Small Cell Lung Cancer Treatment The brain controls many important body functions.<EOS>
<BOS>The brain has three major parts: The cerebrum is the largest part of the brain.<EOS>
<BOS>It is at the top of the head.<EOS>
<BOS>The cerebrum controls thinking, learning, problem solving, emotions, speech, reading, writing, and voluntary movement.<EOS>
<BOS>The cerebellum is in the lower back of the brain (near the middle of the back of the head).<EOS>
<BOS>It controls movement, balance, and posture.<EOS>
<BOS>The brain stem connects the brain to the spinal cord.<EOS>
<BOS>It is in the lowest part of the brain (just above the back of the neck).<EOS>
<BOS>The brain stem controls breathing, heart rate, and the nerves and muscles used to see, hear, walk, talk, and eat.<EOS>
<BOS>The spinal cord connects the brain to nerves in most parts of the body.<EOS>
<BOS>The spinal cord is a column of nerve tissue that runs from the brain stem down the center of the back.<EOS>
<BOS>It is covered by three thin layers of tissue called membranes.<EOS>
<BOS>These membranes are surrounded by the vertebrae (back bones).<EOS>
<BOS>Spinal cord nerves carry messages between the brain and the rest of the body, such as a message from the brain to cause muscles to move or a message from the skin to the brain to feel touch.<EOS>
<BOS>There are different types of brain and spinal cord tumors.<EOS>
<BOS>Brain and spinal cord tumors are named based on the type of cell they formed in and where the tumor first formed in the CNS.<EOS>
<BOS>The grade of a tumor may be used to tell the difference between slowgrowing and fastgrowing types of the tumor.<EOS>
<BOS>The World Health Organization (WHO) tumor grades are based on how abnormal the cancer cells look under a microscope and how quickly the tumor is likely to grow and spread.<EOS>
<BOS>WHO Tumor Grading System Grade I (lowgrade) The tumor cells look more like normal cells under a microscope and grow and spread more slowly than grade II, III, and IV tumor cells.<EOS>
<BOS>They rarely spread into nearby tissues.<EOS>
<BOS>Grade I brain tumors may be cured if they are completely removed by surgery.<EOS>
<BOS>Grade II The tumor cells grow and spread more slowly than grade III and IV tumor cells.<EOS>
<BOS>They may spread into nearby tissue and may recur (come back).<EOS>
<BOS>Some tumors may become a highergrade tumor.<EOS>
<BOS>Grade III The tumor cells look very different from normal cells under a microscope and grow more quickly than grade I and II tumor cells.<EOS>
<BOS>They are likely to spread into nearby tissue.<EOS>
<BOS>Grade IV (highgrade) The tumor cells do not look like normal cells under a microscope and grow and spread very quickly.<EOS>
<BOS>There may be areas of dead cells in the tumor.<EOS>
<BOS>Grade IV tumors usually cannot be cured.<EOS>
<BOS>The following types of primary tumors can form in the brain or spinal cord: Astrocytic Tumors An astrocytic tumor begins in starshaped brain cells called astrocytes, which help keep nerve cells healthy.<EOS>
<BOS>An astrocyte is a type of glial cell.<EOS>
<BOS>Glial cells sometimes form tumors called gliomas.<EOS>
<BOS>Astrocytic tumors include the following: Brain stem glioma (usually high grade): A brain stem glioma forms in the brain stem, which is the part of the brain connected to the spinal cord.<EOS>
<BOS>It is often a highgrade tumor, which spreads widely through the brain stem and is hard to cure.<EOS>
<BOS>Brain stem gliomas are rare in adults.<EOS>
<BOS>(See the PDQ summary on Childhood Brain Stem Glioma Treatment for more information.<EOS>
<BOS>) Pineal astrocytic tumor (any grade): A pineal astrocytic tumor forms in tissue around the pineal gland and may be any grade.<EOS>
<BOS>The pineal gland is a tiny organ in the brain that makes melatonin, a hormone that helps control the sleeping and waking cycle.<EOS>
<BOS>Pilocytic astrocytoma (grade I): A pilocytic astrocytoma grows slowly in the brain or spinal cord.<EOS>
<BOS>It may be in the form of a cyst and rarely spreads into nearby tissues.<EOS>
<BOS>Pilocytic astrocytomas can often be cured.<EOS>
<BOS>Diffuse astrocytoma (grade II): A diffuse astrocytoma grows slowly, but often spreads into nearby tissues.<EOS>
<BOS>The tumor cells look something like normal cells.<EOS>
<BOS>In some cases, a diffuse astrocytoma can be cured.<EOS>
<BOS>It is also called a lowgrade diffuse astrocytoma.<EOS>
<BOS>Anaplastic astrocytoma (grade III): An anaplastic astrocytoma grows quickly and spreads into nearby tissues.<EOS>
<BOS>The tumor cells look different from normal cells.<EOS>
<BOS>This type of tumor usually cannot be cured.<EOS>
<BOS>An anaplastic astrocytoma is also called a malignant astrocytoma or highgrade astrocytoma.<EOS>
<BOS>Glioblastoma (grade IV): A glioblastoma grows and spreads very quickly.<EOS>
<BOS>The tumor cells look very different from normal cells.<EOS>
<BOS>This type of tumor usually cannot be cured.<EOS>
<BOS>It is also called glioblastoma multiforme.<EOS>
<BOS>See the PDQ summary on Childhood Astrocytomas Treatment for more information about astrocytomas in children.<EOS>
<BOS>Oligodendroglial Tumors An oligodendroglial tumor begins in brain cells called oligodendrocytes, which help keep nerve cells healthy.<EOS>
<BOS>An oligodendrocyte is a type of glial cell.<EOS>
<BOS>Oligodendrocytes sometimes form tumors called oligodendrogliomas.<EOS>
<BOS>Grades of oligodendroglial tumors include the following: Oligodendroglioma (grade II): An oligodendroglioma grows slowly, but often spreads into nearby tissues.<EOS>
<BOS>The tumor cells look something like normal cells.<EOS>
<BOS>In some cases, an oligodendroglioma can be cured.<EOS>
<BOS>Anaplastic oligodendroglioma (grade III): An anaplastic oligodendroglioma grows quickly and spreads into nearby tissues.<EOS>
<BOS>The tumor cells look different from normal cells.<EOS>
<BOS>This type of tumor usually cannot be cured.<EOS>
<BOS>See the PDQ summary on Childhood Astrocytomas Treatment for more information about oligodendroglial tumors in children.<EOS>
<BOS>Mixed Gliomas A mixed glioma is a brain tumor that has two types of tumor cells in it oligodendrocytes and astrocytes.<EOS>
<BOS>This type of mixed tumor is called an oligoastrocytoma.<EOS>
<BOS>Oligoastrocytoma (grade II): An oligoastrocytoma is a slowgrowing tumor.<EOS>
<BOS>The tumor cells look something like normal cells.<EOS>
<BOS>In some cases, an oligoastrocytoma can be cured.<EOS>
<BOS>Anaplastic oligoastrocytoma (grade III): An anaplastic oligoastrocytoma grows quickly and spreads into nearby tissues.<EOS>
<BOS>The tumor cells look different from normal cells.<EOS>
<BOS>This type of tumor has a worse prognosis than oligoastrocytoma (grade II).<EOS>
<BOS>See the PDQ summary on Childhood Astrocytomas Treatment for more information about mixed gliomas in children.<EOS>
<BOS>Ependymal Tumors An ependymal tumor usually begins in cells that line the fluid filled spaces in the brain and around the spinal cord.<EOS>
<BOS>An ependymal tumor may also be called an ependymoma.<EOS>
<BOS>Grades of ependymomas include the following: Ependymoma (grade I or II): A grade I or II ependymoma grows slowly and has cells that look something like normal cells.<EOS>
<BOS>There are two types of grade I ependymoma myxopapillary ependymoma and subependymoma.<EOS>
<BOS>A grade II ependymoma grows in a ventricle (fluidfilled space in the brain) and its connecting paths or in the spinal cord.<EOS>
<BOS>In some cases, a grade I or II ependymoma can be cured.<EOS>
<BOS>Anaplastic ependymoma (grade III): An anaplastic ependymoma grows quickly and spreads into nearby tissues.<EOS>
<BOS>The tumor cells look different from normal cells.<EOS>
<BOS>This type of tumor usually has a worse prognosis than a grade I or II ependymoma.<EOS>
<BOS>See the PDQ summary on Childhood Ependymoma Treatment for more information about ependymoma in children.<EOS>
<BOS>Medulloblastomas A medulloblastoma is a type of embryonal tumor.<EOS>
<BOS>Medulloblastomas are most common in children or young adults.<EOS>
<BOS>See the PDQ summary on Childhood Central Nervous System Embryonal Tumors Treatment for more information about medulloblastomas in children.<EOS>
<BOS>Pineal Parenchymal Tumors A pineal parenchymal tumor forms in parenchymal cells or pineocytes, which are the cells that make up most of the pineal gland.<EOS>
<BOS>These tumors are different from pineal astrocytic tumors.<EOS>
<BOS>Grades of pineal parenchymal tumors include the following: Pineocytoma (grade II): A pineocytoma is a slowgrowing pineal tumor.<EOS>
<BOS>Pineoblastoma (grade IV): A pineoblastoma is a rare tumor that is very likely to spread.<EOS>
<BOS>See the PDQ summary on Childhood Central Nervous System Embryonal Tumors Treatment for more information about pineal parenchymal tumors in children.<EOS>
<BOS>Meningeal Tumors A meningeal tumor, also called a meningioma, forms in the meninges (thin layers of tissue that cover the brain and spinal cord).<EOS>
<BOS>It can form from different types of brain or spinal cord cells.<EOS>
<BOS>Meningiomas are most common in adults.<EOS>
<BOS>Types of meningeal tumors include the following: Meningioma (grade I): A grade I meningioma is the most common type of meningeal tumor.<EOS>
<BOS>A grade I meningioma is a slowgrowing tumor.<EOS>
<BOS>It forms most often in the dura mater.<EOS>
<BOS>A grade I meningioma can be cured if it is completely removed by surgery.<EOS>
<BOS>Meningioma (grade II and III): This is a rare meningeal tumor.<EOS>
<BOS>It grows quickly and is likely to spread within the brain and spinal cord.<EOS>
<BOS>The prognosis is worse than a grade I meningioma because the tumor usually cannot be completely removed by surgery.<EOS>
<BOS>A hemangiopericytoma is not a meningeal tumor but is treated like a grade II or III meningioma.<EOS>
<BOS>A hemangiopericytoma usually forms in the dura mater.<EOS>
<BOS>The prognosis is worse than a grade I meningioma because the tumor usually cannot be completely removed by surgery.<EOS>
<BOS>Germ Cell Tumors A germ cell tumor forms in germ cells, which are the cells that develop into sperm in men or ova (eggs) in women.<EOS>
<BOS>There are different types of germ cell tumors.<EOS>
<BOS>These include germinomas, teratomas, embryonal yolk sac carcinomas, and choriocarcinomas.<EOS>
<BOS>Germ cell tumors can be either benign or malignant.<EOS>
<BOS>See the PDQ summary on Childhood Central Nervous System Germ Cell Tumors Treatment for more information about childhood germ cell tumors in the brain.<EOS>
<BOS>Craniopharyngioma (Grade I) A craniopharyngioma is a rare tumor that usually forms in the center of the brain just above the pituitary gland (a peasized organ at the bottom of the brain that controls other glands).<EOS>
<BOS>Craniopharyngiomas can form from different types of brain or spinal cord cells.<EOS>
<BOS>See the PDQ summary on Childhood Craniopharyngioma Treatment for more information about craniopharyngioma in children.<EOS>
<BOS>New types of treatment are being tested in clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>This summary section describes treatments that are being studied in clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>It may not mention every new treatment being studied.<EOS>
<BOS>Information about clinical trials is available from the NCI website.<EOS>
<BOS>Chemotherapy Chemotherapy is a cancer treatment that uses drugs to stop the growth of cancer cells, either by killing the cells or by stopping the cells from dividing.<EOS>
<BOS>When chemotherapy is taken by mouth or injected into a vein or muscle, the drugs enter the bloodstream and can reach cancer cells throughout the body (systemic chemotherapy).<EOS>
<BOS>When chemotherapy is placed directly into the cerebrospinal fluid, an organ, or a body cavity such as the abdomen, the drugs mainly affect cancer cells in those areas (regional chemotherapy).<EOS>
<BOS>The way the chemotherapy is given depends on the type and stage of the cancer being treated.<EOS>
<BOS>Hyperfractionated radiation therapy Hyperfractionated radiation therapy is radiation treatment in which the total dose of radiation is divided into small doses and the treatments are given more than once a day.<EOS>
<BOS>Hyperthermia therapy Hyperthermia therapy is a treatment in which body tissue is heated above normal temperature to damage and kill cancer cells or to make cancer cells more sensitive to the effects of radiation and certain anticancer drugs.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients may want to think about taking part in a clinical trial.<EOS>
<BOS>For some patients, taking part in a clinical trial may be the best treatment choice.<EOS>
<BOS>Clinical trials are part of the cancer research process.<EOS>
<BOS>Clinical trials are done to find out if new cancer treatments are safe and effective or better than the standard treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Many of today's standard treatments for cancer are based on earlier clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients who take part in a clinical trial may receive the standard treatment or be among the first to receive a new treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients who take part in clinical trials also help improve the way cancer will be treated in the future.<EOS>
<BOS>Even when clinical trials do not lead to effective new treatments, they often answer important questions and help move research forward.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients can enter clinical trials before, during, or after starting their cancer treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Some clinical trials only include patients who have not yet received treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Other trials test treatments for patients whose cancer has not gotten better.<EOS>
<BOS>There are also clinical trials that test new ways to stop cancer from recurring (coming back) or reduce the side effects of cancer treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Clinical trials are taking place in many parts of the country.<EOS>
<BOS>See the Treatment Options section that follows for links to current treatment clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>These have been retrieved from NCI's listing of clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>Signs and symptoms of ovarian low malignant potential tumor include pain or swelling in the abdomen.<EOS>
<BOS>Ovarian low malignant potential tumor may not cause early signs or symptoms.<EOS>
<BOS>If you do have signs or symptoms, they may include the following: Pain or swelling in the abdomen.<EOS>
<BOS>Pain in the pelvis.<EOS>
<BOS>Gastrointestinal problems, such as gas, bloating, or constipation.<EOS>
<BOS>These signs and symptoms may be caused by other conditions.<EOS>
<BOS>If they get worse or do not go away on their own, check with your doctor.<EOS>
<BOS>Signs and symptoms of adult primary liver cancer include a lump or pain on the right side.<EOS>
<BOS>These and other signs and symptoms may be caused by adult primary liver cancer or by other conditions.<EOS>
<BOS>Check with your doctor if you have any of the following: A hard lump on the right side just below the rib cage.<EOS>
<BOS>Discomfort in the upper abdomen on the right side.<EOS>
<BOS>A swollen abdomen.<EOS>
<BOS>Pain near the right shoulder blade or in the back.<EOS>
<BOS>Jaundice (yellowing of the skin and whites of the eyes).<EOS>
<BOS>Easy bruising or bleeding.<EOS>
<BOS>Unusual tiredness or weakness.<EOS>
<BOS>Nausea and vomiting.<EOS>
<BOS>Loss of appetite or feelings of fullness after eating a small meal.<EOS>
<BOS>Weight loss for no known reason.<EOS>
<BOS>Pale, chalky bowel movements and dark urine.<EOS>
<BOS>Fever.<EOS>
<BOS>Tests that examine the breasts are used to detect (find) and diagnose breast cancer in men.<EOS>
<BOS>The following tests and procedures may be used: Physical exam and history : An exam of the body to check general signs of health, including checking for signs of disease, such as lumps or anything else that seems unusual.<EOS>
<BOS>A history of the patients health habits and past illnesses and treatments will also be taken.<EOS>
<BOS>Clinical breast exam (CBE): An exam of the breast by a doctor or other health professional.<EOS>
<BOS>The doctor will carefully feel the breasts and under the arms for lumps or anything else that seems unusual.<EOS>
<BOS>Ultrasound exam: A procedure in which highenergy sound waves (ultrasound) are bounced off internal tissues or organs and make echoes.<EOS>
<BOS>The echoes form a picture of body tissues called a sonogram.<EOS>
<BOS>The picture can be printed to be looked at later.<EOS>
<BOS>MRI (magnetic resonance imaging): A procedure that uses a magnet, radio waves, and a computer to make a series of detailed pictures of areas inside the body.<EOS>
<BOS>This procedure is also called nuclear magnetic resonance imaging (NMRI).<EOS>
<BOS>Blood chemistry studies : A procedure in which a blood sample is checked to measure the amounts of certain substances released into the blood by organs and tissues in the body.<EOS>
<BOS>An unusual (higher or lower than normal) amount of a substance can be a sign of disease.<EOS>
<BOS>Biopsy : The removal of cells or tissues so they can be viewed under a microscope by a pathologist to check for signs of cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>The following are different types of biopsies: Fineneedle aspiration (FNA) biopsy : The removal of tissue or fluid using a thin needle.<EOS>
<BOS>Core biopsy : The removal of tissue using a wide needle.<EOS>
<BOS>Excisional biopsy : The removal of an entire lump of tissue.<EOS>
<BOS>If cancer is found, tests are done to study the cancer cells.<EOS>
<BOS>Decisions about the best treatment are based on the results of these tests.<EOS>
<BOS>The tests give information about: How quickly the cancer may grow.<EOS>
<BOS>How likely it is that the cancer will spread through the body.<EOS>
<BOS>How well certain treatments might work.<EOS>
<BOS>How likely the cancer is to recur (come back).<EOS>
<BOS>Tests include the following: Estrogen and progesterone receptor test : A test to measure the amount of estrogen and progesterone (hormones) receptors in cancer tissue.<EOS>
<BOS>If cancer is found in the breast, tissue from the tumor is checked in the laboratory to find out whether estrogen and progesterone could affect the way cancer grows.<EOS>
<BOS>The test results show whether hormone therapy may stop the cancer from growing.<EOS>
<BOS>HER2 test: A test to measure the amount of HER2 in cancer tissue.<EOS>
<BOS>HER2 is a growth factor protein that sends growth signals to cells.<EOS>
<BOS>When cancer forms, the cells may make too much of the protein, causing more cancer cells to grow.<EOS>
<BOS>If cancer is found in the breast, tissue from the tumor is checked in the laboratory to find out if there is too much HER2 in the cells.<EOS>
<BOS>The test results show whether monoclonal antibody therapy may stop the cancer from growing.<EOS>
<BOS>Certain factors affect prognosis (chance of recovery).<EOS>
<BOS>The prognosis (chance of recovery) depends on the following: Whether there are any cancer cells left after surgery.<EOS>
<BOS>The type of tumor.<EOS>
<BOS>Where the tumor is in the body.<EOS>
<BOS>The child's age.<EOS>
<BOS>Whether the tumor has just been diagnosed or has recurred (come back).<EOS>
<BOS>Tests that examine the prostate and blood are used to detect (find) and diagnose prostate cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>The following tests and procedures may be used: Physical exam and history : An exam of the body to check general signs of health, including checking for signs of disease, such as lumps or anything else that seems unusual.<EOS>
<BOS>A history of the patients health habits and past illnesses and treatments will also be taken.<EOS>
<BOS>Digital rectal exam (DRE): An exam of the rectum.<EOS>
<BOS>The doctor or nurse inserts a lubricated, gloved finger into the rectum and feels the prostate through the rectal wall for lumps or abnormal areas.<EOS>
<BOS>Prostatespecific antigen (PSA) test : A test that measures the level of PSA in the blood.<EOS>
<BOS>PSA is a substance made by the prostate that may be found in an increased amount in the blood of men who have prostate cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>PSA levels may also be high in men who have an infection or inflammation of the prostate or BPH (an enlarged, but noncancerous, prostate).<EOS>
<BOS>Transrectal ultrasound : A procedure in which a probe that is about the size of a finger is inserted into the rectum to check the prostate.<EOS>
<BOS>The probe is used to bounce highenergy sound waves (ultrasound) off internal tissues or organs and make echoes.<EOS>
