<BOS>The echoes form a picture of body tissues called a sonogram.<EOS>
<BOS>Transrectal ultrasound may be used during a biopsy procedure.<EOS>
<BOS>Transrectal magnetic resonance imaging (MRI): A procedure that uses a strong magnet, radio waves, and a computer to make a series of detailed pictures of areas inside the body.<EOS>
<BOS>A probe that gives off radio waves is inserted into the rectum near the prostate.<EOS>
<BOS>This helps the MRI machine make clearer pictures of the prostate and nearby tissue.<EOS>
<BOS>A transrectal MRI is done to find out if the cancer has spread outside the prostate into nearby tissues.<EOS>
<BOS>This procedure is also called nuclear magnetic resonance imaging (NMRI).<EOS>
<BOS>Biopsy: The removal of cells or tissues so they can be viewed under a microscope by a pathologist.<EOS>
<BOS>The pathologist will check the tissue sample to see if there are cancer cells and find out the Gleason score.<EOS>
<BOS>The Gleason score ranges from 210 and describes how likely it is that a tumor will spread.<EOS>
<BOS>The lower the number, the less likely the tumor is to spread.<EOS>
<BOS>A transrectal biopsy is used to diagnose prostate cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>A transrectal biopsy is the removal of tissue from the prostate by inserting a thin needle through the rectum and into the prostate.<EOS>
<BOS>This procedure is usually done using transrectal ultrasound to help guide where samples of tissue are taken from.<EOS>
<BOS>A pathologist views the tissue under a microscope to look for cancer cells.<EOS>
<BOS>Diagnostic tests and a biopsy are used to detect (find) and diagnose childhood rhabdomyosarcoma.<EOS>
<BOS>The diagnostic tests that are done depend in part on where the cancer forms.<EOS>
<BOS>The following tests and procedures may be used: Physical exam and history : An exam of the body to check general signs of health, including checking for signs of disease, such as lumps or anything else that seems unusual.<EOS>
<BOS>A history of the patients health habits and past illnesses and treatments will also be taken.<EOS>
<BOS>Xray : An xray of the organs and bones inside the body, such as the chest.<EOS>
<BOS>An xray is a type of energy beam that can go through the body and onto film, making a picture of areas inside the body.<EOS>
<BOS>CT scan (CAT scan): A procedure that makes a series of detailed pictures of areas inside the body, such as the abdomen, pelvis, or lymph nodes, taken from different angles.<EOS>
<BOS>The pictures are made by a computer linked to an xray machine.<EOS>
<BOS>A dye may be injected into a vein or swallowed to help the organs or tissues show up more clearly.<EOS>
<BOS>This procedure is also called computed tomography, computerized tomography, or computerized axial tomography.<EOS>
<BOS>MRI (magnetic resonance imaging): A procedure that uses a magnet, radio waves, and a computer to make a series of detailed pictures of areas of the body, such as the skull, brain, and lymph nodes.<EOS>
<BOS>This procedure is also called nuclear magnetic resonance imaging (NMRI).<EOS>
<BOS>PET scan (positron emission tomography scan): A procedure to find malignant tumor cells in the body.<EOS>
<BOS>A small amount of radioactive glucose (sugar) is injected into a vein.<EOS>
<BOS>The PET scanner rotates around the body and makes a picture of where glucose is being used in the body.<EOS>
<BOS>Malignant tumor cells show up brighter in the picture because they are more active and take up more glucose than normal cells do.<EOS>
<BOS>Bone scan : A procedure to check if there are rapidly dividing cells, such as cancer cells, in the bone.<EOS>
<BOS>A very small amount of radioactive material is injected into a vein and travels through the bloodstream.<EOS>
<BOS>The radioactive material collects in the bones with cancer and is detected by a scanner.<EOS>
<BOS>Bone marrow aspiration and biopsy : The removal of bone marrow, blood, and a small piece of bone by inserting a hollow needle into the hipbone.<EOS>
<BOS>Samples are removed from both hipbones.<EOS>
<BOS>A pathologist views the bone marrow, blood, and bone under a microscope to look for signs of cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Lumbar puncture : A procedure used to collect cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) from the spinal column.<EOS>
<BOS>This is done by placing a needle between two bones in the spine and into the CSF around the spinal cord and removing a sample of the fluid.<EOS>
<BOS>The sample of CSF is checked under a microscope for signs of cancer cells.<EOS>
<BOS>This procedure is also called an LP or spinal tap.<EOS>
<BOS>If these tests show there may be a rhabdomyosarcoma, a biopsy is done.<EOS>
<BOS>A biopsy is the removal of cells or tissues so they can be viewed under a microscope by a pathologist to check for signs of cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Because treatment depends on the type of rhabdomyosarcoma, biopsy samples should be checked by a pathologist who has experience in diagnosing rhabdomyosarcoma.<EOS>
<BOS>One of the following types of biopsies may be used: Fineneedle aspiration (FNA) biopsy : The removal of tissue or fluid using a thin needle.<EOS>
<BOS>Core needle biopsy : The removal of tissue using a wide needle.<EOS>
<BOS>This procedure may be guided using ultrasound, CT scan, or MRI.<EOS>
<BOS>Open biopsy : The removal of tissue through an incision (cut) made in the skin.<EOS>
<BOS>Sentinel lymph node biopsy : The removal of the sentinel lymph node during surgery.<EOS>
<BOS>The sentinel lymph node is the first lymph node to receive lymphatic drainage from a tumor.<EOS>
<BOS>It is the first lymph node the cancer is likely to spread to from the tumor.<EOS>
<BOS>A radioactive substance and/or blue dye is injected near the tumor.<EOS>
<BOS>The substance or dye flows through the lymph ducts to the lymph nodes.<EOS>
<BOS>The first lymph node to receive the substance or dye is removed.<EOS>
<BOS>A pathologist views the tissue under a microscope to look for cancer cells.<EOS>
<BOS>If cancer cells are not found, it may not be necessary to remove more lymph nodes.<EOS>
<BOS>The following tests may be done on the sample of tissue that is removed: Light microscopy: A laboratory test in which cells in a sample of tissue are viewed under regular and highpowered microscopes to look for certain changes in the cells.<EOS>
<BOS>Immunohistochemistry : A test that uses antibodies to check for certain antigens in a sample of tissue.<EOS>
<BOS>The antibody is usually linked to a radioactive substance or a dye that causes the tissue to light up under a microscope.<EOS>
<BOS>This type of test may be used to tell the difference between different types of cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>FISH (fluorescence in situ hybridization): A laboratory test used to look at genes or chromosomes in cells and tissues.<EOS>
<BOS>Pieces of DNA that contain a fluorescent dye are made in the laboratory and added to cells or tissues on a glass slide.<EOS>
<BOS>When these pieces of DNA attach to certain genes or areas of chromosomes on the slide, they light up when viewed under a microscope with a special light.<EOS>
<BOS>This type of test is used to find certain gene changes.<EOS>
<BOS>Reverse transcriptionpolymerase chain reaction (RTPCR) test: A laboratory test in which cells in a sample of tissue are studied using chemicals to look for certain changes in the structure or function of genes.<EOS>
<BOS>Cytogenetic analysis : A laboratory test in which cells in a sample of tissue are viewed under a microscope to look for certain changes in the chromosomes.<EOS>
<BOS>Key Points After neuroblastoma has been diagnosed, tests are done to find out if cancer has spread from where it started to other parts of the body.<EOS>
<BOS>There are three ways that cancer spreads in the body.<EOS>
<BOS>Cancer may spread from where it began to other parts of the body.<EOS>
<BOS>The following stages are used for neuroblastoma: Stage 1 Stage 2 Stage 3 Stage 4 Treatment of neuroblastoma is based on risk groups.<EOS>
<BOS>After neuroblastoma has been diagnosed, tests are done to find out if cancer has spread from where it started to other parts of the body.<EOS>
<BOS>The process used to find out the extent or spread of cancer is called staging.<EOS>
<BOS>The information gathered from the staging process helps determine the stage of the disease.<EOS>
<BOS>For neuroblastoma, the stage of disease affects whether the cancer is low risk, intermediate risk, or high risk.<EOS>
<BOS>It also affects the treatment plan.<EOS>
<BOS>The results of some tests and procedures used to diagnose neuroblastoma may be used for staging.<EOS>
<BOS>See the General Information section for a description of these tests and procedures.<EOS>
<BOS>The following tests and procedures also may be used to determine the stage: Lymph node biopsy : The removal of all or part of a lymph node.<EOS>
<BOS>A pathologist views the tissue under a microscope to look for cancer cells.<EOS>
<BOS>One of the following types of biopsies may be done: Excisional biopsy : The removal of an entire lymph node.<EOS>
<BOS>Incisional biopsy : The removal of part of a lymph node.<EOS>
<BOS>Core biopsy : The removal of tissue from a lymph node using a wide needle.<EOS>
<BOS>Fineneedle aspiration (FNA) biopsy : The removal of tissue or fluid from a lymph node using a thin needle.<EOS>
<BOS>Xray of the bone: An xray is a type of energy beam that can go through the body and onto film, making a picture of areas inside the body.<EOS>
<BOS>Bone scan : A procedure to check if there are rapidly dividing cells, such as cancer cells, in the bone.<EOS>
<BOS>A very small amount of radioactive material is injected into a vein and travels through the bloodstream.<EOS>
<BOS>The radioactive material collects in the bones with cancer and is detected by a scanner.<EOS>
<BOS>PET scan (positron emission tomography scan): A procedure to find malignant tumor cells in the body.<EOS>
<BOS>A small amount of radioactive glucose (sugar) is injected into a vein.<EOS>
<BOS>The PET scanner rotates around the body and makes a picture of where glucose is being used in the body.<EOS>
<BOS>Malignant tumor cells show up brighter in the picture because they are more active and take up more glucose than normal cells do.<EOS>
<BOS>There are three ways that cancer spreads in the body.<EOS>
<BOS>Cancer can spread through tissue, the lymph system, and the blood: Tissue.<EOS>
<BOS>The cancer spreads from where it began by growing into nearby areas.<EOS>
<BOS>Lymph system.<EOS>
<BOS>The cancer spreads from where it began by getting into the lymph system.<EOS>
<BOS>The cancer travels through the lymph vessels to other parts of the body.<EOS>
<BOS>Blood.<EOS>
<BOS>The cancer spreads from where it began by getting into the blood.<EOS>
<BOS>The cancer travels through the blood vessels to other parts of the body.<EOS>
<BOS>Cancer may spread from where it began to other parts of the body.<EOS>
<BOS>When cancer spreads to another part of the body, it is called metastasis.<EOS>
<BOS>Cancer cells break away from where they began (the primary tumor) and travel through the lymph system or blood.<EOS>
<BOS>Lymph system.<EOS>
<BOS>The cancer gets into the lymph system, travels through the lymph vessels, and forms a tumor (metastatic tumor) in another part of the body.<EOS>
<BOS>Blood.<EOS>
<BOS>The cancer gets into the blood, travels through the blood vessels, and forms a tumor (metastatic tumor) in another part of the body.<EOS>
<BOS>The metastatic tumor is the same type of cancer as the primary tumor.<EOS>
<BOS>For example, if neuroblastoma spreads to the liver, the cancer cells in the liver are actually neuroblastoma cells.<EOS>
<BOS>The disease is metastatic neuroblastoma, not liver cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>The following stages are used for neuroblastoma: Stage 1 In stage 1, the tumor is in only one area and all of the tumor that can be seen is completely removed during surgery.<EOS>
<BOS>Stage 2 Stage 2 is divided into stages 2A and 2B.<EOS>
<BOS>Stage 2A: The tumor is in only one area and all of the tumor that can be seen cannot be completely removed during surgery.<EOS>
<BOS>Stage 2B: The tumor is in only one area and all of the tumor that can be seen may be completely removed during surgery.<EOS>
<BOS>Cancer cells are found in the lymph nodes near the tumor.<EOS>
<BOS>Stage 3 In stage 3, one of the following is true: the tumor cannot be completely removed during surgery and has spread from one side of the body to the other side and may also have spread to nearby lymph nodes; or the tumor is in only one area, on one side of the body, but has spread to lymph nodes on the other side of the body; or the tumor is in the middle of the body and has spread to tissues or lymph nodes on both sides of the body, and the tumor cannot be removed by surgery.<EOS>
<BOS>Stage 4 Stage 4 is divided into stages 4 and 4S.<EOS>
<BOS>In stage 4, the tumor has spread to distant lymph nodes or other parts of the body.<EOS>
<BOS>In stage 4S: the child is younger than 12 months; and the cancer has spread to the skin, liver, and/or bone marrow; and the tumor is in only one area and all of the tumor that can be seen may be completely removed during surgery; and/or cancer cells may be found in the lymph nodes near the tumor.<EOS>
<BOS>Treatment of neuroblastoma is based on risk groups.<EOS>
<BOS>For many types of cancer, stages are used to plan treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>For neuroblastoma, treatment depends on risk groups.<EOS>
<BOS>The stage of neuroblastoma is one factor used to determine risk group.<EOS>
<BOS>Other factors are the age of the child, tumor histology, and tumor biology.<EOS>
<BOS>There are three risk groups: low risk, intermediate risk, and high risk.<EOS>
<BOS>Lowrisk and intermediaterisk neuroblastoma have a good chance of being cured.<EOS>
<BOS>Highrisk neuroblastoma may be hard to cure.<EOS>
<BOS>Treatment of chronic eosinophilic leukemia may include the following: Bone marrow transplant.<EOS>
<BOS>Biologic therapy using interferon alfa.<EOS>
<BOS>A clinical trial of a new treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Check the list of NCIsupported cancer clinical trials that are now accepting patients with chronic eosinophilic leukemia.<EOS>
<BOS>For more specific results, refine the search by using other search features, such as the location of the trial, the type of treatment, or the name of the drug.<EOS>
<BOS>Talk with your doctor about clinical trials that may be right for you.<EOS>
<BOS>General information about clinical trials is available from the NCI website.<EOS>
<BOS>Tests that examine the blood, bone marrow, and lymph nodes are used to detect (find) and diagnose chronic lymphocytic leukemia.<EOS>
<BOS>The following tests and procedures may be used: Physical exam and history : An exam of the body to check general signs of health, including checking for signs of disease, such as lumps or anything else that seems unusual.<EOS>
<BOS>A history of the patients health habits and past illnesses and treatments will also be taken.<EOS>
<BOS>Complete blood count (CBC) with differential : A procedure in which a sample of blood is drawn and checked for the following: The number of red blood cells and platelets.<EOS>
<BOS>The number and type of white blood cells.<EOS>
<BOS>The amount of hemoglobin (the protein that carries oxygen) in the red blood cells.<EOS>
<BOS>The portion of the blood sample made up of red blood cells.<EOS>
<BOS>Immunophenotyping : A laboratory test in which the antigens or markers on the surface of a blood or bone marrow cell are checked to see if they are lymphocytes or myeloid cells.<EOS>
<BOS>If the cells are malignant lymphocytes (cancer), they are checked to see if they are B lymphocytes or T lymphocytes.<EOS>
<BOS>FISH (fluorescence in situ hybridization): A laboratory technique used to look at genes or chromosomes in cells and tissues.<EOS>
<BOS>Pieces of DNA that contain a fluorescent dye are made in the laboratory and added to cells or tissues on a glass slide.<EOS>
<BOS>When these pieces of DNA bind to specific genes or areas of chromosomes on the slide, they light up when viewed under a microscope with a special light.<EOS>
<BOS>Flow cytometry : A laboratory test that measures the number of cells in a sample, the percentage of live cells in a sample, and certain characteristics of cells, such as size, shape, and the presence of tumor markers on the cell surface.<EOS>
<BOS>The cells are stained with a lightsensitive dye, placed in a fluid, and passed in a stream before a laser or other type of light.<EOS>
<BOS>The measurements are based on how the lightsensitive dye reacts to the light.<EOS>
<BOS>IgVH gene mutation test: A laboratory test done on a bone marrow or blood sample to check for an IgVH gene mutation.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients with an IgVH gene mutation have a better prognosis.<EOS>
<BOS>Bone marrow aspiration and biopsy : The removal of bone marrow, blood, and a small piece of bone by inserting a hollow needle into the hipbone or breastbone.<EOS>
<BOS>A pathologist views the bone marrow, blood, and bone under a microscope to look for abnormal cells.<EOS>
<BOS>Tests that examine the throat and neck are used to help detect (find) and diagnose hypopharyngeal cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>The following tests and procedures may be used: Physical exam of the throat: An exam in which the doctor feels for swollen lymph nodes in the neck and looks down the throat with a small, longhandled mirror to check for abnormal areas.<EOS>
<BOS>CT scan (CAT scan): A procedure that makes a series of detailed pictures of areas inside the body, taken from different angles.<EOS>
<BOS>The pictures are made by a computer linked to an xray machine.<EOS>
<BOS>A dye may be injected into a vein or swallowed to help the organs or tissues show up more clearly.<EOS>
<BOS>This procedure is also called computed tomography, computerized tomography, or computerized axial tomography.<EOS>
<BOS>PET scan (positron emission tomography scan): A procedure to find malignant tumor cells in the body.<EOS>
<BOS>A small amount of radioactive glucose (sugar) is injected into a vein.<EOS>
<BOS>The PET scanner rotates around the body and makes a picture of where glucose is being used in the body.<EOS>
<BOS>Malignant tumor cells show up brighter in the picture because they are more active and take up more glucose than normal cells do.<EOS>
<BOS>A PET scan and CT scan may be done at the same time.<EOS>
<BOS>This is called a PETCT.<EOS>
<BOS>MRI (magnetic resonance imaging): A procedure that uses a magnet, radio waves, and a computer to make a series of detailed pictures of areas inside the body.<EOS>
<BOS>This procedure is also called nuclear magnetic resonance imaging (NMRI).<EOS>
<BOS>Bone scan : A procedure to check if there are rapidly dividing cells, such as cancer cells, in the bone.<EOS>
<BOS>A very small amount of radioactive material is injected into a vein and travels through the bloodstream.<EOS>
<BOS>The radioactive material collects in the bones and is detected by a scanner.<EOS>
<BOS>Barium esophagogram: An xray of the esophagus.<EOS>
<BOS>The patient drinks a liquid that contains barium (a silverwhite metallic compound).<EOS>
<BOS>The liquid coats the esophagus and xrays are taken.<EOS>
<BOS>Endoscopy : A procedure used to look at areas in the throat that cannot be seen with a mirror during the physical exam of the throat.<EOS>
<BOS>An endoscope (a thin, lighted tube) is inserted through the nose or mouth to check the throat for anything that seems unusual.<EOS>
<BOS>Tissue samples may be taken for biopsy.<EOS>
<BOS>Esophagoscopy : A procedure to look inside the esophagus to check for abnormal areas.<EOS>
<BOS>An esophagoscope (a thin, lighted tube) is inserted through the mouth or nose and down the throat into the esophagus.<EOS>
<BOS>Tissue samples may be taken for biopsy.<EOS>
<BOS>Bronchoscopy : A procedure to look inside the trachea and large airways in the lung for abnormal areas.<EOS>
<BOS>A bronchoscope (a thin, lighted tube) is inserted through the nose or mouth into the trachea and lungs.<EOS>
<BOS>Tissue samples may be taken for biopsy.<EOS>
<BOS>Biopsy: The removal of cells or tissues so they can be viewed under a microscope to check for signs of cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Signs and symptoms of chronic eosinophilic leukemia include fever and feeling very tired.<EOS>
<BOS>Chronic eosinophilic leukemia may not cause early signs or symptoms.<EOS>
<BOS>It may be found during a routine blood test.<EOS>
<BOS>Signs and symptoms may be caused by chronic eosinophilic leukemia or by other conditions.<EOS>
<BOS>Check with your doctor if you have any of the following: Fever.<EOS>
<BOS>Feeling very tired.<EOS>
<BOS>Cough.<EOS>
<BOS>Swelling under the skin around the eyes and lips, in the throat, or on the hands and feet.<EOS>
<BOS>Muscle pain.<EOS>
<BOS>Itching.<EOS>
<BOS>Diarrhea.<EOS>
<BOS>Key Points The results of diagnostic and staging tests are used to find out if cancer cells have spread.<EOS>
<BOS>There are three ways that cancer spreads in the body.<EOS>
<BOS>Cancer may spread from where it began to other parts of the body.<EOS>
<BOS>Stages are used to describe the different types of bile duct cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Intrahepatic bile duct cancer Perihilar bile duct cancer Distal extrahepatic bile duct cancer The following groups are used to plan treatment: Resectable (localized) bile duct cancer Unresectable, metastatic, or recurrent bile duct cancer The results of diagnostic and staging tests are used to find out if cancer cells have spread.<EOS>
<BOS>The process used to find out if cancer has spread to other parts of the body is called staging.<EOS>
<BOS>For bile duct cancer, the information gathered from tests and procedures is used to plan treatment, including whether the tumor can be removed by surgery.<EOS>
<BOS>There are three ways that cancer spreads in the body.<EOS>
<BOS>Cancer can spread through tissue, the lymph system, and the blood: Tissue.<EOS>
<BOS>The cancer spreads from where it began by growing into nearby areas.<EOS>
<BOS>Lymph system.<EOS>
<BOS>The cancer spreads from where it began by getting into the lymph system.<EOS>
<BOS>The cancer travels through the lymph vessels to other parts of the body.<EOS>
<BOS>Blood.<EOS>
<BOS>The cancer spreads from where it began by getting into the blood.<EOS>
<BOS>The cancer travels through the blood vessels to other parts of the body.<EOS>
<BOS>Cancer may spread from where it began to other parts of the body.<EOS>
<BOS>When cancer spreads to another part of the body, it is called metastasis.<EOS>
<BOS>Cancer cells break away from where they began (the primary tumor) and travel through the lymph system or blood.<EOS>
<BOS>Lymph system.<EOS>
<BOS>The cancer gets into the lymph system, travels through the lymph vessels, and forms a tumor (metastatic tumor) in another part of the body.<EOS>
<BOS>Blood.<EOS>
<BOS>The cancer gets into the blood, travels through the blood vessels, and forms a tumor (metastatic tumor) in another part of the body.<EOS>
<BOS>The metastatic tumor is the same type of cancer as the primary tumor.<EOS>
<BOS>For example, if bile duct cancer spreads to the liver, the cancer cells in the liver are actually bile duct cancer cells.<EOS>
<BOS>The disease is metastatic bile duct cancer, not liver cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Stages are used to describe the different types of bile duct cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Intrahepatic bile duct cancer Stage 0: Abnormal cells are found in the innermost layer of tissue lining the intrahepatic bile duct.<EOS>
<BOS>These abnormal cells may become cancer and spread into nearby normal tissue.<EOS>
<BOS>Stage 0 is also called carcinoma in situ.<EOS>
<BOS>Stage I: There is one tumor that has spread into the intrahepatic bile duct and it has not spread into any blood vessels.<EOS>
<BOS>Stage II: There is one tumor that has spread through the wall of the bile duct and into a blood vessel, or there are multiple tumors that may have spread into a blood vessel.<EOS>
<BOS>Stage III: The tumor has spread through the tissue that lines the abdominal wall or has spread to organs or tissues near the liver such as the duodenum, colon, and stomach.<EOS>
<BOS>Stage IV: Stage IV is divided into stage IVA and stage IVB.<EOS>
<BOS>Stage IVA: The cancer has spread along the outside of the intrahepatic bile ducts or the cancer has spread to nearby lymph nodes.<EOS>
<BOS>Stage IVB: The cancer has spread to organs in other parts of the body.<EOS>
<BOS>Perihilar bile duct cancer Stage 0: Abnormal cells are found in the innermost layer of tissue lining the perihilar bile duct.<EOS>
<BOS>These abnormal cells may become cancer and spread into nearby normal tissue.<EOS>
<BOS>Stage 0 is also called carcinoma in situ.<EOS>
<BOS>Stage I: Cancer has formed in the innermost layer of the wall of the perihilar bile duct and has spread into the muscle layer or fibrous tissue layer of the wall.<EOS>
<BOS>Stage II: Cancer has spread through the wall of the perihilar bile duct to nearby fatty tissue or to the liver.<EOS>
<BOS>Stage III: Stage III is divided into stage IIIA and stage IIIB.<EOS>
<BOS>Stage IIIA: Cancer has spread to branches on one side of the hepatic artery or of the portal vein.<EOS>
<BOS>Stage IIIB: Cancer has spread to nearby lymph nodes.<EOS>
<BOS>Cancer may have spread into the wall of the perihilar bile duct or through the wall to nearby fatty tissue, the liver, or to branches on one side of the hepatic artery or of the portal vein.<EOS>
<BOS>Stage IV: Stage IV is divided into stage IVA and stage IVB.<EOS>
<BOS>Stage IVA: Cancer has spread to one or more of the following: the main part of the portal vein and/or common hepatic artery; the branches of the portal vein and/or common hepatic artery on both sides; the right hepatic duct and the left branch of the hepatic artery or of the portal vein; the left hepatic duct and the right branch of the hepatic artery or of the portal vein.<EOS>
<BOS>Cancer may have spread to nearby lymph nodes.<EOS>
<BOS>Stage IVB: Cancer has spread to lymph nodes in more distant parts of the abdomen, or to organs in other parts of the body.<EOS>
<BOS>Distal extrahepatic bile duct cancer Stage 0: Abnormal cells are found in the innermost layer of tissue lining the distal extrahepatic bile duct.<EOS>
<BOS>These abnormal cells may become cancer and spread into nearby normal tissue.<EOS>
<BOS>Stage 0 is also called carcinoma in situ.<EOS>
<BOS>Stage I: Stage I is divided into stage IA and stage IB.<EOS>
<BOS>Stage IA: Cancer has formed and is found in the distal extrahepatic bile duct wall only.<EOS>
<BOS>Stage IB: Cancer has formed and has spread through the wall of the distal extrahepatic bile duct but has not spread to nearby organs.<EOS>
<BOS>Stage II: Stage II is divided into stage IIA and stage IIB.<EOS>
<BOS>Stage IIA: Cancer has spread from the distal extrahepatic bile duct to the gallbladder, pancreas, duodenum, or other nearby organs.<EOS>
<BOS>Stage IIB: Cancer has spread from the distal extrahepatic bile duct to nearby lymph nodes.<EOS>
<BOS>Cancer may have spread through the wall of the duct or to nearby organs.<EOS>
<BOS>Stage III: Cancer has spread to the large vessels that carry blood to the organs in the abdomen.<EOS>
<BOS>Cancer may have spread to nearby lymph nodes.<EOS>
<BOS>Stage IV: Cancer has spread to organs in distant parts of the body.<EOS>
<BOS>The following groups are used to plan treatment: Resectable (localized) bile duct cancer The cancer is in an area, such as the lower part of the common bile duct or perihilar area, where it can be removed completely by surgery.<EOS>
<BOS>Unresectable, metastatic, or recurrent bile duct cancer Unresectable cancer cannot be removed completely by surgery.<EOS>
<BOS>Most patients with bile duct cancer cannot have their cancer completely removed by surgery.<EOS>
<BOS>Metastasis is the spread of cancer from the primary site (place where it started) to other places in the body.<EOS>
<BOS>Metastatic bile duct cancer may have spread to the liver, other parts of the abdominal cavity, or to distant parts of the body.<EOS>
<BOS>Recurrent bile duct cancer is cancer that has recurred (come back) after it has been treated.<EOS>
<BOS>The cancer may come back in the bile ducts, liver, or gallbladder.<EOS>
<BOS>Less often, it may come back in distant parts of the body.<EOS>
<BOS>Key Points Childhood kidney tumors are diseases in which malignant (cancer) cells form in the tissues of the kidney.<EOS>
<BOS>There are many types of childhood kidney tumors.<EOS>
<BOS>Wilms Tumor Renal Cell Cancer (RCC) Rhabdoid Tumor of the Kidney Clear Cell Sarcoma of the Kidney Congenital Mesoblastic Nephroma Ewing Sarcoma of the Kidney Primary Renal Myoepithelial Carcinoma Cystic Partially Differentiated Nephroblastoma Multilocular Cystic Nephroma Primary Renal Synovial Sarcoma Anaplastic Sarcoma of the Kidney Nephroblastomatosis is not cancer but may become Wilms tumor.<EOS>
<BOS>Having certain genetic syndromes or other conditions can increase the risk of Wilms tumor.<EOS>
<BOS>Tests are used to screen for Wilms tumor.<EOS>
<BOS>Having certain conditions may increase the risk of renal cell cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Treatment for Wilms tumor and other childhood kidney tumors may include genetic counseling.<EOS>
<BOS>Signs of Wilms tumor and other childhood kidney tumors include a lump in the abdomen and blood in the urine.<EOS>
<BOS>Tests that examine the kidney and the blood are used to detect (find) and diagnose Wilms tumor and other childhood kidney tumors.<EOS>
<BOS>Certain factors affect prognosis (chance of recovery) and treatment options.<EOS>
<BOS>Childhood kidney tumors are diseases in which malignant (cancer) cells form in the tissues of the kidney.<EOS>
<BOS>There are two kidneys, one on each side of the backbone, above the waist.<EOS>
<BOS>Tiny tubules in the kidneys filter and clean the blood.<EOS>
<BOS>They take out waste products and make urine.<EOS>
<BOS>The urine passes from each kidney through a long tube called a ureter into the bladder.<EOS>
<BOS>The bladder holds the urine until it passes through the urethra and leaves the body.<EOS>
<BOS>There are many types of childhood kidney tumors.<EOS>
<BOS>Wilms Tumor In Wilms tumor, one or more tumors may be found in one or both kidneys.<EOS>
<BOS>Wilms tumor may spread to the lungs, liver, bone, brain, or nearby lymph nodes.<EOS>
<BOS>In children and adolescents younger than 15 years old, most kidney cancers are Wilms tumors.<EOS>
<BOS>Renal Cell Cancer (RCC) Renal cell cancer is rare in children and adolescents younger than 15 years old.<EOS>
<BOS>It is much more common in adolescents between 15 and 19 years old.<EOS>
<BOS>Children and adolescents are more likely to be diagnosed with a large renal cell tumor or cancer that has spread.<EOS>
<BOS>Renal cell cancers may spread to the lungs, liver, or lymph nodes.<EOS>
<BOS>Renal cell cancer may also be called renal cell carcinoma.<EOS>
<BOS>Rhabdoid Tumor of the Kidney Rhabdoid tumor of the kidney is a type of kidney cancer that occurs mostly in infants and young children.<EOS>
<BOS>It is often advanced at the time of diagnosis.<EOS>
<BOS>Rhabdoid tumor of the kidney grows and spreads quickly, often to the lungs or brain.<EOS>
<BOS>Children with a certain change in the SMARCB1 gene are checked regularly to see if a rhabdoid tumor has formed in the kidney or has spread to the brain: Children younger than one year old have an ultrasound of the abdomen every two to three months and an ultrasound of the head every month.<EOS>
<BOS>Children one to four years old have an ultrasound of the abdomen and an MRI of the brain and spine every three months.<EOS>
<BOS>Clear Cell Sarcoma of the Kidney Clear cell sarcoma of the kidney is a type of kidney tumor that may spread to the lung, bone, brain, or soft tissue.<EOS>
<BOS>When it recurs (comes back) after treatment, it often recurs in the brain or lung.<EOS>
<BOS>Congenital Mesoblastic Nephroma Congenital mesoblastic nephroma is a tumor of the kidney that is often diagnosed during the first year of life.<EOS>
<BOS>It can usually be cured.<EOS>
<BOS>Ewing Sarcoma of the Kidney Ewing sarcoma (previously called neuroepithelial tumor) of the kidney is rare and usually occurs in young adults.<EOS>
<BOS>These tumors grow and spread to other parts of the body quickly.<EOS>
<BOS>Primary Renal Myoepithelial Carcinoma Primary renal myoepithelial carcinoma is a rare type of cancer that usually affects soft tissues, but sometimes forms in the internal organs (such as the kidney).<EOS>
<BOS>This type of cancer grows and spreads quickly.<EOS>
<BOS>Cystic Partially Differentiated Nephroblastoma Cystic partially differentiated nephroblastoma is a very rare type of Wilms tumor made up of cysts.<EOS>
<BOS>Multilocular Cystic Nephroma Multilocular cystic nephromas are benign tumors made up of cysts and are most common in infants, young children, and adult women.<EOS>
<BOS>These tumors can occur in one or both kidneys.<EOS>
<BOS>Children with this type of tumor also may have pleuropulmonary blastoma, so imaging tests that check the lungs for cysts or solid tumors are done.<EOS>
<BOS>Since multilocular cystic nephroma may be an inherited condition, genetic counseling and genetic testing may be considered.<EOS>
<BOS>See the PDQ summary about Unusual Cancers of Childhood Treatment for more information about pleuropulmonary blastoma.<EOS>
<BOS>Primary Renal Synovial Sarcoma Primary renal synovial sarcoma is a cystlike tumor of the kidney and is most common in young adults.<EOS>
<BOS>These tumors grow and spread quickly.<EOS>
<BOS>Anaplastic Sarcoma of the Kidney Anaplastic sarcoma of the kidney is a rare tumor that is most common in children or adolescents younger than 15 years of age.<EOS>
<BOS>Anaplastic sarcoma of the kidney often spreads to the lungs, liver, or bones.<EOS>
<BOS>Imaging tests that check the lungs for cysts or solid tumors may be done.<EOS>
<BOS>Since anaplastic sarcoma may be an inherited condition, genetic counseling and genetic testing may be considered.<EOS>
<BOS>Nephroblastomatosis is not cancer but may become Wilms tumor.<EOS>
<BOS>Sometimes, after the kidneys form in the fetus, abnormal groups of kidney cells remain in one or both kidneys.<EOS>
<BOS>In nephroblastomatosis (diffuse hyperplastic perilobar nephroblastomatosis), these abnormal groups of cells may grow in many places inside the kidney or make a thick layer around the kidney.<EOS>
<BOS>When these groups of abnormal cells are found in a kidney after it was removed for Wilms tumor, the child has an increased risk of Wilms tumor in the other kidney.<EOS>
<BOS>Frequent followup testing is important at least every 3 months, for at least 7 years after the child is treated.<EOS>
<BOS>Treatment for Wilms tumor and other childhood kidney tumors may include genetic counseling.<EOS>
<BOS>Genetic counseling (a discussion with a trained professional about genetic diseases and whether genetic testing is needed) may be needed if the child has one of the following syndromes or conditions: A genetic syndrome or condition that increases the risk of Wilms tumor.<EOS>
<BOS>An inherited condition that increases the risk of renal cell cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Rhabdoid tumor of the kidney.<EOS>
<BOS>Multilocular cystic nephroma.<EOS>
<BOS>Certain factors affect prognosis (chance of recovery) and treatment options.<EOS>
<BOS>The prognosis (chance of recovery) depends on the following: The patient's age and general health.<EOS>
<BOS>The level of certain substances in the blood and cerebrospinal fluid (CSF).<EOS>
<BOS>Where the tumor is in the central nervous system, eye, or both.<EOS>
<BOS>Whether the patient has AIDS.<EOS>
<BOS>Treatment options depend on the following: The stage of the cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Where the tumor is in the central nervous system.<EOS>
<BOS>The patient's age and general health.<EOS>
<BOS>Whether the cancer has just been diagnosed or has recurred (come back).<EOS>
<BOS>Treatment of primary CNS lymphoma works best when the tumor has not spread outside the cerebrum (the largest part of the brain) and the patient is younger than 60 years, able to carry out most daily activities, and does not have AIDS or other diseases that weaken the immune system.<EOS>
<BOS>Certain factors affect prognosis (chance of recovery) and treatment options.<EOS>
<BOS>The prognosis (chance of recovery) and treatment options depend on the following: The stage of the cancer (the size of the tumor and whether it is in the lung only or has spread to other places in the body).<EOS>
<BOS>The type of lung cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Whether the cancer has mutations (changes) in certain genes, such as the epidermal growth factor receptor (EGFR) gene or the anaplastic lymphoma kinase (ALK) gene.<EOS>
<BOS>Whether there are signs and symptoms such as coughing or trouble breathing.<EOS>
<BOS>The patients general health.<EOS>
<BOS>New types of treatment are being tested in clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>Information about clinical trials is available from the NCI website.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients may want to think about taking part in a clinical trial.<EOS>
<BOS>For some patients, taking part in a clinical trial may be the best treatment choice.<EOS>
<BOS>Clinical trials are part of the cancer research process.<EOS>
<BOS>Clinical trials are done to find out if new cancer treatments are safe and effective or better than the standard treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Many of today's standard treatments for cancer are based on earlier clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients who take part in a clinical trial may receive the standard treatment or be among the first to receive a new treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients who take part in clinical trials also help improve the way cancer will be treated in the future.<EOS>
<BOS>Even when clinical trials do not lead to effective new treatments, they often answer important questions and help move research forward.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients can enter clinical trials before, during, or after starting their cancer treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Some clinical trials only include patients who have not yet received treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Other trials test treatments for patients whose cancer has not gotten better.<EOS>
<BOS>There are also clinical trials that test new ways to stop cancer from recurring (coming back) or reduce the side effects of cancer treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Clinical trials are taking place in many parts of the country.<EOS>
<BOS>See the Treatment Options section that follows for links to current treatment clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>These have been retrieved from NCI's listing of clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>Key Points After Merkel cell carcinoma has been diagnosed, tests are done to find out if cancer cells have spread to other parts of the body.<EOS>
<BOS>There are three ways that cancer spreads in the body.<EOS>
<BOS>Cancer may spread from where it began to other parts of the body.<EOS>
<BOS>The following stages are used for Merkel cell carcinoma: Stage 0 (carcinoma in situ) Stage IA Stage IB Stage IIA Stage IIB Stage IIC Stage IIIA Stage IIIB Stage IV After Merkel cell carcinoma has been diagnosed, tests are done to find out if cancer cells have spread to other parts of the body.<EOS>
<BOS>The process used to find out if cancer has spread to other parts of the body is called staging.<EOS>
<BOS>The information gathered from the staging process determines the stage of the disease.<EOS>
<BOS>It is important to know the stage in order to plan treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>The following tests and procedures may be used in the staging process: CT scan (CAT scan): A procedure that makes a series of detailed pictures of areas inside the body, taken from different angles.<EOS>
<BOS>The pictures are made by a computer linked to an xray machine.<EOS>
<BOS>A dye may be injected into a vein or swallowed to help the organs or tissues show up more clearly.<EOS>
<BOS>A CT scan of the chest and abdomen may be used to check for primary small cell lung cancer, or to find Merkel cell carcinoma that has spread.<EOS>
<BOS>A CT scan of the head and neck may also be used to find Merkel cell carcinoma that has spread to the lymph nodes.<EOS>
<BOS>This procedure is also called computed tomography, computerized tomography, or computerized axial tomography.<EOS>
<BOS>MRI (magnetic resonance imaging): A procedure that uses a magnet, radio waves, and a computer to make a series of detailed pictures of areas inside the body.<EOS>
<BOS>This procedure is also called nuclear magnetic resonance imaging (NMRI).<EOS>
<BOS>PET scan (positron emission tomography scan): A procedure to find malignant tumor cells in the body.<EOS>
<BOS>A small amount of radioactive glucose (sugar) is injected into a vein.<EOS>
<BOS>The PET scanner rotates around the body and makes a picture of where glucose is being used in the body.<EOS>
<BOS>Malignant tumor cells show up brighter in the picture because they are more active and take up more glucose than normal cells do.<EOS>
<BOS>Lymph node biopsy : There are two main types of lymph node biopsy used to stage Merkel cell carcinoma.<EOS>
<BOS>Sentinel lymph node biopsy : The removal of the sentinel lymph node during surgery.<EOS>
<BOS>The sentinel lymph node is the first lymph node to receive lymphatic drainage from a tumor.<EOS>
<BOS>It is the first lymph node the cancer is likely to spread to from the tumor.<EOS>
<BOS>A radioactive substance and/or blue dye is injected near the tumor.<EOS>
<BOS>The substance or dye flows through the lymph ducts to the lymph nodes.<EOS>
<BOS>The first lymph node to receive the substance or dye is removed.<EOS>
<BOS>A pathologist views the tissue under a microscope to look for cancer cells.<EOS>
<BOS>If cancer cells are not found, it may not be necessary to remove more lymph nodes.<EOS>
<BOS>Lymph node dissection : A surgical procedure in which the lymph nodes are removed and a sample of tissue is checked under a microscope for signs of cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>For a regional lymph node dissection, some of the lymph nodes in the tumor area are removed.<EOS>
<BOS>For a radical lymph node dissection, most or all of the lymph nodes in the tumor area are removed.<EOS>
<BOS>This procedure is also called lymphadenectomy.<EOS>
<BOS>Immunohistochemistry : A test that uses antibodies to check for certain antigens in a sample of tissue.<EOS>
<BOS>The antibody is usually linked to a radioactive substance or a dye that causes the tissue to light up under a microscope.<EOS>
<BOS>This type of test may be used to tell the difference between different types of cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>There are three ways that cancer spreads in the body.<EOS>
<BOS>Cancer can spread through tissue, the lymph system, and the blood: Tissue.<EOS>
<BOS>The cancer spreads from where it began by growing into nearby areas.<EOS>
<BOS>Lymph system.<EOS>
<BOS>The cancer spreads from where it began by getting into the lymph system.<EOS>
<BOS>The cancer travels through the lymph vessels to other parts of the body.<EOS>
<BOS>Blood.<EOS>
<BOS>The cancer spreads from where it began by getting into the blood.<EOS>
<BOS>The cancer travels through the blood vessels to other parts of the body.<EOS>
<BOS>Cancer may spread from where it began to other parts of the body.<EOS>
<BOS>When cancer spreads to another part of the body, it is called metastasis.<EOS>
<BOS>Cancer cells break away from where they began (the primary tumor) and travel through the lymph system or blood.<EOS>
<BOS>Lymph system.<EOS>
<BOS>The cancer gets into the lymph system, travels through the lymph vessels, and forms a tumor (metastatic tumor) in another part of the body.<EOS>
<BOS>Blood.<EOS>
<BOS>The cancer gets into the blood, travels through the blood vessels, and forms a tumor (metastatic tumor) in another part of the body.<EOS>
<BOS>The metastatic tumor is the same type of cancer as the primary tumor.<EOS>
<BOS>For example, if Merkel cell carcinoma spreads to the liver, the cancer cells in the liver are actually cancerous Merkel cells.<EOS>
<BOS>The disease is metastatic Merkel cell carcinoma, not liver cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>The following stages are used for Merkel cell carcinoma: Stage 0 (carcinoma in situ) In stage 0, the tumor is a group of abnormal cells that remain in the place where they first formed and have not spread.<EOS>
<BOS>These abnormal cells may become cancer and spread to lymph nodes or distant parts of the body.<EOS>
<BOS>Stage IA In stage IA, the tumor is 2 centimeters or smaller at its widest point and no cancer is found when the lymph nodes are checked under a microscope.<EOS>
<BOS>Stage IB In stage IB, the tumor is 2 centimeters or smaller at its widest point and no swollen lymph nodes are found by a physical exam or imaging tests.<EOS>
<BOS>Stage IIA In stage IIA, the tumor is larger than 2 centimeters and no cancer is found when the lymph nodes are checked under a microscope.<EOS>
<BOS>Stage IIB In stage IIB, the tumor is larger than 2 centimeters and no swollen lymph nodes are found by a physical exam or imaging tests.<EOS>
<BOS>Stage IIC In stage IIC, the tumor may be any size and has spread to nearby bone, muscle, connective tissue, or cartilage.<EOS>
<BOS>It has not spread to lymph nodes or distant parts of the body.<EOS>
<BOS>Stage IIIA In stage IIIA, the tumor may be any size and may have spread to nearby bone, muscle, connective tissue, or cartilage.<EOS>
<BOS>Cancer is found in the lymph nodes when they are checked under a microscope.<EOS>
<BOS>Stage IIIB In stage IIIB, the tumor may be any size and may have spread to nearby bone, muscle, connective tissue, or cartilage.<EOS>
<BOS>Cancer has spread to the lymph nodes near the tumor and is found by a physical exam or imaging test.<EOS>
<BOS>The lymph nodes are removed and cancer is found in the lymph nodes when they are checked under a microscope.<EOS>
<BOS>There may also be a second tumor, which is either: Between the primary tumor and nearby lymph nodes; or Farther away from the center of the body than the primary tumor is.<EOS>
<BOS>Stage IV In stage IV, the tumor may be any size and has spread to distant parts of the body, such as the liver, lung, bone, or brain.<EOS>
<BOS>Tests that examine the sinuses and nasal cavity are used to detect (find) and diagnose paranasal sinus and nasal cavity cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>The following tests and procedures may be used: Physical exam and history : An exam of the body to check general signs of health, including checking for signs of disease, such as lumps or anything else that seems unusual.<EOS>
<BOS>A history of the patients health habits and past illnesses and treatments will also be taken.<EOS>
<BOS>Physical exam of the nose, face, and neck: An exam in which the doctor looks into the nose with a small, longhandled mirror to check for abnormal areas and checks the face and neck for lumps or swollen lymph nodes.<EOS>
<BOS>Xrays of the head and neck: An xray is a type of energy beam that can go through the body and onto film, making a picture of areas inside the body.<EOS>
<BOS>MRI (magnetic resonance imaging): A procedure that uses a magnet, radio waves, and a computer to make a series of detailed pictures of areas inside the body.<EOS>
<BOS>This procedure is also called nuclear magnetic resonance imaging (NMRI).<EOS>
<BOS>Biopsy : The removal of cells or tissues so they can be viewed under a microscope by a pathologist to check for signs of cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>There are three types of biopsy: Fineneedle aspiration (FNA) biopsy : The removal of tissue or fluid using a thin needle.<EOS>
<BOS>Incisional biopsy : The removal of part of an area of tissue that doesnt look normal.<EOS>
<BOS>Excisional biopsy : The removal of an entire area of tissue that doesnt look normal.<EOS>
<BOS>Nasoscopy : A procedure to look inside the nose for abnormal areas.<EOS>
<BOS>A nasoscope is inserted into the nose.<EOS>
<BOS>A nasoscope is a thin, tubelike instrument with a light and a lens for viewing.<EOS>
<BOS>A special tool on the nasoscope may be used to remove samples of tissue.<EOS>
<BOS>The tissues samples are viewed under a microscope by a pathologist to check for signs of cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Laryngoscopy : A procedure to look at the larynx (voice box) for abnormal areas.<EOS>
<BOS>A mirror or a laryngoscope (a thin, tubelike instrument with a light and a lens for viewing) is inserted through the mouth to see the larynx.<EOS>
<BOS>A special tool on the laryngoscope may be used to remove samples of tissue.<EOS>
<BOS>The tissue samples are viewed under a microscope by a pathologist to check for signs of cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Different factors increase or decrease the risk of oral cavity and oropharyngeal cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Anything that increases your chance of getting a disease is called a risk factor.<EOS>
<BOS>Anything that decreases your chance of getting a disease is called a protective factor.<EOS>
<BOS>For information about risk factors and protective factors for oral cavity and oropharyngeal cancer, see the PDQ summary on Oral Cavity and Oropharyngeal Cancer Prevention.<EOS>
<BOS>Key Points Avoiding risk factors and increasing protective factors may help prevent cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>The following risk factors increase the risk of endometrial cancer: Endometrial hyperplasia Estrogen Tamoxifen Obesity, weight gain, metabolic syndrome, and diabetes Genetic factors The following protective factors decrease the risk of endometrial cancer: Pregnancy and breastfeeding Combination oral contraceptives Physical activity Cigarette smoking It is not known if the following factors affect the risk of endometrial cancer: Weight loss Fruits, vegetables, and vitamins Cancer prevention clinical trials are used to study ways to prevent cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>New ways to prevent endometrial cancer are being studied in clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>Avoiding risk factors and increasing protective factors may help prevent cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Avoiding cancer risk factors may help prevent certain cancers.<EOS>
<BOS>Risk factors include smoking, being overweight, and not getting enough exercise.<EOS>
<BOS>Increasing protective factors such as quitting smoking and exercising may also help prevent some cancers.<EOS>
<BOS>Talk to your doctor or other health care professional about how you might lower your risk of cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>The following risk factors increase the risk of endometrial cancer: Endometrial hyperplasia Endometrial hyperplasia is an abnormal thickening of the endometrium (lining of the uterus).<EOS>
<BOS>It is not cancer, but in some cases, it may lead to endometrial cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Estrogen Estrogen is a hormone made by the body.<EOS>
<BOS>It helps the body develop and maintain female sex characteristics.<EOS>
<BOS>Estrogen can affect the growth of some cancers, including endometrial cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>A woman's risk of developing endometrial cancer is increased by being exposed to estrogen in the following ways: Estrogenonly hormone replacement therapy: Estrogen may be given to replace the estrogen no longer produced by the ovaries in postmenopausal women or women whose ovaries have been removed.<EOS>
<BOS>This is called hormone replacement therapy (HRT), or hormone therapy (HT).<EOS>
<BOS>The use of HRT that contains only estrogen increases the risk of endometrial cancer and endometrial hyperplasia.<EOS>
<BOS>For this reason, estrogen therapy alone is usually prescribed only for women who do not have a uterus.<EOS>
<BOS>HRT that contains only estrogen also increases the risk of stroke and blood clots.<EOS>
<BOS>When estrogen is combined with progestin (another hormone), it is called combination estrogenprogestin replacement therapy.<EOS>
<BOS>For postmenopausal women, taking estrogen in combination with progestin does not increase the risk of endometrial cancer, but it does increase the risk of breast cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>(See the Breast Cancer Prevention summary for more information.<EOS>
<BOS>) Early menstruation: Beginning to have menstrual periods at an early age increases the number of years the body is exposed to estrogen and increases a woman's risk of endometrial cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Late menopause: Women who reach menopause at an older age are exposed to estrogen for a longer time and have an increased risk of endometrial cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Never being pregnant: Because estrogen levels are lower during pregnancy, women who have never been pregnant are exposed to estrogen for a longer time than women who have been pregnant.<EOS>
<BOS>This increases the risk of endometrial cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Tamoxifen Tamoxifen is one of a group of drugs called selective estrogen receptor modulators, or SERMs.<EOS>
<BOS>Tamoxifen acts like estrogen on some tissues in the body, such as the uterus, but blocks the effects of estrogen on other tissues, such as the breast.<EOS>
<BOS>Tamoxifen is used to prevent breast cancer in women who are at high risk for the disease.<EOS>
<BOS>However, using tamoxifen for more than 2 years increases the risk of endometrial cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>This risk is greater in postmenopausal women.<EOS>
<BOS>Raloxifene is a SERM that is used to prevent bone weakness in postmenopausal women.<EOS>
<BOS>However, it does not have estrogenlike effects on the uterus and has not been shown to increase the risk of endometrial cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Obesity, weight gain, metabolic syndrome, and diabetes Obesity, gaining weight as an adult, or having metabolic syndrome increases the risk of endometrial cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Obesity is related to other risk factors such as high estrogen levels, having extra fat around the waist, polycystic ovary syndrome, and lack of physical activity.<EOS>
<BOS>Having metabolic syndrome increases the risk of endometrial cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Metabolic syndrome is a condition that includes extra fat around the waist, high blood sugar, high blood pressure, and high levels of triglycerides (a type of fat) in the blood.<EOS>
<BOS>Genetic factors Hereditary nonpolyposis colon cancer (HNPCC) syndrome (also known as Lynch Syndrome) is an inherited disorder caused by changes in certain genes.<EOS>
<BOS>Women who have HNPCC syndrome have a much higher risk of developing endometrial cancer than women who do not have HNPCC syndrome.<EOS>
<BOS>Polycystic ovary syndrome (a disorder of the hormones made by the ovaries), and Cowden syndrome are inherited conditions that are linked to an increased risk of endometrial cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Women with a family history of endometrial cancer in a firstdegree relative (mother, sister, or daughter) are also at increased risk of endometrial cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>The following protective factors decrease the risk of endometrial cancer: Pregnancy and breastfeeding Estrogen levels are lower during pregnancy and when breastfeeding.<EOS>
<BOS>The risk of endometrial cancer is lower in women who have had children.<EOS>
<BOS>Breastfeeding for more than 18 months also decreases the risk of endometrial cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Combination oral contraceptives Taking contraceptives that combine estrogen and progestin (combination oral contraceptives) decreases the risk of endometrial cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>The protective effect of combination oral contraceptives increases with the length of time they are used, and can last for many years after oral contraceptive use has been stopped.<EOS>
<BOS>While taking oral contraceptives, women have a higher risk of blood clots, stroke, and heart attack, especially women who smoke and are older than 35 years.<EOS>
<BOS>Physical activity Physical activity at home (exercise) or on the job may lower the risk of endometrial cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Cigarette smoking Smoking at least 20 cigarettes a day may lower the risk of endometrial cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>The risk of endometrial cancer is even lower in postmenopausal women who smoke.<EOS>
<BOS>However, there are many proven harms of smoking.<EOS>
<BOS>Cigarette smokers live about 10 years less than nonsmokers.<EOS>
<BOS>Cigarette smokers also have an increased risk of the following: Heart disease.<EOS>
<BOS>Head and neck cancers.<EOS>
<BOS>Lung cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Bladder cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Pancreatic cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>It is not known if the following factors affect the risk of endometrial cancer: Weight loss It is not known if losing weight decreases the risk of endometrial cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Fruits, vegetables, and vitamins A diet that includes, fruits, vegetables, phytoestrogen, soy, and vitamin D has not been found to affect the risk of endometrial cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Taking multivitamins has little or no effect on the risk of common cancers, including endometrial cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Cancer prevention clinical trials are used to study ways to prevent cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Cancer prevention clinical trials are used to study ways to lower the risk of developing certain types of cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Some cancer prevention trials are conducted with healthy people who have not had cancer but who have an increased risk for cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Other prevention trials are conducted with people who have had cancer and are trying to prevent another cancer of the same type or to lower their chance of developing a new type of cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Other trials are done with healthy volunteers who are not known to have any risk factors for cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>The purpose of some cancer prevention clinical trials is to find out whether actions people take can prevent cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>These may include eating fruits and vegetables, exercising, quitting smoking, or taking certain medicines, vitamins, minerals, or food supplements.<EOS>
<BOS>New ways to prevent endometrial cancer are being studied in clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>Clinical trials are taking place in many parts of the country.<EOS>
<BOS>Information about clinical trials can be found in the Clinical Trials section of the NCI website.<EOS>
<BOS>Check NCI's list of cancer clinical trials for endometrial cancer prevention trials that are now accepting patients.<EOS>
<BOS>Key Points Childhood astrocytoma is a disease in which benign (noncancer) or malignant (cancer) cells form in the tissues of the brain.<EOS>
<BOS>Astrocytomas may be benign (not cancer) or malignant (cancer).<EOS>
<BOS>The central nervous system controls many important body functions.<EOS>
<BOS>The cause of most childhood brain tumors is not known.<EOS>
<BOS>The signs and symptoms of astrocytomas are not the same in every child.<EOS>
<BOS>Tests that examine the brain and spinal cord are used to detect (find) childhood astrocytomas.<EOS>
<BOS>Childhood astrocytomas are usually diagnosed and removed in surgery.<EOS>
<BOS>Certain factors affect prognosis (chance of recovery) and treatment options.<EOS>
<BOS>Childhood astrocytoma is a disease in which benign (noncancer) or malignant (cancer) cells form in the tissues of the brain.<EOS>
<BOS>Astrocytomas are tumors that start in starshaped brain cells called astrocytes.<EOS>
<BOS>An astrocyte is a type of glial cell.<EOS>
<BOS>Glial cells hold nerve cells in place, bring food and oxygen to them, and help protect them from disease, such as infection.<EOS>
<BOS>Gliomas are tumors that form from glial cells.<EOS>
<BOS>An astrocytoma is a type of glioma.<EOS>
<BOS>Astrocytoma is the most common type of glioma diagnosed in children.<EOS>
<BOS>It can form anywhere in the central nervous system (brain and spinal cord).<EOS>
<BOS>This summary is about the treatment of tumors that begin in astrocytes in the brain (primary brain tumors).<EOS>
<BOS>Metastatic brain tumors are formed by cancer cells that begin in other parts of the body and spread to the brain.<EOS>
<BOS>Treatment of metastatic brain tumors is not discussed here.<EOS>
<BOS>Brain tumors can occur in both children and adults.<EOS>
<BOS>However, treatment for children may be different than treatment for adults.<EOS>
<BOS>See the following PDQ summaries for more information about other types of brain tumors in children and adults: Childhood Brain and Spinal Cord Tumors Treatment Overview Adult Central Nervous System Tumors Treatment Astrocytomas may be benign (not cancer) or malignant (cancer).<EOS>
<BOS>Benign brain tumors grow and press on nearby areas of the brain.<EOS>
<BOS>They rarely spread into other tissues.<EOS>
<BOS>Malignant brain tumors are likely to grow quickly and spread into other brain tissue.<EOS>
<BOS>When a tumor grows into or presses on an area of the brain, it may stop that part of the brain from working the way it should.<EOS>
<BOS>Both benign and malignant brain tumors can cause signs and symptoms and almost all need treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>The central nervous system controls many important body functions.<EOS>
<BOS>Astrocytomas are most common in these parts of the central nervous system (CNS): Cerebrum : The largest part of the brain, at the top of the head.<EOS>
<BOS>The cerebrum controls thinking, learning, problemsolving, speech, emotions, reading, writing, and voluntary movement.<EOS>
<BOS>Cerebellum : The lower, back part of the brain (near the middle of the back of the head).<EOS>
<BOS>The cerebellum controls movement, balance, and posture.<EOS>
<BOS>Brain stem : The part that connects the brain to the spinal cord, in the lowest part of the brain (just above the back of the neck).<EOS>
<BOS>The brain stem controls breathing, heart rate, and the nerves and muscles used in seeing, hearing, walking, talking, and eating.<EOS>
<BOS>Hypothalamus : The area in the middle of the base of the brain.<EOS>
<BOS>It controls body temperature, hunger, and thirst.<EOS>
<BOS>Visual pathway: The group of nerves that connect the eye with the brain.<EOS>
<BOS>Spinal cord: The column of nerve tissue that runs from the brain stem down the center of the back.<EOS>
<BOS>It is covered by three thin layers of tissue called membranes.<EOS>
<BOS>The spinal cord and membranes are surrounded by the vertebrae (back bones).<EOS>
<BOS>Spinal cord nerves carry messages between the brain and the rest of the body, such as a message from the brain to cause muscles to move or a message from the skin to the brain to feel touch.<EOS>
<BOS>Key Points After colon cancer has been diagnosed, tests are done to find out if cancer cells have spread within the colon or to other parts of the body.<EOS>
<BOS>There are three ways that cancer spreads in the body.<EOS>
<BOS>Cancer may spread from where it began to other parts of the body.<EOS>
<BOS>The following stages are used for colon cancer: Stage 0 (Carcinoma in Situ) Stage I Stage II Stage III Stage IV After colon cancer has been diagnosed, tests are done to find out if cancer cells have spread within the colon or to other parts of the body.<EOS>
<BOS>The process used to find out if cancer has spread within the colon or to other parts of the body is called staging.<EOS>
<BOS>The information gathered from the staging process determines the stage of the disease.<EOS>
<BOS>It is important to know the stage in order to plan treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>The following tests and procedures may be used in the staging process: CT scan (CAT scan): A procedure that makes a series of detailed pictures of areas inside the body, such as the abdomen or chest, taken from different angles.<EOS>
<BOS>The pictures are made by a computer linked to an xray machine.<EOS>
<BOS>A dye may be injected into a vein or swallowed to help the organs or tissues show up more clearly.<EOS>
<BOS>This procedure is also called computed tomography, computerized tomography, or computerized axial tomography.<EOS>
<BOS>MRI (magnetic resonance imaging): A procedure that uses a magnet, radio waves, and a computer to make a series of detailed pictures of areas inside the colon.<EOS>
<BOS>A substance called gadolinium is injected into the patient through a vein.<EOS>
<BOS>The gadolinium collects around the cancer cells so they show up brighter in the picture.<EOS>
<BOS>This procedure is also called nuclear magnetic resonance imaging (NMRI).<EOS>
<BOS>PET scan (positron emission tomography scan): A procedure to find malignant tumor cells in the body.<EOS>
<BOS>A small amount of radioactive glucose (sugar) is injected into a vein.<EOS>
<BOS>The PET scanner rotates around the body and makes a picture of where glucose is being used in the body.<EOS>
<BOS>Malignant tumor cells show up brighter in the picture because they are more active and take up more glucose than normal cells do.<EOS>
<BOS>Chest xray : An xray of the organs and bones inside the chest.<EOS>
<BOS>An xray is a type of energy beam that can go through the body and onto film, making a picture of areas inside the body.<EOS>
<BOS>Surgery : A procedure to remove the tumor and see how far it has spread through the colon.<EOS>
<BOS>Lymph node biopsy : The removal of all or part of a lymph node.<EOS>
<BOS>A pathologist views the tissue under a microscope to look for cancer cells.<EOS>
<BOS>Complete blood count (CBC): A procedure in which a sample of blood is drawn and checked for the following: The number of red blood cells, white blood cells, and platelets.<EOS>
<BOS>The amount of hemoglobin (the protein that carries oxygen) in the red blood cells.<EOS>
<BOS>The portion of the blood sample made up of red blood cells.<EOS>
<BOS>Carcinoembryonic antigen (CEA) assay : A test that measures the level of CEA in the blood.<EOS>
<BOS>CEA is released into the bloodstream from both cancer cells and normal cells.<EOS>
<BOS>When found in higher than normal amounts, it can be a sign of colon cancer or other conditions.<EOS>
<BOS>There are three ways that cancer spreads in the body.<EOS>
<BOS>Cancer can spread through tissue, the lymph system, and the blood: Tissue.<EOS>
<BOS>The cancer spreads from where it began by growing into nearby areas.<EOS>
<BOS>Lymph system.<EOS>
<BOS>The cancer spreads from where it began by getting into the lymph system.<EOS>
<BOS>The cancer travels through the lymph vessels to other parts of the body.<EOS>
<BOS>Blood.<EOS>
<BOS>The cancer spreads from where it began by getting into the blood.<EOS>
<BOS>The cancer travels through the blood vessels to other parts of the body.<EOS>
<BOS>Cancer may spread from where it began to other parts of the body.<EOS>
<BOS>When cancer spreads to another part of the body, it is called metastasis.<EOS>
<BOS>Cancer cells break away from where they began (the primary tumor) and travel through the lymph system or blood.<EOS>
<BOS>Lymph system.<EOS>
<BOS>The cancer gets into the lymph system, travels through the lymph vessels, and forms a tumor (metastatic tumor) in another part of the body.<EOS>
<BOS>Blood.<EOS>
<BOS>The cancer gets into the blood, travels through the blood vessels, and forms a tumor (metastatic tumor) in another part of the body.<EOS>
<BOS>The metastatic tumor is the same type of cancer as the primary tumor.<EOS>
<BOS>For example, if colon cancer spreads to the lung, the cancer cells in the lung are actually colon cancer cells.<EOS>
<BOS>The disease is metastatic colon cancer, not lung cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>The following stages are used for colon cancer: Stage 0 (Carcinoma in Situ) In stage 0, abnormal cells are found in the mucosa (innermost layer) of the colon wall.<EOS>
<BOS>These abnormal cells may become cancer and spread.<EOS>
<BOS>Stage 0 is also called carcinoma in situ.<EOS>
<BOS>Stage I In stage I, cancer has formed in the mucosa (innermost layer) of the colon wall and has spread to the submucosa (layer of tissue under the mucosa).<EOS>
<BOS>Cancer may have spread to the muscle layer of the colon wall.<EOS>
<BOS>Stage II Stage II colon cancer is divided into stage IIA, stage IIB, and stage IIC.<EOS>
<BOS>Stage IIA: Cancer has spread through the muscle layer of the colon wall to the serosa (outermost layer) of the colon wall.<EOS>
<BOS>Stage IIB: Cancer has spread through the serosa (outermost layer) of the colon wall but has not spread to nearby organs.<EOS>
<BOS>Stage IIC: Cancer has spread through the serosa (outermost layer) of the colon wall to nearby organs.<EOS>
<BOS>Stage III Stage III colon cancer is divided into stage IIIA, stage IIIB, and stage IIIC.<EOS>
<BOS>In stage IIIA: Cancer has spread through the mucosa (innermost layer) of the colon wall to the submucosa (layer of tissue under the mucosa) and may have spread to the muscle layer of the colon wall.<EOS>
<BOS>Cancer has spread to at least one but not more than 3 nearby lymph nodes or cancer cells have formed in tissues near the lymph nodes; or Cancer has spread through the mucosa (innermost layer) of the colon wall to the submucosa (layer of tissue under the mucosa).<EOS>
<BOS>Cancer has spread to at least 4 but not more than 6 nearby lymph nodes.<EOS>
<BOS>In stage IIIB: Cancer has spread through the muscle layer of the colon wall to the serosa (outermost layer) of the colon wall or has spread through the serosa but not to nearby organs.<EOS>
<BOS>Cancer has spread to at least one but not more than 3 nearby lymph nodes or cancer cells have formed in tissues near the lymph nodes; or Cancer has spread to the muscle layer of the colon wall or to the serosa (outermost layer) of the colon wall.<EOS>
<BOS>Cancer has spread to at least 4 but not more than 6 nearby lymph nodes; or Cancer has spread through the mucosa (innermost layer) of the colon wall to the submucosa (layer of tissue under the mucosa) and may have spread to the muscle layer of the colon wall.<EOS>
<BOS>Cancer has spread to 7 or more nearby lymph nodes.<EOS>
<BOS>In stage IIIC: Cancer has spread through the serosa (outermost layer) of the colon wall but has not spread to nearby organs.<EOS>
<BOS>Cancer has spread to at least 4 but not more than 6 nearby lymph nodes; or Cancer has spread through the muscle layer of the colon wall to the serosa (outermost layer) of the colon wall or has spread through the serosa but has not spread to nearby organs.<EOS>
<BOS>Cancer has spread to 7 or more nearby lymph nodes; or Cancer has spread through the serosa (outermost layer) of the colon wall and has spread to nearby organs.<EOS>
<BOS>Cancer has spread to one or more nearby lymph nodes or cancer cells have formed in tissues near the lymph nodes.<EOS>
<BOS>Stage IV Stage IV colon cancer is divided into stage IVA and stage IVB.<EOS>
<BOS>Stage IVA: Cancer may have spread through the colon wall and may have spread to nearby organs or lymph nodes.<EOS>
<BOS>Cancer has spread to one organ that is not near the colon, such as the liver, lung, or ovary, or to a distant lymph node.<EOS>
<BOS>Stage IVB: Cancer may have spread through the colon wall and may have spread to nearby organs or lymph nodes.<EOS>
<BOS>Cancer has spread to more than one organ that is not near the colon or into the lining of the abdominal wall.<EOS>
<BOS>Key Points Anal cancer is a disease in which malignant (cancer) cells form in the tissues of the anus.<EOS>
<BOS>Squamous cell carcinoma is the most common type of anal cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>In the United States, the number of new cases of anal cancer has increased in recent years.<EOS>
<BOS>Anal cancer is a disease in which malignant (cancer) cells form in the tissues of the anus.<EOS>
<BOS>The anus is the end of the large intestine, below the rectum, through which stool (solid waste) leaves the body.<EOS>
<BOS>The anus is formed partly from the outer skin layers of the body and partly from the intestine.<EOS>
<BOS>Two ringlike muscles, called sphincter muscles, open and close the anal opening and let stool pass out of the body.<EOS>
<BOS>The anal canal, the part of the anus between the rectum and the anal opening, is about 11 inches long.<EOS>
<BOS>The skin around the outside of the anus is called the perianal area.<EOS>
<BOS>Tumors in this area are skin tumors, not anal cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>See the following PDQ summary for more information about anal cancer: Anal Cancer Treatment Squamous cell carcinoma is the most common type of anal cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>In the United States, the most common type of anal cancer is squamous cell carcinoma.<EOS>
<BOS>Studies show that human papillomavirus (HPV) infection is the main cause of this type of anal cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Another type of anal cancer, called anal adenocarcinoma, is very rare and is not discussed in this summary.<EOS>
<BOS>In the United States, the number of new cases of anal cancer has increased in recent years.<EOS>
<BOS>From 2004 to 2013, new cases of anal cancer and deaths from anal cancer increased each year.<EOS>
<BOS>The increase in new cases was slightly higher in women and the increase in deaths from anal cancer was slightly higher in men.<EOS>
<BOS>The most common sign of childhood soft tissue sarcoma is a painless lump or swelling in soft tissues of the body.<EOS>
<BOS>A sarcoma may appear as a painless lump under the skin, often on an arm, a leg, or the trunk.<EOS>
<BOS>There may be no other signs or symptoms at first.<EOS>
<BOS>As the sarcoma gets bigger and presses on nearby organs, nerves, muscles, or blood vessels, it may cause signs or symptoms, such as pain or weakness.<EOS>
<BOS>Other conditions may cause the same signs and symptoms.<EOS>
<BOS>Check with your childs doctor if your child has any of these problems.<EOS>
<BOS>Sometimes breast cancer occurs in women who are pregnant or have just given birth.<EOS>
<BOS>Breast cancer occurs about once in every 3,000 pregnancies.<EOS>
<BOS>It occurs most often between the ages of 32 and 38.<EOS>
<BOS>Age, gender, and EpsteinBarr infection can affect the risk of adult Hodgkin lymphoma.<EOS>
<BOS>Anything that increases your risk of getting a disease is called a risk factor.<EOS>
<BOS>Having a risk factor does not mean that you will get cancer; not having risk factors doesn't mean that you will not get cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Talk with your doctor if you think you may be at risk.<EOS>
<BOS>Risk factors for adult Hodgkin lymphoma include the following: Being in young or late adulthood.<EOS>
<BOS>Being male.<EOS>
<BOS>Being infected with the EpsteinBarr virus.<EOS>
<BOS>Having a firstdegree relative (parent, brother, or sister) with Hodgkin lymphoma.<EOS>
<BOS>Pregnancy is not a risk factor for Hodgkin lymphoma.<EOS>
<BOS>Key Points Gastrointestinal stromal tumor is a disease in which abnormal cells form in the tissues of the gastrointestinal tract.<EOS>
<BOS>Genetic factors can increase the risk of having a gastrointestinal stromal tumor.<EOS>
<BOS>Signs of gastrointestinal stromal tumors include blood in the stool or vomit.<EOS>
<BOS>Tests that examine the GI tract are used to detect (find) and diagnose gastrointestinal stromal tumors.<EOS>
<BOS>Very small GISTs are common.<EOS>
<BOS>Certain factors affect prognosis (chance of recovery) and treatment options.<EOS>
<BOS>Gastrointestinal stromal tumor is a disease in which abnormal cells form in the tissues of the gastrointestinal tract.<EOS>
<BOS>The gastrointestinal (GI) tract is part of the bodys digestive system.<EOS>
<BOS>It helps to digest food and takes nutrients (vitamins, minerals, carbohydrates, fats, proteins, and water) from food so they can be used by the body.<EOS>
<BOS>The GI tract is made up of the following organs: Stomach.<EOS>
<BOS>Small intestine.<EOS>
<BOS>Large intestine (colon).<EOS>
<BOS>Gastrointestinal stromal tumors (GISTs) may be malignant (cancer) or benign (not cancer).<EOS>
<BOS>They are most common in the stomach and small intestine but may be found anywhere in or near the GI tract.<EOS>
<BOS>Some scientists believe that GISTs begin in cells called interstitial cells of Cajal (ICC), in the wall of the GI tract.<EOS>
<BOS>See the PDQ summary about Unusual Cancers of Childhood Treatment for information on the treatment of GIST in children.<EOS>
<BOS>Very small GISTs are common.<EOS>
<BOS>Sometimes GISTs are smaller than the eraser on top of a pencil.<EOS>
<BOS>Tumors may be found during a procedure that is done for another reason, such as an xray or surgery.<EOS>
<BOS>Some of these small tumors will not grow and cause signs or symptoms or spread to the abdomen or other parts of the body.<EOS>
<BOS>Doctors do not agree on whether these small tumors should be removed or whether they should be watched to see if they begin to grow.<EOS>
<BOS>New types of treatment are being tested in clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>This summary section describes treatments that are being studied in clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>It may not mention every new treatment being studied.<EOS>
<BOS>Information about clinical trials is available from the NCI website.<EOS>
<BOS>Targeted therapy Targeted therapy is a type of treatment that uses drugs or other substances to identify and attack specific cancer cells without harming normal cells.<EOS>
<BOS>Several types of targeted therapy are being studied in the treatment of GI carcinoid tumors.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients may want to think about taking part in a clinical trial.<EOS>
<BOS>For some patients, taking part in a clinical trial may be the best treatment choice.<EOS>
<BOS>Clinical trials are part of the cancer research process.<EOS>
<BOS>Clinical trials are done to find out if new cancer treatments are safe and effective or better than the standard treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Many of today's standard treatments for cancer are based on earlier clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients who take part in a clinical trial may receive the standard treatment or be among the first to receive a new treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients who take part in clinical trials also help improve the way cancer will be treated in the future.<EOS>
<BOS>Even when clinical trials do not lead to effective new treatments, they often answer important questions and help move research forward.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients can enter clinical trials before, during, or after starting their cancer treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Some clinical trials only include patients who have not yet received treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Other trials test treatments for patients whose cancer has not gotten better.<EOS>
<BOS>There are also clinical trials that test new ways to stop cancer from recurring (coming back) or reduce the side effects of cancer treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Clinical trials are taking place in many parts of the country.<EOS>
<BOS>See the Treatment Options section that follows for links to current treatment clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>These have been retrieved from NCI's listing of clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>Key Points Central nervous system atypical teratoid/rhabdoid tumor is a disease in which malignant (cancer) cells form in the tissues of the brain.<EOS>
<BOS>Certain genetic changes may increase the risk of atypical teratoid/rhabdoid tumor.<EOS>
<BOS>The signs and symptoms of atypical teratoid/rhabdoid tumor are not the same in every patient.<EOS>
<BOS>Tests that examine the brain and spinal cord are used to detect (find) CNS atypical teratoid/rhabdoid tumor.<EOS>
<BOS>Childhood atypical teratoid/rhabdoid tumor is diagnosed and may be removed in surgery.<EOS>
<BOS>Certain factors affect prognosis (chance of recovery) and treatment options.<EOS>
<BOS>Central nervous system atypical teratoid/rhabdoid tumor is a disease in which malignant (cancer) cells form in the tissues of the brain.<EOS>
<BOS>Central nervous system (CNS) atypical teratoid/rhabdoid tumor (AT/RT) is a very rare, fastgrowing tumor of the brain and spinal cord.<EOS>
<BOS>It usually occurs in children aged three years and younger, although it can occur in older children and adults.<EOS>
<BOS>About half of these tumors form in the cerebellum or brain stem.<EOS>
<BOS>The cerebellum is the part of the brain that controls movement, balance, and posture.<EOS>
<BOS>The brain stem controls breathing, heart rate, and the nerves and muscles used in seeing, hearing, walking, talking, and eating.<EOS>
<BOS>AT/RT may also be found in other parts of the central nervous system (brain and spinal cord).<EOS>
<BOS>This summary describes the treatment of primary brain tumors (tumors that begin in the brain).<EOS>
<BOS>Treatment for metastatic brain tumors, which are tumors formed by cancer cells that begin in other parts of the body and spread to the brain, is not covered in this summary.<EOS>
<BOS>For more information, see the PDQ summary on Childhood Brain and Spinal Cord Tumors Treatment Overview about the different types of childhood brain and spinal cord tumors.<EOS>
