<BOS>Brain tumors can occur in both children and adults; however, treatment for children may be different than treatment for adults.<EOS>
<BOS>See the PDQ treatment summary on Adult Central Nervous System Tumors Treatment for more information.<EOS>
<BOS>Neuroblastoma is sometimes caused by a gene mutation (change) passed from the parent to the child.<EOS>
<BOS>Gene mutations that increase the risk of neuroblastoma are sometimes inherited (passed from the parent to the child).<EOS>
<BOS>In children with a gene mutation, neuroblastoma usually occurs at a younger age and more than one tumor may form in the adrenal glands.<EOS>
<BOS>Tests that examine the colon and rectum are used to detect (find) and diagnose colon cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>The following tests and procedures may be used: Physical exam and history : An exam of the body to check general signs of health, including checking for signs of disease, such as lumps or anything else that seems unusual.<EOS>
<BOS>A history of the patients health habits and past illnesses and treatments will also be taken.<EOS>
<BOS>Digital rectal exam : An exam of the rectum.<EOS>
<BOS>The doctor or nurse inserts a lubricated, gloved finger into the rectum to feel for lumps or anything else that seems unusual.<EOS>
<BOS>Fecal occult blood test (FOBT): A test to check stool (solid waste) for blood that can only be seen with a microscope.<EOS>
<BOS>A small sample of stool is placed on a special card or in a special container and returned to the doctor or laboratory for testing.<EOS>
<BOS>Blood in the stool may be a sign of polyps, cancer, or other conditions.<EOS>
<BOS>There are two types of FOBTs: Guaiac FOBT : The sample of stool on the special card is tested with a chemical.<EOS>
<BOS>If there is blood in the stool, the special card changes color.<EOS>
<BOS>Immunochemical FOBT : A liquid is added to the stool sample.<EOS>
<BOS>This mixture is injected into a machine that contains antibodies that can detect blood in the stool.<EOS>
<BOS>If there is blood in the stool, a line appears in a window in the machine.<EOS>
<BOS>This test is also called fecal immunochemical test or FIT.<EOS>
<BOS>Barium enema : A series of xrays of the lower gastrointestinal tract.<EOS>
<BOS>A liquid that contains barium (a silverwhite metallic compound) is put into the rectum.<EOS>
<BOS>The barium coats the lower gastrointestinal tract and xrays are taken.<EOS>
<BOS>This procedure is also called a lower GI series.<EOS>
<BOS>Sigmoidoscopy : A procedure to look inside the rectum and sigmoid (lower) colon for polyps (small areas of bulging tissue), other abnormal areas, or cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>A sigmoidoscope is inserted through the rectum into the sigmoid colon.<EOS>
<BOS>A sigmoidoscope is a thin, tubelike instrument with a light and a lens for viewing.<EOS>
<BOS>It may also have a tool to remove polyps or tissue samples, which are checked under a microscope for signs of cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Colonoscopy : A procedure to look inside the rectum and colon for polyps, abnormal areas, or cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>A colonoscope is inserted through the rectum into the colon.<EOS>
<BOS>A colonoscope is a thin, tubelike instrument with a light and a lens for viewing.<EOS>
<BOS>It may also have a tool to remove polyps or tissue samples, which are checked under a microscope for signs of cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Virtual colonoscopy : A procedure that uses a series of xrays called computed tomography to make a series of pictures of the colon.<EOS>
<BOS>A computer puts the pictures together to create detailed images that may show polyps and anything else that seems unusual on the inside surface of the colon.<EOS>
<BOS>This test is also called colonography or CT colonography.<EOS>
<BOS>Biopsy : The removal of cells or tissues so they can be viewed under a microscope by a pathologist to check for signs of cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Anything that increases your risk of getting a disease is called a risk factor.<EOS>
<BOS>Having a risk factor does not mean that you will get cancer; not having risk factors doesnt mean that you will not get cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Talk with your child's doctor if you think your child may be at risk.<EOS>
<BOS>Possible risk factors for astrocytoma include: Past radiation therapy to the brain.<EOS>
<BOS>Having certain genetic disorders, such as neurofibromatosis type 1 (NF1) or tuberous sclerosis.<EOS>
<BOS>Key Points Oral cavity and oropharyngeal cancer are diseases in which malignant (cancer) cells form in the mouth and throat.<EOS>
<BOS>The number of new cases of oral cavity and oropharyngeal cancer and the number of deaths from oral cavity and oropharyngeal cancer varies by race and gender.<EOS>
<BOS>Different factors increase or decrease the risk of oral cavity and oropharyngeal cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Oral cavity and oropharyngeal cancer are diseases in which malignant (cancer) cells form in the mouth and throat.<EOS>
<BOS>Oral cavity cancer forms in any of these tissues of the oral cavity: The front two thirds of the tongue.<EOS>
<BOS>The gingiva (gums).<EOS>
<BOS>The buccal mucosa (the lining of the inside of the cheeks).<EOS>
<BOS>The floor (bottom) of the mouth under the tongue.<EOS>
<BOS>The hard palate (the front of the roof of the mouth).<EOS>
<BOS>The retromolar trigone (the small area behind the wisdom teeth).<EOS>
<BOS>Oropharyngeal cancer forms in any of these tissues of the oropharynx: The middle part of the pharynx (throat) behind the mouth.<EOS>
<BOS>The back one third of the tongue.<EOS>
<BOS>The soft palate (the back of the roof of the mouth).<EOS>
<BOS>The side and back walls of the throat.<EOS>
<BOS>The tonsils.<EOS>
<BOS>Most oral cavity and oropharyngeal cancers start in squamous cells, the thin, flat cells that line the lips, oral cavity, and oropharynx.<EOS>
<BOS>Cancer that forms in squamous cells is called squamous cell carcinoma.<EOS>
<BOS>See the following PDQ summaries for more information about the screening, diagnosis, and treatment of oral cavity and oropharyngeal cancer: Oral Cavity and Oropharyngeal Cancer Prevention Lip and Oral Cavity Cancer Treatment Oropharyngeal Cancer Treatment The number of new cases of oral cavity and oropharyngeal cancer and the number of deaths from oral cavity and oropharyngeal cancer varies by race and gender.<EOS>
<BOS>Over the past ten years, the number of new cases and deaths from oral cavity and oropharyngeal cancer slightly increased in white men and women.<EOS>
<BOS>The number slightly decreased among black men and women.<EOS>
<BOS>Oral cavity and oropharyngeal cancer is more common in men than in women.<EOS>
<BOS>Although oral cavity and oropharyngeal cancer may occur in adults of any age, it occurs most often in those aged 55 to 64 years.<EOS>
<BOS>France, Brazil, and parts of Asia have much higher rates of oral cavity and oropharyngeal cancer than most other countries.<EOS>
<BOS>The number of new cases of oropharyngeal cancer caused by certain types of human papillomavirus (HPV) infection has increased.<EOS>
<BOS>One kind of HPV, called HPV 16, is often passed from one person to another during sexual activity.<EOS>
<BOS>Certain factors affect prognosis (chance of recovery) and treatment options.<EOS>
<BOS>The prognosis (chance of recovery) and treatment options for JMML depend on the following: The age of the child at diagnosis.<EOS>
<BOS>The number of platelets in the blood.<EOS>
<BOS>The amount of a certain type of hemoglobin in red blood cells.<EOS>
<BOS>Certain factors affect prognosis (chance of recovery) and treatment options.<EOS>
<BOS>The prognosis (chance of recovery) and treatment options depend on the following: The stage of the cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>The type and size of the tumor.<EOS>
<BOS>The patient's general health.<EOS>
<BOS>Whether the cancer has just been diagnosed or has recurred (come back).<EOS>
<BOS>Signs and symptoms of adult nonHodgkin lymphoma include swelling in the lymph nodes, fever, night sweats, weight loss, and fatigue.<EOS>
<BOS>These signs and symptoms may be caused by adult nonHodgkin lymphoma or by other conditions.<EOS>
<BOS>Check with your doctor if you have any of the following: Swelling in the lymph nodes in the neck, underarm, groin, or stomach.<EOS>
<BOS>Fever for no known reason.<EOS>
<BOS>Recurring night sweats.<EOS>
<BOS>Feeling very tired.<EOS>
<BOS>Weight loss for no known reason.<EOS>
<BOS>Skin rash or itchy skin.<EOS>
<BOS>Pain in the chest, abdomen, or bones for no known reason.<EOS>
<BOS>When fever, night sweats, and weight loss occur together, this group of symptoms is called B symptoms.<EOS>
<BOS>Other signs and symptoms of adult nonHodgkin lymphoma may occur and depend on the following: Where the cancer forms in the body.<EOS>
<BOS>The size of the tumor.<EOS>
<BOS>How fast the tumor grows.<EOS>
<BOS>Key Points Tests done to detect thymoma or thymic carcinoma are also used to stage the disease.<EOS>
<BOS>There are three ways that cancer spreads in the body.<EOS>
<BOS>Cancer may spread from where it began to other parts of the body.<EOS>
<BOS>The following stages are used for thymoma: Stage I Stage II Stage III Stage IV Thymic carcinomas have usually spread to other parts of the body when diagnosed.<EOS>
<BOS>Tests done to detect thymoma or thymic carcinoma are also used to stage the disease.<EOS>
<BOS>Staging is the process used to find out if cancer has spread from the thymus to other parts of the body.<EOS>
<BOS>The findings made during surgery and the results of tests and procedures are used to determine the stage of the disease.<EOS>
<BOS>It is important to know the stage in order to plan treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>There are three ways that cancer spreads in the body.<EOS>
<BOS>Cancer can spread through tissue, the lymph system, and the blood: Tissue.<EOS>
<BOS>The cancer spreads from where it began by growing into nearby areas.<EOS>
<BOS>Lymph system.<EOS>
<BOS>The cancer spreads from where it began by getting into the lymph system.<EOS>
<BOS>The cancer travels through the lymph vessels to other parts of the body.<EOS>
<BOS>Blood.<EOS>
<BOS>The cancer spreads from where it began by getting into the blood.<EOS>
<BOS>The cancer travels through the blood vessels to other parts of the body.<EOS>
<BOS>Cancer may spread from where it began to other parts of the body.<EOS>
<BOS>When cancer spreads to another part of the body, it is called metastasis.<EOS>
<BOS>Cancer cells break away from where they began (the primary tumor) and travel through the lymph system or blood.<EOS>
<BOS>Lymph system.<EOS>
<BOS>The cancer gets into the lymph system, travels through the lymph vessels, and forms a tumor (metastatic tumor) in another part of the body.<EOS>
<BOS>Blood.<EOS>
<BOS>The cancer gets into the blood, travels through the blood vessels, and forms a tumor (metastatic tumor) in another part of the body.<EOS>
<BOS>The metastatic tumor is the same type of cancer as the primary tumor.<EOS>
<BOS>For example, if thymic carcinoma spreads to the bone, the cancer cells in the bone are actually thymic carcinoma cells.<EOS>
<BOS>The disease is metastatic thymic carcinoma, not bone cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>The following stages are used for thymoma: Stage I In stage I, cancer is found only within the thymus.<EOS>
<BOS>All cancer cells are inside the capsule (sac) that surrounds the thymus.<EOS>
<BOS>Stage II In stage II, cancer has spread through the capsule and into the fat around the thymus or into the lining of the chest cavity.<EOS>
<BOS>Stage III In stage III, cancer has spread to nearby organs in the chest, including the lung, the sac around the heart, or large blood vessels that carry blood to the heart.<EOS>
<BOS>Stage IV Stage IV is divided into stage IVA and stage IVB, depending on where the cancer has spread.<EOS>
<BOS>In stage IVA, cancer has spread widely around the lungs and heart.<EOS>
<BOS>In stage IVB, cancer has spread to the blood or lymph system.<EOS>
<BOS>Thymic carcinomas have usually spread to other parts of the body when diagnosed.<EOS>
<BOS>The staging system used for thymomas is sometimes used for thymic carcinomas.<EOS>
<BOS>Certain factors affect prognosis (chance of recovery) and treatment options.<EOS>
<BOS>The prognosis (chance of recovery) and treatment options depend on the following: The stage of the cancer (whether it affects the inner lining of the rectum only, involves the whole rectum, or has spread to lymph nodes, nearby organs, or other places in the body).<EOS>
<BOS>Whether the tumor has spread into or through the bowel wall.<EOS>
<BOS>Where the cancer is found in the rectum.<EOS>
<BOS>Whether the bowel is blocked or has a hole in it.<EOS>
<BOS>Whether all of the tumor can be removed by surgery.<EOS>
<BOS>The patients general health.<EOS>
<BOS>Whether the cancer has just been diagnosed or has recurred (come back).<EOS>
<BOS>Key Points There are different types of treatment for patients with childhood astrocytoma.<EOS>
<BOS>Children with astrocytomas should have their treatment planned by a team of health care providers who are experts in treating childhood brain tumors.<EOS>
<BOS>Childhood brain tumors may cause signs or symptoms that begin before the cancer is diagnosed and continue for months or years.<EOS>
<BOS>Some cancer treatments cause side effects months or years after treatment has ended.<EOS>
<BOS>Six types of treatment are used: Surgery Observation Radiation therapy Chemotherapy Highdose chemotherapy with stem cell transplant Targeted therapy New types of treatment are being tested in clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>Other drug therapy If fluid builds up around the brain and spinal cord, a cerebrospinal fluid diversion procedure may be done.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients may want to think about taking part in a clinical trial.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients can enter clinical trials before, during, or after starting their cancer treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Followup tests may be needed.<EOS>
<BOS>There are different types of treatment for patients with childhood astrocytoma.<EOS>
<BOS>Different types of treatment are available for children with astrocytomas.<EOS>
<BOS>Some treatments are standard (the currently used treatment), and some are being tested in clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>A treatment clinical trial is a research study meant to help improve current treatments or obtain information on new treatments for patients with cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>When clinical trials show that a new treatment is better than the standard treatment, the new treatment may become the standard treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Because cancer in children is rare, taking part in a clinical trial should be considered.<EOS>
<BOS>Some clinical trials are open only to patients who have not started treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Children with astrocytomas should have their treatment planned by a team of health care providers who are experts in treating childhood brain tumors.<EOS>
<BOS>Treatment will be overseen by a pediatric oncologist, a doctor who specializes in treating children with cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>The pediatric oncologist works with other healthcare providers who are experts in treating children with brain tumors and who specialize in certain areas of medicine.<EOS>
<BOS>These may include the following specialists: Pediatrician.<EOS>
<BOS>Pediatric neurosurgeon.<EOS>
<BOS>Neurologist.<EOS>
<BOS>Neuropathologist.<EOS>
<BOS>Neuroradiologist.<EOS>
<BOS>Rehabilitation specialist.<EOS>
<BOS>Radiation oncologist.<EOS>
<BOS>Endocrinologist.<EOS>
<BOS>Psychologist.<EOS>
<BOS>Childhood brain tumors may cause signs or symptoms that begin before the cancer is diagnosed and continue for months or years.<EOS>
<BOS>Signs or symptoms caused by the tumor may begin before diagnosis.<EOS>
<BOS>These signs or symptoms may continue for months or years.<EOS>
<BOS>It is important to talk with your child's doctors about signs or symptoms caused by the tumor that may continue after treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Some cancer treatments cause side effects months or years after treatment has ended.<EOS>
<BOS>Side effects from cancer treatment that begin during or after treatment and continue for months or years are called late effects.<EOS>
<BOS>Late effects of cancer treatment may include the following: Physical problems.<EOS>
<BOS>Changes in mood, feelings, thinking, learning, or memory.<EOS>
<BOS>Second cancers (new types of cancer).<EOS>
<BOS>Some late effects may be treated or controlled.<EOS>
<BOS>It is important to talk with your child's doctors about the effects cancer treatment can have on your child.<EOS>
<BOS>(See the PDQ summary on Late Effects of Treatment for Childhood Cancer for more information.<EOS>
<BOS>) Six types of treatment are used: Surgery Surgery is used to diagnose and treat childhood astrocytoma, as discussed in the General Information section of this summary.<EOS>
<BOS>If cancer cells remain after surgery, further treatment depends on: Where the remaining cancer cells are.<EOS>
<BOS>The grade of the tumor.<EOS>
<BOS>The age of the child.<EOS>
<BOS>Even if the doctor removes all the cancer that can be seen at the time of the surgery, some patients may be given chemotherapy or radiation therapy after surgery to kill any cancer cells that remain.<EOS>
<BOS>Treatment given after the surgery, to lower the risk that the cancer will come back, is called adjuvant therapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Observation Observation is closely monitoring a patients condition without giving any treatment until signs or symptoms appear or change.<EOS>
<BOS>Observation may be used: If the patient has no symptoms, such as patients with neurofibromatosis type1.<EOS>
<BOS>If the tumor is small and is found when a different health problem is being diagnosed or treated.<EOS>
<BOS>After the tumor is removed by surgery until signs or symptoms appear or change.<EOS>
<BOS>Radiation therapy Radiation therapy is a cancer treatment that uses highenergy xrays or other types of radiation to kill cancer cells or keep them from growing.<EOS>
<BOS>There are two types of radiation therapy: External radiation therapy uses a machine outside the body to send radiation toward the cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Certain ways of giving radiation therapy can help keep radiation from damaging nearby healthy tissue.<EOS>
<BOS>These types of radiation therapy include the following: Conformal radiation therapy: Conformal radiation therapy is a type of external radiation therapy that uses a computer to make a 3dimensional (3D) picture of the tumor and shapes the radiation beams to fit the tumor.<EOS>
<BOS>Intensitymodulated radiation therapy (IMRT): IMRT is a type of 3dimensional (3D) external radiation therapy that uses a computer to make pictures of the size and shape of the tumor.<EOS>
<BOS>Thin beams of radiation of different intensities (strengths) are aimed at the tumor from many angles.<EOS>
<BOS>Stereotactic radiation therapy: Stereotactic radiation therapy is a type of external radiation therapy.<EOS>
<BOS>A rigid head frame is attached to the skull to keep the head still during the radiation treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>A machine aims radiation directly at the tumor.<EOS>
<BOS>The total dose of radiation is divided into several smaller doses given over several days.<EOS>
<BOS>This procedure is also called stereotactic externalbeam radiation therapy and stereotaxic radiation therapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Proton beam radiation therapy: Protonbeam therapy is a type of highenergy, external radiation therapy.<EOS>
<BOS>A radiation therapy machine aims streams of protons (tiny, invisible, positivelycharged particles) at the cancer cells to kill them.<EOS>
<BOS>Internal radiation therapy uses a radioactive substance sealed in needles, seeds, wires, or catheters that are placed directly into or near the cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>The way the radiation therapy is given depends on the type of tumor and where the tumor formed in the brain or spinal cord.<EOS>
<BOS>External radiation therapy is used to treat childhood astrocytomas.<EOS>
<BOS>Radiation therapy to the brain can affect growth and development, especially in young children.<EOS>
<BOS>For children younger than 3 years, chemotherapy may be given instead, to delay or reduce the need for radiation therapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Chemotherapy Chemotherapy is a cancer treatment that uses drugs to stop the growth of cancer cells, either by killing the cells or by stopping them from dividing.<EOS>
<BOS>When chemotherapy is taken by mouth or injected into a vein or muscle, the drugs enter the bloodstream and can reach cancer cells throughout the body (systemic chemotherapy).<EOS>
<BOS>When chemotherapy is placed directly into the cerebrospinal fluid, an organ, or a body cavity such as the abdomen, the drugs mainly affect cancer cells in those areas (regional chemotherapy).<EOS>
<BOS>Combination chemotherapy is the use of more than one anticancer drug.<EOS>
<BOS>The way the chemotherapy is given depends on the type of tumor and where the tumor formed in the brain or spinal cord.<EOS>
<BOS>Systemic combination chemotherapy is used in the treatment of children with astrocytoma.<EOS>
<BOS>Highdose chemotherapy may be used in the treatment of children with newly diagnosed highgrade astrocytoma.<EOS>
<BOS>Highdose chemotherapy with stem cell transplant Highdose chemotherapy with stem cell transplant is a way of giving high doses of chemotherapy and replacing blood forming cells destroyed by the cancer treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Stem cells (immature blood cells) are removed from the blood or bone marrow of the patient or a donor and are frozen and stored.<EOS>
<BOS>After the chemotherapy is completed, the stored stem cells are thawed and given back to the patient through an infusion.<EOS>
<BOS>These reinfused stem cells grow into (and restore) the body's blood cells.<EOS>
<BOS>For highgrade astrocytoma that has come back after treatment, highdose chemotherapy with stem cell transplant is used if there is only a small amount of tumor.<EOS>
<BOS>Targeted therapy Targeted therapy is a type of treatment that uses drugs or other substances to identify and attack specific cancer cells without harming normal cells.<EOS>
<BOS>There are different types of targeted therapy: Monoclonal antibody therapy uses antibodies made in the laboratory, from a single type of immune system cell, to stop cancer cells.<EOS>
<BOS>These antibodies can identify substances on cancer cells or normal substances that may help cancer cells grow.<EOS>
<BOS>The antibodies attach to the substances and kill the cancer cells, block their growth, or keep them from spreading.<EOS>
<BOS>Monoclonal antibodies are given by infusion into a vein.<EOS>
<BOS>They may be used alone or to carry drugs, toxins, or radioactive material directly to cancer cells.<EOS>
<BOS>There are different types of monoclonal antibody therapy: Vascular endothelial growth factor (VEGF) inhibitor therapy: Cancer cells make a substance called VEGF, which causes new blood vessels to form (angiogenesis) and helps the cancer grow.<EOS>
<BOS>VEGF inhibitors block VEGF and stop new blood vessels from forming.<EOS>
<BOS>This may kill cancer cells because they need new blood vessels to grow.<EOS>
<BOS>Bevacizumab is a VEGF inhibitor and angiogenesis inhibitor being used to treat childhood astrocytoma.<EOS>
<BOS>Immune checkpoint inhibitor therapy: PD1 is a protein on the surface of T cells that helps keep the bodys immune responses in check.<EOS>
<BOS>When PD1 attaches to another protein called PDL1 on a cancer cell, it stops the T cell from killing the cancer cell.<EOS>
<BOS>PD1 inhibitors attach to PDL1 and allow the T cells to kill cancer cells.<EOS>
<BOS>PD1 inhibitors are being studied to treat highgrade astrocytoma that has recurred.<EOS>
<BOS>Protein kinase inhibitors work in different ways.<EOS>
<BOS>There are several kinds of protein kinase inhibitors.<EOS>
<BOS>mTOR inhibitors stop cells from dividing and may prevent the growth of new blood vessels that tumors need to grow.<EOS>
<BOS>Everolimus and sirolimus are mTOR inhibitors used to treat childhood subependymal giant cell astrocytomas.<EOS>
<BOS>mTOR inhibitors also are being studied to treat lowgrade astrocytoma that has recurred.<EOS>
<BOS>BRAF inhibitors block proteins needed for cell growth and may kill cancer cells.<EOS>
<BOS>The BRAF inhibitor dabrafenib is being studied to treat lowgrade astrocytoma that has recurred.<EOS>
<BOS>Vemurafenib and dabrafenib have been used to treat highgrade astrocytomas that have recurred but more study is needed to know how well they work in children.<EOS>
<BOS>MEK inhibitors block proteins needed for cell growth and may kill cancer cells.<EOS>
<BOS>MEK inhibitors such as selumetinib are being studied to treat lowgrade astrocytoma that has recurred.<EOS>
<BOS>See Drugs Approved for Brain Tumors for more information.<EOS>
<BOS>New types of treatment are being tested in clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>This summary section describes treatments that are being studied in clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>It may not mention every new treatment being studied.<EOS>
<BOS>Information about clinical trials is available from the NCI website.<EOS>
<BOS>Other drug therapy Lenalidomide is a type of angiogenesis inhibitor.<EOS>
<BOS>It prevents the growth of new blood vessels that are needed by a tumor to grow.<EOS>
<BOS>If fluid builds up around the brain and spinal cord, a cerebrospinal fluid diversion procedure may be done.<EOS>
<BOS>Cerebrospinal fluid diversion is a method used to drain fluid that has built up around the brain and spinal cord.<EOS>
<BOS>A shunt (long, thin tube) is placed in a ventricle (fluidfilled space) of the brain and threaded under the skin to another part of the body, usually the abdomen.<EOS>
<BOS>The shunt carries extra fluid away from the brain so it may be absorbed elsewhere in the body.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients may want to think about taking part in a clinical trial.<EOS>
<BOS>For some patients, taking part in a clinical trial may be the best treatment choice.<EOS>
<BOS>Clinical trials are part of the cancer research process.<EOS>
<BOS>Clinical trials are done to find out if new cancer treatments are safe and effective or better than the standard treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Many of today's standard treatments for cancer are based on earlier clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients who take part in a clinical trial may receive the standard treatment or be among the first to receive a new treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients who take part in clinical trials also help improve the way cancer will be treated in the future.<EOS>
<BOS>Even when clinical trials do not lead to effective new treatments, they often answer important questions and help move research forward.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients can enter clinical trials before, during, or after starting their cancer treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Some clinical trials only include patients who have not yet received treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Other trials test treatments for patients whose cancer has not gotten better.<EOS>
<BOS>There are also clinical trials that test new ways to stop cancer from recurring (coming back) or reduce the side effects of cancer treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Clinical trials are taking place in many parts of the country.<EOS>
<BOS>See the Treatment Options section that follows for links to current treatment clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>These have been retrieved from NCI's listing of clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>Followup tests may be needed.<EOS>
<BOS>Some of the tests that were done to diagnose the cancer or to find out the stage of the cancer may be repeated.<EOS>
<BOS>(See the General Information section for a list of tests.<EOS>
<BOS>) Some tests will be repeated in order to see how well the treatment is working.<EOS>
<BOS>Decisions about whether to continue, change, or stop treatment may be based on the results of these tests.<EOS>
<BOS>Regular MRIs will continue to be done after treatment has ended.<EOS>
<BOS>The results of the MRI can show if your child's condition has changed or if the astrocytoma has recurred (come back).<EOS>
<BOS>If the results of the MRI show a mass in the brain, a biopsy may be done to find out if it is made up of dead tumor cells or if new cancer cells are growing.<EOS>
<BOS>Treatment Options for Childhood Astrocytomas Newly Diagnosed Childhood LowGrade Astrocytomas When the tumor is first diagnosed, treatment for childhood lowgrade astrocytoma depends on where the tumor is, and is usually surgery.<EOS>
<BOS>An MRI is done after surgery to see if there is tumor remaining.<EOS>
<BOS>If the tumor was completely removed by surgery, more treatment may not be needed and the child is closely watched to see if signs or symptoms appear or change.<EOS>
<BOS>This is called observation.<EOS>
<BOS>If there is tumor remaining after surgery, treatment may include the following: Observation.<EOS>
<BOS>A second surgery to remove the tumor.<EOS>
<BOS>Radiation therapy, which may include conformal radiation therapy, intensitymodulated radiation therapy, proton beam radiation therapy, or stereotactic radiation therapy, when the tumor begins to grow again.<EOS>
<BOS>Combination chemotherapy with or without radiation therapy.<EOS>
<BOS>In some cases, observation is used for children who have a visual pathway glioma.<EOS>
<BOS>In other cases, treatment may include surgery to remove the tumor, radiation therapy, or chemotherapy.<EOS>
<BOS>A goal of treatment is to save as much vision as possible.<EOS>
<BOS>The effect of tumor growth on the child's vision will be closely followed during treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Children with neurofibromatosis type 1 (NF1) may not need treatment unless the tumor grows or signs or symptoms, such as vision problems, appear.<EOS>
<BOS>When the tumor grows or signs or symptoms appear, treatment may include surgery to remove the tumor, radiation therapy, and/or chemotherapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Children with tuberous sclerosis may develop benign (not cancer) tumors in the brain called subependymal giant cell astrocytomas (SEGAs).<EOS>
<BOS>Targeted therapy with everolimus or sirolimus may be used instead of surgery, to shrink the tumors.<EOS>
<BOS>Check the list of NCIsupported cancer clinical trials that are now accepting patients with childhood lowgrade untreated astrocytoma or other tumor of glial origin.<EOS>
<BOS>For more specific results, refine the search by using other search features, such as the location of the trial, the type of treatment, or the name of the drug.<EOS>
<BOS>Talk with your child's doctor about clinical trials that may be right for your child.<EOS>
<BOS>General information about clinical trials is available from the NCI website.<EOS>
<BOS>Recurrent Childhood LowGrade Astrocytomas When lowgrade astrocytoma recurs after treatment, it usually comes back where the tumor first formed.<EOS>
<BOS>Before more cancer treatment is given, imaging tests, biopsy, or surgery are done to find out if there is cancer and how much there is.<EOS>
<BOS>Treatment of recurrent childhood lowgrade astrocytoma may include the following: A second surgery to remove the tumor, if surgery was the only treatment given when the tumor was first diagnosed.<EOS>
<BOS>Radiation therapy to the tumor only, if radiation therapy was not used when the tumor was first diagnosed.<EOS>
<BOS>Conformal radiation therapy may be given.<EOS>
<BOS>Chemotherapy, if the tumor recurred where it cannot be removed by surgery or the patient had radiation therapy when the tumor was first diagnosed.<EOS>
<BOS>Targeted therapy with a monoclonal antibody (bevacizumab) with or without chemotherapy.<EOS>
<BOS>A clinical trial of targeted therapy with a BRAF inhibitor (dabrafenib), an mTOR inhibitor (everolimus), or a MEK inhibitor (selumetinib).<EOS>
<BOS>A clinical trial of lenalidomide.<EOS>
<BOS>Check the list of NCIsupported cancer clinical trials that are now accepting patients with recurrent childhood astrocytoma or other tumor of glial origin.<EOS>
<BOS>For more specific results, refine the search by using other search features, such as the location of the trial, the type of treatment, or the name of the drug.<EOS>
<BOS>Talk with your child's doctor about clinical trials that may be right for your child.<EOS>
<BOS>General information about clinical trials is available from the NCI website.<EOS>
<BOS>Newly Diagnosed Childhood HighGrade Astrocytomas Treatment of childhood highgrade astrocytoma may include the following: Surgery to remove the tumor, followed by chemotherapy and/or radiation therapy.<EOS>
<BOS>A clinical trial of a new treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Check the list of NCIsupported cancer clinical trials that are now accepting patients with childhood highgrade untreated astrocytoma or other tumor of glial origin.<EOS>
<BOS>For more specific results, refine the search by using other search features, such as the location of the trial, the type of treatment, or the name of the drug.<EOS>
<BOS>Talk with your child's doctor about clinical trials that may be right for your child.<EOS>
<BOS>General information about clinical trials is available from the NCI website.<EOS>
<BOS>Recurrent Childhood HighGrade Astrocytomas When highgrade astrocytoma recurs after treatment, it usually comes back where the tumor first formed.<EOS>
<BOS>Before more cancer treatment is given, imaging tests, biopsy, or surgery are done to find out if there is cancer and how much there is.<EOS>
<BOS>Treatment of recurrent childhood highgrade astrocytoma may include the following: Surgery to remove the tumor.<EOS>
<BOS>Highdose chemotherapy with stem cell transplant.<EOS>
<BOS>Targeted therapy with a BRAF inhibitor (vemurafenib or dabrafenib).<EOS>
<BOS>A clinical trial of targeted therapy with an immune checkpoint inhibitor.<EOS>
<BOS>A clinical trial of a new treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Check the list of NCIsupported cancer clinical trials that are now accepting patients with recurrent childhood astrocytoma or other tumor of glial origin.<EOS>
<BOS>For more specific results, refine the search by using other search features, such as the location of the trial, the type of treatment, or the name of the drug.<EOS>
<BOS>Talk with your child's doctor about clinical trials that may be right for your child.<EOS>
<BOS>General information about clinical trials is available from the NCI website.<EOS>
<BOS>Certain factors affect prognosis (chance of recovery) and treatment options.<EOS>
<BOS>The prognosis (chance of recovery) and treatment options depend on the following: The stage of the cancer (level of PSA, Gleason score, grade of the tumor, how much of the prostate is affected by the cancer, and whether the cancer has spread to other places in the body).<EOS>
<BOS>The patients age.<EOS>
<BOS>Whether the cancer has just been diagnosed or has recurred (come back).<EOS>
<BOS>Treatment options also may depend on the following: Whether the patient has other health problems.<EOS>
<BOS>The expected side effects of treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Past treatment for prostate cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>The wishes of the patient.<EOS>
<BOS>Most men diagnosed with prostate cancer do not die of it.<EOS>
<BOS>Merkel cell carcinoma usually appears as a single painless lump on sunexposed skin.<EOS>
<BOS>This and other changes in the skin may be caused by Merkel cell carcinoma or by other conditions.<EOS>
<BOS>Check with your doctor if you see changes in your skin.<EOS>
<BOS>Merkel cell carcinoma usually appears on sunexposed skin as a single lump that is: Fastgrowing.<EOS>
<BOS>Painless.<EOS>
<BOS>Firm and domeshaped or raised.<EOS>
<BOS>Red or violet in color.<EOS>
<BOS>Key Points Once a pituitary tumor has been diagnosed, tests are done to find out if it has spread within the central nervous system (brain and spinal cord) or to other parts of the body.<EOS>
<BOS>Pituitary tumors are described in several ways.<EOS>
<BOS>Once a pituitary tumor has been diagnosed, tests are done to find out if it has spread within the central nervous system (brain and spinal cord) or to other parts of the body.<EOS>
<BOS>The extent or spread of cancer is usually described as stages.<EOS>
<BOS>There is no standard staging system for pituitary tumors.<EOS>
<BOS>Once a pituitary tumor is found, tests are done to find out if the tumor has spread into the brain or to other parts of the body.<EOS>
<BOS>The following test may be used: MRI (magnetic resonance imaging): A procedure that uses a magnet, radio waves, and a computer to make a series of detailed pictures of areas inside the body.<EOS>
<BOS>This procedure is also called nuclear magnetic resonance imaging (NMRI).<EOS>
<BOS>Pituitary tumors are described in several ways.<EOS>
<BOS>Pituitary tumors are described by their size and grade, whether or not they make extra hormones, and whether the tumor has spread to other parts of the body.<EOS>
<BOS>The following sizes are used: Microadenoma: The tumor is smaller than 1 centimeter.<EOS>
<BOS>Macroadenoma: The tumor is 1 centimeter or larger.<EOS>
<BOS>Most pituitary adenomas are microadenomas.<EOS>
<BOS>The grade of a pituitary tumor is based on how far it has grown into the surrounding area of the brain, including the sella (the bone at the base of the skull, where the pituitary gland sits).<EOS>
<BOS>Key Points After metastatic squamous neck cancer with occult primary has been diagnosed, tests are done to find out if cancer cells have spread to other parts of the body.<EOS>
<BOS>There are three ways that cancer spreads in the body.<EOS>
<BOS>After metastatic squamous neck cancer with occult primary has been diagnosed, tests are done to find out if cancer cells have spread to other parts of the body.<EOS>
<BOS>The process used to find out if cancer has spread to other parts of the body is called staging.<EOS>
<BOS>The results from tests and procedures used to detect and diagnose the primary tumor are also used to find out if cancer has spread to other parts of the body.<EOS>
<BOS>There is no standard staging system for metastatic squamous neck cancer with occult primary.<EOS>
<BOS>The tumors are described as untreated or recurrent.<EOS>
<BOS>Untreated metastatic squamous neck cancer with occult primary is cancer that is newly diagnosed and has not been treated, except to relieve signs and symptoms caused by the cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>There are three ways that cancer spreads in the body.<EOS>
<BOS>Cancer can spread through tissue, the lymph system, and the blood: Tissue.<EOS>
<BOS>The cancer spreads from where it began by growing into nearby areas.<EOS>
<BOS>Lymph system.<EOS>
<BOS>The cancer spreads from where it began by getting into the lymph system.<EOS>
<BOS>The cancer travels through the lymph vessels to other parts of the body.<EOS>
<BOS>Blood.<EOS>
<BOS>The cancer spreads from where it began by getting into the blood.<EOS>
<BOS>The cancer travels through the blood vessels to other parts of the body.<EOS>
<BOS>Key Points There are different types of treatment for patients with oropharyngeal cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients with oropharyngeal cancer should have their treatment planned by a team of doctors with expertise in treating head and neck cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Four types of standard treatment are used: Surgery Radiation therapy Chemotherapy Targeted therapy New types of treatment are being tested in clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients may want to think about taking part in a clinical trial.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients can enter clinical trials before, during, or after starting their cancer treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Followup tests may be needed.<EOS>
<BOS>There are different types of treatment for patients with oropharyngeal cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Different types of treatment are available for patients with oropharyngeal cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Some treatments are standard (the currently used treatment), and some are being tested in clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>A treatment clinical trial is a research study meant to help improve current treatments or obtain information on new treatments for patients with cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>When clinical trials show that a new treatment is better than the standard treatment, the new treatment may become the standard treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients may want to think about taking part in a clinical trial.<EOS>
<BOS>Some clinical trials are open only to patients who have not started treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients with oropharyngeal cancer should have their treatment planned by a team of doctors with expertise in treating head and neck cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>The patient's treatment will be overseen by a medical oncologist, a doctor who specializes in treating people with cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Because the oropharynx helps in breathing, eating, and talking, patients may need special help adjusting to the side effects of the cancer and its treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>The medical oncologist may refer the patient to other health professionals with special training in the treatment of patients with head and neck cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>These may include the following specialists: Head and neck surgeon.<EOS>
<BOS>Radiation oncologist.<EOS>
<BOS>Plastic surgeon.<EOS>
<BOS>Dentist.<EOS>
<BOS>Dietitian.<EOS>
<BOS>Psychologist.<EOS>
<BOS>Rehabilitation specialist.<EOS>
<BOS>Speech therapist.<EOS>
<BOS>Four types of standard treatment are used: Surgery Surgery (removing the cancer in an operation) is a common treatment of all stages of oropharyngeal cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>A surgeon may remove the cancer and some of the healthy tissue around the cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Even if the surgeon removes all the cancer that can be seen at the time of the surgery, some patients may be given chemotherapy or radiation therapy after surgery to kill any cancer cells that are left.<EOS>
<BOS>Treatment given after the surgery, to lower the risk that the cancer will come back, is called adjuvant therapy.<EOS>
<BOS>New types of surgery, including transoral robotic surgery, are being studied for the treatment of oropharyngeal cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Transoral robotic surgery may be used to remove cancer from hardtoreach areas of the mouth and throat.<EOS>
<BOS>Cameras attached to a robot give a 3dimensional (3D) image that a surgeon can see.<EOS>
<BOS>Using a computer, the surgeon guides very small tools at the ends of the robot arms to remove the cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>This procedure may also be done using an endoscope.<EOS>
<BOS>Radiation therapy Radiation therapy is a cancer treatment that uses highenergy xrays or other types of radiation to kill cancer cells or keep them from growing.<EOS>
<BOS>There are two types of radiation therapy: External radiation therapy uses a machine outside the body to send radiation toward the cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Certain ways of giving radiation therapy can help keep radiation from damaging nearby healthy tissue.<EOS>
<BOS>These types of radiation therapy include the following: Intensitymodulated radiation therapy (IMRT): IMRT is a type of 3dimensional (3D) radiation therapy that uses a computer to make pictures of the size and shape of the tumor.<EOS>
<BOS>Thin beams of radiation of different intensities (strengths) are aimed at the tumor from many angles.<EOS>
<BOS>Stereotactic body radiation therapy: Stereotactic body radiation therapy is a type of external radiation therapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Special equipment is used to place the patient in the same position for each radiation treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Once a day for several days, a radiation machine aims a larger than usual dose of radiation directly at the tumor.<EOS>
<BOS>By having the patient in the same position for each treatment, there is less damage to nearby healthy tissue.<EOS>
<BOS>This procedure is also called stereotactic externalbeam radiation therapy and stereotaxic radiation therapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Internal radiation therapy uses a radioactive substance sealed in needles, seeds, wires, or catheters that are placed directly into or near the cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>In advanced oropharyngeal cancer, dividing the daily dose of radiation into smallerdose treatments improves the way the tumor responds to treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>This is called hyperfractionated radiation therapy.<EOS>
<BOS>The way the radiation therapy is given depends on the type and stage of the cancer being treated.<EOS>
<BOS>External radiation therapy is used to treat oropharyngeal cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Radiation therapy may work better in patients who have stopped smoking before beginning treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>If the thyroid or pituitary gland are part of the radiation treatment area, the patient has an increased risk of hypothyroidism (too little thyroid hormone).<EOS>
<BOS>A blood test to check the thyroid hormone level in the body should be done before and after treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Chemotherapy Chemotherapy is a cancer treatment that uses drugs to stop the growth of cancer cells, either by killing the cells or by stopping them from dividing.<EOS>
<BOS>When chemotherapy is taken by mouth or injected into a vein or muscle, the drugs enter the bloodstream and can reach cancer cells throughout the body (systemic chemotherapy).<EOS>
<BOS>When chemotherapy is placed directly into the cerebrospinal fluid, an organ, or a body cavity such as the abdomen, the drugs mainly affect cancer cells in those areas (regional chemotherapy).<EOS>
<BOS>The way the chemotherapy is given depends on the type and stage of the cancer being treated.<EOS>
<BOS>Systemic chemotherapy is used to treat oropharyngeal cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>See Drugs Approved for Head and Neck Cancer for more information.<EOS>
<BOS>(Oropharyngeal cancer is a type of head and neck cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>) Targeted therapy Targeted therapy is a type of treatment that uses drugs or other substances to attack specific cancer cells.<EOS>
<BOS>Targeted therapies usually cause less harm to normal cells than chemotherapy or radiation therapy do.<EOS>
<BOS>Monoclonal antibodies are a type of targeted therapy being used in the treatment of oropharyngeal cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Monoclonal antibody therapy is a cancer treatment that uses antibodies made in the laboratory from a single type of immune system cell.<EOS>
<BOS>These antibodies can identify substances on cancer cells or normal substances in the blood or tissues that may help cancer cells grow.<EOS>
<BOS>The antibodies attach to the substances and kill the cancer cells, block their growth, or keep them from spreading.<EOS>
<BOS>Monoclonal antibodies are given by infusion.<EOS>
<BOS>They may be used alone or to carry drugs, toxins, or radioactive material directly to cancer cells.<EOS>
<BOS>Cetuximab is a type of monoclonal antibody that works by binding to a protein on the surface of the cancer cells and stops the cells from growing and dividing.<EOS>
<BOS>It is used in the treatment of recurrent oropharyngeal cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Other types of monoclonal antibody therapy are being studied in the treatment of oropharyngeal cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Nivolumab is being studied in the treatment of stage III and IV oropharyngeal cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>See Drugs Approved for Head and Neck Cancer for more information.<EOS>
<BOS>(Oropharyngeal cancer is a type of head and neck cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>) New types of treatment are being tested in clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>Information about clinical trials is available from the NCI website.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients may want to think about taking part in a clinical trial.<EOS>
<BOS>For some patients, taking part in a clinical trial may be the best treatment choice.<EOS>
<BOS>Clinical trials are part of the cancer research process.<EOS>
<BOS>Clinical trials are done to find out if new cancer treatments are safe and effective or better than the standard treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Many of today's standard treatments for cancer are based on earlier clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients who take part in a clinical trial may receive the standard treatment or be among the first to receive a new treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients who take part in clinical trials also help improve the way cancer will be treated in the future.<EOS>
<BOS>Even when clinical trials do not lead to effective new treatments, they often answer important questions and help move research forward.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients can enter clinical trials before, during, or after starting their cancer treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Some clinical trials only include patients who have not yet received treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Other trials test treatments for patients whose cancer has not gotten better.<EOS>
<BOS>There are also clinical trials that test new ways to stop cancer from recurring (coming back) or reduce the side effects of cancer treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Clinical trials are taking place in many parts of the country.<EOS>
<BOS>See the Treatment Options section that follows for links to current treatment clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>These have been retrieved from NCI's listing of clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>Followup tests may be needed.<EOS>
<BOS>Some of the tests that were done to diagnose the cancer or to find out the stage of the cancer may be repeated.<EOS>
<BOS>Some tests will be repeated in order to see how well the treatment is working.<EOS>
<BOS>Decisions about whether to continue, change, or stop treatment may be based on the results of these tests.<EOS>
<BOS>Some of the tests will continue to be done from time to time after treatment has ended.<EOS>
<BOS>The results of these tests can show if your condition has changed or if the cancer has recurred (come back).<EOS>
<BOS>These tests are sometimes called followup tests or checkups.<EOS>
<BOS>Following treatment, it is important to have careful head and neck exams to look for signs that the cancer has come back.<EOS>
<BOS>Checkups will be done every 6 to 12 weeks in the first year, every 3 months in the second year, every 3 to 4 months in the third year, and every 6 months thereafter.<EOS>
<BOS>Treatment Options by Stage Stage I and Stage II Oropharyngeal Cancer Treatment of stage I and stage II oropharyngeal cancer may include the following: Radiation therapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Surgery.<EOS>
<BOS>Check the list of NCIsupported cancer clinical trials that are now accepting patients with stage I oropharyngeal cancer and stage II oropharyngeal cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>For more specific results, refine the search by using other search features, such as the location of the trial, the type of treatment, or the name of the drug.<EOS>
<BOS>Talk with your doctor about clinical trials that may be right for you.<EOS>
<BOS>General information about clinical trials is available from the NCI website.<EOS>
<BOS>Stage III and Stage IV Oropharyngeal Cancer Treatment of stage III oropharyngeal cancer and stage IV oropharyngeal cancer may include the following: For patients with locally advanced cancer, surgery followed by radiation therapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Chemotherapy also may be given at the same time as radiation therapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Radiation therapy alone for patients who cannot have chemotherapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Chemotherapy given at the same time as radiation therapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Chemotherapy followed by radiation therapy given at the same time as more chemotherapy.<EOS>
<BOS>A clinical trial of chemotherapy followed by surgery or radiation therapy.<EOS>
<BOS>A clinical trial of targeted therapy (nivolumab) with chemotherapy given at the same time as radiation therapy in patients with advanced HPV positive oropharyngeal cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>A clinical trial of radiation therapy with or without chemotherapy.<EOS>
<BOS>A clinical trial of transoral surgery followed by standard or lowdose radiation therapy with or without chemotherapy in patients with HPVpositive oropharyngeal cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Check the list of NCIsupported cancer clinical trials that are now accepting patients with stage III oropharyngeal cancer and stage IV oropharyngeal cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>For more specific results, refine the search by using other search features, such as the location of the trial, the type of treatment, or the name of the drug.<EOS>
<BOS>Talk with your doctor about clinical trials that may be right for you.<EOS>
<BOS>General information about clinical trials is available from the NCI website.<EOS>
<BOS>Recurrent Oropharyngeal Cancer Treatment of recurrent oropharyngeal cancer may include the following: Surgery, if the tumor does not respond to radiation therapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Radiation therapy, if the tumor was not completely removed by surgery and previous radiation has not been given.<EOS>
<BOS>Second surgery, if the tumor was not completely removed by the first surgery.<EOS>
<BOS>Chemotherapy for patients with recurrent cancer that cannot be removed by surgery.<EOS>
<BOS>Radiation therapy given at the same time as chemotherapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Stereotactic body radiation therapy given at the same time as targeted therapy (cetuximab).<EOS>
<BOS>Clinical trials of targeted therapy, stereotactic body radiation therapy, or hyperfractionated radiation therapy given at the same time as chemotherapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Check the list of NCIsupported cancer clinical trials that are now accepting patients with recurrent oropharyngeal cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>For more specific results, refine the search by using other search features, such as the location of the trial, the type of treatment, or the name of the drug.<EOS>
<BOS>Talk with your doctor about clinical trials that may be right for you.<EOS>
<BOS>General information about clinical trials is available from the NCI website.<EOS>
<BOS>Key Points Childhood ependymoma is a disease in which malignant (cancer) cells form in the tissues of the brain and spinal cord.<EOS>
<BOS>There are different types of ependymomas.<EOS>
<BOS>The part of the brain that is affected depends on where the ependymoma forms.<EOS>
<BOS>The cause of most childhood brain tumors is unknown.<EOS>
<BOS>The signs and symptoms of childhood ependymoma are not the same in every child.<EOS>
<BOS>Tests that examine the brain and spinal cord are used to detect (find) childhood ependymoma.<EOS>
<BOS>Childhood ependymoma is diagnosed and removed in surgery.<EOS>
<BOS>Certain factors affect prognosis (chance of recovery) and treatment options.<EOS>
<BOS>Childhood ependymoma is a disease in which malignant (cancer) cells form in the tissues of the brain and spinal cord.<EOS>
<BOS>The brain controls vital functions such as memory and learning, emotion, and the senses (hearing, sight, smell, taste, and touch).<EOS>
<BOS>The spinal cord is made up of bundles of nerve fibers that connect the brain with nerves in most parts of the body.<EOS>
<BOS>Ependymomas form from ependymal cells that line the ventricles and passageways in the brain and the spinal cord.<EOS>
<BOS>Ependymal cells make cerebrospinal fluid (CSF).<EOS>
<BOS>This summary is about the treatment of primary brain tumors (tumors that begin in the brain).<EOS>
<BOS>Treatment of metastatic brain tumors, which are tumors that begin in other parts of the body and spread to the brain, is not discussed in this summary.<EOS>
<BOS>There are many different types of brain tumors.<EOS>
<BOS>Brain tumors can occur in both children and adults.<EOS>
<BOS>However, treatment for children is different than treatment for adults.<EOS>
<BOS>See the following PDQ summaries for more information: Childhood Brain and Spinal Cord Tumors Treatment Overview Adult Central Nervous System Tumors Treatment There are different types of ependymomas.<EOS>
<BOS>The World Health Organization (WHO) groups ependymal tumors into five main subtypes: Subependymoma (WHO Grade I).<EOS>
<BOS>Myxopapillary ependymoma (WHO Grade I).<EOS>
<BOS>Ependymoma (WHO Grade II).<EOS>
<BOS>RELA fusionpositive ependymoma (WHO Grade II or Grade III with change in the RELA gene).<EOS>
<BOS>Anaplastic ependymoma (WHO Grade III).<EOS>
<BOS>The grade of a tumor describes how abnormal the cancer cells look under a microscope and how quickly the tumor is likely to grow and spread.<EOS>
<BOS>Lowgrade (Grade I) cancer cells look more like normal cells than highgrade cancer cells (Grade II and III).<EOS>
<BOS>They also tend to grow and spread more slowly than Grade II and III cancer cells.<EOS>
<BOS>The part of the brain that is affected depends on where the ependymoma forms.<EOS>
<BOS>Ependymomas can form anywhere in the fluid filled ventricles and passageways in the brain and spinal cord.<EOS>
<BOS>Most ependymomas form in the fourth ventricle and affect the cerebellum and the brain stem.<EOS>
<BOS>Once an ependymoma forms, areas of the brain that may be affected include: Cerebrum: The largest part of the brain, at the top of the head.<EOS>
<BOS>The cerebrum controls thinking, learning, problemsolving, speech, emotions, reading, writing, and voluntary movement.<EOS>
<BOS>Cerebellum: The lower, back part of the brain (near the middle of the back of the head).<EOS>
<BOS>The cerebellum controls movement, balance, and posture.<EOS>
<BOS>Brain stem: The part that connects the brain to the spinal cord, in the lowest part of the brain (just above the back of the neck).<EOS>
<BOS>The brain stem controls breathing, heart rate, and the nerves and muscles used in seeing, hearing, walking, talking, and eating.<EOS>
<BOS>Spinal cord: The column of nerve tissue that runs from the brain stem down the center of the back.<EOS>
<BOS>It is covered by three thin layers of tissue called membranes.<EOS>
<BOS>The spinal cord and membranes are surrounded by the vertebrae (back bones).<EOS>
<BOS>Spinal cord nerves carry messages between the brain and the rest of the body, such as a message from the brain to cause muscles to move or a message from the skin to the brain to feel touch.<EOS>
<BOS>Avoiding risk factors and increasing protective factors may help prevent cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Avoiding cancer risk factors may help prevent certain cancers.<EOS>
<BOS>Risk factors include smoking, being overweight, and not getting enough exercise.<EOS>
<BOS>Increasing protective factors such as quitting smoking and exercising may also help prevent some cancers.<EOS>
<BOS>Talk to your doctor or other health care professional about how you might lower your risk of cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>The following risk factors may increase the risk of prostate cancer: Age Prostate cancer is rare in men younger than 50 years of age.<EOS>
<BOS>The chance of developing prostate cancer increases as men get older.<EOS>
<BOS>Family history of prostate cancer A man whose father, brother, or son has had prostate cancer has a higherthanaverage risk of prostate cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Race Prostate cancer occurs more often in AfricanAmerican men than in white men.<EOS>
<BOS>AfricanAmerican men with prostate cancer are more likely to die from the disease than white men with prostate cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Hormones The prostate needs male hormones to work the way it should.<EOS>
<BOS>The main male sex hormone is testosterone.<EOS>
<BOS>Testosterone helps the body develop and maintain male sex characteristics.<EOS>
<BOS>Testosterone is changed into dihydrotestosterone (DHT) by an enzyme in the body.<EOS>
<BOS>DHT is important for normal prostate growth but can also cause the prostate to get bigger and may play a part in the development of prostate cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Vitamin E The Selenium and Vitamin E Cancer Prevention Trial (SELECT) found that vitamin E taken alone increased the risk of prostate cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>The risk continued even after the men stopped taking vitamin E.<EOS>
<BOS>Folic acid Folate is a kind of vitamin B that occurs naturally in some foods, such as green vegetables, beans and orange juice.<EOS>
<BOS>Folic acid is a manmade form of folate that is found in vitamin supplements and fortified foods, such as wholegrain breads and cereals.<EOS>
<BOS>A 10year study showed that the risk of prostate cancer was increased in men who took 1 milligram (mg) supplements of folic acid.<EOS>
<BOS>However, the risk of prostate cancer was lower in men who had enough folate in their diets.<EOS>
<BOS>Dairy and calcium A diet high in dairy foods and calcium may cause a small increase in the risk of prostate cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>The following protective factors may decrease the risk of prostate cancer: Folate Folate is a kind of vitamin B that occurs naturally in some foods, such as green vegetables, beans and orange juice.<EOS>
<BOS>Folic acid is a manmade form of folate that is found in vitamin supplements and fortified foods, such as wholegrain breads and cereals.<EOS>
<BOS>A 10year study showed that the risk of prostate cancer was lower in men who had enough folate in their diets.<EOS>
<BOS>However, the risk of prostate cancer was increased in men who took 1 milligram (mg) supplements of folic acid.<EOS>
<BOS>Finasteride and Dutasteride Finasteride and dutasteride are drugs used to lower the amount of male sex hormones made by the body.<EOS>
<BOS>These drugs block the enzyme that changes testosterone into dihydrotestosterone (DHT).<EOS>
<BOS>Higher than normal levels of DHT may play a part in developing prostate cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Taking finasteride or dutasteride has been shown to lower the risk for prostate cancer, but it is not known if these drugs lower the risk of death from prostate cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>The Prostate Cancer Prevention Trial (PCPT) studied whether the drug finasteride can prevent prostate cancer in healthy men 55 years of age and older.<EOS>
<BOS>This prevention study showed there were fewer prostate cancers in the group of men that took finasteride compared with the group of men that did not.<EOS>
<BOS>Also, the men who took finasteride who did have prostate cancer had more aggressive tumors.<EOS>
<BOS>The number of deaths from prostate cancer was the same in both groups.<EOS>
<BOS>Men who took finasteride reported more side effects compared with the group of men that did not, including erectile dysfunction, loss of desire for sex, and enlarged breasts.<EOS>
<BOS>The Reduction by Dutasteride of Prostate Cancer Events Trial (REDUCE) studied whether the drug dutasteride can prevent prostate cancer in men aged 50 to 75 years at higher risk for the disease.<EOS>
<BOS>This prevention study showed there were fewer prostate cancers in the group of men who took dutasteride compared with the group of men that did not.<EOS>
<BOS>The number of less aggressive prostate cancers was lower, but the number of more aggressive prostate cancers was not.<EOS>
<BOS>Men who took dutasteride reported more side effects than men who did not, including erectile dysfunction, loss of desire for sex, less semen, and gynecomastia (enlarged breasts).<EOS>
<BOS>The following have been proven not to affect the risk of prostate cancer, or their effects on prostate cancer risk are not known: Selenium and vitamin E The Selenium and Vitamin E Cancer Prevention Trial (SELECT) studied whether taking vitamin E and selenium (a mineral) will prevent prostate cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>The selenium and vitamin E were taken separately or together by healthy men 55 years of age and older (50 years of age and older for AfricanAmerican men).<EOS>
<BOS>The study showed that taking selenium alone or selenium and vitamin E together did not decrease the risk of prostate cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Diet It is not known if decreasing fat or increasing fruits and vegetables in the diet helps decrease the risk of prostate cancer or death from prostate cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>In the PCPT trial, certain fatty acids increased the risk of highgrade prostate cancer while others decreased the risk of highgrade prostate cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Multivitamins Regular use of multivitamins has not been proven to increase the risk of early or localized prostate cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>However, a large study showed an increased risk of advanced prostate cancer among men who took multivitamins more than seven times a week.<EOS>
<BOS>Lycopene Some studies have shown that a diet high in lycopene may be linked to a decreased risk of prostate cancer, but other studies have not.<EOS>
<BOS>It has not been proven that taking lycopene supplements decreases the risk of prostate cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Key Points There are different types of treatment for patients with paranasal sinus and nasal cavity cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients with paranasal sinus and nasal cavity cancer should have their treatment planned by a team of doctors with expertise in treating head and neck cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Three types of standard treatment are used: Surgery Radiation therapy Chemotherapy New types of treatment are being tested in clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients may want to think about taking part in a clinical trial.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients can enter clinical trials before, during, or after starting their cancer treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Followup tests may be needed.<EOS>
<BOS>There are different types of treatment for patients with paranasal sinus and nasal cavity cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Different types of treatment are available for patients with paranasal sinus and nasal cavity cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Some treatments are standard (the currently used treatment), and some are being tested in clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>A treatment clinical trial is a research study meant to help improve current treatments or obtain information on new treatments for patients with cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>When clinical trials show that a new treatment is better than the standard treatment, the new treatment may become the standard treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients may want to think about taking part in a clinical trial.<EOS>
<BOS>Some clinical trials are open only to patients who have not started treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients with paranasal sinus and nasal cavity cancer should have their treatment planned by a team of doctors with expertise in treating head and neck cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Treatment will be overseen by a medical oncologist, a doctor who specializes in treating people with cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>The medical oncologist works with other doctors who are experts in treating patients with head and neck cancer and who specialize in certain areas of medicine and rehabilitation.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients who have paranasal sinus and nasal cavity cancer may need special help adjusting to breathing problems or other side effects of the cancer and its treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>If a large amount of tissue or bone around the paranasal sinuses or nasal cavity is taken out, plastic surgery may be done to repair or rebuild the area.<EOS>
<BOS>The treatment team may include the following specialists: Radiation oncologist.<EOS>
<BOS>Neurologist.<EOS>
<BOS>Oral surgeon or head and neck surgeon.<EOS>
<BOS>Plastic surgeon.<EOS>
<BOS>Dentist.<EOS>
<BOS>Nutritionist.<EOS>
<BOS>Speech and language pathologist.<EOS>
<BOS>Rehabilitation specialist.<EOS>
<BOS>Three types of standard treatment are used: Surgery Surgery (removing the cancer in an operation) is a common treatment for all stages of paranasal sinus and nasal cavity cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>A doctor may remove the cancer and some of the healthy tissue and bone around the cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>If the cancer has spread, the doctor may remove lymph nodes and other tissues in the neck.<EOS>
<BOS>Even if the doctor removes all the cancer that can be seen at the time of the surgery, some patients may be given chemotherapy or radiation therapy after surgery to kill any cancer cells that are left.<EOS>
<BOS>Treatment given after surgery, to lower the risk that the cancer will come back, is called adjuvant therapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Radiation therapy Radiation therapy is a cancer treatment that uses highenergy xrays or other types of radiation to kill cancer cells or keep them from growing.<EOS>
<BOS>There are two types of radiation therapy: External radiation therapy uses a machine outside the body to send radiation toward the cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>The total dose of radiation therapy is sometimes divided into several smaller, equal doses delivered over a period of several days.<EOS>
<BOS>This is called fractionation.<EOS>
<BOS>Internal radiation therapy uses a radioactive substance sealed in needles, seeds, wires, or catheters that are placed directly into or near the cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>The way the radiation therapy is given depends on the type and stage of the cancer being treated.<EOS>
<BOS>External and internal radiation therapy are used to treat paranasal sinus and nasal cavity cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>External radiation therapy to the thyroid or the pituitary gland may change the way the thyroid gland works.<EOS>
<BOS>The thyroid hormone levels in the blood may be tested before and after treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Chemotherapy Chemotherapy is a cancer treatment that uses drugs to stop the growth of cancer cells, either by killing the cells or by stopping them from dividing.<EOS>
<BOS>When chemotherapy is taken by mouth or injected into a vein or muscle, the drugs enter the bloodstream and can reach cancer cells throughout the body (systemic chemotherapy).<EOS>
<BOS>When chemotherapy is placed directly into the cerebrospinal fluid, an organ, or a body cavity such as the abdomen, the drugs mainly affect cancer cells in those areas (regional chemotherapy).<EOS>
<BOS>Combination chemotherapy is treatment using more than one anticancer drug.<EOS>
<BOS>The way the chemotherapy is given depends on the type and stage of the cancer being treated.<EOS>
<BOS>See Drugs Approved for Head and Neck Cancer for more information.<EOS>
<BOS>(Paranasal sinus and nasal cavity cancer is a type of head and neck cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>) New types of treatment are being tested in clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>Information about clinical trials is available from the NCI website.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients may want to think about taking part in a clinical trial.<EOS>
<BOS>For some patients, taking part in a clinical trial may be the best treatment choice.<EOS>
<BOS>Clinical trials are part of the cancer research process.<EOS>
<BOS>Clinical trials are done to find out if new cancer treatments are safe and effective or better than the standard treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Many of today's standard treatments for cancer are based on earlier clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients who take part in a clinical trial may receive the standard treatment or be among the first to receive a new treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients who take part in clinical trials also help improve the way cancer will be treated in the future.<EOS>
<BOS>Even when clinical trials do not lead to effective new treatments, they often answer important questions and help move research forward.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients can enter clinical trials before, during, or after starting their cancer treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Some clinical trials only include patients who have not yet received treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Other trials test treatments for patients whose cancer has not gotten better.<EOS>
<BOS>There are also clinical trials that test new ways to stop cancer from recurring (coming back) or reduce the side effects of cancer treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Clinical trials are taking place in many parts of the country.<EOS>
<BOS>See the Treatment Options section that follows for links to current treatment clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>These have been retrieved from NCI's listing of clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>Followup tests may be needed.<EOS>
<BOS>Some of the tests that were done to diagnose the cancer or to find out the stage of the cancer may be repeated.<EOS>
<BOS>Some tests will be repeated in order to see how well the treatment is working.<EOS>
<BOS>Decisions about whether to continue, change, or stop treatment may be based on the results of these tests.<EOS>
<BOS>Some of the tests will continue to be done from time to time after treatment has ended.<EOS>
<BOS>The results of these tests can show if your condition has changed or if the cancer has recurred (come back).<EOS>
<BOS>These tests are sometimes called followup tests or checkups.<EOS>
<BOS>Treatment Options by Stage Stage I Paranasal Sinus and Nasal Cavity Cancer Treatment of stage I paranasal sinus and nasal cavity cancer depends on where cancer is found in the paranasal sinuses and nasal cavity: If cancer is in the maxillary sinus, treatment is usually surgery with or without radiation therapy.<EOS>
<BOS>If cancer is in the ethmoid sinus, treatment is usually radiation therapy and/or surgery.<EOS>
<BOS>If cancer is in the sphenoid sinus, treatment is the same as for nasopharyngeal cancer, usually radiation therapy.<EOS>
<BOS>(See the PDQ summary on Nasopharyngeal Cancer Treatment for more information.<EOS>
<BOS>) If cancer is in the nasal cavity, treatment is usually surgery and/or radiation therapy.<EOS>
<BOS>If cancer is in the nasal vestibule, treatment is usually surgery or radiation therapy.<EOS>
<BOS>For inverting papilloma, treatment is usually surgery with or without radiation therapy.<EOS>
<BOS>For melanoma and sarcoma, treatment is usually surgery with or without radiation therapy and chemotherapy.<EOS>
<BOS>For midline granuloma, treatment is usually radiation therapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Check the list of NCIsupported cancer clinical trials that are now accepting patients with stage I paranasal sinus and nasal cavity cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>For more specific results, refine the search by using other search features, such as the location of the trial, the type of treatment, or the name of the drug.<EOS>
<BOS>Talk with your doctor about clinical trials that may be right for you.<EOS>
<BOS>General information about clinical trials is available from the NCI website.<EOS>
<BOS>Stage II Paranasal Sinus and Nasal Cavity Cancer Treatment of stage II paranasal sinus and nasal cavity cancer depends on where cancer is found in the paranasal sinuses and nasal cavity: If cancer is in the maxillary sinus, treatment is usually highdose radiation therapy before or after surgery.<EOS>
<BOS>If cancer is in the ethmoid sinus, treatment is usually radiation therapy and/or surgery.<EOS>
<BOS>If cancer is in the sphenoid sinus, treatment is the same as for nasopharyngeal cancer, usually radiation therapy with or without chemotherapy.<EOS>
<BOS>(See the PDQ summary on Nasopharyngeal Cancer Treatment for more information.<EOS>
<BOS>) If cancer is in the nasal cavity, treatment is usually surgery and/or radiation therapy.<EOS>
<BOS>If cancer is in the nasal vestibule, treatment is usually surgery or radiation therapy.<EOS>
<BOS>For inverting papilloma, treatment is usually surgery with or without radiation therapy.<EOS>
<BOS>For melanoma and sarcoma, treatment is usually surgery with or without radiation therapy and chemotherapy.<EOS>
<BOS>For midline granuloma, treatment is usually radiation therapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Check the list of NCIsupported cancer clinical trials that are now accepting patients with stage II paranasal sinus and nasal cavity cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>For more specific results, refine the search by using other search features, such as the location of the trial, the type of treatment, or the name of the drug.<EOS>
<BOS>Talk with your doctor about clinical trials that may be right for you.<EOS>
<BOS>General information about clinical trials is available from the NCI website.<EOS>
<BOS>Stage III Paranasal Sinus and Nasal Cavity Cancer Treatment of stage III paranasal sinus and nasal cavity cancer depends on where cancer is found in the paranasal sinuses and nasal cavity.<EOS>
<BOS>If cancer is in the maxillary sinus, treatment may include the following: Highdose radiation therapy before or after surgery.<EOS>
<BOS>A clinical trial of fractionated radiation therapy before or after surgery.<EOS>
<BOS>If cancer is in the ethmoid sinus, treatment may include the following: Surgery followed by radiation therapy.<EOS>
<BOS>A clinical trial of combination chemotherapy before surgery or radiation therapy.<EOS>
<BOS>A clinical trial of combination chemotherapy after surgery or other cancer treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>If cancer is in the sphenoid sinus, treatment is the same as for nasopharyngeal cancer, usually radiation therapy with or without chemotherapy.<EOS>
<BOS>(See the PDQ summary on Nasopharyngeal Cancer Treatment for more information.<EOS>
<BOS>) If cancer is in the nasal cavity, treatment may include the following: Surgery and/or radiation therapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Chemotherapy and radiation therapy.<EOS>
<BOS>A clinical trial of combination chemotherapy before surgery or radiation therapy.<EOS>
<BOS>A clinical trial of combination chemotherapy after surgery or other cancer treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>For inverting papilloma, treatment is usually surgery with or without radiation therapy.<EOS>
<BOS>For melanoma and sarcoma, treatment may include the following: Surgery.<EOS>
<BOS>Radiation therapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Surgery, radiation therapy, and chemotherapy.<EOS>
<BOS>For midline granuloma, treatment is usually radiation therapy.<EOS>
<BOS>If cancer is in the nasal vestibule, treatment may include the following: External radiation therapy and/or internal radiation therapy with or without surgery.<EOS>
<BOS>A clinical trial of combination chemotherapy before surgery or radiation therapy.<EOS>
<BOS>A clinical trial of combination chemotherapy after surgery or other cancer treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Check the list of NCIsupported cancer clinical trials that are now accepting patients with stage III paranasal sinus and nasal cavity cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>For more specific results, refine the search by using other search features, such as the location of the trial, the type of treatment, or the name of the drug.<EOS>
<BOS>Talk with your doctor about clinical trials that may be right for you.<EOS>
<BOS>General information about clinical trials is available from the NCI website.<EOS>
<BOS>Stage IV Paranasal Sinus and Nasal Cavity Cancer Treatment of stage IV paranasal sinus and nasal cavity cancer depends on where cancer is found in the paranasal sinuses and nasal cavity.<EOS>
<BOS>If cancer is in the maxillary sinus, treatment may include the following: Highdose radiation therapy with or without surgery.<EOS>
<BOS>A clinical trial of fractionated radiation therapy.<EOS>
<BOS>A clinical trial of chemotherapy before surgery or radiation therapy.<EOS>
<BOS>A clinical trial of chemotherapy after surgery or other cancer treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>A clinical trial of chemotherapy and radiation therapy.<EOS>
<BOS>If cancer is in the ethmoid sinus, treatment may include the following: Radiation therapy before or after surgery.<EOS>
<BOS>Chemotherapy and radiation therapy.<EOS>
<BOS>A clinical trial of chemotherapy before surgery or radiation therapy.<EOS>
<BOS>A clinical trial of chemotherapy after surgery or other cancer treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>A clinical trial of chemotherapy and radiation therapy.<EOS>
<BOS>If cancer is in the sphenoid sinus, treatment is the same as for nasopharyngeal cancer, usually radiation therapy with or without chemotherapy.<EOS>
<BOS>(See the PDQ summary on Nasopharyngeal Cancer Treatment for more information.<EOS>
<BOS>) If cancer is in the nasal cavity, treatment may include the following: Surgery and/or radiation therapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Chemotherapy and radiation therapy.<EOS>
<BOS>A clinical trial of chemotherapy before surgery or radiation therapy.<EOS>
<BOS>A clinical trial of chemotherapy after surgery or other cancer treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>A clinical trial of chemotherapy and radiation therapy.<EOS>
<BOS>For inverting papilloma, treatment is usually surgery with or without radiation therapy.<EOS>
<BOS>For melanoma and sarcoma, treatment may include the following: Surgery.<EOS>
<BOS>Radiation therapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Chemotherapy.<EOS>
<BOS>For midline granuloma, treatment is usually radiation therapy.<EOS>
<BOS>If cancer is in the nasal vestibule, treatment may include the following: External radiation therapy and/or internal radiation therapy with or without surgery.<EOS>
<BOS>A clinical trial of chemotherapy before surgery or radiation therapy.<EOS>
<BOS>A clinical trial of chemotherapy after surgery or other cancer treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>A clinical trial of chemotherapy and radiation therapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Check the list of NCIsupported cancer clinical trials that are now accepting patients with stage IV paranasal sinus and nasal cavity cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>For more specific results, refine the search by using other search features, such as the location of the trial, the type of treatment, or the name of the drug.<EOS>
<BOS>Talk with your doctor about clinical trials that may be right for you.<EOS>
<BOS>General information about clinical trials is available from the NCI website.<EOS>
<BOS>Certain factors affect prognosis (chance of recovery and treatment options).<EOS>
