<BOS>The prognosis (chance of recovery) and treatment options depend on the following: The type of cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>The size of the tumor.<EOS>
<BOS>The stage of cancer (whether it affects part of the ovary, involves the whole ovary, or has spread to other places in the body).<EOS>
<BOS>The way the cancer cells look under a microscope.<EOS>
<BOS>The patients general health.<EOS>
<BOS>Ovarian germ cell tumors are usually cured if found and treated early.<EOS>
<BOS>Certain factors affect prognosis (chance of recovery) and treatment options.<EOS>
<BOS>The prognosis (chance of recovery) and treatment options depend on the following: The patient's signs and symptoms.<EOS>
<BOS>The stage of the cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>The type of Hodgkin lymphoma.<EOS>
<BOS>Blood test results.<EOS>
<BOS>The patient's age, gender, and general health.<EOS>
<BOS>Whether the cancer is recurrent or progressive.<EOS>
<BOS>For Hodgkin lymphoma during pregnancy, treatment options also depend on: The wishes of the patient.<EOS>
<BOS>The age of the fetus.<EOS>
<BOS>Adult Hodgkin lymphoma can usually be cured if found and treated early.<EOS>
<BOS>Signs of penile cancer include sores, discharge, and bleeding.<EOS>
<BOS>These and other signs may be caused by penile cancer or by other conditions.<EOS>
<BOS>Check with your doctor if you have any of the following: Redness, irritation, or a sore on the penis.<EOS>
<BOS>A lump on the penis.<EOS>
<BOS>Key Points Prostate cancer is a disease in which malignant (cancer) cells form in the tissues of the prostate.<EOS>
<BOS>Prostate cancer is the most common nonskin cancer among men in the United States.<EOS>
<BOS>Different factors increase or decrease the risk of developing prostate cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Prostate cancer is a disease in which malignant (cancer) cells form in the tissues of the prostate.<EOS>
<BOS>The prostate is a gland in the male reproductive system located just below the bladder (the organ that collects and empties urine) and in front of the rectum (the lower part of the intestine).<EOS>
<BOS>It is about the size of a walnut and surrounds part of the urethra (the tube that empties urine from the bladder).<EOS>
<BOS>The prostate gland produces fluid that makes up part of semen.<EOS>
<BOS>As men age, the prostate may get bigger.<EOS>
<BOS>A bigger prostate may block the flow of urine from the bladder and cause problems with sexual function.<EOS>
<BOS>This condition is called benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH), and although it is not cancer, surgery may be needed to correct it.<EOS>
<BOS>The symptoms of benign prostatic hyperplasia or of other problems in the prostate may be similar to symptoms of prostate cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>See the following PDQ summaries for more information about prostate cancer: Prostate Cancer Prevention Prostate Cancer Treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Key Points There are different types of treatment for patients with AIDSrelated lymphoma.<EOS>
<BOS>Treatment of AIDSrelated lymphoma combines treatment of the lymphoma with treatment for AIDS.<EOS>
<BOS>Four types of standard treatment are used: Chemotherapy Radiation therapy Highdose chemotherapy with stem cell transplant Targeted therapy New types of treatment are being tested in clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients may want to think about taking part in a clinical trial.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients can enter clinical trials before, during, or after starting their cancer treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Followup tests may be needed.<EOS>
<BOS>There are different types of treatment for patients with AIDSrelated lymphoma.<EOS>
<BOS>Different types of treatment are available for patients with AIDSrelated lymphoma.<EOS>
<BOS>Some treatments are standard (the currently used treatment), and some are being tested in clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>A treatment clinical trial is a research study meant to help improve current treatments or obtain information on new treatments for patients with cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>When clinical trials show that a new treatment is better than the standard treatment, the new treatment may become the standard treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients may want to think about taking part in a clinical trial.<EOS>
<BOS>Some clinical trials are open only to patients who have not started treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Treatment of AIDSrelated lymphoma combines treatment of the lymphoma with treatment for AIDS.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients with AIDS have weakened immune systems and treatment can cause the immune system to become even weaker.<EOS>
<BOS>For this reason, treating patients who have AIDSrelated lymphoma is difficult and some patients may be treated with lower doses of drugs than lymphoma patients who do not have AIDS.<EOS>
<BOS>Combined antiretroviral therapy (cART) is used to lessen the damage to the immune system caused by HIV.<EOS>
<BOS>Treatment with combined antiretroviral therapy may allow some patients with AIDSrelated lymphoma to safely receive anticancer drugs in standard or higher doses.<EOS>
<BOS>In these patients, treatment may work as well as it does in lymphoma patients who do not have AIDS.<EOS>
<BOS>Medicine to prevent and treat infections, which can be serious, is also used.<EOS>
<BOS>For more information about AIDS and its treatment, please see the AIDSinfo website.<EOS>
<BOS>Four types of standard treatment are used: Chemotherapy Chemotherapy is a cancer treatment that uses drugs to stop the growth of cancer cells, either by killing the cells or by stopping them from dividing.<EOS>
<BOS>When chemotherapy is taken by mouth or injected into a vein or muscle, the drugs enter the bloodstream and can reach cancer cells throughout the body (systemic chemotherapy).<EOS>
<BOS>When chemotherapy is placed directly into the cerebrospinal fluid (intrathecal chemotherapy), an organ, or a body cavity such as the abdomen, the drugs mainly affect cancer cells in those areas (regional chemotherapy).<EOS>
<BOS>Combination chemotherapy is treatment using more than one anticancer drug.<EOS>
<BOS>The way the chemotherapy is given depends on where the cancer has formed.<EOS>
<BOS>Intrathecal chemotherapy may be used in patients who are more likely to have lymphoma in the central nervous system (CNS).<EOS>
<BOS>Chemotherapy is used in the treatment of AIDSrelated peripheral/systemic lymphoma.<EOS>
<BOS>It is not yet known whether it is best to give combined antiretroviral therapy at the same time as chemotherapy or after chemotherapy ends.<EOS>
<BOS>Colonystimulating factors are sometimes given together with chemotherapy.<EOS>
<BOS>This helps lessen the side effects chemotherapy may have on the bone marrow.<EOS>
<BOS>Radiation therapy Radiation therapy is a cancer treatment that uses highenergy xrays or other types of radiation to kill cancer cells or keep them from growing.<EOS>
<BOS>There are two types of radiation therapy: External radiation therapy uses a machine outside the body to send radiation toward the cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Internal radiation therapy uses a radioactive substance sealed in needles, seeds, wires, or catheters that are placed directly into or near the cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>The way the radiation therapy is given depends on where the cancer has formed.<EOS>
<BOS>External radiation therapy is used to treat AIDSrelated primary CNS lymphoma.<EOS>
<BOS>Highdose chemotherapy with stem cell transplant Highdose chemotherapy with stem cell transplant is a way of giving high doses of chemotherapy and replacing blood forming cells destroyed by the cancer treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Stem cells (immature blood cells) are removed from the blood or bone marrow of the patient or a donor and are frozen and stored.<EOS>
<BOS>After the chemotherapy is completed, the stored stem cells are thawed and given back to the patient through an infusion.<EOS>
<BOS>These reinfused stem cells grow into (and restore) the body's blood cells.<EOS>
<BOS>Targeted therapy Targeted therapy is a type of treatment that uses drugs or other substances to identify and attack specific cancer cells without harming normal cells.<EOS>
<BOS>Monoclonal antibody therapy is a type of targeted therapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Monoclonal antibody therapy is a cancer treatment that uses antibodies made in the laboratory from a single type of immune system cell.<EOS>
<BOS>These antibodies can identify substances on cancer cells or normal substances that may help cancer cells grow.<EOS>
<BOS>The antibodies attach to the substances and kill the cancer cells, block their growth, or keep them from spreading.<EOS>
<BOS>Monoclonal antibodies are given by infusion.<EOS>
<BOS>These may be used alone or to carry drugs, toxins, or radioactive material directly to cancer cells.<EOS>
<BOS>Rituximab is used in the treatment of AIDSrelated peripheral/systemic lymphoma.<EOS>
<BOS>New types of treatment are being tested in clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>Information about clinical trials is available from the NCI website.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients may want to think about taking part in a clinical trial.<EOS>
<BOS>For some patients, taking part in a clinical trial may be the best treatment choice.<EOS>
<BOS>Clinical trials are part of the cancer research process.<EOS>
<BOS>Clinical trials are done to find out if new cancer treatments are safe and effective or better than the standard treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Many of today's standard treatments for cancer are based on earlier clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients who take part in a clinical trial may receive the standard treatment or be among the first to receive a new treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients who take part in clinical trials also help improve the way cancer will be treated in the future.<EOS>
<BOS>Even when clinical trials do not lead to effective new treatments, they often answer important questions and help move research forward.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients can enter clinical trials before, during, or after starting their cancer treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Some clinical trials only include patients who have not yet received treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Other trials test treatments for patients whose cancer has not gotten better.<EOS>
<BOS>There are also clinical trials that test new ways to stop cancer from recurring (coming back) or reduce the side effects of cancer treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Clinical trials are taking place in many parts of the country.<EOS>
<BOS>See the Treatment Options section that follows for links to current treatment clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>These have been retrieved from NCI's listing of clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>Followup tests may be needed.<EOS>
<BOS>Some of the tests that were done to diagnose the cancer or to find out the stage of the cancer may be repeated.<EOS>
<BOS>Some tests will be repeated in order to see how well the treatment is working.<EOS>
<BOS>Decisions about whether to continue, change, or stop treatment may be based on the results of these tests.<EOS>
<BOS>Some of the tests will continue to be done from time to time after treatment has ended.<EOS>
<BOS>The results of these tests can show if your condition has changed or if the cancer has recurred (come back).<EOS>
<BOS>These tests are sometimes called followup tests or checkups.<EOS>
<BOS>Treatment Options for AIDSRelated Lymphoma AIDSRelated Peripheral/Systemic Lymphoma Treatment of AIDSrelated peripheral/systemic lymphoma may include the following: Combination chemotherapy with or without targeted therapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Highdose chemotherapy and stem cell transplant, for lymphoma that has not responded to treatment or has come back.<EOS>
<BOS>Intrathecal chemotherapy for lymphoma that is likely to spread to the central nervous system (CNS).<EOS>
<BOS>Check the list of NCIsupported cancer clinical trials that are now accepting patients with AIDSrelated peripheral/systemic lymphoma.<EOS>
<BOS>For more specific results, refine the search by using other search features, such as the location of the trial, the type of treatment, or the name of the drug.<EOS>
<BOS>Talk with your doctor about clinical trials that may be right for you.<EOS>
<BOS>General information about clinical trials is available from the NCI website.<EOS>
<BOS>AIDSRelated Primary Central Nervous System Lymphoma Treatment of AIDSrelated primary central nervous system lymphoma may include the following: External radiation therapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Check the list of NCIsupported cancer clinical trials that are now accepting patients with AIDSrelated primary CNS lymphoma.<EOS>
<BOS>For more specific results, refine the search by using other search features, such as the location of the trial, the type of treatment, or the name of the drug.<EOS>
<BOS>Talk with your doctor about clinical trials that may be right for you.<EOS>
<BOS>General information about clinical trials is available from the NCI website.<EOS>
<BOS>New types of treatment are being tested in clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>This summary section describes treatments that are being studied in clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>It may not mention every new treatment being studied.<EOS>
<BOS>Information about clinical trials is available from the NCI website.<EOS>
<BOS>Highdose chemotherapy with bone marrow transplant Highdose chemotherapy with bone marrow transplant is a method of giving very high doses of chemotherapy and replacing blood forming cells destroyed by the cancer treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Stem cells (immature blood cells) are removed from the bone marrow of the patient or a donor and are frozen and stored.<EOS>
<BOS>After the chemotherapy is completed, the stored stem cells are thawed and given back to the patient through an infusion.<EOS>
<BOS>These reinfused stem cells grow into (and restore) the bodys blood cells.<EOS>
<BOS>New treatment options Combination chemotherapy (the use of more than one anticancer drug) is being tested in clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients may want to think about taking part in a clinical trial.<EOS>
<BOS>For some patients, taking part in a clinical trial may be the best treatment choice.<EOS>
<BOS>Clinical trials are part of the cancer research process.<EOS>
<BOS>Clinical trials are done to find out if new cancer treatments are safe and effective or better than the standard treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Many of today's standard treatments for cancer are based on earlier clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients who take part in a clinical trial may receive the standard treatment or be among the first to receive a new treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients who take part in clinical trials also help improve the way cancer will be treated in the future.<EOS>
<BOS>Even when clinical trials do not lead to effective new treatments, they often answer important questions and help move research forward.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients can enter clinical trials before, during, or after starting their cancer treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Some clinical trials only include patients who have not yet received treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Other trials test treatments for patients whose cancer has not gotten better.<EOS>
<BOS>There are also clinical trials that test new ways to stop cancer from recurring (coming back) or reduce the side effects of cancer treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Clinical trials are taking place in many parts of the country.<EOS>
<BOS>See the Treatment Options section that follows for links to current treatment clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>These have been retrieved from NCI's listing of clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>Key Points Lip and oral cavity cancer is a disease in which malignant (cancer) cells form in the lips or mouth.<EOS>
<BOS>Tobacco and alcohol use can affect the risk of lip and oral cavity cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Signs of lip and oral cavity cancer include a sore or lump on the lips or in the mouth.<EOS>
<BOS>Tests that examine the mouth and throat are used to detect (find), diagnose, and stage lip and oral cavity cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Certain factors affect prognosis (chance of recovery) and treatment options.<EOS>
<BOS>Lip and oral cavity cancer is a disease in which malignant (cancer) cells form in the lips or mouth.<EOS>
<BOS>The oral cavity includes the following: The front two thirds of the tongue.<EOS>
<BOS>The gingiva (gums).<EOS>
<BOS>The buccal mucosa (the lining of the inside of the cheeks).<EOS>
<BOS>The floor (bottom) of the mouth under the tongue.<EOS>
<BOS>The hard palate (the roof of the mouth).<EOS>
<BOS>The retromolar trigone (the small area behind the wisdom teeth).<EOS>
<BOS>Most lip and oral cavity cancers start in squamous cells, the thin, flat cells that line the lips and oral cavity.<EOS>
<BOS>These are called squamous cell carcinomas.<EOS>
<BOS>Cancer cells may spread into deeper tissue as the cancer grows.<EOS>
<BOS>Squamous cell carcinoma usually develops in areas of leukoplakia (white patches of cells that do not rub off).<EOS>
<BOS>Lip and oral cavity cancer is a type of head and neck cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Tests that examine the small intestine are used to detect (find), diagnose, and stage small intestine cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Procedures that make pictures of the small intestine and the area around it help diagnose small intestine cancer and show how far the cancer has spread.<EOS>
<BOS>The process used to find out if cancer cells have spread within and around the small intestine is called staging.<EOS>
<BOS>In order to plan treatment, it is important to know the type of small intestine cancer and whether the tumor can be removed by surgery.<EOS>
<BOS>Tests and procedures to detect, diagnose, and stage small intestine cancer are usually done at the same time.<EOS>
<BOS>The following tests and procedures may be used: Physical exam and history : An exam of the body to check general signs of health, including checking for signs of disease, such as lumps or anything else that seems unusual.<EOS>
<BOS>A history of the patients health habits and past illnesses and treatments will also be taken.<EOS>
<BOS>Blood chemistry studies : A procedure in which a blood sample is checked to measure the amounts of certain substances released into the blood by organs and tissues in the body.<EOS>
<BOS>An unusual (higher or lower than normal) amount of a substance can be a sign of disease.<EOS>
<BOS>Liver function tests : A procedure in which a blood sample is checked to measure the amounts of certain substances released into the blood by the liver.<EOS>
<BOS>A higher than normal amount of a substance can be a sign of liver disease that may be caused by small intestine cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Endoscopy : A procedure to look at organs and tissues inside the body to check for abnormal areas.<EOS>
<BOS>There are different types of endoscopy: Upper endoscopy : A procedure to look at the inside of the esophagus, stomach, and duodenum (first part of the small intestine, near the stomach).<EOS>
<BOS>An endoscope is inserted through the mouth and into the esophagus, stomach, and duodenum.<EOS>
<BOS>An endoscope is a thin, tubelike instrument with a light and a lens for viewing.<EOS>
<BOS>It may also have a tool to remove tissue samples, which are checked under a microscope for signs of cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Capsule endoscopy : A procedure to look at the inside of the small intestine.<EOS>
<BOS>A capsule that is about the size of a large pill and contains a light and a tiny wireless camera is swallowed by the patient.<EOS>
<BOS>The capsule travels through the digestive tract, including the small intestine, and sends many pictures of the inside of the digestive tract to a recorder that is worn around the waist or over the shoulder.<EOS>
<BOS>The pictures are sent from the recorder to a computer and viewed by the doctor who checks for signs of cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>The capsule passes out of the body during a bowel movement.<EOS>
<BOS>Double balloon endoscopy : A procedure to look at the inside of the small intestine.<EOS>
<BOS>A special instrument made up of two tubes (one inside the other) is inserted through the mouth or rectum and into the small intestine.<EOS>
<BOS>The inside tube (an endoscope with a light and lens for viewing) is moved through part of the small intestine and a balloon at the end of it is inflated to keep the endoscope in place.<EOS>
<BOS>Next, the outer tube is moved through the small intestine to reach the end of the endoscope, and a balloon at the end of the outer tube is inflated to keep it in place.<EOS>
<BOS>Then, the balloon at the end of the endoscope is deflated and the endoscope is moved through the next part of the small intestine.<EOS>
<BOS>These steps are repeated many times as the tubes move through the small intestine.<EOS>
<BOS>The doctor is able to see the inside of the small intestine through the endoscope and use a tool to remove samples of abnormal tissue.<EOS>
<BOS>The tissue samples are checked under a microscope for signs of cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>This procedure may be done if the results of a capsule endoscopy are abnormal.<EOS>
<BOS>This procedure is also called double balloon enteroscopy.<EOS>
<BOS>Laparotomy : A surgical procedure in which an incision (cut) is made in the wall of the abdomen to check the inside of the abdomen for signs of disease.<EOS>
<BOS>The size of the incision depends on the reason the laparotomy is being done.<EOS>
<BOS>Sometimes organs or lymph nodes are removed or tissue samples are taken and checked under a microscope for signs of disease.<EOS>
<BOS>Biopsy : The removal of cells or tissues so they can be viewed under a microscope to check for signs of cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>This may be done during an endoscopy or laparotomy.<EOS>
<BOS>The sample is checked by a pathologist to see if it contains cancer cells.<EOS>
<BOS>Upper GI series with small bowel followthrough: A series of xrays of the esophagus, stomach, and small bowel.<EOS>
<BOS>The patient drinks a liquid that contains barium (a silverwhite metallic compound).<EOS>
<BOS>The liquid coats the esophagus, stomach, and small bowel.<EOS>
<BOS>Xrays are taken at different times as the barium travels through the upper GI tract and small bowel.<EOS>
<BOS>CT scan (CAT scan): A procedure that makes a series of detailed pictures of areas inside the body, taken from different angles.<EOS>
<BOS>The pictures are made by a computer linked to an xray machine.<EOS>
<BOS>A dye may be injected into a vein or swallowed to help the organs or tissues show up more clearly.<EOS>
<BOS>This procedure is also called computed tomography, computerized tomography, or computerized axial tomography.<EOS>
<BOS>MRI (magnetic resonance imaging): A procedure that uses a magnet, radio waves, and a computer to make a series of detailed pictures of areas inside the body.<EOS>
<BOS>This procedure is also called nuclear magnetic resonance imaging (NMRI).<EOS>
<BOS>Certain factors affect prognosis (chance of recovery) and treatment options.<EOS>
<BOS>Prognosis (chance of recovery) depends on the following: The stage of the cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Where the tumor is in the lip or oral cavity.<EOS>
<BOS>Whether the cancer has spread to blood vessels.<EOS>
<BOS>For patients who smoke, the chance of recovery is better if they stop smoking before beginning radiation therapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Treatment options depend on the following: The stage of the cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>The size of the tumor and where it is in the lip or oral cavity.<EOS>
<BOS>Whether the patient's appearance and ability to talk and eat can stay the same.<EOS>
<BOS>The patient's age and general health.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients who have had lip and oral cavity cancer have an increased risk of developing a second cancer in the head or neck.<EOS>
<BOS>Frequent and careful followup is important.<EOS>
<BOS>Clinical trials are studying the use of retinoid drugs to reduce the risk of a second head and neck cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Information about ongoing clinical trials is available from the NCI website.<EOS>
<BOS>New types of treatment are being tested in clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>This summary section describes treatments that are being studied in clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>It may not mention every new treatment being studied.<EOS>
<BOS>Information about clinical trials is available from the NCI website.<EOS>
<BOS>Other drug therapy Lenalidomide is a type of angiogenesis inhibitor.<EOS>
<BOS>It prevents the growth of new blood vessels that are needed by a tumor to grow.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients may want to think about taking part in a clinical trial.<EOS>
<BOS>For some patients, taking part in a clinical trial may be the best treatment choice.<EOS>
<BOS>Clinical trials are part of the cancer research process.<EOS>
<BOS>Clinical trials are done to find out if new cancer treatments are safe and effective or better than the standard treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Many of today's standard treatments for cancer are based on earlier clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients who take part in a clinical trial may receive the standard treatment or be among the first to receive a new treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients who take part in clinical trials also help improve the way cancer will be treated in the future.<EOS>
<BOS>Even when clinical trials do not lead to effective new treatments, they often answer important questions and help move research forward.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients can enter clinical trials before, during, or after starting their cancer treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Some clinical trials only include patients who have not yet received treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Other trials test treatments for patients whose cancer has not gotten better.<EOS>
<BOS>There are also clinical trials that test new ways to stop cancer from recurring (coming back) or reduce the side effects of cancer treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Clinical trials are taking place in many parts of the country.<EOS>
<BOS>See the Treatment Options section that follows for links to current treatment clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>These have been retrieved from NCI's listing of clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>Obesity and having metabolic syndrome may increase the risk of endometrial cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Anything that increases your risk of getting a disease is called a risk factor.<EOS>
<BOS>Having a risk factor does not mean that you will get cancer; not having risk factors doesn't mean that you will not get cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Talk with your doctor if you think you may be at risk.<EOS>
<BOS>Risk factors for endometrial cancer include the following: Having endometrial hyperplasia.<EOS>
<BOS>Being obese.<EOS>
<BOS>Having metabolic syndrome, a set of conditions that occur together, including extra fat around the abdomen, high blood sugar, high blood pressure, high levels of triglycerides and low levels of highdensity lipoproteins in the blood.<EOS>
<BOS>Never giving birth.<EOS>
<BOS>Beginning menstruation at an early age.<EOS>
<BOS>Reaching menopause at an older age.<EOS>
<BOS>Having polycystic ovarian syndrome (PCOS).<EOS>
<BOS>Having a mother, sister, or daughter with uterine cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Having a certain gene change that is linked to Lynch syndrome (hereditary nonpolyposis colon cancer).<EOS>
<BOS>Having hyperinsulinemia (high levels of insulin in the blood).<EOS>
<BOS>Taking tamoxifen for breast cancer or taking estrogen alone (without progesterone) can increase the risk of endometrial cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Endometrial cancer may develop in breast cancer patients who have been treated with tamoxifen.<EOS>
<BOS>A patient who takes this drug and has abnormal vaginal bleeding should have a followup exam and a biopsy of the endometrial lining if needed.<EOS>
<BOS>Women taking estrogen (a hormone that can affect the growth of some cancers) alone also have an increased risk of endometrial cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Taking estrogen combined with progesterone (another hormone) does not increase a womans risk of endometrial cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Key Points Testicular cancer is a disease in which malignant (cancer) cells form in the tissues of one or both testicles.<EOS>
<BOS>Testicular cancer is the most common cancer in men aged 15 to 34 years.<EOS>
<BOS>Testicular cancer can usually be cured.<EOS>
<BOS>A condition called cryptorchidism (an undescended testicle) is a risk factor for testicular cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Testicular cancer is a disease in which malignant (cancer) cells form in the tissues of one or both testicles.<EOS>
<BOS>The testicles are 2 eggshaped glands inside the scrotum (a sac of loose skin that lies directly below the penis).<EOS>
<BOS>The testicles are held within the scrotum by the spermatic cord.<EOS>
<BOS>The spermatic cord also contains the vas deferens and vessels and nerves of the testicles.<EOS>
<BOS>The testicles are the male sex glands and make testosterone and sperm.<EOS>
<BOS>Germ cells in the testicles make immature sperm.<EOS>
<BOS>These sperm travel through a network of tubules (tiny tubes) and larger tubes into the epididymis (a long coiled tube next to the testicles).<EOS>
<BOS>This is where the sperm mature and are stored.<EOS>
<BOS>Almost all testicular cancers start in the germ cells.<EOS>
<BOS>The two main types of testicular germ cell tumors are seminomas and nonseminomas.<EOS>
<BOS>See the PDQ summary on Testicular Cancer Treatment for more information about testicular cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Smoking is the major risk factor for small cell lung cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Anything that increases your chance of getting a disease is called a risk factor.<EOS>
<BOS>Having a risk factor does not mean that you will get cancer; not having risk factors doesn't mean that you will not get cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Talk to your doctor if you think you may be at risk for lung cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Risk factors for lung cancer include the following: Smoking cigarettes, pipes, or cigars, now or in the past.<EOS>
<BOS>This is the most important risk factor for lung cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>The earlier in life a person starts smoking, the more often a person smokes, and the more years a person smokes, the greater the risk of lung cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Being exposed to secondhand smoke.<EOS>
<BOS>Being exposed to radiation from any of the following: Radiation therapy to the breast or chest.<EOS>
<BOS>Radon in the home or workplace.<EOS>
<BOS>Imaging tests such as CT scans.<EOS>
<BOS>Atomic bomb radiation.<EOS>
<BOS>Being exposed to asbestos, chromium, nickel, beryllium, arsenic, soot, or tar in the workplace.<EOS>
<BOS>Living where there is air pollution.<EOS>
<BOS>Having a family history of lung cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Being infected with the human immunodeficiency virus (HIV).<EOS>
<BOS>Taking beta carotene supplements and being a heavy smoker.<EOS>
<BOS>Older age is the main risk factor for most cancers.<EOS>
<BOS>The chance of getting cancer increases as you get older.<EOS>
<BOS>When smoking is combined with other risk factors, the risk of lung cancer is increased.<EOS>
<BOS>Key Points There are different types of treatment for patients with urethral cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Four types of standard treatment are used: Surgery Radiation therapy Chemotherapy Active surveillance New types of treatment are being tested in clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients may want to think about taking part in a clinical trial.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients can enter clinical trials before, during, or after starting their cancer treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Followup tests may be needed.<EOS>
<BOS>There are different types of treatment for patients with urethral cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Different types of treatments are available for patients with urethral cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Some treatments are standard (the currently used treatment), and some are being tested in clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>A treatment clinical trial is a research study meant to help improve current treatments or obtain information on new treatments for patients with cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>When clinical trials show that a new treatment is better than the standard treatment, the new treatment may become the standard treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients may want to think about taking part in a clinical trial.<EOS>
<BOS>Some clinical trials are open only to patients who have not started treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Four types of standard treatment are used: Surgery Surgery to remove the cancer is the most common treatment for cancer of the urethra.<EOS>
<BOS>One of the following types of surgery may be done: Open excision: Removal of the cancer by surgery.<EOS>
<BOS>Transurethral resection (TUR): Surgery to remove the cancer using a special tool inserted into the urethra.<EOS>
<BOS>Electroresection with fulguration: Surgery to remove the cancer by electric current.<EOS>
<BOS>A lighted tool with a small wire loop on the end is used to remove the cancer or to burn the tumor away with highenergy electricity.<EOS>
<BOS>Laser surgery: A surgical procedure that uses a laser beam (a narrow beam of intense light) as a knife to make bloodless cuts in tissue or to remove or destroy tissue.<EOS>
<BOS>Lymph node dissection: Lymph nodes in the pelvis and groin may be removed.<EOS>
<BOS>Cystourethrectomy: Surgery to remove the bladder and the urethra.<EOS>
<BOS>Cystoprostatectomy: Surgery to remove the bladder and the prostate.<EOS>
<BOS>Anterior exenteration: Surgery to remove the urethra, the bladder, and the vagina.<EOS>
<BOS>Plastic surgery may be done to rebuild the vagina.<EOS>
<BOS>Partial penectomy: Surgery to remove the part of the penis surrounding the urethra where cancer has spread.<EOS>
<BOS>Plastic surgery may be done to rebuild the penis.<EOS>
<BOS>Radical penectomy: Surgery to remove the entire penis.<EOS>
<BOS>Plastic surgery may be done to rebuild the penis.<EOS>
<BOS>If the urethra is removed, the surgeon will make a new way for the urine to pass from the body.<EOS>
<BOS>This is called urinary diversion.<EOS>
<BOS>If the bladder is removed, the surgeon will make a new way for urine to be stored and passed from the body.<EOS>
<BOS>The surgeon may use part of the small intestine to make a tube that passes urine through an opening (stoma).<EOS>
<BOS>This is called an ostomy or urostomy.<EOS>
<BOS>If a patient has an ostomy, a disposable bag to collect urine is worn under clothing.<EOS>
<BOS>The surgeon may also use part of the small intestine to make a new storage pouch (continent reservoir) inside the body where the urine can collect.<EOS>
<BOS>A tube (catheter) is then used to drain the urine through a stoma.<EOS>
<BOS>Even if the doctor removes all the cancer that can be seen at the time of the surgery, some patients may be given chemotherapy or radiation therapy after surgery to kill any cancer cells that are left.<EOS>
<BOS>Treatment given after the surgery, to lower the risk that the cancer will come back, is called adjuvant therapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Radiation therapy Radiation therapy is a cancer treatment that uses highenergy xrays or other types of radiation to kill cancer cells or keep them from growing.<EOS>
<BOS>There are two types of radiation therapy: External radiation therapy uses a machine outside the body to send radiation toward the cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Internal radiation therapy uses a radioactive substance sealed in needles, seeds, wires, or catheters that are placed directly into or near the cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>The way the radiation therapy is given depends on the type of cancer and where the cancer formed in the urethra.<EOS>
<BOS>External and internal radiation therapy are used to treat urethral cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Chemotherapy Chemotherapy is a cancer treatment that uses drugs to stop the growth of cancer cells, either by killing the cells or by stopping the cells from dividing.<EOS>
<BOS>When chemotherapy is taken by mouth or injected into a vein or muscle, the drugs enter the bloodstream and can reach cancer cells throughout the body (systemic chemotherapy).<EOS>
<BOS>When chemotherapy is placed directly into the cerebrospinal fluid, an organ, or a body cavity such as the abdomen, the drugs mainly affect cancer cells in those areas (regional chemotherapy).<EOS>
<BOS>The way the chemotherapy is given depends on the type of cancer and where the cancer formed in the urethra.<EOS>
<BOS>Active surveillance Active surveillance is following a patient's condition without giving any treatment unless there are changes in test results.<EOS>
<BOS>It is used to find early signs that the condition is getting worse.<EOS>
<BOS>In active surveillance, patients are given certain exams and tests, including biopsies, on a regular schedule.<EOS>
<BOS>New types of treatment are being tested in clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>Information about clinical trials is available from the NCI website.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients may want to think about taking part in a clinical trial.<EOS>
<BOS>For some patients, taking part in a clinical trial may be the best treatment choice.<EOS>
<BOS>Clinical trials are part of the cancer research process.<EOS>
<BOS>Clinical trials are done to find out if new cancer treatments are safe and effective or better than the standard treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Many of today's standard treatments for cancer are based on earlier clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients who take part in a clinical trial may receive the standard treatment or be among the first to receive a new treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients who take part in clinical trials also help improve the way cancer will be treated in the future.<EOS>
<BOS>Even when clinical trials do not lead to effective new treatments, they often answer important questions and help move research forward.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients can enter clinical trials before, during, or after starting their cancer treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Some clinical trials only include patients who have not yet received treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Other trials test treatments for patients whose cancer has not gotten better.<EOS>
<BOS>There are also clinical trials that test new ways to stop cancer from recurring (coming back) or reduce the side effects of cancer treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Clinical trials are taking place in many parts of the country.<EOS>
<BOS>See the Treatment Options section that follows for links to current treatment clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>These have been retrieved from NCI's listing of clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>Followup tests may be needed.<EOS>
<BOS>Some of the tests that were done to diagnose the cancer or to find out the stage of the cancer may be repeated.<EOS>
<BOS>Some tests will be repeated in order to see how well the treatment is working.<EOS>
<BOS>Decisions about whether to continue, change, or stop treatment may be based on the results of these tests.<EOS>
<BOS>Some of the tests will continue to be done from time to time after treatment has ended.<EOS>
<BOS>The results of these tests can show if your condition has changed or if the cancer has recurred (come back).<EOS>
<BOS>These tests are sometimes called followup tests or checkups.<EOS>
<BOS>Treatment Options for Urethral Cancer Distal Urethral Cancer Treatment of abnormal cells in the mucosa (inside lining of the urethra that have not become cancer, may include surgery to remove the tumor (open excision or transurethral resection), electroresection with fulguration, or laser surgery.<EOS>
<BOS>Treatment of distal urethral cancer is different for men and women.<EOS>
<BOS>For women, treatment may include the following: Surgery to remove the tumor (transurethral resection), electroresection and fulguration, or laser surgery for tumors that have not spread deeply into tissue.<EOS>
<BOS>Brachytherapy and/or external radiation therapy for tumors that have not spread deeply into tissue.<EOS>
<BOS>Surgery to remove the tumor (anterior exenteration) for tumors that have spread deeply into tissue.<EOS>
<BOS>Sometimes nearby lymph nodes are also removed (lymph node dissection).<EOS>
<BOS>Radiation therapy may be given before surgery.<EOS>
<BOS>For men, treatment may include the following: Surgery to remove the tumor (transurethral resection), electroresection and fulguration, or laser surgery for tumors that have not spread deeply into tissue.<EOS>
<BOS>Surgery to remove part of the penis (partial penectomy) for tumors that are near the tip of the penis.<EOS>
<BOS>Sometimes nearby lymph nodes are also removed (lymph node dissection).<EOS>
<BOS>Surgery to remove part of the urethra for tumors that are in the distal urethra but not at the tip of the penis and have not spread deeply into tissue.<EOS>
<BOS>Sometimes nearby lymph nodes are also removed (lymph node dissection).<EOS>
<BOS>Surgery to remove the penis (radical penectomy) for tumors that have spread deeply into tissue.<EOS>
<BOS>Sometimes nearby lymph nodes are also removed (lymph node dissection).<EOS>
<BOS>Radiation therapy with or without chemotherapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Chemotherapy given together with radiation therapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Check the list of NCIsupported cancer clinical trials that are now accepting patients with distal urethral cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>For more specific results, refine the search by using other search features, such as the location of the trial, the type of treatment, or the name of the drug.<EOS>
<BOS>Talk with your doctor about clinical trials that may be right for you.<EOS>
<BOS>General information about clinical trials is available from the NCI website.<EOS>
<BOS>Proximal Urethral Cancer Treatment of proximal urethral cancer or urethral cancer that affects the entire urethra is different for men and women.<EOS>
<BOS>For women, treatment may include the following: Radiation therapy and/or surgery (open excision, transurethral resection) for tumors that are of an inch or smaller.<EOS>
<BOS>Radiation therapy followed by surgery (anterior exenteration with lymph node dissection and urinary diversion).<EOS>
<BOS>For men, treatment may include the following: Radiation therapy or radiation therapy and chemotherapy, followed by surgery (cystoprostatectomy, penectomy, lymph node dissection, and urinary diversion).<EOS>
<BOS>Check the list of NCIsupported cancer clinical trials that are now accepting patients with proximal urethral cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>For more specific results, refine the search by using other search features, such as the location of the trial, the type of treatment, or the name of the drug.<EOS>
<BOS>Talk with your doctor about clinical trials that may be right for you.<EOS>
<BOS>General information about clinical trials is available from the NCI website.<EOS>
<BOS>Urethral Cancer that Forms with Invasive Bladder Cancer Treatment of urethral cancer that forms at the same time as invasive bladder cancer may include the following: Surgery (cystourethrectomy in women, or urethrectomy and cystoprostatectomy in men).<EOS>
<BOS>If the urethra is not removed during surgery to remove the bladder, treatment may include the following: Active surveillance.<EOS>
<BOS>Samples of cells are taken from inside the urethra and checked under a microscope for signs of cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Check the list of NCIsupported cancer clinical trials that are now accepting patients with urethral cancer associated with invasive bladder cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>For more specific results, refine the search by using other search features, such as the location of the trial, the type of treatment, or the name of the drug.<EOS>
<BOS>Talk with your doctor about clinical trials that may be right for you.<EOS>
<BOS>General information about clinical trials is available from the NCI website.<EOS>
<BOS>Metastatic or Recurrent Urethral Cancer Treatment of urethral cancer that has metastasized (spread to other parts of the body) is usually chemotherapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Treatment of recurrent urethral cancer may include one or more of the following: Surgery to remove the tumor.<EOS>
<BOS>Sometimes nearby lymph nodes are also removed (lymph node dissection).<EOS>
<BOS>Radiation therapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Check the list of NCIsupported cancer clinical trials that are now accepting patients with recurrent urethral cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>For more specific results, refine the search by using other search features, such as the location of the trial, the type of treatment, or the name of the drug.<EOS>
<BOS>Talk with your doctor about clinical trials that may be right for you.<EOS>
<BOS>General information about clinical trials is available from the NCI website.<EOS>
<BOS>Key Points Endometrial cancer is a disease in which malignant (cancer) cells form in the tissues of the endometrium.<EOS>
<BOS>In the United States, endometrial cancer is the most common invasive cancer of the female reproductive system.<EOS>
<BOS>Health history and certain medicines can affect the risk of developing endometrial cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Endometrial cancer is a disease in which malignant (cancer) cells form in the tissues of the endometrium.<EOS>
<BOS>The endometrium is the innermost lining of the uterus.<EOS>
<BOS>The uterus is a hollow, muscular organ in a woman's pelvis.<EOS>
<BOS>The uterus is where a fetus grows.<EOS>
<BOS>In most nonpregnant women, the uterus is about 3 inches long.<EOS>
<BOS>Cancer of the endometrium is different from cancer of the muscle of the uterus, which is called uterine sarcoma.<EOS>
<BOS>See the PDQ summary on Uterine Sarcoma Treatment for more information.<EOS>
<BOS>See the following PDQ summaries for more information about endometrial cancer: Endometrial Cancer Treatment Endometrial Cancer Prevention In the United States, endometrial cancer is the most common invasive cancer of the female reproductive system.<EOS>
<BOS>Endometrial cancer is diagnosed most often in postmenopausal women at an average age of 60 years.<EOS>
<BOS>From 2004 to 2013, the number of new cases of endometrial cancer increased slightly in white and black women.<EOS>
<BOS>From 2005 to 2014, the number of deaths from endometrial cancer increased slightly in white and black women.<EOS>
<BOS>When endometrial cancer is diagnosed in black women, it is usually more advanced and less likely to be cured.<EOS>
<BOS>Key Points Avoiding risk factors and increasing protective factors may help prevent cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>The following are risk factors for anal cancer: Anal HPV infection Certain medical conditions History of cervical, vaginal, or vulvar cancer HIV infection/AIDS Immunosuppression Certain sexual practices Cigarette smoking The following protective factor decreases the risk of anal cancer: HPV vaccine It is not clear if the following protective factor decreases the risk of anal cancer: Condom use Cancer prevention clinical trials are used to study ways to prevent cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>New ways to prevent anal cancer are being studied in clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>Avoiding risk factors and increasing protective factors may help prevent cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Avoiding cancer risk factors may help prevent certain cancers.<EOS>
<BOS>Risk factors include smoking, being overweight, and not getting enough exercise.<EOS>
<BOS>Increasing protective factors such as quitting smoking and exercising may also help prevent some cancers.<EOS>
<BOS>Talk to your doctor or other health care professional about how you might lower your risk of cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>The following are risk factors for anal cancer: Anal HPV infection Being infected with human papillomavirus (HPV) is the main risk factor for anal cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Being infected with HPV can lead to squamous cell carcinoma of the anus, the most common type of anal cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>About nine out of every ten cases of anal cancer are found in patients with anal HPV infection.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients with healthy immune systems are usually able to fight HPV infections.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients with weakened immune systems who are infected with HPV have a higher risk of anal cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Certain medical conditions History of cervical, vaginal, or vulvar cancer Cervical cancer, vaginal cancer, and vulvar cancer are related to HPV infection.<EOS>
<BOS>Women who have had cervical, vaginal, or vulvar cancer have a higher risk of anal cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>HIV infection/AIDS Being infected with human immunodeficiency virus (HIV) is a strong risk factor for anal cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>HIV is the cause of acquired immunodeficiency syndrome (AIDS).<EOS>
<BOS>HIV weakens the body's immune system and its ability to fight infection.<EOS>
<BOS>HPV infection of the anus is common among patients who are HIVpositive.<EOS>
<BOS>The risk of anal cancer is higher in men who are HIVpositive and have sex with men compared with men who are HIVnegative and have sex with men.<EOS>
<BOS>Women who are HIVpositive also have an increased risk of anal cancer compared with women who are HIVnegative.<EOS>
<BOS>Studies show that intravenous drug use or cigarette smoking may further increase the risk of anal cancer in patients who are HIVpositive.<EOS>
<BOS>Immunosuppression Immunosuppression is a condition that weakens the body's immune system and its ability to fight infections and other diseases.<EOS>
<BOS>Chronic (longterm) immunosuppression may increase the risk of anal cancer because it lowers the body's ability to fight HPV infection.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients who have an organ transplant and receive immunosuppressive medicine to prevent organ rejection have an increased risk of anal cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Having an autoimmune disorder such as Crohn disease or psoriasis may increase the risk of anal cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>It is not clear if the increased risk is due to the autoimmune condition, the treatment for the condition, or a combination of both.<EOS>
<BOS>Certain sexual practices The following sexual practices increase the risk of anal cancer because they increase the chance of being infected with HPV: Having receptive anal intercourse (anal sex).<EOS>
<BOS>Having many sexual partners.<EOS>
<BOS>Sex between men.<EOS>
<BOS>Men and women who have a history of anal warts or other sexually transmitted diseases also have an increased risk of anal cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Cigarette smoking Studies show that cigarette smoking increases the risk of anal cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Studies also show that current smokers have a higher risk of anal cancer than smokers who have quit or people who have never smoked.<EOS>
<BOS>The following protective factor decreases the risk of anal cancer: HPV vaccine The human papillomavirus (HPV) vaccine is used to prevent anal cancer, cervical cancer, vulvar cancer, and vaginal cancer caused by HPV.<EOS>
<BOS>It is also used to prevent lesions caused by HPV that may become cancer in the future.<EOS>
<BOS>Studies show that being vaccinated against HPV lowers the risk of anal cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>The vaccine may work best when it is given before a person is exposed to HPV.<EOS>
<BOS>It is not clear if the following protective factor decreases the risk of anal cancer: Condom use It is not known if the use of condoms protects against anal HPV infection.<EOS>
<BOS>This is because not enough studies have been done to prove this.<EOS>
<BOS>Cancer prevention clinical trials are used to study ways to prevent cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Cancer prevention clinical trials are used to study ways to lower the risk of developing certain types of cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Some cancer prevention trials are conducted with healthy people who have not had cancer but who have an increased risk for cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Other prevention trials are conducted with people who have had cancer and are trying to prevent another cancer of the same type or to lower their chance of developing a new type of cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Other trials are done with healthy volunteers who are not known to have any risk factors for cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>The purpose of some cancer prevention clinical trials is to find out whether actions people take can prevent cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>These may include eating fruits and vegetables, exercising, quitting smoking, or taking certain medicines, vitamins, minerals, or food supplements.<EOS>
<BOS>New ways to prevent anal cancer are being studied in clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>Clinical trials are taking place in many parts of the country.<EOS>
<BOS>Information about clinical trials for anal cancer prevention can be found in the Clinical Trials section of the NCI Web site.<EOS>
<BOS>Tests and procedures that examine the skin are used to detect (find) and diagnose Merkel cell carcinoma.<EOS>
<BOS>The following tests and procedures may be used: Physical exam and history : An exam of the body to check general signs of health, including checking for signs of disease, such as lumps or anything else that seems unusual.<EOS>
<BOS>A history of the patients health habits and past illnesses and treatments will also be taken.<EOS>
<BOS>Fullbody skin exam: A doctor or nurse checks the skin for bumps or spots that look abnormal in color, size, shape, or texture.<EOS>
<BOS>The size, shape, and texture of the lymph nodes will also be checked.<EOS>
<BOS>Skin biopsy : The removal of skin cells or tissues so they can be viewed under a microscope by a pathologist to check for signs of cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Key Points After chronic myelogenous leukemia has been diagnosed, tests are done to find out if the cancer has spread.<EOS>
<BOS>Chronic myelogenous leukemia has 3 phases.<EOS>
<BOS>Chronic phase Accelerated phase Blastic phase After chronic myelogenous leukemia has been diagnosed, tests are done to find out if the cancer has spread.<EOS>
<BOS>Staging is the process used to find out how far the cancer has spread.<EOS>
<BOS>There is no standard staging system for chronic myelogenous leukemia (CML).<EOS>
<BOS>Instead, the disease is classified by phase: chronic phase, accelerated phase, or blastic phase.<EOS>
<BOS>It is important to know the phase in order to plan treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>The information from tests and procedures done to detect (find) and diagnose chronic myelogenous leukemia is also used to plan treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Chronic myelogenous leukemia has 3 phases.<EOS>
<BOS>As the amount of blast cells increases in the blood and bone marrow, there is less room for healthy white blood cells, red blood cells, and platelets.<EOS>
<BOS>This may result in infections, anemia, and easy bleeding, as well as bone pain and pain or a feeling of fullness below the ribs on the left side.<EOS>
<BOS>The number of blast cells in the blood and bone marrow and the severity of signs or symptoms determine the phase of the disease.<EOS>
<BOS>Chronic phase In chronic phase CML, fewer than 10% of the cells in the blood and bone marrow are blast cells.<EOS>
<BOS>Accelerated phase In accelerated phase CML, 10% to 19% of the cells in the blood and bone marrow are blast cells.<EOS>
<BOS>Blastic phase In blastic phase CML, 20% or more of the cells in the blood or bone marrow are blast cells.<EOS>
<BOS>When tiredness, fever, and an enlarged spleen occur during the blastic phase, it is called blast crisis.<EOS>
<BOS>Key Points There are different types of treatment for children who have central nervous system (CNS) embryonal tumors.<EOS>
<BOS>Children who have CNS embryonal tumors should have their treatment planned by a team of health care providers who are experts in treating brain tumors in children.<EOS>
<BOS>Childhood brain tumors may cause signs or symptoms that begin before the cancer is diagnosed and continue for months or years.<EOS>
<BOS>Some cancer treatments cause side effects months or years after treatment has ended.<EOS>
<BOS>Five types of treatment are used: Surgery Radiation therapy Chemotherapy Highdose chemotherapy with stem cell rescue Targeted therapy New types of treatment are being tested in clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients may want to think about taking part in a clinical trial.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients can enter clinical trials before, during, or after starting their cancer treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Followup tests may be needed.<EOS>
<BOS>There are different types of treatment for children who have central nervous system (CNS) embryonal tumors.<EOS>
<BOS>Different types of treatment are available for children with central nervous system (CNS) embryonal tumors.<EOS>
<BOS>Some treatments are standard (the currently used treatment), and some are being tested in clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>A treatment clinical trial is a research study meant to help improve current treatments or obtain information on new treatments for patients with cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>When clinical trials show that a new treatment is better than the standard treatment, the new treatment may become the standard treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Because cancer in children is rare, taking part in a clinical trial should be considered.<EOS>
<BOS>Some clinical trials are open only to patients who have not started treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Children who have CNS embryonal tumors should have their treatment planned by a team of health care providers who are experts in treating brain tumors in children.<EOS>
<BOS>Treatment will be overseen by a pediatric oncologist, a doctor who specializes in treating children with cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>The pediatric oncologist works with other pediatric health care providers who are experts in treating children with brain tumors and who specialize in certain areas of medicine.<EOS>
<BOS>These may include the following specialists: Pediatrician.<EOS>
<BOS>Neurosurgeon.<EOS>
<BOS>Neurologist.<EOS>
<BOS>Neuropathologist.<EOS>
<BOS>Neuroradiologist.<EOS>
<BOS>Rehabilitation specialist.<EOS>
<BOS>Radiation oncologist.<EOS>
<BOS>Psychologist.<EOS>
<BOS>Childhood brain tumors may cause signs or symptoms that begin before the cancer is diagnosed and continue for months or years.<EOS>
<BOS>Signs or symptoms caused by the tumor may begin before the cancer is diagnosed and continue for months or years.<EOS>
<BOS>It is important to talk with your child's doctors about signs or symptoms caused by the tumor that may continue after treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Some cancer treatments cause side effects months or years after treatment has ended.<EOS>
<BOS>Side effects from cancer treatment that begin during or after treatment and continue for months or years are called late effects.<EOS>
<BOS>Late effects of cancer treatment may include the following: Physical problems.<EOS>
<BOS>Changes in mood, feelings, thinking, learning, or memory.<EOS>
<BOS>Second cancers (new types of cancer).<EOS>
<BOS>Children diagnosed with medulloblastoma may have certain problems after surgery or radiation therapy such as changes in the ability to think, learn, and pay attention.<EOS>
<BOS>Also, cerebellar mutism syndrome may occur after surgery.<EOS>
<BOS>Signs of this syndrome include the following: Delayed ability to speak.<EOS>
<BOS>Trouble swallowing and eating.<EOS>
<BOS>Loss of balance, trouble walking, and worsening handwriting.<EOS>
<BOS>Loss of muscle tone.<EOS>
<BOS>Mood swings and changes in personality.<EOS>
<BOS>Some late effects may be treated or controlled.<EOS>
<BOS>It is important to talk with your child's doctors about the effects cancer treatment can have on your child.<EOS>
<BOS>(See the PDQ summary on Late Effects of Treatment for Childhood Cancer for more information).<EOS>
<BOS>Five types of treatment are used: Surgery Surgery is used to diagnose and treat a childhood CNS embryonal tumor as described in the General Information section of this summary.<EOS>
<BOS>Even if the doctor removes all the cancer that can be seen at the time of the surgery, some patients may be given chemotherapy and/or radiation therapy after surgery to kill any cancer cells that are left.<EOS>
<BOS>Treatment given after the surgery, to lower the risk that the cancer will come back, is called adjuvant therapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Radiation therapy Radiation therapy is a cancer treatment that uses highenergy xrays or other types of radiation to kill cancer cells or keep them from growing.<EOS>
<BOS>There are two types of radiation therapy: External radiation therapy uses a machine outside the body to send radiation toward the cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Certain ways of giving radiation therapy can help keep radiation from damaging nearby healthy tissue.<EOS>
<BOS>These types of radiation therapy include the following: Conformal radiation therapy: Conformal radiation therapy is a type of external radiation therapy that uses a computer to make a 3dimensional (3D) picture of the tumor and shapes the radiation beams to fit the tumor.<EOS>
<BOS>This allows a high dose of radiation to reach the tumor and causes less damage to nearby healthy tissue.<EOS>
<BOS>Stereotactic radiation therapy: Stereotactic radiation therapy is a type of external radiation therapy.<EOS>
<BOS>A rigid head frame is attached to the skull to keep the head still during the radiation treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>A machine aims radiation directly at the tumor, causing less damage to nearby healthy tissue.<EOS>
<BOS>The total dose of radiation is divided into several smaller doses given over several days.<EOS>
<BOS>This procedure is also called stereotactic externalbeam radiation therapy and stereotaxic radiation therapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Internal radiation therapy uses a radioactive substance sealed in needles, seeds, wires, or catheters that are placed directly into or near the cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Radiation therapy to the brain can affect growth and development in young children.<EOS>
<BOS>For this reason, clinical trials are studying new ways of giving radiation that may have fewer side effects than standard methods.<EOS>
<BOS>The way the radiation therapy is given depends on the type of cancer being treated.<EOS>
<BOS>External radiation therapy is used to treat childhood CNS embryonal tumors.<EOS>
<BOS>Because radiation therapy can affect growth and brain development in young children, especially children who are three years old or younger, chemotherapy may be given to delay or reduce the need for radiation therapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Chemotherapy Chemotherapy is a cancer treatment that uses drugs to stop the growth of cancer cells, either by killing the cells or by stopping them from dividing.<EOS>
<BOS>When chemotherapy is taken by mouth or injected into a vein or muscle, the drugs enter the bloodstream and can reach cancer cells throughout the body (systemic chemotherapy).<EOS>
<BOS>When chemotherapy is placed directly into the cerebrospinal fluid, an organ, or a body cavity such as the abdomen, the drugs mainly affect cancer cells in those areas (regional chemotherapy).<EOS>
<BOS>Combination chemotherapy is treatment using more than one anticancer drug.<EOS>
<BOS>The way the chemotherapy is given depends on the type of cancer being treated.<EOS>
<BOS>Regular dose anticancer drugs given by mouth or vein to treat central nervous system tumors cannot cross the bloodbrain barrier and enter the fluid that surrounds the brain and spinal cord.<EOS>
<BOS>Instead, an anticancer drug is injected into the fluidfilled space to kill cancer cells that may have spread there.<EOS>
<BOS>This is called intrathecal or intraventricular chemotherapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Highdose chemotherapy with stem cell rescue Highdose chemotherapy with stem cell rescue is a way of giving high doses of chemotherapy and replacing blood forming cells destroyed by the cancer treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Stem cells (immature blood cells) are removed from the blood or bone marrow of the patient or a donor and are frozen and stored.<EOS>
<BOS>After the chemotherapy is completed, the stored stem cells are thawed and given back to the patient through an infusion.<EOS>
<BOS>These reinfused stem cells grow into (and restore) the bodys blood cells.<EOS>
<BOS>Targeted therapy Targeted therapy is a type of treatment that uses drugs or other substances to attack cancer cells.<EOS>
<BOS>Targeted therapies usually cause less harm to normal cells than chemotherapy or radiation therapy do.<EOS>
<BOS>Signal transduction inhibitors are a type of targeted therapy used to treat recurrent medulloblastoma.<EOS>
<BOS>Signal transduction inhibitors block signals that are passed from one molecule to another inside a cell.<EOS>
<BOS>Blocking these signals may kill cancer cells.<EOS>
<BOS>Vismodegib is a type of signal transduction inhibitor.<EOS>
<BOS>New types of treatment are being tested in clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>Information about clinical trials is available from the NCI website.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients may want to think about taking part in a clinical trial.<EOS>
<BOS>For some patients, taking part in a clinical trial may be the best treatment choice.<EOS>
<BOS>Clinical trials are part of the cancer research process.<EOS>
<BOS>Clinical trials are done to find out if new cancer treatments are safe and effective or better than the standard treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Many of today's standard treatments for cancer are based on earlier clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients who take part in a clinical trial may receive the standard treatment or be among the first to receive a new treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients who take part in clinical trials also help improve the way cancer will be treated in the future.<EOS>
<BOS>Even when clinical trials do not lead to effective new treatments, they often answer important questions and help move research forward.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients can enter clinical trials before, during, or after starting their cancer treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Some clinical trials only include patients who have not yet received treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Other trials test treatments for patients whose cancer has not gotten better.<EOS>
<BOS>There are also clinical trials that test new ways to stop cancer from recurring (coming back) or reduce the side effects of cancer treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Clinical trials are taking place in many parts of the country.<EOS>
<BOS>See the Treatment Options section that follows for links to current treatment clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>These have been retrieved from NCI's listing of clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>Followup tests may be needed.<EOS>
<BOS>Some of the tests that were done to diagnose the cancer or to find out the stage of the cancer may be repeated.<EOS>
<BOS>(See the General Information section for a list of tests.<EOS>
<BOS>) Some tests will be repeated in order to see how well the treatment is working.<EOS>
<BOS>Decisions about whether to continue, change, or stop treatment may be based on the results of these tests.<EOS>
<BOS>This is sometimes called restaging.<EOS>
<BOS>Some of the imaging tests will continue to be done from time to time after treatment has ended.<EOS>
<BOS>The results of these tests can show if your child's condition has changed or if the brain tumor has recurred (come back).<EOS>
<BOS>If the imaging tests show abnormal tissue in the brain, a biopsy may also be done to find out if the tissue is made up of dead tumor cells or if new cancer cells are growing.<EOS>
<BOS>These tests are sometimes called followup tests or checkups.<EOS>
<BOS>Treatment Options for Childhood Central Nervous System Embryonal Tumors and Childhood Pineoblastoma Newly Diagnosed Childhood Medulloblastoma In newly diagnosed childhood medulloblastoma, the tumor itself has not been treated.<EOS>
<BOS>The child may have received drugs or treatment to relieve signs or symptoms caused by the tumor.<EOS>
<BOS>Children older than 3 years with averagerisk medulloblastoma Standard treatment of averagerisk medulloblastoma in children older than 3 years includes the following: Surgery to remove as much of the tumor as possible.<EOS>
<BOS>This is followed by radiation therapy to the brain and spinal cord.<EOS>
<BOS>Chemotherapy is also given during and after radiation therapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Surgery to remove the tumor, radiation therapy, and highdose chemotherapy with stem cell rescue.<EOS>
<BOS>Children older than 3 years with highrisk medulloblastoma Standard treatment of highrisk medulloblastoma in children older than 3 years includes the following: Surgery to remove as much of the tumor as possible.<EOS>
<BOS>This is followed by a larger dose of radiation therapy to the brain and spinal cord than the dose given for averagerisk medulloblastoma.<EOS>
<BOS>Chemotherapy is also given during and after radiation therapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Surgery to remove the tumor, radiation therapy, and highdose chemotherapy with stem cell rescue.<EOS>
<BOS>A clinical trial of new combinations of radiation therapy and chemotherapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Children aged 3 years and younger Standard treatment of medulloblastoma in children aged 3 years and younger is: Surgery to remove as much of the tumor as possible, followed by chemotherapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Other treatments that may be given after surgery include the following: Chemotherapy with or without radiation therapy to the area where the tumor was removed.<EOS>
<BOS>Highdose chemotherapy with stem cell rescue.<EOS>
<BOS>Check the list of NCIsupported cancer clinical trials that are now accepting patients with untreated childhood medulloblastoma.<EOS>
<BOS>For more specific results, refine the search by using other search features, such as the location of the trial, the type of treatment, or the name of the drug.<EOS>
<BOS>Talk with your child's doctor about clinical trials that may be right for your child.<EOS>
<BOS>General information about clinical trials is available from the NCI website.<EOS>
<BOS>Newly Diagnosed Childhood Nonmedulloblastoma Embryonal Tumors In newly diagnosed childhood nonmedulloblastoma embryonal tumors, the tumor itself has not been treated.<EOS>
<BOS>The child may have received drugs or treatment to relieve symptoms caused by the tumor.<EOS>
<BOS>Children older than 3 years Standard treatment of nonmedulloblastoma embryonal tumors in children older than 3 years is: Surgery to remove as much of the tumor as possible.<EOS>
<BOS>This is followed by radiation therapy to the brain and spinal cord.<EOS>
<BOS>Chemotherapy is also given during and after radiation therapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Children aged 3 years and younger Standard treatment of nonmedulloblastoma embryonal tumors in children aged 3 years and younger is: Surgery to remove as much of the tumor as possible, followed by chemotherapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Other treatments that may be given after surgery include the following: Chemotherapy and radiation therapy to the area where the tumor was removed.<EOS>
<BOS>Highdose chemotherapy with stem cell rescue.<EOS>
<BOS>Check the list of NCIsupported cancer clinical trials that are now accepting patients with untreated childhood nonmedulloblastoma.<EOS>
<BOS>For more specific results, refine the search by using other search features, such as the location of the trial, the type of treatment, or the name of the drug.<EOS>
<BOS>Talk with your child's doctor about clinical trials that may be right for your child.<EOS>
<BOS>General information about clinical trials is available from the NCI website.<EOS>
<BOS>Newly Diagnosed Childhood Medulloepithelioma In newly diagnosed childhood medulloepithelioma, the tumor itself has not been treated.<EOS>
<BOS>The child may have received drugs or treatment to relieve symptoms caused by the tumor.<EOS>
<BOS>Children older than 3 years Standard treatment of medulloepithelioma in children older than 3 years includes the following: Surgery to remove as much of the tumor as possible.<EOS>
<BOS>This is followed by radiation therapy to the brain and spinal cord.<EOS>
<BOS>Chemotherapy is also given during and after radiation therapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Surgery to remove the tumor, radiation therapy, and highdose chemotherapy with stem cell rescue.<EOS>
<BOS>A clinical trial of new combinations of radiation therapy and chemotherapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Children aged 3 years and younger Standard treatment of medulloepithelioma in children aged 3 years and younger includes the following: Surgery to remove as much of the tumor as possible, followed by chemotherapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Highdose chemotherapy with stem cell rescue.<EOS>
<BOS>Radiation therapy, when the child is older.<EOS>
<BOS>A clinical trial of new combinations and schedules of chemotherapy or new combinations of chemotherapy with stem cell rescue.<EOS>
<BOS>Treatment of medulloepithelioma in children aged 3 years and younger is often within a clinical trial.<EOS>
<BOS>Check the list of NCIsupported cancer clinical trials that are now accepting patients with childhood medulloepithelioma.<EOS>
<BOS>For more specific results, refine the search by using other search features, such as the location of the trial, the type of treatment, or the name of the drug.<EOS>
<BOS>Talk with your child's doctor about clinical trials that may be right for your child.<EOS>
<BOS>General information about clinical trials is available from the NCI website.<EOS>
<BOS>Newly Diagnosed Childhood Pineoblastoma In newly diagnosed childhood pineoblastoma, the tumor itself has not been treated.<EOS>
<BOS>The child may have received drugs or treatment to relieve symptoms caused by the tumor.<EOS>
<BOS>Children older than 3 years Standard treatment of pineoblastoma in children older than 3 years includes the following: Surgery to remove the tumor.<EOS>
<BOS>The tumor usually cannot be completely removed because of where it is in the brain.<EOS>
<BOS>Surgery is often followed by radiation therapy to the brain and spinal cord and chemotherapy.<EOS>
<BOS>A clinical trial of highdose chemotherapy after radiation therapy and stem cell rescue.<EOS>
<BOS>A clinical trial of chemotherapy during radiation therapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Children aged 3 years and younger Standard treatment of pineoblastoma in children aged 3 years and younger includes the following: Biopsy to diagnose pineoblastoma followed by chemotherapy.<EOS>
<BOS>If the tumor responds to chemotherapy, radiation therapy is given when the child is older.<EOS>
<BOS>Highdose chemotherapy with stem cell rescue.<EOS>
<BOS>Check the list of NCIsupported cancer clinical trials that are now accepting patients with untreated childhood pineoblastoma.<EOS>
<BOS>For more specific results, refine the search by using other search features, such as the location of the trial, the type of treatment, or the name of the drug.<EOS>
<BOS>Talk with your child's doctor about clinical trials that may be right for your child.<EOS>
<BOS>General information about clinical trials is available from the NCI website.<EOS>
<BOS>Recurrent Childhood Central Nervous System Embryonal Tumors and Pineoblastomas The treatment of central nervous system (CNS) embryonal tumors and pineoblastoma that recur (come back) depends on: The type of tumor.<EOS>
<BOS>Whether the tumor recurred where it first formed or has spread to other parts of the brain, spinal cord, or body.<EOS>
<BOS>The type of treatment given in the past.<EOS>
<BOS>How much time has passed since the initial treatment ended.<EOS>
<BOS>Whether the patient has signs or symptoms.<EOS>
<BOS>Treatment for recurrent childhood CNS embryonal tumors and pineoblastomas may include the following: For children who previously received radiation therapy and chemotherapy, treatment may include repeat radiation at the site where the cancer started and where the tumor has spread.<EOS>
<BOS>Stereotactic radiation therapy and/or chemotherapy may also be used.<EOS>
<BOS>For infants and young children who previously received chemotherapy only and have a local recurrence, treatment may be chemotherapy with radiation therapy to the tumor and the area close to it.<EOS>
<BOS>Surgery to remove the tumor may also be done.<EOS>
<BOS>For patients who previously received radiation therapy, highdose chemotherapy and stem cell rescue may be used.<EOS>
<BOS>It is not known whether this treatment improves survival.<EOS>
<BOS>Targeted therapy with a signal transduction inhibitor for patients whose cancer has certain changes in the genes.<EOS>
<BOS>Check the list of NCIsupported cancer clinical trials that are now accepting patients with recurrent childhood central nervous system embryonal tumor.<EOS>
<BOS>For more specific results, refine the search by using other search features, such as the location of the trial, the type of treatment, or the name of the drug.<EOS>
<BOS>Talk with your child's doctor about clinical trials that may be right for your child.<EOS>
<BOS>General information about clinical trials is available from the NCI website.<EOS>
<BOS>Key Points After endometrial cancer has been diagnosed, tests are done to find out if cancer cells have spread within the uterus or to other parts of the body.<EOS>
<BOS>There are three ways that cancer spreads in the body.<EOS>
<BOS>Cancer may spread from where it began to other parts of the body.<EOS>
<BOS>The following stages are used for endometrial cancer: Stage I Stage II Stage III Stage IV Endometrial cancer may be grouped for treatment as follows: Lowrisk endometrial cancer Highrisk endometrial cancer After endometrial cancer has been diagnosed, tests are done to find out if cancer cells have spread within the uterus or to other parts of the body.<EOS>
<BOS>The process used to find out whether the cancer has spread within the uterus or to other parts of the body is called staging.<EOS>
<BOS>The information gathered from the staging process determines the stage of the disease.<EOS>
<BOS>It is important to know the stage in order to plan treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Certain tests and procedures are used in the staging process.<EOS>
<BOS>A hysterectomy (an operation in which the uterus is removed) will usually be done to treat endometrial cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Tissue samples are taken from the area around the uterus and checked under a microscope for signs of cancer to help find out whether the cancer has spread.<EOS>
<BOS>The following procedures may be used in the staging process: Pelvic exam : An exam of the vagina, cervix, uterus, fallopian tubes, ovaries, and rectum.<EOS>
<BOS>A speculum is inserted into the vagina and the doctor or nurse looks at the vagina and cervix for signs of disease.<EOS>
<BOS>A Pap test of the cervix is usually done.<EOS>
<BOS>The doctor or nurse also inserts one or two lubricated, gloved fingers of one hand into the vagina and places the other hand over the lower abdomen to feel the size, shape, and position of the uterus and ovaries.<EOS>
<BOS>The doctor or nurse also inserts a lubricated, gloved finger into the rectum to feel for lumps or abnormal areas.<EOS>
<BOS>Chest xray : An xray of the organs and bones inside the chest.<EOS>
<BOS>An xray is a type of energy beam that can go through the body and onto film, making a picture of areas inside the body.<EOS>
<BOS>CT scan (CAT scan): A procedure that makes a series of detailed pictures of areas inside the body, taken from different angles.<EOS>
<BOS>The pictures are made by a computer linked to an xray machine.<EOS>
<BOS>A dye may be injected into a vein or swallowed to help the organs or tissues show up more clearly.<EOS>
<BOS>This procedure is also called computed tomography, computerized tomography, or computerized axial tomography.<EOS>
<BOS>MRI (magnetic resonance imaging): A procedure that uses a magnet, radio waves, and a computer to make a series of detailed pictures of areas inside the body.<EOS>
<BOS>This procedure is also called nuclear magnetic resonance imaging (NMRI).<EOS>
<BOS>PET scan (positron emission tomography scan): A procedure to find malignant tumor cells in the body.<EOS>
<BOS>A small amount of radioactive glucose (sugar) is injected into a vein.<EOS>
<BOS>The PET scanner rotates around the body and makes a picture of where glucose is being used in the body.<EOS>
<BOS>Malignant tumor cells show up brighter in the picture because they are more active and take up more glucose than normal cells do.<EOS>
<BOS>Lymph node dissection : A surgical procedure in which the lymph nodes are removed from the pelvic area and a sample of tissue is checked under a microscope for signs of cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>This procedure is also called lymphadenectomy.<EOS>
<BOS>There are three ways that cancer spreads in the body.<EOS>
<BOS>Cancer can spread through tissue, the lymph system, and the blood: Tissue.<EOS>
<BOS>The cancer spreads from where it began by growing into nearby areas.<EOS>
<BOS>Lymph system.<EOS>
<BOS>The cancer spreads from where it began by getting into the lymph system.<EOS>
<BOS>The cancer travels through the lymph vessels to other parts of the body.<EOS>
<BOS>Blood.<EOS>
<BOS>The cancer spreads from where it began by getting into the blood.<EOS>
<BOS>The cancer travels through the blood vessels to other parts of the body.<EOS>
<BOS>Cancer may spread from where it began to other parts of the body.<EOS>
<BOS>When cancer spreads to another part of the body, it is called metastasis.<EOS>
<BOS>Cancer cells break away from where they began (the primary tumor) and travel through the lymph system or blood.<EOS>
<BOS>Lymph system.<EOS>
