<BOS>The cancer gets into the lymph system, travels through the lymph vessels, and forms a tumor (metastatic tumor) in another part of the body.<EOS>
<BOS>Blood.<EOS>
<BOS>The cancer gets into the blood, travels through the blood vessels, and forms a tumor (metastatic tumor) in another part of the body.<EOS>
<BOS>The metastatic tumor is the same type of cancer as the primary tumor.<EOS>
<BOS>For example, if endometrial cancer spreads to the lung, the cancer cells in the lung are actually endometrial cancer cells.<EOS>
<BOS>The disease is metastatic endometrial cancer, not lung cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>The following stages are used for endometrial cancer: Stage I In stage I, cancer is found in the uterus only.<EOS>
<BOS>Stage I is divided into stages IA and IB, based on how far the cancer has spread.<EOS>
<BOS>Stage IA: Cancer is in the endometrium only or less than halfway through the myometrium (muscle layer of the uterus).<EOS>
<BOS>Stage IB: Cancer has spread halfway or more into the myometrium.<EOS>
<BOS>Stage II In stage II, cancer has spread into connective tissue of the cervix, but has not spread outside the uterus.<EOS>
<BOS>Stage III In stage III, cancer has spread beyond the uterus and cervix, but has not spread beyond the pelvis.<EOS>
<BOS>Stage III is divided into stages IIIA, IIIB, and IIIC, based on how far the cancer has spread within the pelvis.<EOS>
<BOS>Stage IIIA: Cancer has spread to the outer layer of the uterus and/or to the fallopian tubes, ovaries, and ligaments of the uterus.<EOS>
<BOS>Stage IIIB: Cancer has spread to the vagina and/or to the parametrium (connective tissue and fat around the uterus).<EOS>
<BOS>Stage IIIC: Cancer has spread to lymph nodes in the pelvis and/or around the aorta (largest artery in the body, which carries blood away from the heart).<EOS>
<BOS>Stage IV In stage IV, cancer has spread beyond the pelvis.<EOS>
<BOS>Stage IV is divided into stages IVA and IVB, based on how far the cancer has spread.<EOS>
<BOS>Stage IVA: Cancer has spread to the bladder and/or bowel wall.<EOS>
<BOS>Stage IVB: Cancer has spread to other parts of the body beyond the pelvis, including the abdomen and/or lymph nodes in the groin.<EOS>
<BOS>Endometrial cancer may be grouped for treatment as follows: Lowrisk endometrial cancer Grades 1 and 2 tumors are usually considered lowrisk.<EOS>
<BOS>They usually do not spread to other parts of the body.<EOS>
<BOS>Highrisk endometrial cancer Grade 3 tumors are considered highrisk.<EOS>
<BOS>They often spread to other parts of the body.<EOS>
<BOS>Uterine papillary serous, clear cell, and carcinosarcoma are three subtypes of endometrial cancer that are considered grade 3.<EOS>
<BOS>Certain factors affect prognosis (chance of recovery) and treatment options.<EOS>
<BOS>The prognosis (chance of recovery) and treatment options depend on the following: Age of the child at the time of diagnosis.<EOS>
<BOS>The child's risk group.<EOS>
<BOS>Whether there are certain changes in the genes.<EOS>
<BOS>Where in the body the tumor started.<EOS>
<BOS>Tumor histology (the shape, function, and structure of the tumor cells).<EOS>
<BOS>Whether there is cancer in the lymph nodes on the same side of the body as the primary cancer or whether there is cancer in the lymph nodes on the opposite side of the body.<EOS>
<BOS>How the tumor responds to treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>How much time passed between diagnosis and when the cancer recurred (for recurrent cancer).<EOS>
<BOS>Prognosis and treatment options for neuroblastoma are also affected by tumor biology, which includes: The patterns of the tumor cells.<EOS>
<BOS>How different the tumor cells are from normal cells.<EOS>
<BOS>How fast the tumor cells are growing.<EOS>
<BOS>Whether the tumor shows MYCN amplification.<EOS>
<BOS>Whether the tumor has changes in the ALK gene.<EOS>
<BOS>The tumor biology is said to be favorable or unfavorable, depending on these factors.<EOS>
<BOS>A favorable tumor biology means there is a better chance of recovery.<EOS>
<BOS>In some children up to 6 months old, neuroblastoma may disappear without treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>This is called spontaneous regression.<EOS>
<BOS>The child is closely watched for signs or symptoms of neuroblastoma.<EOS>
<BOS>If signs or symptoms occur, treatment may be needed.<EOS>
<BOS>Signs and symptoms of hypopharyngeal cancer include a sore throat and ear pain.<EOS>
<BOS>These and other signs and symptoms may be caused by hypopharyngeal cancer or by other conditions.<EOS>
<BOS>Check with your doctor if you have any of the following: A sore throat that does not go away.<EOS>
<BOS>Ear pain.<EOS>
<BOS>A lump in the neck.<EOS>
<BOS>Painful or difficult swallowing.<EOS>
<BOS>A change in voice.<EOS>
<BOS>Key Points After childhood nonHodgkin lymphoma has been diagnosed, tests are done to find out if cancer cells have spread within the lymph system or to other parts of the body.<EOS>
<BOS>There are three ways that cancer spreads in the body.<EOS>
<BOS>The following stages are used for childhood nonHodgkin lymphoma: Stage I Stage II Stage III Stage IV After childhood nonHodgkin lymphoma has been diagnosed, tests are done to find out if cancer cells have spread within the lymph system or to other parts of the body.<EOS>
<BOS>The process used to find out if cancer has spread within the lymph system or to other parts of the body is called staging.<EOS>
<BOS>The results of tests and procedures used to diagnose nonHodgkin lymphoma may also be used for staging.<EOS>
<BOS>See the General Information section for a description of these tests and procedures.<EOS>
<BOS>The information gathered from the staging process determines the stage of the disease.<EOS>
<BOS>It is important to know the stage in order to plan treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>The following procedure also may be used to determine the stage: Bone scan : A procedure to check if there are rapidly dividing cells, such as cancer cells, in the bone.<EOS>
<BOS>A very small amount of radioactive material is injected into a vein and travels through the bloodstream.<EOS>
<BOS>The radioactive material collects in the bones with cancer and is detected by a scanner.<EOS>
<BOS>There are three ways that cancer spreads in the body.<EOS>
<BOS>Cancer can spread through tissue, the lymph system, and the blood: Tissue.<EOS>
<BOS>The cancer spreads from where it began by growing into nearby areas.<EOS>
<BOS>Lymph system.<EOS>
<BOS>The cancer spreads from where it began by getting into the lymph system.<EOS>
<BOS>The cancer travels through the lymph vessels to other parts of the body.<EOS>
<BOS>Blood.<EOS>
<BOS>The cancer spreads from where it began by getting into the blood.<EOS>
<BOS>The cancer travels through the blood vessels to other parts of the body.<EOS>
<BOS>The following stages are used for childhood nonHodgkin lymphoma: Stage I In stage I childhood nonHodgkin lymphoma, cancer is found: in one group of lymph nodes; or in one area outside the lymph nodes.<EOS>
<BOS>No cancer is found in the abdomen or mediastinum (area between the lungs).<EOS>
<BOS>Stage II In stage II childhood nonHodgkin lymphoma, cancer is found: in one area outside the lymph nodes and in nearby lymph nodes; or in two or more areas either above or below the diaphragm, and may have spread to nearby lymph nodes; or to have started in the stomach or intestines and can be completely removed by surgery.<EOS>
<BOS>Cancer may have spread to certain nearby lymph nodes.<EOS>
<BOS>Stage III In stage III childhood nonHodgkin lymphoma, cancer is found: in at least one area above the diaphragm and in at least one area below the diaphragm; or to have started in the chest; or to have started in the abdomen and spread throughout the abdomen; or in the area around the spine.<EOS>
<BOS>Stage IV In stage IV childhood nonHodgkin lymphoma, cancer is found in the bone marrow, brain, or cerebrospinal fluid.<EOS>
<BOS>Cancer may also be found in other parts of the body.<EOS>
<BOS>Signs of childhood craniopharyngioma include vision changes and slow growth.<EOS>
<BOS>These and other signs and symptoms may be caused by craniopharyngiomas or by other conditions.<EOS>
<BOS>Check with your childs doctor if your child has any of the following: Headaches, including morning headache or headache that goes away after vomiting.<EOS>
<BOS>Vision changes.<EOS>
<BOS>Nausea and vomiting.<EOS>
<BOS>Loss of balance or trouble walking.<EOS>
<BOS>Increase in thirst or urination.<EOS>
<BOS>Unusual sleepiness or change in energy level.<EOS>
<BOS>Changes in personality or behavior.<EOS>
<BOS>Short stature or slow growth.<EOS>
<BOS>Hearing loss.<EOS>
<BOS>Weight gain.<EOS>
<BOS>Tests that examine the ovaries are used to detect (find), diagnose, and stage ovarian low malignant potential tumor.<EOS>
<BOS>The following tests and procedures may be used: Physical exam and history : An exam of the body to check general signs of health, including checking for signs of disease, such as lumps or anything else that seems unusual.<EOS>
<BOS>A history of the patients health habits and past illnesses and treatments will also be taken.<EOS>
<BOS>Pelvic exam : An exam of the vagina, cervix, uterus, fallopian tubes, ovaries, and rectum.<EOS>
<BOS>A speculum is inserted into the vagina and the doctor or nurse looks at the vagina and cervix for signs of disease.<EOS>
<BOS>A Pap test of the cervix is usually done.<EOS>
<BOS>The doctor or nurse also inserts one or two lubricated, gloved fingers of one hand into the vagina and places the other hand over the lower abdomen to feel the size, shape, and position of the uterus and ovaries.<EOS>
<BOS>The doctor or nurse also inserts a lubricated, gloved finger into the rectum to feel for lumps or abnormal areas.<EOS>
<BOS>Ultrasound exam: A procedure in which highenergy sound waves (ultrasound) are bounced off internal tissues or organs and make echoes.<EOS>
<BOS>The echoes form a picture of body tissues called a sonogram.<EOS>
<BOS>The picture can be printed to be looked at later.<EOS>
<BOS>Other patients may have a transvaginal ultrasound.<EOS>
<BOS>CT scan (CAT scan): A procedure that makes a series of detailed pictures of areas inside the body, taken from different angles.<EOS>
<BOS>The pictures are made by a computer linked to an xray machine.<EOS>
<BOS>A dye may be injected into a vein or swallowed to help the organs or tissues show up more clearly.<EOS>
<BOS>This procedure is also called computed tomography, computerized tomography, or computerized axial tomography.<EOS>
<BOS>CA 125 assay : A test that measures the level of CA 125 in the blood.<EOS>
<BOS>CA 125 is a substance released by cells into the bloodstream.<EOS>
<BOS>An increased CA 125 level is sometimes a sign of cancer or other condition.<EOS>
<BOS>Chest xray : An xray of the organs and bones inside the chest.<EOS>
<BOS>An xray is a type of energy beam that can go through the body and onto film, making a picture of areas inside the body.<EOS>
<BOS>Biopsy : The removal of cells or tissues so they can be viewed under a microscope by a pathologist to check for signs of cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>The tissue is usually removed during surgery to remove the tumor.<EOS>
<BOS>Key Points After hypopharyngeal cancer has been diagnosed, tests are done to find out if cancer cells have spread within the hypopharynx or to other parts of the body.<EOS>
<BOS>There are three ways that cancer spreads in the body.<EOS>
<BOS>Cancer may spread from where it began to other parts of the body.<EOS>
<BOS>The following stages are used for hypopharyngeal cancer: Stage 0 (Carcinoma in Situ) Stage I Stage II Stage III Stage IV After hypopharyngeal cancer has been diagnosed, tests are done to find out if cancer cells have spread within the hypopharynx or to other parts of the body.<EOS>
<BOS>The process used to find out if cancer has spread within the hypopharynx or to other parts of the body is called staging.<EOS>
<BOS>The information gathered from the staging process determines the stage of the disease.<EOS>
<BOS>It is important to know the stage of the disease in order to plan treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>The results of some of the tests used to diagnose hypopharyngeal cancer are often also used to stage the disease.<EOS>
<BOS>There are three ways that cancer spreads in the body.<EOS>
<BOS>Cancer can spread through tissue, the lymph system, and the blood: Tissue.<EOS>
<BOS>The cancer spreads from where it began by growing into nearby areas.<EOS>
<BOS>Lymph system.<EOS>
<BOS>The cancer spreads from where it began by getting into the lymph system.<EOS>
<BOS>The cancer travels through the lymph vessels to other parts of the body.<EOS>
<BOS>Blood.<EOS>
<BOS>The cancer spreads from where it began by getting into the blood.<EOS>
<BOS>The cancer travels through the blood vessels to other parts of the body.<EOS>
<BOS>Cancer may spread from where it began to other parts of the body.<EOS>
<BOS>When cancer spreads to another part of the body, it is called metastasis.<EOS>
<BOS>Cancer cells break away from where they began (the primary tumor) and travel through the lymph system or blood.<EOS>
<BOS>Lymph system.<EOS>
<BOS>The cancer gets into the lymph system, travels through the lymph vessels, and forms a tumor (metastatic tumor) in another part of the body.<EOS>
<BOS>Blood.<EOS>
<BOS>The cancer gets into the blood, travels through the blood vessels, and forms a tumor (metastatic tumor) in another part of the body.<EOS>
<BOS>The metastatic tumor is the same type of cancer as the primary tumor.<EOS>
<BOS>For example, if hypopharyngeal cancer spreads to the lung, the cancer cells in the lung are actually hypopharyngeal cancer cells.<EOS>
<BOS>The disease is metastatic hypopharyngeal cancer, not lung cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>The following stages are used for hypopharyngeal cancer: Stage 0 (Carcinoma in Situ) In stage 0, abnormal cells are found in the lining of the hypopharynx.<EOS>
<BOS>These abnormal cells may become cancer and spread into nearby normal tissue.<EOS>
<BOS>Stage 0 is also called carcinoma in situ.<EOS>
<BOS>Stage I In stage I, cancer has formed in one area of the hypopharynx only and/or the tumor is 2 centimeters or smaller.<EOS>
<BOS>Stage II In stage II, the tumor is either: larger than 2 centimeters but not larger than 4 centimeters and has not spread to the larynx (voice box); or found in more than one area of the hypopharynx or in nearby tissues.<EOS>
<BOS>Stage III In stage III, the tumor: is larger than 4 centimeters or has spread to the larynx (voice box) or esophagus.<EOS>
<BOS>Cancer may have spread to one lymph node on the same side of the neck as the tumor and the lymph node is 3 centimeters or smaller; or has spread to one lymph node on the same side of the neck as the tumor and the lymph node is 3 centimeters or smaller and cancer is found: in one area of the hypopharynx and/or is 2 centimeters or smaller; or in more than one area of the hypopharynx or in nearby tissues, or is larger than 2 centimeters but not larger than 4 centimeters and has not spread to the larynx.<EOS>
<BOS>Stage IV Stage IV is divided into stage IVA, IVB, and IVC as follows: In stage IVA, cancer: has spread to cartilage around the thyroid or trachea, the bone under the tongue, the thyroid, or nearby soft tissue.<EOS>
<BOS>Cancer may have spread to one lymph node on the same side of the neck as the tumor and the lymph node is 3 centimeters or smaller; or has spread to one lymph node on the same side of the neck as the tumor (the lymph node is larger than 3 centimeters but not larger than 6 centimeters) or to lymph nodes anywhere in the neck (affected lymph nodes are 6 centimeters or smaller), and one of the following is true: cancer is found in one area of the hypopharynx and/or is 2 centimeters or smaller; or cancer is found in more than one area of the hypopharynx or in nearby tissues, or is larger than 2 centimeters but not larger than 4 centimeters and has not spread to the larynx (voice box); or cancer has spread to the larynx or esophagus and is more than 4 centimeters; or cancer has spread to cartilage around the thyroid or trachea, the bone under the tongue, the thyroid, or nearby soft tissue.<EOS>
<BOS>In stage IVB, the tumor: has spread to muscles around the upper part of the spinal column, the carotid artery, or the lining of the chest cavity and may have spread to lymph nodes which can be any size; or may be any size and has spread to one or more lymph nodes that are larger than 6 centimeters.<EOS>
<BOS>In stage IVC, the tumor may be any size and has spread beyond the hypopharynx to other parts of the body.<EOS>
<BOS>Key Points Chronic lymphocytic leukemia is a type of cancer in which the bone marrow makes too many lymphocytes (a type of white blood cell).<EOS>
<BOS>Leukemia may affect red blood cells, white blood cells, and platelets.<EOS>
<BOS>Older age can affect the risk of developing chronic lymphocytic leukemia.<EOS>
<BOS>Signs and symptoms of chronic lymphocytic leukemia include swollen lymph nodes and tiredness.<EOS>
<BOS>Tests that examine the blood, bone marrow, and lymph nodes are used to detect (find) and diagnose chronic lymphocytic leukemia.<EOS>
<BOS>Certain factors affect treatment options and prognosis (chance of recovery).<EOS>
<BOS>Chronic lymphocytic leukemia is a type of cancer in which the bone marrow makes too many lymphocytes (a type of white blood cell).<EOS>
<BOS>Chronic lymphocytic leukemia (also called CLL) is a blood and bone marrow disease that usually gets worse slowly.<EOS>
<BOS>CLL is one of the most common types of leukemia in adults.<EOS>
<BOS>It often occurs during or after middle age; it rarely occurs in children.<EOS>
<BOS>Leukemia may affect red blood cells, white blood cells, and platelets.<EOS>
<BOS>Normally, the body makes blood stem cells (immature cells) that become mature blood cells over time.<EOS>
<BOS>A blood stem cell may become a myeloid stem cell or a lymphoid stem cell.<EOS>
<BOS>A myeloid stem cell becomes one of three types of mature blood cells: Red blood cells that carry oxygen and other substances to all tissues of the body.<EOS>
<BOS>White blood cells that fight infection and disease.<EOS>
<BOS>Platelets that form blood clots to stop bleeding.<EOS>
<BOS>A lymphoid stem cell becomes a lymphoblast cell and then one of three types of lymphocytes (white blood cells): B lymphocytes that make antibodies to help fight infection.<EOS>
<BOS>T lymphocytes that help B lymphocytes make antibodies to fight infection.<EOS>
<BOS>Natural killer cells that attack cancer cells and viruses.<EOS>
<BOS>In CLL, too many blood stem cells become abnormal lymphocytes and do not become healthy white blood cells.<EOS>
<BOS>The abnormal lymphocytes may also be called leukemia cells.<EOS>
<BOS>The lymphocytes are not able to fight infection very well.<EOS>
<BOS>Also, as the number of lymphocytes increases in the blood and bone marrow, there is less room for healthy white blood cells, red blood cells, and platelets.<EOS>
<BOS>This may cause infection, anemia, and easy bleeding.<EOS>
<BOS>This summary is about chronic lymphocytic leukemia.<EOS>
<BOS>See the following PDQ summaries for more information about leukemia: Adult Acute Lymphoblastic Leukemia Treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Childhood Acute Lymphoblastic Leukemia Treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Adult Acute Myeloid Leukemia Treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Childhood Acute Myeloid Leukemia/Other Myeloid Malignancies Treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Chronic Myelogenous Leukemia Treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Hairy Cell Leukemia Treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>New types of treatment are being tested in clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>This summary section describes treatments that are being studied in clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>It may not mention every new treatment being studied.<EOS>
<BOS>Information about clinical trials is available from the NCI website.<EOS>
<BOS>Radiosensitizers Radiosensitizers are drugs that make tumor cells more sensitive to radiation therapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Combining radiation therapy with radiosensitizers may kill more tumor cells.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients may want to think about taking part in a clinical trial.<EOS>
<BOS>For some patients, taking part in a clinical trial may be the best treatment choice.<EOS>
<BOS>Clinical trials are part of the cancer research process.<EOS>
<BOS>Clinical trials are done to find out if new cancer treatments are safe and effective or better than the standard treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Many of today's standard treatments for cancer are based on earlier clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients who take part in a clinical trial may receive the standard treatment or be among the first to receive a new treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients who take part in clinical trials also help improve the way cancer will be treated in the future.<EOS>
<BOS>Even when clinical trials do not lead to effective new treatments, they often answer important questions and help move research forward.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients can enter clinical trials before, during, or after starting their cancer treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Some clinical trials only include patients who have not yet received treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Other trials test treatments for patients whose cancer has not gotten better.<EOS>
<BOS>There are also clinical trials that test new ways to stop cancer from recurring (coming back) or reduce the side effects of cancer treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Clinical trials are taking place in many parts of the country.<EOS>
<BOS>See the Treatment Options section that follows for links to current treatment clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>These have been retrieved from NCI's listing of clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>Tests that examine the lymph nodes are used to detect (find) and diagnose adult Hodgkin lymphoma.<EOS>
<BOS>The following tests and procedures may be used: Physical exam and history : An exam of the body to check general signs of health, including checking for signs of disease, such as lumps or anything else that seems unusual.<EOS>
<BOS>A history of the patient's past illnesses and treatments will also be taken.<EOS>
<BOS>Complete blood count (CBC): A procedure in which a sample of blood is drawn and checked for the following: The number of red blood cells, white blood cells, and platelets.<EOS>
<BOS>The amount of hemoglobin (the protein that carries oxygen) in the red blood cells.<EOS>
<BOS>The portion of the sample made up of red blood cells.<EOS>
<BOS>Blood chemistry studies : A procedure in which a blood sample is checked to measure the amounts of certain substances released into the blood by organs and tissues in the body.<EOS>
<BOS>An unusual (higher or lower than normal) amount of a substance can be a sign of disease.<EOS>
<BOS>Sedimentation rate : A procedure in which a sample of blood is drawn and checked for the rate at which the red blood cells settle to the bottom of the test tube.<EOS>
<BOS>The sedimentation rate is a measure of how much inflammation is in the body.<EOS>
<BOS>A higher than normal sedimentation rate may be a sign of lymphoma or another condition.<EOS>
<BOS>Also called erythrocyte sedimentation rate, sed rate, or ESR.<EOS>
<BOS>Lymph node biopsy : The removal of all or part of a lymph node.<EOS>
<BOS>One of the following types of biopsies may be done: Excisional biopsy : The removal of an entire lymph node.<EOS>
<BOS>Incisional biopsy : The removal of part of a lymph node.<EOS>
<BOS>Core biopsy : The removal of part of a lymph node using a wide needle.<EOS>
<BOS>A pathologist views the tissue under a microscope to look for cancer cells, especially ReedSternberg cells.<EOS>
<BOS>ReedSternberg cells are common in classical Hodgkin lymphoma.<EOS>
<BOS>The following test may be done on tissue that was removed: Immunophenotyping : A laboratory test used to identify cells, based on the types of antigens or markers on the surface of the cell.<EOS>
<BOS>This test is used to diagnose the specific type of lymphoma by comparing the cancer cells to normal cells of the immune system.<EOS>
<BOS>Lab tests and imaging tests are used to detect (find) and diagnose pancreatic NETs.<EOS>
<BOS>The following tests and procedures may be used: Physical exam and history : An exam of the body to check general signs of health, including checking for signs of disease, such as lumps or anything else that seems unusual.<EOS>
<BOS>A history of the patients health habits and past illnesses and treatments will also be taken.<EOS>
<BOS>Blood chemistry studies : A procedure in which a blood sample is checked to measure the amounts of certain substances, such as glucose (sugar), released into the blood by organs and tissues in the body.<EOS>
<BOS>An unusual (higher or lower than normal) amount of a substance can be a sign of disease.<EOS>
<BOS>Chromogranin A test: A test in which a blood sample is checked to measure the amount of chromogranin A in the blood.<EOS>
<BOS>A higher than normal amount of chromogranin A and normal amounts of hormones such as gastrin, insulin, and glucagon can be a sign of a nonfunctional pancreatic NET.<EOS>
<BOS>Abdominal CT scan (CAT scan): A procedure that makes a series of detailed pictures of the abdomen, taken from different angles.<EOS>
<BOS>The pictures are made by a computer linked to an xray machine.<EOS>
<BOS>A dye may be injected into a vein or swallowed to help the organs or tissues show up more clearly.<EOS>
<BOS>This procedure is also called computed tomography, computerized tomography, or computerized axial tomography.<EOS>
<BOS>MRI (magnetic resonance imaging): A procedure that uses a magnet, radio waves, and a computer to make a series of detailed pictures of areas inside the body.<EOS>
<BOS>This procedure is also called nuclear magnetic resonance imaging (NMRI).<EOS>
<BOS>Somatostatin receptor scintigraphy : A type of radionuclide scan that may be used to find small pancreatic NETs.<EOS>
<BOS>A small amount of radioactive octreotide (a hormone that attaches to tumors) is injected into a vein and travels through the blood.<EOS>
<BOS>The radioactive octreotide attaches to the tumor and a special camera that detects radioactivity is used to show where the tumors are in the body.<EOS>
<BOS>This procedure is also called octreotide scan and SRS.<EOS>
<BOS>Endoscopic ultrasound (EUS): A procedure in which an endoscope is inserted into the body, usually through the mouth or rectum.<EOS>
<BOS>An endoscope is a thin, tubelike instrument with a light and a lens for viewing.<EOS>
<BOS>A probe at the end of the endoscope is used to bounce highenergy sound waves (ultrasound) off internal tissues or organs and make echoes.<EOS>
<BOS>The echoes form a picture of body tissues called a sonogram.<EOS>
<BOS>This procedure is also called endosonography.<EOS>
<BOS>Endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography (ERCP): A procedure used to xray the ducts (tubes) that carry bile from the liver to the gallbladder and from the gallbladder to the small intestine.<EOS>
<BOS>Sometimes pancreatic cancer causes these ducts to narrow and block or slow the flow of bile, causing jaundice.<EOS>
<BOS>An endoscope is passed through the mouth, esophagus, and stomach into the first part of the small intestine.<EOS>
<BOS>An endoscope is a thin, tubelike instrument with a light and a lens for viewing.<EOS>
<BOS>A catheter (a smaller tube) is then inserted through the endoscope into the pancreatic ducts.<EOS>
<BOS>A dye is injected through the catheter into the ducts and an xray is taken.<EOS>
<BOS>If the ducts are blocked by a tumor, a fine tube may be inserted into the duct to unblock it.<EOS>
<BOS>This tube (or stent) may be left in place to keep the duct open.<EOS>
<BOS>Tissue samples may also be taken and checked under a microscope for signs of cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Angiogram : A procedure to look at blood vessels and the flow of blood.<EOS>
<BOS>A contrast dye is injected into the blood vessel.<EOS>
<BOS>As the contrast dye moves through the blood vessel, xrays are taken to see if there are any blockages.<EOS>
<BOS>Laparotomy : A surgical procedure in which an incision (cut) is made in the wall of the abdomen to check the inside of the abdomen for signs of disease.<EOS>
<BOS>The size of the incision depends on the reason the laparotomy is being done.<EOS>
<BOS>Sometimes organs are removed or tissue samples are taken and checked under a microscope for signs of disease.<EOS>
<BOS>Intraoperative ultrasound : A procedure that uses highenergy sound waves (ultrasound) to create images of internal organs or tissues during surgery.<EOS>
<BOS>A transducer placed directly on the organ or tissue is used to make the sound waves, which create echoes.<EOS>
<BOS>The transducer receives the echoes and sends them to a computer, which uses the echoes to make pictures called sonograms.<EOS>
<BOS>Biopsy : The removal of cells or tissues so they can be viewed under a microscope by a pathologist to check for signs of cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>There are several ways to do a biopsy for pancreatic NETs.<EOS>
<BOS>Cells may be removed using a fine or wide needle inserted into the pancreas during an xray or ultrasound.<EOS>
<BOS>Tissue may also be removed during a laparoscopy (a surgical incision made in the wall of the abdomen).<EOS>
<BOS>Bone scan : A procedure to check if there are rapidly dividing cells, such as cancer cells, in the bone.<EOS>
<BOS>A very small amount of radioactive material is injected into a vein and travels through the blood.<EOS>
<BOS>The radioactive material collects in bones where cancer cells have spread and is detected by a scanner.<EOS>
<BOS>Other kinds of lab tests are used to check for the specific type of pancreatic NETs.<EOS>
<BOS>The following tests and procedures may be used: Gastrinoma Fasting serum gastrin test: A test in which a blood sample is checked to measure the amount of gastrin in the blood.<EOS>
<BOS>This test is done after the patient has had nothing to eat or drink for at least 8 hours.<EOS>
<BOS>Conditions other than gastrinoma can cause an increase in the amount of gastrin in the blood.<EOS>
<BOS>Basal acid output test: A test to measure the amount of acid made by the stomach.<EOS>
<BOS>The test is done after the patient has had nothing to eat or drink for at least 8 hours.<EOS>
<BOS>A tube is inserted through the nose or throat, into the stomach.<EOS>
<BOS>The stomach contents are removed and four samples of gastric acid are removed through the tube.<EOS>
<BOS>These samples are used to find out the amount of gastric acid made during the test and the pH level of the gastric secretions.<EOS>
<BOS>Secretin stimulation test : If the basal acid output test result is not normal, a secretin stimulation test may be done.<EOS>
<BOS>The tube is moved into the small intestine and samples are taken from the small intestine after a drug called secretin is injected.<EOS>
<BOS>Secretin causes the small intestine to make acid.<EOS>
<BOS>When there is a gastrinoma, the secretin causes an increase in how much gastric acid is made and the level of gastrin in the blood.<EOS>
<BOS>Somatostatin receptor scintigraphy: A type of radionuclide scan that may be used to find small pancreatic NETs.<EOS>
<BOS>A small amount of radioactive octreotide (a hormone that attaches to tumors) is injected into a vein and travels through the blood.<EOS>
<BOS>The radioactive octreotide attaches to the tumor and a special camera that detects radioactivity is used to show where the tumors are in the body.<EOS>
<BOS>This procedure is also called octreotide scan and SRS.<EOS>
<BOS>Insulinoma Fasting serum glucose and insulin test: A test in which a blood sample is checked to measure the amounts of glucose (sugar) and insulin in the blood.<EOS>
<BOS>The test is done after the patient has had nothing to eat or drink for at least 24 hours.<EOS>
<BOS>Glucagonoma Fasting serum glucagon test: A test in which a blood sample is checked to measure the amount of glucagon in the blood.<EOS>
<BOS>The test is done after the patient has had nothing to eat or drink for at least 8 hours.<EOS>
<BOS>Other tumor types VIPoma Serum VIP (vasoactive intestinal peptide) test: A test in which a blood sample is checked to measure the amount of VIP.<EOS>
<BOS>Blood chemistry studies: A procedure in which a blood sample is checked to measure the amounts of certain substances released into the blood by organs and tissues in the body.<EOS>
<BOS>An unusual (higher or lower than normal) amount of a substance can be a sign of disease.<EOS>
<BOS>In VIPoma, there is a lower than normal amount of potassium.<EOS>
<BOS>Stool analysis : A stool sample is checked for a higher than normal sodium (salt) and potassium levels.<EOS>
<BOS>Somatostatinoma Fasting serum somatostatin test: A test in which a blood sample is checked to measure the amount of somatostatin in the blood.<EOS>
<BOS>The test is done after the patient has had nothing to eat or drink for at least 8 hours.<EOS>
<BOS>Somatostatin receptor scintigraphy: A type of radionuclide scan that may be used to find small pancreatic NETs.<EOS>
<BOS>A small amount of radioactive octreotide (a hormone that attaches to tumors) is injected into a vein and travels through the blood.<EOS>
<BOS>The radioactive octreotide attaches to the tumor and a special camera that detects radioactivity is used to show where the tumors are in the body.<EOS>
<BOS>This procedure is also called octreotide scan and SRS.<EOS>
<BOS>Tests that examine the brain and spinal cord are used to detect (find) childhood CNS embryonal tumors or pineoblastomas.<EOS>
<BOS>The following tests and procedures may be used: Physical exam and history : An exam of the body to check general signs of health, including checking for signs of disease, such as lumps or anything else that seems unusual.<EOS>
<BOS>A history of the patients health habits and past illnesses and treatments will also be taken.<EOS>
<BOS>Neurological exam : A series of questions and tests to check the brain, spinal cord, and nerve function.<EOS>
<BOS>The exam checks a patient's mental status, coordination, and ability to walk normally, and how well the muscles, senses, and reflexes work.<EOS>
<BOS>This may also be called a neuro exam or a neurologic exam.<EOS>
<BOS>MRI (magnetic resonance imaging) of the brain and spinal cord with gadolinium : A procedure that uses a magnet, radio waves, and a computer to make a series of detailed pictures of areas inside the brain and spinal cord.<EOS>
<BOS>A substance called gadolinium is injected into a vein.<EOS>
<BOS>The gadolinium collects around the cancer cells so they show up brighter in the picture.<EOS>
<BOS>This procedure is also called nuclear magnetic resonance imaging (NMRI).<EOS>
<BOS>Sometimes magnetic resonance spectroscopy (MRS) is done during the MRI scan to look at the chemicals in brain tissue.<EOS>
<BOS>Lumbar puncture : A procedure used to collect cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) from the spinal column.<EOS>
<BOS>This is done by placing a needle between two bones in the spine and into the CSF around the spinal cord and removing a sample of the fluid.<EOS>
<BOS>The sample of CSF is checked under a microscope for signs of tumor cells.<EOS>
<BOS>The sample may also be checked for the amounts of protein and glucose.<EOS>
<BOS>A higher than normal amount of protein or lower than normal amount of glucose may be a sign of a tumor.<EOS>
<BOS>This procedure is also called an LP or spinal tap.<EOS>
<BOS>A biopsy may be done to be sure of the diagnosis of CNS embryonal tumor or pineoblastoma.<EOS>
<BOS>If doctors think your child may have a CNS embryonal tumor or pineoblastoma, a biopsy may be done.<EOS>
<BOS>For brain tumors, the biopsy is done by removing part of the skull and using a needle to remove a sample of tissue.<EOS>
<BOS>Sometimes, a computerguided needle is used to remove the tissue sample.<EOS>
<BOS>A pathologist views the tissue under a microscope to look for cancer cells.<EOS>
<BOS>If cancer cells are found, the doctor may remove as much tumor as safely possible during the same surgery.<EOS>
<BOS>The piece of skull is usually put back in place after the procedure.<EOS>
<BOS>The following test may be done on the sample of tissue that is removed: Immunohistochemistry : A test that uses antibodies to check for certain antigens in a sample of tissue.<EOS>
<BOS>The antibody is usually linked to a radioactive substance or a dye that causes the tissue to light up under a microscope.<EOS>
<BOS>This type of test may be used to tell the difference between different types of brain tumors.<EOS>
<BOS>Signs of nonsmall cell lung cancer include a cough that doesn't go away and shortness of breath.<EOS>
<BOS>Sometimes lung cancer does not cause any signs or symptoms.<EOS>
<BOS>It may be found during a chest xray done for another condition.<EOS>
<BOS>Signs and symptoms may be caused by lung cancer or by other conditions.<EOS>
<BOS>Check with your doctor if you have any of the following: Chest discomfort or pain.<EOS>
<BOS>A cough that doesnt go away or gets worse over time.<EOS>
<BOS>Trouble breathing.<EOS>
<BOS>Wheezing.<EOS>
<BOS>Blood in sputum (mucus coughed up from the lungs).<EOS>
<BOS>Hoarseness.<EOS>
<BOS>Loss of appetite.<EOS>
<BOS>Weight loss for no known reason.<EOS>
<BOS>Feeling very tired.<EOS>
<BOS>Trouble swallowing.<EOS>
<BOS>Swelling in the face and/or veins in the neck.<EOS>
<BOS>Certain factors affect treatment options and prognosis (chance of recovery).<EOS>
<BOS>Treatment options depend on: The stage of the disease.<EOS>
<BOS>Red blood cell, white blood cell, and platelet blood counts.<EOS>
<BOS>Whether there are signs or symptoms, such as fever, chills, or weight loss.<EOS>
<BOS>Whether the liver, spleen, or lymph nodes are larger than normal.<EOS>
<BOS>The response to initial treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Whether the CLL has recurred (come back).<EOS>
<BOS>The prognosis (chance of recovery) depends on: Whether there is a change in the DNA and the type of change, if there is one.<EOS>
<BOS>Whether lymphocytes are spread throughout the bone marrow.<EOS>
<BOS>The stage of the disease.<EOS>
<BOS>Whether the CLL gets better with treatment or has recurred (come back).<EOS>
<BOS>Whether the CLL progresses to lymphoma or prolymphocytic leukemia.<EOS>
<BOS>The patient's general health.<EOS>
<BOS>Key Points There are different types of treatment for childhood acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL).<EOS>
<BOS>Children with ALL should have their treatment planned by a team of doctors who are experts in treating childhood leukemia.<EOS>
<BOS>Children and adolescents may have treatmentrelated side effects that appear months or years after treatment for acute lymphoblastic leukemia.<EOS>
<BOS>The treatment of childhood ALL usually has three phases.<EOS>
<BOS>Four types of standard treatment are used: Chemotherapy Radiation therapy Chemotherapy with stem cell transplant Targeted therapy Treatment is given to kill leukemia cells that have spread or may spread to the brain, spinal cord, or testicles.<EOS>
<BOS>New types of treatment are being tested in clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>Chimeric antigen receptor (CAR) Tcell therapy Patients may want to think about taking part in a clinical trial.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients can enter clinical trials before, during, or after starting their cancer treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Followup tests may be needed.<EOS>
<BOS>There are different types of treatment for childhood acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL).<EOS>
<BOS>Different types of treatment are available for children with acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL).<EOS>
<BOS>Some treatments are standard (the currently used treatment), and some are being tested in clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>A treatment clinical trial is a research study meant to help improve current treatments or obtain information on new treatments for patients with cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>When clinical trials show that a new treatment is better than the standard treatment, the new treatment may become the standard treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Because cancer in children is rare, taking part in a clinical trial should be considered.<EOS>
<BOS>Some clinical trials are open only to patients who have not started treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Children with ALL should have their treatment planned by a team of doctors who are experts in treating childhood leukemia.<EOS>
<BOS>Treatment will be overseen by a pediatric oncologist, a doctor who specializes in treating children with cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>The pediatric oncologist works with other pediatric health professionals who are experts in treating children with leukemia and who specialize in certain areas of medicine.<EOS>
<BOS>These may include the following specialists: Pediatrician.<EOS>
<BOS>Hematologist.<EOS>
<BOS>Medical oncologist.<EOS>
<BOS>Pediatric surgeon.<EOS>
<BOS>Radiation oncologist.<EOS>
<BOS>Neurologist.<EOS>
<BOS>Pathologist.<EOS>
<BOS>Radiologist.<EOS>
<BOS>Pediatric nurse specialist.<EOS>
<BOS>Social worker.<EOS>
<BOS>Rehabilitation specialist.<EOS>
<BOS>Psychologist.<EOS>
<BOS>Childlife specialist.<EOS>
<BOS>Children and adolescents may have treatmentrelated side effects that appear months or years after treatment for acute lymphoblastic leukemia.<EOS>
<BOS>Regular followup exams are very important.<EOS>
<BOS>Treatment can cause side effects long after it has ended.<EOS>
<BOS>These are called late effects.<EOS>
<BOS>Late effects of cancer treatment may include: Physical problems, including problems with the heart, blood vessels, liver, or bones, and fertility.<EOS>
<BOS>When dexrazoxane is given with chemotherapy drugs called anthracyclines, the risk of late heart effects is lessened.<EOS>
<BOS>Changes in mood, feelings, thinking, learning, or memory.<EOS>
<BOS>Children younger than 4 years who have received radiation therapy to the brain have a higher risk of these effects.<EOS>
<BOS>Second cancers (new types of cancer) or other conditions, such as brain tumors, thyroid cancer, acute myeloid leukemia, and myelodysplastic syndrome.<EOS>
<BOS>Some late effects may be treated or controlled.<EOS>
<BOS>It is important to talk with your child's doctors about the possible late effects caused by some treatments.<EOS>
<BOS>See the PDQ summary on Late Effects of Treatment for Childhood Cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>The treatment of childhood ALL usually has three phases.<EOS>
<BOS>The treatment of childhood ALL is done in phases: Remission induction: This is the first phase of treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>The goal is to kill the leukemia cells in the blood and bone marrow.<EOS>
<BOS>This puts the leukemia into remission.<EOS>
<BOS>Consolidation /intensification: This is the second phase of treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>It begins once the leukemia is in remission.<EOS>
<BOS>The goal of consolidation/intensification therapy is to kill any leukemia cells that remain in the body and may cause a relapse.<EOS>
<BOS>Maintenance: This is the third phase of treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>The goal is to kill any remaining leukemia cells that may regrow and cause a relapse.<EOS>
<BOS>Often the cancer treatments are given in lower doses than those used during the remission induction and consolidation/intensification phases.<EOS>
<BOS>Not taking medication as ordered by the doctor during maintenance therapy increases the chance the cancer will come back.<EOS>
<BOS>This is also called the continuation therapy phase.<EOS>
<BOS>Four types of standard treatment are used: Chemotherapy Chemotherapy is a cancer treatment that uses drugs to stop the growth of cancer cells, either by killing the cells or by stopping them from dividing.<EOS>
<BOS>When chemotherapy is taken by mouth or injected into a vein or muscle, the drugs enter the bloodstream and can reach cancer cells throughout the body (systemic chemotherapy).<EOS>
<BOS>When chemotherapy is placed directly into the cerebrospinal fluid (intrathecal), an organ, or a body cavity such as the abdomen, the drugs mainly affect cancer cells in those areas (regional chemotherapy).<EOS>
<BOS>Combination chemotherapy is treatment using more than one anticancer drug.<EOS>
<BOS>The way the chemotherapy is given depends on the child's risk group.<EOS>
<BOS>Children with highrisk ALL receive more anticancer drugs and higher doses of anticancer drugs than children with standardrisk ALL.<EOS>
<BOS>Intrathecal chemotherapy may be used to treat childhood ALL that has spread, or may spread, to the brain and spinal cord.<EOS>
<BOS>See Drugs Approved for Acute Lymphoblastic Leukemia for more information.<EOS>
<BOS>Radiation therapy Radiation therapy is a cancer treatment that uses highenergy xrays or other types of radiation to kill cancer cells or keep them from growing.<EOS>
<BOS>There are two types of radiation therapy: External radiation therapy uses a machine outside the body to send radiation toward the cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Internal radiation therapy uses a radioactive substance sealed in needles, seeds, wires, or catheters that are placed directly into or near the cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>The way the radiation therapy is given depends on the type of cancer being treated.<EOS>
<BOS>External radiation therapy may be used to treat childhood ALL that has spread, or may spread, to the brain, spinal cord, or testicles.<EOS>
<BOS>It may also be used to prepare the bone marrow for a stem cell transplant.<EOS>
<BOS>Chemotherapy with stem cell transplant Stem cell transplant is a method of giving high doses of chemotherapy and sometimes totalbody irradiation, and then replacing the bloodforming cells destroyed by the cancer treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Stem cells (immature blood cells) are removed from the blood or bone marrow of a donor.<EOS>
<BOS>After the patient receives treatment, the donor's stem cells are given to the patient through an infusion.<EOS>
<BOS>These reinfused stem cells grow into (and restore) the patient's blood cells.<EOS>
<BOS>The stem cell donor doesn't have to be related to the patient.<EOS>
<BOS>Stem cell transplant is rarely used as initial treatment for children and adolescents with ALL.<EOS>
<BOS>It is used more often as part of treatment for ALL that relapses (comes back after treatment).<EOS>
<BOS>See Drugs Approved for Acute Lymphoblastic Leukemia for more information.<EOS>
<BOS>Targeted therapy Targeted therapy is a treatment that uses drugs or other substances to identify and attack specific cancer cells without harming normal cells.<EOS>
<BOS>Tyrosine kinase inhibitors (TKIs) are targeted therapy drugs that block the enzyme, tyrosine kinase, which causes stem cells to become more white blood cells or blasts than the body needs.<EOS>
<BOS>Imatinib mesylate is a TKI used in the treatment of children with Philadelphia chromosome positive ALL.<EOS>
<BOS>Dasatinib and ruxolitinib are TKIs that are being studied in the treatment of newly diagnosed highrisk ALL.<EOS>
<BOS>Monoclonal antibody therapy is a cancer treatment that uses antibodies made in the laboratory, from a single type of immune system cell.<EOS>
<BOS>These antibodies can identify substances on cancer cells or normal substances that may help cancer cells grow.<EOS>
<BOS>The antibodies attach to the substances and kill the cancer cells, block their growth, or keep them from spreading.<EOS>
<BOS>Monoclonal antibodies are given by infusion.<EOS>
<BOS>They may be used alone or to carry drugs, toxins, or radioactive material directly to cancer cells.<EOS>
<BOS>Blinatumomab and inotuzumab are monoclonal antibodies being studied in the treatment of refractory childhood ALL.<EOS>
<BOS>New kinds of targeted therapies are also being studied in the treatment of childhood ALL.<EOS>
<BOS>See Drugs Approved for Acute Lymphoblastic Leukemia for more information.<EOS>
<BOS>Treatment is given to kill leukemia cells that have spread or may spread to the brain, spinal cord, or testicles.<EOS>
<BOS>Treatment to kill leukemia cells or prevent the spread of leukemia cells to the brain and spinal cord (central nervous system; CNS) is called CNSdirected therapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Chemotherapy may be used to treat leukemia cells that have spread, or may spread, to the brain and spinal cord.<EOS>
<BOS>Because standard doses of chemotherapy may not reach leukemia cells in the CNS, the cells are able to hide in the CNS.<EOS>
<BOS>Systemic chemotherapy given in high doses or intrathecal chemotherapy (into the cerebrospinal fluid) is able to reach leukemia cells in the CNS.<EOS>
<BOS>Sometimes external radiation therapy to the brain is also given.<EOS>
<BOS>These treatments are given in addition to treatment that is used to kill leukemia cells in the rest of the body.<EOS>
<BOS>All children with ALL receive CNSdirected therapy as part of induction therapy and consolidation/intensification therapy and sometimes during maintenance therapy.<EOS>
<BOS>If the leukemia cells spread to the testicles, treatment includes high doses of systemic chemotherapy and sometimes radiation therapy.<EOS>
<BOS>New types of treatment are being tested in clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>This summary section describes treatments that are being studied in clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>It may not mention every new treatment being studied.<EOS>
<BOS>Information about clinical trials is available from the NCI website.<EOS>
<BOS>Chimeric antigen receptor (CAR) Tcell therapy CAR Tcell therapy is a type of immunotherapy that changes the patient's T cells (a type of immune system cell) so they will attack certain proteins on the surface of cancer cells.<EOS>
<BOS>T cells are taken from the patient and special receptors are added to their surface in the laboratory.<EOS>
<BOS>The changed cells are called chimeric antigen receptor (CAR) T cells.<EOS>
<BOS>The CAR T cells are grown in the laboratory and given to the patient by infusion.<EOS>
<BOS>The CAR T cells multiply in the patient's blood and attack cancer cells.<EOS>
<BOS>CAR Tcell therapy is being studied in the treatment of childhood ALL that has relapsed (come back) a second time.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients may want to think about taking part in a clinical trial.<EOS>
<BOS>For some patients, taking part in a clinical trial may be the best treatment choice.<EOS>
<BOS>Clinical trials are part of the cancer research process.<EOS>
<BOS>Clinical trials are done to find out if new cancer treatments are safe and effective or better than the standard treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Many of today's standard treatments for cancer are based on earlier clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients who take part in a clinical trial may receive the standard treatment or be among the first to receive a new treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients who take part in clinical trials also help improve the way cancer will be treated in the future.<EOS>
<BOS>Even when clinical trials do not lead to effective new treatments, they often answer important questions and help move research forward.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients can enter clinical trials before, during, or after starting their cancer treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Some clinical trials only include patients who have not yet received treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Other trials test treatments for patients whose cancer has not gotten better.<EOS>
<BOS>There are also clinical trials that test new ways to stop cancer from recurring (coming back) or reduce the side effects of cancer treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Clinical trials are taking place in many parts of the country.<EOS>
<BOS>See the Treatment Options section that follows for links to current treatment clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>These have been retrieved from NCI's listing of clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>Followup tests may be needed.<EOS>
<BOS>Some of the tests that were done to diagnose the cancer or to find out the stage of the cancer may be repeated.<EOS>
<BOS>Some tests will be repeated in order to see how well the treatment is working.<EOS>
<BOS>Decisions about whether to continue, change, or stop treatment may be based on the results of these tests.<EOS>
<BOS>Some of the tests will continue to be done from time to time after treatment has ended.<EOS>
<BOS>The results of these tests can show if your child's condition has changed or if the cancer has recurred (come back).<EOS>
<BOS>These tests are sometimes called followup tests or checkups.<EOS>
<BOS>Bone marrow aspiration and biopsy is done during all phases of treatment to see how well the treatment is working.<EOS>
<BOS>Treatment Options for Childhood Acute Lymphoblastic Leukemia Newly Diagnosed Childhood Acute Lymphoblastic Leukemia (Standard Risk) The treatment of standardrisk childhood acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL) during the remission induction, consolidation /intensification, and maintenance phases always includes combination chemotherapy.<EOS>
<BOS>When children are in remission after remission induction therapy, a stem cell transplant using stem cells from a donor may be done.<EOS>
<BOS>When children are not in remission after remission induction therapy, further treatment is usually the same treatment given to children with highrisk ALL.<EOS>
<BOS>Intrathecal chemotherapy is given to prevent the spread of leukemia cells to the brain and spinal cord.<EOS>
<BOS>Treatments being studied in clinical trials for standardrisk ALL include new chemotherapy regimens.<EOS>
<BOS>Check the list of NCIsupported cancer clinical trials that are now accepting patients with untreated childhood acute lymphoblastic leukemia.<EOS>
<BOS>For more specific results, refine the search by using other search features, such as the location of the trial, the type of treatment, or the name of the drug.<EOS>
<BOS>Talk with your child's doctor about clinical trials that may be right for your child.<EOS>
<BOS>General information about clinical trials is available from the NCI website.<EOS>
<BOS>Newly Diagnosed Childhood Acute Lymphoblastic Leukemia (High Risk) The treatment of highrisk childhood acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL) during the remission induction, consolidation /intensification, and maintenance phases always includes combination chemotherapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Children in the highrisk ALL group are given more anticancer drugs and higher doses of anticancer drugs, especially during the consolidation/intensification phase, than children in the standardrisk group.<EOS>
<BOS>Intrathecal and systemic chemotherapy are given to prevent or treat the spread of leukemia cells to the brain and spinal cord.<EOS>
<BOS>Sometimes radiation therapy to the brain is also given.<EOS>
<BOS>Treatments being studied in clinical trials for highrisk ALL include new chemotherapy regimens with or without targeted therapy or stem cell transplant.<EOS>
<BOS>Check the list of NCIsupported cancer clinical trials that are now accepting patients with untreated childhood acute lymphoblastic leukemia.<EOS>
<BOS>For more specific results, refine the search by using other search features, such as the location of the trial, the type of treatment, or the name of the drug.<EOS>
<BOS>Talk with your child's doctor about clinical trials that may be right for your child.<EOS>
<BOS>General information about clinical trials is available from the NCI website.<EOS>
<BOS>Newly Diagnosed Childhood Acute Lymphoblastic Leukemia (Very High Risk) The treatment of very highrisk childhood acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL) during the remission induction, consolidation /intensification, and maintenance phases always includes combination chemotherapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Children in the very highrisk ALL group are given more anticancer drugs than children in the highrisk group.<EOS>
<BOS>It is not clear whether a stem cell transplant during first remission will help the child live longer.<EOS>
<BOS>Intrathecal and systemic chemotherapy are given to prevent or treat the spread of leukemia cells to the brain and spinal cord.<EOS>
<BOS>Sometimes radiation therapy to the brain is also given.<EOS>
<BOS>Treatments being studied in clinical trials for very highrisk ALL include new chemotherapy regimens with or without targeted therapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Check the list of NCIsupported cancer clinical trials that are now accepting patients with untreated childhood acute lymphoblastic leukemia.<EOS>
<BOS>For more specific results, refine the search by using other search features, such as the location of the trial, the type of treatment, or the name of the drug.<EOS>
<BOS>Talk with your child's doctor about clinical trials that may be right for your child.<EOS>
<BOS>General information about clinical trials is available from the NCI website.<EOS>
<BOS>Newly Diagnosed Childhood Acute Lymphoblastic Leukemia (Special Groups) Tcell childhood acute lymphoblastic leukemia The treatment of Tcell childhood acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL) during the remission induction, consolidation /intensification, and maintenance phases always includes combination chemotherapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Children with Tcell ALL are given more anticancer drugs and higher doses of anticancer drugs than children in the newly diagnosed standardrisk group.<EOS>
<BOS>Intrathecal and systemic chemotherapy are given to prevent the spread of leukemia cells to the brain and spinal cord.<EOS>
<BOS>Sometimes radiation therapy to the brain is also given.<EOS>
<BOS>Treatments being studied in clinical trials for Tcell ALL include new anticancer agents and chemotherapy regimens with or without targeted therapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Infants with ALL The treatment of infants with ALL during the remission induction, consolidation /intensification, and maintenance phases always includes combination chemotherapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Infants with ALL are given different anticancer drugs and higher doses of anticancer drugs than children 1 year and older in the standardrisk group.<EOS>
<BOS>It is not clear whether a stem cell transplant during first remission will help the child live longer.<EOS>
<BOS>Intrathecal and systemic chemotherapy are given to prevent the spread of leukemia cells to the brain and spinal cord.<EOS>
<BOS>Treatments being studied in clinical trials for infants with ALL include the following: A clinical trial of chemotherapy followed by a donor stem cell transplant for infants with certain gene changes.<EOS>
<BOS>Children 10 years and older and adolescents with ALL The treatment of ALL in children and adolescents (10 years and older) during the remission induction, consolidation /intensification, and maintenance phases always includes combination chemotherapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Children 10 years and older and adolescents with ALL are given more anticancer drugs and higher doses of anticancer drugs than children in the standardrisk group.<EOS>
<BOS>Intrathecal and systemic chemotherapy are given to prevent the spread of leukemia cells to the brain and spinal cord.<EOS>
<BOS>Sometimes radiation therapy to the brain is also given.<EOS>
<BOS>Treatments being studied in clinical trials for children 10 years and older and adolescents with ALL include new anticancer agents and chemotherapy regimens with or without targeted therapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Philadelphia chromosomepositive ALL The treatment of Philadelphia chromosome positive childhood ALL during the remission induction, consolidation /intensification, and maintenance phases may include the following: Combination chemotherapy and targeted therapy with a tyrosine kinase inhibitor (imatinib mesylate) with or without a stem cell transplant using stem cells from a donor.<EOS>
<BOS>Check the list of NCIsupported cancer clinical trials that are now accepting patients with Tcell childhood acute lymphoblastic leukemia and Philadelphia chromosome positive childhood precursor acute lymphoblastic leukemia.<EOS>
<BOS>For more specific results, refine the search by using other search features, such as the location of the trial, the type of treatment, or the name of the drug.<EOS>
<BOS>Talk with your child's doctor about clinical trials that may be right for your child.<EOS>
<BOS>General information about clinical trials is available from the NCI website.<EOS>
<BOS>Refractory Childhood Acute Lymphoblastic Leukemia There is no standard treatment for the treatment of refractory childhood acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL).<EOS>
<BOS>Some of the treatments being studied in clinical trials for refractory childhood ALL include: Targeted therapy (blinatumomab or inotuzumab).<EOS>
<BOS>Chimeric antigen receptor (CAR) Tcell therapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Relapsed Childhood Acute Lymphoblastic Leukemia Standard treatment of relapsed childhood acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL) that comes back in the bone marrow may include the following: Combination chemotherapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Chemotherapy with or without totalbody irradiation followed by a stem cell transplant, using stem cells from a donor.<EOS>
<BOS>Standard treatment of relapsed childhood acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL) that comes back outside the bone marrow may include the following: Systemic chemotherapy and intrathecal chemotherapy with radiation therapy to the brain and/or spinal cord for cancer that comes back in the brain and spinal cord only.<EOS>
<BOS>Combination chemotherapy and radiation therapy for cancer that comes back in the testicles only.<EOS>
<BOS>Stem cell transplant for cancer that has recurred in the brain and/or spinal cord.<EOS>
<BOS>Some of the treatments being studied in clinical trials for relapsed childhood ALL include: New anticancer drugs and new combination chemotherapy treatments.<EOS>
<BOS>Combination chemotherapy and new kinds of targeted therapies (blinatumomab or inotuzumab).<EOS>
<BOS>Chimeric antigen receptor (CAR) Tcell therapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Check the list of NCIsupported cancer clinical trials that are now accepting patients with recurrent childhood acute lymphoblastic leukemia.<EOS>
<BOS>For more specific results, refine the search by using other search features, such as the location of the trial, the type of treatment, or the name of the drug.<EOS>
<BOS>Talk with your child's doctor about clinical trials that may be right for your child.<EOS>
<BOS>General information about clinical trials is available from the NCI website.<EOS>
<BOS>Age and a previous molar pregnancy affect the risk of GTD.<EOS>
<BOS>Anything that increases your risk of getting a disease is called a risk factor.<EOS>
<BOS>Having a risk factor does not mean that you will get cancer; not having risk factors doesn't mean that you will not get cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Talk to your doctor if you think you may be at risk.<EOS>
<BOS>Risk factors for GTD include the following: Being pregnant when you are younger than 20 or older than 35 years of age.<EOS>
<BOS>Having a personal history of hydatidiform mole.<EOS>
<BOS>New types of treatment are being tested in clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>Information about clinical trials is available from the NCI website.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients may want to think about taking part in a clinical trial.<EOS>
<BOS>For some patients, taking part in a clinical trial may be the best treatment choice.<EOS>
<BOS>Clinical trials are part of the cancer research process.<EOS>
<BOS>Clinical trials are done to find out if new cancer treatments are safe and effective or better than the standard treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Many of today's standard treatments for cancer are based on earlier clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients who take part in a clinical trial may receive the standard treatment or be among the first to receive a new treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients who take part in clinical trials also help improve the way cancer will be treated in the future.<EOS>
<BOS>Even when clinical trials do not lead to effective new treatments, they often answer important questions and help move research forward.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients can enter clinical trials before, during, or after starting their cancer treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Some clinical trials only include patients who have not yet received treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Other trials test treatments for patients whose cancer has not gotten better.<EOS>
<BOS>There are also clinical trials that test new ways to stop cancer from recurring (coming back) or reduce the side effects of cancer treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Clinical trials are taking place in many parts of the country.<EOS>
<BOS>See the Treatment Options section that follows for links to current treatment clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>These have been retrieved from NCI's listing of clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>Key Points After childhood soft tissue sarcoma has been diagnosed, tests are done to find out if cancer cells have spread to other parts of the body.<EOS>
<BOS>There are three ways that cancer spreads in the body.<EOS>
<BOS>Cancer may spread from where it began to other parts of the body.<EOS>
<BOS>After childhood soft tissue sarcoma has been diagnosed, tests are done to find out if cancer cells have spread to other parts of the body.<EOS>
<BOS>The process used to find out if cancer has spread within the soft tissue or to other parts of the body is called staging.<EOS>
<BOS>There is no standard staging system for childhood soft tissue sarcoma.<EOS>
<BOS>In order to plan treatment, it is important to know the type of soft tissue sarcoma, whether the tumor can be removed by surgery, and whether cancer has spread to other parts of the body.<EOS>
<BOS>The following procedures may be used to find out if cancer has spread: Sentinel lymph node biopsy: A sentinel lymph node biopsy is done to check if cancer has spread to the lymph nodes.<EOS>
<BOS>The sentinel lymph node is the first lymph node to receive lymphatic drainage from a tumor.<EOS>
<BOS>It is the first lymph node the cancer is likely to spread to from the tumor.<EOS>
<BOS>A small amount of a radioactive substance and/or blue dye is injected near the tumor.<EOS>
<BOS>The radioactive substance or dye flows through the lymph ducts to the lymph nodes.<EOS>
<BOS>The first lymph node to receive the substance or dye is removed.<EOS>
<BOS>A pathologist views the tissue under a microscope to look for cancer cells.<EOS>
<BOS>If cancer cells are not found, it may not be necessary to remove more lymph nodes.<EOS>
<BOS>This procedure is used for epithelioid and clear cell sarcoma.<EOS>
<BOS>PET scan: A PET scan is a procedure to find malignant tumor cells in the body.<EOS>
<BOS>A small amount of radioactive glucose (sugar) is injected into a vein.<EOS>
<BOS>The PET scanner rotates around the body and makes a picture of where glucose is being used in the body.<EOS>
<BOS>Malignant tumor cells show up brighter in the picture because they are more active and take up more glucose than normal cells do.<EOS>
<BOS>This procedure is also called positron emission tomography (PET) scan.<EOS>
<BOS>PETCT scan: A procedure that combines the pictures from a PET scan and a computed tomography (CT) scan.<EOS>
<BOS>The PET and CT scans are done at the same time on the same machine.<EOS>
<BOS>The pictures from both scans are combined to make a more detailed picture than either test would make by itself.<EOS>
<BOS>There are three ways that cancer spreads in the body.<EOS>
<BOS>Cancer can spread through tissue, the lymph system, and the blood: Tissue.<EOS>
<BOS>The cancer spreads from where it began by growing into nearby areas.<EOS>
<BOS>Lymph system.<EOS>
<BOS>The cancer spreads from where it began by getting into the lymph system.<EOS>
<BOS>The cancer travels through the lymph vessels to other parts of the body.<EOS>
<BOS>Blood.<EOS>
<BOS>The cancer spreads from where it began by getting into the blood.<EOS>
<BOS>The cancer travels through the blood vessels to other parts of the body.<EOS>
<BOS>Cancer may spread from where it began to other parts of the body.<EOS>
<BOS>When cancer spreads to another part of the body, it is called metastasis.<EOS>
<BOS>Cancer cells break away from where they began (the primary tumor) and travel through the lymph system or blood.<EOS>
<BOS>Lymph system.<EOS>
<BOS>The cancer gets into the lymph system, travels through the lymph vessels, and forms a tumor (metastatic tumor) in another part of the body.<EOS>
<BOS>Blood.<EOS>
<BOS>The cancer gets into the blood, travels through the blood vessels, and forms a tumor (metastatic tumor) in another part of the body.<EOS>
<BOS>The metastatic tumor is the same type of cancer as the primary tumor.<EOS>
<BOS>For example, if soft tissue sarcoma spreads to the lung, the cancer cells in the lung are soft tissue sarcoma cells.<EOS>
<BOS>The disease is metastatic soft tissue sarcoma, not lung cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>New types of treatment are being tested in clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>Information about clinical trials is available from the NCI website.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients may want to think about taking part in a clinical trial.<EOS>
<BOS>For some patients, taking part in a clinical trial may be the best treatment choice.<EOS>
<BOS>Clinical trials are part of the cancer research process.<EOS>
<BOS>Clinical trials are done to find out if new cancer treatments are safe and effective or better than the standard treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Many of today's standard treatments for cancer are based on earlier clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients who take part in a clinical trial may receive the standard treatment or be among the first to receive a new treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients who take part in clinical trials also help improve the way cancer will be treated in the future.<EOS>
<BOS>Even when clinical trials do not lead to effective new treatments, they often answer important questions and help move research forward.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients can enter clinical trials before, during, or after starting their cancer treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Some clinical trials only include patients who have not yet received treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Other trials test treatments for patients whose cancer has not gotten better.<EOS>
<BOS>There are also clinical trials that test new ways to stop cancer from recurring (coming back) or reduce the side effects of cancer treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Clinical trials are taking place in many parts of the country.<EOS>
<BOS>See the Treatment Options section that follows for links to current treatment clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>These have been retrieved from NCI's listing of clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>New types of treatment are being tested in clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>Information about clinical trials is available from the NCI website.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients may want to think about taking part in a clinical trial.<EOS>
<BOS>For some patients, taking part in a clinical trial may be the best treatment choice.<EOS>
<BOS>Clinical trials are part of the research process.<EOS>
<BOS>Clinical trials are done to find out if new treatments are safe and effective or better than the standard treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Many of today's standard treatments are based on earlier clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients who take part in a clinical trial may receive the standard treatment or be among the first to receive a new treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients who take part in clinical trials also help improve the way disease will be treated in the future.<EOS>
<BOS>Even when clinical trials do not lead to effective new treatments, they often answer important questions and help move research forward.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients can enter clinical trials before, during, or after starting their cancer treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Some clinical trials only include patients who have not yet received treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Other trials test treatments for patients whose tumors have not gotten better.<EOS>
<BOS>There are also clinical trials that test new ways to stop tumors from recurring (coming back) or reduce the side effects of treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Clinical trials are taking place in many parts of the country.<EOS>
<BOS>See the Treatment Options section that follows for links to current treatment clinical trials.<EOS>
