<BOS>Key Points There are different types of treatment for patients with mycosis fungoides and the Szary syndrome cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Six types of standard treatment are used: Photodynamic therapy Radiation therapy Chemotherapy Other drug therapy Biologic therapy Targeted therapy New types of treatment are being tested in clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>Highdose chemotherapy and radiation therapy with stem cell transplant Treatment for mycosis fungoides and the Szary syndrome may cause side effects.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients may want to think about taking part in a clinical trial.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients can enter clinical trials before, during, or after starting their cancer treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Followup tests may be needed.<EOS>
<BOS>There are different types of treatment for patients with mycosis fungoides and the Szary syndrome cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Different types of treatment are available for patients with mycosis fungoides and the Szary syndrome.<EOS>
<BOS>Some treatments are standard (the currently used treatment), and some are being tested in clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>A treatment clinical trial is a research study meant to help improve current treatments or obtain information on new treatments for patients with cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>When clinical trials show that a new treatment is better than the standard treatment, the new treatment may become the standard treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients may want to think about taking part in a clinical trial.<EOS>
<BOS>Some clinical trials are open only to patients who have not started treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Six types of standard treatment are used: Photodynamic therapy Photodynamic therapy is a cancer treatment that uses a drug and a certain type of laser light to kill cancer cells.<EOS>
<BOS>A drug that is not active until it is exposed to light is injected into a vein.<EOS>
<BOS>The drug collects more in cancer cells than in normal cells.<EOS>
<BOS>For skin cancer, laser light is shined onto the skin and the drug becomes active and kills the cancer cells.<EOS>
<BOS>Photodynamic therapy causes little damage to healthy tissue.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients undergoing photodynamic therapy will need to limit the amount of time spent in sunlight.<EOS>
<BOS>In one type of photodynamic therapy, called psoralen and ultraviolet A (PUVA) therapy, the patient receives a drug called psoralen and then ultraviolet radiation is directed to the skin.<EOS>
<BOS>In another type of photodynamic therapy, called extracorporeal photochemotherapy, the patient is given drugs and then some blood cells are taken from the body, put under a special ultraviolet A light, and put back into the body.<EOS>
<BOS>Radiation therapy Radiation therapy is a cancer treatment that uses highenergy xrays or other types of radiation to kill cancer cells or keep them from growing.<EOS>
<BOS>There are two types of radiation therapy: External radiation therapy uses a machine outside the body to send radiation toward the cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Internal radiation therapy uses a radioactive substance sealed in needles, seeds, wires, or catheters that are placed directly into or near the cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>The way the radiation therapy is given depends on the type and stage of the cancer being treated.<EOS>
<BOS>External radiation therapy is used to treat mycosis fungoides and the Szary syndrome, and may also be used as palliative therapy to relieve symptoms and improve quality of life.<EOS>
<BOS>Sometimes, total skin electron beam (TSEB) radiation therapy is used to treat mycosis fungoides and the Szary syndrome.<EOS>
<BOS>This is a type of external radiation treatment in which a radiation therapy machine aims electrons (tiny, invisible particles) at the skin covering the whole body.<EOS>
<BOS>Ultraviolet B (UVB) radiation therapy uses a special lamp or laser that directs UVB radiation at the skin.<EOS>
<BOS>Chemotherapy Chemotherapy is a cancer treatment that uses drugs to stop the growth of cancer cells, either by killing the cells or by stopping them from dividing.<EOS>
<BOS>When chemotherapy is taken by mouth or injected into a vein or muscle, the drugs enter the bloodstream and can reach cancer cells throughout the body (systemic chemotherapy).<EOS>
<BOS>When chemotherapy is placed directly into the cerebrospinal fluid, an organ, or a body cavity such as the abdomen, the drugs mainly affect cancer cells in those areas (regional chemotherapy).<EOS>
<BOS>Sometimes the chemotherapy is topical (put on the skin in a cream, lotion, or ointment).<EOS>
<BOS>The way the chemotherapy is given depends on the type and stage of the cancer being treated.<EOS>
<BOS>See Drugs Approved for NonHodgkin Lymphoma for more information.<EOS>
<BOS>(Mycosis fungoides and the Szary syndrome are types of nonHodgkin lymphoma.<EOS>
<BOS>) Other drug therapy Topical corticosteroids are used to relieve red, swollen, and inflamed skin.<EOS>
<BOS>They are a type of steroid.<EOS>
<BOS>Topical corticosteroids may be in a cream, lotion, or ointment.<EOS>
<BOS>Retinoids, such as bexarotene, are drugs related to vitamin A that can slow the growth of certain types of cancer cells.<EOS>
<BOS>The retinoids may be taken by mouth or put on the skin.<EOS>
<BOS>See Drugs Approved for NonHodgkin Lymphoma for more information.<EOS>
<BOS>(Mycosis fungoides and the Szary syndrome are types of nonHodgkin lymphoma.<EOS>
<BOS>) Biologic therapy Biologic therapy is a treatment that uses the patient's immune system to fight cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Substances made by the body or made in a laboratory are used to boost, direct, or restore the body's natural defenses against cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>This type of cancer treatment is also called biotherapy or immunotherapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Interferon is a type of biologic therapy used to treat mycosis fungoides and the Szary syndrome.<EOS>
<BOS>It interferes with the division of cancer cells and can slow tumor growth.<EOS>
<BOS>See Drugs Approved for NonHodgkin Lymphoma for more information.<EOS>
<BOS>(Mycosis fungoides and the Szary syndrome are types of nonHodgkin lymphoma.<EOS>
<BOS>) Targeted therapy Targeted therapy is a treatment that uses drugs or other substances to identify and attack specific cancer cells without harming normal cells.<EOS>
<BOS>Monoclonal antibody therapy and other types of targeted therapies are used to treat mycosis fungoides and the Szary syndrome.<EOS>
<BOS>Alemtuzumab is a monoclonal antibody used to treat mycosis fungoides and the Szary syndrome.<EOS>
<BOS>Monoclonal antibody therapy uses antibodies made in the laboratory, from a single type of immune system cell.<EOS>
<BOS>These antibodies can identify substances on cancer cells or normal substances that may help cancer cells grow.<EOS>
<BOS>The antibodies attach to the substances and kill the cancer cells, block their growth, or keep them from spreading.<EOS>
<BOS>Monoclonal antibodies are given by infusion.<EOS>
<BOS>They may be used alone or to carry drugs, toxins, or radioactive material directly to cancer cells.<EOS>
<BOS>Other types of monoclonal antibody therapy are being studied in clinical trials to treat mycosis fungoides and the Szary syndrome.<EOS>
<BOS>Vorinostat and romidepsin are two of the histone deacetylase (HDAC) inhibitors used to treat mycosis fungoides and the Szary syndrome.<EOS>
<BOS>HDAC inhibitors cause a chemical change that stops tumor cells from dividing.<EOS>
<BOS>Pralatrexate is a dihydrofolate reductase (DHFR) inhibitor used to treat mycosis fungoides and the Szary syndrome.<EOS>
<BOS>It builds up in cancer cells and stops them from using folate, a nutrient needed for cells to divide.<EOS>
<BOS>Pralatrexate may slow the growth of tumors and kill cancer cells.<EOS>
<BOS>See Drugs Approved for NonHodgkin Lymphoma for more information.<EOS>
<BOS>(Mycosis fungoides and the Szary syndrome are types of nonHodgkin lymphoma.<EOS>
<BOS>) New types of treatment are being tested in clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>This summary section describes treatments that are being studied in clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>It may not mention every new treatment being studied.<EOS>
<BOS>Information about clinical trials is available from the NCI website.<EOS>
<BOS>Highdose chemotherapy and radiation therapy with stem cell transplant This treatment is a method of giving high doses of chemotherapy and radiation therapy and replacing bloodforming cells destroyed by the cancer treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Stem cells (immature blood cells) are removed from the bone marrow or blood of the patient or a donor and are frozen and stored.<EOS>
<BOS>After therapy is completed, the stored stem cells are thawed and given back to the patient through an infusion.<EOS>
<BOS>These reinfused stem cells grow into (and restore) the body's blood cells.<EOS>
<BOS>Treatment for mycosis fungoides and the Szary syndrome may cause side effects.<EOS>
<BOS>For information about side effects caused by treatment for cancer, see our Side Effects page.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients may want to think about taking part in a clinical trial.<EOS>
<BOS>For some patients, taking part in a clinical trial may be the best treatment choice.<EOS>
<BOS>Clinical trials are part of the cancer research process.<EOS>
<BOS>Clinical trials are done to find out if new cancer treatments are safe and effective or better than the standard treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Many of today's standard treatments for cancer are based on earlier clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients who take part in a clinical trial may receive the standard treatment or be among the first to receive a new treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients who take part in clinical trials also help improve the way cancer will be treated in the future.<EOS>
<BOS>Even when clinical trials do not lead to effective new treatments, they often answer important questions and help move research forward.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients can enter clinical trials before, during, or after starting their cancer treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Some clinical trials only include patients who have not yet received treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Other trials test treatments for patients whose cancer has not gotten better.<EOS>
<BOS>There are also clinical trials that test new ways to stop cancer from recurring (coming back) or reduce the side effects of cancer treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Clinical trials are taking place in many parts of the country.<EOS>
<BOS>See the Treatment Options section that follows for links to current treatment clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>These have been retrieved from NCI's listing of clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>Followup tests may be needed.<EOS>
<BOS>Some of the tests that were done to diagnose the cancer or to find out the stage of the cancer may be repeated.<EOS>
<BOS>Some tests will be repeated in order to see how well the treatment is working.<EOS>
<BOS>Decisions about whether to continue, change, or stop treatment may be based on the results of these tests.<EOS>
<BOS>Some of the tests will continue to be done from time to time after treatment has ended.<EOS>
<BOS>The results of these tests can show if your condition has changed or if the cancer has recurred (come back).<EOS>
<BOS>These tests are sometimes called followup tests or checkups.<EOS>
<BOS>Treatment Options by Stage Stage I Mycosis Fungoides Treatment of stage I mycosis fungoides may include the following: PUVA therapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Biologic therapy may also be given.<EOS>
<BOS>Radiation therapy.<EOS>
<BOS>In some cases, radiation therapy is given to skin lesions, as palliative therapy to reduce tumor size or relieve symptoms and improve quality of life.<EOS>
<BOS>Topical corticosteroid therapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Retinoid therapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Topical or systemic chemotherapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Biologic therapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Topical chemotherapy may also be given.<EOS>
<BOS>Targeted therapy.<EOS>
<BOS>A clinical trial of a new treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Check the list of NCIsupported cancer clinical trials that are now accepting patients with stage I mycosis fungoides/Sezary syndrome.<EOS>
<BOS>For more specific results, refine the search by using other search features, such as the location of the trial, the type of treatment, or the name of the drug.<EOS>
<BOS>Talk with your doctor about clinical trials that may be right for you.<EOS>
<BOS>General information about clinical trials is available from the NCI website.<EOS>
<BOS>Stage II Mycosis Fungoides Treatment of stage II mycosis fungoides is palliative (to relieve symptoms and improve the quality of life) and may include the following: PUVA therapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Biologic therapy may also be given.<EOS>
<BOS>Radiation therapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Topical corticosteroid therapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Retinoid therapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Topical or systemic chemotherapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Biologic therapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Topical chemotherapy may also be given.<EOS>
<BOS>Targeted therapy.<EOS>
<BOS>A clinical trial of a new treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Check the list of NCIsupported cancer clinical trials that are now accepting patients with stage II mycosis fungoides/Sezary syndrome.<EOS>
<BOS>For more specific results, refine the search by using other search features, such as the location of the trial, the type of treatment, or the name of the drug.<EOS>
<BOS>Talk with your doctor about clinical trials that may be right for you.<EOS>
<BOS>General information about clinical trials is available from the NCI website.<EOS>
<BOS>Stage III Mycosis Fungoides Treatment of stage III mycosis fungoides is palliative (to relieve symptoms and improve the quality of life) and may include the following: PUVA therapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Systemic chemotherapy or biologic therapy may also be given.<EOS>
<BOS>Extracorporeal photochemotherapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Radiation therapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Topical corticosteroid therapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Retinoid therapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Systemic chemotherapy with one or more drugs.<EOS>
<BOS>Topical chemotherapy or radiation therapy may also be given.<EOS>
<BOS>Topical chemotherapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Biologic therapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Topical chemotherapy may also be given.<EOS>
<BOS>Targeted therapy.<EOS>
<BOS>A clinical trial of a new treatment.<EOS>

<BOS>Talk with your doctor about clinical trials that may be right for you.<EOS>
<BOS>General information about clinical trials is available from the NCI website.<EOS>
<BOS>Stage IV Mycosis Fungoides and the Szary Syndrome Treatment of stage IV mycosis fungoides and stage IV Szary syndrome is palliative (to relieve symptoms and improve the quality of life) and may include the following: PUVA therapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Systemic chemotherapy or biologic therapy may also be given.<EOS>

<BOS>For more specific results, refine the search by using other search features, such as the location of the trial, the type of treatment, or the name of the drug.<EOS>
<BOS>Talk with your doctor about clinical trials that may be right for you.<EOS>
<BOS>General information about clinical trials is available from the NCI website.<EOS>
<BOS>Signs of rectal cancer include a change in bowel habits or blood in the stool.<EOS>
<BOS>These and other signs and symptoms may be caused by rectal cancer or by other conditions.<EOS>
<BOS>Check with your doctor if you have any of the following: Blood (either bright red or very dark) in the stool.<EOS>
<BOS>A change in bowel habits.<EOS>
<BOS>Diarrhea.<EOS>
<BOS>Constipation.<EOS>
<BOS>Feeling that the bowel does not empty completely.<EOS>
<BOS>Stools that are narrower or have a different shape than usual.<EOS>
<BOS>General abdominal discomfort (frequent gas pains, bloating, fullness, or cramps).<EOS>
<BOS>Change in appetite.<EOS>
<BOS>Weight loss for no known reason.<EOS>
<BOS>Feeling very tired.<EOS>
<BOS>Key Points There are different types of treatments for patients with intraocular melanoma.<EOS>
<BOS>Five types of standard treatment are used: Surgery Watchful Waiting Radiation therapy Photocoagulation Thermotherapy New types of treatment are being tested in clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>Treatment for intraocular (uveal) melanoma may cause side effects.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients may want to think about taking part in a clinical trial.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients can enter clinical trials before, during, or after starting their cancer treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Followup tests may be needed.<EOS>
<BOS>There are different types of treatments for patients with intraocular melanoma.<EOS>
<BOS>Different types of treatments are available for patients with intraocular melanoma.<EOS>
<BOS>Some treatments are standard (the currently used treatment), and some are being tested in clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>A treatment clinical trial is a research study meant to help improve current treatments or obtain information on new treatments for patients with cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>When clinical trials show that a new treatment is better than the standard treatment, the new treatment may become the standard treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients may want to think about taking part in a clinical trial.<EOS>
<BOS>Some clinical trials are open only to patients who have not started treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Five types of standard treatment are used: Surgery Surgery is the most common treatment for intraocular melanoma.<EOS>
<BOS>The following types of surgery may be used: Resection: Surgery to remove the tumor and a small amount of healthy tissue around it.<EOS>
<BOS>Enucleation: Surgery to remove the eye and part of the optic nerve.<EOS>
<BOS>This is done if vision cannot be saved and the tumor is large, has spread to the optic nerve, or causes high pressure inside the eye.<EOS>
<BOS>After surgery, the patient is usually fitted for an artificial eye to match the size and color of the other eye.<EOS>
<BOS>Exenteration: Surgery to remove the eye and eyelid, and muscles, nerves, and fat in the eye socket.<EOS>
<BOS>After surgery, the patient may be fitted for an artificial eye to match the size and color of the other eye or a facial prosthesis.<EOS>
<BOS>Watchful Waiting Watchful waiting is closely monitoring a patients condition without giving any treatment until signs or symptoms appear or change.<EOS>
<BOS>Pictures are taken over time to keep track of changes in the size of the tumor and how fast it is growing.<EOS>
<BOS>Watchful waiting is used for patients who do not have signs or symptoms and the tumor is not growing.<EOS>
<BOS>It is also used when the tumor is in the only eye with useful vision.<EOS>
<BOS>Radiation therapy Radiation therapy is a cancer treatment that uses highenergy xrays or other types of radiation to kill cancer cells or keep them from growing.<EOS>
<BOS>There are two types of radiation therapy: External radiation therapy uses a machine outside the body to send radiation toward the cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Certain ways of giving radiation therapy can help keep radiation from damaging nearby healthy tissue.<EOS>
<BOS>These types of external radiation therapy include the following: Chargedparticle external beam radiation therapy is a type of externalbeam radiation therapy.<EOS>
<BOS>A special radiation therapy machine aims tiny, invisible particles, called protons or helium ions, at the cancer cells to kill them with little damage to nearby normal tissues.<EOS>
<BOS>Chargedparticle radiation therapy uses a different type of radiation than the xray type of radiation therapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Gamma Knife therapy is a type of stereotactic radiosurgery used for some melanomas.<EOS>
<BOS>This treatment can be given in one treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>It aims tightly focused gamma rays directly at the tumor so there is little damage to healthy tissue.<EOS>
<BOS>Gamma Knife therapy does not use a knife to remove the tumor and is not an operation.<EOS>
<BOS>Internal radiation therapy uses a radioactive substance sealed in needles, seeds, wires, or catheters that are placed directly into or near the cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Certain ways of giving radiation therapy can help keep radiation from damaging healthy tissue.<EOS>
<BOS>This type of internal radiation therapy may include the following: Localized plaque radiation therapy is a type of internal radiation therapy that may be used for tumors of the eye.<EOS>
<BOS>Radioactive seeds are attached to one side of a disk, called a plaque, and placed directly on the outside wall of the eye near the tumor.<EOS>
<BOS>The side of the plaque with the seeds on it faces the eyeball, aiming radiation at the tumor.<EOS>
<BOS>The plaque helps protect other nearby tissue from the radiation.<EOS>
<BOS>The way the radiation therapy is given depends on the type and stage of the cancer being treated.<EOS>
<BOS>External and internal radiation therapy are used to treat intraocular melanoma.<EOS>
<BOS>Photocoagulation Photocoagulation is a procedure that uses laser light to destroy blood vessels that bring nutrients to the tumor, causing the tumor cells to die.<EOS>
<BOS>Photocoagulation may be used to treat small tumors.<EOS>
<BOS>This is also called light coagulation.<EOS>
<BOS>Thermotherapy Thermotherapy is the use of heat from a laser to destroy cancer cells and shrink the tumor.<EOS>
<BOS>New types of treatment are being tested in clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>Information about clinical trials is available from the NCI website.<EOS>
<BOS>Treatment for intraocular (uveal) melanoma may cause side effects.<EOS>
<BOS>For information about side effects caused by treatment for cancer, see our Side Effects page.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients may want to think about taking part in a clinical trial.<EOS>
<BOS>For some patients, taking part in a clinical trial may be the best treatment choice.<EOS>
<BOS>Clinical trials are part of the cancer research process.<EOS>
<BOS>Clinical trials are done to find out if new cancer treatments are safe and effective or better than the standard treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Many of today's standard treatments for cancer are based on earlier clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients who take part in a clinical trial may receive the standard treatment or be among the first to receive a new treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients who take part in clinical trials also help improve the way cancer will be treated in the future.<EOS>
<BOS>Even when clinical trials do not lead to effective new treatments, they often answer important questions and help move research forward.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients can enter clinical trials before, during, or after starting their cancer treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Some clinical trials only include patients who have not yet received treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Other trials test treatments for patients whose cancer has not gotten better.<EOS>
<BOS>There are also clinical trials that test new ways to stop cancer from recurring (coming back) or reduce the side effects of cancer treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Clinical trials are taking place in many parts of the country.<EOS>
<BOS>See the Treatment Options section that follows for links to current treatment clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>These have been retrieved from NCI's listing of clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>Followup tests may be needed.<EOS>
<BOS>Some of the tests that were done to diagnose the cancer or to find out the stage of the cancer may be repeated.<EOS>
<BOS>Some tests will be repeated in order to see how well the treatment is working.<EOS>
<BOS>Decisions about whether to continue, change, or stop treatment may be based on the results of these tests.<EOS>
<BOS>Some of the tests will continue to be done from time to time after treatment has ended.<EOS>
<BOS>The results of these tests can show if your condition has changed or if the cancer has recurred (come back).<EOS>
<BOS>These tests are sometimes called followup tests or checkups.<EOS>
<BOS>Treatment Options for Intraocular (Uveal) Melanoma Iris Melanoma Treatment of iris melanoma may include the following: Watchful waiting.<EOS>
<BOS>Surgery (resection or enucleation).<EOS>
<BOS>Plaque radiation therapy, for tumors that cannot be removed by surgery.<EOS>
<BOS>Check the list of NCIsupported cancer clinical trials that are now accepting patients with iris melanoma.<EOS>
<BOS>For more specific results, refine the search by using other search features, such as the location of the trial, the type of treatment, or the name of the drug.<EOS>
<BOS>Talk with your doctor about clinical trials that may be right for you.<EOS>
<BOS>General information about clinical trials is available from the NCI website.<EOS>
<BOS>Ciliary Body Melanoma Treatment of tumors in the ciliary body and choroid may include the following: Plaque radiation therapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Chargedparticle externalbeam radiation therapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Surgery (resection or enucleation).<EOS>
<BOS>Check the list of NCIsupported cancer clinical trials that are now accepting patients with ciliary body and choroid melanoma, small size.<EOS>
<BOS>For more specific results, refine the search by using other search features, such as the location of the trial, the type of treatment, or the name of the drug.<EOS>
<BOS>Talk with your doctor about clinical trials that may be right for you.<EOS>
<BOS>General information about clinical trials is available from the NCI website.<EOS>
<BOS>Choroid Melanoma Treatment of small choroid melanoma may include the following: Watchful waiting.<EOS>
<BOS>Plaque radiation therapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Chargedparticle externalbeam radiation therapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Gamma Knife therapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Thermotherapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Surgery (resection or enucleation).<EOS>
<BOS>Treatment of medium choroid melanoma may include the following: Plaque radiation therapy with or without photocoagulation or thermotherapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Chargedparticle externalbeam radiation therapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Surgery (resection or enucleation).<EOS>
<BOS>Treatment of large choroid melanoma may include the following: Enucleation when the tumor is too large for treatments that save the eye.<EOS>
<BOS>Check the list of NCIsupported cancer clinical trials that are now accepting patients with ciliary body and choroid melanoma, small size.<EOS>
<BOS>For more specific results, refine the search by using other search features, such as the location of the trial, the type of treatment, or the name of the drug.<EOS>
<BOS>Talk with your doctor about clinical trials that may be right for you.<EOS>
<BOS>General information about clinical trials is available from the NCI website.<EOS>
<BOS>Extraocular Extension Melanoma and Metastatic Intraocular (Uveal) Melanoma Treatment of extraocular extension melanoma that has spread to the bone around the eye may include the following: Surgery (exenteration).<EOS>
<BOS>A clinical trial.<EOS>
<BOS>An effective treatment for metastatic intraocular melanoma has not been found.<EOS>
<BOS>A clinical trial may be a treatment option.<EOS>
<BOS>Talk with your doctor about your treatment options.<EOS>
<BOS>Check the list of NCIsupported cancer clinical trials that are now accepting patients with extraocular extension melanoma and metastatic intraocular melanoma.<EOS>
<BOS>For more specific results, refine the search by using other search features, such as the location of the trial, the type of treatment, or the name of the drug.<EOS>
<BOS>Talk with your doctor about clinical trials that may be right for you.<EOS>
<BOS>General information about clinical trials is available from the NCI website.<EOS>
<BOS>Recurrent Intraocular (Uveal) Melanoma An effective treatment for recurrent intraocular melanoma has not been found.<EOS>
<BOS>A clinical trial may be a treatment option.<EOS>
<BOS>Talk with your doctor about your treatment options.<EOS>
<BOS>Check the list of NCIsupported cancer clinical trials that are now accepting patients with recurrent intraocular melanoma.<EOS>
<BOS>For more specific results, refine the search by using other search features, such as the location of the trial, the type of treatment, or the name of the drug.<EOS>
<BOS>Talk with your doctor about clinical trials that may be right for you.<EOS>
<BOS>General information about clinical trials is available from the NCI website.<EOS>
<BOS>Key Points Adult nonHodgkin lymphoma is a disease in which malignant (cancer) cells form in the lymph system.<EOS>
<BOS>The major types of lymphoma are Hodgkin lymphoma and nonHodgkin lymphoma.<EOS>
<BOS>NonHodgkin lymphoma can be indolent or aggressive.<EOS>
<BOS>Age, gender, and a weakened immune system can affect the risk of adult nonHodgkin lymphoma.<EOS>
<BOS>Signs and symptoms of adult nonHodgkin lymphoma include swelling in the lymph nodes, fever, night sweats, weight loss, and fatigue.<EOS>
<BOS>Tests that examine the body and lymph system are used to help detect (find) and diagnose adult nonHodgkin lymphoma.<EOS>
<BOS>Certain factors affect prognosis (chance of recovery) and treatment options.<EOS>
<BOS>Adult nonHodgkin lymphoma is a disease in which malignant (cancer) cells form in the lymph system.<EOS>
<BOS>NonHodgkin lymphoma is a type of cancer that forms in the lymph system, which is part of the body's immune system.<EOS>
<BOS>The immune system protects the body from foreign substances, infection, and diseases.<EOS>
<BOS>The lymph system is made up of the following: Lymph: Colorless, watery fluid that carries white blood cells called lymphocytes through the lymph system.<EOS>
<BOS>Lymphocytes protect the body against infection and the growth of tumors.<EOS>
<BOS>There are three types of lymphocytes: B lymphocytes that make antibodies to help fight infection.<EOS>
<BOS>Also called B cells.<EOS>
<BOS>Most types of nonHodgkin lymphoma begin in B lymphocytes.<EOS>
<BOS>T lymphocytes that help B lymphocytes make the antibodies that help fight infection.<EOS>
<BOS>Also called T cells.<EOS>
<BOS>Natural killer cells that attack cancer cells and viruses.<EOS>
<BOS>Also called NK cells.<EOS>
<BOS>NonHodgkin lymphoma can begin in B lymphocytes, T lymphocytes, or natural killer cells.<EOS>
<BOS>Lymphocytes can also be found in the blood and also collect in the lymph nodes, spleen, and thymus.<EOS>
<BOS>Lymph vessels: A network of thin tubes that collect lymph from different parts of the body and return it to the bloodstream.<EOS>
<BOS>Lymph nodes: Small, beanshaped structures that filter lymph and store white blood cells that help fight infection and disease.<EOS>
<BOS>Lymph nodes are located along the network of lymph vessels found throughout the body.<EOS>
<BOS>Clusters of lymph nodes are found in the neck, underarm, abdomen, pelvis, and groin.<EOS>
<BOS>Spleen: An organ that makes lymphocytes, filters the blood, stores blood cells, and destroys old blood cells.<EOS>
<BOS>It is on the left side of the abdomen near the stomach.<EOS>
<BOS>Thymus: An organ in which lymphocytes grow and multiply.<EOS>
<BOS>The thymus is in the chest behind the breastbone.<EOS>
<BOS>Tonsils: Two small masses of lymph tissue at the back of the throat.<EOS>
<BOS>The tonsils make lymphocytes.<EOS>
<BOS>Bone marrow: The soft, spongy tissue in the center of large bones.<EOS>
<BOS>Bone marrow makes white blood cells, red blood cells, and platelets.<EOS>
<BOS>Lymph tissue is also found in other parts of the body such as the stomach, thyroid gland, brain, and skin.<EOS>
<BOS>Cancer can spread to the liver and lungs.<EOS>
<BOS>NonHodgkin lymphoma during pregnancy is rare.<EOS>
<BOS>NonHodgkin lymphoma in pregnant women is the same as the disease in nonpregnant women of childbearing age.<EOS>
<BOS>However, treatment is different for pregnant women.<EOS>
<BOS>This summary includes information on the treatment of nonHodgkin lymphoma during pregnancy (see the Treatment Options for NonHodgkin Lymphoma During Pregnancy section for more information).<EOS>
<BOS>NonHodgkin lymphoma can occur in both adults and children.<EOS>
<BOS>Treatment for adults is different than treatment for children.<EOS>
<BOS>(See the PDQ summary on Childhood NonHodgkin Lymphoma Treatment for more information.<EOS>
<BOS>) The major types of lymphoma are Hodgkin lymphoma and nonHodgkin lymphoma.<EOS>
<BOS>Lymphomas are divided into two general types: Hodgkin lymphoma and nonHodgkin lymphoma.<EOS>
<BOS>This summary is about the treatment of adult nonHodgkin lymphoma.<EOS>
<BOS>For information about certain types of lymphoma, see the following PDQ summaries: Adult Acute Lymphoblastic Leukemia Treatment (lymphoblastic lymphoma) Adult Hodgkin Lymphoma Treatment AIDSRelated Lymphoma Treatment Chronic Lymphocytic Leukemia Treatment (small lymphocytic lymphoma) Mycosis Fungoides and the Szary Syndrome Treatment (cutaneous Tcell lymphoma) Primary CNS Lymphoma Treatment NonHodgkin lymphoma can be indolent or aggressive.<EOS>
<BOS>NonHodgkin lymphoma grows and spreads at different rates and can be indolent or aggressive.<EOS>
<BOS>Indolent lymphoma tends to grow and spread slowly, and has few signs and symptoms.<EOS>
<BOS>Aggressive lymphoma grows and spreads quickly, and has signs and symptoms that can be severe.<EOS>
<BOS>The treatments for indolent and aggressive lymphoma are different.<EOS>
<BOS>This summary is about the following types of nonHodgkin lymphoma: Indolent nonHodgkin lymphomas Follicular lymphoma.<EOS>
<BOS>Follicular lymphoma is the most common type of indolent nonHodgkin lymphoma.<EOS>
<BOS>It is a very slowgrowing type of nonHodgkin lymphoma that begins in B lymphocytes.<EOS>
<BOS>It affects the lymph nodes and may spread to the bone marrow or spleen.<EOS>
<BOS>Most patients with follicular lymphoma are age 50 years and older when they are diagnosed.<EOS>
<BOS>Follicular lymphoma may go away without treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>The patient is closely watched for signs or symptoms that the disease has come back.<EOS>
<BOS>Treatment is needed if signs or symptoms occur after the cancer disappeared or after initial cancer treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Sometimes follicular lymphoma can become a more aggressive type of lymphoma, such as diffuse large Bcell lymphoma.<EOS>
<BOS>Lymphoplasmacytic lymphoma.<EOS>
<BOS>In most cases of lymphoplasmacytic lymphoma, B lymphocytes that are turning into plasma cells make large amounts of a protein called monoclonal immunoglobulin M (IgM) antibody.<EOS>
<BOS>High levels of IgM antibody in the blood cause the blood plasma to thicken.<EOS>
<BOS>This may cause signs or symptoms such as trouble seeing or hearing, heart problems, shortness of breath, headache, dizziness, and numbness or tingling of the hands and feet.<EOS>
<BOS>Sometimes there are no signs or symptoms of lymphoplasmacytic lymphoma.<EOS>
<BOS>It may be found when a blood test is done for another reason.<EOS>
<BOS>Lymphoplasmacytic lymphoma often spreads to the bone marrow, lymph nodes, and spleen.<EOS>
<BOS>It is also called Waldenstrm macroglobulinemia.<EOS>
<BOS>Marginal zone lymphoma.<EOS>
<BOS>This type of nonHodgkin lymphoma begins in B lymphocytes in a part of lymph tissue called the marginal zone.<EOS>
<BOS>There are five different types of marginal zone lymphoma.<EOS>
<BOS>They are grouped by the type of tissue where the lymphoma formed: Nodal marginal zone lymphoma.<EOS>
<BOS>Nodal marginal zone lymphoma forms in lymph nodes.<EOS>
<BOS>This type of nonHodgkin lymphoma is rare.<EOS>
<BOS>It is also called monocytoid Bcell lymphoma.<EOS>
<BOS>Gastric mucosaassociated lymphoid tissue (MALT) lymphoma.<EOS>
<BOS>Gastric MALT lymphoma usually begins in the stomach.<EOS>
<BOS>This type of marginal zone lymphoma forms in cells in the mucosa that help make antibodies.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients with gastric MALT lymphoma may also have Helicobacter gastritis or an autoimmune disease, such as Hashimoto thyroiditis or Sjgren syndrome.<EOS>
<BOS>Extragastric MALT lymphoma.<EOS>
<BOS>Extragastric MALT lymphoma begins outside of the stomach in almost every part of the body including other parts of the gastrointestinal tract, salivary glands, thyroid, lung, skin, and around the eye.<EOS>
<BOS>This type of marginal zone lymphoma forms in cells in the mucosa that help make antibodies.<EOS>
<BOS>Extragastric MALT lymphoma may come back many years after treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Mediterranean abdominal lymphoma.<EOS>
<BOS>This is a type of MALT lymphoma that occurs in young adults in eastern Mediterranean countries.<EOS>
<BOS>It often forms in the abdomen and patients may also be infected with bacteria called Campylobacter jejuni.<EOS>
<BOS>This type of lymphoma is also called immunoproliferative small intestinal disease.<EOS>
<BOS>Splenic marginal zone lymphoma.<EOS>
<BOS>This type of marginal zone lymphoma begins in the spleen and may spread to the peripheral blood and bone marrow.<EOS>
<BOS>The most common sign of this type of splenic marginal zone lymphoma is a spleen that is larger than normal.<EOS>
<BOS>Primary cutaneous anaplastic large cell lymphoma.<EOS>
<BOS>This type of nonHodgkin lymphoma is in the skin only.<EOS>
<BOS>It can be a benign (not cancer) nodule that may go away on its own or it can spread to many places on the skin and need treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Aggressive nonHodgkin lymphomas Diffuse large Bcell lymphoma.<EOS>
<BOS>Diffuse large Bcell lymphoma is the most common type of nonHodgkin lymphoma.<EOS>
<BOS>It grows quickly in the lymph nodes and often the spleen, liver, bone marrow, or other organs are also affected.<EOS>
<BOS>Signs and symptoms of diffuse large Bcell lymphoma may include fever, recurring night sweats, and weight loss.<EOS>
<BOS>These are also called B symptoms.<EOS>
<BOS>Primary mediastinal large Bcell lymphoma is a type of diffuse large Bcell lymphoma.<EOS>
<BOS>Primary mediastinal large Bcell lymphoma.<EOS>
<BOS>This type of nonHodgkin lymphoma is marked by the overgrowth of fibrous (scarlike) lymph tissue.<EOS>
<BOS>A tumor most often forms behind the breastbone.<EOS>
<BOS>It may press on the airways and cause coughing and trouble breathing.<EOS>
<BOS>Most patients with primary mediastinal large Bcell lymphoma are women who are age 30 to 40 years.<EOS>
<BOS>Follicular large cell lymphoma, stage III.<EOS>
<BOS>Follicular large cell lymphoma, stage III, is a very rare type of nonHodgkin lymphoma.<EOS>
<BOS>It is more like diffuse large Bcell lymphoma than other types of follicular lymphoma.<EOS>
<BOS>Anaplastic large cell lymphoma.<EOS>
<BOS>Anaplastic large cell lymphoma is a type of nonHodgkin lymphoma that usually begins in T lymphocytes.<EOS>
<BOS>The cancer cells also have a marker called CD30 on the surface of the cell.<EOS>
<BOS>There are two types of anaplastic large cell lymphoma: Cutaneous anaplastic large cell lymphoma.<EOS>
<BOS>This type of anaplastic large cell lymphoma mostly affects the skin, but other parts of the body may also be affected.<EOS>
<BOS>Signs of cutaneous anaplastic large cell lymphoma include one or more bumps or ulcers on the skin.<EOS>
<BOS>Systemic anaplastic large cell lymphoma.<EOS>
<BOS>This type of anaplastic large cell lymphoma begins in the lymph nodes and may affect other parts of the body.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients may have a lot of anaplastic lymphoma kinase (ALK) protein inside the lymphoma cells.<EOS>
<BOS>These patients have a better prognosis than patients who do not have extra ALK protein.<EOS>
<BOS>Systemic anaplastic large cell lymphoma is more common in children than adults.<EOS>
<BOS>(See the PDQ summary on Childhood NonHodgkin Lymphoma Treatment for more information.<EOS>
<BOS>) Extranodal NK /Tcell lymphoma.<EOS>
<BOS>Extranodal NK/Tcell lymphoma usually begins in the area around the nose.<EOS>
<BOS>It may also affect the paranasal sinus (hollow spaces in the bones around the nose), roof of the mouth, trachea, skin, stomach, and intestines.<EOS>
<BOS>Most cases of extranodal NK/Tcell lymphoma have EpsteinBarr virus in the tumor cells.<EOS>
<BOS>Sometimes hemophagocytic syndrome occurs (a serious condition in which there are too many active histiocytes and T cells that cause severe inflammation in the body).<EOS>
<BOS>Treatment to suppress the immune system is needed.<EOS>
<BOS>This type of nonHodgkin lymphoma is not common in the United States.<EOS>
<BOS>Lymphomatoid granulomatosis.<EOS>
<BOS>Lymphomatoid granulomatosis mostly affects the lungs.<EOS>
<BOS>It may also affect the paranasal sinuses (hollow spaces in the bones around the nose), skin, kidneys, and central nervous system.<EOS>
<BOS>In lymphomatoid granulomatosis, cancer invades the blood vessels and kills tissue.<EOS>
<BOS>Because the cancer may spread to the brain, intrathecal chemotherapy or radiation therapy to the brain is given.<EOS>
<BOS>Angioimmunoblastic Tcell lymphoma.<EOS>
<BOS>This type of nonHodgkin lymphoma begins in T cells.<EOS>
<BOS>Swollen lymph nodes are a common sign.<EOS>
<BOS>Other signs may include a skin rash, fever, weight loss, or night sweats.<EOS>
<BOS>There may also be high levels of gamma globulin (antibodies) in the blood.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients may also have opportunistic infections because their immune systems are weakened.<EOS>
<BOS>Peripheral Tcell lymphoma.<EOS>
<BOS>Peripheral Tcell lymphoma begins in mature T lymphocytes.<EOS>
<BOS>This type of T lymphocyte matures in the thymus gland and travels to other lymphatic sites in the body such as the lymph nodes, bone marrow, and spleen.<EOS>
<BOS>There are three subtypes of peripheral Tcell lymphoma: Hepatosplenic Tcell lymphoma.<EOS>
<BOS>This is an uncommon type of peripheral Tcell lymphoma that occurs mostly in young men.<EOS>
<BOS>It begins in the liver and spleen and the cancer cells also have a Tcell receptor called gamma/delta on the surface of the cell.<EOS>
<BOS>Subcutaneous panniculitislike Tcell lymphoma.<EOS>
<BOS>Subcutaneous panniculitislike Tcell lymphoma begins in the skin or mucosa.<EOS>
<BOS>It may occur with hemophagocytic syndrome (a serious condition in which there are too many active histiocytes and T cells that cause severe inflammation in the body).<EOS>
<BOS>Treatment to suppress the immune system is needed.<EOS>
<BOS>Enteropathytype intestinal Tcell lymphoma.<EOS>
<BOS>This type of peripheral Tcell lymphoma occurs in the small bowel of patients with untreated celiac disease (an immune response to gluten that causes malnutrition).<EOS>
<BOS>Patients who are diagnosed with celiac disease in childhood and stay on a glutenfree diet rarely develop enteropathytype intestinal Tcell lymphoma.<EOS>
<BOS>Intravascular large Bcell lymphoma.<EOS>
<BOS>This type of nonHodgkin lymphoma affects blood vessels, especially the small blood vessels in the brain, kidney, lung, and skin.<EOS>
<BOS>Signs and symptoms of intravascular large Bcell lymphoma are caused by blocked blood vessels.<EOS>
<BOS>It is also called intravascular lymphomatosis.<EOS>
<BOS>Burkitt lymphoma.<EOS>
<BOS>Burkitt lymphoma is a type of Bcell nonHodgkin lymphoma that grows and spreads very quickly.<EOS>
<BOS>It may affect the jaw, bones of the face, bowel, kidneys, ovaries, or other organs.<EOS>
<BOS>There are three main types of Burkitt lymphoma (endemic, sporadic, and immunodeficiency related).<EOS>
<BOS>Endemic Burkitt lymphoma commonly occurs in Africa and is linked to the EpsteinBarr virus, and sporadic Burkitt lymphoma occurs throughout the world.<EOS>
<BOS>Immunodeficiencyrelated Burkitt lymphoma is most often seen in patients who have AIDS.<EOS>
<BOS>Burkitt lymphoma may spread to the brain and spinal cord and treatment to prevent its spread may be given.<EOS>
<BOS>Burkitt lymphoma occurs most often in children and young adults (See the PDQ summary on Childhood NonHodgkin Lymphoma Treatment for more information.<EOS>
<BOS>) Burkitt lymphoma is also called diffuse small noncleavedcell lymphoma.<EOS>
<BOS>Lymphoblastic lymphoma.<EOS>
<BOS>Lymphoblastic lymphoma may begin in T cells or B cells, but it usually begins in T cells.<EOS>
<BOS>In this type of nonHodgkin lymphoma, there are too many lymphoblasts (immature white blood cells) in the lymph nodes and the thymus gland.<EOS>
<BOS>These lymphoblasts may spread to other places in the body, such as the bone marrow, brain, and spinal cord.<EOS>
<BOS>Lymphoblastic lymphoma is most common in teenagers and young adults.<EOS>
<BOS>It is a lot like acute lymphoblastic leukemia (lymphoblasts are mostly found in the bone marrow and blood).<EOS>
<BOS>(See the PDQ summary on Adult Acute Lymphoblastic Leukemia Treatment for more information.<EOS>
<BOS>) Adult Tcell leukemia/lymphoma.<EOS>
<BOS>Adult Tcell leukemia/lymphoma is caused by the human Tcell leukemia virus type 1 (HTLV1).<EOS>
<BOS>Signs include bone and skin lesions, high blood calcium levels, and lymph nodes, spleen, and liver that are larger than normal.<EOS>
<BOS>Mantle cell lymphoma.<EOS>
<BOS>Mantle cell lymphoma is a type of Bcell nonHodgkin lymphoma that usually occurs in middleaged or older adults.<EOS>
<BOS>It begins in the lymph nodes and spreads to the spleen, bone marrow, blood, and sometimes the esophagus, stomach, and intestines.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients with mantle cell lymphoma have too much of a protein called cyclinD1 or a certain gene change in the lymphoma cells.<EOS>
<BOS>In some patients who do not have signs or symptoms of lymphoma delaying the start of treatment does not affect the prognosis.<EOS>
<BOS>Posttransplantation lymphoproliferative disorder.<EOS>
<BOS>This disease occurs in patients who have had a heart, lung, liver, kidney, or pancreas transplant and need lifelong immunosuppressive therapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Most posttransplant lymphoproliferative disorders affect the B cells and have EpsteinBarr virus in the cells.<EOS>
<BOS>Lymphoproliferative disorders are often treated like cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>True histiocytic lymphoma.<EOS>
<BOS>This is a rare, very aggressive type of lymphoma.<EOS>
<BOS>It is not known whether it begins in B cells or T cells.<EOS>
<BOS>It does not respond well to treatment with standard chemotherapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Primary effusion lymphoma.<EOS>
<BOS>Primary effusion lymphoma begins in B cells that are found in an area where there is a large buildup of fluid, such as the areas between the lining of the lung and chest wall (pleural effusion), the sac around the heart and the heart (pericardial effusion), or in the abdominal cavity.<EOS>
<BOS>There is usually no tumor that can be seen.<EOS>
<BOS>This type of lymphoma often occurs in patients who have AIDS.<EOS>
<BOS>Plasmablastic lymphoma.<EOS>
<BOS>Plasmablastic lymphoma is a type of large Bcell nonHodgkin lymphoma that is very aggressive.<EOS>
<BOS>It is most often seen in patients with HIV infection.<EOS>
<BOS>Signs and symptoms of small intestine cancer include unexplained weight loss and abdominal pain.<EOS>
<BOS>These and other signs and symptoms may be caused by small intestine cancer or by other conditions.<EOS>
<BOS>Check with your doctor if you have any of the following: Pain or cramps in the middle of the abdomen.<EOS>
<BOS>Weight loss with no known reason.<EOS>
<BOS>A lump in the abdomen.<EOS>
<BOS>Blood in the stool.<EOS>
<BOS>Certain factors affect prognosis (chance of recovery) and treatment options.<EOS>
<BOS>The prognosis (chance of recovery) and treatment options depend on the following: The patients age.<EOS>
<BOS>The phase of CML.<EOS>
<BOS>The amount of blasts in the blood or bone marrow.<EOS>
<BOS>The size of the spleen at diagnosis.<EOS>
<BOS>The patients general health.<EOS>
<BOS>Age, gender, and a weakened immune system can affect the risk of adult nonHodgkin lymphoma.<EOS>
<BOS>Anything that increases your risk of getting a disease is called a risk factor.<EOS>
<BOS>Having a risk factor does not mean that you will get cancer; not having risk factors doesnt mean that you will not get cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Talk with your doctor if you think you may be at risk.<EOS>
<BOS>These and other risk factors may increase the risk of certain types of adult nonHodgkin lymphoma: Being older, male, or white.<EOS>
<BOS>Having one of the following medical conditions: An inherited immune disorder (such as hypogammaglobulinemia or WiskottAldrich syndrome).<EOS>
<BOS>An autoimmune disease (such as rheumatoid arthritis, psoriasis, or Sjgren syndrome).<EOS>
<BOS>HIV/AIDS.<EOS>
<BOS>Human Tlymphotrophic virus type I or EpsteinBarr virus infection.<EOS>
<BOS>Helicobacter pylori infection.<EOS>
<BOS>Taking immunosuppressant drugs after an organ transplant.<EOS>
<BOS>Certain factors affect prognosis (chance of recovery) and treatment options.<EOS>
<BOS>The prognosis (chance of recovery) and treatment options depend on the following: The size of the tumor.<EOS>
<BOS>Where the tumor is in the brain.<EOS>
<BOS>Whether there are tumor cells left after surgery.<EOS>
<BOS>The child's age.<EOS>
<BOS>Side effects that may occur months or years after treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Whether the tumor has just been diagnosed or has recurred (come back).<EOS>
<BOS>The cause of most adult brain and spinal cord tumors is not known.<EOS>
<BOS>Signs and symptoms of transitional cell cancer of the renal pelvis and ureter include blood in the urine and back pain.<EOS>
<BOS>These and other signs and symptoms may be caused by transitional cell cancer of the renal pelvis and ureter or by other conditions.<EOS>
<BOS>There may be no signs or symptoms in the early stages.<EOS>
<BOS>Signs and symptoms may appear as the tumor grows.<EOS>
<BOS>Check with your doctor if you have any of the following: Blood in the urine.<EOS>
<BOS>A pain in the back that doesn't go away.<EOS>
<BOS>Extreme tiredness.<EOS>
<BOS>Weight loss with no known reason.<EOS>
<BOS>Painful or frequent urination.<EOS>
<BOS>Key Points AIDSrelated lymphoma is a disease in which malignant (cancer) cells form in the lymph system of patients who have acquired immunodeficiency syndrome (AIDS).<EOS>
<BOS>There are many different types of lymphoma.<EOS>
<BOS>Signs of AIDSrelated lymphoma include weight loss, fever, and night sweats.<EOS>
<BOS>Tests that examine the lymph system and other parts of the body are used to help detect (find) and diagnose AIDSrelated lymphoma.<EOS>
<BOS>Certain factors affect prognosis (chance of recovery) and treatment options.<EOS>
<BOS>AIDSrelated lymphoma is a disease in which malignant (cancer) cells form in the lymph system of patients who have acquired immunodeficiency syndrome (AIDS).<EOS>
<BOS>AIDS is caused by the human immunodeficiency virus (HIV), which attacks and weakens the body's immune system.<EOS>
<BOS>The immune system is then unable to fight infection and disease.<EOS>
<BOS>People with HIV disease have an increased risk of infection and lymphoma or other types of cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>A person with HIV disease who develops certain types of infections or cancer is then diagnosed with AIDS.<EOS>
<BOS>Sometimes, people are diagnosed with AIDS and AIDSrelated lymphoma at the same time.<EOS>
<BOS>For information about AIDS and its treatment, please see the AIDSinfo website.<EOS>
<BOS>AIDSrelated lymphoma is a type of cancer that affects the lymph system, which is part of the body's immune system.<EOS>
<BOS>The immune system protects the body from foreign substances, infection, and diseases.<EOS>
<BOS>The lymph system is made up of the following: Lymph: Colorless, watery fluid that carries white blood cells called lymphocytes through the lymph system.<EOS>
<BOS>Lymphocytes protect the body against infections and the growth of tumors.<EOS>
<BOS>Lymph vessels: A network of thin tubes that collect lymph from different parts of the body and return it to the bloodstream.<EOS>
<BOS>Lymph nodes: Small, beanshaped structures that filter lymph and store white blood cells that help fight infection and disease.<EOS>
<BOS>Lymph nodes are located along the network of lymph vessels found throughout the body.<EOS>
<BOS>Clusters of lymph nodes are found in the neck, underarm, abdomen, pelvis, and groin.<EOS>
<BOS>Spleen: An organ that makes lymphocytes, filters the blood, stores blood cells, and destroys old blood cells.<EOS>
<BOS>The spleen is on the left side of the abdomen near the stomach.<EOS>
<BOS>Thymus: An organ in which lymphocytes grow and multiply.<EOS>
<BOS>The thymus is in the chest behind the breastbone.<EOS>
<BOS>Tonsils: Two small masses of lymph tissue at the back of the throat.<EOS>
<BOS>The tonsils make lymphocytes.<EOS>
<BOS>Bone marrow: The soft, spongy tissue in the center of large bones.<EOS>
<BOS>Bone marrow makes white blood cells, red blood cells, and platelets.<EOS>
<BOS>Lymph tissue is also found in other parts of the body such as the brain, stomach, thyroid gland, and skin.<EOS>
<BOS>Sometimes AIDSrelated lymphoma occurs outside the lymph nodes in the bone marrow, liver, meninges (thin membranes that cover the brain) and gastrointestinal tract.<EOS>
<BOS>Less often, it may occur in the anus, heart, bile duct, gingiva, and muscles.<EOS>
<BOS>There are many different types of lymphoma.<EOS>
<BOS>Lymphomas are divided into two general types: Hodgkin lymphoma.<EOS>
<BOS>NonHodgkin lymphoma.<EOS>
<BOS>Both Hodgkin lymphoma and nonHodgkin lymphoma may occur in patients with AIDS, but nonHodgkin lymphoma is more common.<EOS>
<BOS>When a person with AIDS has nonHodgkin lymphoma, it is called AIDSrelated lymphoma.<EOS>
<BOS>When AIDSrelated lymphoma occurs in the central nervous system (CNS), it is called AIDSrelated primary CNS lymphoma.<EOS>
<BOS>NonHodgkin lymphomas are grouped by the way their cells look under a microscope.<EOS>
<BOS>They may be indolent (slowgrowing) or aggressive (fastgrowing).<EOS>
<BOS>AIDSrelated lymphomas are aggressive.<EOS>
<BOS>There are two main types of AIDSrelated nonHodgkin lymphoma: Diffuse large Bcell lymphoma (including Bcell immunoblastic lymphoma).<EOS>
<BOS>Burkitt or Burkittlike lymphoma.<EOS>
<BOS>For more information about lymphoma or AIDSrelated cancers, see the following PDQ summaries: Adult NonHodgkin Lymphoma Treatment Childhood NonHodgkin Lymphoma Treatment Primary CNS Lymphoma Treatment Kaposi Sarcoma Treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Certain factors affect prognosis (chance of recovery) and treatment options.<EOS>
<BOS>The prognosis (chance of recovery) and treatment options depend on the following: The stage of the cancer (the size of the tumor and whether it is in the breast only or has spread to other parts of the body).<EOS>
<BOS>The type of breast cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>The age of the unborn baby.<EOS>
<BOS>Whether there are signs or symptoms.<EOS>
<BOS>The patients general health.<EOS>
<BOS>Most people with CML have a gene mutation (change) called the Philadelphia chromosome.<EOS>
<BOS>Every cell in the body contains DNA (genetic material) that determines how the cell looks and acts.<EOS>
<BOS>DNA is contained inside chromosomes.<EOS>
<BOS>In CML, part of the DNA from one chromosome moves to another chromosome.<EOS>
<BOS>This change is called the Philadelphia chromosome.<EOS>
<BOS>It results in the bone marrow making an enzyme, called tyrosine kinase, that causes too many stem cells to become white blood cells (granulocytes or blasts).<EOS>
<BOS>The Philadelphia chromosome is not passed from parent to child.<EOS>
<BOS>Key Points Retinoblastoma is a disease in which malignant (cancer) cells form in the tissues of the retina.<EOS>
<BOS>Retinoblastoma occurs in heritable and nonheritable forms.<EOS>
<BOS>Treatment for both forms of retinoblastoma should include genetic counseling.<EOS>
<BOS>Children with a family history of retinoblastoma should have eye exams to check for retinoblastoma.<EOS>
<BOS>A child who has heritable retinoblastoma has an increased risk of trilateral retinoblastoma and other cancers.<EOS>
<BOS>Signs and symptoms of retinoblastoma include "white pupil" and eye pain or redness.<EOS>
<BOS>Tests that examine the retina are used to detect (find) and diagnose retinoblastoma.<EOS>
<BOS>Certain factors affect prognosis (chance of recovery) and treatment options.<EOS>
<BOS>Retinoblastoma is a disease in which malignant (cancer) cells form in the tissues of the retina.<EOS>
<BOS>The retina is the nerve tissue that lines the inside of the back of the eye.<EOS>
<BOS>The retina senses light and sends images to the brain by way of the optic nerve.<EOS>
<BOS>Although retinoblastoma may occur at any age, it occurs most often in children younger than 2 years.<EOS>
<BOS>The cancer may be in one eye (unilateral) or in both eyes (bilateral).<EOS>
<BOS>Retinoblastoma rarely spreads from the eye to nearby tissue or other parts of the body.<EOS>
<BOS>Cavitary retinoblastoma is a rare type of retinoblastoma in which cavities (hollow spaces) form within the tumor.<EOS>
<BOS>Treatment for both forms of retinoblastoma should include genetic counseling.<EOS>
<BOS>Parents should receive genetic counseling (a discussion with a trained professional about the risk of genetic diseases) to discuss genetic testing to check for a mutation (change) in the RB1 gene.<EOS>
<BOS>Genetic counseling also includes a discussion of the risk of retinoblastoma for the child and the child's brothers or sisters.<EOS>
<BOS>Tests that examine many different body tissues and fluids are used to detect (find) and diagnose neuroblastoma.<EOS>
<BOS>The following tests and procedures may be used: Physical exam and history : An exam of the body to check general signs of health, including checking for signs of disease, such as lumps or anything else that seems unusual.<EOS>
<BOS>A history of the patients health habits and past illnesses and treatments will also be taken.<EOS>
<BOS>Neurological exam : A series of questions and tests to check the brain, spinal cord, and nerve function.<EOS>
<BOS>The exam checks a persons mental status, coordination, and ability to walk normally, and how well the muscles, senses, and reflexes work.<EOS>
<BOS>This may also be called a neuro exam or a neurologic exam.<EOS>
<BOS>Urine catecholamine studies: A procedure in which a urine sample is checked to measure the amount of certain substances, vanillylmandelic acid (VMA) and homovanillic acid (HVA), that are made when catecholamines break down and are released into the urine.<EOS>
<BOS>A higher than normal amount of VMA or HVA can be a sign of neuroblastoma.<EOS>
<BOS>Blood chemistry studies : A procedure in which a blood sample is checked to measure the amounts of certain substances released into the blood by organs and tissues in the body.<EOS>
<BOS>An unusual (higher or lower than normal) amount of a substance can be a sign of disease.<EOS>
<BOS>Xray : An xray is a type of energy beam that can go through the body and onto film, making a picture of areas inside the body.<EOS>
<BOS>CT scan (CAT scan): A procedure that makes a series of detailed pictures of areas inside the body, taken from different angles.<EOS>
<BOS>The pictures are made by a computer linked to an xray machine.<EOS>
<BOS>A dye may be injected into a vein or swallowed to help the organs or tissues show up more clearly.<EOS>
<BOS>This procedure is also called computed tomography, computerized tomography, or computerized axial tomography.<EOS>
<BOS>MRI (magnetic resonance imaging) with gadolinium : A procedure that uses a magnet, radio waves, and a computer to make a series of detailed pictures of areas inside the body.<EOS>
<BOS>A substance called gadolinium is injected into a vein.<EOS>
<BOS>The gadolinium collects around the cancer cells so they show up brighter in the picture.<EOS>
<BOS>This procedure is also called nuclear magnetic resonance imaging (NMRI).<EOS>
<BOS>mIBG (metaiodobenzylguanidine) scan : A procedure used to find neuroendocrine tumors, such as neuroblastoma.<EOS>
<BOS>A very small amount of a substance called radioactive mIBG is injected into a vein and travels through the bloodstream.<EOS>
<BOS>Neuroendocrine tumor cells take up the radioactive mIBG and are detected by a scanner.<EOS>
<BOS>Scans may be taken over 13 days.<EOS>
<BOS>An iodine solution may be given before or during the test to keep the thyroid gland from absorbing too much of the mIBG.<EOS>
<BOS>This test is also used to find out how well the tumor is responding to treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>mIBG is used in high doses to treat neuroblastoma.<EOS>
<BOS>Bone marrow aspiration and biopsy : The removal of bone marrow, blood, and a small piece of bone by inserting a hollow needle into the hipbone or breastbone.<EOS>
<BOS>A pathologist views the bone marrow, blood, and bone under a microscope to look for signs of cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Ultrasound exam: A procedure in which highenergy sound waves (ultrasound) are bounced off internal tissues or organs and make echoes.<EOS>
<BOS>The echoes form a picture of body tissues called a sonogram.<EOS>
<BOS>The picture can be printed to be looked at later.<EOS>
<BOS>An ultrasound exam is not done if a CT/MRI has been done.<EOS>
<BOS>Tests that examine the uterus are used to detect (find) and diagnose uterine sarcoma.<EOS>
<BOS>The following tests and procedures may be used: Physical exam and history : An exam of the body to check general signs of health, including checking for signs of disease, such as lumps or anything else that seems unusual.<EOS>
<BOS>A history of the patients health habits and past illnesses and treatments will also be taken.<EOS>
<BOS>Pelvic exam: An exam of the vagina, cervix, uterus, fallopian tubes, ovaries, and rectum.<EOS>
<BOS>A speculum is inserted into the vagina and the doctor or nurse looks at the vagina and cervix for signs of disease.<EOS>
<BOS>A Pap test of the cervix is usually done.<EOS>
<BOS>The doctor or nurse also inserts one or two lubricated, gloved fingers of one hand into the vagina and places the other hand over the lower abdomen to feel the size, shape, and position of the uterus and ovaries.<EOS>
<BOS>The doctor or nurse also inserts a lubricated, gloved finger into the rectum to feel for lumps or abnormal areas.<EOS>
<BOS>Pap test: A procedure to collect cells from the surface of the cervix and vagina.<EOS>
<BOS>A piece of cotton, a brush, or a small wooden stick is used to gently scrape cells from the cervix and vagina.<EOS>
<BOS>The cells are viewed under a microscope to find out if they are abnormal.<EOS>
<BOS>This procedure is also called a Pap smear.<EOS>
<BOS>Because uterine sarcoma begins inside the uterus, this cancer may not show up on the Pap test.<EOS>
<BOS>Transvaginal ultrasound exam: A procedure used to examine the vagina, uterus, fallopian tubes, and bladder.<EOS>
<BOS>An ultrasound transducer (probe) is inserted into the vagina and used to bounce highenergy sound waves (ultrasound) off internal tissues or organs and make echoes.<EOS>
<BOS>The echoes form a picture of body tissues called a sonogram.<EOS>
<BOS>The doctor can identify tumors by looking at the sonogram.<EOS>
<BOS>Dilatation and curettage : A procedure to remove samples of tissue from the inner lining of the uterus.<EOS>
<BOS>The cervix is dilated and a curette (spoonshaped instrument) is inserted into the uterus to remove tissue.<EOS>
<BOS>The tissue samples are checked under a microscope for signs of disease.<EOS>
<BOS>This procedure is also called a D&C.<EOS>
<BOS>Endometrial biopsy : The removal of tissue from the endometrium (inner lining of the uterus) by inserting a thin, flexible tube through the cervix and into the uterus.<EOS>
<BOS>The tube is used to gently scrape a small amount of tissue from the endometrium and then remove the tissue samples.<EOS>
<BOS>A pathologist views the tissue under a microscope to look for cancer cells.<EOS>
<BOS>Treatment of essential thrombocythemia in patients younger than 60 years who have no signs or symptoms and an acceptable platelet count is usually watchful waiting.<EOS>
<BOS>Treatment of other patients may include the following: Chemotherapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Anagrelide therapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Biologic therapy using interferon alfa or pegylated interferon alpha.<EOS>
<BOS>Platelet apheresis.<EOS>
<BOS>A clinical trial of a new treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Check the list of NCIsupported cancer clinical trials that are now accepting patients with essential thrombocythemia.<EOS>
<BOS>For more specific results, refine the search by using other search features, such as the location of the trial, the type of treatment, or the name of the drug.<EOS>
<BOS>Talk with your doctor about clinical trials that may be right for you.<EOS>
<BOS>General information about clinical trials is available from the NCI website.<EOS>
<BOS>Tests that examine the neck and blood are used to detect (find) and diagnose parathyroid cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Once blood tests are done and hyperparathyroidism is diagnosed, imaging tests may be done to help find which of the parathyroid glands is overactive.<EOS>
<BOS>Sometimes the parathyroid glands are hard to find and imaging tests are done to find exactly where they are.<EOS>
<BOS>Parathyroid cancer may be hard to diagnose because the cells of a benign parathyroid adenoma and a malignant parathyroid cancer look alike.<EOS>
<BOS>The patient's symptoms, blood levels of calcium and parathyroid hormone, and characteristics of the tumor are also used to make a diagnosis.<EOS>
<BOS>The following tests and procedures may be used: Physical exam and history : An exam of the body to check general signs of health, including checking for signs of disease, such as lumps or anything else that seems unusual.<EOS>
<BOS>A history of the patients health habits and past illnesses and treatments will also be taken.<EOS>
<BOS>Blood chemistry studies : A procedure in which a blood sample is checked to measure the amounts of certain substances released into the blood by organs and tissues in the body.<EOS>
<BOS>An unusual (higher or lower than normal) amount of a substance can be a sign of disease.<EOS>
<BOS>To diagnose parathyroid cancer, the sample of blood is checked for its calcium level.<EOS>
<BOS>Parathyroid hormone test: A procedure in which a blood sample is checked to measure the amount of parathyroid hormone released into the blood by the parathyroid glands.<EOS>
<BOS>A higher than normal amount of parathyroid hormone can be a sign of disease.<EOS>
<BOS>Sestamibi scan : A type of radionuclide scan used to find an overactive parathyroid gland.<EOS>
<BOS>A very small amount of a radioactive substance called technetium 99 is injected into a vein and travels through the bloodstream to the parathyroid gland.<EOS>
<BOS>The radioactive substance will collect in the overactive gland and show up brightly on a special camera that detects radioactivity.<EOS>
<BOS>CT scan (CAT scan): A procedure that makes a series of detailed pictures of areas inside the body, taken from different angles.<EOS>
<BOS>The pictures are made by a computer linked to an xray machine.<EOS>
<BOS>A dye may be injected into a vein or swallowed to help the organs or tissues show up more clearly.<EOS>
<BOS>This procedure is also called computed tomography, computerized tomography, or computerized axial tomography.<EOS>
<BOS>SPECT scan (single photon emission computed tomography scan): A procedure that uses a special camera linked to a computer to make a 3dimensional (3D) picture.<EOS>
<BOS>A very small amount of a radioactive substance is injected into a vein.<EOS>
<BOS>As the substance travels through the blood, the camera rotates around the neck and takes pictures.<EOS>
<BOS>Blood flow and metabolism are higher than normal in areas where cancer cells are growing.<EOS>
<BOS>These areas will show up brighter in the picture.<EOS>
<BOS>This procedure may be done just before or after a CT scan.<EOS>
<BOS>Ultrasound exam: A procedure in which highenergy sound waves (ultrasound) are bounced off internal tissues or organs and make echoes.<EOS>
<BOS>The echoes form a picture of body tissues called a sonogram.<EOS>
<BOS>Angiogram : A procedure to look at blood vessels and the flow of blood.<EOS>
<BOS>A contrast dye is injected into the blood vessel.<EOS>
<BOS>As the contrast dye moves through the blood vessel, xrays are taken to see if there are any blockages.<EOS>
<BOS>Venous sampling : A procedure in which a sample of blood is taken from specific veins and checked to measure the amounts of certain substances released into the blood by nearby organs and tissues.<EOS>
<BOS>If imaging tests do not show which parathyroid gland is overactive, blood samples may be taken from veins near each parathyroid gland to find which one is making too much PTH.<EOS>
<BOS>Tests that examine the body and lymph system are used to help detect (find) and diagnose adult nonHodgkin lymphoma.<EOS>
<BOS>The following tests and procedures may be used: Physical exam and history : An exam of the body to check general signs of health, including checking for signs of disease, such as lumps or anything else that seems unusual.<EOS>
<BOS>A history of the patients health habits and past illnesses and treatments will also be taken.<EOS>
<BOS>Flow cytometry : A laboratory test that measures the number of cells in a sample, the percentage of live cells in a sample, and certain characteristics of cells, such as size, shape, and the presence of tumor markers on the cell surface.<EOS>
<BOS>The cells are stained with a lightsensitive dye, placed in a fluid, and passed in a stream before a laser or other type of light.<EOS>
<BOS>The measurements are based on how the lightsensitive dye reacts to the light.<EOS>
<BOS>This test is used to diagnose lymphoplasmacytic lymphoma.<EOS>
<BOS>Bone marrow aspiration and biopsy : The removal of bone marrow and a small piece of bone by inserting a needle into the hipbone or breastbone.<EOS>
<BOS>A pathologist views the bone marrow and bone under a microscope to look for signs of cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Lymph node biopsy: The removal of all or part of a lymph node.<EOS>
<BOS>A pathologist views the tissue under a microscope to look for cancer cells.<EOS>
<BOS>One of the following types of biopsies may be done: Excisional biopsy : The removal of an entire lymph node.<EOS>
<BOS>Incisional biopsy : The removal of part of a lymph node.<EOS>
<BOS>Core biopsy : The removal of part of a lymph node using a wide needle.<EOS>
<BOS>Fineneedle aspiration (FNA) biopsy: The removal of tissue or fluid using a thin needle.<EOS>
<BOS>Laparoscopy : A surgical procedure to look at the organs inside the abdomen to check for signs of disease.<EOS>
<BOS>Small incisions (cuts) are made in the wall of the abdomen and a laparoscope (a thin, lighted tube) is inserted into one of the incisions.<EOS>
<BOS>Other instruments may be inserted through the same or other incisions to take tissue samples to be checked under a microscope for signs of disease.<EOS>
<BOS>Laparotomy : A surgical procedure in which an incision (cut) is made in the wall of the abdomen to check the inside of the abdomen for signs of disease.<EOS>
<BOS>Tissue samples are taken and checked under a microscope for signs of disease.<EOS>
<BOS>If cancer is found, the following tests may be done to study the cancer cells: Immunohistochemistry : A test that uses antibodies to check for certain antigens in a sample of tissue.<EOS>
<BOS>The antibody is usually linked to a radioactive substance or a dye that causes the tissue to light up under a microscope.<EOS>
<BOS>This type of test may be used to tell the difference between different types of cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Cytogenetic analysis : A laboratory test in which cells in a sample of tissue are viewed under a microscope to look for certain changes in the chromosomes.<EOS>
<BOS>FISH (fluorescence in situ hybridization): A laboratory test used to look at genes or chromosomes in cells and tissues.<EOS>
<BOS>Pieces of DNA that contain a fluorescent dye are made in the laboratory and added to cells or tissues on a glass slide.<EOS>
<BOS>When these pieces of DNA attach to certain genes or areas of chromosomes on the slide, they light up when viewed under a microscope with a special light.<EOS>
<BOS>This type of test is used to look for certain genetic markers.<EOS>
<BOS>Immunophenotyping : A process used to identify cells, based on the types of antigens or markers on the surface of the cell.<EOS>
<BOS>This process is used to diagnose specific types of leukemia and lymphoma by comparing the cancer cells to normal cells of the immune system.<EOS>
<BOS>Other tests and procedures may be done depending on the signs and symptoms seen and where the cancer forms in the body.<EOS>
<BOS>Key Points The area where the tumor is found and the childs age are used in place of a staging system to plan cancer treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>The information from tests and procedures done to detect (find) childhood ependymoma is used to plan cancer treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>The area where the tumor is found and the childs age are used in place of a staging system to plan cancer treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Staging is the process used to find out how much cancer there is and if cancer has spread.<EOS>
<BOS>There is no standard staging system for childhood ependymoma.<EOS>
<BOS>Treatment is based on where the cancer is in the body and the age of the child.<EOS>
<BOS>The information from tests and procedures done to detect (find) childhood ependymoma is used to plan cancer treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Some of the tests used to detect childhood ependymoma are repeated after the tumor is removed by surgery.<EOS>
<BOS>(See the General Information section.<EOS>
<BOS>) This is to find out how much tumor remains after surgery.<EOS>
<BOS>A family history of breast cancer and other factors increase the risk of breast cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Anything that increases your chance of getting a disease is called a risk factor.<EOS>
<BOS>Having a risk factor does not mean that you will get cancer; not having risk factors doesn't mean that you will not get cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Talk to your doctor if you think you may be at risk for breast cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Risk factors for breast cancer include the following: A personal history of invasive breast cancer, ductal carcinoma in situ (DCIS), or lobular carcinoma in situ (LCIS).<EOS>
<BOS>A personal history of benign (noncancer) breast disease.<EOS>
<BOS>A family history of breast cancer in a firstdegree relative (mother, daughter, or sister).<EOS>
<BOS>Inherited changes in the BRCA1 or BRCA2 genes or in other genes that increase the risk of breast cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Breast tissue that is dense on a mammogram.<EOS>
<BOS>Exposure of breast tissue to estrogen made by the body.<EOS>
<BOS>This may be caused by: Menstruating at an early age.<EOS>
<BOS>Older age at first birth or never having given birth.<EOS>
<BOS>Starting menopause at a later age.<EOS>
<BOS>Taking hormones such as estrogen combined with progestin for symptoms of menopause.<EOS>
<BOS>Treatment with radiation therapy to the breast/chest.<EOS>
<BOS>Drinking alcohol.<EOS>
<BOS>Obesity.<EOS>
<BOS>Older age is the main risk factor for most cancers.<EOS>
<BOS>The chance of getting cancer increases as you get older.<EOS>
<BOS>NCI's Breast Cancer Risk Assessment Tool uses a woman's risk factors to estimate her risk for breast cancer during the next five years and up to age 90.<EOS>
<BOS>This online tool is meant to be used by a health care provider.<EOS>
<BOS>For more information on breast cancer risk, call 18004CANCER.<EOS>
<BOS>Key Points There are different types of treatment for patients with childhood central nervous system (CNS) germ cell tumors.<EOS>
<BOS>Children with childhood CNS germ cell tumors should have their treatment planned by a team of health care providers who are experts in treating cancer in children.<EOS>
<BOS>Childhood CNS germ cell tumors may cause signs or symptoms that begin before the cancer is diagnosed and continue for months or years.<EOS>
<BOS>Some cancer treatments cause side effects months or years after treatment has ended.<EOS>
<BOS>Four types of treatment are used: Radiation therapy Chemotherapy Surgery Highdose chemotherapy with stem cell rescue New types of treatment are being tested in clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients may want to think about taking part in a clinical trial.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients can enter clinical trials before, during, or after starting their cancer treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Followup tests may be needed.<EOS>
<BOS>There are different types of treatment for patients with childhood central nervous system (CNS) germ cell tumors.<EOS>
<BOS>Different types of treatment are available for children with childhood central nervous system (CNS) germ cell tumors.<EOS>
<BOS>Some treatments are standard (the currently used treatment), and some are being tested in clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>A treatment clinical trial is a research study meant to help improve current treatments or obtain information on new treatments for patients with cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>When clinical trials show that a new treatment is better than the standard treatment, the new treatment may become the standard treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Because cancer in children is rare, taking part in a clinical trial should be considered.<EOS>
<BOS>Some clinical trials are open only to patients who have not started treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Children with childhood CNS germ cell tumors should have their treatment planned by a team of health care providers who are experts in treating cancer in children.<EOS>
<BOS>Treatment will be overseen by a pediatric oncologist and/or a radiation oncologist,.<EOS>
<BOS>A pediatric oncologist is a doctor who specializes in treating children with cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>A radiation oncologist specializes in treating cancer with radiation therapy.<EOS>
<BOS>These doctors work with other pediatric health care providers who are experts in treating children with childhood CNS germ cell tumors and who specialize in certain areas of medicine.<EOS>
<BOS>These may include the following specialists: Pediatrician.<EOS>
<BOS>Pediatric neurosurgeon.<EOS>
<BOS>Neurologist.<EOS>
<BOS>Endocrinologist.<EOS>
<BOS>Ophthalmologist.<EOS>
<BOS>Pediatric nurse specialist.<EOS>
<BOS>Rehabilitation specialist.<EOS>
<BOS>Psychologist.<EOS>
<BOS>Social worker.<EOS>
<BOS>Childhood CNS germ cell tumors may cause signs or symptoms that begin before the cancer is diagnosed and continue for months or years.<EOS>
<BOS>Childhood CNS germ cell tumors may cause signs or symptoms that continue for months or years.<EOS>
<BOS>Signs or symptoms caused by the tumor may begin before the cancer is diagnosed.<EOS>
<BOS>Signs or symptoms caused by treatment may begin during or right after treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Some cancer treatments cause side effects months or years after treatment has ended.<EOS>
<BOS>Some cancer treatments cause side effects that continue or appear months or years after cancer treatment has ended.<EOS>
<BOS>These are called late effects.<EOS>
<BOS>Late effects of cancer treatment may include: Physical problems.<EOS>
<BOS>Changes in mood, feelings, thinking, learning, or memory.<EOS>
<BOS>Second cancers (new types of cancer).<EOS>
<BOS>Some late effects may be treated or controlled.<EOS>
<BOS>It is important to talk with your child's doctors about the possible late effects caused by some treatments.<EOS>
<BOS>(See the PDQ summary on Late Effects of Treatment for Childhood Cancer for more information).<EOS>
<BOS>Four types of treatment are used: Radiation therapy Radiation therapy is a cancer treatment that uses highenergy xrays or other types of radiation to kill cancer cells or keep them from growing.<EOS>
<BOS>There are two types of radiation therapy: External radiation therapy uses a machine outside the body to send radiation toward the cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Certain ways of giving radiation therapy can help keep radiation from damaging nearby healthy tissue.<EOS>
<BOS>This type of radiation therapy may include the following: Stereotactic radiosurgery: Stereotactic radiosurgery is a type of external radiation therapy.<EOS>
<BOS>A rigid head frame is attached to the skull to keep the head still during the radiation treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>A machine aims a single large dose of radiation directly at the tumor.<EOS>
<BOS>This procedure does not involve surgery.<EOS>
<BOS>It is also called stereotaxic radiosurgery, radiosurgery, and radiation surgery.<EOS>
<BOS>Internal radiation therapy uses a radioactive substance sealed in needles, seeds, wires, or catheters that are placed directly into or near the cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>The way the radiation therapy is given depends on the type of cancer being treated.<EOS>
<BOS>External radiation therapy is used to treat childhood CNS germ cell tumors.<EOS>
<BOS>Radiation therapy to the brain can affect growth and development in young children.<EOS>
<BOS>Certain ways of giving radiation therapy can lessen the damage to healthy brain tissue.<EOS>
<BOS>For children younger than 3 years, chemotherapy may be given instead.<EOS>
