<BOS>This can delay or reduce the need for radiation therapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Chemotherapy Chemotherapy is a cancer treatment that uses drugs to stop the growth of cancer cells, either by killing the cells or by stopping them from dividing.<EOS>
<BOS>When chemotherapy is taken by mouth or injected into a vein or muscle, the drugs enter the bloodstream and can reach cancer cells throughout the body (systemic chemotherapy).<EOS>
<BOS>When chemotherapy is placed directly into the cerebrospinal fluid, an organ, or a body cavity such as the abdomen, the drugs mainly affect cancer cells in those areas (regional chemotherapy).<EOS>
<BOS>The way the chemotherapy is given depends on the type of cancer being treated.<EOS>
<BOS>Surgery Whether surgery to remove the tumor can be done depends on where the tumor is in the brain.<EOS>
<BOS>Surgery to remove the tumor may cause severe, longterm side effects.<EOS>
<BOS>Surgery may be done to remove teratomas and may be used for germ cell tumors that come back.<EOS>
<BOS>Even if the doctor removes all the cancer that can be seen at the time of the surgery, some patients may be given chemotherapy or radiation therapy after surgery to kill any cancer cells that are left.<EOS>
<BOS>Treatment given after the surgery, to lower the risk that the cancer will come back, is called adjuvant therapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Highdose chemotherapy with stem cell rescue Highdose chemotherapy with stem cell rescue is a way of giving high doses of chemotherapy and replacing blood forming cells destroyed by the cancer treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Stem cells (immature blood cells) are removed from the blood or bone marrow of the patient or a donor and are frozen and stored.<EOS>
<BOS>After the chemotherapy is completed, the stored stem cells are thawed and given back to the patient through an infusion.<EOS>
<BOS>These reinfused stem cells grow into (and restore) the bodys blood cells.<EOS>
<BOS>New types of treatment are being tested in clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>Information about clinical trials is available from the NCI website.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients may want to think about taking part in a clinical trial.<EOS>
<BOS>For some patients, taking part in a clinical trial may be the best treatment choice.<EOS>
<BOS>Clinical trials are part of the cancer research process.<EOS>
<BOS>Clinical trials are done to find out if new cancer treatments are safe and effective or better than the standard treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Many of today's standard treatments for cancer are based on earlier clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients who take part in a clinical trial may receive the standard treatment or be among the first to receive a new treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients who take part in clinical trials also help improve the way cancer will be treated in the future.<EOS>
<BOS>Even when clinical trials do not lead to effective new treatments, they often answer important questions and help move research forward.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients can enter clinical trials before, during, or after starting their cancer treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Some clinical trials only include patients who have not yet received treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Other trials test treatments for patients whose cancer has not gotten better.<EOS>
<BOS>There are also clinical trials that test new ways to stop cancer from recurring (coming back) or reduce the side effects of cancer treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Clinical trials are taking place in many parts of the country.<EOS>
<BOS>See the Current Clinical Trials section that follows for links to current treatment clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>These have been retrieved from the NCI's listing of clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>Followup tests may be needed.<EOS>
<BOS>Some of the tests that were done to diagnose the cancer or to find out the stage of the cancer may be repeated.<EOS>
<BOS>Some tests will be repeated in order to see how well the treatment is working.<EOS>
<BOS>Decisions about whether to continue, change, or stop treatment may be based on the results of these tests.<EOS>
<BOS>Some of the tests will continue to be done from time to time after treatment has ended.<EOS>
<BOS>The results of these tests can show if your child's condition has changed or if the cancer has recurred (come back).<EOS>
<BOS>These tests are sometimes called followup tests or checkups.<EOS>
<BOS>Children whose cancer affected their pituitary gland when the cancer was diagnosed will usually need to have their blood hormone levels checked.<EOS>
<BOS>If the blood hormone level is low, replacement hormone medicine is given.<EOS>
<BOS>Children who had a high tumor marker level (alphafetoprotein or betahuman chorionic gonadotropin) when the cancer was diagnosed usually need to have their blood tumor marker level checked.<EOS>
<BOS>If the tumor marker level increases after initial treatment, the tumor may have recurred.<EOS>
<BOS>Treatment Options for Childhood CNS Germ Cell Tumors Newly Diagnosed CNS Germinomas Treatment of newly diagnosed central nervous system (CNS) germinomas may include the following: Radiation therapy to the tumor and ventricles (fluid filled spaces) of the brain.<EOS>
<BOS>A higher dose of radiation is given to the tumor than the area around the tumor.<EOS>
<BOS>Chemotherapy followed by radiation therapy, for younger children.<EOS>
<BOS>A clinical trial of chemotherapy followed by radiation therapy given in lower doses depending on how the tumor responds to treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Newly Diagnosed CNS Teratomas Treatment of newly diagnosed mature and immature central nervous system (CNS) teratomas may include the following: Surgery to remove as much of the tumor as possible.<EOS>
<BOS>Radiation therapy and/or chemotherapy may be given if any tumor remains after surgery.<EOS>
<BOS>Newly Diagnosed CNS Nongerminomas It is not clear what treatment is best for newly diagnosed central nervous system (CNS) nongerminomas is.<EOS>
<BOS>Treatment of choriocarcinoma, embryonal carcinoma, yolk sac tumor, or mixed germ cell tumor may include the following: Chemotherapy followed by radiation therapy.<EOS>
<BOS>If a mass remains after chemotherapy, surgery may be needed to check if the mass is a mature teratoma, fibrosis, or a growing tumor.<EOS>
<BOS>If the mass is a mature teratoma or fibrosis, radiation therapy is given.<EOS>
<BOS>If the mass is a growing tumor, other treatments may be given.<EOS>
<BOS>Surgery to remove as much of the mass as possible and check for tumor cells, if tumor marker levels are normal and the mass continues to grow (called growing teratoma syndrome).<EOS>
<BOS>A clinical trial of chemotherapy followed by radiation therapy given in lower doses depending on how the tumor responds to treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Recurrent Childhood CNS Germ Cell Tumors Treatment of recurrent childhood central nervous system (CNS) germ cell tumors may include the following: Chemotherapy followed by radiation therapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Highdose chemotherapy with stem cell rescue using the patient's stem cells.<EOS>
<BOS>A clinical trial of a new treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Because myelodysplastic /myeloproliferative neoplasm, unclassifiable (MDS/MPNUC) is a rare disease, little is known about its treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Treatment may include the following: Supportive care treatments to manage problems caused by the disease such as infection, bleeding, and anemia.<EOS>
<BOS>Targeted therapy (imatinib mesylate).<EOS>
<BOS>Check the list of NCIsupported cancer clinical trials that are now accepting patients with myelodysplastic/myeloproliferative neoplasm, unclassifiable.<EOS>
<BOS>For more specific results, refine the search by using other search features, such as the location of the trial, the type of treatment, or the name of the drug.<EOS>
<BOS>Talk with your doctor about clinical trials that may be right for you.<EOS>
<BOS>General information about clinical trials is available from the NCI website.<EOS>
<BOS>Key Points There are different types of treatment for children with Hodgkin lymphoma.<EOS>
<BOS>Children with Hodgkin lymphoma should have their treatment planned by a team of health care providers who are experts in treating childhood cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Children and adolescents may have treatmentrelated side effects that appear months or years after treatment for Hodgkin lymphoma.<EOS>
<BOS>Five types of standard treatment are used: Chemotherapy Radiation therapy Targeted therapy Surgery Highdose chemotherapy with stem cell transplant New types of treatment are being tested in clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>Proton beam radiation therapy Patients may want to think about taking part in a clinical trial.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients can enter clinical trials before, during, or after starting their cancer treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Followup tests may be needed.<EOS>
<BOS>There are different types of treatment for children with Hodgkin lymphoma.<EOS>
<BOS>Different types of treatment are available for children with Hodgkin lymphoma.<EOS>
<BOS>Some treatments are standard and some are being tested in clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>A treatment clinical trial is a research study meant to help improve current treatments or obtain information on new treatments for patients with cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>When clinical trials show that a new treatment is better than the standard treatment, the new treatment may become the standard treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Because cancer in children is rare, taking part in a clinical trial should be considered.<EOS>
<BOS>Some clinical trials are open only to patients who have not started treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Children with Hodgkin lymphoma should have their treatment planned by a team of health care providers who are experts in treating childhood cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Treatment will be overseen by a pediatric oncologist, a doctor who specializes in treating children with cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>The pediatric oncologist works with other pediatric health care providers who are experts in treating children with Hodgkin lymphoma and who specialize in certain areas of medicine.<EOS>
<BOS>These may include the following specialists: Pediatrician.<EOS>
<BOS>Medical oncologist /hematologist.<EOS>
<BOS>Pediatric surgeon.<EOS>
<BOS>Radiation oncologist.<EOS>
<BOS>Endocrinologist.<EOS>
<BOS>Pediatric nurse specialist.<EOS>
<BOS>Rehabilitation specialist.<EOS>
<BOS>Psychologist.<EOS>
<BOS>Social worker.<EOS>
<BOS>Childlife specialist.<EOS>
<BOS>The treatment of Hodgkin lymphoma in adolescents and young adults may be different than the treatment for children.<EOS>
<BOS>Some adolescents and young adults are treated with an adult treatment regimen.<EOS>
<BOS>Children and adolescents may have treatmentrelated side effects that appear months or years after treatment for Hodgkin lymphoma.<EOS>
<BOS>Some cancer treatments cause side effects that continue or appear months or years after cancer treatment has ended.<EOS>
<BOS>These are called late effects.<EOS>
<BOS>Because late effects affect health and development, regular followup exams are important.<EOS>
<BOS>Late effects of cancer treatment may include: Physical problems that affect the following: Development of sex and reproductive organs.<EOS>
<BOS>Fertility (ability to have children).<EOS>
<BOS>Bone and muscle growth and development.<EOS>
<BOS>Thyroid, heart, or lung function.<EOS>
<BOS>Teeth, gums, and salivary gland function.<EOS>
<BOS>Spleen function (increased risk of infection).<EOS>
<BOS>Changes in mood, feelings, thinking, learning, or memory.<EOS>
<BOS>Second cancers (new types of cancer).<EOS>
<BOS>For female survivors of Hodgkin lymphoma, there is an increased risk of breast cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>This risk depends on the amount of radiation therapy they received to the breast during treatment and the chemotherapy regimen used.<EOS>
<BOS>The risk of breast cancer is decreased if these female survivors also received radiation therapy to the ovaries.<EOS>
<BOS>It is suggested that female survivors who received radiation therapy to the breast have a mammogram once a year starting 8 years after treatment or at age 25 years, whichever is later.<EOS>
<BOS>Female survivors of childhood Hodgkin lymphoma who have breast cancer have an increased risk of dying from the disease compared to patients with no history of Hodgkin lymphoma who have breast cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Some late effects may be treated or controlled.<EOS>
<BOS>It is important to talk with your child's doctors about the possible late effects caused by some treatments.<EOS>
<BOS>(See the PDQ summary on Late Effects of Treatment for Childhood Cancer for more information).<EOS>
<BOS>Five types of standard treatment are used: Chemotherapy Chemotherapy is a cancer treatment that uses drugs to stop the growth of cancer cells, either by killing the cells or by stopping them from dividing.<EOS>
<BOS>When chemotherapy is taken by mouth or injected into a vein or muscle, the drugs enter the bloodstream and can reach cancer cells throughout the body (systemic chemotherapy).<EOS>
<BOS>When chemotherapy is placed directly into the cerebrospinal fluid, an organ, or a body cavity such as the abdomen, the drugs mainly affect cancer cells in those areas (regional chemotherapy).<EOS>
<BOS>Combination chemotherapy is treatment using more than one anticancer drug.<EOS>
<BOS>The way the chemotherapy is given depends on the risk group.<EOS>
<BOS>For example, children with lowrisk Hodgkin lymphoma receive fewer cycles of treatment, fewer anticancer drugs, and lower doses of anticancer drugs than children with highrisk lymphoma.<EOS>
<BOS>See Drugs Approved for Hodgkin Lymphoma for more information.<EOS>
<BOS>Radiation therapy Radiation therapy is a cancer treatment that uses highenergy xrays or other types of radiation to kill cancer cells or keep them from growing.<EOS>
<BOS>There are two types of radiation therapy: External radiation therapy uses a machine outside the body to send radiation toward the cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Certain ways of giving radiation therapy can help keep radiation from damaging nearby healthy tissue.<EOS>
<BOS>These types of external radiation therapy include the following: Conformal radiation therapy: Conformal radiation therapy is a type of external radiation therapy that uses a computer to make a 3dimensional (3D) picture of the tumor and shapes the radiation beams to fit the tumor.<EOS>
<BOS>Intensitymodulated radiation therapy (IMRT): IMRT is a type of 3dimensional (3D) radiation therapy that uses a computer to make pictures of the size and shape of the tumor.<EOS>
<BOS>Thin beams of radiation of different intensities (strengths) are aimed at the tumor from many angles.<EOS>
<BOS>Internal radiation therapy uses a radioactive substance sealed in needles, seeds, wires, or catheters that are placed directly into or near the cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Radiation therapy may be given, based on the childs risk group and chemotherapy regimen.<EOS>
<BOS>External radiation therapy is used to treat childhood Hodgkin lymphoma.<EOS>
<BOS>The radiation is given only to the lymph nodes or other areas with cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Internal radiation therapy is not used to treat Hodgkin lymphoma.<EOS>
<BOS>Targeted therapy Targeted therapy is a type of treatment that uses drugs or other substances to identify and attack specific cancer cells without harming normal cells.<EOS>
<BOS>Monoclonal antibody therapy and proteasome inhibitor therapy are being used in the treatment of childhood Hodgkin lymphoma.<EOS>
<BOS>Monoclonal antibody therapy is a cancer treatment that uses antibodies made in the laboratory from a single type of immune system cell.<EOS>
<BOS>These antibodies can identify substances on cancer cells or normal substances that may help cancer cells grow.<EOS>
<BOS>The antibodies attach to the substances and kill the cancer cells, block their growth, or keep them from spreading.<EOS>
<BOS>Monoclonal antibodies are given by infusion.<EOS>
<BOS>They may be used alone or to carry drugs, toxins, or radioactive material directly to cancer cells.<EOS>
<BOS>In children, rituximab may be used to treat refractory or recurrent Hodgkin lymphoma.<EOS>
<BOS>Brentuximab, nivolumab, pembrolizumab, and atezolizumab are monoclonal antibodies being studied to treat children.<EOS>
<BOS>Proteasome inhibitor therapy is a type of targeted therapy that blocks the action of proteasomes (proteins that remove other proteins the body no longer needs) in cancer cells and may prevent the growth of tumors.<EOS>
<BOS>Bortezomib is a proteasome inhibitor used to treat refractory or recurrent childhood Hodgkin lymphoma.<EOS>
<BOS>Surgery Surgery may be done to remove as much of the tumor as possible for localized nodular lymphocyte predominant childhood Hodgkin lymphoma.<EOS>
<BOS>Highdose chemotherapy with stem cell transplant Highdose chemotherapy with stem cell transplant is a way of giving high doses of chemotherapy and replacing blood forming cells destroyed by the cancer treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Stem cells (immature blood cells) are removed from the blood or bone marrow of the patient or a donor and are frozen and stored.<EOS>
<BOS>After the chemotherapy is completed, the stored stem cells are thawed and given back to the patient through an infusion.<EOS>
<BOS>These reinfused stem cells grow into (and restore) the body's blood cells.<EOS>
<BOS>See Drugs Approved for Hodgkin Lymphoma for more information.<EOS>
<BOS>New types of treatment are being tested in clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>This summary section describes treatments that are being studied in clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>It may not mention every new treatment being studied.<EOS>
<BOS>Information about clinical trials is available from the NCI website.<EOS>
<BOS>Proton beam radiation therapy Protonbeam therapy is a type of highenergy, external radiation therapy that uses streams of protons (small, positivelycharged particles of matter) to make radiation.<EOS>
<BOS>This type of radiation therapy may help lessen the damage to healthy tissue near the tumor.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients may want to think about taking part in a clinical trial.<EOS>
<BOS>For some patients, taking part in a clinical trial may be the best treatment choice.<EOS>
<BOS>Clinical trials are part of the cancer research process.<EOS>
<BOS>Clinical trials are done to find out if new cancer treatments are safe and effective or better than the standard treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Many of today's standard treatments for cancer are based on earlier clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients who take part in a clinical trial may receive the standard treatment or be among the first to receive a new treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients who take part in clinical trials also help improve the way cancer will be treated in the future.<EOS>
<BOS>Even when clinical trials do not lead to effective new treatments, they often answer important questions and help move research forward.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients can enter clinical trials before, during, or after starting their cancer treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Some clinical trials only include patients who have not yet received treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Other trials test treatments for patients whose cancer has not gotten better.<EOS>
<BOS>There are also clinical trials that test new ways to stop cancer from recurring (coming back) or reduce the side effects of cancer treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Clinical trials are taking place in many parts of the country.<EOS>
<BOS>See the Treatment Options section that follows for links to current treatment clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>These have been retrieved from NCI's listing of clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>Followup tests may be needed.<EOS>
<BOS>Some of the tests that were done to diagnose the cancer or to find out the stage of the cancer may be repeated.<EOS>
<BOS>Some tests will be repeated in order to see how well the treatment is working.<EOS>
<BOS>Decisions about whether to continue, change, or stop treatment may be based on the results of these tests.<EOS>
<BOS>Some of the tests will continue to be done from time to time after treatment has ended.<EOS>
<BOS>The results of these tests can show if your child's condition has changed or if the cancer has recurred (come back).<EOS>
<BOS>These tests are sometimes called followup tests or checkups.<EOS>
<BOS>For patients who receive chemotherapy alone, a PET scan may be done 3 weeks or more after treatment ends.<EOS>
<BOS>For patients who receive radiation therapy last, a PET scan should not be done until 8 to 12 weeks after treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Treatment Options for Children and Adolescents with Hodgkin Lymphoma LowRisk Classical Childhood Hodgkin Lymphoma Treatment of lowrisk classical childhood Hodgkin lymphoma may include the following: Combination chemotherapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Radiation therapy may also be given to the areas with cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Check the list of NCIsupported cancer clinical trials that are now accepting patients with stage I childhood Hodgkin lymphoma and stage II childhood Hodgkin lymphoma.<EOS>
<BOS>For more specific results, refine the search by using other search features, such as the location of the trial, the type of treatment, or the name of the drug.<EOS>
<BOS>Talk with your child's doctor about clinical trials that may be right for your child.<EOS>
<BOS>General information about clinical trials is available from the NCI website.<EOS>
<BOS>IntermediateRisk Classical Childhood Hodgkin Lymphoma Treatment of intermediaterisk classical childhood Hodgkin lymphoma may include the following: Combination chemotherapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Radiation therapy may also be given to the areas with cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Check the list of NCIsupported cancer clinical trials that are now accepting patients with stage I childhood Hodgkin lymphoma, stage II childhood Hodgkin lymphoma, stage III childhood Hodgkin lymphoma and stage IV childhood Hodgkin lymphoma.<EOS>
<BOS>For more specific results, refine the search by using other search features, such as the location of the trial, the type of treatment, or the name of the drug.<EOS>
<BOS>Talk with your child's doctor about clinical trials that may be right for your child.<EOS>
<BOS>General information about clinical trials is available from the NCI website.<EOS>
<BOS>HighRisk Classical Childhood Hodgkin Lymphoma Treatment of highrisk classical childhood Hodgkin lymphoma may include the following: Higher dose combination chemotherapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Radiation therapy may also be given to the areas with cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>A clinical trial of targeted therapy and combination chemotherapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Radiation therapy may also be given to the areas with cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Check the list of NCIsupported cancer clinical trials that are now accepting patients with stage III childhood Hodgkin lymphoma and stage IV childhood Hodgkin lymphoma.<EOS>
<BOS>For more specific results, refine the search by using other search features, such as the location of the trial, the type of treatment, or the name of the drug.<EOS>
<BOS>Talk with your child's doctor about clinical trials that may be right for your child.<EOS>
<BOS>General information about clinical trials is available from the NCI website.<EOS>
<BOS>Nodular LymphocytePredominant Childhood Hodgkin Lymphoma Treatment of nodular lymphocytepredominant childhood Hodgkin lymphoma may include the following: Surgery, if the tumor can be completely removed.<EOS>
<BOS>Chemotherapy with or without lowdose external radiation therapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Check the list of NCIsupported cancer clinical trials that are now accepting patients with childhood nodular lymphocyte predominant Hodgkin lymphoma.<EOS>
<BOS>For more specific results, refine the search by using other search features, such as the location of the trial, the type of treatment, or the name of the drug.<EOS>
<BOS>Talk with your child's doctor about clinical trials that may be right for your child.<EOS>
<BOS>General information about clinical trials is available from the NCI website.<EOS>
<BOS>Certain factors affect prognosis (chance of recovery) and treatment options.<EOS>
<BOS>Gestational trophoblastic disease usually can be cured.<EOS>
<BOS>Treatment and prognosis depend on the following: The type of GTD.<EOS>
<BOS>Whether the tumor has spread to the uterus, lymph nodes, or distant parts of the body.<EOS>
<BOS>The number of tumors and where they are in the body.<EOS>
<BOS>The size of the largest tumor.<EOS>
<BOS>The level of hCG in the blood.<EOS>
<BOS>How soon the tumor was diagnosed after the pregnancy began.<EOS>
<BOS>Whether GTD occurred after a molar pregnancy, miscarriage, or normal pregnancy.<EOS>
<BOS>Previous treatment for gestational trophoblastic neoplasia.<EOS>
<BOS>Treatment options also depend on whether the woman wishes to become pregnant in the future.<EOS>
<BOS>Different factors increase or decrease the risk of getting ovarian, fallopian tube, and primary peritoneal cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Anything that increases your chance of getting a disease is called a risk factor.<EOS>
<BOS>Anything that decreases your chance of getting a disease is called a protective factor.<EOS>
<BOS>For information about risk factors and protective factors for ovarian cancer, see the Ovarian, Fallopian Tube, and Primary Peritoneal Cancer Prevention summary.<EOS>
<BOS>Talk to your doctor about your risk of ovarian cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Screening tests have risks.<EOS>
<BOS>Decisions about screening tests can be difficult.<EOS>
<BOS>Not all screening tests are helpful and most have risks.<EOS>
<BOS>Before having any screening test, you may want to talk about the test with your doctor.<EOS>
<BOS>It is important to know the risks of the test and whether it has been proven to reduce the risk of dying from cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>The risks of ovarian, fallopian tube, and primary peritoneal cancer screening tests include the following: Finding ovarian, fallopian tube, and primary peritoneal cancer may not improve health or help a woman live longer.<EOS>
<BOS>Screening may not improve your health or help you live longer if you have advanced ovarian cancer or if it has already spread to other places in your body.<EOS>
<BOS>Falsenegative test results can occur.<EOS>
<BOS>Screening test results may appear to be normal even though ovarian cancer is present.<EOS>
<BOS>A woman who receives a falsenegative test result (one that shows there is no cancer when there really is) may delay seeking medical care even if she has symptoms.<EOS>
<BOS>Falsepositive test results can occur.<EOS>
<BOS>Screening test results may appear to be abnormal even though no cancer is present.<EOS>
<BOS>A falsepositive test result (one that shows there is cancer when there really isn't) can cause anxiety and is usually followed by more tests (such as a laparoscopy or a laparotomy to see if cancer is present), which also have risks.<EOS>
<BOS>Problems caused by tests used to diagnose ovarian cancer include infection, blood loss, bowel injury, and heart and blood vessel problems.<EOS>
<BOS>A falsepositive test result can also lead to an unneeded oophorectomy (removal of one or both ovaries).<EOS>
<BOS>Having hepatitis or cirrhosis can affect the risk of adult primary liver cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Anything that increases your chance of getting a disease is called a risk factor.<EOS>
<BOS>Having a risk factor does not mean that you will get cancer; not having risk factors doesnt mean that you will not get cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Talk with your doctor if you think you may be at risk.<EOS>
<BOS>The following are risk factors for adult primary liver cancer: Having hepatitis B or hepatitis C.<EOS>
<BOS>Having both hepatitis B and hepatitis C increases the risk even more.<EOS>
<BOS>Having cirrhosis, which can be caused by: hepatitis (especially hepatitis C); or drinking large amounts of alcohol for many years or being an alcoholic.<EOS>
<BOS>Having metabolic syndrome, a set of conditions that occur together, including extra fat around the abdomen, high blood sugar, high blood pressure, high levels of triglycerides and low levels of highdensity lipoproteins in the blood.<EOS>
<BOS>Having liver injury that is longlasting, especially if it leads to cirrhosis.<EOS>
<BOS>Having hemochromatosis, a condition in which the body takes up and stores more iron than it needs.<EOS>
<BOS>The extra iron is stored in the liver, heart, and pancreas Eating foods tainted with aflatoxin (poison from a fungus that can grow on foods, such as grains and nuts, that have not been stored properly).<EOS>
<BOS>Key Points Central nervous system (CNS) embryonal tumors may begin in embryonic (fetal) cells that remain in the brain after birth.<EOS>
<BOS>There are different types of CNS embryonal tumors.<EOS>
<BOS>Pineoblastomas form in cells of the pineal gland.<EOS>
<BOS>Certain genetic conditions increase the risk of childhood CNS embryonal tumors.<EOS>
<BOS>Signs and symptoms of childhood CNS embryonal tumors or pineoblastomas depend on the child's age and where the tumor is.<EOS>
<BOS>Tests that examine the brain and spinal cord are used to detect (find) childhood CNS embryonal tumors or pineoblastomas.<EOS>
<BOS>A biopsy may be done to be sure of the diagnosis of CNS embryonal tumor or pineoblastoma.<EOS>
<BOS>Certain factors affect prognosis (chance of recovery) and treatment options.<EOS>
<BOS>Central nervous system (CNS) embryonal tumors may begin in embryonic (fetal) cells that remain in the brain after birth.<EOS>
<BOS>Central nervous system (CNS) embryonal tumors form in embryonic cells that remain in the brain after birth.<EOS>
<BOS>CNS embryonal tumors tend to spread through the cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) to other parts of the brain and spinal cord.<EOS>
<BOS>The tumors may be malignant (cancer) or benign (not cancer).<EOS>
<BOS>Most CNS embryonal tumors in children are malignant.<EOS>
<BOS>Malignant brain tumors are likely to grow quickly and spread into other parts of the brain.<EOS>
<BOS>When a tumor grows into or presses on an area of the brain, it may stop that part of the brain from working the way it should.<EOS>
<BOS>Benign brain tumors grow and press on nearby areas of the brain.<EOS>
<BOS>They rarely spread to other parts of the brain.<EOS>
<BOS>Both benign and malignant brain tumors can cause signs or symptoms and need treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Although cancer is rare in children, brain tumors are the third most common type of childhood cancer, after leukemia and lymphoma.<EOS>
<BOS>This summary is about the treatment of primary brain tumors (tumors that begin in the brain).<EOS>
<BOS>The treatment of metastatic brain tumors, which begin in other parts of the body and spread to the brain, is not discussed in this summary.<EOS>
<BOS>For information about the different types of brain and spinal cord tumors, see the PDQ summary on Childhood Brain and Spinal Cord Tumors Treatment Overview.<EOS>
<BOS>Brain tumors occur in both children and adults.<EOS>
<BOS>Treatment for adults may be different from treatment for children.<EOS>
<BOS>See the PDQ summary on Adult Central Nervous System Tumors Treatment for more information on the treatment of adults.<EOS>
<BOS>There are different types of CNS embryonal tumors.<EOS>
<BOS>The different types of CNS embryonal tumors include: Medulloblastomas Most CNS embryonal tumors are medulloblastomas.<EOS>
<BOS>Medulloblastomas are fastgrowing tumors that form in brain cells in the cerebellum.<EOS>
<BOS>The cerebellum is at the lower back part of the brain between the cerebrum and the brain stem.<EOS>
<BOS>The cerebellum controls movement, balance, and posture.<EOS>
<BOS>Medulloblastomas sometimes spread to the bone, bone marrow, lung, or other parts of the body, but this is rare.<EOS>
<BOS>Nonmedulloblastoma embryonal tumors Nonmedulloblastoma embryonal tumors are fastgrowing tumors that usually form in brain cells in the cerebrum.<EOS>
<BOS>The cerebrum is at the top of the head and is the largest part of the brain.<EOS>
<BOS>The cerebrum controls thinking, learning, problemsolving, emotions, speech, reading, writing, and voluntary movement.<EOS>
<BOS>Nonmedulloblastoma embryonal tumors may also form in the brain stem or spinal cord.<EOS>
<BOS>There are four types of nonmedulloblastoma embryonal tumors: Embryonal tumors with multilayered rosettes Embryonal tumors with multilayered rosettes (ETMR) are rare tumors that form in the brain and spinal cord.<EOS>
<BOS>ETMR most commonly occur in young children and are fastgrowing tumors.<EOS>
<BOS>Medulloepitheliomas Medulloepitheliomas are fastgrowing tumors that usually form in the brain, spinal cord or nerves just outside the spinal column.<EOS>
<BOS>They occur most often in infants and young children.<EOS>
<BOS>CNS neuroblastomas CNS neuroblastomas are a very rare type of neuroblastoma that form in the nerve tissue of the cerebrum or the layers of tissue that cover the brain and spinal cord.<EOS>
<BOS>CNS neuroblastomas may be large and spread to other parts of the brain or spinal cord.<EOS>
<BOS>CNS ganglioneuroblastomas CNS ganglioneuroblastomas are rare tumors that form in nerve tissue of the brain and spinal cord.<EOS>
<BOS>They may form in one area and be fast growing or form in more than one area and be slow growing.<EOS>
<BOS>Childhood CNS atypical teratoid/rhabdoid tumor is also a type of embryonal tumor, but it is treated differently than other childhood CNS embryonal tumors.<EOS>
<BOS>See the PDQ summary on Childhood Central Nervous System Atypical Teratoid/Rhabdoid Tumor Treatment for more information.<EOS>
<BOS>Pineoblastomas form in cells of the pineal gland.<EOS>
<BOS>The pineal gland is a tiny organ in the center of the brain.<EOS>
<BOS>The gland makes melatonin, a substance that helps control our sleep cycle.<EOS>
<BOS>Pineoblastomas form in cells of the pineal gland and are usually malignant.<EOS>
<BOS>Pineoblastomas are fastgrowing tumors with cells that look very different from normal pineal gland cells.<EOS>
<BOS>Pineoblastomas are not a type of CNS embryonal tumor but treatment for them is a lot like treatment for CNS embryonal tumors.<EOS>
<BOS>Pineoblastoma is linked with inherited changes in the retinoblastoma (RB1) gene.<EOS>
<BOS>A child with the inherited form of retinoblastoma (cancer than forms in the tissues of the retina) has an increased risk of pineoblastoma.<EOS>
<BOS>When retinoblastoma forms at the same time as a tumor in or near the pineal gland, it is called trilateral retinoblastoma.<EOS>
<BOS>MRI (magnetic resonance imaging) testing in children with retinoblastoma may detect pineoblastoma at an early stage when it can be treated successfully.<EOS>
<BOS>Signs of breast cancer include a lump or change in the breast.<EOS>
<BOS>These and other signs may be caused by breast cancer or by other conditions.<EOS>
<BOS>Check with your doctor if you have any of the following: A lump or thickening in or near the breast or in the underarm area.<EOS>
<BOS>A change in the size or shape of the breast.<EOS>
<BOS>A dimple or puckering in the skin of the breast.<EOS>
<BOS>A nipple turned inward into the breast.<EOS>
<BOS>Fluid, other than breast milk, from the nipple, especially if it's bloody.<EOS>
<BOS>Scaly, red, or swollen skin on the breast, nipple, or areola (the dark area of skin around the nipple).<EOS>
<BOS>Dimples in the breast that look like the skin of an orange, called peau dorange.<EOS>
<BOS>Key Points Ovarian germ cell tumor is a disease in which malignant (cancer) cells form in the germ (egg) cells of the ovary.<EOS>
<BOS>Signs of ovarian germ cell tumor are swelling of the abdomen or vaginal bleeding after menopause.<EOS>
<BOS>Tests that examine the ovaries, pelvic area, blood, and ovarian tissue are used to detect (find) and diagnose ovarian germ cell tumor.<EOS>
<BOS>Certain factors affect prognosis (chance of recovery and treatment options).<EOS>
<BOS>Ovarian germ cell tumor is a disease in which malignant (cancer) cells form in the germ (egg) cells of the ovary.<EOS>
<BOS>Germ cell tumors begin in the reproductive cells (egg or sperm) of the body.<EOS>
<BOS>Ovarian germ cell tumors usually occur in teenage girls or young women and most often affect just one ovary.<EOS>
<BOS>The ovaries are a pair of organs in the female reproductive system.<EOS>
<BOS>They are in the pelvis, one on each side of the uterus (the hollow, pearshaped organ where a fetus grows).<EOS>
<BOS>Each ovary is about the size and shape of an almond.<EOS>
<BOS>The ovaries make eggs and female hormones.<EOS>
<BOS>Ovarian germ cell tumor is a general name that is used to describe several different types of cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>The most common ovarian germ cell tumor is called dysgerminoma.<EOS>
<BOS>See the following PDQ summaries for information about other types of ovarian tumors: Ovarian Epithelial, Fallopian Tube, and Primary Peritoneal Cancer Treatment Ovarian Low Malignant Potential Tumors Treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>A child who has heritable retinoblastoma has an increased risk of trilateral retinoblastoma and other cancers.<EOS>
<BOS>A child with heritable retinoblastoma has an increased risk of a pineal tumor in the brain.<EOS>
<BOS>When retinoblastoma and a brain tumor occur at the same time, it is called trilateral retinoblastoma.<EOS>
<BOS>The brain tumor is usually diagnosed between 20 and 36 months of age.<EOS>
<BOS>Regular screening using MRI (magnetic resonance imaging) may be done for a child thought to have heritable retinoblastoma or for a child with retinoblastoma in one eye and a family history of the disease.<EOS>
<BOS>CT (computerized tomography) scans are usually not used for routine screening in order to avoid exposing the child to ionizing radiation.<EOS>
<BOS>Heritable retinoblastoma also increases the child's risk of other types of cancer such as lung cancer, bladder cancer, or melanoma in later years.<EOS>
<BOS>Regular followup exams are important.<EOS>
<BOS>Treatment of chronic myelomonocytic leukemia (CMML) may include the following: Chemotherapy with one or more agents.<EOS>
<BOS>Stem cell transplant.<EOS>
<BOS>A clinical trial of a new treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Check the list of NCIsupported cancer clinical trials that are now accepting patients with chronic myelomonocytic leukemia.<EOS>
<BOS>For more specific results, refine the search by using other search features, such as the location of the trial, the type of treatment, or the name of the drug.<EOS>
<BOS>Talk with your doctor about clinical trials that may be right for you.<EOS>
<BOS>General information about clinical trials is available from the NCI website.<EOS>
<BOS>Health history can affect the risk of testicular cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Anything that increases the chance of getting a disease is called a risk factor.<EOS>
<BOS>Having a risk factor does not mean that you will get cancer; not having risk factors doesnt mean that you will not get cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Talk with your doctor if you think you may be at risk.<EOS>
<BOS>Risk factors for testicular cancer include: Having had an undescended testicle.<EOS>
<BOS>Having had abnormal development of the testicles.<EOS>
<BOS>Having a personal history of testicular cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Having a family history of testicular cancer (especially in a father or brother).<EOS>
<BOS>Being white.<EOS>
<BOS>Treatment for testicular cancer can cause infertility.<EOS>
<BOS>Certain treatments for testicular cancer can cause infertility that may be permanent.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients who may wish to have children should consider sperm banking before having treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Sperm banking is the process of freezing sperm and storing it for later use.<EOS>
<BOS>Key Points There are different types of treatment for patients with parathyroid cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Treatment includes control of hypercalcemia (too much calcium in the blood) in patients who have an overactive parathyroid gland.<EOS>
<BOS>Four types of standard treatment are used: Surgery Radiation therapy Chemotherapy Supportive care New types of treatment are being tested in clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients may want to think about taking part in a clinical trial.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients can enter clinical trials before, during, or after starting their cancer treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Followup tests may be needed.<EOS>
<BOS>There are different types of treatment for patients with parathyroid cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Different types of treatment are available for patients with parathyroid cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Some treatments are standard (the currently used treatment), and some are being tested in clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>A treatment clinical trial is a research study meant to help improve current treatments or obtain information on new treatments for patients with cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>When clinical trials show that a new treatment is better than the standard treatment, the new treatment may become the standard treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients may want to think about taking part in a clinical trial.<EOS>
<BOS>Some clinical trials are open only to patients who have not started treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Treatment includes control of hypercalcemia (too much calcium in the blood) in patients who have an overactive parathyroid gland.<EOS>
<BOS>In order to reduce the amount of parathyroid hormone that is being made and control the level of calcium in the blood, as much of the tumor as possible is removed in surgery.<EOS>
<BOS>For patients who cannot have surgery, medication may be used.<EOS>
<BOS>Four types of standard treatment are used: Surgery Surgery (removing the cancer in an operation) is the most common treatment for parathyroid cancer that is in the parathyroid glands or has spread to other parts of the body.<EOS>
<BOS>Because parathyroid cancer grows very slowly, cancer that has spread to other parts of the body may be removed by surgery in order to cure the patient or control the effects of the disease for a long time.<EOS>
<BOS>Before surgery, treatment is given to control hypercalcemia.<EOS>
<BOS>The following surgical procedures may be used: En bloc resection: Surgery to remove the entire parathyroid gland and the capsule around it.<EOS>
<BOS>Sometimes lymph nodes, half of the thyroid gland on the same side of the body as the cancer, and muscles, tissues, and a nerve in the neck are also removed.<EOS>
<BOS>Tumor debulking: A surgical procedure in which as much of the tumor as possible is removed.<EOS>
<BOS>Some tumors cannot be completely removed.<EOS>
<BOS>Metastasectomy: Surgery to remove any cancer that has spread to distant organs such as the lung.<EOS>
<BOS>Surgery for parathyroid cancer sometimes damages nerves of the vocal cords.<EOS>
<BOS>There are treatments to help with speech problems caused by this nerve damage.<EOS>
<BOS>Radiation therapy Radiation therapy is a cancer treatment that uses highenergy xrays or other types of radiation to kill cancer cells or keep them from growing.<EOS>
<BOS>There are two types of radiation therapy: External radiation therapy uses a machine outside the body to send radiation toward the cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Internal radiation therapy uses a radioactive substance sealed in needles, seeds, wires, or catheters that are placed directly into or near the cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>The way the radiation therapy is given depends on the type and stage of the cancer being treated.<EOS>
<BOS>External radiation therapy is used to treat parathyroid cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Chemotherapy Chemotherapy is a cancer treatment that uses drugs to stop the growth of cancer cells, either by killing the cells or by stopping them from dividing.<EOS>
<BOS>When chemotherapy is taken by mouth or injected into a vein or muscle, the drugs enter the bloodstream and can reach cancer cells throughout the body (systemic chemotherapy).<EOS>
<BOS>When chemotherapy is placed directly into the cerebrospinal fluid, an organ, or a body cavity such as the abdomen, the drugs mainly affect cancer cells in those areas (regional chemotherapy).<EOS>
<BOS>The way the chemotherapy is given depends on the type and stage of the cancer being treated.<EOS>
<BOS>Supportive care Supportive care is given to lessen the problems caused by the disease or its treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Supportive care for hypercalcemia caused by parathyroid cancer may include the following: Intravenous (IV) fluids.<EOS>
<BOS>Drugs that increase how much urine the body makes.<EOS>
<BOS>Drugs that stop the body from absorbing calcium from the food we eat.<EOS>
<BOS>Drugs that stop the parathyroid gland from making parathyroid hormone.<EOS>
<BOS>New types of treatment are being tested in clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>Information about clinical trials is available from the NCI website.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients may want to think about taking part in a clinical trial.<EOS>
<BOS>For some patients, taking part in a clinical trial may be the best treatment choice.<EOS>
<BOS>Clinical trials are part of the cancer research process.<EOS>
<BOS>Clinical trials are done to find out if new cancer treatments are safe and effective or better than the standard treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Many of today's standard treatments for cancer are based on earlier clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients who take part in a clinical trial may receive the standard treatment or be among the first to receive a new treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients who take part in clinical trials also help improve the way cancer will be treated in the future.<EOS>
<BOS>Even when clinical trials do not lead to effective new treatments, they often answer important questions and help move research forward.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients can enter clinical trials before, during, or after starting their cancer treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Some clinical trials only include patients who have not yet received treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Other trials test treatments for patients whose cancer has not gotten better.<EOS>
<BOS>There are also clinical trials that test new ways to stop cancer from recurring (coming back) or reduce the side effects of cancer treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Clinical trials are taking place in many parts of the country.<EOS>
<BOS>See the Treatment Options section that follows for links to current treatment clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>These have been retrieved from NCI's listing of clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>Followup tests may be needed.<EOS>
<BOS>Some of the tests that were done to diagnose the cancer or to find out the stage of the cancer may be repeated.<EOS>
<BOS>Some tests will be repeated in order to see how well the treatment is working.<EOS>
<BOS>Decisions about whether to continue, change, or stop treatment may be based on the results of these tests.<EOS>
<BOS>Some of the tests will continue to be done from time to time after treatment has ended.<EOS>
<BOS>The results of these tests can show if your condition has changed or if the cancer has recurred (come back).<EOS>
<BOS>These tests are sometimes called followup tests or checkups.<EOS>
<BOS>Parathyroid cancer often recurs.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients should have regular checkups for the rest of their lives, to find and treat recurrences early.<EOS>
<BOS>Treatment Options for Parathyroid Cancer Localized Parathyroid Cancer Treatment of localized parathyroid cancer may include the following: Surgery (en bloc resection).<EOS>
<BOS>Surgery followed by radiation therapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Radiation therapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Supportive care to treat hypercalcemia (too much calcium in the blood).<EOS>
<BOS>Check the list of NCIsupported cancer clinical trials that are now accepting patients with localized parathyroid cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>For more specific results, refine the search by using other search features, such as the location of the trial, the type of treatment, or the name of the drug.<EOS>
<BOS>Talk with your doctor about clinical trials that may be right for you.<EOS>
<BOS>General information about clinical trials is available from the NCI website.<EOS>
<BOS>Metastatic Parathyroid Cancer Treatment of metastatic parathyroid cancer may include the following: Surgery (metastasectomy) to remove cancer from the places where it has spread.<EOS>
<BOS>Surgery followed by radiation therapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Radiation therapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Chemotherapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Supportive care to treat hypercalcemia (too much calcium in the blood).<EOS>
<BOS>Check the list of NCIsupported cancer clinical trials that are now accepting patients with metastatic parathyroid cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>For more specific results, refine the search by using other search features, such as the location of the trial, the type of treatment, or the name of the drug.<EOS>
<BOS>Talk with your doctor about clinical trials that may be right for you.<EOS>
<BOS>General information about clinical trials is available from the NCI website.<EOS>
<BOS>Recurrent Parathyroid Cancer Treatment of recurrent parathyroid cancer may include the following: Surgery (metastasectomy) to remove cancer from the places where it has recurred.<EOS>
<BOS>Surgery (tumor debulking).<EOS>
<BOS>Surgery followed by radiation therapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Radiation therapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Chemotherapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Supportive care to treat hypercalcemia (too much calcium in the blood).<EOS>
<BOS>Check the list of NCIsupported cancer clinical trials that are now accepting patients with recurrent parathyroid cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>For more specific results, refine the search by using other search features, such as the location of the trial, the type of treatment, or the name of the drug.<EOS>
<BOS>Talk with your doctor about clinical trials that may be right for you.<EOS>
<BOS>General information about clinical trials is available from the NCI website.<EOS>
<BOS>Key Points There are different types of treatment for patients with chronic lymphocytic leukemia.<EOS>
<BOS>Five types of standard treatment are used: Watchful waiting Radiation therapy Chemotherapy Surgery Targeted therapy New types of treatment are being tested in clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>Chemotherapy with stem cell transplant Biologic therapy Chimeric antigen receptor (CAR) Tcell therapy Patients may want to think about taking part in a clinical trial.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients can enter clinical trials before, during, or after starting their cancer treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Followup tests may be needed.<EOS>
<BOS>There are different types of treatment for patients with chronic lymphocytic leukemia.<EOS>
<BOS>Different types of treatment are available for patients with chronic lymphocytic leukemia.<EOS>
<BOS>Some treatments are standard (the currently used treatment), and some are being tested in clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>A treatment clinical trial is a research study meant to help improve current treatments or obtain information on new treatments for patients with cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>When clinical trials show that a new treatment is better than the standard treatment, the new treatment may become the standard treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients may want to think about taking part in a clinical trial.<EOS>
<BOS>Some clinical trials are open only to patients who have not started treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Five types of standard treatment are used: Watchful waiting Watchful waiting is closely monitoring a patients condition without giving any treatment until signs or symptoms appear or change.<EOS>
<BOS>This is also called observation.<EOS>
<BOS>During this time, problems caused by the disease, such as infection, are treated.<EOS>
<BOS>Radiation therapy Radiation therapy is a cancer treatment that uses highenergy xrays or other types of radiation to kill cancer cells or keep them from growing.<EOS>
<BOS>There are two types of radiation therapy: External radiation therapy uses a machine outside the body to send radiation toward the cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Internal radiation therapy uses a radioactive substance sealed in needles, seeds, wires, or catheters that are placed directly into or near the cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>The way the radiation therapy is given depends on the type of cancer being treated.<EOS>
<BOS>External radiation therapy is used to treat chronic lymphocytic leukemia.<EOS>
<BOS>Chemotherapy Chemotherapy is a cancer treatment that uses drugs to stop the growth of cancer cells, either by killing the cells or by stopping them from dividing.<EOS>
<BOS>When chemotherapy is taken by mouth or injected into a vein or muscle, the drugs enter the bloodstream and can reach cancer cells throughout the body (systemic chemotherapy).<EOS>
<BOS>When chemotherapy is placed directly into the cerebrospinal fluid, an organ, or a body cavity such as the abdomen, or the drugs mainly affect cancer cells in those areas (regional chemotherapy).<EOS>
<BOS>The way the chemotherapy is given depends on the type and stage of the cancer being treated.<EOS>
<BOS>See Drugs Approved for Chronic Lymphocytic Leukemia for more information.<EOS>
<BOS>Surgery Splenectomy is surgery to remove the spleen.<EOS>
<BOS>Targeted therapy Targeted therapy is a type of treatment that uses drugs or other substances to identify and attack specific cancer cells without harming normal cells.<EOS>
<BOS>Monoclonal antibody therapy, tyrosine kinase inhibitor therapy, and BCL2 inhibitor therapy are types of targeted therapy used in the treatment of chronic lymphocytic leukemia.<EOS>
<BOS>Monoclonal antibody therapy is a cancer treatment that uses antibodies made in the laboratory from a single type of immune system cell.<EOS>
<BOS>These antibodies can identify substances on cancer cells or normal substances in the body that may help cancer cells grow.<EOS>
<BOS>The antibodies attach to the substances and kill the cancer cells, block their growth, or keep them from spreading.<EOS>
<BOS>Monoclonal antibodies are given by infusion.<EOS>
<BOS>They may be used alone or to carry drugs, toxins, or radioactive material directly to cancer cells.<EOS>
<BOS>Tyrosine kinase inhibitor therapy is a cancer treatment that blocks signals needed for tumors to grow.<EOS>
<BOS>BCL2 inhibitor therapy is a cancer treatment that blocks a protein called BCL2.<EOS>
<BOS>BCL2 inhibitor therapy may kill cancer cells and may make them more sensitive to other anticancer drugs.<EOS>
<BOS>See Drugs Approved for Chronic Lymphocytic Leukemia for more information.<EOS>
<BOS>New types of treatment are being tested in clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>This summary section describes treatments that are being studied in clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>It may not mention every new treatment being studied.<EOS>
<BOS>Information about clinical trials is available from the NCI website.<EOS>
<BOS>Chemotherapy with stem cell transplant Chemotherapy with stem cell transplant is a method of giving chemotherapy and replacing blood forming cells destroyed by the cancer treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Stem cells (immature blood cells) are removed from the blood or bone marrow of the patient or a donor and are frozen and stored.<EOS>
<BOS>After the chemotherapy is completed, the stored stem cells are thawed and given back to the patient through an infusion.<EOS>
<BOS>These reinfused stem cells grow into (and restore) the bodys blood cells.<EOS>
<BOS>Biologic therapy Biologic therapy is a treatment that uses the patient's immune system to fight cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Substances made by the body or made in a laboratory are used to boost, direct, or restore the body's natural defenses against cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>This type of cancer treatment is also called biotherapy or immunotherapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Chimeric antigen receptor (CAR) Tcell therapy CAR Tcell therapy is a type of immunotherapy that changes the patient's T cells (a type of immune system cell) so they will attack certain proteins on the surface of cancer cells.<EOS>
<BOS>T cells are taken from the patient and special receptors are added to their surface in the laboratory.<EOS>
<BOS>The changed cells are called chimeric antigen receptor (CAR) T cells.<EOS>
<BOS>The CAR T cells are grown in the laboratory and given to the patient by infusion.<EOS>
<BOS>The CAR T cells multiply in the patient's blood and attack cancer cells.<EOS>
<BOS>CAR Tcell therapy is being studied in the treatment of chronic lymphocytic leukemia.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients may want to think about taking part in a clinical trial.<EOS>
<BOS>For some patients, taking part in a clinical trial may be the best treatment choice.<EOS>
<BOS>Clinical trials are part of the cancer research process.<EOS>
<BOS>Clinical trials are done to find out if new cancer treatments are safe and effective or better than the standard treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Many of today's standard treatments for cancer are based on earlier clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients who take part in a clinical trial may receive the standard treatment or be among the first to receive a new treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients who take part in clinical trials also help improve the way cancer will be treated in the future.<EOS>
<BOS>Even when clinical trials do not lead to effective new treatments, they often answer important questions and help move research forward.<EOS>
<BOS>Patients can enter clinical trials before, during, or after starting their cancer treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Some clinical trials only include patients who have not yet received treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Other trials test treatments for patients whose cancer has not gotten better.<EOS>
<BOS>There are also clinical trials that test new ways to stop cancer from recurring (coming back) or reduce the side effects of cancer treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Clinical trials are taking place in many parts of the country.<EOS>
<BOS>See the Treatment Options section that follows for links to current treatment clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>These have been retrieved from NCI's listing of clinical trials.<EOS>
<BOS>Followup tests may be needed.<EOS>
<BOS>Some of the tests that were done to diagnose the cancer or to find out the stage of the cancer may be repeated.<EOS>
<BOS>Some tests will be repeated in order to see how well the treatment is working.<EOS>
<BOS>Decisions about whether to continue, change, or stop treatment may be based on the results of these tests.<EOS>
<BOS>Some of the tests will continue to be done from time to time after treatment has ended.<EOS>
<BOS>The results of these tests can show if your condition has changed or if the cancer has recurred (come back).<EOS>
<BOS>These tests are sometimes called followup tests or checkups.<EOS>
<BOS>Treatment Options by Stage Stage 0 Chronic Lymphocytic Leukemia Treatment of stage 0 chronic lymphocytic leukemia is usually watchful waiting.<EOS>
<BOS>Check the list of NCIsupported cancer clinical trials that are now accepting patients with stage 0 chronic lymphocytic leukemia.<EOS>
<BOS>For more specific results, refine the search by using other search features, such as the location of the trial, the type of treatment, or the name of the drug.<EOS>
<BOS>Talk with your doctor about clinical trials that may be right for you.<EOS>
<BOS>General information about clinical trials is available from the NCI website.<EOS>
<BOS>Stage I, Stage II, Stage III, and Stage IV Chronic Lymphocytic Leukemia Treatment of stage I, stage II, stage III, and stage IV chronic lymphocytic leukemia may include the following: Watchful waiting when there are few or no signs or symptoms.<EOS>
<BOS>Targeted therapy with a monoclonal antibody, a tyrosine kinase inhibitor, or a BCL2 inhibitor.<EOS>
<BOS>Chemotherapy with 1 or more drugs, with or without steroids or monoclonal antibody therapy.<EOS>
<BOS>Lowdose external radiation therapy to areas of the body where cancer is found, such as the spleen or lymph nodes.<EOS>
<BOS>A clinical trial of chemotherapy and biologic therapy with stem cell transplant.<EOS>
<BOS>A clinical trial of a new treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>Check the list of NCIsupported cancer clinical trials that are now accepting patients with stage I chronic lymphocytic leukemia, stage II chronic lymphocytic leukemia, stage III chronic lymphocytic leukemia and stage IV chronic lymphocytic leukemia.<EOS>
<BOS>For more specific results, refine the search by using other search features, such as the location of the trial, the type of treatment, or the name of the drug.<EOS>
<BOS>Talk with your doctor about clinical trials that may be right for you.<EOS>
<BOS>General information about clinical trials is available from the NCI website.<EOS>
<BOS>Key Points Pancreatic cancer is a disease in which malignant (cancer) cells form in the tissues of the pancreas.<EOS>
<BOS>Smoking and health history can affect the risk of pancreatic cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Signs and symptoms of pancreatic cancer include jaundice, pain, and weight loss.<EOS>
<BOS>Pancreatic cancer is difficult to detect (find) and diagnose early.<EOS>
<BOS>Tests that examine the pancreas are used to detect (find), diagnose, and stage pancreatic cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>Certain factors affect prognosis (chance of recovery) and treatment options.<EOS>
<BOS>Pancreatic cancer is a disease in which malignant (cancer) cells form in the tissues of the pancreas.<EOS>
<BOS>The pancreas is a gland about 6 inches long that is shaped like a thin pear lying on its side.<EOS>
<BOS>The wider end of the pancreas is called the head, the middle section is called the body, and the narrow end is called the tail.<EOS>
<BOS>The pancreas lies between the stomach and the spine.<EOS>
<BOS>The pancreas has two main jobs in the body: To make juices that help digest (break down) food.<EOS>
<BOS>To make hormones, such as insulin and glucagon, that help control blood sugar levels.<EOS>
<BOS>Both of these hormones help the body use and store the energy it gets from food.<EOS>
<BOS>The digestive juices are made by exocrine pancreas cells and the hormones are made by endocrine pancreas cells.<EOS>
<BOS>About 95% of pancreatic cancers begin in exocrine cells.<EOS>
<BOS>This summary is about exocrine pancreatic cancer.<EOS>
<BOS>For information on endocrine pancreatic cancer, see the PDQ summary on Pancreatic Neuroendocrine Tumors (Islet Cell Tumors) Treatment.<EOS>
<BOS>For information on pancreatic cancer in children, see the PDQ summary on Unusual Cancers of Childhood Treatment.<EOS>
